column2: To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent Ludwig S. Hellborn wants to know the complete figures of strictly new financing for 1937 and 1929, respectively.

(All clubs play two games) Philadelphia at New York-Passeau and Mulcahy vs. Schumacher and Gumbert or Smith. Boston at Brooklyn-Fette and MacFayden vs. Fitzsimmons and Hamlin. Cincinnati at Chicago-Derringer and R. Davis vs. Carleton and C. Davis.

Reassured by their success in filming "Ebb Tide" in color, Paramount yesterday signed a contract with Technicolor to make six technicolor pictures in addition to those already scheduled, which include "Beau Geste," about to go in work; "Jungle Love," and "Men With Wings," for which Director William Wellman returned to the old studio home.

Miss Wilma K. Steinmetz, daughter of Mrs. Frederick W. Steinmetz and the late Mr. Steinmetz, was married to James A. Ransom, son of Mrs. Walter O'Connor of Brooklyn, N. Y., this afternoon in St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church, East Portchester, Greenwich, by the Rev. Frederick W. Grunst, the pastor.

Japan's hopeful belief that Shantung's Governor General Han Fuchu is not loyal to Nanking was exploded this morning when a Government spokesman announced that Han Fu-chu had voluntarily handed over to Nanking his entire silver reserves of $25,000,000, which already have been shipped to safety at Hong Kong.

On the balance sheet of the organized trade union movement in this country the gains and losses of the last twelve months are clearly written. The Wagner Act, with its provisions for collective bargaining, has been upheld by the Supreme Court;

Miss Jean Arnold Stevens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Stevens of Red Bank, N. J., will be married to F. William DeBree, son of Mr. and Mrs. William DeBree of Scotch Plains, on Sept. 17 in St. George's Episcopal Church, Rumson.

Eddie Driggs Jr., Long Island golf star, defeated George Gillespie of Mamaroneck, N. Y., 4 and 3, today to win the international invitation tournament. Driggs's par 4 on the first hole gave him a lead when Gillespie missed a short putt for a half. They both took 4s on the second. Driggs captured the third and fourth.

As part of its -national drive to unionize grand opera artists and recitalists, the American Guild of Musical Artists will devise a standard minimum contract and will seek acceptance by opera and concert managers of an "A. G. M. A. shop," Leo Fischer, the guild's executive secretary, announced yesterday.

A disappointingly small fleet of four International One-Design yachts competed in the special invitation regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club today, but two of these staged a finish that compensated for any other shortcomings in a day of raildown-racing.
All the 7,780 Americans in China have been strongly urged to get out, and any who remain after that warning do so at their own risk, President Roosevelt said today.

Three hundred Japanese women and children and a few men left Hong Kong for Japan today and more are leaving Tuesday. It is expected that all the women and children and a majority of the men will evacuate shortly.

Only in an exceptionally general sense are business men here inclined to assess the prospects of an Autumn revival in the United States. The average observer here generally experiences some difficulty in gauging political trends in America and that difficulty is much greater today than in previous years.

Miss Nancy Felton Bent, daughter of Felton Bent of this city, will be married on Sept. 25 to Howard Spencer Pleasants, son of Dr. Henry Pleasants of West Chester and of Mrs. E. W. Pleasants of Wynne wood.

Herbert G. Wood, English author and educator, told the Friends World Conference tonight that "the integrity of science is menaced by men who substitute propaganda for truth." "We are drifting back to a veritable dark age in which torture and inhumanity are excused as necessary, and even applauded as evidence of men's disinterested devotion to great causes," he said.

Mediterranean developments have become of such vital importance to the Loyalists in Spain that on the eve of the return of this correspondent to Loyalist territory it is desirable to make the situation clear while it can be done without the restrictions of censorship.
New Jersey cyclists swept the national amateur bicycle championships today, capturing the three top honors. Furman Kugler of Somerville scored a grand slam in the four races in the junior class.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 91, which compares with 91.7 a week ago, 91.9 two weeks ago, 91.9 three weeks ago and 91.8 four weeks ago. Last week's average was the lowest since the last week of February.

Autumn approaches without any sign of stiffening of money rates. In fact there has been none of the seasonal movements in money rates for several years owing to the development of a high degree of government control in the money market.

The end-ofAugust settlement was rather easy on the money market here. Bill and treasury bond rates were only slightly changed, except for a small advance in day-to-day money, from 3 1/2 to 3 7/8 per cent.

Although the contract between Broadway's theatrical managers and the stagehands' uniod expired at midnight last night, no new agreement has been reached, it was learned yesterday. Conferences will take place this week between the labor committee of the League of New York Theatres, representing the managers, and Theatrical Protective Union No. 1, the stagehands' organization. The agreement,

IT seems early to be writing about football but I several matters have forced the issue. The Green Bay Packers bowed to an aggregation of college all-stars in Chicago and Johnny Mara's pro football Giants are about to tackle an allstar cast of college products under the arc lamps at the Polo Grounds.

THE islands of the New Hebrides lie far, far off in the Pacific, so far that the likes of us probably will never see them, nor our sons or grandsons either. But with a volume called "Savage Civilization" a certain extraordinary young man named Harrisson brings them as near as the nearest bookstore, and that fact is news.

Mrs. Lillian Solomon Hart of 891 Park Avenue, wife of Barnet Hart, died yesterday afternoon of a coronary thrombosis after a week's illness at the Berkeley-Carteret Hotel, Asbury Park, N. J., where she had been passing the Summer.

The world-famed Barcelona Football Club, here on a good-will tour, played the first of three scheduled games yesterday and defeated the Brooklyn Hispano Soccer Club at Commercial Field, Brooklyn, 4 to 2. The Spanish team led by 2-1 at half time.
Government "theorists" were charged by Senator Bankhead today with a "deliberate effort" to lower cotton prices as Southern farm groups sought a way to bolster growers' returns from the staple.

After twelve years of humanitarian work among some of the State's most hardened criminals, Father Robert J. Booth, who befriended hundreds of convicts from New York City, has resigned as Roman Catholic chaplain of Clinton Prison here.

One of the most important terms of peace which Japan hopes to dictate to China will be absolute prohibition, over a long period of years, against China's owning any fighting planes and bombing airplanes. This was learned here today during a discussion by a high Japanese military authority of the record made by Chinese fliers since the start of hostilities.

Henry T. Fleck, former head of the Music Department of Hunter College, died early yesterday in the White House Hotel, 109-16 Boardwalk, Rockaway Beach, Queens, where he had been spending the Summer with his sons, Harry and Donald Fleck. He was 74 years old.

The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America voted today to assess each of its 130,000 members 5 cents monthly in support of the Committee for Industrial Organization, of which it is an affiliate. The assessment will total about $78,000 a year.

With brokers and renting agents prepared to meet the peak of the rush for apartments following the Labor Day holiday, tenants in large numbers continue to sign leases for new living quarters in every section of the city.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler arrived here this afternoon to open the 1937 National Socialist Congress and with his coming the slowly rising gauge of popular enthusiasm jumped a whole notch.

Miss Betty Zeiller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar F. Zeiller of Bayside, Queens, was married to Dr. Richard Dietz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Dietz of Flushing, yesterday morning in St. Kevin's Church, Flushing, by the Rev.

After waiting eight days the British Government finally received today the Japanese reply to its protest against the bombing and machine-gunning of Sir Hughe Montgomery KnatchbullHugessen, its Ambassador to China.

The marriage of Miss Josephine Taylor Terry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Taylor Terry Jr. of New York and this place, to William Hude Neilson Brune, son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy J. Brune of North Stonington, Conn., took place at noon today in the garden of the Terry home here.

Fire losses in the city for the first six months of 1937 totaled $2,973,507, representing a decrease of $1,463,783 from the total for the same period in 1936, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday.

In June the Chief Constable of Southport, England, got a warrant for the arrest of a man charged with fraudulent conversion. The Chief Constable sent to a number of police forces a document describing the man and his methods. The Daily Dispatch of Manchester reproduced this document with the exception of the names.
Football before breakfast" is the rule at Navy for the training period which began this morning and which will continue until the opening of the next academic session, Sept. 25.
Joseph L. Hall, formerly vice president of the Hall Safe Company of Cincinnati, is with Lebenthal Co. Daniel G. Mullin is in the trading department of M. E. Kennedy Co.

Father Charles E. Coughlin said in an interview today that Great Britain was right in not paying her war debt. "Great Britain didn't pay loans extended to her by the United States but spent the money to build suitable homes for her laboring classes and she should be congratulated for placing human rights before financial rights," the Catholic churchman said.

The Federal Trade Commission today ordered three Newark, N. J., and New York concerns and three individuals to cease what the commission maintains is misrepresentation in the sale of medicinal products.

The National Lumber Manufacturers Association reported today that productive activity in the lumber industry in the week ended on Aug. 28 stood at 73 per cent of the 1929 weekly average and 64 per cent of shipments.

In opening a campaign for new members today at St. Joseph, Mo., and Elizabethville, Pa., the United Lutheran Church in America is beginning what its leaders term one of the "most significant movements in the history of this country."

The excursion steamer Smithfield, which plies between the Battery and Keansburg, N. J., was disabled last evening in the middle of Buttermilk Channel, north of Governors Island, when a crankshaft in her engine broke. There were 300 passengers aboard.

Laying down a thirty-two-hit barrage, the Detroit Tigers defeated the St. Louis Browns by 10 to 9 and 5 to 2 in a holiday double-header at Navin Field today. Pete Fox, the day's batting star of the Tigers, with four hits in the opener and two in the nightcap, was the hero of the first game.

Concerted action by real estate interests is imperative if rising government costs are to be stopped short of a new high, according to the September Real Estate Market Letter of the New York Title Insurance Company, which is edited by William J. Brede.

With one of her four propellers missing, the liner Normandie steamed into her home port here this afternoon on time. Somewhere in the Atlantic, not far out from New York, it is believed, she dropped her central port propeller. As soon as she docked divers went down and confirmed the naturn of the accident.

Unusually heavy purchases of tobacco leaf, from the commonest varieties to the medium grades, throughout the Southern tobacco markets is construed here, a large export center, to be a result of the Sino-Japanese war.

The fourteenth birthday of King Peter was celebrated throughout Yugoslavia today with popular enthusiasm, showing that, whatever the people's hostility to the Stoyadinovitch regime because, in part, of its conflict with the Orthodox Church, the boy King is the idol of the Serbian people and to a considerable extent also of the other peoples in the kingdom.
William J. Graham, vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, announced yesterday three major changes in the agency personnel of the concern.

Cynara, fleet-trotting mare owned by Louis Schneider of Elizabeth, defeated the Newbrook Stable's star 3-yearold colt Freckels at the Road Horse Association of New Jersey holiday matinee in Weequahic Park today. Cynara, driven by Bert Boylan, took two heats in 2:11 and 2:08%.

Fire tonight destroyed the 25-room dwelling of the palatial Virginia Ireland Hearn estate here, often described as the "show place of South Jersey." Family heirlooms and priceless antiques were consumed, among them a table once owned by Napoleon Bonaparte.
Miss Lyda Averill Paz, daughter of Mrs. William Phelps Eno of this place and Washington, D. C., was married to Professor Walter Willard Taylor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Taylor of

Their success in paralleling the proverbial feat of finding a needle in a haystack-by discovering within three days which of New York's more than 19,000 taxicabs was wanted in connection with a hitand-run case-won the commendation of Magistrate Michael Ford for two detectives in Yorkville Court yesterday.

Sol Zito of Egg Harbor, N. J., driving Zito Plane IV, took two of the three free-for-all races in the three-day speed-boat regatta which ended today on the waters of the Ocean City Yacht Club. Zito won at Stone Harbor Saturday, trailed Jack Rutherfurd of Miami at the Absecon Island Yacht Club yesterday and this afternoon he again took the measure of the Florida and New York sportsman, winning the ten-mile scratch event -in 11:46.

Southland, with Egan at the reins, won the first and third heats, after finishing sixth in the second, to capture the $3,141 horseman's futurity 3-year-old trot at the Indiana State Fair track today in the feature of the opening Grand Circuit racing program.

The San Diego Consolidated Gas and Electric Company (a unit in the Standard Gas and Electric Company system) reported a net income of $1,440,605 for the twelve months ended on July 31, 1937, after deductions for interest charges, amortization of debt discount and expenses, compared with $1,317,081, allowing for similar charges, for the previous twelve months.
Brazil will celebrate tomorrow the 115th anniversary of her independence. A parade of 15,000 troops will be reviewed by President Vargas and Dr. Julio R. Roca, Vice President of Argentina.

The Conversion Office for German Foreign Debts will announce today an optional offer of exchange to holders of matured bonds of the following issues and serial maturities: Free State of Bavaria 6 1/2 per cent bonds, external loan of 1925, matured on Aug. 1, 1937; City of Munich 7 per cent bonds, issue of 1925, matured on Aug. 1, 1937, and City of Duesseldorf 7 per cent bonds, matured on Sept. 1, 1937.

The Domei News Agency dispatches from Korea said today that Soviet vessels had seized the Korean patrol boat Asakaze Maru and that the Korean Governor General had demanded her release. The protest was made to the Soviet Consul.

Trading in synthetic gray goods last week was active, according to the report prepared by Nickel, Barrett, Lieberman Quinn, textile brokers. Prices were unchanged on plain loom fabrics, with Fall boxloom weaves somewhat more active at prices about unchanged to slightly lower.

Frugality in industry and government was urged here today by the Rev. Thomas P. Haig, pastor of the Second Reformed Church of Somerville, who told some 3,500 men and women at the annual gathering for Scottish games in Theron McCampbell's Sylvan Forum that the depression of 1929 would have been averted by that quality.

The fourth and last Elkan Naumburg concert of the season was given last night on the Central Park Mall by the Naumburg Orchestra under Leon Barzin. A moderatesized audience attended. The evening opened with "The Star Spangled Banner," and proceeded to Weber's "Freischuetz" Overture.

Although the result of the contest for the Republican nomination for Mayor between Mayor La Guardia and Senator Royal S. Copeland continues to seem uncertain, recent developments have made Victory for Mayor La Guardia appear somewhat more likely than it did a week ago.
A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Carlile Bolton-Smith of this city, formerly daughter of the late D of New York, recently at Columbia Hospital here. Mrs. Bolton-Smith, the daughter of
The town's nine legitimate entertainments gave their holiday matinees on schedule yesterday and none had reason to be sorry. Five, in fact, sold out, three of them playing to standees.

A tavern argument which, according to police, was resumed as a highway duel with automobiles as weapons, ended with the instant death of two youths as one of the cars, skidded ninety-six feet and crashed into a telegraph pole today on the Wheaton-Kensington highway near here.

Eugene H. Kelchner of Camden was re-elected president of the Luther League of New Jersey at the closing session of the forty-second annual convention of the organization in Emanuel Lutheran Church here today.

Three men in their 90's and a woman, 84, who journeyed to California in the days of the covered wagon, returned last night through the skies on a TWA airliner opening a new air route between New York and San Francisco.

The new strange world of twodimensional films only one-tenth of a millionth of an inch thick, recently explored by Dr. Irving Langmuir, American Nobel Prize winner, and his colleagues, has opened up a significant new approach to immunology, it was said here today by Dr. Langmuir at the annual meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

Characterizing John L. Lewis, head of the Committee for Industrial Organization, as a "big bully," Senator Royal S. Copeland, Tammany's candidate for Mayor, dedared yesterday in a Labor Day statement that he was for unionized labor and collective bargaining but was opposed to the efforts of Mr. Lewis and others to use labor as a vehicle for their personal advancement.

The claims of twenty-four American steamship companies for $75,000,000 which they asserted was due them on ocean mail contracts, have been settled by the Maritime Commission for $935,000, it was announced today.

Neutral naval and diplomatic officials in Shanghai are expressing hope that some means can be devised to avoid another bombardment of Nantao, the densely populated section of Shanghai directly adjoining the upriver boundary of the French Concession.

Supporters of Jeremiah T. Mahoney for the Democratic nomination for Mayor moved yesterday to strike from the registration rolls about 5,000 names recorded as eligible voters, in the primary, in eight Assembly districts controlled by Tammany Hall, which is supporting Royal S. Copeland for the nomination.

More than 60,000 tickets have been distributed to children for the "Parade of Stars," field day and sports show to be held this afternoon at the Yankee Stadium under the auspices of the Police Athletic League.

Churning along with tremendous strides that seemed to devour time, space and the Phillies all on the one motion, the pennant-bound Giants regaled a gathering of 46,177 at the Polo Grounds yesterday by outgalloping Jimmy Wilson's forlorn tail-enders in both ends of the holiday double-header.

E. Bright Wilson Jr., young chemist of Harvard University, today explained to members of the American Chemical Society, in session here, work with a machine that, providing answers unattainable by mathematics, makes possible the determination of one fundamental mystery of chemistry, the mystery of how much excitement makes an atom go.

Christian A. Untiedt, a resident of this town forty-five years and for half a century a clerk with Henry Lindemeyer Sons paper warehouse. New York. died yesterday at the home of his son, John H. Untiedt at Schenectady, N. Y., of a heart attack.

The Rev. John P. Boland, chairman of the New York State Labor Relations Board, said in a Labor Day speech at the New York State Fair today that strikes, "like war, should be labor's last weapon after mediation, conciliation and arbitration have failed."
Frank Morrison, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Labor, asserted today that the federation's policy was flexible enough to permit organization of the mass-production industries.

A buckskin horse, its saddle empty, stepped slowly into the plaza of the Will Rogers Shrine of the Sun on Cheyenne Mountain today. Chimes in the Shrine tower pealed solemn notes while persons assembled to dedicate the shrine to the cowboy philosopher bowed their heads.

Mexican labor has declared war on alleged attempts by Nazi organizations in Mexico to obtain raw materials for Germany, the Mexican Labor News, published by the dominant National Labor Confederation, announces today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The pastoral letter, signed by the Spanish prelates, the text of which was published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Sept. 3, is an appeal to the sober and critical opinion of the outside world. It is a carefully reasoned document, bringing to the support of the conclusion which the clergy have reached not only the evidence of recent events but the teachings of scholastic philosophy.

The old square-rigged ships Seven Seas and Joseph Conrad completed their racing voyage from Newport, R. I., today after more than ten days at sea, and tonight the skippers of both vessels claimed victory.

Commissioner of Public Safety Walter P. Cox died last night at Strong Memorial Hospital of complications resulting from Bright's disease. His age was 50. Born in Rochester, son of the late Joseph D. Cox, a shoe manufacturer, and the late Mary Shanhan Cox of Brooklyn, Commissioner Cox entered business following his graduation from high school in 1903.

Lefty Lee Grissom, Cincinnati's star freshman, held the slumping Cubs to one hit today, but that lone blow- a pop-fly double by Phil Cavarretta at the start of the eighth inningled to a two-run "rally" that beat him, 2 to 1, in the second game of a holiday double-header before 29,694.
The little town of Nyon, on the Swiss side of Lake Geneva, was fixed today as the meeting place of the Mediterranean conference to discuss the prevention of "piracy" by submarines and airplanes.

Dolores Ibarruri, or "La Pasionaria," Spanish Communist woman Deputy, today thanked the Soviet Union and "Comrade Stalin, brave defender of our cause," for the help Russia has given the Spanish Government in the civil war.
Representatives of the 75,000 members of the National Federation of Federal Employes supported President Roosevelt today in his expressed view that Government workers should not strike.

Labor Day meant rest and relaxation for millions, but for a group of gayly costumed dancers in Washington Square it was the time for a good deal of strenuous effort. While almost 2,000 of the not-sonimble looked on in envy yesterday afternoon, they danced for two hours near the fountain in the square, presenting the folk dances of seven nations.

The British steamer Burlington was captured off Palermo, Italy today by a Spanish Insurgent cruiser. She was brought to this Insurgent naval base and her cargo, 7,700 tons of Russian oil, was confiscated and unloaded.

Radio stations in Tegucigalpa, capital of Honduras, and Managua have received government instructions to cease broadcasting about the boundary dispute between the two countries. Honduras forbids the delivery of Nicaraguan mail carrying an airmail stamp showing the disputed territory as part of Nicaragua.

Motion pictures point the way for the churches in their battle for revived popularity, the Very Rev. Charles E. McAllister, associate seeretary of the National Council of Episcopal Churches, said here today.

The drawing together of all religions in a united front and the uniting of the forces of democracy against dictatorships were emphasized as needs of today in sermons at Rosh ha-Shanah services in the city's temples and synagogues yesterday, celebrating the Jewish New Year 5698.

Expension of their program for perpetuation of the cultural arts and traditions of White Russia was voted here today by delegates to the eleventh annual convention of the Russian Consolidated Mutual Aid Society. Plans were proposed for making the Rova Farms of this place, a Russian center of recreation and colonization, the hub of the society's program.

Sister Ann Michaella, 65 years old, a member of the Order of the Sisters of Charity and stationed at St. Elizabeth's College at Convent Station, N. J., died today in St. Elizabeth's Hospital here of a cerebral hemorrhage.
The marriage of Miss Frances Waring Lefferts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Raymond Lefferts of this place and New York, to John Edwin McCormick,

Making a parachute spinnaker jibe just before the finish line was reached, Van S. Merle-Smith's International twelve-meter sloop Seven Seas today defeated Clinton H. Crane's Gleam by thirty-seven seconds in the Long Island Sound championship finale for the Larchmont Yacht Club.

The text of the Labor Day address made here today by William Green, president if the American Federation of Labor, at the Greater Texas and Pan-Amerioan Federation of Labor, follows: I journeyed to Dallas because I wished to participate in the celebration of Labor Day with labor and its friends in the State of Texas.
Walter Brannon, 39 years old, a trusty in the Seventh District prison, 317 West Fifty-third Street, escaped through a rear door of the prison shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday morning.

The Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club on Center Island, where the annual yacht races for the Scandinavian Gold Cup and the Seawanhaka Cup are taking place this month, gave a dinner tonight in honor of the skippers of the foreign

Secretary of State Hull will be the principal speaker at a mass meeting on Sept. 19 that will launch a nationwide campaign of public education on problems of world economic cooperation, it was announced yesterday by John Nevin Sayre, president of the National Peace Conference.

With scant prospect that any decline in building material prices in the near future may offset increased labor costs, builders are exploring all possible channels where economies might be effected and permit them to offer a sound product at a lower cost.

A suspected case of typhoid fever on the Hamburg-American liner New York detained the ship fortyfive minutes at Quarantine yesterday while the United States public health officers made an examination. The 441 members of the crew were kept on board for nearly an hour after the vessel docked at the foot of West Forty-sixth Street.
The Mountain View House at this resort had a duplicate contract tournament tonight, arranged by Mrs. Harold E. Hewlett of Babylon, L. I. A concert and dancing followed.

The Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association ended its season series today when Dr. Merrill N. Foote, chairman of the regatta committee of the Bellport Bay Yacht Club, called time on William Simonson's Narrasketuck Class Naiad as she crossed the line at 4:32:31, the last of 124 starters.

The Conservative Government Coalition party expressed confidence tonight that its candidate, Dr. Roberto M. Ortiz, was elected President of Argentina with about 250 out of 476 electoral votes in Sunday's election.

The marriage of Mrs. Frances Peebles Scott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Peebles of Athens, Ala., to Charles Edward Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Brown of Chicago, took place today at Green Ridge Cottage, Summer home of the bridegroom's parents at Sagaponack, near here.

American and Mexican members of the International Boundary Commission of these two nations were in conference here today with John Savage, American engineer, who designed the Boulder Dam. They discussed plans for one or more big storage dams on the Rio Grande if, and when, a treaty is negotiated between the two nations covering use of waters of the river, at the request of people from this area.

Stalin's pinchhitter, Lazar M. Kaganovitch, who probably did more than any one except Stalin himself to insure the success of the collective farm movement and who subsequently reorganized rail transportation with marked success, was not long ago put in charge of heavy industry, of which another efficient organizer, Valery I. Mezhlauk, had been recently appointed commissar.

Purchasing agents among others are looking askance at some of the practices being indulged in in direct mail promotional campaigns under way at the present time. Some of these practices, it was pointed out, will create ill-will in ways that the advertiser in some instances has not anticipated.

An apparent attempt to hold up a sedan containing Tommy Farr, British heavyweight pugilist; his American representative, Jerry C. Casale, two trainers and a considerable sum of money was frustrated about 1 o'clock this morning when Casale summoned State policemen from the Hammonton barracks, eleven miles away, to a White Horse Pike restaurant at Egg Harbor.

Count Haugwitz von Reventlow and the Countess, the former Barbara Hutton, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary for their first visit to the United States since 1935. They left their son, Lance, in Switzerland, as he is only 18 months old.

The warfare between China and Japan kept schools closed throughout nearly all of China today, although normally this would have been the opening of the Fall term. In Shanghai foreign and Chinese education authorities alike, with hostilities ringing the city, decided the hazards of travel and of assembling large numbers of children in one place were too great for their 300,000 charges.

Miss Rachel Roberts Plank of this place, daughter of the late Dr. E. Roberts Plank, was married in her home here this evening to Walter R. Kershner of Shamokin by the Rev. Glenn Shafer of the Second Presbyterian Church.
The Indians and White Sox broke even in a pair of brilliant pitching battles today, each game being decided by a 2-to-1 score. Twenty thousand attended in the morning, 28,000 in the afternoon.
The Chinese Army abandoned the defensive today and counter-charged with desperate fury at the Japanese lines fringing the Yangtze and Whangpoo Rivers on the Northern Shanghai battlefront.

A demonstration of improved methods in the treatment- of persistent juvenile delinquents will be given by the New York School of Social Work in cooperation with the children's division of the Domestic Relations Court, beginning in October, it was announced yesterday.
The Department of Health announced today that a series of one-day institutes for physicians on the diagnosis and treatment of pneumonia will be held during October and November.

Mrs. Clara K. Heflebower, wife of Dr. Robert C. Heflebower, Cincinnati physician, died today at her Summer home here of heart disease. President of the National League of American Pen Women, Mrs. Heflebower was selected two years ago to place the wreath on the Unknown Soldier's tomb in Washington in memorial exercises.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, rallied his Southwestern forces against a campaign by the Committee for Industrial Organization today with a bitter denunciation of that organization's "destructive policy" in splitting organized labor.

One workman was killed, another. fatally hurt and fifteen others burned, three of them seriously, at 6:30 o'clock last night when a coal tar separating tank on which they were working at the Astoria plant of the Consolidated Edison Company exploded and took fire.

Breaking even in a double-header today, the Cardinals and Pirates marked time in their battle for third place in the National League. The Cards won the first game, 4 to 1, behind Lefty Bob Weiland and the Bucs captured the final, 5 to 4, as Russ Bauers outlasted Si Johnson in a pitchers' duel.

Approximately 150 manufacturers who produce about 90 per cent of all the covered buttons, buckles and novelties made in the United States, and their trade organization, the Covered Button and Button Creators, Inc., were ordered today by the Federal Trade Commission to desist from an alleged unlawful conspiracy to fix minimum prices and maximum discounts.

Mr. and Mrs. James Hoyt of McKeesport, Pa., arrived at the pier today to greet their Boy Scout son, James, 17, on his return from the world wide jamboree in Holland, only to learn the boy had died last night as the liner Scythia neared the coast.
Louis Unser, Colorado Springs veteran, hurtled his racing car through snow and clouds today for his third victory in the annual Labor Day dash up Pike's Peak.

In Nanking high Chinese Army officers said they believed Nanking to be the real objective of Japan's thrust into the Yangze Valley, but expressed confidence the capital could be held for at least six months against all Japan could offer.
Alan Hale, who played Little John to Douglas Fairbanks's Robin Hood fifteen years ago, has been engaged for the same role in the 1937 Warner Brothers production of the legend.

The Eastern College All-Stars concluded football training camp activities on the Peddie School field today. The players turned out both in the morning and afternoon for final drills on offensive and defensive assignments.

A warning that industry's reluctance to hire the older worker, even though he is able-bodied and intelligent, "threatens our social structure," was voiced tonight by Miss Frances Perkins in her fifth annual Labor Day talk as Secretary of Labor. She spoke over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The Yankees' celebration of Labor Day today was a mild form of assault upon the hapless Athletics. Before the largest paid attendance of the season in Shibe Park, the Ruppert forces flattened the Mackmen in both ends of a double-header to the deep chagrin of 38,183 fans.

In one of the most closely contested air races of record, Rudy A. Kling, 28-year-old garage mechanic of Lemont, Ill., won the coveted Thompson Trophy in the fastest and final race on the National Air Races program here today.

The Distilled Spirits Institute made public today the results of a survey of governmental reports on crime since repeal of the Prohibition Amendment. The survey disclosed, the institute said, that crime had decreased since repeal and that of the five States that remained dry, the record of each with respect to major crimes was worse than that of any' adjoining State.
FOURTH ROUND Upper Half J. Donald Budge, Oakland, Calif., defeated Joseph L. Abrams, New York, 6-0, 6-1, 6--1; Yvon Petra, France, defeated Gardnar Mulloy, Miami. Fla., 7-5, 3-6, 6-4, 3-6, 6-0;

Baseball-The Giants beat the Phils, 6-2 and 9-3, before a crowd of 46,177 at the Polo Grounds, and increased their lead to three games in the National League pennant race. The Yanks downed the Athletics, 6-3, 2-1. The Dodgers won from the Bees, 2-1, in ten innings, then lost, 6-4.

In a militant mood, John L. Lewis today told a crowd estimated at 150,000 that labor would demand shorter hours and greater authority in the councils of industry within a short time. Speaking at the County Park Fair the chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization said:

BAKER--I. Webster, Jr., of Rye, N. Y., Sept. 5, husband of Laura M., and son of Mr. and Mrs. I. Webster Baker, and brother of Barbara Baker. Services at Christ Episcopal Church, Rye, N. Y., Tuesday, Sept. 7, at 3 P. M., daylightsaving time.

Most of unionism's two great factions here cooperated today in a Labor Day parade and then retired to separate camps to await the climax of the A. F. L. teamsters' "finish fight" against C. I. O. longshoremen and warehousemen.

Despite the damper cast on their end-of-season business by poor weather in late August and over the Labor Day week-end, New Jersey shore resorts reported yesterday a Summer far ahead of last year's and approaching the tempo of the boom days.

ALPER--Mr. and Mrs. I., of 383 Broadway, Lawrence, L. I., wish to extend to their friends and relatives a happy New Year. BURKEN--Mr. and Mrs. Harry Burken extend their best wishes for a happy and prosperous New Year. HERSCHEL--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Herschel and children. Albert, Martin and Judith, of 511 West 232d St., wish their relatives and friends a happy, healthy and prosperous New Year.

Property-tax collections by the Territory of Hawaii at the end of 1936 amounted to $7,351,446, equivalent to 98.15 per cent of the entire property tax levy of $7,485,691 for that year, representing what is believed to be a new record in these collections, according to W. C. McGonagle, Treasurer of Hawaii.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor learned something of pigs, paintings and breadmaking on a farewell visit today to Alfred Wiegele, the versatile village baker. They are going to Hungary.

Calls for accessories and apparel were received in good volume last week in the wholesale market here, Better coats and suits were out, standingly active, at a time when a lull was to be expected. Calls for furs held up well and popular price types started to move.
Mr. and Mrs. Harris B. Fisher of New York and Rumson, N. J., gave a dinner and a costume ball at the Hay Harbor Club tonight.

Bearing huge banners which read "The C. I. O. Is Dead," more than 20,000 trade unionists, in the greatest show of strength in the history of the American Federation of Labor in Massachusetts, marched before 50.000 persons today.

A more cheerful mood greeted the new account on the stock market today, and although there was but little increase in business, most sections registered moderate improvement. Giltedge issues were steady, but Far Easterns continued on an uncertain note.

(Figures in parentheses indicate par) Bayside (7l)--Semi-final round for Lanzner Trophy: C. Cohen defeated V. Celano, 4 and 3; J. Schleiff defeated A. Cunningham, 5 and 4. Joe Lesser made a hole-inone on the 150-yard fourteenth hole with a No. 7 iron while playing with A. Favenza and J. Parsons.

Miss Delta Helen Glass, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Glass of this place, will be married on Saturday evening in Christ Episcopal Church, Lynbrook, to James Simms Wilson Jr. of Paris, Ky. Miss Glass's father is an executive with The Daily News.

More will doubtless be heard of Mr. John L. Lewis's proposal for a political alliance between farmers and trade unionists, in the event that these two groups find that they cannot obtain all that they want from the Roosevelt Administration.

The tissue-building foods -- meat, eggs, milk are examples-are composed in large part of proteins. The proteins in turn are complex forms of nitrogen. By what chemical magic is a piece of beefsteak converted into living muscle?

With vacation at an end for 1,225,000 public school children and 37,535 teachers, registration for the Fall term will get under way tomorrow in 762 schools throughout the five boroughs. Thursday and Friday also have been set aside for registration in preparation for the opening of the term on Monday.

Leaders of 4,000,000 British workers mer here today for their annual conference in an atmosphere that is worth more to the British Government at the moment than a squadron of new warships or a hundred new battle planes.

The first national bar, grill and tavern equipment exposition will be held at the Park Central Hotel Dec. 7 to 10, it was 'announced yesterday by R. W. Rosebury, who will direct the show, in connection with various beverage and grill association executive members.
The seventh annual race meet of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association was held today on the course of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club here.
Seven steamships are due today with 4,279 passengers returning tha from Labor Day cruises to Ber- sur muda, Halifax and Canada. Immigration officials and customs inspectors expect a busy morning,

When America takes to the road on one of the great holiday week-ends we know in advance that an indefinite number of persons will die and a considerably larger number will be injured who would have remained alive and well if there had been no holiday.

Associates of J. P. Morgan said tonight that he was planning to celebrate his seventieth birthday quietly tomorrow at his Scottish estate' at Gannochy, where last year he entertained the King and Queen, then the Duke and Duchess of York.

American consumers might perform "a very real public service" by organizing buyers' strikes against unwarranted increases in living costs, it was stated today by Donald E. Montgomery, consumers' counsel of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

Miss Elizabeth Knight Roberts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward K. Roberts of this place, will be married to Dr. Edward Thegen of Penobscot, Me., on Saturday afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church, Tariffville.

The sanitary campaign commenced in the northern port of Arica to wipe out malaria has revealed that 70 per cent of the population is afflicted, according to figures just published here. Another large shipment of quinine was dispatched today, it was announced.

charge of technical manslaughter was filed here today by the police against Sam Johnson, a Jersey City Negro, driver of an automobile that killed J. Randolph Woodruff, veteran Newark attorney, late last him night. The lawyer, who was 67 years old, was crossing Central Avenue at South Eighth Street. He lived at 37 South Tenth Street.

The number of those who died violently in the observance of America's Labor Day week-end mounted last night to 391, according to a tabulation made by The Associated Press. Almost three-fourths of the deaths were listed as the result of automobile accidents in forty-four States.

Japanese complaints concerning the misuse of missions, temples, schools and neutrals' flags assume a comic aspect in view of what is occurring today at the American Seventh Day Adventist mission compound in Ningkuo Road, in Hongkew, beyond the Japanese barracks.

Twelve faculty members and fortyfive students of the new St. Ignatius House of Study, North Hills, will hold a formal gathering on Friday in the chapel to mark the opening of the first year of study in the palatial former residence of the late Nicholas F. Brady.

Celebration of Labor Day in this area today centered about the grave of Peter J. McGuire, its founder, in Camden. More than 100 labor leaders, most of them from American Federation of Labor unions, gathered in Arlington Cemetery and heard a scathing attack upon the Committee for Industrial Organization and its chief, John L. Lewis.

Miss Emily Carrington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Blake Carrington of Tucson, Ariz., formerly of Newark, has chosen Oct. 8 as the date of her wedding to Rawson Blaine Harmon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rawson B. Harmon of Grosse Point, Mich., and Ojai, Calif.

Wind, rain and low temperatures at most of our coastal fishing ports combined to make a rather unhappy Labor Day week-end for the anglers who had hoped to park their families on the beaches and do a little fishing.

The Japanese offensive at Shanghai made only small gains, and then the Chinese opened a counter-thrust in which they reported offsetting them. The Japanese took Paoshan, but the Chinese reported forcing them from that city. The invaders also penetrated to Kiangwan, in the center. Attempts at landings were repulsed at Pootung and Woosung.

A tabulation by the Citizens Budget Commission of the eighty-three departmental budget requests for 1938 already made indicates that the 1938 budget requests will aggregate $81,000,000 more than 1937 appropriations directly payable out of taxes, or an increased city cost of $29 a voter, Richard C. Patterson Jr., chairman of the commission, said yesterday.

After an easy start, wheat futures in the grain market here improved late today to close about steady. Early selling was induced by a variety of factors. Trade sources cited the recent disappointing behavior of the United States market, fair rains in Australia and Argentina, a bearish private estimate of the Australian crop, an increase in shipments to the United Kingdom, and the heavier bounty on Rumanian exports.

Dr. E. A. Hooton, Professor of Anthropology at Harvard University, comments in relation to his new book, "Apes, Men, and Morons": "After nearly a quarter of a century of study, I have decided that the proper function of the anthropologist is to apologize for man.
The Burnt Mills Polo Club's winning streak was ended at six games on Schley Field today when the quartet lost an extra-period game to the Colonials, 9 to 8.

William Klauberg's yacht Quest sailed to victory over J. Pearsall's Bug by 2 minutes 55 seconds in the Handicap Class of the invitation regatta conducted by the Crescent Athletic Club on Huntington Bay today.
BED OF NEUROSES, by Wolcott Gibbs. (Dodd, Mead, $2.) A collection of articles, reminiscences, stories.

Jerome Kern's musical comedy "Roberta," the sixth and final production for the outdoor season, was presented last night at the Randall's Island Stadium by J. J. Shubert and Fortune Gallo, director of the San Carlo Opera Company,

Lord and Lady Morris of London are expected to arrive today at the Plaza. Mr. and Mrs. T. Wallace Orr, who have been visiting relatives in Paris, will return later this month and will be at the Waldorf-Astoria for the Autumn and Winter.

The annual Commodores Ball will be held on Saturday night at the Devon Yacht Club. On Saturday, the John Carscallen Trophy, a cup given by Mrs. Charles S. Carscallen in memory of her son, will be presented to the champion senior girl swimmer of the Devon Club, Miss Jean Lithgow.
The Froedtert Grain and Malting Company, Inc., reported yesterday a net income of $1,109,391 for the fiscal year ended on July 31, compared with $915,129 in the previous comparable twelve months.

The "Toonerville Fire Company," composed of twenty-five farcically costumed young men who marched in front of an ancient fire truck, made a surprise entry in the forty-sixth annual Boonton firemen's parade today and stole the show from twenty-one other fire companies from Boonton and other North Jersey communities, led by a dozen bands and fife and drum corps.

Ralph Collins, general manager of the Gloversville Knitting Company, announced tonight settlement of the two-week-old strike of the Textile Workers Union against company plants here and at Schenectady.

Gov. Philip F. La Follette of Wisconsin, told Omaha labor union members today that 1940 would witness the rise of "a political alignment that will give the American people a real choice between progressive and reactionary government."

Among stars of its own type the sun is a weakling, emitting only seven-tenths the radiation that it should, it was disclosed today for the first time by research at the Harvard Observatory. In the same study it-was found that the moon was slightly brighter than astronomers hitherto had believed.

Construction awards in Southern States exceeding any year since 1930 were shown today in a survey of building contracts by The Manufacturers Record. Awards amounted to $578,468,000 for the first eight months this year, and "more than equalled the total for the same period of 1936," the magazine said.

For some time yesterday the Dodgers had a Labor Day crowd of 15,844 paying patrons at Ebbets Field convinced that they were about to win a double-header for the fourth' time this season. In fact, the conviction held until the eighth inning of the nightcap-and then faded as quickly as twilight in Tahiti.

Reports of a botanical war to the death between ragweed, common for cause of hay fever, and the sunflower, which has been observed by several persons in correspondence with the editor of THE NEW YORK TIME, received partial confirmaLion yesterday from botanists.
Two hundred owners of small Mexican business concerns informed President Lazaro Cardenas today that they would be forced to cease

Unification within a single agency of all the city's welfare and relief functions, except aid to mothers with dependent children, will be essayed for the first time in the new Richmond Welfare Center, 211 Bay Street, Tompkinsville, S. I., opening tomorrow.

Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their holiday house parties attended the reception and fashion show in behalf of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children this afternoon at the Southampton Beach Club.

Rushing into the lead in the run to the first turn, Hobson C. McGehee's fleet-footed Fair Knightess held six pressing rivals at bay thereafter to win the fourth running of the What Cheer Handicap by a head today before close to 50,000 spectators at Narragansett Park.

With Walter Wood playing at No. 3, stroking five goals, the Ramapo Valley Greens downed the Saxon Woods poloists, 15--4, today. J. Brabson, who alternated at No. 2 with C. Hipp, and A. Clough also starred for the winners, getting three tallies apiece.

The list of passengers booked to sail today for the Channel Ports on the Holland-America liner Statendam includes: Mr. and Mrs. J. B. Dunbaugh, Miss Joyce Dunbaugh, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Rowley, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Iddings,

America's speediest and most graceful mermaids wound up the Women's National A. A. U. swimming and diving championships today with Florida's Miss Katherine Rawls stealing the show and taking the medal for individual scoring.
William Robert Roach, head of W. R. Roach Co., a leading fruit and vegetable packing firm, died at his home here today. He observed his seventy-fifth birthday yesterday.

Industrial training in some form to meet present and future needs for skilled workers has been adopted by four out of every five companies, it is indicated by the report of a survey made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Fifteen deaths among 159 cases of infantile paralysis have been reported in Chicago in the last five weeks. In the week ending yesterday, the city health department listed sixty-four new cases and seven deaths, a record for the first week in September.

Henry Hadley, American composer and conductor, a founder and honorary president of the National Association of American Composers and Conductors, died yesterday at his home, 15 West Sixty-seventh Street, after a prolonged illness. He was 66 years old.

Max Hacker, head of the media department of Pedlar Ryan, Inc., New York advertising company, died of a heart attack this afternoon on the first fairway of the St. Andrew's Golf Club in the town on Greenburgh, near Hastings. His age was 45 and he lived at 1 Kingsbridge Plaza, Mount Vernon.

Germany's military and economic recovery to the limit of her technical capacity is confronting the National Socialist regime with many new problems that are a complete reversal of those that Chancellor Adolf Hitler found on his accession to power. They must test anew all Nazi economic and social theories as well as the power and prestige of the regime itself.

New York's skyscrapers held the attention of a party of 130 Londoners, members of the United Wards Club of London, who spent their second day here yesterday in sight-seeing. Founded sixty years ago, their club is concerned with civic conditions in the twenty-three wards in the old City of London.
Three or four convicted defendants in the Government's Kopald-Quinn Company Security Law violations case were sentenced today to prison for five years by Federal Judge E. Marvin Underwood.

Mrs. Virginia Gibbs Schelling, wife of Clinton W. Schelling of 65 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, died yesterday in the Midwood Hospital, Brooklyn, of meningitis, after a day's illness, in her thirtieth year. Her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Gibbs, and a sister, Miss Anne Gibbs, all of Brooklyn, also survive.
For the first time in nine years Belgium will compete in the international military jumping events at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden from Nov. 3 to 10.

Highways, bridges and ferries in the metropolitan area were jammed by motorists, and rail, bus and air lines were taxed last night as Labor Day traffic started moving in and out of the city. The peak of the outbound rush of visitors who had spent the threeday holiday sightseeing in the city was reached shortly after midnight.

Frank Silvio of the New York A. C., the national and Canadian champion, today won the single sculls quartermile race, main event of the New England Amateur Rowing Association's Fall chamiponship regatta at the West Lynn Boat Club.

Division staff officers of the New York National Guard disclosed today that the 102d Quartermaster Regiment of Brooklyn, commanded by Colonel Foster Hetzel, had established the best attendance record at armory drills and meetings of any guard unit in the State in the latest monthly afttendance reponrt.

The long campaign waged by the National Union of Seamen for abolition of "floating slums" ended in victory today when the Board of Trade ordered owners to provide greatly improved accommodations for crews in all ships built in the future.

William Byrd Northam, attorney and official stenographer of the Delaware County Orphans Court, died today of a heart attack at his home here at the age of 58. Mr. Northam was a descendant of Colonel William Byrd, who settled in Virginia in 1670.

President Roosevelt headed back toward Hyde Park today at the end of his cruise off the eastern end of Long Island. His yacht, the Potomac, left Great Salt Pond, Block Island, about 10 o'clock this morning and cruised north and west. A little after 1 P. M. she passed through The Race, the entrance to Long Island Sound, and anchored in the lee of Fishers Island.
John Gielgud's "Richard II," in which he not only took the name part but was also director and producer, achieved a brilliant success tonight at the Queen's Theatre, where his season was opened.
The Bethpage Browns turned back the Squadron C Yellows of Huntington, 13 to 6, in a polo game at Bethpage State Park today. Shaw Robinson, Bethpage Browns' No. 3, led the attack with six goals.

John T. Mills of Rochester, N. Y., was announced today as one of the leading prize winners in the special matches conducted by the United States Revolver Association. Mills was first in the rapid-fire grand aggregate match with 767 of a possible 800; he won the pocket revolver 50-yard event with 220 of 250, and was third in the .38-caliber national contest, held at slow, timed and rapid-fire stages, with 275 of 300.
Bingo, screen and similar games of chance cannot be played henceforth in State armories, Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commanding the New York National Guard, announced today.

A syndicate headed by Samuel Friedman has purchased the seventy-two-family apartment at 2,187 Holland Avenue, the Bronx, from the Enarc Realty Corporation, for cash above a first mortgage of $250,250. Isidor Tankus was the broker in the deal.

Georgia's Marking the prison troubles returned today with activities, the the escape of four convicts from two county chain gangs in the first breaks reported since Governor Rivers said that automatic dismissal faced wardens and guards involved in escapes.
The international stock market indices for Sept. 4, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

Catholia missionaries in the Orient will ignore every suggestion that they depart from the war zone, it was asserted here this afternoon by the Rev. William O'Shea, secretary general of Maryknoll, largest seminary in America devoted to the training of mission priests and nuns.

The Collegians made it two straight 1937 football victories over the pros when the All-Stars whipped the Chicago Bears, 6 to 0, in the Cotton Bowl tonight. It also was the Collegians' second straight victory here, the All-Stars having defeated the then champion Bears last Fall.

The New York chapter of the American Institute of Banking will hold its consuls' and committee members' dinner at the Hotel Victoria on Thursday night, it was announced yesterday by J. Stanley Brown. president of the chapter.

Ray Phebus, the Senators' 26-year-old rookie from Clovis, Calif., set down the Red Sox with one hit in his first starting assignment of the year today to give Washington the nightcap of a double-header, 2-0, after Boston won the opener, 6-2.

A modest young Detroiter who began at the wheel of harmless little runabouts and graduated up through dangerous bigger craft until he attained the proud and mighty Gold Cup ranks with mile-a-minute speeds two years ago, today turned back almost single-handedly Europe's invasion of boat drivers from Italy and France to defend the 34-yearold trophy for America.

Many prominent persons of Yonkers attended the funeral services today for John W. Burke at St. Denis Roman Catholic Church here. His son, the Rev. Edmund Burke of Kingston, N. Y., was celebrant of the mass.

The Japanese Embassy announced today Gene Lamb, an American writer, had received 800 Chinese dollars as reparation for the invasion and plundering of his compound in the western hills by Japanese soldiers.

The Bethpage Yellows downed the south Shore Whites, 7 to 2, today. The winners held the upper hand Throughout, scoring twice in the opening chapter. Both of the losers' tallies came in the final session.
Tallying in every period except the last, the Long Island Ramblers swept to a 13-to-7 triumph over the First Division quartet at the Fort Hamilton army reservation, Brooklyn, yesterday.

In preparation for the first scrimmage of the pre-season training period, scheduled for tomorrow or Thursday, Coach Jimmy Crowley began the second week of Fordham's Fall football practice yesterday by sending his squad of fortytwo through an intensive afternoon of dummy scrimmaging on Fordham Field. The two-hour morning session was devoted to a light signal drill.

Baron Gottfried von Cramm of Germany was trailing Hal Surface of Kansas City, Mo., by 1-5 in the fourth set yesterday and 13,000 spectators, the greatest crowd that ever turned out for the national tennis championships prior to the quarter-final round, were rubbing their eyes and cheering themselves hoarse in the Forest Hills Stadium.

The renunciation by Japan of its right to hold the 1940 Olympic games in Tokyo is being viewed as a possible contingency, but no decision has yet been made. Matsuzo Nagai, secretary-general of the organizing committee, said today:

There is no longer any doubt of the ability of the San Jose polo team of Argentina. Today, before a crowd of 7,000 at the Sands Point Club field, they fought tooth and nail with Greentree and lost only when Tommy Hitchcock fed a ball up to little Pete Bostwick for the winning goal after the bell had sounded in the last period.

The marriage of Miss Jane Clarke Spalding, daughter of Mrs. Jesse Spalding of New York and this place, to Allison Ripley Maxwell Jr., son of Mrs. Allison Ripley Maxwell of Pittsburgh, took place at noon today in St. Philomena's Church. The Rev. J. J. Flannery performed the ceremony.

After an ownership of fifty-seven years, the commercial property on the northwest corner of Eighteenth Street and Bergenline Avenue, West New York, N. J., has been sold for the Wendel Foundation to the Suburban Building Corporation.

Back at Aqueduct where he had scored in his American debut, Caballero II yesterday captured the $6,850 Aqueduct Handicap before another capacity crowd of 15,000 in time that was only three-fifths of a second slower than Mad Hatter's track record of 1:43.
Thomas W. Lamont, partner in the firm of J. P. Morgan Co., returning from Europe yesterday on the Queen Mary, said he had found economic conditions in Europe improving.

Labor Day is a movable feast in the sense that it has no one numbered day of its own in the calendar. It is the first Monday in September, with a wide range of variation from the first of September to the seventh.
The Newark Bears defeated the Jersey City Giants in both ends of a double-header today, 4-2 and 1-0, to push their victory total for the season to 105 games. A crowd of 8,000 saw the contests.

Miss Charlotte Frisble of this city and Frederick H. Gardner of New York will be married Sept. 18 at the home of the bride-elect's uncle, Robert T. Frisbie, in New Britain. The Rev. Dr. Robbins W. Barstow will perform the ceremony, which will be held at Mr. Frisbie's home
Several recent news items, when taken in conjunction, would seem to imply that the end of the world in these United States has been greatly exaggerated.

The division within the ranks of organized labor, involving a battle for supremacy between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization, has created for the National Labor Relations Board problems which were not foreseen when the Wagner act became law, J. Warren Madden, chairman of the board, declared tonight.
State troopers tonight continued a hunt for a man who, two Johnson City policemen said, held them captive for twelve hours. But the troopers said they were without clues to his whereabouts.

Johnny Goodman of Omaha, national amateur golf champion, and Wilford Wehrle of Racine, Wis., Western amateur ruler, teamed today to defeat Olin Dutra and Willie Hunter, Los Angeles professionals, 1 up; in an exhibition at the Los Angeles Country Club.

Thomas M. Sayman, president of a soap company bearing his name, died tonight at his home here. He was 84 years old. Mr. Sayman built a road-going medicine show into the soap business that netted him a fortune.

Marking the beginning of Fall activities, the Women's National Republican Club will hold an allday conference of members and its national council at its clubhouse, 3 West Fifty-first Street, on Sept. 17, Constitution Day. Members of the national council in attendance will represent seventeen States and the District of Columbia.
The Caravan Theatre, a WPA unit,- will stage the following outdoor shows tonight in public fields and parks of this city: Manhattan, "Riddle Me This," at the Hebrew Orphan Asylum;

Miss Hope Knowles of Philadelphia turned back three opponents to pace the march of seeded players into the fourth round in the twentieth annual national girls' tennis championships at the Philadelphia Cricket Club today.

The surrender of 600 Insurgent soldiers besieged in Belchite Cathedral was reported today in a Spanish Government communique from the Aragon front in Northeastern Spain. The Government claimed the capture of the cathedral gave its forces complete control of Belchite, strategic point twenty miles south of Saragossa along the line of Insurgent communications with Teruel.

Secretary Morgenthau announced today a combined offering of 2 per cent five-year Treasury notes and 11/4 per cent fifteen months' notes in exchange for the $817,483,500 of notes maturing on Sept. 15. There will be no sale of securities for cash at that time.

Old Westbury galloped to a 16-6 victory over Templeton at the J. S. Phipps estate old field today in another one of test matches in preparation for the national open polo championship tourney, scheduled to start on Saturday at the Meadow Brook Club.

Miss Hetty Reid Turner, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Turner of Westwood, The Plains, Va., was married to James E. Wood Jr. of Nashville, Tenn., son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Wood of Terra Ceia, Fla., at noon today in Grace Church, The Plains, by the rector, the Rev. Sanford L. Rotter.

A meeting of taxpayers sponsored by the Taxpayers party will be held Thursday evening at Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street. Mayor La Guardia, Senator Copeland and Judge Mahoney have been invited to speak.
Dr. Joseph Samenfeld of 122 Pennsylvania Avenue, Brooklyn, died suddenly Saturday in Germany while on a European tour, according to announcement made here last night at his residence.

John Emery Efird, father of the "Efird Boys," who operate fiftyfive chain department stores in the Carolinas, died yesterday in Burnsville Township, Anson County, N. C., and was buried today in the churchyard of Rocky Mount Baptist Church.

Delegates to the Friends World Conference heard President Roosevelt accused today of nullifying the Neutrality Act by his failure to invoke it in the Sino-Japanese undeclared war. Frederick J. Libby, executive secretary of the National Council for the Prevention of War, told the Quakers, in session at Swarthmore College, that pressure should be brought on the President to force his hand.

Charles T. Schueler, president of Hildreth Rogers Company, publishers of The Lawrence Eagle and Tribune, died this afternoon at his home here at the age of 64. Mr. Schueler, who began his newspaper career as a pressman thirty-eight years ago, was also advertising director of the two papers. Born in Germany he came to this country in 1899.

Mrs. George H. Bostwick's veteran jumper Fugitive, who has won many cup events in his long career, never scored an easier victory than today, when he had practically a walkover to take the Connecticut Cup, which featured the Autumn meeting of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club.

The first of fifty improved Hudson-type locomotives will go into service today on the New York Central Railroad, bringing the total of these engines in service on the line to 275, F. E. Williamson, president, announced yesterday. The engine, numbered 5405, was built at the American Locomotive Works in Schenectady, N. Y.

Hollyrood Nell, bay mare owned by R. N. Norton of Waterville, N. Y., dropped dead on the track after finishing the second heat of the third race on the inaugural Grand Circuit program before 7,000 fans at the New York State Fair today.

Today's events indicate a Japanese intention to wage war in South China mainly with naval and air forces. Over the week-end radio communication with the Pratas Island meteorological station broke down and it was learned officially the Japanese Navy had seized Pratas and was using it as a base of operation against South China.

Automobile production declined last week, but less sharply than called for seasonally, and the ad. ousted index moved up to 157.4 from 155.2, approaching the all-time high registered for the week ended Aug. 14. For the week ended Sept. 5, 1936. the index stood at 82.3.

More than 200 attended the Lenox Club Labor Day luncheon. Mrs. Edwards Spencer had thirty-five guests, Miss M. Symphorosa Bristed, thirty, and Mrs. David T. Dana and Mrs. Norman H. Davis, twenty each.
The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary arrived yesterday from Europe bringing several artists well known in theatrical circles who have been spending the Summer abroad.

Crowds totaling approximately 249,000 saw eight big league doubleheaders yesterday, The Associated Press reports. The New York Giants drew the biggest group of fans, 46,177, for their double bill with the Phillies at the Polo Grounds.

Japanese heavy artillery was moved up against Machang today after an attack had swept clear the approaches to that Chinese stronghold, forty miles south of Tientsin. Japanese military authorities here said the last Chinese outposts, a mile or two north of the important railroad city, had been driven in and two outlying villages had been captured.

The Bankamerica Company of San Francisco is offering today, by means of a prospectus, a new issue of 125,000 shares of the Puget Sound Pulp and Timber Company 6 per cent convertible cumulative preferred stock of $20 par value at $25 a share, plus dividends from July 1, 1937.

Bernard M. Baruch, financier, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary after a six-week visit to London, Paris and Vichy. "The people in Europe have no hope any more; fear predominates." said Mr. Baruch.

Outnumbered ten to one by their affiliates, but still able to jig to tunes of the United States Marine Band, 187 veterans of the Grand Army of the Republic assembled tonight for the first session of the seventy-first annual national convention.

Mr. and Mrs. F. Bartholomay Jelke, who last year purchased Wisteria Lodge, the former Harriman estate on Bellevue Avenue, and have since had the house rebuilt and enlarged, will give a house-warming dinner on Saturday.

By capturing one first and one third place in today's events of the fourth annual New Jersey glider championship meet, Henry N. Wightman of Montclair, representing the University of Michigan Glider Club, seemed almost certain to retain the State gliding fitle, which he won last year.

Victor Hoo, China's permanent delegate to the League of Nations, today confirmed that his Government would appeal to the League against Japan. He told the press it was "not yet certain, however, which covenant article China will invoke," or on exactly what date, but the appeal would be filed "very soon."
Food sent through the mail for men in a strike-closed plant surrounded by pickets is "abnormal mail" and need not be delivered, William W. Howes, First Assistant Postmas'ter General, said here today.

Maurice P. Davidson, chairman of the Progressive party, announced yesterday that "the opening political gun" of the campaign to re-elect Mayor La Guardia would be fired on Sept. 23, a week after the primary election, at a rally at Cooper Union.

William Cress Wortman, lumber dealer and contractor, died Saturday in Temple University Hospital after an illness of two weeks. He was 41 years old. Surviving are his widow, Ruth; two sisters, Mrs. William we Pancoast of Philadelphia and Mrs. G. Fred Krayer of Woodbury, N. J., and three brothers.

The fifth report of the Irvingi Trust Company, trustee in reorganization proceedings of the RadioKeith-Orpheum Corporation, filed in the Federal Court -here yesterday, shows that for the twenty-sixweek period ended on July 3 the company and subsidiaries had a net profit of $1,448,783, before possible surtax on undistributed profits, compared with $734,492 for the same period in 1936.

White St, 62, 23x110.3; Richard F Fay to Herman L. Mehr, 923 Walton Ave; mtg $62,500 ($1.50). 61st St, 16-24 W, runs s 100.5xe 34xs 100.5 to 60th St, 25 wxe 18xn 100.5xe 48xn 100.5x w 100 to beg; James E. Bennett Jr, ref. to Central Savings Bank, foreclosure (S11).

The Belmont Theatre, Forty- will eighth Street east of Broadway, will reopen today for the new season with the Viennese production "An Orphan Boy of Vienna, played by Ferdinand Maierhofer, Julia Janssen and Hans Olden and featuring the Vienna Choir Boys and the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals restrained the Federal Power Commission today from reopening an investigation of six subsidiaries of the $200,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric Company in Pennsylvania until the court rules on the commission's jurisdiction.
Eight regional officials in the Ukraine and Azov districts died before firing squads today, convicted as "wreckers" in the Soviet agricultural program.
The Rev. William Dunn, pastor of the Queen of the Most Holy Rosary Church in Bridgehampton, died Sunday in St. Vincent's Hospital, New York.
Twenty-one members of the second and third year classes at the Harvard Law School have been elected to the Harvard Legal Aid Bureau on the basis of high scholastic achievement. They are:

The Chinese armies pressed attacks during the night on all fronts in the Shanghai area. Chinese civilians were ordered out of thickly populated sections [Page 1]. A Chinese force west of Peiping was dislodged, the Japanese said [Page 4].

Twenty-eight of the principal law enforcement officials of Westchester County met here tonight in the parish house of St. Paul's Episcopal Church to discuss methods of curbing the wave of perversion which this year has resulted in a doubling of sex offenses against children in the county.

Burleigh Grimes was not managing the Dodgers yesterday, that task having been assigned to Coach Andy High. Whether the Missouri squire will continue to pilot the club for another season apparently was the subject under discussion at a meeting of the Brooklyn Club's board of directors which started before the Bees-Dodgers game, recessed for a while and went into session when the game ended.

The Costa Rican Government today offered its good offices to mediate in the quarrel between Nicaragua and Honduras over a' Nicaraguan postage stamp. Costa Rica also asked the cooperation of the Governments of El Salvador and Guatemala to settle the dispute bv friendly means.

The value of large estates in the Kenilworth Road area of Purchase will be depreciated far below assessed valuations if the Westchester Joint Water-Works 1 is permitted to erect a standpipe ninety feet high and "looking like a cross between a mausoleum and a Turkish. mosque," it was charged here today before Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschiet.

A brilliant sun was shining in the Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon, but 35,000 bright-eyed children who sat there for two and a half hours saw a great many stars--shining lights of the sports world who demonstrated their skills for an appreciative audience in a "Parade of Stars."

The emphasis being placed in recent years on neighborhood improvement and community planning has been a factor in the creation of more attractive designs for factories and industrial structures here and there.

Mal Stevens is engaged in a juggling act with his New York University football squad these days and, since Steve is a clever juggler in a gridiron way, he expects to come out of his experimenting with a better team than last year.

Trading was fair in the wholesale markets yesterday morning, considering that quite a few houses were closed on account of the Jewish holiday. There was no kosher kill and the slaughter of those classes generally dressed kosher was confined largely to lamb. Steer cuts were strong to higher, but other classes showed little change from Friday. as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The Alteration Plumbers, Steamfitters and Helpers Union announced yesterday that it had called a strike of 2,000 mechanics and helpers in the plumbing and heating trade in Manhattan and the Bronx this morning at 7 o'clock.
The sixteen-story oft and store structure known as the New Center Building at 3941 West Thirty-second Street was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.

In his thoughtful speech on the labor problem, President Butler of Columbia University referred to the British Trade Disputes Act of 1927 and expressed the belief that the time has come for the enactment of similar legislation here.

The Bricklayers, Masons and Plasterers International Union has not committed itself to any candidate for the Mayoralty, Frank Della Penna, chairman of the New York Executive Committee of the union, said yesterday, in denying an announcement from Copeland headquarters that the union had gone on record in favor of Senator Copeland's candidacy.

Business failures in the United States numbered 151 in the week ended Sept. 2, the lowest level since July 22, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., announced yesterday. The figure compared with 155 a week earlier and 163 in the corresponding period last year. Applications for corporate reorganization under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act totaled 12.

The theft of jewelry valued at $15,000 from the home here of Robert G. Ilsley, New York broker, has led authorities to believe an organized band of gem thieves is operating in this area and thus far has perpetreated three jewel robberies without leaving a single clue.

Estimates by the Indian Government of a 1937-38 jute crop of only 8,618,000 bales were cabled to the local market yesterday and received with considerable skepticism by brokers and the trade here. If the figure were taken seriously, the market would have soared, according to comment, but it is the current belief here that output will total around 11,000,000 bales, a figure similar to that for last season.
Directors of the Holly Sugar Corporation authorized yesterday a credit of $100,000 for the preferred stock sinking-fund account, against which offerings will be requested from preferred shareholders.

The New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad, now undergoing reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act, is to be inspected next week by Federal Judge William Clark, who authorized the appointment of trustees on June 1.
The mysterious appearance of swastika emblems on the Russian side of posts marking the EstoniaSoviet frontier has curiously strained diplomatic relations between the two countries.

Officials of the Boston Metropolitan District, Mass., have invited bankers to submit bids on Sept. 14 for a new issue of $4,800,000 of refunding bonds, to mature in one to twenty-five years. Bidders are asked to specify the rate of maturity at either 2%, 2% or 23i per cent.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Madeliene Lamb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Walter Lamb of this city, to Raymond Cornelius Strassburger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter F. Strassburger of Butler, N. J., formerly of New York, took place yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

While twenty-two members of the Fordham varsity football squad ran through a signal drill and kicking exhibition at the Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon as part of the program arranged by the Juvenile Aid Society of the Police Athletic League, the rest of the players participated in a long assing drill.
Lou Camps, 133, Bronx, drew with Vernon Cormier, 131 3/4, Worcester, Mass., in the main eight-round event in the Coliseum before 6,000 spectators last night.
The four California pioneers who arrived here Monday night by plane from San Francisco spent yesterday afternoon sight-seeing. They said they were having the time of their lives.
The 3,000-ton British tanker Harpa was attacked tonight by "an unknown battleship" off the coast of North Africa, a Lloyds agent reported from Tunis.

Seventy-nine years after Admiral McClintock made the first attempt to navigate Bellot Strait, Major D.L. McKeand, leader of the Eastern Arctic Patrol, led .a party today through the latest Northwest Passage across the top of Canada.

As announced yesterday, the Treasury will offer, in exchange for $817,000,000 five-year Treasury notes which mature Sept. 15, the choice of new fifteen-month Treasury note 1 1/4s or five-year 2 per cents.
Postmaster General Farley told the National Federation of Postoffice Clerks today that a, shorter work week in the postal service had brought increased business and efficiency.

A feature of the fourth annual convention of the National Security Traders Association, to be held in Atlantic City starting today and ending on Saturday, will be a side trip to Philadelphia tomorrow for Philadelphia Day.

Because of the undeclared war with China, the Finance Ministry today agreed to grant export exchange licenses authorizing spinners to import an additional 100,000,000 pounds of raw cotton valued at $15,000,000.
John L. Lewis is beyond question the country's leading conservative in respect to the English language.
