The Monmouth County Country Club and Evergreen Farms met today in their first Eastern Polo League match of the season and, after six of the fastest chukkers ever played on the Monmouth Field, Monmouth County was victorious, 10 to 3.

Let this morning's main note be on the newly formed Mercury be Theatre, which has taken over the Comedy, has opened offices at 1,432 Broadway and has already set Nov. fo 6 as the approximate opening date for "Julius Caesar." Also, it has been doing a bit of casting, and on the program for opening night ta some of the roles will read like this:
Two men posing as messengers delivering a telegram held up and robbed Yetta Zwerling, Jewish actress, of $20,000 in jewelry in her apartment at 226 East Twelfth Street at 12:20 o'clock this morning.

Thomas A. Mathis, Secretary of State in New Jersey, surrendered here this afternoon to Charles Stanziale, Assistant United States Attorney, to answer to an indictment charging evasion of income tax payments.

Actual work on the construction of a new edifice to replace the red brick Roman Catholic Church of St. Andrew at Duane Street and Cardinal Place will start tomorrow, Mgr. William E. Cashin, pastor, announced yesterday.
To provide for expansion of its warehouse and distribution facilities, R. H. Macy Co., Inc., has extended its large holdings in Long Island City by the purchase of another entire block there.
The Public Health Service said today there were 622 infantile paralysis cases reported in the country during the week ending Aug. 28, a peak for the year thus far.

Senator Royal S. Copeland, candidate for both the Democraticand Republican nominations for Mayor, last night attributed the present troubled local political situation to the reputed Governorship ambitions of James A. Farley, Democratic State and National Chairman.

The principal operating subsidiaries in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company system showed an increase of 55,100 telephones in service during August, as compared with a gain of 66,800 instruments in August, 1936, and one of 27,200 in August, 1935.

William Russell Prall, a former member of the New York Fruit Exchange's board of directors and a prominent Sunday School worker, died here yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 314 Cornelia Street. His age was 79.
Putting a surprise end to widespread rumors, State Senator Clifford R. Powell today appointed his wife, Irene, manager of his campaign for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination.

With the success of the Treasury's September refinancing program apparently assured by reports received today, Secretary Morgenthau announced this evening that the books for it will be closed on Thursday on the offer made this morning of an exchange of 2 per cent five-year notes and 1 1/4, per cent fifteen-month notes for $817,483,500 of 3 1/4 per cent notes which will mature on Sept. 15.
Foreign intervention in the Spanish civil war was strongly criticized today in resolutions adopted at the British Trades Union Congress.

Archie San Romani, lithe Kansas miler, unsuccessfully assailed Stanley Wooderson's recent world mile record in a meet today. San Romani, despite a strong wind, turned in 4:08.8 for the distance to lead four others, including Erik Pettersson of Sweden, who finished second. It was one of the fastest miles ever run in Sweden.

Charging Japanese militarists with the "willful slaughter" of civilians and an "even graver offense" in attack upon the Red Cross, Dr. Chengting T. Wang, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, appealed yesterday for American aid to relieve the victims of what he termed Japan's "campaign of conquest" in China.

De Witt Ward, who for many years photographed the works of famous painters and sculptors in this country, died yesterday at his home here after a long illness. He was born in Manhattan sixty-four years ago and maintained a studio at 227 West Thirteenth Street.

The annual National Socialist Congress, which is more of a spectacle and demonstration than it is a congress, opened this morning with all the ceremony that has become traditional with it. Twelve thousand delegates in brown and black uniforms occupied the floor of the huge Luitpold Hall.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Adriance of Maplewood of the marriage of their daughter, Miss Jane Wheeler Adriance, to Robert J. Ailey, son of District Attorney and Mrs. Mont L. Ailey of New Castle, Pa.
Glenn Gabler, veteran right-hander, won a thrilling pitchers' duel from Bill Lohrman of Baltimore today to give the Jersey City Giants a 1-to-0 victory in the opening game of a three-game series.

Miss Mary Gertrude Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Martin of this city, was married here this morning in St. Genevieve's Church to Charles Earl McDonald of North Arlington, son of Mrs. Walter G. McDonald of Gardiner, Me., and the late Mr. McDonald, by the Rev. Edward J. Kern. The Rev. Dr.

Dr. George A. Works, formerly of Cornell and now a member of President Roosevelt's advisory committee on education, today commenced study of Puerto Rico's educational system, its development needs and objectives in connection with a request for $36,000,000 Federal aid and Mr. Roosevelt's suggestion that the island become bilingual.

Application blanks for renewal of automobile operators' licenses for three years were being distributed yesterday at all police stations, in addition to the offices of the Motor Vehicle Bureau in Manhattan and home the Bronx and County Clerks' offices in the Bronx, Queens and Richmond.

The New York County Republican Committee for the Renomination of Mayor La Guardia moved yesterday to carry its fight into Assembly districts where leaders are supporting Senator Royal S. Copeland for the nomination, by naming temporary leaders in six districts to handle the La Guardia campaign.

With the opening of the national individual rifle match today 1,922 or the country's best rifle shooters were on the firing line competing for the championship with the .30caliber United States rifles.
Mrs. Ruth G. Roosevelt, daughterin-law of the President, plans to enter the radio field, in which he has been active, her husband, Elliott Roosevelt, told the Federal Communications Commission today.

In a stretch duel that lasted for a furlong, the Calumet Farm's Crossbow II got home a scant nose in front of Mrs. Emil Denemark's Genie Palatine in the Exile Handicap which featured the racing at Aqueduct yesterday.

The new price of $19.85 for its Fall known yesterday by Crawford Clothes, retail chain, occasioned little surprise in the trade, which had felt that if the chain were to continue on a strictly cash basis, it would probably have to go below the twenty-dollar-mark.

Russia's flat charge that Italian warships sank Soviet Russian ships and Italy's flat rejection of the charge are as warlike as undiplomatic language can make them. Under the international code of yesterday such an exchange between Governments would have meant war.

IT may seem strange, but the fact is that American biography is only now beginning to be written. Most of it has been attempted before, but most of it needs to be attempted again. It can be argued, for example, that we have no completely satisfactory life of even Abraham Lincoln, despite an immense pile of books about him.
The name of Representative John Dockweiler of Los Angeles was added today to the list of Democrats who will seek the office of Governor In 1938.

Charter service and private airplane operators at North Beach Airport have been notified to vacate the hangars at the field within thirty days. Some of them expressed resentment that in the course of the improvement and enlargement of the airport into

The Sonoco Products Company, Hartsville, S. C., manufacturer of paper and textile supplies, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 2,000 shares of $100-par value cumulative preferred 5 per cent stock to be offered at $102 a share and 20,000 shares of $5-par value common stock to be offered at $17.50 a share for an aggregate of $554,000.

Russia made clear tonight she wanted an indictment of Italy from Friday's European conference on "piracy" in the Mediterranean, and that the success or failure of that wish might determine her future course into the war-clouded horizon.
Eggs with yolks as green as grass are being laid by a 2-year-old Leghorn hen owned by Bryson Foster.

Engagement of $7,347,000 gold abroad for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of this amount, $5,800,000 was taken in Japan for sale to the United States Mint in San Francisco, $982,000 was engaged in England and $565,000 was obtained in India.

Colonel William Harold Terry yesterday officially became the New York Giants' field and farm manager for the next five years when he affixed his signature to a contract with President Horace A. Stoneham in the club's offices on West Fortysecond Street.
Elmer Clint Duncan of Tennessee, World War veteran and captain of the Interior Department's guard service, was today appointed to succeed the late William Wright as inspector in charge of the guards.
Mr. and Mrs. Maxim Karolik are to open their residence on Wednesday afternoon, Sept. 15, for a musical matinee.

Big Bill Lee supplied the pitching and Phil Cavarretta did the important hitting today as the Chicago Cubs beat the Cardinals, 8 to 5, in the first game of their series, to trim the idle New York Giants' National League lead to two and one-half games.

Mrs. Beatrice Bell Laughlin of East Jaffrey and New, York, widow of Laurance Cramer Laughlin of East Jaffrey and daughter of Mrs. Bertrand F. Bell, also of East Jaffrey and New York, and the late Mr. Bell, was married here yesterday in the Emanuel Church to Thomas Bradley Buffum of Morristown, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Arthur Lichtenberger.
J. P. Morgan observed his seventieth birthday today by remaining quietly in the seclusion of his Scottish home at Gannochy.
Grave complications tonight endangered the life of Patricia Maguire, the "sleeping beauty," who has lain in a coma for five and a half years.

Police are investigating an altercation in which Governor Hoffman and Lewis Angelo of Trenton, formerly a State boxing. inspector, figured tonight, in front of the Hotel Hildebrecht, here. Chief William A. Dooling said both men might be summoned to court to explain.

Ben Lipset, artists' representative, in McCutcheon Building, 607 6th Ave; Culver, Hollyday Co. Inc. broker. Sales Films, Inc, motion pictures, in 9 Rocketeller Plaza, Rockefeller Center. Papyrus Papeteries, Inc. in 26 W 29th St; New York Pharmacist Association, in ,27-37 W 60th St: Field, Moses Jones,
The Rockefeller Foundation's investments at the end of 1936 amounted to $172,546,008, compared with $175,781,008 at the end of 1935, its report disclosed yesterday.

Dr. Charles A. Richmond, President Emeritus of Union College in.Schenectady, N. Y., said today at the tenth annual ScottishAmerican memorial service that "America would support Britain in any world conflict despite the Neutrality Act."
Non-recurring expenses were largely responsible for a net loss of $690,000 reported by the Lehigh Valley Railroad for the first seven months of the year, D. J. Kerr, president, said yesterday.

Confronted with the growing disregard of British interests in the Far East and in the Mediterranean, the British Cabinet will meet tomorrow for the first time since July to decide Britain's next moves.

Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., arriving here today from Shanghai, sharply criticized President Roosevelt for his policy in the Orient. She and her son Quentin returned aboard the liner President Jefferson with five other Americans. Mrs. Roosevelt dictated her statement while sitting on a suitcase in her stateroom. It was typed by her son on a portable machine held on his knees.

With a heavy police guard on duty in the surrounding area, the Superior Military Tribunal will meet tomorrow to try the appeals of the thirty-five men sentenced several months ago as the alleged leaders of the Leftist uprising in November, 1935.

A large airplane landing field has been laid out and work of making fills and providing proper drainage will be started in a few days at the Foxcatcher Hounds Hunt Club, Fair Hill, Md. The field will not be ready for use at the race meeting Saturday.

Public schools throughout the city, including four new buildings, will open at 9 o'clock this morning for the registration of 45,000 newcomers in the kindergarten and 1A grades and for pupils desiring transfers from one school to another.
Shaking himself free at the head of the stretch, W. C. Stroube's Huskie Boy drew away from six 2-year-old rivals to win the six-furlong Norwell Purse by two lengths at Narragansett Park today.

Mrs. J. Courtney McGroarty gave a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 2,021 Ditmas Avenue, Brooklyn, at which she announced the engagement of her sister, Miss Isabelle Vera King, to Henry V. Birgel, also of Brooklyn.

Federal Government activities in the mining field were criticized by three speakers today as the fourday annual convention of the American Mining Congress opened here. Nearly 2,000 delegates were present.
The Democratic Presidential candidate in 1940 will be neither an extreme New Dealer nor an extreme conservative, Senator Pittman said in an interview here last night.

A movement to develop uniform State regulations for the growing trailer traffic took form yesterday with the announcement of the appointment of an interstate committee to consider the problem. The movement is intended by its sponsors to counteract the tendency toward a confusing divergence of regulations, in States and municipalities, of the "homes on wheels."

The White House announced today that all of the Governors who will attend the annual Governors' Conference at Atlantic City have been invited by President Roosevelt to lunch with him at the White House on Sept. 16. It is expected that between thirty and fory Governors will attend the luncheon.

Beginning Sept. 15, Mexican Consuls throughout the world will collect in advance a tax on all merchandise shipped to Mexico. This will amount to 3 per cent on 35 per cent of the invoice value of the merchandise being shipped.
John Montague, Hollywood golfer and friend of movie stars, was held today for trial the week of Oct. 11 after he had pleaded innocent of a seven-year-old robbery charge.

New York State Electric and Gas To finance a construction program, an offering of 100,000 shares of $1.25 cumulative preferred stock, with a par value of $25, is being made by the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation. The offering is limited to residents of New York State.

Static electricity generated on a dog's back was blamed today for 8year-old Teddy Fogel's badly burned right hand. John Questa, assistant fire chief, said the boy was petting the dog, which was tied to the back of an automobile.

County Judge John J. Fitzgerald in Brooklyn granted a motion yesterday for the drawing of a special panel of jurors for the retrial of Felix J. Cummings, 29 years old, and George Lewis, 25, on a firstdegree murder indictment in the hold-up killing of Ralph Nischo, a waiter, in a bar and grill at 1,942 Fulton Street, Brooklyn.

Retired Engineer of Steamer Frank L. Edgette, formerly a member of Engine 225, residing at 521 W. 162d St., Manhattan, died Sept. 4. Retired Fireman Frederick Strobel, formerly a member of Engine 57. residing at 7,040 Colonial Road, Brooklyn, died Sept. 5. Funeral will take place from funeral parlors of Joseph Galvin, 7,722 4th Ave.,
Stocks broke 2 to 10 points and closed nervous in heaviest trading since April 29; turnover, 1,871,150 shares.

The semi-annual report of the Burroughs Adding Machine Company and subsidiaries, announced yesterday, showed for the six months ended on June 30 a net profit of $4,514,162 after depreciation, Federal and foreign income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

The first detailed account of the destruction of the American mission and hospital at Nantungchow by a Japanese air raid was brought to Shanghai today when the Rev. C. A. Burch returned after a hazardous inspection trip.

While August registered sizable losses in men's-wear linage for stores of this city, the Fall selling season, which theoretically opened yesterday, is expected to bring about a substantial increase in advertising. At the same time, a new price by one leading clothing chain is believed to have complicated the situation somewhat, according to comment in the advertising field.

At the moment John Payne appears the probable choice for the male lead opposite Ginger Rogers in "Having Wonderful Time" at RKO. If he does get the part, he will literally have fulfilled the title of the picture in his brief but promising Hollywood career.
James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will return tomorrow to Washington to remain a short time before resigning to become dean of the Harvard, Law School.

Kenneth Rush, through Douglas Gibbons Co, in 192 E 75th St: Van Buren Taliaferro, through the J. H. Taylor Management Co, in 315 E 68th St; Harry Angelo, through Payson McL. Merrill Co, in 1,035 Park Ave; Culver, Hollyday Co, Inc, broker.

Replicas of the Constitution of the United States as signed at Philadelphia Sept. 17, 1787, and the Declaration of Independence were presented today to Joseph A. C. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, by Michael Francis Doyle of Philadelphia on behalf of that city, in connection with the 150th anniversary of the Constitution's adoption.

Attorney General Cummings has the advantage on his fellows in the autograph collecting field. His celebrities come to see him. Atop a mahogany table in his office is a huge book, filling up fast now with moro than a thousand signatures of America's foremost figures.

Burglars got $5, but failed to obtain $600 and some antique silverware early yesterday morning when they found a safe too stubborn to crack in the Barbour Restaurant, Inc., 1 West Fifty-second Street. It was the second time in two years that burglars invaded the place. On the first visit the invaders obtained about $700 after cracking a safe.

Robbers ransacked the Georgetown home of James Roosevelt tonight during the absence of. the President's son and his family. Police said several bureau drawers were pulled out by one or more intruders who entered through a side window.
Favored by cooler weather, retail trade here yesterday shook off some of the Summer lethargy which kept sales volume below expectations during recent weeks.

The United States Seniors, those doughty linksmen whose motto is "once a senior, always a senior; sometimes venerable, but never aged," again today took possession of the Apawamis links, scene of the memorable national amateur of 1911, when Harold Hilton, the British invader, won the cup.

Assailing Dr. Frederick B. Robin son, president of City College, for "high-handed methods" in ignoring the Board of Higher Education in making up the college budget, John. T. Flynn, member of the board, declared yesterday at a budget hearing that the college's requests for 1938 included $79,000 for jobs that the board had not acted on.

Today marks the twenty-seventh anniversary of the beginning of railroad service to Long Island from the Pennsylvania station. The Long Island section of the station was opened on Sept. 8, 1910, with the first trains running into the station from Long Island communities, to be followed on Nov. 27 that year with the formal opening of the rest of the Pennsylvania station.

The steel industry of the United States this week is operating at 71.6 per cent of capacity, compared to 84.1 per cent last week, a decrease of 12.5 points, or 14.9 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute computed yesterday.

Is it right for a physician to patent an appliance for the treatment of a disease or a drug that will cure it? The question came up at Rochester before the American Chemical Society. Though nothing new was developed,
A revolt broke out in Asuncion, Paraguay, at dawn this morning to recall Colonel Rafael Franco as President.

There is little doubt but that the "war news" was the immediate cause of the rush to sell securities yesterday. But it is also true that many speculators had been on the anxious seat for some time over the probable extent of the business pick-up this Autumn.

The stock market suffered yesterday its worst break in recent years. Prices tumbled 2 to 10 points as increasing war fears, combined with the cloudy outlook for business this Fall, produced heavy liquidation by investors and traders alike.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler warned the world as the National Socialist party congress opened this morning that it would "no longer be possible to disregard at any time and place" the "community of will" between Nazi Germany and Fascist Italy.

Fifty-five players reported for the first practice of the Colgate eleven today and Coach Andy Kerr, who had made a hurried trip from New York, said that right tackle, the guard positions and left halfback are the berths open on the first team.

Mr. and Mrs. David Wagstaff entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the RitzCarlton for Mr. and Mrs. Johnfritz Achelis, Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Hurd, Mrs. Joseph R. Busk, David Forbes and George Newman.
Dr. Frederick Paulding, actor, writer and lecturer on the drama, died here last night in his home at 15 East Newell Avenue at the age of 78. He suffered a heart attack on Saturday.

Mrs. Caroline S. Marshall is suing her husband, Everett R. Marshall, singer, for a separation, it was disclosed yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente appointed her receiver of all her husband's property within New York State.
The British Museum is said to have nearly completed negotiations for the purchase of the Ashley library formed by the late Thomas J. Wise, bibliographer, collector and editor.
According to insistent reports, substantiated by circumstantial evidence today, Dr. Hjalmar H. G. Schacht has again submitted his resignation as Acting Economic Minister and as Reichsbank president.

The filing of reports of primary campaign committees on contributions and expenditures with the Board of Elections yesterday, while incomplete, indicated that committees promoting the Democratic ticket of Jeremiah T. Mahoney for Mayor, Frank J. Taylor for Controller and Max J. Schneider for President of the Council were the most successful in collecting and spending.
Attorney General Cummings asked the Supreme Court today to reexamine decisions under which private corporations performing Federal contracts have received exemption from State taxation.

Three games in the twelve-goal Autumn Plates tournament of the Meadow Brook Club were played at the club this afternoon while most of the open championship players rested for the resumption of the trial matches tomorrow.
There will be no Farmer-Labor party on Philadelphia ballots in November. The proposal was killed today by Judge Howard A. Davis of Common Pleas Court.
Lady Lyle, wife of Sir Charles Ernest Leonard Lyle, Bart., accompanied by her daughters, the Misses Nancy and Suzanne Lyle, has arrived from London and is at the Waldorf-Astoria.
The report of the Committee for the Study of Raw Materials, just adopted, amounts politically to counter-attacks against armaments and national sufficiency plans.

Unless otherwise stated, the re sults of operations of the following companiess, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes, depreciation and other charges, but before provisions for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.

Today the schools of the greater city open. In whatever measure their splendid physical equipment or their modernized methods of teaching outstrip those of the little red school house, they lag behind it in at least one respect:

British Columbia Power Corporation, Ltd.-Fiscal year ended June 30: Net profit after interest, depreciation, amortization, taxes and other charges, $2,415,428, comparing with a net profit of $1,641,942 in the preceding fiscal year.
Concern over the Mediterranean "piracy" situation held business on the stock markets to an exceedingly small scale today, with little support to counteract the general downward tendency.
A Roman Catholic Archbishop whose archdiocese includes Nineveh, Ur, Mosul and other Near Eastern places famous in biblical times, is in New York.

Jiro Yamagishi, champion of Japan, and Yvon Petra, France's last remaining representative, were eliminated from the national tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday and for a time there was the prospect that they would be accompanied toward the exit by Miss Helen Jacobs and Frank Parker, as well as Charles Hare of Great Britain.
Donald W. Douglas, president of the Douglas Aircraft Corporation, said today that he had closed the Northrop aircraft plant, a subsidiary. He added that it "no longer exists as an industrial entity."
Soles of the F. W. Woolworth Company for August amounted to $22,794,904 compared with $23,186,353 in the same month last year, a decrease of 1.2 per cent.

Frank A. Wood has been appointed manager of the New York office of Otis Co. The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has been appointed cotransfer agent for 482,792 shares of common stock of the Puget Sound Pulp and Timber Company.

State Department officials were regretful and surprised today at reported alarm among American residents of Shanghai that their Government intended to remove what protection it has thus far been providing for them. Secretary of State Cordell Hull indicated, although he declined to discuss the situation in detail, that there had been no change of policy and that none was in contemplation.

Several hundred members of the State Historical Association gathered on the campus of Colgate University today for the annual meeting and heard Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, president of Union College and head of the association, give his annual address on "The Old Farm."

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, made a bid for the support of organized labor yesterday by declaring that conciliation in labor disputes was probably the most important duty of a public official today and pledging himself, if elected, to devise a satisfactory way of ending labor difficulties without losses to both sides.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Pearce Couzens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Secor Couzens of Yonkers, N. Y., to John Bell Thurston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Royal Church Thurston of Rochester and Dennis, took place here this afternoon in the First Parish Chiurch.

Swiss authorities are surveying the limited facilities of Nyon for the proposed Mediterranean "piracy" conference. Nyon, with 5,600 inhabitants, is fifteen miles from Geneva and has only two meeting places to offer the diplomats.

MANY PEOPLE PRIZE IT, by J. C. Furnas. (Morrow, $2.50.) A novel of the boom period. LET YOUR MIND ALONE, by James Thurber. (Harper, $2.50.) A collection of Mr. Thurber's recent writings. THE THIRD MORALITY, by Gerald Heard. (Morrow, $2.75.) On modern living.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 1: Increases of $32,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans and $37,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities, and decreases of $39,000,000 in holdings of United States Government direct obligations and $22,000,000 in "other securities."

In marked contrast to the downward sweep in the securities markets yesterday, price movements of commodity futures were steady to higher in moderate activity. Goodsized gains were recorded in rubber, hide, cottonseed oil and sugar futures, while slight losses were shown in silk, pepper, cocoa and tin futures.

Russia's bold step in demanding indemnity from Italy for two ships sunk by submarines was joyously received in Loyalist Spain today. It is regarded as the first direct move in a game hitherto confined to diplomatic amenities.

James Greenleaf Sykes of 580 Park Avenue and Dorset, Vt., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Martha Greenleaf Sykes, to David Clendon Hale of this city, son of Mrs. David Campbell Hale of Cambridge, Mass.; and Surry, Me., and of the late Mr. Hale.

A ninety-minute scrimmage topped off a double workout for Manhattan's squad at La Salle Military Academy today. Coach Chick Meehan stressed running plays and had the first and second elevens try their offensive skill against a third combination. There was little to choose between the work of the first two squads.
The New Haven office of Yalein-China was informed by cable that the preparatory school in Changsha was opened today despite the Sino-Japanese conflict.

Exports of hardware and allied products from the United States in July were valued at 39 per cent above shipments in July, 1936, the Deapartment of Commerce reported today. The valuation was $4,347,934, compared with $3,955,407 in the same period of 1936. The July figures also reflected a gain of 10 per cent over June.
Returning New Yorkers and departing visitors, both homeward bound after the Labor Day weekend and the close of the Summer season, continued to crowd rail and bus lines yesterday.
Blow Ye Winds," the new comedy by Valentine Davies, with Henry Fonda and Doris Dalton in the leading roles, was presented by Arthur Hopkins at the Shubert Theatre tonight.
The Labor party adopted a city platform praising Mayor La Guardia's rule and asking the expansion of his policies. Page 1.

Much of the crime neuroses, war-hysteria and anti-social behavior in general on the part of individuals and nations might be eliminated from the world if children were taught to understand the physiological functions of the human body and practical ways

Football in New York is at the edge of a new season. Tonight the New York professional Giants and the Eastern College All-Stars will run out under the floodlights at the Polo Grounds for their second meeting.

Freddy Fitzsimmons, returning to action for the first time since he broke a finger in a game against the Pirates in Pittsburgh on Aug. 4, hurled a neat triumph over the Bees at Ebbets Field yesterday, the Dodgers taking the game, 6-1, and the series, two to one.
A "lady in red" was sought tonight by police who said she left a "happily married" man shot dead on the floor of his bedroom and a detective-story murder mystery on their hands.

Soviet Russia, accepting an invitation to the conference on "piracy" in the Mediterranean, made clear that she expected an indictment of Italy. In her note of acceptance she renewed her accusations against Italian warships, questioned the right of Germany to be present at the meeting and suggested that the Valencia Government should be asked to attend. [Page l.]

A blanket increase of 10 per cent in the wages of 6,962 employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau has been recommended by Frank J. Taylor, Controller, following an investigation made at the request of the Board of Estimate, it became known yesterday.
In an editorial believed to state the views of the Turkish Government, the newspaper Aksham declared today that Turkey was entitled

The Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce was accused of encouraging the runaway shop in a National Labor Relations Board report made public here yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the board.

Horace M. Gray, president of the Yonkers City Manager Association, applied to Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief today for an order dismissing all objections to a petition for another referendum on a city manager charter for Yonkers.

THERE are some football enthusiasts who will be looking at the gridiron festival at the Polo Grounds tonight as a test of college football against or in comparison with pro football but this observer would call that a misguided view.

Persons prominent in the fields of music and the theatre are included among the honorary pallbearers for the funeral of Henry Hadley, American composer and conductor, which will be held at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Thirty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue, today at 2:30 P. M. The Rev. Harry B. Taylor will officiate.

A group of 130 members of the United Wards Club of London, all but five of whom are on their first visit to this country, were received by Mayor La Guardia at the Summer City Hall in Queens yesterday on the third day of their visit to New York.

BANOWITCH -- Julius. devoted father of Benjamin, Dr. Morris M., Mrs. Sarah. Goldstein, Charles A. and Harry J., brother of Moses. Funeral services Wednesday, 1 P. M., at his late residence, 1,690 East 7th St., Brooklyn. Interment Washington Cemetery.

Winning three matches within six hours, 17-year-old Miss Barbara Winslow of Hollywood, Calif., the favorite, today led seven other girls into the quarter-finals of the national girls' tennis champoinships at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

The Westchester P. G. A. pro-amateur one-day golf tournament held over the Lawrence Farms golf course today was won by Clyde Usina Jr. and his amateur partner, Dr. John B. Harris, both of Sleepy Hollow, with a best-ball score of 31, 34-65.

A government communique announced today that on Saturday a treaty of friendship had been signed between Italy and Yemen, renewing and bringing up to date the existing treaty. It is understood that it also contains clauses intensifying economic relations.

Orthodox Jewry in temples and synagogues of the city celebrated yesterday the second day of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year. As on the previous day, when the year 5698 was ushered in, rabbis and Jewish leaders used the occasion of the holiday by urging solidarity and by admonishing their congregations to have faith in Jewry.
Chicago's outbreak of infantile paralysis showed no let-up today. In the seventy-two hours beginning at 9 o'clock Saturday morning 33 new cases, 25 suspected cases and 4 deaths were reported.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:

William A. D. Blake, 20 years old, son of the late Dr. Joseph A. Blake, World War surgeon, and John Vernon Morice, 24, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Morice of Southampton and Cross River, Westchester County, were killed here in an automobile accident at 1:15 o'clock this morning.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor said farewell to their honeymoon castle of Wasserleonburg at midday today, apparently becoming wanderers through Central Europe. The Duke's equerry said they have no plans beyond a Hungarian hunting trip that will end on Sept. 14 and a subsequent visit to Vienna.

Louis J. Boury, son of the late Edward and Georgiana Myers Boury of Baltimore, died here yesterday at his home, Boxlawn, where he had lived since his retirement thirty years ago. Previously he had resided at 990 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn.
United States track and field stars won eight of ten events in a meet with athletes from France and Luxembourg at Jean Bouin Stadium today. It was the final meet of the American team's European tour.
Coast guardsmen saved 7,631 lives during the year ended June 30, and gave assistance to vessels valued at nearly $100,000,000, officials announced today.

The marriage of Miss Mary rances Sanborn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Sanborn of this city, to John Gerard Theban, son of Mrs. John G. Theban of Chappaqua, N. Y., and the late Mr. Theban, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration.

Underwater cargo ships, carrying war materials and other supplies safely beneath the surface of the seas during the next war, were predicted yesterday by Simon Lake, inventor of the even-keel submarine, in an interview celebrating his seventy-first birthday last Saturday.
Farmers, attending the State Fair today, heard a legislator's warning to dairymen to "make certain that every effort at compromise is exhausted before the strike weapon is used."

Complaining of repeated personal attacks Premier Paul van Zeeland before a special session of Parliament, which he called to hear his defense, warned that their continuance "soon will make it impossible to govern usefully under such conditions."

Charles Tappan Ward, chairman of the board of directors of the Francis H. Leggett Company, wholesale grocers, died yesterday morning in St. Elizabeth Hospital, Fort Washington Avenue at 190th Street. Mr. Ward's home was at 91 Central Park West. He was in his sixty-fourth year.

The average price of foods is likely to swing back and forth within the limits of a comparatively narrow zone, according to a review issued yesterday by the American Institute of Food Distribution. Inspite of some sacrifice selling as a result of financial pressure and
Victor Kolar, co-conductor of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, announced tonight that he had resigned as conductor of the Ford orchestra's radio broadcasts. The resignation was accepted.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Grace Giberson, Sheffield, Mass., and Anna Giberson. West Cornwall, Conn., daughters, executrices, interests in residuary trust. DU VIVIER, EDWARD F. (July 28). Estate, about $15,000. To Ernest H. du Vtvier, Shore Road, Stratford, Conn.; Charles L. du Vivier, 76 Sedgwick Ave., Darien, Conn.; Louise du Vivier,

Burglars blew out the backs of two safes in the Gramercy Jewelers, Inc., store at 94 Flatbush Avenue, near State Street, Brooklyn, during the holiday week-end and carried off the stock of pins, watches and rings.
The Czechoslovak press expresses satisfaction over a papal bull fixing the boundaries of new Czechoslovak dioceses.

An auction sale of a group of acreage parcels and business lots in Shinnecock Hills, Southampton, L. I., will be held on Saturday, Sept. 25, by J. Edward Breuer. The American Institute of Steel Construction is sponsoring a dinner in the interest of better highways on Sept. 21 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Weirton Steel Employe Representation Plan, through its attorney, charged today that "our organizations" were being "crucified" at the Labor Board hearing in the steel company case. Protesting the questioning by Labor Board attorneys of an employee representative regarding finances of the Employes' Security League at Weirton, William T. Fahey said:

The engineer officers of the United States liner Manhattan refused yesterday afternoon to sign on for the transatlantic voyage that the ship is scheduled to start at noon today. Their action followed the rejection by the line of their demand for wage increases ranging from $40 to $80 a month.
Sales of copper were made abroad yesterday at 13.85 cents a pound c. i. f. European base ports, compared with 13.725 to 13.75 cents at the week-end.

The Claredda Farm of Shrewsbury, N. J., displayed early championship hunter material during the second afternoon program at the Empire State Horse Show today, taking blues in the only qualified hunter classes.

In a welcoming address to the Bronx County September Grand Jury, Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan yesterday assailed the "enforcement officers of this State" for conducting searches and seizures without warrants.

Miss Emma Mills will give her annual talk on European personalities and affairs at the Maidstone Club on Thursday morning. Mrs. Philip Ruxton is among those who will give luncheons at the club afterward.
Mrs. Laura Consuelo Kilpatrick Morgan Thay won back today the American citizenship she lost when she married a Frenchman in 1920.

The Connecticut Federation of Labor, opening its four-day convention here today, upheld the order of its executive council suspending ten locals which had affiliated with the C. I. O. After the vote of 121 to 23 had been recorded, Governor Wilbur L. Cross, in opening his address, said, "I want to congratulate you on what you have just done."

The fiercest fighting of Spain's civil war is reported taking place now on the northeastern Aragon front, where General Francisco Franco's officers say a newly formed Government army a hundred thousand strong is slowly but surely being overwhelmed.

Under the influence of heavy rains over the week-end and covering operations in advance of today's Government crop estimate, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved 4 to 16 points yesterday. Despite weakness in the stock market and the trend of most private estimates toward an increase over last month's figures, a steady demand for contracts furnished resistance and closed the list at the best figures of the day.

Now that Labor Day is over, and the thousands of anglers are dwindling away to hundreds, charter boat skippers are looking over charts of the inland route in preparation for their thrash to Florida waters.
" In this war no prisoners are being taken on either side-not even wounded prisoners." This was the grim admission made privately to this writer today by a Chinese official after close questioning.

Today in the Borough of Richmond the Department of Public Welfare is beginning an experiment that may furnish a model for the administration of all types of public relief in the city. It is in purpose and plan a decentralization of service under a centralized responsibility.

In the first round of the Catholic Youth Organization baseball playoffs the teams of Sacred Heart and St. Nicholas of Tolentine, Staten Island and Bronx champions, respectively, won games played at Bedford Park yesterday.

The State Department today said that Nelson T. Johnson, United States Ambassador to China, had reported under date of Sept. 5 that the following Americans had left Nanking on the British steamship Woosung: For Hankow: Mrs. Ralph Ward. From Nantung, Kiangsu: Miss Nancy Fry, Bedford, Ind.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 13,000 including 1,000 directs. The market was steady to 10 cents lower than Friday's average; top $11.70; bulk good and choice 190-230 pounds, $11.45-65; comparable 150-180 pounds, $10.50-$11.50; 240-300 pounds, butchers $10.90-$11.45; most good packing sows, $9.50-90: best lightweights, $10. Shippers 1,500; estimated holdover 2,500.
New York at Brooklyn--umbert vs. Butcher. Philadelphia at Boston (2)-La Master and Walters vs. Turner and Hutchinson. St. Louis at Chicago-Harrell vs.

On the heels of the announcement that the Norwegian Foreign Minister Halvdan Kolit will visit the United States in October, the Oslo Morgenbladet said today that President Roosevelt intends also to invite the Swedish and Danish Foreign Ministers to Washington.

Sir Frederick Pascoe-Rutter, Sir Harry and Lady Hague, Lady Lyle, Colonel R. B. S. Reford, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Williamson and Dr. A. W. Erskine are among the passengers leaving today for Southampton via Cherbourg on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

T. O. M. Sopwith, British airplane manufacturer and challenger for the America's Cup, visiting the line-up at Police Headquarters yesterday morning, met the policeman who had arrested him twenty-five years ago in Queens for speeding.

Carbon, the stuff of gas masks, has been converted into the coldest "ice" on earth, 446 degrees below zero, Fahrenheit, it was reported to the American Chemical Society here today by Dr. H. T. Gerry of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

36th St, 258-58 W, 35.7x98.9; Rose Bash to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, p m 5 years, interest as per bond; $111,008.62. 93d St, 334 E, 25x100.8; Improval Corp, Max Goldberg, President, to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, 1 p m, 5 years, interest as per bond; $13,000.
Forty-nine candidates reported for the opening of Syracuse University's football camp on the campus today, with late arrivals tomorrow expected to bring the total to fiftyfive.
Reports that the Japanese Government might revoke plans to hold the Olympic games at Tokyo in 1940 because. of its troubles with China have been received with surprise and apprehension in Finland.

United States Senator Lynn J. Frazier of Hoople, N. D., and Mrs. Catherine Paulson of Concrete, N. D., were married in a quiet ceremony here today by the Rev. H. Sigmar, pastor of the Mountain Icelandic Church.

Building plans filed yesterday were most numerous in Queens, where architects submitted the details for the construction of twentyfour houses in various parts of the borough, with a block of fifteen to be built in one development on 255th Street, near Eighty-third Avenue, not far from the Nassau County line.

Army engineers harnessing the erratic Upper Mississippi River in a navigable channel expect to complete their $150,000,000 job next year. Their progress reports disclosed today that the work of stair-stepping the 658-mile length from the mouth of the Missouri River to the harbor at Minneapolis was. well beyond the . two-thirds completed mark.

The Grand Army of the Republic decorated graves of Union and Confederate soldiers today, but reserved for a secret vote the question of joining surviving Southern soldiers in a reunion of the Blue and Gray at Gettysburg next year.
After a day of hurried conferences, the Olympic organizing committee tonight decided to proceed with its plans for holding the international games at Tokyo in 1940.

About 750 passengers in the six rear cars of a Brighton Beach express train of the B. M. T. subway were stalled for twenty minutes half way between the Seventh Avenue and Prospect Park stations in Brooklyn between 5:30 and 6 o'clock last night when a coupling broke and the first two cars went on without them.

License examinations for first assistants in high schools will be given today at the Julia Richman High School, Second Avenue and Sixtyseventh Street, it was announced yesterday at the Board of Education.

Eleven publishers have put fiftythree of their new Fall books and several best sellers previously published under the price maintenance provisions of the Feld-Crawford act, according to notifications received yesterday by retail establishments here.
The onceproud Red Sox who only a few, weeks ago held second place tonight teetered on the edge of the second division after the Senators beat them twice, 11 to 5 and 5 to 4.

Fair trade laws, labor conditions and other timely subjects will be discussed by members of the drug, chemical and allied trades sections of the New York Board of Trade at their Fall meeting at the Buckwood Inn at Shawnee-On-theDelaware on Sept. 17 and 18.

A strike of sixty workers at the plant here of the Hercules-Campbell Body Company, manufacturers of truck and automobile bodies, was settled today. The men, all members of the United Automobile Workers of America, left their work ten days ago.

Clinging lines in mat surface fabrics enlivened by touches of color characterized models from London and Paris openings shown yesterday by Ellerbe Wood, importer, before an audience of almost one hundred designers, stylists and fashion writers at her studio, 610 Fifth Avenue. Many of the afternoon and evening dresses were draped.

Mr. and Mrs. John Noble Stearns Jr. will give a dinner dance on Saturday at their home here for Kiss Elizabeth McKay Cushing, who made her debut in the Spring at a dinner dance given by her parnts, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Goodwin Cushing, at the Piping Rock Club.
In an attempt to bolster their line-up, the Cubs today purchased Carl Reynolds of Minneapolis, a hitting sensation of the American Association. Reynolds, an outfielder, will join the Cubs tomorrow.

With Mrs. G. can-bred Perifox. Mid-Day Sun, strong favorite to establish himself the outstanding 3-year-old of the season, a field of 15 was ready tonight for the 162d running tomorrow of the St. Leger, last of the season's five classics.

Great Britain is determined that the conference on piracy in the Mediterranean shall be held whether Italy and Germany attend or not. Officials declined to comment on Russia's charges against Italy or on the angry retorts which came from Rome.

Philip Krahl, 27 years old, was held without bail for the grand jury today by Mayor Wilson, sitting as a committing magistrate this evening, after he had admitted luring a sixyear-old girl and her three-year-old brother into Fairmount Park and attacking them.

About 1,100 workers, virtually the entire Force of the J. G. Brill Company plant at Sixty-second Street and Woodland Avenue, went on strike today in protest against alleged anti-union activity by the company.

A sharp loss was registered in the number of visiting buyers in town for the week ending yesterday due to Labor Day and religious holidays. For last week 392 buyers were reported, according to the listings in THE TIMES. This compares with 848 buyers for the previous week, and 535 for the corresponding period last year. Yesterday's registrations amounted to 14, as against 314 listed last Tuesday.
Harry Balsamo, Harlem middleweight, defeated Bob Turner of Fairmount, W. Va., in the star bout of ten rounds at the Queensboro Arena last night.

" No comment" was the temporary White House office's answer today to reports that the American Chamber of Commerce in Shanghai and other Americans there were asking the intervention of armed United States forces to protect their lives and property.
A home run by Harry Craft in the ninth inning with the bases loaded and two out enabled Syracuse to defeat Newark, 7 to 6, tonight. The Chiefs broke a five-game Newark victory streak.
The War Department was advised today that Lieut. Col. Harry Thornton Moore, retired, died in Paris this morning. He was in his sixty-eighth year and was born at Magnolia, III., May 24, 1870.

A man tentatively identified as Raymond L. Corlett, 37, of Los Angeles, plunged from an airplane through the roof of a dwelling to his death today, and police reports quoted the pilot as saying it was a suicide.

Movements of vessels follow: Pearl Harbor to Shanghai, Sept. 5: Chaumont, Marblehead. At Portsmouth Yard: Dahlgren, Sept. 7; Pickerel, Sept. 4; Pollack, Sept. 4. Lynnhaven Roads to sea, Sept. 5: Decatur, Dickerson. Charleston Yard to sea, Sept. 4: Fairfax, Herbert, rattnall. At Chefoo J. D. Ford, Sept. 7; Gold Star. Sept. 6.

The 1,000,000,000th passenger to ride the city's Independent Subway System dropped a nickel into one of 593 turnstiles of the 100 stations of the system last Saturday night, it was reported yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

The inhabitation of the model settlement of Greenbelt, the first attempt to run an entire community without any profit, advanced a step nearer today with the incorporation of Greenbelt Consumers Services, Inc.
Delegates began arriving here today for the twelfth annual conference of police benevolent associations of New York State.
Le Baron Colt Anthony of Providence observed his twenty-first birthday today at the Mount Washington Hotel, where his mother, Mrs. Colt Anthony, gave a dinner in his honor in the banquet room.

Despite the large amount of American securities held abroad, most of which have been accumulated in the last few years, the belief in some important banking quarters here is that most of their holders would not dispose of them hurriedly in the event of general hostilities.

The Anchor Line has leased passenger department offices on the ground floor and second floor in 9 Rockefeller Plaza, newest of the Rockefeller Center skyscrapers. Present quarters of the passenger department are in Broad Street.

A process for taking gasoline from coal on a quantity basis was placed before the American Chemical Society here today by the United States Bureau of Mines and opened possibilities of a future race for markets between two of the nation's giant industries.

The National Labor Relations Board has denied the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's request for postponement P of the hearing of evidence on the board's charges against it of unfair labor practices, and will open the hearings tomorrow, as scheduled, at Franklin Boro, Pa. Officials here predict that the hearings may continue for several months.

Mr. and Mrs. Junius Spencer Morgan and their son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Skinner Clark, who are with them at Salutation, their home on West Island, Glen Cove, will give a dinner dance on Saturday in honor of Miss Marie T. McCook, a cousin of Mrs. Clark and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. McCook of Pasadena Calif.

Andy Lapola and Sam Blume of Florham Park, Madison, won the New Jersey State P. G. A. pro-amateur oneday event at the Orchard Hill Golf Club today with a best-ball 68, four under par. The victors were out in 33, three under standard, and returned in 35.

The Goodyear Tire and RubberCompany of Alabama denied today, through testimony of its general superintendent, A. C. Michaels, the National Labor Relations Board charges of discrimination against members of the United Rubber Workers of America in the Gadsen plant.
The MacGregor Arctic expedition's ship continues to drag her anchors every now and then toward the open sea because of strong gales blowing off the Greenland ice caps.
Japanese Army headquarters here announced today that Japanese troops successfully dislodged a force of Chinese troops west of Peiping following rather severe fighting there.

Chinese and Japanese official spokesmen address foreign correspondents daily, at the Metropole Hotel in the International Settlement and at Mayor 0. K. Yui's home in the French Concession, only a mile and a half away.

L-2, Sept. 7.-A fairly thorough search over the area included between Lat. 82 N. to 84.45 N. and Long. 148 W. to 145 W. has failed to locate Sigismund Levanevsky, the missing Soviet transpolar flier, and his five companions.

After a day of intense exchanges of views between 1taly on one hand and Great Britain Lnd Germany on the other, followng the bolt from the blue repre;ented by yesterday's Russian note ao Rome protesting the sinking of soviet merchantmen, Italian parcipation in the coming Mediteranean conference still hangs in the balancee this evening.

Vesta Hanover, owned by Harry Short of Columbus, Ohio, and Frisco Dale, owned by P. S. Hungerford of Shelbyville, Ind., divided honors today on the Indiana State Fair's Grand Circuit program with victories in the two Horseman Futurity races.
The number of, employes in the executive branch of the Federal Government decreased 15,243 during July and totaled 854,917 at the end of that month, the Civil Service Commission reported today.

William J. Ward, Brooklyn banker and proprietor of Ward's Baths, West Twelfth Street and the Boardwalk, Coney Island, died yesterday in his Summer home at the baths of a heart ailment after a threeweek illness.
Reflecting the unsettlement in other security markets, bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday suffered the broadest decline in many months in fairly active trading.

Great perturbation has been aroused among the Americans in China as a result of wide publication of a statement by President Roosevelt to the effect that all United States citizens have been warned to leave China and that this Eastern warfare amounts to an "awful mess."

Mrs. Amory Lawrence of Winter Park, Fla., entertained with a luncheon party at the Bar Harbor Club today for Mrs. Charles W. McAlpin, Miss Flora Benjamin, Mrs. Montgomery Wilcox, Mrs. Reginald White, Mrs. Charles Sprague-Smith and Mrs. George Spencer Eastwick.

Hilda Williams, 20, Plymouth waitress, and her escort, Michael Schlemmer, 47, of Chicago, were killed this afternoon when they fell from the top of a 240-foot chimney being built at the new Burroughs Adding Machine Company plant here.

Although women, under the law which lately became effective, may serve on juries in this State, they are barred from membership of special panels of talesmen for murder trials, it was revealed yesterday by Frederick H. Cahoon, Acting Commissioner of Jurors.

Steel ingot production maintained the previous week's level of activity last week when a nominal decline was seasonal and the adjusted index stands at 130.4. It was 130.3 for the previous week and 110.7 for the week ended Aug. 5, 1936.

The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Sept. 3: COMMANDER McCrea, J. L., naval station. Guam. to office Judge Advocate General, Navy Department, Washington. D. C. LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS

President Roosevelt today accepted the resignation of Edward F. McGrady as Assistant Secretary of Labor. Mr. McGrady will become director of labor relations for the Radio Corporation of America. His resignation has been pending for some time.

Two members of the Harvard Medical School staff engaged in a WPA-backed study of alcoholism in the Boston City Hospital reported today in The New England Journal of Medicine that alcoholism was increasing and had become "a great chronic emergency."

Mrs. Robert W. Collins, wife of Colonel Collins, commanding officer at Fort H. G. Wright here, was a luncheon hostess at the Hay Harbor Club this afternoon. Among her guests were Mrs. William H. Harris, Mrs. Stephen M. Melnick, Mrs. William C. Foote, Mrs. Robert L. Herndon, Mrs. Lester Walling,

S. W. Rogers, cashier of the First National Bank at near-by Scenery Hill, announced tonight the bank would close voluntarily tomorrow because of excessive State and Federal taxes and difficulty in placing the bank's funds in desirable investments.
The Chinese armies all yesterday and last night until dawn today wrested the offensive from the Japanese on all Shanghai fronts and attacked gallantly hour after hour.
Growing apprehension over the possible international complications in the Mediterranean and the Far East was reflected today in the action of the world's wheat markets.

The Chinese delegation, which said yesterday China's appeal to the League of Nations would be filed "very soon," was less sure today, saying that the step would not be taken for several days and possibly not before the League Assembly opens next Monday.
Kenneth F. Simpson, New York County Republican leader, made a surprise stump speech last night in support of Mayor La Guardia in the Republican primary,

1st Lt. Ambelten M. Ahrens. C.A.-Res.. P. O. Box 472. Ramsey. N. J., 2d Coast Artillery District, is ordered to active duty Sept. 6 at the Coast Artillery School, Fort Monroe, Va.. for the purpose of pursuing the anti-aircraft course for National Guard and Reserve officers. He will be relieved from active duty Dec. 1.

Protest against the prominence given to radical speakers and movements in the program of the forthcoming General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in Cincinnati is voiced by Bishop William T. Manning of the Diocese of New York in a letter sent to all the weekly publications of the Episcopal Church and made public here yesterday.

Mrs. Ida Pulis Lathrop, artist, died tonight after a brief illness. On Saturday she put the finishing touches on a group of paintings to be known as the Lathrop exhibit, which is to be shown this Fall at the Albany Institute of History and Art.

Although he carefully complies with the proprieties by saying that the Tokyo Government must deecide the issue, Major Gen. Kumakichi Harada, the new military attache at the Japanese Embassy here, personally thinks that at the conclusion of the Sino-Japanese hostilities it will be necessary that Japan demand the concession to her of Shanghai or at least some special area where Japanese subjects can live, trade and invest their money with real peace and genuine security.

The United States won a professional golfers' team match from Canada today by a margin of eight victories to four, capturing five of eight eighteenhole singles and losing only one of four best-ball foursomes over the St. Andrews Golf Club course.
William A. Bedworth, 54 years old, an interfor decorator with offices here, was killed by illuminating gas tonight in the kitchen of his home at 673 South Fifth Avenue.

Mr. and Mrs. Ambrose Whitney Rose of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Whitney Rose, to Donaid Frederick Hackstaff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William Hackstaff, also of Huntington.

Announcement has been made of the marriage in Fort Myers, Fla., on Monday of Miss Marion Smith, daughter of Mrs. C. W. Smith of Fort Myers and the late Mr. Smith, to John Thomas Nolan of Scarsdale, N. Y., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas Nolan of this city. Mr. and Mrs. Nolan will reside in Miami.

While the charter of the newly formed Greenbelt Consumer Services, Inc., organized to conduct all of the business enterprises at the Resettlement Administration's model suburban town at Greenbelt, Md., provides for "manufacturing," it was denied yesterday that this meant that the cooperative organization intended to go into manufacturing.
Two men charged with passing counterfeit money and one accused of possessing it were arraigned yesterday before Federal Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn.

Asserting that political managers in past campaigns had importuned Government workers to contribute to campaign funds and take part in campaigns, the National Federation of Federal Employes urged its officers today to "investigate the extent of the practice and suggest what remedial action can be taken."

Blair, owned by Stacy Smith's Newbrook Stable of Short Hills, N. J., and driven by Vic Fleming, captured the $4,000 Ten Eyck Stake, 2-year-old trot, which featured the second day of the Grand Circuit races at the New York State Fair today.

A miniature Tin Pan Alley developed out of the strike of eighty employes of the Maxwell House Coffee Company, Inc., plant at Second Avenue and Fortieth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday. Demanding increased wages and changes in working conditions the employes, members of the Coffee Workers Union, Local 21,129, A. F. of L., went on strike last Thursday.

Brig. Gen. De Witt Clinton Falls, retired, former commander of the 107th Infantry Regiment, National Guard of New York, died in a West End hotel today at the age of 72. The general, who had been ill in the United States, came to London five weeks ago on one of his regular visits, but suffered a relapse on his arrival.
Floor traders on the New York Stock Exchange remarked yesterday that prices appeared to be softer than at any time since the collapse in October, 1929.

I agree with Rudolph Pell Ellis's contention in his letter that labor, which means all of us, can consume only whit is produced; that if waste exists in production, the cost of this waste affects all of us.

A report on the experiments made at Duke University in extra-sensory perception has been made the Book-of-the-Month selection for October. J. B. Rhine, who conducted the experiments, is the author, and the title of the book is "New Frontiers of the Mind." Farrar Rinehart are the publishers.

The controversy between the skippers of the square-rigged ships, Seven Seas and Joseph Conrad, concerning the finish yesterday of their long race from Newport, R. I., became more involved today, while both held to their respective claims of victory.
Port of New York Authority purchased from George H. Billingham for $4,000 the one-story concrete garage at 277 Hackensack Plank Road, Weehawken, assessed at $350.
The five-story apartment house at 1,916 Grand Concourse, on the southeast corner of Echo Place, has been purchased by Isadore Geller, on behalf of a syndicate, from the Echo Place Realty Corporation.

A group of seventy-seven Chinese sailors will arrive here tomorrow to man three reconditioned Shipping Board freighters scheduled to sail later this month for China with supplies for Chinese soldiers engaged in the undeclared war with Japan.
An agricultural year for Guatemala has been established by law, running from April 1 to March 31. The change has been made to coincide 'with the crop s '-sons so as to make statistics more accurate.
The public hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission on the reorganization plan of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, which was adjourned last July, is to be resumed tomorrow.
Magistrate D. Joseph D'Andrea ruled yesterday in Coney Island Court that the games operated by concessionaires in Coney Island were games of skill and not games of chance or lotteries.

The practice of exchanging students between two countries was hailed last night as making toward peace by Dr. Frederick H. Sill, headmaster of Kent School, one of the founders of the exchange movement in this country.

" The legislative basis has been laid for a real start on slum clearance and low-rent housing in this country through 'the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill and other housing programs such as that of the FHA," in the opilnon of Dwight L. Hoopingarner, executive head of the American Construction Council.
Ouster of Mayor Wilson as a member of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company's board of trustees was sought today by four stockholders of the company.

The Federal Trade Commission announced stipulations whereby two New York concerns will cease alleged misleading advertising or branding. They are the Beauty Tea Corporation, 565 Fifth Avenue, and Charm Silk Undergarments, Inc., 112 Madison Avenue.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $26,751,951 after depreciation, Federal income taxes, reserves for possible excessprofits tax and other charges, but before depletion of metal mines.
Eight chess experts from seven different countries assembled here today for the formal opening of the international masters' tournament. Fourteen rounds will be played.

With Paul Shields's Six-Meter Rebel, the defender, half a mile from the finish and the Norwegian challenger Buri more than that distance astern of her, the four-hour time limit expired this evening, th making no contest of the first race for the Seawanhaka Cup. It meant that a hard struggle in light air had gone for naught.

Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, who has devoted more time to fishing than to golf this year, retained enough of his old form today to capture the qualifying medal in the nineteenth annual Arcola invitation tournament.

On the basis of figures already presented by various branches of the city government, the Citizens Budget Commission estimates that budget requests for 1938 may exceed by a margin of $81,000,000 the 1937 appropriations directly payable out of taxes. This would be an increase of $29 for each voter.

W. C. Fields-has signed an agreement with Paramount giving the studio permission to reproduce on the screen a number of routines which he made popular on the stage. The agreement, it was said, stipulates that Mr. Fields "shall not be credited as author."
Professor Edson Forbes Hitchings, naturalist and educator, former State Entomologist of Maine, died at his home here today after a long period of ill health at the age of 84.
At the strategic city of Paoshan, twelve miles north of Shanghai, Japanese engineers blasted a way through its forty-foot-high walls with bombs strapped to their backs.

BRYNHILD OR THE SHOW OF THINGS, by H. G. Wells. (Scribner, $2.50.) AN INTRODUCTION TO MEDIEVAL EUROPE, 300-1500, by James Westfall Thompson and Edgar Nathaniel Johnson. (Norton, $5.50.) An authoritative volume.

Burleigh Grimes, who succeeded Casey Stengel as manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers, last night was re-engaged to pilot the Brooklyn club for another year. Announcement of Grimes's retention, made by Secretary John Gorman after a meeting of the Brooklyn club's board of directors,
Surpassing the average of trade estimates and some expert opinion in the Deapartment of Agriculture, the 1937 cotton crop was forecast today at 16,098,000 bales by the Crop Reporting Board.

Many seizures of Korean fishing boats by Russia in Possiet Bay have occurred recently, and twentyeight boats with crews aggregating 277 men are now said to be in custody. The charge is undisclosed here, bbt presumably they are accused of illegal inshore fishing.

To Rear Admiral Purnell Frederick Harrington, 93 years of age and the oldest living graduate of the Naval Academy, went today the first of the certificates conferring the Bachelor of Science degree on graduates prior to 1931.

The second program of the series called "The Federal Music Project in Review" was given last night at the Theatre of Music. It presented a program of variety and interest. Rachmaninoff's "Fantasie for Two Pianos," played by Martha Thompson and Everett Roudebush, opened the evening.

Gross earnings of the Northern Pacific Railway last month were at about the same level as in August, 1936, Charles Donnelly, president, said yesterday. The movement of wheat on the Eastern division of the line has been the heaviest in seven years and a substantial movement of this commodity from the West may be expected, he continued.

Minister of Defense Sir Archdale Parkhill, presenting estimates on defense expenditures to the House of Representatives today, said it was necessary to increase defenses in the shortest practicable time.

William Phillips, United States Ambassador to Italy, and Mrs. Phillips; Mgr. Ralph Hayes, rector of North American College at Rome; Mrs. Augusto Rosso, wife of the Italian Ambassador to Russia; Townsend Martin, General Ulisse Longo,

Funeral services for Henry T. Fleck, former head of the Hunter College Music Department, who died here Monday, were held yesterday at his home, 587 Riverside Drive. The Rev. Ernest Brennecke, pastor of Trinity Lutheran Church, conducted the services.
Ted Broadribb officially severed his managerial connections today with Tommy Farr, British Empire heavyweight boxing champion, by signing over his contract rights to Thomas (Babe) Culnan of Newark.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 10,000 including 2,500 directs. The market was mostly steady to 10 cents lower than Tuesday's average;
War Talk again dominated the wheat market in the early trading today with prices on the Board of Trade here advancing around 2 cents a bushel and Winnipeg as much as 4 cents at the extreme,

Philip Schnee, an Alderman since 1936, resigned from the Socialist Common Council today with a declaration that he refused "to be a rubber stamp." Mayor Jasper McLevy was noncommittal on Mr. Schnee's statement beyond saying that the council would choose a successor at its next meeting two weeks hence.

A record turnout of eighty-six craft competed today in the opening races of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's fifth annual Fall series, with members of the host club scoring victories in the features. The program will last four days.

The Limited Editions Club announces that it will again award a gold medal to the new book that, in the opinion of a group of judges, has the greatest chance of some day being considered a "classic." The first such medal was given two years ago to Donald Culross Peattie for his book "An Almanac for Moderns."
Luncheon, Rotary Club. Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. "The Japanese Viewpoints on the Situation in China," Consul General Kaname Wakasugi.
Alexander Edward Kastl, retired civil engineer of Pelham Manor, N. Y., died yesterday in the New Rochelle Hospital. He was 76 years old.

Douglas Strowe, 16 years old, and Winifred DeVoe, 14, were killed tonight by an automobile driven by Detective Captain Joseph Linarducci Jr. of the Essex County Prosecutor's office as they were crossing Central Avenue, one of the main traffic arteries here.
The heavy selling of securities in the last two days is not alarming, Colonel Leonard Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company and nationally known statistician, said tonight.

William Alexander of Brooklyn, N. Y., a retired compositor of The New York Herald Tribune, died here yesterday after a brief illness. Mr. McLeod. who was visiting his niece, in Hamilton, Mrs. Frederick Harper, after a long illness, retired three years ago after serving The New York Herald and The New York Herald-Tribune for twenty years.
The tension between Nicaragua and Honduras over the issuance of a Nicaraguan postage stamp bearing a map that includes as "in dispute" territory claimed by Honduras has been somewhat lessened by an

Federal as well as State regulation of the investment banking and security business is here to stay, Wallace H. Fulton, director of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., said today at the opening of the fourth annual convention of the National Security Traders Association in the Hotel Traymore here.

Chez Rosette, a fashion shop, was formally opened in its new building at 10 East Fifty-sixth Street yesterday afternoon. Mrs. Pleasants Pennington, the proprietor, received guests from 5:30 to 7 o'clock.

Dr. William Charles Hands, retired physician, died yesterday at his Summer home at Washingtonville, N. Y. He was 80 years old and last July celebrated his fiftyfifth wedding anniversary. His mother and father had celebrated their- sixty-second wedding anniversary.

For the past week seven American anglers have been giving their tackle an overhauling such as it never had before, in preparation for the first international tuna tournament, which will get under way Saturday off Wedgeport, N. S.

A new type of sub-system in the universe in which one giant cluster containing hundreds of stars revolves about a more massive group, much as the moon travels around the earth, was disclosed today by James Cuffey of the Harvard Observatory.
Two men were killed instantly here at 8:12 o'clock this morning when their automobile was struck by a locomotive at the McCoy Road crossing of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad.

Dr. Franz Boas, Professor Emeritus of Anthropology at Columbia University, made public yesterday an appeal to General Francisco Franco, leader of the Spanish Insurgents, and to the military commander of Santander, urging them not to execute the 2,000 civilians capture at the fall of that Loyalist city.

T. O. M. Sopwth, who recently completed a second challenge for the America's Cup, sailed for England yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. Far from displaying disappointment at his second unsuccessful effort to capture the "old mug,"

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,692,550' barrels, compared to 3,745,500 in the preceding week, a drop of 52,950, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Alan J. Villiers, sailor and author, was injured about the head and-face tonight when an airplane he was piloting crashed at the Southend Airport.

Princess Natalie Paley of New York, daughter of the late Grand Duke Paul of Russia, was married to John Chapman Wilson today at the bridegroom's home here. The Rev. Joseph H. Twitchell of this place performed the ceremony in the presence of a small group of relatives and friends. There were no attendants.

The defending champion, Miss Quebec III, driven by Jack McInnis of Bergerville, Que., captured the first heat of the world championship race for 225-meter motor boats at the Canadian national exhibition tonight.
The novel "Gone With the Wind" was the basis of a suit in Federal court here today in which the author, Margaret Mitchell, seeks an accounting from Billy Rose, producer of the Casa Manana revue.

A proposal to discard the present ad valorem property tax system and substitute taxation only on income-producing real estate was made yesterday by August Heckscher, the philanthropist, who started last week a one-man campaign for tax reforms in newspaper advertisements.

A stockholders' committee of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to deny a request to postpone consideration of the Louisiana Arkansas Railway's application for authority to acquire the Rock Island, Arkansas Louisiana road.

The Transit Commission's $30,000,000 plan for removal of the Long Island Railroad's grade crossings along Atlantic Avenue, in Brooklyn, was unanimously approved yesterday by a special committee of the Board of -Estimate, headed by Controller Frank J. Taylor.
Miss Anna Hempstead Branch, poet and welfare worker, died today at the old Hempstead house, her family home here. She was 62 years old.

Robert Waterman Gardner of Hampton Bays, L. I, architect and archaeologist, died last night at the Southampton Hospital. Mr. Gardner, who was 70 years old, had suffered a cerebral hemorrhage on Aug. 10.

It was officially stated today that an agreement between the Yugoslav Government and the Orthodox Church would be announced soon.' Unofficial information indicates the Orthodox Church in its fight against the Vatican Concordat has won a complete victory over Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch.

The Los Angeles Police pistol unit won the national championship team match today when it finished with 1,332. out of a possible 1,500 for a new record. The previous mark of 1,330 was set by the United States Marines in 1920.

Morris Kamber of 251 West Eightyninth Street; a practicing lawyer in this city for thirty-five years, died suddenly yesterday in the Wayne Country Club, Tyler Hill, Pa., according to information received here. He was 62 years old.
A marriage today that received the Papal blessing from Rome was that of Miss Sally Eulalia Rowsey, daughter of Mrs. Frank A. Rowsey of this community and New York, and James Vincent McFadden,

In Hampshire House, the thirtyseven-story apartment hotel on Central Park South, which is rapidly nearing completion for occupancy in October, the main dining room, the cafe lounge, the. bar, the garden restaurant and the private entertaining rooms on the second floor,

Champagne was ready yesterday afternoon at the Consolidated Shipbuilding Corporation, Morris Heights, the Bronx, for the launching of Mrs. Doris 'Duke Cromwell's neW $50,000 yacht. But the silt bottom of the Harlem River spoiled what was to have been a perfect ceremony.

Miss Caroline Auguste Schreiber, daughter of George Gebner Schreiber of this place and the late Mrs. Schreiber, became the bride this afternoon of Milan Raynard Bump, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. M. R. Bump of Wilmington, Del. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Berthold von Schenk, pastor of St. John's Church, Hoboken, in the garden of the bride's home. A large reception there followed.

Dr. William Gaul, Yonkers surgeon, is in a serious condition in Moses-Ludington Hospital here as the. result of a brain concussion and possible skull fracture caused by a fall downstairs early today at a Lake George Summer cottage. He was found by other members of the family, who were unable to explain the cause of the accident.
Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d, former State Senator and former minority leader of the Board of Aldermen, announced yesterday his candidacy for membership on the new City Council. Mr. Baldwin,

A strike of 1,500 members of the Alteration Plumbers, Heaters, Steamfitters and Helpers Union, an independent organization, became effective yesterday morning. The employers' group in the industry, the Greater City Master Plumbers Association, denounced the walkout as a violation of the union's contract.

Mrs. Ernest R. Adee and her granddaughters, the Misses Barbara and Geraldine Bradley, have returned from Europe and will be at Almost Brook, Tuxedo Park, for the Autumn. Mrs. Charles Page Perin, who is visiting Mrs. W. Henry Brown in Newport, will return here on Monday.
