Charles Carroll Collmus Jr., president of the Virginia Real Estate Association, died here yesterday. Active in political, as well as civic and religious affairs, he was an unsuccessful candidate for the House of Delegates in the August primary.
SUPERIOR TOY PRODUCTS CORP., 42 Greene St.--Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $18,525 and assets of $19,935.

A preview of Macy's Little Shops was held yesterday afternoon from 5:30 until 7 o'clock, at which time an inspection also was made of the store's fashion floors. The visitors included more than 300 manufacturers of merchandise represented in the display, as well as stylists.

When the Department of Agriculture increased its estimate of the cotton crop 505,000 bales yesterday, the addition was so much more than generally had been expected that prices on the Cotton Exchange dropped $1 a bale.

Provisional President Felix Paiva of Paraguay was restored to office this morning after all-night fighting in the streets of Asuncion following a counter-revolt against the forces of a military triumvirate set up yesterday to recall former President Rafael Franco, who was ousted Aug. 13 and took refuge here. Revolt leaders were jailed.
Retired Engineer of Steamer Edward Vollborn, formerly a member of Engine 249, residing at 291 Rutland Road, Brooklyn, died Sept. 2.

Women tobacco strippers are entitled to a minimum wage of $1 under a ruling of the District Court, which held that this phase of tobacco processing was an industrial and not an agricultural occupation and therefore was not exempt under the law.

Harold H. Neff of the Securities and Exchange Commission told the mining industry today to discard any impression which it might have that the commission looked with disfavor on securities of new mining companies.

Dr. Rudolf Schoenheimer of Columbia University announced today results of research with heavy water, in which the living body was found to be a chemical laboratory where varied and complex transformations of matter are taking place incessantlv.

Mrs. Clarence F. Alcott and Mrs. Eltinge Warner are arranging for the annual flower show luncheon, to be held at the Maidstone Club on Wednesday in connection with the East Hampton Garden Club's flower show, which will take place in the afternoon and evening at Guild Hall.
The Deutsche Bank, which in 1929 merged with the Disconto Gesellschaft as the Deutsche Bank und Disconto Gesellschaft, has resumed its old name without any change in the financial structure.

Stockholders of the Standard Steel Spring Company approved yesterday at a meeting in Pittsburgh, Pa., proposals to reclassify the authorized stock into 12,500 preferred shares of $100 par value and 287,500 shares of common stock of no par value instead of $5 par.
Thirteen war-shocked Americans arrived here safely today' after a harrowing trip by land and sea from Mokanshan, in the interior of Chekiang Province, to escape the dangers of Sino-Japanese war.
Lafayette St, 226-30; 6-story loft, office and store building, 76.3x50.3xirreg; Andrew Freedman Home against Savoy Holding Co; due, $89,679; to plaintiff for $50,000.

George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, declared yesterday that the La Guardia administration had done more than any previous city administration to aid him in his efforts to integrate and motorize Queens' transit systems.

For the first two acts of "Bonnet Over the Windmill," presented at the New Theatre tonight, Dodie Smith provides adroit entertainment with her peculiar gifts of observation and her astonishing power to recrd and slightly exaggerate the superficial humors of mankind.

Announcement has been made here by Mrs. Huntington Clark of Roxbury, Conn, of the marriage of her daughter, Mrs. Eunice Clark, to John Knox Jessup of this city, which took place on Tuesday in San Francisco, where the bride had been visiting her godmother, Miss Anne W. Beaver.

While the stock market decline at the end of April this year had practically no effect on advertising plans, the current setback in securities is apparently being taken more seriously by large companies, according to comment in the agency field yesterday.

Recent manifestations of FinnoEstonian amity, especially the conclusion of a new trade pact, are arousing apprehension in other East Baltic State. Latvia particularly sees in it an indication that Estonia is drifting away from her long cooperation with her southern neighbors.

One hundred thousand Fascist leaders will be mobilized here Oct. 28, It Popolo di Roma announced today, to celebrate the fifteenth anniversary of Italian fascism. The newspapers likened the gathering to the Nazi party congress at Nuremberg, Germany.

Mayor La Guardia will break ground at 10:30 o'clock this morning for the $12,762,000 improvement of North Beach Airport on Bowery and Flushing Bays, Queens, which will give the city the most accessible and one of the most complete land and sea air terminals in the world.

Miss Priscilla M. de Forest, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Johnston de Forest of Wawapek Cottage on the Shore Road here, was honored tonight at a large supper dance given by her parents for about 300 members of the younger set of the North Shore colonies and their house guests.

AGRICOLA, HENRY C. (Sept. 3). Estate, $1,000. To Elizabeth Schmidtke, niece, 162 W. 124th St., residue. Alfred C. Ditolla, 7,320 14th Ave., Brooklyn, executor. ANGELL, FREDERICK W. (Aug. 24). Estate, less than $10,000. To Walter Angell, son, and Adelaide Angell, daughter, executrix, both of 241 E. 31st St., residue equally; four specific bequests.

Air Minister Hermann Goering has ordered an extensive search for the Lufthansa plane JU52, lost somewhere between Anshi and Kabul, Afghanistan. Piloted by Baron von Gablenz, a Lufthansa director, the plane crossed the Pamir Mountains last month. It left Anshi a few days ago for the return flight to Kabul via Wakhan Pass.

Establishing a precedent for retail establishments with annual sales of $8,000,000 or less, the William F. Gable Company, department store of Altoona, Pa., will require complete merchandise data from its supply sources,

The five-story old-law tenement at 348 East Forty-sixth Street, adjoining First Avenue, has been sold by the Fifth Avenue Bank, as trustee, to the G. G. Service Corporation. The house, which is on a plot 27.6 by 80 feet, will be rehabilitated to meet the requirements of the Multiple Dwelling Law.

A resolution calling for the setting up of a Quaker center in Shanghai to "spiritually inspire" the Chinese was adopted today at the closing session of the Friends' World Conference at Swarthmore College.

Reports that extremists were to be removed from the payroll of the United Automobile Workers of America gained credence today as Homer Martin, president, asserted that Communists were entitled to membership "only in the rank and file and not as U. A. W. A. organizers."

At an adjourned annual meeting held yesterday in Corinth, N. Y., stockholders of the International Paper Company authorized a $37,500,000 reduction in capital of the company by writing down each of the 1,000,000 outstanding common shares from $52.50 to $15 a share.

George Kenyon, secretary of the C. Kenyon Co., manufacturers of tires and rubber goods, and brother of Miss Helen Kenyon, chairman of the board of trustees of Vassar College, died Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital, the day before his fiftyfifth birthday.

Italy's unexpected refusal to attend the Nyon "piracy" conference strengthens the belief in League of Nations circles that the political center will remain in Geneva and that the Nyon meeting will be confined to technical problems.
Vandals who broke into St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here during the night caused more than $1,500 in damage and property loss to the altar, according to the Rev. Sylvester Neri, pastor.
Mrs. Ella Truesdell, widow of James Henry Truesdell, former village trustee and business man of Ossining, died yesterday at the home here of her daughter, Mrs. Adolph Heuss.

A Spanish Government fleet of two cruisers and five trawlers steamed in battle array in the Western Mediterranean today to engage an Insurgent warship and try to keep the sea lanes clear for supply ships bound for the Government coast.

William A. Brady, theatrical producer, instituted suit yesterday in Supreme Court to restrain radio station WOR and the Mutual Broadcasting System from presenting a series of radio features under the title "Way Down East" this Autumn.

A recommendation that Congress carry forward the governmental reorganization program proposed in the recent session, particularly as it affects the functions of the Treasury Department, was made tonight by Wayne C. Taylor, Fiscal Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, in a radio address in the Cabinet Series, sponsored by the Columbia Broadcasting Company.

5th Ave. 664; to 5-story tenement; Peikin Studios. Inc, 565 5th Ave, owner; B. Robert Swartburg, architect; cost, $7,500. Bank St, 82; to 4-story hotel and restaurant; Valentin Aguirre, premises, owner; F. Savignano, architect; cost, $3,000.

An investor represented by Charles Kellman, attorney, bought from David S. Meister the six-story apartment house on a plot 112 by 110 feet at 437 Morris Park Avenue, northwest corner of Tremont Avenue, the Bronx.

Production of steel ingots in the United States last month amounted to 4,861,789 gross tons, the second highest level for the month on record, and compared with 4,939,086 tons produced in August, 1929, and to 4,184,287 tons in August, 1936.

Jerome Ave (11-3195), s w cor of 182d St, 100x50; Jacob Horne to Aberdeen Garage, Inc, 29-31 St. Clair Pl. Rosedale Ave (15-3873), w s, 317 ft s of 174th St, 33x99; Samuel W. Phillips, referee, to John C. Aisenbrey, 33 Parkview Pl, Baldwin N. Y.

A total of 29,264,848 working days was lost by strikes in 1936 in twenty-one countries for which figures were available, according to the current edition of the International Labor Office year book. Labor disputes in those countries in that year totaled 6,684 and involved 24,233,430 workers.

British observers at Hong Kong, British crown colony on the South China coast, reported growing fear there today that the next phase of the Japanese campaign in South China might be seizure of Hainan Island, the largest island under Chinese sovereignty, situated between Hong Kong and Britain's naval base at Singapore.

American shipping, was warned today by the Navy Department of dangerous conditions in the Mediterranean at the same time that Secretary of State Cordell Hull indicated concern over the attacks by unidentified craft on merchant ships in that area.
Georgia chain gang wardens reinstated "shoot to kill" orders for fugitives today and asked restoration of the lash to discipline the unruly among their 7,500 prisoners.

R. H. Marwin Co., Inc., as principals, have sold to John Stahl Sons, Ino., the two-story warehouse, on a plot 50 by 100, at 6 North Street, Mount Vernon, Westchester; the two six-family apartment houses at 861-3 Fortieth Street, Brooklyn,

Sir Hubert Wilkins returned in his Soviet-owned seaplane URSS L-2 to his base at Aklavik, Canada. yesterday afternoon after searching 5,500 miles between Lat. 82 N. and Lat. 84:45 degrees N. and between Long. 139 degrees W, and Long. 150 degrees W. for Sigismund Levanevsky, the missing Russian aviator, and his five companions, according to messages received here by the Explorers Club.

With the report of nineteen new cases of infantile paralysis in Chicago alone in the last twenty-four hours, officials of the State Department of Health at Springfield predicted that the epidemic in the State would reach an all-time high record of about 1,200 cases.

Answering Jones W. Mersereau's query concerning the source of my assessment figures, may I refer him to Page 4 of a mimeographed report issued by William Stanley Miller, president of the Department of Taxes and Assessments, Feb. 7, 1937, which lists the following summary:

The William L. Crow Construction Company announces that it has received a contract for the construction of a new church and rectory for St. Andrews Roman Catholic Church on the site of the present edifice, on the corner of Duane Street and Cardinal Place.

Very firmly, John Hay Whitney decided the other day that he was through financing Broadway productions. The news this morning is that Mr. Whitney was not so firm about it as he might have thought. He has acquired the dramatic rights to "On Borrowed Time," the novel by Lawrence Edward Watkin, published last Tuesday.

Dramatic incidents marked the first day of the hearing on the appeal of thirty-five men sentenced as leaders of the November, 1935, Leftist uprising. Machine guns were placed at vantage points, and heavy police contingents guarded the Supreme Military Tribunal.

Sit-down strikes have reached Monaco. Workers occupied the gas plant tonight, and house painters and street cleaners joined in the strike. Moreover, unless the demands are granted, masons, plumbers, electricians, cooks and others will strike in sympathy.

Increased export trade in certain mineral and chemical products was noted in July by the Department of Commerce, which also reported that imports of some commodities, while still large, were decreasing.

The National Maritime Union, which warned the National Labor Relations Board on Tuesday that it would call a strike on Atlantic and Gulf shipping unless action were speeded up to bring about a general union election of the unlicensed personnel,

Stocks closed steadier after dipping to lowest level of movement; turnover, 2,257,520 shares. United States Goverment bonds steady and mixed; Japanese, German and corporate bonds lower; transactions, $9,880,775.

President Roosevelt took a group of relatives and neighbors for a cruise on the Hudson today. In the party on the yacht Potomac were the President's son and secretary, James Roosevelt; Captain Paul Bastedo, his naval aide, and twenty others, almost all of them relatives.

The first of the debutante parties of Long Island's "little season" was a dinner dance given tonight at the Piping Rock Club by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Robins Jr., who are at their cottage in Cold Spring Harbor for the season, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Mary Van Rensselaer Robins.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Pettigrew, daughter of Mrs. P. Shelton Pettigrew of 277 Park Avenue and of Todd Maro Pettigrew of Toronto, to William Cleveland James, son of Mrs. Henry Beecher James of Jackson Heights, Queens, and the late Mr. James, took place here yesterday noon at the home of her mother. The Rev. Heber C. Benjamin of Flushing performed the ceremony.
Magistrate Charles Solomon criticized yesterday Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan's attack on magistrates as "thoroughly unwarranted" and "reprehensible."

A. G. Spalding Bros. reported yesterday for the quarter ended on July 31 a profit of $424,121 after depreciation, amortization, interest, taxes and other charges. No mention was made of any provision for Federal taxes.

Governor Hoffman's attention was divided today between his street encounter here last night with Lewis Angelo of Trenton, a former State boxing inspector, and consideration of the unemployment relief situation.

Although school does not open officially for the 1,225,000 public school children of this city until Monday, the vacation season will come to an end for 37,535 teachers tomorrow morning, when they report to work.

Treasury officials said today they were studying various proposals designed to send the tax collector calling on tax-exempt security owners and Government employes. Holders of most Federal and State securities pay no tax on the interest they receive.
An eight-run rally in the ninth inning gave Syracuse a 15-to-9 victory over the champion Bears today in one of the daffiest games of the season.

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, urged yesterday the use of the East River for commercial purposes. In a letter to the Interstate Sanitation Commission meeting in Queens Borough Hall, Long Island City, he aligned himself with the manufacturers in opposition to engineers from the Board of Estimate and Queens.

The Ohio Edison Company, Akron, Ohio, a subsidiary of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation of Delaware, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933, a registration statement covering $8,500,000 of first mortgage bonds, 4 per cent series of 1937, due in 1967.

Miss Margaret Drennan, 20 years old, a secretarial school student living on Sonora Avenue in Iselin, N. J., was held without bail for the grand jury here today on a charge of murder. She is alleged to have signed a statement confessing that she shot and killed Paul Reeves, 25,

The crews of two radio patrol cars assigned to the Broadwaymidtown area were suspended from duty yesterday morning and ordered to stand departmental trial for leaving their automobiles unguarded during the early morning hours of Sept. 2.

The sporting withdrawal of her protest by Seven Seas ended an awkward impasse at the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club this morning and the Joseph Conrad was announced as the winner of the long race from Newport, R. I., between the two square-riggers.

Carrying banners with legends sympathetic toward the defendant, pickets marched back and forth in front of the Huntington Town Hall today as Suffolk County Supervisor Arthur J. Kreutzer of Huntington appeared for examination on the charge of attempting to obtain a contract to supply materials for the $600,000 County Home and Infirmary at Yaphank.

Engagement of $8,629,000 gold abroad for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of this amount, $5,800,000 was taken in Japan and $2,829,000 in England, including $294,000 yesterday and $2,535,000 on some previous date.

Small loan companies that continue many of the evils of "loan shark days," including overzealous solicitation and collection methods, were scored yesterday by W. Bruce Cobb, former magistrate and now attorney-in-chief of the Legal Aid Society.

The number of new cases of infantile paralysis recorded in New York City last week dropped below the figure for the preceding week, and there were no deaths from the disease during the week, Health Commissionr John L. Rice reported yesterday.

6th St, 407 E. 21.5x90.10; Felix A. Muldoon, referee, to Amelia E. Callahan, 74-18 Park Lane, South Woodhaven, L. I.: foreclosure ($1.50). 127th St, 224 E, 25x99.11; Esterken Estates, Inc, Kenneth L. Bright, president, to Elvus Realty Corp. 38 W 33d St (50c).
Kenneth F. Simpson, Republican leader, approved all of the Labor party's platform except the plank on municipal ownership of utilities. [Page 1.]

Miss Rosa Anne Grosvenor has selected next Tuesday afternoon for the annual bridge and entertainment which she gives at Wyndham, her home, for the benefit of the Speyer League and its work among animals in New York.

Amid threats of bloodshed and increasing evidence of shipping paralysis, the A. F. of L. teamsters union completed its blockade of San Francisco Bay ports today in its "finish fight" against C. I. O. longshoremen over the right to organize warehouse workers.

A bullet fired yesterday afternoon by a detective to warn a fleeing prisoner bounced from the sidewalk in front of 305 West 116th Street and struck and slightly injured Mrs. Marie Ciroma, 58 years old, and her daughter Matilda, 6, both of 307 West 116th Street.
The executive council of the West Virginia State Federation of Labor decided tonight to apply for a C. I. 0. charter. John B. Easton, president, left for Washington to file the application.
The stock markets were highly nervous today as a result of the international situation and prices continued to drift downward on a small volume of business. Gilt-edge issues were weak.

One whirlwind attack in the middle of the second half and one fierce goal-line defense in the closing minutes combined to give the New York Giants a spectacular 14-7 victory over the Eastern All-Stars at the Polo Grounds last night in a thrill-packed game that left a crowd of 38,000 limp at the finish.

A greatly improved loan situation in 1937, compared with 1934, for the national banks of the country was pictured today by J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, in an address to the Washington Chapter of the American Institute of Banking.

Baltimore evened its series with the Jersey City Giants today by taking the second game of the set, 11 to 3. The Orioles belted Rollie Stiles, starting Jersey City pitcher, for eight hits and five runs in the first four innings.

Officials of San Francisco announced yesterday the sale to R. H. Moulton Co. and Whealen Co. of $3,500,000 of tax-anticipation notes at a 1-per-cent interest rate plus a premium of $210. The notes are dated Sept. 9 and will be due on Sent. 21.

The General Dyestuffs Corporation of New York City has taken a fifteen-year lease on the five-story building at 117-23 South Second Street, known as the Neumann Building, and the six-story structure to the rear, known as 127-31 Gatzmer Street, in Philadelphia.

Boston at New York-McKain vs. Gomez. Washington at Philadelphia (2)Lanahan and Linke vs. Kelley and Williams. Cleveland at Detroit-Galehouse vs. Lawson. Chicago at St. Louis-Rigney vs. Trotter or Hildebrand.

Now the days are growing shorter; now the actors are returning hopefully from theatres by the sea and in the mountains; now the night clubs grow livelier and taxicabs in the amusement district drive the traffic policemen to distraction; soon straw hats will be falling like the leaves of the forest and vests will reappear on manly bosoms;

Miss Mary Rita Halpin, daughter of Mrs. Leo Halpin of this place and the late Dr. Halpin, was married here this morning in the Church of Our Holy Redeemer to Neil Justin McCarthy of Chicago, son of Joseph McCarthy of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. McCarthy. The ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's cousin, the Rev. Daniel C. Fives, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

Encke's comet, a periodic visitor to these parts, tonight was speeding earthward again, but there was little likelihood of its being widely viewed. It is 'one of the oldest of the heavenly phenomena and has been making earthly visits almost triennially since its discovery in 1786.

Never in the history of the oil industry in Texas has there been such a scramble by operators for leases of the oil and gas rights to State public lands as was shown in the receipt by the State Land Department yesterday and today of approximately 650 sealed bids on 100,000 acres of submerged lands lying within the three-mile limit of the Gulf Coast.

Tuesday's violent decline on the Stock Exchange, following the news of the Mediterranean submarines and Russia's note to Italy, had the effect on the public imagination which sharp movements of the stock market usually have.

Professor James Grafton Rogera of Yale University and Mrs. Rogers today announced the engagement of their daughter, Lorna Rogers, to Stephen H. Hart, son of Mrs. Richard H. Hart of Denver. The wedding will take place early next year.

The rush for apartments that was expected to follow the week-end holiday got into full swing yesterday when brokers and renting agents reported new leases over a wide area. The renting activity was brisk in East and West Side houses and extended to the Bronx, Brooklyn and the suburbs.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe yesterday appointed Raymond C. Kramer a trustee in the reorganization proceedings of the Postal Telegraph Company. Mr. Kramer will work with the trustees previously appointed by the court, former Governor Alfred E. Smith and General George S. Gibbs.
State police announced today that they had tentatively identified the bodies of two women who met death with a man when their car plunged into the Champlain Canal near Fort Edward Monday night.

If football had the Rugby rule of no substitutions, Mr. Lou Little reckons that he might be the coach of a Rose Bowl team again. His Columbia University squad includes as fine a first eleven as could be found anywhere in the East, but there are no reserves to give it support and stability.
The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Aug. 31 shows an increase in the ratio of gold reserve to notes in circulation from 128.98 per cent on Aug. 15 to 130.60 per cent.

The Tigers lost ground in their fight to retain second place in the American League when they split a doubleheader with the Indians today while the Sox were defeating the Browns. Johnny Allen, Indian right-hander, won his tenth straight game of the season when he beat Detroit, 6 to 1, in the opener.
The Frigidaire Division of the General Motors Corporation today went into production with a line of newly developed electric ranges to be marketed nationally along with its electric refrigerators.

IT is rumored that three or four major league managers will soon be asked to turn in their uniforms and vacate the premises. A fellow named Ruth once said that he would be interested in that kind of work, but with the chance of business in that line opening up, he's off somewhere in the hinterlands playing golf.

The Bradford (Pa.) Electric Company was sold recently to Keystone Utilities, Inc., Alter Thomas of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation announced here today. The sale was described as "a further step in the simplification of the corporate structure of the Niagara Hudson system."

A panoramic view of the fruitful Kiangsu plain, its normally peaceful and industrious populace gripped in the harsh exigencies of wartime, was obtained by this correspondent today in a motor trip from Shanghai to Nanking.
The Marine Midland Trust Company of New York sold to an investor the three-story dwelling at 750 St. Marks Avenue, between Nostrand and New York Avenues, Brooklyn, through the Bulkley Horton Company.

At Corlears Park in Manhattan tonight the Federal Caravan Theatre will stage D. V. Rubin's play, "Riddle Me This." Other free WPA presentations in the metropolitan district will be: Brooklyn, "Pirates of Penzance," at Kelly Field; the Bronx, ten vaudeville acts,

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary sailed yesterday with 1,100 passengers, who included twenty-six American students going abroad for a year's study in England and Germany, and fiftynine English public school boys who had been touring Canada since Aug. 21.

The pick of this city's amateur hill-billy music exponents competed last night in a contest that sent the thin, wailing melody which is attributed by city dwellers to mountaineers, floating across the Mall in Central Park.

Al Roth, durable lightweight from the Bronx, will fight Paul Junior of Lewiston, Me., in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Junior was named yesterday as a substitute for Billy teauhuld, who suffered at injury to his right hand while training and was forced to withdraw from the bout.

More than 500 persons, many of them prominent in music and the theatre, yesterday afternoon attended funeral services for Henry Hadley, American composer and conductor, which were held at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Thirtyseventh Street and Fifth Avenue. Dr. Hadley, who was 66 years old, died at his home, 15 West Sixtyseventh Street, on Monday.

The Nazi congress this year nas been decreed "The Congress of Labor." Today was the day of the Arbeitdienst when the lads of the National Labor Service, who are reclaiming Germany's waste land, draining her marshes, building her new motor roads -and making the Reich the most highly cultivated country in the world, paraded before Chancellor Adolf Hitler and the German: people who are gathered here.

Bubbling with almost girlish joy, Mrs. Frances Hatman Ryan, 84year-old San Franciscan, arrived here on Monday with three other pioneer California settlers on an airliner, opening a New York-San Francisco route.

Mrs. Nettie C. Josephi, widow of Emanuel A. Josephi, died yesterday at her home, 41 West Eightysixth Street, in her seventy-fifth year. Born in Milroy, Ind., she spent her early years in Shelbyville, Tenn,, and was married in Denver, Colo.

Twenty battalions of Government militia fleeing along the Bay of Biscay coast today made a stand about twelve miles west of this small Asturian port, which is fifty miles west of Santander and half way between that city and Gijon.

Residents of the Saugatuck Valley who have been opposing efforts of the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company to condemn land for a three-mile reservoir suffered a setback today when Judge P. B. O'Sullivan in Superior Court overruled a demurrer which had attacked the water company's proeedings as illegal.

Reports reaching Paris tonight said the yacht 'Sister Anne, owned by the Hon. Mrs. Reginald Fellowes, had been fired upon by a Greek warship when the yacht entered a militarized zone off the Island of Aegina, twenty miles south of Athens.
Frederic H. Cahoon snapped down the small, hinged door of a revolving drum at headquarters of the Jury Commission in the Hall of Records yesterday, and gave it a vigorous spin.

American labor standards figured largely in discussions on British working conditions as the annual convention of the Trades Union Congress today adopted a series of resolutions aimed at bettering the lot of British workers.
Arthur Vernon Lucas. a real estate broker, died today at his home, 109 Archer Avenue, at the age of 65. He was a member of the West chester Country Club and a founder of the Siwanoy Country Club.

Operators of the legitimate Broadway theatres have been advised that, by a Treasury Department ruling effective Oct. 1. theatre Tickets must include the seat or box numbers on that part of the ticket which is collected by the management.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith will come actively to the support of Senator Royal S. Copeland in the Senator's campaign to win the Republican and Democratic mayoralty nominations, it was announced lastnight at Copeland headquarters.

Turpentine firm, 30 1/2c; sales, 181 barrels; receipts, 1,113 barrels; shipments, 35 barrels; stock, 36,439 barrels. Resin firm: sales, 448; receipts, 2,648; shipments, 295; stock, 56,405. Quote: B, D, E. $7.50; F to K, $7.82 1/2; M, $7.95; N, $8.05; WG, $8.25; WW, X, $8.80.

State and local police of Pompton Lakes and Oakland were searching the woods between the two communities tonight for a man who criminally assaulted a 17-yearold school girl about 5:30 this afternoon. The girl, whose name was withheld, is under a physician's care.

Corporation Counsel Paul Windels will receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws at the fourth annual Summer commencement of Brooklyn Law School of St. Lawrence University tonight in the Law School auditorium, 375 Pearl Street, Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by Dean William Payson Richardson.

Dr. John William Porter, pastor of the Immanuel Baptist Church here for thirteen years, died late tonight after an attack physicians attributed to a heart ailment. He was 74 years old. Noted as an evangelist and editor, Dr. Porter came here twenty-seven years ago.

The Administrator of New Guinea, Brig. Gen. W. Ramsay McNicoll, reports a violent volcanic eruption in the vicinity of Mount Bagana, in the Crown Prince Range, on Bougainville Island, the largest of the Solomons, within the mandated territory of New Guinea, 250 miles southeast of Rabaul.

The Tientsin American Chamber of Commerce decided today to send a protest to the State Department on President Roosevelt's alleged statement that Americans remaining in China do so at their own risk because they have been warned to leave.

Bids for 372,500 yards of assorted textils for the Works Progress Administration were asked today by the Procurement Division of the Treasury Department. The bids are to be opened Sept. 15 for delivery Sept. 30. The list follows:
Alexander Gaston, father of Milton Gaston, former Yankee pitcher, and of -Alex Gaston, former Giants' catcher, died at his home here today after a lingering illness.
John T. Flynn, member of the Board of Higher Education, and Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, President of City College, renewed yesterday an exchange of sharp criticisms.

The State Department announced today that Winthrop R. Scott, United States Consul at Kobe, reported that Americans arriving at Kobe yesterday from Shanghai on the Shanghai Maru included Michael Khoury, 540 Forty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, N. Y.;

In the middle of a hearing yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter on an action to obtain the reinstatement of 456 election inspectors ousted in the dispute between Jeremiah T. Mahoney and Senator Royal S. Copeland factions in Tammany, Corporation Counsel Paul Windels withdrew as counsel to the Board of Elections.
Mayor La Guardia, giving his address as City Hall, reported yesterday to the Board of Elections that he had received no contributions during the primary campaign and had made no expenditures.
Japan's extraordinary Parliament session ended today after the House of Peers, without a dissenting vote, enacted a supplementary war budget of $600,000,000.

Colonel Bill Terry's Giants continued on their pennant-winning way at Ebbets Field yesterday by hanging up their fourth straight victory, 9-7, but the Dodgers gave them a touch-of the Autumn attack of jitters.

The oldest living bartender in America and the oldest extant bungstarter, described by the dictionary as a mallet or stave used in broaching casks, were in demand yester,day for a four-day exhibition of bar and tavern equipment, which will open on Dec. 7.

Services marking the third anniversary of the Morro Castle disaster were held on the Convention Hall pier here at 2 o'clock this afternoon. Following prayers by clergymen representing the Protestant, Catholic and Jewish faiths,

Commercial rentals reported yesterday by brokers principally inevolved full floor units for manufacturing purposes. Several leases with firms and individuals engaged in artistic lines also were among the contracts announced.

Railroad issues were forced to bear the full force of the selling in the bond market yesterday, and in the heaviest trading volume in nearly four months on the New York Stock Exchange prices of the carriers broke sharply, many registering new low marks for the year.
Chicago's revived Cubs beat the Cardinals toiday for the twelfth time this season, breezing to a 4-to-O triumph on Southpaw Larry French's five-hit pitching and Catcher Gabby Hartnett's hitting.

The Japanese Minister has addressed an inquiry to the Foreign Office concerning contracts for Czechoslovak deliveries to China that Dr. H. H. Kung, Chinese Foreign Minister, made during his recent visit here. Foreign reports that Japan had protested these contracts were declared incorrect.

Little Pat, owned by the Biery Farms of Butler, Pa., and driven by Will Caton, breezed to victory in the first running of the $3,800 Pacing Derby, covering the mile and a half, plus handicap, in 3:12.
Behind locked doors, veterans of the Grand Army of the Republic studied today the question of whether they should join with Confederate soldiers in a reunion at Gettysburg next year.

Thomas E. Dewey, special vice prosecutor and Republican designee for District Attorney, made his first campaign appearance last night at a smoker of the New York Young Republican Club at the Harvard Club.
In a light northerly breeze today on Long Island Sound, Paul V. Shields's six-meter defender Rebel won the first race for the Seawanhaka Inter[national Challenge Cup.

The renewed insistence at the annual National Socialist Congress at Nuremberg on the duty of work and of the tightened belt, with no promise of immediate economic betterment, and the reemergence of reports of the retirement of Dr. Schacht as Acting Economic Minister and as Reichsbank president, lend added force to the full-length portrait that Otto D. Tolischus, our Berlin correspondent, has drawn in a series of articles of Germany's authoritarian economy.

A funeral service for Edwin C. Scott, for forty years an employee in the composing room of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will be held at 2:30 P. M. today at his home, 543A Halsey Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Scott died on Saturday in Halifax, Nova Scotia, at the age of 77.

The activities of Mayor Daniel J. Shields and the Johnstown Citizens Committee in furthering a "back-to-work" movement during the Bethlehem Steel strike in June will be intensively examined by lawyers for the National Labor Relations Board in the hearing which began today, it was indicated.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that the administration of relief to the needy was a proper function of modern government. which must and would be kept free from politics. He spoke at the opening of offices of the Staten Island Unified Welfare Agency at 211 Bay Street, Tompkinsville.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Cosse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cosse of Mount Vernon, N. Y., to Walter Edward Richards, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Frederick Richards of St. Louis, took place yesterday noon in the rectory of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The ceremony was performed by the rector, Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle.
After a fortnight on the road the Yankees came home yesterday to give New York fans some of those won-in-the-ninth thrills that have shot the club so far ahead in the American League race.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis B. Crowninshield of Boston arrived on their schooner yacht Cleopatra's Barge today with Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Butler and their daughter, Miss Anna G. Butler, as their guests. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Burrall Pike of Chicago are entertaining in their honor with dinner tomorrow evening at Greenway Court.

Rosemary Gavagan, 2-year-old daughter of Representative and Mrs. Joseph A. Gavagan of New York, died tonight of burns received this afternoon at the family's Summer home at Ludlow, twenty-five miles south of here.

The Arab congress opened tonight at Bludan, Summer resort twenty miles from Damascus. Although no Arab country sent official representatives, about 400 persons were present from Lebanon, Palestine, Iraq, Trans-Jordan, Hedjaz, Syria and Egypt. In a large hall elaborately decorated with different Arab flags, the congress was inaugurated "in the name of God and Arabism."

Alfred W. Knoeppel, mechanical engineer, vice president and a director of the John Simmons Company, large Long Island City plumbing and steamfitting supply house, and a World War veteran, died yesterday at Windsor Tower, Tudor City, Manhattan, after a long illness. Mr. Knoeppel, a bachelor, was 50 years old.

Milburn Shoffner, 31-year-old southpaw from the Bees' New York-Penn League farm at Scranton, made his National League debut by holding the Phillies to a three-hit 1-0 shut-out in the second game of today's double-header.

The up-and-down Pirates supplanted the Cardinals in the National League third position by wresting both ends of a double bill from Cincinnati today. Pittsburgh took the ten-inning opener 7 to 6, then went on with the four-hit pitching of Jim Tobin, Coast League graduate, to sweep the second game, 8 to 2.

Trading was fair to good. Fresh pork prices were uneven; some cuts stronger and others lower. Cow and bull were steady to strong. Other classes were strong to higher. The first kosher markets, since last Friday, indicated lamb prices to be weak to $1.00 under Friday's opening market; beef and veal steady to higher as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

A force of 4,000 Japanese troops was reported today to have been wiped out by a deadly Chinese ambush in the rocky hills west of here. The Japanese line was said to have been thrust back five miles by the sudden onslaught.

Conflicting reports on Chinese market conditions were put before export credit men yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania for the first of the Fall series of monthly roundtable meetings sponsored by the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, returned to Washington today for a final series of meetings before giving up Government service to become dean of the Harvard Law School.

Mrs. Walter Olcott Smith of Pasadena, Calif., who has been passing the Summer at the Mountain View, Whitefield, with her family, gave a luncheon today at Pecketts. Her guests, besides her mother, Mrs. William Brownback,
Three Philadelphia area players and one from California advanced today to the semi-finals of the national girls' tennis championships at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

The conference of Foreign Ministers of Sweden, Denmark, Norway and Finland here adjourned today after covering "the general international position" and deciding that "the work initiated by the previous conference is developing in a satisfactory manner and should be continued."
Japanese war planes and warships bombed and shelled this South China port for two hours today, gravely endangering American lives. The United States warship Asheville was caught in the bombardment.

Philippine women were enfranchised today when the National Assembly in a special session approved a new election law. To circumvent President Manuel Quezon's threat to veto the bill if women were not required to pay a poll tax, the Assembly provided that men and women might be identified at polling booths by birth or baptismal certificates or a sworn statement of identity.

The Cabinet committed Britain today to an international effort-first of its kind since the sanctions episode-to stamp out submarine "piracy" in the Mediterranean. Objections from Italy and Germany were virtually brushed aside in advance.

Sales of Bonwit, Teller Co. in August were 15.9 per cent above that month last year, and sales thus far this year are running 19 per cent ahead of 1936, it was reported yesterday. Stocks of merchandise on hand were 10 per cent ahead of last year at the end of August.

Officials of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation have decided to register the $715,000,000 public utility concern with the Securities and Exchange Commission in compliance with the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, it was learned yesterday.

Reports from Europe indicate that Italy and Germany are unwilling to meet on Swiss territory and in close proximity to the headquarters of the League of Nations for the purpose of considering the present situation in the Mediterranean.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 4: Bly, Jr. Lt. R. E., Pensacola, Fla., to the San Francisco. Kuhl, Jr. Lt. J. H., VCS-5, the Chicago, to the San Francisco.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor have arrived at Borsodivanka Castle as guests of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Bedaux of New York. A hunting party was arranged for this afternoon.

A champion was beaten at Forest Hills yesterday and Baron Gottfried von Cramm of Germany and Robert L. Riggs of Los Angeles stood with their backs to the wall in a day of stirring battle that riveted most of the gallery of 8,000 spectators to their seats until darkness fell upon the stadium of the West Side Tennis Club.

Pierre Quesnay, French economist and general director of the Bank for International Settlements [World Bank] at Basle since its organization, was drowned today while swimming in a pond near Saint Leomar in the Department of Vienne.

Models of Independence Hall were sent today to Governors of the twelve other original States and to President Roosevelt and Vice President Garner. The messengers carrying the plaster models also extended invitations to attend the observance at the hall in Philadelphia of Constitution Day, on Sept. 17.
Isidor Lubimoff, who had been the butt of constant criticism for failure to overcome the lag in light industry, was removed today from the post of Commissar of Light Industry.

Efforts by counsel for respondent to show that market operations in Austin Silver Mining Company shares were conducted according to Instructions given by a Securities and Exchange Commission official featured the commission's hearing yesterday. John F. Davidson,

Harry Godoff, vice president and chairman of the building committee of Israel Zion Hospital, Tenth Avenue -and Forty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, and retired president of the Godoff Dress Company, died in Atlantic City on Tuesday.

Three groups of sculpture were revealed to the public yesterday when scaffolding was removed from around the entrances of 9 Rockefeller Plaza. The works, cut into the limestone of the building, are by the American sculptors Carl Paul Jennewein, Attilio Piccirilli and Lee Lawrie.

In the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association held over the Hempstead course today the contestants deviated from routine to play a match against women's par in which seven-eighths of the individual handicaps were allowed.
The Harbor Hill Steeplechase, the only event of its kind in this country open exclusively to 3-year-olds and which was inaugurated at Belmont Park in 1905, will be held no more.

Drygoods markets, already quieted by failure of distributors to achieve the volume they had anticipated in their purchases earlier in the year, were brought to a standstill yesterday by the estimate of a cotton crop of 16,098,000 bales by the Crop Reporting Bureau as against 15,593,000 bales estimated in August.

No prisoners are being taken in the Chinese fighting. That was one of our terse Shanghai news items yesterday. Our correspondent had the grim fact in so many words from a Chinese official, and on the Japanese side his questions were sidestepped.

W. B. Spofford, executive secretary of the Church League for Industrial Democracy, retorted yesterday to the statement of Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York that the league was of "militantly partisan and radical character," with the reply "I hope we are."

Mid-day Sun, Mrs. G. Butt Miller's highly regarded son of Solario, suffered his first defeat since winning the Derby today as Lord Glanely's Chulmleigh won the 162d renewal of the St. Leger, last of the season's 3-year-old turf classics.

Hearings were resumed today before the Interstate Commerce Commission on the reorganization plan for the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad System, with E. G. Buckland, chairman of the railroad's board, on the stand.
A class of twenty-two boys and girls got a double dose of education today on the first day of the new school year at Center Groton's little white school house.

Loans and discounts, including overdrafts, of 13,881 insured commercial banks totaled $17,011,773,000 on June 30, an increase of $1,906,642,000, or nearly 13 per cent, over the total for 14,055 insured banks on June 30, 1936, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today.

Directors of the Eastman Kodak Company approved today the company's agreement with the Rochester Roman Catholic Diocese for the purchase of St. Patrick's Cathedral and announced plans to erect a new building.

Ralph Guiliano, 39 years old, of 210 Bridge Street, Brooklyn, and Vito Dellino, 35, of 170 East Eightyeighth Street, Manhattan, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to an indictment charging them with possession of thirty counterfeit $5 notes.

A countrywide search for J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, fugitive from justice in Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's policy ring investigation, began yesterday when Federal Judge John W. Clancy issued a warrant for his arrest after being informed that he was wanted as a material witness in the John Torrio income tax case.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Corinne Frances Welsh, daughter of Mrs. Harry E. Welsh of Los Angeles, to H. Clark Burrowes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Burrowes of Red Bank, N. J.

The air which New Yorkers breathe next year probably will be cleaner and much freer of smoke than it is today. When the new Building Code goes into effect on Jan. 1, 1938, more stringent regulations with regard to furnace equipment and structual rules to guard tenants against smoke in case of fire will be enforced.

By virtue of a par-matching 36 on the first nine holes at the Apawamis Club, scene of the thirty-first annual championship, W. R. Tuckerman, tall, sparse Washington golfer, set the pace for the first group of United States seniors today.

State Senator Lester H. Clee, candidate for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination, formally opened his primary campaign tonight in a speech to 1,200 members and guests of the Essex County Republican Committee at Essex House.

Re-establishment of the American market and a greater share in the nation's income were outlined today by Louis J. Taber, master of the National Grange, as necessary for the enduring prosperity of the Ar?erican farmer.

A total of 1,358 foreign-born residents of New York City were assisted by the Naturalization Aid Service of the WPA-Adult Education Program of the Board of Education between Aug. 1 and 13, according to figures released yesterday by Alexander Shear, program administrator.

John Roosevelt, the youngest of the President's sons, returned on the French liner Paris yesterday from a tour of Europe. Seated in the ship's veranda cafe, with his shipboard acquaintances gathered about, young Mr. Roosevelt denied flatly that he had hit Mayor Pierre Noveau of Cannes over the head with a wet bouquet and poured champagne into his hat on the evening of Aug. 15.

Plans for the development of an expanded program for the various groups of the National Association of Apparel Chains will be actively pursued this Fall, A. H. Klubock, president, said yesterday. The controllers' group, he pointed out, is already well advanced on its program.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidate for the Democratic Mayoralty nomination, redoubled yesterday his attacks upon his primary opponent, Senator Royal S. Copeland, in a series of ten campaign addresses, nine of them last night.

Miss Sylvia Shethar and her American Yacht Club crew of Misses Babs Shethar, Ella Manny and Elizabeth Craighead virtually made a parade today of the first three races of the women's national sailing championship for the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams trophy by capturing two of them and finishing second in the other.

State Senator Powell, who will be a candidate for Governor in the Republican primaries, has appointed his wife as manager of his campaign. A number of Republicans in Burlington County and elsewhere are said to have sought the post, but it is unnecessary and inurbane to believe that the choice was made to avoid ill feeling among these competitors.

A trailer chapel, in which two priests of the Paulist order will cover their "parish" of 7,000 square miles in Tennessee, was putt on display yesterday at the Chittenden, Chapin Co. showroom, 234 Central Park South. It will be shown today also.

The marriage of Miss Marian Hewitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Alexander Hewitt, to Thomas Jewett Hallowell Jr. of New York took place today at Christ Episcopal Church, Ballston Spa. The Rev. William Brown officiated.

A selected list of 100 interestpaying real estate bonds will produce a yield of approximately 7 per cent, according to an analysis prepared by Eli T. Watson Co. The average price asked for these issues is 56 and interest at the average rate of 3.9 per cent is being paid on the face value. The yield, on this basis, would average 6.95 per cent.

The Red Army, through its official organ, tonight threatened individual Soviet action to obtain redress from Italy for the two Soviet merchantmen Russia accuses Italian submarines of having sunk in the Mediterranean.
Nornay Saddler, a smooth foxterrier owned by the Wissaboo Kennels of Westbury, L. I., was adjudged best in show as the twenty-fourth annual exhibition closed at the New York State Fair today.

The Rev. John Ross of Belfast, Ireland, a rabbi who speaks with a brogue, visited Supreme Court Justice Edward Riegelmann in Brooklyn yesterday and sat with him on the bench during the trial of several undefended divorce actions. Later,. on being interviewed concerning his impressions, he said:

The Athletics and Senators exchanged shutouts today, Philadelphia taking the first game of a doubleheader, 2 to 0, and Washington the second, 1 to 0. George Caster and Earle Brucker, the Philadelphia battery, won their own game in the opener.

Miss Sally Marie Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Bernard Brown, of Brooklyn, was married to Robert Kenneth Robertson, son of Mrs. William Edgar Robertson, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr Robertson, yesterday afternoon in Our Lady of Refuge Church, Ocean and Foster Avenues, Brooklyn. The Rev. William J. Gately performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Hotel St. George.

Josiah Erickson, who flew here from Great Inagua Island in a chartered plane, admitted to the press tonight that most of the damage in the Great Inagua riot of Aug. 20 had been caused by two men, but he insisted they were part of a large gang.
Frank (Fatty) Alexander, contemporary of Roscoe (Fatty) Arbuckle, Kuple Morgan and other heavyweight comedians of the silent screen, died today after a heart attack.

The threat of war, although apparently disturbing to speculative business, has not yet hampered United States internal and external trade and industry, Secretary Roper of the Department of Commerce, said today.

Three of the national open championship teams rode through a round-robin on Belmont Field at the Meadow Brook Club today and left the spectators who watched the long session of polo with the feeling that the championship picture was not so clear as it seemed after the opening game.
Rain ended Ab Jenkins's assault on land speed records today but not before he covered 177.05 miles in one hour's run, breaking his own record of 171 miles.
A year's retirement from baseball was recommended today for Dizzy Dean, ailing ace hurler of the Cardinals, by Branch Rickey, vice president and general manager of the Gas House Gang.

Wallace Beery, film actor, obtained a special deputy sheriff's commission and a pistol permit today so he would be prepared, he said, to deal with any extortionists. Mr. Beery and his 8-year-old adopted daughter, Carol Ann Beery, appeared at the Sheriff's office and were fingerprinted.

Victor D'Aloia of Newark sought Governor Hoffman's permission today to appear before the Court of Pardons as counsel for George B. Harris, who, with Herman G. Mulock Jr., was sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of a Newark cafe proprietor.

First to win a game in the international chess masters' tournament at the Hotel Panhans, Samuel Rehevsky of New York, the United States champion, today defeated V. [Petrow of Latvia in the opening round.

Declaring the Domestic Relations Court was hampered by lack of personnel, Presiding Justice John Warren Hill urged yesterday that provision be made in the court's 1938 budget for 241 new employes at an added cost of $324,000.

An investing client of Henry S. Mansfield, attorney, has purchased from Springfield Estates, Inc., the recently completed one-story taxpayer on the corner of Springfield Avenue and Cummings Street, Irvington, N. J.

John Woodruff, Pittsburgh Negro who holds the Olympic 800-meter title, was beaten at his specialty today, but America's track and field athletes outpointed a combined Japanese-Manchukuan array, ten first places to six.

There were 363,675 holders of General Motors shares in the third quarter of 1937, compared with 359,630 in the second quarter and 342,384 in the third quarter of 1936. This compared with a high of 372,284 in the first quarter of 1933 and a subsequent low mark of 342,384 in 1936.

The Belgian Chamber tonight gave an ovation to Premier Paul van Zeeland when, after a two-day special session, it exonerated him of charges of irregularities in payments to him as vice president of the Bank of Belguim. The vote was 130 to 34, with 21 abstaining.
Sales of copper were made abroad yesterday at 13.95 cents a pound c.i.f. the European base ports. This compares with 13.85 cents on Tuesday. The domestic price was unchanged at 14 cents a pound.

ANDERSON, LARS (March 4, 1930). Gross assets, $3,750; net- $3,750. To daughters, Ida A. Selleck, May A. Ginsburg, Lillian A. Duggan; son, Lawrence R. Anderson; grandchildren, Elsie P. De Jonkhere and Charles Springer. Chief assets, cash, $750: mortgages, notes and accounts, $3,000. Ellery E. Albee, attorney, Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.
The twelfth annual conference of police benevolent - associations of New York State opened tonight with a dinner at the Westchester Country Club, attended by 350 delegates from 137 associations.

Directors of the Engineers Public Service Company declared yesterterday dividends of $3.75 a share on the $5 preferred, $4.12 1/2 on the $5.50 preferred and $4.50 on the $6 preferred stock. These dividends, which are payable on Oct. 1 to holders of record of Sept. 20, are on account of cumulative dividends accrued and in arrears.

The New York State Historical Association voted today to sponsor the Guide for New York State (outside New York City), prepared by the Federal Writers Project, if the text conforms with the requirements of a special committee to be appointed by the association.
The Chicago White Sox, still in the fight for runner-up position in the American League, encountered little opposition as they defeated the eighthplace St. Louis Browns today, 10 to 1.

Although the stock market closed fairly steady, if slightly lower, it was not without its nervous moments yesterday. Following an irregular and active opening, a wave of selling kept the ticker three minutes behind the market and sent the average price level down to a new low mark for the year.

Mr. and Mrs. A. Perry Osborn gave a supper party last night in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for his daughter, Miss Lucretia Osborn, who celebrated her twentyfirst birthday. The other guests were the Misses Nancy C. Blagden, Anne Paul, Marietta Mander, Cardine E. Bogert, Taziana Kunis and Nathalie Osborn:
Sales resistance is personified in Mrs. Alice Cohen, 24 years old, of 703 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, it was indicated yesterday in Pennsylvania Avenue Court, Brooklyn.

What the industry regards as a most constructive move in the program to rehabilitate the silk and rayon printing industry was made today when the two major printing groups combined to form the Rayon and Silk Printing Association.

Coach Jimmy Crowley sent his Fordham football players through their first scrimmage of the season at Fordham Field yesterday. Two elevens of veterans and sophomores alternated in running the ball against a scrub line and backfield.

The estimate of 16,098,000 bales as the probable yield of this year's cotton crop, issued yesterday by the Department of Agriculture, resulted in the price of the staple dropping to the lowest level for the current movement, with the nearby months only slightly above the nine-cent level.

The largest sales for an August in the company's history were reported yesterday for last month by the General Motors Corporation. Sales to dealers in the United States and Canada, together with shipments overseas, were 188,010, compared to the previous high mark of 186,653 in August, 1928, and a third highest August of 168,185 in 1929.

The firm of Pell Tibbits, Inc., has been dissolved and Theodore Roosevelt Pell and Henry R. Tibbits will continue in business separately. C. Wesley Copp Jr. will be an associate in the new firm of Henry R. Tibbits, Inc.
Ivor Nicholson, chairman of the publishing firm of Ivor Nicholson Watson, Ltd., died in London today after a long illness. He was 46 years old.

Brokers and renting agents report that business locations are finding a ready market with a demand regarded as unusual for this period of the year. There is a well-defined call for stores, as well as for space on upper floors for display, sales and office purposes.

Mrs. Matilda Parsons Cowles, a leader in local civic affairs until recently, died at her home here today. Mrs. Cowles, who was the widow of David S. Cowles, pulp and paper manufacturer, was 76 years old.

Trading was spotty in the woolgoods markets this week, with most clothing manufacturers too busy shipping out Fall apparel to give much attention to piece-goods requirements, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. 'Fabric manufacturers were reported to be curtailing production substantially, and a few began to show lines for the next season.

Madison St., 202; to 5-story tenement and stores; Neplon Holding Corp, 285 Madison St, owner; J. C. Schnall, architect; cost $3,500. Brooklyn Ralph Ave, 2,362-70; 1-story frame church; Kingslawn Community Church, 2,422 Ralph Ave, owner; E. Holmgren, architect; cost $20,000.

James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who will retire from government service soon to become dean of the Harvard Law School, in an interview today told of some of the accomplishments under the two Securities Acts, which he held had served public interest and brought a better understanding on all sides of the problems involved.

While it has been feared that heavy production might force Japan to dump supplies of rayon goods in world markets because of the present conflict with China, Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, in a report issued yesterday, expressed the opinion that this concept is entirely erroneous.

The doors of the Federal Building at Foley Square were locked for half an hour yesterday afternoon while guards and Federal agents, responding to an alarm, searched on thirty floors for two prisoners who had walked out of the United States Attorney's office while they were waiting with three guards to be questioned.

Eleven firemen and four others injured in the fire which destroyed the Pure Oil Company's gasoline storage plant and resulted in injury of more than 170 persons here July 16 sued the company today for damages totalling $136,500.

Two starting pitchers couldn't help the Giants yesterday, but the relief hurling of Dick Coffman, plus heavy hitting by Mel Ott and other Terrymen, gave them an even break in the double-header with the Dodgers at Ebbets Field and increased their National League lead over the Cubs, who lost, to three games.

Mgr. Jean-Baptiste Pelt, Bishop of Metz, died today. He was 74 years old. Jean-Baptiste Pelt, D. D., LL. D., French ecclesiastic and historian, was born in 1863 and educated at the seminaries of Metz, Paris and Rome.

Ground was broken yesterday afternoon for the new church which will replace the Church of St. Andrew, Roman Catholic edifice at Duane Street and Cardinal Place, not far from the once celebrated Park Row of the newspaper world.

Forty-nine of the city's leading civic and trade associations have written to urge Mayor La Guardia to sign the ordinance passed by the Board of Aldermen on July t3, repealing the 50 per cent rise in water rates, according to a statement made public yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission.
Bernard K. Marcus, who served a term in Sing Sing Prison after the failure of the Bank of United States, of which he was president, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal Court.
Jean Renoir's French film adaptation of the Maxim Gorki play, "The Lower Depths" (Na Dnie), will have its American premiere at noon today in the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse.

A PART from a number of nice medical terms like apicat phthisis and phrenicotomy, and one lone, solitary naughty term-the less said of which the better-there is little in A. J. Cronin's new novel* that the most innocent lambs among us don't already know.

Trophies were presented at a meeting held in the open-air arena late this afternoon, with General M. A. Reckord, executive vice president of the National Rifle Association, presiding. The prizes included those in the national rifle and pistol matches.
The stock market today displayed a firmer tone, although the volume of business continued small. Gilt-edged issues were generally up, Chinese and Japanese bonds being exceptions to the trend.

A group of the early short stories that William Sydney Porter wrote before he developed the pen name O. Henry have been collected from the yellowing pages of a Texas newspaper and will be published early in January by Doubleday, Doran under the title "O. Henry Encore."

Plans filed with the Manhattan Department of Buildings in August called for construction of nineteen new buildings at a total cost of $3,978,850, Samuel Fassler, Commisisoner of Buildings, announced yesterday.

Ford Frick, president of the National League, yesterday disallowed a protest by the Cubs on a disputed play in the second game of last Sunday's double-header with the Pirates, The Associated Press reports.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today. as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Recepits 8,000, Including 2,500 directs. The market was 15-25 higher than Wednesday's average; mostly 25 higher late; top $11.90;

That perennial ecstasy that grips femininity when confronted with those prima donnas of the style world-first Autumn fashions-bemused a hypercritical crowd last night in the Fifth Avenue salon of Bergdorf-Goodman.

Well-known New York builders and architects who less than a decade ago were occupied almost entirely with the construction of office and residential skyscrapers in Manhattan now have turned their attention to the erection of small dwellings in the suburbs of New York.

First drawing in this county and the Bronx Wednesday of names of women registered for jury service under the State law that went into effect Sept. 1 set in motion a change which is almost forty years old in the first State that adopted it.

Miss Priscilla Hollister, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Buell Hollister of Corning, N. Y., and Salters Point, South Dartmouth, Mass., will be married to Territt H. Mowbray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Mowbray of Monticello, Bermuda, on the afternoon of Sept. 25 in St. Aidan's Chapel, South Dartmouth.
Satisfactory preliminary arrangements have been made for Japan's participation in the New York World Fair,Herbert S. Houston, commissioner for the fair, said as he sailed for the United States today.
The committee for holders of Colombian bonds has objected to the use by the State of Antiaquia of 75,000 pesos a year of revenues of the Antioquia Railway for highway construction purposes.

Pierce W. Bradley of counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission rested yesterday its case against the Austin Silver Mining Company in stop-order proceedings based on the government's allegation that a misleading registration statement was filed.
The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices advanced to 94 per cent of the 1926 average on Sept. 7 from 93.7 on the Tuesday previous.

Traders in wheat paid little attention today to the character of the political developments in Europe, the upturn in securities being taken as indieating much less apprehension regarding the Mediterranean situation, and profit-taking developed on the minor rallies.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday for the first half of 1937 a consolidated net income of $4,285,854, equal to 67 cents a share on 6,399,002 shares of stock, against $1,662,374, or 26 cents a share, in the 1936 period.

Plots at Candlewod Knolls, Candlewood Lake, and at Knollcrest, near Danbury, Conn., have been purchased by John W. Fish of Yonkers, C. B. Mullins of Baldwin, L. I., George L. Murphy of Harrison, N. Y., Karl Ermer of the Bronx, Emery L. Hamilton of Rosedale, L. I., and a group of three plots by Gilbert H. and Elmer F. Lawrence of Danbury.

Japanese authorities issued formal notice yesterday that they considered all methods, centers and channels of transportation and communication between Shanghai, Nanking and Hangchow as at present being put to Chinese military use and, therefore, the Japanese would bomb them more and more intensively.
A young American wife's written plea of "Please don't destroy my happiness" won a promise of life and freedom today for her imprisoned aviator husband.

Holders of first general mortgage bonds of the Norfolk Southern Railway are to meet at 35 Nassau Street on Sept. 17 to discuss a plan or reorganization for the company proposed by fiduciary and other investors, the Guaranty Trust Company, trustee of the issue, announced yesterday.

John D. Peace Sr., special deputy clerk in charge of the Queens County Supreme Court, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 152-24 Twelfth Road, Whitestone, Queens. His age was 59. He recently returned from his Summer home in Maine.

Mr. and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., returning from their wedding trip abroad, will arrive today on the Europa of the North German Lloyd Line, which brings 2,088 passengers from Bremen and Channel ports.

Some 20,000 New York patrons at the moment are on the Theatre Guild's subscription rolls for the 1937-38 season-a total smaller by 10 per cent than last year at this time. The Guild, however, is not worried. Not only does it figure that its impressive program will attract additional subscribers, but it feels that the list has about reached the saturation point.

A new Hungarian-language newspaper, The Hungarian Daily World (Amerikai Magyar Vilag), will be published here on Oct. 6, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Feher, who will be its managing editor. At the daily's office,

Price movements of commodity futures were irregular and activity was on a more moderate scale yesterday on the local markets. Domestic sugar futures declined on news that Secretary Wallace indicated that the Department of Agriculture would raise sugar quotas, if necessary, to protect the consumer from higner prices.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Lillian Jester of Dallas to Percy Selden Straus Jr. of New York, took place here this evening. The ceremony was performed at the Highland Park Methodist Church by Dr. C. C. Selecman, president of Southern Methodist University.

Greentree won another national open championship trial match tonight, defeating Templeton, 11 to 9. The game started as if the defending champions would roll up a decisive triumph, as they were in front by 8 to 2 at half time, but in the last four periods Templeton came along with a rush to outscore them, 7 to 3.

Up until yesterday 17-year-old Robert Oliver, who lives at the Hotel Fulton, was merely an office boy at the offices of Chamberlain Brown, theatrical manager, at 145 West Forty-fifth Street, and the script of the play "Merely Murder" was virtually unknown, except to Mr. Brown and Rowland Stebbins, who is planning to produce the play.

Seymour Knox, captain of the Aurora polo quartet, said today the team had decided to enter the Argentine open championship, which begins Nov. 11. One member of the team, Lindsay Howard of San Mateo,. Calif., has left by plane for Buenos Aires.

Miss Hanna Randle Monroe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Parker Monroe of this city, was married here last night in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church to Gerald Abner Eubank Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald A. Eubank of 655 Park Avenue, New York, by the Rev. Stanley V. Wilcox.

With the arrest of an ex-convict as one of the robbers, the police disclosed last night a hold-up in the Mayflower Hotel, 17 Central Park, West near Sixty-first Street; last Saturday morning in which Miss Evelyn Dean, a dancer, was left bound -in the bathroom of her apartment by two hold-up men who fled with loot valued at several thousand dollars.

Rex Ingram, Negro actor, who played the part of "De Lawd" in the talking picture version of "Green Pastures," filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday, listing liabilities of $9,511 and no assets except wearing apparel valued at $20, which is exempt from the claims of creditors.

The State's evidence against Miss Margaret Drennan, 20 years old, held for the slaying of Paul Reeves, 25, will be presented to the grand jury next Thursday if the investigation of her story is completed before that date, Assistant Prosecutor James- S. Wright announced here today.

Cotton holdings of the crops of 1934 and prior years of the Commodity Credit Corporation, accumulated under loan programs, have been withdrawn from the market, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said todav.

Mr. and Mrs. James Scott Denham, who are passing the season at Elm Croft, their Summer home in the East Norwich colony, gave a large supper dance tonight to introduce their daughter, Miss Carolina Coleman Denham, who was graduated from the Westover School last June.

A new Park Department play ground at Thirtieth Road, between Forty-fifth and Forty-sixth Streets, Astoria, Queens, will be opened today. This will be the 236th playground added to the recreational system under the La Guardia administration.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 8 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:
The Vatican apartment of Mgr. Arborio Mella, Papal Master of the Chamber, was robbed last night of jewels, decorations and money, including some church funds entrusted to Mgr. Mella's care.
Mrs. Anna Matilda Corkran, widow of Benjamin W. Corkran Jr. and for many years active in philanthropic and club circles, died at her home here last evening at the age of 79.

Whitehaired Jack Cooper of Kansas City sent his Tops II over the finish line at 70.6 miles an hour tonight in the final of the one-mile event for 225-cubic-inch motor boats on the Canadian National Exhibition waterfront. The ten-mile world championship event was canceled owing to rough water.

Fourteen lots on the east side of Seventy-second Place, between Calamus Avenue and Fifty-second Avenue, Woodside, Queens, have been sold by David F. Kemp to a local builder, who plans to improve the parcel with a number of dwellings. Edwards Co. was the broker.

Baltimore took the odd game in its three-game series with the Jersey City Giants today behind the sturdy pitching of Southpaw Carl Fischer by a score of 2 to 1. Fischer, who went the route, restricted the little Giants to six hits, struck out seven and walked only one as he scored his eighth victory of the season.

Miss Jane Holt, daughter of Dr. Matthew S. Holt of Washington, D. C., and sister of United States Senator Rush D. Holt, was married this afternoon in the First Congregational Church here to Ralph K. Chase, Washington attorney and son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. B. Chase.

138th St, 112-16 W: 6-story brick apartment, 90x99.11; Gussie Morgenstern against 112 W 138th St Holding Corp: due, $148.407; to plaintiff for $1,000. By B. HOLLANDER SON Madison Ave, 1,839; 3-story atone tenement and store, 17.9x83; Bowery Savings Bank against Matilda Hanania; due, $14,550; taxes. etc $2,000 to plaintiff for $12,000.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today that repayments to that organization on loans probably would not more than equal disbursements because of the new cotton-loan program and the possibility of a corn loan program.

Bellaire Kitty, chestnut mare owned by Mr. and Mrs. Reed A. Albee of Larchmont, reserve to the grand champion at the Empire State Horse Show in 1936, made an impressive showing tonight in winning the blue ribbon in an interesting saddle class.

Trading was fair to good. Prices were strong to higher on most classes. Thursday, being an off-kosher day, the slaughter of those classes usually dressed kosher was light at most points. Kosher lamb business was slow and prices steady to weak, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

In the one-day tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association at the Innis Arden Country Club today a tie for low gross honors resulted between Mrs. Emmett F. Whalen of Westchester Hills, with a card of 45, 42-87, and Mrs. Edward Stevens of Round Hill, who posted 44, 43-87.

Eight pickets arrested in the Horn Hardart cafeteria strike were found guilty of disorderly conduct yesterday by Magistrate Michael Ford in Jefferson Market Court. Seven who elected to serve a day in jail rather than pay fines of $1 each were released at 4 P. M. The eighth d paid a $2 fine.

Records of the District Attorney's office revealed yesterday that on Aug. 31 the grand jury dismissed the grand larceny charge made on July 9 in the Felony Court by Miss Maris Warrington, an art collector, of Rutherford, N. J., against Gustave Nassauer, 65 years old, a real estate agent, of 56 East Eighty-seventh Street.

Billy Rogell's single with the bases full in the last half of the ninth enabled the Tigers to conquer the Indians, 10 to 9, today. Four Indian hurlers, Galehouse, Whitehill, Hudlin and Harder, saw service, Harder being charged with the defeat.

Peter Clark, a golf professional whose pupils had included many Westchester County residents and members of the old Mamaroneck motion picture colony operated by D. W. Griffiths, died here today at his home. He was 62 years old.

In a note delivered to the British and French Charges d'Affaires this morning the Italian Government, as expected, refuses the invitation to attend the Nyon conference until the incident created by the Russian note delivered on Monday is satisfactorily settled-and suggests that the subjects which were to be discussed at Nyon be taken up by the Non-Intervention Committee in London.

Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau said today that the stock market's break on Tuesday had not.affected adversely the Government's financing program for Sept. 15, under which 2 per cent five-year notes and 11/4 per cent fifteen-month notes were offered on Tuesday morning in exchange for $817,000,000 of 31/4 per cent notes which will mature on that date.

Suit was filed in United States District Court here today by counsel for the Port of New York Authority, on behalf of four trucking companies, for an injunction restraining the Interstate Commerce Commission from enforcing its recent order defining the "New York zone" exempt from general Federal regulation.

Miss Sylvia Shethar of the American Yacht Club was still in the lead tonight in the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Trophy series for the women's national sailing championship but her margin at the end of six races was none. too secure.

The most vindictive campaign against national food brands which has developed this year has been launched by a small cooperative group of stores in Iowa and is causing considerable uneasiness to large manufacturers, who fear that such drives may spread, it was learned here yesterday.

Ledyard Gardner of New York entertained at the Cave Grill supper dance tonight in honor of Mrs. Henry Clay Cowles, also of New York. More than 100 played in Mrs. Frank S. Dodge's bridge party at the Mountain View, Whitefield, tonight, with supper and dancing Ho later.

Farm Administration officials announced today a proposal to control commercial potato acreage "at the average level" next year under the Soil Conservation Act. The Agricultural Adjustment Administration said that all commercial potato producers would be asked to vote this month "on whether they want the 1933 agricultural conservation program to contain special provisions that would tend toward acreage stabilization for potatoes."

The finals in the third annual American Ballad Contest for "barber shop quartets" will be held Sunday evening at the Randall's Island Stadium in connection with the performance of "Roberta," the season's last Gallo-Schubert offering at the Stadium, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Parks.
