The recent application by a large German fishing concern to the Finnish Government for the lease of land in the Petsamo district on the Arctic coast to facilitate German deep-water fishing and to establish cooperation with Finnish fishing, an application that caused suspicion abroad, particularly in Russia, is understood to have been shelved by the Cabinet.
Belief that outright war in Europe now would mean "a revolution in every country" was expressed in an address here today by Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick.

Provisional President Felix Paiva, who assumed the government of Paraguay by a revolt Aug. 13 on a pledge to restore the constitutional form of government, suspended the Constitution today by declaring martial law for two months throughout the country.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Clara Levinger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Levinger of Maplewood, to Joe Webb Peoples of Middletown, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Peoples of Asheville, N. C., took place today at the Canoe Brook Country Club.
Mrs. Fred John Brockway of 57 East Eighty-eighth Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Dorothy Brockway, to Harold S. Osborne of Upper Montclair, N. J.

Carl Bechter made a bet with Police Judge Martin P. Devlin in Traffic Court here today and lost. It cost him $16. Bechter, who lives at 2,003 McGalliard Avenue, Trenton, was arraigned on a charge of driving forty-five miles an hour and fined $8.
The United States was the principal beneficiary of Canada's increased import trade in July, according to an analysis by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

Vince DiMaggio's homer with two on bases and two out in the sixth today enabled the Bees to conclude their series with the Phillies with a 5-3 victory. Frank Gabler, who relieved Ira Hutchinson in the sixth, was credited with the triumph.
Pig iron production in August, according to The Iron Age, totaled 3,605,818 gross tons, up 3 per cent over July, based on the daily rate of 116,317 tons against 112,866 tons.

Electric power production last week made a new all-time high and showed a greater increase than anticipated by seasonal and long-term factors. The adjusted index has moved upward to 108.9 from 108.4. This compares with 104.0 for the week ended Sept. 5, 1936.

Secretary Morgenthau announced today that bids would be received at the Federal Reserve Banks and their branches until 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, on Monday for $50,000,000 of Treasury discount bills of 273-day maturity.

Licensed engineers of the Grace Line and Panama Mail Steamship Company were ordered today by the National Labor Relations Board to hold new elections to determine, for the second time, whether they desire to be represented for purposes of collective bargaining by the Marine Engineers' Beneficial Association or the United Licensed Officers of the United States of America or the International Union of Operating Engineers.

Dr. James Nathaniel Jenne, Dean of Medicine at the University of Vermont, died here today at the age of 77. He left no near relatives. Dr. Jenne, who served the University of Vermont for forty-six years, had been dean of the university's College of Medicine since 1926.

Governer Herbert H. Lehman, addressing a Governor's Day crowd at the New York State Fair today, warned agriculture to guard against "dissension and distrust" within the State's $2,000,000,000 dairyindustry, for such, he asserted, -might force appeals for restoration of government control "more stringent than before."

" The Japanese have their wind up," observed one foreign military observer this morning. He was citing the fact that one Chinese sniper with a rifle took two pot shots at the Izumo last evening from the Pootung shore, after which the Izumo and a destroyer poured shells into Pootung for the next forty minutes.

August was the fourteenth consecutive month in which new paidfor life insurance gained over the same month of the previous year, according to the Fidelity Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia. Insurance in force totaling $362,373,000 increased $6,738,000 in the period.
William J. Denman, a page on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange since his graduation from high school, in June, 1929, was elected yesterday a member of the Exchange.

The navy will ask Congress to authorize a program of civilian naval training next Summer similar to that now conducted by the army through its citizens' military training camps, members of Congress interested in naval affairs said today.

The last obstacle to promoting the most pretentious boxing program in the history of the game was removed yesterday when all the top-flight warriors who will be seen in the Carnival of Champions at the Polo Grounds Sept. 23 signed formal articles at the offices of the New York State Athletic Commission.

Colonel Sir Theodore Brinckman, who served with distinction in the South African and World Wars, died here last night. He was 75 years old. Sir Theodore was the first husband of the late Lady Houston, suffragist and philanthropist.

Prince Christian of SchaumburgLippe, nephew of King Christian of Denmark, married Princess Feodora, eldest daughter of Prince Harald and Princess Helena of Denmark, today. The bridegroom's mother was a sister of King Christian.

Angel Child, holder of the track trotting record, found the Indiana State Fair Grounds oval to her liking again today and went on to victory in three straight heats of the $1,500 L. S. Ayres 2:09 trot.

The week's Federal Reserve statistics disclosed yesterday the' paradoxical circumstances of a drop of $21,000,000 in member bank reserve balances and a rise of $10,000,000 in member bank excess reserves.

The death of an apartment house superintendent and a case of alleged assault on another man followed the opening yesterday of a building service employes' strike described as a "major move" to complete the organization of workers in 250 Manhattan structures by Oct.- 1.

Charles Jennings of Roaring Gap, N. C., who won the individual championship of the United States Seniors' Golf Association three years ago, made a gesture toward repeating today as the second half of the field in the thirty-third meeting launched its attack on par at the Apawamis Club.

A woman prisoner escaped from a police patrol wagon last night as she was being taken from Police Headquarters to the detention jail at the West 123d Street station. A city-wide alarm was broadcast saying she might have been injured in her escape.
The British freighter Stanwold was captured within Spanish territorial waters off Gijon yesterday by an Insurgent torpedo boat.

Two veteran members of the American pro golfing brigade, Leo Diegel and Harry Cooper, took the lead in the Canadian open championship today with first-round scores of 67, three strokes under par for the rolling St. Andrews Golf Club course.
Vincent Rao of 210. East Sixtyfirst Street, retired electrical contractor, died of a heart ailment early yesterday morning in his Summer home at Mount Kisco, N. Y. He was 70 years old.

Shipments from motor-vehicle factories in the United States and Canada in August amounted to 410,200 units, according to the preliminary estimate made public yesterday by the Automobile Manufacturers Association. This was an increase of 49 per cent over the same month last year.

Oddly heeled over under a parachute spinnaker, Paul Shields's sixmeter sloop Rebel today won her second straight race in defense of the Seawanhaka Cup. In a fifteenknot breeze and a sea, conditions the challenger Buri of the Royal Norwegian Yacht Club had wanted, Rebel led over twelve miles by 1 minute 5 seconds.

A supplementary war budget of $600,000,000, voted by the five-day extraordinary session of Parliament which closed this week, is Japan's gauge of the Eastern conflict. This vast expenditure-together with the approximately $150,000,000 previously authorized, greatly exceeding the entire imperial budget for 1936-37-was voted by the two houses of the Diet without a dissenting voice.

The Independent Food Distributors Council, which has requested the Department of Agriculture to assist in planning producer-retailer marketing campaigns, yesterday announced the periods during which various nation-wide events will be held to promote sales of apples, lamb, Fall pears, tea and walnuts.

Mayor La Guardia dug the first shovelful of earth yesterday from a twenty-five-foot bluff at North Beach Airport, thus starting the initial development of the port which eventually will quadruple its present area.

The three winners of the children's city-wide peace pledge contest, arranged jointly this Summer by the Hearn Department Stores, Inc., and World Peaceways, Inc., were announced yesterday by the latter organization.
The Chinese are busy perfecting two more barriers across the Yangtze above the barrier already blocking the river in the vicinity of Chinkiang.

Sleepy Jim Crowley rarely is at a loss for words. A quick and flippant answer is always hanging on the tip of his tongue. But Somnolent James cannot evaluate his Fordham University eleven for the coming season.

The French franc yesterday broke away from its official controls and plunged downward in the foreign exchange market to the lowest levels it has touched since the latter part of 1926 when Poincare was "saving" it from its post-war collapse.

Stocks rallied and closed firm, with 1 to 3 point gains in the leaders; turnover, 1,411,500 shares. United States Government and corporation bonds generally higher; German issues lower; transactions, $7,774,500.
During the week ended Sept. 8 member bank reserve balances decreased $21,000,000.
Senator Wheeler of Montana, a leader in the fight against President Roosevelt's court reorganization plan, raised today the question:
President Roosevelt is considering a plan for a single day of registration of the country's unemployed on a nation-wide basis. The present election machinery would be used.
With few exceptions, favorites came through the first two match play rounds without mishap today in the nineteenth annual Arcola Country Club invitation golf tournament.

George. H. Houston, president of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, announced tonight that the company was prepared to complete its plan of reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The plan was confirmed by the United States District Court on Sept. 1.
William Phillips, United States Ambassador to Italy, returned on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia yesterday with Mrs. Phillips for his annual leave.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. E. McCormack Day of East Hampton, L. I., and 150 East Thirty-ninth Street, this city, of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Jeanne Day, to Edward John Noble of Greenwich.
The guns of Spanish Insurgency boomed tonight against the fortifications of Gijon, the Government's last sea foothold on the northwestern ledge of Spain. Misty rain hampered ground advances.

Gordon S. (Mickey) Cochrane prepared to night to leave for Europe to com plete his convalescence from a recent skull fracture after signing a contract as non-playing manager of the Tigers for 1938 and 1939.
The Mother Lode Coalition Mines Company will have to cease operations after the extraction of the small tonnage of ore remaining, Charles Earle, president, advised stockholders in a letter yesterday.

THE CITADEL, by A. J. Cronin. (Little, Brown, $2.50.) A novel attacking some current medical practices in England. ANIMAL TREASURE, by Ivan T. Sanderson. (Viking Press, $3.) A naturalist in the tropics.

Mrs. Hope Robinson Hitchcock, an authority on English sheep dogs, died late today in the Northern Westchester Hospital at Mount Kisco. She lived on Bedford Road, Pleasantville, where she kept a kennel of English sheep dogs which once was the largest in the country.

The Connecticut Federation of Labor, at its final session today, defeated a resolution calling for a unity convention to settle all differences with the C.I. O. and for setting up one united trade union center in the United States.

Augustus Phillips, who has conducted a pawnbroker's shop at 157 Bowery for the last thirty years, has leased the two-story building at 1,748 Amsterdam Avenue, near 146th Street, from Walter J. and Rudolph U. Fimian, plumbing contractors.
The nation's newest destroyers, it was learned yesterday, are to be "streamlined"-the first instance in our navy of the application of streamlining principles to fighting ships.

Rounzy Realty, Inc., Morris Rappaport president, sold to the Braving Holding Corporation the six-story apartment house on a plot 175 by 100 feet at the southwest corner of Wythe Place and 172d Street, the Bronx.
Ben White annexed both feature races on today's grand circuit program at the New York State Fair track before a capacity crowd.

Kenneth Dayton, Acting Budget Director, held a public hearing yesterday on the request of the Fire Department for a 1938 budget allowance of $34,386,472, or $9,343,266 more than the appropriation for 1937.

Chemists working in perplexing substances, which may in time yield the secrets of life, were told by Dr. Alsoph H. Corwin of Johns Hopkins University today that one of their most important tools was giving them inaccurate answers.

Ralph K. Guinzburg, president of the I. B. Kleinert Rubber Company, has started on a 9,000-mile air trip throughout the country to study business and fashion trends. James Talcott, Inc., has been appointed factor for the Filatex Corportion, manufacturers of latex thread.

Tonight's program of free productions as sponsored by the WPA Caravan Theatre will be as follows: Manhattan, "Riddle Me This," at Washington Square Park; Brooklyn, "Pirates of Penzance," at the Prospect Park bandstand;

Again successful, as in the opening round yesterday, Samuel Reshevsky of New York, the United States champion, today gained another point in the international chess masters tournament, four games of which were decided in the second round.
The Japanese gave notice they would bomb all transportation routes in the Shanghai, Hangchow and Nanking districts. Safety to neutral refugees will be granted only when special arrangements are made.

Mgr. Cashing, the rector of St. Andrew's Church in City Hall Place, is to have a new church edifice in place of the little red brick building; and many people outside of his parish and many of other denominations will rejoice with him and his parishioners.

Tenderers for the $3,000,000 new public improvement issue and the $1,500,000 of refunding issue of the Territory of Hawaii, to be sold on Sept. 14, may bid for both issues or for one, and may condition their biels on the award to them of all or no part of the bonds sought, W. C. McGonagle, Treasurer of the Territory, announced yesterday.
Mrs. W. Harry Brown of Pittsburgh, who has Mrs. Post Wheeler and Mrs. Charles Perin as her house guests, entertained at Hopedene with a musical and tea this afternoon.

Rentals reported yesterday by brokers and managing agents of apartment houses indicated a demand for large suites in houses on Park Avenue. The quest for large apartments also extended to the West Side, where the principal demand for this type of apartment was in evidence in rentals in houses on Central Park West.

The touring New Zealand cricket team today compiled 285 runs in reply to H. D. G. Leveson-Gower's eleven, which hit up a total of 380 yesterday. Going in a second time, the English players had made 105 for five wickets when stumps were drawn.
The financial community here is still at its wit's end trying to discover how Wall Street knew of an impending European war Tuesday when London did not.
Directors of the National Steel Corporation yesterday voted to declare an extra dividend of 50 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly distribution of 62 1/2 cents.
Despite the refusal of the Italian and German Governments to attend the Nyon conference on how to suppress piracy in the Mediterranean it will be opened tomorrow.

22d St, 228 W, 20x98.9; Max Margulis and another, to Domenico Sassarini. 228 W 22d St; p. m. mtg, prior mtg $11.500, 5 years 5 per cent; $2,900. 88th St, 343-353 W, 118.5x100.8: Crown Equities, Inc, A. Weinstein, president, to Merit Factors Corp, 41 E. 57th St; demand 6 Per cent; $3,820.
Frank Ferguson, actor, playwright and lecturer, died on Wednesday at the Home for Incurables, 183d Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx, at the age of 74. He lived at 275 West Seventy-third Street.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has obtained a permit from the town of Mount Pleasant in Westchester County for the erection of a $140,000 indoor tennis court as an addition to the Playhouse on his Pocantico Hills estate, it was disclosed yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Dora Margaret Fergusson, daughter of Mrs. Frank Kerby Fergusson and the late Brig. Gen. Fergusson of Fort Totten, to Albert Edward Posener of Great Neck, son of Mrs. Theodore Coleman of Punta Gorda, Fla., and of Philip Posener of New York, took place this afternoon in the home of the bride's mother in this army post.
Arky Vaughan's ninth-inning triple and Bill Brubaker's single gave the Pirates a 1-to-O triumph over Cincinnati today. It was the thirtieth time this season the Reds have been beaten by one run.

George Fetzko, a $45-a-week crane man employed by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Cambria plant for twenty-six years, told the National Labor Relations Board hearing today that the company sought through its alleged company union to organize employee sentiment against the Wagner act while the bill was being debated in Congress.
L. Hamilton Rainey, Deputy State Attorney General and prominent in Democratic politics of Nassau County, died here last night following an operation at the Nassau Hospital.
Business in the Pittsburgh district made furother gains last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

Eighty-one parcels of Westchester real estate, assets of closed national banks in that county, brought a total of $581,000 in the series of auction sales held in the New York Naval Militia Armory in New Rochelle, a tabulation yesterday revealed.

In the three weeks ended on Labor Day, forty cabin sites were sold in Highland Lakes, the 1,500-acre lake community near Stockholm, N. J., according to Seckler Shepperd, Inc., the developers of the resort.

The American Woolen Company is taking an impartial attitude in the election arranged by the National Labor Relations Board for its Wood Ayer Mills at Lawrence, Mass., on Sept. 15 and 16, and "has no intention or desire to do otherwise than to comply with the wishes of the majority of its workers," Moses Pendleton, president, declared in a statement issued here yesterday.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Miss Dorothy Taft Sears, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd A. Sears of Binghamton, N. Y., to George H. Minor of Cleveland, which took place on Tuesday at the Sears home.
We had two shovel and spade stories in our paper yesterday. One was an advance notice of Mayor La Guardia

An increase in the number of infantile paralysis cases was reported yesterday by the City Health Department. Ten new cases were recorded for the three days ending Labor Day, 13 for Tu day and 13 for Wednesday.

Warning against long-term installment selling and announcing a study of it, L. S. Crowder, general manager of the National Retail Credit Association, commented today that "'three years to pay' will be a forgotten phrase within a year."

The nine-Power conference which has been summoned to convene at Nyon for the purpose of dealing with the problem of "piracy" in the Mediterranean will meet today, with Italy and Germany conspicuously absent.

Negotiations were terminated without results yesterday by the Greater City Master Plumbers Association, employers' group, and the Alteration Plumbers, Heaters, Steamfitters and Helpers Union, which began a strike of 1,500 members on Wednesday.

The eighteen-family garden apartment at 64 Jefferson Avenue, White Plains, Westchester, has been purchased from the Dry Dock Savings Institution by Loomis J. Grossman, operator. The building, which was erected in 1929, stands on a plot 95 by 119 feet and was bought for cash above a first mortgage of $48,000. A. Arthur Klar acted for Mr.

Supreme Court Justice, Meier Steinbrink ruled in Brooklyn yesterday that the New York State Board of Mediation has no power to compel either party in a labor dispute to submit its case for mediation by the board.
While Mayor La Guardia expressed confidence of victory in the Republican primary, Samuel S. Koenig, former New York County Republican chairman, appealed for his election.

The Economic Committee of the League of Nations in its report tonight gloomily surveys the lack of progress during the year toward the economic objectives of the Anglo-French-American monetary accord and finds the immediate outlook dark.
Present army communication methods have become obsolete because of the speed of motorized fighting forces, War Department experts said today.
Steady sixhit pitching by Lon Warneke and a barrage of sixteen blows against Charley Root and Roy Parmelee enabled the Cardinals finally to rout their Cub jinx today and win, 8 to 2.

Despite a sharp decline from the total of the previous week as a result of the Labor Day holiday, bank clearings for the five days ended on Wednesday rose above the corresponding five-day period of last year.
Miss Emma Mills gave a talk at the Maidstone Club this morning. Miss Mills is the guest of Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford at her dune residence here.

You don't have to go to New England or Canada for good bass fishing, as was proven this week by B. H. Bandell of New York, who took a nice creel of small mouth bass and one six-and-a-half-pound large mouth out of Lake Mahopac in Putnam County.

Jefferson Caffery, recently appointed United States Ambassador to Brazil, stressed President Roosevelt's personal good-will toward this country today at a luncheon given by the American Chamber of Commerce. It was his first official appearance before American business men here.

United States citizens in almost all the principal seaports of China today were urged to evacuate in the face of increasing perils from Japan's air and naval attacks along all China's 2,150-mile coastline.

Representatives of A. F.-of L./ teamsters rejected tonight an offer of C. I. 0. longshoremen and warehousemen to settle a jurisdictional fight threatening waterfront paralysis here. Both sides called sessions to map future strategy.

The Bell Rangers and the Delray teams rode into the final round of the 12goal Autumn plates tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today. The Rangers turned back the Fox Hunters, 9 to 6, and Delray defeated Broad Hollow, 8 to 7.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order permitting effectiveness of amendments made on, July 17 by the Consolidated Funds Corporation, Delaware, to a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 in December, 1933. and dismissed proceedings questioning the sufficiency of the original statement and earlier amendments.

Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and president of the Reichsbank, returned hurriedly to Berlin today, apparently without having patched up his reported differences with Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

The net profit of the Climax Molybdenum Company and subsidiaries for the five months ended on May 31 last amounted to $3,331,197 after depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and other charges, according to the report announced yesterday.

Charges in a National Labor Relations Board report that the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce had encouraged the "runaway shop". were termed "ridiculous" yesterday by Howard E. Galvin, executive vice president of the chamber, who in turn accused the board of being partial to labor and indifferent to employers.
Paul Junior, rugged lightweight from Lewiston, Me., and Al Roth of the Bronx fought a draw in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

Steel companies in the United States continue to expect a gradually rising trend in new business this month, but there is a question whether volume demand will come in sufficient time to forestall a decline in the ingot-production rate over the next few weeks, The Iron Age says this week.

Because Brazil is a poor country, a central reserve bank is an imperative necessity to help stabilize the nation's economy, supervise the currency, .control the national credit by rediscounts and act as guardian of bank reserves, said Finance Minister Arthur de Souza Costa today.

The Daily Times said in a copyrighted article today that "in uniforms strangely suggestive of those worn by Adolf Hitler's Nazi Storm Troops, a relatively small but rapidly growing army is preparing for the American counterpart of 'Der Tag,' when it plans to seize control of the United States."

John L. Lewis's C. I. O. reached out today to embrace State federations of labor discarded by the American Federation of Labor. John Brophy, C. I. 0. director,' announced that the Lewis organization had decided to charter the West Virginia State Federation of Labor, driven from the A. F. of La. for refusing to purge its ranks of C. I. O. local unions.

A boycott against all German Nazi journalists in Upper Silesia has been declared in Katowice by the local press association, effective today. The Katowice association has asked the Warsaw General Journalists Association to support and extend the boycott.
Farm Administration officials made public today a list of thirty-two farm benefit payment recipients who received more than $10,000 for participating in the 1936 soil conservation program.

The American Communications Association, formerly known as the American Radio Telegraphists Association, filed charges of unfair labor practices yesterday against the Western Union Telegraph Company with Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the NLRB.

The annual exhibition of the Ridgefield Garden Club was held on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. George Doubleday this afternoon. The judges for the exhibition were Mrs. Samuel Seabury of New York and East Hampton, Mrs. Warren Kinney of Morristown, N. J.; Mrs.
Philip Block, executive director of the American Ort Organization, returned from Europe yesterday on the French liner Ile de France.
Tonight's performance of "La Tosca" will open the third weekend of opera at the Hippodrome. "Trovatore" will be given tomorrow, "The Barber of Seville" Sunday night.

China's most prominent intellectuals appealed today to "the peoples of the world to pool their material, spiritual and moral strength to help China deal a death blow to Japanese militarism so that justice, law and morality may be vindicated and the spirit of aggression may be destroyed."

Regret at the blow to Japan's trade that will result from the current conflict in China was expressed today by Chokyo Kadono of Tokyo, chairman of the Japanese economio mission that recently toured Europe and America. Mr. Kadono arrived here on the liner Empress of Britain.
Prince Fumimaro Konoe, Premier, issued in the name of the Government tonight the following message to the Japanese people:

Today's session of the Arab congress at Bloudan was devoted to the election of committees. The political committee is headed by Nuri Pasha Said, former Premier of Iraq, and includes twenty-five other members. Nuri has not yet arrived, but is expected tomorrow.

Assemblyman Pritchard H. Strong distributed one-tenth of his estimated $2,500,000 estate to two Rochester institutions under his will, filed for probate here today. The bulk of the estates of the Assemblyman and Mrs. Strong were left in trust for their only daughter, Ann Emerson Strong, aged 9.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today a further decline in its index level of wholesale commodity prices in the week ended on Sept. 4. The official index, based on the 1926 average as 100, declined to 86.4 from last week's 86.5.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip Ammidown were among those who gave dinners last night at the opening for the season of Mon Paris. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Carl Schuster, Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Heminway, Miss Ann Curie and John Duff.

Seven naval vessels-the battleships New York and Texas, the new gunboat Erie and the four old destroyers J. Fred Talbott, Jacob Jones, Dahlgren and Roper-will be anchored in the Hudson River from about Sept. 19 to 24 during the American Legion convention, naval officials here said yesterday.
Moderate improvement extended over a broad list of domestic bonds, including United States Government issues, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Joseph Wasserman, who for many years headed the Artloom Corporation of Philadelphia, manufacturers of seamless Wilton rugs, died on Wednesday night at the Peter Brigham Hospital in Boston. Mr. Wasserman, who retired from business about a year ago, became ill at his Summer home in Falmouth, Mass. His age was 79.

The Spanish Government disclosed tonight it had taken steps to check the fall of the peseta in foreign markets by stamping all currency taken out of the country. It attributed the weakness of the Government currency to illegal exportations for speculation.

Representative James M. Mead of Buffalo indicated in a speech today that he might become a candidate for the Senate. Addressing the convention of the National Federation of Postoffice Clerks, Mr. Mead lamented the difficulty of getting certain House-approved measures to the Senate floor.

Hamilton Pl, 105. 16.3x61.2x15.2x54.10; Annie L. Ricker to Katie Capsis and Tony F. Chapas, 105 Hamilton Pl; mtg $6,250 ($1). Same property: Katle Capsis and another to Beatrice Goldstein, 1,162 53d St, Brooklyn; mtg $6,250.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Woodruff Folsom of 70 South Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Constance Folsom, to Montague T. Smith, son of Mrs. Edward O. Smith of Montclair, N. J., and the late Mr. Smith.

London delegates departing for the Mediterranean "piracy" conference opening at Nyon today, hoped to prevent Russia from continuing her quarrel with Italy in its session. Britain has no wish to accentuate the division of Europe into two camps. Foreign Secretary Eden will make practical suggestions, probably favoring a declaration by all the powers at the parley authorizing attacks on submarines interfering with peaceful shipping.

It was learned here today that Mordka Zylberberd, a Jewish merchant of this city, had died mysteriously in a Danzig jail. After arriving in the Free City on business, Mr. Zylberberd was arrested by the Gestapo [Nazi Secret Police] for "racial defilement" when he was seen talking to some German women. All attempts to obtain his release failed.

Mrs. Anna J. Hollenback, mother of William M. Hollenback, former allAmerican football player at the University of Pennsylvania, died of pneumonia tonight in her apartment at the Hotel Philadelphian. She was 75 years old.

Owing to the absence of Japanese competition and weak support by United States interests, the prices of Monday's wool sales declined 5 to 7 1/2 per cent for the best sorts, and 10 to 15 per cent for others compared with the previous Monday. Clearance, too, was only 65 per cent.

John Roosevelt left the family estate by motor early today for Boston. With him were Miss Anne Lindsay Clark, Boston debutante, and John Drayton, Harvard classmate who toured Europe with John during a vacation that ended yesterday. Mr. Drayton and Miss Clark were overnight guests at the Summer White House.
Miss Hortensia Odones, Puerto Rico's first woman to request a court permit to carry arms, much to her surprise found her request opposed by Prosecuting Attorney Pales Matos, locally famed as a poet.

Establishment of a commission of business men and progressive labor leaders to determine why industries move from this city will be one ol his first acts when he is elected, Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidate for the Democratic Mayoralty nomination, said yesterday.

Senator Royal S. Copeland resumed the role of anti-New Deal crusader yesterday after dropping it for forty-eight hours. He challenged Jeremiah T. Mahoney, his Democratic primary opponent, to answer a series of questions on the stand he would have taken on legislation which President Roosevelt sponsored and which the Senator opposed.
The gravamen of James T. Shotwell's letter of Sept. 7 seems to be that the Spanish Episcopacy has failed to justify the Nationalist appeal to arms in the current Spanish crisis.

Although business loans continued to expand, the total of loans and investments of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City fell $7,000,000 net in the week ended on Wednesday, covered by their condition statement issued yesterday.

Was it from affection for the original, ambition or a fondness for illustrious names that the United States has nineteen villages, towns or cities called Paris? South Paris Village, on the New Androscoggin River in Maine, may be called a colony of the mother metropolis, Paris, of which it is a part.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date, while note circulation was at the highest.

Patrolman William Kurz of the Flushing precinct in Queens captured three confessed burglars last night virtually single-handed, holding two of them at bay for about ten minutes while the third, handcuffed to him, struggled to foil his efforts and to free himself.

While the total of all awards for engineering construction made during the week ended yesterday bettered the same week of last year by 5 per cent, with a figure of $36,868,000, private construction contracts, amounting to $15,746,000, were 101 per cent above the 1936 week.

KEEP politics out of baseball. That's what Joseph Edward Cronin says, with tears in his eyes. The manager of the platinum-plated Fenway Millionaires says that his club might have gone somewhere this year except that some gents in Yankee uniforms evidently had been reading political news and had taken that Soakthe-Rich chorus of the hustings as their theme song on the diamond.

Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif.; Frank Parker of New York, Mlle. Jadwiga Jedrzejowska of Poland, and Miss Helen Jacobs of Berkeley all came through to the semi-finals of the national championships without the loss of a set among them yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

Miss Hope Knowles of Philadelphia and Miss Polly Morrill of Boston advanced, today to the semi-finals in the girls' national tennis doubles championships today, beating Miss Christine Waples of Chicago and Miss Marian Chester of Milwaukee, 6-2. 6-0.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the membership of the late Bancroft Smith had been transferred to Arthur J. Low at Leopold Spingarn Co., and that of Robert A. Montgomery to Edward D. Untermyer of Prescott, Biggar Co.
A woman, listed by the police as a suicide, was responsible for an explosion and fire yesterday afternoon which threw a thickly populated section of East Sixteenth Street into turmoil.

Construction of a. 115,000-horsepower steam generating plant soon will be undertaken by the Niagara Hudson Public Service Corporation (to be renamed the Central New York Power Corporation) at a site in Central New York, according to an announcement.

Grand Concourse (11-2809), s e cor of Echo Pl, 104x122; Martha Beerman to Essex Estates. Inc, 292 Madison Ave; mtg $150,000. Washington Ave, 1,384 (11-2910); 1,384 Washington Ave Corp to Audica Properties, Inc, 384 E 149th St; mtg $12,500. 139th St, 589 E (10-2552); Anton Heiss to Samuel I. Cole, 74 Winter Ave, New Brighton. S. I.

Acquisition of Clarence Nachand, right-handed outfielder, from the Bees as part payment for Max West was announced today by the San b Francisco Missions. West, an outfielder, went to Boston for an unannounced sum plus Nachand.

An order authorizing the appointment of Stanley Roth as a vice president of the Schulte Retail Stores Corporation, D. A. Schulte, Inc., of New York and D. A. Schulte, Inc., of Delaware, at a salary of $20,000 for the year, was signed yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox.

Grass, ducks and a home-made xylophone entertained the Duke of Windsor today at this his second honeymoon castle. He scythed the long grass on the castle grounds. He bagged four ducks in an impromptu hunting trip on the Tisza River last night.

Hone Ave, 2,936; dwelling, 24.6x100: Home Owners Loan Corp against Maria Lambias; due, $8,936; to plaintiff for $5,000. By JAMES R. MURPHY Westcnester Ave, 1,101; 5-story brick tenement and stores, 91.llx48xirreg; Chemical Bank and Trust Co, trustee. against Marbert Realty Co: due, $56,113;

The Treasury and Postoffice Departments announced today joint approval of 319 public building projects authorized under a $70,000,000 emergency construction fund approprtated at the last session of Congress.
The Spanish Insurgents recently bought four submarines, which are now operating in the Mediterranean, it was asserted by General Gonzalo Queipo De Llano in an interview tonight.
The third-place White Sox made a clean sweep of the two-game series with the Browns, defeating the cellardwellers today, 9 to 8.

Regulations for the health and physical education program in the public schools of New York State to protect the health of school children have been adopted by the State Department of Education, Dr. Hiram A. Jones, director of the State Health and Physical Education Department, disclosed yesterday.

Twelve Westchester country clubs will give a reception and dinner to Felix M. Warburg, chairman of the executive board of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City, and Mrs. Warburg at the Beach Point Club, Mamaroneck, N. Y., tomorrow at 7 P. M., it was announced yesterday.
A squad of eighteen men reported to Coach Nelson Nitchman and his assistant, Walter Nelson, for the first practice of the Union College football team today.

Philip F. Donohue, treasurer of Tammany Hall for thirty-five years, who died on Aug. 15, left an estate of less than $10,000. This was learned yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Sunrogate's Court.

Walter E. O'Hara, central figure in a battle with Governor Robert E. Quinn over the managing directorship of the Narragansett race track, was arrested late last night on two charges of criminal libel. Early today he pleaded innocent to both charges and was released on a total of $10,000 bail.

Japan's merchants have already lost to American traders more than $150,000,000 worth of orders because of the undeclared war in China, according to Dr. Alfred Lum, member of the Central Executive Committee of the Nanking Government, who arrived here today.

The Japanese Government is reported to desire to furnish free radio sets to families of soldiers serving in the North China campaign, so they may hear the official broadcasts on the situation at the front.

Uncle Robert, who has spent the last thirty years in behalf of underprivileged children and afflicted adults, celebrated his seventy-fourth birthday yesterday with a dozen patients in the children's ward at Bronx Hospital, 169th Street and Fulton Avenue.
The Grand Army of the Republic voted late today to join Conferedate veterans in a Blue-Gray reunion at Gettysburg, Pa., next Summer.

William M. Lee of Detroit, a dealer in securities, occupied the witness stand at the Securities and Exchange Commission's hearing yesterday against the Trenton Valley Distillers Corporation and testified to his share in the underwriting of 273,000 shares of $1 par-value stock.

International events have intruded to an unexpected extent upon the National Socialist congress here. The complications arising from the Mediterranean situation obviously are giving Chancellor Adolf Hitler and his advisers a good deal of concern.
Leading producers of sheets, pillowcases, and sheetings announced extension of discounts yesterday which brought reductions ranging up to 8 per cent on net prices.

More than 51,000 accounts of $10 or more, amounting to $5,413;790, unclaimed for at least fifteen years and held by State-chartered banks, trust companies, private bankers and savings banks, have been listed by 440 banking institutions to the State Banking Department, according to a report made public yesterday.

This city is suffering from its most extensive epidemic of infantile i paralysis since 1918, when 300 cases were reported. Two hundred and eighty persons have been attacked since the end of June, including nine adults. Only two of the children stricken were more than 12 years old. There have been twentytwo deaths, including five adults, but respirators have saved many lives.

A city-wide strike of cleaners, dyers, retail tailors and others in allied trades, which is expected to affect 20,000 workers, will be started on Monday morning at 8 o'clock, according to an announcement yesterday by Alexander Hoffman, director of an organization drive in that field.

Expressing concern over continued budget increases which he said had raised the cost of city government here from $39.09 per capital in 1913 to $86.08 in 1932, Clarke G. Daily, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, issued a statement yesterday deploring "the probability that attention will be diverted from the 1938 budget during the current municipal campaign."
Retail package deliveries for the week ended Sept. 4 registered a decrease of 7 per cent under the corresponding week a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service.
The engagement of Miss Mary Frances Lyman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Homer C. Lyman of Winchester, Va., to Richard Stevenson Hawkey of this city has been announced here by her parents.
The Navy Department announced today the death at Pensacola of Lieutenant Claude W. Hughes from injuries received in an airplane crash at the Naval Air Station there on Tuesday.

Yermie Stern, organizer of the Casino de Paree, night club, now closed, filed a libel suit yesterday in Federal court against Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., which, he alleges damaged him and the club to the extent of $1,000,000 in its picture, "Go Into Your Dance."
Governor Blanton Winship, before departing for Washington today, said he would lay: before Secretary of Interior Harold L. Ickes plans for developing the island's tourist trade.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Aug. 28 totaled 309,506,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.
The Interstate Commerce Commission heard today two pleas for a breakup of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad System. The proposals were made at a hearing on reorganization of the carrier.

A new astronomical mystery, revealed by a "candid camera" of the skies, was presented to members of the American Astronomical Society, meeting today at Williams College, when Dr. Charles H. Smiley of Brown University displayed photographs which he had taken from the mountains of Peru of the total eclipse m June.

Although it seemed as if the Red Sox tried hard to present yesterday's encounter at the Stadium to the Yankees, the proud American League-leaders wouldn't accept charity and in the end crumpled before Joe Cronin's athletes as a sixgame winning streak was broken.

Miss Hilda Clausen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George U. Clausen of 823 Park Avenue, was married yesterday morning to Selden Rodman, editor and writer of this city, in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building.

The marriage of Miss Helen Elizabeth Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Martin of 923 Eightysecond Street, Brooklyn, to Ernest Sackville Turner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Turner of Glasgow, Scotland, took place last night in the Union Church of Bay Ridge.
The Securities and Exchange Commission today called a hearing for Sept. 21 on an amendment by Minnesota Utilities Company of Savanna, Ill., a subsidiary of American Utilities Service Corporation.

The story of a remarkable mother who exerted great influence on Roscoe Conkling was unfolded today by Ellis Baldwin of The Utica Observer Dispatch in an address before the State Historical Association, holding its annual meeting here.

The investigation into the theft of jewelry valued at $30,500 from Miss Luella Gear, musical comedy actress, and Mrs. John W. Kiser at the Kiser estate Monday, continued today without any tangible clues to work on.

The Senators won both ends of a double-header with the Athletics today, 13-6 and 12-10. Seven runs in the fifth, inning of the opener and nine in the third of the nightcap virtually clinched both games.

Frank A. Weber, as executor under the will of Christian Weber, sold to the Diamond Alkali Company -as a site for a factory the vacant parcel at Carroll Avenue, Thorne Street and Tonnele Avenue, Jersey City. The parcel has a frontage of 205 feet on Carroll Avenue, 291 feet on Thorne Street, and 50 feet on Tonnele Avenue.

" The twentieth World Zionist Congress marked the turning point not only in the history of the Zionist movement, but also in the international renaissance of the whole Jewish people," Louis Segal, general secretary of the Jewish National Workers Alliance, declared at the opening session of the annual conference of the organization's New York branches at the Pennsylvania Hotel last night.

Negotiations looking toward the unfreezing of more than $1,140,000 in American funds tied up in Nicaragua by exchange restrictions, will be launched at the close of this month by the National Foreign Trade Council, Inc., officials indicated yesterday.

Business failures declined in all five groups in the week ended Sept. 2, compared with the figures for the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Retail failures dropped one under last year's total, but were slightly ahead of those in the previous week. The detailed report is as follows:

With rain reported at ninety-seven stations in the Cotton Belt following almost daily showers for more than two weeks, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered nearly $1 a bale yesterday to end with gains of 4 to 10 points.

The center Groton district school situation, where two teachers are doing the job of one, kept a furrow in the brow of Groton officialdom today, but it was not bothering the twenty-two boys and girls who spent their second day under dual instructions.

Farm Administration officials warned sugar beet and cane growers today that they must comply with the child labor provisions of the new sugar act to qualify for benefit payments therein provided. The ban on child labor became effective when President Roosevelt signed the sugar act of 1937 on Sept. 1.
For the second day in a row Frank H. Van Winkle sailed his Themis II home a winner today in the International Star Class at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's annual Fall series.

Despite the intrusion of international affairs the program of the National Socialist Congress here is being fulfilled just as if all were peaceful in Southern Europe. An outstanding development in today's proceedings was an intimation that Germany hereafter is going in for sports nationally and in a large way.
The text of the Italian reply to the Anglo-French invitation to a Mediterranean anti-piracy conference follows:

Henrl Solliez, who as secretary to the chief steward of the French liner Paris was said to have had a free run of the entire vessel during her last voyage, was in the Federal House of Detention last night following the discovery of 178 ounces of heroin valued at $20,000 in his cabin.
Detective Captain Joseph Linarducci .Jr. of the Essex County Prosecutor's staff, who ran down and killed a 16-year-old boy...

Now that Germany and Italy have refused to attend the "piracy" conference opening in Switzerland tomorrow the chief anxiety here is that Russia may delay or prevent its success by recriminations against the fascist powers.

Richard C. Congdon, an engineer long prominent in the manufacture of gas, who was in charge of the Nassau and Suffolk Lighting Company's gas-making plant at Hempstead, L. I., died today at Nassau Hospital here of pneumonia after an operation.

Phillip Mack, 46, Hamden insurance agent who dropped from sight June 7, walked into the Hamden police station at 4 o'clock this morning. Officers said he was "in terrible shape" physically and he was immediately taken to St. Raphael's Hospital in New Haven.

Captain Antonio Lena brought the Italian liner Conte di Savoia into harbor for the last time yesterday, marking the end of a forty-fiveyear career on the sea. The veteran shipmaster reaches the retirement age of 60 this month and will leave the merchant marine on his return to Genoa.
Japanese interests have recently attempted to obtain control of manganese deposits in Panama and are reported interested in manganese in Costa Rica, according to The Panama American.

Miss Mary Theresa McDonald, daughter of Mrs. William Francis McDonald of this city and the late Mr. McDonald, was married to Paul Thomas Sheridan, also of this city, yesterday morning in the Church of Our Lady of Lourdes by the Rev. Louis Cusack of Kingston, N. Y., an uncle of the bridegroom.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull made amply clear today that the United States Government would protect its nationals in China to the limit of its ability and that it intended to retain its military and naval forces in the Far East during the Sino-Japanese emergency.

Dr. Ernest F. McVane, prominent surgeon, died suddenly at his home here this afternoon soon after he had completed an operation on a patient. Death was believed due to a heart ailment. His age was 57.

Broad-shouldered Ralph Flanagan, 20-year-old Olympic veteran from Miami, crammed four record-smashing performances into one race today as he outclassed his field to win the Amateur Athletic Union's one-mile swimming championship for the third straight year.

At the request of the defense lawyer, Judge Wallace in' General Sessions yesterday postponed until Nov. 15 the trial of Robert Edward Edmondson, 65-year-old pamphleteer, accused in an indictment of having libeled in 1936 Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, and the Jewish religion.

F. Trubee Davison Jr., eldest son of F. Trubee Davison, president of the American Museum of Natural History, and Mrs. Davison, died at 7:45 o'clock last night in Harkness Pavilion, Presbyterian Hospital, of leukemia, a rare blood disease, after an illness of several months. He was 15 years old and was a pupil at Groton School for Boys, at Groton, Mass.

The marriage of Miss Mary Sue Anderson, daughter of Dr. T. B. H. Anderson, medical director of the United States Marine Hospital here, and Mrs. Anderson, to Preston B. Hundley, son of Dr. Preston G. Hundley of Lynchburg, Va., took place this evening in Grace Methodist Episcopal Church. The Rev. Robert Lee Wright officiated.

Exports and imports of the United States by classified groups of merchandise in July, as announced by the Department of Commerce, are compared with those of the preceding month and with July, 1936. Exports as given cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods reexported.

The Bank of Canada reported today that its notes in circulation rose from $148,414,558 to $152,475,547 in the week ended yesterday and that its holdings of sterling and United States dollars increased from $25,802,905 to $28,072,006.

Charging that the shoe industry here is threatened by heavy importations of cemented shoes from Czechoslovakia, the board of directors of the National Shoe Retailers at a meeting here yesterday adopted a resolution urging the State Department in its negotiations of a reciprocal trade agreement with that country "not to lower the existing duties as set forth in the Tariff Act of 1930, nor to agree to a binding of such duties."
The Rev. Michael J. McGlue, a curate at St. -Patrick's Roman Catholic Cathedral here, died yesterday at St. Michael's Hospital, after a long illness, of a heart ailment. He was 39 years old.
Miss Bette Perry Edgar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Arthur Edgar of Bryn Mawr, was married this afternoon to John Dorrance Warriner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Dexter Warriner of Philadelphia.

A company has been formed in Hamburg for catching sharks in West Indian waters and utilizing the various parts of the fish for leather, oil and fishmeal, all in connection with the Nazi Four-Year Plan. The concern, titled the Experimental Company for Shark and Deep Sea Fishing, has been launched with a capital of 200,000 marks.
The oldest war story in existence was reincarnated at Shanghai yesterday-the life of a Japanese soldier was saved when his mother's photograph stopped a bullet.

City vehicular traffic is more dangerous than wild beasts of the jungle, Frank Buck, animal hunter, and R. Cheyne Stout, director of the Central and Prospect Park Zoos, agreed yesterday afternoon after the automobile in which they 5 were riding was crushed at 1 P. M. between a Seventh Avenue trolley car and an elevated pillar on Flatbush Avenue near Hanson Place, Brooklyn.

The residents of Marble Bar, a small mining township in Northwest Australia containing 300 people and known as the hottest place in Australia, where the average temperature throughout the year is 96 degrees Fahrenheit and Summer temperatures range up to 120 degrees, have been "on the waterwagon" because of a beer strike for the last three months, as a protest against prices.

Mr. and Mrs. Reginald B. Lanier have come from Newport to the St. Regis. Mr. and Mrs. William J. Hutchinson and members of their family are returning Sunday from Seal Harbor, Me., where they passed the Summer, and will be at Hale Place, Mendham, N. J., for several weeks before coming to 720 Park Avenue.

Walter Lovell of Bay Shore, L. I., who was an- aviator in the Lafayette Escadrille during the World War, died today on his fifty-third birthday in the Southside Hospital here, after an illness of three months.

Harry Hollins Bowly died last night at Homeopathic Hospital, East Orange, at the age of 82. Before his retirement ten years ago he had been employed as an assistant engineer for the Jersey City Street and Water Department.

The marriage of Miss Helen E. Roughan, niece of Mrs. Edward Brennan of this city, to Dr. Joseph A. Villa, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Villa, also of Hartford, took place yesterday in St. Lawrence O'Toole's Church.

In vestors place an almost complete reliance on credit ratings of municipal bonds which is not justified by any rating service now in existence, Gaylord C. Cummin of Reynolds Co., New York, declared today at the second session of the annual convention of the National Security Traders Association, held in the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel here, No rating at all is better than the present inaccurate ratings, Mr. Cummin maintained.
A greater than seasonal decline took place in lumber production last week, and the adjusted index has eased to 81.8 from 82.9. This compares with 86.9 for the week ended Sept. 5, 1936.

The number of dead heats, which have become common since the advent of the camera, was increased yesterday at Aqueduct when Encore and Specify finished so closely locked in the featured Kittewake Purse that neither the judges nor the camera could separate them, and for once there was little dissatisfaction with the machine.
Luncheon, Fashion Group, Biltmore Hotel, 12:30 P. M. Speakers: Marjorie Castle, Florence Cavanaugh, Maud Moody. Marian Stephenson.

Dr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Locke of Boston and Williamstown have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Swann Locke, to Vanderpoel Adriance Jr. of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. Vanderpoel Adriance of Williamstown.

Despite his recent rejection of support by Nazis in this city, Senator Copeland again was endorsed by that party, according to an editorial appearing yesterday in the Deutscher Weckruf und Beobachter, official organ of the Nazi party in the United States. The weekly declared that the Nazis would not "compromise with La Guardia and Mahoney."
Colonel Edward Hall Teall, president of the Homer P. Snyder Manufacturing Company of this city, died today in Cooperstown Hospital after several months' illness. He was 52 years old.

Holders of the Dreferred stock of Continental Shares, Inc.. received yesterday a letter from a committee of such holders headed by George H. Charls, proposing a plan of reorganization for the company.

DURING the chilly days of last Winter Elmer Adler, the Pynson Printer and venerable editor of the quarterly Colophon, confronted twenty of his former contributors with a questionnaire. He was planning to gather from The Colophon the essays these twenty had written on their early literary experiences, and he wanted data on methods of composition to put beside them.
News from the center of the solar system is getting to be almost as contradictory as from the Spanish fronts.

A crowd estimated at close to 200,000 persons witnessed the Festival of Floats on the Boardwalk this afternoon. The parade is one of the features of the annual jubilee which includes the beauty and talent contest to select "Miss America."
A colorful field of forty-one teams started play today in the third annual tournament for the Mrs. William Goadby Loew Challenge Cup at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club.

American correspondents who listened to the speech of Dr. Otto Dietrich, Nazi press chief, on freedom of the press yesterday without taking it too seriously in view of long acquaintance with him are forming here the Most Noble Order of Journalistic Vultures, with its first Eyrie in Berlin.

Three "wreckers" were shot in the Zolochev region of the Ukraine following conviction on charges of antiSoviet activities against the collective farm program. They were the chief of a tractor station, the chairman of a collective farm and the chief of the regional agricultural department.
Secretary Wallace told 2,000 New Hampshire- and Vermont farmers today that the New England farm situation was better than that of any other section.

The four-masted schooner Alvena of Portland, Me., was towed out of Port Newark this morning without its captain and mate, W. W. Torrey and C. H. McDonough. The air was blue with nautical language when those two worthies returned from a shopping trip and found the Alvena missing.
The theft of $24,000 in jewelry from the Summer home at Narragansett Pier of H. H. Ramsay, New York City lawyer, was being investigated today.

Canon Burnett Hillman Streeter, provost of Queens College, Oxford, and his wife were believed to have been two of three persons killed when an airplane on the Berne-Basle route crashed today in the Jura Mountains in a fog. The third victim was Pilot Willi Eberschweller.

John F. Tinker, retired New York police lieutenant, died here today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Morgan Andrews. Mr. Tinker, who retired about ten years ago, was in the police department for thirty-six years.

The American National Retail Jewelers Association will become a member of the American Retail Federation, Charles T. Evans, secretary, announced yesterday. The executive committee voted to accept the invitation of the A. R. F. following the association's recent convention here.

Directors of the Alleghany and Chesapeake Corporations decided at a meeting here yesterday to appeal against an injunction issued by the Federal court in Baltimore against a proposed, merger of the two corporations.

The rush for apartments was accompanied yesterday by leases of several dwellings. Cornelis De Wilde leased from Robert Oppenheim the three-story residence on a lot 20 by 100 feet at 324 West Eighty-fifth Street. Bracher Hubert were the brokers.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Mae Cunningham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howell Chestnut Cunningham of this place, to Donald Holman Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Melville Parker of Englewood, N., J., took place here this afternoon in St. John's Evangelist Episcopal Church.

Yesterday's grain crop estimates by the Government were, as was expected from some unfavorable August weather, reduced from those of a month ago. But the decrease in estimated yield for the five major grain crops was only 108,000,000 bushels, or barely 21/3 per cent.

It has been clear from the beginning that the forthcoming "voluntary registration" of the unemployed will be worthless. It will supply us with no information that we do not already possess. We already know how many persons are on relief.

Grand National will present "The Shadow Strikes," first in a series of four pictures based on the Maxwell Grant stories, this evening at the Central Theatre. Rod LaRocque is the Shadow of the title and others involved include Lynn Anders, James Blakely, Kenneth Harlan, Walter McGrail and John St. Polls.
Going straight through from his first class, the American-bred dog Sandy of Craiglea today was awarded the best in show title at the annual specialty fixture of the Brussels Griffon Club of America.

The Republican National Committee received, $181,6864.07 in contributions between June 1 and Aug. 31, it reported to the Clerk of the House of Representatives today. Of this amount, $153,259.34 represented gifts of more than $100, while those of less than $100 totaled $16,052.22.

All of the 230 newsstands operated in the Interborough and B. M. T. stations by the Collier Service Corporation and the Collier Advertising Service, Inc., were closed yesterday by a strike of about 400 employes that inconvenienced thousands of subway passengers.

The New York State Historical Association ended the four-day program of its annual meeting today by unanimously endorsing the proposal of the State Historian, Dr. Alexander C. Flick, to petition the Governor and Legislature to authorize the erection of a State Archives Building in Albany.

Although the details of the largescale public housing program to be initiated under the Wagner-Steagall bill have not yet been worked out, it appears likely that many important model housing projects conceived but later abandoned under the PWA plan will now be revived.

A good-will flight of three Cuban and one Dominican airplane will begin a tour of Central and South American countries, Mexico, the United States and Canada Oct. 12, with a view to promoting early construction of a gigantic lighthouse and flying field at Punta Torrecilla, Dominican Republic, where Columbus is believed to, have first landed in this hemisphere.

Miss Anne Miller and Miss Nancy Victor, daughters of Mrs. J. Morris Miller of Glen Cove and Mrs. Royall Victor of Syosset and New York, were introduced tonight at a dinner dance given by their mothers at the Creek Club in Lattingtown.

Several hundred additional members and guests of the National Security Traders Association from New York, Boston, Cleveland and Philadelphia arrived here this morning to participate in the association's "field day" at the Sea View Golf Club.
Mrs. Mary C. Hart, mother of William Dickinson Hart and Reeves Welch Hart of Stamford, died yesterday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Brison Howie of New Rochelle.
The next few weeks will find the New England States preparing for the arrival of the late anglers and the early hunters, and according to reports they are expected to arrive in droves.

The Building Service Employes International Union, Local 32-B, which called a strike of workers in ten buildings on Thursday, starting its "major move" to complete the organization of workers in 250 Manhattan structures, plans to call out employes in twenty-five additional buildings on Monday, it was disclosed yesterday.
Robert F. Milligan, former Mayor of Saratoga Springs, died this afternoon at his residence, 102 Circular Street. He was 82 years old.

Two armed men held up Miss Betty Falk, 27 years old, cashier of the Hollywood Hat Company at 65 West Thirty-ninth Street, yesterday afternoon, forced her to hand over a payroll of $2,200, and escaped.

Chester Pearce, 32-year-old roofer, of 626 Carlyle Place, Union Township, was under arrest tonight as a fugitive from justice in connection with the slaying in 1927 of May Belle Matheson, 19 years old, of West Roxbury, Mass. Her bludgeoned body was found in a swamp in West Roxbury, a Boston suburb, on Jan. 22 of that year.

Theta Sigma Phi, national honorary journalistic society for women, opened a two-day regional convention yesterday at the Hotel Lincoln. Arranged by alumnae groups in New York and vicinity, the convention is being attended by undergraduate delegates from Syracuse, Pennsylvania State, Temple and New York Universities.

Morocco will occupy from 10,000 to 35,000 square feet at the 1939 World's Fair and the Moroccan Government will spend 1,500,000 francs for its exhibition, according to Henri Amieux, former president of the Chamber of Agriculture of Casablanca, Morocco, who arrived here last week to arrange for the construction of the Moroccan pavilion and was interviewed yesterday at the Hotel Astor, in his headquarters.
The increase in cotton-mill activity last week was a little larger than seasonal, and the adjusted index has moved to 135.0 from 134.5. This compares with 129.6 for the week ended Sept. 5. 1936.
Reflecting to some extent the unsettlement in security markets generally, the volume of new bond financing this week dwindled to $4,515,000 and was restricted exclusively to the tax-exempt field.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is co-paying agent for $1,500,000 of certificates and dividend warrants of the Chicago Great Western Railroad 3 1/2 per cent equipment trust certificates, Series D.

The Arab Congress at Bloudan ended tonight. Palestine demands were repeated today in resolutions adopted by the congress. They are: 1. Palestine is an inseparable part of the Arab countries. 2. To refuse the partition scheme and the establishment of a Jewish State.

Following many recent changes in the administrative organization of the WPA Federal Theatre Project, the appointment of George Kondolf as director for New York City was announced yesterday by Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, national director.

A break in the stock market yesterday, the largest since 1933 and rivaling - that of Tuesday, sent prices tumbling to new low levels. Losses of 2 to 10 points were suffered by the leading issues, while prices in inactive stocks were forced down as much as 20 points.

The fiftieth anniversary of the Bristol-Myers Company was celebrated yesterday with a "Golden Jubilee" salesmen's convention at the Hotel Biltmore. The company began business Dec. 13, 1887 at Clinton, N. Y., under the name of the Clinton Pharmaceutical Company. In 1900,

The unusual sight of refugee ships leaving and entering Shanghai was afforded yesterday. The steamer Elephant departed carrying 900 Sikhs and their wives and children. These great-bearded, turbaned and swarthy men who have been a familiar Shanghai sight, employed as policemen and watchmen, are being taken to Calcutta via Hong Kong on a steamer operated by the Government of India--probably never to return.

Magistrates who hold accused criminals on evidence obtained by the police without search warrants are proceeding in accordance with the State Constitution, Magistrate Rudich said yesterday in a statement issued in answer to recent criticism of such action by Supreme Court Justice McGeehan of the Bronx.
Vandalism marked the strike of 13,000 painters in Manhattan, the Bronx. Brooklyn and Richmond yesterday while negotiations were under way with prospects of a settlement.

Let today's first item concern Miss Joan Bennett, of cinema fame, who has decided to return to what still is called the legitimate. For it was announced yesterday that she is to head the touring company of the Edna Ferber-George S. Kaufman "Stage Door," filling the role originated on Broadway last year by Margaret Sullavan.

Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius has returned from Hot Springs, Va., and will be at The Shelter, her place in Locust Valley, for the Autumn. Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Vietor of Mayfair House will return from California next week.

Larry Kelley, Yale's All-America opportunist, concluded his football-playing career in spectacular fashion tonight when his All-Star collegians scored a 14-0 victory over the Shamrocks, Boston's American Professional League team, before 8,000 spectators at Fenway Park.

Esther Mite, owned by the Good Time Stable, Goshen, N. Y., and driven by Harold Dill, scored an upset in the 2-year-old consolation trot, feature of the closing Grand Circuit program at the State Fair today. After splitting the first two heats with Long Key, the property of E. J. Merckle, Columbus, Ohio, Esther Mite surprised by coming from behind to capture the run-off by a head.

Internal troubles, like those that forced the surrender of Santander last month, were reported in Insurgent dispatches tonight to be hastening the fall of Gijon, the last Governmentheld' seaport on the Bay of Biscay.

The committee studying reform of the covenant of the League of Nations reopened its sessions today with Carlos Edwards of Chile insisting more strongly than ever upon preliminary consultation with all nonLeague members with a view to achieving universal membership.

The sailors of the United States cruiser Augusta gave a minstrel show last night at the city's largest theatre, devoting 'the proceeds from the packed house to the relief of the hundreds of Chinese and Russian children they have made their special wards.

The number of shares sold in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday, the day after a wide break in values, exceeded the number of shares bought, according to statistics made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A resolution opposing the establishment of camps, organizations and societies which aim to "encourage and instill allegiance to foreign powers and governments" was adopted here today at the State Convention of the American Legion.
The Federal Reserve Board reported today August department store sales increased 4 per cent over the same month last year. Percentage changes by Federal Reserve districts were listed as follows:

The marriage of Miss Barbara Wiley, daughter of Mrs. Albert Bruton Strange of this. city and Bernardsville, N. J., and of the lath Channing Price Wiley of Salem; Va., to Edwin Lex Bacon of New York took place yesterday afternoon in the chantry of St. Thomas Church.
The Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Trophy is on its way down East once -again tonight, still in the possession of Miss Frances McElwain of the Cohasset Yacht Club.

Minister of Government Jose Tomas Calderon -has instructed the police to prohibit the use by saloons of names of countries, cities or persons. Cantinas in Central America often have picturesque names such as "The Hand of God" or "The Lame Duck." They are frequented by political "outs."

The Brooklyn Dodgers came from behind in the last period to defeat the Philadelphia Eagles in a National Football League game at the Municipal Stadium tonight, 13-7. Reno Nori, new quarterback from North Illinois Teachers, completed a sensational 60-yard-touchdown pass to Jeff Barrett to settle the game.

The marriage of Miss Constance Lodge, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. James Thorton Lodge of this place, to John Stanley Dey, son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Dey of Newark, took place this evening at St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church of which the bride's father is rector.

The Massachusetts National Guard team scored 1,852 out of a possible 2,000 in the first four stages of the national rifle team match, which opened today. The total places the squad in a strong position in the National Guard division of the competition.

The battle of the Duke Power Company to stop the Government from financing a $2,852,000 county-owned hydroelectric plant at Buzzard Roost, S. C., was again brought today to the Supreme Court, which returned the lawsuit to the lower courts in December for further procedure without passing on the merits of the controversy.

The Rev. Dr. Leslie D. Weatherhead, pastor of the City Congregational Temple, London, England, will address a meeting of Protestant clergymen to be held Sept. 20, at 10:30 A. M., in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at-Fifty-fifth Street.

Two winners of the six persons to receive silver cups from Mrs. J. Sergeant Cram, founder and director of the Peace House, Fifth Avenue and 109th Street, for deeds of courage without violence, were announced yesterday.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows British stocks, 699,000 bales, against 702,000 a week ago, 728,000 two weeks ago, 752,000 three weeks ago and 742,000 a year ago; of which American 220,000 bales, against 235,000 a week ago, 239,000 two weeks ago, 258,000 three weeks ago and 229,000 a year ago.

J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, said today that the receiver of the Monroe National Bank, Monroe, N. Y., had been authorized to pay a final dividend of 8.37 per cent to the creditors. This dividend will effect a distribution of $31,000 to 749 claimants who have proved claims aggregating $381,400.

For some forty years pathologists have been fighting poliomyelitis-infantile paralysis to the man in the street. To say in the light of Chicago's present epidemic and the sad experiences of many another State that no progress has been made in all that time is to deny the facts of research.

Despite the disturbing and tragic events in the East and West that have many of the characteristics of war, though without its formal declaration, one continues to hope that disaster will not come to make a mockery of such efforts for human welfare as are reviewed in Dr. Raymond B. Fosdick's first report as president of the Rockefeller Founndation.

Renting in houses on Riverside Drive featured yesterday the Fall rush for apartments. The demand for rooms also added many names to tenant rosters in buildings on Central Park West, West End Avenue and adjacent streets.

Payrolls of $580,643,012 for the first half of 1937 reported by steel companies and certain of their subsidiaries which do not produce iron or steel were 46 per cent greater than the $396,662,446 in the first half of 1936, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

Sermons will be preached tomorrow in the churches of the city in observance of the one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the adoption of the Constitution of the United States, Constitution Day being next Friday.

While cooler weather stimulated retail trade activity this week, the post-holiday pause spread to the majority of the principal wholesale markets and sales volume was estimated at only 8 to 16 per cent ahead of the figures for the corresponding period last year, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Arthur Wesley Dakin, Syracuse teacher of penmanship for more than half a century, died this morning at his home in North Syracuse. He was 79 years old. Mr. Dakin retired from Central City Business Institute only a month ago, after teaching there twenty-five years.
A six-week boycott of Sheffield Farms' up-State plants spread to seven counties today as dairymen and company officials differed over who should attend a proposed settlement conference.

Prospective tenants of Williamsburg Houses, the recently completed PWA housing project, which has been leased to the New York City Housing Authority, may gather new ideas for furnishing and decorating their apartments from exhibits which have been installed in two apartments in the group.

For the first time since it became an annual institution, the National Socialist congress was distinguished today by the presence of virtually the entire diplomatic corps represented in Berlin. There are only four absenteesthe Papal Nuncio and the Russians, for obvious reasons; the Norwegians,
Though an agreement in principle was reached yesterday at Nyon, M. Litvinoff did his best to upset the British Government's theory of the way in which the Mediterranean conference should be handled.

In the first six months of this year the W. L. Douglas Shoe Company showed a net profit of $72,701, after Federal income and undistributed profits taxes and other charges. This is equal to $1.94 each on 37,477 shares of $100-par, 7 per cent preferred stock on which dividends in arrears amount to $43.75 a share.

Charging there was a "whispering campaign" that, if he were elected Mayor, there would be no more Federal funds for New York City, Senator Royal S. Copeland, Tammany's candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, denounced last night such a report as "an absurd lie."

A group of men in the automotive industry were discussing international affairs around a table the other day in Detroit. They were asking the unanswerable questions all of us are asking: Will there be war in Europe? How long can the German economy stand the present pace and strain? Is the Spanish

American seamen seeking clearance from the National Maritime Union which will make them eligible for employment on merchant ships as members of the union will receive that privilege without trial or cost, it was announced yesterday.

The New Economics Group of N. Y. and renewals with Gary Eigner Corp, Samuel Weiss, Alec Goldberg, in 170 5th Ave; J. D. Robilotto Co, Inc, broker. Robert Cumings, in 1,133 Broadway; Hugh C. Edmiston, in 212 5th Ave; Joseph P. Ryan, John W. Robinson, Robert W. Earley, in 80-90 8th Ave; Modern Form Foundations, Inc, foundation garments, in 133 W 21st St; Anida Undergarment Co, ladies'

Counsel for Pedro Ernesto Baptista, former Mayor of Rio de Janeiro, argued today before the Supreme Military Tribunal for a reversal of his sentence of three years and four months in prison for his alleged part in the 1935 uprising.
John Dickey Jr., Philadelphia attorney, died today at his Summer home at Eastern Point Lake, near Gloucester, Mass. He was 58 years old and his home here was at 135 South Eighteenth Street.

Walter Rosberg, 46 years old, a patient at the Castle Point Veterans Hospital, Castle Point, N. Y., jumped or fell at 3:45 P. M. yesterday from the top deck of the municipal ferry-boat President Roosevelt a few minutes after the vessel had pulled out of her South Ferry slip for St. George, S. I. He was rescued by a tugboat crew and taken to Broad Street Hospital.

The marriage of Miss Peggy Morris, daughter of Mrs. Dudley Mixer Morris and the late Mr. Morris, to Russell Sherman Cate, son of Mrs. Russell D. Cate and the late Mr. Cate, took place this afternoon at the Morris home in Black Rock.

Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman, for twenty-five years the sole conductor of the Goldman Band, announces that his son, RiChard Franko Goldman, will henceforth assume duties as associate conductor of the band. His son will start at the band's series of Fall concerts at Kismet Temple, Brooklyn.
Further statistics corroborate statements that August was the best eighth month of any year since 1929, and for all time before then, for the heavy industries in this country.
The Dodgers reached into the minor leagues and obtained four pitchers and a third baseman yesterday, making deals with five clubs. Harry Eisenstat,

Although rains continued in Arkansas and Mississippi, conditions over the balance of the belt improved and pressure on the Cotton Exchange increased perceptibly yesterday. Prices moved into new low ground since October, 1933, with December selling at 8.96 cents a pound and all months ending around their low points, 14 to 16 points off.
