A new high record for production of gold was set. in the Transvaal in July, according to figures supplied to the Department of Commerce by H. Earle Russell, American Consul General.

Mrs. S. De Lancey Townsend gave a luncheon today in the Austrian Stube at Peckett's for Mrs. William H. Davis, Mrs. Charles B. Colyer, Mrs. Lawrence- Gilman, Mrs. Robert Hartshorne, Mrs. William G. Bibb, Mrs. Frederick H. Cone, Mrs. Joel S. Coffin Jr., Mrs. Philip Aston Rollins, Mrs. John F. McGuire,
Building projects submitted yesterday including plans for altering structures in Manhattan and for several new homes in communities in Queens. Details of the plans follow:

Bermuda has had one of the hottest Summers within living memory. The meteorological station's summary shows last month's mean temperature was 83.9 degrees, the highest mean for August since records were commenced in 1891.

The Representative Assembly of the Newspaper Guild of New York, the governing body of the Guild in this city, authorized last night the calling of a strike in the editorial and commercial departments of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle.
The few foreigners remaining in Nanking find themselves living in strange isolation. The Chinese are showing themselves indisposed to maintain old friendships and cordial associations.

From widely separated parts of China hundreds of Americans today were being evacuated to escape the perils of the Sino-Japanese conflict. Officials estimated 7,000 non-military Americans were in China; most of these, it is believed, will leave in the next few weeks.

Julio Pinto Gandia, president of the Nationalist party, resorted to biting today after Acting Judge Wolf held him with nine others for the attempted assassination of United States Judge Robert Cooper, continuing the defendants' bonds at $25,000 each.
Summer City Hall will be the scene this afternoon of police promotion and graduation exercises presided over by Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine.

On British Admiralty charts of the Mediterranean the nine-power Nyon cor-2:'ence this evening penciled out zones covering the usual trade routes in which it proposes henceforth to treat submarines as outlaws and so put an end to those "acts of piracy against merchant shipping" which have become byproducts of the Spanish civil war.

A wideopen struggle for the Canadian. open golf championship developed today as Lawson Little tossed his. title overboard with a 76 on the second round, while a half dozen or more sharpshooters battled to take his place.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Roy Manny of Larchmont and Mr. and Mrs. Edmund C. Stanton of Rye gave a supper dance tonight at the Apawamis Club here to introduce to society their daughters, Miss Lorraine Craven Manny and Miss Mary Lane Stanton.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has a whole town on its hands as a result of a foreclosure sale at public auction of the municipality of Progreso and 3,000-acres adjoining in the lower Rio Grande Valley, according to information received here today.

Among the seven parcels of Manhattan real estate sold yesterday at auction in the Vesey Street salesrooms were- the twelve-story Allerton Apartments at 2,889-99 Broadway and the two seven-story Earls Court and Norfolk apartments at 306-8 West Ninety-fourth Street.

DYER, ANNIE S. (March 31, 1937). Gross assets, $11,283; net, $10,211. To sons, John, George and William F. Dyer, onethird of residuary estate each. Chief assets, real estate, $9,500; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $225; miscellaneous property, $1,062; transfers, $495. Rernard Noskin. attorney. 16 Court St.
H. P. Derry, WPA employment officer here, said today about a hundred men released from WPA jobs to work in cotton fields had refused the assignments. The workers,

Clinton Ferguson, the sensational Massachusetts prep school youngster who collected three national and three Eastern divisional outboard championships a year ago, saw one of them get away from him this afternoon on the Schuylkill River.

A 1938 budget request for $34,534,748 was submitted yesterday by the Department of Sanitation to Acting Budget Director Kenneth Dayton at a public hearing. The amount sought is $5,552,606 more than the department received for 1937.

Dr. Henry Kimball Hadley, who died last Monday in New York, will be honored in memorial programs of more than 100 of the major symphonic and concert units of the WPA Federal Music Project under instructions sent today to all State directors and supervisors by Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff, national director.

By means of a new photographic emulsions extremely sensitive to red light, astronomers have recently been able to photograph closer than ever before to the center of the galaxy. This is the grindstone-shaped system of which the Milky Way stars, as well as the sun and all the others that we can see, are part.

A decline of 0.5 per cent in the cost of food in the month ended on Aug. 17 was reported today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The foodcost index for Aug. 17 was 85.5 per cent of the 1923-25 average, an advance of 1.8 per cent over the levels of a year ago.

One of the first efforts to combat the popular impression that building costs are too high was taken recently by a South Bend lumber company in its newspaper advertising and may be the forerunner of other campaigns throughout the country.

Quincy Howe's 'England Expects Every American to Do His Duty," has brought a satiric fable from H. G. Wells that is about an "old lady called Mrs. Quincy Howe" who heard voices and whispers and the ringing of bells and locked herself securely in her own house. The house burned down and killed the old lady, "but, anyhow, the English didn't get her." In passing this on,

Flashing American, 8-year-old chestnut gelding of the Kilkare Farm, Elberon, N. J., was crowned grand champion saddle horse at the Empire State horse show tonight. The reserve was Wild Honey, 9-year-old chestnut mare exhibited by Mr. and Mrs. Reed A. Albee of Larchmont. The Albees' Bellaire Kitty was reserve to the champion of the 1936 Syracuse show.

The State Commission to study Conditions of New York's Urban Negro Population, following a meeting yesterday in its office at 36 West Forty-fourth Street, announced that public hearings would be held in November and December in ten communities having large Negro populations.

Miss Mildred C. Leck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Leck of this place, was married to Irvine Franklin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cleveland Franklin of Bermuda, today at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. E. A. Wasson, former rector of St. Stephen's Church, Newark, performed the ceremony.

Roman Yucopicio, Governor of the northern border State of Sonora, will not come to Mexico City to answer the findings of a congressional investigating committee that he is acting against the "revolutionary" program of the Cardenas Government.
The work of mental hygienists is one of the most interesting and valuable examples of public service, President Roosevelt told the graduating class of nurses at the Hudson River State Hospital today.
Sixty members of the Chamber of Commerce Secretaries of New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey, arrived here tonight for the opening session of their fourth annual conference in the Hotel Claridge.

This matter of. clinching a pennant that just keeps dangling in front of your nose continues to be a rather messy and elusive piece of business for the Yankees, who, with the eyes of the baseball world upon them to see how neatly they can cut the American League to ribbons, seem to be hacking away at the moment like a very dull 'pair of scissors.

Now that the Fall and the American Legion both are forming for a march on the city, the proprietors of post-midnight Broadway are beginning to take heart again. Cooler weather means the end of vacation, the return of the native from Boothbay Harbor, Woods Hole or Fire Island and the resumption of what the Fifties are pleased to call life.

The mystery of the barking bird which fluttered through the window of Isadore Renner's home at 2,918 West Twenty-third Street, Coney Island, on Wednesday and growled at him when he tried to feed it bird-seed, was cleared somewhat yesterday by attendants of the A. S. P. C. A. at Twentyfourth Street and Avenue A. They identified it as a bittern, a heronlike bird found in bogs and reedy swamns.

Following the substantial oversubscription of the last 700,000,000-mark loan, the Reich Government today increased the amount of the loan to 850,000,000. This brings the total "consolidation" loans floated since 1935 to approximately 6,850,000,000 marks.

Democratic supporters of Jeremiah T. Mahoney in Manhattan lost yesterday their legal battle to obtain the reinstatement of 456 election inspectors ousted at the request of Tammany supporters of Senator, Royal S. Copeland.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 4 totaled 804,633 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 17,260 cars, or 2.2 per cent, more than for the preceding week 1/2 39,502 cars, or 5.2 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 212,692 cars, or 35.9 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Agriculture Department experts said today that the radio was conducive to barnyard harmony. Typical of reports coming to the attention of the bureau is one from Portland, Ind., where Joe Bryan reports that he is getting more milk by turning on a radio in his barn.

Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2:30 P. M. "The Armor Galleries; Drypoint-A Demonstration." motion pictures. New York Botanical Garden, Lecture Hall of the museum building. Bronx Park, 3:30 P. M. "Native Plants Used for Dyes and Paints by the American Indians," G. L. Wittrock.

Charles T. Douds, national director for the National Labor Relations Board, announced early today that the A. F. of L. had received 780 ballots and the C. I. O. 675 in voting yesterday to determine which of two unions should represent the National Electric Products Corporation workers in collective bargaining.
Miss Amelia Marburg, member of a prominent family which gave large sums to Johns Hopkins Hospital and the university, died last night at her home here at the age of 85.

Mrs. Edward T. M. Cane, a resident of Brooklyn for nearly fortyfive years and for many years a member of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, died Thursday after a long illness at her home, 119 Kingston Avenue, Brooklyn. She was 70 years old.
With a southerly wind pushing them twelve crack cruising craft started from the Larchmont Yacht Club tonight in the revival of the New Rochelle-Cornfield Light Vessel Challenge Cup race.
Day-long battles were fought here yesterday but they were indecisive. Again the conflicting claims of Chinese and Japanese make determination of the front lines difficult.

Seven hundred Summer residents and a representation from Fall River gathered in the Palm Garden at Newport Beach tonight for the annual Harvest Ball, with Mrs. Moses Taylor as chairman and Mrs. Dan W. Jones as vice chairman, for the benefit of the Rocky Farm Camp for Crippled Children, which serves unfortunate children of both this city and Fall River.

Victorious in a court battle to prevent his removal as managing director of Narragansett race track, Walter E. O'Hara, Providence turfman-publisher who is free on bail on two criminal libel charges, was assured tonight of the running of the $25,000 Narragansett Handicap at his Pawtucket race track tomorrow.

Dissatisfied with their recent race from Newport, R. I., to Bermuda, which developed into a drifting match lasting more than ten days, the owners of the old square-rigged ships Seven Seas and Joseph Conrad have agreed to another contest, Charles Lang, representing the New York Yacht Club race committee, announced today.
Domestic corporation bonds, paced by secondary railroad and convertible industrial issues, went through another severe decline in heavier trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

On the eve of a State Mediation Board hearing, striking truck drivers in this vicinity tonight claimed 175 recruits, to make a total of 825 drivers out. The strike, begun three days ago, is for higher wages and more time for making the New York run.

A business building and a dwelling in the midtown area passed to new control in deals announced yesterday. Arthur S. Vernay, interior decorator, sold to Frederick Brown the four-story structure on a plot 41.8 by 100 feet at 19 and 21 East Fiftyfourth Street, near the northwest corner of Madison Avenue.

After teetering uncertainly at the levels reached by the previous day's rally, the stock market fell heavily yesterday afternoon and closed 2 to 10 points lower in the biggest break since the Summer of 1933.

Benjamin H. Hewitt; Town Counsel, asserted today that two teachers might continue to teach the three R's to a single class of twenty-two pupils in Center Groton's little white school house, but as far as the town was concerned only one of them was going to get paid for it.
Bob Johnson drove in four runs today with his twenty-first home run of the season and a single to lead the Athletics to a 5-to-3 victory over the Senators in the last of a fivegame series.

The Battle of the Marne was fought for six consecutive days, stretching from Sept. 6 to Sept. 12, 1914; the hurried retreat of the Germans occurred on Sept 9. Last Thursday, therefore, was the twenty-third anniversary of that celebrated French victory, recognized nowadays by all historians as the real turning point of the Great War.

A strange drama, all the stranger for its surface unsuitability to the cinema, the French film of Gorki's "The Lower Depths" is a mature, impressive, extraordinarily fascinating production. Gorki himself never believed it could be translated to the screen;

Public officials, labor leaders and business men have made a practice during recent labor disputes in the State of trying to hide their own shortcomings by heaping "abuse" upon policemen, representatives of 45,000 policemen charged here today at the twelfth annual State conference of 137 Police benevolent associations.

Mrs. Susan Bittle, 72 years old, of 60-65 Fifty-fifth Street, Maspeth, Queens, was struck and killed by a trolley yesterday morning a few minutes after she had left Our Lady of Miraculous Medal Church, where she had said prayers for a friend who died Thursday.

The Board of Realtors of the Oranges and Maplewood, N. J., will hold its first Fall business meeting on Wednesday evening at the board rooms. T. O. Dunam has leased a rustic lodge on Ridge Road and Mrs. Marie L. Shea has bought a plot on Sunset Trail, at Candlewood Isle, Candlewood Lake, Conn.

Although such details as clinching the current American League pennant race and preparing for another world series still remain to be disposed of before this season is over, Yankee plans for 1938 are already well under way.
The Cleveland Railway Company today mailed to stockholders a notice of the resignation of its entire board of directors and called for a -meetingwithin thirty days to elect a new group.

Raleigh W. Lee, 62-year-old ace from Columlbus, Ohio, where he cavorts on the Scioto course, famous as the scene of one of Bobby Jones's open championship triumphs, today regained the United States Seniors Golf Association crown that he won here four years ago.
Baltimore dropped a double-header to the champion Bears tonight, but even that wasn't enough to keep the Orioles from all but clinching a berth in the International League playoffs.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
The San Jose team of Argentina and Aurora cantered through easy games today in their final workouts for the national open championship which opens here tomorrow.

The trend in the Chinese delegation to the League of Nations seems now to be toward invoking the covenant's Article XVII against Japan, although no decision was taken at a meeting of the Chinese delegation tonight, a member said. The argument that invocation of Article XVII might force Washington to apply its Neutrality Act is met in Chinese circles by this argument:

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The market has gone almost flat this week. Hardly any wool is being sold on Summer Street of any description. Prices are easier in sympathy with the decline in prices in Australia, especially on fine wools, although it is difficult to quote the market with any sense of certainty.
Puccini's "La Tosca" last night opened the third week-end of the Fall season of the New York Hippodrome Opera Company. The audience was of moderate size, but demonstratively enthusiastic, as usual.

Although held to a draw in his third game in the international chess masters tournament today, Samuel Reshevsky of New York, the United States champion, continued in the lead with 2 1/2 points out of 3 to his credit. His opponent was V. Ragosin of Russia, who declined the queen's gambit offered by the American.

Charley Whitehead of the Plainfield Country Club, winner of the qualifying medal, and Billy Dear of the Montclair Golf Club today gained the final round of the nineteenth annual Arcola Country Club invitation golf tournament.

Through the cooperation of newspapers and radio stations, one of the most unusual educational experiments ever undertaken will begin Monday in an effort to make up for the time lost to Chicago's 450,000 school children by the closing of the schools due to infantile paralysis.

Supporting Tex Carleton's brilliant pitching with an extra-base attack that brought runs in five innings, the Cubs closed in on the league-leading Gaints today by romping to an 11to-O victory over the Cardinals in the final of the series.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Louise MacLaren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. MacLaren of West Orange, to Walker V. Thomas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Thomas of Hackettstown, took place here this evening in Ridgeview Community Church. The Rev. E. A.

Affiliation with the C. I. O. and broadening the eligible base to include commercial department workrs has been upheld by the membership of the American Newspaper Guild in a national referendum, it was announced last night on completion of final tabulation of the votes.

A special dividend of 50 cents a share was declared yesterday on the common stock of the Brunswick - Balke - Collender Company. This is the first payment since Nov. 15, 1929, when 75 cents for a quarter was disbursed.

Polo comes to the climax of its season today with the start of the national open championship. At 4 o'clock this afternoon, Aknusti and Old Westbury will ride out at Meadow Brook, Westbury, L. I., to start the field of six teams off in quest of the highest honors the game has in this country.

Bertram Braucher, 27 years old, a student at the Chicago Technical College, ended his life by electrocution in his home today. His studies gave him the technical knowledge necessary to rig up an effective death device. He employed a transformer from an old radio set which increased the current to 300 volts.

Arthur Cross, president of the Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation, Ltd., announced today names of officers and directors of the former Canadian subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation recently purchased by his company. The subsidiaries are the Canadian Bridge Company, Canadian Steel Corporation, Canadian Steel -Lands, Canadian Steel Wire Company and the Essex Terminal Railway.
A Japanese War Office communique states that a general offensive against the Chinese positions in the neighborhood of Machang, about thirty-five miles south of Tientsin, began at dawn today.

An extraordinary term of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn heard arguments yesterday on an appeal by the District Attorney of Nassau County from a recent decision of Acting County Judge Richard W. Hawkins dismissing an indictment charging bookmaking and gambling against two officials of the

The possibility of a political career has not seriously concerned Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., who returned on the North German Lloyd liner Europa yesterday with his bride, the former Ethel du Pont, after an absence of two months.

Charles C. May, architect, died of a heart attack at his home here today at the age of 55. Mr. May had designed many groups of homes in the metropolitan area, particularly at Pleasantville, N. Y. He also was former associate editor of The Reader's Digest.

Several two-family dwellings in the Greenville section of Jersey City, N. J., have passed into new ownership, according to J. I. Kislak, Inc., who acted as broker in the sales. William J. Sammon bought the house at 236 Wegman Parkway, containing apartments of five and six rooms, from Alfred K. Welker;

With followers of amateur racing gathering here from all parts of the East it is expected that 30.000 will witness the fourth renewal of the Foxcatcher National Cup steeplechase tomorrow over one of the finest and most difficult brush courses in this country.
Further difficulties between Japan and the Soviet Union were reported today. The Japanese Government announced that it insisted on fishing in Siberian waters up to the threemile. limit.

Campaign headquarters of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, New Deal candidate for the Democratio nomination for Mayor, were filled yesterday with a stream of erstwhile supporters of Senator Royal S. Copeland, Mr. Mahoney's primary opponent, eager to switch their political allegiance.

For 2 hours and 55 minutes the Giants battled gallantly today to protect their lead in the race for the National League flag, but they cracked under the strain, went down before the Bees in the twelfth inning, 2 to 1, and lost a precious game of their threegame advantage.

Nine new bids for textiles for the Works Progress Administration were called for today by the Procurement Division of the Treasury Department. The bids are to be opened Sept. 21, with shipment of goods by Oct. 15. The bids are:

Moving with startling swiftness, the Maritime Commission today instructed the captain of the American steamship Algic at Montevideo to put his crew in irons if the men refused to perform their duties because of sympathy with Uruguayan longshoremen whose strike was stopping the ship from sailing.

Mrs. Theodore Pratt opened the gardens and lawns of her home in the Lattingtown colony this afternoon for a bridge tea in aid of the Nassau County Federation of Republican Women. More than 600 women from all parts of the county attended.

Major Gist Blair and Mrs. Blair of Washington celebrated their birthdays with a dinner party this evening at the Pot and Kettle Club. Guests included Mr. and Mrs. Orme Wilson, Mr. and Mrs. Henry O. Tallmadge, General J. W. Kilbreth and Mrs. Kilbreth, Mr. and Mrs. Timothee Adamowski, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hall Stevenson, Mrs. John T. Dorrance. Mrs. Nathan C. Wyeth, Mrs. Platt Hunt, William Stewart, Colonel Arthur Cosby and Fergus Mackie.
A decline of 109,000,000 bushels in the prospective corn crop in August due to drought in the Western corn belt and the great plains area was reported today by the Government Crop Reporting Board.

Waner connected for a single with two out in the ninth inning today, driving home the winning run in Pittsburgh's fourth successive triumph over Cincinnati, 7 to 6. It was the fourteenth defeat for Chuck Dressen's Reds in their fifteen meetings with the Bucs so far this season.

The National Labor Relations Board today was "caught in the middle" of the A. F. of L-C. I. O. controversy relating to elections among seamen, with each side, at a hearing, threatening dire consequences if the board did not uphold its contentions.

Colonel Stephen A. Douglas, a consulting engineer, and a reserve officer in the Chemical Warfare Service of the United States Army, died of a heart attack yesterday in the hallway of the apartment house at 660 Fort Washington Avenue where he resided. He was 64 years old.
Offers from Costa Rica, Guatemala and El Salvador to act as mediators in the boundary question between Nicaragua and Honduras have been received by the Nicaraguan Government.

The th-eat of reprisals against Italy that Maxim M. Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, made at Nyon today was received with a prompt and energetic reply in well-informed Italian circles which stated that any such move would be considered as an act of aggression and dealt with accordingly.
Ralph Flanagan, Miami's contribution to major league American swimming, stroked to another triumph today in his program of three national A. A. U. outdoor titles and records to go with them.

Miss Virginia Gildersleeve, dean of Barnard- College, returned from Europe yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa, somewhat cheered by a slight beam of hope in the international: situation, but depressed by the fact that the world is again witnessing the shame of "wandering scholars."
Miss Elizabeth Hartshorne Emlen, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Emlen of Awbury, Germantown, was married this afternoon to L. Gordon Walker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Gordon Walker of Richmond, Va.

The Alteration Plumbers, Steamfitters and Helpers Union, declaring that its strike not embraced 2,200 men in 250 shops of the ?? er City Master Plumbers Association and that 600 men in 150 open shops had been brought under union agreements, challenged yesterday the validity of the old contract between the union and the association.
Determination that a chemical process causes the muscles of the human body to move was announced at the American Chemical Society convention here today by Dr. R. R. Renshaw of New York University.
John R. Crews, Brooklyn Republican leader, who had been classed as opposed to the renomination of Mayor La Guardia, called at City Hall yesterday and announced his support of the Mayor.

With both players returning 77s over Bethpage's difficult black course, a 6,600-yard lay-out, Tommy Strafaci of Shoreview and Frank Schiller of Branch Brook finished in a tie for medal honors in the qualifying round of the Metropolitan Public Links golf championship today.
Rockwell Kent, often called America's fightingest artist, refused yesterday to get excited over the possibility of his becoming an American Diego Rivera.

An interstate commission to regulate fisheries now being "dangerously depleted" in the Atlantic and Great Lakes areas was recommended by representatives of riparian States yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel Biltmore called by the New York Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation.

Dr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Brown of 277 Park Avenue gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for their daughter, Mrs. Alburta Brown Wood, and Frederick T. Pierson of Pittsford, N. Y., whose marriage will take place today in Port Washington, L. I. Other guests were Mrs. Frederick T. Pierson, mother of the prospective bridegroom;

Miss Nancy Hunter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tracy Gould Hunter of 124 East Eighty-first Street, this city, and Savannah, Ga., has selected the afternoon of Oct. 2 for her marriage to Howard Hoyt Froment, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene MeKibben Froment of 175 East Seventy-ninth Street.

Retail trade here was brisk during the week, with cooler weather stimulating a sharp increase in volume over the corresponding period a year ago. Department store executives estimated gains ranged from 10 to-15 per cent over 1936. This week's gains will bring the showing for the month to date about even with, or slightly ahead of, last year. Thus, the poor trade last week, particularly on Saturday, has been offset in large part.

The Detroit Lions crushed the Cleveland Rams, 28 to 0, in the latter team's National League professional football debut tonight. A bad pass from center rolled over the Cleveland goal line and led to a touchdown.

Dismissing special drives against crime as inadequate, Irving B. Bleam, clerk -of the New Jersey prison, stressed the more permanent crimeprevention work of churches, fraternal organizations and industrial concerns in his annual report submitted today to R. William Lagay, head keeper.

John Torrio, former Chicago gangster, who put up $100,000 bail in cash last year when he was arraigned before a United States commissioner on a mere complaint, recovered $50,000 of that money yesterday, after Federal Judge T. Blake Kennedy, visiting jurist from Wyoming, had heard his plea of not guilty of income tax fraud charged in two indictments.

Acceptance of jury service as a responsibility of citizenship was urged upon New York State women this afternoon by Miss Kathryn Starbuck, secretary of Skidmore College, the principal speaker at a jury school held in the Harriet May Mills Memorial Building at the State Fair Grounds.

Officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Reserve Board kept a careful watch today on the sharp break in the value of shares on the Stock Exchanges, but there was no indication that any action, such as a lowering of margin requirements or modification of other restrictive regulations was contemplated.

John Yost, a retired police lieutenant, died on Wednesday in Swedish Hospital, Brooklyn. Lieutenant Yost was a roundsman on the old City of Brooklyn Police Department in 1898 when he was selected to head a squad of picked men to direct traffic on Fulton Street.

The Board of Superintendents has reported unfavorably on the request of a committee of thirty-six trade unions and a number of individuals interested in labor for permission to sponsor officially a proposed contest on "Labor and the Constitution" in the junior and senior high schools of this city.

Officials of the Long Island Railroad conferred yesterday, at the offices of the Transit Commission, 270 Madison Avenue, with the special subcommittee recently named to study the proposed $30,000,000 grade crossing elimination and civic improvement project on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn.

Philadelphia today began with colorful ceremonies a ten-day sesqui-centennial celebration of the signing of the Constitution. Special events will be held every day until Sept. 19, with the principal exercises next Friday, "Constitution Day."

A 60-year-old man, identified from his papers as Edwin Willcox, a real estate man of 68 Chippewa Road, Tuckahoe, N. Y., was killed at 9:20 o'clock last night when he jumped out of the window of his sixth-floor room at the Hotel Bryant, at the southwest corner of Fifty-fourth Street and Broadway.

The duties of the new Reich Sport Office were published today in the Official Gazette. All sport activities, from small clubs and associations to international athletic events in which Germans participate will be under the supervision of the National Socialist Government.
A 44-year-old father occupied a jail cell under a thirty-day sentence tonight because he admitted that he gave his 17-year-old son some beer and then permitted him to drive an automobile.

The hitherto unused basement of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, the present edifice of which has stood for eighty-three years at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, has been renovated so that it can be used for church activities.

The Official Gazette today carried a decree under President Lazaro Cardenas's signature extending until Aug. 31, 1938, the rights of the Bank of Mexico to operate without legal regulation except for three unimportant articles in its organic act.

Dr. Wilhelm Filchner, presumably en route from Sinkiang in Central Asia by caravan to Northern India, is still unaware of the award to him of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's national prize for art and science.

An agreement between the Philco Radio and Television Corportion and the Philadelphia Battery Company to reduce the basis on which the battery company paid royalties to the Radio Corporation of America for radio sets it manufactured was upheld today in an opinion by Chancellor J. W. Wolcott.

Over-assessments of real estate, which he charged the Mayor had done nothing to correct, was given yesterday by Lawrence B. Elliman, prominent in real estate and business, as one of the reasons why he was supporting Senator Royal S. Copeland instead of Mayor La Guardia for the Republican nomination for Mayor.

Baron Gottfried von Cramm came from behind again yesterday to thwart Robert L. Riggs of Los Angeles with his superb fighting qualities after losing the first two sets and now stands face to face with Donald Budge in the match the American tennis public has waited all Summer long to see.

Matched colors in costumes for men and women-as worn by the Duke and Duchess of Windsorwere among the style trends for the Winter resort season predicted yesterday by Miss Marian Stephenson, fashion photographer, at the first Autumn luncheon of the Fashion Group at the Hotel Biltmore.

Postmaster General Farley said in a press conference today that the Democratic National Committee would take no part in 1938 State primaries in reprisal against members of Congress who opposed President Roosevelt's court bill.
The possibility of Japan or other foreign powers procuring control of manganese in Panama was denied by Edward C. McKay on his return here today from an inspection of property in Veraguas Province.
J. G. L. Molloy, Mayor La Guardia's law secretary, was relieved of his duties yesterday at his own request so-that he may run as a candidate for the City Council in the November election.

The North German Lloyd liner Berlin, arriving today from Bremen and other European ports, will bring among her passengers one hundred members of the Brooklyn Arion Singing Society, who attended the German Saengerbund in Breslau. In the party are Dr. Gotthard E. Seyfarth, honorary president, and the director, Leopold Syre.

American merchant vessels were warned by the State Department today that it was dangerous to operate in waters adjacent to the danger zone along the Chinese coast where the Japanese have announced a blockade and the Chinese have declared their intention to retaliate.
The Securities and Exchange Commission-today made public the following application from New York City for registration as brokers or dealers in the over-the-counter markets:

The Hudson City Savings Bank sold to the Old Colony Company, Stella Badois, president, the fourstory, sixteen-family flat at 108-110 Waldo Avenue, near Newark Avenue, Jersey City. It took back in part payment a purchase money mortgage for $27,000, due Oct. 1, 1942 at 41/2 per cent.
The first tropical disturbance of the season to reach hurricane force exerted its strength tonight on the open waters of the Atlantic far from the nearest land.

Florida's boundaries, closed for two Winters to fundless jobseekers, will be open this year to all who come South. But "vagrants, crooks and racketeers in fine limousines or Pullman cars" had best beware of local police and Sheriff's forces.

Lifeboat crews representing ships of five nations will race this afternoon off Bay Ridge in the presence of shipping officials of their native lands and thousands of spectators if the weather is favorable.
Mrs. Sophie Wilhelmine Rahe, former Superintendent of Public Schools in Baltimore, died yesterday at her home, 3,830 Waldo Avenue, the Bronx, after a short illness. She was 73 years old.

Being an ultra-conservative these days, Chick Meehan refuses to make any prognostications about his Manhattan College football team this season but there is a gleam of contentment in his eyes. It is rather easy to see that John Francis Meehan is expecting big things from his Jasners.

The six weeks' old marriage of Merry Fahrney and Baron Arturo Berlingieri, Italian nobleman, landed in the divorce court today. The Baroness charged that ten days after their wedding, July 31, in Harrison, N. Y., Baron Berlingieri struck her while they were on a California honeymoon.

A modified plan of reorganization for the Scullin Steel Company, designed to meet the objections of certain holders of bonds and preferred stock, was approved today by United States District Judge John C. Collet.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $25,260,000, to be represented by one Territory, one State and fifty municipalities. This compares with the revised total of only $12,850,027 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $26,749,844.

The current strong vogue for women's suede shoes will reach its peak this Fall and Winter and from that time on will start to recede in favor, while smooth-surfaced footwear will be on the upgrade for next Spring and Summer, according to a summation of the "testimony"

For the third successive time in four years the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club International Challenge Cup, blue ribbon prize of small- sloop racing, which was brought here from Scotland in 1932, was defended successfully today.

Making her first political speech in support of Mayor La Guardia, Mrs. Samuel Gompers, widow of the president of the American Federation of Labor, last night urged the voters of the city to exercise a patriotic duty and vote at the coming primary election to continue a clean city government.

Miss Henrietta Warburton Durant of Charleston, S. C., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward Warburton Durant, was married to Richard Horace Bassett, son of Mrs. John Spencer Bassett of Northampton, Mass., and the late Mr. Bassett, here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Resurrection by the Rev. Frank Sparling North.

Mr. and Mrs. Artemas Holmes of 760 Park Avenue and Old Brookville, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Holmes, to Caspar Wister, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Caspar Wister of Wynnewood, Pa.

THEY must have forgotten that Roger WilTHEY went down and fixed up a place now known as Rhode Island so that folks who wanted a little peace and quiet would have somewhere to go. What with tax collectors and Indians and witch-burners and other annoyances in adjacent colonies, Roger figured that some haven of repose would please the harassed citizens of those rough days and he picked Rhode Island.

William A. Rodenberg, who represented the East St. Louis (Ill.) district in Congress for more than twenty years, died here today in a hospital, where he had been taken last Friday after an attack of paralysis at the Summer home of former Senator James A. Reed of Missouri, sixty miles south of Alpena.

An interchange between a witness at the Labor Board hearing here and counsel for the Bethlehem Steel Corporation concerning the "rightto-work" philosophy of the Johnstown Citizens Committee provided the opening wedge today for the proposed inquiry by the National Labor Relations Board into both the local and national citizens committees, which are alleged by the C. I. O. to be vigilantes organizations.

Reed Vetterli, Federal agent, who has hunted down kidnappers and killers since 1926, when he joined the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Omaha, assumed command yesterday of the bureau's New York office as successor to Rhea Whitley, former chief agent here, who recently resigned to enter the private practice of law.

Through adoption by the Board of Finance this city has accepted a plan for retiring its term bonds, which will save $185,000 in the 1938 budget. The plan will obviate the fluctuation in funds for this purpose to which the city has been subjected in recent years.

Crop statistics published today show that about 196,000,000 acres of grain had been out by Sept. 5, which was about 1,500,000 more acres than had been cut up to the same date of last year and was 87 per cent of the total plan.

An injunction which prohibits the Hawkins County School Board from appointing teachers kept more than 100 schools closed today and about 6,000 pupils from their desks. The court order was obtained by 190 teachers elected by the retiring school board last March for the 1937-38 school term, but who have not been certified by the present board. Schools were to have opened Sept. 7.

The Hilton Davis Chemical Company, Cincinnati, manufacturing and research chemists, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 15,000 shares of $5-par $1.50 cumulative preferred stock optioned to underwriters at $27.50 a share for resale at $30 a share or at the market.

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation in August totaled 1,107,858 tons, second only to 1,360,523 tons shipped in August, 1929, and compared to 923,703 tons in August, 1936. The gain over last year was 184,155 tons, or 20 per cent. Shipments were 78,894 tons below July, 1937.
The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that non-farm foreclosures in New York and New Jersey dropped 29 per cent in July as compared with July last year.

The $37,000,000 Wheeler Dam of the Tennessee Valley Authority was dedicated today. The third gigantic unit in the Federal Government's economic experiment under the TVA was officially opened on the 101st anniversary of the birth of General Joseph Wheeler, Confederate and Spanish War hero, with President Roosevelt taking part.

The third gigantic unit in the Federal Government's economic experiment under the TVA was officially opened on the 101st anniversary of the birth of General Joseph Wheeler, Confederate and Spanish War hero, with President Roosevelt taking part.

Charles Biederman, who as a band leader toured the country with Buffalo Bill and later established the Newark Police Band, died today after having undergone an operation three days ago at the Beth Israel Hospital. He was 80 years old.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That the Spanish Bishops in their collective letter, recently published in THE NEW YORK TIMES for Sept. 3, "have neither proved a case against their enemy nor justified their own," is the judgment of Professor James T. Shotwell, writing in THE TIMES of Sept. 7.

An East-West match for the singles championship of the twentieth annual girls' national tennis tournament was assured today when Miss Hope Knowles of Philadelphia and Miss Barbara Winslow of Hollywood, Calif., gained the final.

Attired in shorts and sleeveless shirts, Columbia's football forces cavorted on the practice gridiron at Baker Field yesterday in the season's opening workout for the Lions. Thirty-four candidates participated in a varied program of actity under the guidance of Lou Little and his aides during morning and afternoon sessions.

Dr. J. Eastman Sheehan, Professor of Plastic Surgery at the Polyclinic Medical School, New York, began today a tour of Insurgent Spain to repair shattered faces. Medical aides to Generalissimo Francisco Franco said there were as many mutilated faces in the Insurgent Army as there were in the British Army at the end of the World War.

After hearing arguments for and against the bill providing a five-day week for city employes yesterday, Mayor La Guardia refrained from saying whether he would sign it. At the end of the statutory public hearing in City Hall,

The British Trades Union Congress today gave the Government overwhelming support for its rearmament program in a resolution adopted by a tremendous majority. Tabulation of the votes on the basis of workers represented by voting delegates gave the resolution a majority of 3,544,000 to 224,000.

With the dissolution of the voting trust that has dominated the corporate affairs of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company for fifteen years now in progress, the impending battle for control of the management of the company has taken a new turn with the formation of a committee seeking proxies to be voted at the annual meeting on Sept. 22, it became known yesterday.
Two British Royal Air Force officers were killed today in the sixteenth. King's Cup air race when their plane crashed near here in full sight of 1,000 persons.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I think that the criticism to which Joe Louis has been subjected since his fight with Farr is unfair and not to the credit of American boxing fans.
The Indians defeated Detroit, 6 to 5, in the final game of the series between the clubs today, rain halting the contest at the end of the seventh inning.

Caballero II and Tiger will be the stars under test this afternoon in Aqueduct's two richest races, the $10,000 Edgemere Handicap, and the $12,000 Junior Champion. Caballero II is the imported horse from Chile who has won most of his races, and never finished out of the money in this country.

Commodity futures were irregular in moderate activity on the local markets yesterday. Raw hide futures experienced a sharp dip and silk, lead and world sugar futures were also lower. Coffee, tin and rubber futures were better.
Charles Neave, counsel and member of the board of directors of the General Electric Company, died today at his home here. His age was 69.

The Swedish liner Kungsholm arrived yesterday from Gothenburg, bringing in her holds a large collection of Swedish art objects for display at the Swedish Tercentenary Art Exhibition at Rockefeller Center late this month.
The wheat market on the Board of Trade had a weak undertone today, and while trade was not large the closing sales showed net losses of 1% to 2 cents a bushel, the latter on the May.

Noak Victor Hybinette, inventor of the electrolytic process bearing his name for refining nickel, died in Malerno, Italy, on Tuesday, it was announced yesterday. Born in Falun, Sweden, he was in his seventy-first year.
International interest was added to the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's annual Fall regatta today when the Italian entry, 0 Sole Mio II, with Mario Perretti as skipper, triumphed among Star Class racers.

THE FUTURE OF CHRISTIANITY, by Edgar Sheffield Brightman. (Abingdon Press, $1.50.) Dr. Brighton attempts to show clearly the difference between religious and scientific knowledge, and to interpret the future of the Bible, the Church, and faith in God.

The trustees of the British Museum have purchased for the nation the Ashley Library, the most famous modern English book collection, made by Thomas James Wise, who died last May at the age of 77 years.

The Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported tonight the lowest Canadian wheat crop since 1914. The bureau said the grade and quality of the 1937 crop "is indicated to be very high although slightly below the record of 1936."

Gardiner M. Heath, a lifelong resident of New Canaan, except for a brief period when he resided in New York State, for many years cashier of the First National Bank of New Canaan, now the First National Bank and Trust Company, and formerly a member of its board of directors, died here yesterday at the home of his sister-inlaw, Mrs. Stephen E. Heath, aftera short illness. He was 85 years old.

A preliminary meeting of leaders of the American Federation of Labor to form a committee to support Mayor La Guardia for re-election was held yesterday in the offices of the State federation in the County Trust Building, 265 West Fourteenth Street, where headquarters will be opened next week.
Police Commissioner Valentine and Magistrate Antony Savarese commended yesterday the patrolman and sergeant who captured three alleged burglars in Queens d on Thursday night.
An air of general cheerfulness continued to buoy the stock market in a modest way today, but the volume of dealings again was small.

Professor Moritz A. Geiger, chairman of the Department of Philosophy at Vassar College, died yesterday morning at the Hollis Center. (Me.) Hospital while on his way from Seal Harbor, Me., to this city.
Fred Remington Greene, retired finan-: cier and industrialist, died today of a heart ailment at his home in the highlands. He was 70 years old.

Delta, owned and driven by Gordon Adamson of Highland Park, Ill., won the world 225-inch motor boat racing championship at the Canadian National Exhibition today as Jack Cooper, veteran Kansas City driver, lost by missing a buoy in the final heat.

The Treasury announced today that, on the basis of incomplete figures, approximately 94 per cent of its $817,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent notes maturing on Sept. 15 had been presented in exchange for the new notes offered on Tuesday. Books on the conversion closed last midnight.

The French franc continued yesterday to decline to levels below any it had touched since November, 1926. -Pursuing the course which had carried it down almost 10 points on Thursday, France's currency unit lost 6 3/8 points net yesterday to close here at 3.56 1/8 cents.

Mr. and Mrs. Hoyt A. Moore of 898 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Parsons Moore, to James Wilson Tower of Cambridge, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Tower of this city and Falmouth, Mass.
Threatened embroilment of more ports in the newest A. F. of L.-C. I. O. controversy marked strategy meetings here today of teamsters and longshoremen, fighting for control of Western warehousemen.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler inspected 3,000 police drawn from all parts of Gerany here this morning. They paraded before him in their new green uniforms, adopted in accordance with the dictum that the world's bestdressed police force must be German.

Steps were taken yesterday by the Cuban Sugar Institute to solve the difficulties arising out of the conflict between the rules of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and a recent ruling by the Cuban Government on the problem of export certificates in the No. 4, or world sugar contract.

The WPA Federal Art Project will formally present to the City Home, Welfare Island, on Tuesday afternoon at 2:30 o'clock, "Circus," a mural painting by Emanuel Romano. Designed and executed under the Project's direction, the mural has been installed in the auditorium of the new Klondike Building of the home and is a colorful and gay scene of circus life. The exercises will be held in the auditorium.

A solemn requiem mass was celebrated yesterday morning at the Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier, Carroll Street and Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, for William J. Ward, Brooklyn banker, who died on Tuesday.
Prince Chi- in chibu of Japan will call on Chancellor Adolf Hitler at Nuremberg tomorrow, leaving later for Hamburg to embark for the United States.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 11 (AP).--Pushing his program to "getrid of" Walter E. O'Hara as managing director of the Narragansett race track, Governor Quinn filed fresh charges today, seeking his removal and the revocation of the track's license.

MEXICO CITY.--The Mexican Congress is expected to act favorably this term upon the recommendation of President Lazaro Cardense that women be granted full suffrage. The step indicates a gradual change in the position of women in this country.

Following studies made during the Summer by the Pollak Foundation for Economic Research, a meeting of those interested in sponsoring the Consumer Foundation, Inc., will be held around the middle of next month, it was learned here yesterday.

OAK BLUFFS, MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass., Sept. 11.--Andrew A. Highlands of Brookline, secretary of the Massachusetts Public Utilities Commission and noted Harvard athlete of the '90s, died here today of a cerebral hemorrhage. His age was 64.

SEA ISLE CITY, N.J., Sept. 11. --Six commercial fishermen of this resort were saved from drowning by the crews of two other local fishing boats today when their thirty-one-foot pound boat, San Salvatore, capsized in a heavy sea on the bar off Townsends Inlet.

The Republican supporters of Senator Copeland worked hard to offset the announcement for Mayor La Guardia of John R. Crews. Eleven other Brooklyn leaders con ferred to press Copeland's cam paign and predicted he would carry that county by 10,000.

Forty-five of the district's leading pros will tee off Friday in the Metropolitan P. G. A. champion ship tournament, which will be con ducted over the Gedney Farm Golf Club's course in White Plains.

The Federal Housing Administra tion's plan of insuring mortgage loans is proving a stimulus to home ownership among families of small income, George W. Loft, chairman of the board of the South Shore Trust Company, informs Thomas G. Grace, State Director of the FHA.

Three hundred and fifty lawyers, neophytes and veterans of the bar, will voluntarily assemble next week in this city for the opening of the tenth session of a series of practical law courses designed to keep them abreast of developments in their own profession.

With the first drawing of New York's women jurors already his tory, and a second scheduled for Tuesday at the Hall of Records, members of women's civic groups have renewed their efforts at dis pelling any mysteries still associated with the jury box.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics announced today that receipts from the sale of the principal farm products in New York increased $20,862,000 in the first seven months of this year, compared, correspondingly, with 1936.

The Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman, pastor for the last twenty years of St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, announced yesterday that he was leaving New York to. become pastor of the Methodist Episcopal Church of the Saviour in Cleveland.

Crowds on the Coney Island boardwalk at dusk last night were startled to see a "plane" swoop low offshore and then dive and sink quickly in the water a short distance from the end of the pier where an excursion boat was taking on passengers for the return to the city.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 71 per cent of capacity, against 84 per cent in each of the two weeks preceding. Mills lost more than 24 per cent because of the Labor Day holiday, but later made up a little of the loss.

Riding over the opposition of Connecticut and Rhode Island delegations, the New England Young Republicans tonight threw their support behind a proposal for a national party conference next year to draw up a program for the 19381940 elections.

John Steinbeck, returning to California after a stay here and abroad, sends word that he has stopped in Southwest Oklahoma, where he will spend several weeks gathering material for a new novel. His story, "The Red Pony," will be published by Covici, Friede in a limited edition on Sept. 24.

Five stars were added to the gold star flag of the Honor Legion of the city's Police Department yesterday afternoon at the annual memorial service on the Mall in Central Park. Each star represents a policeman killed in the performance of his duty.

Lake Shore Mines, Ltd., has announced in the annual report an income of $15,692,652 for the year ended on June 30. This figure compared with an income of $16,361,530 for 1936. Cash on hand for 1937 was $7,999,135, compared with $8,633,265 for the previous year.

Dr. and Mrs. Walter Damrosch of New York entertained with luncheon today. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. William S. Moore, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Satterlee, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bell Sweeney, Mr. and Mrs. A. Atwater Kent, Mr. and Mrs. John Hampton Barnes, Mrs. John T. Dorrance, Mrs. Blaine Beale, Mrs. James Byrne and Mrs. A. Murray Young.
Two red lacquer pieces, a side chair and a card table, made by Giles Grendey (1693-1780) of London, are among the recent acquisitions of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

The "Anti-Jewish month," during which a Jewish boycott, proclaimed by the anti-Semitic Nationalist party, is being carried out with great harshness. In Warsaw, Vilna, Lublin, Grodno and other towns boycotts are causing Jews much harm and loss.

Thomas Worrell Stevenson, 86 years old, brother of the late Adlai E. Stevenson, Vice President of the United States in Cleveland's second administration, died here yesterday. He was the last survivor of the six Stevenson brothers, who for a generation were prominent in business and political affairs of McLean County. Ill. and the nation.

Excluding commutation passengers, the number of travelers on the New York Central Railroad in July increased over July, 1936, by 14 per cent, with a 10 per cent gain in revenue, according to the road.

George Bernard Shaw, after announcing it was "unquestionable" that the British public does not want the proposed national theatre and is unwilling to give "a brass farthing" for it, has reached the Shavian conclusion that the project must be carried out with State aid.
Professor Alfred James Ewart of the University of Melbourne, author and lecturer on botany and plant physiology, died today. He was 65 years old.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Russell E. Watson of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Watson, to William Bryan Moses Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Moses of Portland, Me.

New York State's birth rate in July was the lowest on record for that month, while the death rate was, with but a single exception, the highest for the month in eleven years, Dr. J. V. DePorte, Director of the Division of Vital Statistics, reported today.

The 200th anniversary of the Kingwood Presbyterian Church was observed today, but not a single member of the church attended. None went to the celebration, conducted by the Presbytery of New Brunswick, because the last member, James Ashcroft, died two years ago.

International speculation in the face of troubled world conditions was largely responsible for large purchases of foreign exchange and foreign securities in this market during the week, as domestic affairs are not such as to justify a belittling of the fact.

The Board of Superintendents has recommended the repeal of the school by-law which bars from an examination a candidate. who has failed in two previous tests for the same teaching license, James Marshall, vice president of the Board of Education, disclosed yesterday.

President Roosevelt is returning to Washington tomorrow, a day earlier than he originally planned, because much work has accumulated there and he is eager to get it cleaned up before returning here next week-end.

Henry N. Wightman of Montclair, representing the University of Michigan Glider Club, successfully defended his New Jersey gliding title today as the three-day championship meet closed on Schley Field, near here. A crowd of 3,000 saw Mr. Wightman break all previous endurance records here when he kept his du Pont utility craft aloft 9 minutes and 15 seconds.

Bowery, 114, 24.11x101.3: 114 Bowery Realty Co, Ida Rudolph, president, to Alfred S. Horowitz, 4,91$ 15th Ave, Brooklyn; mtgs $21,150 (50c). Broadway Terrace, 1, 35x100; also 11 Broadway Terrace, 35x100; Newburgh Savings Bank to Bessie Kaufman, 6,309 23d Ave, Brooklyn ($65).

In brilliant sunshine upward of a quarter of a million young Russians of both sexes marched through Red Square past Joseph Stalin, Premier Vyaceslaff M. Molotoff, Vice Premier Anasthasius I. Mikoyan, President Mijhail I. Kalinin and other leaders in celebration of the twenty-third "International Youth Anniversary."

Announcement was made here tonight that the strike of railroad employes of the Conemaugh and Black Lick Railroad, controlled by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, will be terminated at 12:01 tomorrow morning.

Describing the United States Constitution as "that great instrument of human understanding," Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, in a message to religious teachers of the diocese yesterday afternoon, called on them to bring to their students "a clear and new intellectual understanding of our country's basic law."

Miss Priscilla Chapman, daughter of Mrs. Henry Chapman of Swampscott, Mass., yesterday became the bride of John G. Schroeder Jr. of New Haven, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Schroeder of East Orange, N. J., in the Branford Congregational Church. The Rev. D. H. Cooley officiated.

Vaudeville appearances by jurors and other trends tending to transform a public trial into a spectacle were rebuked sharply today by an American Bar Association committee headed by Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War during the World War.
The Chicago Cardinals defeated the champion Green Bay Packers, 14--7, in a National League professional football game today before a crowd of 10,000 persons.

The drama of life with God-the principal character-left out can never be more than a mediocre production, the Rev. Dr. Lynn Harold Hough, dean of Drew Methodist Theological Seminary, Madison N. J., declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

The Wedgeport tide rip, long the feeding grounds for the giant tuna, was barren of bluefins today, and when the horn sounded from the board boat at 5 P. M. the day's score stood at goose eggs for both British and American tuna teams.

Joshua Barney and his stout old contemporaries of the days of sail would undoubtedly have snorted indignantly and "spliced the main brace" if any one had suggested in their time that a sailor should also be a Bachelor of Science.
After knocking at the door for some time, Biene v. Elbe Bogen Se Sumbula, brilliant brindle boxer bitch, today entered the charmed circle of best in-show winners.

The Italian conquerors of Ethiopia announced today that the Coptic Christian Church of Ethiopia under the new regime has been virtually divorced from the Coptic Patriarchy at Alexandria, Egypt, which formerly controlled it.

One of the features of the celebration of constitutional week in this city will be held Tuesday afternoon at the local library when the Daughters of the American Revolution will present a framed copy of the United States Constitution to be hung on the wall of the library.

Douglas Castle in Lanarkshire, the 176-yearold ancestral residence of the Earl of Home, one of Britain's greatest land owners, will be demolished this month to permit the mining of large veins of coal, recently found beneath it.

Losses of more than [Pound]15,000,000 have been incurred by British investors who subscribed to [Pound]36,000,000 out of the ??80,000,000 for League of Nations loans to European countries between 1923 and 1928.

The church has lost its radiance and is no longer the chief cultural institution of our national life, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

Charles E. Hughes Jr. announced yesterday his support of Mayor La Guardia and urged all enrolled Republicans to vote for the Mayor on primary day. The only issue in the city campaign is good local government, Mr. Hughes contended. National issues, he held, have no place in the campaign.

Mayor La Guardia of New York, breaking away for a few hours from a turbulent campaign for re-election, advised industrial workers here today "to take advantage of what Federal laws have given you and organize to obtain those rights."

Encountering a lot of stout and surprisingly stubborn - resistance from a quarter where they least expected it, the Yankees, performing before the appraising gaze of a gathering of 48,725 at the Stadium yesterday, blazed both their pitching aces--Charles (Red) Ruffing and Vernon (Lefty) Gomez-into the Senators in the hope of winding up their three-game series with a grand flourish and a clean sweep.

Washington dispatches, intimating that the Securities and Exchange Commission was "keeping careful watch" of the much-discussed break on the Stock Exchange, did not foreshadow any action or reversal, of policy. The position is interesting, however, for the reason that if last week's abrupt decline was a consequence mainly or wholly of a "professional bear raid," the present machinery of classifying sales ought to indicate the fact.

Prices for cotton continued to decline last week. Although prices for futures broke through the ninecent level toward the end of the week, there were indications of increased resistance at that point.

The books of two of the largest distributors of milk, the Borden Company and Sheffield Farms Company, are to be audited by the accounting firm of Ernst Ernst of New York City, designated by Holton V. Noyes, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets.

London does not view the Wall Street decline as due to a "war scare," but, on the contrary, observers here feel that any general conflict would engulf Great Britain and leave the United States in "splendid isolation."

The engagement has been announced here of Miss Hazel Priest, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Priest of Narragansett, R. I., and the late Mr. Priest, to George W. Korper Jr., son of Mrs. George W. Korper of New York and the late Mr. Korper.

The Nyon agreement to patrol the Mediterranean has accomplished on the outskirts of Geneva but definitely outside Geneva what the League of Nations in its most influential days was never able to do. It has put teeth into an international accord. A symbolic international guard protected the Saar plebiscite.

James Talcott, Inc., has been appointed factor for the Black Hosiery Mill, Midland, N. C. L. T. M. Ralston, New York divisional manager since July, 1936, has been named manager of a new division of the Kelvinator commercial department which will handle part of the commercial territory previously directed from the New York office.

The front brick walls of two fivestory unoccupied tenement houses toppled into East Forty-seventh Street near First Avenue at about 11 o'clock last night, several hours after the walls had been heard crackling.

Alice Devine, 14 years old, of 1,913 Fiftieth Street, in the Borough Park district of Brooklyn, was found dead. at 2.P. M. yesterday in George Tong's laundry at 4,918 Nineteenth Avenue, just around the corner from her home.
A suit for $1,640,000, charging an "irregular" stock transaction, was filed against twelve officials and directors of the Republic Steel Corporation in Common Pleas Court here today.

Report, a 5-year-old chestnut gelding, that joined the stable of Miss Clare S. Weber of Mount Kisco about six months ago; captured the hunter championship of the seventh annual horse show conducted by the Lawrence Farms Hunts Club today.

Scheduled to reach the Broadhurst Theatre next Monday night, "Honor Bright" will be along later. Further polishing is in order, the same to take place late this week in Wilmington. The position of Catholics and their church under present world conditions was the subject of a speech delivered here today at the Holy Name rally by William D. Cunningham, a former judge of the State Court of Claims.

After a series of postponements the new International Casino is now slated to open next Friday night. It was to have opened tonight but the management reported that certain parts of the stage could not be finished on time.

Some people in this "Steel City of the South," ten years ago one of the strongholds of the Ku Klux Klan, will be surprised to hear that Hugo L. Black, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, according to a series of forthcoming articles by Ray Sprigle, copyrighted by The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette and the North American Newspaper Alliance, Inc., has been a member of the Ku Klux Klan and still is.

Wage earners of the steel industry in 1935 produced an average of $6,155 worth of finished, iron and steel from an average of $3,767 worth of raw materials, according to calculations by the American Iron and Steel Institute based upon the recently issued Federal Census of Manufactures for that year.
Johnny Allen scored his eleventh straight victory of the season today in the second game of a doubleheader with the Browns and the Indians won, 6 to 1, after taking the opener, 6 to 3.

LINCOLN'S RISE TO POWER, by William E. Barringer; (Little, Brown, $4.) Lincoln as a practical politician. THE TIDE OF TIME, by Edgar Lee Masters. (Farrar Rinehart, $3.) A novel set in the Middle West during the Civil War.

Staging a four-run outburst in the ninth frame, the New York City Fire Department nine beat the New York A. C., 9-7, at Travers Island yesterday. Daly and Fernandez clouted homers for the firemen, the former getting his in the fourth with one on and the latter hitting for the circuit in the fifth with no one aboard.

Ginger Rogers's work in "Stage Door" has caused RKO to haul out "Vivacious Lady," dust it off, and announce it for production with Miss Rogers therein, immediately following "Having Wonderful Time," in which she is now working.

The destructive typhoon which killed at least sixty persons yesterday along Japan's western and southern coasts before swinging into the Sea of Japan, claimed ten more lives today by striking inland again through Aomori Prefecture, at the northern tip of the main island, Honshu.

The commandant of United States Coast Guard announced today that the following cadets at the Coast Guard Academy in New London, Conn., had completed their courses suecessfully and would be graduated with the commission of ensign on Sept. 20:

Invitations have been sent out by Mr. and Mrs. Allen Fleming Myersof 31 Wilder Street, this city, for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Theodora Winslow Myers, to Aaron Moore Bagg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Clark Bagg of Holyoke, Mass., on Oct. 2 in St. John's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Dr. Lyttleton E. Hubard will perform the ceremony.
William Fox, 19 years old, of 93 North Ocean Avenue, Freeport, L. I., was drowned at 8:30 this morning, while bathing a quarter of a mile west of the Hither Hills Coast Guard station.

A widespread belief persists that the National Labor Relations Board and its trial examiners have been acting not as impartial judges of disputes between employers and unions but rather as prosecutors of employers. This belief is not confined to the employers immediately concerned or even to conservatives.

A. Robert Elmore, a recruiting officer in the United States Navy, stationed at Chicago, died yesterday of- a heart ailment at the United, States Veterans Hospital, at Lyons, N. J. Born in London, England, Mr.

Four men, believed by the police to be the makers of the plates from which the recent flood of "good" counterfeit money is being printed, were under arrest yesterday, while a pet was spread for several other alleged members of the ring.

Three men and a woman were killed early this evening near the St. Joseph County airport when the plane in which they were riding crashed with another in mid-air and fell, with one wing stripped off, into a field near by. The accident was witnessed by nearly 1,000 persons.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation and its subsidiaries, the Robins Dry Dock and Repair Company of Brooklyn and the Tietjen Lang Dry Dock Company of Hoboken, were found to have violated the National Labor Relations Act in a report by Frank Bloom, trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board, made public yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, the board's regional director.

Public school education that stresses only the earthly life and ignores the eternal life is inadequate and deficient, the Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg declared yesterday in a sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Senator Copeland has "practically thrown in the sponge," so far as the Republican nomination for Mayor is concerned, Newbold Morris, candidate for President of the City Council, said yesterday.

ARONSON--On Sept. 11. Charles W., 126 St. Mark's Ave., Brooklyn, at PolYclinic Hospital, beloved husband of Minnie A., brother of Edward; member of Masons, Elks and Grand Street Boys. Funeral services at the Stafford. Funeral Chapel, 307 West 51st 'St., on Tuesday afternoon, Sept. 11, at 2 o'clock. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery.

The Treasury has temporarily reversed the policy of "sterilizing" gold which it started Dec. 22 and under which it has accumulated $1,385,761,102.51.

Floyd Hogland, 26 years old, a pilot for aerial photographers, was burned to death this morning when an airplane he was flying crashed almost immediately after taking off from the local field. The dead man lived in Hercules Park, near by, and leaves his wife and a year-old daughter.

Tommy Bridges held the White Sox to three hits today to give the Tigers a 4-to-0 victory and a clean sweep of the series. The triumph moved the Tigers four games ahead of the Sox in the battle for second place. The Sox hit only three balls to the outfield. It was Bridges's thirteenth triumph of the season.
The markets here were sharply reactionary this week. Prices fell more in the first three days of the week than in any like period since the beginning of the year.
This and other European markets are completely dominated by the political situation in the Far East and in the Mediterranean, which has caused nervousness and sharp price movements.
Both infantry and artillery troops of the Salvadorean Army have been recently engaged in manoeuvres thirty miles from the Honduran border.

Forces of the Committee for Industrial Organization merged today into a "solid front" in San Francisco and voted to back efforts of their longshoremen's union in its struggle against the American Federation of Labor teamsters for control over organized warehouse men.

Exercises celebrating the 170th anniversary of the founding of St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church in the Manor of Cortlandt were held here today at the present St. Peter's Church and at the original church at Van Cortlandtville, two miles north of here, with more than 2,000 parishioners and residents of the vicinity taking part in the ceremonies.

The Stock Exchange was sharply disturbed by the precipitous break this week in New York, and, after a long interval, sentiment in the City has come, once again, under the influence of Wall Street trends.

A pontifical mass was celebrated yesterday at Our Lady of Lebanon Roman Catholic Church, 295 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, by the Most Rev. Cyril George Dallal, Archbishop of Mosul, Iraq, metropolitan of the vicinity there.
September corn on the Board of Trade fluctuated last week within a range of 1011/2 cents a bushel. The changes largely reflected professional operations.

The crash of the Royal Air Force bomber in which four officers lost their lives at Guisborough, Yorkshire, yesterday has brought the total deaths for the year to more than 100--a melancholy record never equaled in the Air Force in the same space of time.

The Chase National Bank announces that definite ten-year 4 per cent sinking fund debentures due on June 1, 1947, of the Saseway Stores, Inc. are available for delivery in exchange for the temporary debentures at its corporate trust department, 11 Broad Street.
Soviet Pilot Basil Zadkoff crashed in the Arctic Ocean north of here, it was reported today, while searching for the six Russian transpolar airmen missing since Aug. 13.

Chilly weather but an enthusiastic audience of 6,500 greeted the finalists in the city-wide barber shop quartet contest held last night in the Randalls Island stadium as an adjunct to the final performance of operetta this season.

As an aftermath of the many criticisms that were leveled at it in 1936, the American Olympic Association took steps yesterday to remedy defects and to guide its future action at an executive committee session at the New York Athletic Club. Thus, it cleared the decks for its quadrennial meeting on Nov. 17 at Washington.
Commodore John Barry, "father of the American Navy," was honored here today in "Barry day" features of Constitution week.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses and official observers of the United States Government -and radio er gineers were among the 1,500 spectators on hand yesterday afternoonfor the annual Walter Eliot Memorial model boat races on the lake in Bowne Park, 159th Street and Twenty-ninth Avenue, Flushing.

Increased protection for the rights of citizens was urged in a resolution adopted by the Chamber of Commerce secretaries of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, who closed their fourth annual conference in the Hotel Claridge today.

A large scale experiment in the issuance of low-priced books will be started tomorrow when- eleven new books in paper bindings, to retail at 25 and 35 cents a copy, will be published by Modern Age Books, Inc., of 155 East Forty-fourth Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Bruce Coates Jr. of North Andover, Mass., and Rindge, N. H., have announced here the marriage of their daughter, Miss Velma Fulton Coates, to Grahame Enthoven, son of Mrs. E. H. Skene Enthoven of this city and of Edward J. Enthoven of Malba, N. Y., which took place here on Saturday in the Church of the Transfiguration.

Ceremonies marking opening of new London Terrace branch of New York Post office. Tenth Avenue between Twenty -. third and Twenty - fourth Streets. 12:15 P. M. Speakers: Postmaster Albert Goldman, Representative John J. Boylan, John J. Cavanagh.

IVAN T. SANDERSON is a young Scotch naturalist-still in his middle twenties-who trains in London's night clubs to keep fit for long stays in the tropics. In the tropics he works hard stalking, trapping, skinning, stuffing, packing animals, and making notes on how they behave and making paintings of their appearance and environment.

Miss Jane Connolly, a sister of the late Maurice E. Connolly, former Democratic leader and Borough President of Queens, died yesterday at her home, 47-26 Junction Boulevard, Elmhurst, L. I., of a complication of ailments, after an illness of two years.

The world crisis today is a phenomenon of the war between the forces of God and the forces of antichrist, the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, said yesterday in his first sermon, since his return from a trip to Europe.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs Clyde Parker Johnson of this city of the engagement and approaching marriage of their only daughter, Miss Mary Jane Johnson, to Cyril L. Fellowes Colmore, elder son of Mrs. D. Everett Waid of Wilson Point, South Norwalk, Conn., and the late Squadron Commander George C. Colmore, British Royal Naval Air Service.

Mike Cestone, 33-year-old mailman from Montclair, N. J.. turned back Walter Thoren of Brooklyn, 3 and 1, in the final match of the annual metropolitan public links championship at Bethpage State Park today.

The 13,000 members of the American Bankers Association were urged yesterday to attend the annual convention of the association to be held in Boston on Oct. 11 to 14, in letters sent to them by Tom K. Smith, president.

The National Socialist Congress reached its climax today with the roll-call and march past the Fuehrer, Adolf Hitler, of the party's military and semi-military organizations. Today also, despite gray skies that threatened rain, all prognostications of waning interest in this annual party celebration were negatived.

Six celebrated composers gave world premieres tonight before an enthusiastic audience, in which was Crown Princess Marie Jose. Igor Stravinsky, the Russian corn poser, drew most applause for his suite "Jeu de Cartes."

A tentative agreement, expected to lead to settlement of the strike of 13,000 painters in Manhattan and the Bronx, was reached last night by representatives of District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers and the Association of Master Painters and Decorators.

Miss Kitty Lou Coulbourne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Evitts Coulbourne of Germantown, will be married to Robert Henry Schneider, son of Mrs. Jacob Matthew Schneider of Los Angeles on Oct. 12 in the Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul, Logan Square.
While a crowd of 55,000 cheering fans looked on, the New York Police Department baseball team defeated. the Department of Sanitation nine at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
