The subway offers a workaday test of Christianity, the Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw, pastor of the Fort Washington Presbyterian Church, 174th Street near Broadway, said in his sermon there yesterday.
Walter N. Rothschild's Avanti today won the Larchmont Yacht Club's race from Larchmont breakwater to Cornfield light vessel and return, a distance of 137 miles.

J. Donald Budge, the acknowledged world champion amateur tennis player, took an exhibition match victory from his Davis Cup doubles partner, Gene Mako, today, 10-8, 6-3. A day after winning the national singles championship at Forest Hills, N. Y., Budge headlined an exhibition also featuring Mlle.

The report of the Bank of France, disclosing further heavy borrowing by the Government last week, caused a precipitate flight of French capital from the franc, although other domestic affairs across the Channel also were responsible, in the view of observers here.

Mrs. James H. Van Alen, who reopened last week Dal Ash, her home in Roslyn, heads the committee in charge of the tenth annual Glen Head horse show, which will be given next Sunday on the estate of Stephen H. Townsend in Glen Head in aid of the Children's Shelter, a Nassau County society for the prevention of cruelty to children.

Bermuda is bracing for winds of gale force that are expected to accompany the passage of a hurricane about 100 miles east of the colony about 8 A. M. tomorrow. Small boats have moved to securer anchorages and houses are being shuttered.

Bootleg coal mining in Pennsylvania is doomed to a natural death in coming years even if no legal means are found to eradicate it, the State Anthracite Coal Commission predicted in a report made public today.

More than 2,000 cleaners and dyers met yesterday afternoon at Irving Plaza to map final plans for a city-wide strike in their industry, scheduled for 4 A. M. today. The workers are members of Local 239 of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, a C. I. O. union.

Richard Ely, a member of the law firm of Reeves, Todd, Ely Beaty, 165 Broadway, counsel for John Wanamaker, and a director of the real estate firm of Horace S. Ely Co., died at his Summer home in Old Lyme, Conn., yesterday in his fifty-seventh year.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sturgis S. Wilson of 155 East Ninety-first Street of the engagement of her sister, Miss Katharine Lois Gould of 1,160 Park Avenue, to Henry Pratt Foster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Crosby Foster of Plainfield, N. J.

A committee of savings bank and insurance companies, headed by John W. Stedman, vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company, announced yesterday that it would file with the Interstate Commerce Commission a plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific Railroad, which, if put in effect, would wrest its control from the Alleghany Corporation.

The Board of Trade's wholesale index averaged 111.4 in August, against 111.5 in July, this being the second setback since June, 1936. Compared with August, 1936, there was a gain of 17 per cent, with foodstuffs up 9 1/2 per cent and industrial materials 20 1/2 per cent higher.

Clyde Derrick, awaiting a hearing next Friday on a charge of kidnapping two Johnson City policemen, blames gambling as "the cause of it all." Derrick surrendered peacefully to, Rome (N. Y.) police officers yesterday after being sought for six days.

When the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary docks at Southampton today Captain J. C. Townley will turn over the ship to Captain Robert B. Irving after having had command of her for eight consecutive voyages, the record number for any master since the liner came into the service in May, 1936.

Edward E. Spafford, former national commander of the American Legion, declared today that Americans resent the charge that Italy was responsible for the so-called submarine piracy in the Mediterranean.

The six-story and office building at 20 and 22 East Forty-sixth Street has been sold by the Homeport Realty Corporatidn, represented by Leon Gibson, attorney, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

Ruffin G. Pleasant, Louisiana's wartime Governor, died of a heart attack today in his sixty-seventh year. The former State Executive had been retired from active politids and legal practice since 1926.

The Brooklyn Dodgers' eleven registered a 19-0 victory over the Bristol West Ends today in an exhibition game which attracted 3,700 spectators. The visiting team made touchdowns in the first, third and fourth periods, using an aerial attack to score all three.

Troopers W. D. Sawyer and Dennis Dore of the Hightstown Barracks of the New Jersey police tonight shot and killed Alexander Marciniak, 47 years old, employed on the farm of Harry H. Smith near that place, after the man allegedly tried to attack his employer's wife and then murdered another hired man known only as Louie.

What will be probably the first automotive copy for 1938 will break on Saturday when Hupp Motor Car Company releases a schedule in trade papers through Grace Bement. On the following Tuesday, Studebaker is expected to announce its new models in advertisements.

Patrick Spollen, a Staten Island high school senior, was killed instantly early today when an automobile he was driving crashed into an electric light pole at Hudson Boulevard and Seventh Street, near the BayonneStaten Island bridge.

The wholesale price index for Sept. was 106.4, compared to 106.7 for Aug. 1. In the first eight months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index, based on the average of 1913 as 100, ranged between 106.9 on Aug. 11 and 105.2 in the first week of January.

Long Island exhibitors had a banner day at the eighth annual Soldiers and Sailors Club horse show at Brighthome Farm today.- They dominated the entry lists and accordingly captured the laurels in the chief features of the forty-fourevent program.

To honor the memory of Henry Hadley, New York composer and conductor, the Funeral March from Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung" was played by the Federal Symphony Orchestra, under Eugen Plotnikoff, before the scheduled all-Tchaikovsky program given at the WPA Theatre of Music last night.

Miss Alice Jane Burger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Harold Burger of West Hartford, and Lewis Pitkin Cheney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Cheney of Manchester, were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Trinity Episcopal Church. The Rev. Raymond Cunningham officiated.

The touring United States track and field team crushed the strongest opposition it has faced in Japan, defeating an all-Japan team, 98 to 79, in a two-day meet concluded today. Points were scored on a 4-3-2-1 basis.

The San Jose team of Argentina found itself with a real fight on its hands today against an Aurora four which did not believe at all in being the underdog and galloped shoulder to shoulder with the favored South Americans for four periods.
Mr. and Mrs. Willing Spencer are expected today at the St. Regis from Colorado Springs. Miss Mary Pearsall Field of the Plaza will return from Europe tomorrow on the Aquitania.
Isaae Wolf Orgel, Hebrew scholar and retired jewelry manufacturer, died early yesterday morning of a heart -attack at his home, 152. South Eighth Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 79.
Secretary Wallace's Ever-Normal Granary is an excellent idea .on paper but it never will be fool-proof until

The first half of 1937 saw a 36 per cent increase in dwelling units for practically all of the urban areas of the United States, according to the Department of Labor. The number of new units added was 118,597, against 85,160 in the corresponding period last year.

As though by one signal, stench and tear-gas bombs were set off in twelve movie theatres in the Bronx and ten in Manhattan about 9 o'clock last night, driving thousands of persons to the streets and causing minor injuries to fifty.
Lester J. Fleury of Newark carried off top honors in a contest to determine the "best" bald head at the annual outing of the Morning Club of Essex County held today at Olympi Park here.
Industry here is relatively quiet, but Christmas orders are coming in earlier than usual, and manufacturers of cutlery, toys, bicycles and other minor lines are well occupied.
Louis Franck, governor of the Bank of Belgium, will retire at the end of the year, it has been announced here.

John L. Lewis tells us that the C. I. O. "is conceived within the principles of the national Bill of Rights and committed to the proposition that the workers are free to assemble in their own forums, voice their own grievances, declare their own hopes and contract on even terms with modern industry for the sale of their own material possession-their labor."
The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 88 on Sept. 8, compared with 83.8 a fortnight before, 84.2 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931,
Ten weeks of Summer vacation will become- merely a memory for 1,145,000 city children this morning, when the public schools open their doors.

After a steady opening, the Bourse this week went through active selling waves, engendered in part by international difficulties and also by Tuesday's break in Wall Street, although prices were not affected as much as had been feared.
The new and greater Brooklyn College stands in stately majesty but in Flatbush with five new buildings, a five-acre athletic field and sumptuous surroundings in every direction.
A factor which may cause Mayor La Guardia to disapprove the pending local law establishing a five-day week for city employes

Although every one recognizes a reign of law 'in the physical world, "we are less convinced that there is also a reign of law in the moral world," the Rev. Leland B. Henry said in a sermon yesterday in St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square, east of Third Avenue.

Every city, town and village in the county was represented today at the thirty-sixth annual field day and tournament of the Westchester County Volunteer Firemen's Association on the athletic field of the Harrison High School.

A plan by which 18,000 employes of the Eastman Kodak Company may increase their group life insurance, adding about $15,000,000 coverage to the $25,000,000 in force under the company's existing plan, will be announced to the workers tomorrow by Frank W. Lovejoy, president.
Puerto Rico's overpopulation and unemployment may find relief in emigration, according to C. A. Pringle, general administrator of Henry Ford's rubber properties in Brazil and Liberia.

A woman, about 25 years old, ended her life at 7 o'clock last night by jumping. from the center of-the George Washington Bridge to the Hudson River, 250 feet below. There were no notes or papers to show.who she was.
Cable communications between Shanghai and the outer world were restored today after having been cut for fifteen days.

The thirty non-union men and twenty others in arrears in union dues were brought into the fold today thereby effecting a last-minute settlement of the threatened South Wales collieries strike involving 13,000 workers.

Republicans who dislike Mayor La Guardia or disagree with his political philosophy were urged yesterday by Kenneth F. Simpson, New York County chairman, to follow the example of tolerance set by Abraham Lincoln and vote for the Mayor in the Republican primary because Mr. La Guardia has been the most efficient Mayor New York bas had in many years.

The champion Newark Bears concluded their International League campaign today by turning back the Baltimore Orioles in both ends of a double-header before a crowd of 10,000. The Bears won the first game by 8-4 and squeezed out a 6-5 verdict in the seven-inning nightcap.

The Cardinals broke up a pitching duel between Bob Weiland and Lee Grissom this afternoon to shut out the Reds, 2 to 0, in the nightcap of a double bill. Cincinnati was outbatted in the opener but won, 10 to 7, with the aid of three errors.

In the Senate debate on Aug. 16 on Senator Black's qualifications for the Supreme Court bench, Senator Borah of Idaho declared that thousands of telegrams attributing Klan membership to Senator Black had been received by Senators, but that Senator Black's denial had been sustained by the absence of any evidence of membership.

The condition of former President Thomas G. Masaryk took a sudden turn for the worse last night, when his temperature, rose to 102.3 and he lapsed into semiconsciousness. His heart action weakened and the physicians found an inflammation in the right lung.
The Chinese delegation to the Eighteenth As sembly of the League of Nations, opening here tomorrow, gave to the press today a written statement, beginning:

Sir Plunket Barton, Bart., one of the bestknown Anglo-Irish lawyers of this generation and a well-known biographer and historian, died here yesterday at the age of 83. He was descended from the Tipperary branch of the family, which settled in Ireland in the eighteenth century.

Catholic men and women were urged to uphold the Constitution of the United States and to be thankful for the religious freedom it has granted to all, in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Thomas V. McMahon at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church, 137 East Fortythird Street.
The captains and crews of the old square-rigged ships Seven Seas and Joseph Conrad had plenty to say today concerning the fickleness of the weather.
Money is now in demand, mainly for income-tax payments. Of the Reichsbank's month-end credits, totaling 683,000,000 marks, only 222,000,000 marks were repaid in the first week of September.
The Football Giants smothered the New Rochelle Bulldogs, 35 to 0, today before 3.000 spectators to show they were ready for the opening National Football League game in Washington on Thursday night.

Harold Denny, who is the Moscow correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES. is on leave in Paris, where he is writing a series of seven articles telling of conditions in Russia. He will deal particularly with the great purge of the army and officialdom, which has startled and puzzled the outside world. The first article of the series follows:
Japan's war aims have now been stated by both Prince Fumimaro Konoe. the Premier, and Foreign Minister Koki Hirota in terms that reveal a definite policy. It lacks nothing in boldness of conception.
In a moving demonstration of devotion.100,000 Catholics gathered today to offer thanks for the blessings that have come to this country since the signing of the Constitution 150' years ago.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,919,549,400. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

Public offering of 65,000 shares of $1 par common stock of the Eastern Footwear Corporation is being made to residents of the State of New York by Thomas Griffith at $2.50 a share. The company recently increased authorized capital from 250,000 to 500,000 common shares.

Evil exists not in man's weakness but in hiding weakness, Professor Reinhold Niebuhr of Union Theological Seminary said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

A 1 per cent increase in employment in factories in the State and 1 1/2 per cent increase in payrolls featured the August report of the division of statistics of the State Labor Department, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, announced today.
Cargoes through the Canal in August showed an increase of 304,237 tons, 12.3 per cent more than in July, with a total of 2,780,603 tons.
Sunday at Ebbets Field was unusually exciting. A gathering of 12,940 paying guests, angered and excited, saw the Dodgers drop the opener, 4--3, in ten innings, then win the nightcap. 9-5.
The Febus News Agency carried unconfirmed reports tonight that the crew of a submarine sunk off Cartagena last week may be alive.

While three military tribunals are sitting permanently, the work of classifying about 50,000 prisoners in concentration camps near Santander goes ahead. Between 100 and 150 Cases are tried here daily.

Morris Sabin's discovery that toothaches are caused by a parasite visible to the naked eye may not rock the scientific world or ruin the toothpaste business, but it has created a mild sensation in his home community, particularly since it became known that a Columbia professor had invited Mr. Sabin to demonstrate his method of. extracting the parasite.

Contracts for supplies for various Government agencies, valued at $4,924,376, were awarded under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Thursday, the Department of Labor has announced. Ten agencies made seventy contracts.

President Roosevelt continued to keep in close touch with the international crises in Europe and the Far East today, discussing world conditions with Norman H. Davis, his Ambassador at Large, and with James A. Moffett, the former Housing Administrator who returned last Spring from a trip through China and Japan.

Miss Anne Marie Semler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans J. Semler of this place, will be married to John E. Mahoney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis A. Mahoney of Brooklyn and Freeport on the morning of Sept 28 in St. Patrick's Church here A reception at the Lido Country ceremony.
Bishop William H. Heard of the African Methodist Episcopal Church died early yesterday morning in the Hahnemann Hospital in Philadelphia, according to word received here. He was 87 years old.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidate for the Democratic Mayoralty nomination, made a surprise "inspection tour" yesterday afternoon of the Chisholm Manor at College Point, Queens, which has been used this Summer by Mayor La Guardia as City Hall.
Harvesting of the soy bean crop has 'started in Indiana and Iowa, but no official estimates have been made concerning the probable yield for the country.

The Cubs split a double-header with Pittsburgh today and stood still in the National League pennant race. The Chicagoans won the opener, 5 to 0, and dropped the nightcap, 4-2. The New York Giants likewise split with Boston and retained their one and one-half game lead.

Sound movies of the interior parts of the human body, some of those recesses where the forces of life and death battle to a conclusion, were announced as a reality here today at the opening of the fifth International Congress of Radiology.

B/G Foods, Inc.--Thirty-two weeks ended Aug. 13: Sales, $2,042,993, against $1,870,742 in corresponding period a year ago; profit, $68,556, equal after preferred dividend requirements to 59 cents a share on 79,489 common shares, against $55,750, or 43 cents a common share.
The American financial interests that obtained options on manganese deposits in Costa Rica and Panama are represented by Joseph B. and Edward W. Creevy

Summing up the progress of the PWA's slum clearance and low housing program, Howard A. Gray, the Administration's director of housing, reported today that 3,000 families had already moved into fourteen completed projects and that 78,000 families had registered as prospective tenants, although only 21,800 units will be available.

President Lazaro Cardenas reciprocated today the long friendship he has enjoyed with the United States by issuing a strong appeal for the cooperation of all workmen of Mexico, especially the oil workers, asking them clearly to understand their position regarding Mexico's economy.

The United States was urged to renounce its trade in arms and munitions in the Far East by invoking the provisions of the Neutrality Act in a resolution adopted today at the closing session of the twenty-second national conference of the Fellowship of Reconciliation.

Boynton Ave (14-3715). a e cor of Watson Ave. 15Ox100; Ida Soloway to Dorfield Realty Corp. 1,117 W Farms Rd; mtg $204,600. Southern Blvd (11-3108). w s. 79 ft ?? of 180th St. 37x99; Workmen's Sick and Death Benefit Fund of U. S. A. to Snek, Inc. 17 E 42d St.

The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette begins publication today of a series of six articles in which it is alleged that former Senator Hugo L. Black of Alabama, recently appointed to the Supreme Court of the United States, was and now again is a member of the Ku Klux Klan.

The Duke and Duchess of Roxburghe, who arrived from Scotland on Friday night to be the guests of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Goelet at Ochre Court, were guests of honor at a large dinner given by their host and hostess tonight. The Duke is a nephew of Mr. Goelet.

Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, said today that an unexpected crisis threatened the Government's merchant marine program because of the "apparent inability" of some private operators to finance their share of construction costs.

Alfred Kierschner of 367 East 198th Street, Bronx, died Saturday night at his Summer home in Atlantic Highlands, N. J., at the age of 79. He retired in 1927 after fifty-two years with the hide and skin importing and exporting house of J. H. Rossbach, this city.
Two murals depicting the Crucifixion and the Sermon on the Mount were unveiled in the Star of Bethlehem Negro Baptist Church today by Mrs. Max Eastman, who painted them.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 91.2, which compares with 91 a week ago, 91.7 two weeks ago, 91.9 three weeks ago and 91.9 four weeks ago.

Northeast of Paris today gay throngs cheered thousands of marching war veterans celebrating the twenty-third victory of the Marne. Northwest of Paris 45,000 troops manoeuvred under the eyes of a critical French high command.

Greentree, winner of the national open polo crown for the past two years, triumphed over Templeton by 9 to 6 today in a test match before one of the season's largest crowds at Bostwick Field. The stands were jammed and the attendance was estimated at 7.000.
The Paterson Panthers opened their season at Hinchliffe Stadium today by defeating the Brooklyn Eagles, 1936 American ,Association champions, 28-0.

Man in this restless age needs to learn anew the value of prayer, the Rev. Carlos G. Fuller, pastor of the Featherbed Lane Presbyterian Church, University Avenue and 174th Street, the Bronx, said in his sermon yesterday.
Cardinal Segura y Saenz, Primate of Spain, who fled from the country about the time former King Alfonso was exiled, has returned to Insurgent Spanish territory, prelates revealed tonight.

Harry Hopkins, Administrator of the Works Progress Administration, said in an address today that one of the first and most important jobs a democratic government had is the responsibility for "making every person and every group keep his hands off every one else."
Mrs. Frank B. Reynolds gave a party last night at the Mount Washington, Bretton Woods, in honor of Mr. and Mrs. R. Foster Reynolds, her week-end guests.

Increased reorder activity in the wholesale market here last week was indicative of the stimulus to retail buying created by cooler weather. Most apparel lines showed better action. Costume suits still held the center of the stage in the dress market, in all price ranges, and better dresses of the simple "basic" type also moved well.

Germans were highly pleased with the decision of the Nyon conference barring Russia from the Mediterranean operations against submarine "pirates." They considered it a victory over the Soviet. They feared, however, the concentration of Anglo-French naval forces in that sea might lead to dangerous complications. [Page 1.]

Undaunted by the prestige of some of his eighteen rivals, a Larchmont youngster, Roy Manny Jr., brought his Star Class yacht Aim home at the head of a fleet which included several contenders for the coming international championship in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's special regatta today.

The Commerce Department estimated today that labor will receive the largest slice of the national income on record during 1937. National income is expected to aggregate about $70,000,000,000 this year, an increase of 12 per cent over last year but about 13 per cent under 1929.

Miss Mary Starr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Coleman Starr of Haverford, will be married on Oct. 1 to David Evans Williams 3d, son of David Evans Williams Jr. of Robinwood, Ardmore, and the late Mrs. Williams.

Samuel Reshevsky, chess champion of the United States, and Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, former world champion, played a rather tame draw in the fourth round of the international masters' tournament today. A battle royal had been expected, but the match went only twenty moves.
All the resources of the French police and detective services were mobilized today to capture the terrorists who late last night blew up the headquarters of-two employers' associations in Paris.

Eleven Nationalists accused of murdering a Puerto Rican policeman in a political riot March 21-will go on trial at Ponce tomorrow. The clash between Nationalists and police at Ponce resulted in twenty-one deaths and the injury of more than 100 persons.

The Rev. Dr. Charles Edward Jefferson, for thirty-two years pastor of the Broadway Tabernacle Church in New York City, died here today at his Summer home. The Congregational clergyman, who was also well known as an educator and author, was 77 years old.

The Giants took farewell of the Bees at National League Field today and, if the truth must be known, they had no regrets. The National League leaders had to be content with an even split of a twin bill which attracted 33,275 fans, one of the largest crowds of the season here and the largest the Giants have attracted here since 1934.

Subscription of $250,000 in stock of the East Texas Newsprint Mill, to be constructed at Lufkin, has been assured by members of the Texas Newspaper Publishers Association. Officials said more than 80 per cent of the required capital had been arranged, subscriptions totaling $6,250,000.

The speed with which the Nyon conference worked out its "anti-piracy" scheme is praised on all sides today although there were openly-expressed misgivings over the attitude Germany and Italy, particularly Germany, will take toward the joint Anglo-French patrol in the Mediterranean.

Dutch observers view Wall Street's decline this week as attributable to a combination of factors: first, exaggerated press reports on the Mediterranean situation; second, bear raids based upon these reports; third, growing doubts of the Autumn business recovery, partly due to increasing costs;
Carl J. Weese of Newark, N. J., today successfully defended his metropolitan archery championship and thus will retain for a third consecutive year the handsome silver loving cup at stake.

Neither morality nor benevolence but what God does for the people is the true essence of religion, the Rev. Dr. Augustus Steimle declared yesterday at the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway at Ninety-third Street.

In the first seven months of 1937, the United States had an unfavorable trade balance amounting to $115.000,000, Ernest A. Tupper, chief of the division of foreign trade statistics of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, revealed today.

Getting to George Caster in the closing innings, Boston came from behind to defeat the Athletics today, 13 to 6. The Athletics scored four runs in the fourth inning in a wild baserunning drive, during which they stole five sacks and were aided by a wild throw. Werber's homer added another in the fifth.

Suffolk County Attorney Edgar F. Hazleton, who was accused yesterday by Supervisor Arthur J. Kreutzer of Huntington of having advised Mr. Kreutzer it would be proper to solicit business in connection with the construction of the county almshouse and infirmary at Yaphank, denied the accusation today.

Mr. A. P. Herbert of Punch and the House of Commons finds himself, like many other M. P.'s, inundated with inquiries about his Matrimonial Causes Act, which goes into effect on Jan. 1. He has had to take to broadcasting. He advises people, and especially poor people, who are seeking information to let Parliament men alone and apply to the Poor Persons Committee, a magistrate or a lawyer.

Jersey City ended its Tnternational League season today by dividing a double-header with Syracuse before a crowd of 15,243, which turned out to pay tribute to Manager Travis Jackson. The Little Giants won the opener, 8 to 5, but dropped the nightcap, 2 to 1.

Rossini's "Barber of Seville" was presented by the Hippodrome Opera Company at the Hippodrome last night before an audience of 4,100 persons. The cast comprised Lucrezia Sarria (Rosina), Mildred Ippolito (Berta), Lawrence Power (Almaviva), Claudio Frigerio (Figaro), John Ciccia (Bartolo) and Nino Carboni (Basilio). Giuseppe Bamboschek was the conductor.

The administrative committee of the Zionist Organization of America, at a meeting yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Astor, declared its acceptance of the resolution adopted at the world Zionist-congress in ZUrich last month author. izing negotiations with the British Government to ascertain the precise terms of the proposed Jewish State in -a part of Palestine.
Current "clever dance arrangements" of classical airs are as "ludicrous as your lovely grandmother made up to look like a chorus girl," Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff asserted here today.
The annual "visitors' day" at Camp Smith here attracted more than 30,000 persons today, when Governor Herbert H. Lehman reviewed the 369th Infantry of Harlem, commanded by Colonel John G. Grimley.

A struggle between the two groups claiming jurisdiction among theatrical press agents in New York looms as a new source of Broadway conflict, it was disclosed yesterday. The possibility of dispute lies in the fact that there is not room in the field both for the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union and the newly organized New York Theatrical Press Agents.

Fire in building material stored under the east portico of the Capitol damaged stonework of three of the building's arches today. The blaze, originating in cork insulation' intended for air conditioning equipment, brought fire trucks roaring to Capitol Hill.

A remarkably favorable account of Chancellor Adolf Hitler, the Nuremburg congress, which she attended, and Nazi Germany generally appeared in The Daily Mail today under the signature of Viscountess Snowden, widow of the Labor Chancellor of the Exchequer, who is a Socialist writer.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, announced today that the A. F. L. had "outlawed" the American Newspaper Guild, and that his organization had begun "a militant drive" against the C. I. O. The A. F. L. will set up its own newspaper unions, he said.

The engagement of Miss Vera Jay Bertholf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Bertholf of this place, to Henri Courtenay Clinch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Clinch of River Edge, has been announced by her copal parents.

Mr. and Mrs. Clayton French Shoemaker Jr. of Bala-Cynwyd have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phiania French Shoemaker, to Dr. John Andrew Rose, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Rose of Houston, Texas, and nephew of Wickliffe Rose of New York.

There has been a fairly sharp rise in manufactured consumers' goods. Regarding the future course of export prices for manufactured goods, the Volkswirt believes that, owing to better domestic markets everywhere, the compulsion to export at any price has ceased, but it complains that dumping of finished textile products is continuing.

A. R. Johnson, business agent for the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, said today that the American Federation of Labor boycott against goods produced at the National Electric Products plant would be lifted.

The National Labor Relations Board ruled yesterday in Washington that the results of an election among employes of the Max Fleischer Studios in this city gave the Commercial Artists and Designers Union, an A. F. of L. affiliate, the right to act as exclusive collective bargaining agent for the studio's production employes.

Preparations were under way today for instruction of children at home while the schools are closed because of the prevalence of infantile paralysis. Meanwhile, medical reports gave little hope that the disease would subside markedly in the next few days.
Judge and Mrs. Eugene O'Connor gave a tea today at their home here for Miss Nancy Harrison of Washington, whose engagement to Eugene O'Connor Jr. has been announced.
Richard G. S. Howland, veteran newspaper man, died here today at the age of 74. He had been correspondent here for The Utica Press and other Central New York papers for many years.

The reconciling of business with Christianity constitutes "a major problem in our religious thought today," the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams said in a sermon yesterday morning at the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Henry and Clark Streets, Brooklyn.

Miss America, 1937, packed her bags and went home today while newsreel cameramen, reporters and photographers, pageant officials and spectators waited' on the end of, the steel pier for her to appear.

Former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidate of the Brooklyn, Bronx, Queens and Richmond leaders, appears to have the advantage over Senator Royal S. Copeland, Tammany's candidate, in the contest for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, according to surface indications.

One week of ceremonies throughout the nation commemorating the 150th anniversary of the signing of the articles of the Constitution on sept. 17, 1787, opened here yesterday afternoon with exercises on Bedloes Island at the foot of the Statue of Liberty and in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

Steel output in August was 987,700 tons, against 1,059,200 tons in July and 872,700 tons in August, 1936. The figures reflect efforts to reduce shut-downs over the August holidays and further to augment basic production rates.

Bert G. Hoadley, president of B. G. Hoadley Quarries, Inc;; died last night of a heart attack it Eagle River, Wis., while on a fishing trip. His age was 61. Mr. Hoadley was a. pioneer in the Indiana limestone industry. With his brother, Albert, and their father, John, he entered the limestone business in his youth.

Miss Dorothy Traung of San Francisco and Frank Strafaci of Lakeville, the 1936 winners, repeated their triumph today by overcoming Miss Virginia Guilfoil, blond young Syracuse star, and Willie Turnesa, the metropolitan champion, 3 and 2, in the final of the third annual mixed foursome tournament for the Mrs. William Goadby Loew Challenge Cup at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club.

Mrs. Rodney Proctor entertained at tea yesterday in the Stockbridge Golf Club. At the Lenox Club today, Mrs. Willard F. Smith of Ledgeland, Lee, gave a luncheon for eighteen. Mrs. Smith and Mr. and Mrs. William Marshall Bullitt are to sail from New York Wednesday on the Normandie - for several weeks abroad.

The Constitution is a keystone that holds the government of the' United States in enduring strength, the Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Saxon declared in a sermon yesterday at the Christ Church, Methodist Episcopal, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

The solution of religious and world problems lies in proper training in the home, the Right Rev. Irving Peake Johnson, Bishop of Colorado, said in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Bartholomew's Church, Protestant Episcopal, Park Avenue and Fifty-second Street.

Arriving this afternoon from Europe on the French liner Normandle will be Marc Peter, Swiss Minister to the United States, and Mme. Peter; J. van de With, Minister from the Netherlands; Lieut. Col. Emmanuel Lombard, French Military Attache at Washington;

Governors and their wives who will begin arriving in Atlantic City tomorrow for the annual conference of Governors will not have a "dull moment," according to a press release from the office of Governor Hoffman, New Jersey's Chief Executive.

Billy Winn of Kansas City drove to a new world record over the 100mile dirt track at the New York State Fair today, cutting more than three minutes from the record he set here two years ago as he roared over the route in 1 hour 8 minutes 34.71 seconds.

The results of the Nyon conference caused little satisfaction here although it is felt that the emendation of the conference findings to exclude the phrase which appeared to imply recognition of General Francisco Franco was a last-minute gain for Soviet diplomacy.
Yom Kippur or the Day of Atonement, the most solemn holy day in the Jewish calendar, will be observed beginning tomorrow at sundown and continuing through Wednesday.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler interrupted his routine of parades, speeches and mass demonstrations this morning long enough to receive a group of foreign correspondents, with whom he conversed frankly and quite simply about the international outlook and the situation in Germany and his own plans for his country.

Stocks sharply lower; declines widest since week ended on Oct. 21, 1933; turnover, 9,266,560 shares. United States Government issues steady; corporate and foreign bonds lower; transactions, $42,303,075.
A minor war scare which developed in the world wheat market early last week resulted in a fair upturn in prices but the bulge weakened the technical position;

Walter N. Rothschild, merchant and civic leader, will head the $6,250,000 joint campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities, it was announced last night.

In a radio broadcast to members of the American Legion who will attend the Legion convention opening in-New York City next Monday Major Gen. James G. Harbor, president of the convention organization, told the former service men yesterday that the years since the World War had been among the "most difficult, the most tragic"

The cotton market was rather quiet the first half of last week because of the Labor Day holiday and the disposition of traders to await the Government's crop forecast and the ginning report on Wednesday.

A general reshuffle of ace German diplomats, including the transfer of Ambassador Joachim von Ribbentrop from London to Berlin, where he would replace Dr. Otto Meissner as head of the Presidential Chancellery, is now being considered, The Daily Telegraph reports from Nuremberg.

Almost the oldest and most primitive of man's simple pleasures is the delight in fire. So annually, for those who live in the country and for some who are sentenced to an urban existence, the first cool nights and mornings, forerunners of Fall, have a special recompense.

A policy of employing building craftsmen regardless of union or nonunion affiliation has been made known by the Building Contractors' Association of Southern California, largest building organization in California.

Mgr. Thomas Aquinas Quirk died today in the bleak parish house atop Loveberry Ridge while more than fifty parishioners chanted the rosary for "the Little Father of -the Hills." Half a hundred more were gathered in the churchyard.

Miss Harriet Dorothea Escher, daughter of G. Edward Escher of this place and the late Mrs. Escher, has completed the plans for her marriage to Harrison Ball, son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Arthur Ball of New York and Water Mill, L. I., which will take place here the afternoon of Oct. 1.

President Roosevelt called upon the people of the United States yesterday to participate in the forthcoming nation-wide campaign toraise funds for private health and welfare organizations under the auspices of the Community Mobilization for Human Needs.

Ordinarily, Wall Street considers itself bound to provide for any striking movement on the Stock Exchange the precise explanation. But as regards the violent break in stocks, last Tuesday and Friday, it owned up at the week-end to being completely nonplussed.

Andrew O. Wittreich, one of the three Republican members of the Hudson County Board of Elections, announced today he had ordered the dismissal of all-of the 616 Republican Election Board officers in Jersey City.

It is a religious paradox that the church loses its real power in those periods when it is most powerful, the Rev. Dr. Paul C. Warren, associate pastor, said in a sermon yesterday morning as services were resumed in the renovated West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

The following free concerts will be given today under the auspices of the Federal Music Project: Manhattan Concert Band, Poe Park, 8:30 P. M.; Gramercy Chamber Trio, Seamen's House Y. M. C. A., 550 West Twentieth Street, 7:45 P. M., and Orpheus Group, Hamilton House, 72 Market Street, 8:30 P. M.
Dr. Thomas S. Davis, a practicing physician here for fifty-three years, died today at his home at the age of 85. He was born in Philadelphia and was graduated from Hahnemann Medical College in 1884.

Colonel Royden R. Beebe, who is leaving the Eighteenth Infantry to assume new duties in the Inspector General's office, was guest of honor last night at a dinner tendered by the officers of the regiment, who are taking part in the manoeuvres of the First Division at Indiantown Gap, near here.
Dr. John E. Loveland, who had practiced medicine here since 1893, died today at his Summer home in Old Saybrook of a cerebral hemorrhage at the age of 72.

IN the wake of the final at Forest Hills, some tennis fans have been putting the Don Budge of today up there in the top bracket with the Tilden of yesteryear. That's rushing the net. The long, lean redhead from California is now king of the amateur courts. He has had a remarkable year. He won at Wimbledon.

Royal S. Copeland and his backers for the Democratic nomination for Mayor pressed yesterday, in a last-minute drive for votes, the charge that Hugo L. Black, appointed to the United States Supreme Court by President Roosevelt, was and still is a member of the Ku Klux Klan.

Mr. and Mrs. Merritt C. Randall gave a dinner last night in the Orangerie of the Astor, which was reopened for the season. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Robert Atwood, Mr. and Mrs. George K. Pound, Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Lutes and Captain Harrison W. Wilson.

Harry Rene Lee, adjutant general of the United States Confederate Veterans, said today that "Confederate uniforms and flags will be very much in evidence" at the Blue and Gray reunion at Gettysburg next Summer.

Priscilla Paul, 40 years old, one of Father Divine's "archangels" in his "Heaven" at 20 West 115th Street, was convicted of third-degree assault yesterday in Special Sessions on the complaint of Humility Consolation of 207 West 128th Street, a former archangel in the religious cult.
The Bears haven't ever landed on top in International League playoffs, but this year, Manager Oscar Vitt said today, "it's going to be a different story."

An autopsy performed yesterday at Kings County Hospital on the body of Alice Devine, who was found shot dead on Sunday in George Tong's Chinese laundry, at 4,916 Nineteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, revealed she had not been criminally assaulted.

The Rev. Dr. John W. Schmitthenner, pastor of St. Peter's Evangelical Lutheran Church here since 1935, died yesterday in the South Nassau Hospital following an operation. He was 43 years old and was born in Flushing, L. I.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange has revised its form of requirements for applications for listing of securities to include additional protective provisions for "mortgages, indentures and deeds of trust" and for "trustees for bond issues," the Exchange announced yesterday.

John D. M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, was quoted today as describing the elevation of former Senator Hugo L. Black to the Supreme Court as "the most illadvised appointment ever made to a dignified governmental body."

Retail trade definitely improved in all sections of the country last week, if the volume of mail orders received and the number of visiting buyers here yesterday could be taken as a barometer, according to resident offices.

The Maritime Commission heard objections today from three Atlantic ports to an examiner's report in the Colombian coffee cases. Representatives of Boston, Philadelphia and Norfolk asserted before the commission that the Colombian,

A brisk rally in the United States Government bonds in response to the Treasury's decision to release $300,000,000 of the "sterilized" gold funds did not cheek the decline in domestic corporation bonds in active trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Several West Side properties figured in deals announced by brokers yesterday. The eight-story apartment building containing fifty-two apartments, on the southwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue and, 140th Street, has been purchased by Samuel Yesersky for investment from Adele Kneeland, who has owned the property since 1918, when it was constructed.

Upholding the right of government workers to organize into unions, Mayor S. Davis Wilson declared today that when "elected Governor next year" he would "extend the civil service into every State department and every municipality."
Carl Henrik Henrikson, assistant dean of the School of Business of the University of Chicago, will join the staff of the National Association of Credit Men tomorrow as educational director.

Manhattan Alterations Washington St. 837-43; to two-story offices and market; Zanville Realty Co., Inc., 822 Greenwich St., owner; D. M. Oltarsh, architect; cost, $30,000. 3d St, 86 E; to 5-story tenement and stores; John J. Downey, trustee, 410 W 34th St., Owner; J. Lewis, architect; cost, $15,000.

A total of about $340,000 will be presented to the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation for the fight against infantile paralysis as a result of the birthday balls held throughout the nation on Jan. 29, it was announced yesterday by Keith Morgan, treasurer of the national committee for the Birthday Ball for the President.

Price movements of commodity futures yesterday continued downward in active trading on the local Exchanges. Heavy losses were recorded in rubber, hide and cottonseed oil futures with new seasonal lows being touched. On the cash market silk, Straits tin, antimony and lard advanced, but all the grains, cotton, flour, pork, rubber, printcloths, raw sugar and wool tops declined.

Seyyid Riza, leader of the Kurdish rising in the Dersim region last Spring, of which nothing was known by the public until the Turkish Government had completed the small-scale war required to suppress it, has surrendered to the authorities at Erzinjan, it was learned today.

The crew of the Export liner Exeter, which is scheduled to sail this afternoon for Mediterranean ports, refused to sign the ship's articles yesterday because of the line's rejection of their demand for a bonus of $250 to each man for the risk entailed in entering Spanish waters.
Dr. Charles Gray Shaw, Professor of Philosophy at New York University, declared yesterday that the cause of most of life's unhappiness was summed up in the one phrase, "It's a man's world."

The Manufacturers Trust Company announced yesterday that alterations had been started at 1,717 Kings Highway, Brooklyn, to provide a new office for it. The work is expected to be completed about the end of November, at which time the business of the present Kings Highway branch at 1,709 will be transferred to the new quarters.

Four hoodlums armed with axes, knives and a pistol wrecked the Log Cabin bar and grill, rendezvous of residents of Knickerbocker Village, yesterday in the first case of violence reported to the police as directly attributable to the primary campaign and an outgrowth of the bitter fight for the Tammany leadership of the eastern half of the First Assembly District.

What is really happening in Russia? What is the true meaning of the systematic and ever-widening Soviet purge, now in process for more than a year? The cleansing began in August, 1936, with the public trial and execution for high conspiracy of well-known revolutionary leaders like Zinovieff and Kameneff.

Due to the Labor Day holiday and to the fact that insolvencies usually reach their lowest level in September, business failures in the United States dropped sharply in the five business days ended Sept. 9 to 96, compared with 151 in the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Realty men, who long have contended that real property bears more than its proper share of the tax,burden, are preparing to carry on a more determined campaign in various parts of the, country either to force economies in municipal spending or at least to shift a part of the burden to other sources of revenue.

Shooting started today at Paramount on "Big Broadcast of 1938," starring W. C. Fields. It was Fields's first work before the cameras in eighteen months but the opening day's shooting found him on location at the Bel Air Country Club racing over the fairway on a two-wheeled motor scooter which he has mastered after two weeks of assiduous practice at home.

The marriage of Miss Judith Ann Wilcox, daughter of Mrs. Harold G. Wilcox of this place and the late Dr. Wilcox, to Hugh Wheeler Sanford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh W. Sanford of Knoxville, Tenn., will take place in the Second Congregational Church here on Nov. 24. The Rev. Daniel Bliss,

Mrs. F. Haven Clark of Arlington Street, Boston, and Nahant today announced the engagement of her oldest daughter, Miss Anne Lindsay Clark, to John Aspinwall Roosevelt, youngest and only unmarried son of the President.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ignazio Porto of 421 Van Sicklen Avenue, Brooklyn, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marguerite Porto, to Dr. William L. Bennett of Albany.

One of the largest cash sales in real estate in Yonkers in many years is involved in a plan announced today for payment of an additional 10 per cent dividend to depositors and creditors of the old First National Bank and Trust Company of Yonkers,

The shares will be Continental Can Company, Inc., New York City, has filed .a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 200,000 shares of no-par value $4.50 cumulative preferred stock.

Many employes of THE NEW YORK Times and their families entered the third annual flower show of THE TIMES, which opened yesterday in The Times Annex. The exhibit of flowers, fruit and vegetables will continue until 5 P. M. today, and is open to the public.

With a spirited election in view and amid confusion following withdrawal of several leading candidates, delegates to the adjourned convention of the Episcopal Diocese of Central New York began arriving here today to select a Bishop Coadjutor.

The lofty north rim of the Grand Canyon turned back a party of scientists today on the first leg of a perilous journey to an "island in the sky" which, they hope, will take them 35,000 years back into history.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration is considering action to raise the price of apples. Possibilities of large purchases for relief distribution and of organizing marketing agreements are being studied.

On Aug. 18 Guthrie McClintic was announcing that, come October, he would present Ina Claire on Broadway in a new dramatization of "Barchester Towers." It seems now to be less certain than Mr. McClintic indicated at the time.

A hustling ride by Jonnny Gilbert got Louis Strube's Rust up in the last stride or two to win the Kingdon Class C handicap at Aqueduct yesterday and provide the only thrill of the day for a rain-soaked crowd.

Death Announced Retired Fireman John J. Peterman. formerly a member of Engine 268, residing at 95-23 78th St., Woodhaven, died Sept. 11. Funeral will take place from Brome Funeral Home, 87-20 Woodhaven Boulevard, Woodhaven, at 9:30 A. M., Tuesday, Sept. 14. Interment at St. John's Cemetery. The Deputy Chief of the 13th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen, as funeral escort.

William K. Struss, president of the Bush Terminal Railroad and a director of the Bush Terminal Company, died yesterday at his home, 138 Glenwood Avenue, Staten Island, at the age of 41. He never recovered fully from an attack of pneumonia suffered a year ago.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith last night urged the Democratic voters of the city to vote for Senator Royal S. Copeland, Tammany's Mayoralty candidate, and his running mates, Frank J. Prial and Samuel Levy, in the interest of the people of the city and in the interest of the Democratic party because only the Copeland ticket could "beat the hippodrome artist at the City HalL"
The text of former Governor Alfred E. Smith's address at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night follows: Mrs. Ray. chairman of this im portant meeting, my good friends of Brooklyn:

The Federal Reserve - Treasury plan for a renewed "easy-money" operation, involving the release of $300,000,000 of sterilized gold and the purchase of an 'undisclosed amount of Government securities in the open market was criticized strongly in Wall Street yesterday as a gesture designed to restore bullish sentiment which was unequal to the Purpose.

For the first time since marketing of the new crop started in the South more than six weeks ago, yesterday's quantity of hedges reached proportions that kept contracts under pressure throughout the entire trading session.

The indefatigable Six-Meter Class, which has had about fifty races under all kinds of conditions this Summer, stayed ashore today rather than venture into a raging northeaster, driving rain and towering seas for the scheduled first event of the class' race week.
The Count of Covadonga and his Cuban commoner wife Marta Rocafort appeared before the Court of the First Instance here this morning and ratified their desire for a divorce by "mutual dissension."

George J. Garofalo of 86-17 121st Street. Richmond Hill, Queens, became the fifteenth person filing a designating petition for City Councilman yesterday. Others who have filed include Robert K. Straus and Charles N. Gelber in Manhattan:

The Vatican City police announced today the capture of two men suspected of having taken articles and money valued at more than $5,000 from the apartments of the papal major-domo, Archbishop Mella di Sant' Elia.

Steady, pounding all-day rain drenched New Yorkers yesterday as a storm of near-hurricane intensity swept the Atlantic coast from Maine to Florida. In the city the chill downpour was driven on a forty-eight-mile wind in the coolest weather since May.
The "armed reserves"--peasants who have received land and rifles and pistols from the. Government

Counsel for the Max Fleischer Studios, producers of animated cartoons of "Popeye" and "Betty Boop," challenged yesterday the validity of a National Labor Relations Board decision that the Commercial Artists and Designers Union, an A. F of L. affiliate, be recognized as exclusive collective bargaining agent for all production employes, including animators.

Bankers should devote their efforts to making the banking business popular instead of scoffing at politicians, Thomas J. Kiphart of Cincinati, president of the Financial Advertisers Association, said here today in an address before the twenty-second annual convention of the association.

William Woodward's Omaha, the champion 3-year-old of 1935, who has been racing abroad for more than a year, arrived yesterday on the American Merchant of the United States Line and was shipped at once to the Hancock Stud in Kentucky. where he will stand as a sire.

The Nanking Government admitted last night that the Chinese forces around Shanghai were falling back to prepared positions, running approximately from North Station in Chapei through Tachang and the Liuhang-Lotien sector, about fifteen miles north of Chapei.

For the second day in a row, Ceferino Garcia, in training here for his welterweight title engagement with Champion Barney Ross in the Polo Grounds Carnival of Champions, Sept. 23, today dropped Nick Pastore, a sparring partner, with a right cross that cut short-a two-round workout.

Despite heavy rain, the New York University football squad drilled for more than two hours this morning on a drenched field. In the afternoon the players attended a skull session in the training house.

Regardless of the break in values on the stock exchanges on last Friday, buying in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange on Saturday continued to exceed selling, according to figures made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The annual field day of the Bond Club of New Jersey will be held on Sept. 24 at the Shackamaxon Country Club, Westfield, N. J., Fred J. Brown of H. L. Allen Co., chairman of the field-day committee, announced yesterday.

When we got up with the Americans they were lying under some olive trees along a little stream. The yellow dust of Aragon was blowing over them, over their blanketed machine guns, over their automatic rifles and their anti-aircraft guns.

Despite a driving rain at the very hour of school opening yesterday more than 1,000,000 children reached their classrooms on time as the city's machinery of public education was set in motion for another year.

There were possibly several motives for the Treasury's decision, at the request of the Federal Reserve, to release from its vaults $300,000,000 of the $1,385,761,000 "inactive gold" accumulated since the "sterilizing" order of Dec. 21, 1936.

Warren W. Ayres, vice president and director, has been made president of the Lawrence Portland Cement Company, succeeding the late Frank M. Smith. He has been a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Kean, Taylor Co. since 1925 and will retire from it on Sept. 30.

Squadrons of bombing planes smashed Government resistance south of the Europa Mountains today, enabling one of the Spanish Insurgent columns converging on Gijon to push six miles nearer its objective.

Dan Allen of East Canton, a Republic Steel Corporation employee for twenty years, testified today at a National Labor Relations Board hearing that he was beaten and kidnapped after he and two Republie officials tried to prevent trouble during the steel strike by halting a back-to-work crowd.

The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette publishes today the second in a series of six articles in which it is charged that Hugo L. Black of Alabama, recently appointed to the Supreme Court of the United States, was and still is a member of the Ku Klux Klan.

A complete breakdown of negotiations between the B. M. T. management and the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. 0. affiliate, for higher wages, shorter hours and other improvements in working conditions, was announced last night at union headquarters, 153 West Sixty-fourth Street.
Charles Beach Atwell, professor emeritus at Northwestern University, Evanston, Ill., died yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. John A. Detlefsen. He was 82 years old.

Mrs. Robert Low Bacon, for the last three years vice chairman of the Republican State Committee, is expected to resign soon, and will be succeeded by Assemblywoman Jane Todd of' Westchester, it was learned last night.

The New Jersey State Federation of Labor, which opened Its fiftyninth annual convention here today, voted to expel from membership all organizations affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization. The action,

Mr. and Mrs. George Burnham Calkins of this place have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Marion Calkins, to Leonard Dewes Burgmeyer, son of Mrs. Dewes Burgmeyer of Winnetka and Chicago and of Henry Burgmeyer of Buffalo.

Bernard Kundell, violinist, will be the soloist at the first two symphonic concerts to be given by Macklin Marrow and his New Court Symphony at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, the Bronx, on Sept. 28 and 30.

Massachusetts State varsity football practice got under way today with forty-one candidates reporting to Head Coach Ebb Caraway, who held the workout in the Physical Education Building cage on account of heavy rain.

General Manager Branch Rickey of the Cardinals registered surprise today when his playful pitcher, Dizzy Dean, with whom he has had many verbal wrangles, stepped into his office carrying a pistol and demanded:
Morton D. Wainwright, 72, former Seattle United States deputy marshal, convicted of sending a letter threatening the life of President Roosevelt, was sentenced today to serve a year in jail.

The four champions who will appear on the all-star boxing card at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 23 will ask the New York State Athletic Commission today to force their challengers to weigh in a second time if rain should cause a one-day postponement of the card.
Sale of the St; Paul Volks-Zeitung, German language daily and Sunday newspaper, to Val J. Peter of Omaha, Neb., publisher of several other German language newspapers, was announced today.

India's new Constitution was hailed by the Marquess of Linlithgow, Viceroy of India, as a link binding the British Empire together to resist the suppression of political liberty, in an address from the throne today before the joint session of the Council of State and the Legislative Assembly.

Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Fraser of 123 Waverly Place, Beechhurst, Queens. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rita Elizabeth Fraser, to John Waterhouse of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Waterhouse of Echo Point, Wheeling, W. Va.

Assistant District Attorney Miles M. O'Brien, head of the Homicide Bureau, announced yesterday that the first-degree murder trial of Robert Irwin, the 29-year-old sculptor, in the Gedeon slaying had been indefinitely postponed.
Cleveland at New York--Galehouse vs. Pearson or Andrews. Detroit at Washington--Auker of Poffenberger vs. Krakauskas. St. Louis at Philadelphia--Koupal or Walkup vs. Kelley.
An aged man clad in tattered clothing was taken to a hospital for observation today after police found in his pockets $1,494 in cash and bank books showing deposits of $15,000.

The popular need of the church, in the face of "the turmoil of political upheaval" and the "daily news of wars," was emphasized by Dr. Emmanuel E. Poppen of Columbus, Ohio, acting president, in the opening sermon that he delivered tonight to the more than 300 clerical and lay delegates attending the annual convention of the American Lutheran Church.

Conditions today generally were quiet on the stock market. Nevertheless there was a slight tendency to weakness despite the higher opening in Wall Street. This helped sentiment in some sections, but prices closed mostly lower.

Offering will be made today by Goodwin, Griswold Co., Inc., of 50,000 shares of common stock of the Detroit Compensating Axle Corportion at $3.25 a share. This will be the first public offering of common stock of the company, which hitherto has been privately financed.

O. R. Hood, counsel for the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company of Alabama, sought today to curb activities of counsel for the United Rubber Workers of America in a National Labor Relations Board hearing of charges that the company discriminated against U. R. W. A. members.

Their great spreads of canvas taut in a fresh south-southwest breeze that reached more than 30 miles an hour in gusts and averaged 18 miles during the half-hour preceding the start, the old square-rigged ships Seven Seas and Joseph Conrad today began their long race northward to Newport, R I.

Invitations have been sent out by Mrs. E. Lewis Brown of Maplewood for the marriage of her daughter, Miss Ruth Brown, to Arthur Perrin Britten, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence M. Britten of Maplewood. The ceremony will take place here on Oct. 1 at Prospect Presbyterian Church. The pastor, the Rev.
MANHATTAN EISENBERG, HARRY (July 28, 1935). Gross assets, $385,180; net, $344,889. To Daughters of Jacob Home, Bronx,

Former President Herbert Hoover arrived in New York City yesterday. He will remain for several weeks. Lawrence Richey, an aide, said at the Waldorf-Astoria, where the former President is staying, that Mr. Hoover would attend meetings of a number of boards of directors.

Fearful that deaths or serious injuries might result from further bombings in crowded motion-picture theatres, the Police Department and the District Attorneys of Manhattan and the Bronx launched separate investigations yesterday into the explosion of tear gas and stench bombs in twenty-one theatres Sunday night.
The Rev. Charles J. Deane, Fordham College dean, welcomed 400 freshmen yesterday morning and G pointed out that 100 years ago the first class at Fordham was started with only six students.

Another set in the Old City Fiction Series that was started by Edith Wharton's four stories, "Old New York," some years ago, will be published this week by Appleton-Century. The new set consists of four short novels written by E. V. Lucas and set in London.

The agreement reached on Sunday by officers of the Association of Master Painters and Decorators and District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers was ratified yesterday by the 15,000 members of twelve Manhattan and Bronx locals affiliated with the union.

The British tuna team reeled in seven points today in the international tuna tournament held off this place, while the American team failed to land a single bluefin. Three fish boated today by Wheeler, Baker and Wulff of the British team brought the score to nine to three in favor of the British.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Warner of 1,890 Ditmas Avenue, Brooklyn, and this place, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Warner, to Charles W. Neilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Christian Neilson of Perth Amboy. N. J.

President Roosevelt left here for Washington in a special train at 11 o'clock tonight, a day earlier than he had planned, because of an accumulation of work at the White House. It was indicated there would be a special meeting of the Cabinet tomorrow, in view of the fact that he will be away from the White House on Friday visiting the battlefield of Antietam, where he will make a speech.
A preliminary estimate from the Commerce Department today placed the prospective 1937 national income at $70,000,000,000, an increase of 12 per cent over last year.
The international stock market indices for Sept. 11, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:
Sixty candidates for the Yale football team were registered tonight for practice, including most of last year's regulars who were not graduated in June.

A funeral service for Lady MacNeal, the former Edith Gould, was held yesterday afternoon at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-third Street, with only a few friends, servants and members of her family present. Lady MacNeal,
Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of Hunter College, welcomed 1,200 members of the freshman class yesterday at a special meeting at the Adams Memorial Church, 207 East Thirtieth Street.

The eighteenth anniversary of the founding of the Communist party in the United States on Sept. 1, 1919, was observed last night at a meeting arranged by the Communist party in Madison Square Garden and attended by about 15,000 persons.

China's appeal, made yesterday at the opening of the regular session of the League of Nations Assembly, is unhappily of little immediate consequence, for there is no expectation of any effective response.

Governor Bibb Graves of Alabama admitted Saturday that he formerly was a member of the Ku Klux Klan. denied that he still is, and said he "could not recall" ever meeting former Senator Hugo L. Black, now an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, at any Klan meetings or conferences.

With a view to preventing the abuse of the British flag in Chinese waters the Board of Trade has advised masters of British ships bound for Chinese ports that in the absence of a British warship they should, if requested to heave to by a Japanese warship, allow Japanese officers to examine the certificate of registry.
With city and State police and officials forming a guard of honor, first notables arrived here tonight for the National Governors Conference opening tomorrow.

More than 90 per cent of the companies doing an export business with China have retired from that market for the time being and are seeking replacement business elsewhere, particularly Latin America, Oren O. Gallup, export manager for the Faultless Caster Company, and secretary of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., reported here yesterday.

Now what is the explanation for the Soviet's unceasing purge of allegedly disloyal elements and its dragnet hunt for spies? The precise reasons are hidden behind the inscrutable Kremlin walls and the grim graygreen Lubyanka prison-headquarters of the political police, with its execution chambers beneath-and they may never be known.

Ten men, nine of whom gave their occupations as newspaper men, were arrested on disorderly conduct charges last night during mass picketing at the plant of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, 24 Johnson Street, where a strike of editorial and commercial employes was called by the American Newspaper Guild unit there after the last of the evening editions was on the street.

The Westchester County Board of Supervisors and the New York City Board of Water Supply reached an agreement today designed to rid Westchester home owners of annoyances caused by the construction of New York's new Delaware Aqueduct under the county.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad announced yesterday that it is to build twenty steel cabooses in its shops in Sayre, Pa. The cars are to contain all the latest improvements and, according to the company, experts on safety declare they will be the safest to be constructed.
A squad of twenty-three candidates for the Union College football team settled down to work in earnest today under the watchful eye of Coach Nelson Nitchman.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with some alarm the letter of William P. Thomas. If the majority of Americans held his views on our participation in the apparently forthcoming European war it would be far more tragic than most of us could conceive.

Six more teams were eliminated today in the national amateur baseball tournament, leaving thirteen to battle for the title Only four are undefeated. Fisher Foods of Cleveland, 1936 champions, remained in the running, defeating Barberton, Ohio, 4 to 3, although held to four hits by Russ Garcia.

Lehman Brothers and R. W. Pressprich Co. jointly obtained the award yesterday of a new issue of $2,000,000 of relief bonds of Milwaukee County, Wis., on their bid of par, plus a premium of $440, for 1.20 per cent notes. The bonds,
Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. D Sherwood of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Sherwood, to Martin V. Callagy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin F. Callagy of New York.

Much has been said by certain critics of the Supreme Court concerning its lost prestige, and only a few days ago President Roosevelt expressed the opinion that there has been a decline of confidence in the judicial process -a "widening chasm between the people on the one side and the courts and the bar on the other."

Eugene Kirkby, one of the new directors of the. Trenton Valley Distillers Corporation, notified the Securities and Exchange Commission today that the company's board had voted to admit general deficiencies in the registration statement for 273,000 shares of common stock, on which the SEC's current stop-order proceedings have been based, and would file stipulations to that effect, consenting to a stop order.

Mrs. Oakley Sheldon of 170 East Seventy-eighth Street and Bethlehem, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alelhia Brandford Sheldon, to R. Alastair Macleod of 210 East Sixtyeighth Street, younger son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Macleod of Sun Court, Hadleigh, Suffolk, England.

An Appellate Division inquiry into charges of unprofessional conduct against Dana Wallace, former District Attorney of Queens County be and a practicing lawyer for thirtyseven years, began yesterday before Official Referee Burt Jay Humphrey in the Brooklyn Municipal Building.
Luncheon meeting, Lions Club, Hotel Astor, 12:30 P. M. Address by William Griffin. Luncheon, Sales Executives Club, Hotel Roosevelt, 12:30 P. M. Address by Harry Boyd Brown.

John D. M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, was in New York City yesterday and conferred with other Republican leaders on party finances. He scrupulously refrained from discussing the local Mayoralty situation, which all national leaders believe has a bearing on the 1940 election.

Intelligence tests taken today by thirty New Jersey police officers enrolled in the traffic officers' training school at Rutgers University resulted in a much higher rating than the national police average, it was announced by Lawrence B. Tipton, director of the school.

Mrs. Edith Livingston Fryer Test, wife of Colonel Frederick C. Test, U. S. A., died Saturday night in the Walter Reed General Hospital, Washington, D. C., in her fifty-fifth year. She was a native of Albany, N. Y., a daughter of Alexander and Clara Catlin Fuller Fryer.

The marriage or Miss Julla Hall Owsley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Ebsworth Owsley of this city, to John Goodyear, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradley Goodyear of Springfield Center, N. Y., will take place in the Emanuel Episcopal Church in Greenwood, Va., on the afternoon of Oct. 2.

In taking first steps here today to file appeals from the convictions of Ellis H. Parker, chief of Burlington County detectives, and his son, Ellis Parker Jr., for conspiracy in the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, attorneys for e defendants said the Parkerq were unable to pay the cost of printing the records, which will be filed with the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

For the ninth time in as many years, the Irish Free State team will compete in the nightly international military jumping contests at the National lorse Show to be staged at Madison Square Garden from Nov. 3 to 10.

Mayor La Guardia faced yesterday his first and perhaps his only Republican audience during the primary campaign. The occasion was a luncheon under the auspices of the Women's Division of the Republican Primary Campaign Committee for La Guardia, held in the big ballroom at the Hotel Commodore.

The effects of the Treasury-Federal Reserve plan to spend the proceeds of $300,000,000 of gold now held in the inactive fund may be expected to show up soon in the money market. Indirectly they began to appear yesterday when the Treasury canceled a "call" for repayment by depositary banks of $49,000,000 which had been scheduled for tomorrow.
Buick automobile models for 1938 were unveiled here today in a press preview for some 200 automobile editors and technical writers from all parts of the country.

Work started today on the Banco Popular Building, which will be ten stories high and constructed of reinforced concrete. It will be the island's tallest building and possibly the tallest in the Caribbean.
The supply ship General A. W. Greely is now well anchored off Reindeer Point near Egah, Greenland. Weather observations have been started and a pilot balloon is sent aloft daily.
Although Harvard's football drills will not start until Wednesday, twenty-seven candidates, including most of the veterans, reported at Soldiers Field today for equipment.

The slight downward trend of food sales which had lasted several weeks has been halted by a definite pickup since Labor Day, the American Institute of Food Distribution reported yesterday. Sales records for August show a drop in comparison with August, 1936, when sales were running sharply ahead of the previous year. Late August,

Winner of two straight races on fast tracks, Mrs. Stephen Orr's Hope Eternal came back in the sloppy going at Narragansett Park today to make it three in a row as she triumphed by a length and a half in a field of five horses in the mile-and-a-sixteenth Sharon Purse.
Thomas Garrigue Masaryk, founder and first President of Czechoslovakia, died at 3:29 this morning. Heart trouble was the chief cause of death but there were lung complications. He was 87 years old.

A trail of counterfeit quarters from New York to Washington, halted before James K. Cullen, United States Commissioner, here today when a boy and a girl testified that their father made them "pass" the fake money.

Bids for 2,798,675 yards of assorted textiles for the Works Progress Administration were asked today by the Procurement Division of the Treasury Department. The bids will be opened Sept. 24, with delivery Oct. 30. The list follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13.-David Saperstein, director of the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission since Aug. 1, 1934, has resigned to re-enter the private practice of law in New York City, the commission announced today.

Chairman Kennedy of the Maritime Commission said today -that building plans for shipping which Congress sponsored in the new Subsidy Act, together with the merchant marine's needs, possibilities and costs of rehabilitation, can be determined only after digesting the survey now under way.
Mrs. Laura E. Felter of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Virginia Bedman Felter, to Jerome Putnam White, son of Mrs. Clara M. White.

Brilliant runs by Dick Nye and Phil (Flea) Clinton enabled the West Chester State Teachers varsity football team to outscore Rutgers in a practice game today in the rain, 12-6. The teams played an hour and a half. Many substitutions were made by both coaches.

Under the most difficult and discouraging conditions, the tracking contest scheduled in connection with the annual specialty competition of the Obedience Test Club was held today on the estate of Henry J. Whitehouse in this town.

In a series of leases and purchases the Gottfried Baking Company has assembled a T-shaped parcel fronting on Eleventh Avenue and on Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets, upon which, after demolishing the buildings now existing on the plot it will construct a twostory garage which will occupy 17,500 square feet.

Although this town of 3,000 inhabitants was still excited today over the triumph of Bette Cooper, 17-year-old high school girl, in the Atlantic City beauty contest on Saturday, Miss 'Cooper remained secluded in her home.

The Osservatore Romano announces today that Pope Pius has. sent a "conspicuous sum" to Catholic missions in China especially ..those in the Shanghai region which have been particularly hard hit by the present Sino-Japanese conflict.

Many new apartment tenants listed yesterday by brokers and renting agents found their wants satisfied in buildings on Park Avenue and in the midtown, district. The length of the day's report indicated little slackening in the search for new accommodations.

Dr. Thomas J. Conte, defending champion, turned in a 78 to take first honors in the qualifying round of the New York Athletic Club's closed golf championship today at the Winged Foot Golf Club. The heavy rain kept all but four from competing in this, the twenty-fifth, annual tournament.

The Export Steamship Corporation, 25 Broadway, through a new subsidiary, American Export Airlines, expects to establish a new transatlantic airline direct from New York to Lisbon, Portugal, it was learned yesterday.

Counsel for the Austin Silver Mining Company opened yesterday its defense against the stop-order proceedings instituted by the Securities and Exchange Commission, based on the Government's allegation that a misleading registration statement
