Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Florence Louise Moser, daughter of Mrs. George Moser of this place and the late Mr. Moser, to William Arthur Sullivan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Sullivan of Yonkers, N. Y. The wedding will take place here on Oct. 4.

New York City and New York University entered a partnership yesterday to study sanitary engineering. The partnership became effective with the formal dedication at 11 A. M. of the joint research and sanitation laboratory at Burnside and Sedgwick Avenues, University Heights, the Bronx.

The new proxy committee that has been formed to solicit proxies to be voted at the annual meeting of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company started its drive yesterday by mailing to shareholders of the company a letter requesting authorization to act for them at the meeting. In the letter Ernest A.

MANHATTAN CARUCCI, Peter (July 17). Estate, about $5,000. To Adelina Carucci Bracigllano, niece, executrix, 335 E. 114th St. FLECK, HENRY T. (Sept. 6). Estate, not more than $6,000. To Harry D. and Donaid D. Fleck, sons, 587 Riverside Dr.. life estate in residue. August Kleb, 284 Hancock St., Brooklyn, executor.

The stock market decline has left business unaffected except in a superficial way, a check of retail and industrial buyers indicated here yesterday. Stores are proceeding with normal purchasing for Fall requirements, while purchasing agents for industrial plants are covering their requirements in most commodities to the end of the year in the expectation of a normal season of Fall production.

Automobile accidents, deaths and injuries in the city decreased last week as compared with the same period in 1936, according to figures made public yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine. The weekend showed a decrease in the number of accidents and injuries but an increase in fatalities.

Application for a temporary. administrator of the estate of the late Mrs. Frederic de Puyster Foster was made here today before Surrogate Charles Taylor of Orange County by former Supreme Court Justice Humphrey J. Lynch, representing the two Foster servants, who claim to be the sole and equal beneficiaries under a document purporting to be the second and last will.
Bobby Pacho, Mexican welterweight challenger, battered his way to an eight-round decision over Harry Rubin of Philadelphia tonight. Pacho scaled 1491/2 and Rubin was one pound lighter.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marian Greenlee, daughter of Mrs. Ralph Stebbins Greenlee of this place and Chicago and the late Mr. Greenlee, to Detmar H. Finke, son of Mrs. Detmar Heinrich Finke of New York and the late Mr. Finke of Bremen, Germany.

The radio broadcasts of the American Legion convention opening in New York City next Monday are expected to be the most extensive since the inauguration of President Roosevelt in January, it was announced yesterday from the headquarters of the American Legion 1937 Convention Corporation, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

A Negro house painter who took time between brush strokes to admire the easel paintings of Mrs. Max Eastman has started her upon a career as a painter of murals, she disclosed here today. Her murals have been hung in a church and a saloon in Ossining.

Having driven all Chinese soldiers from Chahar Province in operations in Northwest China in the last two weeks, Japanese forces are now well within the borders of Shansi Province, and yesterday they captured Tatung, second city of the province and an important railroad junction, it was officially announced today.

Still clinging tenaciously to their game-and-a-half lead in the National League's torrid pennant race, the Giants, with Colonel Bill Terry in high command and Rear Admiral Eddie Brannick making certain no stragglers are left behind, plunged resolutely over the Alleghenies last night for their final sweep around the Wsetrn loop, with the flag at stake.

Former President Marcelo de Alvear, Radical party candidate, continued to lead Roberto M. Ortiz, candidate of the Conservative coalition of President Agustin P. Justo, in Argentina's Presidential election today.

Mrs. Bula E. Croker, widow of the one-time leader of Tammany Hall, Richard Croker, was adjudged bankrupt in Federal court at Miami today after filing a voluntary petition, which listed heavy debts and cited Palm Beach ocean front propertv as her chief asset.

Miss Ann Boardman Reynolds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Wilson Reynolds of this place, has chosen Oct. 2 as the date for her marriage to Rockwell Braddock Ward, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Burwell Ward, also of West Hartford. The ceremony will take place in St John's Church here.

13.-A crowd of several thousand persons hailed the news tonight that the former Mayor of Rio de Janeiro, Pedro Ernesto Baptista, convicted of sedition last May, had been acquitted by the Supreme Military Tribunal on an appeal.

There is no danger of a European war, according to Grover Whalen, president and commissioner general of New. York World's Fair 1939, Inc., who returned yesterday on the Normandie of the French Line after a fortnight's visit abroad.

The engagement of Miss Dorothy Emerson Denton of 1,095 Park Avenue and Old Greenwich, Conn., to Eldon Frederick Le Poer Power, son of Mrs. Frederick Joseph Power of London, England, and the late Mr. Power, has been announced by her cousins, Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Jackson.
Wallace Beery shot himself in the leg today with a blank cartridge. Studio officials thought it would be several weeks before he could resume his role.

The French franc gave further evidence yesterday of having found a steadying point, after its severe fall of last week. It clung throughout the day to a range between 3.567/8 cents and 3.58 cents and closed at 3.571/2 cents, unchanged from Saturday's final price.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company of New York petitioned the Federal District Court today for the second time to be admitted as an intervenor in the reorganization of the Philadelphia Reading Coal and Iron Companv.

American Fruit Growers, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on June 30 a net profit of $571,491 after interest, depreciation, miscellaneous surplus charges, normal Federal income taxes and other deductions.
Light on what is happening in Russia is thrown by the newspaper Red Karelia, official organ of the Soviet Karelian Autonomous Republic.
Week-end arrivals increased the Wesleyan football squad to twentyfive men today but heavy rain necessitated holding the practice in the field house.
Stocks rallied at close after falling 2 to 10 points from opening levels; turnover, 2,561,820 shares. United States Government issues active and higher, other bonds lower; transactions, $10,084,525.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Burton Strait of San Diego, Calif., of the engagement of their granddaughter, Miss Suzanne Hart Strait of this city and San Diego, to George Henry Fremon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Fremon of St. Louis.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 11, unless specified: Boston Yard to St. Thomas, V. I.: Arkansas, Wyoming. At New York Yard, Sept. 12: Dahlgren, Potomac, Vega. Boston Yard to sea, Sept. 13: Decatur, Dickerson, Fairfax, Herbert, Leary,
Norbert (Cyclone) Warkem, from the hills of Kentucky, achieved the remarkable accomplishment today of pitching two no-hit games in succession in the national softball championships.

The obligations of Jews to their own people will be discussed in sermons by rabbis tonight and tomorrow in temples and synagogues where thousands will gather to observe the Day of Atonement, or Yom Kippur.

Automobile production last week declined only little more than the holiday would warrant. Due to the small change likely this year as a result of the changing over to new models, it has been considered advisable to revise the seasonal factors upward.

A new and grave incident has arisen in the Chaco situation as the result of the arrest of two neutral military observers by a Paraguayan patrol within the neutral zone set up by the Chaco Deace conference.

Guy Austin Peck, vice president and general manager in charge of Edison Wood Products, Inc., subsidiary of Thomas A. Edison Industries, died today of a heart ailment at his home here. His age was. 47.

Governor Rivers announced today that the State Board of Education had canceled its contract with Henry Holt Co. of New York for a public-school text book because the book said Massachusetts was the first State in which ether was used as an anesthetic.

Retail prices continued the uninterrupted advance in August which began in the corresponding month last year, according to the Fairchild Index issued yesterday. Prices on Sept. 1 show the same increase as compared with a year ago that was recorded on Aug. 1, which was three-tenths of 1 point.

Following is the text of Mayo La Guardia's address yesterday a the Hotel Comemodore luncheon: Madam Chairman, ladies and men, who are here by tolerance: The Mayor is deeply -grateful for your invitation, and I am glad of the opportunity to clarify the situation. You know, there is a new technique developing in the art of campaigning.

The Michigan football forces sprang a surprise today with a twohour scrimmage on the third day of the Big Ten practice season, a manoeuvre for which veteran observers could remember no precedent. Fred Trosko, sophomore halfback, played well.

The American Bridge Company has taken an order for 2,500 tons of steel for the upper deck administration building and toll booths for the Henry Hudson Bridge, New York, and Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation has booked 1,600 tons for a warehouse for the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company.

" Mrs. Jones," average American woman and the subject of the essay that won first prize in a contest conducted by the New York League of Business and Professional Women, was praised by Mayor La Guardia last night at the league dinner given at the Hotel Biltmore to announce the awarding of the prizes.

H. A. Scandrett, president of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, has filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission a petition; which was made public today, asking for an indefinite postponement of the reorganization proceedings for the railroad.
Arthur Coward, father of Noel Coward, actor and playwright, died here yesterday at his Kentis farm at the age of 81.

The first public utterance came from Japan's bankers concerning the Government's stringent financial and economic policies today. It was fatalistic and envisioned a "third party" in the Sino-Japanese war.

General liquidation developed in the wheat market on the Board of Trade here today following an arly upturn of around one cent a bushel and the decline was not checked until prices had dropped around 4 cents from the high level and into new low ground for the season.

The League of Nations Assembly was opened today by Dr. Juan Negrin, Premier of war-torn Spain, as president of the League Council. He yielded the chair on the election of the Aga Khan, India's delegate, president of the Assembly.
Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York said yesterday that he could support "no man for public office who subscribes to the bigoted views of an organization like the Ku Klux Klan."

Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of baseball, tonight called a meeting of officials of the contending clubs in the National and American Leagues to meet here Saturday morning to arrange World Series details.

That well-known cry of the British turf! "Come on Steve!" will be heard no more. Steve Donoghue, now 52, has decided to call it quits as a jockey and will devote his time hereafter to training. He will preside over some racing stables at Newbury in Berkshire.

The action of the Government in freeing $300,000,000 of "sterilized" gold in an effort to lighten the credit needs of the country acted as a boomerang on the stock market yesterday, and the liquidation of last week returned with greater momentum.

The International Casino, Broadway's newest night club, restaurant and cocktail lounge in Times Square between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets, was dedicated yesterday and is now scheduled, after a series of postponements, to open Friday night.

The Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions has sold to Joseph L. Ennis Co. the vacant plot on the west side of the Grand Concourse, 107 feet south of 140th Street, the Bronx. It fronts 101 feet on the Concourse an 55 feet on the northerly line, by irregular depth.

Captain Frank H. Roberts, U. S. N., secretary of the Naval War College, and Mrs. Roberts have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sabra Roberts, to Smith Hempstone Oliver of New York, a son of Captain Fred Lansing Oliver, U. S. N. retired, and Mrs. Oliver of New York.

The names of 412 enrolled Democrats were ordered stricken from the registration. lists yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter. At the same time, Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente took under consideration a series of motions made by supporters of Jeremiah T. Mahoney in the Mayoralty race to strike out 5,000 more names.

The Chicago Board of Education began today its newspaper-radio courses of instruction by which it hopes to keep about 300,000 elementary school pupils abreast of their studies during the suspension of classes due to the outbreak of infantile paralysis.

Mr. and Mrs. William Parker Kirk of this place have announced the coming marriage of their daughter, Miss Florence Henley Kirk, to Alfred Wheeler Roberts Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred W. Roberts of Allendale,

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 10: Jones, Capt. H. A., when discharged from treatment at the Naval Hospital, San Diego, Calif., ordered home, relieved from all active duty.

The French Government announced tonight a reward of 100,000 francs for information leading to the arrest of the criminal or criminals responsible for the bombings here Saturday night of the headquarters of two employers' associations.

Thomas Masaryk made one of his last public appearances as President of the republic he founded riding a white charger down Wenceslas Square in Prague. But for the warmth of the acclaim he received from the cheering crowds,

William M. Leader, president of Branch 1 of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers and head of the local C. I. 0. council, was made defendant with two other union officials today in contempt of court proceedings brought by the Crystal Hosiery Mills Corporation.

Mark Redmond, a first-grade detective attached to the West 123d Street station, died on Sunday in the Royal Hospital, 2,021 Grand Concourse, the Bronx. He was 40 years old and lived at 4,316 Edson Avenue, the Bronx.

An increase in the volume of dry goods offered at auction was reported here yesterday by leading auctioneers, while those specializing in furniture and kindred lines said they were handling a slightly lower amount of goods.

The Admiralty today rushed forward plans for carrying out the British part of the Mediterranean patrol under the Nyon agreement, while the Mediterranean command began quick action to readjust itself to its new responsibilities.
Tobacco Mrs. H. A. Torriente's 4-year-old, showed a great burst of speed in the stretch to win the sixth race at the Fair Grounds today.

Samuel Reshevsky of New York, chess champion of the United States, and Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia, who are tied for the lead in the international masters tournament, are scheduled to meet for the first time in the fifth round tomorrow.

The Duke and Duchess of Roxburghe, accompanied by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Goelet, have returned from Newport and are at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Gourlay Thacher have left the Pierre to pass the Autumn in Glen Cove.

The five members of the Senate who could be reached here today were unanimously of the opinion that Associate Justice Hugo L. Black's membership or non-membership in the Ku Klux Klan could have no possible bearing on his eligibility to take the oath of office as a member of the Supreme Court, now that he has been confirmed by the Senate In accordance with the Constitution.
This is the sixth of a series of articles on Eastern college football teams and their prospects for the season.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works, including the Midvale Company, reported orders of $4,234,568 accepted in August, against $1,844,545 in August, 1936. This lifted bookings for the first eight months of the year to $26,217,029, against $21,372,767 in the same period last year.

The marriage of Miss Doris R. Oxer, daughter of Mrs. William R. Oxer of Greenwich and the late Mr. Oxer, to Henry W. Staby of Pound Ridge, N. Y., will take place on Saturday at the Summerfield Methodist Episcopal Church.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles A Robinson of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Jean Robinson, to Everett W Redfearn. son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Redfearn, also of East Orange.

Thomas F. McDonald, a retired police inspector, died on Saturday at his home, 152-11 Eighty-fifth Drive, Jamaica, Queens, of a heart attack after a long illness. Inspector McDonald, who was 63 years old, won the medal of honor in 1902 for saving two persons from drowning.

President Roosevelt is expected to give intensive consideration to the Far Eastern situation upon his return from Hyde Park tomorrow. He will receive detailed reports from Secretary of State Cordell Hull and take up various phases of it with his Cabinet either tomorrow or during the next few days.

A direct challenge to the International Typographical Union to take a definite stand on the question of affiliation with the Committee for Industrial Organization was made today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in a speech before the printers' convention.

Admiral Sir Charles Little, commanding the British fleet in China waters, lost his temper yesterday. As a result, Britons in particular and foreigners in general expect much less difficulty henceforth in obtaining Japanese passes to enter Hongkew and Yangtzepoo to survey damage to their homes and businesses and to salvage whatever is left of their warehouses.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 13.-Mr. and Mrs.. Lindley E. Parker of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rachel Warner Parker of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., to Dr. Lyman C. Craig, son of Coy Craig of Carlisle, Iowa, and the late Mrs. Craig. The wedding will take place in the Winter.

After a chase on foot through Times Square, Andrew Cianelli, 19 years old, was arrested and charged with grand larceny early last night on the complaint of Fyodore Nazinoff, whose pocket he is alleged to have picked in the lobby of- the Times Square Theatre, 229 West Forty-second Street.
The court surgeon, Dr. I. P. Hartmann, performed an intestinal operation on Queen Alexandrine shortly before last midnight at the hospital at Skagen, where she was taken yesterday morning.
The engagement of Miss Shirley Joyce Zaglin. daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Zaglin of Brooklyn, to Dr. Harold Lefft, also of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents.

More than 6,000 cleaners and dyers in the five boroughs stopped work yesterday in response to a C. I. O. strike call, but representatives of large chain organizations reported that their business was affected only slightly.
Gerald Savory, 27-yearold author pf the London comedy hit, "George and Margaret," wrote the play in six weeks and "didn't think much of it" until it was finished.
George G. Goodwin, assistant curator of mammals of the American Museum of Natural History, returned to his desk yesterday after a three-month expedition in the Canadian Northwest Territories.
George G. Goodwin, assistant curator of mammals of the American Museum of Natural History, returned to his desk yesterday after a three-month expedition in the Canadian Northwest Territories.

Arthur A. Fisk, president of the Insurance Advertising Conference, told 100 members of the organization, in annual convention at Briarcliff Lodge today, that newspapers were among the most valuable media for all types of insurance advertising and that their use should be expanded.

Again in the quest for the secret of cancer was indicated at the International Congress on Radiology here today with the announcement by Dr. Hillyer Rudisill Jr. of Charleston, S. C., that he and a co-worker had found out what happens in a cell of the human body when it is killed by an X-ray beam.

Dr. Hiram W. Evans, Imperial Wizard of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, asserted tonight that Justice Black is not now a member of the Klan, but refused to discuss charges made by The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette that Mr. Black joined it in 1923 at Birmingham, Ala., "resigned" in 1925 and received life membership in 1926.
The United States carried off two Individual titles in the world weight-lifting championships just completed at the Sports Palace.
Summoned by a note' tied to the collar of a pet white poodle, a physician sought today to save the life of Mrs. Christine H. Toth, 70 years old, a victim of toadstool poisoning.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Seaver Jr. of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothea M. Seaver, to Samuel Powel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Powel of Providence, R. I.

A committee of independent holders of bonds of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, headed by Charles A. Beard as chairman, has petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission to oppose any reorganization plan of the road which would result in any of its reorganization securities going to the Alleghany Corporation.

Arraigned on an indictment charging first degree murder, Stanley Martin Jr., 29, of 305 West Ninety-eighth Street, pleaded not guilty yesterday before County Judge Thomas Downs in Long. Island City. Date for trial was set for Oct. 18.

The Fifth Ward Savings Bank of Jersey City sold to Isaac Adelman for investment the house containing five apartments and a store at 235 Avenue E, Bayonne, N. J. Julius A. Rose was the broker. Robert Hoehl brought from the Hudson Trust Company the apartment house at 67-69 Park Avenue, Guttenberg, through J. I. Kislak, Inc.

Steel operations in the United States are scheduled at 80.4 per cent of capacity for the c--rrent week, as compared to 71.6 per cent in the previous week, including Labor Day, a gain of 8.8 points or 12.3 per cent, and to 84.1 per cent in the week before Labor Day, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports. A month ago the rate was 83.2 per cent.

Mayor Daniel J. Shields of Johnstown, who was one of the most active opponents of the C. I. O. strike against the Bethlehem Steel Company's Cambria plant here last June, ignored yesterday a subpoena by the National Labor Relations Board to its hearing here.

The Japanese Ambassador to China, Shigeru Kawagoe, fidgeted nervously today in his machine-gun protected official residence and declared Americans and other foreigners in Shanghai should not be "unnecessarily apprehensive" of thei safety.

Cardinal Segura y Saenz, formerly Archbishop of Toledo and Primate of Spain, was appointed Archbishop of Seville by Pope Pius today. He resigned his Toledo See soon after the advent of the republican regime, in order to avoid embarrassments that might have been created by his presence, since it was well known he was devoted to the monarchical cause.

For weeks now Mr. Copeland and Mr. Mahoney have been debating with each other regarding the merits of the New Deal, and Mr. Copeland has been asking Mr. Mahoney what he would have done if he had been Senator In 1934, and what he thinks of the soldiers bonus.
Word was received here today of the death yesterday of the Rev. Peter Maguire, C. P., former pastor of St. Michael's Monastery parish here, at St. Joseph's Hospital, Hancock, Mich. His age was 43.
A team averaging 186 pounds and including nine men who won their major letters against Army was picked today by Lieutenant Harry J. (Hank) Hardwick, head football coach at the Naval Academy.

President Roosevelt declined to comment today on stories being printed by The Pittsburgh PostGazette, THE NEW YORK TIMES and other newspapers that Associate Justice Hugo L. Black of the United States Supreme Court was a member of the Ku Klux lan.

Following a military display that thrilled a quarter of a million German onlookers with the realization of the power of their rapidly increasing air force and highly mechanized new army, Chancellor Adolf Hitler closed the National Socialist Congress here tonight with a new tirade against bolshevism and a declaration of Germany's relentless opposition to any extension of its influence.

S. Liebovitz Sons, cotton converters, in 261 5th Ave.; Harry Thoens Co., brokers. S. Wyler, Inc., silversmiths, store for branch at 681 Lexington Ave.; Albert A. Samuels and Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers. Mrs. Julia Lauri, hosiery and corsets, store at 3,644 Broadway; George R. Read Co., brokers.

An opinion by Carman G. Blough, chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission, outlining a procedure which would prevent write-ups arising in the consolidation of accounts by a parent company with those of its subsidiaries through the elimination of only a part of the investment account was issued today by the commission.

Ellis Parker, Butler, author of "Pigs is Pigs" and other books, died today in the near-by village of Williamsville, where he had lived the life of a retired country gentleman for the last two years. He was 67 years old.

Miss Dorothy Clark Bellah, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Bellah of this place, became the bride tonight in St. James Episcopal Church of Henry Orlando Marcy 3d, son of Mrs. Henry Orlando Marcy Jr. of Newton, Mass., and the late Dr. Marcy. The rector,

THE SAVAGE. HITS BACK, by Julius Lips. (Yale University Press, $5.) What savage peoples think of civilization. THE MAKING OF A SCIENTIST, by Raymond L. Ditmars. (Macmillan, $2.75.) Partly autobiographical.

New authorizations of all kinds by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation rose to $159,728,694 in August, due chiefly, however, to one of $150,000,000 to the Commodity Credit Corporation in connection with the cotton loan program.
Joe Louis received the National Boxing Association's official ranking as world heavyweight champion today to the tune of some caustic remarks about the Brown Bomber's fight with Tommy Farr.

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding declined $7,675,196 in August to $343,881,754, at which level it showed an increase of $35,769,613 over a year ago, according to the monthly acceptance survey of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, issued yesterday.
Since there must be schools and new school years yesterday was a perfectly ideal day for New York's school children to go back to their

Police Department orders issued yesterday disclosed that Detective William J. (Bill) Quaine, who for years used his fists instead of his service pistol to throttle gangsterism in Harlem's Little Italy, will retire voluntarily at midnight tomorrow. He is 58 years old,

A million and a half homeless, hungry, disease-ridden war refugees were packed into Shanghai's foreign settlements today. They constituted a menace to the city's safety that was paralleled only by the war itself.

The eighth-place Reds unconditionally released Manager Charley Dressenand Coaches Tom Sheehan and George Kelly today, paid them in full on their season's contracts, and named Bobby Wallace, veteran of nearly a half century in baseball, as acting pilot.

Ray Steele, veteran mat campaigner, defeated Hank Barber of Cambridge, Mass., in the feature wrestling exhibition at the New York Hippodrome last night. A crowd of about 1,000 witnessed the encounter, which was not particularly thrilling or exciting.

The Soviet Foreign Office today informed the Japanese Embassy here that the Soviet Government had. withdrawn consular rights and privileges from Japanese consuls at Odessa on the Black Sea and Novosibirsk in Western Siberia.

Nation-wide launching of men's hat advertising campaigns for Fall is scheduled for this week, provided the weather turns more propitious for retail purchasing, manufacturers said yesterday. Yesterday, Weber Heilbroner broke large-space copy for Stetson hats, but other stores and manufacturers held up copy in newspaper offices pending a clearing of the weather.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 10,000, including 2,000 directs. The market was generally 25-40 cents higher than Friday's average; medium-grade hogs and packing sows, 35-50 cents up late:

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, due today from England and France, includes Bishop and Mrs. Francis J. McConnell, Sir Humphrey Milford, Mr. and F. Mrs. William Lescaze, Mrs. Price Collier, aunt of President Roosevelt; Lady Crawford,

Formation of a nation-wide "nonpartisan" organization known as the Knights of Progress, which is dedicated to Americanism and which will combat "any subversive activities, schemes or plans aimed at the sanctity and security of these United States of America," was announced yesterday afternoon by Lewis B. Smith, self-styled "chairman of the board of national directors."

Having reported unfavorably last year on a proposal that a ship canal 27 feet deep and 300 feet wide be constructed across New Jersey from Bordentown to Sayreville, a special board of army engineers advised the State Board of Commerce and Navigation today that a survey was being made to determine cost and utility of a barge canal 14 feet deep and 150 feet wide.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. - The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 8.

Basic minimum wage rates for men of 331-3 cents an hour and $15 a week, second highest in Canada, will go into effect in Alberta Oct. 1, it was announced here today by E. C. Manning, Provincial Minister of Trade and Industry.

Secretary Morgenthau expressed gratification today at the reaction of the bond market to the money-easing program announced this morning, whereby $300,000,000 of sterilized gold held by the Treasury will be used to supply the banks with money while the Federal Reserve Banks in open market operations will buy short-term Government securities to the same end.
Apart from an accelerated pace in dealings among the Transatlantics, which closed on a generally improved note, the stock market today was an extremely quiet affair.

The challenge cricket match between Yorkshire, champion county, and Middlesex ended today in a smashing victory for the former by an innings and 115 runs. Yorkshire's total of 401 proved altogether too high for the challengers, who were dismissed for 185 and 101.

The lower raw cotton market and the maintenance of the higher raw wool values were reflected yesterday in opening prices for the Spring, 1938, season on men's underwear and bathing suits, the first dry goods items to be priced for next season. Men's and boys'

The Rev. Dr. Oliver J. Hart, rector of St. John's Church at Washington, was elected Coadjutor Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Central New York on the fifth ballot at the diocesan convention, held in Trinity Church here today.

Fifteen hundred special Deputy Attorneys General, selected from both major political parties, will be appointed to serve throughout the five counties of the city for tomorrow's primary election. AttorneyGeneral John Bennett Jr. announced yesterday.
James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, submitted his resignation to President Roosevelt today.
The Lenox Garden Club council held an experience meeting this afternoon at the Pleasant Valley bird and wild flower sanctuary. Mrs. Owen Johnson, president, led in the discussion.

A board of officers is appointed to meet at Utica, N. Y., at the call of the president thereof, to examine such persons as may be properly ordered before It to determine their fitness for appointment or certificate of capacity in the Officers' Reserve Corps.

Full protection and facilities will be given to Americans preparing to evacuate from the interior of China via Haichow and to United States destroyers that are to be sent there next Sunday and Sept. 29 to embark them.

The First National Bank of New York headed the syndicate that won yesterday the award of a $4,800,000 issue of Boston Metropolitan District refunding bonds. The winning bid was 97,9079 for 2 3/4 per cent bonds dated Oct. 1, 1937, and maturing on Oct. 1, 1938 to 1962, inclusive.

Mary Brown Warburton, granddaughter of John Wanamaker, died at 11 A. M. yesterday in her apartment at 277 Park Avenue after an inhalator crew from the Consolidated Edison Company had worked almost two hours in a vain effort to revive her.
The annual dinner of the National Association of Nurse Anesthetists in the Hotel Ritz-Carlton tonight was served by eighteen presidents of its affiliated State groups when the waiters went on strike.

A temporary injunction halting construction of a water tower beside Kenilworth Road, Purchase, was granted today by Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief. Purchase residents contended the tower would resemble a Turkish mosque and would be out of place in a neighborhood devoted exclusively to large homes and estates.

President Roosevelt moved swiftly today to avert the possibility of incidents on the high seas that might involve the United States in the Sino-Japanese conflict by imposing a partial embargo on arms to the two warring countries.
The Columbus Red Birds, 1937 American Association champions, defeated the third-place Minneapolis Millers, 11 to 5, tonight in the first game of the league play-off series before 2,369 spectators.

The improved sentiment in financial markets was reflected yesterday in the listed bond market, with prices in most sections moving upward and many of the pivotal issues recovering part of their most recent losses.

Miss Electa Brush, daughter of Mr. and. Mrs. Ralph E. Brush of this place, gave a dinner at her home tonight in honor of Miss Sally Foster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Taylor Foster of Greenwich and her fiance, A. Oram Fulton of Boston.

The request of the four titleholders who will defend their crowns at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 23 that all contestants be required to weigh in a second time if a 24-hour postponement occurs was tabled for one week at a meeting of the New York State Athletio Commission yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Lucile Thornton Thieriot, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Thieriot of 1,175 Park Avenue, New York, and Cedar Hill, Oyster Bay, to Elisha Walker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Elisha Walker, also of Oyster Bay, took place this afternoon at the Creek Club, where an improvised chapel had been arranged in the small lounge. Mgr. Charles J.

Investment banking has come a long way from "caveat emptor" and "the public be damned" days and the public should be reminded of that change, Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, a partner in Kuhn, Loeb Co., said today to the National Financial Advertisers Association, which is in convention here.

Next week the New York Republican and Democratic State Committees will meet to name fifteen delegates at large to the Constitutional Convention and a candidate for associate judge of the Court of Appeals. Political views must necessarily enter into the choice by each party of the delegates.

The first step toward establishment of an apprentice engineering service in city departments will be taker today when Paul J. Kern, member of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, asks the commission to approve a program for the employment of ten recent graduates of the Columbia, City College, New York University and Cornell engineering schools as "cadet engineers" for the Board of Transportation.

Payments on account of accumulated interest on Missouri-KansasTexas Railroad 5 per cent adjustment bonds will not be made now, Matthew S. Sloan, president, said yesterday. This, he added, was because the management wanted to maintain the company's "present favorable cash position." The next coupon on the bonds is due on Oct. 1.

M. F. Blakeslee, formerly manager of the Chicago division of the RCA Manufacturing Company, has been appointed manager of the Eastern division to succeed L. W. Teegarden, who has been placed in charge of radio tube sales to wholesale distributors. Richard A.

Leonard Hartman of New York advanced to the quarter-final round of the Eastern New Jersey clay courts tennis championship today when Richard Bender of Elizabeth defaulted. Hartman, seeded third, led at 3-0 when illness forced Bender to stop.

Greyhound, the Gray Ghost of harness racing, clipped by almost 10 seconds the existing world trotting record for the mile and half today but a high wind kept him from cracking the mile mark-the previously announced goal.

The demand for automatic heat will boost fuel oil sales in this country this year to an all-time high of nearly 75,000,000 barrels of forty-two gallons each, according to an estimate made public yesterday by E. L. Sylvester, sales manager of the automatic heating department of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation.
The advocates of a new system of realty taxation based on the use or income value of property have won new support from various sources recently.

The last camp of five members of the German Polar Expedition headed by Lieutenant Schroeder-Stranz, who perished in 1912 in an attempt to measure the speed of a drifting ice floe, has been found on the shores of Dove Bay.
The Osservatore Romano, Vatican newspaper, protested again today against the attacks on the Catholic Church in Germany and predicted "direst consequences" if they were allowed to continue.
Improvement in general business in the Fall was forecast today by Roger W. Babson, statistician and economist, in an address before members of the Boston Chamber of Commerce.
WASHINGTON. -The Mortgage Bank of Ecuador, at Guayaquil, has been authorized to call for quotations for the purchase of 5,000 tons of imported sugar, the Commerce Department reports.

Mr. and Mrs. Alexander L. Dommerich gave a large supper-dance at their home here tonight to introduce their daughter, Miss Jean Dommerich, to society. Three hundred guests attended. Miss Mary Houston of Philadelphia assisted Miss Dommerich and her parents in receiving.

Issuances of automobile license plates during the week ended Sept. 11 totaled 2,783, or about 7 per cent fewer than the 2,979 total for the corresponding week last year, Commissioner Charles A. Hartnett of the Motor Vehicle Bureau announced yesterday.

James J. Johnston, former Madison Square Garden promoter, is listed as one of three directors of the Thirtieth Century Athletic Club in incorporation papers on file today with Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn.
Thirteen-months-old Gene McMahon had a big job the other day explaining a black eye that rivaled the best ever worn by a prizefighter. Gene's story wasn't the ancient one of running into a doorknob.

The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette publishes today the third in a series of articles in which it is alleged that Hugo L. Black of Alabama, recently appointed to the Supreme Court of the United States, was and still is a member of the Ku Klux Klan.

New York State's 1937 apple crop, ripened rapidly by unusually warm August weather, will more than double last year's yield and will far exceed the average for the last five years, the State and Federal Agriculture Departments said today in a joint fruit crop report.

A temporary injunction was granted to Mrs. Margaret Mitchell Marsh, author of "Gone with the Wind," here today, restraining the Forth Worth Frontier Fiesta Association from paying to Billy Rose any share of the income from the fiesta.
French trade figures, available today for the first eight months of 1937, show an increasing deficit, which is featured b a sharp rise in the volume of imports and in the prices paid for them.

There was a temporary lull yesterday in Japanese attempts at a large-scale advance, but meanwhile "everything is being moved forward-tanks, light and heavy artillery, every weapon of modern warfare-and more men are pouring in," a Japanese spokesman explained.

Senator David I. Walsh declared today that Justice Hugo Black "owes it to the President, the Senate and the country to declare publicly whether he is a member of the Klan, and, if so, to declare in unmistakable language his repudiation of the Ku Klux Klan and its principles."

Representative John E. Miller, life-long Democrat, accepted today designation as an "independent" candidate for the Senate. His nominating petition, bearing 363 signatures, was filed with the Secretary of State.

The arraignment of nineteen Norwegian seamen in the Tombs Court yesterday on disorderly conduct charges made by the captain of the motorship Norbris the night before, when they refused to leave his vessel after being discharged, developed into what is expected to prove an important international legal question.

The Pennsylvania Railroad received today from the Baltimore City Board of Estimates a second three-year extension for the carrying out of improvements included in the electrification program provided for by an ordinance enacted in 1929.

The Garden Club of East Hampton will hold its annual flower show tomorrow afternoon and evening in Guild Hall. Mrs. Clifford H. McCall is chairman of the flower committee. A luncheon at the Maidstone Club for Garden Club members and their guests is being arranged by Mrs. Clarence Alcott and Mrs. Eltinge Warner.

Two home runs fashioned from three pitched balls in the last half of the ninth inning provided a story book finish to the first International League play-off game today and gave the Newark Bears a 2-to-1 victory over the Syracuse Chiefs.
Miss Anne Faith Donaldson was married here today at Valleyhead, home of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Kirby Lunt, to Russell Grace D'Oench of New York. Dr. Samuel A. Eliot read the marriage service.

The WPA Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra, with Emerson Buckley as guest conductor, will give the third concert in the Federal Music Project in Review series at the Theatre of Music tonight. Frances Ernest, soprano, and Harry Neidell, violinist, will be soloists.

Colombia has rejected Uruguay's proposal that American nations accord joint recognition of belligerency to both sides in the civil war in Spain. Colombia takes the stand that absolute neutrality toward the internal affairs of others is the only protection for small countries from intervention in their civil conflicts.

Inaugurating the fifty-second consecutive annual Jewish theatrical season in America, curtains rise tonight in six Yiddish playhouses in Greater New York, to be followed Friday evening and next week by additional premieres.
Spanish Insurgents reported today that Anarchists in Gijon had seized control of the Government army there and ordered the execution of high Government officers who "lost Bilbao and Santander."

Charges that a former Peruvian dictator forced him to marry a South American sefiorita, or be "accidentally" shot, were aired in an annulment petition today by Lewis M. Clarkson, former American representative in Lima, Peru.

Four teams were eliminated from the national amateur baseball tournament field today as the contests entered the fifth round. Eliminated were Indianapolis, Youngstown, Birmingham, Ala., and Edenborn, Pa.
Stocks recovered and closed higher in less active trading; turnover, 1,508,450 shares. United States Government bonds active and strong, other issues also improved; transactions, $9,236,700.

Colonel Henry L Doherty, national chairman of the National Birthday Balls for the President, announced yesterday that the movement had raised a total of $1,090,779.23 this year for the fight against infantile paralysis. Of this,

The staggered strike of elevator operators and other building service employes was extended to Washington Heights yesterday by the Building Service Employes International Union, Local 32-B, in its "major move" to bring about 250 buildings under union contract.

The Citizens Union issued a statement yesterday supporting Mayor La Guardia for re-election, urging his renomination in the Republican primary and suggesting a "writein" vote for him in the Democratic primary.

The Socialist party, through Jack Altman, its secretary, issued yesterday a ten-point platform for the city campaign and expressed its desire to cooperate with the American Labor party "in the election of candidates for the City Council and in support of such other of their candidates not running on the Republican or Democratic tickets as

The passenger and freight ship Exeter, a 9,360-ton vessel owned by the Export Steamship Corporation, was held at her Jersey City pier yesterday afternoon when the company refused to pay a bonus of $250 and provide insurance of $25,000 to each member of her crew as compensation for the danger to which they might be subjected by reason of the ship's entering Spanish waters.

Miss Edna Maria Dudley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Leonard Dudley of Hearthstone, this place, has chosen Oct. 9 for her marriage to -Burr Vanderburgh Brower, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Henson Brower of New York and Cleveland.
John A. McGregor, president of the Utica and Mohawk Valley Cotton Mills, Inc., and widely known in the textile industry, died today at his home here after a brief illness at the age of 73.

Republican leaders who are supporting Mayor La Guardia for a second term said yesterday they were greatly encouraged by the reaction to the Mayor's speech at the luncheon of Republican women at the Hotel Commodore.

Longwood Ave (10-2696): n s. 41 w of Dawson St. 78x107; Citizens Savings Bank to Bessie Handler, 1,491 McCombs Rd. 140th St (10-2552), s s, 468 e of St Anns Ave, 37x100: Aaron Feinberg to 610 E 140th St Realty Corp. Adee Ave (16-4548), a e cor of Holland Ave, 100x136: Carlo Pellerano to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp, trustee.

The wrestling card in Madison Square Garden tonight will show Steve (Crusher) Casey against Benny Feldman in one of the special bouts. Danno O'Mahoney, former world heavyweight champion, will grapple with Ed Don George; Yvon Robert will meet Billy Bartush, and George Clark will oppose Jim Wallis.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, former Commissioner James Bolan and other police officials, as well as an escort of more than three hundred police, headed by the departmental band and color guard, attended services for Thomas F. McDonald, retired police inspector, yesterday forenoon in Jamaica.
Vesta Hanover, 2:05, bay filly, owned and driven by Harry Short, Columbus, Ohio, raced to straight heat honors in the postponed $2,135 Reading Fair 2-year-old Futurity Trot today.

In a brief filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission, nineteen Southern omnibus companies operating lines from Virginia to Florida and west to the Mississippi River presented charges that the methods of routing and operation of five subsidiaries of the Greyhound Corporation were in violation of the Motor Carrier Act and tended to create a monopoly.
A high wind sweeping in from the Sound sent scores soaring in the women's annual club golf championship over the south course of the Westchester Country Club today.

Santiago Iglesias, Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico, said today that he was preparing protests to Secretary Ickes and Postmaster General Farley against Rockwell Kent's Puerto Rican mural in the new Postoffice Building.
Two women were under arrest last night, one here and one in Philadelphia, with the disclosure of an intricate scheme for the adop tion of two children by a woman who was childless.
The last-place Browns pounded out an easy 11-to-4 victory over the Athletics today in a game that marked the major league pitching debut of Chubby Dean, former Philadelphia first baseman.

Coach Jimmy Crowley surprised his football squad by ordering a scrimmage on Fordham Field yesterday afternoon. The first eleven took possession of the ball on its own 10-yard line and was asked to advance it the length of the field. A team made up of second and third string candidates deployed on defense.

A sharp increase in British exports of war materials during August was disclosed tonight by the Board of Trade. Exports of arms were valued at [Pound]116,710, compared with [Pound]43,965 in July and f58,628 in August, 1936.

The National Retail Credit Association re-ported today 14,160 stores in forty cities experienced average increases of 2.2 per cent in collections, 6 per cent in credit sales and 5.1 per cent in total sales in August as compared with the same month a year ago.

For twenty-four years movie audiences have laughed-always with a tinge of pity-at the antics of a pathetic tramp who scuttled around corners on one foot, poked his springy bamboo cane into trouble and wore a mute expression of wonder at the havoc he brought.

Lawrence J. Connery, Democrat, of Lynn, and State Representative Edward D. Sirois, Republican, of Lawrence, won nominations today in primary balloting for the Seventh Congressional District seat of the late William P. Connery Jr.
William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, explained today his plans for organizing the editorial and non-editorial employes of newspapers under the banner of the federation.

The Nyon agreement has been received here with real, though qualified, satisfaction. A long and vigorous editorial in Izvestia, the Government organ. stresses these three points: First, that marked changes in the agreement from its original outline, especially the refusal to recognize General Francisco Franco, were due to the success of Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff's efforts;

William H. Ball, an appraiser for a realty firm and formerly for many years in charge of real estate for the Pennsylvania Company for Insurances on Lives and Granting Annuities, died at his home in North Hills today in his sixty-ninth year.
Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets and Republican candidate for District Attorney of New York County, announced last night the appointment of Millard H Ellison as manager of his campaign.

The gloom into which the Czechoslovak Republic was plunged today is the measure of the greatness of Thomas G. Masaryk, beloved first President, who died at 3:39 o'clock this morning. Three years ago he retired from public affairs.

The organizing committee of the Descendants of the American Revolution, a new patriotic society formed of men and women opposed to the policies of the Daughters of the American Revolution, met yesterday at Greenwich House. 27 Barrow Street, to discuss plans for financing and establishing headquarters.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pepper Vaux of Portledge, Rosemont, announced today the marriage of their daughter, Miss Alice Vaux, to Reginald Minturn Lewis, son of Mrs. Frederic E. Lewis of 23 West Fifty-second Street, New York, which took place this afternoon at Portledge.

The Collier Service, Inc., announced yesterday that it had reopened forty of its 230 newsstands in stations of the I. R. T. and B. M. T. systems, which were closed by a strike begun last Thursday by the Retail Newsstand Employes Union, Local 906-B,

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wagner of 821 Cross Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth M. Wagner, to Morris Reisen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry K. Reisen of Newark.

Speaking editorially of Justice Hugo L. Black and the Ku Klux Klan, William Allen White said in his Emporia Gazette: "The evidence is indisputable that Justice Hugo Black was and is a member of the Ku Klux Klan.

Life insurance is taking every step, through efficiency and economy, to meet the rising costs of conducting business, Walter LeMar Talbot, president of the Fidelity Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia, said on Monday at the opening of the annual convention of the Leaders Club at The Cavalier, Virginia Beach, Va.

GLASS, MORRIS (Sept. 10). Estate, more than $10,000. To Gloria Hattie Glass, granddaughter, 5 W. 91st St., $1,000; Ray Weinstein, friend, 58-54 Chestnut St., Philadelphia, Pa.; Florence G. Lehman, daughter, executrix, 330 W. 72d St., household, personal effects, specific insurance, $12,600 and one-half residue; Harold S. Glass, son, executor, 5 W. 91st St., specific insurance, $5,000 and onehalf residue. William Leon, 334 W. 86th St., executor.

Sixty-two members of Yale's football squad arrived at Gales Ferry from New Haven at 5 o'clock tonight to establish the third annual football training camp. The squad occupies four houses at the ferry and the practice field is situated conveniently just north of the quarters.

The Ku Klux Klan, while taking no active part in this year's Mayoralty contest, will keep a hooded eye on "this un-American city" to learn how to combat the "foreign elements" who are using it as a proving ground for tactics in the national campaigns of 1938 and 1940.

Stockholders of the Union Bag and Paper Company approved a four-for-one split-up of its capital stock yesterday at a special meeting in Jersey City and authorized the issuance of $7,000,000 of convertible debentures.

Coming from Budapest, the Duke and Duchess of Windsor arrived this afternoon in Vienna, and a large crowd awaited them at the station, greeting them with hearty cheers. They drove straight to the Hotel Bristol. Tomorrow they leave for Nicolsburg, Czechoslovakia,

An official Tammany poll of enrolled Democratic voters in parts of six Assembly districts in Manhattan and Brooklyn, picked to get an expression of opinion from sample election districts, showed Mayor La Guardia leading both Royal S. Copeland and Jeremiah T. Mahoney by a substantial margin.
Secretary Woodring announced today the allocation of $505,000 for improvement of Flushing Bay, to provide a waterway from the East River to the site of the World's Fair.

Dr. Arthur Greg Holland, for several years executive assistant to Dr. James W. Manary, superintendent of the Boston City Hospital, and a former resident surgeon of the East Boston Relief Hospital, died suddenly last night at his home, 12 Burwell Road, West Roxbury. He was 47 years of age,

Total advertising linage in newspapers of fifty-two major cities for August, measured by Media Records, registered a gain of 4.6 per cent over the corresponding month of last year. Linage totaled 103,698,823 as against 99,166,026 in the like month of 1936.

Representatives of the Trenton Valley Distillers Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a stipulation consenting to a stop order in connection with a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933, filed on Jan. 26, 1936, covering 273,000 shares of $1 par value common capital stock.

The indisposition of Mrs. Edgar J. Lauer, wife of Supreme Court Justice Lauer, prevented yesterday the completion of the examination of thirty-two pieces of baggage, detained by Customs officials when she arrived with her husband on the French liner Normandie Monday night.

Play will be resumed today. in the national open polo championship with the first of the semi-final games at the Meadow Brook Club, Westbury, L. I. Returning to Hitchcock Field, where the opening game saw them overwhelm Aknusti last Saturday,

Negotiations for a settlement of the Pozarica oil strike, which is tying up 60 per cent of the national production, were broken off, at least temporarily, today, despite President Lazaro Cardenas's warning to labor Sunday to end the walkout.

Wall Street executed another about-face yesterday and, convinced that any recession in the expected Fall business had been sufficiently discounted by the three market breaks of the last week, proceeded to buy stocks.

A number of security holders of General Theatres Equipment, Inc., have neglected to obtain and sell or exercise rights which will expire on Oct. 1 despite letters and advertisements used throughout the country to acquaint them with this fact, Edward C. Delafield, chairman of the reorganization committee, announced yesterday.

RISING SUN GOLF COUNTRY CLUB, INC., Pines Bridge Road, New Castle, Westchester County-Voluntary proceeding under section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $4,000 and assets of $18,100. The company operates the club under a lease from Rising Sun Holding Co., Inc., which owns the property.

Mannattan Alterations Park Ave, 1,001: to 15-story and pent house tenement; 1,001 Park Ave Corp, premises, owner; Gurney Clavin, architects; cost, $4,000. 71st St, 350 W; to 4-story tenement: 322 West 108th Street Corp, 322 W 108th St, owner; Miller Goldhammer, architects; cost, $6,000.

The Cardinals took both ends of a double-header with the Phillies today, but the stubborn Phils forced the opener to fourteen innings before losing, 9 to 8, and then Lon Warneke won a shortened second game, 1 to 0, for his eighteenth victory.

With strong winds, racing waters and dense fog, the international tuna tournament held off this port came to an end early this morning, with the Alton B. Sharp Trophy going to the British team, the first international trophy gathered in by John Bull this year.

With the signing of the "anti-piracy" agreement at Nyon, nine more British destroyers and the 4,200-ton cruiser Cairo were ordered today to speed southward from home waters to reinforce the Anglo-French patrol fleet in the Mediterranean.
Introducing Master Charles (Buck) Marrow, 27 years old, weighing 200 pounds, 6 feet 4 inches tall and a right-handed pitcher by trade.
Charlie Badami, 1411/2, of Yorkville outpointed Lew Raymond, 146, of Baltimore in the eightround main event at the New York Coliseum last night before 5,000 fans.
Passengers sailing today for Europe on the French liner Normandie will include Mr. and Mrs. C. F. Kettering, H. K. Wood, Michel Detroyat, Marcel Dorcet, Maurice Vasseur, Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Denton,

A bulletin issued this morning at Skagen Hospital following last night's operation on Queen Alexandrine for a stomach ailment said: "The Queen had a quiet night. Her condition under the circumstances is satisfactory."

Engagement of $12,426,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $7,438,000 in England and $4,988,000 in India, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of the metal taken in England $3,900,000 was marked for shipment on some previous day, and the rest yesterday.

Speaking at the opening yesterday of the new Richmond County Health Center and Borough Office Building at 51-63 Stuyvesant Place, St. George, S. I., Mayor La Guardia denounced politics as having no place in the administration of health service.
Announcement has just been made here of the marriage of Mrs. Lucienne Prado Salgado to Maurice Newton of this city, which took place on Saturday in London. They are expected to arrive here soon.

The Commerce Department reported today that August gold imports totaled $105,013,011. July imports were $175,623,720 and in August, 1936, the total was $67,524,433. August silver imports amounted to $4,964,161, compared with $4,475,629 the previous month and $16,637,249 in August,.1936.

The 600 members of the joint executive board of the Transport Workers Union, representing 50,000 union employes of the I. R. T., Third Avenue Railway, Fifth Avenue Coach Company, New York City Omnibus Company, Independent Subway and taxi companies, voted unanimous support last night for strike action by B. M. T. employes to force better wages and working conditions.

Pearl St, 391. 32x132xirreg: Besal Realty Corp (Alfred Heller, pres), to Catharine A. Conway, 52 Roosevelt St, p m mtg. 8 yrs, 5%; $13,500. 29th St, 334-36 W. 45x98.9: Harold Holding Corp (Joseph Roth, pres). to Leonard Levin, 1,164 Cromwell Ave, 3 yrs, 6%; $4,000.

In his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University, Dean John T. Madden of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance said yesterday that business leaders were responsible to a large degree for labor problems.
James W. Fosdick of New York, mural painter and pioneer in the art of fire etching in this country, died today in a Boston hospital after a short illness. He was 79 years old.

The Securities and Exchange Commission heard details today of the plan of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc.,. to comply with the so-called "death sentence" section of the Utility Holding Company Act. Philip Ross,

President Roosevelt confided to news men today that he had his own financial troubles. He was asked at his press conference about the general monetary situation, and particularly if he thought there was any prospect of a "money pinch."

Federal Judge John W. Clancy issued an order yesterday authorizing Robert Frazer, United States consul general in London, to take testimony from four officers of the British-American Tobacco Company, Ltd., to be used here in its suit to recover 1,018 bars of gold from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The immediate results of the Treasury's release of $300,000,000 "sterilized gold" have been a slight fractional recovery in price of outstanding United States bonds, which had lost 1 to 2 points in the continuous though slow decline since early August, and a small rise in the rate bid for a new issue of short Treasury bills.

R. R. Rogers, second vice president, has been elected vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, succeeding the late Lester E. Wurfel. Robert M. Green, treasurer, was made second vice president in addition to which he will assist the home office departments formerly under Willard I. Hamilton, retired vice president Clifford W. Brown, assistant treasurer, was elected treasurer. George E. Potter,

Whereas, arising out of the Spanish conflict, attacks repeatedly have been committed in the Mediterranean by submarines against merchant ships not belonging to either of the conflicting Spanish parties, and Whereas these attacks are violations of the rules of international law referred to in Part IV of the treaty of London of April 22, 1930, with regard to the sinking of merchant ships,
Canada led the world last year in exports of wheat, newsprint paper and asbestos. In shipments of wheat flour the Dominion stood second, being exceeded by Australia only.

Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday ore than doubled those for the preceding week but fell somewhat below the corresponding week of last year, according to the listings published in THE TIMES.
NAPOLEON, by R. McNair Wilson. (Longmans, Green, $3.50.) A new biography. CHINA AT WORK, by Rudolf P. Hommel. (John Day, $5.) Chinese life photographed and described.

The Business Conduct Committee of the Chicago Board of Trade in a surprise move today called for a complete list of commission house customers who are long or short of the September delivery of corn and, in addition to the amounts, they were requested to furnish the names and addresses of these customers.

Emphasizing the seriousness of current conflicting taxation methods, Governor Lehman of New York called upon the Federal Government and the forty-eight States today to develop a definite program for coordination of the entire tax system of the nation, Federal, State and local.

A program designed to keep the United States out of war is expected to occupy the most important place on the agenda of the nineteenth annual convention of the American Legion opening in New York City on Monday, it was disclosed yesterday by Legion leaders.

All records were broken in the first six months of this year in the production of steel sheets, strip and tin plate, resulting principally from the demand of industries which manufacture consumers' goods, according to a report issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.
A net estate of $416,517 was left by William H. Dunn, retired shoe manufacturer, according to a tax deposition filed here. He died March 24. The gross estate was listed at $664.659.

Mrs. Julia Raine, musician, and widow of Gilbert D. Raine, former Memphis publisher, died at a hospital near here yesterday in her eighty-first year. Composer of the State centennial hymn, "In Tennessee," Mrs. Raine was an accomplished pianist.

Daily gross crude-oil production in the United States last week was 3,642,400 barrels, compared with 3,692,550 in the previous week, a decline of 50,150, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

A comprehensive agricultural adjustment program designed to hold production of the nation's food, feed and fiber supplies to probable domestic and foreign demand in 1938, and to promote the fertility of land not planted to such crops, was laid by Farm Administration officials today before a conference of more than a hundred farm leaders and officials of the forty-eight States.

The greatest number of births recorded in this city in a single week since July, 1934, was reported during the week ended Sept. 11 when 2,250 babies were born, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday. The figure represented an increase of 359 births over the preceding week and brought the birth rate for the week to 15.8.

Joseph P. Day, Inc., through its Flushing office, has leased the following private dwellings: In Brooklyn, 1,248 Eightieth Street to Alfredo Marano, 1,058 East Thirtyfifth Street to Charles Tucker, 1,553 East Fifty-fourth Street to Valentine Longo, 678 Fifty-third Street to Sam Berger, 2,048 East Thirty-fifth Street to Alexander Unger;
There was a large attendance this afternoon at Wyndham, home of Miss Rosa Anne Grosvenor, for the annual bridge and mah jong party given in the interest of the Speyer Animal League of New York.
Ecuador has suspended the surcharge of 50 per cent in the duty on imports from Japan, Czechoslovakia, Algiers, Egypt and Guatemala, the Commerce Department reported today.

Republican and Democratic organizaLions routed insurgent factions at the primary polls today when voters of both parties nominated organizaiion-backed candidates in preparation for the municipal election in November.
Carl Hanford, who rides for Mrs. Val Crane, was the victim of another accident at Aqueduct yesterday when he was tossed from his mount, Bonsoir, going to the post in the first race.

THERE must be mountains of letters and papers stored away in vaults and secret bureau-drawers. There must be mountains of this material all told, some of no earthly importance to any one, some of general literary and historical interest.

An advertising campaign in about 100 large city newspapers and 1,200 small town papers will be launched to promote a special offer of Calox tooth powder, made by McKesson Robbins, and Dr. West's tooth brushes, manufactured by the Western Company.

Lincoln Ellsworth, explorer, left by airplane for New York today to seek aid from Jacqueline Cochrane, flier, and her husband, Floyd B. Odlum, New York capitalist, in a proposed search for six Russian fliers who were lost in the Arctic Aug. 13 on a flight from Moscow to California.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to listing Standard Steel Spring Company new $5 par common stock and has suspended dealings in the old no par common stock. The shares are being exchanged on an even basis.

More than 2,000 distributors and dealers gathered at the Masonic Temple here today saw the unveiling of the 1938 line of six and eight-cylinder Hudson automobiles and of Hudson terraplanes. The cars were successively illuminated by slow floodlights on a darkened stage.
Sinclair Lewis has returned to New York after sperling the Summer in Stockbridge, Mass. He expects to complete his manuscript of "The Prodigal Parents" before the end of the month.

Members of the Board of Education made a special plea yesterday to Kenneth Dayton, acting budget director, for an increase in funds for repair and maintenance of school buildings, when they submitted a 1938 estimate of $160,324,561, an increase of $14,784,607 over the 1937 educational expense.

Charles West, Under-Secretary of the Interior and liaison officer in legislative matters between President Roosevelt and members of Congress, said today that he had no intention of resigning his office.

" That Certain Woman," co-starring Bette Davis and Henry Fonda, will have its premiere today at the Strand Theatre, under the auspices of Warner Brothers.... Another premiere-the American premiere this time-will be that of "Le Juif Polonais" ("The Polish Jew"), featuring Harry Baur, this evening at the Cinema de Paris.

That Max Schmeling-Joe Louis fight situation bobbed up before the National Boxing Association today with a strongly worded suggestion the Bomber signify within thirty days his willingness to fight German Maxie or doff his heavyweight crown.

The Art Students League has put up a large show of work by members and associates in the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. This league annual, which occupies all three galleries, will be opened this morning at 10 o'clock, and the work, chiefly in oil, is to remain on public view through Oct. 14.
Supreme Court Justice Hugo L. Black left for the English countryside today after refusing to comment on allegations that he was and now is again a member of the Ku Klux Klan.

Representative Alfred N. Phillips Jr., a supporter of much Administration legislation, wrote to President Roosevelt today asking the Chief Executive to "purge the National Labor Relations Board of further relationship with Communists."

Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement and the most sacred Jewish holy day, was observed by Jews throughout the world at sundown last night. The traditional "Kol Nidre" was intoned at orthodox, conservative and reform services in the city's temples and synagogues.

The Trades and Labor Congress of Canada today voted to ask for establishment of a sixhour day and five-day week in all occupations but rejected a recommendation that it ask for a minimum wage of 50 cents an hour.
Domestic mills opened the new cotton season with the largest consumption ever recorded for August, with one exception, the Census Bureau reported today.

This is the night they are reopening "King Richard II" at the St. James Theatre, the same to linger there until it is time to tour. Maurice Evans, who last season became Broadway's most applauded Shakespearean scholar, again will play the title role, and others in his company include Frederic Worlock, Lee Baker, Eleanor Phelps,

There is an ironic paradox in the fact that the new wave of shootings and arrests in Russia coincides with the going into effect of the new Soviet Constitution and the preparations for free and equal elections this Fall. Many diplomatic observers in Moscow believe that the coincidence is not altogether accidental and that the widely heralded liberality of the new "Stalin Constitution" actually is one factor in the purge.
A concerted effort to obtain legislation extending and strengthening the merit system under civil service in the National, State and municipal governments was advocated today by Albert E. Neale,

With one withdrawal and one added entry, thirty-seven prospective starters, a record fleet, were left tonight for the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association's world championship, which will start tomorrow under the auspices of the association and the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

The forty-first annual Bryn Mawr Horse Show will be held Sept. 22 to Sept. 25 at the Bryn Mawr polo field. The Bryn Mawr is the only openair show in the country that has been in continuous existence for more than forty years.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. John W. Sinclair of 299 Park Avenue and East Hampton, L. I., yesterday at Doctors Hospital. Mrs. Sinclair is the former Miss Laura L. James, daughter of Mrs. Ellery S. James of this city and the late Mr. James. The child,

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn dismissed yesterday an appeal by the District Attorney of Nassau County from a recent decision of Acting County Judge Richard W. Hawkins in which he dismissed an indictment charging bookmaking and gambling against two officials of the Nassau Kennel Club, operator of the greyhound racing track at Mineola, L. I.

A modern hospital with a properly planned and intelligently supervised maternity department is the best place in the world for a maternity patient, although babies are better off born at home than in a poorly equipped and carelessly managed hospital,

Eugene Cronin, 43 years old, former Navy man, New York University alumnus (class of '23), parttime solicitor for the alumni magazine, appeared before Magistrate Overton Harris in Yorkville Court yesterday, accused of refusing to pay $3.25 cab fare for an earlymorning ride.
Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for the Mayoralty nomination, moved yesterday to strengthen the fight for the Mahoney-Taylor-Schneider ticket.

Shipments of pianos in August totaled 7,749 units, an increase of 1,611 or 26.25 per cent over the same period last year, W. A. Mennie, secretary of the National Piano Manufacturers Association, reported today.
Baron Gottfried von Cramm and Heinrich Henkel proved today their victory over Don Budge and Gene Mako for the United States doubles championship was no fluke.

Si Moskowitz, recently sales manager in the Greater New York area for Oldetyme Distillers, Inc., has been appointed Metropolitan sales manager for the Schenley Products Company, Louis E. Golan, vice president in charge of sales, announced yesterday.
Police Commissioner Valentine served notice yesterday afternoon upon ranking police officers that he expected "a clean, honest and orderly election" at the polls throughout the city on primary day.
A second indictment charging murder of a policeman was returned, after brief deliberation today, by the Middlesex County grand jury against Edward P. Simpson.

Although many British and French destroyers will soon be patrolling the Mediterranean on the lookout for "pirate submarines," cautious Lloyd's underwriters have not yet canceled the recent increases in insurance rates.

A mural depicting the gaiety of the circus was presented yesterday afternoon to the City Home on Welfare Island. The large painting by Emanuel Romano, designed and executed under the direction of the WPA Federal Art Project, has been installed in the auditorium of the new Klondike Building, the recreation center for the aged and infirm residents of the City Home.
Dates selected for the playing off of postponed American League games and schedule changes were announced today by William Harridge, president of the circuit.
In a moderate and shifting northwest breeze, the first of the final series of six-meter races for the season was held today by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

The Port of New York Authority purchased at Union City the vacant parcel 42 by 80 at 623 Hudson Avenue from Charles Uhde, the threestory flat at 526 Thirtieth Street from John Loeffler and the vacant lot at 528 Thirtieth Street from Mrs. Amin N. Khouri.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 13: Desobry, Col. E. C., the Adjutant General' Dept., 2 days' extension of leave. Schmidt, Major F. O., Infantry, to 14th Brigade, Fort Snelling, Minn.

An investing client of Horace G. Marks bought from David S. Meister the six-story apartment at 3,230 Cruger Avenue, on the southeast corner of South Oak Drive, the Bronx. Accommodations for seventy-nine families are provided in the 222 rooms which comprise the house.

More than a year ago a committee of the American Bar Association made a report on what it called the "hippodroming" of criminal justice and recommended rules to stop "prejudicial publicity" in criminal cases. A "sensational" murder trial is utterly remote from a solemn rite of justice.

In a note delivered to the British and French charges d'affaires at 7 o'clock this evening the Italian Government refuses to give its adherence to the conclusions of the Nyon conference unless Italy participates in patrolling the Mediterranean on a footing of perfect equality with Britain and France.

Two local hotels were placed in permanent receivership today in Chancery Court. On its own petition, the affairs of the Galen Hall Company were placed in the hands of Sidney L. Knisell, its president, and Maurice Y. Cole, local attorney, as permanent receivers by Vice Chancellor W. Frank Sooy in Chancery Court.

The Governors' Conference at Atlantic City could have chosen no more timely subject to which to devote its attention than that on which Governor Lehman spoke yesterday. This is the question of duplicate and conflicting taxation as among the several States and between the States and the Federal Government.

Prolonged fighting in China will handicap Japan in serving her export markets and that is one reason why the present conflict will be short, Otoichi Kinoshita, executive director of the Japan Trade Association, said yesterday on his arrival here at the head of a group of Japanese business men who are making a world tour.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES today it is stated that former Secretary of War Newton D. Baker, heading a joint committee of the press and the American Bar Association, will offer a report to the convention of the association on Sept. 27 denouncing the political choice of, and promotion of, judges and their election by public vote, because of which the traditions of the judiciary often fare badly.

A military funeral service was held yesterday morning for Brig. Gen. De Witt Clinton Weld in the 105th Field Artillery Armory at 166th Street and Franklin Avenue, the Bronx. He commanded the regiment at the close of the World War. There were more than 200 officers and men of his command in the group which was present yesterday morning.

The Interstate Commerce Commission hearing on the proposed increase from 6 to 10 cents in the Hudson Manhattan Railroad's fare between lower Manhattan and points in Jersey City and Hoboken, which was scheduled to start today, has been postponed to Nov. 10 by agreement between the railroad and - commuters' representatives.

Vincent P. Donihee, a lawyer who had practiced for many years before the United States Supreme Court, died suddenly on Monday morning as he reached the top of the stairs of the Culver Line station, at Avenue I, Brooklyn. Mr.

Lucius F. Deming, an engineer and former Philadelphia amateur golf champion, died in Chestnut Hill on Sunday in his sixty-second year. Born at Amboy, Ill., he was graduated from Yale University as an electrical engineer.

Thomas Franklin Manville Jr., heir to the Manville asbestos fortune, reached an agreement yesterday with his fourth wife, the former Marcelle Edwards, show girl, on a settlement that will end their four-year-old marriage.

Strikes to gain closed shops to protect workers were held legal here today in a ruling by Vice Chancellor John O. Bigelow. The opinion was given in a denial of an injunction to restrain members of the Metal Polishers, Buffers and Electro Platers Union from picketing the Four Plating Company at 179 South Street, Newark.

2d Ave. 484, 24.9x100; Bertha G. Newman, indiv and as trustee under the Solomon Weinhandler indenture to Bertarem Realty Corp; mtg, $30,000; $300. Same property; Pauline J. Weinhandler to same; quit claim; mtg, $30,000. Same property; Francis H. Morse to same; quit claim; mtg. $30,000.
