Chinese military airplanes and the guns of the Boca Tigris forts, at the entrance to the Canton River, were reported today to have defeated a Japanese fleet in what was described as a major naval engagement.
John C. Vought of Johnson City was elected today to be State councilor of the New York State Council, Junior Order of United American Mechanics.

The experience gained by the Federal Government in recent years adds point to two recent utterances paying tribute to the proved value of private effort and independent initiative in fields as diverse as the relief of human need and the relief of agriculture.

Flexibility and adaptability in advertising and merchandising are more necessary today than ever before, because of rapid changes in the public's wants and desires, Harry Boyd Brown, national merchandising manager of Philco Radio and Television Corporation, yesterday told the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Ed Widseth, All-America tackle from Minnesota, and Gerry Dennerlein, recruit tackle from St. Mary's, will start for the New York Giants in the opening National Football League game of the season in Washington Thursday night.

Activity in Manhattan realty reported yesterday centered in the sale of several Washington Heights and Harlem multi-family dwellings and in the leasing of buildings on the East Side both for business and for personal occupancy.

Dr. Ralph Horn, who has been teaching for twenty of his thirty-eight years, was named Dean of Buffalo State Teachers College today. Announcement of the appointment was made at the general assembly which began the school's sixtyseventh year.
Playing over her home course, Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. today annexed a women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament and also retained her Crestmont Golf Club title.

Announcement was made here this evening by the former Marcia Farrell Keresey, one of the heirs of the estate of her grandfather, Anthony N. Brady, New York traction man, that she and George McPike Hart,

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 10,000, including 1,500 directs. The market was unevenly 25 to 50 cents higher than Monday's average;

Ocean grain freights out of Montreal were at the highest levels today since the boom days of the late twenties. Deals were consummated at the rate of 4s 6d a quarter for carriage of wheat from Montreal to Manchester, a cost of 14 cents a bushel.

The engagement of Miss F. Ernestine Gierding, daughter of Dr. Ernest C. Gierding of West Orange, and the late Mrs. Gierding, to C. Raymond Supplee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph C. Supplee of West Orange, has been announced.

A declaration that "there ought to be more Jewish people in our congregations of the American Lutheran Church," was made in the principal address at today's session of the annual convention of the Eastern district of the church by the Rev. Dr. O. C. Mees of Canton, Ohio.

Organized consumer groups, especially women, have become critical of advertising, not because all advertising is unsuccessful or because they feel advertising adds to the cost of goods, but because "too often t does not render a service in helping them to understand and use the products it romotes," G. Lynn Sumner,

A two-story store and apartment building at 314 Kings Highway, Brooklyn, was sold to an investing client of the Bulkley Horton Company through the Morgan Management Corporation. The Bank for Savings was the seller of the property, which is on a plot 20 by 100 feet.

The first day of the Coney Island Mardi Grass was marred last night by one fatality and two injuries to visitors. George Berry, 37 years old, of 53 Maple Street, Keensburg, N. J., who was riding in a car, of the Mile Sky Chaser, a Luna Park roller-coaster, fell, the police said, as the car reached one of the summits of the ride. Apparently he was killed almost at once.

The Treasury announced today the success of its September refinancing operation, with an aggregate of $775,643,700 of the $817,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent notes maturing tomorrow offered in exchange for either five-year 2 per cent notes or fifteenmonth 1 1/4 per cent notes.

A proclamation designating Friday as Constitution Day was issued yesterday by Mayor La Guardia. He will be the principal speaker at an observance at the Eternal Light in Madison Square in the forenoon, arranged by the Mayor's committee headed by Colonel Maurice Simmons.

Benjamin Shiverts, an attorney with offices at 61 Broadway, confirmed reports yesterday that a series of letters now held by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation indicate that Mrs. Alice McDonnell Parsons,

Continuance of a brisk pace in apartment leasing for Oct. 1 occupancy is revealed in reports received yesterday from brokers in scattered parts of the city. Many leases, the reports showed, were for quarters in buildings on the east side of the mid-town section.

Senator Copeland was attacked yesterday by Jeremiah T. Mahoney, his opponent for the Mayoralty nomination, and by Samuel Untermyer, one of Mr. Mahoney's supporters, for dragging the question of Justice Hugo L. Black's Ku Klux Klan affiliation into the city campaign in what both charged was a desperate attempt to attract racial and religious support.

The Maritime Commission sold seventeen ships in its laid-up fleet tonight, fifteen for scrap and two for conversion into colliers to be operated in domestic waters. It realized $688,365 on the vessels for scraps and $130,019 on the others.

The Tennessee Valley Authority, declaring'that the basic principle of railroad rate-making should be "the prevention of rate barriers against regional or territorial development," made public today three suggestions for changing the method of fixing charges.

In the early morning hours after the last night of the National Socialist Congress, which decreed the terms of the trend of German political thought during the next year and so will affect the whole course of Continental Europe, one, has leisure to evaulate it and, from what one has seen and heard here. to attempt to measure the strength of the movement it represents.

Directors of the Western Union Telegraph Company failed to declare the usual 75-cent quarterly payment on the company's capital stock at the dividend meeting yesterday, explaining that the matter had been deferred until later in the year, when "it is hoped the business trend can be more accurately appraised." On Jan. 15,

Most of the players in the bimonthly Long Island amateur oneday golf tournament over the windswept North Hills course at Douglaston, L. I., yesterday found the hilly layout too difficult, with the result that none of the thirty-four starters was able to equal par and only six succeeded in breaking 80.

The Tigers came from behind today to drive rookie Joe Krakauskac from the box and score an 11-to-6 victory over Washington. The Tigers' starting pitcher, Jake Wade, also was knocked out of the box, but effective relief pitching by George Gill muffled the Senators' bats and the Tigers went on to triumph.

Twenty-one American refugees left Shanghai yesterday on the United States cruiser Sacramento for Hong Kong and most of them will proceed to the United States on the steamer President Coolidge, which is due at San Francisco on Oct. 6, the State Department was informed today.

After elimination rounds at individual golf clubs and also by districts, the metropolitan amateur handicap golf champion was finally selected at the Lido Country Club today by the process of a final eighteen holes of medal play.

For a pension of $12,000 a year for himself, James J. Walker "killed beyond any hope of resurrection Tammany's last glimmering chance of success at the polls this year," Corporation Counsel Paul Windels declared yesterday in a radio speech from Station WABC. Mr. Windels spoke under the auspices of the City Fusion party.

By-stander," a three-act play by Robert Brennan, secretary of the Irish Lenation at Washington, was received with enthusiasm at its American premiere tonight at the Hedgerow Theatre, Moylan-Rose Valley.

Iron girders supporting a 10,500gallon water tank on the roof of the Armstrong Cork Products Company's warehouse at 216 Plymouth Street, Brooklyn, collapsed yesterday afternoon and the heavy wood and metal container smashed through the roof and the two upper floors of the building.

The election of Miss Ann M. Kenny as president of the Women's Traffic Club of Greater New York was announced yesterday. Miss Kenny, who served last year as secretary of the club, is employed by the Lehigh Valley Railroad.

Formation of "blue book" committees to set up maximum allowances on radio trade-ins was planned here yesterday, following the intimation by Senator A. Spencer Feld, co-author of the FeldCrawfcrd Fair Trade Act, that he favors the determination of maximum allowances on the blue book principle.

Steel ingot production- last week was lower on the basis of a full working week, but allowance for the holiday brought the daily average up to the previous week's level. As there was a nominal seasonal decline the index lifted to 130.7 from 130.4.

A group of leading British yachtsmen, dissatisfied with the prohibitive expense of Class J craft, are backing a move to substitute the smaller L class and issue a new challenge for the America's Cup, it was learned tonight.

The Brooklyn Daily Eagle continued to print yesterday despite the first full day's strike of 305 employes, who are members of the American Newspaper Guild. A twenty-two page paper appeared on the street at the regular hour shortly before noon, but readers had some difficulty buying the sporting editions early last night at newsstands in the Borough Hall district.

R. Nelson Hickman, chief construction engineer of the Williamsburgh Savings Bank Building, Brooklyn, has been placed in charge of the Real Estate Management Division of the Brooklyn Trust Company. G. Norman Munks,

President Roosevelt declined to comment today on the stories that the new Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, Hugo L. Black, was and is a- member of the Ku Klux Klan until Mr. Black returns from abroad.

128th St, 109 W 3-story tenement, 18.3x 99.11; Margaret C. S. Carroll against Lawrence A. Giscombe: due. $7.653; taxes, etc, $100: to plaintiff for $5,000. By JACQUES COHEN 36th St, 108 E. 4-story dwelling, 25x98.9: Harlem Savings Bank against Fred F. French Operators. Inc; due, $58.524; taxes. etc. $828: to plaintiff for $2.000.

The cleaners and dyers strike spread to New Jersey yesterday when 200 employes of the Empire Cleaners and Dyers Company, which does the work for sixty-three New York stores, and the Verger Waldo Cleaners on River Road, both of Edgewater, walked out.

The marriage of Mrs. Alexandra de Vergensky of this city and Paris, daughter of Mrs. Julian M. de Vergensky and the late Mr. de Vergensky, to F. G. Aubrey Nash, also of New York, took place yesterday afternoon in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building.

Alexander Hiller, newspaper representative. in 545 5th Ave; Philip Weissbrot, sewing machine parts, floor in 800-2 6th Ave; Barnaba Photographs Corp, additional space in 183 Madison Ave: Welmac Building Corp, in 1.841-43 Broadway; the Cross Brown Co. broker.

A range of temperature no greater than that between the level of a "refrigeraor and body heat has a life and death" effect on living matter subected to X-rays, Dr. Janet Howell Clark of Johns Hopkins University old the International Congress of Radiologists today.

Influenced by the sharp recovery n the stock market and active buyng for Liverpool and Bombay accounts, prices on the Cotton Exchanged improved yesterday and ended with gains of 3 to 7 points. As a result of pressure from the marketing movement,

Fracisco Ciccotti, famous Italian journalist, at one time a close friend and collaborator of Premier Benito Mussolini, died here today after a brief illness at the age of 57. Mr. Ciccotti entered the Italian Socialist party as a youth and eventually became one of its most prominent leaders.

Dr. Henry Robert Murray Landis, a pioneer in the study of silicosis, a medical writer, editor and teacher, died today in Bryn Mawr Hospital in his sixty-sixth year. He had been in ill health for years.

Attorneys for the National Labor Relations Board were undecided today as to their next move to get to the witness stand Mayor Daniel J. Shields of Johnstown, who yesterday ignored a subpoena calling for his appearance at the hearing in the Bethlehem Steel company's case.

By EDWIN J. McDONALD Country Club Rd, 3,147, 102.10x50x100 irregular; J. Ard Haughwout, trustee, against George Edward Jupp; due, $10,310; to plaintiff for $6,000. Shakespeare Ave. 1,183, 2-story dwelling, 50x34.5: Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Association against Luigi Casali: due, $13,170; to plaintiff for $500.

Many American Legion veterans here for the national convention are expected to be present at the Polo Grounds Saturday afternoon to witness the exhibition baseball games and pageant which will be staged for the benefit of the House of Calvary Hospital for Incurable Cancer Cases at Featherbed Lane.

Detroit defeated a team from the Oklahoma oil town of Sapulpa, 1 to 0, tonight to win the men's national softball championship. Twenty-year-old Miss Mary Skorvich pitched Cleveland to its second consecutive championship in the final of the girls' division, when the Ohioans defeated Detroit, 7 to 1.

Some Chinese delegates to the League of Na- e tions said tonight they would ask soon for a meeting of the advisory committee to bring concerted action by the League and the United States, which accepted non-voting participation on this committee.

Boston's Bees dealt the Chicago Cubs' National League title hopes a body blow today, winning both games of a double-header, 9 to 0 and 4 to 2, through an eight-run, fifth-inning assault in the opener and dazzling fielding, which included a triple play and two double killings, in the second game.
Miss Deborah Crease, daughter of Mrs. Orlando Crease Jr. of Germantown, was introduced to society tonight at a dinner dance given by her mother at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

Open market commercial paper amounting to $329,000,000 was outstanding at the end of August, according to reports by dealers to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This compared with $324,700,000 at the end of July and $205,200,000 at the end of August, 1936.

Retail failures dropped slightly in the five business days ended Sept. 9, compared with the corresponding period last year, while in the manufacturing group there was an increase of one, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Joe McCarthy's Yankees lambasted three of Steve O'Neill's pitchers and ran the Indians bowlegged chasing extra-base blows and distant flies as they swamped the hapless Cleveland crew, 17 to 5, at the Stadium yesterday.

Postmaster General James A. Farley said today regarding the New York City primary: "It is my sincere belief that every enrolled voter should participate in the primaries and assist in selecting his or her party nominees.

The subject of this round-table conference is very important and and its solution vital to the material interests of the nation and the State. All citizens and taxpayers of the nation are at one and the same time citizens and taxpayers of some one of our forty-eight States and of one or more layers of local government.
A team of track and field stars from the United States made a clean sweep of events in which they competed against Danish athletes today.

Heavily laden with trophies and souvenirs, a squad of ten American track and field athletes arrived yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania after an extensive competitive junket through Europe.

After undergoing a physical examination at the training house on Franklin Field, forty-eight candidates for the University of Pennsylvania football team left by train this afternoon for the new camp at Hershey.

An outstanding social event of the early Fall season was the annual card party of Putnam Hill Chapter, D. A. R., held this afternoon at the Greenwich Country Club, at which 300 persons, including many of the socially prominent of the town attended.

Goods sold to Mexican buyers will have to carry higher prices than those quoted to all other markets of the world as a result of the Mexican Government's decision to impose a tax of 3 per cent on the invoice value of imported goods, exporters said yesterday in discussing the latest regulation at a luncheon meeting of the Export Managers' Club of New York, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The new order,

Trading continued active on most classes of non-kosher meats yesterday. Veal, calf and fresh pork prices were strong to sharply higher. Other classes were strong to slightly higher with the exception of lamb, some sales of which were 50c off. The kosher slaughter was heavier than Monday and prices showed little change from Monday's close, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Mrs. Lillian R. Sire, who as president of the Women's National Democratic Club is conducting a training school for women jurors, was one of 229 jurywomen drawn yesterday for the October panels of the Court of General Sessions, the Surrogate's and Municipal Courts.
With the election of eight new clubs at the quarterly meeting yesterday, membership in the American Kennel Club, governing body of pure-bred dog activities in this country, reached a new high.

Emile Joseph, proprietor of the meat business that has borne his name in Washington Market for half a century, died yesterday at his home, 25 Central Park West, of pneumonia after an illness of several weeks. He was 73 years old.

A marked revival in the European demand for North American cash wheat with sales of around 2,000,000 bushels of Canadian and 1,000,000 of United States grain reported, and a marked reversal in the trend of Liverpool sent prices soaring on the Board of Trade here today and while the best figures were not maintained the close here was at net gains of 2 to 21/8 cents a bushel.

Following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of August: Total imports, [Pound]86,650,000; exports of British products, [Pound]42,540,000; re-exports, [Pound]6,680,000; total exports, [Pound]49,220,000; excess of imports, [Pound]37,430,000.

Retired Fireman William Towart, formerly a member of Engine 50. residing at 2,685 University Ave., Bronx, died Sept. 12. Funeral will take place from Cooke's Funeral Parlor, 190th St. and Jerome Ave., Bronx, at 2 P. M., Wednesday, Sept. 15. The Deputy Chief of the 7th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.

The American Scandinavian Foundation gave a dinner in honor of Viggo Christensen, Commissioner of Public Welfare of Copenhagen, Denmark, and Mrs. Christensen, at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East Sixty-sixth Street, last night.

Mrs. Helene W. Hanscom, 29 years old, wife of Richard S. Hanscom, an official of a Philadelphia baking concern, was found asphyxiated by illuminating gas in the laundry room in the basement of the Hanscom Summer residence, 81 Atlantic Boulevard, here today.

Controller Frank J. Taylor will recommend when the Board of Estimate meets on Sept. 24 that the city buy a tract at 108th Avenue, 109th Avenue, 155th Street and 157th Street in the South Jamaica section of Queens.

BASCH, REBECCA F. (Jan. 6, 1933). Gross assets, $2,070; net, $437. To husband, George S. Basch. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $400; miscellaneous property, $1,670. Theodore Pearle. attorney. 26 Court St:

An extensive advertising campaign in a large list of newspapers throughout the country will back up G. W.'s national magazine drive this Fall, it was announced yesterday by Ralph Niece, advertising and sales promotion manager for Gooderham Worts.
There are several good reasons why the break in the stock market cannot be regarded as a war scare; chief among them,

A year ago this time a stringy halfback of 143 pounds answering respectfully to the name of Monkey Meyer was hitting the bullseye with a football and cutting up and off tackle behind a line that would knock your eye (and teeth) out. The idea got abroad that beating Army was one of the jobs of the season.

Irving Halper, 45 years old, of 161 West Seventy-second Street, who was arrested Sept. 3 on a charge of vagrancy and questioned about the slaying of Mrs. Esther Gordon, whose body was found Aug. 27 near the Hell Gate Bridge, in Queens,

Oppenheim, Collins Co., Inc., reported yesterday for the year ended on July 31 a net profit of $240,125 after expenses and other charges but before deducting Federal income and undistributed profits taxes of $41,800. The profit is equivalent to 99 cents a share on the outstanding capital stock and is in contrast to a net loss of $16,383 in the preceding fiscal year.

Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Taylor Baldwin gave a dance here tonight to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Hope Baldwin. The party took place at Shallow Brook Farm, the home of the debutante's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Clark Baldwin.

Twenty-four passengers in a New York bound Hudson-Manhattan tube train, were in a near panic this afternoon when fire broke out in the cab of the second car of the train as it drew into the station here.

Miss Lucie Madeline Riordan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Riordan of this city, was married here this morning to John J. McKeon Jr. of New Haven in St. Joseph's Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frederick T. McKeon, member of the faculty of Notre Dame University, an uncle of the bridegroom.

While yesterday's leaders in the international chess masters tournament, Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, and Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia, challenger for the world title, played to an adjournment in today's fifth round at the Hotel Panhans, Reuben Fine of New York and Paul Keres, Estonia, slipped into the lead by winning their games.

A three-month downtrend in machine tool orders was checked in August, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported today. The association's index, with 1926 shipments taken as 100 per cent, stood at 179.8 in August compared with 171.1 in July.
The British cruiser York, flagship of Vice Admiral Sidney J. Merrick, commander of the America and West Indies Station, -stood into New York yesterday afternoon for a few days' visit.

Ten Princeton University teams, competing in three branches of sport, will plav fifty-seven contests this Fall, according to schedules released today by Asa S. Bushnell, '21, graduate manager of athletics.

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden gained precedence in the League of Nations Council today for Britain's plan for the partition of Palestine and he pushed the Council energetically toward quickly granting his request for authorization to proceed on the general principle of partition.

The Porto Rican American Tobacco Company, the island's largest cigar manufacturers, with the largest industrial payroll in San Juan, has ceased operations for export and has concentrated manufacturing at its Newark factories.

The Supreme Court has been asked by the Justice Department to overrule several former decisions to end tax exemption, of those doing business with the Federal and State Governments, Attorney General Cummings stated today.

The Autumn meeting of the White Mountain Garden Club was held today at Arden, in the home here of the president, Mrs. John W. Guider of Washington. A buffet luncheon was served and more than fifty attended.
The most elaborate anti-aircraft defense exercises ever held in Japan began today with about 40,000 volunteer workers standing by in Tokyo and four adjacent prefectures.

In a dispatch from New City, N. Y., published on Aug. 14 in THE NEw YORK TIMES, it was said that Mrs. Arthur T. O'Leary of Blauvelt, N. Y., had protested that a Rockland County fiesta on behalf of Spanish refugee children was "under the sponsorship of communistic elements." This was an error. Mrs.

The Portland General Electric Company has completed arrangements for an extension of collateral notes and two bank loans aggregating $1,500,000 with the Chase National Bank and the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, according to a statement filed with the New York Stock Exchange for the listing of an additional $1,216,000 of 4 1/2 per cent mortgage bonds.

The Giants' perilous pennant dash into the West opened today with a variety of fortunes befalling the troops of Colonel Bill Terry which for a time had both a crowd of 10,000 and Secretary Eddie Brannick a trifle puzzled to know just how things stood.

WHILE the members of the executive committee of the American Olympic Association were settling some fine points in our future Olympic policy, the Japanese were advancing from the Peiping-Suiyuan Railroad toward the Yu River, thus touching another and more distant point in Olympic policy.
Mrs. Frances Parkinson Keyes became the editor today of The D. A. R. Magazine. The wife of former Senator Henry W. Keyes of New Hampshire succeeds Miss Natalie Lincoln, who died two years ago.
Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, is expected to allot today to banks and dealers $100,000,000 of New York State short-term notes. The proceeds will be used for general State purposes.

If Hugo L. Black received a life-membership card or gold "grand passport" from the Birmingham Klan in 1926, it was merely a "local gesture of an honorary nature," according to a statement made today by Dr. Hiram W Evans, Imperial Wizard of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan.

John Duroska purchased the three-story store and dwelling property at 979 Broadway, North Bergen, N. J., from the Hudson Trust Company. The building contains one store and two apartments. George Moser represented the seller and Irving Goldberg was the attorney for the purchaser. J. I. Kislak, Inc., negotiated the transaction.

The flow of gold to this country spurted yesterday when engagements of $12,426,000 of the metal abroad for shipment here were reported. These were the largest engagements in one day for several weeks and followed a period in which the movement of the metal here had seemed to be drying up.

Foreign demand for United States chemicals and related products continued at a high level in July, the Department of Commerce reported today. Shipments for the month were $16,523,000 in value, compared with $17,000,000 in June.

The contract settling the strike of 13,000 painters in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond, Which began on Aug. 25, was signed yesterday afternoon by representatives of the Association of Master Painters and District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers at a conference at the association's headquarters at 2 Park Avenue.

Of the 12,629 bills introduced in the last session of Congress, 529 were found to affect retailers directly or indirectly, according to a legislative review entitled "The Retailer and the Seventy-fifth Congress," issued yesterday by the American Retail Federation.
An offering of 50,000 common shares of the Gaylord Container Corporation will be made today by Hemphill, Noyes Co. and Stifel, Nicolaus Co., Inc., at $18.75 a share. Coincidentally,

Misbehavior of the thyroid gland was advanced today as the cause of derangement of the other internal secretion glands in the human body and as the source of about 90 per cent of the nervous ailments of men and women, in a report by Dr. J. Thompson Stevens of Polyclinic Hospital, New York.

Neutrality laws alone cannot assure our security, Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, told a radio audience tonight, adding that in these days of "distrust and uncertainty" the United States could not afford to disregard "the lessons of unpreparedness."

Alexander Watson, a designer of English period furniture and secretary-treasurer of Smith Watson, Inc., antique dealers, at 20 East Fifty-fifth Street, New York, died of a heart attack here this evening at his home, 16 Stuyvesant Avenue. He was 62 years old.

Owing to the Jewish holiday. Yom Kippur, there were no kosher markets yesterday. A large percentage of the wholesale and retail houses being closed affected trading and business was generally slow. Lamb prices were barely steady to $1 lower than Monday. Fresh pork prices were strong to higher; other classes showed little change, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Reports on retail sales from many sections of the country indicate average gains since Labor Day of 10 to 15 per cent over a year ago. These increases mark something of a reversal of the August trend, when the Federal Reserve Board reported an average increase for the country as a whole of 4 per cent.

A contract for a railroad exhibit at the New York World's Fair of 1939 was signed yesterday by the Eastern Presidents Conference, composed of the heads of thirtyfour Eastern lines, and Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair. The exhibit will occupy the greatest amount of space and be the largest single display at the fair, it was announced.
A stiff southwester with a twenty-five-mile velocity kicked up a rolling sea for the second race of the Six-Meter Class held under the auspices of the American Yacht Club today.
Resolutions offered before the Trades and Labor Congress of Canada today demanded that the Canadian Government nationalize rdium and nickel ore.
Everything sort of rolled along for the Giants today as Colonel Bill Terry's troops swung briskly into their second day of pennant campaigning along the western front.

Throughout the city and nation tomorrow flags will be flown in honor of the 150th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution of the United States. Patriotic organizations will conduct ceremonies and hundreds of dinners will, be held at which speeches on the Constitution will be delivered.
A number of benches along the fashionable Kurfuerstendamm have been reserved for "non-Aryans" with prominent yellow inscriptions, "For Jews only."

Frank R. McNinch, new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, will devote most of his time there to "helping to formulate policies," he said today, after a conference with President Roosevelt. He said that was what the President wanted him to do.

Miss Cornelia Janeway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore W. Janeway of Dongan Hills, S. I., was introduced to society last night at a dinner dance given at the Plaza by her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Ray Alan Van Clief of Paget, Bermuda.

Wheat on the Board of Trade here fluctuated today erratically within a moderate range, being firmer early in sympathy with the market in Liverpool, only to weaken later when it became apparent importing countries were not in the market for larger supplies of North American cash wheat.

III for twelve years, Mrs. Eva Cohen, 76 years old, was fatally injured shortly before 8 o'clock yesterday morning when, according to the police, she jumped or fell five stories to the street from a bedroom window of her apartment at 1,901 Hennessey Place, the Bronx,

Mrs. Phyllis S. Adams of New York today won a divorce from Charles E. Adams, industrialist, on a charge of cruelty. They were married at Greenwich, Conn., Feb. 3, 1917, and have two children, Phyllis and Janet.

Competition from new publications, linage declines in September issues, and lack of advance business are chief reasons why magazine publishers are launching heavy promotional campaigns for the Fall season, according to comment here yesterday.

The award of Lucius N. Littauer scholarships to help ten young women receive training in fashion and textile designing at the New York School of Applied Design for Women, 160 Lexington Avenue, for a school year beginning Oct. 4,

Mr. J. M. Landis, resigning from the Securities and Exchange Commission, ends an official career which has been diligent, unsensational and, on the whole, conservative. Under his chairmanship he has followed his predecessor, Joseph P. Kennedy, in avoiding the hostile attitude toward the institutions supervised which has characterized many other Government bureaus since 1933.

Coach Raymond W. (Ducky) Pond greeted sixty-one of the finest conditioned football players Yale ever has seen on opening day as the Elis started their fourth year of preseason training at the crew training quarters today.

With eight named for the Fall highweight handicap, the opening feature, the Autumn meeting of the Westchester Racing Association will begin today at Belmont Park with the highest expectations of success.

KING RICHARD II. a return engagement of the revival of Shakespeare's play; costumes by David Ffolkes; directed by Margaret Webster; produced by Eddie Dowling and Robinson Smith. At the St. James Theatre.
Mrs. Maud Lane, formerly associted with Port Burke, has joined Brett Wyckoff, Inc. She will specialize in apartment and private dwelling rentals.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora revoked yesterday a permit granted by the Board of Standards and Appeals for the erection of a motion picture theatre at Lexington Avenue and East Seventy-seventh Street.

The last concrete on the Tygart River Dam, a gaint faucet holding back a potential 327,500 acre-feet of water, will be poured Saturday, marking one of the final steps in the first project designed 'to protect Pittsburgh from flood waters.

Mexican consular offices here began yesterday to collect the 3 per cent levy on the invoice value of shipments destined for that country in conformity with an order issued last week by the Mexican Government.

" Should Government regulation of business in the future follow the pattern of the last fifty years, we face the prospect of steadily increasing the responsibility of both, while steadily diminishing their power to fulfill," Donald R. Richberg of Washington, co-author and general counsel of the NRA, said today in an address at the thirty-fifth annual convention of the National Petroleum Association in the Hotel Traymore here.
The Foundation for Americans of Mature Age, Inc., will start a campaign to combat what its leader said was a "growing prejudice" against employing persons over 40.

Mrs. Henry March of North Shore led a small field in the weekly one-day tournament of the Long'Island Women's Golf Association over the Rockaway Hunting Club course today, returning a card of 43, 41-84. Scoring 43, 44-87, Mrs. Sylva Annenberg of Fresh Meadow, the Long Island match play champion, took second.
Colonel William H. Moore, a former president of the American Good Roads Congress, was fatally injured tonight when struck by a motor car almost in front of his home. He was 81.
Ed Tellier, 180-pound junior from Leominster, Mass., replaced sophomore Jerry Fall at the running guard post in a scrimmage session held yesterday by the Manhattan football squad in Innisfail Park.
President Roosevelt and John L. Lewis met face to face today for the first time since May in a talk at the White House. Their recent public utterances had indicated a breach between them.

Alfred V. Leaman 3d was named defendant in a divorce suit filed in the Circuit Court here today by Mrs. Eunice Putnam Leaman. Her attorneys said she alleged mental cruelty. She is spending the Summer at East Hampton, L. I., while he is understood to be traveling in Europe.

Life membership in the Association of Foreign Press Correspondents in the United States has been awarded by its executive committee to Percy S. Bullen, British newspaper correspondent, A. Bernard Moloney, president of the group, announced yesterday.

Electric power production was lower last week. In spite of allowance for the holiday, daily average output also declined, contrary to the usual seasonal and long-term trends, and the adjusted index has dipped to 105.2, its lowest point since the week ended Jan. 2. It was 108.9 for the previous week, and 103.6 for the week ended Sept. 12, 1936.

Mortgage certificates acquired by repurchase by the company that guaranteed them are subordinate in interest to the certificates still in the hands of outside investors, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler ruled yesterday. The decision drew a distinction between certificates that the guaranteeing company never had sold and those that it had sold and bought back.

Officials of the Board of Trade moved swiftly today to prevent what is regarded by the trade as an attempted corner in September corn. The Clearing House Association of the Exchange late this afternoon announced that margins on September corn would be 8 cents a bushel effective tomorrow, compared with 4 cents, which has prevailed heretofore.
It was a happy thought, that decision of President Will Harridge of the American League throwing out the Yankee-Cleveland game of last Aug. 6 on the protest of Steve O'Neill.

Shipping interests of New York are strongly in favor of legislation that will subject ship-owners and maritime unions to public control and are equally firm in the belief that the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 as it now stands will not encourage the development of a strong merchant marine, according to reports published yesterday by the Merchants Association and the Maritime Association.
New York City will be bone dry today during the primary voting hours, 3 P. M. to 10 P. M., by decree of Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the State Liquor Authority.

In the closing moments of perhaps the fiercest primary campaign this city has ever witnessed in a year of a Mayoralty election, a definite movement was taking form yesterday for the writing in of Mayor La Guardia's name on Democratic primary ballots.
The annual flower show of the Old Greenwich Garden Club, held today at the June Binney Memorial Parish House, was a wellattended social event.

Representations made on the floor of the Senate that Hugo L. Black was not a member of the Ku Klux Klan influenced a number of his Senate colleagues to vote to confirm him as a Supreme Court justice, Senator David I. Walsh, Democrat, said in a statement issued here today.

Gene Schott, hard-luck pitcher for the Reds, furnished the only mild sensation in today's second division double-header warfare. The young Cincinnati-resident right-hander, who had won only two games all year, shut out the Dodgers in the opener in the fast time of 1 hour and 23 minutes.
To a large number of people Arthur Garfield Hays in a liberal lawyer of New York who has written several books and spends a great deal of time lending legal aid to the "under dog."

George Poulos, alias Pappas, and John J. Blake, arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents on charges of transporting women across State boundaries for immoral purposes in violation of the Mann Act, were a held today in $25,000 and $20,000 bail, respectively, by United States Commissioner Marvin A. Spaulding to await grand jury action.
State Controller Tremaine headed a motor procession of toll-reduction celebrants and paid the first halfdollar toll as new rates on the Mid Hudson and Rip Van Winkle Bridges went into effect today.

The dubious future of Shanghai's foreign trade possibilities when hostilities cease near this great seaport were somewhat clarified today during an interview with a Japanese admiral whose name at his request cannot be divulged.
The polls in New York City will be open today between 3 and 10 P. M. Up-State the polls for the primary election will be open from noon to 9 P.M.

Bill Trotter gave the St. Louis Browns an even split in a double header with the Athletics today winning his first game of the sea son, 3 to 1, in the nightcap after Philadelphia had taken the opener 8 to 2.

A Harlem transaction yesterday involved the five-story apartment house at 257 West 122d Street, which was bought by Harry Hackett, operator, through Low Gross, Inc., brokers. The building is on a lot 25 by 100 feet and was sold for cash over a mortgage of $19,000 at 3 per cent-for five years.

The directors of Bird Son, Inc., and stockholders' trustees under the voting trust expiring on Oct. 9 approved yesterday a plan of capital readjustment to reduce the stated value of 600,000 common shares from $10 to $5 a share, or from $6,000,000 to $3,000,000, and allow for issuance of 30,000 shares of new $5 cumulative preferred stock to common stockholders.

The marriage of Mrs. Lily W. Ruperti Howells, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Justus Ruperti of this community and Elizabeth, N. J., to Havens Grant of New York, took place this afternoon at Marigolds, the Ruperti home.
The army's only woman warrant officer, Olive L. Hoskins of Pasadena, Calif., received the personal consent of President Roosevelt today to retire from duty after thirty years of service.

Monsignor Cesare Orsenigo, Papal Nuncio to Germany, who is in Italy on his annual vacation, was received this morning by Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, to whom he delivered a detailed report on the religious situation in Germany.

Funeral services for Ellis Parker Butler, humorist, who died Monday at his Summer home in Housatonic, Mass., were held yesterday at the Hallett Homestead, Northern Boulevard and 147th Street, Flushing, Queens. About 200 persons attended.

Chief Counsel, bay colt by Volomite, raced through a crack field of 2-year-old pacers to win two straight heats and first place in the $4,600 Village Farm Stake, feature of the second day of Grand Circuit racing at the Reading fair today.
The Government of Spain has authorized the payment of commercial debts owed by Spanish interests to American individuals and corporations that were incurred prior to the outbreak of the civil war.

The National Labor Relations Board's policy of protecting employee witnesses who refuse to disclose union membership lists led the Bethlehem Steel Company today to threaten to summon all of its 15,000 employes at the Cambria plant to testify at the hearing here.

The German Propaganda Department requested today that all patriotic citizens report to the police any suspicious conversations or actions of individuals or groups that might indicate espionage. The warning reads:

The partners in Hayden, Stone Co. announced yesterday that they would continue the annual Charles Hayden Trophy golf tournament as a tribute to the memory of the late Charles Hayden. For fifteen years this tournament has brought many of Wall Street's best golfers into competition as representatives of their firms.

The Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra, Emerson Buckley conducting, presented a program at the WPA Theatre of Music last night, with Frances Ernest, soprano, and Harry Neidell, violinist, as soloists. Miss Ernest was heard in arias from Mozart and Leoncavallo, and Mr. Neidell played works by SaintSaens and Sarasate.

Stockholders of the Lehman Corporation, at their annual meeting on Oct. 20, will consider a proposal to amend the management agreement of the corporation with Lehman Brothers, under which that firm is required to buy stock of the corporation at book value with any compensation paid to them under the agreement.

The Sinclair Prairie Producing Company, the principal-producing subsidiary of the Consolidated Oil Corporation, completed seventy producing oil wells in July and August, with an initial net production of 41,008 barrels daily, the company announced yesterday.

A report from New York that the railroads are planning to offer operating employes a series of three hourly wage increases of 2 cents each in the next six months was denied today by H. A. Enochs, chairman of the Conference Committee of Managers.

The Cardinals and the Phillies battled for thirteen innings today, and then with the score 6 to 6 the umpires decided to postpone the struggle. After Dolph Camilli had homered in the first inning with two mates on base, Joe Medwick hit his twenty-ninth home run in the Cards' half to drive in two runners ahead of him and deadlock the count.

A disgranted former client, who felt that he had been "double-crossed," confessed he had killed one attorney and stabbed another a few hours earlier in their offices in the Loop area. He gave himself up at a police station.
The search for new living accommodations, by families whose needs thus late in the season have not been met, vered to the West Side, according to brokers' reports submitted. yesterday.
Mar Le, dark bay misstep gelding, outgamed W. S. Stroube's Huskie Boy to carry the silks of the Lemar Stock Farm to victory in the sixfurlong Nayatt Handicap today at Narragansett Park.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Newton Gilmore of 78 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, and Babylon, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Gilmore, to Duncan Cameron Stevenson of West Islip, L. I.

More than 100 employes of S. B. Penick Co., one of the largest botanical drug companies in the world, had narrow escapes from death and injury yesterday when a flash from an electric switch in the cellar of the mixing plant in lower Weehawken started a fire in the dust-dry stores that swept the three-story brick building from one end to the other.

Important changes in ocean-shipping insurance rates, reflecting war conditions in the Far East, were made today by the Institute of London Underwriters, representing more than fifty of the principal marine insurance companies.
Bronx White Plains Rd, ?? e cor of Magenta St, 34x45; 1-story service and repair shop; Pizzutello Holding Corp, 3,365 Cruger Ave, owner; J. W. Clyde, architect; cost $5,000.

The field of contenders for the post vacated by Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, was being rapidly enlarged tonight as the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization indicated their rivalry for the office.
The Roosevelt Administration's attitude on power and flood control projects was sharply attacked today at the Governors .Conference by Governor George D. Aiken of Vermont.
The report of the American Gas and Electric Company-and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended July 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all expenses and charges of $13,128,016.
Jules Mendel of 1,120 Park Avenue, president of Howse, Mead Sons, woolen importers, 9 East Thirty-seventh Street, died suddenly at his desk yesterday afternoon of a heart attack.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor left this afternoon for hunting at Nicholsburg castle in Czechoslovakia as guests of Prince Alexander Dietrichstein. Because of the national mourning for former President Thomas G. Masaryk, the Prince asked the population to abstain from beflagging their homes and a public welcome.
Mrs. Alvina Gaertner of North Bergen, N. J., died in a hospital today after a bus accident in which fourteen persons were injured while returning from the Nazi party convention at Nuremberg.

Rear Admiral Harris Laning, now commanding the Third Naval District, New York, and who will retire on Nov. 1, will become governor of the Naval Home at Philadelphia, the Navy Department announced today.

Thomas J. Walsh, building contractor and former Democratic member of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors, died today at his home here. At one time he was with the Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company here.
British defenders of this strategic Mediterranean naval base today were constructing a giant cable net-such as was used during the Ethiopian crisis-to bar intruding submarines from Malta's harbor.

I am amused by J. B. Milgram's statement that I appear to yearn for the good old days before La Guardia. I don't see why Mr. Milgram persists in talking about what the present Mayor has done in keeping down real estate taxes, when in his previous communication to you he admitted the correctness of my statement that real estate taxes for the last four years had been regulated solely by the bankers' agreement.
The Norman Lila Estates, Inc., operators, bought from Weissman Ackerman the six-story apartment house for seventy-six families at 751 Gerard Avenue, southwest corner of 157th Street, the Bronx.

The will of Dr. Leonidas Le May Mial, on file today for probate, directs that "no suit be brought" on any of his uncollected accounts. Instead, he ordered a receiptedd bill with my best wishes" be given to patients who failed to pay bills.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, WPA Administrator, announced yesterday that 100 bookkeepers in his offices would be replaced by payroll machines within the next few weeks in line with the program to decrease non-productive workers and assign them to more productive fields.

In celebration of the 116th anniversary of the independence of El Salvador and other Central American countries from Spain; Congress today conferred the title of "Benefactor of the Nation" on President Maximiliano Martinez Hernandez.

Charles A. Rice of 834 West Seventh Street, Plainfield, N. J., who was connected with Joseph Bancroft Sons, Inc., New York cotton brokers, died here today in Post-Graduate Hospital, where he had undergone an operation. He was born in Brooklyn sixty-five years ago.

COONEY, ALICE M. (Sept. 3). Estate, less than, $10,000. To Margaret E. Walker, sister, 3 E. 77th St., executrix. GUDE, EDWARD C. (Sept. 2). Estate, more than, $10,000. To Margaret Adams Gude, widow, 117 E. 72d St., residue. Walter E. Gude, nephew, 957 Springfield Ave., Summit, N. J., and A. Spotswood Campbell, 155 E. 52d St., executors.
Cotton farmers, a number of them armed, today stood guard over fields in Warren County, Georgia, to prevent a threatened walkout.

JUST the other day there came a story from high over the sea that Steve Donoghue, who rode six winners in the Epsom Derby, was climbing down out of the saddle and hanging up his tack. Some of the racegoers in this country will remember Steve.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Moore Longcope Jr. of this city and Shady Lawn Farm, Buckingham, Pa., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Wilhelmina Scherer Longcope, to Elliott Ross Weyer of New York, son of Dr. Edward Moffatt Weyer of Washington, Pa., and Foote's Bay, Ont.

The Japanese are preparing a new autonomous government for South Chahar Province at Kalgan. Tu Wei-yu, former Finance Commissioner of the old Provincial Government, will apparently be put in as its head.

Employes of the Newark Museum are thankful today that the exhibit storeroom is a cool place, for it was found yesterday that it contained an old item-a stick of smokeless powder, a powerful explosive, three feet long and an inch in diameter.

Domestic stocks of refined copper at the end of August were 123,484 tons, an increase of 5,744 over the 117,740 reported at the end of July, according to the Copper Institute. Apparent domestic consumption in August was 68,019 tons, compared with 67,356 in July, domestic output was 91,228 tons, against 85,224 in July. Domestic exports were 6,373 tons, against 5,534. Blister stocks increased 11,095 tons.

Hugo L. Black, President Roosevelt's nominee for associate justice of the Supreme Court and now declared to be a life member of the Ku Klux Klan, is already a full-fledged member of the high court with as complete powers as any other of the justices, high legal authorities said today.
Vittorio Mussolini, 20-year-old son of the Italian Premier, left Rome today bound for Hollywood to hire technical crews for his new film company, it was announced here.

As expected, the Federal election will be held Oct. 23, exactly three years after the first meeting of the present Parliament. The date was officially announced in the House of Representatives yesterday by Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons.
Steve (Crusher) Casey, powerful Irish heavyweight wrestler, easily disposed of Benny (Crusher) Feldman of Louisiana in the feature wrestling exhibition at Madison Square Garden last night.

One hundred and fifty modern fighting planes of the Army Air Corps will stage three flights above the Fifth Avenue parade of the American Legion next Tuesday, it was announced at American Legion Convention headquarters yesterday.

The new Soviet Constitution, going into effect as Americans commemorate the birthday of their own Constitution and analyze anew the basic charter of their liberties, suggests comparisons that have no basis of reality. Even if the document loudly heralded as the Magna Charta of Socialist democracy were all it purports to be, a paper Constitution cannot be compared with a working Bill of Rights tested by 150 years of experience.
After a traffic accident at Clinton and Fulton Streets, Brooklyn, in which he was knocked down and injured about the head, hands and knees,

A memorial service for Thomas Garrigue Masaryk, first President of Czechoslovakia, who died Tuesday at his home in Lany, will be held here Sunday morning at 10:30 in the 'Jan Hus Czech Brethren Presbyterian Church, 351 East Seventy-fourth Street. Mr. Masaryk was a member of the Czech Brethren Communion.
The German Government is sending an airplane from Berlin to search for the Lufthansa machine that disappeared on a return flight from Soochow, China to Kabul, Afghanistan.

Dr. Jean Wells, daughter of Mrs. Ernest A. Wells of Ithaca, N. Y., formerly of Hartford, will be married to Dr. Joseph Bentley Hollinshead, son of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus L. Hollinshead of West Englewood, N. J., on Sept. 25 at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Donald B. Wells of West Hartford.

Just a few days ago Fredric March was noting that he and his wife, Florence Eldridge, would not be appearing on Broadway in Talbot Jennings's "This Side Idolatry." Apparently that didn't mean the pair wouldn't be on Broadway, for here they are announced for the leading roles of "The Christian Hero," a new one by Horace Jackson and a play based on the essayists. Addison and Steele.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and adjacent surburban areas showed an increase of 3 per cent for the week ended Sept. 11, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. For the previous week the delivery organization had reported a decline of 7 per cent under a year ago.
Argentina imported 8,248 typewriters in the first half of 1937 and of these 5,098 were from the United States and 1,821 from Germany, the Department of Commerce stated today.

Henry T. (Dick) Merrill, transatlantic flier and one of the chief pilots for Eastern Air Lines, was fined $500 today by the Bureau of Air Commerce, and the company was penalized in the same amount on a charge that he violated a traffic regulation governing Washington Airport.
Hospitals Commissioner S. S. Goldwater said yesterday that a shortage of trained nurses for city hospitals might delay full establishment of the eight-hour day for nurses next year.

Business executives from banking, brokerage and insurance houses and other commercial fields served as jurors last night at a fashion show for business girls "on their way up," held in the downstairs fashion store in the north building of John Wanamaker's.

Ernest C. Gier was elected president of the Duplan Silk Corporation at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday. He succeeds Paul C. Debry, who was named chairman of the board. Mr. Debry will continue to devote all of his time to the executive duties of the company.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of Sept. 13, 1937, on the eligible list of holders of license as research assistant, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license: Barthelmness, Harriet M., 81.00; Eads, Laura K., 80.58; Bittner, Margaret A., 71.2; Guanella, Frances M., 69.55; Landry. Herbert A., 68.75; Noll, Victor H., 66.78.

Pending the approval of the United States Lawn Tennis Association at its annual meeting on Jan. 15 in Miami, this country will defend the Davis Cup in 1938 at the Germantown Cricket Club in Philadelphia over the Labor Day week-end.

A four-color double-page spread in one picture magazine this week will promote the new DeSoto advertising theme to emphasize their dealers' services. The advertisement will be in the form of a newspaper front page with the message "See Your DeSoto dealer-for a great car, fine service and a square deal."

Mgr. Jose Torres Diaz, Vicar General of San Juan and Apostolic Delegate of the San Juan Diocese, died last night. He was 76 years old. After studying for the priesthood at St. Ildefonso Seminary in San Juan, he was ordained in 1885. A parish priest during the Spanish regime, he became closely associated with the American Bishops appointed after the change ?? sovereignty.

215th St (16-4686), n e cor of Bronxwood Ave, 100x100 also 215th St, n e side, 100 ft e of Bronxwood Ave, 25x95: Bronxwood Holding Corp, to Jacob-Seligson, 16 East 208th St. Gunther Ave, 4.149 (17-5004): Samuel T. McCarthy to Mary Rosatl, 900 Rogers Pl.

Miss. Daphne Elizabeth Greenwood, daughter of Mrs. Richard Greenwood of Rydal, was introduced to society this afternoon at a tea dance given by her grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Thornton, at their home, Thornton Abbey, in Haverford.

A pageant of forty years of progress in the automobile industry was unfolded here today when the Olds division of General Motors unveiled its new six and eight cylinder cars for 1938 before some 250 automobile editors and magazine men in its new engineering building.

The strike in the British-controlled Pozarica oil fields, which tied up 60 per cent of the Mexican oil production for two months, was settled at dawn today after President Lazaro Cardenas had again intervened, insisting on the end of the walkout.

Setting as its objective "the promotion of the position of the wholesaler," the Council of National Wholesale -Associations has -been organized and has drawn up rules of procedure, Henry Matter, secretary, announced yesterday.

Justice Edgar J. Lauer of the State Supreme Court and Mrs. Lauer spent nine hours yesterday at the Appraisers Stores, 201 Varick Street, while Customs officials examined nineteen pieces of their baggage which had been taken from the pier Monday night when the Justice and his wife arrived from Europe on the French liner Normandie.
A brain research institute equipped with 5,000 human and animal brains, instruments for their study and cameras to record all progress began functioning today.

The tourist movement to France since Spring of this year has showed steady growth, Benjamin Tulley, consul at Paris, has informed the Department of Commerce. It is 33 per cent above the corresponding period last year.
The Tigers came from behind in a ninth-inning rally today to score a 4-to-3 decision over Washington. It was their second straight victory over the Senators.

The Dartmouth College Club, now in a leased building at 24 East Thirty-eighth Street, is reported to be closing negotiations for a longterm rental of a larger structure in the same neighborhood. The lease on the present quarters soon will expire.

The Coast Guard tonight ordered two cutters out to search for the British yacht Endeavour after its convoy, the motor yacht Viva II, limped into port at Newport, R. I., and reported her tow line to the racing sloop had parted in a gale of hurricane force 200 miles out in the Atlantic.

The failure of prices of cotton in Liverpool to follow the recent declining tendency here and in New Orleans brought a further upturn yesterday in prices on the Cotton Exchange and the list gained 8 to 15 points. At one time,

The candidacy of United States Senator A. Harry Moore for Governor of New Jersey was endorsed overwhelmingly by delegates at the'fifty-ninth annual convention of the New Jersey Federation of Labor which came to a close here today.

There are doubtless many progressive Democrats, and many independent voters temporarily enrolled as Democrats, who will borrow a phrase today from Mr. Roosevelt and William Shakespeare. To the two candidates who seek their support in the Democratic primary they will say, a plague on both your houses.

Two hundred members and guests of the Committee of One Hundred attended the club's eighth annual Autumn dinner at the Greenbrier tonight. Sir Wilmot Lewis, Washington correspondent for The Times of London was guest speaker. Afterward an old-fashioned barn dance was held in the Cameo Ballroom.

Another important change in the Chinese line between Kiangwan and Lotien, about five miles and twenty miles, respectively, north of Shanghai, was announced officially by Chinese headquarters here yesterday.

After walking off their ship with the explanation that their new commander had told them all who wished to could leave, sixty members of the crew of the Valencia Government destroyer Jose Luis Diez are spending the night at Falmouth under guard.

Employes of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company today rejected a compromise proposal of a 5-centsan-hour wage increase, made yesterday by company trustees, and instructed their representatives to demand a flat rise of 10 cents an hour free of all conditions.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul Denckla Howe of Chestnut Hill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Blumer Howe, to Walter H. Lippincott Jr. of Sydbury House, Wynnewood, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Lippincott.

Four managers to supervise the reorganization of the Lawyers Mortgage Company, taken over by the State Insurance Department for rehabilitation in 1933, were appointed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler. At the time it was taken over, the company had guarantees amounting to $350,000,000 outstanding.

The Interstate Commerce Commission notified today the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad that its request for an indefinite postponement of hearings on its reorganization plan had been denied.
The American Friends of the Chinese People, 168 West Twenty-third Street, plans to have a motor boat picket the Nippon Yusen Kaisha Line at Pier 16, Brooklyn, at noon today.

Fred E. Graham, in charge of sales in the Southern territory for the Hickok Manufacturing Company, Inc., manufacturer of men's belts, braces and jewelry, and Leo H. Schiff, head of the Los Angeles office, have been named directors of the company.

William V. Winslow of South Orange, seeded fifth, was upset in the third round of the third annual Eastern New Jersey clay courts tennis championship today by Clifford M. Baker of Plainfield, 6-8, 6-4. The victory placed Baker in the quarter-final round.

Magistrate Aurelio, in Intoxication Court, continued yesterday until Oct. 13 the hearing on charges of assault and driving while intoxicated against William F. Carey Jr., 24 years old, of 1 Beekman Place, son of the Commissioner of Sanitation.

H. L. Lowton, examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, filed a report today recommending a denial of the application of the Liberty Forwarding and Distributing Corporation of New York for a common carrier's certificate and a contract carrier's permit to operate as a motor carrier in New England, Middle Atlantic and the Great Lakes territory.

William E. Kelly, member of the last United States Olympic water polo team and recently enrolled patrolman, made his first felony arrest yesterday afternoon. After running down a supposed pickpocket, he rescued his prisoner from an angry crowd.
Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, announced today that he would allot by telegraph tonight $100,000,000 of short-term budgetary notes of the State to some eighty-five banks and bond firms.

Ksar, famed French stallion who sired winners of European race classics, is dead at A. S. Hewitt's Montana Hall Stable in Northern Virginia. The owner today told of the death by internal hemorrhage of the stallion, whose winnings Hewitt said exceeded $100,000.

Amendment to the charter of the Barker Brothers Corporation providing that, so long as consolidated earned surplus is less than $1,500,000, only one-half of the net earnings theretofore earned in any year after preferred dividends may be distributed to common stockholders or used to buy common stock, was adopted yesterday at a special meeting of stockholders in Baltimore.

Those who are anxious to: keep the realty boat on an even keel in a rising tide of sales and renting are sounding a new warning against the danger of excessive appraisalsa major factor in the mortgage problems growing out of the period of declining prices.

Spencer Tracy and Luise Rainer make their bow as a co-starring team at the Capitol this morning in "Big City," which Frank Borzage directed for Metro from an original story by Norman Krasna. Among the supporting players list Charles Grapewin, Janet Beecher, Eddie Quillan and Victor Varconi.

Robert Harriss, who was Queens campaign manager for Joseph V. McKee in the city election of 1933 and now is chairman of a Queens citizens committee, called for the nomination of Copeland, Prial and Levy last night in a radio address over station WERL in Woodside, Queens.
Dr. Wallace S. Sayre, an assistant Professor of Government at New York University, became secretary of the Municipal Civil Service Commission yesterday, succeeding Dr. William H. Allen.
The U. S. S. Nashville, a light cruiser and the third American naval vessel of that name, will be launched at 11:30 A. M. on Oct. 2 at the plant of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation here.

Dr. Robert F. Sheehan, former chief neuro-psychiatrist for the United States Bureau of War Risk, and at one time adviser to the United States Federal Vocational Board, will join the faculty of the Fordham University Department of Psychology next week, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Walter G. Summers, chairman of that department in the Fordham Graduate School.

After warning both sides in the threatened B. M. T. strike that he would tolerate no interruption of subway or bus service, Mayor La Guardia asked the company and the union yesterday to submit their differences to negotiation without delay.

The Polish Government through the League Commissioner to Danzig has made an energetic protest to the Danzig Senate against violation of Poland's rights in the Free City. Monday the Danzig Gestapo [secret police] ordered the arrest of Polish postmen and introduced censorship of Polish mails.

Wall Street and other centers of "great finance" are suffering from a serious deficiency in imagination, according to Charles F. Kettering, vice president of General Motors in charge of research and development, who sailed with his wife yesterday on the French liner Normandie.

A portrait of President Roosevelt by Arturo de Ferraris will be unveiled here tomorrow afternoon in the Hall of Springs at Saratoga Spa, the State-owned institution for treatment of chronic illnesses, where it will remain on permanent display.

A Japanese spokesman declared today that the first naval battle of the Sino-Japanese war occurred yesterday afternoon near Canton, when Japanese warships bombarded the Bocca Tigris forts. Two Chinese warships were put out of action, the spokesman added.

Mayor La Guardia was greeted with applause and showered with confetti and streamers last night by a crowd of about 400,000 persons lining Surf Avenue, as he led the police parade in an automobile on the second day of the Coney Island Mardi Gras.

The Board of Education decided tonight to open all high schools and junior colleges and all special schools tomorrow morning. The elementary schools, kept closed on the opening date, Sept. 7, as a measure to prevent the spread of infantile paralysis during the present outbreak, will remain closed.

East Side Chamber of Commerce, 1 Cherry Street, Franklin Square, noon. Constitution Week exercises. Speakers: Alvin F. Harlow, Dr. Richard T. Ely. Luncheon of the Rotary Club of New York, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. "Present Day Business Ethics," Joseph Mezo.
President Roosevelt's decision avoids, at least temporarily, the dilemma with which the Neutrality Act has confronted him since the outbreak of the Sino-Japanese conflict, more than two months ago.
Oliver Burke, for many years active in Brooklyn charitable and church organizations, died there on Tuesday at his home, 540 East Nineteenth Street, in his ninety-first year.

John Wellington Finch, director of the United States Bureau of Mines, urged today closer cooperation between mining organizations in his country and Canada to facilitate "purposeful planning of the future of the mineral industries."

The civil service status of former Mayor James J. Walker of New York will be considered by the State Civil Service Commission at a closed meeting Friday, it was announced today by Miss Grace A. Reavy, president of the commission.
Cherry St, 328, 4-story brick loft building, 24.3x99, Title Guarantee Trust Co, against Max Leibowitz; due, $10,944, taxes, etc, $441; to plaintiff for $9,000.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, leaving today for Southampton via Cherbourg, included Mrs. Paul G. Pennoyer, Mr. and Mrs. Elisha Walker Jr., Mr. and Mrs. James R. Doolittle, Commander John Allyne Gade, United States Naval Attache at Lisbon; Mrs. Dunlevy Milbank and Mrs. Grace Leeds.

The Hajada Realty Corporation has sold to a group of investors a vacant plot containing about 97,000 square feet in the block bounded by Queens Boulevard, Ninetieth Street, Fifty-seventh and Fiftyeighth Avenues, in Elmhurst, Queens.

Mr. and Mrs. James Rockwell Sheffield will come from Saranac Inn today to the Plaza. Rear Admiral Louis R. de Steiguer, U. S. N. (retired), and Mrs. de Steiguer have returned to the Vanderbilt from Newport. Mrs. Hugh D. Auchincloss has come from McLean, Va., to the Gotham.

The annual report of the Singer Manufacturing Company for 1936, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $15,137,713 after expenses, taxes and other deductions. This was equal to $16.82 a share on the 900,000 shares of $100 par capital stock.

The Council of Foreign Bondholders and the League Loans Committee, in a statement on the offer of the Greek Government to pay 40 per cent of the interest due in the current fiscal year, have reiterated that they could not recommend bondholders to accept the offer.

The White Sox said their 1937 farewells to the Red Sox today by pounding Bob (Lefty) Grove hard in the seventh inning to come from behind for a 5-3 victory. It gave the visitors a 12-10 edge for the season.

Yesterday's statement by Charles R. Gay cannot be considered a reply to James M. Landis's "good-bye interview" as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, any more than Mr. Landis's interview could be considered a genuine reply to Mr. Gay's annual report as president of the New York Stock Exchange.

Mrs. Josephine D. Neustadter, mother of Newton H. Neustadter, general partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Strassburger Co., died here in her home at the Hotel St. Francis early yesterday at the age of 80. Death was due to heart disease.

Bishop William T. Manning yesterday accused The Churchman, which is regarded as the organ of the liberal wing of the Protestant Episcopal Church, of violating the principles of "liberalism and fair journalism" in refusing to publish the bishop's letter on the activities of the Church League for Industrial Democracy.

Mrs. Martin G. Missir, medalist and winner of the crown for the past four years, led the way with an easy triumph as match play in the annual golf championship for women members of the Westchester Country Club began over the south course today.
BEER, DAVID (Oct. 2. 1936). Gross assets, $56,985; net, $54,784. To Alfred Beer, son. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $52,303. Arnold Lichtig and Herbert A. Mossler, attorneys, 521 5th Ave.
POPE PIUS XI AND WORLD AFFAIRS, by William Teeling. (Stokes, $2.50.) Published in England under the title, "The Pope in Politics."

Carelessness was cited as a cause of cross infection in hospital children's wards by Dr. Philip S. Barba and Dr. John C. Williams, both of the Germantown Hospital, Philadelphia, in a paper read before the thirty-ninth annual meeting of the American Hospital Association here today.

Moscow is somewhat disquieted by the growing frequency of reports that Italy and Japan are about to conclude an agreement similar to the GermanJapanese pact for "mutual protection against the Bolshevist danger."

Last night at sundown the blowing of the shofar, the ram's -horn, terminated for Jews throughout the world the ten days of penitence that began with the dawning of the year 5698 of the Jewish calendar on Sept. 5.

If there are people who still wonder if a Constitution 150 years old can be effective, they might go on to ask themselves if an embargo on trade with foreign nations can be effective. In our national history the embargo is very nearly as old an institution as the Federal charter.

All today's press comment confirms the first impression that yesterday's Italian note created, namely, that Italy is quite willing to give her adherence to the conclusions of the Nyon conference as soon as she is placed on a footing of absolute equality with Great Britain and France.

Mrs. Marion Stephens Hopper of Chappaqua, N. Y., wife of Franklin F. Hopper, head of the circulation department of the New York Public Library, died yesterday morning in St. Luke's Hospital at the age of 45.
Stocks closed irregular after recovering opening losses; turnover, 1,143,400 shares. United States Government bonds strong, other issues generally higher in quiet trading; transactions, $5,985,525.

Henry Armstrong, recognized by several governing bodies as the world's featherweight champion, will tackle Johnny De Foe of the West Side in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

The two-family dwelling at 744 Thirty-sixth Street, North Bergen, N. J., has been sold to Samuel Citron by John Duroska through J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker, who arranged a first mortgage loan on the property for the buyer.

Joseph A. Reilly of 2,366 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, former secretary of the New York State Racing Commission, who had been associated with horse racing in the East for many years, died on Tuesday night in the Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, at the age of 62.

The name of the Niagara Hudson Public Service Corporation, a unit of the Niagara Hudson System, was changed to the Central New York Power Corporation at a meeting of the stockholders held at the company offices here today.

Moving with an effortless precision that made it seem they had rehearsed every play they made, the Old Westbury poloists rode into the final round of the national open championship with a stunning triumph over Templeton today, 19 to 5.

Tied together like beads on a string, a party of scientists disappeared over the rim of Grand Canyon this afternoon to a saddle of land leading to Shiva Temple, towering "island in the sky," where a 300-acre plateau isolated from the mainland since the Ice Age is believed to preserve plant and animal life of prehistoric America.

Predicting that 1938 will be "a good year in the automobile business, if we keep right on working," William S. Knudsen, president of the General Motors Corporation, today pleaded for the freedom of American industry from the red tape advocated by politicians and the practices in vogue under European dictatorships.

David C. Lewis, Municipal Court justice in the Seventh district, has served for nearly ten years with an ability, integrity and independence that have won him general esteem in his district and among lawyers.

Administrative as well as spiritual matters commanded the attention of the annual convention, Eastern District, American Lutheran Church, at three sessions today. The 1938 budget was set at $6,500, and adopted. Nominations were made for officers to be elected tomorrow.

The circumstances attending the nomination and confirmation of Hugo L. Black of Alabama as a justice of the Supreme Court of the United States will bear repetition at this time. They construct a tale of political jockeying between the President and the Senate, of a contest in tactics in which all the winners seem to have lost.

The Canadian Department of National Revenue reported today that excise taxes jumped from $13,346,640 in August, 1936, to $16,427,336 last month, an increase of $3,080,696; customs duties from $6,142,829 to $8,108,732 and excise duties from $4,156,100 to $4,937,302.

Public opinion about American business is molded largely in the -newspapers, William A. Thomson, director of the bureau of advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, said today to the 500 delegates to the convention of the Financial Advertising Association which is in session here.

Thirty-one strong and in peak condition after four weeks of training, the New York Football Giants will leave at noon today for Washington, where tonight they will open their 1937 National Football League campaign against the transplanted Redskins in Griffith Stadium.

If, between dawn and darkness, you can find Somewhere, some secret loveliness to lie Cool on the heart: some attribute of sky, Hushing the vicious wheeling of the mind; Some attribute of earth-a willow frond, Lifted by wind; three snow-white birches bowed

The crews of the freighters Exchange and Excello, operated by the Export Steamship Corporation to the Black Sea and the west coast of Italy, respectively, refused yesterday to sign the ships' articles because of the company's refusal to pay "war zone" bonuses of $250 and insure each man for $25,000.

Miss Jean Phelan, daughter of Major Gen. John J. Phelan of this city and the late Mrs. Phelan, was married yesterday morning in Holy Trinity Church, Eighty - second Street and Broadway, to George Rohrs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Rohrs, also of New York, by the Rev. Robert Verdon.

The Yugoslav Government's hopes of coming to terms with the Croats were shattered tonight by the revelation that Serbs and Croats had formed a united Opposition front to win revision of the Constitution and the restoration of democratic institutions.
Hot, oppressive weather enveloped the coast from Portland, Ore., to the Mexican border today, breaking temperature records in some sections and causing at least two deaths and scores of prostrations.
Paintings by five well-known American artists have been acquired by the Toledo (Ohio) Museum of Art, as a part of a plan to strengthen its collection of work by contemporary painters.

The Boerse continued weak today, but transactions have been kept under such strict control that they have shrunk to the vanishing point. The list of issues traded is growing shorter daily, and even that list is dotted with innumerable blanks.

Directors of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation yesterday voted a special year-end dividend of 40 cents a share on the common stock. It is payable Sept. 25 to stock of record of Sept. 20. On Aug. 26, when a 40-cent quarterly dividend was declared, it was stated that consideration would be given to a yearend payment at this meeting.

Miss Helen H. Ashbrook, daughter of Mrs. Frank G. Tallman and of Donald S. Ashbrook of this city, was married to J. Taylor Woodward yesterday morning in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The Rev. Francis Craighill performed the ceremony.

The Angriff publishes some startling news from America today. The Nazi newspaper reports in a dispatch with a New York date line that American Masonic lodges are continuing to be active in their support of "Spanish Bolshevists"

The Paraguayan delegation to the Chaco peace conference has hastened on its own initiative to present excuses to the conference for the arrest of two neutral military observers by the Paraguayan patrol in the neutral zone last Friday and to promise that the incident would not be repeated.
