A communique issued this morning ascribed the crash of a plane of the Faucett Airlines last night, in which eight persons, including the pilot and one other American, were killed, to heavy fog over the coast. The plane hit the crest of a hill a few miles south of Lima.

The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that it had decided to accept as part of the record the plan of reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company offered as a substitute for the road's own plan a week ago by Arthur Garfield Hays, counsel for the independent bondholders reorganization committee for the New Haven.

Agents continued yesterday to expand the tenant rosters of apartment houses in all sections of the city. The approach of the traditional moving day spurred leasing activity as families prepared to occupy their new living quarters on or about Oct. 1.

Jouett Shouse, president of the American Liberty League, arrived last night on the United States liner Washington with Mrs. Shouse after a two-month tour of Europe. He said he had made a point of talking to as many "ordinary" people as he could find, and learned that the people of Europe were all eager to avoid war.
Prince Prospero Colonna, member of a family which has been prominent in Italy for 800 years, died today after a prolonged illness. He was 79 years old.

Mrs. Elizabeth Eaton Guggenheim, wife of Colonel M. Robert Guggenheim, youngest son of the late Daniel Guggenheim, philanthropist and mining executive, left here Sunday to obtain a divorce at Reno. She will charge general incompatibility, according to her attorney, William Hall of Bay Shore, L. I. A property settlement will be made out of court.

A charge that the city is being "exploited" through the payment of excessive amounts for school sites in Harlem was made yesterday by James Marshall, vice president of the Board of Education, at the first meeting of the new school term at the board headquarters, 500 Park Avenue.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended Sept. 4 totaled 310,417,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

With no contests for county and State offices in the Republican and Democratic primaries, interest in the Suffolk County balloting centered today in the Republican County Committee election in Huntington, where sympathizers of Supervisor Arthur J. Kreutzer started a write-in campaign against the regular designees.

Soviet Russia has succeeded to the extent that she has--and the successes in many fields are great indeed-because her present system as now administered, is the antithesis of communism, which is her ultimate ideal.

The "Blue" and the "Gray" moved to the Antietam fields tonight, pitching camp as they did seventy-five years ago on the eve of the "bloodiest battle of the Civil War." Coming from Pennsylvania, Maryland and the District of Columbia, the troops will re-enact the battle fought at Antietam Creek in 1862, where 22,000 died, 5,000 of them in "Bloody Lane."

Universal's young singing star, Deanna Durbin, will make her second appearance on the Roxy's screen this morning in "100 Men and a Girl." Her supporting company includes Leopold Stokowski, Adolph Menjou, Mischa Auer, Alice Brady and Eugene Pallette.... A

Canadian exports of motor vehicles and automotive parts during July amounted to $3,030,251, an increase of 15 per cent over June and 61 per cent as compared with July, 1936, the Department of Commerce announced today.

The air-conditioning project at the Capitol, the Senate Office Building and the House Office Building was tied up today by a strike of 100 steamfitters engaged in fitting the water pipes for the system.
Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Germany's Minister of Economics, arrived today for a brief vacation. He comes at a time when there are rumors in Berlin that he will resign.

Deserting the blank verse which has characterized most of his recent plays, Maxwell Anderson has written what he calls a modern comedy, "The Star-Wagon." It had its world premiere here tonight at the Erlanger Theatre with Burgess Meredith and Lillian Gish featured.

During the first seven months of this year France imported $98,440,000 worth of goods from the United States, an increase of $39,748,000, as compared with the corresponding period of 1936, the Department of Commerce announced today.

43d St, 308 W, 5-story brick tenement, 25x 100.11; Patrick J. Hayes, executor, against Irston Realty Co; due, $72,228; to plaintiff for $30,000. By RALPH W. LONG 2d Ave, 2,309-17, 6 5-story brick tenements and stores; Bowery Savings Bank against 1,930 Realty Corp; due, $59,874; taxes, etc., $2,000; to plaintiff for $45.000.
Developments in the few days since the conference at Nyon last week show that more may emerge from the negotiations than the formulation of measures to end "piracy" in the Mediterranean.

The Rev. R. Anderson Jardine, who performed the marriage ceremony of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor and who came here for a lecture tour after resigning his post as vicar of St. Paul's Church, Darlington, will sail for England on the United States liner American Merchant.
While the President awaits information from Justice Black as to whether he is, or ever was, a member of the Ku Klux Klan, Mr. Roosevelt is reported to be deeply perturbed. That is entirely natural.

Marking the first time that an industry has proposed that all fabric content be identified, producers of synthetic yarns yesterday presented and approved nine tentative fairtrade-practice rules intended as the basis for establishing principles and standards for identification and advertising of all textiles.

C. S. Howard's Coramine, fleet little 3-year-old daughter of Stimulus, today scored her first victory in seven starts this season. She triumphed by a length at Narragansett Park after a six-furlong battle with Mrs. E. A. Rotelli's Woof in the Hyde Park Purse.
W. van Hutschler and J. Weise of Hamburg, Germany, today took the second of the international Star Class championship contests on Long Island Sound.

Stephen Salter, one of the founders of the famous boat building firm of Salter Brothers, which constructed boats for the Oxford crews, died here yesterday at the age of 102. Sixty years ago he retired from business because of failing health, but outdoor life on the Isle of Wight enabled him to confute the doctors' predictions.

The undeclared war between China and Japan has caused a great Number of American exporters to cancel their advertising campaigns in the former country, H. N. Elterich, head of agency bearing his name, which specializes in foreign advertising, said here yesterday.

Impartial machinery for conciliation in industrial disputes was advocated by Assistant Secretary of Commerce Ernest G. Draper in an address here today before the thirtyfifth annual meeting of the National Petroleum Association.

The Public Service Commission authorized the Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation yesterday to issue up to $2,500,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds at 3 1/2 per cent interest, due in 1967. The bonds are to be sold at not less than 102 per cent of par and accrued interest to realize proceeds of not less than $2,550,000.

After five rounds of the international chess masters tournament, in which they were undefeated, a break finally came today in the successful march of Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, and Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia, and both were among the losers in the sixth round.
New York City, led by Mayor La Guardia, will join today with the nation in celebrating the signing at Philadelphia 150 years ago of the Constitution of the United States of America.

General Victor Beauregard, treasurer of the Confederation of French War Veterans, arrived last night on the United States liner Washington to represent his country for the third time as official commissioner to an American Legion convention.

One hundred and fifty years ago today the great charter of American democracy was adopted by a Constitutional Convention which sought to form "a more perfect union" out of the existing chaos of a young Republic.

Ion Swinley, stage, screen and radio actor, whose voice was said to have been one of the finest on the English stage, died suddenly at his home here today at the age of 45. Deep resonance and a natural beauty in diction won him many Shakespearean roles and at his death he was playing in the open-air production of "A Comedy of Errors."

Mrs. Louise A. Dreyfus, 80 years old, well-to-do Staten Island widow, philanthropist and friend of Mayor La Guardia, was challenged as a voter by election inspectors yesterday on the ground that she had recently moved and failed to enroll in her new election district.

Alarmed by underground activities of Leftist elements hostile to the Negrin Government, the Spanish Communist party issued an appeal for unity among all the anti-Fascist forces and demanded that dissidents be crushed.

New York City's primary election, the most bitterly contested in a generation, resulted yesterday in an overwhelming victory for Mayor La Guardia over Senator Royal S. Copeland, Tammany's candidate for both Republican and Democratic nominations, an equally overwhelming defeat for the Senator by Jeremiah T. Mahoney for the Democratic nomination and a surprisingly good write-in vote for the Mayor in the Democratic primary.
Showing the form that enabled him to win fifteen games last year, Harry Kelley pitched and batted the Athletics to a 4-to-3 victory over the St. Louis Browns today.

While trading in men's wear fabrics was virtually at a standstill in the wool goods markets this week, indications are that a number of manufacturers will start showing lines for the Spring season next week, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

Sharply higher prices for hogs and increased quotations for several other items lifted the Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to 94.7 on Tuesday from 93.9 (revised) the Tuesday previous.
It is the firm belief of our neighbor The Post that Justice Black should resign from the Supreme Court,

The stock markets here were generally quiet and steady today, while some sections were slightly better. Giltedge issues were inactive but firm. Among the foreign loans, Far Eastern bonds were uncertain. International shares drooped and, despite late support, closed lower.

Primary returns indicated tonight that County Republican Chairman Edwin F. Jaeckle and Tom Holling, an independent Democrat, would be the opposing candidates for Mayor of Buffalo at the November election.

Five hundred doctors of forty different nationalities gathered here today at France's leading spa for a three-day congress devoted to the study of liver complaints. The United States delegation, comprising more than fifty medical specialists, was headed by Dr. Anthony Bassler of New York.

" Stepping up your advertising results means studying your product, then presenting that information pleasantly, informatively, intelligently and dramatically from the customer's point of view," Arthur H. Brayton, personnel manager of Marshall Field Co., Chicago, said tonight to the 500 delegates to the twenty-second annual convention of the Financial Advertisers Association in the course of the principal address at a dinner here.
It was not necessary last night to peruse the primary returns to determine how Tammany Hall was faring. There was a depressed air over the hall that had not been apparent in past years.
Rapid Japanese advances in sweeping North China campaigns were outstanding developments today as the conflict continued savagely over most of the 2,000-mile Chinese war front.
Spain's civil war raged with revived ferocity on many fronts today as the contending armies strove to establish new gains before cold weather sets in.

In the first seven months of this year the Ludlum Steel Company made $1,032,139 after all charges, including depreciation, normal Federal income taxes, but exclusive of allowances for any surtax on undistributed income.' The net profit is equivalent to $2.07 a share on 497,600 shares of outstanding common stock.

The first large football crowd of the 1937 season has already gathered in this section. On Sept. 1, in Chicago, the 1936 college All-Stars met the champions of the National Football League before a crowd of 85,000 rabid football fans.

Miss Frances Earle Patterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Patterson of Haverford, and Miss Ann Mather, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Mather of Ardmore, were introduced this afternoon at a tea given by their grandmother, Mrs. George Howard Earle Jr., and their parents at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Patterson.
In the Commonwealth of Australia three years is the maximum life of the House of Representatives. The Fourteenth Federal Parliament began business on Oct. 23, 1934.

Jeremiah Titus Mahoney, native New Yorker, the son of Jeremiah Mahoney, a policeman, who hailed from County Cork, and Marel Ellen Harronk Mahoney, who was born in County Donegal, Ireland, was born almost under the shadow of Brooklyn Bridge, on the East Side, June 23. 1875.

Despite bitterly waged contests to displace them, the present Republican leaders in Yonkers, Mount Vernon and White Plains will retain their control over local political machines as a result of today's primary election, according to unofficial returns here tonight.

Excused The following firemen shall be excused for one day, Saturday, Sept. 18, and shall be directed to report to Fireman Harry F. Guerin, at Station WNYC, Municipal Building, Manhattan, at 10 A. M. on that date:

The directors of Pacific American Fisheries, Inc., have adopted a resolution proposing the authorized creation of 100,000 shares of 5. per cent convertible cumulative $100-par preferred stock, to be issued at such times and in such amounts as they deem advisable.

The discovery of an isolated Jewish community in the Near East which is still using Aramaic, the language of the Talmud, with Hebrew script, was revealed here yesterday by Dr. Walter J. Fischel, Research Professor of Islam History at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.
A portrait of President Roosevelt, the gift of George Foster Peabody, was unveiled at the Hall of Springs of the Spa this afternoon by Marjorie Peabody Waite, daughter of the donor.

Captain James S. Taylor, vice president of the Newark and New York Towboat Company; died today at his home here after a two-year ill-ness. His age was 70. Born in Newark, he navigated his father's steam yacht in his youth with two late brothers, Norris and Charles K. Taylor.
Dominion Grattan's straight-heat victory in the free-for-all pace featured the third card of grand circuit racing at the Reading Fair today.

Four Coast Guard cutters plowed the Atlantic Ocean off Nantucket tonight searching for the British racing sloop Endeavour, believed in danger after a gale parted the towline which joined her to the convoy yacht Viva II.

Philippine sugar and tobacco producers today told the joint preparatory committee that free trade with the United States in the volume provided by the Independence Act should be continued indefinitely.
Speculators who contracted to deliver corn this month on the Board of Trade here face heavy losses and possible expulsion from the Exchange because of inability to make good on their contracts.

Transfers and Assignments SERGEANT Raymond T. Weiss, from 108th Precinct to Borough Headquarters Squad, Manhattan, for duty with Midtown Squad. PATROLMEN - Lawrence L. Hammer, from 48th Precinct to Borough Headquarters Squad, Manhattan, for duty with Midtown Squad.

Merger of the two largest companies in the United States dealing in special shingles and stained shingles, the Creo-Dipt Company of North Tonawanda and the Weatherbest Company of North Tonawanda, was announced here today by H. P. Kendall, president and general manager of the Creo-Dipt Company.

Representative John J. O'Connor of New York, chairman of the House Rules Committee, is canvassing members of Congress on their "attitude on possible impeachment proceedings against Supreme Court Justice Hugo L. Black" because of his alleged membership in the Ku Klux Klan, according to a statement yesterday by Representative Edward L. O'Neill of New Jersey.
The flag of Delaware, first State to ratify the Constitution, was presented today to the Constitution Sesquicentennial Commission. in a formal ceremony on the steps of the Capitol.

The strong hints that Virginio Gayda threw out yesterday that Italo-British friendship may be impaired unless Italy is admitted to the Nyon agreement on a footing of equality are followed today by a strongly worded attack against Foreign

Captain Robert A. (Bob) Bartlett, Arctic explorer and author, arrived last night in New York Harbor in his Gloucester fishing schooner, the Effie M. Morrissey, from his eleventh Summer trip to the Arctic regions with two passengers, who were glowing testimonials to sailing in the Far North as a health measure.

The Council of the League of Nations decided at a private session today to refer the Chinese appeal against Japan to the Far Eastern Advisory Committee set up in 1933, in which the United States Government accepted nonvoting membership.

Now that the anti-piracy patrol has begun its work the British are curious and just a little anxious to know what its diplomatic consequences may be. About the success of the naval patrol they have no doubt whatever.

Arturo Toscanini, who resigned as director of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last year, will return to this country about Dec. 15 to conduct the NBC Symphony Orchestra in a series of ten radio concerts, opening on Christmas night, it was announced yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company.
Movements of naval vessels follow: Tangier Sound to Washington Yard, Sept. 16: Decatur, Dickerson, Sept. 15. At Callao, Peru: Bull, Ranger, Worden, Sept. 15.

The musical comedy "Going Greek," which opened at the Gaiety Theatre tonight is in the tradition of that house's offerings, inheriting most of the players and even much material of previous Gaiety hits.

The marriage of Miss Helen Elizabeth Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton S. Brown, to William E. U. Udal, only son of Mr. and Mrs. William Udal of Weymouth, Dorset, England, took place here this afternoon at the home of her parents.

Despite vigorous efforts by Mayor La Guardia, Arthur S. Meyer of the State Mediation Board and other would-be conciliators, the prospect of an early strike of members of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, employed on the rapid transit, street car and bus lines of the B. M. T. was apparently stronger than ever last night.
Truman H. Newberry, former Secretary of the Navy, and Mrs. Newberry are returning today from Watch Hill, R. I., and will be at the Plaza until they leave for Detroit.
Ninety Scandinavian seamen visited Washington today and sent representatives to call on members of the Maritime Commission, the Labor Department and the State Department.

The Nyon conference technicians are understood to have made such progress on the problem of protection against surface and air attacks that the conference may be called to meet tomorrow in Geneva to adopt these measures.

At the close of 1936 there were 77,494 acres of State and interstate parks in the metropolitan district, compared with 55,238 acres at the close of 1928, according to an announcement yesterday by the Regional Plan Association. The association said that in the same eight-year period county parks increased in acreage in the district from 24,121 to 26,127.

The purpose of yesterday's primary in this city was to designate officially the candidates of the two major parties, but the result of the primary will not shape the issue of the campaign which now begins.

Engineering construction awards reported in the week ended yesterday totaled $47,347,000, which was a drop of 16 per cent from the figure for the corresponding week of 1936, $56,382,000, according to The Engineering News-Record.

The formal opening of the conservatory gardens in Central Park at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, which will mark the maturing of plans formulated eighty years ago, will take place today at 12:30 P. M. Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Dr. John H. Finley will make speeches welcoming the public to enjoy the gardens.

The recent collapse of the French franc in the foreign exchange markets has wiped out half of the value of that currency since its former parity of 6.63 cents was abandoned a year ago. In terms of gold the franc is now worth about one-tenth of its old pre-war parity of 20 cents.

The marriage of Miss Helen Elizabeth Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton S. Brown, to William E. U. Udal, only son of Mr. and Mrs. William Udal of Weymouth, Dorset, England, took place here this afternoon at the home of her parents.

Despite vigorous efforts by Mayor La Guardia, Arthur S. Meyer of the State Mediation Board and other would-be conciliators, the prospect of an early strike of members of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, employed on the rapid transit, street car and bus lines of the B. M. T. was apparently stronger than ever last night.
Truman H. Newberry, former Secretary of the Navy, and Mrs. Newberry are returning today from Watch Hill, R. I., and will be at the Plaza until they leave for Detroit.
Ninety Scandinavian seamen visited Washington today and sent representatives to call on members of the Maritime Commission, the Labor Department and the State Department.

" The Dead March," latest in a long line of anti-war pictures, will have its first local showing today at the Broadway Theatre. The film is in the main a compilation of actual war scenes from the archives of various nations and has a musical score by Erno Rapee.

A mass commemorating the nineteenth anniversary of the death of Cardinal Farley was held yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Mgr. Lavelle, rector of the cathedral and vicar general of the archdiocese, was the preacher.

There is every reason to welcome the results of Thursday's primary in this city. Mayor La Guardia has won his nomination by a smashing majority, and the enrolled Republicans who gave it to him wisely chose to enlist their party in the service of good government in New York, instead of throwing their votes away in an entirely futile gesture aimed at Washington.
Ab Jenkins, king of speed endurance drivers, ended a twenty-four-hour stock car run on the salt beds tonight to capture twenty-five American unlimited records and twenty-five American Class C marks.
The first postoffice resembling a bank will be opened Monday by Postmaster Albert Goldman in the new Government-owned building at 149-53 East Twenty-third Street, it was announced yesterday.

Miss Catherine Merriam Atwater, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Atwater of Plandome, was married here tonight in the Reformed Church of North Hempstead to John Kenneth Galbraith, son of W. A. Galbraith of Iona, Ont., by the pastor, the Rev. Oscar Maddaus.

Expansion in trade movements this week was extended beyond the usual Fall proportions, with the vigorous demand for merchandise building up the largest volume thus far this year at some retail stores, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Edwin Schoonmaker, lecturer and writer, was- seriously injured late this afternoon when his car hit a tree after a blowout. His skull, right arm, left leg and left kneecap were fractured and there are also possible internal injuries.
Chester C. Jennings of Baltimore was elected today president of the National Association of Mutual Insurance Agents at the closing session of the sixth annual convention of the organization here.

Plans for the forty-fourth annual meeting of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, to be held at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., Oct. 20 to 22, were announced yesterday by Andrew Mills Jr., president of the association, who is also president of the Dry Dock Savings Institution.

Royal S. Copeland, defeated in his attempt to win both Democratic and Republican nominations for Mayor, pledged his support yesterday to Jeremiah T. Mahoney, his victorious rival in the Democratic party, but spoke freely of the plight of conservative voters in the city and predicted a realignment of political parties.

Md., Sept. 17.--Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address today: The passage of time has a strange effect on all great crises, especially on those which have occurred in comparatively recent years.

The Bankers Trust Company sold to Isadore Koletsky for investment the building at 75-54 Jamaica Avenue, Woodhaven, Queens. The deal was arranged by King King, Ino., for all cash over a first mortgage.

The engagement of Miss Dorothy Sarnoff, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Sarnoff of Brooklyn, to Dr. Shepard G. Aronson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Aronson, also of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents.
The League of Nations Council, in an extremely guarded resolution, yesterday gave Great Britain the authorization she asked to continue studying a Palestine solution based on the partition principle.

After a period in which few registration statements for large issues of securities had been filed under the Securities Act of 1933, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today five filings aggregating $69,790,000.

Motors were tuned and practice runs made in the rain today as 109 of America's outstanding pilots made final preparations for the three-day national outboard championships opening on the mud-laden James River tomorrow.

" American Legion Sunday" will be observed tomorrow in virtually every church in the city. All faiths have announced that the doors of their edifices would be "wide open" to the World War veterans who will be here attending the national convention of the Legion next week.
Mayor La Guardia seems to have taken the beat course possible in his efforts to prevent the threatened strike on the B. M. T. Following the general

Anthony H. Raymond Doll, popular song writer and pianist, known professionally as Ray Doll, died on Wednesday at the Holy Family Hospital, Brooklyn, after an illness of three weeks. Mr. Doll, who lived at 739 Kelly Street, the Bronx, was 35 years old and a native of Jersey City.

Lady Cynthia Asquith, daughter-in law of the Countess of Oxford and Asquith, will receive [Pound]30,000 and half of the residue of the estate of Sir James Barrie, famed British author, who died on June 19, it became known here today. Lady Cynthia was his secretary.

Calling for a broad interpretation of the Constitution to meet changing economic and social conditions, Secretary Wallace said in a radio address tonight that the Supreme Court had been often influenced by "its own economic predilections"

Anxious eyes on the bridges of a dozen vessels tonight scanned the North Atlantic in a constantly widening search for the big British racing sloop Endeavour, which was parted from its convoy in a gale late Monday night.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

American business must make up its mind whether it favors regulation by competition as contemplated in anti-trust laws, or "the only probable alternative - government control," Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General, declared yesterday before some 390 trade association executives at a luncheon sponsored jointly by the Trade and Commerce Bar Association and the Trade Association Executives in New York City.
The Rev. Dr. Roy George Catlin, since 1931 president of the Illinois Synod of the United Lutheran Church in America, died yesterday after a brief illness at Maywood, III., at the age of 53.

President Roosevelt declared tonight in an address on the Constitution his intention to press forward with his program of social, political and economic reforms and left no doubt in his auditors' minds of his purpose to fight on for a reorganization of the Supreme Court.

With Greentree and Old Westbury awaiting their meeting in the national open championship final tomorrow, Templeton and Aurora start the last of the polo season's major events today with the first game of the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup tournament.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 16 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:
The bond market lost much of its recent enthusiasm yesterday as prices fluctuated irregularly in most sections on a sharply reduced

The program for Premier Benito Mussolini's forthcoming visit here has been decided in all its details. He will arrive by air on the morning of Sept. 25, leaving the same night to attend manoeuvres. His brief stay here will be fully occupied in seeing the "sights" of the Nazi movement and attending parades of various Nazi organizations in which the "old fighters"-the survivors of the 1923 putsch-will have the place of honor.

Judge Curtis Bok today ordered a grandjury investigation into the existence of vice and crime in Philadelphia, coupling his order with a warning against efforts to use the inquiry for political purposes.

Further stiffening their position, the nine Nyon signatories extended the Mediterranean anti-submarine agreement here tonight to cover attacks on any non-Spanish shipping by surface vessels and aircraft. The agreement outlaws all aircraft attacking merchantmen.

Assemblyman Phelps Phelps ofthe Third district made public yesterday a letter he has sent to Langdon Post, chairman of the New. York City Housing Authority,, emphasizing the need for a Federal housing project in the West Side of the city below Seventieth Street.

Slammin Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., ignored a cold and heavy wind today to blast out a parshattering 68 and gain a two-stroke edge over the field at the end of the first round f the thirty-seventh annual Western open golf championship.

Lou Fette, one of Boston's two outstanding rookie pitchers, tried hard for his eighteenth victory today but ran into Johnny Mize's home run in the eighth and St. Louis won, 2 to 0. The 30-year-old recruit gave four bases on balls, one of them to Jimmy Brown just before Mize lifted the ball onto the roof of the right field pavilion for his twentysecond homer of the season.

David Werbelowsky, president and founder of the Hebrew Publishing Company and a leader in Jewish communal activities, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 50 Plaza Street, Brooklyn. He was 59 years old.

Fiftyseven golfers braved the rain and cold to take part in the New Jersey women's one-day tournament over the Arcola course today. Five players broke 90, with Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches leading the field with a score of 41, 41-82. That rising young star from Montclair, Miss Marion Bradshaw, shot 41, 42--83.

The draft of a bill to "legalize" the appointment of Supreme Court justices filling vacancies created by retirement of members of the court under provisions or the Sumners act, and the enactment of which automatically would have prevented the appointment of Associate Justice Hugo L. Black, was prepared during the last session of Congress by Senator Borah of Idaho, it was disclosed today.

A scientist toiled down the precipitous walls of Shiva Temple today with two tiny leaf-eared mice which may prove the key to present-day life on the "lost forest," believed isolated from changes of the earth since the Ice Age.

Fred H. Bogert has sold a tract of thirty acres of wooded land in Ridgewood, N. J., to Village Builders, Inc., of Ridgewood. The purchasers plan to divide the property into one-acre plots and improve them with a number of Colonialtype dwellings. Realty Exchange of Ridgewood was the broker.
Susan Hillman Bacon, widow of George A. Bacon, publisher, died today at her home in Bolton in her ninety-first year. She was born in Northampton and attended Nichols Academy at Dudley.

Large quantities of an opium derivative, either morphine or heroin, caused the death on Tuesday of Miss Mary Brown Warburton, granddaughter of John Wanamaker, at her home at 277 Park Avenue, according to a report filed yesterday with the Chief Medical Examiner by the office of the city toxicologist.

There are many signs that Russia feverishly is hastening the erection of fortifications along the Estonian frontier and the fortified zone stretching from Estonia to the Black Sea is nearing completion.

The Rhode Island Racing Commission tonight suspended the license of the Narragansett Racing Association, effective at 7 P. M. tomorrow, and ordered the removal of the race track director, Walter E. O'Hara.

Ritchie Imports, Inc,-Imported sportswear, in 735 Madison Ave; Pease Eliiman, Inc, broker. Steve Salmieri. barber. store in 693-7 Broadway; Manhattan Nut Co, floor in 457-9 Broome St; M. L. Hess, Inc, broker. Charles Conway, store and basement, in 307 W 47th St; Haggstrom-Callen-Davis Co, Inc, broker. J. K. Hill, grocer, store in 4,950 Broadway; Ernest T. Bower, broker.

The New York Shipping Association, representing seventy ship lines operating in the deep-water trades out of this port, rejected yesterday the demand of the International Longshoremen's Association for a new contract that would include higher wages and a shorter working week.

To those who understand it, the Constitution presents a mirror on which the panorama of America is etched. The Constitution is so closely knit with our economic development that a proper perspective is unattainable without an understanding of the basic factors that make up our economic life.

" Free America is not ready for obituary yet," Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg declared in a speech which won an ovation at a gathering here today, celebrating the anniversary of the signing of the Constitution.

Joseph Fybush, a real estate operator with an office at 134 West Thirty-second Street, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home, 137-04 Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Belle Harbor, Queens, after an illness of several months. His age was 67.
A baseball double-header today will feature the program of "American Legion Day." The games will be played at the Polo Grounds for the benefit of the House of Calvary Hospital.

Joseph A. Doto, 35 years old, of 103 Eighty-first Street, Brooklyn, better known as Joe Adonis, described by police as Brooklyn's leading racketeer, was freed of a charge of assault and robbery by Magistrate Troy in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday, when the complainant failed to identify him.

Miss Helen Macfadden, eldest daughter of Bernarr Macfadden, the publisher, was married yesterday morning at the home of her father, 1,136 Fifth Avenue, to Joseph P. Wiegers, son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Wiegers of Woodlawn. Judge Lester W. Patterson of the Bronx County Court performed the ceremony in the presence of a few relatives and friends of the couple.

The Rev. Dr. Christopher J. McCombe will preach his first sermon as pastor of St. Paul's Methodist Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, on Oct. 10. He comes to the pastorate from the Methodist Church of Our Saviour, Cleveland, where he has served for eleven years.

The marriage of Miss Betty Buechner, daughter of Mrs. C. Fred Buechner of 940 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Buechner, to Morgan Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. George David Baker, also of this city, took place last night at the SherryNetherland. The Rev. Everett Moore Baker of Boston, brother of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

Senator Carter Glass issued a terse statement today relative to charges that Hugo L. Black is a member of the Ku Klux Klan. "My vote against the confirmation of Senator Black for the Supreme Court," Senator Glass said, "reflects then and now my judgment of the utter unfitness of his nomination, regardless of the Ku Klux Klan charges.

" Extra-curricular" activities of the Park Department, such as a $9,000 outlay for the American Legion parade next Tuesday, are partly responsible for the estimated increase of $4,065,769 in the department's 1938 budget, Assistant Budget Director Kenneth Dayton was informed yesterday.
A group of government trade analysts noted today a slackening of general business activity in recent weeks and said the Fall outlook was uncertain.

The will of Municipal Court Justice Joseph S. Rosalsky, filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday, named his widow, Mrs. Laura V. Rosalsky, as executrix and sole beneficiary of his estate, which was formally valued in the petition for probate at "more than $10,000."

Just before President Roosevelt made his fighting speech on the Constitution and the Supreme Court tonight, the White House announced that he would leave Wednesday afternoon for a swing through the West and Northwest.

President Oscar R. Benavides opened the Inter-American Aviation Conference in the Town Hall here last night. He said the task before the conference was to formulate an aviation code for the Americas that would meet the demand for this rapidly expanding means of communication and would at the same time safeguard the sovereignty of American republics.

A New York wine importer and hotel owner was kidnapped by a masked thug from the sleeping porch of his Dutchess County resort hotel two weeks ago and held a prisoner in a tomb in dense woods in a $20,000 ransom plan for which preparations had taken more than a year, it became known last night.
Secretary Ickes injected the President's Supreme Court reorganization fight today into a speech praising the founders of the Constitution, but calling the Supreme Court a "super-government."

Secretary Wallace increased today the 1937 sugar quotas for the mainland sugar cane area, Cuba, Hawaii, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands by dividing among them 216,352 tons originally assigned to the mainland sugar beet sections.

Morrison Shafroth, chief counsel, and Russell J. Ryan, his assistant, have resigned from the Internal Revenue Bureau. In a brief statement they declare that they were unable to convince themselves "that it was proper to use the Bureau of Internal Revenue as planned in the tax avoidance and evasion investigation.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "At the lower levels of prices, which have slowly been crystallizing on the finer wools in particular, there has been a little business done.

A Chinese and an American flag were presented yesterday to F. J. H. Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, in his eighteenth floor office in the Municipal Building by two Chinese-American children in appreciation of his aid in providing a recreation center in Manhattan's Chinatown.

The Tiger is starting from scratch this year. The sleek, powerful jungle cat that they were all gunning for from 1933 on is no more and in its place roams a young cub that doesn't know its own strength yet but which may show a sharp set of claws by November.

Mrs. Julius Helbing of Athens, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Luise Helbing, to the Rev. Dr. Alfred B. Moldenke, pastor of St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, this city.

Miss Barbara Brewer was married today to Charles Russell Lowell Sturgis of Milton at St. John's Episcopal Church. The Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Episcopal Bishop of Massachusetts, officiated. Miss Elsie C. Brewer was maid of honor for her sister and Howard O. Sturgis, brother of the bridegroom, was best man. John Roosevelt, son of the President,

Senator Burton K. Wheeler decried the fascist dictatorships of Europe tonight in urging Americans to guard against "one-man" government. He told a Constitution Day audience at the Chicago Stadium in a prepared address:

Documents purporting to prove the existence of a revolutionary plot against the United States were introduced today in the trial of eleven Puerto Rican Nationalists for the murder of a native policeman last March in a political riot.

Charles S. Dodson, 49 years old, of 149 East Fortieth Street, sales manager for the Angostura-Wuppermann Corporation, 70 Pine Street, manufacturers of bitters, died in Bellevue Hospital at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon of a skull fracture received when he was struck

Edward B. Schofield, for sixty-five years a druggist in Greenwich, died today at the Greenwich Hospital at the age of 80. He was the oldest member of the Connecticut Pharmaceutical Association, of the Amogerone Fire Company and of Acacia Lodge. 85. A. F. and A. M.

Despite the wretched weather, which was hardly conducive to good golf, the first annual invitation member-guest best-ball handicap tournament at the Tamarack Country Club got off to a flying start today, with sixty-four combinations seeking top honors.

Tammany Hall, beaten in the mayoralty primary contest, and with three of its district leaders unseated in favor of insurgents, was prepared yesterday to back to the limit the mayoralty candidacy of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, to salvage what it can from the present situation.

One needs only to scan the list of major intersectional games to be convinced that the college elevens of Dixie feel able now to take care of themselves in competition with those from any other part of the map.

Rushing across six runs before a man was out in the first inning, a revamped Cub team went on to defeat the Phillies, 10 to 2, today and remain three and one-half games behind the league-leading Giants, who won at Cincinnati. Larry French held the Phils to five hits and recorded his fourteenth victory of the season, his third in succession.

Miss Florence Taylor Sisson, daughter of former School Board President Harry Rowley Sisson and Mrs. Sisson of 313 North Union Avenue, was married to George Francis Richards, son of Mrs. F. St. John Richards and the late Mr. Richards, tonight in the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. William R. Sloan.

More than 1,000 students and teachers of secondary schools in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut gathered in the Town Hall yesterday afternoon to hear United States Senator Bennett Champ Clark of Missouri and other speakers warn against any weakening of constitutional guarantees of essential liberties.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 11 amounted to 711,299 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 93,334 cars,

Rainland, one of the year's busiest campaigners, made good at the first asking in Maryland today when he won the $2,500 added Susquehanna Handicap, opening-day feature. He paid $7.10 for $2 and ran the six furlongs in 1:12 3-5. Answering the urging of Jockey C. Parke, the Shandon Farm's star bounded through the stretch to draw clear of A. G. Vanderbilt's Speed to Spare and score by a length and a half.

Net income of the El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on July 31 was $1,535,463 after Federal income taxes, interest, amortization and provision for retirements and after non-recurring debit of $3,493, according to a statement issued yesterday.

Louis E. Stoddard's Blackcock, winner of the event last-year, and Mrs. James Cox Brady's Crooning Water are expected to fight it out at the finish for the Piping Rock Handicap Steeplechase, feature of the card of five races at the Autumn meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association at Cedarhurst, L. I., today.

China protested to the United States today the partial embargo imposed by President Roosevelt on the shipment of arms, ammunition and implements of war to China and Japan as unfair to China and favorable to Japan.
The deficiency judgment, employed by some lenders when foreclosing a mortgage in order to exact additional payments from the distressed property owner, is no longer the bugaboo it once seemed to be.

Mayor La Guardia told an audience of several thousand who stood in the drizzling rain yesterday at the Eternal Light, where one of the city's many observances of Constitution Day was held, that "we, the inhabitants of New York City, say less about the Constitution and do more for it than any other group of citizens in the country."

Mayor La Guardia, speaking late yesterday afternoon at the dedication of a children's playground at the Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception, 754 Gun Hill Road, in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx, declared that he would like to do much more in the way of providing playgrounds if politicians would let him, and assailed the custodial system in the public schools whereby "janitors can charge for overtime for the use of city property."

Joseph A.C. Avenol, Secretary-General of the League of Nations, formally notifified Leland Harrision, United States Minister to Switzerland, today that the advisory committee on China would meet Monday evening after the Assembly's election of three Council members if there was still time, and otherwise on Tuesday.

Pressing relentlessly onward, with motors humming a pleasing tune, the Giants swept into this metropolis today, sidewiped the Reds, and when the last was seen of either party, affairs were still moving as they had been these last few days.
Garret Sanderson is in the executive department of the midtown division of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, at Madison Avenue and Forty-first Street.

With the end of the account at hand, the stock market ruled quiet but steady today. No special movements were apparent among the gilt-edge issues other than an advance among the German obligations. Prime home investments were firm.
Junior varsity football will be re-established at Rutgers University this season after a two-year lapse, with Tom Kenneally, former assistant coach of the varsity, serving as mentor.

The Bureau of the Budget is at work on a supplemental budget estimate which probably will be made public about the end of this month. It is reported that, as a result of additional burdens placed on the Treasury by Congress in the last

The new International Casino, which has stood there on Broadway, poised, these many weeks, finally took the plunge last evening, despite a last-minute clutch of adversity which sought to upset its drive.

George G. Ruppersberger, founder of one of the oldest and largest meat packing houses here, died at his home last night at the age of 70. Entering the meat packing business here in 1889, Mr. Ruppersberger was active in the affairs of George G. Ruppersberger Sons until his retirement.

Officials of the city's law department took issue yesterday with the contention of James Marshall, vice president of the Board of Education, that the city is being "exploited" through payment of excessive amounts for Harlem school sites acquired through condemnation.
It is unusually interesting to observe the large number of Holy Cross College athletes who have jumped from the campus right into the big time, especially in major league baseball.
The Treasury probably will continue indefinitely to pay domestic producers of silver a bounty for their output, Administration officials said today.

The State Division of Licenses in the State Building discontinued its action yesterday against the Postal Telegraph Company on charges that it operated theatre-ticket agencies in violation of State regulations.

Newark's "wonder team" reached the International League's play-off finals tonight by beating the Chiefs, 3 to 1, for a sweep of the four-game semi-final series. Behind five-hit pitching by Phil Russo, a rookie from Long Island,

Slowly but surely the angler is beginning to put away his tackle and look to his guns, for September is now on the ebb and mornings are growing brisker, with something in the air that says the flights will soon be on.
Spanish Insurgent troops and artillery battered a wide breach today in Government lines south of Gijon, the last Governmet stronghold on the northeastern Spanish coast.
New Jersey observed the sesquicentennial anniversary of the signing of the United States Constitution with an official celebration here tonight in McCarter Theatre.

Verne, Wells, Conan Doyle-how many writers have not written of a lost world, a place isolated by geological forces, a place where life moves on in forgotten ways, its representatives theoretically extinct?

The figure of Abraham Lincoln, third in a "Shrine of Democracy" hewn from the granite face of Mount Rushmore, was dedicated today before 5,000 spectators. Senator Edward R. Burke, Democrat, of Nebraska, a leader in the Senate fight against President Roosevelt's court reorganization bill, challenged the administration's right to deviate, as he said, from the limitations of the Constitution, and warned against a centralization of power.
The Six-Meter series came to an end today with Briggs Cunningham sailing Fun to her third victory in four races. Fun is owned by Fred T. Bedford.

The premiere last night at Leicester Square Theatre of the film "Victoria the Great" provoked general enthusiasm among British critics today. The British picture, made at Denham, won the "Cup of All Nations" when recently shown at the international film exposition at Vienna.

A recess granted by S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, to local election boards in upper Manhattan districts caused acrimony yesterday at a meeting of the city-wide election body as its clerks were starting the official canvass of the primary vote that must be completed within five days of the primary.
Joe Mitchell, 190-pound sophomore end from Bellaire, Ohio, was designated understudy to Manhattan's . star kicker, Ed Kringle, after a punting drill at Innisfail Park yesterday.
Glenn Cunningham, the master miler, will take a whirl at the twomile distance this afternoon in the Fall track and field games of the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island.

A bill reorganizing Cuba's agricultural schools and placing this branch of national education under the control of the civic military school authorities was approved this afternoon by the House of Representaties.
British naval sources reported today sighting two submarines fifty miles from this British island naval base, both flying Insurgent Spanish colors and both escorted by Italian and German destroyers.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to only $11,073,517, to be represented by sixty-six municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $27,208,000 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $26,762,227.

The Rev. Dr. Lewis Nichols, since 1934 a member of the staff of Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street, died last night at 9:30 o'clock of a heart attack at his home in the Trinity Clergy House, 29 Munroe Place, Brooklyn. He was in his sixty-ninth' year.

Governor Wilbur L. Cross called upon the people today to preserve the Federal Constitution which, he said, embodies "those fundamental laws under which we and our ancestors have long lived and thrived."

A decrease of 13,808 workers on the rolls of the Works Progress Administration from the previous week was reported today by Administrator Hopkins for the week ended Sept. 4, when 1,468,899 persons were recorded.

Spokesmen of three maritime unions demanded yesterday that Senator Royal S. Copeland resign as chairman of the Senate Committee on Commerce, in the light of his defeat in the primary contest for the Mayoralty. The primary returns,

United action of business and industry to defeat the Black-Connery bill, which would set up a permanent board of five men to fix wages and hours for labor in all industry, was urged today by Charles C. Sheppard, president of the Louisiana Central Lumber Company, and former president of the National Lumber Manufacturers' Association.

Striking hard in the second and final periods, the West Chester Teachers opened their football season with a 19-0 victory over Pennsylvania Military College at Wayne Field tonight before 8,000 spectators.

The United States cannot do less than accept the invitation of the League of Nations to continue to participate in its Far Eastern Advisory Committee, to which the Council has just referred the Chinese charges against Janan.

Hopelessly outclassed through five innings, the Baltimore Orioles came back in the late frames tonight to trounce the Montreal Royals, 9 to 6, in the second game of their International League semi-final play-off and even the four-in-seven series at one game each.

Magistrate Frank Oliver received a communication in the Tombs Court yesterday from Henry Dodge of counsel for the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey denying that when nineteen alien seamen were arraigned before the magistrate last Tuesday on disorderly conduct charges, lodged by the captain of the motor ship Norbris, the complainant had been represented by counsel for the company.

The board of governors of the Commodity Exchange, Inc., yesterday suspended Albert R. Simon from all rights and privileges as a member of the Exchange for a period of three trading days, beginning yesterday, for violation of the general trading rule 504, subdivisions C, D and F.

He shuffles restless feet, and with his pen Traces his lines across a crumpled page. But naught is here to tell the wand'rer when The fox will hide, the spider leave her cage To dusty petals; and he seeks in vain Some lore of meadowland he knows so well:

Giving the customers what they want as well as what they can pay for was offered yesterday as a profitable program for the Republican party by Miss Marion E. Martin in her first speech here as assistant to the Republican national chairman at the Women's National Republican Club.

Despite the fact that operations on most fronts are bogging down ever more deeply as the rains intensify, the Japanese Army reports one important advance, namely the capturing of the village of Tungchiao, 2,500 yards west of Lotien, on Friday morning.

The League for Germanism Abroad will hold a two-day convention here starting tomorrow. The organization differs from the one which recently met at Stuttgart, being composed of persons of German origin who have become citizens of other countries.
Sir Anton Bertram, former Attorney General of the Bahamas, died here today at the age of 68. He held the Bahamas office from 1902 to 1907 and was chief justice of Ceylon from 1918 to 1925.

Organized groups of Catholics today guarded churches in Coatepec, Vera Cruz, after two days' demonstrations. After being officially permitted to hold mass Wednesday night, the Catholics marched through the streets, shouting "Long live Christ, the King!"

Clifford Smith, who directed fortyfive of William S. Hart's early films and many other Westerns, died today from complications following an appendectomy. Mr. Smith was born fifty-one years ago in Richmond, Ind.

More than 500 Columbia freshmen assembled in the McMillin Academic Treatre yesterday afternoon to hear brief addresses of welcome by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes and other university officials. The meeting constituted part of a threeday orientation program.

With the opening of the Conservatory Garden in Central Park at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street today by Park Commissioner Robert Moses, New York City will receive a sylvan gift that is expected to rival Washington's cherry blossom show on the Potomac next Spring for color and beauty.

To the editorr of The Neto York Times: Your recent editorial "The Right to Strike" sets forth that there are no absolute- rights, either for labor or for property. It well restates the theme of liberty versus license. These many months writers in the press of the nation have been arguing about the relative rights of workers, employers and the public in the many industrial disputes rampant throughout the country.

Danger of a strike on the rapid transit, street car and bus lines of the B. M. T. system was averted temporarily yesterday when the Transport Workers Union and the company agreed to a fact-finding inquiry and mediation to be conducted by a three-man board appointed by Mayor La Guardia.
The Vatican today asked its nunciature in Berlin to take up with the Nazi Government the attacks on Catholicism by German newspapers.

Directors of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company have deferred further dividend payments on the prior preference stock, the city of Seattle having defaulted a $208,400 street railway bond interest payment due to the company on Sept. 1, it was announced yesterday.
The demand for large apartments on the East Side centered yesterday in houses on Park Avenue, while the leading leases on the West Side were made in buildings on Riverside Drive and West End Avenue.

Construction contracts in the thirty-seven Eastern States during August reached a total of $285,104,100, or a gain of 4 per cent over the same month of last year, when the figure was $275,281,000, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

Miss Catherine Spackman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Spackman of Chicago, was married tonight to Edward W. Hellwig in the Hellwig Summer home here. The ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace Salvatore Mazzeo of Darien.

Herman L. Gantvoort, former Broadway producer, died early yesterday in the Post-Graduate Hospital. In the silent days of the moving pictures Mr. Gantvoort wrote scenarios and produced numerous films. He was 50 years old.
There must be feminists who resent the familiar newspaper pictures of domestic harmony at the polls.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Karla Lois Collins, daughter of Mrs. Martin Henry Collins of Montclair and the late Mr. Collins, to Dr. Paul Stephen Habbe of New Haven, Conn. Miss Collins attended Western College, Oxford, Ohio, and the professional school in group work education at George Williams College in Chicago.

The engagement was announced yesterday of Miss Muriel Bache Richards, daughter of Mrs. Frederic Beckman of 791 Park Avenue and of Frederick Lloyd Richards, also of this city, to Francis Warren Pershing, only son of General John J. Pershing, Commander-in-Chief o the A. E. F. during the World War. The wedding is planned for next Spring.

Mrs. Martin G. Missir and Mrs. L. M. Lloyd became the finalists in the annual championship golf tournament for women members of the Westchester Country Club by scoring victories on the club's south course today.

Final tabulation today of the vote in the bitterly waged primary contest for the Mayoralty of the City of Long Beach gave the nomination to the regular organization candidates both of the Republican and Democratic parties.

Dahlias featured the annual exhibition of the Tuxedo Horticultural Society and the Garden Club of Orange-Dutchess Counties which opened today at the parish house of St. Mary's Protestant Episcopal Church here. Exhibits throughout the show were marked by a quality high above previous years.

Paul Keres of Estonia, the latest sensation in European chess circles, and Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, former world champion, finished their schedules in the first half of the international chess masters tournament today by engaging in a hard-fought draw.

The State Board of Tax Appeals reduced today to $1,952,936 an assessment of $5,500,000 imposed for 1936 taxing purposes by the Newark Board of Assessment and Tax Revision on intangible personal property of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey situated in Newark.

Mem ber trading in round lots for own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Aug. 21 fell to 18.62 per cent of total volume, the lowest percentage shown since the Securities and Exchange Commission began the publication of these figures last October, the commission reported today.

Michael J. Sewak, burgess of Franklin Borough, where most of the Cambria strike trouble was centered last June, told the National Labor Relations Board today that officials of the Bethlehem Steel Company made him two financial offers if he would "go along with them" in the strike situation.
Cotton mill activity dropped sharply last week when an increase was seasonal, and the adjusted index slumped to 122.2 from 132.5 (revised). It was 133.0 for the week ended Sept. 12, 1936.
Senator Lonergan of Connectiout today proposed creation of a commission to study suggested changes in the Constitution in a letter to Senator Ashurst, chairman of the Judiciary Committee.

Sharpsburg, Md., Sept. 17.-Standing on the peaceful green slopes where seventy-five years ago the armies of McClellan and Lee met in the bloodiest single day of battle ever fought on United States soil, President Roosevelt called on the people of the country today to act as one nation.

The State Civil Service Commission late this afternoon advised seven civic organizations of New York City that another twenty-four hours would be granted by the commission to enable them to appear in protest against the appointment of James J. Walker, former Mayor, as special assistant counsel to the Transit Commission at a salary of $12,000 a year.

The Federal Trade Commission today filed complaints against Askin's Retail Stores, Inc., 425 Fourth Avenue, and Russeks Fifth Avenue, Inc., and Fashion Firsts, Inc., both of 390 Fifth Avenue, New York City.

Miss Jean Arnold Stevens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Stevens of Red Bank, was married to F. William Debree, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Debree of Scotch Plains, this afternoon in St. George's Episcopal Church, Rumson, by the Rev. Herbert S. Craig, rector of Trinity Episcopal Church of Red Bank.
The proprietor of the beer garden where Bruno Richard Hauptmann used to drink beer and play cards committed suicide yesterday, according to Dr. Charles Hochman, assistant medical examiner.

By coming home in 35 despite the drizzling rain that made clubs slippery, Herman Barron, sturdy 22year-old Fenway pro, today left his pursuers far behind to win the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association title vacated by Paul Runyan of the Metropolis Club.

A campaign "to rid the electric industry of all unlawful intercorporate dealings and profiteering" through the medium of an inquiry into the lawfulness of existing interlocking directorates in public utility and related-companies was announced today by Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Power Commission.
The Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee in New York included ninety-two titles in its Autumn list of recommended books, which was made public yesterday. The list follows:

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that proposed rules and regulations for the rayon and cellulose yarns industry, approved by the industry yesterday at a conference in New York City, were not acceptable to the commission.
The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a supplemental list of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations for July.

William C. Gilman, director of the Public Utilities Division of the Securities and Exchange Commission since Oct. 5, 1935, has resigned, effective Oct. 4. He will leave the commission to organize, with William Hickey, formerly an analyst in the Utilities Division, a firm of consulting engineers.

Cohen, Goldman Co. will launch its Fall newspaper rotogravure campaign for its line of Worsted-Tex and other suits in ten cities tomorrow, Leon Hirsch, advertising manager made known yesterday. Fullpage space will be taken in New York, Boston, Pittsburgh, Cincinnati, Detroit, Indianapolis, Chicago, St. Louis, Los Angeles and San Francisco. "Restrained" color will be used in the New York and Chicago papers, he said.

Expressing misgivings regarding the fate of Japan's export trade in the face of a protracted campaign by Japanese forces in China, Choykuro Kadono, head of the Japanese Economic Mission which conferred with business men here last June, predicted yesterday that the fighting in China will be of short duration.

The National Container Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Airdepot Realty Corporation, reported yesterday a consolidated net profit of $338,042 for the seven months ended on July 31. The profit is after allowance for Federal income taxes and other charges. It equals $1.02 a share on 330,482 shares of capital stock.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Gray gave a large supper dance tonight at Longford, their country place on Bayville Boulevard, to introduce to society their younger daughter, Miss Beatrice D. Gray. Miss Gray, who returned last week from Newport, where she passed the Summer with her parents, is a sister of Miss Audrey Gray, who made her debut last year.

Despite the drizzle of rain, a crowd estimated at 2,500 persons gathered at Broad and Wall Streets yesterday noon to witness the twenty-second annual celebrations by the Sons of the American Revolution of the adoption of the Constitution.

Although showers occurred at some points west of the Mississippi River and a tropical disturbance in the Gulf of Mexico brought predictions of unsettled weather, prices on the Cotton Exchange here moved yesterday into new low ground and ended with losses of 4 to 6 points.

The marriage of Miss Jane Tinsley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Jenking Tinsley of Roland Park, to Harry Forrest Swope Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Forrest Swope, took place today in the Brown Memorial Church. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers, pastor, officiated. The reception was at the Woman's Club of Roland Park.

Odell Hale whacked a 3-and-2 ball out of the park with two mates on base and two out in the seventh inning today to break up a pitching duel between Johnny Allen and Buck Newsom and give the Indians a 4-1 victory over the Red Sox.

A decided improvement in investment sentiment has taken place in the last few days and prospective borrowers and their underwriters, encouraged by this development, are proceeding with increased confidence with several major corporate loans.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Re-enactment of the Battle of Antietam by the United States Army on the seventy-fifth anniversary has turned the years backward to Sept. 17, 1862. The tread of Lee's unconquered legions over one of the most brilliant fields of all time is being heard around the world. The fate of a young nation is hanging in the balance, under the smoke of lifted guns.
America's cotton textile shipments to the Philippines dwindled to 26 per cent of the total imported by the Islands last year, the PhilippineUnited States joint preparatory committee was told today.

Democratic supporters of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia who wrote in his name in the Democratic primary ballot had considerable difficulty with the spelling of his name, it was revealed yesterday. The Mayor's name appeared on the ballots spelled 155 ways.

A standard unit for measuring the amount of X-rays and radium to which patients are to be exposed in curative work was adopted for the physicians of the world here today as the Fifth International Congress of Radiology ended.
The pre-Christmas advertising campaign for Swank men's jewelry will be launched next week in full color pages in three weekly and one monthly magazines and in black and white in a woman's magazine.

Brooks Weber of Heller, Bruce Co., San Francisco, and K. T. Murphy of Munds, Winslow Potter shared golfing honors yesterday at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, N. Y., where the New York Security Traders Association played host at an outing for the national body.

YOUNGHILL KANG, who teaches Comparative Literature at New York University, grew up in Korea. Having told of his boyhood and youth in "The Grass Roof," published here some years ago, he now writes of his later experience-what he calls the making of an Oriental Yankee-in a book entitled "East Goes West."*

Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon Gould o? 160 East Seventy-second Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Silvia Gould, to Charles Dabney Thomson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Thomson of 5,907 Belmont Avenue, College Hill, Cincinnati.

The Japanese are on the point of completing a victory in North China that one of their war correspondents compares with the Battle of Tannenberg. About 50,000 Chinese troops have been enveloped in the triangle formed by the PeipingHankow Railroad and the Sungying River,
Total production of polished plate glass by members of the Plate Glass Manufacturers of America was 17,898,064 square feet in August, as against 15,344,855 in July and 18,710,040 in August, 1936.
Sky Larking, Hopeful Stakes winner and potential 2-year-old champion, will go to the post this afternoon in the sixty-seventh running of the historic Champagne Stakes, which goes back to 1867.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, with the approval of Federal Judge John W. Clancy, entered a stipulation yesterday with Archie M. Andrews, Simons Co., and others, agreeing to discontinue its suit to restrain them from engaging in allegedly illegal transactions in the stock of the Dictograph Products Co., Inc.

Royal displeasure at the unauthorized commercial use of portraits of members of the royal family-which since the coronation period has been rampant on chocolate, cosmetics and other boxes-was indicated in a notice issued by the Home Office today.

Complete returns in the primary election here showed today that all candidates sponsored by J. Harvey Turnure, city Republican chairman, scored decisive victories yesterday over their opponents for the White Plains Republican nominations. Chauncey T. S. Fish received 3,447 votes to defeat Mayor Walter Rogers for the Republican Mayoralty nomination.

The Securities and Exchange Commission's hearings on stop-order proceedings against the Austin Silver Mining Company ended yesterday in a blaze of fireworks. Pierce W. Bradley of counsel for the SEC, and Frank L. Miller, representing the respondent, tangled strenuously over a remark by the former which the latter characterized as a contemptible statement." John F. Davidson,

Miss Agnes Ladson Dana was introduced to society tonight at a dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Anderson Dana, at Brookwood, their home here. The residence and surrounding grounds were beautifully decorated for the event.

Nine parcels of Manhattan real estate were sold at auction in the Vesey Street rooms yesterday, ineluding the fifteen-story apartment at 54 Riverside Drive and the twelve-story Allendale Apartment building at 806-08 West End Avenue.

The felonious assault charge against Edward Lawford, 24 years old, a real estate broker of the Hotel Gladstone, made last May 12 in the shooting of William (Bill) Corum, sports columnist for The New York Journal and American,

The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette publishes today the last of a series of six articles in which it is charged that Hugo L. Black of Alabama, recently appointed to the Supreme Court of the United States, was and still is a member of the Ku Klux Klan.

Following is the text of President Roosevelt's radio addresss tonight: My Fellow-Americans: Tonight, 150 years ago, thirtyeight weary delegates to a convention in Philadelphia signed the Constitution.

Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANTS-Gerard R. Littlefield, from 77th Precinct to Police Academy. Assignment to desk duty discontinued. Arthur Wertheim, from Juvenile Aid Bureau to 2d Division. Assigned to desk duty.
Thomas J. Evers, a practicing lawyer in Brooklyn for forty-four years with offices at 215 Montague Street, died on Thursday at his home, 252 Westminster Road, at the age of 67.

Building projects filed yesterday included plans for a six-story tenement at Lexington Avenue and East Thirty-first Street to cost $180,000. Numerous plans for altering existing structures in Manhattan also were filed.

R. M. Gray of Toronto, Canadian titleholder, and Raleigh W. Lee, United States champion from Columbus, Ohio, tied for top honors in the North American seniors' golf championship today. Each posted a 79 in the eighteenhole medal play at the Lambton course.

New York began to get a taste of what it may expect all next week as the graying veterans of the Ameri can Legion, who passed through New York twenty years ago e?? route to France, came pouring into the city to an estimated number o?? 50,000 for the nineteenth annual Legion convention opening Sunday night.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kelso Cassatt gave a dinner at The Orchard tonight. Mrs. Moses Taylor will be among those entertaining this week-end. Mrs. Bradford Norman was a dinner hostess at Brook Farm tonight. Frazier Jelke will give a dinner at Eagle's Nest tomorrow evening in honor of his week-end guests, who include Major and Mrs. Hallam Boyd /of New York and Reginald Baxter of London,

Mrs. Elbridge Gerry Chadwick of this city and Syosset, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Dorothy Douglas Robinson, to Randolph Appleton Kidder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Vincent Kidder of Beverly Farms, Mass.

Frank Moy, unofficial Mayor of Chinatown and head of the On Leong Tong here for many years, died today. He was 63 years old. Friends said he had been overworking in his task of directing the Chinese Emergency Relief Society in raising funds for victims of the fighting in China.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Craig Colgate of Flushing of the engagement of their elder daughter, Miss Ellenor Brigham Colgate, to Benjamin Loring Young Jr., son of Mrs. Mary Coolidge Young of Santa Barbara, Calif., and of B. Loring Young of Weston Mass.
Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora severely condemned Hugo L. Black last night at a dinner of the United States Constitution Sesquicentennial Committee at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The make-up of the Suffolk County Republican Committee remains unchanged under Chairman W. Kingsland Macy as the result of yesterday's primary election in which contests were fought in twenty-two of the county's 162 election districts, chiefly in the towns of Huntington, Babylon and Islip.

Many contests enlivened the quest for nominations to the 1938 Assembly at Thursday's primary election. In most instances candidates running with organization backing emerged victorious both in the Republican and the Democratic primaries, but there were notable exceptions, mostly on the Democratic side, where the rivalry was keener and primary fights more numerous.

Eugene F. Savage, painter, sculptor and member of the Federal Commission of Fine Arts at Washington, will design the mural decorations for the United States Building at the New York World's Fair in 1939, and Edward H. Burdick will serve as director of exhibits the building, according to announcement yesterday by Theodore T. Hayes, executive commissioner of the Federal commission for the fair.
Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, suggested today that public utilities disseminate "impartial and truthful" data showing what charges are added

Portugal has replied to Secretary of State Cordell Hull's enunciation of peace principles in his July 16 statement of policies that should guide the nations in the conduct of foreign affairs, with a biting analysis that stamps her alone of the more than fifty powers that have replied as the notable exception in a chorus of general approval. The reply was received here without comment.
John W. Fitzgerald, vice president of William Iselin Co., a private banking corporation, died yesterday at his home, 133 West 179th Street, the Bronx, after a long illness. He was 58 years old.

Taking her second straight race of the Star Class international championship series, the German sloop Pimm loomed this afternoon as the craft to watch. No other European entry ever has equaled her performance in the three contests sailed.
Dr. Alexis Carrel confirmed today that he and Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh were collaborating on new scientific experiments.

The slump in the New York stock market and the decline of the French franc are wholly unrelated phenomena, but their conjunction serves to point up the vital difference between the situation in France and the United States and to light up the strange and significant discrepancy between French currency and French economy.

Ernie Dusek, 228, Omaha, wrestled to a draw with Joe Cox, 224, Texas, in the feature bout at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night before a crowd of 3,000 persons. The bout lasted fifty-seven minutes.

The Italian liner Vulcania, sailing today for Mediterranean ports and Trieste, will have among her passengers Count Vittore Vittorelli, Dr. and Mrs. Erhard von Loehr, Mr. and Mrs. Adolfo Riva, Mr. and Mrs. Philip M. Morgan, Mrs. Hortense S. Britt, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel F. Engs, Mr. and Mrs. Rolland J. Hamilton, Mrs. Charles R. Ogsbury, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Seward, F. P. Haywood, Aitken Reichmer and H. P. Rolfe.

A book first published forty-eight years ago, and that has had steady sales since then, has been revised by its author and will be published in a new edition next week by Macmillan. The book is "Outlines of Economics." It was published for Chautauqua use in 1889 under the title, "Introduction to Political Economy."

Allen H. Fagan, for more than twenty years a stage manager and actor and a brother of Miss Ina Claire, the actress, died early yesterday morning of a heart attack in his home, 177 West Ninety-fifth Street. Mr. Fagan, who was 47 years old, had been ill for six weeks.

The Board of Tax Appeals sustained Daniel Gimbel of Philadelphia, to day in his contention that the Bureau of Internal Revenue erroneously determined he was $15,737 deficient in income taxes for 1932, 1933 and 1934.

A century and a half, to the hour, after the American Constitution was signed representatives of the city, state and nation assembled today in the room where the signing took place to hear warnings against over-centralization of government in Washington, along with confident predictions that democracy would prevail in this country.

A dozen contests, nine of these in the Democratic and three in the Republican primaries, featured the nomination of candidates for district delegates to the constitutional convention that will meet next year to revise or rewrite the organic law of the State.

Rutgers University devoted the major part of its Fall convocation today to the observance of the 150th anniversary of the Constitution. Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of the institution, urged university men to rededicate themselves to the ideals of the Constitution,

Delegates from more than 200 American Federation of Labor unions, representing upward of 600,000 union members in the city, pledged $10,000 yesterday to the conduct of a non-partisan campaign for the re-election of Mayor La Guardia. The pledges were made at a meeting in Beethoven Hall, 210 Fifth Street.

Thomas W. Walsh, retired. clothing manufacturer, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 141 West Ninety-fifth Street, at the age of 84. Mr. Walsh was born in Sheffield, England, and came to this country when he was 14 years old. He started as a clerk in a small clothing establishment and later established the firm of Lange Walsh, men's clothiers.

The inference that Great Britain's Equalization Account had been actively supporting the pound sterling by the sale of dollars here during its recent decline was drawn in financial circles yesterday from the arrival from England on the liner Washington of $17,500,000 of gold, of which only $2,781,700 showedd up
