By a vote of ninety-five to thirtytwo, members of Actors Equity Association yesterday reversed the action of Equity Council in imposing suspended fines on approximately fifty Federal Theatre performer who had disregarded Council instructions to cross picket lines and report to their duties during a one-day work stoppage last May 27.

Constitution celebrations were held today in schools and public buildings throughout Westchester County and this afternoon more than 500 persons, some dressed in Colonial costumes, paraded through White Plains.

The New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to extend for ten years beyond Oct. 1, next, the maturity date of $16,381,000 of the road's first mortgage bonds, with interest reduced from 4 to 3 1/2 per cent.

The Civilian Conservation Corps revised its schedule for New York State today to continue three CCC camps previously slated to be closed on Oct. 1. Robert Fechner, director of the CCC, said camps at Margaretville, Delaware County; Slaterville Springs, Tompkins County,

Psychoanalysis and the treatment of nervous disorders are not separate sciences and should never be divorced from ordinary medicine, according to reports submitted today by American delegates to the international congress devoted to the study of liver insufficiencies in session here.

Stocks erased Thursday's. gains and closed lower in second lowest trading of month; turnover, 814,050 shares. United States Government bonds quiet and fractionally higher; other issues irregular; transactions, $6,148,850.
There was a lot of color in Forbes Field today but little, if any, was supplied by the Dodgers, who subsided before Ed Brandt and the Pirates by a 10-4 count.
Albert Chase Bowman, well known in the textile industry and banking and official of mills and stores in Springfield, Keene, N. H., and Skowhegan, Me., died today at his home.

Mrs. Jean Russ, 27-year-old wife of a Norwalk, Conn., farm hand, was cleared of a charge of improper maintenance of two young children, when Magistrate Michael A. Ford, sitting in the Bronx magistrate's court on Thursday, ruled that her conduct while in this city was blameless.

MANHATTAN GOLDSTEIN, DAVID (Dec. 31, 1936). Gross assets, $15,807; net, $13,945. To Gussie Goldstein, widow, $4,815; Rachel Seader and Babette Goldstein, granddaughters, $2,000; Samuel Goldstein, son, Sadie and Ruth Minsky, daughters, $1,923 each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $11,393. Livingston Livingston, attorneys, 51 Chambers St.

No flutter or frenzy dominated headquarters of the American Legion Auxiliary yesterday at the Hotel Astor, where the machinery of preparation for the influx of delegates and visitors proceeded at a brisk pace.
Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today that the week's output of the automobile plants would total 30,150 assemblies, which, the summary indicated, probably will be the low point of the year.

Supreme Court Justice Edgar L.Lauer sent a check for $10,400 yesterday to customs officials in payment of duties and penalties on jewelry, furs and other apparel that he and Mrs. Lauer failed to declare on their return from Europe aboard the Normandie on Monday.

Dr. Thomas J. Conte, defending champion, gained the semi-final round today in the New York Athletic Club golf championship at the Winged Foot Golf Club. The qualifying leader of the tournament gained the quarter-final bracket by a default from Eustace De Cordova. Pitted against Trumbull Richard later, he won by 4 and 3.

New bond financing this week amounted to $7,641,000 and again was restricted exclusively to the tax-exempt field. This compares with only $4,515,000 in new issues placed on the market last week, and with a total of $113,531,000 marketed during this period a year ago.
John D. M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, condemned partisan criticism of President Roosevelt today in a statement on the Ku Klux Klan affiliation of Justice Hugo L. Black.
General short covering developed in September corn on the Board of Trade here today after the price had advanced 6 1/2 cents a bushel to $1.16 3/4, a new high for the season.

There are "chompeens" out here in several languages getting ready for the four-ply fight festival Uncle Mike Jacobs has planned for the Polo Grounds. The titles may not be recognized by the New York State Athletic Commission but the gents going around here in turtle-neck sweaters are more polite.
Dr. Arthur G. Noehren, superintendent of the Naini Leper Asylum in Allahabad, India, died suddenly Wednesday of a heart ailment, it was learned here yesterday. He was 52 years old.

Dr. Robert E. Speer will be honored Monday evening at a dinner at Schrafft's, 220 West Fifty-seventh Street, by the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions in observance of his seventieth birthday. Dr. Speer, who has served his board as a secretary for forty-six years, is retiring. His birthday was on Sept. 10.

Both Marcel Thil and Pedro Montanez continued today to pound away at spar mates and punching bags in their preparation for title bouts in the carnival of champions next week, but for Ceferino Garcia it was strictly a holiday.

The Rotunde Hall, built in 1873 for the Vienna World Exhibition and one of Central Europe's biggest buildings, burned today. The fire started from a short circuit. The entire Vienna Fire Department was unable to control the blaze.

Co-winner of the event last year, Charles Shelden of Siwanoy today served notice on the field of fiftyfive teams in the annual Nassau Country Club invitation best-ball tournament that he is out to repeat.
Seven new courses and several new lecturers have been added for the Fall term of the New York University School of Retailing opening next Tuesday, Dean Norris A. Brisco announced yesterday.

One of the largest apartment properties in the Bronx changed hands yesterday when Noonan Towers, a seven-story building accommodating 162 families at 939 Woodycrest. Avenue, was sold by Bernard Noonan and associates to the Towercrest Realty Corporation, an investor represented by Levy, Murphy Stokes, attorneys.

The marriage of Miss Emily Bullard Chatfield, daughter of Thurber Redmayne Chatfield of Washington, Conn., and the late Mrs. Chatfield, to Dr. Joseph Cutler Woodward, son of Mrs. Joseph Hooker Woodward of this city and South Lyme, Conn., took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, charged tonight that the Committee for Industrial Organization, of which John L. Lewis is the head, sought to "purchase" favors from the Administration and from Congress through large campaign contributions.

The second reopening of the week takes place tonight at the Winter Garden, where "The Show Is On" will visit for a time before going out on tour. Willie and Eugene Howard, who were in last season's second engagement of the musical are there again, this time co-starred with Chic York and Rose King Also important to the cast are Charles (Cookie) Bowers, John McCauley, Jack Good, Terry Lawlor and Roy Cropper.

With both sides claiming victory, delegates to the annual convention of the International Typographical Union ended their week-long session today without a direct vote on the question of C. I. O.-A. F. L. affiliation.
Housing properties in Harlem proved attractive to buyers in transactions announced yesterday. Some of the properties were sold by banks.

Miss Catherine Lewerth, daughter of Mrs. Daniel Lewerth of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Mr. Lewerth, was married yesterday afternoon at the home of her mother to Lloyd Vincent Almirall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Juan A. Almirall of Brooklyn and Cragsmoor, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by Mgr. John L. Belford, pastor of the Church of the Nativity of Our Blessed Lord, Brooklyn.

It seems historically fitting that a Governor of Vermont should select Constitution Week as a time to protest against what he regards as an attempted Federal raid on State sovereignty. Vermont, like Texas, was for some years an independent republic. It still feels pretty independent.

Due mainly to increased purchases by the United States, Germany was able to achieve another foreign trade record when her exports in August reached 541,300,000 marks. This is 11,400,000 marks or 2 per cent more than in the preceding month.

WASHINGTON. WHEN he was appointed director of the Bureau of Air Commerce nearly six months ago Fred D. Fagg Jr., as one of his first tasks, reorganized the bureau into seven departments, which began functioning at once.

IN Spain, the sword having ascendancy over the pen, the past fourteen months have been for publishers and writers what the Spanish refer to as a time of vacas flacas, or lean cows. During 1936, until the bombing of Madrid began, many valuable works were published, but there was practically no time or opportunity to make them known.

THE Grand Canyon of the Colorado is a Library of Time. Nowhere else in the world has nature kept, in one spot, so complete a record of millions of years of change; nowhere written her story in more sublime color.

IT was on Sept 22, seventy-five years ago, that President Lincoln opened a meeting of his Cabinet by reading to them from Artemus Ward's new book. "A High-Handed Outrage at Uticy." It was the kind of humor that Lincoln enjoyed, though the more sophisticated members of his Cabinet did not, and it served to relieve the tenseness of his feelings For it was a tense moment.

THE Composers' Forum-Laboratory of the WPA Federal Music Project will inaugurate. its third season Wednesday night, Oct. 6, in the Federal Music Theatre with the following orchestral program by Roy Harris:

Bryan that W. (Bitsy) Grant, Atlanta star, who gave way to Frankie Parker of Chicago as No. 2 singles player on the Davis Cup team in its successful European invasion, defeated Parker, 6-3, 6-3, today in a roundrobin tournament.

MR. TILDEN has written a book whose entertaining qualities are sure to appeal to the reader, but they will hardly prove effective in disguising the inconclusiveness and conflicting reasoning of its major thesis.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Evelynola Hoon, daughter of Mrs. Clarence Earl Hoon of this place and the late Rev. Dr. Hoon of Detroit, to Robert Ralston Cawley, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frank Edward Cawley of Boston, took place this afternoon in the Methodist Episcopal Church of New Milford.

The last remaining apartments in the large buildings at 912 Fifth Avenue, 111 East Eightieth Street and 1,200 Fifth Avenue have been leased by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., agents. A total of thirty-one large East Side structures, managed by that organization, are now 100 per cent occupied, it is reported.
Virginia Tech scored in every quarter to defeat Roanoke College, 27 to 7, in the opening football game, played before 4,000 in Miles Stadium today.

THE provocative curving of her rich lips, the fresh silkiness of her skin, the alabaster finish of her hands and arms, the luxuriant hair, smooth and shining, portrayed a woman who hardly belonged to the present, but seemed rather to have stepped out of a canvas by . . ." The author was stuck.
Southwest Kansas farmers and business men have not lost faith in wheat as the crop that offers the largest return for labor and money.

Complete civil order prevails in that part of Spain held by the forces of General Francisco Franco and there are no signs of disaffection with the Insurgent rule, Russell Palmer, publisher of World Petroleum, a trade journal, declared last week on his return on the liner Normandie from a Summer in Spain.
Mr. and Mrs. Lammot du Pont have issued invitations for the wedding of their daughter, Miss Alexandrine du Pont, and Howard Alfred Perkins Jr., on Oct. 16, it was announced today.
Syracuse University's opening football game with Clarkson has been moved up to Friday night, Oct. 1. It originally was scheduled for the the following afternoon.

Seeking such solace as they could from the conviction that the Reds simply could not do such a thing singlehanded, the Giants steamed and fumed out of this metropolis tonight firm in the belief it must have been a sunken log that unexpectedly retarded their gay pennant dash today.
Josephus Daniels, the United States Ambassador, asserted in a press conference today that Mexico was violating the spirit of the Buenos Aires conference by raising tariff barriers.

Ten young women, chosen from among 100 applicants, have received Lucius N. Littauer scholarships to the New York School of Applied Design for Women, according to announcement by Mrs. Dunlap Hopkins, founder of the school.

The cafeteria-goer who habitually holds up the line while deciding which is the biggest piece of pie is doomed by the invention of an "equal cut piepan" for which a patent (No. 2,093,307) has just been granted here to a resident of Culver, Ind.

New York is ready for. the lodging, feeding, entertaining and safeguarding of some 75,000 women and 10,000 children as well as upward of 300,000 men expected here this week for the American Legion Convention.

Suit for $42,000,000 damages against the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and six subsidiaries operating in Ohio was entered today in the Common Pleas Court of Franklin County on behalf of more than half a million gas consumers.
THE French Riviera has provided subject-matter for many books and has supplied scenery for many more. Fryniwyd Tennyson Jesse has, in "Act of God," made it the battleground of religious controversy.

Miss Mabel Barbara Thomas, daughter of Mrs. David P. Thomas of this city, was married to Russell Bryden Waddell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Waddell of East Orange, this evening in the Second Presbyterian Church, Newark.

The Trades and Labor Congress of Canada today voted in favor of State medicine and hospitalization, establishment in all provinces of federations of labor, referred to its executive the question of more active participation in reorganization work, demanded jail terms for gold high-graders and adjourned.
John G. Hides, a former officer of the Papuan Government, who made important discoveries in Papua in 1935, including a previously unknown race of natives,

Presidents of two upstate colleges, Dr. Alan Valentine of the University of Rochester and Dr. James Laurence Meader of the Russell Sage College at Troy, have been named to the New York State Examinations Board.

The engagement was announced here today by Mrs. Francis W. Bird of East Walpole, Mass., of her daughter, Miss Mary Reynolds Bird, to Walter Massey Phillips, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Phillips of Mrs. Shadybank, Torresdale.

The action of District Attorney Charles F. Kelley this week in asking for a grand jury investigation of alleged "wide open" gambling surprised Philadelphians, not because of the absence of suspicion that gambling houses were operating, but because Mr. Kelley less than three months ago had belittled clergymen's charges that vice and crime were rampant in the city.

Thomas H. Fraser, realty man or 88 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, has taken over the business of the late William Stephany at 391 Sunrise Highway, Lynbrook, and will operate it as a branch office under the direction of his son, Gordon W. Fraser.

From coast to coast, in villages of a few hundred population and in metropolises of millions, preliminaries are being settled for the launching next month of the most ambitious national program of community study yet to be undertaken by a single organization. It is entitled "Our Town's Business," and is consigned wholesale to the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Sept. 15, aggregated $9,451,000,000, or 46 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week, which included only five business days, and 3 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

ONE of the better-known proverbial sayings in German is: Der Krug geht so lange zum Brunnen bis er bright! which may be translated to mean: There is a limit to everything! Reading this thinnish but fact-crowded volume. "an independent examination of the results of National Socialism," we pause and wonder if Hitler.
" Subway series" or not, there will be no day off for the weary athletes during the world series this Fall unless the weather man happens to provide one.

Sales in retail stores during August totaled $2,900,000,000, a gain of $100,000,000, or about four per cent over the sales volume of August, 1936, according to calculations made public yesterday by the American Retail Federation.

Yale University has arranged in the Sterling Memorial Library an exhibition in honor of Roger Sherman, the only man who signed all three of the fundamentals of the early American Government, the Declaration of Independence, the Articles of Confederation and the Constitution.

Thomas Garrigue Masaryk has returned for the last time to the city that he made the capital of his liberated land. His body was brought back last night to give the people he freed an opportunity to do personal homage.

On Aug. 7 superintendent of a machine shop with 300 men under him, on Aug. 8 managing director of the whole plant, with 25,000 employes-that is the "success story" of Jacob Yusim, 33 years old, the archetype of the "Stalinist generation" whose challenge to its elders is one of the outstanding factors in Russia today.

The New York Curb Exchange has been notified that shareholders in the Canadian Hydro-Electric Corporation, Ltd., of record of Sept. 24 will be entitled to receive shares of the Gatineau Power Company to be distributed upon surrender of their certificates.

Dowager Lady Loch celebrated her ninetysixth birthday on Wednesday without her twin sister, Dowager Countess of Lytton, who died three days after last year's celebration. In the family party were Sir Edwin Lutyens and his daughters, Mrs. Euan Wallace, Lady Ridley and Mrs. Ian Glennie.

ASORT of West Coast, or roadcompany, Tecumseh.has just picked up a stray item of more than casual interest--more than casual, because it concerns the latest work by that Mordaunt Shairp whose "Green Bay Tree" flourished in the Broadway soil a few seasons back.

Every year more than a billion passengers ride on the subways, elevated, trolleys and buses of the Brooklyn Manhattan Transit Corporation, otherwise the B. M. T. This service is Brooklyn's lifeline, and its absence would spell deep chaos.
Governors, Mayors and other State and local officials from all sections of the nation will be on hand for the opening of the American Legion convention.

Justice Lott R. Herrick of the Illinois Supreme Court died in an oxygen tent here this afternoon. Cerebral lesions were said by physicians to have been the immediate cause of death. Justice Herrick, who was 65 years old, was brought to Rochester last week. He had been seriously ill since Aug. 24.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bolden Graham of Grosse Pointe, Mich., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Graham, to Duval Adams Headley, son of Mr. and Mrs. George William Headley of Lexington, Ky.

On a mounting crescendo of color and excitement, preliminaries of the American Legion Auxiliary convention program moved rapidly last night into the final phases, with mass arrivals and individual reunions, queues at the registration desks in various hotels and queries by the score tossed at the besieged staffs of information desks.
The Pittsburgh Symphony Society announced today the engagement of Michel Gusikoff, formerly concert master for Philadelphia and New York orchestras, as its concert master and assistant conductor.

The coincidence last week of a further break in the market with the eighth anniversary of the peak of the 1929 bull market naturally evoked comment on the similarities and contrasts between present conditions and the earlier ones.

Out of 787 revocations and suspensions of automobile registrations and licenses to drive in the past two weeks, 266 owners must show proof of financial responsibility before new applcations for licenses will be considered, according to Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.

Miss Sarah Patterson Foster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Taylor Foster of Greenwich, was married to Arthur Oram Fulton Jr., son of Mrs. Arthur O. Fulton of Boston, in Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon.
SHEEPSKIN: Congress recently authorized the Naval Academy at Annapolis to award the degree of Bachelor of Science to all who were graduated

Nathaniel Rutherford, 2-year-old pacer owned by C. D. Robbins of Maplewood, and Cynara, trotting mare owned by Lou Schnieder of Elizabeth, won the feature events of the matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

A warning that Chinese vessels suspected of having changed their registration to evade the Japanese blockade will be detained and examined, although flying a foreign flag, was issued by the Foreign Office tonight.

" Aida," Friday night. Mmes. Greco and Maru Castagna, and Messrs. Lindi. Stephano Ballerini, Zorin and Molle. Conductor, Plotnikoff. "La Traviata," Saturday night. Mmes. Greco and Ippolito, and Messrs. Power. Cozzi and Ciccia. Conductor Bamboschek.

Relief cases in Illinois have been steadily increasing in number since last June. In July the total was 3.6 per cent higher than in the same month a year ago. In August they were 6.1 per cent higher than in July, and in September they are nearly 5 per cent ahead of August figures.

Alpheus Crosby Beane of 636 Lake Avenue, Greenwich, New York broker, died this morning of a heart attack at the age of 48. He had lived in Greenwich for the last fourteen months and was a member of the Round Hill Club and a wellknown golfer.

Unless a large amount of new construction is begun in the interval, it is likely that the navy list to be issued by the German Government toward the end of the year will show that comparatively few ships have been laid down since it was last issued, toward the end of 1936.

With less than two weeks remaining before Mayor La Guardia must submit his 1938 executive budget to the Board of Estimate on Oct. 2, the city confronts a strong likelihood that its next budget will be the largest in its history.
ARONSON--SARNOFF--Dr. and Mrs. J. Sarnoff of Brooklyn announce the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy, to Dr. Shepard G. Aronson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Aronson of Brooklyn.

Westchester County brokers are looking forward to an active home selling campaign during the next two months. The present year in practically all of the choice residential centers has been productive of more realty interest than has been seen -for several seasons and the building operations, while not excessive, have been very satisfactory and have been properly proportioned to the needs of the- various communities.

Stiffening Chinese defense, coupled with the fact that the Japanese forces must consolidate their gains, is believed responsible for the comparatively small advances made by the Japanese troops southward and westward in the last twenty-four hours.

A three-day visit to the Aragon front has satisfied your correspondent that the Government won a victory there greater than has been realized. It ranks, in fact, as one of the Loyalists' biggest triumphs, and as such it has repaid close study.
The British destroyer Fearless reported today to London naval authorities that it had been attacked by a bombing plane off Gijon, Spain.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Greenbelt is shortly to be opened to its first residents. It is a community sponsored by the suburban division of the Resettlement Administration, now under the Department of Agriculture.

One out of every four persons in America is going to school this month. In this school procession of 33,000,000 persons, the largest in our history, there are fewer children but more adolescents and adults than ever before.
Miss Jane Douglas Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kendrick Roscoe Wilson of this city, became the bride of Charles Clark Stover Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Stover of Providence, R. I.,

I have the honor to invite you to take cognizance of the fact that Japan has invaded China. With these words Dr. Wellington Koo, chief Chinese delegate to the League of Nations, made his long-awaited plea at Geneva last week.

While its organization is still in provisional form, the Consumer-Retailer Relations Council, following a meeting here toward the close of last week, has initiated a program designed "to enable consumers better to judge values and uses in the merchandise they buy through adequate informative labeling."

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 2,000 head, including 1,500 direct; generally steady; one load. choice around 215 pound averages $12.65. Shippers took 100; estimated holdover 500. Compared week ago generally 40 to 50 cents a hundred weight higher.

The demand of the five trainoperating unions for a 20 per cent increase in wages has provided a major problem for the nation's railroad managements. While railroad earnings have been running at the best levels since 1930,

Significant of the results obtained by the State Mortgage Commission in -rehabilitating properties under the provisions of the revolving fund, established by the Legislature for such purpose, is the case of the six-story apartment house at 1,410 Plimpton Avenue, the Bronx.
Bernie Friedkin, 130 1/2 Brooklyn, outpointed Jimmy Lancaster, 30 1/4, Wilmington, Del., in the six-round feature bout at the Ridgewood Grove in Brooklyn last night. A crowd of 3,000 looked on.

Premier Benito Mussolini's Newspaper, Il Popolo d'Italia, declared tonight that at least 800 Spanish Government war planes have been brought down by Italian planes and Italian anti-aircraft batteries fighting for the Insurgents in Spain.
DISCUSSIONS of American industrial leaders at the ninth Boston Conference on Distribution, to be held tomorrow and on Tuesday, will be broadcast through Station W1XAL, Boston, on 11.79 megacycles.

Mayor La Guardia, John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, and Dr. Nathan B. Van Etten, speaker of the house of delegates of the American Medical Association, will speak on Wednesday at 1 P. M. at exercises marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of compulsory milk pasteurization in this city.

Miss Catherine Weatherby Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Abercrombie Taylor of Chestnut Hill, was married this morning to T. Gihon Jordan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Jordan Jr. of Ventnor, N. J., in Holy Cross Church, Mount Airy.

The Federal Housing Administration reports that during the three years in which the insured mortgage system has been in effect the three - Middle Atlantic States of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania have taken 20 per cent of the total volume of mortgages accepted for insurance. This figure is based on the transactions closed on June 30, 1937.

In celebra tion of the "Day of German Folkdom," which is being observed today and tomorrow for the purpose of consolidating the 30,000,000 Germans of foreign citizenship scattered over the world, the Voelkischer Beobachter published today a remarkable article that in diplomatic quarters was interpreted as nothing less than a threat of military action against Lithuania.

Mrs. Reinhard Siedenberg of the Greenwich Garden Club has been chosen as general chairman of the twenty-sixth annual flower show of the Westchester and Fairfield Horticultural Society and the Garden Clubs of Greenwich and Rye, to be held at the State Armory here on Sept. 28, 29 and 30.

THIS is the second of a series of volumes designed to develop an appreciation in children of the phenomena of life which are accepted so naturally and which, in analysis, are so far from the commonplace.

The need for certifying appraisers and uniform appraisal reports will be among the questions discussed at the third annual convention of the Society of Residential Appraisers at the Biltmore Hotel, Los Angeles, Calif., on Oct, 7, announces H. O. Walther, president. New officers and governors for the coming year will be elected. More than 200 appraisers are expected to attend.
The first fatality in the history of the Detroit race track occurred in the fourth race today when Sydney Erwin, 28-year-old jockey from Dallas, Texas, was killed in a spill.
A special train pulled into the Union Station at Washington last Tuesday morning. It brought President Roosevelt back to the capital after eighteen days' absence.
" BACKSTAGE AT THE OPERA," by Rose Heylbut and Aime Gerber, means backstage at the Metropolitan Opera House. The authors of this book have had unusual advantages for their work.

The financial report of Dartmouth College for the year ending June 30, just submitted to the trustees by Halsey C. Edgerton, treasurer, disclosed that $103,936 contributed to the Alumni Fund by 7,942 graduates wiped out a deficit of $79,540 and afforded a balance toward paying off the debt on the rebuilding of Dartmouth Hall.
MANHATTAN KLEBER, FRANCES (Sept. 8). Estate. about $1,000. To Marcus Patty, brother, executor, 147-03 Hanover Ave., Briarwood, L. I.

Torn between political and commercial interests in the Far East Germany is seeking to maintain an attitude of neutrality in the Sino-Japanese conflict which requires as much tight-rope walking as did her neutrality in the Italo-Ethiopian conflict and the League of Nations sanctions campaign.

Miss Kate E. Turner, principal of Bay Ridge High School, Brooklyn, the first woman to be entrusted with such a position in the city and the oldest high school principal in point of service, retired last week and Dr. Hugo Newman, assistant superintendent, retired as of Sept. 1.

The Uptown Chamber of Commerce announces that, after a twoyear campaign, the Madison Avenue ramp to the 138th Street bridge over the Harlem River is now open to two-way traffic, eliminating the former detour to Fifth Avenue by Manhattan-bound traffic.
Mr. and Mrs. William D. Gardner of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Gardner, to Hubert Walter Moseley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert R. Moseley of Crestwood, N. Y.

George J. Anderson, former president of the Consolidation Coal Company of West Virginia, has purchased from Mrs. Catherine W. Siemon the twenty-two-acre estate at New Preston in the town of Washington, Conn., overlooking Lake Waramaug. The property has been owned by the Siemon family for many years and has been extensively improved.

Charles E. Hilton established a record by winning ten first awards at the second day of the annual flower show of the Tuxedo Horticultural Society and the Garden Club of Orange-Dutchess Counties. Mr. Hilton exhibited in the amateur section of the show.

Five appointments to the faculty of Rutgers Preparatory School were announced today by Stanley Shepard Jr., headmaster. R. Blount Ralls. a graduate of Annapolis and the University of Bordeaux, was named master of French and Spanish and Walter G. Petke, a Dartmouth College graduate, master of German and biology.

One of the leading debutante parties of the "little season" on Long Island took place tonight when Mrs. Margaret Emerson of Palm Beach and Cedar Knoll, this place, gave a supper dance to introduce to society her only daughter, Miss Gloria Baker.
North Carolina State's Wolfpack defeated a fighting Davidson eleven tonight, 6 to 2, in the season's opening tilt between two Southern Conference foes.

Football authorities, tuning up for the rapidly approaching college season, eagerly listened to a discussion of the rules at the meeting of the Eastern Association of Intercollegiate Football Officials at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday.

The heated political activity of the past week reached its climax tonight when the backers of Jose Americo de Almeida for the Presidency announced that the campaign would continue as planned. The proposal to put up only one candidate with the backing of all factions apparently has met with failure.

The glories of the golden age of Augustus, which Premier Benito Mussolini said recently was the only age to be compared with the fascist era of today, will go on exhibition Thursday to commemorate the''2,000th anniversary of the birth of Augustus, first of the Caesars.

The marriage of Miss Katharine Pritchard Colt, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Colt of this city, to Reginald Hathaway Johnson Jr. of New York, son of Reginald H. Johnson of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Mrs. Frances Barnard Goodwin, took place here at noon today at the home of the bride's parents.

A view of the stars as they were visible from the Western Front on the night before the Armistice has been arranged for visiting Legionnaires at the Hayden Planetarium, Central Park West and Seventyninth Street, Dr. Roy Chapman Andrews, director of the American Museum of Natural History, announced yesterday.

Miss Ann Van Dugteren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold J. Van Dugteren of Flushing, L. I., was married to Hugh Vincent Alessandroni, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Alessandroni of this city, yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier in West Sixteenth Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Paul Hanas.

With hopes for a record Fall season killed by business declines last month, producers of rugs and carpets are still confident that the coming weeks will bring them a volume of business close to the figures of a year ago.

Further increases in both number and volume of trade are to be anticipated for super-markets in the food trade, but they have already reached a maximum in some sections, notably Los Angeles, and they are unlikely to dominate in food retailing, according to J. G. Ericsson, who, for the past year, has been making a study of food distribution in this country under a fellowship of the University of Commerce in Stockholm, Sweden.

Purchasing of the Spanish Loyalist Government in the United States this year will reach a total of slightly more than $20,000,000, according to information obtained yesterday at the offices of the Hanover Sales Corporation, buying agent here for the Valencia Govefnbent.
The scene is the same as ever at the Assembly this year, for its stately hall in the new League of Nations Palace is not yet ready, and it meets for the last time in the Geneva Electoral Building.
AS the motor car industry begins to swing into production of 1938 automobiles it is putting into operation for the first time new manufacturing facilities costing millions of dollars.
To show two of the dominant trends in home decoration W. J. Sloane have decorated and furnished two model apartments in th Parc Vendome on West Fiftyseventh Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenue.
Stocks weakened and closed lower, losing 1 to 5 points; turnover, 703,370 shares. Second-grade rail bonds lower; United States Government issues and others irregular; transactions, $3,357,600.
AS long as Ireland was in the frenzy of her struggle for independence it was perhaps inevitable that much Irish history written by Irishmen should be distorted by passion and propaganda.

Delivery of 291,000 bushels of cash corn on September contracts, including retenders, threw the market on the Board of Trade into a turmoil today and started general selling by scattered longs which disclosed a lack of the heavy short covering of yesterday, so prices dropped the permissible limit of 8 cents a bushel, closing at the bottom.

THE Mediterranean basin-cradle of civilization and artery of trade-is again the theatre of international drama into which the future of Europe is woven. The continued depredations of "pirate" submarines upon international shipping, which culminated in the Nyon conference and an undeclared "state of war" in this sea of eternal conflict. have again emphasized that the problems of the Mediterranean are the crux of European difficulties.

IN "Oleander River" G. B. Stern has found a theme admirably suited to her versatile gifts as a story-teller. Less ambitious and elaborate than any of the novels of the Matriarch series, this civilized comedy of life in the Mediterranean hills is nevertheless not frothy and inconsequential.

Kenneth McAleenan became the golf champion of the New York Athletic Club when he vanquished Dr. Thomas J. Conte, 1936 titleholder, in the final of the twentyfifth annual tournament today over the Winged Foot G. C. links.

(Figures in parentheses indicate par.) Cherry Valley (72)--Match-play handicap against par, Class A: C. W. Ulsh, 1 down: J. C. Donaldson, 2 down; F. B. Hamlin, 2 down. Class B: B. F. Hogan, 4 down; K. Lord, 5 down; J. S. Johnston, 5 down.

ARTURO TOSCANINI'S ten radio concerts, in which he will conduct an eighty-piece symphony orchestra specially organized by the National Broadcasting Company, will be presented as a Yuletide gift to the radio audience, with the opening broadcast scheduled for Christmas night from 9 to 10:30 o'clock over WEAF's coast-to-coast network.

The Garden Club of Mount Vernon, N. Y., meets tomorrow at 8 P. M. in Washington Junior High School for a lecture by Patrick McKenna of the New York Botanical Garden on "Selection and Culture of Roses." The club's flower show at the high school gymnasium closes tonight. On Wednesday the club will visit by invitation the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Carll Tucker in Mount Kisco.

THE American Minister had been obliged to go down into the Province of Hainaut, and on the way back to Brussels the road passed near to the "ugly mound at Waterloo," looming in the twilight with the lion just visible in silhouette against the dull sky.

WHEN Mabel Dodge was nearing her destination on her trek to the Southwest twenty years ago, she suddenly decided, at a way station, to forsake the train. Snatching up her purse and her fur coat, she left behind on the seat, she says, The New Republic, The Atlantic Monthly and the Mercure de France.

Bronx detectives are working diligently and Bronx patrolmen are on guard to solve the mystery of the purloined manhole covers. For the last eight months some one has been stealing manhole covers, each of which weigh 175 pounds. The motive, so far, has been unfathomed.
ONE reiterated point in our recent correspondence forum debate on abstract art stirred this department's deep interest and gave rise to a queer sort of feeling of- premonitory dismay.

Robert V. McKim obtained a divorce here yesterday from Mrs. Lillian Stokes Bostwick McKim on ground of cruelty. An agreement coveredcustody of their three children. They were married in New York City on Sept. 18, 1928.

Searches of houses took place in numerous localities in France yesterday as police followed up arrests made Thursday of four members of a secret society called "Hooded Men," which is the French counterpart of the Ku Klux Klan.

FOLLOWING experience gained from numerous successful long-distance flights over water and land, the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation has completed plans to modify one of its most formidable military planes for private and commercial use as an aerial yacht, according to C. A. Van Dusen, vice president of the corporation.

Edgar Conway Felton, a retired industrialist who was on the directorate of the Pennsylvania Railroad and who served for twenty years as president of the Pennsylvania Steel Company, died at his home in Haverford today after a brief illness. He was in his eightieth year.
Three Autumn flower shows will feature the social activities in Westchester. The first one will be staged by the Garden Club of New Rochelle in the public library here on Tuesday and Wednesday. Mrs.

A week ago the Italo-German boycott of the Nyon parley, sponsored by Mussolini, was being hailed in Italy as a brilliant diplomatic manoeuvre. His refusal to have an Italian sit at the board with Russia was regarded as the reason for the BritishFrench decision to bar the Soviet from participation in the antipirate patrol of the Mediterranean; and that was looked on as a first-class victory.

If the Democratic Senators who successfully opposed President Roosevelt's legislative program during the past session of Congress thought he had "learned his lesson" after defeat of the court plan, they have by this time probably revised their estimates.

Yvon Delbos, French Foreign Minister, gave a warning today in the Assembly of the League of Nations to the practical effect that should Italy answer the Nyon arrangement by sending either arms or reinforcements to General Francisco Franco she runs the risk of relieving France and others from nonintervention and threatens to break the European balance.
Miss Harriet M. Dewey, who had been associated with Chicago newspapers for sixtyfour years before her 'retirement five years ago, died here today at the age of 93.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va.--Of interest here is the prospect of the opening, in two weeks, of Kate's Mountain Crest Inn, a sky drive for motorists to enjoy on Fall days.

Sixty-seven of the 350 men who were associated with The Stars and Stripes, the A. E. F. newspaper that was published in Paris during the World War, attended a reunion dinner last night at the Hotel McAlpin.

THE death of Thomas Garrigue Masaryk at Prague last Tuesday removed a figure whose face has been familiar to philatelists for seventeen years. Approximately fifty of his country's stamps have carried his portrait, and it is expected that memorial postal paper will appear shortly.

Six huge conflagrations were started in Yangtzepoo, several on foreign-owned properties, and one Chinese Curtiss Hawk plane was shot down and the pilot killed during a series of six Chinese air raids between 6:30 P. M. Saturday and 12:30 A. M. Sunday.

Several theatre parties already have been arranged for this Autumn to further the maintenance of various philanthropic agencies. The performance of the new Gilbert Miller production "French Without Tears" on the on the night of Oct. 7 at Henry Miller's Theatre.

Johnny Hutchinson of Philadelphia outpointed Willie Davis of Mexico in the ten-round main event at the Rockland Palace last night before a crowd of 2,000. Hutchinson weighed 128 3/4 and Davis 133 1/2.
With the stock markets here closed, weekend loans ??re plentiful today at half of 1 per cent; three-month bills were steady at seventeen-thirty-seconds of 1 per cent.

The marriage of Miss Frances Louise Hitch, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Emmet Francis Hitch of Wilmington, Del., to Harcourt Crandall Vernon. son of Mrs. Frederick F. Vernon of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Vernon, took place here yesterday morning in Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Benjamin M. Johns of Wilmington.
ARRYING the completed score for three movements of his new symphony with him, plus sketches for a finale, Howard Hanson has started motoring back East.

Construction and modernization of industrial plants in the United States are proceeding this year at the fastest pace since 1929 and may. in view of the numerous refinements to machinery and processes made in recent years, represent the largest addition to the nation's manufacturing capacity at any time since the World War.
To the Music Editor: Mr. Bawden's second letter of Sept. 5 has so confused the issue of his first letter of Aug. 8 that I am prompted to the following comments. To clarify the issue I shall

WILLIAM BLACKSTONE, a Cambridge University graduate, liked to be alone with his books and with nature. So, at the earliest convenient moment, he moved from his home in Weymouth, Mass., and bought himself a couple of lonely hills overlooking a harbor farther north.

With meat prices holding high and no break in sight, the market's offerings in substitutes rich in proteins are of special interest to the housewife. Eggs, cheese, poultry, clams, and sundry cuts of meats not ordinarily used in most households can be served in infinite variety and at a great saving if the menu-planner is willing to go to a little extra trouble in trying out unusual dishes.

Believing that existing State laws are inadequate to cope with presentday sex offenders, law enforcement officials and citizens' groups in Westchester County outlined campaigns today to obtain reforms in the statutes. They also hope to curb the circulation of "lascivious motion pictures and publications" by arousing public opinion against them.

CZECHOSLOVAKIA has just issued a stamp to mark the 150th anniversary of the birth of Johannes E. Purkinje. He was a well-known scientist and gained fame as a teacher of new methods to physicians. He died in 1869.

To the Drama Editor: I think it important that some further illumination be cast on the subject of tryouts, discussed recently by Melville Burke. With all deference to Mr. Burke, it must be pointed out that what he has to say does not present by any means a comprehensive view of the situation In the Summer tryout field.
First Title Bout--Marcel Thil, France, International Boxing Union middleweight champion, vs. Fred Apostoli, San Francisco.

Glamorous large handbags tha the Paris designers showed with their new clothes are just beginning to appear in the New York shops which go in heavily for importing. Beautiful leathers, soft suedes and antelopes have been used. One big pannier bag is made of two large, separate sacs that tie at the top. They have zipper openings at the under sides.
NOT once nor twice have dying Englishmen rendered the homage of their hearts to the realm that old John of Gaunt revered as the royal throne of kings, this other Eden, demi-paradise.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-With many of the Summer visitors leaving for their homes, many more are arriving here for the business sessions of a series of national conventions which started last week and continue until the end of the year.

Veterans are coming to their convention with more in their duffle bags and more extra equipment than War-time regulations allow. The Los Angeles delegation, campaigning for the next convention, is bringing 30,000 oranges, police band and a police motorcycle drill squad.

The Legion convention will bring together nearly 20,000 veterans of the First Division in the biggest reunion that famous fighting unit has ever held. Members of the American Legion, the veterans, who are organized as the Society of the First Division, A. E. F., have arranged their own special program, including a day at Governors Island, where units of the present First Division are quartered.

Members of the Yaddo music group, who study and play their own compositions as well as those of other American composers, are "rendering an accounting" this week-end by presenting four programs of modern music.
A couple of old friends get together once or twice a year to make sure the peacefully negotiated boundaryline between the United States and Canada stays put.

ALL weather always brings an increased demand for meat and fish, cheese and eggs, rice, spaghetti, beans and renewed alertness to the potency of herb and spice, the onion, green leaves of celery, pan and kettle browning and various other devices for enriching the flavor of the main-course foods.

Business "stepped up" considerably last week throughout the New York wholesale market, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers.

More than a fifth of the total gold imports into the United States during the week ended on Sept. 10 were from Japan, the combined value of Tokyo's refined bullion shipments totaling $5,815,460, according to the weekly statement of the Department of Commerce on gold and silver movements.
AFTER spending a year on the island of Ischia and collaborating with his wife on the story of their stay there in a book called "Island in the Sun," Geoffrey Bret Harte is now in the Lofoten Islands,
Contracts have been awarded on textile supplies for the army at the local quartermaster depot as follows:

When Frederic F. Van de water, who has a home here, wrote his book, "A Home in the Country," he included "Harry, the hired man" as one of the characters. Harry was portrayed as going barefoot in the Summer.

Behind this week's fall in the exchange value of the franc lies the incontestable fact that neither French capital nor French labor has responded to appeals of the Government and put its back into restoring production to the level needed to assure solvency.
The designs of Great Britain's new warships are severely criticized by Captain Bernard Acworth, retired submarine commander, in a sensational book, "Britain in Danger," just published.
Sixtysix airplanes from the aircraft carrier Ranger flew over Lima today to the city's airport to entertain delegates to the Inter-American Aviation Conference.

Rain caused postponement of six of the eight first-round games scheduled today in the amateur world series of the American Baseball Congress. Battle Creek's two entries emerged victorious in the only contests played.

Managua rice speculators lost heavily and the price of rice fell when 5,000 sacks purchased from the United States by the Government arrived here today. President Anastasio Somoza announced that the rice would be sold to the public at cost.

Bronx Legionnaires and champion baseball teams of the motion-picture industry in New York City paraded yesterday and played before more than 2,000. spectators at the Polo Grounds in a charity benefit pageant for the House of Calvary Hospital for Incurable Cancer Cases.

The United Hospital Fund of New York will share in the proceeds of the exhibition of the Robert L. Ripley "Curioddities," which opens tomorrow for a three-week view at the R. H. Macy Co. store, Broadway at Thirty-fourth Street.
GERMANY has reissued the Munich Races Sheet of last year with a new surcharge. The original sheet carried a single 42 pfennig (brown) stamp picturing several race horses.

Starting off the last major polo event of the season, Winston Guest's Templeton riders took the first step today in defense of the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup, defeating Aurora in the first match of the high-goal handicap event on Hitchcock Field, 16 to 7.

Andrew McSorley and his wife, Doris, have arrived at the State Teachers College here intent on demonstrating that it is possible to travel to college in a trailer, live and study in it and depart in it with degrees won.

Funeral services for the Rev. Lewis Nichols, since 1934 a member of the staff of Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street, who died Friday evening at his home in the Trinity Clergy House, 29 Munroe Place, Brooklyn, will be held at 10 A. M. tomorrow at Trinity Church.

Miss Lucetta Plum, daughter of Mrs. William Terhune Plum of Wilberlu Fam, Locust, N. J., and the late Mr. Plum, as married in St. George's-by-the-River here today to Lester Butler Churchill Jr., son of Mrs. Lester Butler Churchill of this place, and the late Mr. Churchill.

The marriage of Miss Edith Ruth Koewing, niece of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney M. Kempe of East Orange, to William Frederick Nixon, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Nixon of Newnan, Ga., took place this afternoon in Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church.

A sensational shot on the fifteenth or "hill" hole at Canterbury gave Slammin' Sam Snead from White. Sulphur Springs, W. Va., a one-stroke edge over the field at the halfway mark in the thirty-seventh annual Western open golf championship today.

Mrs. Grace Morrison Poole, former president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, now dean of Stoneleigh College, Rye Beach, N. H., will be married to Dr. Henry Gilbert Reynolds of Paducah, Ky., on Sept. 29.
The East Orange High School eleven scored a 6-to-0 victory over Cranford High today in the opening game of the season for both teams.

THE obvious temptation would be to call him a strong, silent man-for if ever there was a fellow who sheers off from interviewers as though their papers were ominous death writs and their pencils were poison pens, that man is Henry Hathaway.

Lack of nearby support for secondary and convertible corporation bonds forced prices in those issues sharply lower yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The movement, which carried numerous loans to new low marks for the year or longer, developed on only a meager sales volume.

John J. Kanavy, 33 years old, a plumber of 189 Washington Avenue, Mineola, was killed tonight when his car was in a collision with a truck on Jericho Turnpike. Mr. Kanavy's car sidewiped the truck, coming in the opposite direction, and skidded into a ditch, it was said.
A request for ammunition, indicating he was stalking big game atop towering Shiva Temple, came today from Dr. Harold E. Anthony, mammalogy curator of the American Museum of Natural History.

Miss Pauline Estelle Stanley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Stanley of this place, was married this afternoon at her parent's home to Cameron Earl Ogden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold Earl Ogden of Upper Montclair by the Rev.
All four championships at stake in the third annual New Brunswick Horse Show, held on the grounds of the New Jersey State College of Agriculture today, were captured by New Jersey exhibitors.

The result of the primary election on Thursday has made clear to everybody that which was apparent before. That is that Mayor La Guardia has a tremendous popular following and that it will be difficult, if not impossible, for former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney, who won the Democratic nomination, to defeat him for reelection.
WITH a dramatic flair for showmanship and patriotism, broadcasters throughout the world are short-waving ethereal "flags" to identify themselves in lands across the seas.

Choosing a neighborhood in which to buy a home is a matter that should receive as careful thought as the qualities of the house itself, points out David Minkin of the building firm of Minkin Osias, developers of a residential community at Kings Highway and Fiftysecond Street near Utica Avenue, in the- lower Flatbush. section of Brooklyn.
Ralph R. Leffler, city engineer, proposed today that Chicago build an airport on the bottom of Lake Michigan 20 feet below the present surface of the water and 21.4 square miles in area.
The Athletics broke even in an American League double - header with the Tigers today. The Athletics lost the first game, 5 to 2, then came back to take the second contest 5 to 4.

The Tarrytown estate of the late Henry Ollesheimer, president of the Metropolitan Bank during the sixteen years of its existence from 1905 until 1921, when it was absorbed by the Chase National Bank of this city, will be sold at auction on the premises next Saturday afternoon by Major William Kennelly.
Nanking thinks Japan's "big push" has begun, and military headquarters feel that China's armies at Shanghai are facing the supreme test. A terrific assault by the Japanese forces is now going on.

With the return of five cruisers to the Atlantic City Tuna Club, a record catch of 252 tuna, prized game fish, was announced today. The catch was all made in a day, totaling 7,000 pounds and including specimens running close to 90 pounds.

A wartime corporal in the line-smashing Thirtieth Division, Elmer C. Duncan, has been appointed chief of the United States Building Guard. With 800 District of Columbia guards under him, he directs the protection of 125 government buildings in Washington for which the National Park Service of the Department of the Interior is custodian.

The new passenger ship Nieuw Amsterdam, which is under construction in Rotterdam for the Holland-America Line, will be equipped with twenty-two aluminum lifeboats capable of carrying 1,946 persons, according to information received by the New York office of the line.
William L. Durham, an architect, died in Hahnemann Hospital today, four days after undergoing an operation. He was 56 years old and his home was in Narberth, a suburb.

Secretary Wallace approved today regulations under the new sugar legislation to control entry of sugar into the continental United States. The regulations prohibit entry of sugar or liquid sugar except through customs ports of entry.

FALL trade disclosed much brighter spots here and there through the country last week, but the general appearance was still one of spottiness. Retail volume in the Southwestand deep South recorded the best increases over a year ago, according to reports, but in other areas such as New England and Ohio Valley industrial centers, sales continued to lag below expectations.

Simultaneously with the setting up of Franco-British naval cooperation in the Mediterranean for the suppression of "piracy," Leslie Hore-Belisha, the British Secretary of State for War, has been attending the French Army manoeuvers in Normandy, and yesterday at their close he declared enthusiastically, "This army can never be beaten. It will never be beaten."
New York University's football squad motored to West Point from Lake Sebago today and played an informal practice game with Army at Michie Stadium.

The silver anniversary of the Altar Society of Our Lady of Refuge Church, Brooklyn, will be celebrated in connection with the organization's annual Autumn bridge party, tea and fashion show, which will be held here on Oct. 16 at the Plaza. The Very Rev. Francis P.
To select a Pacific Coast Conference champion at this stage of the game is just as simple as picking the winner of the Kentucky Derby to be run next Spring.

A taxicab operator testified today that Mayor Daniel J. Shields of Johnstown paid him $1,466 in cash as rental for taxicabs and cars used by city policemen during the strike last Summer at the Bethlehem steel mills.

The Terry-Holden expedition, headed by Dr. W. H. Holden of the American Museum of Natural History, launched today upon a six months' trek into British Guiana jungle country in search of scientific information.

The marriage of Miss Susanne Fisher, Metropolitan Opera Company singer, and Clifford Menz Jr., of New York and St. Paul, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Menz Sr. of St. Paul, was solemnized tonight in the home of the bridegroom's parents with the Rev. Paul Grove, pastor of the Fairmount Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, officiating.

THE Boston Symphony Orchestra enters its fifty-seventh season in Symphony Hall, Oct. 8. This will be Serge Koussevitzky's fourteenth year as conductor. The new season will include twenty-four pairs of concerts on Friday afternoons and Saturday evenings, and a double series of six Monday evenings and six Tuesday afternoon concerts.

THE twenty papers brought together here were first printed in The Colophon and have more or less (and occasionally nothing) to do with the literary debuts of their authors. The book might not too frivolously have been called "Twenty Years After,"

ONCE more the streets of New York will see the splash of color of uniformed men. This week brings here the convention of the American Legion. Hundreds and thousands of legionnaires, most of them wearing uniforms of one type or another, will trickle through the railroad terminals or roll up to the doors of hotels in dust-covered cars.
While the surge of Fall buying spread in most of the leading centers last week, in some areas retail trade activity continued to lag, although sales generally exceeded last year's volume.

Residential building in the five boroughs of New York City offers a potential l market for $53,431,504 worth of modernization, repair and remodeling work, according to a survey by the Johns-Manville staistical research department, based on figures recently compiled by the United States Government in a national housing study.
IF Finland can produce another novel as good as "Katrina" and will send it to America (though this one, it so happens, was written here), let us send back the war debt.

Miss Gertrude Katherine Maxfield, daughter of Thomas Oakes Maxfield of Bloomfield, was married to Captain Paul Dwight Sherman, U. S. M. C., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Sherman of Melrose, Pa., this afternoon at the home of the bride's father.

The world's biggest parade-the annual march of the American Legion-will flow up Fifth Avenue Tuesday from early in the morning into and through the night while the-biggest crowd ever to see the World War veterans in their annual jamboree looks on from office windows, roof tops and the sidewalks of New York.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, Mrs. Caroline O'Day, Representative-atlarge; Mayor John Boyd Thacher of Albany and Former lieutenant Governor Thomas F. Conway of Plattsburgh are the only persons definitely selected so far for nomination for delegates-at-large to the constitutional convention at the meeting of the Democratic State Committee at Albany on Friday.

Turpentine firm. 30 3/4c sales, 104 barrels; receipts, 499 barrels; shipments, 1,562 barrels; stock, 39,480 barreis Resin firms sales, 501; receipts, 1,925; shipments, 3,621; stock, 63,568. Quote: B and D, $7.50; E, F, G, H, I and K $7 92 1/3; M, $8; N. $8.05; WG. $8.25; WW and X, $8.67 1/2.

Award of fifteen fellowships for a year's graduate study of traffic and highway subjects was announced today by the Bureau for Street Traffic Research of Harvard University. Each man will receive $1,200 plus $200 for travel and field investigation.

Scoring almost at will, Clemson's Tigers routed the Presbyterian College eleven today, 46 to 0. A fast and hard-charging Clemson line and a superior backfield ripped the Blue Stockings to shreds and passes were completed whenever they were needed.

Mlle. Jadwiga Jedrzejowska, Polish tennis star who arrived today for the Pacific Southwest tournament, reported a foot injury suffered on the train last night may keep her from continuing her American campaign.

Today is the eighth anniversary of the peak of the bull market of the late '20's in Wall Street. There is little but memories to remind the financial district of that era of sensational price rises, and it is almost a sacred date--Sept. 19--to those who have carried over from the 1928-29 boom.
The number of girls who will be introduced to society here this Winter has reached seventy-three. There undoubtedly will be others who will make their debuts at the Bachelors' Cotillion.
AHRENS--Mr. and Mrs. Milton S. (nee Beatrice E. Sussman), a son, Sept. 18, at Mount Vernon Hospital. COOK--Mr. and Mrs. Lewis G., announce birth of a son, Sept. 16, 1937, at Polyclinic Hospital.

Solely for the purpose of heartening the hard - fighting Chinese troops, Mme. Chiang Kai-shek today visited the extreme front lines in the Chapei and North Station sectors, chatting with soldiers and distributing cigarettes and sweetmeats.
Six thousand regular army troops and their fighting machines came to this modern military training plant today to begin two weeks of practical experience in the science of war.

For the first time since their abortive conversations in Venice in June, 1934, Premier Benito Mussolini and Chancellor Adolf Hitler will again meet face to face when Il Duce steps on German soil at Munich next weekend.
With fourth place at stake, the Indians put on a six-run rally in the eighth today to gain a 7-6 victory over the Red Sox and take over their first division berth.

Henry T. Sloane, senior director and former treasurer of W. J. Sloane, household furnishings, Forty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue, New York, died here today of pneumonia after a month's illness. He would have been 92 years old on Dec. 1.

If the State does not capitulate and consent to share in the cost of building a new $600,000 viaduct across the Bronx River Valley, between Yonkers and Mount Vernon at Fleetwood, Westchester County officials may close the existing viaduct and sever the Cross County mute Parkway into halves.
A high wind again prevented Greyhound, 5-year-old trotter, from making an assault today on the world's trotting record for one mile. The existing mark of 1:56 3/4 was set by Peter Manning in 1922.

Two events of this week indicate the difficulty the United States has in keeping to the path of isolation: (1) President Roosevelt's ban on the transport of arms to the Orient on government-owned ships.

Up to two years ago, C. Howard Nash, aged 60, had never climbed a mountain. In less than six months, he says, he has ascended forty-eight major Adirondack and Catskill peaks, all over 4,000 feet in height.

The fifth annual National Socialist Congress was scarcely distinguishable from its predecessors. In the picturesque medieval setting of Nuremberg there was the same gorgeous spectacle of massed men and banners, the same resoundiug claims of miracles achieved,
Leon Trotsky declared tonight he had been informed that his former secretary, Erwin Wolff, 34 years old, had been arrested in Spain by Russian secret police agents.
Corwin Black of New York obtained a divorce today from Mrs. Julia Morrison Black. An agreement provides for a $200 month payment until Mrs. Black remarries.
A new Wallach's store at 253 Broadway, at Murray Street, occupying 7,500 square feet of space on the main floor of the Paragon Building, will be opened tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.
EIGHTEEN stations are now licensed in the United States to transmit television images experimentally, according to the latest figures of the Federal Communications Commission.
With a record of 716 youths enrolled from fifty States and foreign countries, Phillips Andover Academy this week began its 160th year, the fifth under Claude M. Fuess as head master.
Mlle. Stanislawa Walasiewicz (Stella Walsh) today claimed three new world records for women track and field athletes.

The home and gardens of Miss Miriam Walker here will be the setting for a Georgian tea party on Wednesday in the interests of the preservation of Stratford Hall, ancestral home of the Lees in Virginia. The event has been arranged under the auspices of a Connecticut committee associated with the Lee Memorial Foundation, Inc., of which Mrs. Charles D. Lanier of Greenwich is president.

THE fertile field of Italian opera exhumations has been fruitful enough this year, Central and Southern Italy were first, with "L'Incoronazione di Poppea" at Florence, "L'Olimpiade" at Jesi, "I Guarany" at Rome and "II Giuramento". at Altamura.

Best of 850 dogs entered in the ninth annual all-breed show of the Somerset Hills Kennel Club held on the Fair Grounds today was the Scottish terrier bitch Heather Gloria, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Stalter of Hohokus, N. J., and handled in the ring by Phil Prentice.

SINCE the Summer of 1936, when twenty-nine teachers took a course in "traffic safety and automobile operation" at Pennsylvania State College--the first such course for teachers to include classroom instruction and practical road work in driving--the movement for scientific training of automobile operators has gained rapidly.

IF the reviewers may be taken at their printed word, George Prentice has won the first personal triumph of the new acting year. Not a player likely to alienate many of Maurice Evans's devotees nor one who may be expected to pioneer a trend, Prentice has nevertheless enjoyed a spotlight-basking denied to some of the mighty.

Transoceanic airplane flights bring new worries to Agriculture Department officials guarding against the importation of new agricultural pests. Avery S. Hoyt, assistant chief of the Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine, said plans already had been laid to inspect ocean fliers, their passengers and planes to make certain new cropdestroying insects do not land on our shores.

WINDOW ROCK is Arizona's newest community and because its residents can sit on their front porches and hurl a rock into the State of New Mexico, it is better known to the people of the western section of that State.

Presiding Judge of the United States Customs Court Charles P. McClelland and Mrs. McClelland gave a reception this afternoon at Sussex Hall, their home here, to celebrate the fifty-eighth anniversary of their marriage.

THESE rather rhetorical letters in rhymed couplets are addressed to Robert Frost, to Charles Townsend Copeland, to James B. Munn (to whom, incidentally, the book is dedicated as "spiritual patron of the art of poetry"), to Peyton Randolph Campbell, to Bernard De Voto, to the poet's son, and to Queen Nefertiti.

The Constitution of the United States, especially as the guarantee of religious freedom, was praised by rabbis in Constitution Week sermons yesterday. Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein, at the West Side Institutional Synagogue, 122 West Seventy-sixth Street, expressed gratitude to the Supreme Court for guarding the Constitution.
The Costa Rican Legation nounced today the forthcoming wedding of Miss Maria Eugenia Castro, daughter of Minister Ricardo Castro Beeche, to Oscar Rodriguez of Costa mica.

THIS year may bring to an end the old custom of giving women no voice in the management of contract bridge laws and championships. Some of the women active in bridge affairs voiced a long-felt protest at the 1937 meeting of the American Bridge League's "women's auxiliary,"

Very helpful results toward a wider appreciation of a well designed small home have been achieved by the twenty-two small home planning conferences which have recently been held under the auspices of the Federal Housing Administration in various cities throughout the country.
As a historian of ancient musical instruments Canon Galpin has long enjoyed an enviable reputation. In the present volume he presents the history of contemporary European instruments of music.

AN unusual show of the early Autumn has opened at the Frederick Frazier.Galleries, to continue throughout October. Some thirty small paintings by Eastman Johnson have been assembled, revealing that mid-nineteenth century artist's rather protean development during the years from 1851 to the late Eighties.

TOKYO. WITHIN a week I have been in Peiping and Tokyo. The difference in atmosphere between the two cities is a measure of the difference in the attitude of the Chinese and Japanese people toward the war in which they are engaged. It is a measure, too, of the gulf that separates them.

In the emergency caused by the outbreak of poliomyelitis, Chicago was confronted with the problem of caring for the educational needs of children during the period of the enforced closing of the schools.
Enos Slaughter, Columbus Red Birds' young outfielder, is the new American Association batting champion.

Miss SaraRosalie Wheeler, daughter of Mrs. S. Maguire Wheeler of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday morning in Our Lady of Martyrs Church; Forest Hills, to John Edward Hessian, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Hessian, also of Forest Hills.

The greatest fistic carnival in all the long history of boxing here is scheduled for Thursday night at the Polo Grounds, under the direction of the Twentieth Century S. C. and its promoter, Mike Jacobs.

Most people up North probably thought the Ku Klux Klan was dead until the spotlight was thrown on it by the controversy over Senator Hugo L. Black's appointment to the Supreme Court of the United States. It was-almost but not quite.

The marriage or Miss Phoebe Esther Brown, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Lane Brown of this city, to Louis Stannard Baker of Parlin, son of Mrs. James Frederick Baker of Wayland, Mich, and the late Mr. Baker,

TWO books have recently appeared which should make con tributions toward safety on the highway. One is "Youth at the Wheel," by John J. Floherty; the other, "Drive and Live," by James A. Fitzgerald, Carl A. Hoffman and John R. Bayston, working in collaboration.

IN a well-considered grouping of antiques, the choice of authentic accessories is coming to be as important as the furniture itself. The lover of antiques, while appreciating to the full the excellence of individual pieces, now seeks in addition a certain unity in design and craftsmanship when grouping them.

Priestley, happy in the knowledge that his "Time and the Conways" already has established itself as the new season's outstanding success, is looking forward even more eagerly to the production of "I Have Been Here Before" on which the author himself sets more store than on any other of his works.

WRITERS on the sea taught us long ago that ships have personalities. Indeed, isn't there a Conrad story of a ship that would fail to answer the helm at critical moments so that she killed a seaman, or brought down some of her spars on every voyage, thus earning for herself the name of being a "killer"? Hence.

Ceferino Garcia, making his next to final training appearance before he climbs through the ropes to meet Barney Ross for the welterweight title next Thursday night, worked impressively in six rounds of sparring today.

The engagement of Miss Caroline Baury de Bellerive Jansen, daughter of Lieut. Col. Thomas E. Jansen, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Jansen of this place, to William Adams Pope, son of Mrs. Walter F. Pope of Boston, and Sandwich, Mass., and the late Mr. Pope, has been announced by her parents.
In a setting of gladioluses, irises, palms and ferns, Miss Frances Isabel Tomes was married to Paul Sanford Lee Seward at the old Stockbridge Congregational Church this afternoon.

Prizes, were awarded last week to ten boys and girls of the Educational Alliance gardening clubs at the annual harvest festival in the children's garden in Seward Park, in the lower East Side. The awards were for the best-kept plots and finest produce.
Teddy, a shepherd dog, was dead today, apparently the victim of a broken heart. He followed in, death his life-long companion, a horse owned by Fred McNulty.

A new football season comes from behind the scenes and steps into the spotlight Saturday. Here and there throughout the country various teams have already left the practice fields and stepped into actual competition, and New York has already had an appetizer in the form of the Giants-All-Stars game.

Announcement of the opening of new sections in three developments for improvement with homes marked the realty activities in New Jersey last week. In addition, many sales were made of homes in completed sections of other developments.

The first four teams in yesterday's qualifying round were still in the running tonight as the first and second rounds of the Nassau Country Club's annual best-ball invitation golf tournament were concluded. Charles R. Shelden, the Siwanoy ace, and his partner, Harold W. Matzinger of Indian Creek, the medalists, won their first-round encounter rather handily but were pressed to the home green in the afternoon.
ANY one picking up a book entitled "The Third Morality" will naturally wonder even before he guesses what the third one is, what the first two--now presumably moribund-are.

Senator Edward R. Burke of Nebraska, one of the Democratic leaders in the Senate opposition to revision of the Supreme Court, today accepted as a challenge the President's Constitution Day message that he would continue the fight for the objectives sought in his court reorganization program.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Mackey of this city have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Ethel Marie Mackey, to Joseph Andrew Evans of Lawrence, Mass., which took place here on Thursday in Holy Trinity Church, Arlington.

CHARLES CHAPLIN'S announcement last week that he would never again appear on the screen as the pantomimic little tramp with the derby hat, baggy trousers, oversized shoes and flexible cane was sudden but scarcely surprising.
The steamer Liguria sailed from here tonight carrying several thousand Italian troops. Officials said they were bound for the Italian North African colony of Tripoli.

A marked increase in Manhattan real estate sales during the first eight months- of 1937 as compared with the same period last year was noted in the monthly analysis of open-market trading for the borough made public yesterday by the Real Estate Board of New York.

The Connecticut Committee for the preservation of Stratford Hall, ancestral home of the Lees in Virginia will hold a Georgian tea party on Thursday at the house and garden of Miss Miriam Walker in New Canaan.

Franz Hanawald, 36 years old, accused of abducting a 63-yearold wine importer and keeping him chained for eight hours in a manmade cave while he haggled vainly over ransom terms, was held today for the grand jury on a kidnapping charge.

Secretary Ickes, whose department will be charged with the administration of the Wagner-Steagall Act, today urged all States and municipalities which have not already done so to establish local housing authorities so that they may participate in the benefits of the national housing program under the act.
DESPITE all the heavy competition in other fields of endeavor, the art of being William Powell is still unique in the world. Whether his vehicle is "The Great Ziegfeld" or "My Man Godfrey,"
The Dollar liner President Hoover, when she arrived here Wednesday, drew hundreds to view the scars of her bombing at Shanghai. Dollar officials estimated repair costs at $100,000.

Lambert Murphy, 23-year-old son of Ray D. Murphy, vice president and actuary of the Equitable Life Assurance Company, ended his life with a rifle bullet about 8 o'clock this morning in the Murphy home at 28 Godfrey Road, Montclair.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in relatively small volume. Virtually all the calls were for future months. Prepayments thus far ordered for September now aggregate $153,174,000, compared with $129,660,000 last month and with $195,048,000 in September, 1936, for the corresponding weeks.

The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Sept. 16: LIEUTENANTS Coffin. C. E. Jr., to the Tutuila; orders of July 23 modified. Smyth, J. B., Navy Yard, New York, N. Y., to the Melville, in November.
THE Norman Conquest of Apulia and Sicily does not figure so conspicuously in the histories of Italy as does the Norman conquest of Britain in those of that country. Both were in the eleventh century:

Giving New Yorkers, who had not quite forgotten the sweltering heat of the Summer, a taste of almost ideal weather conditions, the tem perature dropped at 7 A. M. yesterday to 45 degrees, just one point above the low record for the date established in 1875.

Resurgent interest in the still unsettled site for the proposed Jefferson Memorial in Washington, accelerated by the passing of John Russell Pope, architect for the project, portends wide discussion of the matter among women's groups here as the club season advances.

SYDNEY, Australia. THE fact that seventeen ardent film fans made a trek through 650 miles of jungle and swamp on the equatorial edge to see one of his movies, daring crocodiles when swimming rivers, and arriv-.

As Republican leaders worked to get united support for Mayor La Guardia, and supporters of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic nominee for Mayor, sought to end factional differences in that party, the American Labor party went ahead yesterday with arrangements for a meeting in Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening, Sept. 30, at which the Mayor and all other Labor party candidates will receive formal notice of their nomination.
The award of three college scholarships to sons of employes of the Pennsylvania Railroad has been announced by H. A. Enochs, the railroad's chief of personnel.

THOSE persons scattered throughout the United States who are so kind as to follow these desultory and alas! infrequent Italian letters may remember that two years ago we wrote of the novel of Alberto Moravia, "Mistaken Ambitions," that "this book will last, and that its author in time will give us very great things indeed."
