Officially dead and yet alive, is the position in which Joseph Bibeau of Manville finds himself today. Bibeau, who was born in Manville and whom every one thought to be dead, including his parents, drove into Manville yesterday in a car with California registration plates and startled his old acquaintances with clippings, discharges, medals and souvenirs of his world travels.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Goldsborough of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marta L. Goldsborough, to Russell Wetmore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard L. Wetmore of New York.

Miss Muriel Gordon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Holdsworth Gordon of 38 Franklin Place, Flushing, Queens, was married this afternoon in the gardens at Edgewater, the Summer home of her parents here, to Bard Pendleton Rogers, son of Mrs. E. Victor Loew of Tuxedo Park, N. Y., and of the late John Shillito Rogers.

The Citizens Budget Commission called upon the Board of Education yesterday to justify its 1938 budget request of $159,234,144, an increase of $14,745,580, in view of the fact that there has been a "startling decrease in elementary school registration."

IF one had expected to catch him swinging lightly from a chandelier, shooting spit-balls at solemn-faced people or indulging in some other unrighteous prank, one would have been disappointed. It may have been that the day was too hot for such reputed pixyisms.

The marriage of Miss Anne Robison Mackey, daughter of Mrs. Charles L. Mackey of Pleasantville, N. Y., and the late Rev. Mr. Mackey, to John Charles Holme, son of Mrs. John C. Holme of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Holme, took place here yesterday afternoon in St. George's Episcopal Church on Stuyvesant Square.

With a sweeping grand jury investigation into Philadelphia vice and crime scheduled to get under way early next week, it as reported today that evidence has been uncovered that a city official had banked about $128,000 in the last two years.
Berlin's 4,000,000 population is about to experience something that the populations of London and Paris went through during the World Warlife in complete darkness.

PARIS.--Things are not the same in thousands of cafes in Paris and its environs. A governmental decree has put a stop to the operation of slot machines which, during the past two or three years, have done a flourishing business-making millions of francs monthly for owners and operators.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Muriel Mosle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Mosle of this place, formerly of New York, to Dr. Richard G. Lyon of Santa Barbara.

Last week's disturbed stock market alarmed more than just the speculator and the investor. Business and political leaders throughout the country were disquieted. For more was involved than loss to those who had bought stocks: they presumably had taken their risk with their eyes open.

American Federation of Labor unions, in increasing numbers, have begun to attack the National Labor Relations Board as being biased in favor of the Committee for Industrial,Organization and the industrial-union form of organization as against the craft-union set-up. The board denies the charges and points to its decisions in support of its denial.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Vail Burton of this city have announced the betrothal of their daughter, Miss Frances Burton, to the Rev. James Trimble Marshall Jr., son of the Rev. J. T. Marshall of Kensington, Md., and the late Mrs. Marshall.
The Insurgent column driving toward Gijon from the south reported today it had swept another obstacle from its path to the last remaining Government seaport on the Bay of Biscay.

Summer training of the State National Guard was ended at noon today when 1,060 members of the 369th Infantry of Harlem, ' commanded by Colonel John C. Grimley, were mustered in and paid off after a two-week period of training here at Camp Smith, which will be closed tomorrow.

The Nova Scotia Government threatened today to "draft and enforce" regulations governing settlement of labor disputes unless union officers and steel company officials at Sydney could "decide on a general method to be followed in all cases for settling grievances."

The performance of Bizet's "Carmen" at the Hippodrome last night was heard by the largest audience of the Hippodrome Company's season to date, the house being filled almost to capacity. Maru Castagna appeared in the name part. Nina Quartin was the Micaela; Aroldo Lindi, the Don Jose, and Mario Cozzi, the Escamillo.
Brogan, the big brown gelding owned by David Dows, and driven by his son-in-law, C. N. Bliss Jr., won the free-for-all trot and pace today at the Nassau Driving Club meet in three heats.

Assemblyman Harold P. Herman, chairman of the New York State Assembly Real Estate and Mortgage Committee, speaking before the Long Island Real Estate Board last week in Garden City declared that New York State needs a comprehensive revision of its tax structure so as to apply taxes more equitably.

THE dime novel breaks into the news of our time with remarkable frequency, considering that it had its day long ago and supposedly went its way to oblivion. Gone it may be, but its ghost walks the earth, a lively spook. Every month or so a public library rejoices over acquiring a set of, say, "Daring Dicks,"

Former City Treasurer Edmund L. Dolan today was ordered to repay the City of Boston some $171,579 which, a Superior Court judge found, represented "secret and illegal profits" made in purchase of bonds for the city through his Legal Securities Corporation.

Among the thirteen inventions recognized by President Roosevelt's National Resources Committee as having great economic and sociological implications is an application by Dr. W. F. Gericke of the University of California of a method of growing plants without soil.

It will be interesting to observe the progress of Anglo-Italian relations this Fall. Powerful forces are at work with the object of delaying the rapprochement which Premier Neville Chamberlin and Benito Mussolini equally desire.

The United States Maritime Commission this week opened bids for a new liner to replace the Leviathan on the North Atlantic, and all indications are that the low bid, submitted by the Newport News Shibuilding and Drydock Company, will be accepted.

ROSA PONSELLE has not yet signed a contract for the coming Metropolitan Opera season. It was not until a short time before the opening that Miss Ponselle indicated a willingness to return last year. Evidently she again wants more time to consider her course.
THERE is not much to tell of the brief life of Sir Philip Sidney and his heroic death at Zutphen is perhaps better remembered as a romantic legend than for its

Invitations have been issued by Mr. and Mrs. William T. McGeachie of this place for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Ruth McGeachie, to Leroy J. Martin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Hugo Martin, also of Elizabeth. The wedding will take place Oct. 2 at Trinity Episcopal Church, with the Rev. Robert Bull Jr., the rector, officiating.

The annual invitation mixed foursome competition of the Piping Rock Golf Club will open next Friday with the qualifying field limited to three sixteens. Match play will start the following morning With two rounds of eighteen holes scheduled, and the final will be played on Sunday.
Miss Mae King Chandlee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Chandlee of Moylan and Bay Head, N. J., has completed plans for her marriage on Oct. 22 to Wilson Foss 3d, son of Mrs. William K. Yarrow
The following WPA Federal Art Project exhibitions will be on view this week: Post Graduate Hospital, Twentieth Street and Second Avenue, (Surgical Ward), thirty-five children's paintings.

TODAY Music Hall of the Air inaugurates the fifth season of symphonic broadcasts under the direction of Erno Rapee, during which musical works seldom heard on the air will be presented from time to time. A Sibelius festival, comprising the seven symphonies of the Finnish composer, is scheduled to begin early next month, coincidental with Sibelius's seventy-third birthday.

Citing some of the facts regarding the increased chain stores activities recently presented by the National Association of Real Estate Boards, I. Jerome Riker, head of the realty firm bearing his name, says that the chain stores in the metropolitan area are in an exceptionally sound position at the pres??nt time.

After seventy days of undeclared war in China, the power of the Japanese military machine began to be applied last week with increasing effectiveness against the illequipped, conglomerate Chinese armies.

Education of the public to an understanding of the commercial value of roadside attractiveness has supplanted, to a certain degree, the old ambition of women's clubs to relegate to the scrap heap the billboards that mar the rural landscape.

Petals, as heavy as rich satin, open to the sun to show black velvet centers and dark square splotches of contrasting color--the appearance of an Oriental poppy suggests that some painter with his brush must have tried to add to its beauty.
The radiologists of the world met in Chicago last week and in a hundred recondite scientific addresses drove home the enormous progress made in alleviating disease by means of invisible radiations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letters which have been called forth by my comment on the pastoral letter of the Spanish Bishops raise new and serious issues. There are two questions which lie in the background of all the others. One is the attitude of mind toward a great state paper.

Harvard Law School has been a prolific source of aides for the Roosevelt Administration. Outstanding among them has been James McCauley Landis, born in Tokyo thirty-eight years ago, graduated with a Harvard LL. B.

The marriage of Miss Irene Susan Winslow, daughter of Mrs. I. Gillespie Winslow and of Dr. Paul V. Winslow of this city, to John J. Campagna, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Campagna of Riverdaleon-Hudson, took place yesterday afternoon in I'Eglise de Notre Dame, Morningside Drive and 114th Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas J. Brown.

INIATURE automobiles as well as full-scale ones are to have their day in the sun next month. A miniature-automobile show, for the benefit of the Boys Brotherhood Republic, is to be held on the mezzanine of the International Building, Rockefeller Center,
THE Greenwich House Music School, which is entering its twenty-fourth season, is starting a new plan believed as yet untried by a settlement school.

ON LOCATION-Tomorrow evening at the Ritz Theatre.' By Kent Wiley, this one deals with a director, a camera man and Hollywood, the cast including Jack Norworth, Leslie Denison, Virginia Hart, Leonard Doyle, Mollie Burt and Mark Linder.

THE hunting season is on in Hungary, with visiting foreigners following the rare mouflon ram through forest preserves. This specie of wild sheep, imported many years ago from its native habitat in Corsica, is considered a prize trophy.

The 1937 Chandler Medal in chemistry will be awarded to Dr. John Howard Northrop of the Rockefeller Institute in recognition of his "fundamental discoveries concerning bacteria, the constitution. of proteins and the chemistry of digestion," it was announced yesterday by Professor J. Enrique Zanetti of the Columbia University Department of Chemistry.

Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association, wrote yesterday to the Board of Elections, expressing belief that many persons might fail to vote for candidates for the City Council unless the Board took steps to encourage voters to mark their ballots for Council candidates before they went to the voting machines to vote for candidates for other offices.

IT was just a hundred years ago that Carlyle's "French Revolution" was first published. The occurrence of this centenary has revived the well-known story of the destruction of part of the original manuscript.
Annapolis, the home town of Charles Carroll of Carrollton, signer of the Declaration of Independence, held a celebration of the 200th anniversary of his birthday today.

Members of the New York Newspaper Women's Club and their friends and guests will attend a preview cocktail party Wednesday evening from 5 to 7 o'clock at the Old Whalers' bar in the Midston House, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, where the club has headquarters. Proceeds of the event will be added to the fund for assistance of unemployed and invalid women reporters.

Miss Helen Maifarth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugo Maifarth of this city, was married today at the home of her parents to Durant J. Morey, son of Mrs. L. A. Morey of Passaic. Mrs. George E. Gaba was matron of honor for her sister and Lindley Morey was best man. The Rev. Dr.

Shingoro Takaishi, editor of the Tokyo Nichi Nichi and the Osaka Mainichi, will leave for the United States on Oct. 7 as one of three unofficial envoys, who at Premier Prince Fumimero Konoe's request will explain Japan's East Asian policy to the American people.

William Alvin Bowen, lawyer and writer of fairy tales for children, died at his home here today at the age of 60. Associated with the law firm of Flint McKay for twenty-five years, Mr. Bowen achieved major recognition most recently for his work as special master in hearing the claims in the Richfield reorganization suit.

The West Side Tennis Club began the defense of its metropolitan interclub championship yesterday by blanking the Seminole Club, 9-0, on the West Side Club's courts. The match was one of eight conducted in the first round of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's twenty-ninth annual tournament.
The 135th semester of Hunter College will begin tomorrow for more than 7,000 students at the Park Avenue, Lexington Avenue, Bronx and Thirty-second Street buildings.

For all the cries of treason, spying, counter revolutionary plotting and sabotage that the Soviet authorities are raising on all sides as they prosecute their purge, it is probable that Joseph Stalin is more firmly fixed in the saddle than ever before.

Miss Louise J. Anthony, daughter of Mrs. Mark Anthony of Garden City and the late Mr. Anthony, was married to Henry S. Castor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry F. Castor of Philadelphia, here today in the chapel of the Cathedral of the Incarnation by the Rev. John H. Esquirol.

Miss Geraldine Marion Hettema, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Myron Hettema of Angola, Ind., formerly of this city, was married here today to Edwin Alan Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Harris of Sea Cliff. L. I.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete version of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish.

Following a morning of surprising reversals in which two favored teams were eliminated, the only surviving pre-tournament choices, Arthur H. Arnold and Jack Creavy, rallied brilliantly in their quarter-final encounter with E. E. Ketcham and William S. Meany Jr. and advanced to the semi-finals of the first annual member-guest invitation best-ball handicap golf test at the Tamarack Country Club today.

Despite numerous complaints about rising production costs, many manufacturers of national brands in a wide variety of fields are planning to bring out lower-price ranges for 1938, to forestall consumer resistance, offset growing competition from private labels and escape the penalty of price-pegging at levels that cut volume under fair trade contracts, it was learned here during the week.

DURING this season of bird migration another migration not so generally noted is in progress-that of the Monarch (or milkweed) butterflies. These familiar brown and black striped insects gather in great numbers, head for the South and reach their Winter resorts about Nov. 1.

A much larger volume of business was transacted yesterday on the Cotton Exchange than the fivepoint fluctuating range indicated. After making new low records for the year, the list closed a point lower to a point higher than on Friday.
A great great-grandson of Joseph Brandt, Mohawk Indian chieftain who attached himself to the British cause during the Revolutionary War, was barred from a WPA job today as an "alien."
Arrangements have been about completed for the annual field trial meetings of the two leading American retriever specialty organizations, the Labrador Retriever Club and the American Chesapeake Club.

The Grand Dragon of the Pennsylvania Ku Klux Klan announced today at the close of a State convention here that Pennsylvania Klansmen "will support President Roosevelt foursquare no matter what the outcome of the controversy over the appointment of Justice Hugo L. Black
AS a fashioner of strange tales of far-away places Edison Marshall has few equals in the field of light fiction today.

Miss Lenore Overton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Terry Overton of Southampton, L. I., was married here yesterday morning in the Church of the Transfiguration to William Henry Craig Sim, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Sim of Woodhaven, Queens. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harold F. Lemoine, assistant to the rector.

Frustrated in their efforts to capture the Gold Cup classic at Detroit on Labor Day, the two visiting Italian speedboat drivers, Count Theo Rossi and Guido Cattaneo, have entered the eleventh running of the President's Cup in Washington this week, according to George W. Sutton Jr., president of the American Power Boat Association. This event features a regatta Friday, Saturday and Sunday.
Miss Joan Ransom, daughter of Mrs. Philip Cox Ransom of Concord, today was married to Samuel Franklin Engs 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell L. Engs of Darien, Conn., in the garden of the bride's home.

EDWARD J. O'BRIEN, through his annual anthologies of the best short stories of the preceding year, has so notably established himself as a reliable judge in this field that when he turns from the moderns to writers of an earlier day the reader can follow him with confidence, sure that his critical acumen will remain unimpaired.

Among the important topics to be discussed at the forthcoming convention of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York at Niagara Falls, Sept. 30 to Oct. 2, will be suggestions for tapering off the emergency mortgage fore closure moratorium and plans to regulate public policy in regard to deficiency judgments.
Sky Larking broke his leg at the fetlock in the running of the sixtyseventh Champagne Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday and was destroyed within twenty minutes by the track veterinarian.
Over 140,000,000 pounds of steel welding wire were produced during 1936, or enough to. make a strong weld 134,000 miles long, according to estimates made by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

WALLACE BEERY injected a painful note of realism into the script of "Bad Man of Brimstone" the other day when he stumbled and shot himself just above the kneecap with a blank cartridge. It happened when Beery, portraying a bad hombre of the early West,

Natives of the Bronx must have thought they were on the fringe of Shanghai's International Settlement yesterday as Yankee siege guns bombed four White Sox hurlers in the process of taking two games from Jimmy Dykes's team.

Miss Lydia Field Emmet 2d, grand-niece and namesake of Miss Lydia Field Emmet, well-known portrait painter, and a descendant of Philip Hone of diary fame, was married here this afternoon in St. Paul's Cathedral to Lewis Croxton Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Blair Williams

A detective who once played on Notre Dame's football teams used a flying tackle and bullets today to capture Michael Montanaro, 28 years old, described by Police Captain James Ryan as "one of the biggest of the remaining Philadelphia gangsters."

Strong support for the establishment of Summer camps for New York City's underprivileged school children was disclosed last week when the Board of Education empowered Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, to appoint a committee to study the "advisability and feasibility" of free camping facilities.
President Roosevelt was urged yesterday by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, 69 Fifth Avenue, to call upon Associate Justice Hugo L. Black

Wassif Boutrous Ghali Pasha, the Egyptian Foreign Minister, raised today the first voice the League of Nations Assembly has heard against the British proposal to partition Palestine, which the League Council on Thursday authorized the British to continue exploring.

William Lurie of Brooklyn, sixthseeded player in the Eastern New Jersey clay courts singles tennis championship, upset fourth-seeded Morris Adelsberg of Brooklyn, 6--8, 6-2, 12-10, to enter the semi-final round today.

In a twentysix-hour sitting that terminated at 5 o'clock this afternoon the House of Representatives approved about 200 laws before beginning a recess of regular sessions till the first Monday of November.

The Vienna Telegraf published reports tonight from its Berlin correspondent to the effect that the German Propaganda Minister had forbidden publication of President Roosevelt's speech criticizing dictatorships.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes, depreciation and other charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

Contracts amounting to $4,720,576 were awarded by Government agencies in the week ended on Sept. 16, under provisions of the Federal Contracts Act, according to an announcement today by the Department of Labor. Thirteen agencies let ninety-two contracts.

Purchases from Cuba by the United States in the first seven months of this year amounted to $113,163,402 and represented 85.8 per cent of Cuba's total export trade for that period, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Home horticulturists who specialize in dahlias are now pruning and disbudding plants and picking blooms, for with the first cool nights and heavy dews dahlias perk up and begin to flower munificently.

THE American Legion marching into New York this week for its twentieth anniversary convention will be the inspiration for numerous broadcasts with band music and speeches on wave lengths leading to all parts of the nation and overseas.

Miss Ruth Aleta Law, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pierce Law, was married here this evening in the home of her parents to George Herbert Buck of Brooklyn, son of Mrs. Catherine Buck of Ringstead, Iowa, by the Rev. Albert E. Legg, pastor of the Methodist Episcopal Church, Herkimer.

Revisions and innovations in the official journals of women's organizations of the State have been more numerous this season than for several years. New occupants have been named to editorial chairs and important changes made in the appearance and direction of some publications.

After 149 days of continuous occupancy, striking employes of H. Anton Bock Co., Inc., have ended their sit-down in the cigar factory at 1,228 Second Avenue, it became known yesterday. With their claim to the longest sit-down strike undisputed, the strikers filed from the building on Sept. 10 a few hours after Supreme Court Justice Poletti had dismissed on technical grounds a motion by the company to force evacuation of the plant.

Representative Hamilton Fish, Republican of New York, today assailed Senator Joseph F. Guffey, Democrat of Pennsylvania, as a "plain ordinary rubber stamp" and attacked President Roosevelt's New Deal with the assertion that "we are verging on a Fascist or authoritarian State."

Senator Glass today said he had no idea that anything could or would be done by either the President, the Senate or any one else to remove Justice Black from the Supreme Court in the event that allegations that he is or was amember of the Ku Klux Klan were true.
Catholic Young Women's Club-Bus trip to West Point, 10:30 A. M. National Council of Jewish Juniors (Brooklyn Section) - First Fall meeting, Garfield Temple.

A miniature automobile show, in which the exhibits will include autos from three inches to six feet in length, will be held from Oct. 5 through Oct. 12 in the International Building at Rockefeller Center.

Announcement has been made by Albert H. Dalrymple of this place of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Phyllis Dalrymple, to Laurence Brownell Freeburn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Irwin Freeburn, also of Winchester and Marblehead.

H. L. Bowman, defending titleholder, moved nearer another New York Athletic Club tennis singles championship by beating John Flanagan, 6-1, 6-1, in the quarterfinals of the Class A competition yesterday on the club's courts at Travers Island. R. E. Johnston eliminated Paul McHugh, 6--4, 6--4, and William Fallon won from E. R. Donovan by default.

E. L. Ostendorf of Cleveland, president of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers, points out that appraisers are again under pressure to certify excessive estimates of real estate value. This pressure, in many instances, he says, comes from lending institutions competing for mortgages.

De spondent because a vacation trip around the world had failed to restore his health, Waverly P. Waggoner, 48 years old, executive vice president of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company of Los Angeles, killed himself with a shotgun last night in his mother's home in Venice. Calif.

Property of the estate of Elenore J. Mortimer of Tuxedo Park, will be sold at auction on the premises next Saturday, beginning at 11 A.M. under the management of the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc. The auction will comprise furnishings of her residence, Mortmar. Included will be oil paintings, tapestries, and garden furniture.

THE American Legion convention, which officially opens tomorrow, is bringing us several hundred thousand visitors. This is a large bite for even Gargantuan New York to swallow. If ever Father Knickerbocker had an entertainment job on his hands, this is it.

In a welcoming address yesterday to the class of '41, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College remarked: "I was struck this Summer that at this moment a college education is of greater value than at any other time.

Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, announced yesterday that the twelfth annual World's Championship Rodeo, in which 200 cowboys and cowgirls from all sections of the West will compete for prizes totaling $40,000, would be presented in Madison Square Garden from Oct. 6 to 24.

The increasing tempo of events both at home and abroad, succeeding one another in a manner to confuse the most avid student of current history, gives greater than usual significance to the second annual NEW YORK TIMES Review of the News Conferences, opening Friday in the auditorium of the Woman's Club of New Rochelle.

WHEN a half-mile frontage on the Thames River opposite Runnymede was added recently to the setting of the most famous meadow in the English-speaking world, the purchase by the Buckinghamshire County Council symbolized more than another step to preserve this historio site where King John signed the Magna Carta.

Compulsory medical examinations of all auto drivers before an auto license is issued to them was advocated yesterday by Dr. Charles N. Gelber, candidate for Councilman from Manhattan, as a means of reduring auto fatalities.

News of an aerial attack upon a British destroyer off the coast of Spain weakened the pound sterling in the foreign exchange market yesterday, dropping it to $4.95 15-16, off 5/8 cent from the previous day and 1 1/4 cents from a week ago.

IN 1747 the Swedish Academy of Sciences, wishing to add to the industries of its country, decided to investigate silk manufacture. They cast about for some one to send to America to find a mulberry tree that would withstand the Swedish climate and their choice fell upon Peter Kalm, a promising young pupil of the great naturalist Linnaeus. Kalm started from Uppsala "in the name of the Lord, right after dinner."

MUSKOGEE, Okla. IN the Cookson hills, once a bandit-infested region centering about fifteen miles southeast of this city, Muskogee is noncommittally watching a large Federal WPA multiple-use project which soon will provide Eastern Oklahoma with a 2,000-acre recreational area.

Every Chicago household containing an elementary grade pupil is a school these days as a result of a cooperative experiment that is unique in educational procedure. The current epidemic of infantile paralysis, which has killed a score of children and stricken more than 250 others in the past seven weeks, is the cause.

Rookies Joe Krakauskas and Ray Phebus, recently recalled from Trenton and Chattanooga, respectively, pitched the Senators to a double victory over the Browns today. The scores were 6 to 2 and 10 to 3.
Production of Young-Davidson Mines, in the Matachewan area, a subsidiary of Hollinger Consolidated, established a new record in August at $108,958 recovered from 28,946 tons, averaging $3.77 a ton.

Boys' club directors require specialized university training in the same sense that teachers do, former President Herbert Hoover told thirty educators yesterday at a conference called by the Boys Clubs of America to discuss means of placing improved training facilities at
Tom Reis, ace Wilkes-Barre right-hander, hurled a no-hit, 8-to-0 victory over the Elmira Pioneers today in the third game of the final series for the New York-Pennsylvania League Governors' Cup.

With a twelve-hit attack featured by homers by Rip Collins and Joe Marty plux six-hit pitching by Tex Carleton, the second-place Cubs moved to within two and one-half games of the National League. leading Giants today by defeating the Phillies again, 9 to 3.

The Wheatley Stable's Snark made a runaway of the mile and three-sixteenths Rochambeau Handicap today as the last program of Narragansett Park's stormy Summer meeting was held before a crowd of 25,000.
A card party will be held on Nov. 3 at the Plaza for the benefit of the Sacred Heart College and three academies in the metropolitan district.

The Missouri Pacific Railroad, now in process of reorganization, petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission today for leave to intervene in the reorganizations of the Denver Rio Grande Western and the Western Pacific, submitting a plan of its own.

THE twe symphonic recordings of the month have for some time been badly needed on domestic lists. In Columbia Masterworks 302 is Beethoven's Second, in D, Op. 36, by Sir Thomas Beecham and the London Philharmonic, and half of Victor M-344 is devoted to the Sixth, in D minor, of Sibelius, played by the Finnish National Orchestra under the understanding direction of Georg Schneevoight.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Tomorrow Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit(com.). Carolina, Clinchfield Ohio Ry. (com.).
Representatives of the railroads and the operating brotherhoods ended a fourth week of Government-sponsored mediation today with no indication of settlement of their wage dispute.

PARIS. "TWENTY years after-an A. E. F. of good-will to Europe," is the official designation of the American Legion pilgrimage which, late this month and early October, is expected to bring some 5,000 to 7,000 exsoldiers, ex-sailors and ex-marines from the United States to France.

Asserting Massachusetts wageearners were threatened with the "impoverishing effect" of reciprocal trade treaties, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, today urged a protest to the State Department against a proposed agreement with Czechoslovakia.
Thomas L. Elder's opening coin sale for the present season will be held next Friday and Saturday afternoons at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street.

Many luncheons were given today by members of society who have their homes In the South Shore colonies and who have kept them open to entertain house parties for the Autumn meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association this afternoon at the Rockaway Hunting Club.

Mrs. Martin G. Missir carried off the women's golf championship of the Westchester Country Club for the fifth time in the last six years by overwhelming Mrs. L. M. Lloyd, 13 and 11, in the final listed for thirty-six holes over the club's south course today.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor returned today from their Czechoslovakian visit and prepared for a brief stay here before going on to Paris, where the Duchess plans to do some shopping.

Miss Constance Alden Baker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Sherman Baker of Maplewood, was married this evening in Morrow Memorial Church here to Jay Tongate Rodgers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur T. Rodgers, also of this place. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. John E. Charlton.

HEAVY rains along the Atlantic Coast last week brought to New York the first stormy weather of the season and showed the trend of seaplane terminal development when the British flying boat Cavalier, inbound from Bermuda, was forced to steer clear of turbulent Long Island Sound and alight on the sheltered Patapsco River at Baltimore.

WITH Rene Morax's "Valaisan legend" in four acts, music by Gustave Doret, produced on the rustic stage of Mezieres (above Lausanne) this Summer, the so-called Theatre du Jorat has added another wreath to its abundant collection of laurels.

ACME--Al Chet, Yiddish drama.* ASTOR--The Firefly: Jeanette MacDonald, Allan Jones.* BELMONT--An Orphan Boy of Vienna: Hans Olden.* BROADWAY--The Dead March, documentary film. CAMEO--Baltic Deputy, Russian drama.* CAPITOL--Big City: Spencer Tracy, Luise Rainer. CENTRAL--Charlie Chan on Broadway: Warner Oland. CINEMA DE PARIS--Le Juif Polonais: Harry Baur.

A thousand delegates, representing the street railway and bus transportation companies of the United States and Canada, began to assemble here today for the opening on Monday of the fifty-sixth annual convention of the American Transit Association at the Greenbrier Hotel.

The Autumn Festival period in the White Mountains, starting today, will continue for a month, and many New York society folk are expected to arrive to enjoy the brilliant changes in foliage, which will be at the height of its beauty three weeks hence.

To the American Legion Auxiliary, this week is the men's show. Of course the women will be here-60,000 strong, they estimate. But the feminine convention that for sheer numbers exceeds anything New York has experienced for years, constitutes only an adjunct to the main performance, as it were. Its delegates will be in the picture consistently, and they're a pictorial lot, but they refuse to monopolize the spotlight in any way.

American paint and varnish manufacturers and others employing tung oil in their processes have shown concern over recent developments in China which have almost entirely cut off this country's supplies of this essential drying oil, according to C. C. Concannon, chief of the Commerce Department's Chemical Division.

After a week's hearing of evidence on other issues, the National Labor Relations Board undertook on Thursday an examination into the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's labor situation through a devious inquiry into the origins and finances of the citizens' committee's "right-towork" movement, which is now being organized on a national scale.

IT must be a consolation to collectors to know that the first edition of Robert Frost's earliest volume of verse is unobtainable. The book has no title page but its name, "Twilight," appears on the front cover.

Miss Eileen T. Leahy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Leahy of Astoria, L. I., and Francis X. Walsh, son of Mr and Mrs. Nicholas F. Walsh of this city, were married here yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

More than threescore neighbors of Paul Guy descended upon his thirty-acre field of standing corn with corn knives today and in two and a half hours cut and shocked the entire crop and went away as silently as they came.

TWO new series of dance events are to be added during the coming season to the activities of that highly important section of the annual schedule which comes into being under strictly non-commercial and educational auspices.

The people of Georgia will not tolerate return of the lash in the State prison system. When, to their amazement, they heard the proposal last week, they spoke with such emphasis that they did more than put an end to the suggestion.

Mrs. Ethel V. Mars's Sky Larking, hailed as the 2-year-old champion of the turf, broke a leg during the running of the Champagne Stakes at Belmont Park and was destroyed. The race was won by H. P. Headley's Menow, a 12-to-1 shot. Sky Larking was the even-money choice. Pasha, also at 12 to 1,...

Continued declines in mill activity in major divisions of the textile industry were in prospect yesterday as mills planned further curtailment to avoid accumulating stocks. A considerable reduction in operations from the peak reached last Spring already has been accomplished.

Clyde Appleton Jr., 21 years old, of 467 Kearny Avenue, was arrested late last night for drunken and deckless driving and as a suspect in the death of Thomas Wightman, 9 years old, who was killed by a hitand-run driver in front of his home at 98 Bergen Avenue at 9 o'clock last night.

Quebec golfers took a 6point lead over New York's shotmakers today in the first day's play in the annual Lesley Cup international team matches. Gaining most of its margin in the Scotch foursomes that began the competition, Quebec amassed a total of 31 points.

A NEW YORK physician's entry recently won first prize in an exhibition of model Mississippi River showboats. It was a copy of the Cotton Palace. This contest directs attention to a phase of the widely popular avocation of building ship models, which is comparatively new.
A golf tournament ball was held tonight at the Berkshire Hunt and Country Club, Lenox, in honor of players in the last major men's golf event of the season in Berkshire.

Believing that the low prices of men's Summer suits in the season just closed, in contrast to the advances on regular Spring weights, may have been the reason for the popularity of the former, manufacturers are making every effort to hold down advances on the 1938 lines due this week, reports here yesterday indicated.

President Roosevelt cleared his desk of official business today before leaving late tonight for Hyde Park and a few days' rest preparatory to a trip to the West Coast on which he is expected to campaign for his court plan and his broad program of social and economic changes.

Proof that Hugo L. Black, the new Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, is a member of the Ku Klux Klan should result in his resignation or, at least, a statement repudiating Klan principles, Senator Lonergan asserted today in a statement given out from his office.
Eward Irving Smith, retired associate justice of the Waltham District Court and a graduate of the Harvard Law School in 1899, died yesterday at the Haymarket relief station. He was 76 years old.
Dr. Roswell Gray Ham, third president of Mount Holyoke College, will be formally inducted into office at a simple ceremony at the opening convocation of the 101st academic year on Thursday morning.

Miss Ann Bradford, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth Bradford of this city, was married tonight- in the First Presbyterian Church to John Kirk Train Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. John K. Train of Savannah, Ga., by the Rev. Dr. Hunter B. Blakely.

HOLLYWOOD. PUBLICITY from the film city will, in the very near future, pass a milestone. The new era marker is the colored still photograph, mass-produced, yet allegedly as excellent in quality as the black and white stills which are laid in sacrificial bundles every Monday morning on the desk of every motion picture editor in the country.

Donald T. Pomeroy of Syracuse will, explain the methods of utilizing industrial properties worked out recently in that city to the delegates at the forthcoming convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in Pittsburgh, beginning Oct. 20.

The annual joint convention of the New York State Nurses Association, the New York State League of Nursing Education and the New York State Organization for Public Health Nursing will be held at Lake Placid from Sept. 28, through Sept. 30, it was announced yesterday.

Herndon Morsell, formerly for more than forty years the musical director of the Gridiron Club and at one time an operatic tenor, died at his home here yesterday after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

Raildown at the end, but floundering for most of the afternoon, 145 craft took part in the Long Island Sound championship regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today. It was by far the largest Fall gathering in the history of the sailing sport.
CONVICTION: In front of one of Father Divine's "heavens" last June one of his former "archangels," Humility Consolation, shouted: "God Di-' vine is a racket."

While William Green and John L. Lewis plan policies and strategy on the other side of the continent, the first definite showdown between their embattled labor organizations looms along the Pacific Seaboard.

With acceleration in business activity, the relentless flow of population from farm to city areas once again has set in, retarded from 1930 through 1935 only by lack of industrial employment opportunities:

GUIDING genius of the annual National Air Races which recently closed at Cleveland Municipal Airport is Clifford W. Henderson, 42, who has been managing director of aviation's annual classic since 1928.

Ballela, one of three horses imported early this year by Joseph Aubrey Hale of Greenwich, Conn., came through with a pair of blues today in the opening session of the eighth annual Boulder Brook Club horse show to indicate to every one that he is definitely on the road to a brilliant career.

The attitude of American residents of China toward evacuation is emphasized by the latest figures here showing that approximately 5,400 out of 7,789 American civilians residing in China have departed or begun their departure. These figures include those on the week-end train from Hankow to Canton.

With the troublesome bonus issue a thing of the past, the American Legion, whose advance guard cluttered traffic, swarmed through hotels and railroad terminals and hooted at Mayor La Guardia's antinoise crusade yesterday, will steer a safe course through ticklish but pressing social and political issues at its convention opening here tomorrow and devote itself to the cause of peace.

Six years ago tonight a broken rail on the South Manchuria Railroad was the pretex for a Japanese invasion of China. In seventeen months she overran in excess of 500,000 square miles in Manchuria and the Province of Jehol, embracing more than 30,000,000 persons.

High officials of the Chinese Government frankly admit that the extremist faction among Nanking officialdom is so bitterly disappointed by Washington's attitude on neutrality that they favor some retaliatory step which would indelibly impress the United States Government and people with the extent of the resentment felt here over the embargo on shipments of arms and munitions to China on government ships.

The New York Conservation Department has reached across the sea to Finland for a sample shipment of black grouse and capercailzie, two fine Finnish game birds, and it is hoped that they will be adaptable to our environment.
The Elon College ele??n scored a stunning upset on Alumni Field today by defeating V. M. I.'s favored Cadets, 12 to 6.

THE Art Students League is holding its annual exhibition in the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. It opened last Wednesday and will be current until Oct. 14. Members and associates are represented.

Discussing the building situation in the current issue of Forbes Magazine, L. Seth Schnitman, chief statistician of the F. W. Dodge Corportion, finds that the year 1937 "much to the disappointment of those who expected a boom, must end with an expenditure for new housing construction which at best will be only about 35 per cent above that for 1936.

Miss Margaret Hope Berry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Parker Berry of Glen Ridge, and James Witten Stupalsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Edwin Stupalsky of Montclair, were married this evening in Glen Ridge Congrenational Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. William Weston Patton.

ODD things turn up in the mail. Sometimes the oddest are the most provocative. From Fayetteville, Ark., a correspondent inquires: "Do you see any sound reason for entertaining the prospect of an early spiritual, awakening?

THE "American School of the Air" of the Columbia Broadcasting System returns to the air for the ninth season on Oct. 18 with an expanded curriculum in which the National Education Association will cooperate.

CURRENT and pending anniversaries of historic events, together with happenings of present interest in lands abroad, are combining to produce significant postal paper to add to 1937's philatelic deluge.

William Matheus Sullivan's Playhouse was opened here this afternoon for its dedication and first concert. The playhouse, at which Mr. Sullivan, a New York attorney, intends to stage an annual Mozart festival similar to the Glyndebourne festival in England, was visited by more than 400 persons, who attended the garden party-musicale for the benefit of Danbury Hospital at which $4,000 was realized for the hospital's building fund.

After scoring seven times in the first three innings, the Bees were blanked today until the tenth, when they put across a run on Al Fletcher's single and Bobby Reis's double to beat the Cardinals, 8 to 7.

AS one whirls from collection to collection during the ten days in which the couture marathon takes place, one views nigh on to a thousand dresses a day; and one is forcibly struck with the individuality that marks the creations of each designer.

FOOTBALL will occupy much of radio's time on Saturday afternoons beginning on Sept. 25. Sponsors have contracted for many of the major games, but the stations that go to the gridiron on a sustaining program basis plan to keep their schedules flexible in order to broadcast descriptions of the contests in which the greatest interest prevails.

Moscow has always been a "city of dreadful rumor and strange fantasy," but now, when the Russian imagination has been stimulated by overt events and hidden mysteries, there seems to exist no limit to popular inventiveness.

Japanese policy in South China now consists mainly of naval and aerial raids carried out at various points, mostly appearing unimportant strategically. It appears that these raids are merely intimidatory and designed to keep the Chinese anxious.

American high school students hold astonishingly inconsistent beliefs on major social issues like unemployment, free speech, democracy and work relief if the preliminary results of classroom tests in thirty public and private schools disclosed, coincidentally, with school opening by the Progressive Education Association are typical.

The twelve-story apartment building at747-751 West End Avenue, between Ninety-sixth and Ninetyseventh Streets, will be offered at auction Wednesday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. The property has a frontage on West End Avenue of 50 feet and runs back 100 feet.

The Dominican Republic champions, recognized as the leading Negro team in baseball, will clash with a picked Negro nine in one of the contests in an American Legion three-club double-header which will be staged at the Polo Grounds this afternoon.

Mrs. William H. Pouch, organizing secretary general of the National Society, D. A. R., will be a special guest Thursday evening at a dinner at the Hotel Shelton at 7 o'clock, where details of the formation of the Junior Round Table of the chapters in and adjacent to New York will be completed.

A feature of the literary tea to be held on Friday at Winfield Hall, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Reynolds at Glen Cove, L. I., will be the "Living Book Reviews" with interpretative dances and the reading of extracts from books.

IN community, county and State fairs throughout the nation the Boy Scouts are taking an active part. Not only do they stage demonstrations, pageants and exhibits, thus bringing to public notice some of their many activities, but also they serve as guides.

Employes of the Department or Education who are delegates to the American Legion convention will be, excused from their duties at the Board of Education during this period, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, has announced.
Henry Hollister Dawson, executive and attorney of several insurance and financial organizations in Newark and former president of the Newark Y. M. C. A., died today at his home here. His age was 77.

Mr. and Mrs. August Eimer will celebrate the sixtieth anniversary of their marriage, which took place in New York, tomorrow afternoon at their Summer home on Shell Island, East Port Chester, Conn. Before the celebration at their home, there will be a luncheon at the Pickwick Arms Hotel here.

In the designing of new jumps for the nightly international military jumping events which will be a feature of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 3-10, three officers of the United States Cavalry were consulted.
Quelle Joie, a big gray, owned and shown by Allan MacDougal of Convent, placed first in the Spring Valley Hounds jumping class for the Seth E. Thomas Jr. Memorial

The international board of the Young Men's Christian Association, 347 Madison Avenue, announced yesterday that it had received a report from China that nine Y. M. C. A. buildings in Shanghai had escaped damage in the recent bombardments. Most of the buildings are being operated at capacity, the report said, and the association is carrying on relief work among civilians and soldiers.

Addition of some products to the list of German-made goods eligible for payment from inland accounts and removal of others was announced here yesterday by the Board of Trade or German-American Commerce following the receipt of information cabled from Germany.

Coach Fritz Crisler gave his Princeton University football squad its first real test of the season on University Field today. Three varsity elevens hammered the scrubs into submission, 26-7, in 90 minutes of play.

The Government this week advised all women athletes to wear shortsleeved dresses in the new "fitterBritain" campaign because a "dress of this type will be found more generally becoming to all figures than blouse and knickers or shorts, which are now the accepted dress for gymnastics."
With much that the President said in his Constitution Day address there will be widespread and whole-hearted agreement.
The marriage of Miss Helen Patricia Grady, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Grady of this city and Danmore, Winsted, Conn., to the Rev. John William Hammons, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. J.

THE WPA Federal Theatre Project had to be organized in a hurry. After several months in the Fall of 1935 of trying to select personnel for a theatre project, an administrative order from Washington was issued requiring that 5,000 persons be added to the payroll in New York City in two weeks.

THE recent appointment of James W. Gerard, wartime United States Ambassador to Germany, as an adviser to the United States Tourist Bureau, marks Uncle Sam's first step in a proposed campaign to give travelminded Europeans an idea of what is to be seen over here.
While Paul Keres of Estonia remained at the top, Reuben Fine of New York drew two of his games and took second place today in the international chess masters' tournament.

After the job of Chief Executive of the United States, one of the most important posts in the nation is that of Chief Magistrate of its greatest city. True, the Mayor of New York governs only 7,000,000 people, compared with the President's 130,000,000.

The Commonwealth will build flying-boat bases in the Netherland East Indies for improved air mail service, reducing the flying time to London at first to ten, then ultimately to seven days. The service will be inaugurated in 1938, the Minister of Defense, Sir Archdale Parkhill, said today after the Cabinet had finally approved the air mail agreement with the United Kingdom.
One of the principal factors delaying the settlement of the war in Spain is the international complication arising from foreign investments in that country.
Clearings of The Westchester County Clearing House Association, for last week totaled $3,153,036, compared with $2,345,394 in the preceding week; and $2,852,262 for the corresponding week last year.
Charles F. Hosford Jr., chairman of the National Bituminous Coal Commission, predicted today that the coal industry would never return "to the days of so-called free and unrestricted competition."

NOT since Luther's time has the church in Germany been so hated and so cherished as now. Millions of Germans who never bothered about their religion are now convinced that Christianity is the greatest obstacle to realizing their ideals.
Thomas P. McNamara, chief of police in the village of Kings Point, died of a heart attack last night in Conway, N. H., while on vacation with his wife, Mrs. Sarah E. McNamara. His age was 61.
TWO cycles devoted to Mozart, Schubert and Schumann will be presented this season by the New Friends of Music at the Town Hall at 5:30 P. M. on Sundays. The full programs follow:

THERE was a cloud of smoke in one corner of the restaurant and, naturally, where there was so much smoke, there had to be some Dykes. It was James himself, in person, and quite a picture. He was wearing a double-breasted suit that was "le dernier cri" from Michigan Avenue and he was smoking a third-rate cigar.
The death in Spain of Dr. Randall Sollenberger of Baltimore, a graduate of the United States Military Academy in 1924, was confirmed here yesterday by friends upon receipt of letters from his mother.

The engagement of Miss Bernice Andrus Hayes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Howard Hayes of this place, to the Rev. Warren Gardner Hunt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil M. Hunt also of Arlington, has been announced by her parents.

Miss Martha Foster Coyle, daughter of the Rev. Thomas Coyle and the late Mrs. Coyle, was married here this afternoon to John Hart Ely, son of Mrs. Richard Ely of Short Hills, N. J., and Black Hall, Old Lyme, Conn., and the late Mr. Ely, in the Westhampton Presbyterian Church.

The United Laundry Workers, Local 300 of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, scored an overwhelming victory over its A. F. of L. rival in an election held yesterday by the State Labor Relations Board to determine a collective bargaining agency for employes of the Consolidated Laundries Corporation.

Whether it's an altruistic desire for civic service, a lively curiosity about what transpires in court rooms, or a purely mercenary eye to the daily fee that animates them, members of women's organizations are increasingly absorbed in matters concerned with jury service under the new permissive law.

BEFORE teaching by radio can win the success of which it is capable, both educators and broadcasters will have to assume their full responsibilities, according to Frank E. Hill, author of "Listen and Learn."

The Peter Habib Realty Company reports an increased demand within the past six weeks for homes and apartments, particularly in the Elmhurst vicinity of Queens. Ten homes were sold and twenty apartments rented in that area since Aug. 1.

It was fortunate for the Dodgers that they already had the decision in the season's series with the Pirates safely tucked away before checking in here, for they dropped the second straight to the Buccos today, 3-2. The Grimes boys had won twelve of their previous meetings with Pittsburgh.

The AAA has revealed its new crop reduction program for 1938 to a conference of farm leaders and officials. It has announced "acreage goals" for cotton, corn, tobacco, potatoes, peanuts, rice and "other soil-depleting crops."
Miss May Denckla Howe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Denckla Howe of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to George R. Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy H. Clark of Cynwyd.

Growing anxiety for the safety of twenty men aboard the British racing sloop Endeavour, missing since she lost her tow in a 100-mile gale Monday night, was met tonight with the suggestion that the sloop might have continued across the Atlantic rather than turn back, as did the convoy.

YOUR article that appeared Sept. 5 on "The Manchester Idea" has been brought to my attention. Those responsible for carrying the project through annually and the artists participating deserve great credit and commendation.

John Laing, well-known British general. contractor and home builder, will arrive in New York tomorrow on the Queen Mary for a study of building operations and housing trends in this country, it was announced yesterday by Thomas S. Holden, president of the New York Building Congress.

ACK from Hollywood came Mr. Brady the other day to confide, without reluctance, that he would produce Elmer Harris's "The Invisible Silence." And he might just do it, and Kenneth MacKenna might be his partner in the venture and also appear in it.

THE BRONX will have its own series of orchestral concerts. Under the auspices of the recently formed Bronx Theatre, League, of which Margaret V. Wall is managing director, six programs will be given this season by the New-Court Symphony, under Macklin Marrow, the-young American conductor.

The solution of the present unemployment problem, in the opinion of George H. Davis, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, does- not lie in the absorption of the unemployed by industry.
Canadian organized labor gave a signal demonstration this week that it has maintained a unity notably wanting in the United States.

Alfred G. Vanderbilt's bay colt Pit Bull outclassed a field of nineteen today to win the Eastern Shore Handicap, important Fall test for two-year-olds. Jockey Sammy Renick got the son of Bull Dog-Bourscamp out in front soon after the start and he was never headed. Townsend B.

The violent Soviet newspaper campaign against many prominentCommunist officials in the Russian Karelian Republic, accused of es-pionage and industrial sabotage on Finnish Nazis' instigation, is interpreted here as foreshadowing a ruthless purge in that region.

Foreign Minister Josef Beck's pronouncement at Geneva Tuesday on the Palestine problem had, needless to say, a loud echo in Poland, where the Jewish problem is at present undergoing an unprecedented crisis.

The national boxing tournament of the American Legion Convention, which will be held Thursday night in the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Astoria, Queens; promises to be one of the largest amateur shows of the year.

With employment and payrolls, production and distribution holding their gains made earlier in the year, the business of the country appears ready to move ahead with steadily increasing production and consumption, according to a summary of conditions made public in the current issue of the Washington Review, a periodical published by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York and head of the Alliance Realty Company, will speak on "The Future of the Real Estate Market" on Wednesday evening, Sept. 29, at the West Side Y. M. C. A.
In 1918, when the war profits tax was imposed on excess profits at rates as high as 80 per cent, it was not uncommon for corporations to spend themselves free of the higher brackets.

Evidences of the ambition to own a home in the metropolitan area are indicated, points out Thomas G. Grace, FHA director for New York State, by the fact that during the month of August, 916 insured mortgages were issued by the Housing Administration, aggregating $4,663, 500 on residential properties in and around New York City, of this number, 643, representing $3,118,200 were made for new home construction.

The State Committee of the Socialist party today adopted a nine-point legislative program to which the party's candidates for the Assembly will be pledged. It was announced by James Lipsig, secretary, as follows:
Selection of their twenty-third National Commander will be one of the important matters to come before the delegates to the American Lesion convention.

Combahee Lion, a merry going white and lemon pointer owned by Charles L. Lawrance of East Islip and handled by Albert Hanford, carried off top honors in the open shooting. dog stake as the annual two-day field trial meeting of the Babylon Hunt Club began on the estate of Colonel M. Robert Guggenheim today.

WHEN the late Richard B. Harrison, the benign and beloved old gentleman who played "de Lawd" in "The Green- Pastures" for five years, finally tuckered out on the afternoon of March 2, 1935, and was compelled to turn over his "divinity" to a faithful understudy, he whispered feebly to his successor before leaving the theatre forever, "Hold me up, Charlie, hold me up; the world needs this play at this time."
The Perfumery and Cosmetic Buyers Conference will open tomorrow and continue through next Thursday at the Hotel Commodore, it was announced yesterday by J. J. Kimm, associate managing director.

Columbia Universitywill enter its 184th year on Wednesday afternoon, when Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia, leads a faculty procession into McMillin Theater to participate in traditional opening exercises.

FREQUENT folksong festivals are being held at the Paris exposition and are offering gratifying evidence of the fruitful efforts of various provincial groups who wish to perpetuate their local musical traditions so often, alas, in danger of falling into oblivion before the steady influx of jazz-an idiom which can never become an authentic mode of expression for the French.

EUROPEAN, Japanese and American physicians, all specialists in the treatment of disease by X-ray, radium and radiations in general, assembled last week in, Chicago. It was the Fifth International Congress of Radiology.

LONDON SUMMER and the holiday mood do not prevent the British lover of music from indulging his favorite hobby. Opportunities are provided by various organizations for study or performance in suitable surroundings and under exceptionally favorable conditions.

In all the merry hubbub with which Times Square will resound as Legionnaires take it over for their chief playground during their convention there will be one quiet moment. That pause will come at noon Wednesday, when veterans of the Rainbow Division will lay a wreath on the statue of Father Francis P. Duffy, wartime chaplain of the Old Sixty-ninth, which became the 165th Infantry of that famous division.

Miss Rose Weld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Balch Weld of 113 East Seventy-ninth Street, New York, and Indian Neck, Wareham, was married today to Ian Baldwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Clark Baldwin of New York and Shallow Brook Farm, Mount Kisco, N. Y., at the home here of the bride's parents.

The well-known chateau D'Abondant near Dreux, France, fortyeight miles west of Paris, has been purchased by Baron Jules de Koenigswarters of Paris in one of the most interesting realty deals reported from abroad in recent months.

An increase in freight and passenger traffic on the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad in the last year has not been accompanied by a corresponding increase in net operating income, Ralph Budd, president, said tonight before the company's Veterans Association here.

Pope Pius today warned German pilgrims against "a new prophet, exalted to act and write against all those who wish to remain faithful." His warning came in a general audience for Austrian, British, French and German pilgrims, attended also by several Americans, including Robert L. Aste and Mrs. Aste of New York City.
William F. Shanahan of New York, secretary to Representative Edward Curley of New York, died today at his Summer home here at the age of 46.
The first large wave of the rank and file of the American Legion rolled into town yesterday and immediately took over Times Square and the surrounding midtown area.

The revamped Brooklyn Dodgers will make their local National Football League debut at Ebbets Field this afternoon when they meet the Pittsburgh Pirates with the Eastern division lead at stake. Both teams have triumphed once and a victory will send the winner into first place. The kick-off is scheduled for 2:45.

" Yossel and His Wives," the musical comedy which opened the season Friday night at the Second Avenue Theatre, is determined to show that musical comedy also can be serious. The curtain is hardly up five minutes before you are introduced to a workers' delegation, a churlish boss, an agitator, a strike demonstration.

A three-year building program. which is expected to result in the construction of 1,500 homes in Queens and Nassau Counties, has been worked out by the Cooperstein family, builders. Through their Najin Building Corporation they have taken title to 1,500 lots, or which they plan to construct 500 homes every year for the next three years. All the houses will sell under $5,000.

Standing a few feet from the historio table at which the Constitution was signed 150 years ago, Mayor La Guardia of New York voiced the conviction today that the preservation of the nation's basic law and the "institutions of freedom" was "safe in the hands of the American people."

TRACK EVENTS One-Mile Run. Handicap-Won by Phil Silverman, Millrose A. A. (65 yards); Thomas V. Quinn, Polish Falcons, Elizabeth, N. J. (65 yards) second; William Ray, New York Curb Exchange A. A. (25 yards). third. Time--4:18.2.
Led by Bill Tranavitch, sophomore halfback, the Rutgers football team outplayed Panzer College in a practice scrimmage today.
TRAILERS and trailer life were generally whitewashed by the recent meeting here of the Council of State Governments; no "menace" was seen in the increasing popularity of the home on wheels.

The marriage of Miss Janice Siesel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Siesel of Land o' Hope, Bedford Village, to Henry Winterling, son of Mrs. John W. Winterling of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Winterling, took place here this afternoon in St. Peter's Church, of which the bride's father has been vestryman for fifteen years.

Forty-three thousand applicants, the largest group in the history of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, have filed for the second grade clerk examination to be given Saturday, Oct. 16, James E. Finegan, president of the commission, announced yesterday. The examination will determine assignments to 3,000 clerical posts after Dec. 15, when the Emergency Relief Bureau is to be absorbed by the Department of Public Welfare.

IVOR NOVELLO, an extremely adroit showman, has a habit of filling the vast auditorium of Drury Lane and there is no reason to suppose that his new piece, "Crest of the Wave," will break him of it. It will succeed.
The fighting Baltimore Orioles came from behind tonight to defeat Montreal, 6 to 5, and go one up on the Royals in their International League play-off.

Abitibi Power and raper Company--Eight months ended Aug. 31: Earnings after general expenses but before bond interest, depreciation and income taxes, $3,121,299, against $1,230,467 last year. August: Earnings, $500,668, against $217,782.

Mrs. Frederic F. de Rham, chairman of the Tuxedo Autumn Ball to be held at the Tuxedo Club Oct. 23, is completing- plans for the event. Several informal meetings were held during the week. Members of her committee are Mrs. David Wagstaff, Mrs. S. Sloan Colt, Mrs. Victor Loew and Mrs. Reginald LeGrand Auchincloss.

A tract of thirty-three acres in the Manhasset section of Nassau County, L. I., and which for many years was part of the large Grace estate, will be formally opened this week as a new residential community in that popular home area. The opening will be featured by the exhibition of seven model homes recently completed in different types of architecture.
ASHEVILLE, N. C. SEPTEMBER visitors to the mountains of Western North Carolina find Autumn touching the highest gums and maples with scarlet and gold.

Citing the fact that Italy gives a twenty-five-year tax exemption on all new construction, Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, writing from Italy where he recently inspected some of the latest housing developments, says that demolition is carried on by the government. By this process the government clears out the slum areas and provides proper compensation for the owners.

Members of the Newspaper Guild of New York and sympathizers staged another mass demonstration at 7 o'clock last night outside the plant of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle at Washington and Johnson Streets, Brooklyn,

Charles Abrams, counsel to the New York City Housing Authority, will speak at the first of a series of twelve lectures on contemporary housing and rehousing to be given at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, on successive Wednesday evenings, beginning Sept. 29. His topic will be "General Orientation."

The ten-story apartment house at 160 Columbia Heights, corner of Clark Street, 'is rapidly nearing completion for occupancy earl in October. The suites range from two to eight rooms, and the builders, Silk Hitlin, report that 80 per cent of the apartments are now rented.
At Lat. 80 degrees, 45 minutes N. and Long. 148 degrees W. flying toward the North Pole to hunt for Sigismund Levanevsky and the other missing Russian fliers.

Less than an hour after the race meet closed tonight at Narragansett Park, the State Racing Commission clamped down a suspension of the track's license in an order that also called for removal by Sept. 30 of Walter E. O'Mara as managing director.

THE work of the painter-sculptor, Warren Wheelock, with numerous reproductions of his sculptured figures, comes in for extensive consideration in the current (September) issue of Art Instruction, published at Stamford, Conn. Mr. Wheelock contributes an explanation of his three very diverse statues of Lincoln. This number also contains a commentary, with illustrations, on the wood engraving of Allen Lewis.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Lelper Breed, daughter of Dr. Charles H. Breed, headmaster of Blair Academy, and Mrs. Breed, to Edward Cowan Marshall, son of Dr. and Mrs. Watson Marshall of Pittsburgh, took place this afternoon in the sunken garden on the Blair campus.
The appointment of former Mayor James J. Walker as temporary assistant counsel of the Transit Commission was approved today by the State Civil Service Commission.

Higher wage and raw material costs have added at least 10 per cent to the average price at which American manufactured goods must be marketed in foreign markets, exporters estimated yesterday in planning more aggressive sales and promotional campaigns abroad.

ERNA SACK, coloratura soprano of the Dresden Opera Company, and Jussi Bjoerling, 26-year-old tenor of the Royal Opera at Stockholm, have signed as members of the singing group to be affiliated with WJZ's Sunday evening symphonic hour beginning Oct. 3 at 8 P. M.

Charles Whitworth, 22, of Asheville, N. C., a licensed pilot who was training for a transport license, was killed late today when a borrowed open-cockpit plane he was piloting struck an electrical line and crashed in afield near Centerville. Ill.

Eight years of foot-racing warfare have not checked Joe McCluskey's speed. Cracking an American record that was almost as old as himself, the 26-year-old Winged Foot veteran provided the high spot of the 1937 track and field games of the New York Athletic Club at picturesque Travers Island yesterday.

THE eminent architect, Ralph Adams Cram, has arrived in his latest book at conclusions sufficiently startling to make even the 50.per cent American rub his eyes. For here, in cold print, is the deliberate and reasoned suggestion that this country would be better off under a government approximating a constitutional monarchy.

Fifth Avenue today is one of the busiest sections of the city with respect to construction operations nearing completion or about to be undertaken. New business buildings as well as apartments are rising in various parts of this well-known thoroughfare, and the shopping areas continue to expand here and on the adjacent avenues and side streets.

INTRODUCING Theodolinda Bonner, detective. And not a trained nurse or an idle middle-aged spinster, but a professional detective, with a licensed agency in New York-this being the vocation she has chosen for herself when left penniless in her early twenties by the crash in Wall Street.

The labor policy of the B. M. T. was assailed yesterday by Michael J. Quill, president of the C. I. O.chartered Transport Workers Union, in a radio speech in which-he accused the company of holding down wages and maintaining "inhuman" working conditions at a time when it was paying substantial profits to stockholders and earning an ample return from operation of its rapid transit, street car and bus system.

The marriage of Miss Irma Elfrieda Hoffmann, daughter of Mrs. John Hoffmann of this city and the late Mr. Hoffmann, to William Douglas Wallace, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Wallace of Fernie, B. C., took place here this afternoon in St. Mark's Lutheran Church.
Many of the Summer families here are planning to stay for the Autumn season, while other colonists who have been away have returned just for this period.

One of the first apartment houses in New York to be equipped with air-conditioning and also the first building to be erected over the New York Central tracks in the Grand Central zone is now 100 per cent rented, it was announced yesterday by Donald Jones, vice president of Wm. A. White Co., agents.

MORNING EVENTS Class 26, Model Hunters--First, Joseph Aubrey Hale's ch. g. Ballela; Mrs. Julius Bliss's ch. g. Tupello, second; Mrs. Carlo M. Paterno's gr. m. Maylay, third; Morton Govern's ch. g. Hard Lines, fourth. Class 18 A, Children's Horsemanship (under 10 years)--First, Miss Barbara Griffiths; Miss Carol Gussenhoven, second; Miss Louise Johnson, third; Tommy Johnson, fourth: Herbert W. Marasche Jr., fifth; Miss Eve Prime, sixth.
South Carolina's Gamecocks, employing more than four complete teams, outmanned and crushed Emory and henry in the season's opener today, 45 to 7.

Horace Harding Boulevard, destined to be the most important highway entrance to the World's Fair, according to Grover Whalen, president of the fair corporation, was opened for traffic yesterday morning on a two-mile stretch from Queens Boulevard east over Flushing Meadow Park.

Communism as the destroyer of religion, home and family was denounced today by Cardinal Leme da Silviera, the Archbishop of Rio de Janeiro. In a long encyclical that will be read tomorrow from the pulpit of every Catholic church in Brazil the Cardinal invoked God's will against communism.
British press and radio have displayed much interest in our Constitution and its 150th birthday.
Sharp declines in four of its components put THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity almost three points lower for the week ended Sept. 11.

Miss Coralie Barry and Miss Geraldine Jackson will give a dinner Tuesday in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for Miss Janet Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Smith of this city, and Gerald Hughes Phipps, son of former United States Senator and Mrs. Lawrence Phipps of Denver, whose marriage will take place Friday in St. Thomas Church.
A famous son of a famous father cartried on a tradition in speedboat racing today on the James River.

Colleges and universities in New York and nearby States universally report large enrollments for the new academic year, which in most cases will begin this week. The rush of students to college, either for freshman orientation weeks or for the early opening of actual class work, began last week. Colleges for men and women, and the co-educational institutions as well, will be crowded to capacity in the next few days.

On the site of the old Grande Maison de Blanc building at 538-40 Fifth Avenue, near Forty-fifth Street, a new six-story business structure soon will rise in Georgian Colonial style, such as has been utilized in the restoration of Williamsburg, Va.

Recently H. St. John Philby, English explorer and authority on Arabia, made a journey between the Hedjaz and the Indian Ocean, through territory the greater part of which had never been seen by any European traveler. In this, the second of two articles, he completes the description of his discoveries in ancient Arabia.

Documentary evidence was introduced today in the trial of eleven Nationalists, charged with murder, purporting to show they took oaths to fight for the separation of Puerto Rico from the United States.

Mrs. Genevieve B. Earle, member of the commission which. drafted the new city charter and candidate of the City Fusion party for member of the City Council, announced yesterday that she had opened campaign headquarters at 304 Fulton Street, Brooklyn.

Frederick J. Dolan, developer, reports the sale of cottages at his Babylon Beach (L. I.) development to Gustave Fuge, Harold Bennett, Frank Randazzo and Margaret Fallon. Plots in the same section were sold to Otto Homan, William Fox, John Stringer, John Dooley, Erling Brusted, Margaret Linsky, Katherine Zabriskie and James Guidice.

LONDON.--Every time the political situation in Europe becomes especially threatening there is talk on every hand in Great Britain about the desirability, if not necessity, of "a better Anglo-American understanding."

The Conservatory Garden in Central Park was opened yesterday, when Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, turned over the six-acre plot at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street to the city, inviting residents to enjoy its quiet and beauty.

Unprecedented progress in both the acquisition of acreage and thedevelopment of existing areas has occurred in New York City in the last four years, "when what is believed to be a nation-wide record in park progress was set up," the Regional Plan Association announced yesterday in a statement on park development in the metropolitan area.

The first Fall meeting of the board of governors of the New York Building Congress will be held at the Engineers' Club in Forty-second Street on Tuesday afternoon. The enlarged program of activities planned by various committees during the Summer months will be discussed.

FIRST RACE--Purse $1,000; claiming; 3year-olds; six furlongs. Wulftstan, 108..(F. Jones) 6.80 4.20 3.40 Bugle Call. 111.(Bierman) .... 7.40 5.10 Ky. Eagle, 106..(Marrero) ....... 6.40 Time 12 3-5. Nebraska City, Lambs Wool, Sis Royal, Nellie Mc., High Martin, Broadkill and Just Dun also ran. >SECOND RACE-Purse $1,000; claiming; 4-year-olds and upward; six furlongs.

Miss Eleanor Gray, daughter of Mrs. Arthur R. Gray of Garrisonon-Hudson and the late Rev. A. R. Gray, was married here today in St. Philips-in-the-Highlands Church, to David Howell Cheney of New York, son of Howell Cheney of Manchester, Conn., and the late Mrs. Cheney.

Crooning Water, 5-year-old bay mare owned by Mrs. James Cox Brady Jr. of Far Hills, N. J., scored an easy victory in the Piping Rock Handicap before 5,000 spectators at the Autumn meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association today.
