ANHALT--THOMPSON--Edna A. Thompson, daughter of Amelia L. Thompson, to Edward B. Anhalt, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Anhalt of New York City. No cards.
Executives of the Securities and Exchange Commission are far from callous to the criticism which financial circles have been heaping upon them and the acts they administer.

President Mildred H. McAfee of Wellesley College and Dr. William Price Rainey, director of the American Youth Commission, will be the principal speakers at a convocation of educational leaders at Oberlin College on Oct. 8, marking the centennial of coeducation and the entrance of women into education on the college level.

Edward P. Trainer, business manager of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, announced yesterday that sit-down strikes would be called tomorrow on thirteen Morgan Line vessels unless the Southern Pacific Company, operator of the line, agreed to negotiate with the union on labor matters.

The Wellington Fund, Inc., an investment trust of Camden, N. J., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement proposing a stock issue of $3,951,507, it was announced today. The shares will be $1 par.
Members of the Latter Day Saints Church in and around this city will go hungry tomorrow, because they fear a depression within a few years "far more serious than the one we are now finishing."

After winning the qualifying medal with a two-over-par 72, Gene Homans of Knickerboker and John F. Kidde of the home club today reached the semi-finals of the first annual Montclair Golf Club invitation best-ball tournament. Following their medal-winning effort in the best-ball event, they defeated H. F. Morse of Montclair and Eddie Down of Echo Lake, 2 and 1.
Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg called tonight for "a union of hearts and hands regardless of previous party lines" as the only form for successful opposition to what he termed "the Roosevelt party."

Seventeen trailer manufacturers from widely separated sections of the country will exhibit the newest vehicles for tourists and mobile home owners in the New York Trailer Show opening at 11 A. M. tomorrow at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue.

WELLINGTON, N. Z. GREAT BRITAIN has sent the patrol sloop Leith from Suva, Fiji, to Canton Island, in the Phoenix group, with two wireless operators and materials and equipment to establish a radio station there.

A tract of 450 improved lots Flushing, L. I., in the area bounded by Bayside Avenue, Cross Island Boulevard, Willets Point Boulevard and 154th Street, will be sold at auction on Oct. 16 by J. Edward Breuer on behalf of Flushing Manor, Inc., Louis Rosenberg, president.

Wall Street has apparently not yet made up its mind what was the meaning of the past fortnight's rapid fall in stocks. Nearly three-fourths of the market's precipitous decline in the week after Labor Day was canceled early last week, but the recovery left speculative minds even more hopelessly in the dark.

The forty-eight State delegations and nine foreign departments in attendance at the American Legion convention have set up their own headquarters in seventeen hotels in the mid-town area, several. choosing the same hotel.
Patriotic demonstration of the Youth Division of the Mayor's Committee for the Observance of the Constitution's birthday, The Mall, Central Park, 1:30 P.M.

Harold Dahl, the American flier impriosned here since July 12, when his plane was shot down by Nationalists [Insurgents] on the Madrid front, was asked today if he desired official permission for his pretty young wife to reside in Salamanca while awaiting either his unconditional pardon by General Francisco Franco or an opportunity to be exchanged for a Nationalist aviator held prisoner by the Valencia authorities.
PROFESSOR DICK'S extremely interesting book is mainly concerned with a period
The Automobile Club of New York is asking members, except those who are members of the American Legion, to reduce as much as possible the use of their cars in Manhattan during the Legion convention.

Scattered remains of the earliest known members of the order of life to which modern man belongs have been discovered in Central Montana by three scientists who in succession spent nearly thirty years exploring a wooded paradise of 70,000,000 years ago, according to a report issued by the Smithsonian Institution.

Installment-share savers have increased their invested capital in building and loan associations throughout the country during the past six months to the point where such investors are now contributing 50 per cent of the total capital of those institutions, the United States Building and Loan League announces.
Marie Good Thomas is named residuary legatee of the. $150,000 estate of Leonard M. Thomas of this city under his will,

Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, announced yesterday that eight concerns have been added to the list of those which will occupy exhibition space at the exposition. He said the charge for all space in fairbuilt exhibit buildings was at the uniform rate of $14 a square foot.

C. Edward Paxson of Travis, Brownback Paxson, counsel for subsidiaries of the Associated Gas a ?? Electric Company in the proceedings before the Federal Power Commission regarding offices or directorships in more than one operating company, issued yesterday a statement in response to publicity given out by the commission.

GOLDENBERG--LEVIN--Irving Goldenberg and Sydell Levin, Sept. 18, by Rabbi J. M. Lawn. HELLER--SCHAUER--Mrs. Kathe Schauer announces the marriage of her daughter Alma, Louis, son of Mrs. Leonore Heller, Sept. 18. Rev. Dr. J. M. Lawn officiated.

Performing in a noteworthy manner throughout his test, Middleburg Dan, black and white pointer owned and handled by L. R. Durbarow of Maplewood, N. J., triumphed in the important open all-age stake today. The event marked the close of the annual two-day field trial meeting of the Babylon Hunt Club on the estate of Colonel M. Robert Guggenheim.
The exhibition football game between the New York Yankees and the Bay Parkways scheduled for the Coney Island Velodrome yesterday
They laughed at Mayor Frank D. Livermore when he got up at a Village Commission meeting here a month ago and announced that he wanted to appoint a college graduate to a vacancy on the police force.
The engagement of Miss Carolyn Abbott Chance, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Robinson Chance of this place, to William Abner Knight 2d has been announced by her parents.
Loans of production credit associations outstanding on Sept. 1 were $27,000,000 above the amounts outstanding on the same date last year, the Farm Credit Administration announced today.

Hope that a reciprocal trade agreement between Great Britain and the United States would be concluded soon was expressed yesterday by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Minister, in an international radio broadcast under the sponsorship of the National Peace Conference.

Johnny Taylor, a 20-year-old fast ball hurler from Hartford, Conn., pitched a no-hit, no-run victory for the Negro National League Stars against the champion team of the Dominican Republic at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Senator Dixie Graves of Alabama, who was appointed by her husband, Governor Bibb Graves, to the Senate seat left vacant by Supreme Court Justice Hugo Black, declined to discuss the present prominence of her predecessor as she reached New York last night for the sessions of the American Legion Auxiliary convention.

Mr. and Mrs. Rodney S. Jarvis gave a dinner tonight at their Wheelbarrow Hill Farm in Great Barrington in honor of their week-end guests, Mrs. Kirkwood E. Jewett and Kirkwood E. Jewett Jr. of New York.
Quebec's Lesley Cup team won the annual international golf tournament for the trophy today, leading squads from Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and New York.

Taking advantage of the presence of New England Governors at the opening of the Eastern States Exposition here, Governor Francis P. Murphy of New Hampshire today invited them and their advisers to a luncheon conference to discuss the Federal Government's new attitude on the Connecticut River flood control interstate compact.

Too rugged in the line and too deft in ball-carrying manoeuvres, the Pittsburgh Pirates blanked the Brooklyn Dodgers in the National Football League opener in New York yesterday, crushing the Dan Topping troupers, 21 to 0, before a gathering of 18,000 at Ebbets Field.

An audience of 1,900 persons attended a performance of "II Trovatore" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night. The cast of the Hippodrome Opera Company, which is presenting these Brooklyn performances, included Norina Greco as Leonore, Lillian Marchetto as Azucena, Pasquale Ferrara as Manrico, Arturo D'Amico as Di Luna, Vladimir Zorin as Ferrando and Philine Falco and Francesco Curci. Gluseppe Bamboschek conducted.

Connecticut Socialists of the party's right-wing faction voted at a State convention here today, subject to approval in a referendum, to affiliate with the National Social-Democratic Federation, of which Mayor Jasper McLevy is national chairman.

The Republic of Uruguay will announce today a formal offer to holders of its dollar bonds to exchange them for new readjustment bonds carrying generally higher rates of interest than the 3 1/2 per cent rate now being paid and providing for substantial sinking funds to retire the new securities.

Miss Barbara Martin, 18-year-old freshman at the University of Wisconsin, was found dead today in her room at Ann Emery Hall, women's residence dormitory, a few blocks from the campus. Her home was at Birmingham, Mich.

Hunts Point Ave (10-2763b). w u, 343 ft a of Coster St, 75x100; Aurelia Waintrob to Lillian Cotkin, 1,895 Belmont Ave; mtg, $98,000. Simpson St, 989 (10-2724), w s, 480 ft n of 163d St. 42x107; Jomin Properties, Inc, to Frieda Rubin, 984 Simpson St; mtg, $31,Onn.
Coach Earl (Dutch) Clark led the Detroit Lions to a 16-7 triumph over the Chicago Cardinals in a National Football League game today.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Ethel Kemmerer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy C. Kemmerer of Jamaica, Queens, to Edgar M. Matthews Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar M. Matthews, also of Jamaica.
Mexico gained its second straight victory over a picked team of soccer stars from the United States, 7 to 3, today and won the Castillo Najera Cup.

Cooperation by the United States in any action the League of Nations may take in regard to China's complaint against current Japanese operations will entail danger of American involvement in the Far Eastern quarrel unless the Neutrality Act is immediately invoked,
Celebration of the sesqui-centennial of the signing of the Constitution of the United States inspired comment from two New York City pulpits yesterday.

The first death of a visiting Legionnaire occurred under mysterious circumstances last night when a visitor from Salem, Mass., died in a hospital after he had been found injured lying on a track in Grand Central Terminal.

The Soviet Embassy announced tonight the receipt of the following message from the radio station at Aklavik, Canada, regarding Sir Hubert Wilkins, who has been flying over the Arctic to search for missing Russian fliers:

For the fourth time, the smooth foxterrier Nornay Saddler today was awarded a best-in-show title. Under the judgment of William L. Kendrick of Philadelphia this blackheaded chap topped a field of more than 600 dogs in the sixth annual all-breed exhibition of the Camden County Kennel Club, held on the grounds of the Central Airport.

Announcement has been made to friends here by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hutchinson Poole of Lake Forest, Ill., of the engagement of their daughter, Mis Nancy Marie Poole, to Joseph E. Rich, son of Mrs. Reuben J. Rich of Winnetka, Ill.

Japan's conquest of the Chinese Northwest extended deeper today into the provinces of Suiyuan and Shansi. Rapidly moving columns of cavalry and motorized infantry thrust southward toward Yenmen Pass in North Shansi, while another column continued after seizing Fengchen, the first important station in Suiyuan on the Peiping-Suiyuan Railway.
The Green Bay Packers, National Football League champions, suffered their second consecutive circuit reversal today at the hands of the Chicago Bears, who beat them, 14 to 2, before 15,658 fans.

Normal retail activity for the first half of September brought a good volume of apparel business into the wholesale market here last week, as retail stocks, which had been held to a minimum, required replenishment. Dresses in all price ranges moved actively.

The Detroit Tigers yesterday were a living example of that Salvation Army cry about being down and not out. The only club the Yankees have not yet eliminated from the pennant race by a mathematical certainty, the Bengals,

An appeal for the retention of the basic theories of education in a changing world was voiced by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, S. J., president of Fordham University, in a sermon at the annual vesper service and conference of religious teachers of the Archdiocese of New York at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon.

Defending Champion Ralph Guldahl and Horton Smith, both of Chicago, staged a "photo finish" at even par 288 today in the thirty-seventh annual Western open golf championship. An eighteen-hole play-off tomorrow morning will determine the winner of the $500 first prize and the title.

Nearly 1,000 persons, including members of German-American societies and patriotic organizations, visited Valley Forge Park today in tribute to Friedrich Wilhelm, Baron von Steuben, the German soldier who aided Washington's troops during the Revolutionary War.

Miss Beatrice Child, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Child of Garden City, L. I., has completed plans for her marriage to Arthur William Gilbart of Ridgewood, N. J. The ceremony, which will take place on Oct. 8 at the Sherry-Netherland, will be performed by the Rev. John H. Esquirol of the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City.
Gustav Zimmermann, a retired hotel proprietor formerly well known as a rifle shot, died yesterday at his home, 2,026 Creston Avenue, the Bronx. He was born in Baden, Germany, eighty-three years ago.

The Federal Symphony Orchestra presented the fourth program in its series of Tchaikovsky concerts at the WPA Theatre of Music last night. Eugene Plotnikoff conducted the Suite No. 3 in G, Op. 55, and the Sixth symphony. A capacity audience that included standees turned out for the concert and responded to conductor and orchestra with prolonged applause.

Anxious watchers on two sides of the Atlantic tonight pinned their chief hope for the safety of the British racing sloop Endeavour'and her twenty men on the possibility that she might have continued to England after losing her convoy in a hurricane nearly a week ago.

Sixty-nine chapters of the American Institute of Architects throughout the country will unite to support the national housing program under the Wagner-Steagall measure, Walter R. McCornack, chairman of the Institute's committee on housing announced yesterday.

If some of the Florida Legionnaires are wondering what hapopened to a sixteen-inch alligator mascot lost somewhere in Greenwhich Village, it is in the Charles Street police station and Lieutenant James Sullivan, who is not familiar with Florida wild life, is worried having a "crocodile" in his midst.
Two men drowned and a third was saved early this evening when their rowboat foundered about fifty feet from shore in a creek leading to Manhasset Bay, where they had been fishing.
William A. Sailer, formerly prominent in American pharmacy, died in a hospital here tonight. He was 75 years old. Mr. Sailer retired from the drug business in 1926.

Horses belonging to Mrs. Julius Bliss of Bronxville again were outstanding as the eighth annual Boulder Brook Club horse show came to a brilliant end today. Bay Flight, winner of the championship jumper rosette in addition to a pair of blues, was the big victor for the stable.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday his endorsement of Borough President George U. Harvey for re-election and said he would campaign for him. The Mayor's declaration of his position in regard to Mr. Harvey, with whom he has had numerous differences in the Board of Estimate, was in reply to questions put to him by reporters.

Unduly stringent governmental supervision over private business is tending to destroy. American industrial initiative and to send the United States on the economic pathway now being traveled by France, according to Professor Georges F. Doriot of the Harvard School of Business Administration, who has just completed a comparative study of economic conditions in the two republics.
Stocks irregular, but slightly above the low levels of the movement; turnover, 7,623,110 shares. United States Government bonds higher; other issues irregular; transactions, $43,387,550.

In one of the liveliest games ever played here Baltimore gained a three-to-one edge over the Montreal Royals in the International League Governors' Cup series by scoring a 14-13 victory today in the fourth game.
With the rusty Leviathan offering a gloomy background, hundreds of Legionnaires gathered today for memorial ceremonies in the city from which many of them sailed for France during the World War.

The body of Clare P. Simonsen, Borough Treasurer and tax collector, who had been missing since Tuesday, was found tonight in his automobile in a lonely wooded section of the Post-Cunhard Road, a mile from here.

The church of yesterday was "theological," the church of today is "transitional" and the church of tomorrow will be philanthropicall," the Rev. Dr. Frank Oliver Hall said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity, Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street.

The report of the Mead Corporation, for the thirty-six weeks ended on Sept. 4, shows a net profit of $1,584,631, after depreciation, interest and taxes on funded debt and other deductions. This is equivalent to $2.19 a share on 619,374 shares of common stock outstanding at the end of this period, after allowance for preferred dividends.

President Roosevelt praised the patriotism of American Jews in a message addressed to the fortysecond annual national encampment of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, made public yesterday by the convention committee.

" Industrial management must drop its outworn system of discipline by dictatorship and devise a plan of discipline by consent if an explosion is to be avoided in the present labor crisis," declared Alvin Johnson, director of the New School for Social Research and associate editor of the Encvclopaedia of Social Science,

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,347,887,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

The meetings of the Board of Standards and Appeals, scheduled for tomorrow, will be held at 10 A. M. and 2 P. M. on Wednesday. The postponement was made because Tuesday, American Legion Day, has been declared a holiday for municipal ??mployes.

A drive to organize 130,000 employes in bank, brokerage houses, Stock Exchanges and other financial houses in this and other cities has been started by the Financial Employes Organizing Committee, it was announced yesterday by Lewis Merrill, chairman of the committee and general president of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, C. I. O. affiliate.

Socalled "poverty diseases," including tuberculosis and pneumonia, can be most effectively brought under control through slum clearance, it was stated in a pamphlet on public health issued today by the National League of Women Voters on the eve of the housing conference called by Secretary Ickes for tomorrow morning.
Charles Carroll Thomas, 34 years old, an ardent hunter, accidentally killed himself today in the living room of his home at 305 Central Parkway here while cleaning a bear-hunting rifle.
Mayor Watkins Overton, in a formal week-end statement, warned that "imported C. I. O. agitators, Communists and high professional organizers are not wanted in Memphis."

Shares of German banks were firm at the close of this week in response to the action of the Dresdner Bank in repurchasing from the Government the shares it had sold to the Reich in the financial crisis of 1931.
The whole Soviet Union is now plunging into the campaign for the first elections under the Stalin Constitution with extraordinary intensity.

Possible reduction of the motor vehicle tax burden in New Jersey was seen today by E. J. Leary, secretary of the New Jersey Petroleum Industries Committee, in view of substantial increases in State revenues from registration fees and gasoline taxes.
The six articles that our correspondent, Harold Denny, has just completed on Soviet Russia significantly supplement those of Otto D. Tolischus on Germany.
Wesleyan University sold to an investing client of William H. Marquand's Son, broker, the store and apartment building at 1,568 Fulton Street, Brooklyn.

With the day of reckoning almost at hand, the Republican campaigns of State Senator Lester H. Clee and State Senator Clifford R. Powell for the nomination for Governor in Tuesday's primary, moved toward a close today in the traditional manner.

A bonus of $4,400,000 will be paid to the International Harvester Company's 65,000 employes in the United States and Canada early in November, Sydney G. McAllister, president, informed employes today.

Professor and Mrs. Arthur J. Farley of this city have issued invitations for the wedding of their daughter, Miss Margaret Wheatie Farley, and Henry Frederick Skelton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reinhold Skelton of Elmhurst, L. I.

Asserting there should be one nurse for every 1,500 school children instead of one for 2,900, as at present, the Advisory Committee on Nursing recommended yesterday that 250 additional nurses be provided for in the 1938 Health Department budget.

All last night and today the great pilgrimage to the bier of Thomas Garrigue Masaryk continued uninterrupted. It takes nine hours standing in line to pass the body, but the black ribbon of mourners winding up the hillside grows even longer.

Gustav Adolf Scheel, leader of the National Socialist Students organization, issued today what he terms the Ten Commandments of the German student. They are somewhat repetitious, with stress on Nazi patriotism, reading:
The text of Secretary Hull's address at the meeting held yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the National Peace Conference at the West Forty-fifth Street Theatre follows:

The plot of O. Henry's story, "The Gift of the Magi," was enacted in real life here by Clifton Bass. American sailor, at the fleet air base, and his wife, the former Miss Estelle Darrell, who came from New Jersey to work in the Atlantic Cabaret.

Terminating its Summer training here at Camp Smith, the 369th Infantry of Harlem took the field early this morning in the final ceremony of the season in which more than 20,000 guardsmen have received training at the four State cantonments under the direction of Major Gen. William N. Haskell,

With their eyes on the country council elections next month, for which all political parties in France are preparing with unusual vigor, Premier Camille Chautemps and no less than eleven of his Ministers today addressed meetings throughout the country defending and explaining their accomplishments and policy.

Morning rain, which drenched the broad expanse of International Field, disappointed the players and several thousand spectators who came to the Meadow Brook Club today for the final match of the national open polo championship between Old Westbury and Greentree.

Martin M. Adler of 433 West Thirty-fourth Street, of the insurance brokerage firm of Martin M. Adler, Inc., 470 Lexington Avenue, died yesterday afternoon at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, 689 Fort Washington Avenue, a short time after he was stricken with a heart attack while playing tennis at Bennett Avenue and 184th Street. His age was 45.
An offering to the public will be made today by the Floyd D. Cerf Company of $700,000 of first mortgage 51/2 per cent convertible bonds of the Hayes Body Corporation at 98 and accrued interest.
A census of children of school age, to determine the number not in school but who should be if fa cilities were provided, has been de termined upon by Commissioner of Education Juan M. Gallardo.

The Giants' inspiring pennant drive through the West came perilously close to skidding right off the course today when stalwart Wally Berger laid a heavy hand on the wheel and effected what one might almost call a very miraculous escape.
Three speed records were believed set today at the Detroit National Air Show. Colonel Roscoe Turner flew his Laird special 289.908 miles an hour over a 100-kilometer course.

The international picture as well as the French economic and financial situation is still disquieting. With the approach of the local elections, party struggles are increasing and further success by the revolutionary elements is feared.

The financial markets here are likely to continue unsettled until the Stock Exchange settlement on Thursday, because of the heavy differences to be met. There was much forced liquidation of domestic issues last week to provide funds to meet losses on American securities, and professionals in London and Glasgow reduced their commitments.

Winnie Melville, one of England's best-known musical-comedy stars in recent years, died today at the age of 42. She and her husband, Derek Oldham, were long known as the stage's happiest couple, but he obtained a judicial separation in 1932 while she was touring the United States.
Charles A. Guttentag, Republican leader of Ocean County and president of the Ocean Gate Council, died here today at his home on Chelsea Avenue, after a year's illness, at the age of 62.

In his sermon for Succoth, Feast of the Tabernacles, at Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street, last evening, Rabbi Abraham L. Feinberg warned that "the revival of the Ku Klux Klan as a fact, or as an issue, will resurrect racial and religious rancor and will bring only confusion."

President Roosevelt's criticism of dictators in his Constitution Day speech has met with no response from tropical fuehrers in Central America and it is unlikely that their subjects will hear of the speech because government censorship does not permit its publication.
Within about two years the strength of the British metropolitan, or home, air force has been tripled, according to the latest reports on British military plane strength.

Dwight Deere Wiman was protesting amiably last week at this column's suggestion that it might be he who would produce the adaptation of "On Borrowed Time," the Lawrence Edward Watkin novel to which John Hay Whitney aoquired the dramatic rights. Mr. Wiman today formally announces that he will place the play in rehearsal as soon as it is dramatized, and that he has assigned the adaptation to Paul Osborn.

Directors of the Cudahy Packing Company have decided to make no further payments of dividends on the preferred and common stocks "until improved conditions warrant doing so," it was announced yesterday in a letter sent to shareholders by E. A. Cudahy Jr., president.
In an attempt to make grand opera in Chicago the delight of the many, rather than of the few, a new organization, the Chicago City Opera Guild, was announced today.

A determined effort by the WPA to enforce its prohibition on the use of relief workers in jobs that should be on the regular city payroll was foreshadowed yesterday in the appointment by Lieut. Col. Brehon B.

William Loeb, secretary to President Theodore Roosevelt, former Collector of the Port of New York and corporation executive, died here early today in the North Country Community Hospital. He succumbed to pneumonia following an illness of twelve days.

National and international patience and self-restraint; avoidance of force in the pursuit of policy; noninterference in the internal affairs of other nations; the use of peaceful means to adjust differences; the faithful observance of agreements;

Robert McC. Shields's Canvasback won the International Class race in the regatta held by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club today. Canvasback crossed the finish line four seconds ahead of Aileen, owned by Cornelius Shields. The boats sailed a ten-mile course in a fresh northwesterly breeze. The summaries:

The money market here was slightly tighter this week, following the capital outflow leading the franc's decline, and transactions were small because of the decrease in funds available. Franc funds, it was held, were more profitably invested in the forward foreign exchange market.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Flled-By MAX DWORKIN, grocer. 400 E. 169th St.Liabilities, $5,007, assets, $3,100. ARTHUR R. SAFFRAN, salesman, 900 West End Ave.-Liabilities, $3,059; no assets. EASTERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-By HERMAN ANTIN. salesman. 959 Carroll St., Brooklyn.-Liabilities, $1,145.44; no assets.

The salvation of a world in its present turmoil lies in clinging firmly to the church and the principles of Jesus Christ, the Rev. L. A. Edelblute declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Aposties, Ninth Avenue and Twentyeighth Street.
Henry P. Shaw, retired broker, died here yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 57. Born in Lexington, Ky., Mr. Shaw was a graduate of Yale University in 1901.

The Shoe Merchants Council will hold its golf tournament on Sept. 29, instead of Sept. 22, at the Fairview Country Club, Westchester County. Jane Engel, Inc., dress chain store, has acquired the following shops: Town and Country,

Spring St, 64-66, s w cor of Lafayette St, 50.4x73.2x50.3x76.4; Max L. Arnstein, referee, to Andrew Freedman Horne; foreclosure ($50). 2d St, 107-109 E, 50x105.11; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Lane Equities, Inc, 270 Bway; p m mtg $30,182 and building loan mtg $3,295 ($30.50).

After a weekend of diplomatic effort in Rome, the British Government now hopes that it has removed the worst of the soreness Italy has felt since the conclusion of the Nyon anti-piracy agreement a week ago.

President Roosevelt arrived here today for a brief rest at his mothher's home before leaving on Wednesday for a Western trip to take the fight for the objectives of his court reorganization plan and other Administration measures to the country.

Yesterday was the two hundredth anniversary of the birth of Charles Carroll, whom "every schoolboy" knows or used to know as the last surviving signer of the Declaration of Independence for the six years before his death in 1832.

Dr. Hjalmar Horace Greeley Schacht was among those present at the opening of the Nuremberg congress. Immediately afterward he returned to Berlin. A week later he turns up in Genoa, ostensibly on vacation but refusing to comment on reports that his brief appearance at Nuremberg marked his exit from the National Socialist government.

The wheat market has turned reactionary after a bullish week on the prospect of more settled European conditions. Prices, however, closed slightly above the lows, the rebound being helped by a freight shortage,

The New Jersey executive board of the Disabled American Veterans of the World War charged today that the State WPA Administration had ignored the recent order of Administrator Harry L. Hopkins to give needy veterans preference on WPA employment rolls.

This city can take special pleasure in bidding welcome to the American Legion. Precisely twenty years ago many of the men who are now meeting here in national convention came to New York in uniforms which marked their enlistment in the service of their country and it was from this port that they embarked for a foreign battlefield.

The Rev. Dr. J. V. Moldenhawer, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street, asked his congregation yesterday morning to join him in three prayers for the state of the world.
The German wholesale price index on Sept 8 Stood at 106.3, against 106.4 on Sept. 1. Prices of copper, zinc, tin and goods partly manufactured from these metals have fallen 0.9 per cent;

Miss Mary Leavitt Crist, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Miller Crist of Swarthmore, who are the heads of both Wildcliffe Junior College and the Mary Lyon School, was married to Wlliam Thomas Fleming Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Fleming of Fort Smith, Ark., last evening in the Swarthmore Presbyterian Church. Dr. John Ellery Tuttle, pastor emeritus of the church, performed the ceremony.

The Millinery Stabilization Commission and the joint board of the Millinery Workers Union issued statements over the week-end explaining their cooperative program for raising standards in the industry.

In his letter to THE TIMES A. M. Pinney states that in my letter I tend to confuse constitutional oligarchy with true democracy. The subject of my letter was not true democracy but the question whether ours is a government where the majority in immediate action is expressly restrained by the Constitution.

William D. Hymers, who took over the management of Government financed sugar properties at Central Lafayette a year ago when they passed to cooperative ownership, was buried this afternoon at Guayama.

In addition to a motion before Supreme Court Justice Witschief at White Plains for an injunction to stop noises, taxpayers of East Yonkers and Lawrence Park, adjoining communities west of Bronxville, will hold a protest meeting on Sept. 28 against explosions and other noises incident to sinking the Delaware aqueduct shafts.
Opening of the new Honors College at Wesleyan University with an initial attendance of forty members of the junior and senior classes was announced today by President James L. McConaughy.
It is recorded of the death of Pierrot: "As the dawn broke, Pierrot fell into his last sleep. Then upon tip-toe,
Gyrations the price of September corn and the development of congestion i? that delivery were the feature o? the grain markets on the Board o? Trade here last week.

JAMES HOWARD WELLARD set out to be flip with the English, but he has read too many books. Shakespeare, Dickens, Fielding, Kipling, keep getting in his way. Mr. Wellard is an exceedingly clever young Englishman who grew up in an orphan asylum over there and won awards in London University that made it possible for him to come to America. Still under 30,

The number of registrants with the United States Employment Service in August was 29 per cent below a year ago, and the service attained its second highest total in monthly placements in private industry, Secretary Perkins reported today.

The Sunday strollers who inspected the American Legion trailer colony at Mott Avenue and 138th Street in the Bronx yesterday afternoon proved a little too much even for that hardy outfit. The site was prepared for the occasion by the borough administration and is a little more than an acre in size.

Warning that nations across the sea are preparing for another conflict, Harry W. Colmery, national commander of the American Legion, said last night at a memorial concert for the war dead that the Legion was here to launch a mighty crusade to keep the United States at peace.

Featured by the remarkable allaround work of Captain Robert Dulaney, the Fort Hamilton four crushed the Governors Island Blues, 14-5, yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in an Eastern League game before a crowd of 5,000. Proceeds of the contest, which determined the winner of the Rogers Trophy, will go to the Fort Hamilton Chapter Fund of the Army Relief Society.
The East Orange Post 73 Drum and Bugle Corps of East Orange, N. J., won first place today in an American Legion drum and bugle corps contest held as a part of the Constitution Week observance.

Disavowing political motives for himself and the American Legion, Harry W. Colmery, its national commander, in his annual report, made public yesterday, called upon nearly 1,000,000 followers to help rouse the country to the dangers besetting constitutional checks and balances and threatening the independence of the judiciary.

AROUND the corner of the Yankee Stadium came Al Schacht, the Clown Prince of Baseball. The last report on Mr. Schacht was that he was making a hatful of money going around the country and putting on his baseball comedy acts in minor league parks. This time he was not wearing a hat. It probably was at home, stuffed with money.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Martha Hannah Parke, daughter of William More Parke of 1 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn Heights, and the late Mrs. Parke, to Charles Henry Carter 3d, son of Mrs. Edward H. McKeon of Baltimore, which will take place the evening of Oct. 9 in Grace Church, Brooklyn. The Rev. David Atwater will perform the ceremony.
Members of the Latter Day Saints Church in and near this capital of Mormonism fasted today because they fear a depression--their hunger an example to 625,000 faithful throughout the world.

The newest trick in Japanese competition with the United States for Latin American markets as discovered here involves the labeling of Japanese goods "Made in U. S. A.," and the shipment of them to several countries in violation of quotas limiting Japanese imports.

Revisions in the departure and running times of their long-distance trains between the East and West will be put into effect next Sunday by the New York Central System and the Pennsylvania Railroad in connection with revision of their time-tables incident to the termination of Daylight Saving Time.

Making the third appearance of its United States tour before a crowd of 5,500 at Commercial Field in Brooklyn yesterday, the Barcelona Football Club gained its third triumph, beating a team of American League stars by 2-0.

Winners of the traffic safety contest conducted in the last school year among school teachers and students by the C. I. T. Safety Foundation, set up by the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation, were announced yesterday.

The eleventh annual Pacific Southwest tennis tournament, listing almost every well-known amateur star in the world, opened before 4,000 fans today with seeded players advancing rather easily, but with the favored Moody-Budge tandem forced to divide an exhibition.

Louis Harlow of Milton, Mass., organizer and for ten years director of the Aleppo Shrine Band, died today at a hospital here at the age of 69. Mr. Harlow directed his band on the first program broadcast from WEEI.

Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Grant Ecker of 38 East Eighty-fifth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christine Ecker, to Harold Dorr Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Miller of Flushing, Queens.

It has long been the belief of sport fishermen that any one who would shoot or harpoon a fish "would think nothing of stealing sheep." Therefore, it is not at all surprising that the Freeport Boatmen's Association is up in arms over the rumor that they have been taking out anglers who harpooned tuna when they couldn't make them accept their bait.

The neutrality laws of the United States were denounced by the Rev. Dr. J. T. Van Burkalow, pastor of the St. James Methodist Church, Madison Avenue at 126th Street, in his sermon yesterday morning, as giving aid to the aggressor nations to the disadvantage of the innocent.

William M. Hurley, treasurer of the Hurley Shoe Company in Rockland, died today at his home here at the age of 67. He had been a manufacturer of men's shoes since 1893. He was for many years the owner of Willow Brook Farm in Pembroke and a breeder of blooded Guernsey stock exhibited throughout the country.

Lugging sail in a piping west-southwest wind that reached 23 knots strength and blew up seas, Walther von Hutschler today sailed his German sloop Pimm to her third straight victory in the Star Class international championship.
The Athletics took both ends of a double-header from Cleveland today, 8 to 4 and 5 to 3, dropping the Indians into fifth place behind the Red Sox.

External trade statistics again are exceptionally unfavorable, with August's figures contributing further to the decline in the franc. The value of exports in the month was 1,861,000,000 francs, against 1,872,000,000 in July and 1.169,000.000 in August, 1936.

It is axiomatic that a football team is only as strong as its line, that a strong line in front of a weak backfield is a happier set-up than a powerful set of ball carriers without support up forward.

The main attack of the forces of anti-Christ is against the home, the State and the church, the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Eighteen months ago Julius Pulvino was found murdered in a bar at 8,704 Eighteenth Avenue, Brooklyn. The police arrested a few days later Frank J. Keenan, a 26-yearold longshoreman, of 461 Fortysixth Street, Brooklyn. Reluctantly they released him, unable to link him to the murder of Pulvino.

American Legion playboys took over the city early yesterday afternoon with individual and mass attacks of clowning. By 7:30 P. M. they held Times Square against all comers, had traffic blocked off in the theatre zone from Thirty-fourth Street to Columbus Circle and were priming up at countless bars for new assaults.

Carl Crow, who has been an advertising man in China for twenty-five years and has just had a book of experiences, "40,000,000 Customers," published by Harpers, will arrive here today, His publishers say that he "escaped" from Shanghai with only two suitcases and enough money to his fare to New York. He arrived in Seattle last Wednesday.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that Three Star Clothes, a Chicago corporation had entered into a stipulation with the commission to discontinue representing in its advertising that its suits were made of wool, unless they should be made from all wool materials.

Never trailing, though the losers pulled even at the thirteenth, Walter Tynan and Walter Caswell triumphed over Arthur H. Arnold and Jack Creavy, 1 up, in the final of the first annual member-guest invitation best-ball handicap golf tournament at the Tamarack Country Club today.

Recommending that the Federal Government concern itself with the problems of city dwellers as it has with a farmers through the Department of Agriculture, the National Resources Committee transmitted to President Roosevelt today a report based on the first national study of urban communities undertaken in the Cros United States.

Divisional Coast Guard headquarters reported today that fifteen men were rescued from the Canadian motor barge J. H. Redfern a few minutes before it sank four miles off Point Betsie, north of Frankfort, Mich.

Recent years have witnessed a very rapid increase in the mechanization of Soviet agriculture. Take as a single example that whereas there were 32,000 harvesting combines working two years ago, they had risen by Aug. 1 of this year to 121,000, which are scheduled to reap more than 42 per cent of the current grain crop.
The Dodgers today took their first look at the remodeled Cub ball park, with its nice brick wall and lovely vines already growing profusely, and they didn't like it-especially the brick wall.

Despite murky, overcast skies and a chilly wind that brought an occasional gust of rain, 15,000 persons crowded the Central Park Mall yesterday afternoon to participate in the patriotic youth demonstration that concluded Constitution Week in New York City.

The seventy-second year of the Peddie School will begin on Wednesday evening, when the student body will meet for special exercises in Ayer Chapel. Eighteen States and eight foreign countries are represented among the students.

The world's debt to the Christian Church is in figures "too high to be computed," the Rev. Ernest R. Palen, pastor of the Middle Collegiate Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

One man was killed in a battle when a dozen Franco sympathizers tried to escape with the Spanish Government submarine C-2, laid up in the navy yard here for repairs since early September. The dead man is Jose Maria Gabarain-Goni, 25 years old, believed to be a submarine officer.
Twenty-eight Scholarships with a total value of more than $67,000 have been awarded to freshmen in Columbia College, it was announced yesterday by Frank H. Bowles, director of admissions.

Tense activity among all foreigners has been provoked here as the result of the warning issued by the Japanese at Shanghai yesterday that there was likelihood of air attacks on all sections of Nanking beginning after tomorrow noon.

In the most ambitious aerial operation yet undertaken by the Japanese, big squadrons of their war planes bombed Nanking twice yesterday, apparently in retaliation for the spectacular raids carried out by Chinese planes Saturday night against Japanese warships and land positions in the Shanghai area.

A pair from the Garden City Golf Club, Henry Picoli and W. E. Stockhausen, today won the Nassau Country Club annual invitation best-ball golf tournament when they turned back Charles R. Shelden, Siwanoy ace and co-winner of last year's event, and Harold W. Matzinger of Indian Creek, 3 and 2.

Apartments in houses on Park Avenue continue to be the center of attraction for families seeking living quarters for occupancy this Fall. Agents and brokers announced over the week-end lists of names they have added to tenant rosters in buildings on this thoroughfare and others streets throughout the city.

Executors of the estate of Andrew W. Mellon are expected to file his will for probate tomorrow, the first step in what may be a prolonged legal process that will involve inventory, payment of taxes, disposal of resources and other adjustments.
Alexander Korda and Samuel Goldwyn, leading figures of motion picture finance, announced today they were negotiating for the joint ownership of the United Artists Corporation.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 81 per cent of capacity, 3 points down from the rate two weeks before. The intervening week contained the Labor Day holiday and was not indicative.

Dean John T. Madden of New York University's School of Commerce. Accounts and Finance, announced yesterday the setting up of a new department on public utilities and transportation concurrent with "the expansion of government regulation in the increasing list of public utility industries."

It is understood here that the British Cabinet will discuss next week the franc's position, but that direct interference is unlikely. The normal policy of the Treasury is to examine all financial situations affecting sterling as they develop, and no official objection was taken to the fall in the franc's sterling rate to 147 on Thursday.

Short covering in September and October lard as the result of a good shipping demand for the cash product and steadily decreasing supplies in cold storage ran the price of the near-by futures up 1 to 11/4 cents a pound last week, and while the best prices were not maintained, September contracts, which closed yesterday at $11.62 1/2 for 100 pounds, showed a net gain of $1.25.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Isabelle Kirkpatrick Marckwald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Hunt Marckwald of this place, to Daniel Bushnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Davis Bushnell of Montclair.

As Coney Island's annual Mardi Gras wound up at daybreak yesterday morning with an estimated record attendance for the week of 3,000,000 persons, officials began laying plans to entertain members of the American Legion this week.

Beer advertising linage in newspapers for the coming Fall and Winter season should run substantially ahead of last year, because most brewers have decided not to relax their advertising campaigns during the cold weather months, according to agency executives.

The South Shore Polo Club gained a 5-4 Eastern Polo League victory over the Blind Brook Knights today at Hazard Field. Bernie Blausen took a short pass from Walter Eaton in the closing seconds of play and converted it for the winning tally.

Herbert George Golding, secretary of Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company and for a half-century associated with its Yonkers mills, died last night of a heart attack, shortly after dinner, at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Arthur E. Snyder of 322 Bellevue Avenue. His age was 63.
The Paterson Panthers defeated the Mount Vernon Cardinals to remain undefeated in the American Football Association today, 17-0.
Asturians came out of their rugged strongholds today and delivered a furious surprise attack on the Insurgent line along the valley of the Sella River, east of Gijon.

With its practice of common sense, Christianity is a golden mean between narrow intolerance and an easy license of belief and action the Rev. Dr Alfred B. Moldenke pastor of St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue at Fiftyfourth Street, declared yesterday morning.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler tonight arrived in the area where the army, navy and air manoeuvres begin tomorrow. The area comprises most of Mecklenburg, part of Pomerania and Brandenburg on the Baltic Coast.
John Laing, well-known British general contractor and home builder, will arrive in New York today on the Queen Mary for a study of building operations and housing trends in this country.

There was entertaining today at several homes in the Summer colony. Mrs. Clarence W. Dolan had luncheon guests at Seaweed and Mrs. James B. Duke was hostess at Rough Point. Mr. and Mrs. Crawford Hill gave a dinner tonight at Elm Tree Cottage and Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt entertained at Oakland Farm.

Three of the newest anti-aircraft searchlight batteries capable of illuminating war planes as high as six miles from the ground, will be used tomorrow night to add a touch of color to the air pageant during the American Legion' parade.

Five Royal Air Force flying boats reached Malta from England today to help in protecting commerce from "pirates" in the Mediterranean. It is understood that they will patrol the narrows between Malta and Sicily and Malta and Pantellaria, Italy's heavily fortified base near Tunis.
The Dresdner Bank, which has done a good business this year, on Thursday rebought from the Government its shares which were taken over during the financial crisis of 1931.

Edward F. Barrett, vice president and a director of the Long Island Lighting Company, will on Oct. 1 become president of the company, succeeding Ellis L. Phillips, who will become chairman of the board, it was announced yesterday.

The American Legion's fun and honor society - La Societe des 40 Hommes et 8 Chevaux-opened its convention last night a day ahead of the parent organization with Mayor La Guardia, a member, and Governor Lehman as principal speakers of the opening session, or "promenade," as they call it.
The University of San Francisco's rejuvenated Dons started their 1937 football campaign today with a 7-to-0 victory over St. Mary's University of San Antonio, Texas.
William James Whiteside, wireless operator at the Father Point (Que.) station on the St. Lawrence River at the time of the Titanic disaster in 1912, died yesterday while visiting his parents here.

Championship rosettes were awarded to a pair of brown geldings, Miss Anne Miller's Casque and Richard I. N. Weingart's Lough Foyle, to climax the tenth annual Glen Head Horse Show held today on the estate of S. H. Townsend.

Harvesting of the new soy bean crop is under way in various parts of the main producing area, and official returns Indicate that with normal weather the yield will probably be the second largest on record.

Registration for the evening elementary schools for adults will take place Wednesday and classes will begin next Monday, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday in announcing that sixty-five schools and annexes had been set aside by the Board of Education for free educational instruction to adults.

Unfilled orders have reached the highest level in the history of North American Aviation, Inc., officials of the company announced this week-end. The backlog of orders now stands at approximately $9,200,000, an increase of $4,000,000 over the first of the year.

The Army Relief Society, born at the New York home of Mrs. Daniel S. Lamont at the close of the SpanishAmerican War, grew out of the dire need of the widows and orphans of soldiers killed in that war.

ACKERLY--Eugenie, at her residence, 135 West 104th St., on Sept. 19, 1937. mother of the late Vera, daughter of the late Rosina and Antonio Mestri, wife of the late Archibald. Funeral. services at the the Campbell Funeral Church, Broadway and 66th St., Wednesday, 'Sept. 22, at 2 P. M. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

Two five-story buildings at 177 Church Street and 78-82 Reade Street, the northeast corner, have been sold by the heirs of Eliza L. Edgar to the 177 Church Street, Inc., a corporation controlled by Morris Brukenfeld.
Using line-ups studded with fresh farm team talent, the Senators divided with the White Sox today in a double-header, winning the opener, 5 to 4, and. dropping the nightcap, 9 to 1.

In accordance with a resolution adopted by the Board of Education at its meeting last Thursday, all public schools will be closed tomorrow, providing a general holiday for this city's 1,145,000 school children and 40,000 teachers.

At its first meeting of the 19371938 season, held at the Hotel Astor yesterday morning, the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., featured on its demonstration program the work presented at Summer conventions of dancing masters in various cities.

Greetings of "Hochs" rather than "Heils" filled the air yesterday at Old Point Comfort Park, the Bronx, where 5,000 gayly dressed persons witnessed a ceremony that started 102 years ago on the banks of the Weser River in Germany as a gesture of thanksgiving after a bountiful harvest.

The Rev. Dr. William H. Rogers, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street, presented in his sermon last even ing six reasons why a Biblical Christian should reject evolution He said it was "a pagan theory';
The Pennsylvania entries in the National League divided their doubleheader today, Philadelphia taking the opener, 8 to 1, and the Pirates winning the second, 5 to 1.

Christ must be forever separated by the church from the war spirit, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Persecution of religious minorities under European dictatorship and the readiness of Christians to suffer martyrdom- was cited in their sermons here yesterday by three members of the clergy, two of whom recently had returned from abroad.

A. De Bary Lyon, 23-year-old son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Lyon of Harrow Hill on Muttontown Road here, died early this morning in Nassau Hospital at Mineola of injuries received earlier when he was struck by an automobile while crossing Jericho Turnpike to reach his own car.
Execution of twenty-six more convicted "spies and wreckers" in widely separated sections of Soviet Russia was disclosed today.

Holders in this country of Unstamped Government of the French Republic twenty-year 7 1/2 per cent bonds, dated June 1, 1921, and the twenty-five-year 7s, dated Dec. 1, 1924, have been advised by the French Government, to present their bonds at the offices of J. P. Morgan Co., here or in Paris,
Purchase of excess anthracite reserves by the State of Pennsylvania was recommended today in a report made public by W. Jett Lauck, chairman of the State Anthracite Coal Industry Commission.

A letter to Mayor La Guardia characterizing as a "rank injustice" the failure of his administration to restore water rates to the level prevailing in December, 1933, when a 50 per cent increase became effective, was made public yesterday by the First Avenue Association.
THE DEAD MARCH-Text by Samuel Taylor Moore, narrated by Boake garter; musical score by Erno Rapee. Production conceived and directed by "Bud" Pollard Presented by Imperial Pictures. At the Broadway.

Special nurses called to attend a 5-year-old boy at the J. B. Thomas Hospital here after the child had been operated on for an upsidedown stomach went on a "stayaway" strike because the case was an "insurance case" and they would not get their pay for a year.

The surprise package of the Carnival of Champions that Mike Jacobs will offer at the Polo Grounds in New York Thursday night may turn out to be none other than Marcel Thil, the baldheaded French middleweight.
Walter E. Edge, former United States Ambassador to France, and Mrs. Edge; Justice George Sutherland of the United States Supreme Court and Mrs. Sutherland;

A chartered bus loaded with Legionnaires bound from Worcester, Mass., to New York City for the American Legion convention left the road and crashed into a tree near the Wethersfield-Hartford line early today.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Ruth Carolyn Stenberg, daughter of A. Godfrey Stenberg of New Bedford and Mattapoisett, Mass., and the late Mrs. Stenberg, to Dr. Rockwood Keith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Keith of Worcester, Mass.

Miss Rhoda Herrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham J. Herrick of 1,654 Fiftieth Street, Brooklyn, was married Yesterday afternoon in Garfield Temple, Brooklyn, to Murray Cohen, son of Jacob Cohen, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mrs. Cohen, by the Rev. Isaac Landsman.

One hundred and thirty employes of a local cookie making concern whose proprietor organized the business during the depression to give them employment when work was curtailed in his candy machinery factory, found themselves out of jobs today as a result of their strike. This strike demanded a 33 per cent raise and a preferential shop.

At the beginning of 1929 two and sixty-six hundredths per cent of the metropolitan area of New York City, including parts of three States, was laid out in public parks. This gave each inhabitant of the area eighty-eight ten thousandths of an acre of park.

Scoring his fifth victory in the ninth round, Paul Keres, brilliant young expert representing Estonia, today strengthened his lead in the international chess masters tournament. He defeated V. Ragosin of Russia in a queen's gambit declined lasting thirty-nine moves.
Mrs. Herbert Hoover, wife of the nation's former Chief Executive, said today that she planned to retire shortly from the presidency of the national organization of the Girl Scouts of America.

The New York Cocoa Exchange will announce today that it will award a first prize of $1,000 for the best thesis on the subject, "New Uses for Cocoabeans and Products of Cocoabeans." Five additional prizes of $100 each will be awarded to the five next best essays submitted.

Belief that international cooperation, if it can still be obtained, may yet be effective in ending the bloodshed in the Far East will be expressed by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, in his speech to the League of Nations Assembly tomorrow morning, it is understood.

The inedex of French wholesale prices has advanced from 580 at the end of July to 591 at the end of August. The rise was due solely to the higher prices for domestic products, which climbed from 584 to 604.

A seventy-five-foot boom crane of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation was borrowed by the Glenn L. Martin Aircraft Company to swing into place the outer wings and motors of what will be, upon its launching next month, the largest flying boat in the world.

Miss Lucille Anne Murphy, daughter of Mrs. James Dunworth Murphy of this city and the late Mr. Murphy, was married to James Arthur Walker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Smith Walker, also of New York, yesterday afternoon in St. Elizabeth's Catholic Church, 187th Street and Wadsworth Avenue, by the Rev. James J. Seery.

Herbert E. Maxson, vice president of the six fire Insurance companies of the America Fore Insurance and Indemnity Group, who has had charge for the last thirteen years of the local department of the Continental, Fidelity-Phenix, American Eagle and First American companies at the home office, 80 Maiden Lane, will retire on Dec. 1, it was announced yesterday.

Secretary Morgenthau has assigned Harold N. Graves, the Treasury's administrative expert, to overhaul the Internal Revenue Bureau. Officials said today that the projected re-gearing of tax collecting machinery should eliminate "red tape," speed the flow of revenue...
The Reds dropped the first game of a double-header to the Bees, 7 to 6, today after using twenty-one men in a free-hitting contest, but came back to win, 2 to 0.

With a brilliant putting surge which won four out of the last five holes, W. H. Taft of Montclair and Marin Issler of Rock Spring today won he Montclair Golf Club invitation ??est-ball tournament, defeating H. Kimball Halligan of Montclair and Or. S. G. Lee Jr. of Essex Fells, ?? up, in nineteen holes.

Frank E. Gannett, chairman of the National Committee to Uphold Constitutional Government, in a statement today challenging the "accuracy and the fairness" of President Roosevelt's Constitution Day address, accused him of "a poorly camouflaged attempt to destroy the Constitution by undermining the people's confidence in their judiciary and in lawyers."
Colonel Jesus C. Ogarte, commander-in-chief of the Peruvian cavalry and a prominent figure in politics in Peru, died today as his train neared the Dearborn Street Station. His age was 53.

Imports of gold in August were [Pound]30,708,680, making a total of [Pound]242,693,838 in the first eight months of 1937, against [Pound]195,474,259 correspondingly last year. August's exports of the metal were [Pound]6,597,320.

The engagement of Miss Edith Wynne Groff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alden D. Groff of this place, to Donald Brendel Geddes, son of Mrs. L. Brendel Geddes of Zanesville, Ohio, and of Donald Y. Geddes of Elizalbeth, has been announced by her parents.

Reflecting the increased weight of new-crop hedging operations, cotton prices last week sank to new low levels since the Autumn of 1933. Net declines in prices for active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 11 to 17 points.
Baron Constantin von Neurath, the Foreign Minister, was today appointed an honorary member of the Schutzstaffeln, the black-uniformed Hitler Elite Guard.

Spencer S. Adams has been elected president of the South Norwalk Trust Company, South Norwalk, Conn., to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Charles E. Hoyt, it was announced yesterday by trustees of the bank.

Mr. and Mrs. S. Carter Hall of this city and Wilton, Conn., formerly of Glens Falls, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Jennings Hall, to Albert O'Beirne Andrews, son of Mrs. Champe S. Andrews of 925 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Andrews of Chattanooga, Tenn., and New Haven, Conn.

Two teams tied for top honors with 73s in the special pro-amateur bestball one-day golf tournament held over the Fairview Country Club course today. They were Johnny Farrell of Baltusrol and Harry S. Bandler, and Walter Doyle of Mount Vernon and Sidney Wilde.

Lorraince seersuckers are held at the suggested retail price of $12.75 with the wholesale price increased from $7.37 1/2 to $7.50, according to an announcement released here today for Haspel Brothers, manufacturers of New Orleans.

THE SHOW IS ON (Third Edition), a revue in two, acts and twenty-one scenes. Sketches by David Freedman and one by Moss Hart. Music and lyrics by the Messrs. Duke, Fetter, Carmichael, Adams, Dietz, Schwartz, Gershwin (George and Ira), Harburg, Arlen, Hupfeld, Irwin, ?? Rodgers. Hart.
The National Resources Committee, in its study, "Our Cities-Their Role in the National Economy," made public today, disclosed some unusual facts about city dwellers. These include:

Mr. and Mrs. August Eimer of Shell Island, East Port Chester, celebrated their sixtieth wedding anniversary today with a luncheon at the Pickwick Arms Hotel here. There were eighty guests present at the luncheon, which featured the diamond wedding anniversary.

While the rank and file of the American Legion spent the day celebrating their arrival, campaign headquarters of the five candidates for national commander of the Legion bustled with activity yesterday.

Outside interest in the oats market here was light last week, but futures showed a firm undertone and the close yesterday showed net gains of 1/4 to 3/8 cent a bushel, with the September position at 31 1/4, December 30 3/8 and Way 31%.

The marriage of Miss Jean Bradley, daughter of Mrs. Jay B. Bradley of Interlaken, to Ray Stephens Ashbery, son of Mrs. George Ashbery of Trumansburg, took place here this afternoon in the Sage Chapel of Cornell University.

Eight new names were written on the list of national outboard champions in the two-day regatta that ended today on the upper James River. In a spectacular and unexpectedly sensational series of upsets only one of all the nine defenders who came to Richmond from coast to coast was able to take back home the same title and trophy he won in 1936.

Richard Sharpe 6th, a member of a family that pioneered in the anthracite industry, died at his country estate at Glen Summit today after a long illness at the age of 85. A native of Carbon County, where his father developed coal lands before coming here to head the Alden Coal Company, Mr. Sharpe attended Yale, where he was graduated in 1875.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 92.4, which compares with 91.2 a week ago, 91 two weeks ago, 91.7 three weeks ago and 91.9 four weeks ago The average of two weeks ago-was the lowest since the last week of February.
Dr. and Mrs. O. H. Perry Pepper of Ithanlea, Ithan, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eulalie Pepper, to Francis A. Lewis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. F. A. Lewis of Bryn Mawr.

Mrs. Reginald Cuyler Elphinstone of 124 East Ninety-first Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Beatrice Barclay Elphinstone, to Henry Van Duzer Wing, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan Wing of this city and Shadow Lodge, Millbrook.
The first official welcome of the city to the American Legion was extended last night by Mayor La Guardia at the reunion dinner of the American Legion Founders in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Food and supplies for an extended stay atop Shiva Temple. unexplored "forest in the sky," were dropped by an airplane today to Dr. Harold E. Anthony, studying the evolutionary effects of isolation on small animals.

A test of New Jersey blue laws will be made on Tuesday in two Gloucester County towns when voters will be asked to approve Sunday motion pictures and sports. No municipality in the county permits football, baseball or movies on Sunday.

Pink and lavender asters and dahlias decorated the home of Robert T. Frisbie of New Britain yesterday afternoon for the marriage of his niece, Miss Charlotte Frisbie, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Frisbie, to Frederick Hunt Gardner of Cambridge, Mass., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Gardner.

The Governors Island polo team began its defense of the Colyer Trophy by routing the First Division, 13--8, in the opening contest of their annual series yesterday at Morris Memorial Field. The series has been shortened from five games to the best two of three.

An attempt to set up a prefabricated house in one day was started yesterday by Herman T. Backhus and eight helpers. This evening, after one full and one-half day's work, one-fourth of the structure remained to be put in place, the result of joint trouble and a half day's rain.

The Rev. A. Muller Eggen of the Waverly Lutheran Church, Truman, Minn., former chaplain of the Minnesota department of the American Legion, likened the deaths of our soldiers to the crucifixion of Christ in a sermon yesterday morning as guest preacher at Zion Lutheran Church, Fourth Avenue and Sixty-third Street, Brooklyn.
The arma ments program still is exerting an influence on British trade, imports for eight months--117,800,000 higher than last year-reflecting the increase in needed raw materials at dearer prices.
Three students of St. Joseph's Seminary at Dunwoodie, Yonkers, were ordained to the Roman Catholic priesthood at services in the seminary today by Bishop Bernard of the Bahama Islands.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Mulroy of South Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rita Catherine Mulroy, to Melville P. Chamberlain Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Melville P. Chamberlain of Hightstown.

A guard and two convicts were slain, the warden critically injured and at least seven other persons were wounded today in savage fighting with knives and clubs that followed an abortive attempt by seven convicts to escape from Folsom Penitentiary.

The money market was under a strain this week to meet the mid-month settlements and the requirements of commerce and trade, with the result that there was considerable recourse to the discount market, where little inclination toward private purchasing was shown.

The din of the carnival of fun in Times Square swirled about the Hotel Astor yesterday, but within a series of consecutive committee meetings carried forward the preliminary business of the American Legion Auxiliary on a muted key, except for one incident.

Fire which swept this Allegany County hamlet today burned seven homes to the ground and badly damaged a church and several dwellings. Sparks from a defective chimney in a 40-mile-an-hour gale were blamed.

The War Office announced today that public donations to the army since July 7, when the conflict with China began, had reached 16,000,000 yen. Army spokesmen said these voluntary contributions in a little more than two months indicated patriotism was running higher than in any of Japan's previous wars.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Gleeson of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Sargent Gleason, to Edward Dunbar Rich Jr. of Beverly Hills, Calif., son of Colonel and Mrs. Edward D. Rich of Lansing, Mich.
The Brookhattan Soccer Club defeated the New York Americans, 3--2, at Starlight Park yesterday before 3,000 fans.

The Chattanooga Drum and Bugle Corps of Davis King Summers Post in Chattanooga, Tenn., one of the most unusual units in the American Legion, brought its own mud supply with it last night, when it paraded into the Cadillac Hotel in Times Square.

With examinations for teaching licenses in 124 vocational and academic high school subjects listed for this Fall, the Board of Examiners has now returned to its pre-depression level and faces the busiest year it has had since 1929, Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg, chairman of the board. disclosed yesterday.

Edward F. Howe, a retired police lieutenant who was twice cited for meritorious conduct during his forty-two years in the department, died yesterday at his home, 3,034 Kingsland Avenue, the Bronx, after an illness of two months.
Members of society and their children attended the tenth annual Glen Head horse show today on the Stephen Townsend estate and, in spite of rain at intervals, crowded about the show ring.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale'a, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's and Womrath's:
Chief Justice Hughes will return from a vacation Tuesday to prepare for the annual conference of senior Circuit Court justices starting Thursday.

The heroic dash of two prospectors, one of them seriously ill, from the plateau of Central New Guinea to the coast proved vain yesterday when David Lyall died in Daru of beriberi. He was 26 years old. Rescuers are on the way to the interior to aid sick native porters who were left behind along the shores of the Fly River.

A Bronx deal representing an investment of about $1,000,000 was closed when Abraham Weinstein, operator, sold to a client of Goodman Mabel the three five-and-ahalf story apartment houses covering the triangular block at Freeman Street,

On the eve of its national convention the American Legion was hailed from New York City pulpits yesterday as a bulwark of peace. The Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said in his morning sermon:

A bridge party and tea will be held at the Pierre on Oct. 2 under the auspices of the alumnae of the Academy of Mount St. Vincent. The event marks the nintieth anniversary of the founding of the academy.

Unexpected and lively opposition to American Legion endorsement of the Copeland-Bloom pre-grade educational bill caused the withdrawal yesterday of two resolutions presented at the meeting of the American Legion Child Welfare Committee at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Idaho Power Company - Seven months to July 31: Net income after expenses, taxes, amortization, interest, depreciation and $16.000 surtax on undistributed profits amounted to $781,897, equal to $12.36 each on 63,257 combined preferred shares.
Percy A. Chapman, Associate Professor of Modern Lauguages at Princeton University since 1913, died Sunday midnight of a heart attack on board the liner Queen Mary, which arrived here yesterday.

The first reunion of the officers and men of the U. S. S. Quinnebaug, which operated out of Inverness, Scotland, as a mine layer in the North Sea during the World War as part of the United States Mine Laying SAuadron, was held yesterday with a luncheon in Fitzgerald's restaurant, 845 Eighth Avenue.

Mrs. George Dwire of Essex Fells and Glen Ridge, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane Dwire, to Joseph Paull Marshall, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Marshall of 2,405 Tracy Place in Washington.

While urging preparedness, Mrs. Herbert Hoover, wife of the former President, told the Women World War Veterans yesterday that future wars should be planned and declared by those who fought in the last war as the best way of avoiding hasty action.
Stocks rallied and closed steadier and lower, after dropping to lowest levels of the movement; turnover, 1,550,350 shares. United States Government and other bonds lower; transactions, $9,178,700.

With Nanking, Shanghai and Madrid as warnIng examples that air raids on open towns, denounced as barbarous during the World War, have become commonplace features of modern warfare, Berlin and all Northern Germany went on a "war footing" today as part of the most elaborate and most realistic war manoeuvres in German history.

Japanese troops in tanks and armored trains advanced tonight to within fifteen miles of Paoting, important Chinese stronghold in North China. Steadily driving detachments of stubborn Chinese defenders down the Peiping-Hankow Railway, Japanese occupied the towns of Kiucheng and Ansuhsien.

The Treasury Procurement Division today invited bids on the following lots of textiles: To be opened Sept 20, for delivery by Nov. 10: 563-T, printed dimity, 94x64. 35inch minimum, 17,200 yards: 564-T, plain bleached painsook. 94x78 185,800 yards:
The Pompton Lakes High eleven recorded a 13-to-7 triumph over the Clearwater (Fla.) High team before a crowd of 5,500 at Hinchliffe Stadium tonight.
A tentative itinerary for President Roosevelt's trip, which will take him through the Northwest and out of the United States into Victoria, B. C., was announced today.

The first roller skating party of a series to be given through the Autumn for the members of the Summer colony took place tonight at the rink at Newport Beach. Mrs. Dan W. Jones had charge of arrangements.
Into the State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations the prudent outlander will make no rash entrance. It is a State of declared war between The McCoy, Mayor of Pawtucket, and Governor Quinn.
Mrs. Helen Hazard Beadleston Little, widow of Julian McCarty Little, mining engineer, died at her estate here this morning of pneumonia. She was born forty-six years ago in Shrewsbury, N. J.
Cornell's football squad resumed routine training today, anticipating tomorrow's final heavy scrimmage before the opener with Penn State Saturday.

A study of New York building reoords for the first eight months of 1937 shows that the upturn in permits for new construction in Brooklyn and Queens has more than offset the sharp drop which has ocourred in Manhattan and the Bronx, with the result that the estimated expenditure for the five boroughs rose to $117,593,000, as compared with $107,202,000 for the same period last year.

Offered in three lines and twelve kinds of bodies,the 1938 models of the Studebaker automobile will be put on display today in dealers' showrooms throughout the country. The new cars had been previewed at South Bend, Ind., by automobile editors of newspapers and trade journals.

About 2,000 workers for some 250 manufacturers and sixty jobbers were called out in a stoppage effective this morning by Locals 2, 24 and 42 of the Millinery Workers Union because the shops are alleged to have failed to comply with the rules drawn up and approved this Summer under the auspices of the Millinery Stabilization Commission.

Three of the nine existing world one-mile outboard records were broken today as the nation's leading pilots churned up the James River in time trials to bring to a close the ninth annual national championships.

The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that the United Automobile Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, was entitled to exclusive bargaining rights in the Bendix Products Corporation plants at South Bend, Ind.

Advocator, one of Seabiscuit's lesser stable mates, shook himself free of six rivals at the eighth pole and raced home to victory by two lengths for the Shawsheen Purse, feature of the opening day card at Rockingham Park today.

Manufacturers and retailers stand almost evenly divided on the question of whether the fixed trade-in should be abolished or placed under some control, the National Better Business Bureau announced yesterday in the third and final installment of a nationwide survey on the subject of trade-in allowances.
Mrs. John Mahony of Belmont, Mass., has announced here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Janet Mahony, to Robert V. Daly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Daly of this city and Long Beach, L. I.

Esau Hartwright of Old Greenwich, died at the Greenwich Hospital last night at the age of 89. He had been a resident of the community for fifty-eight years. He had engaged in the florist business for many years.
Controller Frank J. Taylor asked that his force be increased by sixtyeight employes in submitting yesterday the departmental estimate for 1938 for the office of the Con- on Sunda troller.

The announcement of Claude R. Porter of the Interstate Commerce Commission that the commission would prepare its own plan of reorganization for the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad was in conformity with the

Accused of obtaining about $500,000 from some 1,500 investors through fraudulent stock market transactions, J. Overton Paine, head of the Paine Statistical Corporation here, and four of his alleged aides were charged with fraud today in the purchase and sale of securities in warrants issued at the office of William Wachenfeld, Essex County Prosecutor.
