The engagement of Miss Ruth Vette, daughter of Mrs. Meta Vette of Rego Park, Queens, to Harry F. Schroeter Jr. of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry F. Schroeter, has been announced by her mother.

Mayor La Guardia spent an hour yesterday afternoon, during which he appeared in a smiling, jovial mood, at the headquarters of the Aviators Post 743 of the American Legion in the Midston House, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, where open house was being held.

Hirosi Saito, the Japanese Ambassador, was summoned to the State Department late today by R. Walton Moore, Acting Secretary of State, for what he agreed to announce as a general conversation concerning the Sino-Japanese situation.

Miss Edith Mary Young, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert S. Young of this place, was married here this evening to Dr. George S. Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward K. Baker of Baltimore, at the home of the bride's parents.

Mrs. Thomas Fortune Ryan 2d of Sheridan, Wyo., sued today for separate maintenance and a property settlement from her estranged husband, grandson of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan. Her petition accused Mr. Ryan of "intolerable" indignities, desertion and failure to provide.

By far the longest session in the international chess masters' tournament was recorded today between Samuel Reshevsky of New York, the United States champion, and Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia, chosen by the International Federation as challenger for the world title. They finished their adjourned match from the fifth round and it resulted in a draw.
Edwin Sparkman Young, a retired department executive of the old Consolidated Gas Company, died yesterday in the New Rochelle Hospital at the age of 80. He had lived here for half century. Mr.

79th St, 226 W, 17x102.21; Hugh J. Riley to Brooklyn Trust Co, 177 Montague St, Brooklyn; p m mtg, 5 years, 4 per cent; $27,00P). 122d St, 260-62 W. 50x100.11; Vivldon Realty Corp, Michael Lichtman, president, to Thomas S. Doughty, 12 Chestnut St, Ridgewood, N. J., and another, trustees of Eliza G. Board; p m mtg, due Sept. 1. 1947. 31/.-414 ner cent: S17.500.

Boston Insurance Company -- As of June 30, 1937, total assets amounted to $25,009,997, compared with $26,451,748 at end of 1936; surplus based on investment at market was $14,979,994, against $16,253,741; earned premiums, $4,707,638, against $4,547,850, and cash of $1,032,532, against $1,376,639. Investments at market value

Eight teams remained in the "amateur world series" of the American Baseball Congress today with only two of the group undefeated. The unbeaten teams are Battle Creek United Steel and Wire, which halted Sheboygan, Wis., 8 to 1, and Fresno, Calif., which downed Ada, Okla., 6 to 5.

The American Legion Women were urged last night to make their stand for peace by speakers who addressed more than 750 members of that group of the Legion's nineteenth annual convention at their annual dinner at the Hotel Biltmore.

Robert L. Ripley, cartoonist and creator of the "Believe It or Not" series, opened an exhibition yesterday morning of many of his choicest curiosities at R. H. Macy Co., THE Broadway and Thirty-fourth Street, for the benefit of the United Hospital Fund of New York.

C. L. Hippensteel of Morristown, N. J., a chemical engineer and a member of the technical staff of Bell Telephone Laboratories, 463 West Street, died here today at Mountainside Hospital of Septicemia after a long illness. His age was 40.

Two significant speeches on the question of competition and Government control have been made in the last few days by members of the Administration. The first was by Ernest G. Draper, Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

The Interstate Commerce Commission said today it had extended until Oct. 4 the deadline for the filing of briefs on proposals to increase bus fares between upper New York City and points in New Jersey. The briefs were due today.

Faith in the seamanship of a grizzled veteran of many a North Atlantic blow tonight kept buoyant the hope that the first Endeavour had weathered the gale that separated her from her convoy a week ago.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 19, unless specified: At Tsingtao: Bulmer, Marblehead, Pope, Sept. 20. At Shanghai: Chaumont, Edsall. At Naval Operating Base. Norfol??: Claxton, Dickerson, Sept. 18; Manley. At Washington Yard, Sept. 18: Coyahoga, Potomac.
Six stalwart braves of the Onondaga Indian reservation were bearers today for Mrs. Martha Wilson Manross, forty years a missionary at the reservation, who died Saturday night at the age of 75.

Leon Pettigrew, former Indiana amateur and now one of Al Ciuci's assistants at Fresh Meadow, and his playing partner, Henry Dobbs, gave the field in the weekly one-day pro-amateur tourney something to admire today.

A full-blooded burro was presented by the Colorado delegation to the American Legion convention to Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City at the City Hall this afternoon. Commissioner Arthur Potterton received the delegation and later entertained the veterans at an informal reception in the basement of the Jersey City Armory.

The laundry business throughout the nation is running approximately 30 per cent ahead of last year and is reaching the levels attained at the top of the boom, Stanley Brook, president of the Laundry Owners National Association, reported today. It is likely that $500,000,000 worth of business will be done this year, he said.

Bearing the scripts of twenty-five plays that have been produced on Broadway in the last two seasons but have never been sold to the films, Sidney R. Fleischer, arbiter of screen rights sales on behalf of the Dramatists Guild and producers. will leave Friday for Hollywood.

Options for purchasing 20,715 shares of common stock of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation were outstanding at the close of business on Aug. 31, the company has notified the New York Stock Exchange.

William H. Parsons Jr. made public yesterday an appeal to the author of the recent series of letters informing him that his wife had died in the hands of kidnappers, requesting information that would enable him to find his wife's body and give it proper burial.

George Zengaras, East Side lightweight, fought- a draw with Maxie Berger of Montreal in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Royal Windsor last night. A crowd of 2,000 fans witnessed the battle in the midtown club which for years was known as. the St. Nicholas Arena.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Thomas A. O'Callaghan of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Patricia Eleanor O'Callaghan, to William Sheperdson Abell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Abell of Chevy Chase, Md.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, ordered all central labor bodies and State Labor Federations today to purge themselves of affiliates of the American Newspaper Guild because the Guild had left the federation and joined the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Legionnaires predominated in the gathering of 8,646 which saw yesterday's final skirmish between the Yankees and Tigers in the Stadium, and they saw Vernon Gomez go over the top to victory, not with shot and shell but with the power and cunning of his good left arm.

Steel operations in the United States are scheduled at 76.1 per cent of capacity this week, against 80.4 per cent last week, a decline of 4.3 points, or 5.3 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Aloha M. Wollaston of Larchmont, formerly of Oakland, Calif., to William Edward Malone Jr., son of William E. Malone of this city and the late Mrs. Malone.

The steady rise in the prices of t obligations of the United States j Government was halted yesterday as substantial offerings forced quotations down as much as 12-32 i point. The rest of the bond market fell in sympathy with stocks,

Miss Mary Vail Hewitt, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Dexter Wright Hewitt of Irvingtonon-Hudson, will be wed on Oct. 22 to Edwin H. Mairs 2d, son of Mrs. John Mairs of New York and the late Mr. Mars.
About 9,000 department stores and specialty shops throughout the country are featuring silk this week in window and interior displays and in advertisements.

Joseph Osavia, a West Indian Negro, wanted to return to Jamaica but had no money for a ticket. He tried to solve the difficulty by offering for sale a "deck" of a narcotic to Desk Sergeant William Beaver at the police station.

Andrew W. Mellon's will, the content of which were outlined by his attorney, Donald D. Shepard, on the day of the funeral, was filed here today. The household furnishings in the mansion on Woodland Road Mr. Mellon left to his son, Paul, and his daughter, Ailsa-Mrs. David K. E. Bruce.

The Marine Midland Trust Company has been appointed successor fiscal agent for Antioquia (Republic of Colombia) secured sinking fund gold bonds due on Oct. 1, 1957, issued under agreement dated July 13, 1927, and on supplemental agreements of Nov. 22, 1927, and June 14, 1928. This appointment will be effective on Oct. 15.

With a tropical disturbance reported swinging toward the west coast of Florida instead of toward the Mississippi Valley, a renewal of pressure on the cotton market yesterday carried prices into new low ground, with losses of 9 to 11 points.

The list of the French Line motor ship Lafayette, due today from Havre via Southampton, includes the Hon. Graham Eyres Monsell, Mr. and Mrs. H. T. Lewis, Emmanuel List, basso of the Metropolitan Opera Company;
Edgar Fiske Allen, president of the International Society for Crippled Children, died here today. His age was 75.

Secretary Morgenthau and Sir Frederick Phillips, Under Secretary of the British Exchequer, began a series of conferences today on financial and economic relations between the United States and Great Britain. They may be followed by talks with representatives of other nations in relation to the tripartite agreement for the stabilization of international currency.

While 300,000 visitors to the nineteenth annual convention of the American Legion made merry in the streets, 15,000 of the more serious-minded attended the opening session at Madison Square Garden yesterday, heard prominent speakers warn them that the democracy for which they fought twenty years ago again was in danger and listened to varying counsel on the action it should take.

Classing the recent water rate reduction adopted by the Board of Aldermen as "vote and run legislation," Mayor La Guardia vetoed the cut yesterday and chided the Aldermen for trying to put the Mayor "on the spot" in a campaign year.

Mrs. Louise J. Birmingham, wife of an army infantry officer, and Henry John Norman Imrie, supervisor for a local radio manufacturing company, were found dead of gas asphyxiation today in the Birmingham home here. Police said they apparently had entered into a suicide pact.

Old Westbury and Greentree will clash tomorrow in the most important polo match of the season, postponed from last Sunday, to decide the national champion for the year. The date for the final-round match was scheduled yesterday and the Long Island Railroad annoultied its special train would leave the Manhattan terminal at 3 o'clock.

Retired Fireman Peter J. Vellia, formerly a member of Engine 282, residing at 256 Midwood St., Brooklyn, died Sept. 18. Funeral will take place from his late residence, at 9:30 A. M., Tuesday, Sept. 21. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery. The deputy chief of the 12th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen, as funeral escort.

A team of four officers has been named to represent the Sixty-first Cavalry Division of New York in the interstate military and police tournament at the national horse show starting Nov. 3 in Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday by Colonel George M. Russell, Chief of Staff of the division.

Bernard Wollman, special agent for the Prudential Insurance Company of America, died suddenly of a heart attack today while worshipping at a Succoth, Jewish harvest festival, service at the Jewish Center of Mount Vernon.

Ernie Dusek, 228, Omaha, defeated Nick Campofreda, 220, of Maryland in the feature finish wrestling exhibition at the Hippodrome before a crowd of 1,000 last night. Dusek twice threw his rival against the steel ring posts, then applied a hammerlock.
Nearly 2,000 manuscripts on the general topic "The American Way" had been received by Harper's Magazine when their thousanddollar prize contest closed last week.

Leaving behind a great gnashing of teeth and a greatly deflated Gas House Gang that seemed to have nothing better to do than stew in its own fury, the Giants effected a triumphant evacuation of this city today.
In the past three years it has been demonstrated that there is more to Yale football than meets the carping eye of the itinerant correspondent.

Succoth, the Festival of Tabernacles, which began Sunday evening, was observed yesterday by Jews in temples and synagogues throughout the city. Rabbis in their sermons reminded the worshipers of the spiritual meaning of the hut, the succah, which has been built during this feast as a symbol for the Jew.

A drop in temperature in most sections of the country played a decisive part in improving retail trade last week, with the result that merchandise orders received in the New York market yesterday were substantial, according to manufacturers and resident offices.

With Long Island sound blown white-topped and green, the final race of the Star Class international championship was sailed today, and Walther von Hutschler, famed German skipper of the Hamburg fleet, made it four straight out of five with the white-hulled Pimm.

The Treasury's offering of about $50,000,000 of discount bills of nine months' maturity was subscribed more than three times today, and the selling price was at an annual rate of 0.441 per cent on a bank

Mr. Giraud Van Nest Foster entertained with a luncheon today at the Lenox Club for her guest, Miss Alicia Jumonville of New Orleans. Others in the company were Mrs. David T. Dana, Mrs. R. Jay Flick, Mrs. Owen Johnson, Mrs. Chauncey C. Loomis, Mrs. John M. Deeley, Mrs. Johannes A. L. Van Den Bosch, Mrs. George Rockwood and Mrs. Robert S. Hibbard.

The following Reserve officers, recently released to Headquarters, First Military Area, N. N. Y., for assignment, are assigned as indicated: 391st Infantry-Maj. Joseph Polowe, Inf.Res., Veterans Administration Facility, Batavia N. Y.
The Legion convention is a demonstation of at least one fact, and that is the surprising way in Which the American male of our time hangs on to his youth.

Four persons were executed and six imprisoned today in a drive against anti-Soviet "wreckers" that caught grain elevator crews at Ordjonikidze, in the Caucasus. Nine men faced similar charges in trials opened at Moscow.
The return match between Tippy Larkin, Garfield lightweight, and Maxie Fisher of Newark was postponed indefinitely today because the Newark boxer was stricken with grippe.

The Jewish All-Star soccer team, representing the Hakoah and Hatikvoh Football Clubs, faced the Barcelona Football Club of Spain at Dyckman Oval last night in the fourth and last match of the visitors' United States tour.
Harry Stowe, retired New Bedford police captain and onetime major league baseball player under the name of Harry Stovey, died today at the age of 80.
A bewildered and slightly shellshocked New York modified its workaday routine yesterday to fit the lusty whimsy of the merry-andrews and mad wags of the American Legion.

The Theatre Guild opened its sixth joint subscription season in association with the American Theatre Society with the world premiere of Ben Hecht's new play, "To Quito and Back," at the Colonial Theatre this evening. The play required three hours and was produced by Philip Moeller.

Net income of the W. A. Sheaffer Pen Company for the six months ended on Aug. 31 amounted to $227,775 after depreciation, normal Federal income taxes and other charges, according to the report announced yesterday.
Funeral services for Rev. Lewis Nichols of the staff of Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street, were held yesterday morning at Trinity Church.
SHEET METAL WORKER-$1.056, $1.116, $1,176 per hour, Navy Yard, Brooklyn, N. Y. Applications must be on file with the Recorder, Labor Board, Navy Yard, Brooklyn N. Y., not later than Oct. 15.

The band of Boston Newspapermen's Post 305 of the American Legion, said to be the only newspapermen's band in the country, serenaded THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday afternoon as a gesture of professional courtesy.
Henry Seymour Brown announced today his resignation as superintendent of the Church Extension Board of the Presbytery of Chicago to become vice president of Princeton Theological Seminary.

Commercial and industrial failures in the week ended Sept. 16 were at the lowest level for any full week since Oct. 15, 1936, despite a rise from the aggregate in the holiday period preceding, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

September corn fluctuated rapidly today on the Board of Trade here within a range of 6 5/8 cents, breaking 5 1/4 cents early to 99 1/4 cents a bushel, the lowest level quoted since Sept. 7 and 17 1/2 cents under the high point of last Thursday.

The intricacies of the Crisler offensive became more and more evident today on University Field as three Princeton varsity elevens concluded another long day with a seventy-five minute stationary scrimmage against combination varsity-scrub teams.

After having been out of communication with the outside world for twenty-eight hours, Sir Hubert Wilkins sent a message last night to the radio department of THE NEW YORK TIMES from his plane by way of Aklavik, saying that he would soon send information regarding his plans to return home with his four companions.

Despite a violent thunderstorm last night, accompanied by torrential rains, there was no break in the long procession of pilgrims determined to bid farewell to the founder of their State. Up to midnight 500,000 had filed past the body of Thomas Garrigue Masaryk, first President of Czechoslovakia.

Miss Natica Waterbury, debutante daughter of Mrs. Samuel Welsh of Chestnut Hill and of the late John C. Waterbury of New York, was the honored guest at a dinner dance given tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. B. Widener 2d at Lynnewood Lodge, their Elkins Park residence.

The text of the address by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, at the dinner of the national commander of the American Legion at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night follows: It is my privilege tonight to bring to you of the American Legion personal greetings from the Chief Executive of our nation.

Five hundred veterans of the Twenty-sixth Division, formed from the New England National Guard and known as the Yankee Division during the World War, attended a reunion and dinner last night at the Roger Smith Restaurant, 40 East Forty-first Street.
Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt, whose trial for the murder of his fiancee, Mrs. Verna Garr Taylor, resulted in a mistrial last May, was shot and killed on the steps of the Armstrong Hotel here tonight.

Mr. and Mrs. Ramsay Peugnet of Bronxville, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Peugnet, to Morss Lippincott, son of Mrs. J. Evans Lippincott of Cincinnati and the late Mr. Lippincott.
The Interstate Commerce Commission closed its hearing today in The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company's reorganization proceedings.

For the third successive year, a quartet from Kayser, W. Va., carried off the championship for their class in the national music contest sponsored by the American Legion Auxiliary, at the Columbia Broadcasting Company Little Theatre last night.

The Elmira Pioneers added the Governor's Cup to their trophy collection, which also includes the New York - Pennsylvania League pennant, today when they defeated Wilkes-Barre in the fifth and final game of the post-season play-off series, 3 to 0.

The Rev. Mathias Nett. O. S. B., assistant at the Little Flower Monastery in Newton, N. J., and chaplain of the Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Franklin, N. J., for fourteen years, died at Holy Name Hospital here today of a heart attack. His age was 53.

Administrators of the estate of Arthur W. Cutten, once one of the largest grain traders in La Salle Street, intensified efforts today to determine his true wealth at the time of his death, June 34, 1936.

The hearing on the declaration of the Northern States Power Company, recently held before a trial examiner, will be reopened on Thursday before the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was announced today.
It is announced semi-officially that Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy will spend five days in Germany, three of them in Berlin.

A syndicate composed of the Anglo California National Bank, the Bancamerica Company, the American Trust Company and the Capital National Bank purchased yesterday an issue of $1,212,000 of registered warrants of the State of California on an interest basis of 1 per cent plus a premium of $137.17.

John A. Walsh, former judge of the city court and Democratic leader of Stamford, his native city, for a quarter of a century, died at Stamford Hospital this morning after a long illness at the age of 62.

Ralph Guldahl of Chicago, 25-year-old national open champion, banged out a par 72 over Canterbury's rugged terrain to defeat Horton Smith, also of Chicago, by four strokes in an eighteen-hole play-off for the thirty-seventh annual Western open championship today.

Declaring its members held unredeemed city relief checks totaling about $1,000,000, the Newark Merchants Association served notice tonight that it would "take appropriate legal action" if the City Commission did not arrange for a redemption of the checks by Wednesday.

Accused of attempting to smuggle two aliens into the United States an Sept. 18 at Pier 7 of the Bush Cerminal in Brooklyn, Francisco Justino De Souza, 36 years old, of Rio de Janeiro, a seaman on the Lloyd-Brazilian freighter Camanu, pleaded not guilty yesterday before United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn Federal Court and was held in $5,000 bail for a hearing Oct. 5.

Plans have been completed by Miss Page Underwood, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clarence F. Underwood of Stamford, for her marriage on Oct. 23 to Richard B. Edwards of Greenwich. The ceremony will take place in St. John's Episcopal Church here. A reception at the Stamford Yacht Club will follow.

Although attendance was reduced by the difficulty of getting hotel accommodations, the Perfume and Cosmetic Buyers Conference and Exhibition, opening yesterday at the Commodore Hotel, attracted 145 buyers, and the thirty-five exhibitors booked orders totaling $42,000, according to announcement by J. J. Kimm, associate director.

La Society des 40 Hommes et 8 Chevaux gave New York yesterday such a show as it has seldom if ever seen before as it held its annual promenade down Eighth Avenue as a preview to the gigantic American Legion parade today.
Three courses of action in nominating candidates for delegates-atlarge to the constitutional convention are under consideration by the American Labor party, it was revealed yesterday.
A tract of land containing about 100,000 square feet, in the immediate vicinity of the World's Fair grounds, has been sold by the Arthur A. Johnson Corporation to the Hajada Realty Corporation.

The new account opened today without any untoward price disturbances in so far as domestic securities were concerned, but the Transatlantic issues reflected in no uncertain degree the impact of Wall Street's sharp decline on Saturday.

The United Automobile Workers of America called a strike in the plant of the Imperial Furniture Company today, claiming that 400 employes went out. Union leaders said 250 were on strike at the Furniture Shops of America.

Canada's export trade in August reached $101,471,000, an increase of $8,911,000 over August, 1936. The United States was Canada's best customer, taking $44,122,000 of goods, slightly less than in August of last year.

Apartment leasing activity, as evidenced by the lists of new tenancies submitted by rental agents yesterday, is maintaining the brisk pace set in recent weeks. West Side and East Side locations appear to be equally in demand, and a number of large suites are reported to have been taken.
Onofrio Lauri led Charles Seaback, 198 to 112, at the conclusion of the second block of their ten block pocket billiard match at the Fourteenth Street Billiard Academy last night.

A benefit dinner dance entitled "A Night in Krakow" will be given next Tuesday night in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis to formally open that rendezvous for its third season. Net proceeds will be donated to the United States branch of the Russian Invalids of the Great War.

The Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled today that stock of the Chase Securities Corporation, former affiliate of the Chase National Bank, New York, was sold illegally in Massachusetts because the corporation failed to file a statement with the State Securities Division before sale of the stock.

Health authorities refrained today from considering a date for the reopening of elementary schools due to a week-end increase in the number of infantile paralysis cases after a drop last week had given rise to hope that the peak of the outbreak had been passed.

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company, trustee under the indenture covering part of the debt of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company, including the 5 1/4 per cent secured serial notes, announced yesterday that while the committee representing first and refunding mortgage 5 per cent bonds had filed a modified plan in which the 5 1/4 per cent notes received an allotment of two shares of participating preferred stock and eight common
The gagement of Miss Hopkins Kemp, daughter of Mrs. W. Thomas Kemp of Annapolis, Md., to Jacques Redway Hammond of Rochester, N. Y., has been announced.

The following is a list of events scheduled for today for the nineteenth annual convention of the American Legion and affiliated organizations: 7:15 A. M.-Breakfast to National Commander Harry W. Colmery by the Empire State Club, Alfred E. Smith, president.

Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers aren't going anywhere this year but they put Charley Grimm on the verge of nervous prostration today when they suddenly burst out of an eight-inning shutout at the hands of Bill Lee and came within a gnat's eyebrow of setting the Cubs back on their heels.

The office of the Papal Secretary of State today sent instructions that Catholic services, recently resumed in Valencia, must cease, unless conducted in the traditional ritual by a duly authorized priest.
The American Federation of Labor may drop Secretary Perkins from the list of those to be invited to address its Denver convention next month.
Captan Russell Allen of the Harvard football team made his first appearance in togs today, and while he took no part in the sorimmage ordered by Coach Harlow, he engaged in the general workout.

The Baltimore Orioles defeated the Montreal Royals, 4 to 2, tonight to win their semi-final series in the International League's post-season play-offs and enter the final round against the champion Newark Bears for the Governors' Cup and the right to represent the league in the Little World Series.

79th St. 226 W. 17x102.2; Brooklyn Trust Co to Hueh J. Riley, 144 W 72d St; p m mtg S27.000 ($33). 122d St. 260-62 W., 50x100.11: Thomas S. Doughty. ano. trus. Eliza G. Board. to Vivldon Realty Cnrp, 202 W 108th St; p m mtg 817.500 ($20). Amsterdam Ave, 1,457. 2.5x100: Maurice E. Downing. ref. to North River Savings Bank: foreclosure ($15).
Thomas J. Qualters, 33, personal bodyguard to President Roosevelt, and Miss A lene Eade of Lynn were married at St. Mary's Church, Lynn, here before 1,500 persons.

Hunter College students earned $119,693 last year at positions obtained through the bureau of occupations and the NYA exclusive of Summer work, Mrs. Dean Schloss, in charge of undergraduate placements, announced yesterday.
Earnings of the Western Pacific Railroad in August ran somewhat ahead of August, 1936, Thomas M. Schumacher, chairman of the executive committee, said yesterday.

With Joe Ober of New York, veteran 220pound regular tackle, on the injured list due to a dislocated knee, the Pennsylvania coaches today concentrated on substitutes. Ober was hurt in Saturday's scrimmage, and Dr. Ilarion Gopadze, team physician, says he will not be available for the first three games.
The Navy football squad, under Head Coach Hardwick, began today its last week of preparation for its opening game next Saturday with William and Mary.

The lists of commercial leases submitted yesterday by brokers revealed a growing demand for store units. Several contracts for large upper floor space also were reported. Among the lessees was Amber Mines, Inc., operators of what is reputedly the only amber mine in the world.

Within a year or two Europe will face an economic collapse such as this country experienced in 1929, or a military catastrophe, unless the program of international reciprocal trade pacts is carried through, Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, said here this noon at the ninth annual Boston Conference on Distribution.

International Paper and Power Company $15-par common stock and $100-par cumulative convertible 5 per cent preferred stock were admitted to the list by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, and dealings in Class A, B and C common and 7 per cent preferred stock of the company were suspended.

The average age in the American Legion on its Twenty-Years-After holiday is presumably around 40. Middle-aged men are discharging bombs and ringing cow bells and sounding sirens on Broadway and shooting of cannon in the hotel lobbies.

The Red Sox wound up their season's series with the Browns today by splitting a double-header. After losing the opener, 8 to 6, they came back to take the nightcap, 7 to 5, for their fifteenth victory of the year over St. Louis against seven defeats.

While tens of thousands of their comrades held carnival in Times Square and other parts of the city yesterday, other thousands of American Legion members, here for their nineteenth annual convention, spent the day sight-seeing.

After having received Panama's acceptance of President Roosevelt's invitation to participate in the New York World's Fair in 1939, Edward F. Roosevelt, the fair's commissioner to Latin America, flew to Costa Rica today. He is returning to the United States through Central America and Mexico. He had arrived here from Venezuela after visits to all the South American countries.
The Federal Trade Commission announced today that two New York concerns had entered into stipulations to discontinue "false and misleading representations" in the sale of their products.

By the end of this week, it is estimated, one-fourth of the total population of the United States will be enrolled in school. But as stated in Sunday's TIMES, there will be a million fewer pupils in our elementary schools than there were eight years ago, according to the forecast of the United States Office of Education.

Eight ships of the Morgan Line, maritime subsidiary of the Southern Pacific Railroad, were tied up yesterday in Atlantic and Gulf ports when the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association demanded a new wage contract.

The marriage of Miss Geneva Grace Crossman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman Weeks Crossman of 355 Riverside Drive, to Edson Sweet Stevens, son of Harold L. Stevens of Los Angeles and Martha's Vineyard, Mass., and the late Mrs. Stevens, took place last night at the home of her parents. ,.

Harold D. McAneny, brother of George McAneny, chairman of the board of trustees of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company of New York, died here today in the Muhlenberg Hospital following an appendicitis operation.

A suit to recover more than $1,000,000 against twenty-one officers and directors of the Empire Title and Guarantee Company, the First Mortgage Securities Corporation and the Second Mortgage Securities Corporation has been filed in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn by Max Mencher, secretary to William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, on behalf of himself and other stockholders.

Belle Baker, vaudeville and night club singer and comedienne, will be married at 2 P. M. today to Elias E. Sugarman, editor of Billboard, the theatrical trade magazine. Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins will officiate at the ceremony, which will take place at the Democratic Club, 233 Madison Avenue.

The big parade of the American Legion is on today. At 9 A. M. thousands upon thousands of Legionnaires will start marching up Fifth Avenue from Madison Square to Seventy-ninth Street and it is expected that more than 1,000,000 persons will view them as they put on their colorful show.
Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday that the general death rate for the city for the week ended Saturday, Sept. 18, was 7.8 per 1,000 of population.
Earl Smith, 28, of Montezuma, was temporarily safe in a hospital bed tonight after his fifteenth narrow escape from death.

Asserting that harmony had been restored in Tammany Hall, Representative Christopher D. Sullivan said yesterday that he had no intention of resigning as leader and was occupied in organizing Tammany to get out a full vote for the ticket headed by Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic nominee for Mayor.

Mrs. Mary C. Haws of Johnstown, Pa., was elected "Le Chapeau National," chief officer of the Eight-and-Forty, the honor society of the American Legion Auxiliary, at the sixteenth annual convention held yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr. of Baltusrol led a field of 115 starters in the fifteenth annual New Jersey State championship over the West Course of the Essex County Country Club today to capture the qualifying medal with a score of 40, 39-79.
Philip E. Burch, passenger train conductor who on Sept. 9 completed fifty years' service with the Long Island Railroad, was honored yesterday at exercises held in the Jamaica offices of the road.

The new Madison Square branch of the postoffice at 149-153 East Twenty-third Street was opened yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman at ceremonies in which several members of the Twentythird Street Association and representatives of large wholesale houses in the district participated.

From a vantage point in the Hotel Astor, Police Commissioner Valentine looked down upon the thousands of Legionnaires surging through Times Square last night and realized that for perhaps the first time in the city's history traffic was beyond police control.
Senora Carmen Rivera Font's husband, Agapito, disappeared and she charged he had been kidnapped by Eduardo and America Font, his own children by a former wife.

Jacob Messner, manager of the Powers Hotel here for twenty years, died today in his home at the age of 74. Born in Trossingen, the famous Black Forest region of Germany, Mr. Messner came to this country at 16.

Mrs. Muriel Barker Churchill of Brookline. Mass., widow of Clarence Farnsworth Churchill, was married to Frederic Augustus Eustis of Milton, Mass., yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

Fifteen teams, five of which failed to return cards, participated in the Westchester Golf Association's final pro-amateur best-ball test of the season today at Briar Hills, with Frank Strazza and Willie Turnesa setting the pace with a 34, 35-69.
Estate, more than $20,000. To Robert W. Bonynge, husband, executor, 230 Central Park West, residue; 15 relatives and friends bequests of personalty.

Promoter Mike Jacobs, who cast a proprietary glance over the training camp here the other day, left too soon. Complications have arisen. Three of the contenders in the approaching fight festival are now wrapped up in a big football mystery.

About 300 boys and girls, who walked out of classes last week and picketed the high school, returned to their seats today. The Board of Education will meet tomorrow night to consider the strikers' demand that homework assignments be shortened and that the present school schedule of about seven hours daily be reduced by two hours.
Convinced that one good moving picture is better than two second-rate films, two residents here have formed what they call the AntiMovie Double Feature League of America.
Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Company, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen from his annual trip to Europe.
Representative Pettengill, Democrat, of Indiana, said today in a statement that he would vote to impeach Justice Black of the Supreme Court if it is shown that he is a member of the Ku Klux Klan.
Fifteen thousand Legionnaires, members of the women's auxiliary and their friends gathered in Madison Square Garden yesterday and cheered Governor Lehman

The five-story tenement with store at 342 Lenox Avenue, 25 by 100 feet, adjoining the northeast corner of 127th Street, was purchased by William Perry Doing, operator, head of the Fanpardo Realty Corporation. The property is assessed at $30,000. Fass Woiper were the brokers.

Curtailment of assemblies as models are changed brought automobile output last week down to little more than half the previous week's figure, and the adjusted index slumped to 108.7 from 159.9. This compares with 87.5 for the week ended Sept. 19, 1936.

Led by America's Don Budge and Germany's Baron Gottfried von Cramm, favorites came through unscathed in opening rounds of the men's singles in the Pacific Southwest tournament at the Los Angeles Tennis Club today.

Steve Wilkerson of the University of Mississippi, national intercollegiate 160-pound champion, reached here last night from the South to take part in the American Legion amateur boxing card which will be held Thursday night in the Madison Square Garden Bowl.
The address of Governor Lehman to the American Legion at Madison Square Garden yesterday follows:

Declaring that an attempt was being made to radicalizee and politicalize" the Protestant Episcopal Church, the recently formed Church Layman's Association joined yesterday in the attack made two weeks ago by Bishop William T. Manning on the activities of the Church League for Industrial Democracy, which is composed of Episcopalians.

The engagement of $10,336,000 gold abroad for shipment to this country was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of this amount $7,900,000 is coming from Belgium, $2,260,000 from England and $176,000 from India.

Luncheon, Anthracite Club of New York and Scranton Chamber of Commerce, Hotel Astor, 12:30 P. M. Roderick Stephens, toastmaster. Metropolitan Museum of Art, "Firearms of Our Forefathers." "Eve of the Revolution" (Yale Photoplay), motion pictures 2:30 P. M.; "Dutch Paintings in the Altman Collection," Edith R. Abbot, 4 P. M.
The Calumet Farm's filly Four Eleven, who had made a fine record In the West, showed her speed to New Yorkers at Belmont Park yesterday for the first time this year and lived up to her reputation.

A suit charging R. H. Macy Co., Inc., the department store, with violation of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade act by making excessive trade-in allowances on radios was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court. The plaintiff is Clarence H. Schimpf who does business at 41-24 Main Street, Flushing, Queens, as Croker-Evans Service.

In a speech bearing marks of serious last-hour revision, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Great Britain made clearer in the League of Nations Assembly today that Britain at present was much more concerned with Italy than with Japan,

Development of the "habit of hard work" was recommended to 800 Union College students today at exercises opening the institution's, 143d year by Ralph H. Tapscott, president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and a graduate of 1909.
Puerto Rico's first cooperative sugar enterprise, which is financed by the government, showed a profit of $232,000 on the first crop harvested, according to the liquidation report just completed.

Homer Saint-Gaudens, director the Department of Fine Arts at Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, met the two European members of his international jury yesterday and succeeded in getting them as far as the Harvard Club by lunch time.
The text of the State Department's announcement concerning American representation on the Advisory Committee on the Far East follows:

Richard G. Babbage, president of Savoy-Plaza, Inc., has advised holders of income bonds and votingtrust certificates of the company that since there exists for the period from Oct. 31, 1936, to July 31, 1937, a deficit in available net income as defined in the deed of trust securing the income bonds, the board of directors has been compelled to determine that no interest on the income bonds is payable on Oct. 1.
The Rayon and Synthetic Yarn Group will meet in the near future to discuss the Federal Trade

Miss Margaret Luer St. John, daughter of Mrs. G. Cyrus St. John of this place and the late Mr. St. John, will be married here to Elbridge Cleghorn Gale of Boston and Gloucester, Mass., in St. Bede's Chapel, Rosemary Hall, Oct. 29.

Department store sales in the metropolitan area for Sept. 1 to 15 registered an increase of 2.7 per cent, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. New York and Brooklyn department stores had a rise of 3 per cent, while Northern New Jersey units showed an advance of only 1 per cent.

Indicating a more aggressive promotion of its own brands, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company is launching its first prize contest in several years for Ann Page products. A series of twelve weekly contests with $55,000 in merchandise prizes are scheduled.

Herbert R. O'Conor, State Attorney General, ruled today that no magistrate has the right to hold secret hearings or trials. Magistrate S. Robert Levinson requested the ruling after Magistrate Lulu E. Powell had barred reporters from a trial.
John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, announced today that a meeting of the Committee would be held beginning Oct. 11 in Atlantic City.

John J. O'Hare, superintendent of the color department at The Boston Post for thirty years, who was recognized as an authority on newspaper color processes, died today after being stricken with a heart attack while passing City Hall on his way to work. He resided in Brookline.
Two naval aviation pilots were killed here today when a scouting plane in which they were flying crashed in a wooded section on the estate of Albert Smith.
About 200,000 persons, among them many Legionnaires, gathered under a full moon on the Boardwalk at Coney Island last night to watch a display of fireworks in honor of the American Legion.

The question as to whether Japan will raise export prices because of higher production costs or cut quotations in order to sell more goods and get needed exchange, continued to agitate both foreign traders and domestic producers here last week.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York endorsed last night for re-nomination and re-election Irving Lehman, Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals; Edward J. Glennon of the Appellate Division, Supreme Court, First Deapartment, and Salvatore A. Cotillo, Justice of the Supreme Court whose terms expire Dec. 31.
Automotive exports from the United States in July totaled $30,669,383 in value as compared with $17,754,406 in July, 1936, according to the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

Marcel Thil, the Frenchman who is European middleweight champion, and two challengers, Pedro Montanez and Ceferino Garcia, who will battle in the Carnival of Champions at the Polo Grounds Thursday night, were close to their fighting weights today.

The problem of minor nationalites, especially in the frontier regions, is proving unexpectedly difficult in recent times if one judges by the constant diatribes in Moscow newspapers, especially Pravda.

Settlement of the strike of 300 employes of the Noma Electric Corporation, manufacturers of radio and electrical accessories, with a plant at 524 Broadway, was announced yesterday by the State Mediation Board through Jules T. Freund, its executive secretary.

The theft of jewelry valued at $1,500 from the home here of Charles V. Rich Jr., New York investment broker, puzzled the police and members of the family today. All doors and windows of the home at 190 Hillair Circle were found securely locked when the family returned late Saturday from a tenday vacation.
Gaining 665 yards in two games, more than double the number made by their opponents, the Pittsburgh Pirates got off to a good start in the quest for offensive honors in the National Football League.
Charles Delany, retired president of the Kensington National Bank here, died on Saturday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. William D. Powell, at Greens Farm, Conn. He was 80 years old.
Mrs. Marietta Robbins, wife of William H. Robbins, Bay Shore attorney, and prominent for many years in Long Island music circles, died at her home today at the age of 61.

SERGEANT-Herbert W. Koehler, from 110th Precinct to Police Academy, Pistol Instruction School. Temporary Assignment PATROLMAN-Ralph H. Hanson, from 23d Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, Kings County, for 15 days.

Jewish Senators formally protested to the authorities today the increasing attacks upon Jews on Warsaw streets. They complained that assailants used iron bars and that the windows of synagogues, Jewish-owned stores and clubs had been smashed.

The United States destroyer Polk has completed the evacuation of many Americans from the interior of China who had gathered at the port of Haichow, whence they were taken to Tsingtao and landed safely today.

Governor Gordon Browning of Tennessee, a Legionnaire visitor to the convention, outlined yesterday at the Hotel Astor a tour of his home State for neighboring Governors and other guests starting the week of Oct. 17.

A tea was given by Mrs. Charles A. Slossoni at her home here this afternoon for Miss Jean Sterling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Sterling, who will be wed to Newton Buckner on Saturday. Mrs. George Fisher will entertain for the prospective bride on Wednesday afternoon and Miss Jane Weadock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. B. F. Weadock, will give a dinner Wednesday for the couple.

Mrs. William Winston Roper of Winston Road, Chestnut Hill, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elisabeth Binney Roper, to William Edgar Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. H. Parker of Montreal.
James S. Troy, lawyer and former engineer, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital of a kidney ailment at the age of 33.
Joseph E. Austin, who created the role of building inspector of New Haven and filled it the last thirtyone years, died at his home last night in his seventy-ninth year.

Mr. and Mrs. Horace Roberts of Hooten Hall, Moorestown, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Hooten Roberts, to the Rev. Wilson Bennett, son of Mrs. Eleaze Bennett Reed of Princeton, N. J.
Professor Philip Van Ness Myers, noted historian, former president of Farmers College and once dean of the academic faculty at the University of Cincinnati, died today at the age of 91.

In a glow of color and fragrance, delegates representing the 440,000 members of the American Legion Auxiliary took over the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor yesterday for the first of their official sessions. Then a schoolboy from Indiana stole their show.
Gross assets, $100,302; net, $89,462. To Nesbitt H. Bangs, son, and Mary E. Bangs, stepdaughter, specific bequests and one-half residue in trust each; several specific bequests.
It is entirely appropriate that Governor Lehman's address at the opening session of the American Legion convention should have emphasized anew the essential principles of American democracy.

Plans were filed yesterday on behalf of the Brick Presbyterian Church for the new edifice and sixstory parish-house which that congregation will erect on the site known as 1,140 44 Park Avenue and 71-81 East Ninety-first Street and 36-70 East Ninety-second Street.
A casualty list published today swells Italian losses in Spain to 996, compared with 1,148 officers and men killed in fighting throughout the entire Ethiopian campaign.
Brown University will confer the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws on Dr. Heinrich Bruening, former German Chancellor, at a convocation Wednesday marking the beginning of the university's 173d year.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Atterbury McGinley of Oak Knoll, Sewickley Heights, Sewickley, Pa., of the engagement of Mrs. McGinley's daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Floyd, to Walter Nathaniel Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Calvin Brown of Plainfield, N. J.

The New Jersey primary campaign ended tonight with major interest centered on the contest between State Senators Lester H. Clee and Clifford Powell for the Republican nomination for Governor. United States Senator A. Harry Moore is the only Democratic candidate.
Miss Bertha Bolling, sister of Mrs. Woodrow Wilson, was discovered dead this morning in her apartment at the Powhatan Hotel here. Miss Bolling was 67 years old.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 15:
Appointment by President Roosevelt of John Phillip Wenchel to be assistant general counsel for the Bureau of Internal Revenue was announced today by Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury.
The American airman, Harold Dahl, now held in a Seville jail, will be promptly released in exchange for other prisoners held by the Valencia government. it was learned on the best authority today.

C. Edward Paxson, counsel for subsidiaries of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, was called upon today by the Federal Power Commission to show cause on or before Friday why he should not be barred from practice before that body
Special twenty-four-hour sentries guard the army's new light tanks, biggest secret of Eighth Division manoeuvres here.
The United States Navy saluted the visiting Legionnaires last night with a searchlight show by six fighting ships stretched in a line ten blocks long in the Hudson River off 125th Street.

The British Government is awaiting the threatened Japanese bombing of Nanking with grave anxiety. Although no representations to Tokyo have been made, the fact that the Chinese capital is an "open" city is likely to bring a protest if the bombing is made with the thoroughness that is feared to be likely.

The Rev. Dr. Russell Morse Brougher, for ten years pastor of the Baptist Temple, Third Avenue and Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, announced yesterday his resignation to take effect Oct. 25. Harold R. Swallow, chairman of the board of trustees, said the congregation would act on the resignation tomorrow night.

John Daley of New York City was elected president of the State Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association, Inc., at a meeting of the board of governors here today to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Albert Ehler of the Bronx.

The Foreign Office spokesman expressed the hope yesterday that other Governments would follow an example set by Britain in cooperating with the Japanese Navy in carrying out the fresh blockade measures announced on Saturday.
The evacuation of the United States Embassy here last night by Ambassador Nelson T. Johnson and seven members of his staff evoked a storm of Chinese criticism.

Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, criticized today the lack of proper discipline on American ships, when he delivered the graduation address to a class at the Coast Guard School here.
Governor Lehman announced publicly for the first time last night it at a dinner of the Twenty-seventh Division Association that he would not be a candidate for office again.

The mortgage dated June 1, 1928, securing the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., bonds was "illegal, void and unenforceable," Roy S. McPherson, liquidator of the company, declared in a defense issued at Osgoode Hall on Saturdav.

Upstate hunters will get the first crack at woodcock this Fall. The State Conservation Department said today the open season north of the main tracks of the New York Central Railroad, and north of the Boston Albany tracks to the Massachusetts line will be from Oct. 1 until Nov. 1.

An agricultural conservation program involving the retirement from intensive cultivation in 1938 of between 15,000,000 and 30,000,000 acres planted to cash crops this year, and establishing national, State and county acreage goals to which farmers will be asked to conform, was announced today by Secretary Wallace.

" The Japanese Navy never has and does not intend to use poison gas," its spokesman declared this morning in reply to an inquiry whether in the threatened bombings of Nanking the use of gas was contemplated.

William H. Davis, chairman of the State Mediation Board, announced last night that he had invited representatives of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle and the American Newspaper Guild to his office at 165 Broadway Wednesday morning to discuss a settlement among the employes of the editorial and commercial departments, who have been on strike since last Monday night.
There has been a decided decrease in the Italian press campaign against Great Britain and France.

Liberalization of fair trade practice conference rules at the January session of Congress will be sought by about a half-dozen industries, partly as a result of the fear that the threatened tightening of Anti-Trust Law prosecution may result in charges against some industries for their current practices, according to reports here yesterday.

With the approach of the first hearing on the B. M. T. labor situation by Mayor La Guardia's threeman fact-finding board, the transit company's board of directors deferred action yesterday on the common dividend usually declared at this time, and the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. 0. affiliate, announced a broad campaign of speeches and pamphlets to win public support.

Despite the influx of motor traffic into the city because of the convention of the American Legion, traffic accidents, fatalities and injuries declined last week and week-end compared with the figures of the corresponding periods of 1936.
Edwin F. Jaeckle, chairman of the Erie County Republican Committee and his party's candidate for Mayor, announced today that he would resign the chairmanship if he was elected Nov. 2.

IF WAR COMES, by R. Ernest Dupuy and George Fielding Eliot. (Macmillan, $3). What future wars will mean. HALL OF MIRRORS, by Lenore G. Marshall. (Macmillan, $2.50). A novel. NEW WRITING, edited by John Lehmann. (Knopf, $2.75.) Stories, sketches and poems by young writers.
Julius Oppenheimer, former president of Rochfeld, Stern Co., importers of linings, died yesterday at his residence, 277 Park Avenue, after a brief illness at the age of 66.

The constitutionality of the recent Mexican land expropriation law is regarded as doubtful here in the light of a ruling by the Mexican Supreme Court that indemnity must be paid on seizure or immediately thereafter.- The expropriation law allows ten years for payment.

The British Foreign Secretary, in his address yesterday before the League of Nations Assembly, surveyed broadly the international situation and reaffirmed Britain's position on several major issues, but broke little new ground. Diplomatically alternating words of conciliation with words of warning, he gave scant indication of specific measures by which the general principles he advocated are to be made effective.

The Yiddish Art Theatre began its season last night at its new quarters on Fifty-ninth Street with "The Brothers Ashkenazi," dramatized from I. J. Singer's novel by the author himself and Maurice Schwartz, director of the company.
French police held under guard tonight a high Spanish military official who readily told them he had organized an attempt to steal a Spanish Government submarine from a dockyard at Brest, France.

Solemn warning that the United States must continue to steer a middle course between utter isolation from world affairs and complete entanglement in them, if it desires to avoid the tragedy of twenty years ago, was given last night by Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

One-day jail terms were given today to a Newark, N. J., woman who admitted that she kidnapped her former finance to force him to marry her, and to a White Plains, N. Y., lineman who said he helped her.

The story of how a two-year suicide clause in a life insurance policy balked the plan of a man who took his life to have his insurance devoted to reorganizing his bankrupt business and paying off creditors was disclosed here today.

Turpentine firm, 30 3/4c: sales, 172 barrels: receipts, 507 barrels; shipments, 164 barrels: stock, 39,823 barrels. Resin firm, no sales; receipts 1.287; shipments, 210; stock, 64,645. Quote: B. D. $7.50; E, to K. $7.8T7; M, $7.95; N, $8.05; WG, $8.25; WW, X, $8.70.
Legal action to prevent the employment of former Mayor James J. Walker as assistant counsel to the Transit Commission was initated yesterday in Supreme Court by the Civil Service Reform Association.

After an exchange of friendly letterms, Governor Harold G. Hoffman and Boake Carter, radio commentator, settled today the $100,000 slander suit the Governor started against Mr. Carter in July, 1936, over criticism of his conduct of Hauptmann case.

Mrs. Ida L. Wilson, a soft-spoken woman now 57 years old, remembered yesterday morning in her home at 239 Fowler Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., that she entered Saks department store on Herald Square in the first rush of customers on Oct. 2, 1902.
Sidney M. Goldin, who had been a moving picture director for more than twenty-five years, died Sunday night in the French Hospital of a heart ailment at the age of 57.

Mrs. Helen McNulty Hammett, who married George Howland Hammett, Newport lumber dealer, at his hospital bedside Sept. 15, the day before he died, receives $75,000 outright and the residue of an estate estimated at $200,000 in her husband's will, filed today. To Mr.

Mayor La Guardia will march twice in the Legion parade today. He will launch his day of parading with Major Gen. William N. Haskell, the grand marshal, at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street as the big demonstration starts.

Miss Margaret Brosnahan, daughter of Mrs. Timothy J. Brosnahan of this place, will be wed on Oct. 9 to John Wade Roche, son of Mrs. John Roche of Pelham, N. Y. The ceremony will take place in the lChurch of the Assumption.

Fifteen persons were injured slightly when combination tear-gas and stench bombs were set off at about 8:50 o'clock last night in seven theatres in upper Manhattan and the Bronx, apparently in a revisit by the gang of bombers that loosed the gas fumes in six of these and in sixteen others eight days ago.

Long sought by students of wild life as one of the rare inhabitants of Northern British Columbia, four specimens of the stoni blue sheep were shot by Michael Lerner, New York, field associate of the American Museum of Natural History.
" And-what must be done to make duck hunters take an active part in duck restoration?" The answer was short and crisp. "They must be organized," said John C. Huntington, emphatically.
A devastating exchange of explosives shook Madrid today from dawn until after darkness. Tonight the thunder of big guns and mines continued the city's fiercest artillery battle in months.

The square-rigger Seven Seas tonight rode at anchor in Newport Harbor, first to arrive in a two-vessel race from Bermuda, but the like-rigged Joseph Conrad, though unreported, still had a chance to win.

Another attempt to salvage the treasure that has lain in the sunken liner Merida in thirty-five fathoms of water fifty miles off Cape Charles, Va., since 1911 will begin next March, it was announced yesterday by the group of marine insurance underwriters who now are owners of the vessel.

After a workout in fundamentals, Captain Jack Daly of Belleville, N. J., and Bill Dorsey of Martins Ferry, Ohio, veteran ends, were named yesterday by Coach Chick Meehan as starters in the season's opener Saturday with St. Bonaventure in Ebbets Field.

In the gargantuan manner in which the Legion does things, the pick of the fife, drum and bugle corps of the country strutted and tooted from 9 o'clock yesterday morning until after 11 o'clock last night at the Polo Grounds to pick a new national champion and winner of a $1,250 purse.

Just in time to avert an ordeal for those who are not too confident about the fine points of flag etiquette, Colonel James A. Moss, U. S. A., retired, President General of the United States Flag Association, issued a welcome dictum yesterday.

About 350 officers and men of the 32d Division. known as the AllAmerican Division because its personnel was drawn from all parts of the country, held their reunion dinner in the Hotel Roosevelt last night.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul Pickering Wrigley of Bronxville have announced the engagement of Mr. Wrigley's sister, Miss Marian Chapin Wrigley of 142 East Fortyninth Street, this city, to James Dion Flaherty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Denis Flaherty of Brooklyn.
The Japanese are renewing their threats to attack the densely populated Nantao section of the Chinese city on the southeast of Shanghai adjoining the French Concession.

The Spanish Government received a hard diplomatic blow today when the League of Nations Assembly refused to reelect Spain to the Council. The vote was 24 against and 23 for Spain, with 32 votes required for the necessary two-thirds.

Resisting efforts by the Electric Bond and Share Company and other public utility defendants to test the constitutionality of the Public Utility Holding Company Act as a whole, the Securities and Exchange Commission filed yesterday a brief

Federal Judge George A. Welsh ordered the Atlantic Mercantile Company of Philadelphia today not to dispose of any securities until the Government's claim of $44,488 in taxes on other security transactions was decided.

It is the pleasure of Arthur Hop- to kins this evening to offer the first D new play of the 1937-38 season, this being Valentine Davies's somewhat nautical comedy, "Blow Ye Winds." With Henry Fonda starring on the quarter-deck, it ties up at the Fortysixth Street Theatre-where,

With twenty assorted trailers from fourteen manufacturing companies bivouacked on the main drill floor of the Seventy-first Regiment Armory at Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, and as many more expected to be on exhibition by Wednesday, New York's first alltrailer show opened yesterday morning at 11 o'clock.

Men over 40 are likely to turn out more production, likely to be more conscientious about phases of their work hard to check up, and more likely to be open-minded toward criticism, in the belief of members of the Sales Executives Club and for these and twenty-two other reasons, men over 40 are preferred by the club members, it was shown by a survey conducted by Charles C. Stech, it was announced yesterday.

BY one of those miracles of comprehension that sometimes occur, a small bomb exploding under this reviewer's feet as he passed the McAlpin yesterday with a copy of Jules Romains's latest volume under his arm made him realize that the Legion had come to town. And with that realization, a slow train of thought started off: Legion in town, Legion equals lobby, lobby equals bonus.

At this advanced stage in the country's education by newspapers most people do not have to be told that the President's Western journey has a more public objective than calling on his daughter and her family in Seattle. Mr.

Lady Grotrian, wife of Sir Herbert Brent Grotrian, Bart., accompanied by her daughters, the Misses Desiree and Joiselle Grotrian, is at the Waldorf-Astoria until sailing on Thursday for her home in Leighton Buzzard, Bedfordshire, England.

The five candidates for national commander of the American Legion trained their campaign guns yesterday on the 1,339 delegates to the convention in an attempt to line up the 670 votes necessary for election.
United States Public Health Service agents in China informed Surgeon General Thomas Parran today that the cholera in Shanghai was now "officially considered epidemic."
Collaboration of New England Governors in a plan for definite cooperation between the New England States and the Federal Government on flood control came today at a hastily called conference.
Dr. Alexander O. Snowden, a practicing physician in this village for nearly sixty years, died at his home Here today of a heart attack at the age of 83.

Briggs Ave, (12-3293), e s 614 ft a of 174th St, 30x101: Manzi Realty Corp to East Coast Properties, Inc, 300 Madison Ave; mortgage, $13,500. 222d St. 858 E, (16-4680); Nellie Bavinski to Stefania Cleslelski, 858 E 222d St; mortgage, $9,000. Bronx River Ave. 1,219 (14-3769); Bond Mortgage Guarantee Co to Lena Rubin, 889 Stebbins Ave.

While colorful American Legion bands were competing at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and picturesquely uniformed Legionnaires were playing jokes on one another and "taking over this seaport town," there was one group of nearly a thousand members of the A. E. F. that had small part in the celebration.

Percy Alport Molteno, shipowner, died yesterday at Zurich, Switzerland, according to word received here today. Mr. Molteno, 76 years old, was a son of Sir J. C. Molteno, first Premier of Cape Colony, South Africa, and was called to the bar in England in 1886.

Memorial services for policemen of the entire nation who have been killed in line of duty were held yesterday morning at the Astor Theatre, Broadway and Forty-fifth Street, under the auspices of the Queens Police Post 1103 of the American Legion.

Winthrop W. Case ably analyzed in THE TIMES Sunday some of the reasons that call for caution and constructive action. He overlooked, however, the following: The large production of automobiles this year, after a 4,500,000-car year immediately preceding, suggests a sharp contraction of the car industry in the near future.

A proclamation was issued by President Roosevelt today designating the week beginning Oct. 3 as Fire Prevention Week and inviting the cooperation of the people in eliminating fire hazards and preventing fire waste. The proclamation follows:

The estate of Abraham L. Erlanger, theatrical producer, who died on March 9,, 1930, is insolvent, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The assets of the estate were valued at $1,400,816, but funeral and administration expenses amounted to $202,738 and debts to $3,095,677.

Joseph T. Ailing, chairman of the trustees of the University of Rochester and chairman of the board of Ailing Cory Company, wholesale paper company, died tonight in Strong Memorial Hospital at the age of 82.

Charles D. Hilles, Republican National Committeman, after continuous service since 1920 and, prior to that, in the four-year period from 1912 to 1916, chairman of the committee, last night handed his resignation to Chairman William S. Murray of the Republican State Committee.

Making a plea for more "intelligent cooperation of workers and management," Paul H. Nystrom, president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association and Professor of Marketing at Columbia University, presented at the Boston Conference on Distribution today a nine-point program aimed- at "not only insuring the rights of labor but also the rights of industry, and especially the publie interest."

Applicatians by thirty-one residents of Lawrence Park West, Yonkers, for injunctive relief against noises and other annoyances caused by the construction near their homes of an aqueduct shaft by the New York City Board of Water Supply were rejected today by Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich.

Secretary Hull's address today to the Boston Conference on Distribution was as follows: It was with great pleasure that I accepted the invitation to speak here on the subject of international trade and the role played by international trade pacts.
The $50 prize for the best-equipped and best-looking vehicle in the 40-and-8 parade was awarded last night to the "train" of Voiture 290 of Palm Beach, Fla.

A 1938 Fordham varsity football schedule of nine games was announced yesterday by John F. Coffey, graduate manager of athletics. As in the past several years, intersectional opponents from the South, Middle West and Far West will visit New York to engage the Maroon.

On the assumption, foolhardy perhaps, that the Legion hasn't taken over the picture houses as yet, it may be that the Globe this morning still is showing the new Jimmy Cagney picture, "Something to Sing About," which opened above the hubbub yesterday.

An automatic electric washing machine which washes, rinses and damp-dries clothes by the setting of two dials will be put into production this week by Bendix Home Appliances Corporation at South Bend, Ind., D. O. Scott, president, announced yesterday.

The National Emergency Council, at one time one of the most influential organizations in the New Deal but in recent months one of gradually diminishing importance with the passing of the emergency, was ordered abolished by President Roosevelt today, effective Dec. 31.
Volume 1, No. 1, of the "Shiva Daily Gazette," edited by Dr. Harold E. Anthony atop the Grand Canyon's "lost world," made its appearance today, 'featuring page one complaints about the mosquitos.

The National Labor Relations Board decided today that an election in the dispute between the C. I. 0. longshoremen and the A. F. of L. teamsters on the West Coast involving warehousemen was unnecessary.
72d St, 140-146 W; four 5-story apartments and stores, 80x102.2; Central Savings Bank of New York against Louis J. Ehret Holding Corp; due, $273,007; to plaintiff for $10,000.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 17: WARRANT OFFICERS Lawson, Chief Bosn. J. F., Naval Proving Ground, Dahlgren. Va. to the Boise and on board when commissioned.
The Nationalist [Insurgent] left flank, commanded by General Mujica, today was ready to emerge from the province of Leon and continue its arduous march northward over the Esturian Mountains.

Army's varsity football squad was hit by injuries as it turned out today for a 40-minute drill. Jim Mather, starting left tackle, with badly-torn leg muscles and Pete Kopcsak, second-string fullback, with a broken leg and a dislocated ankle, were out as the result of Saturday's practice game with N. Y. U.

State Senator Lester H. Clee, in 106 out of 276 election districts in Union County, had 4,308 votes, against 3,431 for State Senator Clifford Powell, in the contest for the Republican nomination for Governor as the returns were tabulated here tonight.

The Yacht Racing Association will meet tomorrow to decide whether the time has come to scrap the J Class boats with which Britain has made countless efforts to regain the America's Cup and build smaller and less expensive L Class craft.

Two new lines of Chrysler automobiles for 1938 were displayed here today at a press pre-view in the company's engineering building. Details, which will not be publicly disclosed until the national automobile show in New York, were explained to a meeting of about 250 automobile editors and magazine men, over which A. E. Tongue, director of advertising, presided.

Sir Hubert Wilkins, explorer, concerning whom widespread anxiety had been felt after he was unreported on the return leg of an Arctic flight in search of the missing Russian aviators headed by Sigismund Levanevsky, returned safely yesterday to his base at Aklavik, Canadian Northwest Territory.

Sales of fertilizer tax tags in the South in August were less than in the same month of the last three years, according to reports by State officials to the National Fertilizer Association. The decline is without any particular significance, it is contended, since sales in August are relatively unimportant
Police here have discovered the headquarters of a Balkan recruiting committee, headed by a woman who speaks several languages, for Government.

Miss Edith Thacher, daughter of William L. Thacher of this place and the late Mrs. Hilda Blumer Thacher, was married yesterday to Francis S. Dane Jr. of Los Angeles and Lexington, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis S. Dane of Lexington. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas R. Oliver of the Ojai Presbyterian Church in the Thacher School, with which the bride's father has been associated for many years.

A suggestion that an international conference be called to seek a solution of world economic conflicts through the elimination of unemployment was made to all American nations by the Cuban Government today.

Senator Copeland of New York tonight urged a coalition of the two major political parties "if constitutional government is to be preserved." "So long as we cling to the worthless baubles of party labels," the Senator declared, "we will get nowhere."

A last-round rally by Eddie McGeever, 139 3/4, Scranton. Pa., earned him a draw with Joe Ghnouly, 131, St. Louis, Mo., in the eight-round feature bout at the New York Coliseum last night. About 5,000 fans witnessed the contest.
Leonard Del Genio of Harlem outpointed Phil Furr, Washington welterweight, in a hard-fought tenround battle at the Broadway Arena last night before 4,000 fans.

The square-rigger Seven Seas today was awarded victory in the Bermuda-to-Newport sailing race when her similarly rigged but smaller opponent, the Joseph Conrad, failed to reach here at 2 A. M. (Eastern Standard Time), end of the time allowance given the latter.
Dr. Paul D. Emerson, senior soil scientist of the Soil Conservation Service, died in a lonely canyon eight miles from here while attempting to stem the poison of a rattlesnake bite.

Sheriff Michael J. Boyle testified today at the Labor Board hearing of the Bethlehem steel case that C. R. Ellicott, general manager of the Cambria works, was "very enthusiastic" about asking the Governor for martial law during the steel strike early in the Summer.

Pincus Friedlander, father of the late Professor Israel Friedlaender of the Jewish Theological Seminary, died on Monday in Montefiore Hospital, after an illness of six weeks. He was 85 years old. His home was at 530 West 113th Street.

Japanese air raiders launched their threatened attack to annihilate Nanking today and bombed this Chinese capital for an hour and a half. The Japanese planes swooped over the city at 10:35 A. M. and the "all clear" was not sounded until noon.

The Westchester Seniors Golf Association held-its annual Fall tournament today, over 100 linksmen, fifty or more years young, competing for net and gross prizes over the 1,125-yard Westchester Hills layout.

Mickey Kobrosky, the Trinity College backfield star who stole the spotlight with his spectacular passing and running at the all-star game a week ago, yesterday signed a contract with the New York Football Giants and reported for practice.

The recent barrage of speeches by democratic statesmen urging peace through economic cooperation and inveighing against dictatorships, armaments and economic nationalism passed over Germany without making any apparent bent in her political and economic fronts.

Lenpola, flying the orange and blue colors of R. A. Firestone, scored in her first Maryland start in the running of the Conowingo Purse, feature race today. The trim daughter of Victorian, winner of her last two New York outings, drove to the wire a length in advance of C. H. Trotter's Historic Era, who took second money in a photo finish with Detroit Bull, a slight favorite over the victor.

Robert L. Vann, Negro editor of The Pittsburgh Courier, which circulates nationally, telegraphed President Roosevelt today to cast "political expediency" aside and remove Justice Black from the Supreme Court.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Railroad Employes Corporation, New York, has been called for Sept. 29 to consider a proposed increase in the authorized Class A common stock from 60,000 shares, of which 48,981 are outstanding, to 250.000 shares of no par value.
Sales of confectionery and competitive chocolate products in August were valued at $16,202,746, compared with $15,352,746 in the same month last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

The three Garr brothers were formally charged today with the murder of Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt, whom they spectacularly shot down here last night on the eve of his scheduled retrial for the death of their sister, Mrs. Verna Garr Taylor. His first trial resulted in a hung jury last May.
TIME OF OUR LIVES, by Orrick Johns. (Stackpole, $3.) Father and son, in an autobiography. THE HOUSE IN ANTIGUA, by Louis Adamic. (Harper, $3.) Experiences in the ruined Guatemalan city.

Graham B. Hobson, long a leader in the political and business life of Richmond, died yesterday at his home here. He was 66 years old. Mr. Hobson served in the Common Council, the Board of Aldermen and on the old city administrative board.
Two Baltimore fleets of taxicabs have been equipped with blinker lights by which the drivers may signal that they are suspicious of their passengers, are being held up, or are otherwise in distress.

The combined German Army, Navy and Air Force manoeuvres are in full swing. Press and military observers at this ordinarily peaceful Baltic resort saw Red troops land as an invading army against the Blues, concentrated in Mecklenburg and Pomerania.

The Army lined up three elevens against B squad teams today in a long scrimmage, as coach Gar Davidson continued his efforts to perfect the cadet offense and defense. Several shifts in the backfield were made as the Army mentor endeavored to find the most effective combination.
With chemical warfare already proved in the World War, experts now are busy discussing the potentialities of germ warfare.

The recent growing importance of industrial and public relations for business organizations has finally impressed advertising agencies to the extent that they are now more willing to consider such work as a part of their duties, agency executives admitted yesterday. One large agency was said yesterday to be contemplating the establishment of a publicity or public relations

In an examiner's report presented today to the Interstate Commerce Commission the Class I railroads of the country were charged with widespread violations of the law in their dealings with forwarding companies.

Walter E. O'Hara, turfmanpublisher, today moved to retain control of his Pawtucket horse-racing track through a petition to the State Supreme Court, asking a review of the State Racing Commission's action in suspending Narragansett Park's license.

Multi family properties in Harlem and the upper West Side were involved in several sales of Manhattan real estate yesterday. The two buildings at 2,560 and 2,562 Eighth Avenue, containing most thirty-two apartments, were sold by Larkin Estates, Inc.,

Residential properties of various types figured in the realty transactions in Queens reported yesterday. The five-story Carmel Court apartment, on the southwest corner of Newtown Avenue and Crescent Street, Astoria, Queens, has been sold to William M. Girden,
