Late returns from the New Jersey primary held yesterday made certain the victory of the Rev. Dr. Lester H. Clee, State Senator from Essex County, and the defeat of Clifford R. Powell, State Senator from Burlington County, for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders, dated Sept. 18: Smith, Comdr. W. H., Civil Engineer Corps, Navy Dept., Washington, D. C., to Navy Yard, New York, N. Y. Gwynn, Lt. B. C., when discharged from treatment at the Naval Hospital, Washington, D. C., to home, relieved from all active duty.

Funeral services were held today for Justice Lott Russell Herrick, member of the Illinois Supreme Court since 1933, who served from June 1, 1936, to June 1, 1937, as Chief Justice. He was 66 years old. Justice Herrick died Saturday afternoon in the Mayo Clinic,
Funds for the erection of a monument at the grave of the first yeomanette are being raised by her associates in the Yeoman F, it was announced yesterday.
Five industrial plants were picketed today as labor troubles spread from the furniture manufacturing field to a knitting mill and an automobile appliance factory.

A disastrous 7 on the par 4 last hole prevented Dr. Walter F. Barry of Essex County, the defending champion, from taking the lead in the first round of the sixteenth annual New Jersey State seniors' golf championship today at the Essex Fells Country Club.

Damages aggregating $125,000 are being sought from the Reading Railroad Company because of injury suffered by Miss Janet I. McKenna of New Rochelle; a Bucknell University student, when a train of the defendant company was derailed near Clement, Pa., on Jan. 30, 1936, according to papers filed in Supreme Court here today.
A plea to employers to "extend human friendship to youth" was made here today by Cameron Beck, director of the New York Stock Exchange Institute.

New Jersey's primary election today turned up one man who would vote if he could, but he couldn't. He was number one in a chain of shackled prisoners led from the court house to the jail, right past the Second Ward, Fourth district, polling place.

Christ Episcopal Church was crowded this morning at funeral services for William Loeb, former secretary to the late President Theodore Roosevelt, which were conducted by the rector, the Rev. Harold Pattison. Mr. Loeb died on Sunday at the North Country

Alberto Santiago Lovell, Argentine heavyweight, signed a contract yesterday with Promoter Mike Jacobs to make his first local ring appearance at the Hippodrome on Oct. 15 in a battle of ten rounds against Bob Olin, local boxer.

Rumors that a difference of opinion has arisen between President Kemal Ataturk and Premier Ismet Inonu which may lead to the Premier's resignation have been aroused by an official announcement that at the Premier's own request the President had granted him a forty-five-day leave.

The problem of keeping men and women over 40 years of age employed is inextricably linked with that of finding work for the hordes of young men and women now leaving high school and college, Walter B. Pitkin of Columbia

Democratic voters considered here today the nomination for Justice of the Peace of Clayton Burdick, 24year-old lawyer, said to be the youngest aspirant for that office in the political history of Southern New Jersey.

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's offer to discuss means of facilitating the purchase by Germany and other "havenot" powers of raw materials from British possessions is heartily endorsed by The Times of London in an editorial which repeats the Foreign Secretary's warning that all must cooperate in the effort to restore international trade.

Scoring three birdies on the inward nine, Joe Thompson, wellknown in amateur golf circles, romped off with the President's Cup in the twenty-second semi-annual tournament of the Wall Street Golf Association when he carded 39, 36--75 and set the pace

Hyman Rosen, former cigar manufacturer, who was a member of the old Newark City Council from 1915 to 1917, died today of a heart attack while walking on Prince Street. He was 57 years old and resided at 196 Renner Avenue.

The consciousness, felt rather than expressed, that we are an island of peace in a world at war or threatened with war; some natural release of spirits at the lifting of the depression; the inborn buoyancy of this many-raced
The role of investigator is offered to a good many fishermen. The particular job which they may undertake from now until the end of next month has to do with a study of striped bass.
A rival union to the United Automobile Workers of America re-entered the lists today demanding labor concessions from the Ford Motor Company.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company citation, scheduled for last night at yesterday introduced the first is- the Astor Hotel, was postponed at sue of a house organ, simulating the request of hotel officials in view of the Times Square activities of the popular picture magazines, to Legionnaires, and will be held at be circulated among the company's the Astor on Sept. 30, the associa60,000 dealers in this country. Called the "Flying Red Horse"

Charles Michelson, publicity director for the Democratic National Committee, said here today that he believed President Roosevelt would not seek a third term unless he was "badly needed." In an interview Michelson predicted there would be only two major parties in the next election.

Chief of Detectives John L. Sullivan announced tonight that Thomas McCall, 39 years old, an engraver, had confessed he was the brick-carrying invader who attacked Miss Virginia Austin. 25-year-old artist and sculp tor of New York City, Aug. 15 in her room at a hotel here.

Gasoline taxes collected by Federal and State governments this year will reach nearly $1,000,000,000, or more than double that collected from motorists in 1929, Baird H. Markham, director of the American Petroleum Industries Committee, said yesterday in a statement issued in connection with an interstate conference of committee secretaries at 50 West Fiftieth Street.

Queen Wilhelmina opened the new session of Parliament today, reading a speech from the throne that stressed the Government's intention to spend considerable sums on defense without delay. The speech indicated the Government would take protectionist measures.

Fighting it out for the dubious honor of eighth place, Cincinnati and Philadelphia split a double bill today, the Reds taking a 6-to-3 victory in the opener only to lose the nightcap, 10 to 1, beneath a barrage of base hits.
Stocks erased part of early gains and closed irregularly higher; turnover, 981,550 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds higher, foreign issues lower; transactions, $6,848,900.

A suit charging that Beram D. Saklatwalla is attempting to dominate illegally the affairs of the United States Rustless Steel and Iron Company, of which he is president, was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court. The principal plaintiff is Joseph De Wyckoff, vice president of the company.

Unidentified persons, described by witnesses as "soldiers," turned the fun tables on Severin P. Rodischin of the New Hampshire American Legion last night by stealing his imitation French locomotive from in front of 45 East Sixty-sixth Street, while he was inside the building visiting.

Behind the spectacular one-hit pitching of Joe Beggs,the champion Newark Bears conquered the Orioles tonight, 2 to 0, in the opening game of the final series of the International League play-offs to determine the little world series representative.
Miss Janet Younker of the Century Country Club registered an 85 today to win the low gross laurels in the women's metropolitan oneday handicap tournament contested at the Gedney Farm Golf Club.
The Yankees today have a chance to settle forthwith the American League's representative in the world series.

Kingsland Ave. 2.312. 44.6x100.3; Willam C. Clausen against Ursula Chingas; due. $10,424; taxes, etc., $2,075; to plaintiff for $6,000. Noble Ave, 1,208, 24.6x99.75; Home Owners Loan Corp against Antonio Fazio; due. $11.452; taxes, etc., $1,710;

When the Grace liner Santa Inez docked yesterday at the foot of Re tor Street, officers reported they had sighted a four-masted schooner flying distress signals in the Caribbean. The liner went alongside and found that the schooner, with nine men aboard, had been becalmed for fifteen days and without water for three days.
Production of lead in the United States in August totaled 46,965 tons, against 45,496 tons in July and 33,542 in August, 1936, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.

For twenty-five years, through good days and evil for his party, Mr. Charles D. Hilles has been one of the most powerful figures in it. Of his associates in the Republican Big Three, the late Mr. Roraback of Connecticut and Mr. Daniel E. Pomeroy of New Jersey,

Public Works Administration officials said today that further reductions in PWA personnel would occur at regular intervals. Reductions of about 2,000 in January and 1,000 since then have brought the staff to about 7,000, they asserted, adding that vacancies developing recently had not been filled.
A prisoner was still at large tonight after scaling a fifteen-foot wall at the Burlington County jail here early today.

Mr. and Mrs. John Livingston Thomas, who are sailing today on the Queen Mary, will visit in London and Paris before going to the French Riviera, where they will be guests of Countess de Bourg de Bozas on a yachting cruise in the Mediterranean.

Taking as its theme the interdependence of the navy and the merchant marine, Navy Day will be observed on Oct. 27, under the auspices of the Navy League, it was announced yesterday by Nelson Macy, vice president of the league and national chairman of Navy Day.

Virtually eighteen times as much per year is being spent on public school education in Puerto Rico as was spent in 1898, the last year the islands were under Spanish rule, said Governor Blanton Winship of Puerto Rico yesterday afternoon in an interview at the Hotel Plaza during Governor Lehman's reception for the American Legion.

Two lawyers who were said by Detective Sergeant Frank O. Brass to have been Bought for more than a year as fugitives in connection with New York City insurance frauds were in custody today because one of them tried to join the District of Columbia Fire Department.

Mrs. George Alfred Cluett and Mrs. Bentley Wirt Warren presided at the tea tables today at a Williamstown Garden Club party given by Mrs William Tracy at Ormeland. "Bulbs" was the subject of a talk by William M. Craig.

Former Senator Hiram Bingham of Connecticut came back from England yesterday on the French liner Lafayette still chuckling over researches that will set the bitterest Yale-Harvard foes by their ears. Mr. Bingham and his wife spent three months in England gathering material for his forthcoming biography of Elihu (Eli) Yale, founder of Yale and traditional hero of its minstrelsy.
An increase. of 66 per cent in bank tax receipts in New York State in the last year was seen today by Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner, as "convincing proof" of improved banking conditions.

Among the six Manhattan properties sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street Salesrooms was the sixteen-story apartment house at 166-68 East Ninety-sixth Street. This parcel was bought in by the plaintiff, the 166 East Ninety-sixth Street Corporation, for $406,000.

Unless they are checked by "reasonable restraint" on the part of business and labor leaders, rising prices and unwarranted labor demands will hinder business recovery, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager

The impact of the recent shocks in Wall Street upon the stock markets in Great Britain was brought home forcefully today as investors and speculators began to figure the amounts they would have to remit on settlement day for the old account, which will occur on Thursday.

Spanish Government officers said tonight that a fierce Government offensive in Southern Spain drove-Insurgent troops back toward Cordoba and Seville with heavy losses. In a day of some of the costliest fighting the Spanish civil war has seen, Government troops annihilated two Insurgent battalions, destroyed three Insurgent-held towns with artillery barrages, and captured three others, a Government communique said.
Boston's erratic Red Sox today split a doubleheader with the Detroit Tigers, pushing across ten runs in the fifth inning to capture the opener. 12--7, and dropping the nightcap, 4--1.
Ralph Bates, novelist and member of the central stoff of the International Brigade in Madrid, returned on the French liner Lafayette last night on a two-months leave.
The United States has made vigorous representations to Japan against the threatened mass bombing of Nanking and is hoping that the attack will not occur.

An automobile that failed to stop afterward struck and killed Theodore Ditolla, 14 years old, of 1,838 Seventy - third Street, Brooklyn, shortly after 9 o'clock last night in front of 1,646 Victory Boulevard, West New Brighton, S. I. With his brother, Joseph, 15, the boy had attended a picnic at Clove Lake Park, West New Brighton, and was returning home by bicycle.

Leasing of several Manhattan buildings will be followed by alterations to the structures involved. Two of the properties, one in Greenwich Village and the other in Duane Street, will be occupied as restaurants.

Thomas G. Andrews of Oklahoma City today succeeded George E. Hershman of Crown Point, Ind., as Grand Sire of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows. Mr. Andrews is a former Oklahoma Supreme Court Justice. Burton A. Gaskill of Atlantic City, N. J., was elected Deputy Grand Sire by the national convention of the order.

Instead of a feared split in its ranks over the appointment of a new commissioner and the conduct of its affairs, the Eastern Intercollegiate Association yesterday broadened its base from only football to all forms of intercollegiate athletics in a brief, friendly meeting at the Hotel McAlpin.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Ames Bigelow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Horace Bigelow of this city and Worcester, Mass., to Raymond Russell Camp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Southwick Camp of Spring Lake, N. J., took place here last night in the Church of the Ascension. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Williams, rector of St. Thomas Church, Bellerose, L. I.

State Senator Lester H. Clee was leading State Senator Clifford H. Powell in Passaic County by a vote of 3,606 to 1,774 for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination on the basis of returns from 60 out of 215 election districts in today's primary election.

A determined effort which is being made by Alberta oil producers, backed by powerful Eastern.interests, to have importations of United States oil barred from the Canadian Prairie Provinces and to have the increasingly important Alberta oil industry subsidized by the Federal Government by construction of pipe lines and other means is reported to have a good chance of succeeding.

The uniform and excellent quality of nationally advertised brands of food products establishes confidence with the consumer, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America. Inc.

Movements in the livestock market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 12,000. including 1,500 directs. Market uneven, 200 pounds down 15-25 cents lower than yesterday's average.
Franz Hanawald, 36-yearold apartment house janitor, was indicted today for the kidnapping of Julius Redlich, 60, wealthy Wingdale resort owner.

The thrilling story of a running sea battle between a lone Spanish Insurgent cruiser and a Loyalist squadron nine destroyers and light cruisers convoying two freighters -was recounted today by members of the crew of the American Isthmian Line freighter Steel Mariner.

The board of directors of National Ice Advertising, Inc., comprising ice executives from every section of the United States, will meet here tomorrow to hear the results of divisional meetings, just concluded, and to set the 1938 advertising budget.

Several entertainments have been planned for Miss Helen Louise Heim and John Evans Love, who will be married Friday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. Mr. and Mrs. Eberhard Faber will entertain at a dinner tomorrow at their home, 820 Fifth Avenue, for their niece, Miss Heim;

The Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted a rule under the Securities Act of 1933 forbidding its agents from producing in court under subpoena information or documents submitted as confidential unless permission has been given by the commission.

The Union Trust Company and the Mellon Securities Corporation, both of Pittsburgh, obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,500,000 of school district bonds of Pittsburgh, Pa., on their bid of 284 101.0008 for 2 1/2s. The bonds will be dated Nov. 1, 1937, and will mature serially from Oct. 1, 1938 to 1962.
Japanese troops advanced tonight to within two miles of North China's famous line of concrete fortifications, where the decisive battle of the Sino-Japanese conflict in the North appeared imminent.

Warning against complacency toward "a spirit of revolt" in the country, Governor Charles F. Hurley of Massachusetts issued an appeal yesterday to Legionnaires for Cooperation in preserving democratic and orderly government.

With but eight days remaining until Oct. 1, the recognized end of the Fall apartment renting season, brokers continue to report a heavy demand for living quarters. Listings of new tenants submitted yesterday reveal little preference for a particular section of the city, with approximately equal numbers finding suites to their liking on both East and West Sides.

The Giants' grand pennant offensive in the West was upended with considerable violence today as the Cubs. riding on the crest of Gabby Hartnett's murderous clouting, repulsed Colonel Bill Terry's troops in the opening clash of a three-game series that at the moment seems to have this volatile metropolis in a turmoil of civic enthusiasm.

William Orville Douglas was elected unanimously today as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission to succeed James M. Landis, who recently retired, at a meeting attended by Commissioners Mathews, Healy and Ross. Mr. Douglas, who succeeded former Chairman Joseph P. Kennedy

Count Stone won the thirty-fifth Manhattan Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, but quite as much interest attached to the reappearance of the Milky Way Farm's Tiger, who finished last in the Junior Champion. Tiger triumphed and is likely to be the Futurity favorite in place of Sky Larking, considered the best Milky Way colt, who had to be destroyed after breaking his leg last Saturday.
It is astonishing how one can pick inconsistencies in the New Deal if one gives his mind to it. Yesterday this column registered

Boyze McKinley Kinney, 21 years old, a Negro, was seized at his home here today and turned over to the Secaucus police, who, with a posse of citizens, had searched the Secaucus meadows last night for a Negro who allegedly struck a white girl and attempted to assault her.

An impression of the American Legion parade is given here by a visiting Australian, editor of The Sunday Sun, Sydney, who describes, by way of contrast, the parade of the Anzacs in Sydney last April 25.

Business men should organize into a union, Hector Lazo, vice president of the Cooperative Food Distributors of America, told the convention of the National Industrial Stores Association today. "Business men have 500 associations, each fighting each other," Lazo said.

Responsibility for correct fabric designation in the field of synthetic textiles starts with the manufacturer of the yarn, Ephraim Freedman, director of the Bureau of Standards of R. K Macy Co., Inc., declared in a statement yesterday.

Jonathan Eddy, executive vice president of the American Newspaper Guild, issued a statement yesterday denouncing the recent "series of widely publicized attacks" on the Guild by William Green as "an obvious plot between the misleaders of the American Federation of Labor and certain anti-labor publishers."

The New Jersey Grand Lodge, Knights of Pythias, opened its seventieth annual convention with a dinner at the Hotel Madison here tonight. Ninety-seven lodges, having a combined membership of about 8,000, are represented by delegates.

Criminologists of the Department of Justice who have been experimenting secretly for more than a year with two human hands reported progress tonight in a comparatively new method of restoring obliterated fingerprints

The New York Stock Exchange has authorized the listing of 500,000 shares of E. I. duPont de Nemours Co. $4.50 cumulative preferred stock, no-par value; 436,363 additional shares of Bethlehem Steel Corporation common stock, no-par value; 399,999 additional shares of Cutler-Hammer, Inc., common stock, no-par value, and $3,500,000 of Liquid Carbonic Corporation tenyear 4 per cent convertible sinking fund debentures, due in 1947.
James English, founder and for thirty-seven years president of the United States Illuminating Company of this city, died at his home late last night. He was 84 years old.

A committee named by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, opened discussion here today with representatives of mine operators in a final effort to negotiate a wage agreement for Indiana mine fields.

The McKeesport Tin Plate Corporation notified yesterday the New York Stock Exchange of the proposed creation of 100,000 shares of no-par preferred stock, issuable in series. The company has called a special meeting of stockholders on Oct. 18 to vote on the plan.

State Senator Lester H. Clee in a statement issued by his headquarters here at 11:30 o'clock tonight claimed that he would carry Essex County by 50,000 votes over his opponent, Clifford Powell, for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination.
Coach Fritz Crisler sent his Princeton Tigers through their hardest workouts of the season this morning and afternoon on University Field.

A heavy stream of taxpayers dollars into the Federal till this month has reduced the deficit and the public debt, Treasury account books showed today. On Sept. 18 the public debt dropped below $37,000,000,000 for the first time since Aug. 24.

The revival of the anthracite in dustry through advertising and the use of modern automatic heating equipment were hailed yesterday at a luncheon given by the Anthracite Club of New York, for members of the Scranton Chamber of Commerce, in the Hotel Astor.

Fagged but happy, the feminine contingent balanced up last night its meed of blistered heels and sunburned noses against the vivid spectacle the Legion provided, and called the day a distinct success. Some in uniforms brave and gay had quickstepped up Fifth Avenue in the anonymity of marching units.

Osgood Perkins, a leading actor of stage and screen, died of heart disease early today, three hours after the final curtain fell on the opening last night of "Susan and God," in which he was co-starred with Gertrude Lawrence, the British actress,
Wheels Incorporated, automotive jobbers, have leased the building formerly occupied by the General Motors Truck Company at Warren, Newark and Wilsey Streets, Newark.

From Washington comes a private report that the Presidential comforters have been on the job in the case of Justice Black. Mr. Roosevelt has been volunteered these three opinions: That the matter will blow over.

Morgan J. Thoman, agent of the Federal Alcohol Tax Division, told a Federal court jury today that wire-tapping had aided in uncovering a liquor conspiracy ring involving forty-two men and women defendants from the Bradford-Olean area of Pennsylvania and New York.
Jesse Jones, justice of the peace, tonight ordered six Clarksburg Councilmen held for grand jury action on Nov. 9 on charges of conspiracy to demand bribes for a garbage disposal franchise.
The Pirates' siege guns blasted Lou Fette, Boston's ace right-hander, 'for seven runs in the first two innings today, Pittsburgh coasting in for a 9-to-2 victory.

From the time the Legion parade started, punctually at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, until far into the night, there was no hitch in moving the thousands of formations from the starting points on to the avenue.

While New York took a holiday yesterday to enjoy the spectacle of the American Legion parade, the veterans' brain trusters, in hotel rooms far from the rattle of drums and the blare of trumpets, met in little groups to evolve a program to keep the United States out of war and safeguard the democracy they fought to save twenty years ago.

The fact-finding committee of three men appointed by Mayor La Guardia to inquire into the demand of the Transport Workers Union for wage increases for B. M. T. employes and the transit company's rejection of the demands will hold its first hearing today at 2 P. M. in Room 422 of the State Supreme Court Building, Foley Square. The meeting will be open to the public. Arthur S. Meyer, chairman, will preside.

Viscount Kikujiro Ishii, member of the Japanese Privy Council and veteran Japanese diplomat, who was former Ambassador to Washington, declared that the guilt for the present Sino-Japanese conflict rests upon the Chinese Army, in an address to the American people broadcast from Tokyo last night over a network of the National Broadcasting Company. The address was indistinctly heard.
Manhattan Island, for two and a half miles of its busiest extent, was divided yesterday almost as effectually as if the Grand Canyon, instead of Fifth Avenue, ran through its midst.

Mrs. Albertina S. Weis, wife of Herman K. Weis, president of the Board of Realtors of the Oranges and Maplewood, died today at her home here after a long illness. Surviving, besides her husband, are her mother, two daughters, Mrs. Wolcott H. Rogers of Millburn, N. J.,

Frederick G. Haendel, former supervisor of music in Orange public schools, died yesterday of bronchial pneumonia at his home here. His age was 87. Born in Eisfeld, Thuringen, Germany, Mr. Haendel became a music teacher in Orange in 1884.
Construction of the new $2,000,000 plant of the Ternstedt Division of General Motors Corporation here was halted today when 200 workers went on strike.
Dense forests and deep canyons on Shiva Temple are yielding "lots" of specimens, according to a radio message received today from scientists seeking secrets of evolution atop the mysterious plateau.

The Pacific Southwest tennis championship retained its international flavor today as seeded stars from America, England and Japan moved into the quarter-finals of the men's singles. The biggest casualty of the day befell Henner Henkel of Germany. He tripped on his racquet and twisted his right ankle during a struggle with Gene Mako of California.

With the opening today of St. John's College, about twenty freshmen enrolled for a course based on the reading and study of a hundredodd books, selected by President Barr and Dean Buchanan as the essentials of a liberal college education.

A mobile school where owners and drivers of trailers can be instructed in safe and efficient handling of their rolling homes and how best to enjoy life on wheels will be featured today at New York's first alltrailer show at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory at Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, according to A. B. Hopkins, director of the show.

Striking north country dairymen decided tonight to employ the sit-down strike in their fight for higher prices and recognition of the Dairy Farmers Union from Sheffield Farms, Inc. At a meeting in Plattsburg, members of the union who have been on strike against the company for two months voted to stage a mass sit-down of dairymen, their wives and children on roads leading to the Sheffield condensary plant here tomorrow morning.

Steve (Crusher) Casey, Irish grappler, threw Jack Marshall of England in the feature wrestling exhibition at the Royal Windsor Arena last night. While a crowd of 1,000 fans looked on Casey scored with an airplane spin and body press in 29 minutes 31 seconds. Casey weighed 225, Marshall 215.

The engagement of Miss Dorothy Dawson Page, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Randolph Page of 127 East Sixty-second Street, to Andrew Gibson Curry, son of Mrs. Rufus Curry of Windsor, N. S., and the late Mr. Curry, has been announced by her parents.
The conservative newspaper Czas was confiscated today for printing Ignace Paderewski's reply to the Government's confiscation of his recent manifesto urging the Poles to resist fascism.

With the opening of Columbia University's 184th academic year today, total enrollment in fifteen divisions of the university is expected by Edward J. Grant, registrar, to reach 18,700, the aggregate attendance at the Winter session last year.

The Rivoli will have a new tenant this morning, namely, "Make a Wish," an RKO production set to the music of Oscar Straus. Bobby Breen, the boy star, sings the Straus lyrics with the assistance of St. Luke's Choir, an aggregation of sixty-eight boys.
Prize money for the 1938 Thompson Trophy air race has been increased to $45,000, sponsors of the National Air Races announced here today. It was $24,000 this year.

Lynn A. Willis, a radio announcer, jumped to his death today from a second-floor window at Presbyterian Hospital, where he had been a patient since Saturday. He suffered a nervous breakdown several months ago and last week had an attack of acute appendicitis. An operation was performed on Sunday.

Despite the German-Japanese antiCommunist pact, Germany is sending large quantities of munitions to China "and is prepared to send much larger quantities," W. N. Ewer, The Daily Herald diplomatic correspondent, reported from Geneva.

Monetary and financial factors warrant the expectation of a further upswing of "at least another 50 per cent or so" in commodity prices, with the current reaction an intermediate "zigzag" that does not necessarily indicate the rising trend has stopped, Dr. Melvin T. Copeland, Professor of Marketing at the Graduate School

Sun glinted yesterday on the wings of a far more formidable flying fleet than the A. E. F. ever knew as more than 100 of the army's most modern planes roared above the city in an aerial salute to the American Legion.

Miss Frances Carlene Haines Waitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wymer Hinckley Waitt of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Esmond Brown Gardner, son of Mrs. Isaac B. Gardner of New York and the late Dr. Gardner, on Oct. 9 in St. Thomas Church, New York.

Four election officials, two of them Democrats and two Republicans, were locked up last night a few minutes before their polling place closed at 243 Montgomery Street, on charges of violating the election laws.

Premier Juan Negrin of Spain predicted in an interview today that if the French frontier was opened to permit the Loyalists to import arms the war would end by next Summer, even if the Rebels' foreign allies remained.

Miss Jean Nash, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Nash of 35 Fifth Avenue and Short Hills, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to John P. Beresford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Percival Beresford of Edgartown, Mass., formerly of Short Hills, in the Church of the Ascension here. The Rev. Donald B.
Most commodity futures were higher in moderate activity on the local Exchanges yesterday. Goodsized gains were recorded in tin, copper, rubber and hide futures. Cocoa and coffee futures declined.

Celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of compulsory milk pasteurization, opening of Riverside Pasteurizing Plant of the Borden Company, 615 West 131st Street, 12:30 P. M. Speakers: Mayor La Guardia, Health Commissioner John L. Rice, Dr. Nathan B. Van Etten.

There are definite signs that Brown's football is on the mend. The Bruin has been but a feeble shadow of himself for the past four years, with the material running thinner each season and major victories rare occurences.
A spoke from the left rear wheel of the "Mormon Meteor" struck Ab Jenkins, noted automobile speed racer, in the head this afternoon, but apparently did not seriously injure him.

Injured in a football game on Saturday, 14-year-old Lloyd Walter Grandy died here last night. The boy suffered a blow on the head which dazed him for a period. Playing again last night, he suddenly collapsed and died without reviving. The boy apparently suffered a brain hemorrhage.
The Soviet arctic camp has drifted 240 miles from its starting point near the North Pole just four months ago. In the past twenty days it has drifted seventy miles.

Miss Pauline Nancy Watts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Watts of Revonah Manor, has set Oct. 12 for her marriage to John Carman Inch, son of Mr. and Mrs. William John Inch of Toronto, Ont. The date is also the wedding anniversary of Miss Watts's grandparents, Mrs. Jasper Edwards of Lake City, Fla., and the late Judge Edwards.
It was lucky for the Legionnaire who shinnied up the flag pole on the Public Library grounds at Fortieth Street and Fifth Avenue that the crowd was so dense at that spot at 7 o'clock last evening.

Oscar Bartolini, 51year-old former Quincy chef, was convicted early today of murder in the first degree in the slaying of Grayce Asquith, Weymouth widow. A defense attorney asserted in closing arguments to the jury that a missing World War veteran was the murderer.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Edith Zable, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. L. Zable of Brooklyn, to Leo Mosh, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. S. Mosh of Newark, N. J. The ceremony took place here on Saturday at Richtman Hall. Miss Ethel Fink Elstein of Brooklyn and Seymour Mosh, cousin of the bridegroom, were the couple's only attendants.
The State Board of Social Welfare voted yesterday to withhold State relief funds from local work relief projects started independently of WPA.

The newspapers give great prominence today to an incident that occurred yesterday in Tunis between Italian naval cadets and sailors from the training ships Colombo and Vespucci and antiFascist elements. The following version is given here:

They are overwhelmed by the men and don't make so much whoopee, but if there are any spectators among the millions of New Yorkers participating in the current carnival they have not failed to observe a good many women among the Legionnaires.

A proposal that the Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church should have a permanent see as Bishop of Washington, D. C., was approved yesterday by an official committee of the church in a report to be presented next month at the triennial general convention of the church, opening on Oct. 6 in Cincinnati.

The Legionnaires who marched in the parade yesterday were still fresh when they crossed the finish line at Seventy-ninth Street and Third Avenue. With their colors flying and their voices raised in song, the men who twenty years ago pledged not to come back until "It's Over Over There," stepped briskly to the end.
Shipments of pneumatic casings in July totaled 5,190,107, compared with 5,389,274 in June and 5,743,867 in July, 1936, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association.

The revolt of Huntington Township Republicans against the leadership of W. Kingsland Macy, Suffolk County leader, gained impetus today when it was announced that former Judge Edgar F. Hazleton, who had been Republican leader of the township for the last ten months, had been succeeded by Herbert A. Roselle of Halesite.

A building and permanent loan of $900,000 has been arranged for Kensington Estates, Inc., with the Equitable Life Assurance Society of America by Lawrence, Blake Jewell, brokers, on the eighteenstory apartment building which is to be erected at 965 Fifth Avenue.

What the Museum of Modern Art is now showing could not but prove a far cry indeed from the gay carnival spirit of the American Legion, as displayed yesterday on Fifth Avenue. The Museum of Modern Art, in its temporary quarters in Rockefeller Center (14 West Fortyninth Street), has placed on view a group of war etchings by Otto

All thought of a change in the leadership of Tammany Hall before the November election ended yesterday when James J. Hines, leader of the Eleventh Assembly District, called on Representative Christopher D. Sullivan to establish peace and harmony in the organization.

Chinese war planes, rising to fight off two Japanese air raids on Canton today, shot down at least six, possibly ten, Japanese planes. One Chinese pursuit plane was seen crashing in flames and others also may have fallen.

A contra-seasonal decline in steel ingot output last week caused the adjusted index to dip sharply to 121.9 from 130.7. The index was 110.6 for the week ended Sept. 19, 1936. Production was at 81 per cent of capacity during the week, according to THE NEW YORK TIMES estimate.

Leading interests in Wall Street were more than a little annoyed yesterday at hints from the Securities and Exchange Commission that "bear raids" had been responsible for the recent break in stock market prices.

By personally reimbursing the corporation, Gustavus F. Swift, president of Swift Co., has brought about dismissal of a suit which accused the company's directors of misapplying its resources by paying $3,500 for Democratic national campaign books.

An unusually brisk demand for commercial space in the downtown section of Manhattan during this season of the year is seen by Carl A. Leasenfeld of the realty firm of Carl A. Leasenfeld and Elliott H. Binzen.

Miss Coralie Barry and Miss Geraldine Jackson gave a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for Miss Janet Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Smith of New York, and Gerald Hughes Phipps, son of former United States Senator and Mrs. Lawrence Phipps of Denver, whose marriage will take place Friday in St. Thomas Church.

The Chase National Bank has been appointed warrant agent for warrants to purchase shares of $15 par common stock of the Interna tional Paper and Power Company It also has been made registrar for the stock of the same company.
Dr. B. M. Gancy, Filipino lawyer, urged the American Legion convention today to ask Congressional postponement of Philippine independence for twenty years. Mr.
With two million persons converging on two miles of Fifth Avenue yesterday to watch the American Legion parade, it was inevitable that a few accidents should occur.
Twelve orthopedic surgeons conferred today with Dr. Herman N. Bundesen, president of the Board of Health, on measures to be used in combating infantile paralysis.

An increase of $3,603,054, or more than 20 per cent in the 1938 budget request for payments by the city to charitable institutions, was proposed at a hearing before Acting Budget Director Kenneth Dayton yesterday. The estimate, totaling $18,687,254, was submitted by Harry G. Lynn, chief of the division of charitable institutions of the Deapartment of Finance.

Chances of a deadlock on the floor of the American Legion convention tomorrow, when the 1,339 delegates choose their national commander from a field of five candidates, appeared to have dwindled yesterday as supporters of Daniel Doherty,...

The world's production of tin in July was 15.900 tons, compared with 17.100 in June, while consumption declined to 14,700 tons from 14,990 according to the International Tin Research and Development Council.

State Senator Lester Clee, foe of Governor Hoffman, appeared tonight to have carried Bergen County over Senator Clifford Powell, ally of Governor Hoffman, in the race for the Republican nomnation for Governor.

Japanese planes staged a terrific attack on Nanking, bombing the Chinese capital for an hour and a half. Sirens announcing the approach of the aerial armada had sent the populace scurrying to bombproof shelter. The United States Embassy staff was still quartered on a gunboat offshore in the Yangtze River. [Page 1.]

Jacqueline Cochran, New York aviatrix, averaged 293.05 miles an hour in four flights over a three - kilometer course today, bettering the women's land-plane speed record of 276.527 miles an hour established in 1934 by the late Helene Boucher of France.

Yesterday, while hundreds of thousands of Americans in the City of New York cheered the squadrons of fighting planes flying in formation over the Legion's parade, hundreds of thousands of Chinese and many foreigners in Nanking, tense with terror,

President Roosevelt's address on the Constitution hardly needs any comments. It is so timely, so truthful, so brilliant that it is bound to awaken in the mass of our citizens a faith born of experience that in the final analysis we will work out our perplexing problems without resort to measures similar to those in other lands.

Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy will cross Austria en route to Germany Saturday. He will arrive by train at Brenner and leave Austria near Kufstein. The railroad through Austria will be guarded with a sentinel every fifty yards, while tunnels will be particularly watched.

British warships rushed to the protection of a French steamer in the first attack reported in the Mediterranean since the Nyon accord was reached. The steamer was the Koutoubia, bound from Corsica for Casablanca, Morocco.

Miss Julia Manley L'Ecluse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton L'Ecluse of East Neck, Huntington Bay Village, has announced the plans for her marriage to L. Livingston George, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. George of Englewood, N. J.

A second attempt to upset the constitutionality of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act in the United States Customs Court resulted yesterday in a setback to those challenging the law. Without ruling on the constitutionality of the measure, the Customs Court dismissed a suit brought by George C. Wislar of Bridgeport, Conn.,

Because of the increasing use of highspeed machinery and plant equipment in Germany, that country has ceased to regard leather belting as efficient as other types, according to a report to the Department of Commerce. Increased use of highspeed belting made from silk and cotton has been noted.

Lincoln 0. Robertshaw will make a bid for a second leg on the New York Curb Exchange championship trophy on Friday, when the trading body will hold its annual Fall golf tournament at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club, Mamaroneck.

With a solid London run behind it, the play called "George and Margaret" calls tonight at the Morosco, to which John Chapman Wilson, in association with the Warner Brothers, has summoned an English cast to do the performing.

The deputy Foreign Office spokesman said at a press conference today that the Chinese authorities were suspected of plotting to attack foreign embassies at Nanking by Chinese planes disguised as Japanese machines.

The gross receipts of Public Utility Companies here will be taxed 1 per cent by the city until next July 1, but an effort will be made by city officials to exempt the Westchester Electric Railroad Company, according to resolutions adopted last night by the City Council. The tax went into effect today.

Newark's effort to capture a greater share of gross receipts taxes paid by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company was blocked today by the action of the State Tax Commissioner, J. H. Thayer Martin, in reducing the municipality's $60,000,000 valuation on the company's property to $29,634,000.

Manila has opened a national produce exchange to handle future and spot transactions in sugar, rice and any other Philippine staples as the demand may arise, the Department of Commerce announced today. Exchange transactions are free from sales tax, except where there is an actual physical transfer of the goods.

A meeting of the Board of Aldermen to override Mayor La Guardia's veto of the bill repealing the 50 per cent increase in water rates was proposed to Aldermanic President William F. Brunner yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission, the Broadway Association and the Twenty-third Street Association.

A plan for the formation of a national perfume and cosmetic buyers' club, broached by Miss Jean MacFarlane of Stern's, Williamsport, Pa., will be discussed today by the perfume and cosmetic buyers' conference and exhibition at the Commodore Hotel.
With the aid of Hal Trosky's fifthinning home run with the bases loaded, Johnny Allen hung up his thirteenth pitching triumph of the season today as Cleveland defeated Washington, 6 to 3.

Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Deere Wiman gave a supper dance at their home, Tantallon, here tonight to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Nancy Wiman. The party was held on the lawn near the swimming pool, a marquee of blue and white cellophane having been erected over the dance platform.
Miss Theodosia de Riemer Hawley, an artist and a former instructor at Miss Spence's School here, died on Monday at her home, 114 East Eighty-fourth Street, after a long illness. She was 67 years old.
City planning became a science worthy of an experimental laboratory today when the University of Buffalo announced that it would establish a "planning research station" on or near the campus.

A proclamation was issued by President Roosevelt today designating Oct. 11 as General Casimir Pulaski Memorial Day in honor of the Polish hero of the American Revolution, who fell at Savannah, Ga., and died of his wounds on Oct. 11, 1779.

Plans to close 5,000 retail butcher shops, serving about 2,000,000 persons in New York City, Paterson and Passaic, N. J., were laid last night at a meeting of the Federation of Kosher Butchers in the Broadway Central Hotel.
All the favorites came through to win their matches in the first round of the women's New Jersey State golf championship over the West Course of the Esser County Country Club today.

Enough time has now elapsed, since the release of $300,000,000 "inactive gold" from the Treasury on Sept. 13, to judge how far the purpose of that action has been accomplished. The immediate objective was increase of member-bank reserves and maintenance of very low money rates.

Representatives of the American Federation of Actors and the Variety Revue Association, which includes operators of the fourteen former burlesque theatres in the city, meeting in the offices of the Eltinge Theatre, 236 West Fortysecond Street yesterday afternoon, signed a tentative agreement for improved working conditions.

Hazen (Kiki) Cuyler, veteran of fifteen years in big-time baseball, announced today his retirement, effective at the end of the season, but left the way open to consideration of a berth as coach or manager.
A wreath of yellow, green and gold flowers was yesterday placed on the pedestal of the statue of Father Francis P. Duffy at the island separating Broadway and Seventh Avenue at Forty-seventh Street.

Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Breckenridge Cochran of Alexandria have announced the engagement of their eldest daughter, Courtenay Marshall Cochran, to Park Edmund Ticer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Fillmore Ticer of Alexandria.

Legionnaire F. H. La Guardia received a tremendous cheering from the thousands who lined Fifth Avenue last night as he led the New York Division of the American Legion parade up the Avenue from Twenty-ninth to Seventy-ninth Streets.

Intent upon improving Manhattan's passing and running game before the season's opener with St. Bonaventure at Ebbets Field Saturday, Coach Chick Meehan sent his squad through a two-hour passing scrimmage with the New York Football Giants yesterday.

Rockwell Kent has offered to make the amende honorable to Puerto Ricans who protested against his mural, in the Postoffice Department Building here, in which he sketched in tiny characters what he and others say is a message of encouragement, in an obscure Alaskan Eskimo dialect, to the Puerto Rican independence movement.

Asserting that the tide of events is running against Individualism and private enterprise, Dr. Glenn Frank, formerly president of the University of Wisconsin, declared last night that as life grows more complex the part Government plays must expand,

ONE of the Leeward Islands is called Antigua, but Louis Adamic's "House in Antigua"* has nothing to do with that. It deals with the ruined Guatemalan city of the same name, the old capital destroyed by an earthquake about 150 years ago. It seems that last Winter Mr.

Twelve members of the Columbia Club, an exclusive Republican stronghold since the days of Benjamin Harrison, posted a notice today suggesting the word "Republican" be stricken from the club's constitution, and that the institution be made non-political.

Press).-Gold production continues to increase in Canada. It reached 347,474 ounces in July, compared with 344,895 in the previous month and 321,107 in July, last year, it was reported today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.
Discussion of the Palestine partition proposal began in the League of Nations Assembly's sixth commission today with sentiment thus far more favorable to it than had been expected.
Cardinal Mundelein consecrated the Rt. Rev. Ambrose Pinger as Bishop of the vicarate of Chowtsun, Shantung Province, China, amid much ceremony at Holy Name Cathedral today.

Rather than rely on the Federal Trade Commission, industry must give greater consideration to selfgovernment, B. H. Lerner, executive director of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers, Inc., and chairman of the Blouse

Turpentine firm, 30 3/4c; sales 82 barrels; receipts 697 barrels; shipments 806 barrels; stock 39,714 barrels. Resin firm; sales 435; receipts 2,024; shipments 6,335; stock 60,314. Quote: B, D. E, $7.50; F to K. $7.85; M, $7.90; N, $8; WG, $8.20; WW, X, $8.65.

A sale of the paintings and drawings by Rifka Angel and Milton Douthat is being held at their studio, 211 West Tenth Street, through September. The artists announce that proceeds will go in their entirety to the North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy for use in its current Children's Home Campaign.

After the patrol boat Larrakia had arrested the Japanese pearler Tokyo Maru in territorial waters off Bremer Island, in the Gulf of Carpentaria, the engineer of the Tokyo Maru deliberately disabled the vessel's engine, obliging the commander of the Larrakia to sail the lugger to port.
Structurally speaking, the American architect has fallen for the eagle, and the Government is going to see that he does right by our national bird.
Two New York cities had high ratings today in a survey of housing facilities in sixty-four cities, made public by Dr. Paul M. Pearson, assistant director of the PWA housing division.

The marriage of Miss Rachael Lee Stitt, daughter of Mrs. Nelson Stitt of Monte Vista, Col., to James Frank Drake Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Frank Drake of Pittsburgh, took place here yesterday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

Paleontologists will be asked to verify what is believed to be a nest of petrified dinosaur eggs, laid perhaps 60,000,000 years ago. They were discovered after a landslide in Waterton National Park, forty-five miles southwest of Lethbridge.

A steam locomotive which, its designers say, will be able to maintain a speed of 100 miles an hour on level track when hauling fourteen Pullman cars, has been laid down by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad. It has sixteen cylinders and marks a radical departure from conventional design.

A comprehensive program of courses in modern retailing will be given in the evening sessions of City College, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street, beginning next Monday night, Herbert L. Redman, managing director of Saks-34th Street and chairman of the advisory committee for courses in retailing, announced yesterday.

For more than two years Leo C. Fennelly, Assistant United States Attorney, nursed his conscience and practiced patience. Responsible for the prosecution of an alleged $1,000,000 mail fraud in stocks, he had to keep himself in leash while one of eight defendants roamed the world, immune to legal process.
Amid a vast demonstration by a united people the body of former President Thomas Garrigue Masaryk was borne through the streets of Prague today and buried in the village churchyard at Lany.

Following the example of the American Labor party, the Socialist party and the Communist party, the City Fusion party at a meeting of its executive committee failed yesterday to follow Mayor La Guardia in his endorsement of George U. Harvey for re-election as Borough President of Queens.

Alter having been held by the same family for more than 240 years, a Third Avenue corner in the Harlem section of Manhattan has just changed ownership. The sale brought to mind the vast changes which have taken place in the district immediately north and east of the upper reaches of Central Park since the time a vast portion of that land,

In the absence of Frank Gillmore, Equity president, Paul Dullzell, executive secretary and treasurer, issued the following statement based on a resolution passed yesterday by the Equity council: "Osgood Perkins served Equity loyally and faithfully as a councillor and as an officer for more than six years.

A reward of $1,000 for information leading to the arrest and indictment of the gang responsible for the explosion of twenty-nine stench and tear gas bombs in Manhattan and Bronx motion-picture theatres was announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia. The reward was posted by a group of citizens interested in law enforcement.

The legality of police summonses attached to automobiles here was challenged today in the Mount Vernon City Court by Manlio S. Severino, an attorney. He said he had no intention of answering a ticket placed on his car for alleged overtime parking.

The Maritime Commission, intervening for a second time in ten days in strikes on governmentowned ships, warned the crew of the America France Line freighter Vincent last evening that if they did not immediately end a sit-down strike and take their ship to sea their licenses as seamen would be imperiled.

ACKERLY-Eugenie, at her residence, 135 West 104th St., on Sept. 19, 1937, mother of the late Vera, daughter of the late Rosina and Antonio Mestri, wife of the late Archibald. Funeral services at the the Campbell Funeral Church, Broadway and 66th St., Wednesday, Sept. 22, at 2 P. M. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.
A plan to disseminate birth control information among the 130,000 members of the congress was adopted today by the executive committee of the Illinois Congress of Parents and Teachers.

George O. Frank, first teller of the Stock Clearing Corporation of 8 Broad Street, an affiliate of the New York Stock Exchange, was found murdered early yesterday on his forty-seventh birthday on South Portland Avenue in downtown Brooklyn, a few doors from De Kalb Avenue and opposite Fort Greene Park.

107th St. 163 W, 25x100.11; Geroge F. Brown to Louise S. Guentzer, 1,909 Vyse Ave, due Oct. 1, 1947, 4%; $20,000. 3d Ave, 2,065-2,069, 75.7x104.6; Jason Holding Co, James S. Anderson, president, to City Bank Farmers Trust Co and another, trustee Annie W. Gould et al; p. m. mtg. 5 yrs. 4 1/2%; $15,000.

Title to the three-story taxpayer at 272-276 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, has been taken by the Horman Realty Company, Maurice Epstein, treasurer. The Brooklyn Savings Bank, represented by its attorneys, Orr Brennan, was the seller. Harry A. and Eric C. Gordon represented the purchaser.

Four Coast Guard cutters turned homeward tonight from a fruitless search for Endeavour, but in the waterfront gathering places of mariners hope still lingered that the big British racing sloop remained afloat off the beaten path, far out on the Atlantic.
Teams from the two largest cities in the nation were eliminated from the "amateur world series" of the American baseball congress in the two games played today.

The Census Bureau reported today that the cotton spinning industry had operated during August at 130.5 per cent of capacity, compared with 121.9 per cent during July this year and 115.8 per cent during August last year.

A British protest was delivered today to the chief of General Francisco Franco's diplomatic office as a result of derogatory remarks about Thomas Bates, British consul at Santander, Spain, by General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano over the Spanish Insurgent radio on Sept. 11.

A who's who of American golf assembled on Belmont's hilly, windy course today to polish their games for the richest cash awards of the season-those in the $12,000 international match play tournament that opens tomorrow and runs until next Tuesday.

As a means of restoring "free and independent competition" in Pennsylvania's hard coal fields the Anthracite Coal Industry Commission, headed by W. Jett Lauck of Washington, recommended today the imposition of a graduated tax on the gross income from anthracite royalties.

With automobiles capable of traveling eighty miles an hour and more, the city dweller is actually traveling at speeds slower than those in the horse-and-buggy days, the American Institute of Steel Construction was told last night by its president, Clyde G. Conley of Mount Vernon, Ohio, at a special dinner meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria

Just as the theatre notices were appearing in the Washington newspapers Osgood Perkins died. He had not felt in the best of health during the opening performance of "Susan and God" in Washington on Monday evening.
Greentree and Old Westbury, the two most interesting teams the polo season has produced, will meet this afternoon in the delayed final of the national open championship.
After Dickinson College called off today's practice game with Pennsylvania, due to injuries, Head Coach Harvey Harman sent four teams through a brisk scrimmage.

The annual business meeting of the Real Estate Board of New York will be held at 2:30 P. M. today in the Hotel Commodore for the election of members of the board of governors, nominating and auditing committees for the coming year and for action on a change in the code of ethics.
A clause in New York's new seventy-twohour marriage law was invoked today to permit the wedding of a young couple from Newport, R. I.

Replying to the Citizens Budget Commission, which had called on the Board of Education to justify an increase of more than $14,000,000 in its 1938 budget, James Marshall, vice president of the board, declared yesterday that the commission's statement was "either misleading or benighted."

Stating that if there is widespread crime in this city one can be pretty sure that "some one in the municipal government has been accepting money for it," Judge Curtis Bok instructed the October grand jury today to determine whether Philadelphia's system of law enforcement works, "and if it doesn't, why it doesn't."
Directors of the Southern States Industrial Council adopted resolutions here today opposing the Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill and asking amendment of the Wagner Labor Relations Act.

72D ST, 140-46 W, 80x102.2; Joel I. Schweitzer, ref, to Central Savings Bank, foreclosure ($11). 81ST ST, 164 W, 18.1x102.2. Benj. Baskin to Alice Phelan, 344 W 121st St, and Mary A. Phelan, 413 E 84th St; mtg. $9,000 ($4). 93D ST, 142 W, 20x100.8: Jos. Shulof et al, exrs; Herman H. Shulof to Oscar Hentham, 148 W 93d St: mtg, $14,200 ($3).

Recall proceedings were started today against Premier Aberhart, head of Alberta's Social Credit government, in an effort to remove him as representative of Okotoks-High River constituency in the Provincial Legislature.

A vigorous attack on the Anglo-French thesis that the League of Nations is too crippled by non-membership to act against the wars in Spain and China was made in the Assembly today by Maxim M. Litvinoff, the Soviet Foreign Commissar .

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 20: COLONELS Gullion, A. W., Judge Advocate General's Dept.: 2 days' leave, Sept. 22, and 2 days' leave Oct. 2. Ulio. J. A. (Adjutant General's Dept.). General Staff Corps; relieved from detail as a member of the General Staff Corps, Hawaii, and ordered to the Adjutant General's Dept., headquarters, ??vernors Island, N. Y.

Japan's land campaign forces have necessari?? been content with modest gains in the last few days. The naval lines in the Shanghai vicinity have been unable to move forward, while the army, endeavoring to thrust forward on a broad first front, has advanced only 3,000 yards.

George Backer, son-in-law of the late Mortimer Schiff, will run for Congress on the American Labor Party ticket in the silk-stocking Seventeenth Congressional District, it was announced yesterday by Alex Rose, executive secretary of the party.

Plans were filed yesterday for three apartment buildings, two in the Bronx and one in Queens. The Bronx houses are to be six stories in height and will be erected on Richardson Avenue, near 242d Street and on White Plains Road, near 242d Street.

Trial of James Rand Jr., president of Remington-Rand, Inc., and Pearl H. Bergoff on charges of violating a Federal statute during a strike at the Rand plant in Middletown was assigned for Nov. 8 today by Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the District Court.

As the hour approached for him to defend his world's welterweight title, Barney Ross yesterday moved nearer the battleground to complete training for the bout which will be one of the features of the Carnival of Champions in the Polo Grounds tomorrow night.

WHILE the Giants are grappling with the Cubs and the entrants in the fistic carnival set for tomorrow night are resting up, there is just time to run through a brief signal drill on football. It's about time to warm up.

Philip Rockhill Dougherty, for the last ten years night supervisor of the mail department of R. H. Macy Co., died this morning of a heart attack at his home here, 276 East Westfield Avenue. He was 44 years old.

Mayor David H. Slayback, who has headed the Verona Borough Council for the last twenty-two years, defeated Stephen Bergdahl for the Republican nomination for Mayor in today's primary election. Mr. Slayback received 1,536 votes and Mr. Bergdahl, 1,007.

Passengers sailing for Europe today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary include Harley V. Earl, Viscount Cowdray, Lieut. Col. S. S. Cohen, Dr. Donald Guthrie, Dr. and Mrs. Russell Reynolds, Captain and Mrs. I. J. Lewis, Miss Rosita Diaz, Charles S. Munson,

The report of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System for August, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $19,903 after expenses and charges, but before provision for surtax on undistributed profits, as compared with a net of $311,969 in August, 1936. Gross operating revenues for the month aggregated $2,352,560, against $2,487,403 in the same month last year.

Samuel Reshevsky, United States champion, and Reuben Fine, both of New York, had the stage to themselves tonight in the international chess masters tournament when they completed their game adjourned from the seventh round and in which they already had held two sessions. The result was a draw after ninety-five moves.

Charges and counter charges alleging there had been manipulation in September corn of late, voiced by individual members of the Board of Trade here, were today revealed as under investigation by the Commodity Exchange Administration.

The Interstate Commerce Commission delved today into the corporate set-up of the Alleghany Corporation and the Chesapeake Corporation to lay groundwork for its claim that it has jurisdiction over them.

At least 15,000 persons are expected to attend the fourth biennial convention of the Union of Democratic Clubs of New York State at Niagara Falls Friday and Saturday. Governor Lehman, Postmaster General James A. Farley, Senator Robert F. Wagner and Lieutenant Governor M. William Bray will be among the speakers.

Major Julian Troncoso, Spanish Nationalist [Insurgent] military governor of Irun, after being detained overnight at Hendaye, at the Franco-Spanish border, by French authorities, was arrested today in connection with their inquiry into an attempt to seize the Spanish Loyalist submarine C-2 at Brest.

Miss Hope Knowles, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Knowles of Chestnut Hill, was introduced to society this afternoon at a tea which her parents gave at their home. The debutante, who finished at Springside School in June, received with her mother.
St. Louis at New York (2)--Kott and Hogsett vs. Pearson and Wicker. Detroit at Boston-Bridges vs. McKain. Chicago at Philadelphia-Lee vs. Kelley. Cleveland at Washington-Harder vs. DeShong.

Both the Bar Association and the board of directors of the New York County Lawyers Association have adopted resolutions in censure of Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy, and the former organization, though not the latter, has refused to endorse his candidacy for re-election.

The Battle of Broadway was conceded yesterday to the Peter Pans of the American Legion. Local police, the Street Cleaning Department and most New Yorkers, still peeping from behind the barricades, just wiped the confetti out of their eyes and could not get over the wonder of it.

C. E. Snively, former postmaster and newspaper publisher here and for many years a leader in Republican affairs, died today of a stroke in the Graham Hospital. He was born eighty-four years ago at Ellisville, Fulton County.
The Dodgers landed near these Mississippi shores today and all but fell in without a boat or a life preserver in sight. They lost both ends

The discussions of many years in high naval circles over whether to organize the fleet along tactical lines by types of ships or maintain it on administrative lines ended today in a decision to adopt the tactical method to provide maximum battle efficiency and the greatest striking power.
President Roosevelt has had no word, direct or indirect, from Associate Justice Black, who, it has been alleged, was and is a member of the Ku Klux Klan.
At 2 o'clock this morning State Senator Lester H. Clee jumped into the lead over his rival, State Senator Clifford R. Powell, to carry Hudson County for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination.

While business failures declined in the four other trade groups in the week ended Sept. 16, compared with the corresponding period last year, the retail division showed an increase, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,671,200 barrels, compared with 3,642,400 in the previous week, an increase of 28,800 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

American Federation of Labor leaders began organizing a "solid front" council of maritime unions today, designed to crowd all Committee for Industrial Organization elements off Pacific Coast waterfronts.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas More Storke of Santa Barbara have announced the engagement of Mr. Storke's daughter, Miss Jean Isabel Storke, to Ernest Frederick Menzies of London and Calcutta. Miss Storke, who has resided in New York for several years, returned here from a trip around the world last week.

Justice Department attorneys seized upon a 67-year-old statute today as a weapon to punish alleged anti-union terrorism in the Harlan, Ky., coal fields. The law provides for a maximum of $5,000 fine and 10 years imprisonment for "conspiracy to injure

CHAMBERS. MILDRED (Nov. 19, 1935). Estate, $100. To James Chambers, husbaid, executor, 240 W. 144th St. CROWLEY, MARGARET E. (Sept. 14). Estate, about $2,000. To Agnes C. Mahoney, sister, and George F. Crowley, brother, both of 154 Stearns Ave., Westwood, Mass., and John P. Crowley, brother, 37 Eastern Ave., Dedham, Mass., $500 each; one other bequest. Helen E. Sanford, 333 E. 43d St., executrix.

Harry W. Colmery, national commander of the American Legion, did not get the breakfast he expected yesterday morning at the Empire State Club. According to the convention's printed program, the commander was to be the guest of former Governor Alfred E. Smith at 7:15 A. M. at the club.

The opinion is held in some Government bond circles that the stimulating effect of the Treasury's release of $300,000,000 of "sterilized" gold funds on the market for Government issues has about run its course. Having had a persistent upward trend about ten days following the Treasury's move, the market for Government issues weakened on Monday

Because of recent controversies over the use of the word "custom" in designating or describing merchandise, the Better Business Bureau of New York yesterday urged strict observance by the retail trade of the definition of the National Association of Better Business Bureaus. This definition is:

The Republican State Committee, when it meets here later today, will receive a recommendation from its executive committee that selection of a successor to Charles D. Hilles as Republican National Committeeman be deferred until a meeting of the committee to be called at some future date by Chairman William S. Murray.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William J. Garbow of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor V. Garbow, to Dr. Leon C. Grossman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Grossman, also of this city. Miss Garbow was graduated from Columbia University.

The finding of a customers list containing about 1,500 names in the records of J. Overton Paine, who is charged with being the chief operator in a group that is alleged to have swindled residents in Newark and vicinity out of about $500,000, was reported today by detectives in the office of Essex County Prosecutor William Wachenfeld.

Attorney General Cummings, who has asserted that the Justice Department made no investigation of the qualifications of former Senator Hugo L. Black as a Supreme Court justice, was declared here today to have been able to ascertain without going out of his office that the Senator had been a member of the Ku Klux Klan.

Wally Moses' twenty-fifth home run of the season after Appling's error put Pinchhitter Jesse Hill on base gave the Athletics a 5-to-4 victory in eleven innings over Chicago today. The Sox scored a run in their half of the last session to break a 3-to-3 tie.
Miss Chrystal MacMillan, a barrister who had long devoted herself to women's claims to suffrage and equal citizenship, died in Edinburgh today at the age of 65.

Mrs. Benjamin Jerome Sands of Upper King Street, Port Chester, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Esther Willson Sands, to Lon Hocker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lon O. Hocker of St. Louis.

Boynton Ave, 1,121 (14-3740); Ray Rosenstein to Lillie Blum, 500 43d St, Union City, N. J.; mtge, $10,000. 173d St, 415 E (11-2898); Thomas O'Connor to Thomas Malone, 415 E 173d St. Taylor Ave., 716 (14-3599); Chemical Bank Trust Co, trustee, to Max Brust, 716 Taylor Ave. Boston Rd (11-2934), s w cor of Jefferson P1, 148x103; East River Savings Bank to 1,365 Boston Road Realty Corp, 336 Central Park W.
Captain Flavel Williams, former naval officer and inventor, was cleared of a morals charge in Criminal Court today when Judge W. A. Valentine nolle pressed the case, growing out of a marital tangle.

Directors of the American Smelting and Refining Company declared yesterday a dividend of $1.75 a share on the common stock, payable on Nov. 30 to stock of record of Nov. 5. Three payments of 75 cents each already have been made on the common stock this year.

The eighty-eighth year of classes at City College will begin today when about 9,000 students report to the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, the School of Technology and the School of Business and Civic Administration.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 20 unless specified. Pearl Harbor to Bremerton Yard: Lark, Oglala, Preble, Pruitt. Quail, Slcard, Tanager, Tracy, Whippoorwill. Acushnet, Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, to sea, Sept. 21. Bulmer, Tsingtao to Shanghai. Sept. 21. Canopus, Tsingtao to Manila, Sept. 21, Cormorant. at Kitty Hawk, Sept. 21.

Thomas Iredale, 60 years old, of 124 Court Street, White Plains, a veteran motorman of the Boston Westchester Railroad, died, apparently of a heart attack, at the controls of his train just north of the Morris Park Avenue station at 180th Street, the Bronx, at 7:30 a. m. yesterday.

Mrs. Ernest E. Eldred of Cedarhurst was the winner of the tricolor and best exhibit award at a Fall horticulture show held today at the Lawrence Village Park clubhouse in which members of the Cedarhurst Garden Study Group, the Woodsburgh Garden Club, the Woodmere Garden Club and the Peninsula Garden Club took part.

An injunction suit to halt the ferry service to Governors Island and the sightseeing ferry to the Statue of Liberty on Bedloes Island was filed in Federal court yesterday by the McAllister Navigation Company, Inc. It charged Major John R.

Announcement has been made here by Mrs. Christopher C. Crowell of Newtonville, Mass., of the engagement of her sister, Miss Hazel B. Atwood, to G. Vreeland Johnson of 188 Rutland Road, Brooklyn, son of Mrs. Albert N. Johnson and the late Mr. Johnson.

Foreign movie distributors today disclosed that the Finance Ministry had informed them licenses for foreign films with the exception of newsreels would not be granted during the period from Sept. 4 to Jan. 1.

Italy, her honor satisfied by French and British recognition that she is a "great mediterranean power," agreed yesterday to enter into talks looking to her inclusion in the anti-piracy patrol. The conversations will be held in Paris shortly. [Page 1.]

The Church League for Industrial Democracy, through its executive committee, issued a denial yesterday of the charges of "espousing and promoting communism" made by the Church Laymen's Association. Both groups are Protestant Episcopal organizations.

Representatives of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle and the newspaper's unit of the American Newspaper Guild will meet this morning at the office of William H. Davis, chairman of the New York State Mediation Board, at 165 Broadway in an attempt to end the nine-day strike of the paper's editorial and commercial department employes.

Moderate improvement appeared in most sections of the bond market yesterday, in contrast with the unsettled conditions of the preceding day, although trading in the main was spiritless and price movements generally held to narrow limits.

Directors of the American-La France-Foamite Corporation yesterday authorized a payment of 2 3/4 per cent on the company's twenty-year income notes for the six months ended on June 30 payable on Oct. 16 to registered holders of record of Oct. 9.
A better tendency prevailed in the stock market here today, although dealings were small and interest still was centered upon the down trend in Wall Street.

The question of Associate Justice Black's membership in the Ku Klux Klan and President Roosevelt's demand for changes in the Supreme Court have had a definite political effect and may be the real issues in the Congressional elections next year, John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today after sentiment was sounded at a conference of eight Republican leaders representing cities of more than 500,000 population.

The United States Sugar Corporation, operating sugar plantations in the Florida Everglades, reported yesterday net earnings of $871,082 for the fiscal year ended on June 30, after all charges and Federal income taxes, compared with $804,910 in the preceding year. After preferred dividend requirements,
The first general membership meeting of the Middle Atlantic group of the League of American Writers will be held tomorrow evening at 8 at the Cooperative School for Student Teachers, 69 Bank Street.

With the United States present and Italy absent, the League of Nations Advisory Committee of twenty-three sat briefly today to deal with China's appeal and with the war situation, which has become a much worse nightmare during the committee's three-year slumber.
The State Corporation Commission authorized today the App.lachian Electric Power Company to execute a refunding operation involving $67,000,000 in securities.
Conrad Engel, a member of the New York City Board of Child Welfare, died yesterday at his home, 89-25 138th Place, Jamaica, Queens, after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

Contention over the American Constitution will be submitted to academic scrutiny this year by nine experts from various universities at the Columbia University Extension. Professor James C. Egbert, extension director, announced yesterday.

The number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was well below the preceding week. The total was also less than in the Corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings published in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals were 701,
The American Legion covered fifty-three blocks of Fifth Avenue, the highway of big parades, with a noisy panoply of remembrance yesterday, while on the sidelines 2,000,000 cheered.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange, after resistance for several hours, sank yesterday into new low ground and ended at the bottom, unchanged to 2 points lower than on Monday.

Leander K. Carr, managing editor of The Newport Herald and one of New England's best known reporters during the Eighteen Nineties, died suddenly today at his home here as he was preparing to leave for Cape Cod on vacation with his wife, Mrs. Abbie Carr.

If the weather and track are right War Admiral, the 3-yearold champion, may end his absence from the races Saturday by starting in the $10,000 added Potomac Handicap, mile and sixteenth test for thoroughbreds of his age.

The semester at the Textile School of New York, 117 West Forty-eighth Street, will begin next Tuesday, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Leonard Seymour Friedman, dean, who also stated that Louis Semel, a graduate textile engineer of the Philadelphia Textile School, has been added to the faculty.

Boxing will be conducted on Monday nights at the Hippodrome and the St. Nicholas Palace, now known as the Royal Windsor, according to the dates approved yesterday by the State Athletic Commission. The conflict will not occur until November and will run only to Jan. 1.

Harry G. Gebhard. Inc., has arranged first mortgages of $11.000 on the private dwelling at 85-27 Edgerton Boulevard, Jamaica Estates. and $4,500 on the onefamily house at 31 Lawson Avenue, Rockville Center, with the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company. Loans have been placed by Harold 1. Cross. Jamaica, broker, as follows: $29,500 on 227-01-11 Merrlck Rd.. Laurelton, for the Leda Realty Corp.;

The airplane has diminished the value of surface men-of-war, particularly in "closed seas," and Italian aerial strength makes it possible for Italy to control the Mediterranean, General Giuseppe Valle, Italian Under-Secretary for Air, declares in an interview mailed to THE NEW YORK TIMES from Rome.
Miss Jane Bowne Haines, founder and president of the Pennsylvania School for Horticulture for Women in Ambler, Pa., died in Germantown Hospital yesterday in her sixty-ninth year.

In keeping with the other stupendous proportions of the American Legion parade, the Department of Sanitation reported yesterday that a picked staff of 1,500 men working twenty-two hours had collected 625 tons of waste paper in the parade and Times Square areas, more than six times the quantity produced by the reception for Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh.

An effort to settle the ten-day strike of editorial and commercial employes of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle was begun yesterday by the State Mediation Board, under whose auspices representatives of the paper's management and the New York Newspaper Guild met at the office of William H. Davis, chairman of the board, at 165 Broadway.
