Declaring that "taxation has become a bugaboo in corporate planning," the committee on Federal taxation of the American Institute of Accounts recommended yesterday at a meeting there the creation of a "qualified nonpartisan commission to conduct the research required for the unbiased dtermination of fixed principles of Federal income taxation," according to The Associated Press.

The Old Thomas homestead in Hasbrouck Heights, N. J., for many years a landmark which often served as a picturesque background for motion picture companies on location, has been purchased by the Hasbrouck Heights Hospital Association from the Fidelity Liquidating Trust.

Abram Michael (Abe) Orpen, who parlayed the profits from a handbook into ownership of three Canadian race tracks, died today after a long illness. The dean of the country's race track owners was 83 years old.

Miss Doris Terhune, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ten Broeck M. Terhune, was married to Herbert N. Rawlins Jr., son of Herbert N. Rawlins of this city and Southampton and the late Mrs. Natalie Hatch Rawlins, at noon yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, 45 East Sixty-sixth Street.
Settlement of a $140,000 claim against the former directors of the closed New Jersey National Bank and Trust Company here for $15,000 was authorized today by Federal Judge William Clark.

The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today the payment of $10,000 a year to Hudson J. Bordwell and $6,000 a year to Walter Kidde as maximum compensation for services as trustees of the property of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad. Mr. Bordwell will also act as chief operating of ficer of the property.

Selection of William O. Douglas as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission to succeed James M. Landis is likely to be well received. Mr. Douglas has been a member of the commission since January, 1936, and Stock Exchange officials have been in frequent personal contact with him;

The New York Stock Exchange decided yesterday to list 350,000 shares of Interborough Rapid Transit Company capital stock and $5,949,700 United , Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation 5 per cent sinking fund bonds due in 1952. Listing does not mean that either will be admitted immediately to dealings.

President Manuel Quezon, angrily denouncing the "inhumanity" of a court decision, today ordered government contracts withheld from an employer who won a legal victory over a family seeking compensation for the death of a worker.

Historic Granja de Torrehermosa, in Southwestern Spain, tonight was a blazing no man's land in the path of the Spanish Government's offensive in the Cordoba battle zone. The Government said its forces swept across the Cordoba-Badajoz provincial border and into the outskirts of the town after their air force had bombarded it throughout the day. The civilian population had abandoned their homes.

Due to a knee injury sustained by Anton Mischo, junior end from New York City, Head Coach Harvey Harman of Pennsylvania today wired Joseph Sims Jr., substitute end on last year's unbeaten freshman squad, to come to camp.

The American Legion Convention, which met in a desultory session at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday, will wind up the business of its nineteenth annual reunion, jamboree and talk fest today with the election of Daniel Doherty of Boston as National Commander and a conscious effort to follow Mayor La Guardia's welcoming advice to "mind your own business," according to every indication last night.

With more than 700 hounds entered for the three-day exhibition, the Bryn Mawr hound show got under way today to a new high in the twenty years' existence of this event, which is being held on the polo grounds, adjacent to the Bryn Mawr horse show field.

While the German press continues to attack the Geneva speech of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Great Britain, rejecting Germany's colonial claims as an attempt to keep the Reich in economic subjection, the newspapers also announce with appropriate laudatory comments the extension of German food sources through new efforts at self-sufficiency.

Joseph Klaw, son of the late Marc Klaw, theatrical producer, was found dead last evening in his automobile in a lonely patch of woods on the outskirts of Douglaston, Queens. One ehd of a twelvefoot length of rubber tube had been attached to the exhaust and the other projected through a rear window into the car.

The National Vaudeville Artists Club has leased new quarters in the Navex Building, 223-25 West Fortysixth Street, to be occupied Oct. 1. A housewarming show and dance will head the list of the season's entertainments. Clown nights will be re-established.

A plot of land 125 by 100 feet, on the east side of Seventy--second Place, 150 feet south of Calamus Avenue, in Woodside, Queens, has been sold by Mrs. E. Freese to the Dunwell, Homes Company through Edwards Co., broker. The new owner plans to improve the parcel with six brick houses.
Headquarters of the United Automobile Workers of America ordered additional organizers to Memphis today, after the beating of two of its representatives last night.
Henry H. Stansbury, a newspaper man for forty years, died yesterday at the age of 63 after a long illness in a suburban sanitarium. At one time he was general manager for Universal Service.
Miss Alice Louise Morton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot H. Morton of Huntington, will be married on Oct. 2 to Leroy S. Wells at the Huntington Baptist Church.

Maurice J. (Big Clipper) Smith painted a glowing picture of Villanova's 1937 football prospects to New York alumni of the Philadelphia college at an athletic reunion in the Catholic Center Club last night.
Captain Freeman Hatfield, Nova Scotia skipper of the Gypsum Queen, was found guilty today by a supreme court jury of defrauding the Canadian World War Reparations Commission of $71,276.

With the expectation of one of the largest crowds ever to witness an A. A. U. boxing tournament, plans have been completed for the holding of the American Legion show tonight in the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City. This is listed as the final event on the program of the Legion convention.

Dr. Roberto M. Ortiz received enough electoral votes tonight to assure his election as President of Argentina. Although the counting of the popular ballots was unfinished, Dr. Ortiz, candidate of the conservative coalition organized by retiring President Agustin P. Justo, had won provinces with 196 electoral votes.

The Municipal Bond Club of New York will hold its sixth annual field day at the Oakland Golf Club, Bayside, L. I., on Oct. 1. George J. Gllies of the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation is chairman of the field day committee, which includes A. W. Phelps of Phelps, Fenn Co.;

Twenty-five thousand residents of Rio de Janeiro met today in St. John the Baptist Cemetery to pay tribute to seventeen officers who died defending the Government in the 1935 revolt. President Getulio Vargas in an address said the pilgrimage was a warning "to those who aim to destroy the country by implanting Communism."
Thaddeus Cowden, who was King Neptune in the Atlantic City beauty pageant of 1935, died in the Atlantic City Hospital tonight from a stroke suffered a week ago.

To hear the story from the hotel managers of the midtown zone, as it was told last night, so orderly were the Legionnaires during their stay here that the total damage amounted to a broken lamp shade and one or two torn laundry bags.
The proposal made last Spring at the North American Wildlife Conference for a National Wildlife Week has become a reality.

The American Federation of Labor has failed to invite Secretary Perkins to address the annual meeting in Denver next month. This was revealed today when the list of those to whom invitations have been sent was made public.

Plans for the merger of the Interstate Bakeries Corporation and its subsidiaries, the Schulze Baking Company and Western Bakeries Corporation, Ltd., were announced yesterday by R. L. Nafziger, president of the Interstate and Schulze companies. Mr. Nafziger said that one reason for the merger was that the Federal Government no longer permitted consolidated tax returns.
Scoring in every period, the Los Angeles Bulldogs defeated the New York Yankees, 27 to 6, at Randalls Island last night for their second victory in as many American Football League encounters.
Miss Martha Bradbury Brown, daughter of Mrs. Paul Willits Brown of Downingtown and the late Mr. Brown, was married this afternoon to MacLean Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund F. Brown of Radnor.
The Childs restaurant chain has signed an agreement with a committee representing the Hotel, Restaurant and Cafeteria Employes Union, A. F. of L. organization, it was announced yesterday.

Frank Campbell's Rascal led a fleet of eight International One-Design sloops today in the weekly race off the Larchmont Yacht Club. Clair Farrand's Flicker was a close second with Robert N. Bavier third in Frolic.

With virtually no rain in the Cotton Belt and pressure of the marketing movement increasing, prices on the Cotton Exchange here dedined to new low levels again yesterday and ended with losses of 1 to 5 points. Most deliveries sold 4 points lower than the lowest quotations of the previous day and this carried December to 8.57 cents a pound.

The Wheatley Stable's Merry Lassie, who has made an enviable record since she started her racing career at Empire City last July, stamped herself as one of the outstanding 2-year-old fillies of the year at Belmont Park yesterday when she captured the Invermoor Purse for juveniles of her sex at five and a half furlongs over the Widener course.
Raymond Casey, State property management supervisor for the Home Owners Loan Corporation, died tonight at the age of 36.

Foreign Minister Paul Spaak returned today from Geneva and was received for a long audience with King Leopold. According to the newspaper Derniere Heure the subject discussed was Belgium's new policy because of her altered position as a member of the League of Nations Council.

Praise for the police for their handling of the American Legion parade on Tuesday came yesterday both from Mayor La Guardia and Commissioner Valentine. The Mayor, in a message sent to the Police Commissioner over the police teletype system, said:

Hard-pressed British steel manufacturers will obtain 1,500,000 additional tons of iron ore annually under the plans for the expansion of the Grangesberg mines, it was announced today by Finance Minister Ernst Johannes Wigforss. Increased production will total 2,000,000 tons, of which Germany will receive the remaining 500,000 tons.

The city was host last night to more than 17,000 of the more serious-minded members of the American Legion in a three-hour performance at Madison Square Garden dramatizing the education of policemen and firemen.

Ten white officers and thirty Negro members of the crew of the commercial fishing boat S. H. Beckwith were rescued at sea tonight a short time before the boat sank about five miles off the jetty here.

A generally cheerful tone prevailed on the stock market here today and improvements were registered in all sections. Gilt-edge issues were in active demand; foreign loans behaved uncertainly. Transatlantic stocks were well supported and United States Steel and International Nickel advanced.

The Chinese people will be the ultimate losers in the present undeclared war in the Far East "in everything except a new moral stamina and a deepened realization of the necessity for unity," Hallett Abend, chief correspondent in China for THE NEW YORK TIMES, said last night in a radio address from Shanghai.

Edward A. Billene, Boston merchant, who is in the American Hospital at Neuilly, suffering a serious attack of pneumonia, was examined by his physician at 8 o'clock tonight. According on a bulletin issued later his general conditino was satisfacroy and his illness was following its course. It will be several days before a defi-will be several days before a definite pronouncement can be made.

A policy of persistent air raids of Canton is evident with the intensive bombing of the city this morning in which nearly a dozen Japanese planes participated. The city for more than an hour was rocked by the explosions of bombs and anti-aircraft fire which observers describe as accurate, forcing the raiders to fly high.
Following are the candidates for delegates at large to the constitutional convention, nominated by the Republican State Committee today:
The short interest on the New York Curb Exchange on Aug. 31 was 36,927 shares, compared with 41,530 shares on July 30.

The first kosher markets since last Friday opened unevenly yesterday: beef sold higher; veal and calf steady; lamb lower. Trading in non-kosher meats was active to slow and price trends were irregular. The general beef market was steady to higher, veal and calf steady, lamb lower. Fresh pork mostly steady to sharply lower, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The A. E. F.'s First Division marched again in New York yesterday, not as khaki-clad soldiers parading triumphantly on Fifth Avenue as in 1919, but as veterans assembled eighteen years later to renew the spirit of their division, which was the first to reach France in the World War and the last to leave.

Considerable pick-up in textile business is forecast by Fred Allen, secretary of the Southern Combed Yarn Spinners Association. With improvement in sight, yarn manufacturers here and in Gastonia believe that present curtailment will not be necessary much longer.
A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. James J. Kennedy Jr. of Bronxville, N. Y., on Sunday at the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn.

Announcement yesterday by Russeks Fifth Avenue, Inc., of a policy of remaining open Thursday evenings until 9 o'clock followed inauguration of this plan last week by franklin Simon Co. Other stores were reported considering a similar move.

Cliff Melton, long, lean and left handed, and about the only person one can find in these parts who remains utterly unperturbed by the pennant struggle raging all about him, today became the man of the hour for the Giants.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. O. Wentworth Huckel of 524 Riverside Drive on Sept. 15 at the Harbor Hospital. Mrs. Huckel is the former Miss Mary Elizabeth Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott L. Brown of Dawn Harbor, Riverside, Greenwich.

Bobby Breen, who never strikes twice in the same place (for the obvious reason that one blow is enough), hit the Rivoli yesterday, rather than the Roxy or Music Hall where Breens 1 and 2 were shown, with his newest offering, a melodious item called "Make a Wish."

For the first time in the history of New York University a girl will assume the presidency of a senior class. She is Miss Ethel Simon of 117 Post Avenue, who will lead the seniors of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance for the 193738 academic year, it was announced at the university yesterday.

Yale's final half hour of today's practice marked the first plunge of the season into defensive strategy. Placed at their own 20-yard line, the regulars were forced to meet the attacks of the reserves, but only a single touchdown was pushed across the regulars' line before curfew sounded.

Election of three new directors was announced tonight by the Farmers National Grain Corporation, cooperative marketing association, at the close of a two-day annual meeting. Four directors were re-elected and six remain as members of the board inasmuch as their terms did not expire.

Loew's State Theatre, New York's sole remaining vaudeville house, today begins a celebration of its sixteenth anniversary. During the sixteen years, in which time the theatre has adhered to a policy of combination vaudeville and motion pictures, more than 75,000,000 persons have purchased tickets, the management said.
Harry E. Phillips, who for thirty years was a statistician for Barron G. Collier, Inc., died on Monday in New York Hospital.
For several hours yesterday fifty Japanese planes staged two series of raids on Nanking, and after the last bomb had fallen more than 200 civilians were found to have been killed or wounded.

David L. Podell, president of Beth Israel Hospital and an active worker in the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities, will speak today at 5:15 P. M. in a broadcast from radio station WJZ on "The Human Side of Federation."

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Streeter gave a cocktail party this afternoon at their home here to introduce to society Miss Helen MacDonald, granddaughter of Mrs. Gordon MacDonald and daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gordon MacDonald Jr.

The General Shaver Corporation and other subsidiaries of Remington Rand, Inc., as well as their officers, have been cited by Judge Edwin S. Thomas to appear in the United States District Court here on Oct. 6 on an order to show cause why they should not be held in contempt of court for violation of an injunction.

The board of trustees of the Omaha - Council Bluffs Missouri River Bridge District has awarded to John Nuveen Co. and associates a new issue of $1,500,000 of bonds on a bid of 91 for 4 3/4s. Proceeds from the sale of these bonds will be used to construct the bridge between the two cities. Official details of the award were not available last night.

The fortieth suspect in the Federal Government's investigation of the disability insurance racket was arrested yesterday. He was, Abraham Hochberg, 48 years old, of 449 Sterling Street, Brooklyn, who was held in $1,500 bail for a hearing on Oct. 5.

Mayor La Guardia's mediation board began yesterday, at the Supreme Court Building, its fact-finding inquiry in an effort to avert the strike on the B. M. T. rapid transit, surface car and bus lines for which 9,000 of its employes, members of the Transport Workers Union, voted recently.

Members of fifteen leading hotel and culinary organizations will join with prominent men and women of the city in paying tribute to "Oscar of the Waldorf" and his wife at a dinner in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Thursday, Oct. 7.

A protest by orderlies, who seized the kitchen of the Jewish Sanitarium and Hospital for Chronic Diseases at East Forty-ninth Street and Rutland Road, Brooklyn, delayed the serving of the evening meal to patients yesterday until the police had been called to eject the demonstrators.

Yesterday marked the opening of the 184th year of Columbia University. This is a respectable age for any school, and as the birthday of the Constitution witnesses that we are among the oldest of existing Governments, so this event reminds us that as a nation, a human development and a special culture we are no longer young.

While Wall Street's welcome of William O. Douglas as the new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission has proved to be something less, than enthusiastic, financial leaders consider his election less of a bearish factor than was that of his predecessor, James M. Landis.

Two of the most important posts vacated by Senator Guglielmo Marconi's death were filled today when Gabriele d'Annunzio, Italy's soldier poet, accepted the presidency of the Royal Italian Academy and Marshal Pietro Badoglio, the conqueror of Ethiopia, was appointed president of the National Research Council.

Holders of debentures of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation have been notified by the corporation that it is unnecessary to file proof of their claims. By an order entered on Sept. 13 in the United States District Court an order entered on July 30 was changed to eliminate the need of filing claims.

Charging that electricity consumers on Staten Island had been subjected to improper overcharges of $1,750,000 in the last four years by the Staten Island Edison Corporation, Mayor La Guardia filed a rate complaint with the Public Service Commission against the company yesterday asking an immediate cut of at least $400,000 a year in rates and an ultimate cut of not less than 15 per cent.
Sailing under a jury-rigged maintopmast, the square-rigger Joseph Conrad, defeated by the similarly rigged Seven Seas in a race to this port from Bermuda, arrived here tonight.

The Rumanman Government intends to expel thousands of emplayed foreigners to help alleviate the unemployment situation among native workers, it was revealed Sunday in a speech by Valerian Popp, the Minister of Commerce.

Manhattan West Broadway, 190-4: 30x14: for 1-story lunch wagon; George Langer. 33 Leonard St. owner; M. V. Grant. architect; cost, $9,000. Alterations 40th St. 123 E; to 4-story tenement. estate of Forbes R. McCreery. West Cornwall, Conn., owner; J. T. Boyd Jr, architect: cost, $7,000.
Fulvio Suvich, Italian Ambassador to the United States and his wife are arriving today from Europe on the Italian liner Rex.
Mrs. Elizabeth Lyman, active for many years in women's societies of the First Presbyterian Church here, died yesterday at the age of 82.
Howard C. Beck, for many years auditor of the United States Chamber of Commerce and former Baltimore City auditor, died at his home here today. He was born in Irvington,

Miss Elizabeth Reed Stromberg, daughter of Captain and Mrs. William T. Stromberg of this city, was married to Ensign J. W. Naab Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Naab of Des Moines, Iowa, this morning in St. Mary's Star of the Sea Church here by the Rev. Raymond J. O'Callaghan. Ensign Naab was graduated Monday from the Coast Guard Academy.

President Kemel Ataturk designated Jelal Bayar, Minister of National Economy, Interim Prime Minister today after giving the Prime Minister, General Ismet Inonu, a long leave of absence. At the same time he provoked strong rumors of a major shake-up in the Cabinet by unexpectedly recalling Foreign Minister Tewfik Rushdu Aras from Geneva.

For the first eight months of this year, the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company estimates its net income at $4,485,894 after allowing for Federal income taxes, interest, depreciation, depletion, amortization and other charges.

Dr. John H. Finley, editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and Dr. Arthur H. Compton, Professor of Physics at the University of Chicago and a Nobel Prize winner, were appointed today as co-chairman of a laymen's committee which will seek a $10,000,000 sesquicentennial fund for Christian education.
A sixty-minute scrimmage in which various varsity combinations scored six times against the freshman team featured yesterday's Fordham football practice.
Plans for the construction of 2,766 miles of new airways completely equipped with beacons, radio beams and lighted intermediate landing fields were announced today by Secretary Roper.
Metropolitan Opera House 8:30 A. M.--Music. 9:00 A. M.--Call to order, Harry W. Colmery, national commander.

Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers seem to be arranging matters on this final Western visit so that the law of averages will just about catch up with them when they meet the Giants in what may be one of those "croocial" series.

The Italian Consul here, Bova Scopa, called on Yvon Delbos, the French Foreign Minister, today and their talk caused speculation. According to French quarters it did not change matters much and the French, though recognizing Italy's "moral equality" in the Mediterranean, do not intend changing or expanding the patrol zone offered to Italy [the Tyrrhenian Seal, and least of all offering her the patrol of the passage between Tunis and Sicily.
Sir Herbert Sloley, former Resident Commissioner of Basutoland, died today after living for many years in retirement. He was 82.

Richmond, Virginia, is fortunate in having sons and daughters more competent than any outsiders to sing her bicentennial praises. The special number of The Richmond News Leader is one affectionate testimonial that, taking cognizance of the passing of 200 years over her head, sees her rise with great memories and with reborn hope, after a period of dark poverty.

Fitzsimmons Stores, Ltd., of Los Angeles has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement for 30.000 shares of $1-par 5 per cent cumulative Class A stock, to be offered at $5 a share.
The League the of Nations yearbook, "World Economic Survey, 1936-37," published yesterday, joins in the expression of alarm over the economic effects of the armaments race.

A half million spectators, more than attended any night of last week's Mardi Gras, flocked to Coney Island last night to see New York's second American Legion parade. More than 3,500 members of fifteen posts turned out to march again, this time along Surf Avenue.

The text of the United States Government's- note to Japan protesting against the previously announced plan of Japan to bomb Nanking, the Chinese capital, was made public today by the State Department and is as follows:

Miss Isabel Milliken Spaulding, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morril B. Spaulding of 108 East Eighty-first Street, was married yesterday afternoon in St. Bartholomew's Church to Laurance Page Roberts, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Brinton Roberts of Bala, Pa. The Rev. Francis Craighill performed the ceremony.

Turoentine firm. 30 3/4 c; sales, 261 barrels; receipts, 379 barrels; no shipments; stock, 40.093 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 282; receipts, 1,327; shipments, 7; stock, 61.634. Quote: B. D. E. F. $7.85; G. H. I. K. $87 1/2; M. $7.90; N. $8; W G $8.20; WW, X, $8.65.

The War Veterans of the Federal Theatre charged the WPA Federal Theatre Project here yesterday with blocking the scheduled presentation of three one-act plays announced for next Sunday night at the Adelphi Theatre.

One of the oldest golf competitions in the financial community will be held today when members and guests of the Doherty Men's Fraternity tee-off in their annual Fall tournament at the Westchester Hills Golf Club at White Plains. The highlight of the tournament will be the competition for the Grace Doherty Cup for the low gross score for thirty-six holes.

Production of lead throughout the world in August amounted to 158,373 tons compared with 156,583 in July, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. The output in the United States last month was 42,460 tons, against 42,480 in July. For the first eight months of this year total world production was 1,211,685 tons.
Samuel Otis Dimmick, last surviving member of the Long Island Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, died suddenly last night at his home here at the age of 87.
Newsprint exports in August amounted to $10,662,000, the Bureau of Statistics reported today. This was lower than the $11,234,000
Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Saunders Dixon gave a tea at Thorncroft Farms, their home in Paoli, this afternoon to introduce to society Mrs. Dixon's daughter, Miss Elisabeth Biddle Hopkinson.
Members of society were out in full force this afternoon at International Field for the final match in the open championship polo series at the Meadow Brook Club.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margaret Tiernan of New Hope, Pa., and this city, daughter 'of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Tiernan of New Hope, to Dr. Edward T. Yorke, son of Mrs. Mary E. Yorke of Linden, N. J.

Members of the Board of Elections have disagreed over the appointment of a Republican director of the count for proportional representation with the La GuardiaCopeland issue in the background, it was disclosed yesterday.

With backlogs greatly depleted, the steel mills are adjusting downward their ingot producing and rolling schedules, The Iron Age says today in its weekly summary. The trade journal believes that, unless business improves more rapidly than in the last two or three weeks, a further drop in the ingot production rate for the country is indicated.

Twelve hundred veterans attended the reunion dinner given last night by the Father Duffy Chapter of the Rainbow Division Veterans at the armory of the 165th Infantry, Lexington Avenue and Twentysixth Street. James A. Clarke, national president of the Rainbow Division Veterans, said that with an inspiration such as Father Duffy the chapter named in his honor ought to continue as an outstanding unit to the last man.
Harold Dyott, who for years had been billed in sideshows throughout Europe as "Tiny Tim, the World's Smallest Man," died today at Hemel, Hempstead, at the age of 50.

Greyhound, E. J. Baker's great grey trotting gelding, today equaled Peter Manning's 15-year-old world trotting record when he negotiated the mile oval at the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association track in 1 minute 56 3/4 seconds.

The Bureau of Mines estimated today that a daily average production of 3,568,100 barrels of crude oil would be necessary to meet the nation's demand in October. The estimate was 58,800 barrels higher than the daily average estimated for September and 477,900 barrels more than the actual daily production in October, 1936. The estimate was 12 per cent higher than the actual demand for domestic crude oil last October.
A hush fell over the little island that separates Broadway and Seventh Avenue at Forty-seventh Street yesterday as a bugler played taps at the foot of the statue of the late Rev. Francis P. Duffy.
Miss Bernice K. Levy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Levy of 755 Park Avenue and Essex, Conn., was married to Albert D. Hutzler Jr. of Baltimore last night at the Pierre.

The American Legion gave Times Square back to New Yorkers at daybreak yesterday after holding it more than three days. Before dawn the tumult and the shouting died. The roar of cannon faded with the dark. Except for an isolated bit of buffoonery, here and there, the gayest party in the city's history was ended.

Movements Sentiment in favor of the of livestock in the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 10,000, including 2,000 directs. The market was steady to 10 cents lower than Tuesday's average;

The election of Daniel J. Doherty, I Boston lawyer, as National Commander of the American Legion at the closing session of the nineteenth annual Legion convention today was virtually assured early this morning when it was learned that the Illinois and Nebraska delegations had swung to his-support.

Warm praise for the accomplishments of Park Commissioner Robert Moses in rehabilitating Brooklyn parks and projecting new parkway links in the proposed interborough circumferential boulevard system was given yesterday by Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn.

Gaining control of a gold mine at Reading, Calif., through the alleged underwriting of a $7,000 obligation, Moe Platt, head of Platt Co., a brokerage house in New York, and president of the Backbone Gold Mining Company of Reading, and five associates are accused by Government agents of having manipulated the stock over the counter for a personal profit of between $250,000 and $500,000.

Following yesterday's two victories at the Stadium, the Yankees announced that applications for world-series tickets would be accepted as they come in. Reservedseat tickets will be sold in sets of three only, for admission to the first, second and sixth games at the Stadium.

A simple ceremony is announced for the induction on Oct. 8 of Dr. James P. Baxter 3d as president of Williams College. John C. Jay, of New York, is to welcome Dr. Baxter on behalf of the Society of Alumni of which he is president. Bentley W. Warren, senior trustee, will give the induction address.

President Roosevelt announced today the formation of a new national foundation to fight infantile paralysis, in a statement issued before he left on his Western trip. The function of the new agency would be to coordinate all three phases of the fight against the disease, said Mr. Roosevelt, who is himself a sufferer.
Miss Virginia Earl, who was a favorite of musical comedy firstnighters in the Nineties and after the turn of the century, died on Tuesday in a New Jersey sanitarium.
Rodman Wanamaker 2d of New York, a grandson of the late John Wanamaker, was sued for divorce today by the former Alexandra Van Rensselaer Devereux, whom he married in June, 1930.
A collection of 70,000 banknotes worth $250,000 and bearing a face value of about $30,000,000 was stolen today from an asbestos-lined safe in which they were stored in a London home.
Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy, disapproved by the Bar Association, was endorsed for re-election last night by the Republican County Committee of the Bronx as it rather reluctantly gave its

Hoping to obviate difficulties in "when issued" securities such as arose reently in Baldwin Locomotive dealings, the New York Security Dealers Association has ruled that, in transactions between members, a request to "mark to the market" may be made.

Having held up the regular schedule for two days because of the three adjourned games in which Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, was a participant, the committee of the international chess masters tournament decided today to start the four games in the tenth round. Results were recorded in two of these, while two were adjourned.

Jimmy Thomson, the blond bomber of golf, hit the ball long and accurately over Belmont's long, difficult course today and, wiping out its 14-year-old competitive record, gained a two-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the 36-hole qualifying test in the $12,000 open match play tournament with a three-under par 68.
Boxing history will be made tonight at the Polo Grounds. Michael Strauss Jacobs, promoter of the Twentieth Century S. C., outdoing even so daring a promoter as the late Tex Rickard,

Representative Dickstein reiterated today his charge that German aliens and German-Americans were joining the State Militia in this country to obtain military training required by the Hitler Government.

The Treasury Department reported tonight that individual and corporation income taxes deposited from Sept. 1 to 21, inclusive, as part of the third quarterly installment, amounted to $473,054,978, indicating that the estimate of about $500,000,000 to be reecived this month would be met.

Arrangements with officials of the State and Treasury Departments for the reception of Vittorio Mussolini, son of the Italian Premier, who will arrive this morning on the Italian liner Rex, were made yesterday by the Italian Consul General, Gaetano Vecchietto.

Princeton Theological Seminary opened its 126th year this morning at 11 o'clock with a service in Miller Chapel on the campus. Dr. John A. Mackay, beginning his second year as president of the institution, gave the opening address. There are 215 students enrolled for the coming year.

Relations between the Rome-Berlin axis and Great Britain will be the most important subject to be discussed when Premier Mussolini and Chancellor Hitler meet in Berlin next week for a series of political conversations that may well shape Europe's history for the next few years.

Miss Gertrude O'Keefe, 37-yearold typist employed by the Bankers Trust Company, 16 Wall Street, was booked on a chargeof homicide last night at the Classon Avenue police station, Brooklyn, in connection with the death of' George 0. Frank, 47-year-old first teller of the Stock Clearing Corporation of the New York Stock Exchange, 8 Broad Street.

After forty-eight hours of chaotic conditions in midtown Manhattan, traffic dwindled yesterday almost to normal proportions in that area as thousands of Legionnaires and their friends and families turned from merrymaking to sight-seeing.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, opened the institution's 184th academic year yesterday with a bitter denunciation of "the three military dictatorships of Japan, Italy and Germany." He urged free people to oppose acts of aggression with "the policies which they compel."

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Lillie Van Suan Berry of this place, daughter of the late Captain and Mrs. Robert Laurence Berry, to Charles Jackson Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Howard Smith, also of Short Hills.

The Treasury Procurement Division today announced the following awards for textile purchases: 539-T-Broadcloth, pin striped, M. Lowenstein Sons, 35,000 yards; broadcloth. plain colors, S. B. Marks, 40,000 yards; percales. solid colors. M. Lowenstein Sons, 55,000 yards: percales, prints, M.

Milton R. Leader and Francis J. Kleban, represented by Max Monfried, attorney, bought from the Manufacturers Trust Company, as trustee, the twelve-story apartment house at 11 West Eighty-first Street. Assessed at $350,000,

A summary of the revised Insurance Law was issued yesterday by the Insurance Department of New York State. The law provides for an increase in the minimum capital of new stock life insurance companies from $100,000 to $300,000 and for the retention of a surplus equal to 50 per cent of the capital stock.

Secretary Wallace announced today that the Administration had abandoned its original goal of "parity prices" for farm products. The new aim was to try to give "the average farmer the same purchasing power he had in the fifty years before the World War."
J. Donald Budge of the United States and Baron Gottfried von Cramm of Germany overcame powerful opposition today in their drive for the men's singles title of the Pacific Southwest tennis tourney.

Declaring the wisdom of the law was the concern of the Legislature, the Court of Errors and Appeals upheld today the constitutionality of the 1932 statute requiring all publis school pupils to salute and pledge allegiance to the United States flag.
Alfred G. Vanderbilt, becoming 25 years old today, received his second quarter share of an estimated $20,000,000 left him from the estate of his father, who was drowned in the Lusitania.

Charles H. Tuttle, chairman of the City College Administrative Committee of the Board of Higher Education, will be the principal speaker today before more than 1,000 members of the entering freshman class at City College. The first chapel of the new semester to be held in the Great Hall will serve to introduce the incoming students to Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president, who will officially welcome them to the college.

President Roosevelt started late this afternoon on a trip which will take him into the Pacific.Northwest and which will be closely watched for any indication of political trends in the nation. Although he has warned against putting a political interpretation on the tour, he plans many informal talks.
The scheduled attempt to obtain the approval of the Yacht Racing Association for the substitution of L Class for J Class yachts in recognized competition has been postponed, it was learned tonight.

Mayo La Guardia, the guest of honor at a Borden Milk Company luncheon yesterday opening the new Riverside Pasteurizing Plant, at 615 West 131st Street, took the occasion to criticize the cost of bottling and distributing milk and said he was chiefly interested in "giving the cow and the consumer a break."
Four extra-base blows, three of which figured in the scoring, gave Philadelphia a 3-to-2 victory over Cincinnati today to lift the Wilsonmen into seventh place and plunge the Reds into the cellar.

International Settlement and French Concession health authorities are now considerably alarmed by the continued rapid increase in the number of cholera cases in their foreign areas despite the advent of slightly cooler weather, which it was hoped would check the epidemic.

The participation of Jews in the development of the United States was praised by President Roosevelt in a message sent today to Harry H. Shaffer, commander in chief of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, whose forty-second annual encampment opens here Friday night.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx declared yesterday that the cordial and friendly welcome that the people of New York had extended to the hundreds of thousands of American Legionnaires was a most convincing proof that the vast majority of the city's population was impervious to the various "isms" current today. Mr.

The board of governors of the United Infants and Children's Wear Association, at a meeting at the Hotel New Yorker last night, decided to postpone definite action regarding the proposal that the contents of all fabrics be identified. It is planned to query the members in general about the proposal.

The champion Newark Bears moved into a commanding lead of two games to none in the final series of the International League playoffs today as they trimmed the fighting Baltimore Orioles, 6--5, before 3,500 spectators.

A leopard can't change its spots and it would be asking just as much to expect Gilmour Dobie to agree with the widely prevalent opinion that Boston College is one of the strongest football teams of the East.

It would be nwise to estimate too highly the ower of the Tokyo Government to verrule the commanders on active service, but the prompt and vigorus protests by the American and ??ritish Ambassadors against Ad??iral Hasegawa's warning have ad some effect.

The National Labor Relations Board will begin today the task of polling 50,000 unlicensed seamen on ships operating from Atlantic and Gulf ports on the question of their choice of a labor union to represent them in bargaining for new wage contracts.
The majority of members of the National Industrial Advertisers Association increased their advertising appropriations this year over 1936, according to a survey made public this week by the group.

The marriage of Miss Dorothea Ponce, daughter of Philip L. Ponce of Cincinnati and the late Mrs. Ponce, to J. Richard Verkamp, son of Mrs. Joseph B. Verkamp, also of Cincinnati, and the late Mr. Verkamp, took place here yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Kenealy.
Defeat of a proposal to permit sports events and motion pictures on Sunday was heralded by the pealing of church bells here at 2 o'clock this morning when results of the referendum became known.

The marriage of Miss Natica Peabody, daughter of Mrs. Vivian Spencer of 340 Park Avenue and George Russell Peabody, also of this city, to Beverly Kennon Sinclair of New York took place at noon yesterday in the chantry of St. Thomas Church The Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, the rector, performed the ceremony.

Governor_Hoffman isn't yet what John W. Forney, a once famous and now forgotten journalist, called Andrew Johnson, "a dead duck." He still has influence enough to help beat a candidate unfortunate enough to have his approval. State Senator Powell,

MANHATTAN ALDRED, GEORGE D. (Aug. 24). Estate, $3,500. To Mary H. Aldred, widow, 179 W. 102d St., residue. Edward McKenna, 619 E. 141st St., and John Fiske, Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, N. Y., executors.

In the bright glare of the Autumn sun atop the British Building in Rockefeller Center yesterday afternoon, the World War seemed long ago and far away until snatches of conversation from the uniformed members of the Jane A. Delano Post of the American Legion, greeting their guests from every corner of this country, wiped out an interval of twenty years.

Population pressure due to lack of birth control has made Japan, Italy and Germany menaces to world peace, Mrs. Margaret Sanger, birth control leader, said in a letter made public yesterday by the Birth Control Clinical Research Bureau, 17 West Sixteenth Street.
George J. Naegele, who for years was in the real estate business here, died Tuesday night at his home, 40 Leighton Aenue.
Europe's "isms" have no place in this country, Dr. Hugh P. Baker, president of Massachusetts State College, declared today at the college's opening exercises.

Political historians may in time note the significance of the retirement of Charles D. Hilles from official place in the Republican party in its period of greatest flux. For he has been a good deal of a landmark during many years, important for what he represented in the dominant councils of the party.

Luncheon of the Rotary Club of New York. Hotel Commodore,-12:15 P. M. "Progressive Rotary," Alfred Edwards. Luncheon meeting of the Traffic Club of New York, Hotel Biltmore, 12:15 P. M. "Foreign Trade Zone No. 1," Commissioner John McKenzie.

Mayor Wilson was formally requested by a representative of Judge Curtis Bok today to present any evidence he and City Solicitor Joseph Sharfsin might possess to support their charges of criminal negligence against the office of District Attorney Charles F. Kelley.

While Japanese airplanes rained death upon hundreds of men, women and children in Nanking and Canton today the note from the Japanese Government was published here pledging all possible efforts to spare innocent civilians in China.

Dr. J. Arthur Myers of Minneapolis, president of the National Tuberculosis Association, praised the Queens plan to check tuberculosis, in an address last night at the eighteenth annual meeting of the Queensboro Tuberculosis and Health Association, held with the Queens County Medical Association at the Queens Valley Golf Club, Forest Hills.

The Pontiac division of the General Motors Corporation expects in the coming year to continue increase in production at the rate which has stepped up the annual output from 76,553 cars in 1934 to 236,189 in the current model year. H. J. Klingler.

Regardless of reprisals against French consular officials in Insurgent Spain the French authorities today kept Major Julian Troncozo, the Rebel military commander at Irun, in the Bayonne jail and are proceeding to take measures for the rapid punishment of those involved in the attempt to seize the Loyalist submarine C-2 in the French port of Brest.

A proposal of a substantial increase in wages by the Greater City Master Plumbers Association to the 3,000 members of the Alteration Plumbers, Steamfitters and Helpers Union, who have been on strike for two weeks, was unanimously rejected by the strikers at a meeting held last night in Irving Plaza Hall, Fifteenth Street and Irving Place. More than 2,000 members of the union were present.

Japanese aerial bombers attacked Nanking yesterday, killing or wounding scores of noncombatants and causing considerable damage, but the attacks, in the morning and afternoon, left China's capital without apparent loss of morale and without vital material damage.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 21: LIEUTENANT COLONEL Stokely, C. C., Inf., Pasadena. Calif., to Hawaiian Dept., to sail from San Francisco about Dec. 7.

A funeral service for Henry T. Sloane, senior director and former treasurer of W. J. Sloane, furniture dealers, was held yesterday morning in St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street. Burial was at Woodlawn Cemetery, the Bronx.

Well-timed was the announcement of the President's intention of furthering the establishment of "a new national foundation for infantile paralysis" which will "lead, direct and unify the fight on every phase of this sickness."

Dr. William Neuss of this village, former Suffolk County Welfare Commissioner and a practicing physician for the last forty-eight years, died today in the Swedish Hospital, Brooklyn, after a ten days' illness. He was 71 years old.

Funeral services for Professor Percy A. Chapman, Princeton University faculty member who died while at sea on the Queen Mary Sunday night, were held here this afternoon in the university chapel, with more than 400 friends and relatives in attendance. Burial was in Hillside Cemetery, Plainfield, N, J.

If it is in bad taste to say that "George and Margaret" is thin entertainment, this column is going to be indecorous this morning. For Gerald Savory's comedy, which opened at the Morosco last evening, is a British drawing-room whimsey that has been much prized in London since last February and has been installed in New York with a new British cast.

Grim examples of what happens to "smalltown grafters" nowadays in the Soviet Union were provided today by the fate of eight leaders of Lotoshina County, in Moscow Province, who after a four-day trial were all sentenced to death.

BAHRENBURG-On Wednesday. Sept. 22, 1937, George W., beloved husband of Edna Mason and brother of Louise Nleber, Walter, Paul and Herbert Bahrenburg. Services on Saturday at 2 P. M. at his home, 362 Burns St., Forest Hills, L. I. Interment Greenwood Cemetery.

Hobart C. Chatfield-Taylor, author and publicist, in resigning today from all civic responsibilities, disclosed that at the coronation of King George he suffered a heart attack which has not responded to treatment.

Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, reopened yesterday for its 102d year. The formal exercises took place in the James Memorial-Chapel at 4 P. M. The new class was welcomed by the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, who this Fall completes a decade as the president.

Eleven parcels of Manhattan realty were sold at auction in the Vesey Street Salesrooms yesterday. Seven were multi-family dwellings and four business properties. The eight-story brick store at 1,146-50 Sixth Avenue, 60.5 by 125 by irregular, was bid in by the plaintiff, the United States Trust Company of New York, for $340,000, in satisfaction of a judgment against the Cowperthwait Holding Company of $362,583 and taxes and other liens of $6,310.

The weather of the week was very favorable for the cotton crop in most portions of the belt. With abundant sunshine and seasonable temperatures very helpful in eastern sections. In Texas, progress and condition of cotton were generally good and picking and ginning made rapid advance under favorable conditions. In Oklahoma, picking cotton made fairly good progress.
Friends of the late George Gershwin have formed a committee which will undertake the creation of a Gershwin Memorial Forest in Palestine, it was announced yesterday. I. A. Hirschmann is chairman.

Mrs. Harris Fahnestock gave a birthday dinner at Eastover, Lenox, tonight in honor of Mr. Fahnestock. Other guests were Mr. Fahnestock's daughters, Mrs. A. Coster Schermerhorn and Miss Faith Fahnestock; his son, Harris Fahnestock Jr.; Mr. and Mrs. David T. Dana, the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Anson Phelps Stokes, Mr. and Mrs. Christopher J. Mileham, Mrs. Frederick S. Delafield, Miss Mary Parsons, Giraud Foster, Albert Eugene Gallatin and Clarence M. Mitchell.

In its own language, the American Legion took the New York Stock Exchange yesterday "in the same way the Stock Exchange took us in 1929." By the end of the day 1,450 Legionnaires and families had been admitted to the two galleries.

Corporation Counsel Paul Windels informed the Sinking Fund Commission yesterday that its recent reduction in commutation rates on the Staten Island ferry line was invalid because of a provision of the city charter requiring the commission to act upon the recommendation of the Department of Plant and Structures, which operates the line.
Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan ruled today that Surrogate William J. Sheils of Westchester County must stand for re-election in November.

Lawrenceville School opened its 128th year today with an enrollment of 512 students, the largest in recent years. Dr. Alan V. Helly, headmaster, gave the opening address at a meeting of the entire school this morning in the auditorium.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am pained to read in this morning's dispatch from Shanghai that the traditional friendly attitude of the Chinese people toward America has turned "hostile," or at least is being "jeopardized"' as a result of the partial embargo and the removal of the American Embassy in compliance with a request from the Japanese admiral.
Ridden hard down the stretch, J. P. Meehan's Campillo today won the sixfurlong White River Handicap at Rockingham Park by a head.

A group of fifty Legionnaires and members of the auxiliary participated yesterday in a tour of the grounds and buildings of City College, 138th Street and Convent Avenue. Dr. John R. Turner, dean of men, led the group to the points of interest in the buildings and on the grounds.

The Real Estate Board of New York joined yesterday with other groups in criticizing Mayor La Guardia for his veto of the WaterRate Reduction Bill, and called upon the Board of Aldermen to readopt the measure over the veto.

A floating zoo entered Halifax Harbor today. Loaded almost to the plimsoll line, the freighter Silverdash is a miniature jungle, bringing from Sumatra, Ceylon and Siam 1,500 species of wild life for the United States Government Zoo at Washington.

The Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday that 65 per cent of New York Steam Corporation preferred stocks had been presented in assent to their exchange for Consolidated Edison preferred stock.

The new C. I. O. union of State, county and municipal workers asked Governor Lehman for a statement on the right of State employes to organize, it was disclosed yesterday and received a reply from Nathan R. Sobel, the Governor's assistant counsel, as follows:

In a discussion in the League of Nations Assembly's first Committee of Equal Status for Women, Miss Hesselgren of Sweden gave the following statistics based on official and private information received by the League:

Vyse Ave (11-2992). s w cor of E Tremont Ave. 127x103; Bankroft Management Corp to Pact Realty Corp. 349 E 149th St: mtg $167.500. Harding Ave (18-5607). s s. 180 ft w of Robinson Ave. 50x152: Klell Realty, Inc, to Katherine Hartog. 318 E 95th St.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy M. Frankfurter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Frankfurter of New York, to Stanley D. Hart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vivian S. Hart, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bridegroom's parents, 300 West 108th Street.

The American Legion was asked yesterday to merge its patriotic strength with that of the American Federation of Labor in a joint fight on communism and all the other "isms" that have threatened the "sanctity" of labor.

The Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today that pensions paid by the Railroad Retirement Board are exempt from the Federal income tax. The bureau cited a provision of the Rail Retirement Act that pensions are not subject "to any tax, garnishment, attachment or other legal process."

The Securities and Exchange Commission today set Oct. 12 for a hearing on an application for a report by it on a plan of reorganization for Midland Utilities Company, which has been filed by a committee for holders of that company's 6 per cent Series A gold debentures.

First Title Bout-Marcel Thil, France, International Boxing Union middleweight champion, vs. Fred Apostoli, San Francisco. Second Title Bout-Barney Ross, Chicago, world welterweight champion, vs. Ceferino Garcia, Philippines.

A library which is designed to be a "living memorial" to the late Henry Wright, New York architect and town planner, was dedicated last night at the Federation Technical School, 116 East Sixteenth Street.

Miss Teresa O'Donohue, who for fifty years was an active social worker, bequeathed half of her residuary estate to the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York. Her will, disposing of an estate formally valued at "more than $10,000,"' was filed yesterday for probate.

Jurists and representatives of the Bar Association and a dozen other organizations to which James S. Troy, lawyer, former industrial engineer and former instructor in engineering at Syracuse University, belonged, attended his funeral here today.
With wholesale And retail prices of beef at the highest levels in years, choice steers sold Ft a new top level for eighteen years of $19.50 a hundredweight in the livestock market here today.

MANHATTAN GRETTON,. ROSE (Jan. 11, 1937) Gross assets, $9.233: net, $7.562. To Marie C. Turberg and Julie C. Bourquard, sisters, one-half residue each; two specific bequests. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, Hunt. Jaeckel Brown, attorneys,

Miss Anne Shepard Chapin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Chapin of this city, will be married to Simon James Stanfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Jordan Stanfield of New York, on Oct. 9 in Trinity Church by the Rev. Raymond Cunningham.

Two legionnaires died in their hotel rooms yesterday, both of natural causes, bringing the hotel deaths in the Legion here to three since the convention. Martin G. Lyford, 50 years old, of 125 South Teaney Street, Phila delphia, a member of the Philadelphia Police Post, was found dead in his room at the Hotel Taft shortly after he had seen his wife and ?? off on a train for home.
The British seemed leaning today toward a Far Eastern conference of all parties interested in China, as proposed yesterday by Stanley M. Bruce of Australia.

Senator David I. Walsh declared today that Justice Hugo L. Black of Alabama, by not "disclosing his previous membership in the Ku Klux Klan," had obtained his elevation to the Supreme Court "by deception." By his silence, Senator Walsh contended, Mr. Black had grossly imposed on President Roosevelt and his colleagues even before his confirmation.
Low-cost home construction in the United States in some respects is inferior to that of England, declares John Laing, British builder, who is studying housing conditions in this country.
Charles P. Smith, chairman of the board of the Burlington Savings Bank and its former president, died at his home early today. He was 90 years old.

W. Kingsland Macy, former State Republican leader, was re-elected chairman of the Suffolk County Republican Committee for his seventh consecutive two-year term at a meeting of the newly elected committeemen at the Suffolk County Republican Club in Timber Point tonight.

The Cement Institute today filed with the Federal Trade Commission a denial of charges brought last July that the industry was maintaining a nation-wide system of price maintenance which retarded recovery, added to taxation and impaired the efficiency of emergency legislation.

The specter of taxation is hovering over the schism-shaken domain of Father Divine, it was disclosed yesterday with the filing of seventy-two income tax liens against followers of the Harlem cult leader who purchased property in his "promised land" in Ulster County.
The second round of the women's New Jersey State championship, played today over the West course of the Essex County Country Club resulted in four closely contested matches.

Careful stock control, especially in selection of new items, is necessary to profits in cosmetics departments, Northam Warren of the Northam Warren Corporation declared at a luncheon yesterday of the Perfume and Cosmetic Buyers' Conference and Exhibition at the Hotel Commodore.

4:30-5:00 P. M.-United States Army Band Concert-WABC. 8:00-9:00 P. M.-Vallee's Varieties: Doc Rockwell, Comedian; Tommy Riggs, Monologist, and Others-WEAF. 8:00-11:00P.M.-Boxing: Championship Bouts, at Polo Grounds-WJZ. 8:00-8:45 P. M. -Concert Orchestra, Vittorio Gianini, Conductor-WABC.

A suit brought in Supreme Court to prevent the election of Dr. Paul E. Santangelo s Tammany leader of the First Assembly District, east, in place of Joseph A. Greenfield was dropped yesterday without explanation when a stipulation of discontinuance was filed by attorneys for both sides.
Several hundred women from all sections of Connecticut were present today at the Georgian Tea Party held here at the house and garden of Miss Miriam Walker.

Plans for the reorganization of an American Federation of Tenant Associations have been mapped out by a group of local organizations interested in "protecting the rights of tenants," it was learned yesterday.

Prices for Spring clothing fabrics were made yesterday by the American Woolen Company showing reductions of from 2 1/2 to 5 cents under Fall opening prices. Clothing manufacturers said this difference will not be sufficient to change clothing prices.
Henry Esberg, a retired business man who for more than twenty years was actively engaged in civic and charitable work, died yesterday in his sixty-fifth year at Mount Sinai Hospital.
Mrs. Adelaide McAlpin Pyle, widow of James Tolman Pyle and charter member of the Colony Club, died early today at her home here. She was in her seventy-eighth year.

Seated around a large table decorated with a model of the World's Fair, seventy-five Legion visitors, representing twenty-four States, attended the luncheon given them yesterday by Grover A. Whalen at the Metropolitan Club, and received an invitation to return in 1939 to see a show that might even rival the one put on by the American Legion.

The jinx hovering over "Susan and God," the Rachel Crothers play, having its tryout here this week, continued in force today when the illness of Gertrude Lawrence, the British star playing the feminine lead, forced cancellation of the scheduled matinee and refunds at the box office to a sold-out house.

Sprinting into the lead at the break, M. Vehon's Threadneedle, a Reigh Count filly, withstood all efforts to dislodge her and drove to a length victory over Mrs. Louise Viau's Conquer in the Westminster Handicap, today's outstanding event.

The Port of New York Authority purchased from Mrs. Harriet Gifford the house at 62 Kingswood Road, Weehawken. Jane M. and George J. King sold to Margaret W. Phillips the Bayonne Pleasure Park at West Second, Humphreys and Newman Avenues, Bayonne.
Mrs. Delcie N. Dickerson, lifelong resident of this village, died today at her home after a prolonged illness.

The program for tightening credit terms in order to avoid a period of rising losses was supported by A. H. Buckeridge, executive manager of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York in an address before the Metropolitan Controllers Associatin at the Roger Smith Restaurant, 40 East Forty-first Street, last night.

There was a further contraction Con in volume yesterday in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. Values in the more im- BO portant sections varied only slightly from the preceding day's finals and the market as a whole ended the day with a mixed undertone. Transactions in all bonds amounted to $6,174,750, compared with $6,484,900 on Tuesday.

William O. Douglas, who was elected unanimously yesterday chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and who interrupted his vacation in Massachusetts for a hasty trip to Washington, said here today that it would be the commission's policy, beginning in October, to proceed immediately on a course of swift and direct action wherever the facts may justify.

Captain George E. T. Eyston, 40-year-old British speedster, sent his Speed of the Wind roaring over the Bonneville Salt Flats today, tuning up for an assault Friday on Ab Jenkins's many land speed records.

Sales of cars and trucks produced by the General Motors Corporation to dealers overseas in August were 27,253 units, an increase of 9.2 per cent over August last year, the company announced yesterday.
Fusion's hold on public offices has been steadily weakened since the landslide victory of the La Guardia ticket in 1933, the City Affairs Committee showed yesterday in a bulletin to its members.

Directors of the United wall Paper Factories, Inc., have re-elected the following: Charles W. Kellogg, president; John S. McCoy and Robert Griffin, vice presidents; and A. F. Kletzien, secretary, treasurer and controller. Palmer and Serles were re-elected counsel.
Rudy York's thirty-third home run of the season, with two mates aboard in the second inning, gave Detroit the margin for a 6-to-4 victory today over Boston's faltering Red Sox.
Just before leaving on his Western trip, President Roosevelt at a conference today with John D. Biggers approved the plans for registration this Fall of the unemployed.
The final rush for apartments before the traditional Fall moving day resulted yesterday in expansion of tenant rosters in practically every section of the city.
Hundreds of holidaying Jews were assailed yesterday in Warsaw streets and parks by well-organized gangs of Nationalist youths, mostly members of the "Falanga"-the National Radical group.

The Legion's fun and honor society, La Societe des 40 Hommes et 8 Chevaux, got down yesterday to the serious business of electing officers, and also instructed its members to return a number of police traffic stanchions taken as trophies for the 40-and-8 box-cars. The group then adjourned.

It would have been an "act of impertinence" for the Department of Justice to have investigated the private life of Hugo L. Black before his appointment to the Supreme Court, Attorney General Cummings said today at the first press conference he has held since the public issue arose concerning charges that Mr. Black was or is a member of the Ku Klux Klan.

Dr. and Mrs. Carl Eggers entertained at dinner last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for Dr. Hermann Holthausen, president of the International Radiological Congress, and Mrs. Holthausen, who sailed at midnight on the Bremen.

Jimmy DeShong pitched Washington to a 6-to-4 victory over Cleveland today despite an eighth-inning rally which threatened to drive him from the box. The Senators took a 6-to-O lead in the first five innings. Deshong allowed only two hits in the first seven frames.

While announcement of a definite official program for Premier Mussolini's Berlin visit still awaits word from Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the Propaganda Minister, the scale on which preparations for his welcome are being rushed leaves no doubt that the event will resolve itself into another triumph of Nazi showmanship.
A withholding levy on taxable salaries up to $5,000 will be proposed to a House tax subcommittee by Chairman Vinson, Democrat, of Kentucky, as a means of simplifying the revenue system.

The three apartment buildings on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 673, 675 and 677 Ninth Avenue were leased for twenty-one years by Rosalie C. Tysen to Harry Turek. represented by Shulman Reiger. Edward J. Grenier represented the lessor.

61st St. 123 E. n s, 19.6x100.5: Paul T. Connolly to Harry C. McClarity. Westport, Conn.; prior mtg $25.000; 3 years, 6 per cent; $5,000. 93d St, 67 W. n s. 17x71.5x17x72.1: Ida Grossman to Franklin Society for Home Building and Savings, due as per bond, 6 per cent: $5,200.

Miss Teresa O'Donohue, who for fifty years was an active social worker, bequeathed half of her residuary estate to the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York. Her will, disposing of an estate formally valued at "more than $10,000,"' was filed yesterday for probate.

Mr. and Mrs. C. Alan Hudson gave a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for Miss Eleanor Herr Colt and their son, C. Alan Hudson Jr., whose marriage will take place today in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.
Frank X. Schwab, brewer and ex-Mayor, pitched his hat into the middle of Buffalo's Mayoral campaign today and made a five-cornered race of it.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur John Ridley 2 East Eighty-sixth Street and ??rewster, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Mrs. Hazel Ridley Bergen, to Maxwell Ludlam Scott, son of Mrs. Seaton Mackenzie Scott of 17 East Ninety-sixth Street and the late Mr. Scott.

THE CASE OF LEON TROTSKY, (Harper, $3.) Report of hearings on the charges made against Trotsky in the Moscow trials, by the Preliminary Commission of Inquiry, John Dewey, chairman. HE DID NOT DIE AT MEYERLING: The autobiography of "R," a Habsburg who becomes an American. Written in collaboration with Henry Lanier. (Lippincott, $3.)

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 20: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Marley, A. S. Jr., VS-3, the Lexington: when discharged from treatment at the Naval Hospital. Mare Island. Calif.,

Announcing that the West Side improvement would open on Oct. 12, Park Commissioner Robert Moses asked yesterday for the designation of the waters of the Hudson River between the Harlem Ship Canal and West Seventy-second Street as Class A, the classification in which the waters are expected to be used primarily for recreational purposes.

Because David Lloyd George objected to an anecdote ascribing to Mrs. Lloyd George the remark that the first time she met him he was in the hands of the police "and she sometimes wished she had left him there," "Trivial Fond Records," a book of reminiscences by a veteran civil servant, has been withdrawn from publication.

Heavy short covering in September corn on the Board of Trade today advanced the price of that delivery 7 7/8 cents a bushel to $1.12 1/2 with the close at the top and within 1/8 cent of the permissible limit for a single day's upturn.

Important conversations between President Eduard Benes, Foreign Minister Kamil Krofta, Vice Premier Leon Blum of France Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch of Yugoslavia and Premier George Tatarescu of Rumania took place today.
President Roosevelt issued this proclamation today designating Oct. 12 as Columbus Day. "Whereas Public Resolution 21, Seventy-third Congress, approved April 30, 1934, provides:

Mayor La Guardia received a gift of a gavel made from one of the timbers of the old frigate Constitution yesterday at City Hall from A. F. Mulkearn, of Columbia Post of the Legion in South Boston. With the gavel came a copper bolt from the keel of the old vessel.

The Republican State Committee adjourned early this evening after refusing to nominate Mayor La Guardia as a delegate at large to next year's Constitutional Convention and accepting by unanimous vote a slate of delegates at large, on which eight of the fifteen candidates were from New York City.

William Denis Gargan, who lived until a year ago at 106 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, died yesterday in Beverly Hills, Calif., at the home of his son, William Gargan, the moving picture actor, according to word received here. Mr. Gargan had been ill for two years.

Miss Marie Brooke Heck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Callendine Heck, has completed plans for her marriage to James Tileston Baldwin, son of Mrs. James Clarke Tileston Baldwin of Chestnut Hill, Pa., and the late Mr. Baldwin, which will take place Oct. 16 in the Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown in Locust Valley.

The City Affairs Committee added its voice yesterday to those of the civic groups that have asked Milo R. Maltbie, head of the Public Service Commission, to veto the Transit Commission's appointment of former Mayor James J. Walker as an assistant counsel at a salary of $12,000 a year.
St. Louis at New York - Hildebrand vs. Ruffing. Detroit at Boston - Lawson vs. Henry. Chicago at Philadelphia - Whitehead vs. Ross. Cleveland at Washington - Hudlin vs. Krakauskas.
Holders of Canadian Hydro-Electric Corporation, Ltd., 6 per cent cumulative first preferred shares of record Sept. 24 are entitled to
The Japanese Army's conquest of a buffer corridor between China and Sovietprotected Outer Mongolia proceeded, rapidly today as another mechanized Japanese column pushed into Suiyuan Province.

Mrs. Mary Connor Myers was Secretary of Agriculture today under a technicality in the Federal Marketing Act. Secretary Wallace designated Mrs. Myers, 42-year-old Government lawyer, from Fairfield, Iowa, to hear protests by Boston milk-distributing companies.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 21 unless specified: At Chefoo: Gold Star, Sept. 22: Pecos. At Mare Island Yard : New Orleans, Sirius, Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. Avocet, at Pearl Harbor.
J. Irving Baucus, former Sheriff of Rensselaer County and once prominent in Republican politics in the town of Schaghticoke, died in his home here last night after a long illness at the age of 85.

As "one who loves peace and has seen the cost of war," Representative Edith Nourse Rogers of Massachusetts summed up for the Legion's Auxiliary yesterday the Significance of this convention and :he march of Tuesday up Fifth avenue.

Judge John Boyd Avis of the United States District Court sentenced five young women today to serve sentences of a year each in the Hudson County jail after they had been cited for contempt for refusing to testify before the Federal grand jury investigating white slave traffic.

Parcel deliveries in the week ended on Sept. 18 were 9 per cent ahead of those for the corresponding week last year, a sharply better gain than in the previous week, the United Parcel Service reported yesterday. Deliveries in the four weeks ended Sept. 18 were 2 per cent ahead of 1936.

The Court of Errors and Appeals upheld today the constitutionality of the legislative act of. 1936 creating a commission of four members to operate Asbury Park's beach-front enterprises independently of the city administration.
Ruth Roland, known as the "Queen of the Thriller Serials" two decades ago, died at her home here today. She was 39 years old.

All manner of army, navy and air tactics were brought into play today during the second day of the German manoeuvres. With North Prussia and the Baltic as the arenas, "severe fighting" went on all day and until late at night. Honors were divided between the western Red army and the invading eastern Blue army.

With the Legion's big parade a part of history, many visiting Legionnaires and their wives and families yesterday turned to the Seventy-first Regiment Armory at Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue to look over New York's first all-trailer show.
Jay Cooke McClure, partner in the New York stock brokerage firm of Bodell Co., died in New Haven Hospital yesterday, after a short illness, at the age of 55.

Two all-women juries brought in swift, varied and conservative verdicts in a mock trial held yesterday morning at the Women's National Republican Club, with Municipal Court Justice George L. Genung presiding. Mrs. Edward A. St.

The British cruiser Orion, which joined the American West Indies station only a short time ago, raced at 29 knots today to the U. S. S. Annapolis, a training ship, more than 300 miles from Bermuda to take ff a cadet seriously ill with acute appendicitis.

Representatives of the maritime unions and shipping companies, whose vessels sail to the Far East and Mediterranean ports, failed to reach an agreement today over the demands of the seamen for bonuses and insurance on vessels sailing into the so-called "war zones."

Following is the text of the note Foreign Minister Koki Hirota submitted to Sir Robert L. Craigie, the British Ambassador: I now have the honor to inform Your Excellency that the inquiry in Shanghai and vicinity having been completed, the Japanese Government desires to make the following reply:

The White Sox kept the Athletics in check for eight innings today after Philadelphia scored three first-inning runs, and took the game, 9 to 3. The contest stood tied at three at the end of the second.

A unique educational experiment will be started today when 1,200 high school boys and girls, accompanied by their teachers, will journey along New York City's waterfront to study civics, geography and government from the deck of a slowly moving ferryboat instead of in the conventional classroom.
About 100 Legionnaires from twelve States met yesterday in the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce in Long Island City and formed an organizatino which they named the Chemical Warfare Veterans.
Announced as first performance in America, Ernest Bloch's pianoforte sonata was presented by Reginald Boardman as solo artist at the Crawford House Ensemble's concert here this afternoon.

Dr. Walter F. Barry of Essex County, defending champion, was deprived of his title in the New Jersey State seniors' golf championship today at the Essex Fells Country Club when he carded an 88 on his second and final round for a total of 168, which put him temporarily in third place.

The bombing of Nanking and Canton has aroused horror in almost all sections of the British press. The Liberal News Chronicle is the only newspaper which points out in so many words that unless world opinion is aroused "what is happending in the far-off East today will happen in our own West tomorrow."
The 26-foot cabin cruiser, Miss New Jersey, finished first today in a 500mile race from New York to Washington, a feature of the President's Cup regatta.
Harvard College in the role of fastidious employer was twice in the news yesterday, with items just 234 years apart.

Arthur Maudlin, Republican City Chairman for more than ten years, was ousted by the newly elected committee tonight and replaced by Frank B. Cotter, president of the Common Council and Republican nominee for Mayor.

At sunrise today about 300,000 Japanese soldiers on all the Chinese fronts marked the Autumn Festival of the Imperial Japanese ancestors. They first bowed their respects toward the Commander-in-Chief's headquarters. Then, honoring the Emperor, all faced in the direction of the palace in Tokyo for one minute of silence.

State Senator Lester H. Clee, the Newark Presbyterian clergyman who entered politics three years ago on a "clean-government" platform, confounded old-line political leaders and won the New Jersey Republican nomination for Governor with a plurality of 60,896.
THE CHAIRMAN-Well, the first thing I can say is that it is a lot nicer up on Cape Cod than it is down here. This is the first time I had to interrupt my vacation for a long time.

Although shareholders of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company had not had the privilege of holding an annual meeting for five years, when the opportunity presented itself yesterday the combined vote of both proxy representation and those present was not enough to constitute a quorum and the meeting, of necessity, was adjourned until Oct. 22.

Following his prescription of plenty of contact work for Army's varsity squad, Head Coach Gar Davidson devoted the entire afternoon today to a scrimmage, with both the B squad and the Plebes as opponents for three big elevens.

Foreign trade of the United States in July increased over July, 1936, in respect to all geographical grand divisions and almost all fifty-one countries listed by the Department of Commerce, an analysis made public today disclosed.
A sharply pointed pencil pierced the heart of Marian Knippel, 7 years old, when she stumbled and fell on the lawn at her home today. She died soon afterward in a hospital.

Once a year the American Legion speaks its mind through a set of resolutions expressing the collective judgment of the delegates to its convention. Necessarily, on these occasions, it avoids issues which are partisan or factional. To pursue any other course would be to jeopardize its unity.

The Governors Island polo quartet easily defeated the First Division, 7 to 3, yesterday on the winner's field before a large crowd. This was the second victory in the annual series and gave the home team the Colyer Trophy for the fifth year in a row. Only four periods were played.

Antonio Bird Cerra, foreman of the grand jury that indicted Pedro Albizu Campos, president of the Nationalist party, and other Nationalists for sedition, was shot to death today following a quarrel by Jose Espinosa, a tugboat captain at Humacao. Espinosa and his son, Jose Manuel, were arrested.

Pennsylvania won the first two places yesterday in a contest of the American Legion's Junior Drum and Bugle Corps. First place went to the corps from Gallitzin, with a rating of 94.3; second, to that from Bristol, with 92.2.

It is virtually a matter of hours now before the Yankees will have completed a successful defense of the American League championship. Certainly none can dispute their superiority after yesterday's double victory over the Browns and whatever mathematical chance remains for the second-place Tigers is entirely negligible.
