Brandt and the Pirates lost an extra-inning pitching duel to Milt Shoffner and the Bees, 3 to 2, today when Vince DiMaggio singled Ray Mueller home in the tenth. Brandt gave up only one hit in seven innings and only five over the full route, but Boston made excellent use of its opportunities.

"The Ku Klux Klan today is all bluff," Colonel William J. Simmons, founder and former emperor and imperial wizard, declared here today. "The organization is unworthy of- anyman. It is without purpose, except selfish aggrandizement," he added.
Mrs. Catherine Blaney, a participant in welfare work here for. thirty years, died today in New Rochelle Hospital at the age of 67.

The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross established twenty stations in midtown to care for and aid members of the American Legion, it was announced yesterday. Staffs of nurses, physicians and first-aid personnel have been maintained throughout the convention. An information service has also been provided at the stations, the announcement said.

Maxim Hershey, automotive accessories in 1.974 Broadway: Haggstrom-CallenDavis Co. Inc. broker. H. J. Heinz Company. Great Lakes Coal and Coke Co. and Rheem Mfg Co. additional space in RCA Building: Westinghouse Electric Elevator Co. additional space in Nine Rockefeller Plaza: Pettingell Fenton, Inc. Marcella Johnson Studio, additional space in International Building: Rockefeller Center leases.

New York City taxpayers will pay an annual bill of $60,000,000 for the city pension and retirement system within ten years unless preventive action is taken, Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Citizens Budget Commission, said last night in a radio session of the American Labor Party's Public Affairs Court over Station WEVD.
The Dartmouth varsity scored three touchdowns on the third team today, but it was the running ability of the halfbacks rather than blocking which made the scores possible.

A heroic son and a quick-witted motorman saved the life of Paul Kuchegde, 42 years old, of 1,945 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday morning when he fainted while standing on the south-bound local platform of the Times Square I. R. T. subway station and fell to the tracks.

More than 1,800 men who twenty years ago this month were straggling into Camp Upton as raw recruits for the Seventy-seventh Division, gathered last night to honor the "great soldier" who led them a year later through the historic days in the Argonne Forest.

THERNMOHALE, INC., 111 Wall St., Sy Frederick Photo-Gelatine Press. Inc., for $125; Elizabeth Hamill, $298; Louis Nadelson, $293. Petitions Filed-By CHARLES EARLE DESMOND, brakeman, 357 W. 34th St.-Liabilities $714; no assets. HENRY ALLEN FARNHAM, commercial artist, 54 W. 85th St.-Liabilities $2,354; no assets. BERNHARD FRINGS. bakery and lunchroom, 1,409 3d Ave.-Liabilities $4,768; assets $688.

A declaration of principles ought to be written by the Republicans in a convention, perhaps early in 1938, in the opinion of R. B. Creager, national committeeman from Texas. Mr. Creager arrived today to attend the meeting of the executive committee, which will consider plans tomorrow for making the party organization stronger as well as the proposal for such an informal convention.

The American Labor party, acting through its State executive committee, last night nominated Thomas E. Dewey, special rackets prosecutor, for District Attorney of New York County, but rejected Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens, although Mr. Harvey has been endorsed by Mayor La Guardia.
William C. Kramer, a department head at the Singer Manufacturing Company plant -here, was found dead in bed this morning at his home.
J. Bayard Hearn, assistant to thepresident of the Lobdell Car Wheel Company, died of heart disease today at his home here.

A decision to return $5,000 contribute to their convention expenses by the Distilled Spirits Institute and $500 given by the Continental Distilling Company was adopted on Tuesday at a closed meeting of the executive committee of the National Conference of State Liquor Administrators in the Hotel Commodore.

Electric power production increased last week, but average daily output showed a decline when both seasonal and long-term factors called for a gain, and the adjusted index has dropped one point to 104.2. This compares with 105.2 for the previous week and 104.6 for the week ended Sept. 19, 1936.

The Greyhound Corporation applied toto the Interstate Commerce commission for permission to acuire control of Buckeye Stages, nc., by buying 60 per cent of the ??uckeye company's common stock for $300,000.
The Bomar Stables's Gold Band romped to an easy victory in the $1,200 sixth race, headline event of today's program at the Fair Grounds.
Paul Patterson, president of the A. S. Abell Company, publishers of The Baltimore Sun newspapers, said here today: "The Associated Press is the life blood of newspapering."

114th St, 54 W,. s s 17.8x100.11: Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Millicent Realty Corp. 213 W 139th St: p m mtg $7.500 ($7 50). 127th St. 77 W. 25.6x99.11; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to St Marks and 9th St Leasehold, Inc, 516 1st Ave; p m mtg s19,145 ($19.50). Lexington -Ave. 142-44. 24.6x100: Julia R. Small to Rudolf Modley. 160 E 36th St; p m mtg $19,800 ($21).
Southeastern Greyhound Lines, Inc., petitioned the I. C. C. today for permission to merge all its subsidiaries, ten bus lines serving the Central South, into one company.
The American Labor party here, at a meeting of its executive committee today, designated a full councilmanic ticket of five members and planned a vigorous fight in the coming municipal election.

Postponed from Tuesday, "Blow Ye Winds" will take the leap tonight at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, defying the traffic conditions and convention hilarity that alarmed Arthur Hopkins, producer, earlier this week. It is still Valentine Davies's comedy, starring Henry Fonda and featuring Doris Dalton. Curtain at 8:30 P. M.

Two of the season's early roadshow successes will have their first popular-priced showings hereabouts today. Metro's "The Good Earth," with Paul Muni, Luise Rainer, Walter Connolly and Tilly Losch, will move into the Capitol, and Columbia's "Lost Horizon," with Ronald Colman, Jane Wyatt, Edward Everett Horton, H. B. Warner and Margo, will be the attraction at Radio City Music Hall.

The forty-first annual Bryn Mawr Horse Show got under way today with perfect weather conditions prevailing and a large, well balanced field of hunters competing in the varied events. This year the saddle classes were entirely eliminated.
A more determined stand, the most forthright to date, was taken by the United States Government today in the Sino-Japanese situation as a result of the bombings of Nanking by Japanese air raiders.

Funeral services for James MacKirdy, head linotype machinist of The New York Herald Tribune, were held last night by the Rev. John H. Fitzgerald, rector of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church of Bay Ridge, in the chapel at 7,614 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn.

In "I Have Been Here Before,". staged at the Royalty Theatre tonight, J. B. Priestley sets himself the formidable task of dramatizing the theory that people repeat over and over again a life that is nearly always identical and that a sense of premonition is the memory of events experienced in previous cycles.
Abraham Kutz, active in the civic organizations of Far Rockaway, L. I., died Tuesday night after a long illness in the Manhattan Hospital. He was 52 years old.
J. Bayard Hearn, assistant to thepresident of the Lobdell Car Wheel Company, died of heart disease today at his home here.

A decision to return $5,000 contribute to their convention expenses by the Distilled Spirits Institute and $500 given by the Continental Distilling Company was adopted on Tuesday at a closed meeting of the executive committee of the National Conference of State Liquor Administrators in the Hotel Commodore.

Electric power production increased last week, but average daily output showed a decline when both seasonal and long-term factors called for a gain, and the adjusted index has dropped one point to 104.2. This compares with 105.2 for the previous week and 104.6 for the week ended Sept. 19, 1936.

The Greyhound Corporation applied toto the Interstate Commerce commission for permission to acuire control of Buckeye Stages, nc., by buying 60 per cent of the ??uckeye company's common stock for $300,000.
The Bomar Stables's Gold Band romped to an easy victory in the $1,200 sixth race, headline event of today's program at the Fair Grounds.
Paul Patterson, president of the A. S. Abell Company, publishers of The Baltimore Sun newspapers, said here today: "The Associated Press is the life blood of newspapering."

In the first application of the building differential subsidy provided in the Merchant Marine Act of 1936, officials of the Maritime Commission and the United States Lines are facing an unexpected difficulty.
A more determined stand, the most forthright to date, was taken by the United States Government today in the Sino-Japanese situation as a result of the bombings of Nanking by Japanese air raiders.

Funeral services for James MacKirdy, head linotype machinist of The New York Herald Tribune, were held last night by the Rev. John H. Fitzgerald, rector of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church of Bay Ridge, in the chapel at 7,614 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn.

In "I Have Been Here Before,". staged at the Royalty Theatre tonight, J. B. Priestley sets himself the formidable task of dramatizing the theory that people repeat over and over again a life that is nearly always identical and that a sense of premonition is the memory of events experienced in previous cycles.
Abraham Kutz, active in the civic organizations of Far Rockaway, L. I., died Tuesday night after a long illness in the Manhattan Hospital. He was 52 years old.

During the first six months of this year the United States regained first place among the trading and industrial nations of the world in the value of its exports to Chile, the Commerce Department stated today.

For the third time since 1925, Station WMCA has leased new quarters to provide room for expansion of its broadcasting facilities. The entire fourth floor and the penthouse structure of the Hollywood Theatre Building, on the west side of Broadway, between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets, containing about 30,000 quarere feet of space, has been leased by the broadcasting company for eight years, according to Donald Flamm, president.

The marriage of Miss Frances Langsdorf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse E. Langsdorf of New York and Stratford, Conn., to Henry Greenebaum, son of Mrs. Michael H. Greenebaum, also of this city, and the late Mr. Greenebaum, took place last night at the Waldorf-Astoria. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman.
Inspection of new dwellings in New York's expanding suburban communities has become a favorite pastime for thousands of families on Sunday anil holidays.

German Day will be celebrated this year by sixteen German societies of the city on Oct. 3 in Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday by the United German Societies at their headquarters, 347 Madison Avenue.

Roy Wenzlick, St. Louis real estate economist, analyst and publisher, tonight predicted increased real estate business with a "boom period" in the early 1940's. In an address prepared for delivery before the forty-ninth annual convention of the Massachusetts Cooperative Bank League, Mr. Wenzlick said:

Convinced by John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, that he and others instead of former President Hoover had originated the idea of a mid-term national convention to draft a declaration of principles,

Lord Rothermere, British publisher, today declared that he did not think any fear need be felt that Southern pine would displace Canadian pulp for newsprint. "There is no Southern tree which can give as good newsprint as can those from the Northern woods," he said.

Neutral foreign military observers here are indulging in speculation as to how the Chinese armies in the immediate future will obtain the vitally necessary war supplies which China is unable to manufacture and must import from abroad.

Having waited over to attend the first night of his new play in London and to see another play through final rehearsals, J. B. Priestley will sail for New York early next week. Mrs. Priestley and their five children are already on their way to pass the Winter in Arizona,

Mrs. Richard C. Harrison of New York was hostess at Kenmore Hall, Richmond, this afternoon for the Richmond Valley Garden Club's annual meeting. Officers elected were Mrs. Henry M. Seaver of Pittsfield, who succeeded Mrs. Shaun Kelly as president; Mrs. E. Pomeroy Cutler, vice president; Mrs. Charles L. Sherrill, treasurer, and Mrs. Ralph Hooker, secretary.

Six scholarships and two fellowships with a total value of $16,900 have been awarded to educators in the United States and abroad by the School of Advanced Education of Teachers College, Columbia University, Dr. Paul R. Mort, director of the school, announced yesterday.
The four-story elevator apartment at 330 Central Avenue, Leonia, N. J., has been sold by the Prudential Insurance Company of America to a client of Richard I. Epstein. The house occupies a plot
Readjust-, ments for the old account today apparently were negotiated with a minimum of disturbance, for, although business was on a small scale, the tone of the stock market generally was firm.

Rumors that the former Kaiser of Germany had left Doorn secretly and crossed the German frontier were denied categorically on all sides-by the Burgomaster of Dorn, by the district chief of police and by the Interior Department here.

Patrolman John H. A. Wilson, 37 years old, almost eleven years on the force, was shot fatally yesterday when, single-handed, he charged up dim-lit stairs at 65 Fulton Street to face three hold-up men whom he knew to be armed.
Dismissal of James J. Goodwin of Newark as examiner in the State Department of Banking and Insurance, was sustained today by the Civil Service Commission.

Logan Howard-Smith, secretary of Geyelin Frank, Inc., travel agents, died at his home in Rosemont yesterday after a month's illness. He was 54. He was born at Montclair, N. J. He was a graduate of Germantown Academy and the University of Pennsylvania.
The new De Soto models for 1938, details of which will be made public next month, were shown here today at a newspaper preview at the engineering building of the Chrysler Corporation.
The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Sept. 22 were announced today: LIEUTENANTS Anderson, C. A. A.. the Tallapoosa, to Base 4. Anderson, E. A., the Apache, to the Cayuga.

The fast-fading army of the American Legion, its convention over, rallied for one last stand at the Legion amateur boxing carnival at the Madison square Garden Bowl, Long Island City, last night as a crowd of 35,000 gathered to watch youngsters from all over the country battle for honors.
Former President Cleto Gonzalez Viquez of Costa Rica died today after a long illness. He had been planning to leave shortly for the United States for medical treatment.

Eight days' work atop Shiva Temple, the wooded plateau towering above Grand Canyon's arid depths, tonight had yielded close to 100 animals to scientists searching for the evolutionary results of isolation.

John T. Flynn, chairman of the Queens College administrative committee of the board of higher education, charged yesterday County Judge Charles S. Colden of Flushing was seeking to make the new Queens College a "political department" and therein place "a horde of job hunters in Queens."

Harry B. Salmon of the home club, 1930 titleholder, was crowned the New Jersey State senior champion when the positions of yesterday's first five players remained undisturbed in the final eighteen-hole round today at the Essex Fells Country Club.

Broadening of the scope of trademark registration, closer conformity to Federal statutes in the matter of classification and an increase in regulatory powers, were among possibilities offered by uniform trade-mark legislation suggested by Doris I. Byrne, executive deputy secretary of State of New York befor the Twentieth Annual Conference of Secretaries of State here today.
Now it is China which has its united front. Chinese Communists, under the hammer blows of Japan, have discovered that they

CHAMPIONSHIP DIVISION Semi-Final Round-Mrs. William HockenJos Jr., Crestmont, defeated Miss Laddie Irwin, Glen Ridge. 4 and 3; Miss Clarrle Tiernan, Essex Fells, defeated Miss Charlotte Glutting. Rock Spring. 2 and 1. SECOND DIVISION Semi-Final Round--Mrs. Harvey Mack. La.e Hopatcong, defeated Miss Margaret Gould. Essex County. 4 and 3: Mrs. N. Goldberger. Hollywood. defeated Mrs. V. C. Smith, Echo Lake. 4 and 3.

Nothing but sympathy should be extended to John D. Biggers, whose thankless job it is to secure a "voluntary registration" of the unemployed and partially unemployed in the hope that the final figure will have some meaning. Mr. Biggers has hit upon the idea of doing the whole thing by mail.

The problem of economic conditions in various fields of industry is "a business man's problem and does not rest in the hands of labor," Charles Johnson Post, an official in the conciliation division of the United States Department of Labor

Tennessee voted overwhelmingly today for retention of its prohibition laws in a referendum from which repeal leaders held aloof on the ground that it was "meaningless." Drys hailed the victory as marking the end of repeated attempts in the Legislature to legalize liquor.

An increase in the State's appropriation for the Motor Vehicle Bureau, so that it may be able to give prospective drivers an hour's test instead of the ten-minute period now devoted to this preliminary to a driver's license, was favored today by the Empire State Automobile Merchants Association at its annual meeting.
Dr. Lewis Nathaniel Chase, scholar, writer and editor, died at the Garfield Hospital here today after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

Mayor La Guardia raised numerous questions yesterday about the propriety of charging private employers a special fee for the use of city police on guard duty when his veto of the Keegan ordinance imposing such charges was printed in the City Record.

As a tribute to Miss Helen Keller, a gala benefit concert will be presented at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, Oct. 23. Sergei Rachmaninoff, the pianist, will join with the Philadelphia Orchestra, directed by Eugene Ormandy, in presenting the program.

A general return to time payment practices which prevailed in the building material industry prior to 1934 when the Federal Housing Administration first started to function, was foreshadowed here yesterday by announcement of Lewis H. Brown, president of the JohnsManville Corporation, that the maximum time for payment under the Johns-Manville Credit Corporation's deferred payment plan has been reduced to twenty-four months from the previous maximum of thirtysix months.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Second Lt. Judson D. Wilcox, FA-Ree., unassigned now at Madison Barracks, New York, is placed on active duty, effective Sept 18. He will report to the Commanding Officer, 5th Field Artillery, for training. He will be relieved at such time as
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a warehouse in West Thirtieth Street to be erected by the New York Central Railroad. Details of this and other plans follow:

Except for the fact that among his three remaining opponents he must encounter Jose R. Capablanca and Samuel Reshevsky in the international chess masters' tournament, Paul Keres of Estonia seems to be headed straight for the first prize.

The outstanding loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New way. York City fell $120,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday toa total of $8,165,000,000, according to the weekly condition statement of the banks, issued yesterday. The drop, which followed a contraction of $85,000,000 in the previous week, was made up of a shrinkage of their $49,000,000 in loans and one of $71,000,000 in investments.
Sales totaling more than $1,200 have been made by artists exhibiting in the twelfth semi-annual out-door art exhibition in the streets around Washington Square, it was announced yesterday.

Daniel J. Doherty, 43-year-old attorney from Woburn, Mass., who practices in Boston, is the first New Englander to be elected National Commander of the American Legion. He has held many local, State and national offices in the Legion.

The American Labor party will in all probability name Mayor La Guardia as a member of its slate of candidates for delegates at large to the State constitutional convention, Alex Rose, executive director of the party, clearly indicated yesterday.

In a formal decision, Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora appealed yesterday to the Municipal Civil Service Commission to consent to the appointment of Jay Beck of 61 Fifth Avenue as director of male education in the Department of Correction.

The Merchants Association yesterday began circulating a. questionnaire among a large number of trad, business and industrial enterprises in an effort to find to what extent there is a demand for an amendment to the State Insurance Law Conv in order to provide greater

The ringleaders In the raid on the Spanish submarine at Brest today were identified as Spanish aristocrats high in the counsels of General Francisco Franco, it was revealed tonight. Major Julian Troncozo, arrested by the French and held at Bayonne in reality is Count Julian Troncoso

The New York Stock Exchange committee on foreign business has elected Victor B. Cook of Fenner Beane and Robert F. Whitmer Jr., of Edward B. Smith Co. to fill vacancies caused by the death of Alpheus C. Beane and the resignation of Howland S. Davis.

Miss Virginia Foster Shields gave a luncheon yesterday in the Regency Room of the New Weston for members of the junior committee working for the success of the first Miniature Automobile Show. The Boys Brotherhood Republic will be the beneficiary of the show, which will open with a tea on the afternoon of Oct. 5 in the International Building of Rockefeller Center.

In his first interview after his election as National Commander of the American Legion, Daniel J. Doherty, Boston lawyer, said individual members of the American Legion must take their stand on any labor controversy "as private citizens, not as Legionnaires."
The Boston' Maine Railroad reported yesterday a profit and loss surplus of $6,446,772 as of June 30, against $2,661,618 a year previously. Total assets were $289,538,611, against $290,323,782.

The New York Football Giants will leave for Pittsburgh today and Sunday's game with the Pirates. A squad of twenty-five will make the trip. This battle may settle the fate of the Maramen in the race for Eastern divisional honors in the National League, since a Pittsburgh victory would give Art Rooney's team three victories and no defeats while the New Yorkers would have two setbacks.

The third of a series of auction Sales of properties of the closed First National Bank and Trust Company of Yonkers will be held on Saturday afternoon at 2:30 in the Yonkers State Armory. Joseph P. Day, Inc.; Albert M. Greenfield Co., Inc., and William A. White Sons are the auctioneers for Arthur E. Muth, receiver for the bank.

Charles A. Knorr, Chicago tenor in the Eighties and highly regarded as a singer of oratorios, died today in New Carlisle, Ind. He was 85 years old. For twenty years Mr. Knorr was director of St. Paul's Episcopal boys' choir in Chicago.

Shareholders of the Ludlum Steel Company voted today at a special meeting here to authorize an increase in the capital stock from 500,000 shares to 1,000,000 shares of common of $1 par value. Hihland G. Batcheller, head of the company, presided.

A British official broadcast said that Italy had assured Britain she would send no more volunteers to Spain. London believed she might exchange her interest in the civil war for recognition of the Ethiopian conquest.

The election of Roberto M. Ortiz, the government party candidate, as the next President of Argentina is conceded by the opposition. Indications are that he will have 238 electors out of a total of 376 in the Electoral College.
Fordham university's Graduate School and Teachers College opened their 1937 school year yesterday with an enrollment of 1,700 to date and registration still going on.

John McKenzie, Commissioner of Docks, assured members of the Traffic Club of New York, composed of representatives of various' branches of the transportation industry, that the foreign trade zone at the city's piers on Staten Island "is here to stay," whether it is to be operated by a private corporation or by the city Administration.

Plans for the annual convention of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks, which is to be held in the Waldorf-Astoria here on Oct. 7 to 9, were announced yesterday by Dr. Luther Harr, Secretary of Banking for Pennsylvania, who is chairman of the program committee.

The Swedish Tercentenary Art Exhibition opened with a very simple ceremony last evening in the Mezzanine Galleries of International Building, Rockefeller Center. Brief addresses were delivered by Wollmar F. Bostrom, Swedish Minister to the United States, and Dr. Sixten Strombom, curator of the Swedish National Museum of Art.

Mrs. Ray Gold of the Bronx, N. Y., asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to redetermine deficiencies aggregating $139,606 in 1935 income taxes assessed against her as an individual and as transferee and administratrix of Morris Gold, deceased. She contended the

The marriage of Miss Ruth B. Froehlich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvan H. Froehlich of 530 West End Avenue, to Harold E. Strasser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Strasser, also of New York, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.
Thomas Cover Jr., a leather manufacturer whose home was in Bryn Mawr, died yesterday at his camp near North Hero, Vt.. at the age of 60. He was founder of and a partner in Cover Co. of this city.

Erich Windels, German Minister to Canada, is among the passengers arriving from Europe today on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland. Others are Mr. and Mrs. Henry Freese, Dr. Friedhelm Draeger, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Mueller, Mrs. Stanley D. Embick, Judge Charles S. Sullivan, August Janssen and Mr. and Mrs. Harold C. Keith.

Schenectady, N. Y., will be in the market on Sept. 30, with a new issue of $627,000 of debt equalization, general municipal, public improvement and fire-equipment bonds. The issue will be dated Sept. 1, and will mature serially from Sept. 1, 1938 to 1950. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 3 per cent.

Three trawlers, designed to net more fish in less time, were launched today by the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation. The vessels, 147-foot Diesel-powered craft with tripod masts, were named "Annapolis," "West Point" and "Yale" by their owner, the General Sea Foods Corporation, a subsidiary of General Foods.

An attendance of several hundred residents of this place and surrounding Westchester communities, and including others who will motor from New York for the occasion, is expected at the Cosmo Villa Barn Dance to be held tomorrow night at the Schmidt Farm here. The party will be for the benefit of Irvington House, a non-sectarian sanatorium for child heart patients at Irvington-on-Hudson.

Negotiating today with officers of the Chrysler Corporation, the United Automobile Workers demanded wage increases for all the more than 50,000 Chrysler hourly rate workers and changes in the rate of production.

A move to win steel shipping from New York to the port of Philadelphia was started today by Governor George H. Earle, who announced that he would fly to Washington Monday to confer with army engineers on the possibility of deepening the thirty-five-foot channel.

Mayor Tormos Diego declared today that he revoked a permit to the Nationalist party for a Palm Sunday celebration when he became convinced a "military concentration" of the party's liberation army was planned.
In the lake-studded country about 100 miles southeast of this ancient Hanseatic city a major battle has

They gave Fred Apostoli a shining target in the first of the big bouts at the Polo Grounds. He couldn't miss seeing the shining dome of the Bald Eagle of the Left Bank under those bright lamps. Sometimes the glare of the Thil headlight seemed to have San Francisco Fred in a daze.

Frank Pinola, 44, of Kingston, former Pennsylvania State commander of the American Legion, and Republican candidate for State Treasurer at the last election, his wife and two friends are recovering at Easton Hospital from serious injuries suffered last last night in an automobile collision near here.

An application of the Securities Exchange Corporation, Lincoln, Neb., for registration as broker and dealer in the over-the-counter market has been denied by the Securities and Exchange Commissioh. The SEC said it should be noted that the corporate name of the applicant had a striking similarity to that of the Commission.

Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., and subsidiaries announced yesterday that the net profit for the six months ended on July 31 amounted to $9,049,644 after depreciation, amortization, Federal and State income taxes, provision for Federal surtax on undistributed income and other charges.

For the first time in medical history colored motion pictures have been successfully taken of a living blood stream, it was disclosed today as the Biological Photographic Association began its annual meeting here.

Government economists protested against the increased bread prices today, declaring the boosts had added $50,000,000 a year to the public's food bill. D. E. Montgomery, consumers' counsel of the Agriculture Adjustment Administration, contended that the increases had been made "in spite of relatively low wholesale prices of bread ingredients."
The United States destroyer Barker arrived here today from Foochow for an indefinite stay. The American

Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti was endorsed yesterday for election to a full fourteen-year term in his present office by the New York Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild and a number of well-known lawyers, including Senator Robert F. Wagner, John W. Davis and Frank L. Polk. Justice Poletti is serving until the end of this year by appointment of Governor Lehman, for whom he was formerly counsel.
Harold C. George, department head in the School of Mines at the University of Pittsburgh, died today upon his return after a leave of absence because of illness. His age was 56.
Miss Sophronia Andersen, who was active here in civic and welfare organizations, died today at her home, 569 Mount Prospect Avenue, after a short illness with a heart ailment. She was 78 years old.
German shepherd dogs are assisting the Japanese Army on the China war fronts, officers said today.
Dr. W. C. Cosby, optometrist, died here yesterday at the age of 51. Dr. Cosby, a native of Hanover County, Va., was graduated in 1913 from the California School of Optometry in Los Angeles.

The Supreme Court affirmed today a verdict of $12,500 awarded to Senator Edward P. Stout of Hudson County for legal services to Bayonne. The Senator represented the city in railroad tax litigation, begun in 1931, which resulted in an increase of $500,000 in the city's assessment of rail properties.

Eldridge St. 87. 25x74.10: Joseph P. Fran. referee. to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp, trustee, 46 Broadway; foreclosure ($1). La Salle St. 61, 25x99.11: Reuben J. Aronson, referee, to Dekasar Realty Corp, 1,472 Broadway; foreclosure (50c).

Mervin (Red) Dutton, manager of the New York Americans of the National Hockey League, announced yesterday that he has acquired two players, Happy Day and Jack Shill, from the Toronto Maple Leafs. The terms regarding the transaction were not disclosed.

Freed by a Presidential pardon, John W. Tilton, 24-year-old newspaper publisher of Rochelle, III., walked out of the De Kalb County jail tonight and set out for home. He entered the jail June 1 under a six-month sentence for probation violation.
Sharp advances in the cost of farm products and foods sent the general level of wholesale prices upward in the week ended on Sept. 18, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Unter den Linden, Berlin's via triumphalis, blazed forth tonight in all the glory of its new lighting effects created for the meeting of Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Premier Benito Mussolini as hundreds of golden Nazi eagles, perched on as many gleaming white pillars along that avenue, seemed to gaze proudly at the spectacle.

MANHATTAN GUMPERZ, MARY (Sept. 16). Estate. more than $20,000. To Jerome Gumperz. son, executor. 27 W 96th St, residuary estate and life income from $100,000; Rose August Gumperz. daughter-in-law, same address, succeeding estate in trust; eight contingent requests.
Government reports showed today this year's large cotton crop was being picked and ginned at a nearrecord pace. The Census Bureau announced 4,266,617 running bales had been ginned prior to Sept. 16.

Miss Eleanor Herr Colt, daughter of Mrs. John Colt of 829 Park Avenue and Mr. Colt of Red Bank, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church to C. Alan Hudson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Alan Hudson of this city, Rumson, N. J., and Miami Beach, Fla.

Legion Committee Discharged The Fire Department National Convention Committee and the sub-committee, appointed on Oct. 6, 1936. for the purpose of making arrangements for the participation of this department in the activities of the American Legion Convention and parade, is discharged, said committee and sub-committee having terminated their duties in a satisfactory manner.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has set Oct. 13 for a hearing on an application by the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the 8 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $100-par value, of Kresge Department Stores,

Frederick C. Field, a consulting engineer, died yesterday in Germantown Hospital. He was 62 years old. Born in Brooklyn, N. Y., he was graduated from Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1897 and served as a major in the Ordnance Department during the World War.

The noisy hum of trim outboard motor boats interrupted the usual calm of the Potomac today as America's foremost drivers tuned up for the President's Cup regatta this week-end. The opening day tomorrow will be devoted to the tiny craft, most of them fresh from national championships at Richmond, Va.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Halsey Sayles of Elmira, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Boardman Sayles, to Bela Crane Tifft, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Tifft, also of Elmira.

Miss Manie Hetherington Connor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Powers Connor of this place, was married here tonight in St. George's Episcopal Church to Walter Robertson Williams Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. Williams, also of Maplewood. The ceremony was performed by the rector,-the Rev. Francis Richey.

Notice of an agreement consolidating the Crown Central Petroleum Corporation (Delaware) and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Crown Central Petroleum Corporation (Maryland) has been received by the New York Curb Exchange. The resulting company will bear the des- ( igenation of the latter.

The Maritime Commission refused tonight to grant the demands of maritime unions whose members are in the Far Eastern and Mediterranean trades for a bonus of $250 a voyage for each member of the crew and a bonus for officers amounting to double pay for each voyage into the Sino-Japanese and Spanish war zones.
With the influx of Legionnaires into town during the week, two of the three chief out-of-town newsstands in the midtown sector reported yesterday a big increase in sales.

Plans to exert efforts to stop socalled "celebrity nights" in night clubs and hotels, which professional entertainers feel are disadvantageous to employment conditions in their ranks, will be made at a directors' meeting of the New York Theatre Authority on Oct. 7, Alan Corelli, executive secretary, announced yesterday.

Miss Edna J. Strauss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Strauss of 275 Central Park West, was married to Sidney Treitel, son of Henry Trei tel of Yonkers and the late Mrs. Treitel, here yesterday in the study of the Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise of Central Synagogue, who performed the ceremony.

After a thrilling battle, Miss Clarrie Tiernan, 21-year-old girl who was 1936 champion of Ireland and now is a member of the Essex Fells Club, fought her way to the thirtysix-hole final round of the women's New Jersey State golf championship over the west course of the Essex County Country Club by eliminating a four-time winner of the title, Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring today, 2 and 1.

State and local officials, here for a conference on the new $526,000,000 housing program, predicted today that Federal subsidies would be sought quickly for scores of projects. Most of the projects, they reported, had already been shaped for Public Works Administration loans and grants that were not forthcoming.

In recognition of fifty years as organist of the First Methodist Episcopal Church of this village Miss Lilly A. Romaine was honored at a dinner here tonight by members of the church. The organ dedicated fifty years ago on the day that Miss Romaine became organist is still being used. Miss Romaine, who

Class 48. Thoroughbred Novice or Green Hunters--First, Mr. and Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart's b. m. Gay Queen; Arthur I. Meigs's br. g. Machicolation, second; Springsbury Farm's ch. g. Dress Rehearsal, third.
The signing of a closed-shop contract with the Parmelee System, Inc., operator of the largest taxicab fleet in the city, was announced yesterday by the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. 0. affiliate.

An industrial committee of prominent business men and executives cooperating with city officials will present the advantages of Jersey City as an industrial location in a new advertising and publicity campaign to be undertaken by the municipality, it was announced yesterday by Mayor Frank Hague.

Charles W. Chase, president of the Indianapolis Railways, Indianapolis, Ind., was elected today president of the American Transit Association to succeed Thomas Conway Jr. The association, at its fifty-sixth annual convention, also elected A. J. Lundeberg, president of the East Bay

The Federal Trade Commission published a complaint today against Louis H. Tabach, 1,060 Broad Street, Newark, charging unfair competition in the sale of women's hosiery. Tabach, it was said, traded under the names Long Wear Hosiery Company, Certified Hosiery
The total of awards for engineering construction in the week ended yesterday was $43,677,000, a decline of 36 per cent from the 1936 figure of $68,041,000, the Engineering News-Record reports.

THE GOOD SOCIETY, by Walter Lippmann. (Little, Brown, $3.) A review of modern governments and social systems. EUROPE IN LIMBO, by Robert Briffault. (Scribner, $2.75.) A novel by the author of "Europa."

Argentina's 1937 polo invasion of the United States ended in defeat on Hitchcock Field of the Meadow Brook Club today when the fighting Aknusti team upset the San Jose team, 8 to 7, to send them out of the Waterbury Cup tournament,

Pleas by more than a score bf the nation's prominent men for increased tolerance and racial goodwill were made in messages to members of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, who opened their forty-second annual convention here today.

The possibility of some form of reciprocal tax agreement that would tie in with the "hot" money problem will be discussed by officials of the Treasury with Sir Frederick Phillips, Under-Secretary of the British Exchequer, in the series of conferences now being held, Secretary Morgenthau said today.

F. F. Brooks, president of the First National Bank at Pittsburgh, has been elected a director of the Pittsburgh Steel Company. The meeting of directors of the Hecker Products Corporation has been postponed until today.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

The White Sox, making it two out of three over the Athletics, bowed out of Shibe Park for the season by capturing the final encounter today, 1 to 0. Johnny Whitehead bested Buck Ross in a hurling duel, keeping the Athletics' seven hits well scattered. Ross yielded six hits,
United States Government bonds were the only major group to resist yesterday a fresh decline in bond
Buying by customers in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Sept. 18 exceeded the selling by substantial proportions, according to the weekly summary published today by
Charles Stollberg, former vice president of the American Can Company, died yesterday in his apartment at the Hotel Drake after a brief illness. He was 77 years old.

As thousands of worn out but happy Legionnaires started the big push homeward yesterday local merchants and purveyors of food, drink and entertainment consulted their cash registers and voted that the convention had been a huge success.

Harry Cakes, Toronto mining executive, has donated ?80,000 to St. George's Hospital, Hyde Park Corner, the largest single amount yet subscribed to the hospital's rebuilding fund. The donation will allow a start on construction next year.

WHAT ails the world today, Walter Lippmann tells us in his new book,* may be summed up in the word collectivism. As he sees it, collectivism ranges in virulence from Mr. Roosevelt's New Deal to absolute dictatorship, but it rests always upon a single principle-that of coercion and authority.
