Frank B. Arnold, retired New York showman who brought China some of that country's first motion pictures, died yesterday after a brief illness at the age of 60.

Spanish Insurgent troops trudged through fresh-fallen snow tonight into the outskirts of Covadonga and Cangas de Onis, bulwarks of the fortified line protecting Gijon on the east. Naval guns and air forces joined the marching columns in opening the "big push" against this line,

The report of the Italian Superpower Corporation for the three months ended on June 30, issued yesterday, showed a net loss of $105,343 after expenses, charges and taxes, compared with a-net loss of $169,505 in the three months ended on June 30, 1936.

Barney Ross weighed 143 pounds, Ceferino Garcia 145 3/4. Billy Cavanagh was the referee and George Lecron and Abe Goldberg were the judges. The fight by rounds: First Round Garcia drove a long right to the head. Ross was short with a left to the face. They traded lefts at long range. Garcia hooked a light left to

Miss Geralda Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Moore of 1,314 Albemarle Road, Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas I. Parkinson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas I. Parkinson of this city and West Islip, L. I., in Holy Innocents Church, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Thomas J. Sheridan.
Two smashing upsets, with Sefiorita Anita Lizana of Chile and Miss Helen Jacobs of California the victims, provided the fireworks for today's play in the Pacific Southwest tennis championships.

Secretary Wallace announces that the Administration has abandoned its original goal of "parity prices" for farm products. The new goal will be "parity income." The Government will try to give "the average farmer the same purchasing power-the same share of the national income per capita--that he had in the fifty years before the World War."

Plans for a long-range program of research in banking, credit and allied problems, to be carried out through an impartial research agency, have been completed by the Association of Reserve City Bankers, it was announced yesterday by Robert Strickland, president of the association and president of the Trust Company oL Georgia, Atlanta.

Avoiding any declaration on the controversial issue of Supreme Court sanctity, the American Legion mildly attacked labor unions and employers alike yesterday for flouting legal rights in industrial disputes, but failed to slam the door permanently against possible future Legion partisanship in the economic struggle between capital and labor.

Ernie Hewitt, 147, Flatbush, outpointed Ray Napolitano, 145, Williamsburg, in the ten-round feature bout at the Fort Hamilton Arena in Brooklyn last night. The six-round semi-final was won by iLeo (Red) Finnigan, 163, West

Jean La Guardia, the Mayor's 9year-old daughter, and twenty-two of her class-mates in the fourth grade of the Horace Mann School will visit the City Hall this morning for an insight into New York City Government.

The Penn football team engaged in a practice scrimmage with Lebanon Valley College today. Coach Jerry, Frock of Lebanon brought thirtytwo players here and Harvey Harman, Red and Blue mentor, agreed not to exceed that number during the hour's practice. Touchdowns were not permitted, but big Jim Connell, sophomore fullback, played brilliantly for Penn.

The fearful dilemma of culture in all ages lies on the one hand in regimented thought and on the other in utter freedom degenerating ultimately into intellectual libertinism, President Roswell Gray Ham of Mount Holyoke College said this morning in his inaugural address.

Premier Mussolini's 21-year-old aviator son Vittorio passed through an elaborate protective system laid out in the harbor by city police, the coast guard and the State Department yesterday, and landed safely from the liner Rex for a day's visit in New York.

Expenditure of approximately $2,000,000 for improvements to the plant of the American Rolling Mill Company in Butler, Pa., was announced last night by George M. Verity, chairman of the board, at a community celebration of the

Prizes are being offered for a marching with which to welcome Japan's soldiers home "next Spring." Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoe will make the award and the Government will give a money prize and a medal to the winner.
Turpentine firm, 30c; sales 172 barrels; receipts 316 barrels; shipments 170 barrels; stock 40,239 barrels.

E. R. Bradley, only man to own four Kentucky Derby victors, gained a double at Belmont yesterday and just missed a triple when Baby League lost by the slim margin of a head. The victors, in the white silks with green hoops, were the former stake performer, Billionaire, in the featured Lion d'Or Handicap, and Blind Eagle, in the curtain-raiser.

Fred Apostoli weighed 159 1/2 pounds and Marcel Thil 159. The referee was Arthur Donovan and the judges were Charley Lynch and Abe Goldberg. The fight by rounds: First Round Thil hooked a left to the head and drove a left and right to the body. He was short with a left for the head, then sent a right to the jaw.

When the ship on which Justice Black is a passenger reaches the Virginia coast the President will be with his daughter and her family at Seattle, a whole continent away. When the Justice takes his place with other members of the Supreme Court on Oct. 4

When Hugo L. Black returns from Europe next week to take his new position as associate justice of the Supreme Court, he will find that a man who is a Negro and a Catholic has been selected to be his personal messenger.
My dear Commander Colmery: I extend to you and through you to the members of the American Legion greetings on the occasion of the nineteenth annual convention.

President Kooseveit, pausing in the heart of the corn country late this afternoon on his way to the Northwest, told a cheering crowd of 1,500 gathered around his train at Marshalltown, Iowa, that some method must be found to stabilize the prices of major crops such as corn and cotton.

Charging cruelty, non-support and abandonment, Mrs. Helen C. McHale, 43 years old, of 7 Garden Avenue, Bronxville, today filed a separation suit against Vincent R. McHale, New York City investment broker and formerly chief examiner for the Federal Farm Loan Board. Mrs. McHale declared her

Ted Peckham, the young man from Cleveland who founded the Guide Escort Service, here two years ago, which provides college men escorts for New York and visiting matrons for dinner, dances and the theatre, announced yesterday on his return from Europe on the French liner Champlain that he had signed up seven British peers for escort and theatrical engagements during the social season here this Winter.

The demand for apartments in scattered sections of the city continued yesterday when renting agents announced additional lists of names that have been added to tenant rosters. Every area shared in the activity.

Trading was fair to slow. The beef market was steady to higher, lamb weak to lower, fresh pork uneven, veal and calf mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef and lamb to be steady to strong, veal steady, calf weak, as rePorted by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Thirtyfive policemen comprised a special detail charged today with the task of solving eleven attacks on women in Chicago hotels and hospitals during the last two years, and rounding up all sex degenerates.

The sixteen-story, E-shaped apartment house on the northeast corner of Eighty-third Street and Riverside Drive was sold at auction in the Vesey Street salesrooms yesterday to the plaintiff, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, for $1,000,000. The house stands on a

Under the heaviest hedging operations since the new crop began to move early last month, the sagging tendency in evidence for several weeks gained momentum yesterday and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange broke 14 to 19 points. The ;

AS Mark Antony said: "If you have tears, prepare to shed them now." This is pretty sad. It was an incident of the training season of M'sieu Marcel Thil, Senor Pedro Montanez and Ceferino Garcia, the Filipino Fashion Plate, in the Pompton Lakes area.

Winthrop R. Scott, the American Consul at Kobe, informed the State Department today that this week there had arrived at Kobe from Shanghai on foreign vessels the following Americans: Miss B. Austin, Chicago.

Mrs. Irene Castle McLaughlin, former dancing star, filed suit for divorce here today against Major Frederic McLaughlin, owner of the Chicago Blackhawk hockey team and president of a coffee importing house.
Paoting, the capital of Hopeh Province, was attacked today as the Japanese forces continued their drive southward along the PeipingHankow Railway.
Twenty new appointments to the engineering and art faculties of Cooper Union were announced yesterday by Gano Dunn, president. Eleven are in the Engineering School and nine in the Schools of Art.

Mrs. William A. Barstow entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the RitzCarlton for Mrs. J. Grenville Bates Jr., Mrs. A. Duer Irving, Mrs. William Raymond Jr., Mrs. Robert R. Hitt and Mrs. William Boulton Bates. Another luncheon in the

They kept us awake for four nights. They fired cannon under our windows and sometimes through their own windows. They threw water on us, poked us with electric shockers and held up miles of traffic in order to see that our windshields were properly wiped.

Forty-eight lots on Sixty-second Avenue, between 146th and 150th Streets, Flushing, Queens, close to the World's Fair grounds, have been sold by the B. H. B. Realty Holding Corporation, a concern controlled by Benjamin R. Harriman, attorney, to Benjamin Nerven.

Although the extremely rapid expansion in retail installment sales last year was one of the important factors in slowing down consumer purchasing this Summer, it is now losing its force, according to a statement issued yesterday by A. W. Zelomek, economist of the International Statistical Bureau, Inc., and the Fairchild Publications. The necessity of maintaining installment payments has been widely nin overestimated as a factor in Fall business. Mr. Zelomek states.

Surrogate William J. Shells said today he would file an appeal from Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan's ruling in Albany yesterday that he did not receive a plurality in the general election last November and must therefore stand for election this November.

Publocation of revised budget estimates for the fiscal year has been deplayed until the middle or end of October, while the Administration checks the effect of new legislation on expenditures and makes renewed efforts to cut expenses.

Hundreds of dead and dying Chinese, mangled by high explosives in the narrow streets of Nanking and Canton, mock the bland assurances which the Japanese Government has given to the Western nations. Replying finally, after several weeks of delay, to the protest filed in Tokyo over the wounding of the British Ambassador to China, the Japanese Government expressed its deep regret and

The only thing the Dodgers had to cheer about as they beat a disorderly retreat from the Western front today was Heinie Manush's 2,500th major league hit, which the veteran of fifteen years' major league service slashed out as a pinch hitter off Mike Ryba in the fifth inning.

The rise of $140,000,000 in excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday in the weekly statement was a direct outcome of the use by the Treasury of the proceeds of its $300,000,000 of "desterilized" gold to redeem maturing Treasury bills. It lifted total excess reserves

Two deputy controllers of the United States Department of Internal Revenue were arrested on charges of extortion yesterday after they were alleged to have accepted $100 from a bar proprietor in a hallway on Third Avenue.

Senior judges of the ten Federal judicial circuits met today with Chief Justice Hughes to talk over the problems of their respective jurisdictions. The judicial conference, an annual affair, will continue through Saturday. A report will be made by the Chief Justice next week.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 21: Bunkley, Comdr. J. W.. Buenos Aires. to Naval Operations, Washington, D. C. Keaney, Comdr. F. P., Med. Corps, Philadelhia, Pa to the San Franciscon.

The New Democracy, a liberal and critical monthly magazine, of which Representative William I. Sirovich will be an editor, will be published by the Paul J. Swift Publishers, Inc., 521 Fifth Avenue, beginning Dec. 1, 1937, it was announced yesterday.

A trio of Washington rookies combined today to give the Senators a 3-to-2 victory over Cleveland that sent the Indians down into the second division. Joe Krakauskas, recently imported from Trenton of the New YorkPenn League, reeled off his third victory in four major league pitching starts.

The Federated Malay States Government has announced duty reductions on foodstuffs and other products, the Commerce Department revealed today. The chief items affected are sugar, butter, milk, fish, kerosene, electric torches,

Though the increase in farm income from July to August was less than seasonal, income from farm marketing in August was $131,000,000 higher than a year earlier, it was reported today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

German sailors came to the help of British tars in a fight with Italian sailors and Italian residents at Palma, Majorca, last week, it was learned today. A cabaret was wrecked during the disturbance. It ended when British patrols were rushed ashore.

Chinese troops west of Shanghai began some sort of movement in the rear of the fighting front last night, which continued until daylight this morning. Large forces hurried toward Kungshan, about thirty-five miles west of Shanghai. [Soochow is about forty-five miles west of Shanghai.]

Charles H. Tuttle, chairman of the City College administrative committee of the Board of Higher Education, addressing 1,000 freshmen at City College yesterday, condemned star chamber proceedings and declared that the faces of judges must not be hidden "behind stone walls, closed doors or garments, be they bed sheets or otherwise."

Speaking before the Danbury Lions Club today, Roger Burlingame, author, attacked the plan of the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company to convert the Saugatuck River Valley into a watershed for the city of Bridgeport.
Graduating exercises for fortytwo students of the School of Nursing of St. Vincent's Hospital were held last evening in the auditorium of the nurses' residence, 158 West Twelfth Street.

Restraining orders issued by Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer blocked the election of Democratic leaders in three Manhattan assembly districts last night. The orders were issued after charges of fraud had been filed with the court. As a result of the judicial action only one new district leader was seated last night. He was Dr. Paul Santangelo, who defeated Joseph A.

Mrs. Caroline Miller, Georgia novelist who won the Pulitzer prize in 1934 with her book "Lamb in His Bosom," was married to Clyde H. Ray Jr. of Waynesville, N. C., here today. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. J. 0. J. Taylor, pastor of Trinity Methodist Church of Waycross, at the home of Mrs. D. J. Lott, a sister of the bride.
Temple University open its football season against Virginia Military Institute at the Owls Stadium tomorrow night. Only two veterans,

Secretary Morgenthau said today that he would meet on Wednesday with the executive committee of the Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve Board to discuss the advisibility of substituting another form of security for the 273-day Treasury bills that now are being marketed weekly to meet maturin bill issues.
Substantial reductions in Mediterranean shipping insurance rates were made by underwriters today as a result of the operation of the Nyon agreement for patrolling the main routes. No change was made,

In the Political Commission of the League of Nations today, Eamon de Valera, Irish Free State President, raised the only European voice against Britain's Palestine partition policy. What he said is recounted in the official minutes as follows:

Foreign Minister Koki Hirota's reply to the note from Cordell Hull, United States Secretary of State, protesting the Nanking bombings will be sent this week, Foreign Office spokesman stated today. As an outline of the Japanese Government's policy on which the reply will be based, he read the following statement:

In a report of a broadcast by Hallett Abend, Shanghai correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, he was misquoted in its columns yesterday. As his remarks were transcribed he was made to predict "the victor will not be too ungenerous" and "the final terms of peace will be so sane that the like of what is going on now will not recur again."

Twelve hundred excited boys and girls, substituting the thrill of a waterfront voyage for the staidness of their classrooms, studied civics and government-interspersed with such extra-curricular activities as dancing and singing-from the deck of a municipal ferryboat as the first in a series of experimental tours around Manhattan began yesterday.

A special meeting of stockholders of the American Cyanamid Company has been called for Oct. 4 to consider a proposal to authorize 2,500,000 shares of new 5 per cent $10-par cumulative preferred stock, convertible into Class B common stock, and an increase in authorized Class B stock from 3,000,000 to 3,620,000 shares.

Intensive experiments with television out-of-doors, including pickups from football games and other sports, parades and various activities, will begin here next month, according to an announcement yesterday by Lenox R. Lohr, president of the National Broadcasting Company.

Trading in September corn futures on the Board of Trade here today was relatively light, the price fluctuating rapidly within a range of 3 1/4 cents a bushel, touching $1.14 3/4 at the extreme, at which figure brokers who frequently act for the leading long appeared to be plentifully supplied with selling orders.

American Legion officials officially thanked 400 Boy Scouts from the Manhattan Council yesterday for their assistance to the visitors. From their information headquarters at 20 West Fortieth Street the officials denied reports that the youngsters had been detailed to attend intoxicated Legionnaires.

Advocating a middle of the road policy in banking, Leo T. Crowley of Washington, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, in an address at the final session of the annual convention of the Kentucky State Bankers Association here today, said that unregulated and individualized pursuit of the banking business ends disasterously.
Panama Al Brown knocked out Maurice Huguenin of France in the third round to win the International Boxing Union's featherweight championship at the Salle Wagram tonight. It was the second

One world titleholder fell by the wayside in the excess of flying fists that was the Carnival of Champions last night at the Polo Grounds, European titleholder suffered a knockout in his American debut, and two world champions retained their crowns while a crowd of 35,000 men and women thrilled to a night of fighting that has had no parallel in the long history of the ring sport.

By coming within four strokes of men's par with a 39 on the first nine holes of the Whippoorwill Golf Club course today in spite of a 7 on the 542-yard No. 7 hole, Mrs. Edward Stevens of the Round Hill Club, Greenwich, annexed low gross honors in the regular one-day meeting of the members of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association.

Although lumber production increased last week, the daily average was lower. However, the decline was smaller than allowed for seasonally, and the adjusted index has moved up to 86.1 from 83.4. It stood at 88.2 for the week ended Sept. 19, 1936.

Straining every muscle, B. M. Byers's Thorson lasted to win by a head from A. G. Vanderbilt's Chanceview in the annual running of the Penn Athletic Club Handicap, a glorified $1,200 race that featured the program today. The rivals clashed midway of the stretch run and battled on to the wire ahead of Giant Killer from the Millsdale Stable.

Joseph P. Day, Inc., reports the sale of homes in Brooklyn to Jack Fisher at 399 East Forty-sixth Street; to Kenneth Rahn, at 1,337 East Ninety-first Street; to William Lieblein, at 1,176 East Tenth Street.

Many of the business leases announced yesterday were for entire floors. Among them was a contract with S. H. Kress Co., which took the ninth floor in 114 Fifth Avenue, thus making fourteen floors occupied by this company in the building. The lease was made for the
William H..Matthews, retired chief of the local Fire Department and of that at Greystone Park in Morris Plains, N. J., died last night of a heart attack at his home here. His age was 80.

Murry Goldstein, 35 years old, a diamond merchant of 66 Bowery, was found semi-conscious in the third floor hallway at 295 Fifth Avenue at 2:15 P. M. yesterday, muttering incoherently that he had been robbed of about $700 in cash and a quantity of uncut diamonds.

Announcement has been made here by Dr. and Mrs. John C. Phillips of Wenham, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nina Phillips, to Stanley Washburn Jr., son of Colonel and Mrs. Stanley Washburn of Minneapolis.

Miss Juliette Curry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Curry, of this place was married to Farnsworth Chapin of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Chapin of Mount Vernon, N. Y., tonight in the Hitchcock Memorial Church, Scarsdale, N. Y. The Rev. George Smythe performed the ceremony.

The Com monwealth Edison Company today made formal offer to the stockholders of the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois for an exchange of securities under the plan of financial consolidation proved earlier by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

To the Editor of The New York Times: No liberal American who heard or has read President Roosevelt's address on the Constitution can fail to agree with most of the general principles and objectives enunciated therein.

From a hideaway in New Jersey, Allen Boretz, co-author with John Murray of "Room Service," reports himself working on a tolerably full schedule that includes at least one new title. The new one: "False Faces," now in synopsis form from which it should emerge as a play by next March.

The Utilities Power and Light Corporation in a letter to all classes of security holders yesterday gave notice that previous notices calling for the filing of claims should be disregarded. The company,

Perfect weather greeted the second day of the forty-first annual Bryn Mawr Horse Show. Close competition in the various classes was the rule, morning and afternoon. Mrs. O. V. Whitney's gray gelding Lincoln topped a select field of jumpers in the Knockdown-andOut Stake. This event, open to all, was decided by the most jumps without a knockdown.
The field of candidates in New Jersey's Gubernatorial contest in November was reduced to nine today by the withdrawal of one of the two Moores.

Charles J. Lundgren, a dentist in Brooklyn for almost fifty years, died yesterday of bronchial pneumonia at his home in Garden City, L. I. Next Wednesday he would have celebrated his seventy-fourth birthday and his golden wedding.

The two-story business building at 301-303 East Fordham Road, near Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, has been sold by Martin H. Lemaire to the Fork Realty Company through John J. Reynolds, broker. The Maurice Miller estate has a lease on the property running until 1950.

Miss Rose Rothenberg, co-leader of the south half of the Seventeenth Assembly District, Manhattan, since 1918, was unexpectedly deposed last night at a meeting of the district county committee at the clubhouse of her leader, Isidor J. Greenberg, 74 West 114th Street.

Houses in Harlem proved attractive to investors in deals announced yesterday. Some of the properties were held by banks. The United States Trust Company sold to an investing client of Arthur L. Dryfoos, broker, the five-story tenement on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 2,899 Eighth Avenue. The house was renovated recently.

Mrs. Addie M. Miller has announced the marriage of her daughter, Miss Bessie L. Miller, to Oliver B. Ellsworth, which took place at Clayville, N. Y., yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Rev. F. L. Anthony, pastor of the First Methodist Church.
Britain rejoiced briefly today at a report that the missing America's Cup yacht Endeavour I had been sighted off the Azores, only to have her joy dashed by word that the story was untrue.

The beautifully fashioned football team that put Dartmouth back up among the football powers last Fall is now but a skeleton. After as heavy an exodus of varsity material as any C college in the East has known this year, the Green launches a new campaign with one of the least-experienced squads in its section.

Fired by the flaming spirit of sandy-haired Jimmy Ripple and a brief but supreme pitching effort by their lanky and seemingly inexhaustible Cliff Melton, the Giants today fastened what is practically a strangle hold on the National League pennant by wrenching the series final from the Cubs in an exciting struggle by a score of 8 to 7.

During the week ended Sept. 22 member bank reserve balances increased $112,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from a decrease of $25,000,000 in money in circulation and $155,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and an increase of $3,000,000 in Treasury currency, offset in part by an increase of $49,-

Apparel manufacturers were reported yesterday to have bought heavily of percales in the last few days, but virtually all of the covering has been against immediate needs. Large producers were said to have booked a volume ranging from 500,000 to 1,500,000 yards daily this week, although usually in individual lots averaging not much better than 60,000 yards.
A request from President Roosevelt for aid in the fight on unemployment was received yesterday by the soberly alert group of 1,300 men and women that runs the American Legion.

The Meadow Brook hounds of New York, with Harry T. Peters and Harvey D. Gibson as masters, took the major honors in the secondday program of the twenty-first annual Bryn Mawr hound show held on the polo field today.

Common stockholders of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company subscribed to about $18,278,000 of the $25,321,500 offering of fifteen-year 4 per cent convertible sinking fund debentures, subject to possible acceptance of belated subscriptions if any are received by the close of business today, it was an- increase nounced yesterday by Hayden, 500,000 Stone Co., heading the underwriting group.
BLOW YE WINDS, a comedy in three acts and eight scenes, by Valentine Davies. Settings by Cirker Robbins; staged and produced by Arthur Hopkins. At the Forty-sixth Street Theatre.

Some of us in recent years have grown skittish about "plans." So often, as in Russia, they seem to wind up with people getting shot for offenses which in this country would merely cause them to be fired, or, as in Germany and Italy, they point toward war.

Since the week ended on July 10, the market for stocks on the New York Stock Exchange has had seventeen upward movements, when more issues gained than lost. Nine of these rises lasted a single day, six for two days and two for three days. Since July 10, therefore,

Louis C. Doremus of Garden City, L. I., a salesman for a St. Louis company, died of a heart attack today in St. Luke's Hospital after he collapsed on a Chicago-bound train near Gary, Ind. His age was 61.

Solemn but brief ceremony characterized the closing hours yesterday of the convention of the American Legion Auxiliary at the Hotel Astor, where Mrs. Malcolm Douglas was elected by acclamation and installed as president to succeed Mrs. Oscar W. Hahn of Lincoln, Neb. Withdrawal of her only opponent, Mrs. A. H. Hoffman of Des Moines, Iowa, made possible her unanimous selection.

Mrs. Margaret Chapin Vurgason, wife of John M. Vurgason and a daughter of Henry Sterling Chapin, president of the Educational Foundations, Inc., in which she held the position of vice president, died on Tuesday in the Jewish Hospital, after a brief illness.

A new Jack Holt action melodrama, "Outlaws of the Orient," featuring Mae Clarke, Harold Huber and James Bush, will open at the Rialto this morning.... The newcomer at the Palace today is "Hideaway," with Fred Stone, Emma Dunn and Marjorie Lord ....
Leading Argentine polo players will lend nineteen ponies for the use of the Aurora team which is coming here from the United States to particiPate in the Argentine championship tournament.
Japan's air forces today carried their campaign of death and terror to a score or more cities throughout nearly all of Eastern China.

Like his predecessor, General Alexander Koutiepoff, who disappeared out of the center of Paris one morning about seven years ago, General Eugene Miller, head of the White Russian war veterans, disappeared yesterday in circumstances almost more mysterious.

A warning to exporters that the good volume of orders they are now enjoying from Europe must be considered as "spot" business which may disappear in 1938 or the year after, depending upon developments there, was given yesterday by R. C. Thompson, president of the Overseas Automotive Club, Inc., in an address at the organization's first Fall meeting in the McGraw-Hill Building.
The Newark Bears moved within one game of clinching the International League final play-off series tonight by beating Baltimore, 7 to 5, for their third straight victory in the best-of-seven series.

Officials of the National Polo Pony Society, whose annual show is to be held at the Meadow Brook Club tomorrow, announced tonight that an entry of 100 had been received for the six classes. The list includes some of the most famous ponies

Tentative discussion of American claims involving $30,000,000 to $50,000,000 in commercial balances tied up in Spain since before the outbreak of the revolution there has been set with the National Foreign Trade Council for today by Miles M. Sherover, president of the Hanover Sales Corporation, representing Spanish Loyalist Government interests in the negotiations, it was announced yesterday.

Tournament-tempered Tony Manero from near-by Salem, 1936 national open champion, birdied two of the last three holes of his second qualifying round for a two-under-par 69 today to gain the $250 medalist prize in the $12,000 Belmont open match play golf tournament. He posted 140 for the thirty-six holes.

The Tunis shooting affray on Monday between Italian sailors and anti-Fascist political refugees, in which one person was killed and three were wounded, led today to action by the French Charge d'Affaires. He called on Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano and, after having presented the French version, asked reparation and punishment of those guilty.

A seasonal increase in cash requirements throughout the country was reflected in the weekly statement of the Bank of Canada for Sept. 22, issued today. Note circulation increased more than $3,500,000 in the week.

No damage was done to foreign property in the bombing of Nanking Wednesday except for the sinking of a ferry boat belonging to a British company, according to Japanese reports. The Navy Department's official account states that thrice Wednesday naval aircraft attacked Nanking. The places bombed are

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted to be at the highest point of the year to date. Total gold holdings were unchanged from last week, when they reached a new high figure for the year.

The Newark Tornadoes defeated the Brooklyn Eagles tonight, 21 to 0. in a professional football game. The home team scored a touchdown in the first three quarters. Rudy Choborda, Joe Demyanovich and Turk Schumell scored for Newark in that order. Points were added by Ray Vaniewski, Arnie Truex and Demyanovich.

Mrs. Florence Pratt Scull, wife of William Ellis Scull, former vice president of the Winston Company, died last night in Bryn Mawr at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Alexander Biddle. She was in her late seventies.
It is going to be a tough Winter, with plenty of snow, in the opinion of E. B. Rideout, who was formerly with the United States Weather Bureau.

Mr. and Mrs. F. Cecil Baker gave a tea yesterday in their penthouse apartment at 433 East Fifty-first Street for their debutante niece, Miss Reid Handy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Truman P. Handy. Miss Handy was introduced formally to society at a tea dance given for her by her parents on June 19 in the garden of their estate in Riverdaleon-Hudson.

Germany briefly notified Joseph A. C. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, today of its refusal of the League's invitation to participate in the Far Eastern Advisory Committee, not explaining why. There is reason to believe, however, that Germany, which has very great material interests in China, took pains today to explain

Despite protests of the United States and Britain against aerial bombings of civilians the Japanese sent fleets of planes over a score or more of cities in Eastern China. Canton reported more than 2,000 dead or wounded in two days. Nanking was spared, but planes visited forts up the Yangtze. Ambassador Johnson remained at the capital and had no intention of leaving. [Page 1.]

To express their "gratitude for the consideration shown labor," members of Local 337 of the International Association of OilWorkers tendered a dinner here tonight to Alexander Weinstein and Frank R. Calgano, trustees in bankruptcy under Section 77b who have just completed a reorganization of the Warner Quinian Company.

Although unable to clinch the pennant through their own efforts at the Stadium, the Yankees yesterday retained the American League flag as one of their former teammates, Ben Chapman, up in Boston, blasted the faint hopes of the second-place Tigers.

Justices Leon C. Rhodes of this city and James P. Hill of Norwich, Republicans, were renominated today for another fourteen-year term on the Supreme Court by both the Republican and Democratic Sixth Judicial District conventions. Democratic endorsement of Mr. Hill, Presiding Justice

Because of the damage to animal hides inflicted by barbed wire for pastures the Province of Buenos Aires, Argentina'?? largest cattle-raising area, may pass legislation prohibiting or strictly limiting the use of barbed wire, the Commerce Department disclosed today.

Mrs. Mary Bella Von Rosen Houk, widow of Judge Leonidas Campbell Houk, died yesterday of a heart attack at her home, The Pines, Fishkill-on-Hudson, N. Y. Judge Houk was a member of the Supreme Court of Tennessee. For many years he was a Congressional Representative from Tennessee.

President Roosevelt, on his "intake tour" of the country, will find that Wyoming, the first State in which he speaks, is for him just as it was last Election Day, when he carried this once Republican stronghold 62,000 to 38,000. At the same time,

A plan of recapitalization has been mailed to stockholders of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation under which the present series A 6% per cent cumulative preferred stock would be redesignated as 5 per cent preferred stock.

Substantially increased in size and with allsteel bodies, the Packard eight, formerly known as the one-twenty, and the Packard six for 1938 were unveiled at a newspaper preview here today. At the same time the

A Netherland commercial center will be opened in New York, according to the preamble of the budget which was published yesterday. In 1938 the Government will contribute 25,000 florins toward the building, after which the American Netherlands Chamber of Commerce and the Dutch East Indies will share in the expenses.

Dolph Camilli's home run in the third and three ninth-inning doubles gave Philadelphia a 9-to-5 victory over the Reds today in the last game between the two clubs this season. Trying vainly to stem a free-hitting attack, Acting Manager Bob Wallace sent twenty-two men into the Reds' line-up-a record for the club this year.

A committee comprising about fifty leaders in the garment, resident office and retail fields was organized at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor yesterday to arrange for a testimonial dinner to John Block of Kirby, Block Co., veteran resident buyer, to be held Sunday evening, Oct. 31, at that hotel.

KINGS BORCHARDT, LOUISE (May 9, 1937). Gross assets, $14.061; net, $13.012. To daughter, Irma M. Borchardt, and son, Albert H. Borchardt, one-half of residuary estate each. Chief assets, real estate, $13,000; miscellaneous property. $1.061. Edward H. Wilson, attorney,
The Treasury awarded today a $3,249,500 contract to McCloskey Co. of Philadelphia for construction of a new Federal court house in that city. The company was the

Check transactions for the week ended on Wednesday rose to the highest total since the week of May 5 and were 22.5 per cent in exce`s of the corresponding period last year. The increase was attributed to middle-of-the-month settlements which were not included in the same week of 1936.

Crow meat--canned for the first time-will make its bid for a place on the American dinner table at a meeting of food experts who will attend the Canned Foods Marketing Conference called by the Independent Grocers Alliance of America, to be held next week here.

The Mexican Government announced its intention today to make peace with General Saturnino Cedillo, who heads the last privately-controlled army in Mexico, after efforts to force him to go abroad or report to Mexico City for military duty had failed.

Manhattan's football squad engaged Columbia in a two-and-ahalf-hour scrimmage at Baker Field yesterday as the Jaspers made ready for their opening game against St. Bonaventure tomorrow at Ebbets Field. The scrimmage was spiritedly waged under normal game conditions, except that there were no pauses between periods and no score was kept.

Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, an opponent of President Roosevelt's Supreme Court reorganization plan, said late today he had not received an invitation to accompany the President on his trip through the State. He added that he was "happy" the President would visit Cheyenne tomorrow morning, saying:

Ben Chapman's ninth-inning homer off Eldon Auker today gave the Red Sox a 4-to-3 victory over Detroit and ended the American League pennant race, with the New York Yankees mathematically certain of the flag.

The general indignation in Finland over the wholesale flights of Soviet army airplanes far into Finnish territory has intensified since some of the planes flew over an important Finnish fortified area between Leningrad and Wiborg.

The underlying trend in European diplomacy is unquestionably toward a four-Power Western pact. Despite the profound differences which separate Great Britain and France from Italy and Germany and the considerable divergences of policy which persist between London and Paris and between Berlin and Rome, the two democracies

Dr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Sullivan of 375 Park Avenue will give a supper dance to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Katherine G. Sullivan, on Jan. 1 at Sherry's. Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hoving have left Southampton and are now at Hillside Farm, Syosset, L. I.

Legionnaires apparently like not only parades but fishing, too. In an afternoon chat, Walter Willis, chief of the fishing information bureau in Pennsylvania Station, had been relating some of his early history as a commercial fisherman, of the first sword fish he harpooned off Montauk, and of many experiences that made the hustle of the station outside his office door seem remote.

Miss Gertrude O'Keefe, prim-appearing, slightly built 37-year-old stenographer, was arraigned yesterday in felony court in Brooklyn, charged with the killing of her former fiance, George 0. Frank, New York Stock Exchange teller.

Samuel Seabury, whose Investigation of the Walker Administration was one of the major factors in Mayor La Guardia's election in 1933, called last night for the election of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey as District Attorney of New York County to free that office from Tammany Hall, rid the county of racketeers and complete the victory of good government in New York.
Wilhelm Furtwaengler, one of the greatest Teutonic conductors alive, may stay away from Salzburg's famous festival next Summer because of a quarrel with Arturo Toscanini.

Jim Turner chalked up his nineteenth victory of the season as the Boston Bees capitalized on loose base running by the Pirates today and eked out a 2-to-1 victory. Paul Waner, hard-hitting Buc, was nailed at third in the fourth inning in an attempt to speed from first on a sharp single to right.

A decree confirming the plan of reorganization of the Louisiana Oil Refining Corporation was entered at the end of last week by the Federal Court in Shreveport, La., providing that all property, assets, rights and franchises of the company and its subsidiary will be conveyed to the Arkansas Fuel Oil

Richard H. Kirkpatrick, 40 years old, a $3,000 clerk for the local branch of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, who was authorized to trade annually in millions of dollars in bonds, was arrested yesterday in District Attorney Dodge's office on forgery charges involving the alleged loss of at least $100,000 to the institution since last March.

Two British officials of the Fiji Government service are now en route to Canton Island, where they will establish permanent quarters on the coral atoll which Britain and the United States recently discovered to be of immense value as a base for transpacific flying service.
Dr. Fritz von Briesen and Nelson Littell, New York lawyers, have been elected members of the National Alumni Council of the George Washington University here.
The following Marine Corps changes were announced today, dated Sept. 20: Mixson, Major J. A., Quantico, Va., to Headquarters, Dept. of Pacific, San Francisco, Calif. orders to Shanghai revoked.

Officials of the United States Lines have virtually decided to accept the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company's bid of $15,750,000 for the construction of a new passenger and freight ship, it was learned yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Hambleton Symington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Symington, of Tallwood, Green Spring Valley, to Lawrence Perin, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Perin, took place this afternoon in Grace and St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church.

Two new liners-one of them the largest built in Britain since the Queen Marywere launched today to provide quicker and more comfortable communication between the mother country and the self-governing dominions.

J. F. Cade. in the Witmer Russell residence on Oaldhurst Rd, Shore Acres. Mamaroneck, Westchester; Edward W. Lewis, the Anna Lennig residence on Melbourne Ave, Mamaroneck; Peter C. Doern Jr.; Inc, broker.

One more problem in international law arrived from Spain today when General Francisco Franco, leader of the Insurgents, renewed his request for permission to establish consulates in the United Kingdom.

Four hundred recipients of home relief in New York City will start a four-month course in vocational schools next Monday in a common effort by branches of the Federal, State and municipal governments to retrain them for jobs in private industry and concurrently reduce relief costs.

5th Ave (16-4683-4783). n e cor Briggs St. 56x100; also Eastchester Rd. e s, 395 ft' s of Adee Ave. 43x100; Madelina Cataldi to William Vitarelli, 114 Morningside Drive. Bay View Ave (18-5417), e s, 150 ft s of Ampere Ave. 50x100; Kasper Reheuser to Lisa Mingeram, 3,254 Lucerne St.

Following a trend evident for some time, German exports of silk and rayon gloves to the United States declined sharply to only one metric ton during the first six months of 1937, the Commerce Department announced today.
Carrie Northey, known on the stage as Caro Roma, who composed the song "Can't You Hear Me Calling, Caroline," died here today at the age of 72.

Harvard's hardest and most satisfactory scrimmage of the Fall season was held today. Coach Dick Harlow worked his first and second varsities against third and fourth-team combinations. Line plays were stressed, signals being called in the huddle by the head coach himself.

A summary of registration statements made effective in August under the Securities Act of 1933 was issued today by the Securities and Ex $60,268,000, or 35 per cent of the securities to be offered for cash sale, was intended for new money purposes, including $21,003,000, or 12.2 per cent, for plant and equipment and $39,265,000, or 22.8 per cent, for additional working capital.

Samuel Van Saun Muzzy, retired merchant, died at his home here today after an illness of five days. He was 84 years old. Formerly dealing in mill supplies and seeds, Mr. Muzzy was active until recently in military circles. He was a colonel in the New Jersey National Guard.

Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, announced today he would take part of a six-months' leave of absence granted to him last Spring by the university board of trustees and named an administrative committee to assume his duties while he is gone. Dr. and Mrs. Clothier will

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition Filed-By ANNA BARGER, doing business as Edgar's Bird Store, 3,633 _3d Ave.-Liabllitles $1,764: assets $1,000, exclusive of insurance. DAVID A. BANKS, chauffeur, 105 Fulton Ave., Mount Venon.-Liabilities $662; assets $2,64. ANITA H. CARLSON, technician, 121 E. 31st St.-Liabilitles $648; no assets.

With low clouds blanketing the lower Yangtze Valley and rain at many points, Nanking was spared from a Japanese air bombardment yesterday. The city's essential public services--water, power, posts, telephones, telegraphs and buses-are functioning almost normally again, with most of the evidences of Wednesday's bombing removed.
Whit Burnett, author and editor, will conduct an advanced seminar in short-story writing at Columbia University Extension this year, Dr. James C. Egbert, extension director, announced yesterday.

Veterans who served ,with the 306th Infantry in France renewed old friendships and talked over old times last night at the regiment's twentieth annual reunion at the Manhattan Opera House. The reunion was under the auspices of the 306th Infantry Association.

A former call-boy, W. M. Jeffers was elected yesterday president of the Union Pacific Railroad to succeed Carl R. Gray. He was the first Union Pacific employee to rise from the train yards to this position. A call-boy's duty is to locate engine and train crews when they are expected to serve on trains for which they have not received previous notice.

Robert Quinn, the 17-year-old cadet who was rushed from the United States training ship Annapolis more than 300 miles away to a hospital here aboard the British cruiser Orion, is still in danger after an operation for appendicitis.

ANSTETT-Henrietta, Sept. 23, wife of Alfred Anstett, devoted mother of Edna Boscowitz and Mildred Anstett, sister of Helena Just. Services 8 P. M., Saturday, at Walter B. Cooke, Inc.. Funeral Home, 1 West 190th St. Funeral 2 P. M. Sunday.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Esther Wallace, daughter of Mrs. A. Ramsey Wallace of Flushing and of the late Mr. Wallace, stage and screen actor, to Richard Dudgeon Kohler of Glen Cove, L. I., took place yesterday afternoon in the offices of The Churchman at 425 Fourth Avenue.

Lafayette College has received an ananonymous gift of $20,000 from a friend to enlarge the Van Wickle Library building. The gift is in connection with the "Decade of Progress" fund, which now totals $151,000.

Mrs. Matthew J. Looram of this city and Great Barrington, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Constance Peabody Looram, to Theodore P. Dixon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dixon of New York and Sag Harbor, L. I.

The big parade gets under way today. Some 300 college football teams, weeks of arduous training behind them, will open their seasons in grandiose style, and before another fortnight has passed the national madness will have gripped the nation in earnest.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine said yesterday that the hundred picked detectives searching for the three hold-up men who fatally wounded Patrolman John H. A. Wilson Thursday afternoon as he sought to frustrate the robbery of a gold refining shop in Fulton Street were "working on something that looks very good."

David Lazarus, the 81-year-old former Tammany district leader of the Sixth Assembly District, abandoned yesterday his court fight to prevent Sol Eisler, winner of a primary fight for the district leadership, from taking his place on the Tammany executive committee. Mr. Eisler had been elected Thursday night as successor to Mr. Lazarus, despite a court order staying a meeting of the county committeemen of the district.

The American Newspaper Guild announced yesterday that it had petitioned the National Labor Relations Board to conduct collective bargaining elections for employes other than telegraphers, in the Washington, Philadelphia, and Boston offices of The Associated Press.

Mrs. Margaret Mary Kiernan of 23 Pleasant Place, Brooklyn, died at her home last night after an illness of a year at the age of 66. She was the mother of twenty children, of whom twelve, seven sons and five daughters, survive, as do thirty-two grandchildren.

Winding up the outboard racing season in the same victorious style that has kept him in front of all amateurs and pros in the point scoring this Summer, Douglass C. Fonda of Orange, N. J., had another sensational afternoon in the final major regatta of 1937.

Horse lovers and members of society from New York and Long Island will gather on the estate of F. Ambrose Clark at Westbury, L. I., today to witness the thirtyninth running of the famed Meadow Brook Cup, oldest hunts race in this country.

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended Aug. 31, issued for publication today, shows a net income, after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes, amortization and other expenses and charges, of $8,461,894, as compared with a net of $6,687,598 in the twelve months to Aug. 31, 1936, an increase of $1,774,296.
Four successive errors and five hits gave the Pirates six runs in the sixth inning today and sent them on to an 8-to-2 victory in a series opener with the Reds.

ABOUT two years ago the miracle of Robert Briffault's "Europa" became known-a miracle not in that "Europa" was a great novel, which it wasn't, but in that a distinguished anthropologist and scholar living in relative obscurity and something like poverty became suddenly famous as the author of a best-selling work of fiction.
