Miss Silvia Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kingdom Gould, and Charles Dabney Thomson, whose engagement was announced recently, were guests of honor at a reception and tea given by Gavin Welby yesterday afternoon in his apartment at 310 East Forty-fourth Street.
Governor Miller, Governor Ammons of Colorado, and I think I can say my old friends of Cheyenne-because, as you know, since 1932 Cheyenne has been on my annual visiting list:

Immediate litigation to determine whether State and local housing authorities may constitutionally assume obligations under the Wagner Housing Act met with the apparent approval today of the American Federation of Housing Authorities.

Jean La Guardia, 9-year-old daughter of Mayor La Guardia, paid a visit to City Hall yesterday with a dozen of her fourth-grade classmates in Horace Mann School and saw her father conduct a Board of Estimate meeting.

Driven by 11-year-old Alma Sheppard, the Hanover Farm's Dean Hanover established a world mile record for three-year-old trotters of 1:58 1/2 today in an exhibition race at the opening of the sixtyfifth annual meeting of the Grand Circuit.
The new security market again failed this week to lift itself out of its prolonged period of inactivity and a total of only $3,278,000 in new bond issues was offered for public subscription.
Miss Mary Dimon Francis of Brooklyn was married today to, Otis Cook Stanton of New York at, the Summer home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Witherbee Francis.

Work on about forty-five WPA projects was delayed and idleness was forced upon several thousand relief workers on WPA rolls yesterday when 450 workers, members of American Federation of Labor unions, began a strike against about twenty-five contractors under contract with the WPA on park, highway and sewer construction jobs.

Cotton-mill activity increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index has advanced to 133.0 from 125.1, the revised figure for the previous week. It was 134.0 for the week ended Sept. 19, 1936.
Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey announced yesterday the arrest in Los Angeles of Max Silverman, a top flight racketeer who has been a fugitive from New York twenty-one months.

Gustavus T. Kirby has sold a tract of fifteen acres on Guard Hill in Mount Kisco, Westchester, to a client of Holbrook B. Cushman. The buyer plans immediately to begin the construction of a twenty-tworoom residence from plans by William E. Shepherd of New Yorkh City.

Miss Alice Marble, former U. S. women's singles tennis champion, and Miss Gracyn Wheeler of Santa Monica won their way today into the final of the Pacific Southwest tennis championships. Avenging a defeat at Forest Hills, Miss Marble downed Miss Dorothy Bundy of Santa Monica, 2-6, 6-0, 6-4.

The leading foreign exchanges strengthened yesterday in terms of the dollar in response to the recall from this market of funds realized from the selling of securities by foreigners. An exception to the trend among the European units was provided by the belga, which continued to weaken, and the Far Eastern exchanges were all lower, despite the rise of sterling, which most of them usually follow.

The mystery of the disappearance of the yacht Endeavour I remained as deep as ever today while Lloyd's tried to trace the false report, given out yesterday, that she had been sightse ed off the Azores.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., announced yesterday that holders of more than two-thirds of the outstanding preferred shares of its affiliate, the New York Steam Corporation, had accepted the plan of exchange for the $5 preferred stock of the parent company and that the plan would become effective today.

Conferences and meetings were in progress last night in attempts to obtain endorsements by the American Labor party of candidates for delegates to the constitutional convention and of Supreme Court Justices who are or will be candidates on the Republican ticket.

Too big to go through the doors on of the Seventy-first Regiment thi Armory at Thirty-fourth Street Do and Park Avenue, a four-room, onestory bungalow on wheels-the largest trailer to be shown at New York's first all-trailer show-was put on exhibition yesterday at the curb outside the armory.

Traffic on the Central Railroad of New Jersey is running about 1.5 per cent ahead of the level a year ago and about 4 per cent ahead of that in August, E. M. Scheer, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting in Jersey City. Including special deposits, the company has about $6,200,000 in cash, he added.

Transfers and Asslgnments PATROLMEN-James T. Mackay, front Mounted Squadron 2 to 79th Precinct. a.i signment to mounted duty discontinued. From precincts indicated to 18th Division, designated as third grade detectives: Thomas B. Clarke 17 J. F. Finnerty... 18. Temporary Assignment PATROLMAN-Daniel Linker, from 30th Precinct to 3d Division, assigned to duty th plain clothes, for 15 days.

With farmers everywhere calling for help, there is no excuse for an ablebodied man on relief to be out of a job, according to Municipal Judge Calvin Stewart. Elmer Ruffalo, 22 years old, brought before the judge yesterday

Daily average sales of retailers in small towns and rural areas gained about 12 per cent in the Far West in August over the same month in 1936, a gain of 2 per cent in the Middle West, and practically no change in the Eastern and Southern areas, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce reported today.

Vittorio Mussolini, son of the Italian Premier, left Newark airport at 6:04 P. M., daylight saving time, today for Los Angeles, aboard the T. W. A. plane Sky Chief. He is due to arrive in Los Angeles at 7:04 A. M., Pacific Coast time.

Mr. and Mrs. Diederich H. Ward of Brooklands, this place, gave a supper dance tonight at the Lawrence Farms Golf Club, Mount Kisco, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie Ward, to William Winton Goodrich Rossiter Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William W. G. Rossiter, also of Bronxville.

Notice Deputy Chiefs shall grant leaves of absence, without unnecessary delay, to officers, members and probationary firemen to reimburse them for time lost in connection with the drills and presentation of "The Midnight Alarm." A record to be made in company journal of all such leaves granted.
Bucknell battered its way to a 21-0 victory over Ursinus in its opening football game in Memorial Stadium tonight.

Miss Virginia Holloway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Harry Holloway of this place, was married here tonight in the Presbyterian Church to James Wadsworth Furbee, son of Mrs. Truman A. Furbee of Clarksburg, W. Va., and the late Mr. Furbee.
Warfare's newest weapon-a mass parachute attack-was used by the Russians yesterday against a "Western invader" in the big-scale manoeuvres now in progress in the northwest a section of White Russia.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "For the time being, at least, there is a better sentiment in the wool market. Foreign markets appear to have established a working basis at the lower levels and there is a better feeling in consequence in this market.

After two brokers and the employe of another brokerage firm had been held yesterday in $5,000 bail each in Felony Court in the alleged larceny of $86,000 in bonds, Assistant Attorney General Ambrose V. McCall obtained a Supreme Court order to place the affairs of the two brokers in the hands of a receiver.

Fishel Podliashuk, 43 years old, of 2,195 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, president of the American and Oriental Fur and Hides Export Company, Inc., was killed yesterday in a fall from the seventeenth-floor offices of the company at 247 West Thirtieth Street. His body was found in a court between two buildings.

Findlay Ave. (9-2433), n e cor of 165th St, 40x100: John Selnfeld to State Mortgage Commission; extends mtg to Oct. 1, 1938, at 41, per cent; $37,500. Westchester Ave (10-2759) s * side, at w s of New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Co, property 172x902; Waterlou trustee; extends mtg to Oct. 1, 1939, at 2 to 3 per cent; $99,500.

The Rev. Dr. Hurley D. Sheldon, in charge of open-air evangelism for the National Bible Institute, 340 West Fifty-fifth Street, submitted yesterday to that institution the annual report of his Summer's work.

Mgr. Edward P. Hoar, rector since 1931 of the Roman Catholic Seminary of the Immaculate Conception, Huntington, L. I., has been appointed vicar general of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn by Bishop Thomas E. Molloy.
The National Maritime Jnion threatened yesterday to establish its own police force to protect its agents from the attacks of members of a rival union operating on the. waterfront.

As becomes one who spends a good part of his time with a scalpel in his hand, Dr. Edward Anderson is one of the most even-dispositioned coaches in football. He brings to the gridiron the same quiet assurance that is so comforting to the patient in the operating room, and not even the advent of a crisis can shake the serenity of his approach

Only those who have lost entirely the light of day (that is, who have entered the Valley of the Shadow) since 2 A. M. of April 25, 1937, will have lost an hour of time as reckoned by clock and calendar next Sunday morning. Time offers to restore the lost hour to all who are prepared to receive it. That is, for many millions, an hour

A resolution condemning present governmental tendencies as "an intolerable infringement of the rights of minorities and a threat of intolerable tyranny through bureaucratic control" was carried yesterday by the board of governors of the Women's National Republican Club. The text was drafted and

A turning of the world tide in favor of peace, despite current conflicts in Europe and the Far East, was seen here today by speakers at the second annual Westchester County Review of the News Conference, given by THE NEW YORK TIMES. More than 1,200 clubwomen attended the sessions at the Woman's Club of New Rochelle, 50 Lockwood Avenue, and an overflow meeting in the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity next door.
Daylight-saving time ends at 2 A. M. tomorrow, when clocks are set back one hour. About 30,000,000 persons in the United States are affected by the time change, of which 10,000,000 are in New York.
The Prudential Insurance Company of America, which has its home office here, announced today several changes in the administrative personnel of its mortgage loan offices.
Mrs. Huntington Tappin will give a luncheon on Oct. 19 in the penthouse of the St. Regis for her debutante granddaughter, Miss Elise Irving van Siclen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. van Siclen.

Jose Perez Losada, Spanish colony leader, died of a heart attack late yesterday at the age of 58. Today his body reposed in the Ateneo Puerto Riqueno, of which he was an honorary member. Many stores here were closed as a respect to his memory.

The pace in the eighteen-hole sprints today was much too hot for Denny Shute, Boston's two-time Professional Golfers Association champion, and three of his Ryder Cup team-mates in the opening rounds of the $12,000 Belmont open golf match play tournament.

The debt service appropriation, the largest single item in the cost of running the city, will total $162,596,862 in the 1938 budget, according to an estimate submitted yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor to acting Budget Director Kenneth Dayton.

A. J. Sackett's Tabitha led throughout the running of the Gilmore Purse, today's feature race. The Victorian mare survived a thrilling stretch duel with Mrs. K. N. Gilpin's Buck Langhorne. Baby Talk was third, five lengths behind the first-money struggle.

A tablet in memory of Edgar Wilson (Bill) Nye was dedicated yesterday, forty-one years after the humorist's death, on the site of his birthplace in this town. Dr. Shailer Matthews of Monson, dean-emeritus of the University of Chicago Theological School, eulogized the country newspaper man, whose comic-philosophical writings made him famous.
Henry Jaworski, for many years prominent in church and fraternal circles here, died yesterday in his seventy-second year at his home, 321 Nepperhan Avenue, Yonkers.
Morris Harvey broke a losing streak that dated back to 1935 by taking a nip and tuck football game from Marietta College today, 7--6. The horne team had lost fourteen straight games in two
To the region including the western strip of Maryland, the Blue Ridge and Alleghany Ridge counties of Virginia,

Although the flow of new mortgage money into Manhattan real estate slackened somewhat last month, the increase in new financing in this borough ,or the first eight months of 1937, as compared with the same period last year, is running far ahead of the percentage gain for the country as a whole.

Premier Mussolini left for Germany at noon today aboard a special train of nine armored coaches after an enthusiastic send-off from thousands of Fascisti. He is scheduled to arrive in Munich at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning to begin his five-day German visit.

Premier Mussolini's entry into Germany, by far the most notable, the most discussed and the most carefully protected ceremonial visit in recent years, will be made here tomorrow morning. Munich is already thrilled by the mere preparations for it.

Ten scholarships, with a total value of $2,250, have been awarded by the Columbia University School of Medicine for the new academic year, Dean Willard C. Rappleye announced yesterday. The recipients and their awards are Winona M. Gould of Manchester. N. H.. $500: Vincent J. Torney
William A. Remsen, a retired carpenter and one of the oldest residents of Elmhurst, Queens, died Thursday in Flushing Hospital after a brief illness. He was 80 years old.

The State Banking Department announced today the receipt of an organization certificate of the Real Estate Trust Company of New York, which has a capital of $500,000. The incorporators include Maurice J. Moore, John A. Cunehan, George C. Meyer, Graham C. Woodruff, Peter E. Bennett,

The four-story corner apartment house at 72-06 Sixty-ninth Street, Glendale, Queens, has been sold for Realty Mortgage Servicing Company to an investing client of Hy. and D. Agar, Inc., broker. The building has accommodations for twenty-three families and there are four stores on the street level.

The appointment of Dillon F. Broderick of Lynbrook, L. I., as principal examiner in the Life Bureau of the State Insurance Department, 80 Center Street, was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance. Mr. Broderick succeeds

In the export copper market, sales were reported yesterday at 12.875 to 12.90 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports. The volume of business was exceptionally small. On Thursday, sales were made abroad at 12.95 cents. The domestic price was unchanged yesterday at 14 cents.

Statements for August issued yesterday by railroads reflected the effects of the increase in wages of 5 cents an hour granted to non-train operating employes on Aug. 1. In explaining its results for the month, the Seaboard Air Line pointed out that if wages, tax accruals and maintenance had been

A MHERST vs. Vermont-Who said that? For that matter, who said: "Lafayette, we are here"? But it was George Moore, the Irish novelist, who said: "The difficulty in life is the choice." For better or worse, one vote for Amherst.

Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti, appointed last Spring to fill out the late Judge McAvoy's term, and now a candidate for election for the full fourteen-year period, has earned the support he is receiving from a variety of groups which do not always see eye to eye in public matters.
Assistant Corporation Counsel Oliver Wendell Holmes died of a heart attack today while riding in an elevator in the City Hall. His age was 55.
Senator Burton K. Wheeler is convinced that Supreme Court enlargement is a "dead issue" as far as Congress Is concerned, but that there will be a special session in November to consider farm relief.

Miss Agnes Sylvia Breck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wesley Breck of this place, was married here tonight to Robert Wilson Blake, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Blake of New York, in the Church of the Ascension, which was founded by the bride's grandfather, the late Charles A. Breck, and of which her father and grandfather have been vestrymen for many years.

That an attempt was made last night to assassinate Lombardo Toledano, leader of the radical National Workers Confederation and often called Mexico's John L. Lewis, was charged today by his organization, the C. T. M.

The Sun announced yesterday that it had signed a contract with the newly organized Sun Editorial Employer Union, after five days of negotiation, covering working conditions for employes on the editorial payroll.

Ruth Roland, one-time "queen of the thriller serials," was buried today with a eulogy by movie director W. S. Van Dyke, who once acted in her pictures. Music was played by David Rubinoff, violinist, and Salvador Santaella, pianist, with solos by Donald Novis.

County Judge Charles S. Colden of Queens, chairman of the executive committee of the Queens College Association, yesterday accused John T. Flynn, chairman of the Queens College administrative committee, of misstating facts and resorting to personalities to becloud the issue, arising from the exclusion of 103 students from Queens College by a quota ruling.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Chase of Forest Hills, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Jane Chase, to Parmely Frederick Pritchard of 7 West Seventysecond Street, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph W. Pritchard of La Grange, Ill.

The National Industrial Advertisers' Association today concluded a three-day conference, which was termed by William B. Murphy, general chairman, as "the greatest convention of advertising executives ever held in the United States."

The arrival at Shanghai last night of 101 Americans, principally women and children, several of whom were ill, from Mokanshan, China, was reported to the State Department today by Clarence E. Gauss, the American Consul General in Shanghai.

Evidence that Mr. Roosevelt is determined to avoid any indication that this tour partakes of the nature of a reprisal against those Senators who opposed his Supreme Court program was seen today when, speaking in Wyoming, the home State of Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, he made no reference to the court.
General and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt are entertaining at Beaulieu tomorrow, the birthday anniversary of their daughter, Mrs. Vanderbilt Davis.

Peter J. Harmon, 50 years old, fireman attached to Engine Company 61 at Williamsbridge Road and Poplar Street, the Bronx, was injured fatally yesterday when he fell from the second to the main floor of the firehouse.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: With the football season just getting under way, I consider one of the chief faults of the game the toofrequent use of substitutes.
Dennis Galehouse pitched the Indians back into fourth place in the American League today by downing the Tigers, 2 to 1, in the opener of a four-game series.
Member trading in round lots for own account on the New York Stock Exchange was 20.99 per cent of total volume in the week ended on Aug. 28, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
James A. Farley is due to resign as Postmaster General to become president of the Pierce-Arrow Motor Car Company, it was disclosed here tonight.

The British Government today flashed instructions to Sir Robert L. Craigie, its Ambassador at Tokyo, to deliver a strong protest against the slaughter of innocent noncombatants in Canton and other cities in China.

Newark's Bears, "wonder team" of the minor leagues, completed a recordsmashing sweep of the International League play-offs tonight by whipping Baltimore, 10 to 7, to win the championship and qualify for the little world series against the American Association titleholder.

Electrical appliance buyers came into the market late this week seeking replacement merchandise for immediate shipment and goods for late October and early November delivery. Purchases were confined to low and medium price goods. Electric irons, percolators and toasters were favored items.
Mrs. William A. Blackman, prominent here in patriotic organizations, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital after an illness of several months.

Miss Eleanor Dommerich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Louis Dommerich of this place, was married to Robert Morris Schmeltzer, son of Mrs. John Schmeltzer, also of Greenwich, and the late Mr. Schmeltzer, here this afternoon in the garden of the Dommerich home.

The "Ada Hoffman" dahlia, a huge, orange-colored seedling dahlia in the undisseminated group, was named last night by Miss Ada Hoffman blonde-haired daughter of Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey, at the twenty-third annual dahlia show of the American Dahlia Society in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Gaining a pawn by means of energetic mid-game tactics, then conducting a difficult rook and pawn ending in faultless style, Erich Eliskases of Vienna, chess champion of Austria, today administered the first defeat sustained by Paul Keres of Estonia in the international chess masters' tournament.

Alexander Hamilton vs. Seward Park, at Commercial Field, Albany and East New York Avenues, Brooklyn, 2 P. M. Flushing vs. George Washington, at Memorial Field, Flushing. 2 P. M. Jamaica vs. Adelphi Academy, at Jamaica Stadium, Gothic Drive and 168th St., Jamaica, 2:30 P. M.

The 1937 Manhattan football team, considered the strongest to be coached by Chick Meehan in his six years at the Riverdale college, will open its season this afternoon when it meets a doughty St. Bonaventure eleven at Ebbets Field.

Plans were announced yesterday for a six-story apartment house at Lexington Avenue and Thirty-first Street in connection with the leasing of an "L" around the northeast corner by W. Forbes Morgan Jr. to Samuel Belkind and Max Horowitz. The property is known as

Forcing the Northern and Western gates under cover of fierce artillery fire, Japanese infantry entered Paoting, strategic city 85 miles southwest of Peiping, at 10:30 this morning, and had completely occupied the Hopeh provincial capital by 1:30 in the afternoon.

The "120 greatest living Jews" were named today to a Jewish Hall of Fame selected in a world-wide poll by The Ivrim, honor society of Chicago Jewish students. Their purpose was to hold up "living ideals" to Jewish youth, and they required only that nominees must have been alive on Rosh HaShanah (Jewish New Year) of 5697 (Sept. 28, 1936).

Mrs. Marie De Ronde, a resident of Englewood for twenty-seven years and socially prominent, has decided to leave Englewood and New Jersey forever, decreeing that both are "unfit for honest citizenship."

The proposal that the Black-Connery bill to regulate hours and wages in industry be amended to prevent the granting of discriminatory power of administration by a national board was made yesterday by Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr. of New Jersey, a member of the Labor Committee in Congress for the last ten years.

Ward's Spring when the first na Automotive Reports, Inc., said today that the output of the motorcar factories reached its bottom point of the year this week with the assembly of 28,030 cars and trucks, as compared with 30,150 last week and 20,597 at this time last year.

Walter H. Atherton, 21-year-old Harvard senior and son of Henry F. Atherton, president and chairman of the board of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, was found dead in his room here this afternoon, with a bullet wound in the head and an automatic pistol beside him.

A short-lived strike in a chain of loft buildings, largely in the garment center area, managed by Adams Co., Real Estate, Inc., was called yesterday by the Building Service Industrial Union, newly organized rival of Local 32-B, Building Service Employes International Union.

American-bred ponies dominated the highly successful revival of the show of the National Polo Pony Society on the grounds of the Meadow Brook Club today. Horses bred in this country accounted for four of the blue ribbons, three third-place ribbons, three fourth-place ribbons and the championship of the show.

The nominations of William C. Potter, chairman of the board of the Quaranty Trust Company, and Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, for directorships on the board of. the Federal Reserve Bank of New York were announced yesterday by a nominations committee of the State Bankers Associations of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

Two more arrests were made yesterday in the Government's investigation of the disability insurance racket, making a total of fortythree defendants rounded up by postal inspectors and specially assigned city detectives.

The New York Stock Exchange yesterday added Interborough Rapid Transit capital stock to its list and suspended from dealings voting trust certificates for the shares. Simonds Saw and Steel Company no par common stock will be admitted today to the list.
They had hoped to see Jane Cowl rehearsing "The Austrian Woman" next Monday, looking forward to a Broadway opening about the usual six weeks afterward. But it is not to be. There are bridges.

The Peruvian delegation to its, boundary dispute negotiations with Ecuador rejected today an Ecuadorean proposal to submit the entire dispute to arbitration by President Roosevelt in the event proceedings failed.

On the eve of his third annive-. sary as Police Commissioner, Lewis J. Valentine looked back yesterday over the Police Department record of the last three years and found it good. The commissioner, who wan sworn in office by Mayor La Guardia on Sept. 25, 1934, told

Annual military spectacle in aid of the Army Relief Day benefit on Governors Island, 2:30 P. M. Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2:30 P. M. "Digging Into the Past; Daily Life of the Egyptians," motion pictures.

The Cubs' game with the- Cardinals was called off in the second inning today, rain washing out the secondplace Chicagoans' chances of picking up ground on the idle Giants in the National League pennant race.

With consumer purchasing gaining force, many buyers returned to the wholesale markets this week and covered with less caution the balance of their Fall requirements for Winter and Christmas merchandise, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Retail sales

-Mark Stuart, former metropolitan champion, had little trouble winning the low gross trophy today in the Fall New York Curb Exchange golf tourney at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club, scoring 35, 35-70 to equal par.

Mayor La Guardia moved yesterday for a speedy determination of regulations governing signs, parking spaces and amusements in the World's Fair site in Flushing Meadows, Queens, when he directed that a special meeting of the Board of Estimate be held at 2 o'clock Monday to vote on the matter.

Leland Stanford Stillman, 31, member of a New York and California family, died at his ranch of a "gunshot wound inflicted with suicidal intent," a coroner's jury held today. Stillman was found shot last night at the ranch, 40 miles northeast of here. Coroner Gordon S. Clark said the body was found by the ranch foreman about 150 yards from the house.

For the first time the American Section of the Universal Christian Council on Life and Work and the American Section of the World Conference on Faith and Order will hold a joint meeting on Thursday. It will take place in the George Washineton Hotel, Lexington
Reint Sobering, chief steward of the Holland-America liner Volendam, died Wednesday in Rotterdam, according to cable advice received yesterday at the offices of the line in this city.

Stressing the growing interest in "Sweetest Day," which this year falls on Oct. 16, the National Confectioners Association has launched a movement throughout the candy industry to rank it with the nationally accepted Mother's Day, Father's Day and St. Valentine's Day.

Conrad Nagel's first directorial effort, "Love Takes Flight,!' will have its initial Broadway showing this evening at the Central Theatre It is a Grand National production car and features Bruce Cabot, Beatrice car Roberts, Astrid Allwyri and Gordon Elliott.

Allen Cain, 35 years old, of 1,554 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, and Irwin Levin, 31, of 1,098 Grand Avenue, the Bronx, lawyers and deputy colsectors of the Federal Internal Revenue Department, pleaded not guilty yesterday in the Felony Court when arraigned before Magistrate,

A Rhodes scholar from the University of Manitoba, in a letter written at Oxford and received today by Russell Ellis, former principal of Sydney Academy, declared he was returning the Governor General's medal he won at the academy in 1930.
At Long last the Gilbert and Sullivan operas are to be filmed and will soon be available to every movie goer, it was announced today by the D'Oyly Carte : Opera Company.

Informed sources declared tonight that Premier Mussolini and Chancellor Hitler had agreed to make a joint world appeal for peace when they address a huge demonstration in Berlin's Olympic Stadium Tuesday.

A. R. Small Jr., house on Rose Ave, Halstead Manor, Mamaroneck; Houghton, Company, broker. Miss Mary O'Malley, in 209 East Post Rd, White Plains; Lusby Simpson, in 4 Van Wart Ave; and renewals with Leon B. Lent. in 216 Hartsdale Rd; John R. McCullough, in 11 Macy Ave; John Triggs, in 26 Benedict Ave; Meuer Auerbach, Inc. broker.

The Far Eastern crisis which St comes to a pinhead in "Outlaws sc of the Orient" is such an insignificant and unspectacular affair that even the Rialto patrons declined yesterday to give it more than polite attention. The picture is one

Faced with a strike of 150 employes in addition to financial discouragements, Drake's Restaurant, 119 West Forty-second Street, will not reopen, it was announced last night by Edward D. Bryde, counsel for William Richters, proprietor of the restaurant.

The five-and-a-half-story building! containing twenty-five apartments at 1,483 Hoe Avenue, the Bronx, was bought by David Greenstein from the Chattel Real Estate Corportion. Three years ago the property was purchased from the Verkler estate for $6,500 cash over the mortgage through N. R. Hyman, broker, and now is being conveyed for $10.000 over the mortgage.

The Federal Trade Commission today ordered Parco Products, Inc., 19 West Forty-fourth Street, New York City, to cease and desist from certain alleged unfair trade methods in the distribution of casein paint, which is sold under the trade brand name Artwall and Partwall.
Mass executions of spies and saboteurs on Far Eastern railways-accused of being in Japanese secret service pay-today claimed nineteen more lives at Vladivostok, Soviet Pacific seaport.

Four new Republican Assembly district leaders in Manhattan were elected at meetings of district county committees last night. These were Lester Baum, who succeeded I. Arnold Ross in the Ninth district; John Kerrigan,

Prices on the Cotton Exchange broke rapidly into new low territory again yesterday and closed at the bottom. The December broke below 8 1/4 cents a pound to the lowest quotation since May, 1933, and all other months except July sold under 8 1/2 cents for a loss of $1 a bale to end 21 to 24 points lower than on Thursday.

If Harvey Shaffer and Mrs. Ruth M. Torgerson had only been able to play the ninth, tenth and eleventh holes the way Hugo Rutherfurd and his sister Alice did today there would have been no question as to who will be the medalists in the annual Piping Rock invitation mixed foursome golf tournament.

Mr. and Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice of Mount Hope, this place, and 5 West Fifty-third Street, New York, have announced the engagement of their only daughter, Miss Mary Adeline Prentice, to Benjamin Davis Gilbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Thorne Gilbert of Clayville, N. Y.

Dr. Gustave Roussy has been named rector of Paris University, replacing Sebastien Charlety, who has retired. Dr. carry Roussy has been head of the faculty of medicine since 1933. He is well known for his cancer research.

Assistant United States Attorney Frank J. Parker applied yesterday to Judge Moscowitz in the Federal court in Brooklyn for an order directing the reorganization trustees of the Prudence Company. Inc., to put $750,000 in cash in escrow as security for a claim of $1,100,000 in corporation taxes made by the Government against the company for the years 1923 to 1935.

The Board of Governors of the National Hockey League held an all-day meeting at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, to draw up a schedule for the coming season, and to revise a few of the rules applying to the ice sport.

Mr. and Mrs. George Huntington Hartford Jr. were among those who gave dinners last night at the formal opening for the season of the Persian Room of the Plaza. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Earl E. T. Smith, Miss Lucy T. Saunders and Vadim Makaroff.
Alf M. Landon asserted today that President Roosevelt "now is in the position of being unable to retreat or go forward without suffering serious losses in his control over Congress."

United States MEDICAL SOCIAL WORKER, $3,800 a year; Associate Medical Social Worker, $3,200; Assistant Medical Social Worker, S2.600. Children's Bureau, Department of Labor. Applications must be on file not later than Oct. 18. if received from States other than those named below: Oct. 21, if received from the following States:
The Paterson East Side High School football team opened its season tonight, defeating Washington Central High, 6--0, before 5,000 spectators at the Hinchliffe Stadium.
The condition of Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, took a turn for the worse tonight, according to a bulletin issued by the American Hospital.

The American Weekly, a Sunday newspaper magazine, announced yesterday that for the first time in its forty-one years of publication, beginning Jan. 2, 1938, it will be distributed with Sunday newspapers other than those owned by William Randolph Hearst.

The luck of the Irish prevailed as Miss Clarrie Tiernan, former champion of Erin, won her first tournament on American soil by defeating Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr., defending titleholder, 6 and 4, in the thirty-six-hole final for the New Jersey State crown over the west course of the Essex Country Club today.

24.-Miss Mary Russell Cottinghan, daughter of Mrs. George Russell Cottingham of this place and the late Dr. Cottingham of Fauquier County, was married to Thomas Joseph Laffey Jr. of Wilmington, Del., this afternoon in the University Chapel by the Rev. Dudley E. Boogher of McIlhany Parish.

Of Mr. Black's appointment to the Supreme Court, Senator George W. Norris says that it was "wonderfully good." To this he adds: "Even if he was a member of the Klan, there's no legal objection to that." Mr. Black is courageous, "able and shrewd," a good

When popular indignation against a prolonged carnival of airy misgovernment swept Mayor La Guardia into the City Hall nearly four years ago the office of District Attorney of New York County remained a Tammany island in a Fusionist sea.

The city of Buenos Aires will present an Argentine flag to the city of Philadelphia in return for an a American flag presented to Buenos Aires by Philadelphia last December on the occasion of the PanAmerican Peace Conference here.

To all right-thinking, after-dark sentimentalists, the head of the night club table is wherever Helen Morgan of the sad songs is sitting on a piano. Since last Saturday, this would be at the new Club El Dorado, in West Fifty-sixth Street, which has Miss Morgan and a piano and a spotlight and is therefore O.K.

Kenneth F. Simpson. whose support of Mayor La Guardia was a main factor in the Mayor's victory in the Republican primary election, would like to decline re-election as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, it was learned yesterday.

Signal fires burning on Wotan's Throne, the unexplored plateau near the "Sky Forest" of Shiva Temple, heralded tonight the safe arrival of climbers who blazed a trail to the wooded table where scientists will continue their search for isolated mammal specimens.

Miss Helen Frazier Reinhard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Reinhard of this place, was married this evening to Frank Dickinson Illingworth, son of Mrs. Samuel B. Illingworth of Newark and the late Mr. Illingworth.

Hudson St, 166-72, n a cor Laight 100x38; Hermann H. Cammann and another to George P. Cammann, Tuxedo Park, N. Y., et al, joint tenants. Same property; Francis de Lancey Cunningham to Hermann Cammann, Merrick, L. I., and another, deed dated Dec. 15, 1920. Hudson St, 265, w s, 16x65; Hermann H. Cammann and another to George P. Cammann, Tuxedo Park, N. Y., et al,

The Rev Yaroo M. Neesan, pastor of the Old Assyrian Church here, died here yesterday at the age of 84. Father Neesan came to Flint in 1924 and organized the Assyrian colony to form the church. He was born in 1853 in Persia.
The Rev. Thomas F. Ryan, retired pastor of the Catholic Church of St. Philip Neri, died last night in the church rectory after a long illness. He was 77.

Winfield Hall, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Reynolds, was the scene today for a series of tableaux, or "living book reviews," which were the feature of a literary tea given to about 200 members of literary and society groups in the Red Springs colony.

Contrasting with customs in the United States, 98 per cent of the deceased of Tokyo are cremated, R. Nakayama, Cemetery Commissioner of the Japanese city, reported yesterday at the twenty-first convention of the Cremation Association of America in the Hotel New Yorker.

Buoyed by the success of their recent Western trip, the Giants returned yesterday and braced themselves for a last stand in the more friendly East. Nothing short of a complete collapse by the Terrymen, combined with a wild and woolly sprint by the Cubs, can check the staging of another nickel world series.

Several shots were fired at the Japanese Legation from a passing car at 2 o'clock this morning, the police have revealed. Mexico declared against the Japanese "aggression" in China at Geneva this week and the Mexican position received wide publicity here. It was thought that extremists were probably responsible for the shots.

Jack Sabol and Mrs. Emmett Whalen of the Westchester Hills Golf Club turned in a 77 to win the Westchester P. G. A. pro-women's Scotch foursome championship today at the Hudson River Country Club. The winners were out in 38
Malcolm E. Falk, a member of the Massachusetts Mutual Insurance Company, died last night of a heart attack. He was 53 years old and lived at 205 East Seventy-eighth Street.
Two armed bandits escaped yesterday afternoon with an $8,600 payroll which they took from a clerk of the Benrus Watch Company, 200 Hudson Street, who was returning in a taxicab from an uptown bank.

The Census Bureau reported today that manufacturing activity in New York City's industrial area increased during 1933-35, but still was substantially below 1929 levels. In 1935, the bureau reported, not including salaried workers, 779,486 persons were employed in 32,237 manufacturing establishments which paid out $899,086,826 in wages and produced goods valued at $5,739,353,054.

The continued break in the stock market this week has led to renewed discussion in Wall Street of the effect of the various security regulations and other governmental measures adopted in the last few years.

The marriage of Miss Jane Louise Warren, daughter of Mrs. John Brush Warren of this city and Philadelphia, to George Starr Scofield 4th, son of Mrs. George S. Scofield of Geneseo, N. Y., and the late Mr. Scofield of Staten Island, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.
Litigation begun by the State Banking Department, as liquidator of the Westchester Trust Company of Yonkers, against the estate of

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 22: COMMANDER Griffin. I. P., Civil Engineer Corps. Navy Yard. Pearl Harbor, T. H., about Oct. 12 to Bureau of Yards and Docks, Navy Dept.. Washington, D. C. LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Fladeland. R. H., Dental Corps, the Utah.

The Meadow Lark Beagles of New Brunswick, N. J., took the honors among the 15-inch beagles with Meadow Lark Draftsman at the Bryn Mawr round show on the polo field of the Country Club today. Draftsman defeated Curate of the Vernon-Somerset beagles, Peapack, N. J., for the top award.

An increase in the demand for imported cigarettes in Mexico has prompted two manufacturers there to plan introduction in that market of competitive brands, the American Trade Commissioner has reported to the Department of Commerce.

Eddie Becker, 18-year-old graduate of Seward Park High School, was installed as the new Mayor of the Boys' Brotherhood Republic at its headquarters and clubhouse at 290 East Third Street, last night. More than two hundred "citizens" of the republic and their friends filled the gymnasium of the four-story building for the inauguration of the Mayor and sixteen other government officials.

While Italian papers described Premier Benito olini's departure with eight-column headlines and columns of enthusiastic stories, the Osservatore Romano gave exactly fourteen words to the same announcement.

MANHATTAN CURRAN, KATE (April 3). Estate, less than $5,000. To Mary A. O'Leary, sister, executrix, 5,582 Broadway. FALLS, DE WITT CLINTON (Sept. 7). Estate, more than $20,000. To the Seventh Regiment Fund, $20,000 and a collection of army insignia; Veterans of the Seventh Regiment, $5,000; Company K, Seventh Regiment. $5.000: St. Thomas Church.

Manhattan Alteration. 5th Ave. '630; to 38-story offices: Rockefeller Center, Inc, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, owner; Reinhard Hofmeister, architects; cost, $15,000. Brooklyn Johnson St, 86; alteration in 1-story brick boiler room: American Safety Razor Corp, 315 Jay St, owner: W. Higginson Son. architects: cost. $10.100.

After breaking through on a wide front, the Blue infantry, accompanied by tanks and field artillery, attempting to enfold the Red flank in wide, encircling movements as the main battle of the German Autumn military manoeuvres still rages in the lake district southeast of this city, with its result still uncertain.

Stocks crumbled yesterday in one of the most general waves of liquidation since 1929. Industrial leaders declined an average of 7.48 points on a volume of 2,482,000 shares. Corporation and foreign bonds hit new low averages for the year.

More than 200 persons were killed and more than 500 wounded when Japanese bombers attacked Hankow yesterday afternoon. It was the first severe bombing of Hankow, and it caused horrible destruction in the slum districts.

Most of the rear guard of the American Legion left New York yesterday and in their wage the hotel men, merchants and restaurant keepers added up the take. They found that about 110,000 Legionnaires, including their wives and children, had been in town and had spent around $5,500,000.
Brooklyn at New York-Frankhouse vs. Gumbert. Boston at Philadelphia-Fette vs. Walters. Chicago at St. Louis-Carleton vs. Warneke. Pittsburgh at Cincinnati-Tobin vs. Derringer.

Annual Rally Sunday will be observed tomorrow in many of the churches. The observance will mark the opening of the annual Religious Education Week. Its purpose, according to the Greater New York Federation of Churches and sister organizations which are its

Approval for the immediate construction of nine ski trails, seven in the Catskills and two in the Adirondacks, has been given by Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner. The action followed a hearing

The Brooklyn Daily Eagle management agreed yesterday at a conference before the State Board of Mediation to submit its payroll for examination in course of negotiations for a settlement of the strike of editorial and commercial department employes called by the Eagle Unit of the New York Newspaper Guild on Sept. 14.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses termed "entirely impractical" yesterday a proposed local law, backed by the Playground Directors Association, which would fix salaries for city playground directors in the Park Department within a range of $1,800 to $2,400 a year and would give them a six-hour day.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 18 amounted to 826,565 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 115,266 cars, or 16.2 per cent more than for the preceding week; 36,708 cars, or 4.6 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 119,745 cars, or 16.9 per cent more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 6,000, including 2,500 directs. The market opened steady, closing 10c lower than Thursday's average on butcher's 260 pounds up and packing sows; good and

Another quiet period in the field of new State and municipal financing is indicated for next week, when a total of ,nly $7,650,389 is scheduled, to be represented by one State and forty-six municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $12,285,517 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now-stands at $26,381,261.

Twenty-two States joined forces against "commuting criminals" today in a compact for uniform control of paroled convicts. Other objectives of the Interstate Commission of Crime, made up of State officials and created slightly less than two years ago, are uniform laws on fresh pursuit (chasing across boundary lines), extradition, and attendance of witnesses.

Net earnings of the Hayes Body Corporation for the three months ended on July 31 amounted to $34,289 after all charges including depreciation but before Federal taxes, A. A. Anderson, president, announced yesterday. In the same period of 1936 there was a net loss of $48,825.

Temple University opened its football season with an 18-7 victory over Virginia Military Institute tonight before 15,000 fans. It was the 300th victory for a Glenn S. Warner-coached team and marked the start of his forty-third year as a tutor of college elevens.

Twelve thousand truck drivers struck for higher pay today, sharply curtailing trucking activities in nine upState New York cities and intervening rural areas. The strike was called in Syracuse after six weeks of wage negotiations ended in a deadlock. State police reported no acts of violence.

"Aviation Day," the twenty-seventh anniversary of the death of the Peruvian Jorge Chavez, who lost his life in one of the earliest flights over the Alps, was observed here yesterday with a demonstration by 137 planes. The craft were flown

The question why virtually no war prisoners have been taken on either side was discussed yesterday at an interview with Japanese Army and Navy spokesmen. The former admitted that "almost no Chinese war prisoners have been taken" and smiled broadly when told of the Chinese claim that one Japanese soldier had been imprisoned.

Miss Charlotte Pepper, granddaughter of former United States Senator and Mrs. George Wharton Pepper and daughter of George Wharton Pepper Jr., architect, and Mrs. Pepper, of St. Davids, was introduced at a tea at the home of her grandparents this afternoon.

Sale of a New York Stock Exchange seat was reported yesterday at $72,000. The last previous sale was for $75,000. on Sept. 11. The Stock Exchange partnership of Townsend, Graff Naumberg will be dissolved Oct. 7.

A sharp deeline among the transatlantics provided the outstanding feature in today's stock market. This development weakened the list all round. Gilt-edge issues, however, were quietly firm and Far Easterns were steady.

The marriage of Miss Irene M. Lamb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Lamb of Hollis, Queens, to Dr. Peter C. Wright of Yonkers, N. Y., took place last evening in the Riverside Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Clarence M. Gallup.
It was indicated tonight that the Chicago Board of Trade would establish a settlement price at which all contracts in September corn would be ordered settled.

Major William Kennelly will sell at auction at 2 P. M. today on the premises, the estate of the late Henry Ollesheimer, at Prospect and Martling Avenues, Tarrytown, N. Y., for the executor. The property consists of about eight acres, with a three-story colonial-type dwelling, and outbuildings.

Miss Janet Alice Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Smith of 941 Park Avenue, was married yesterday afternoon in St. Thomas Church to Gerald Hughes Phipps, son of former United States Senator and Mrs. Lawrence C. Phipps of Denver. The Rev. Dr. Roelif H.

Rental agents and real estate brokers reporting on apartment leasing activity yesterday submitted lists of new tenants the length of which evidences no diminution in the number of families seeking new living quarters. As has been the rule in the last several days, rentals are being made all over the city, as well as in the -earby suburbs.

A large supply of spinach from up-State New York and Pennsylvania has arrived in the wholesale produce markets, ending a scarcity in this vegetable, according to the Food Guide of the Department of Public Markets, Weights and Measures.
Colonel Ike Thomas Pryor, cattle leader, died today after a long illness at the age of 85. He was president of the American National Livestock Association two terms.
Frank M. Rourke, teacher of English at Roman Catholic High School for Boys, died at his home here today at the age of 74. He had been on the high school faculty fortyfour years.

The Union of Orthodox Rabbis of the United States and Canada, 673 Broadway, appealed yesterday to rabbis throughout the country to devote their sermons on Monday, the Eighth Day of the Tabernacles, to the Constitution of the United States, in celebration of the 150th anniversary of its signing.

lst Lt. Raymond C. Woodward, AirRes., 265 Jackson St., Hempstead, L. I., 861st Observation Squadron, is ordered to active duty, Sept. 26. at Mitchel Field, L. I., for training with the 861st Observation Squadron. He will be relieved from active duty Oct. 9.

Weekly cotton statistics are as. follows: British stocks 684,000 bales, against 691,000 a week ago, 699,000 two weeks ago, 702,000 three weeks ago and 744,000 a year ago; of which American 220,000 bales, against 209,000 a week ago, 220,000 two weeks ago, 235,000 three weeks ago and 227,000 a year ago.

Governor Lehman, in a letter addressed to Chairman James A. Farley of the Democratic State Committee declined with thanks today an invitation to head the list of Democratic nominees for delegates at large to next year's Constitutional convention.

The testimony of banking and brokerage houses with foreign connections continues to show considerable conflict as to the part that is being played in the current market decline by liquidation from foreign sources. One such house reported
Leading railroads disclosed today that they are laying off thousands of employes. The move, it was made known, has been necessitated by higher operating and maintenance costs. The announcement

Verdi's "Aida" was presented by the Hippodrome Opera Company at the Hippodrome last night as the first of two gala performances arranged for the week-end in honor of the American Legion. An enthusiastic audience of 3,500 persons attended.
Governmnent Asturians and Insurgent Na varrese today fought savagely in a mountain snowstorm on the front east of Gijon in Northwestern Spain.

Stocks declined 2 to 6 points to lowest levels since October, 1935, and closed weak; turnover 2,482,010 shares. United States Government, Italian and Japanese issues lower; second-grade rail bonds weakened transactions, $9,712,500.
A convict attack on Warden James A. Johnston today disclosed a new rebellion in Alcatraz Prison, island fortress where the Federal Government keeps its most hardened criminals.
Mexico fears the Pnited States will cancel the silver purchase agreement by which the Treasury has been buying Mexican silver at high prices, the newspaper El Universal reports today.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, denounced Mayor La Guardia last night as a "one-man band" and a "lightning change artist" and accused him of having passed the last four years in "coddling" Communists and squandering the taxpayers' money.

The Commission on Marriage and Divorce of the Protestant Episcopal Church announced yesterday that ten of its eleven members have approved its report urging a liberalization of the divorce canon of the church which would permit the remarriage of divorced persons at the

Swamped by high seas in a roaring southeast wind, the Sin-Mac Lines steamship Neebing keeled over and sank today in Nipigon Straits, between Nipigon Bay and Lake Superior, carrying five of a crew of fifteen to death.

Sage advice, applicable in this country or Canada, is given by the Hon. F. W. Pirie, Minister of Lands and Mines for New Brunswick, in an attempt to minimize accidents during the hunting season. The advice has been given by many others before, but it never is out of date for the simple reason that it is always needed.

The Yankees' clinching of their ninth American League pennant hasn't minimized their desire for victory. They put on a characteristic ninth-inning rally at Fenway Park today before a ladies' day gathering of about 8,000, rushed over four runs as they routed Archie McKain and downed the Red Sox, 5 to 1.

The National Lumber Manufacturers Association tonight was presented the American Trade Association Executives' award for its work in connection with construction of more than 1,500 demonstration homes throughout the country on the "model-home plan" as a part of its program to stimulate small-home construction.

Britain and France made a dramatic entrance into the Italo-German conference yesterday when their charges d'affaires visited Mussolini before his departure and asked for an immediate threepower conference to settle Spanish issues. London and Paris will

County Judge Gerald Nolan of! Westchester County was nominated unanimously at a Republican judicial convention this afternoon to run for Supreme Court Justice in the Ninth Judicial District, comprising Westchester, Rockland, Dutchess, Putnam and Orange Counties. The convention, attended

Movements of vessels follow, all dates Sept. 23 unless specified: At New Orleans: Herbert, Leary, Tillman. At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Kwaydin, Sept. 24; Vega. New York to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Sept. 24: Jacob Jones. Roper. Arkansas, Boston to Philadelphia Yard, Sept. 24.

Prices of bonds crumbled to new low levels of the year and longer yesterday in the most severe break fir a single session 'since July 26, 1984. Domestic corporation issues were again the most vulnerable to the fresh attack.

The Central New York Power Corporation, a subsidiary of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, expects to spend about $19,590,000 on new construction before the end of 1939, according to testimony given yesterday before the Public Service Commission by A. W. Andrews, chief engineer of the company. Mr. Andrews said $16,529,000

Shlps of the Asiatic Fleet will protect Americans throughout the duration of the Sino-Japanese emergency and any risks that may be involved will be accepted, according to a statement of policy communicated to all units of that fleet by Admiral Harry E. Yarnell, Commander-inChief of the Asiatic Fleet.

The government's first move in the new parliamentary session is the introduction of a bill for universal compulsory military service, which will increase recruits available for the army and navy from 19,500 to 32,000. The period for training infantry privates will be doubled to eleven months.

Britain and the United States showed a stiffer front on the Chinese problem yesterday. The British Ambassador to Tokyo was instructed to make a strong protest against slaughter of noncombatants by bombing planes.
Yale climaxed ten days of football training here with a practice game today in which the Blues, or regulars, rolled up a 33-0 score on the Grays.

The reply of C. Edward Paxson, counsel for subsidiaries of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, to an order of the Federal Power Commission calling upon him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from practice before it because of a statement he issued on Sept. 18 and which the commission

Turpentine, 30c, nominal; no sales; receipts 315 barrels; shipments 217 barrels; stock 40,337 barrels. Resin firm; sales 552; receipts 1,882: shipments 75; stock 64,629. Quote: B, D. E $7.50: F to M. $7.85; N, $7.90- WG, $8.15: WWX, $8.60.

With Tommy Hitchcock recovered fully from a fall in the final round of the open on Wednesday, the Greentree four will start after the Monty Waterbury Cup, last of the high-goal trophies of the polo season, this afternoon.

Immediate outcry from the financial community greeted reports from Washington today that the United States Government was seeking to arrange a reciprocal tax on foreign investments in the United States and Great Britain.

Gaynell Tinsley, Louisiana State's all-America end last year, scored three touchdowns tonight to give, the Chicago Cardinals a 21-to-14 triumph over the Washington Redskins in a National League football game before 22,367 spectators. Another professional freshman, Halfback Sammy Baugh, passed the Redskins to both their scores.
No trace whatever was found today of either General Eugene Miller or General Skobline, White 'Russians who disappeared Wednesday, although General Skobline's wife has been found.

The 100th birthday of the Division of Science and State Museum, chief scientific agency of the State Government, will be observed Oct. 15 at the convocation of the University of the State of New York.

Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc. has placed a first mortgage loan of $110,000 on the recently completed six-story apartment on the south side of Clark Pl., 110 feet west of Walton Ave., the Bronx, for Raclin Fagin, with the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.
Thomas Allsop, a machinery manufacturer, died today at his home in Mount Airy after a short illness. He was 71 years old. Mr. Allsop came

Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, Fusion candidate for District Attorney of New York County, whose prosecution of former officials of Locals 16 and 302 of the Waiters and Cafeteria Workers Union sent several to prison for racketeering, has been invited to be present this morning when representatives ol Local 302 and the Childs Company sign an agreement covering some 3,000 Childs employes.

Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the State Department of Public Service, returned to the Transit Commission yesterday, "without approval or disapproval," that body's request for his approval of its recent appointment of former Mayor James J. Walker as an assistant counsel at an annual salary of $12.000.
Three government agencies were held liable today to the receivers of two failed banks for return of a portion of the proceeds from the sale of collateral posted by the banks on secured deposits.

Duquesne's powerful Night Riders swept over a gallant but outclassed Waynesburg College eleven, 33 to 7, tonight in a football inaugural observed by 13,606 fans. Fleet-footed George Matsik, right halfback who scored the Dukes' winning marker over Pitt last year, blazed a brilliant trail with two touchdowns.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Dorothy Eckstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Maurice Eckstein of 141 West Seventy-third Street, to Francis J. Herrmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick F. Herrmann, also of this city, took place at noon yesterday at the Hotel Olcott.

Failing to obtain permission from Portugal for a descent at the Azores, the French Air Ministry tonight canceled the proposed flight of the six-engined seaplane Lieutenant de Vaisseau Paris to New York.

Roy Garr, one of the three brothers accused of shooting Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt, took the blame on himself today and swore he shot because he was afraid the war veteran would kill him. He and his one brother, Dr. E. S. Garr, were released in $20,000 bail each. Another brother, Jack Garr, is free on $10,000 bail.

Mike Jacobs's Carnival of Champions of 1937 fell just short of clearing expenses, according to the head of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.. After taking stock yesterday and paying the eight fighters on the championship card their guarantees, Promoter Jacobs expressed the opinion that he finished a little in the red.

Their second half-centuries of intercollegiate football will be launched by Penn State arid Cornell elevens on Schoellkopf Field tomorrow. The teams staged final light workouts today, with Penn State's squad going to Watkins Glen for the night.

The Japanese drop bombs on twenty Chinese cities. So frightful is the slaughter that Canton alone reports 2,000 dead or wounded in two days. Yet the slaughter that goes on year after year in these peaceful United States is more appalling. If we do not protest

Fordham College formally began its ninety-seventh academic year yesterday with the celebration of the traditional solemn mass of the Holy Ghost in the university chapel before 1,500 students and faculty members.

After receiving representatives of fifty-two civic organizations who went to City Hall yesterday to protest against Mayor La Guardia's veto of the recent cut in water rates adopted by the Board of Aldermen, Aldermanic President William F. Brunner announced that the board would meet at 2 o'clock on Oct. 4

Trading showed little change from Thursday. Beef cuts were steady to higher, lamb continued a downward price trend; pork loins were lower and call cuts weak to lower. Early trading in kosher meats indicated top good to prime steer chucks and plates to be higher and others weak to slightly lower.

CLASS A AMATEUE First Heat-Won by Douglass C. Fonda, Orange. N. J.; Thomas Tyson, Chestnut Hill, Pa., second; Warren Kenny, Garden City, L. I., third; John H. Thacher, Bay Head, N. J. fourth; Earl Hildebrand, Richmond, Va., fifth. Time--7:21 3-5. Speed--40.761 m. p. h. Second Heat-Won by Fonda; Tyson, second; Hildebrand, third; Thacher, fourth. Time-7:17. Speed--41.190 m. p. h. Final Standing-Fonda. 800 points; Tyson, 600; Hildebrand, 352; Thacher, 338; Kenny, 225.

Stackpole Sons announce a contest for the best photograph illustrating crowds, exhibitions, horseracing or any other characteristic feature of a county fair. The prize photograph will receive $25 and will be included in a picture book, "County Fair," by Phil Stong and Dr. Josephine von Miklas, to be published in the Spring.

Returning to the air Madrid after a six-week absence except one finds the shadow of Winter al- strength ready overhanging the city. There is a nip in the air and anxious work PLEA is being done by civilian and military authorities alike to minimize as much as possible the inevitable hardships which will have to be 600 faced.

President Roosevelt made a "right nice" speech here today, in the opinion of the man in the street. The politicians agreed with that point of view, adding privately that it was a good speech because the President "didn't say much."

The offer made last month by the Republic of Peru to purchase the two oldest unpaid coupons of the Peruvian Government dollar bonds was assailed yesterday by the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., as entirely inadequate and not consistent with that country's resources.

Support for the Spanish Loyalists was urged at a meeting of the Nathan Hale Branch of the Young Communists League last night at the De Witt Clinton High School, Jerome Avenue and Mosholu Parkway, with about 600 persons, onethird of whom were young people, in attendance.

This little prairie village saw its first President today. During a two-minute train service stop President Roosevelt went out on the rear platform and chatted briefly with a group of two-score villagers, mostly in overalls. He said it was the first

Owing partly to a substantial gain in freight shipments and partly to a Pronounced increase in department store sales, business in the Pittsburgh district last week recovered considerably more than half of the drop reported in the week ended Sept. 11, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.

The marriage of Miss Helen Louise Heim, niece of Mr. and Mrs. Eberhard Faber of New York and Pinehurst, N. C., to John Evans Love, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kirk Love of Johnstown, Pa., took place here yesterday afternoon in the by

The political commisison of the League of Nations Assembly adopted today a much more noncommittal resolution on the proposed partition of Palestine than the one the League Council adopted without, however, interfering with the latter.

While New York turned out the other day for the parade of the Legion, a crowd of equal size gathered in faraway Prague for the burial of President Masaryk. The account of the funeral is a moving description of the mourning of a nation for its first citizen.

Brig. Gen. De Witt Clinton Falls, retired commander of the 107th Infantry, National Guard of New York, author and artist, who died in London, England, on Sept. 7, last, left several bequests commemorating his military service in his will filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.
The E. I. du Pont de Nemours Company purchased from the town of Kearny a vacant parcel, 327 by 454 feet, on the east side of Schuyler Avenue, foot of Laurel Avenue, Kearny, N. J.

Treasury officials predicted today that a new tax program now being drafted will contribute materially to business stability. Experts working under the direction of Roswell Magill, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, expect to complete recommendations for revamping the revenue structure by November.

The monthly report on chartered banks issued today by the Dominion Finance Department showed that Canadian savings accounts mounted to $1,577,638,802 on Aug. 31 from $1,572,154,385 at the end of July, and current accounts to $686,448,383 from $666,767,428.

Dr. Samuel B. Heckman, founder and director of the Educational Clinic at City College since 1913, was appointed head of the Department of Education, it was learned here yesterday. Dr. Heckman, who is a professor in the college's School of Education, fills the vacancy in that position created by the resignation of Dr. Paul Klapper, president of the new Queens College.

Two transit corporations of New York appealed today to the Supreme Court in an endeavor to recover taxes which they paid the city under State laws permitting the taxing for unemployment relief of a public service utility holding a franchise from the city. The tax imposed was 3 per cent upon annual gross income.

Calling upon Mayor La Guardia to "help save an industry," representatives of 5,000 kosher butcher shops in this city announced yesterday that an indefinite stoppage had been scheduled to begin next Friday as a protest against the high meat prices charged by wholesalers and packers.

Modern furniture, stressing simplicity, comfort and utility, squeezed its more ornate and imposing predecessors into the background again today as National Furniture Week opened in 3,000 retail stores in 500 cities.
An unsatisfactory situation has arisen, it is stated in a dispatch to the newspaper Pravda from Alexandrovsk, the capital of Soviet Sakhalin, with the Japanese oil and coal concessions there.

A golf team representing Hemphill, Noyes Co. won yesterday the fifteenth annual Charles Hayden Trophy tournament, played at the Oakland Golf Club, Bayside, L. I. The victory, with a score of 319, gave the firm a leg on the third Hayden trophy, on which G. M.-P. Murphy Co. won the first leg last year.

The Rev. James E. Corridan, pastor of St. John Chrysostom's Roman Catholic Church, 985 East 167th Street, the Bronx, died in Listowel, Ireland, on Wednesday, after a long illness, according to word received here yesterday. Father Corridan, a

Albert Worthington Atwater of Chattanooga, Tenn., died yesterday in City Hospital, Welfare Island, of injuries received on Sept. 14, when he was struck by an automobile at Forty-third Street and Sixth Avenue. Mr. Atwater, a civil engineer,

Miss Gertrude O'Keefe, -37-yearold typist charged with the murder of her former fiance, George O. Frank, a bank teller, maintrained her composure yesterday in Women's Detention Prison as the police continued an apparently unsuccessful search for the automatic pistol used in the slaying in Brooklyn early Tuesday morning.

Dr. John Woodford Farlow, librarian emeritus of the Boston Medical Library and former instructor in laryngology at the Harvard Medical School, died yesterday at his Summer home in Manchester at the age of 84. His Winter residence was at 127 Bay State Road, Boston.

Eight editorial employes of The Waterbury Democrat, an evening newspaper, went on strike today and picketed the plant. The strike is supported by the Waterbury Newspaper Guild, a unit of the National Newspaper Guild.

Miss Yetta Dankner, 24 years old, of 459 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, was robbed of $3,500 in cash at 10:30 A. M. yesterday as she stood at De Kalb Avenue and Skillman Street, according to police of the Grand Avenue station who broadcast a an general alarm for a dark man about 22 years old, wearing a dark suit and light felt hat.

People of this State are consuming more alcoholic beverages than at any time since prohibition, Mark Graves, Commissioner of Taxation, said today in making public figures for eight months of the year.

A rise in the city's birth rate during August as compared with the same month in the last four years was reported yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of records of the Department of Health. A total of 8,857 births were reported to the department last month, an increase of about 400 over August, 1936, and greater by about the same number over any August since 1933.
ALDOUS HUXLEY'S new book, "Ends and Means," to be published by Harpers, has been completed. A first reader reports that in "Ends and Means" Mr. Huxley has set out to answer three questions:

Mrs. Marie J. Drolet, for years a private tutor in languages, died yesterday in Atlantic City Hospital at the age of 76. Mrs. Drolet was born in St. Anne's, Quebec. She lived here for the last fifteen years and for twenty years before that was a resident of Philadelphia.

Steam shovels have moved into a densely wooded tract of thirty-five acres in Flower Hill, on Long Island's North Shore, and winding roads will begin to take form within a few days in the secluded region to mark the beginning of the transformation of the property into a modern residential community.

Sir Hubert Wilkins and his four flying aides, who have just completed a five weeks' search in the Arctic for Sigismund Levanevsky, the Russian aviator, and his five companions who disappeared six weeks ago on a projected flight from Moscow to the United States were honored today at a luncheon given by Constantine A. Oumansky, charge d'affaires at the Soviet Embassy
The Golden Gophers of Minnesota warmed up in spectacular style for their 1937 campaign today, crushing a game North Dakota State football team, 69 to 7, before 48,000 spectators.

Miss Barbara White, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Clarke White of this place and Stanmore, Pembroke, Bermuda, was married here this afternoon in Gloria Dei Episcopal Church to F. Linsley Roessler of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. F. L. Roessler of New Haven, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Frederick Swindelhurst, godfather of the bride.

Net income of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31 amounted to $13,690,534, after expenses, interest and Federal taxes, according to a statement issued yesterday. For the twelve months ended o Aug. 31, 1936, the net income on the same basis, was $13,596,765.

With almost 6,000 graduate and undergraduate students on the campus, the Pennsylvania State College opened the Fall semester with the starting of a $6,500,000 building program which will be completed in two years. The present physical plant of the college is valued at $10,000,000.

BANOWITCH--Dr. and Mrs. Morris M., announce the birth of a daughter, Joyce Gail, on Sept. 22 at the Beth Moses Hospital. BEIRSTEIN--Dr. and Mrs. Samuel S., announce the birth of Carol Kohnstamm, Sept. 22, at Lenox Hill Hospital.

Miss Mallory Mixsell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell of New York and Forest Edge in this community, was hostess tonight at a large supper dance at the Creek Club in honor of her guest, Miss Minna Mary Royds, a London debutante of this season and daughter of Lady Royds.
Gil Dobie's Boston College Eagles opened the season today with a 35-to-2 victory over the Northeastern University eleven.

STUDENTS of English literature have of recent years shown increasing interest in the seventeenth century particularly the early decades. It is true that critical estimates have not been greatly changed by these researches. A poem is poetry, or it is not, irrespective of philosophical, historical or social backgrounds in the period in which the poem was composed.

WHEN Miss Jacqueline Cochran of New York flew a Seversky plane six times over the three-and-one-half-kilometer(2.18 miles)course here last week at an average speed of 293.05 miles an hour, she did more than establish a new world's speed record for women. for women.

The dominant influences in the League of Nations Assembly at its current session are the fear of a general war and the belief that it is nearer, accompanied by a somewhat greater confidence in the ultimate power of the democracies.
BOGART-FRAADE--Mr. and Mrs. Max Fraade announce the marriage of their daughter, Lillian, to Aaron Harvey Bogart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris J. Bogart, Brooklyn, Sunday, Sept. 19.

BELGIUM issued two stamps on Sept. 15 to mark the International Music Congress and honoring Eugene Ysaye, the violinist. The stamps bear a full-face portrait of Queen Elizabeth, with a portion of a violin shown in the background.
Observance of the conditions specified by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation are creating sounder and more uniform home financing methods, states Nugent Fallon, general manager.

Enrollment figures released by Alfred D. Donovan, registrar of Manhattan College, showed an increased registration of twenty students over last year. In 1936, 1,238 young men attended the institution as compared with 1,258 now in attendance.

By land and by sea, President Roosevelt is an untiring traveler. In his campaign last Fall he covered nearly 10,000 overland miles, but that was not enough. Soon after the election he was off on a 6,000-mile cruise to Buenos Aires. Last week he said:

By winning today from William and Mary, 45 to 0, the Navy registered the largest score made in the dozen years the Indians have inaugurated the Annapolis season. Under its new coach, Lieutenant Hank Hardwick, Navy justified the prediction that the team was far advanced in its preparations.
Count Kosho Otani, newly wedded spiritual leader of 13,000,000 Japanese, will become a common soldier on Oct. 1.

The University of Maine and Rhode Island State launched their 1937 football campaigns by battling to a scoreless tie in a game witnessed by 3.000 fans at Alumni Field today. Not one serious scoring threat was made by either team.

Canada's gold production continues to increase, with 347,474 ounces mined in July, compared with 344,895 in June and 321,107 in July, 1936. The latest report from the Dominion Bureau of Statistics brings the 1937 gold production figure up to 2,320,725 ounces, compared with 2,096,815 in the same period in 1936 and 1,805,890 in 1935.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to dealings, as a security exempt from registration, Gatineau Power Company common stock, without par value, and 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value.

Samuel Larcombe, 85 years old, former "wheat king," finds the time-heavy on his hands in the city and is thinking of going back to the farm. Though he has lived at the home of his daughter in Winnipeg for several years, his toil-hardened hands were itching to get back to work on the land where he homesteaded at Birtle Creek, Man., forty-eight years ago.
PARAGUAY has issued two attractive sets, one to comremo rate the 400th anniversary of the founding of Asuncion, the nation's capital, and the other to mark the First National Eucharistic Congress.

With this Fall marking the ninetieth year of New York's first venture into free college instruction, municipal higher education in the city, regarded as the greatest system of the kind in the world, is starting a period of unprecedented expansion.
Dartmouth College looks forward to the coming year as one of the most fruitful in a long span. A new student social system is gradually taking shape in many phases.

Railroad employes disclosed today that Cornelius F. McAuliff, 69 years old, a locomotive engineer employed by the New York Central Railroad for fifty-two years, has retired on pension becuase of ill health.

The work of the American Dahlia Society, because of the many additional regional memberships in the last few years, has grown to such an extent that there is dire need for "many more new workers who are willing to go out and disseminate the work of the Dahlia Society," Lynn B. Dudley, president of the society, said yesterday at the society's twenty-third annual meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Never before have gloves for different purposes looked so distinctive as they do this season. New dressy afternoon gloves to wear with a teatime frock are as different from the ones to wear with a tweed topcoat as a lounge lizard is from an Iowa farmer.

The silk parade held last week stimulated sales of better merchandise in all departments carrying silk, according to early reports from stores in New York and in other sections of the country, it was announced yesterday by the International Silk Guild.
Has Turner, one of America's leading jockeys during the pre-war years, died of a heart attack early today at his home in Asnieres. His age was 56.

Miss Rose Marie de Foix Edmunds, daughter of Mrs. Gustave A. Heckscher of Islesbrook, Strafford, was married this afternoon to Burnham Grosvenor Chapman, son of Mrs. George McMurtrie Godley of Greenwich, Conn., and of the late Burnham Chapman, formerly of Rye, N. Y. The ceremony was performed in the Church of the Redeemer at Bryn Mawr.

The Phillips Exeter Academy, which held its opening exercises Wednesday, now is in its 156th year, with a student body of 723, an unusually large number. Dr. Lewis Perry, the principal, announced the appointment of six instructors: Dr. R. C. Conard,

HEPPNER, Ore. OREGON boasts the only archers' game preserve in the entire Northwest. The Canyon Creek Game Refuge, located on the scenic and historic Three Flags Highway (U. S. 395), offers more than a thousand square miles of hunting "for archers only."

This week the instructional period for gardeners begins. Thursday afternoon at 5:15 o'clock the New York Botanical Garden opens a series of twelve Thursday lectures, to which interested amateurs will be admitted for a nominal fee. The course is that which the garden's own students take as part of their training.
