Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes returned to Washington last week after his annual vacation. Justices Brandeis, Sutherland and Butler were also in town, and their colleagues were either on their way to the capital or about to return for the Supreme Court's Fall session that opens on Oct. 4.
Vanderbilt, striking with a hard-running attack, led by the sophomore Bert Marshall, opened the football season in the rain today with a 12-to-0 Southeastern Conference victory over Kentucky.

Les Tietje, former member of the White Sox who has been in the Texas League this year, came back to beat the Chicago team today when the St. Louis Browns scored a 4-to-3 triumph in the opened of a three-game series.

Hope Eternal, 5-year-old daughter of Eternal-Balance Sheet, which Mrs. Samuel Orr picked up in a $3,000 claiming race in Texas, today charged home to her fourth straight victory in the mile and a sixteenth General Green Handicap, at Rockingham Park.

A faint bluish tint that made them a collector's item instead of ordinary stamps with an original value of $2.68, gave forty postage stamps a sale value of $5,800 yesterday. That is what they brought at an auction of stamps of the United States and possessions at the Uptown Stamp Company, 140 West Forty-second Street.

Miss Elizabeth Luff Carman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Miller Carman of Quogue, was married here today in the Westhampton Presbyterian Church to Alanson Noel Rogers, son of Mrs. Alanson Pierson Rogers of Westhampton and the late Mr. Rogers, by the pastor, the Rev. Thomas Coyle.

ETCHINGS have seldom, perhaps have never, been known to jam the turnstiles of an exhibition. They lack the fanfare of paint; also the size that for some seems to count for a good deal. Nevertheless, the Otto Dix war plates, from his folio of fifty called "Der Krieg,"
Edwin Henry Wolf, former manager of the Herald Square store of Rogers Peet Company, died yesterday at his home, 15 East Sixty-ninth Street, after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

The marriage of Miss Eileen Shea, daughter of Mrs. Dennis Clinton Shea of Washington and the late Mr. Shea, to Charles Thomas Zahn, son of John T. Zahn of Westminster, Md., and the late Mrs. Zahn, took place at noon yesterday in the rectory of the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

The meeting of Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Premier Benito Mussolini unites on one spot two of the world's master magicians in mass control. They have been applauded by more millions and more fervently perhaps than any other two human beings

THIS is the time of year when car manufacturers are busy tuning up their sales engines in preparation for the season's drive ahead. Car factories have witnessed a constant procession of press representatives, field sales staffs, distributors, dealers and dealers' service managers who have come in to get an advance look at the new models and to hear about the selling program for 1938. 38.
Governor George H. Earle's reputed Presidential aspirations were attacked by Senator H. Styles Bridges of New Hampshire at a meeting of the Republican State Committee here today.

Plans have been completed by Miss Harriet Ellis Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wyckoff Wilson of West Hartford, Conn., for her marriage to Willard Copp Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence H. Jones of West Roxbury, Mass., which will take place the afternoon of Oct. 16 in St. John's Episcopal Church, West Hartford.

With an optimism that deserves to be successful Finance Minister Georges Bonnet has presented to the Finance Committee of the Chamber of Deputies a budget project for next year that shows or paper a surplus of 1,600,000,00O francs.

READERS of Major Wren's earlier story, "The Spur of Pride," will not want to miss this sequel (or companion book, as he quite properly calls it) to that stirring tale of intrigue and high adventure in that far and wild corner of the world, the Anglo-Russian-Afghan border.

Mrs. Madeleine R. Cahall, Russian wife of Dr. W. L. Cahall, has devoted two rooms in her seven-room apartment at Broadway and 151st Street, to birds. In addition to her indoor pets, she daily feeds a flock of pigeons on Broadway and cares for injured pigeons and sparrows.

Coincident with preparations for the opening of the National Automobile Show here Oct. 27, manufacturers and dealers throughout the country are going ahead with plans for presenting and selling their 1938 models.

THE subject of this book is explosive. For nearly two decades, the problem of the "Anschluss," the union of Germany and Austria, has kept Europe's statesmen busy. At first Austria wanted it so badly that she all but threw herself into Germany's arms.

" Madama Butterfly," Saturday matinee. Mmes. Samson and Ippolito, and messrs. Power, Stefan Kozakevich (debut), Angelini, Molle and Bozza. Conductor, Bamboschek. "Otello," Saturday night. Mmes. Ruth Peter and Ippolito, and Messrs. Lindi, Valle, Curci, Bozza, Miller and Molle. Conductor, Bamboschek.

Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Coe of Belgrade Lakes, Me., and Belleair, Fla., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Spelman Coe, to Warren Oakes Taylor of Boston, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Frederic W. Taylor of Cambridge, Mass.

Miss Helen Jensen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl C. Jensen of this place, will be married to Peter Smith of Horton, Wyo., on Oct. 23 in the First Congregational Church of Old Greenwich by the Rev. Alden S. Mosshammer, the pastor.

The following Foreign Service changes since Sept. 11 were announced today by the State Department: Lester Maynard of San Francisco, Consul General at Copenhagen, will retire from the Foreign Service on the basis of thirty years service, effective Dec. 31. George J. Haering of Huntington Station, N. Y.. assigned to Warsaw as Consul; orders to Antwerp canceled.

Groups of C. I. O. longshoremen broke through one A. F. L. teamster union picket line and escorted fellow workers past others today, amid growing tension in their struggle for jurisdiction over warehousemen.

Minkin Osias report that many leases have been made in two new Queens apartment buildings owned and operated by them and which will be ready for occupancy Oct. 1. In the Allendale, 34-24 Eighty-second Street, Jackson Heights, suites have been leased by John F. Knebel, Eric Y. Munson, John F. Walsh,

Municipal STEAMFITTER--Labor Class. Salary, $11.20 per day, pension, vacation. Vacancies, occur from time to time; three appointments made from last list. Ages, not under 21 when filing and not over 45 on day of examination. Applicants must produce birth certificates at time of filing.

WHEN the Postoffice Department considers the issue of a new stamp it naturally turns to the nation's No. 1 stamp collector, who happens to be the President of the United States. This it did recently when it wished to pay tribute
Norman Thomas was nominated as a candidate for delegate at large to the constitutional convention by the State convention of the Socialist party yesterday.
The roar of bombs' explosions and the cries of thousands of innocent victims in China could be heard this week in places as distant as the highceilinged rooms of the British Foreign Office,

S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, told the Sinking Fund Commission last week that many polling places now in use were too small to permit the installation of booths in which the vote for City Councilmen might be cast.

The six New England Governors have been in conference over the united movement in nine Southern States for a revision of railroad freight rates. The Southern demand for "rectification" contemplates the possibility that the Black-Connery

A match between the New Jersey Women's Golf Association and the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association will be played on Monday over the Wykagyl Country Club course for the Mrs. J. J. Thompson Trophy.

Nature is playing one of her fantastic tricks on housewives this Fall-lavish with some foods, niggardly with others. The result is that some prices in the food stores are at rock bottom while others are sky high.

FOURTEEN young men, al accomplished airplane pilots, last week took their places at desks and tables in one of the larger rooms of the Bureau of Air Commerce and started training for a place in the new Certificate and Inspection Division.

Trading in September corn was suspended by the directors of the Chicago Board of Trade before the opening of the market today. The order was voted to end the technical corner resulting from the inability of shorts to obtain corn to deliver in accordance with their contracts.

President Seymour of Yale announced today the appointment of a committee from the university to cooperate with the city committee appointed to arrange for the celebration of New Haven's tercentenary. y.

Fire, brought temporarily under control late today in the outlying residential section of North Oakland, broke out anew tonight at a point three-quarters of a mile away and endangered homes in the Tunnel Road district.

Dr. and Mrs. George S. McLaughlin of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carroll McLaughlin, to Keith Rollin i Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Keith R. Manville of Highland Park. rk.

Miss Alice Mason Tyler, daughter of Mrs. William Thomas Tyler and the late Mr. Tyler, was married to Robert Wheelwright Henley, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Leonard Henley of Tappahannock, this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church here.

In an effort to determine some of the underlying factors behind the action of the stock market in the last three weeks, when prices have fallen in one trading session after another, the New York Stock Exchange addressed yesterday a questionnaire to all members requesting full information on all trades in United States Steel common stock.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John S. Cox of this place of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Verna Frances Cox, to Kenneth Perkins Kenyon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Perry B. Kenyon of New London, Conn.

The marriage of Miss Isabel Marie Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Z. Smith of this place, to Arnold E. Mooz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Mooz, also of Scars dale, took place here this evening in the Church of St. James the Less.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Marcus of Stratford Place, this city, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Evelyn Florence Marcus, to Aaron Goldstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Goldstein of New York.

Max Schmeling, visibly embarrassed in top hat and morning coat, stole the show today at a lavish beauty exhibition staged by Chancellor Adolf Hitler for the benefit of his Italian guest, Premier Benito Mussolini. .

A book for boys, published thirty-six years ago and sold for a small price, has become one of the rarities which book collectors hunt. The book is entitled "White Horse Fred or Julian Among the Outlaws" and was written by "Harry Castlemon."
In a statement to the German press, Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy, who arrived in Munich this morning, emphasizes that Germany and Italy are pursuing a common policy for peace.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 24: COLONELS Mitchell, H. D., Adjutant General's Dept., six days leave, Sept. 27. Scott, G. H., Med. Corps, four months leave, Sept. 30. Upham. J. S., Inf., three months and 25 days leave, Oct. 6.

A world economic boycott against any nation resorting to the bombing of civilians was proposed yesterday by Rabbi Abraham L. Feinberg in his sermon at Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street. He declared "non-resistance to evil" could be the slogan of modern religion when confronted with the "deliberate bombing of noncombatants in China or anywhere else."

Dr. William M. Leiserson of the National Mediation Board said today conferences between committees of the Big Five railroad brotherhoods and managers of eighty-six roads had been adjovrned until Wednesday.

The fighting Illinois team polished to a high lustre the opening of Bob Zuppke's silver jubilee year as head football coach today with a smart 20-6 triumph over the battling Bobcats of Ohio University.

Thirteen-year-old Archie Dean Jr. of Larchmont piloted Mrs. Gordon Wright's veteran campaigner, Sonny, to the jumping championship in the sixth annual Byran River Beagle Club horse show today and a few minutes later captured the horsemanship title for himself to provide two of the exhibition's features.

Breaking 100 straight in a shootoff, Louis Paglinghi of Vineland won the first Atlantic States trapshooting championship at the North Jersey Gun Club today. At the end of the regular 200-target shoot, Paglinghi, A. S. Cornhill of City Island and E. H. Young of Dayton tied with 197's.

A STATEMENT on the policy of the British Broadcasting Corporation regarding the broadcasting of "peace propaganda" has been sent to the International Broadcasting Union at Geneva in reply to the following question: "Have you organized programs to foster international good-will; since when, and what conclusions have you drawn?"
Two army planes collided in mid-air today, killing one of the pilots while the other parachuted to safety.

Results of football games played in the British Isles today: ENGLISH LEAGUE. First Division. Charlton Athletic 1, Middlesbrough 0 Chelsea 2. Stoke City 1. Derby County 2. Arsenal 0. Everton 1. Huddersfield Town 2. Grimsby 1. West Bromwich Albion 4.

Supporters of Mayor La Guardia's anti-noise campaign will have something of perhaps more fundamental importance than the departure of the American Legion to cheer about on Tuesday, when for the first time a new breed of barkless" dogs will be introduced to this noisy community and to the United States.

WHILE in many instances engineering details remain confidential until such time as public announcements of the 1938 models are made by the manufacturers, two facts at least may be disclosed in regard to the passenger cars of the coming season as a result of the previews for automobile and technical men which have been held by the industry during the last few weeks.

Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, put in a busy day yesterday signing Utah for space in the Hall of States, the first State to enter into a formal agreement for representation at the 1939 exposition on the Flushing meadows, and escorting Italian and German delegations around the fair grounds.

Wayne C. Robinette and Sydney Vann have opened a real estate office at 58 Cedar Lane, Teaneck, N. J. An eight-room residence of Georgian type is being erected by Donald Leavens from plans by Matthews M. Simpson in Countryside,

Sophomores shouldered the responsibility for a build-up in University of Wisconsin football prestige today by contributing flashly aerial and ground plays toward a 32-to-0 victory over South Dakota State in the opening game.

The first forty-five of the 1,622 families who eventually will occupy the Williamsburg Houses in Brooklyn, the largest public low-rent housing center in the United States, will move into their new homes next Thursday, it was announced yesterday by Langdon W. Post, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, in charge of the project under lease from the Public Works Administration.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, said today that Robert Travis, organizer who was in charge of union activity in Flint, Mich., during last Winter's General Motors strike, would be transferred to an undetermined post.

BERDYAEV is indubitably the most exciting writer on religious themes today. Though a scholar with the scientific and religious thought of the time at his finger-ends, he writes creatively, with passion, with a kind of concentrated rationalization, reminiscent of Dostoevsky's dictum, "I philosophize like a poet."

Dr. Kean Henri Nicolas, rose expert and for nine years director of research at the Jackson and Perkins trial and display rose gardens here, died in his sleep early today in the Hotel Ten Eyck, Albany. His age was 62. Dr. Nicolas had been making a week's inspection tour of nurseries and rose gardens in Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Connecticut.

J. Fred Essary, Washington correspondent of The Baltimore Sun, will be among speakers at the annual meeting of the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers at Providence, R. I., Oct. 6 and 7, it was announced yesterday.

Four hundred thousand freshmen entering college this Fall, North, South, East and West, face a very different course of study from that through which their parents were graduated a quarter-century ago, according to a study of over 200 college catalogues just completed by the writers. On the other hand, the entrance requirements which these same freshmen have just passed off are not so different from those of their parents' day as is usually supposed.
A power-driven University of Texas football machine celebrated Coach Dana X. Bible's re-entry into Southwestern gridiron warfare today by crushing Texas Technological College, 25 to 12.

Virtually every player on the University of Maryland squad saw action today as the Terrapins opened their football season with an easy 25-to-0 victory over St. John's College of Annapolis. Immediately following the opening kickoff, the Old Liners marched to a touchdown and there was no doubt of their strength from then on.

Miss Mary Pierce Hammond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman Pierce Hammond of Greens Farms, Conn., was married to Edward Hawley Roper, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Charles Roper of New York and Indian Head Point, Riverside, this afternoon in Saugatuck Congregational Church in Westport, by the Rev. Richard T. Elliott, the pastor.

Although he failed to come in for leadership in any of the divisions at the end of the first round today in the second annual Glen Ridge Country Club's invitation best-ball golf tournament, Fred Kammer of Baltusrol stole the show with a sub-par 70.
Mr. and Mrs. Dwight F. Davis Jr. have come to the Madison from The Clovers, Southampton, where they passed the Summer. Mr. and Mrs. George Higginson 2d of Brookline, Mass., are at the Ritz-Carlton.

To the Music Editor: I have read with much interest Mr. Downes's article of Sept. 19. Through long custom, Saturday night has become established for regular subscription concerts by most of the symphony orchestras throughout the country. New York,

Further meetings of executives of leading rayon fabric mills are scheduled this week in an effort to determine upon a curtailment program satisfactory to all interests. While a number of complications have arisen during the preliminary discussions in the last few weeks, some traders said yesterday they are convinced that a workable plan will be developed.

South Africa defeated New Zealand, 17-6, before a crowd of 50,000 spectators today, winning the rubber in the threegame Rugby series against the famous All Blacks. In the first test at Wellington, Aug. 14. the home players triumphed, 13-7, but the Springboks earned a 13-6 decision in the second at Christchurch, Sept. 4.
Quentin Cooper and Bobby Ackerman led the Pompton Lakes High School gridiron squad to its twentieth-consecutive victory as Ramsey High School was beaten, 6 to 0, today.

Ruth Roland, former film actress, who died Wednesday, left 50 per cent of her estate to her husband, Ben Bard, producer, and the other half to relatives, her will and codicil showed today. The estate was valued unofficially by lawyers at about $1,000,000, mostly in real estate.

Another dormitory in Radcliffe's quadrangle, Ella Lyman Cabot Hall, the sixth in the group of Georgian buildings of comparatively recent construction, is being opened this week-end to welcome seventy-two students from many localities whose classes begin Monday.

Professor Carl Frederick Schreiber of Yale University and Mrs. Schreiber have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Schreiber, to George Sullivan Stearns Jr. of New Britain, Conn., son of Mrs. Naomi Campbell Stearns of Miami, Fla., and the late George Sullivan Stearns of Cincinnati and Miami.

Dr. Rush Rhees, president emeritus of the University of Rochester, and Mrs. Rhees of Rochester, N. Y., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Henrietta Seelye Rhees, to Dr. John Dunham Stewart of Boston, son of the late Dr. Henry Dixon Stewart and Mrs. Stewart of Monroe, N. C.

Before the expression "adult education" became little more than a catch phrase to unthinking masses, the American Association of University Women had launched its "continued-study" program which in the New York City branch has assumed such proportions that materially larger quarters have had to be provided.

Preliminary play for the Westchester County contract bridge tournament for the J. Noel Macy Trophy will get under way on Monday night, Oct. 4, in ten districts in the county. The finals will be held on Oct. 25 and 26 at the Westchester Country Club in Rye.

A DREAM of seventeen years ago be comes a reality for the President of the United States. The long, black mountain locomotive that pulls his special train over the crest of the Continental Divide and down into the vast fastnesses of the Pacific Northwest takes Franklin D. Roosevelt on an epic pilgrimage. It is a journey he has awaited for nearly a generation. n.
Greentree reached the final round of the last of the season's major polo tournaments when it turned back Templeton, 10 to 6, on Hitchcock Field today in the Waterbury Cup competition.
MOVING DAY, dawning next Friday, is likely to see more New York households in transit, bag and baggage, from old diggings to new than any other October first has seen since 1928.

Spectacular scoring runs by a trio of Dartmouth backs, Bob MacLeod. Bill Hutchinson and Joe Cottone, enlivened an otherwise dull contest today as the Big Green ran up a 39-0 count on Bates. At no time did the Indians manage to stage a consistent march and only the running ability of Bob MacLeod and Dartmouth's penchant for grabbing loose aerials caused the score to mount.

The University of Tennessee, making touchdowns almost at will, triumphed, 32 to 0, in the season's opener with Wake Forest College today. Tennessee's initial two touchdowns came in the first ten plays. The Vals used three teams.

The University of Georgia annihilated Oglethorpe University in the opening game of the football season here today. The score was 60 to 0. The Bulldogs, after being held scoreless in the first period, broke through for a touchdown in the early part of the second quarter and from then it was a rout.

The American premiere of Terence Rattigan's English comedy, "French Without Tears," was received by a capacity audience here tonight in McCarter Theatre. Presented by Gilbert Miller, the play enjoyed a year's run in London before being brought to this country.
WE were not present when the virile representatives of the American Legion fired pistols in Macy's department store. No one assaulted us with a squirt gun.

Checks for $4,000 to the Newark club for finishing first in the Governor's Cup series, and for $2,000 to the Baltimore club for being the runner-up in that set, were mailed yesterday by William J. Manley, secretary-treasurer of the International League, The Associated Press reports.

A staff of executives has been selected to direct the service at Hampshire House, the new thirty seven story apartment hotel which will open on Central Park South Oct. 1. Among those chosen is Rene Durand, former chef at the Louis Quatorze Restaurant in Rockefeller Center, who will serve in a similar capacity at the new hotel.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 24, unless specified: Boston Yard to sea, Sept. 25: Case. Conyngham. At New York Yard: Dahlgren, Texas. Badger, at Annapolis. Cassin, at Newport. Guyama, San Pedro to Puget Sound Yard, Sept. 25. Erie. at Nantucket. Sept. 25.

The Foreign Office announced tonight that Mamoru Shigemitsu, Ambassador to Moscow, shortly would protest to the Soviet Government against alleged mistreatment of Japanese workmen in the Russian half of Sakhalin Island.

With its backfield entirely different from the one that started a week ago, the Brooklyn Football Dodgers will seek to get back into the Eastern divisional pennant chase at Ebbets Field this afternoon when they meet the new but powerful Cleveland Rams.
Through the air and around the ends Purdue University romped to a 33-to-7 victory over Butler University today in the opening football game of the season for both schools.

Middlebury College, only undefeated eleven in the East last season, dropped her opening encounter to Williams today by 7-0. A 54-yard drive in the second period gave the victors their only touchdown. Captain Fielding Simmons plunged over from the one-yard line and kicked the extra point.

Four foreign exchange students are registered at Barnard College this term as Students Fellows. They include Mathilde Perez Zabala, from Argentine; Caroline Fessia, Italy; Svetla Nacheva, Bulgaria, and Ilse Wiegand, Germany.
THE author of this book is a well-known international publicist--a trifle mystical, possibly--but with sound judgment on British and German industrial, social and economic problems.

Recommendations that the State mortgage moratorium be "tapered off" so that the mortgage business might be restored to a normal basis by the end of 1941 have been approved by the special mortgage committee of the Metropolitan Association of Real Estate Boards, according to Clarke G. Dailey, chairman of the committee and president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

A plan circled and landed at the Lido Civil Airport in Venice one June morning in 1934. Adolf Hitler, Chancellor of Germany since January. 1933, soon to proclaim himself the German Fuehrer, alighted to be greeted by Benito Mussolini, Premier, and dictator of Italy Since October, 1922.

Justice O. Byron Brewster of the Supreme Court suggested last night as a "cure to end county-government strife" the election to a four-year term of a Supervisor at Large. Addressing the annual convention of the Supervisors Association of New York State, Justice Brewster said:

The State committee of the American Labor party nominated for delegates-at-large to the constitutional convention yesterday seven of the Democratic candidates named at Albany by the Democratic State Committee. It failed to nominate any Republican candidate for delegate-at-large.

J. Thomas Heflin, opening his comeback Senatorial campaign today, declared opposition to the pending Federal Wages and Hours Bill and said that he saw "no necessity" of increasing the Supreme Court "as it stands today."

Jogues Memorial Day will be celebrated today. In thousands of churches the feast day of St. Isaac Jogues, St. John de Brebeuf and their six companions in pioneer missionary work among the North American Indians will be eulogized.
A new course in advertising production is announced by the evening session of City College at its School of Business, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street. The course is open to men and women.

Mail and telegraph orders received in the New York wholesale market last week were heavier than usual as American Legion activities caused postponement of buying trips, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 1st Lt. John K. Coughlan, Air-Res., 24 Allen St., Hillside Heights, New Hyde Park, N. Y., 305th Balloon Squadron, is ordered to active duty effective, Oct 3, at Fort Bragg, N. C., for training, Lt. Coughlan will rank from Sept. 19 and will revert to inactive status Oct. 16.
Red-haired Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., retained his Pacific Southwest tennis title today by achieving his fourth important victory of the season over Baron Gottfried von Cramm of Germany.

ALLARDYCE NICOLL, Professor of Dramatic History and Criticism at Yale, is inspiring and directing a tremendously interesting and valuable work at his university-the gathering of material for a comprehensive photographic collection of theatrical plans and designs. So far over 30,000 prints and drawings in English, American. French, German, Italian,

Miss Mildred D. Everett, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. E. Everett of Berkeley, Calif., was married this afternoon to Raymond P. Ensign at the home of Miss Harriet Bache here. The Rev. Wendell Phillips of the Trinity Episcopal Church of this city performed the ceremony.
Richard Halliburton, author and world traveler, has bought a site at Laguna Beach, Southern California, on which he is having constructed an ultra-modern, ferroconcrete dwelling for his occupancy.

Stanley M. Bruce of Australia proposed today to the Economic Committee of the League of Nations Assembly that the League undertake four inquiries, including among the subjects "hot money" and how to avoid the slump that he fears is coming.

The hearing of the murder charge against Miss Gertrude O'Keefe, charged with the slaying of her former fiance, was again adjourned yesterday until Tuesday after the Brooklyn District Attorney's office asked for additional time in which to investigate.
Officials of gas companies in all parts of the United States will meet tomorrow in Cleveland to attend the American Gas Association's nineteenth annual convention.

Welcomed on the campus this week by a reception committee of ten upper classmen he 143 members of the freshman class will be greeted at a tea tomorrow by President Marion Edwards Park. She will address the entire undergraduate body at chapel Tuesday morning.

An opportunity to hear themselves as others hear them is being granted to freshmen beginning their college careers at the University of Rochester. Each student speaks into the "mike" and the record is played back. Wilbur Dingwell, instructor in English and dramatics director, makes the recordings, points out defects and offers suggestions for their cure.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Ann Callery, daughter of Mrs. John Callery of Weehawken, to Lawrence Kenneth Dugan, son of Mrs. John Van Vorst of Ilion, N. Y., and the late Dr. Lawrence K. Dugan, took place here at noon today in St. Augustine's Church.

The joint board of the Workers Alliance of Greater New York announced yesterday that the organization of WPA workers and home relief recipients would support Mayor La Guardia and the American Labor party ticket in the forthcoming municipal election.
The graves of eleven signers of the Constitution will be marked by the Pennsylvania Constitution Commemoration Committee in simultaneous services in three States Wednesday.

THERE is and always has been something about islands, or perhaps it would be more nearly accurate to say about the idea of islands, which lures humanity. "All the best stories of one's youth have islands in them," Russell Murray reminds Cornelia.
The reorganization of physical education courses at Hunter College will affect almost 4,000 students enrolled in gymnasium classes in the day and evening sessions.

IS poverty a bar to distinction as a poet? This question has been debated of late in the press as part of a larger controversy provoked by Professor John Hilton's complaint of the disparity between the opportunities open to a boy from an elementary school and those available to one whose parents can afford to give him an expensive education.

By taking the measure of the Dodgers, 7-3, the Giants maintained their lead of three and a half games in the National League pennant race. The second-place Cubs also triumphed, turning back the Cardinals, 5-2. Lefty Gomez pitched his twenty-first victory of the year for the Yankees, who beat the Red Sox, 5-2. .

Scattered embers from a bonfire in which a paint can exploded early last night caused serious injury to two children at Home Place and Willow Brook Road, West New Brighton, S. I. Both were taken to St. Vincent's Hospital, near by, where little hope is held for their recovery.

The three-story home of Colonel Donald M. Liddell at 1,341 North avenue was destroyed by fire about ? o'clock tonight. The loss was placed unofficially at $20,000, not including damage to antique furniture and several valuable chess tests, of which Colonel Liddell is a Collector.

Seven hundred airmen, representing executive, manufacturing and operating divisions of the aviation industry, will meet in Los Angeles Oct. 7 to 9 for the National Aircraft Production Meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers, it was announced at the office of John A. C. Warner, general manager of the society, yesterday.

NOW, having reached the ripe old age of 28, Mr. Harvey reveals his life to the world and tells that world. in passing, what is wrong with it. Incidentally, he tells in a frank and forthright manner what was wrong with Basil Harvey.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marion Dudley Tobey, daughter of Mrs. Earle Deyo Tobey of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., and Nantucket, Mass., and the late Mr. Tobey, to Lieutenant Kjell Haakon Emil Rustad, son of Mr. and Mrs. Trygve Thorleif Rustad of Oslo, Norway.
China's greatest cities, except those under Japanese occupation, were subjected today to devastating bombing by the Japanese air forces, ranging over nearly all the eastern Provinces.

A member of the rare tribe of voluntary walkers, fresh from a trip on the hoof, pack on back, through the Green Mountains (though the White Mountains, the Rockies or the Sierras would doubtless have done as well), writes to say that what this country needs most is a revival of pedestrianism.

A new era dawns for Cornell University with the seventieth opening faking place tomorrow. Marking as it does the beginning of the administration of Dr. Edmund Ezra Day, who will be inaugurated as Cornell's fifth president on Oct. 2, the start of the new academic year has a deeper significance for Cornellians than that of many previous years.

German and Italian overtures to secure fishing rights and stretches of land in the Finnish Petsamo district on the Arctic coast, which caused irritation in the Finnish press because it was feared the grant of a concession would have dangerous political implications for Finland, now have definitely failed.

Massachusetts State College was held to a 6-6 tie today by the American International College eleven of this city. The game was marred by many fumbles on both sides. On the other hand, the line play of Carlo Siniscalchi for American International was outstanding.

IT is nearly fourteen years since the Pierpont Morgan Library was converted into a public educational institution. How comfortably it has surmounted the lean years is shown in a "Review of the Activities and Acquisitions of the Library From 1930 Through 1935," recently published. It is a record that other institutions must regard with envy.

A movement to prolong the current wholesale and retail season for coats and suits will be instituted this week by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., who said yesterday that in previous seasons late October sales had tended to bring the cold weather coat season to an untimely conclusion.

IN the morning of Jan. 30, 1899, the dead body of Crown Prince Rudolph, son of Emperor-King Franz Joseph of Austria and Hungary, was found in the imperial shooting lodge of Mayerling, in the Vienna woods. Next to him lay the lifeless body of 19-year-old Baroness Marie Vetsera, a Vienna society girl.

BOOKS titled with the name of a foreign land are usually classified under the heading of travel, which, as this one proves, can be a great mistake. It is a book of understanding and interpretation, and there is little in it for the tourist.

The marriage of Miss Marguerite Hillebrandt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Hillebrandt, to Charles Wesley Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. E. W. Johnson of East Rockaway, L. I., took place here this evening in the Presbyterian Webb Memorial Chapel. The Rev. John W. Parks, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo., where President Roosevelt is spending this week-end, has been setting new tourist records this year, with 500,000 visitors registered thus far. Yellowstone is the oldest and largest of the national parks, but until recent years it has been a wilderness area not easily seen by the tourist. It is still a wilderness,

Open Champion Ralph Guldahl, fresh from his Western free-for-all conquest, moved into the quarterfinal round of the $12,000 Belmont open match play golf tournament today by overwhelming Paul Runyan of White Plains, N. Y., a former P. G. A. titleholder, 8 and 7.

The most successful gardeners are those who do not hesitate to get out of the well-worn ruts. This does not imply that they are ready to try every new theory advanced--any one who grows things knows how often theories that apparently have been successfully applied in experiments

A goal by T. A. Bradley in the closing seconds of the final period gave the Rumson Country Club polo team a 6-5 victory over the Governors Island four yesterday at Morris Memorial Field, where 2,000 persons turned out for the annual Army Relief Day program.

Politicians and hostile commentators who had confidently expected President Roosevelt to unsheath his scalping knife when he visited the bailiwick of Senator O'Mahoney of Wyoming yesterday must have been temporarily forgetful of the President's political acumen. If there are scalps to be sought, as has been persistently reported in reliable circles, the time apparently has not yet arrived. d.
Headed by Governor Lehman and Postmaster General Farley, the Democratic chiefs of New York puts their State-wide campaign into motion here today at a rally of the Union of Democratic Clubs.
Mr. And Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney gave a large dance tonight at their home, which adjoins that of Mr. Whitney's mother, Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney, in Old Westbury. ry.

President Roosevelt arrived here today to spend two days and a night seeing the park. In contrast to the first two days of his trip, which saw Mr. Roosevelt pledging himself to continue his New Deal policies, today was devoted to a motor tour of the park.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Chamberlin, daughter of Mrs. John H. Casanave of The Trees, Wayne, Pa., and Longport, N. J., to J. Blair Hutton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh A. Hutton of Margate, took place here today in St. James Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William F. Doyle.
A Federal subsidy for cotton growers was advocated here yesterday by Colonel Lawrence Westbrook, special investigator for the Senate Committee on Agriculture.

THE annual invasion of America's institutions of higher learning is now drawing to a close. Frantic days of registration and interviews are about over; quiet and order are being swiftly restored at colleges
Westminster Abbey, stripped of its coronation draperies and panels at last, has been restored to its former quiet dignity and will be opened tomorrow for public inspection and worship.

An alert White Plains High School football team turned back Chaminade, 20 to 7, today at the White Plains Stadium before a crowd of 1,500 persons. Each of the winner's touchdowns came on a recovered fumble.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Sept. 22, aggregated $9,236,000,000, or 2 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 20 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Sentiment in investment banking circles is rapidly coming to a boil, presaging open rebellion against official regulation. With stock and bond prices thudding sullenly downward, wrecking the market for new issues, leaders of the community find their patience at an end.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Weye Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Everett Smith of this city, to John Beauchamp Coppedge Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Coppedge of East Orange, took place this evening. The ceremony was performed in Hillside Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. John A. MacSporran.
Armchair economists of 1914 predicted a short war because Europe had no money for a long one. They were wrong. A war is one luxury which the nations seem able to afford at any time.

Dean Ned H. Dearborn of the New York University Division of General Education announced yesterday the appointment of seven authorities to teach as many new courses in training for public service this Fall. Classes will begin tomorrow.

THE winding up of Summer shows, the reopening of galleries for Fall and plans for the new season all played a part in the news of the week just ended. The closing days of September this year are marked by unwonted signs of activity.

A Marquette eleven that alternately played excellent and ragged football disposed of Ripon College, 14 to 0, in the season's opener before 5,000 fans today. Coach John L. (Paddy) Driscoll, who took over the Marquette job this year, seeking a candidate to replace Ray (Buzz) Buvid, the 1936 All-America passing ace, found a promising candidate among his sophomores in Andy Bakula, a big Milwaukee lad.

THE sculptor Bourdelle was endowed with a winning personality which made him many friends during his active and fruitful life and caused the general public to feel, when he died, that France had lost a rare man as well as an outstanding artist.

Miss Kathleen Elizabeth Boyce, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Richter of Boonton Park, was married in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church this afternoon to Christopher J. McCulloch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter S. McCulloch of New York. e pastor, the Rev.

Old age assistance and the liberalization of the public pension have not, contrary to expectations, reduced the population of the city's homes for the aged and thus has not cut the cost to the city of this type of care, Hospital Commissioner S. S. Goldwater reported yesterday. In fact, Dr. Goldwater said,

" The Japanese airmen's impressions, gained at a height of 12,000 feet while attempting to dodge anti-aircraft shells, can hardly be more accurate than those of the pilots who from a height of a few hundred meters mistook the limousine of a neutral Ambassador for a motor-bus."

Mrs. Mabel Craddock, who was the delegate of the Altrusa Club of New York to the international Altrusa convention, held in Cuernavaca, Mexico, June 23 to 26, will present a convention report at the opening meeting of the club on Tuesday at 7:30 P. M.

Revealing a wealth of power in both the aggressive and defensive phases of the game, the New York University football team opened its season by registering a decisive triumph over the Pennsylvania Military College eleven at Ohio Field yesterday.

Miss Anna May Voege, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry William Voege of Brooklyn and Garden City, was married to John J. Tun-more, son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Tun-more of Garden City, here yesterday afternoon in the rectory of the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola by the Rev. John L. Gittrich of Chaptico, Md.

Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, who observed his third anniversary yesterday as commander of the New York Police Department, made a gift to the members of the uniformed force in the form of a general order granting two additional days vacation for their work during the four-day American Legion convention.

The common grievance that the middleman is the omnipresent character who deprives the factory of its profit and makes goods dear to the consumer was partly exploded last week by no less an authority than a government economist.

A hard-driving, tricky Indiana University aggregation trounced a stubborn but outclassed Centre College eleven, 12 to 0, before approximately 8.000 fans today. Corby Davis, 200-pound fullback from Lowell, Ind., scored touchdowns for Indiana in the first and fourth periods after steady downfield marches.

THE Worcester Music Festival opens Monday, Oct. 4, and continues through Saturday, Oct. 9. There will be five evening events, all at 8:15 o'clock, and a young people's concert Wednesday, Oct. 6, at 4:15 P. M.
Mrs. Herman Adaskin of Springfield, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Viola Adaskin, to Eugene B. Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. I. Nathan Schwartz of Jersey City.
A horse that could have been claimed three weeks ago for $1,500 yesterday captured the $23,540 Lawrence Realization at Belmont Park before a completely flabbergasted crowd of 20,000 persons.
NOW that Edward Johnson has returned from abroad, word may be expected shortly regarding definite details for the coming Metropolian Opera season, Mr.Johnson's third as general manager.
With the aid of a good passing attack and a strong line, the University of New Hampshire scored an easy victory over Lowell Textile, 20-0, today.

The Rev. Dr. Barnard C. Taylor, internationally known as a Hebrew scholar, died at his home in Red Bank, N. J., last night in his eighty-eighth year. He broke a rib in a fall a month ago but it had healed. Death was attributed to a heart ailment.
The marriage of Marjorie I. Peet of New Haven, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Peet of this town, to Everett C. Bradley of West Haven took place this afternoon in the Congregational Church.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Miriam Read Brands, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Jergen Brands of this place, to S. Brevoort Hood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Hood, also of Ridgewood.

Miss Odette Lapointe, only daughter of Minister of Justice Ernest Lapointe, was married here today to Roger Ouimet of Montreal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ouimet of Ottawa, in Saint Coeur de Marie Church.

Miss Dorothy Elizabeth Pitman, daughter of Mrs. Hugh Seaman of Cos Cob, was married to Robert J. Olsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Olsen of Port Chester, this morning in St. Catherine Roman Catholic Church, Riverside, by the Rev. Joseph A. Ganley.
Premier Mussolini tonight sped by special train to the army manoeuvre area in Mecklenburg and is now "somewhere in the field" with the Third Reich's field-gray warriors.

Virginia's eleven, coached by Frank Murray, who came here last Spring from Marquette, won from Hampden-Sydney today, 13 to 7. The Tigers took the lead in the third quarter when Walden raced 75 yards to score, but the Cavaliers came back with two touchdowns in the same period.

The retirement of Anton G. Christensen, general passenger agent of the United Staets Lines and an employe of the International Mercantile Marine Company for forty-five years, was announced yesterday. Mr. Christensen is one of the most widely known men in the maritime passenger field and for years handled the travel arrangements of men and women prominent in the financial and social world.

BASEBALL New York Giants vs. Brooklyn Dodgers, at Polo Grounds, 157th Street and Eighth Avenue .........................3 P. M. New York A. C. vs. Long Island City Club, at Travers Island ............................ 3:30 P. M. Dominican Republicans vs. Negro National League Stars, at Yankee Stadium, 161st Street and River Avenue ................. 2 P. M.

With the end of daylight saving time effective at 2 A. M. today, millions of persons in New York and elsewhere were expected to have to set back their clocks and watches one hour when they retired last night.

THE scene: A bench in Bryant Park. Time: An Autumn afternoon, 1913. The tragic occupant of the bench is a young man, just turned 20. Behind him is a six-month scuffle with the faculty of the University of Washington, a term at the Academy of Dramatic Arts, an implication in three out-of-town fiascoes. He is wrestling with a problem. Into which river shall he hurtle, the Harlem or the Hudson?

Intervention by the bureau of mediation and arbitration of the division of industrial relations of the State Labor Department in 114 strikes, involving 32,923 workers, during the month of August has been announced by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews. Sixty-nine of the strikes, involving 26,319 employes, were terminated during the month.

Jack Hagerty, Georgetown University's gridiron mentor, is coaching by remote control these days. Ill with influenza, Hagerty is directing his charges from his sick bed by direct telephone to the football field.

Cardinal Hayes has set apart Oct. 3 as the first "Catechetical Sunday." This hereafter will be an annual observance and will be known as "The Feast of Christian Doctrine." Its purpose will be to pray for a deeper and wider interest in the study of the doctrines of the Roman Catholic Church.

Pearce P. Williams of Montclair, N. J., has purchased a new residence containing eight rooms in the Cannon Hill section of Huntington, L. I. The house occupies a plot of half an acre and was constructed by L. E. Berkey Son, Huntington builders. Moore Hutchins of New York City were the architects.
Robert H. Davis, 21 years old, of Troy former Rensselaer Polytechnic In stitute athlete, died today after lying paralyzed for more than two years with a broken back suffered in a gymnasium accident.

The appointment of Joseph C. Shipman as library consultant to assist Helmer L. Webb in charge of the library at Union College, has focused attention again on what the college is doing to encourage personal cultivation by each student.
A well balanced squad of Negro athletes from Tuskegee Institute in Alabama carried off premier honors today at the 1937 Women's National A. A. U. track and field championships.
Arriving for a conference with Alf M. Landon, 1936 Republican Presidential nominee, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr.

John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, warned State and county leaders of New Jersey today against proposals for coalition with Democratic Senators who voted against President Roosevelt on the Supreme Court issue.

Declaring that public secondary schools have other functions "quite as important" as preparing students for college, an associate commissioner of the State Education Department recommended today several changes in regents examination requirements.

Indian Day celebration, Inwood Hill Park, 2:30 P. M. Speakers: Chief George P. Littlemoose, Chief George Thomas, Chief James Deer. Metropolitan Museum of Art. Motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.: "Elements of Design," Grace Cornerll, 3 P.M.

Many factors indicate that Lexington Avenue in the blocks from Sixtieth to Ninety-sixth Street will, in the near future, become one of the popular residential thorough-fares on the East Side, declares Douglas L. Elliman, head of the realty firm bearing his name.

Miss Helen Marie Faissole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Faissole of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Eugene Jose Antuna, son of Mrs. Josepha Braga de Antuna of Tenafly and the late Bernardo Antuna, which will take place on Oct. 7 in New York.

The new Anglo-French policy of more resolution and courage, which expressed itself ten days ago in the framing of the Nyon convention, despite Italian and German opposition, is considered to have taken a step forward.
ABOUT twenty-five years ago Mr. Lippmann wrote a book called "A Preface to Politics." The general scheme of the human future, he tells us, seemed fairly clear to him then.

STREAMLINING has reached the field of road building machinery too. Striking models of power shovels, paving mixers, finishing machines, tractors, trucks, crawler wagons, compressors, graders, rollers and engines are promised for the six acre road show and convention of the American Road Builders Association scheduled for Cleveland from Jan. 17 to 21.

IT was on a warm, sunny afternoon last May-immediately after his second round-trip flight across the North Atlantic-that Richard T. (Dick) Merrill was caught up in the Hollywood dragnet. His proud captors, Monogram Pictures, invited the gentlemen of the press to their Radio City offices, where sandwiches and cooling drinks were served, to witness the flyer sign his first motion-picture contract.

Many of the late-staying members of the Summer colony were present at the Art Association today to hear James Stewart Cushman speak on "India in the Recent Crisis." Mr. and Mrs. Cushman were in India last Winter. Mr. Cushman was introduced by Mrs. Maud Howe Elliott.
One of the most important events in the Autumn social calendar of the North Shore is the Piping Rock Horse Show Ball, scheduled for Friday, the third day of the show at the Piping Rock Club.

The last Kaiser once placed himself, oratorically, by the side of Austria-Hungary "in shining armor." At Nuremberg recently Adolf Hitler did the same for Italy, giving further occasion for talk about the "Berlin-Rome axis."

The Federal Home Loan Bank Review, in its current issue, points out some striking contrasts in the tax rates of cities of comparable size in different parts of the country. One city of the 75,000 population class is cited as having a tax rate averaging 18.75 with a bonded debt less than 5 percent of the market value of the assessed property.

For fear of compromising his work of restoration, Premier Paul Van Zeeland today decided to withdraw his resignation and will remain at his post. The Cabinet will remain unchanged and the crisis which threatened the Government for the second time within a month again has been averted.

Announcement has been made here of the forthcoming marriage in Bar Harbor, Me., of Mrs. Lola Fraley Crounse, widow of William Livingston Crounse of Washington, and J. Whitla Stinson, formerly an attorney in the Latin-American Division of the State Department and afterward special attorney in the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice.

EUROPEAN peasant art, colorful and naive, is a vital source of inspiration this season for new designs in fabrics and furniture. Our own museums, as well as those abroad, have sections devoted to this basic folk expression, and now to our own shores comes a remarkably complete exhibition from Sweden-part of a large display, including rare prehistoric implements and stone carvings and paintings and tapestries dating from the seventeenth to the nineteenth century. entury.

A touchdown by Frank Fey in the final two minutes of the game gave the Jamaica High School football team a 6-to-0 victory over Adelphi Academy yesterday at the Jamaica Stadium as both teams launched their 1937 campaigns.

The growth and decline of the Ku Klux Klan, the American Liberty League and other phenomena should be included in any adequate-American history, fourteen members of the Social Science Research Council agreed here today at the Hotel Dennis.

Dr. Levering Tyson, former director of the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education, will be installed as the fifth president of Muhlenberg College the week-end of Oct. 1 and 2. He succeeds the late Dr. John A. W. Haas, president for thirty-three years.

Miss Adele Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elisha Walker of New York and the Muttontown colony here, was married to Joseph M. d'Assern at noon today in St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay.

The marriage of Miss Jane Stix Ogden, daughter of Paul Ogden of New York and the late Mrs. Adelaide Stix Ogden, to Samuel M. Kootz, also of New York, son of Mrs. Anne Kootz, took place here today at the home of Charles Sheeler.
Japanese infantry launched fierce drives today along a forty-mile front from Lotien, north of Shanghai, to the devastated Kiangwan civic center on its outskirts.

While business moved at a faster pace in most sections of the country last week, as the demand for Fall merchandise continued to gain, conditions were spotty in industrial and other districts. Hot weather and the drop in the stock market cut volume sharply in the Chicago area and widespread rumors of employe lavoffs caused some uneasiness. Railroads have started to curtail maintenance-of-way work.

MISS DODIE SMITH, formerly known in the theatre as C. L. Anthony and author of "Autumn Crocus," "Service," "Touch Wood" and "Call It a Day," is the most consistently successful playwright in England, and one to whom no one grudges her success. She is unpretentious; ous;

Pope Pius received Mgr. Stephen Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, this morning at a private audience at his Summer home here lasting half an hour. He entrusted to him a special blessing for New York Catholics.

Dr. Sinclair Tousey of Garden City, L. I., X-ray and radium specialist, died today after an illness of several weeks. Dr. Tousey, author of several books on X-ray and radium, had been a Summer resident here for many years. Six years ago he donated $5,000 worth of radium to the Morrison Hospital here.

Construction of a modern building to expand the world-famous Bodleian Library in Oxford University, England, as part of a general reconstruction and extension program is now under way and, according to present plans, will be completed within three years.

Miss Phyllis Ivins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Haddon Ivins of this place, was married this afternoon to Konrad W. Valentin, also of Englewood, formerly of Berlin-Dahlem, Germany, son of Mrs. Wilhelm J. Valentin of Johannesburg, South Africa, and the late Major Valentin.

A 50-yard forward pass, Sid White to Johnnie Murphy, freshman end, gave the Brooklyn College eleven a 12-to-6 victory over Montclair State Teachers College in the first game of the season for both teams today. The contest marked the opening of Montclair's new athletic field. A crowd of about 1,500 attended.

Wang Chung-hui, the Chinese Foreign Minister, declared in an interview today that the United States must decide whether it is willing to cooperate in concert with other nations on the re-establishment of peace in the Pacific.

Santa Clara took up its football chores today where it left off in the New Orleans Sugar Bowl last New Year's Day and defeated Stanford, 13 to 7, in the opening game of the season for both elevens. A crowd of 35,000 saw the contest.

THIS is a book that will appeal to animal lovers of any age. Bob Barton, veteran clown, animal trainer and trapeze artist, tells of his long friendship and years of close association with Trixie, the famous orangutan, born in 1904 when "The Greatest Show on Earth" was in Winter quarters at Bridgeport. t.

Miss Nancy Felton Bent, daughter of Felton Bent of this city, was married at noon today to Howard Spencer Pleasants, son of Dr. Henry Pleasants of West Chester and of Mrs. E. W. Pleasants of Wynnewood. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gibson Bell, assisted by the Rt. Rev. Roscoe P. Faust, dean of the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, at the Church of the Nativity.

The fame of Joyce Kilmer as a poet and World War hero will be perpetuated in the name of a new society at Georgian Court College here. Results of a student poll conducted last Spring by The Court Page, campus newspaper, together with the intention of honoring a poet native to the State of the college, led to the selection of Kilmer.

A Dutchess County jury today convicted Vincent A. Currie, Hudson River State Hospital attendant, of "harsh and cruel treatment" in connection with the death of a patient after acquitting him on a charge of second-degree manslaughter.

The hazards of sickness and propeller trouble that have been the besetting evils of ship schedule makers struck twice in recent weeks at transatlantic ships but failed to upset the immediate operations of the affected lines.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Sept. 15 showed that the reserve ratio of its gold to notes in circulation had risen to 132.29 per cent from 130.60 on Aug. 31. The reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities was 91.02 per cent, against 89.62 on Aug. 31.
Accused of trying to smuggle money out of Poland, Walter Milewski of Milwaukee, Wis., was sentenced today to ten months in jail and fined 9,000 zlotys. The court confiscated 60,000 zlotys.

AUTHUMN weather, lovely though it generally is, brings to the motorist another set of driving problems. Having to do with such matters as safety and economical operation of the oar, these problems are not so acute as those which Winter will bring, but their solution will make much easier and less expensive those which will be ushered in with the really cold months not so far away. far away.

Bringing new compositions listed for performance here this season, Eugene Ormandy, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, will return from Europe on Tuesday, and will begin a few days later rehearsals for the orchestra's thirty-eighth season, opening on Oct. 8.

A babysized warship, formidable, and with an unusual secrecy surrounding her, won an extraordinary naval battle on the Potomac today. Jack Rutherfurd, with his brand-new Juno, in a surprise invasion of racing circles, carried off the first heat of the President's Cup race and put himself in a position to add the second and third fifteen-mile heats tomorrow.

Dr. Robert Beddoe of the American Southern Baptist Convention, stationed at the Stout Memorial Hospital in Wuchow, has sent a signed open letter to a newspaper here calling upon Nelson T. Johnson, United States Ambassador to China, to resign following his recent temporary evacuation of the embassy in Nanking.

Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr. warned 1,200 members of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States tonight of the threats to democracy and liberty inherent in bigotry, intolerance and schemes for a "will o' the wisp security."

Civic leaders and workers and local political figures joined last night in a dinner for John J. Ott, president of the Kings County Consolidated Civic League, given by the organization at the Half Moon Hotel, Coney Island. About 600 persons were present. William A. Horton, former president of the Kings Highway Board of Trade, was toastmaster.

Thomas E. Dewey, Fusion and Labor candidate for District Attorney, was cheered lustily yesterday by about 3,000 members of District Council 9 of the Painters Union when he told them that he had provided the impetus by which they had freed themselves of racketeer control.

Designed to make easier the reading of current industrial news and to broaden popular understanding of labor disputes, a brief dictionary of labor terms has been compiled and issued by the New York City League of Women Voters.

Lou Fette won his eighteenth game of the season today, shading Bucky Walters in a pitchers' battle as the Boston Bees beat the Phillies, 2 to 1. Walters yielded only five hits to eight by Fette, but a streak of wildness in the second, when he issued three consecutive bases on balls, after a single by Reis, hurt his cause.

The $15,000,000 railroad tax litigation involving five steam carriers in this State will resume on Monday in United States District Court here before Judge Philip Forman. The hearings were adjourned by Judge Forman on June 23.

ASTOR-The Firefly: Jeanette MacDonald, Allan Jones.* BELMONT-Pan Twardowski, Polish film. BROADWAY-The Dead March, documentary film.* CAMEO-Baltic Deputy, Russian drama.* CENTRAL-Love Takes Flight: Bruce Cabot. CINEMA DE PARIS-Le Julf Polonais: Harry Baur.* CRITERION-Shanghai Express; Sophie Lang Goes West: Gertrude Michael, Wednesday. 55TH ST. PLAYHOUSE-The Lower Depths: Louis Jouvet.*

Recent developments indicate that the prime question in Mexico now is whether the regime of President Lazaro Cardenas can support the economic costs of its social revolution at the present advanced tempo.

Scoring in the last minute of play after Penn State had knotted the count late in the battle, Cornell passed its way to a 26-19 victory over the Nittany Lions before 6,000 shirt-sleeved fans who witnessed the fifty-first football opener for both teams on Schoellkopf Field today.

ECUADOR'S black giant, the volcano Tungurahua, which dominates the Pastaza Valley a hundred miles south of Quito, is a constant challenge to the adventurous traveler in the Orient jungles. Its ascent is strictly a Summer task,

Fordham University's department of psychology will begin on Oct. 6 a fourteen-week series of bimonthly psychological forums, to provide a medium for the exchange of opinions and theories by educators and persons entrusted with the care and guidance of children and adolescents.

A difference of opinion concerning the trend or Fall and Winter business exists among purchasing executives, but in no instance is there evidence of extreme pessimism, according to the monthly survey of business conditions released yesterday by the special committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

Spontaneous disintegration appeared yesterday to have blighted the feminine campaign for fifty-fifty representation in the Constitutional Convention of next April for revision of the State Constitution, which was flourishing last Spring with every promise of a sizable flock of candidates this Fall.

Princeton University will officially open its 191st academic year Tuesday afternoon in the university chapel. President Harold Willis Dodds will welcome some 630 freshmen. The entire university faculty will attend the ceremonies.

PREDICTIONS that Florida will entertain 2,250,000 visitors during the coming sea son are reflected in railroad plans for increased service to Southern resorts. The Seaboard Airline expects to use 11 per cent more air-conditioned Pullmans and reclining seat coaches with faster schedules and additional sections for all through trains.

Jesse v. d. Sonnenhoehe, a magnificent specimen of the Doberman pinscher breed, today was awarded the best-in-show title at the thirteenth annual all-breed exhibition of the Storm King Kennel Club held on the Kenridge Farm race track in this town.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Stuart Hotchkiss of Wyndham, East River, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Washington Hotchkiss, to Sydney Messer Williams Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Messer Williams of Wellesley, Mass., and Peterborough, N. H.

Completing bankruptcy papers intended to purge himself of debt and thus assure his new business career against old creditors, Bernard K. Marcus, convicted president of the defunct Bank of United States, filed schedules in Federal Court yesterday that showed he has known debts and liabilities totaling $18,709,147. He said he has no assets.

The supply of coffee on its way to the United States, which includes coffee afloat from Brazil, stands today at 1,147,690 bags, the smallest figure since early in 1933, according to the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
Preparations were being completed tonight for the opening on Monday of Chicago's public and parochial schools, which have been closed since Sept. 7 to prevent the spread of infantile paralysis.
Two men used artificial respiration to keep the breath of life in George Nibel, 25, infantile paralysis patient, during a careening seventy-mile auto dash to an "iron lung" respirator here today.

LEVY-Mr. and Mrs. Dolph Levy, 740 West End Ave., announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Richard. at Mount Neboh Temple. Saturday, Oct. 2, at 10 A. M. At home Sunday. 3 to 6. No cards. NEADERLAND-Adolph Charles. Mr. and Mrs. Herman Neaderland announce the bar mitzvah of their son. Adolph Charles.

The engagement of Miss Kathryn Ankenbrandt, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert A. Ankenbrandt of Jackson Heights, Queens, to Walter Friedrich Kolb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Kolb of Mount Carmel, III., has been announced by her parents.
United in a twenty-five-State compact for control of paroled convicts, the Interstate Commission on Crime turned today to the job of cutting off the criminal's gun supply.
KIDNAPPERS: Irving M. Ames of Newark, N. J., was kidnapped last Spring by Miss Josephine Goldman, aided by Edward F. Marr. Miss Goldman was seeking to force Mr. Ames to marry her.

Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, died at the American Hospital here at 3:45 A. M. today at the age of 77. Mr. Filene suffered a pneumonia attack last Saturday while on his way to London after a tour of Europe. Brought to the hospital here,
Protests were received by the League of Nations today against the sumptuous festival prepared by the Aga and Begum Khan for tonight's gala dedication of the League Assembly Hall.

WASHINGTON. NEXT week the American Public Health Association will hold its sixty-sixth annual convention in New York. Organized originally for the purpose of improving the sanitary conditions in one city, today it is a national institution with a membership made up of public health officials, doctors, nurses, statisticians, biologists, chemists -in short, of men and women interested in preventing disease.

WITH the bicentennial celebrations a crop of Stradivarian literature has flowered in Italy this year; eassays on lutherie and much popular rehasing of familiar material. But some new studies on the disputed date of Stradivari's bith interest music history.

AN entirely new line of passenger cars and trucks, with 1938 prices from $75 to $125 below any other auto in the lowest-price field, will be shown at the New York Automobile Show, Oct. 27 to Nov. 4, and at all other shows.

WELLINGTON. N. Z.-Signs of collapse of New Zealand's effort to colonize Sunday Island, 300 miles north of here, were to be read when the Government sent a special steamer to remove a band of dissatisfied pioneers from the subtropical Eden.

The American Mail Line, Ltd., of Seattle, an affiliate of the Dollar Line, has settled its ocean mail contract, terminated by law June 30, the Maritime Commission announced today. A temporary contract, effective Sept. 24 to run for six months, was signed.

As part of their home work in a civic service project emphasizing the importance of safety, pupils at Public School 500, at 126th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, are engaged in picketing the school building and march up and down the street with realistic signs slung over their back urging their classmates to "boycott dager."

Mr. and Mrs. Silas H. Chance of Clayton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Beebe Chance of Caldwell, to Ralph Scott Nestor, son of Colonel and Mrs. J. Eugene Nestor, also of this place.

Paul D. Cravath, president of the Metropolitan Opera Association, returned last week on the Italian liner Rex expressing optimism concerning prospects for the coming opera season. He said the association probably would be in a better position financially than it was last year and that Edward Johnson, general manager, had written him of "many interesting things" planned for this year. .

THE visit of Benito Mussolini to Adolf Hitler highlights the big question mark written on the international sky. The meeting was carefully timed by the best showmen in Europe to focus attention on that question, create dramatic suspense-and leave it hanging in the air, bolder, clearer, but still unanswered-Will the Rome-Berlin axis hold?

Applications for Social Security account numbers still are coming in at the rate of about 30,000 each working day. The Baltimore office of the Social Security Board, where records of individual earnings are kept, already has set up accounts for some 34,000,000 persons.
More than a hundred Hobart College students braved smoke and flames tonight to save a valuable collection of Chinese prints and other art objects in the college arts building.

Heelfly, T. P. Morgan's longlegged bay racer from Texas, strengthened his claim to top-flight ranking among the 3-year-olds by outclassing eleven others of his age today in the mile and a sixteenth Potomac Handicap, a $10,000 added event.

Thrusting back a valiant but futile bid by the losers in the late stages of the game, the James Madison football team downed a stubborn Manual Training eleven, 7-0, on the Abraham Lincoln High School Field in Brooklyn yesterday.

Colgate's Red Raiders opened the season unimpressively in beating a battling St. Lawrence team, 21-0, before a crowd of 7,000 which sweltered in the stands under clear skies and in midsummer heat. The home team showed sustained drive only in the first quarter, when two touchdowns were scored. In this period Colgate took the ball on its 48-yard line.

With the thirteenth round postponed until tomorrow, the eight contestants engaged in the international chess masters' tournament enjoyed another rest today before entering upon the final and most trying stage of the struggle, in which Paul Keres of Estonia is leading by 1 1/2 points. Reuben Fine of New York is, for the time being, the runner-up.

Directors of the Children's Village, a community home in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., have chosen for their annual theatre benefit the performance of Maxwell Anderson's play "The Star-Wagon"--with Burgess Meredith and Lillian Gish in the leading roles--on the night of Oct. 6 at the Empire Theatre.

The Rev. Dr. John J. Moment and Mrs. Moment of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Gairdner Moment, to Walter Spalding Douglas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Douglas, also of Plainfield.

Kenneth F. Simpson, New York County Republican chairman, criticized yesterday the Democratic State Committee for not nominating Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals as a candidate for delegate at large to the constitutional convention.

William H. Parsons, husband of Mrs. Alice Parsons, who disappeared from her home at Stony Brook, L. I., on June 9 and has been the object of an intensive search by State police and Federal investigators, has received another note relating to the kidnapping.

THIS is the first comprehensive study in English of a subject which has been called the terra incognita of monetary economics. Its author, Dr. Paul Einzig, possesses the requisite qualifications to present the pertinent facts, the analysis and the conclusions that are essential to a realistic understanding of the latest and the most far-reaching refinement of international finance. .

A clearer approach to problems of labor relations, distribution costs and long-term changes, standards for consumer goods and taxation was the chief contribution of the Boston Conference on Distribution last week, according to the consensus of the record number of business executives who were in attendance.

Because many local real estate problems are in reality national in scope all communities should join hands to achieve a united front in meeting these issues, declares Paul E. Stark of Madison, Wis., president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

Miss Elsie Ruth Timmis, daughter of Mrs. Henry Timmis of Leonia and the late Mr. Timmis, was married here tonight at the home of her brother-in-law and sister, Dr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Matthews,nto Howard Roberts Van Zandt of New York. The Rev. Dr. John Ingraham of Leonia officiated.
A 25-yard forward pass, MacGregor to Burrill, gave Colby a touchdown and a 6-3 victory over Union College today. This was the Colby eleven's first game under Coach Al McCoy.
IF there is a schoolboy today who does not know Tennynyson's fine "Ballad of the Revenge," the sixteenth-century tale of the English man o'-war which, single-handed.

" THIS book is an essay on faith," is the author's own characterization of the volume. Unfortunately this reviewer cannot agree. It is a very interesting and capable exposition of the assumptions of natural scientists in practice, especially in their use of mathematics, but it is not an essay on faith.

In the following dispatches, correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in eight States through which President Roosevelt passes on his Western tour, have attempted to gauge popular sentiment toward him and his administration today.

Miss Joan Sterling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Sterling of this place, was married here this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church to Newton Buckner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer N. Buckner of New York and Fishers Island.

President Mildred H. McAfee opened the sixty-third session of Wellesley College this morning by acknowledging the fact that never before had the college of liberal arts met so strong a necessity for self-justification.

AT a height of twelve to twenty miles is an ozone layer. It cuts off much ultraviolet radiation from the sun and also from the stars. We have reason to be thankful that the layer exists. If it were not in the sky we should be struck blind.

Dr. and Mrs. Frederic C. Paffard of 89 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Paffard, to John Streeter Hamill of San Francisco, son of Mrs. Philip W. Hamill of 210 East Sixty-eighth Street, New York, and the late Mr. Hamill.
The Silver Cross Day Nursery will be the beneficiary of a bridge party to be held on Nov. 17 at the Plaza, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Albert F. Dexter.

Mrs. Martha Barber Eaton, wife of Dr. Edward Dwight Eaton, president emeritus of Beloit College, died today at her home. Since her husband's retirement they have lived at Wellesley, Mass., and Washington, D. C. They came to Fairfield about two years ago. Mrs. Eaton was a native of Lancaster, Wis.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. A number of light frosts during the past several days have started to turn the forests into flaming colors and promised one of the most beautiful seasons in the Poconos and the Delaware Water Gap. ap.

Miss Eleanor Wynkoop Hoover, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman R. Hoover of this city, was married this afternoon to Franklin McKeage Finsthwait, son of Mrs. Frank Finsthwait, also of New Rochelle, in the First Presbyterian Church here.

David H. Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, returned yesterday on the French liner Paris from a five weeks' visit to Europe. He said the estate of the late Senator Marconi had been overestimated in the published accounts by millions of dollars.

It is quite likely that the Dodgers, still wearing their Kelly Green caps and stockings to match, though otherwise looking forlorn, indeed, were of a mind to give the Giants no helping hand as Colonel Bill Terry's jaunty troops bowed themselves into the Polo Grounds yesterday after their triumphant sweep through the West.

The social service committee of Grasslands Hospital will sponsor a concert Tuesday evening at the County Center here. The United States Marine Band will play and Frank La Forge, composer-pianist, and Harrington van Hoesen, baritone, will be the soloists.

This week's grade and staple report for the Cotton Belt as a whole, issued by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, shows that 58 per cent of the cotton classed this week was white middling or better in grade and that 65 per cent of all the cotton classed to date from the 1937 crop was of this classification.

AN AUTOBIOGRAPHICAL SKETCH BY JOHN MARSHALL. ?? Ann Arbor, Mich.: The University of Michigan Press. $2. Printed for the first time from the original manuscript. Edited by John Stokes Adams. HE DID NOT DIE AT MEYERLING. ?? Philadelphia, Pa.: J. B. Lippincott Company. $3. 3.

THIS young autobiography was published in England under the title of "Loose End, and loose-ended it certainly is. Just as truly, it is a record of adveture, and of taking chances in variuos parts of the world.

Miss Lynda D. Dickinson, the daughter of Mrs. Lynford Dickinson of New York and Noroton, was married this afternoon in Noroton Presbyterian Church to Richard Lewis Linkroum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard G. Linkroum of Hackensack, N. J.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor passed through Munich tonight on their way from Vienna to Paris. Their train waited a half hour at the Munich station and the Duke and Duchess left their compartment to chat with the British Consul General, who with several friends had gone down to meet them.
