The second day's program of Lexington's Grand Circuit meeting had to be postponed today after one heat had been raced in the Walnut Hall Cup, the Kentucky futurity for 2-year-old trotters and the sixteen pace.

An S. O. S.--Stay-on-the-Sidewalk party and parade was held yesterday morning by 2,500 children from schools in the midtown west side district led by Uncle Robert, philanthropist and benefactor of New York's very young generation.
Courses in sports and dancing for girls are being offered for women teachers in the New York City high schools under the auspices of the Association of Teachers of Health Education.

In selecting the type of the new home to be built, the woman's choice is the prevailing decision in the largest number of cases. According to a recent survey the woman's decision prevails to the extent of about 82 per cent.
The Chaco Peace Conference has put into effect very stringent regulations for neutral policing of the zone separating the armies of Bolivia and Paraguay in the Chaco.

The preference shown in the season just past for dark shades in men's Summer clothing has been so greatly emphasized that manufacturers may cut down their production of whites and light shades too far next season, according to opinion among retail clothing men here yesterday.

The hopes of approaching world monetary stability which were raised a year ago yesterday when the United States, Great Britain and France joined in their tripartite currency agreement, have been rudely dashed in the past few weeks by the collapse of the French franc to levels lower than it had touched for eleven years.
Taxable gain, even under our present complicated income tax system, results from the disposition of property and not ordinarily from its acquirement by purchase.

The curtain fell for the last time tonight at Daly's Theatre, Leicester Square, which as housed some of the biggest musical hits of the last two generations. Built forty-four years ago, the old landmark will be town down to make way for a new film theatre.

Returning to Africa after three years' absence, I find it very little changed from the Africa which Martin [Mrs. Johnson's husband, who was killed in an air crash in California last January] and I have always loved and have lived in for nearly twenty years.

Charles P. Ware gave a reception last night at his home, 400 East Fifty-second Street, for Miss Martha Holcomb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Wainwright Holcomb of Waterbury, Conn., and Fishers Island, N. Y., and Frank Ronald Stemp of England and Bermuda, whose marriage will take place next Thursday in St. John's Episcopal Church in Waterbury.
The University of Richmond scored in the final period at Mayo Island today to defeat its ancient football rival, Randolph-Macon College of Ashland, 6 to 0.

The Transit Commission plans prompt action in the situation created on Friday by the refusal of Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the state Department of Public Service, either to approve or disapprove the commission's appointment of former Mayor James J. Walker as an assistant counsel at an annual salary of $12,000.

To commemorate the death on Sept. 28, 1895, of Louis Pasteur, a WPA Federal Art Project mural panel has been hung in the physicians' dining room of the Willard Parker Hospital, East Sixteenth Street and the East River. The painting is a composite presentation of Pasteur's accomplishments in the world of medicine.

The calendar was turned back nine years here this week, when the October grand jury, summoned early to its task, started out to ascertain whether the city really was "wide open" and, if so, why; to discover whether vice syndicates were paying for protection, and, if so, who gets the cash.

Frederick F. Jordan, director of Wildlife Restoration Week, has already begun the mobilization of public opinion "to do something about the crisis that exists" concerning our wildlife resources. Already the work of organizing the nation is going ahead.

President Roosevelt's Constitution Day speech-despite his strictures on dictatorships--has stimulated speculation in certain German quarters as to whether the American President's political philosophy is rapidly developing into his own brand of Weltanschauung [Philosophy of Life].

Mortmar, once one of the show places of American society and the locale of many of its most brilliant assemblages, took another step further toward oblivion today. The Italian Renaissance mansion of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard Mortimer is to be torn down and in preparation for that day its furnishings and art treasures were put up for sale at public auction by the heirs.

A French magistrate today issued a warrant for the arrest of General Nicholas Skobline, commander of the Korniloff Regiment, on charges of kidnapping in connection with the mysterious disappearance two days ago of General Eugene Miller, commander of the White Russian veterans in France.

Miss Kathryne Ruth Spragg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse L. Spragg of Steubenville, Ohio, was married to Roy Udell Wood, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Wood of this city, here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church by the Rev. Benjamin F. Saxon.

THE familiar khaki uniform of the Boy Scouts is one of the significant features of the movement. Its use is restricted to those who are qualified to wear it, and it serves to identify the wearer with the world's largest youth organization, now numbering more than two and a half million members.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Lida Read Voigt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Read Voigt of this city and St. Petersburg, Fla., to Henry Lane Young Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Young of Atlanta, Ga.

Acting on the complaints of many shopkeepers in the midtown area, the police rounded up yesterday 100 roving bootblacks and sixty-two others, the latter group suspected of charting horse races and making bets on the sidewalks. All were charged with disorderly conduct and held for Night Court.

Two rose plantings that have won unusual praise this year, from rose experts and from the general public alike, are the new rose gardens at Hershey, Pa., and the display gardens of Jackson Perkins at Newark, N. J.
HAVANA.--Cuba is once more suffering from a mild attack of gold fever, which first appeared at the time Columbus discovered the island and has manifested itself at various periods since.
The Soviet Government day nullified the census of some 170,000,000 inhabitants taken last Jan. 1, and ordered a new census in January, 1939, because reults were "defective."
Miss Jean Wanamaker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence H. Wanamaker of this city, was married this afternoon to Clark Chamberlain Cone, son f Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Della Torre Cone of Montclair.
Horsemen and horsewomen from Western New York touched spur to flank this morning and rode off in the opening Fall meet of the historic Genesee Valley Hunt, second oldest in the United States.

The marriage of Miss Mary Wallace Knott, daughter of Mrs. Edson Akin Starks of Red Bank, to Walter E. Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Jones of Canton, Ohio, took place here at noon today in St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Morton A. Barnes.

South African farmers will soon have an opportunity to learn at first hand American methods of growing soybeans. M. C. Campbell, whose Scotch ancestors have farmed in Natal for generations, will carry back to that country the story of the rise of soybean culture in the corn belt of America.

John W. Laing, British builder, who is in this country making a study of housing projects and trends, will discuss British building and his impressions of building activity in the United States at the first Fall luncheon meeting Wednesday of the New York Building Congress at the Hotel Astor.

While thousands of New York families were taking advantage of the week-end to occupy their new apartments, those who had neglected to arrange for transfer of their household goods were jostled out of their inaction yesterday by a warning that a heavier volume of changes in living quarters was likely to bring them trouble in the last-minute rush of the traditional Fall moving day.

Delegates from thirty States were registered here today, and more than 700 are expected to arrive in time for the formal opening tomorrow of the annual convention of the National Council of Catholic Women.

For the first time in its history, the Dollar Company will have a double sailing on a Sunday, two of its big President liners departing tomorrow for the Orient. The President Monroe, which arrived Thursday from New York, will proceed westward on her voyage around the world.

Turpentine firm. 27 1/2c: sales 80 barrels; receipts 394 barrels; shipments 74 barrels, stock 40,657 barrels. Resin firm: sales 498; receipts 849; shipments 130; stock 65,348. Quote B. D and E, $7.50; F. G and H. $7.75; I. K and M, $7.80; N. $7.90; WG, $8.20; WW, $S.65. and X, $8.65.

Having obtained magnificent specimens of Rocky Mountain goat and Alaskan brown bear, the ClarkKissel Alaskan expedition for the American Museum of Natural History has returned to New York after spending forty-one days in Southeastern Alaska, museum officials announced last night.

The Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club wrote "finis" to the championship season of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound today. In one respect Horseshoe's regatta was consistent with most of its twenty-one predecessors, being distinguished or, more to the point, plagued by inadequate wind conditions.
The "Guide to China," published in 1924 by the Japanese Government Railways, says of Nanking: "The city was planned on a magnificent scale, worthy of the capital of a great country."

Dr. Currier McEwen, assistant dean of the New York University College of Medicine, in his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University yesterday, paid tribute to the late Dean John Wyckoff as a "great man, unaware of his greatness,"

Three persons were killed near here today when their automobile was struck by a freight train. Three other persons were injured seriously, including two members of the St. John's team, which played Gustavus Adolphus College last night.

The Riverside Yacht Club held its final weekly dinner dance of the season tonight, with about seventy in attendance for dinner and hundreds more who came for dancing. The club will close tomorrow afternoon with a cocktail party at the club house.

Princess De Braganca, the former Anita Stewart; Group Captain G. C. Pirie, air attache to the British Embassy at Washington; Dr. Raymond B. Cattell, Miss Vera Brittain, author; Morgan Jones, M. P., and Rhys Davis, M. P., are among the passengers due today from England and France on the Cunard White Star motorship Georgic.
With the stock markets here closed, weekend loans were in quiet demand today at one-half of 1 per cent and three-month bills were steady at seventeen thirty-seconds to nine-sixteenths of 1 per cent.

DEAR Clara was so brave and capable and kind and good. It was really- wonderful how she had built up such a secure success with that Literary Advice Bureau when she was left widowed and penniless in middle age.

A new trade and clearance agreement has been concluded in Berlin between Greece and Germany; it was announced here today. The negotiations were rather complicated as a result of past experiences-Germany being unable to pay for purchases of agricultural products,

Two thousand persons marched through the streets of downtown Brooklyn yesterday to indicate their support of the strike called by the Newspaper Guild of New York among employes of the editorial and commercial departments of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle.

Sir Frederick Phillips, Under-Secretary of the British Treasury, and UnderSecretary Magill of the United States Treasury discussed today mutual tax problems of the two nations. The only information made available was that no proposals had been made and that the meeting was informal.

West Virginia University, under a new coach, Marshall Glenn, presented a well-drilled, powerful eleven to overpower the West Virginia Wesleyan Bobcats, 14 to 0, today. The Mountaineers scored in the second and fourth periods.

THE metropolitan bridge championships, which start Oct. 10 at the Park Central, this year include an event from which ranking players are excluded. It is an "amateur" pair game and is scheduled as the final tournament event, to be played in two sessions, Sunday afternoon and evening, Oct. 17. 17.

AS a result of an ingenious bit of "grafting," television pictures of finer detail and with all the natural shading and background can now be transmitted, greatly amplified yet with considerably less accompanying noises, it is revealed in a patent (No. 2093166) granted to Leslie E. Flory, Oaklyn, and George A. Morton, Haddon Heights, N. J., two Radio Corporation of America researchers.
Laden with a collection of interesting small animal specimens, Dr. Harold E. Anthony, mamalogy curator of the American Museum of Natural History, prepared tonight to descend from Shiva Temple.

The National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery announced yesterday that plans were nearing completion for the observance of Loyalty Days next Saturday and Sunday in countless churches and synagogues throughout the country.

History that is In the making the world over will receive authoritative interpretation from eight speakers at the second NEW YORK TIMES Review - of - the - News Conference, which opens Tuesday at 10:30 A. M. for the special benefit of New Jersey clubwomen at the Shubert Theatre in Newark.

The letter from Judith Grunfeld, first received at the New York office of THE TIMES, was sent to Berlin so that THE TIMES correspondent, Otto D. Tolischus, might have an opportunity to answer Miss Grunfeld's comments. Both letters follow.

Mrs. George Gardner Monks was hostess for a large tea and reception this afternoon at Clipston Grange, Lenox, complimenting her mother, Mrs. William F. Knowles, and the Rev. Dr. Monks's mother, Mrs. George Howard Monks, both of Boston. At the tea tables were the Misses Mary Parsons and Olivia Phelps Stokes, Mrs. Samuel Frothingham, Mrs. George S. Reynolds and Mrs. Walter Clark.
West Side and Jackson Heights entered the semi-final round in the twenty-ninth annual metropolitan interclub tennis championship under the auspices of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association yesterday.

The University of Washington triumphed, 14 to 0, over the University of Iowa today in an intersectional opener witnessed by 24,000 fans in the Washington Stadium. The fancy throwing right arm of Captain Fritz Waskowitz started the defending champions of the Pacific Coast Conference auspiciously at the expense of the Big Ten Conference representative, opening the season under its new coach, Ira Tubbs.

AN outstanding feature of the national stamp show under the sponsorship of the New .York Museum of Science and Industry me will be an exhibit of covers from the collection of President Roosevelt, America's No. 1 philatelist.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Arthur T. Pendleton of 1,201 Fairmont Avenue of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Taylor Pendleton, to Archibald G. Ogden of Boston, son of Mrs. Archibald Gracie Ogden of this city and the late Mr. Ogden. Miss Pendleton's father was the late Arthur T. Pendleton.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edmund John Drummond of Holley Hill, Lakeville, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Holley Drummond, to John Van Benschoten Griggs, son of Mrs. John Stillwell Griggs and the late Mr. Griggs.

Japan has begun to put into practical effect the strategical plan stated in generalities in the last few weeks. The bombardment of Nanking, Canton and other cities, the offensive along the Peiping-Hankow Railway, aimed at clearing Central China of its strongest forces, and the sweep through Shansi and Suiyuan Provinces are the evidence.

Germany is pretty much a man's world nowadays. What, in that man's world, is happening to the German women? Most of the German women hang out the swastika flags on holidays and go docilely to the National Socialist meetings to listen to the propaganda of Dr. Goebbels.

Miss A. Margaret Finnegan, daughter of Mrs. Patrick Finnegan of Greenwich and the late Mr. Finnegan, was married to Joseph A. Balsamo of New York, formerly of Cos Cob, Greenwich, this morning in St. Mary's Catholic Church, here. The Rev. James Q. Dolan,

Fall is the season for planting, dividing and resetting most perennials. Especially is it the best time for setting out Spring flowering varieties. Summer and Autumn bloomers may be left until Spring, though all the work of making over a perennial border can be done in October.

An Associated Press story last night naming "the 120 greatest living Jews" compiled in a poll by the Ivrim, Jewish honor society, erroneously included the name of Percy Selden Straus among seven nominees who have died since the original compilation. Mr. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co. of New York, is alive.

New names were added to the foster of athletic champions yesterday when 400 boys and girls, the ?? of 20,000 competitors, gathered in two Manhattan streets to compete in the finals of the paddle tennis and shuffle board tournament sponsored by the Police Athletic League and the street and play centers of the WPA Recreation Department. nt.
The University of California, displaying crushing power and remarkable early season blocking, opened the 1937 football campaign today with a 30-to-7 victory over St. Mary's Gaels.

The Rev. John P. Boland, chairman of the State Labor Relations Board, announced yesterday that a meeting would be held tomorrow morning at the board's offices, 366 Broadway, among representatives of the Realty Advisory Board, Local 32B of the Building Service Employes International Union and the Building Service, Industrial Union.

Miss Marie Louise Hoerning, daughter of Mrs. Paul Otto Hoerning of this city, was married to Wesley Atwood Harrington, son of Mrs. William C. Harrington, also of Mount Vernon, this afternoon in the Church of the Ascension here. The Rev. Melford L. Brown, the pastor, officiated.

The author who takes his typewriter in hand is apparently still the exception to the old pen and pencil rule. Of the twenty authors who discuss the mechanics of their trade in Elmer Adler's "Breaking Into Print" Sinclair Lewis, Robert Benchley, Mackinlay Kantor, H. L. Mencken and Carl Van Vechten compose directly on the typewriter.
The Ellerman's Wilson Line in New York announced yesterday that two new ships, the Consuelo and Bassano, would be completed in England in time to enter the Atlantic service during the Winter.

Due to the increasing demand for smart shops on Madison Avenue, a new two-story building, which will contain space for several stores, is being erected on the site of the former branch of the Dry Dock Savings Institution at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street.

Duke University defeated Virginia Polytechnic Institute, 25 to 0, tonight before 12,000 fans to open the defense of its Southern Conference football championship. Duke scored in every quarter and turned back two real V. P. I. threats in the last half.
Premier Mussolini's passage through Austria to Germany was without incident. Both at Innsbruck and at the German border he was greeted by local authorities and inspected guards of honor.

THIS month Britain's famous P. O. (Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company) celebrates its hundredth birthday. As blazer of speedy sea routes, its ships provided a link between England and her expanding territory in India.

One hundred and ten properties representing the realty assets of eight closed national banks on Long Island will be offered in the third series of bank property auction sales to be held under the direction of Joseph P. Day, William A. White Sons and Albert M. Greenfield Co.
Mr. and Mrs. George M. Beyea of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Muriel Beyea, to William B. Hutchinson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Hutchinson of Leonia.
A blanket reorganization of the City College cooperative store has taken place, Professor Joseph Allen, chairman of the Faculty-Student committee -for the store, has announced, after a meeting.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 23: Ogden, Lt. Comdr. S. B., Schenectady, N. Y., to the Honolulu and on board as Engineer Officer, when commissioned. Quinby, Lt. Comdr. C. M. S., the Saratoga, to the Savannah and on board as Engineer Officer when commissioned.
Three names came to the tongues of political observers today as possible successors to that of James A. Farley on the door of the Postmaster General.

Permission having been granted by Justice Alfred Frankenthaler to reorganize the Lawyers Mortgage Company, the first New York guaranteed mortgage organization to receive such permission, the reorganization managers will proceed immediately to solicit the assent of the guarantee holders and stockholders in the company to the reorganization.

Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Tomorrow Holly Sugar Corp. pf. Tuesday Allied Chemical Dye Corp. American Can Co. Consolidated Cigar Corp. pf. Hershey Chocolate pf. and com. Lane Bryant, Inc., pf. Norfolk Western Ry. Co. pf. Reading Co.

A luncheon and card party under the auspices of the Marymount College Auxiliary will be held Oct. 16 at the Empire Club in the Empire State Building. Mrs. William F. Donohue and Mrs. Richard J. Cronin are co-chairmen of the committee in charge.
Smith College has been celebrating this week the hundredth anniversary of the birth of Laurenus Clark Seelye, its first president, who served from 1875 to 1910.

The British Great War Veterans of America are planning their seventeeth annual Armistice Ball which will be held on Armistice night, Nov. 11, in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The net proceeds, as in past years, will be devoted to the relief fund of the organization.

Mr. and Mrs. Bernhard Levitow of Kew Gardens, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diana Levitow, to Lester A. Blumner of East Stroudsburg, Pa., son of Mrs. Samuel Blumner of New York and Yonkers and the late Mr. Blumner.

Miss Mildred Barry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Barry of Astoria, Queens, was married to Bernard J. Fergerson Jr. of Flushing, yesterday morning in the Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, Astoria, by Mgr. John J. Clark, an old friend of the bride's family.

Piling up the amazing total of 33,367 points, the largest number in the history of the sport of outboard racing, Douglas C. Fonda, middleaged amateur from Orange, N. J., is winning this year the major trophies and awards for regatta performances.

Max Silverman, the top ranking New York racketeer who was held in bail of $250,000 in Los Angeles yesterday at the request of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, will face a murder investigation upon his return to New York.

Mgr. William E. Cashin, pastor of St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church, Duane Street and Cardinal Place, just back of the city's administrative buildings, sent a letter yesterday to parishioners and to friends of the old church reporting that the work of building a new edifice was being started "with the approval and support of Cardinal Hayes and the blessing of the Pope."

Francisco Tudela, chairman of the Peruvian delegation to its boundary dispute negotiations with Ecuador, today denied that Peru had rejected the Ecuadorean proposal to submit the entire dispute to arbitration by President Roosevelt in the event actual proceedings failed.

A test of the lot market in the metropolitan area is scheduled for Saturday afternoon, Oct. 16, when J. Edward Breuer will offer at auction 450 lots located a short distance from the World's Fair grounds in Flushing, L. I.

Daffodil fanciers seem to be partial to the gorgeous large trumpet sorts which add such splendor to the Spring garden. "Medium-trumpets," dainty as they are, have been somewhat neglected. One sees some of them in cultivation, but not nearly so many as their merits call for.

Amherst College undergraduates returning for the opening of the year's activities found their campus in a partial state of upheaval and the relatively extensive building program proceeding at full speed.
The Soviet grain harvest is approaching completion with only a few million of the 220,000,000 acres sown remaining to be reaped.

Anthony Eden's hopes for early consummation of an Anglo-American reciprocal trade agreement, broadcast from Geneva early in the week, awoke sympathetic response here among government experts who have long wrestled with the intricate problems the British Foreign Secretary wishes to solve.
Percy Seibert, the American manager here of the Braden Copper Company, was decorated today by President Arturo Alessandri. Mr. Seibert received the Medal of Merit.

Mayor La Guardia has received a report from Chief Justice William R. Bayes of the Court of Special sessions saying the new practice of having one judge instead of three try policy cases has speeded up the court calendars, and that the calendars are up to date in all five counties in the city.
President Manuel Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth invited his critics today to impeach him for his criticism of what he termed "outrageous injustice" in the insular courts.

Miss Mary Therese Graden, daughter of Mrs. Rudolph Munt of Ashley, Pa., was married to Donald French Bartells, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Sheridan Bartells of Montclair, this afternoon in the First Baptist Memorial Church, Newark. The pastor, the Rev. Dr. George E. Dawkins, performed the ceremony.

More than 400 delegates and guests are expected to attend the "trail-blazer" convention of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York at the Hotel Niagara, Niagara Falls, N. Y., next Thursday, Friday and Saturday. Many persons of State and national prominence will speak.

Many social and economic developments are affecting the pattern of urban civilization in the United States, points out James C. Downs Jr. of Chicago, editor-in-chief of The Journal of Real Estate Management, published by the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

The marriage of Miss Victoria Corse Thorne, daughter of Dr. Victor Corse Thorne and the late Mrs. Thorne, to Albert Bruce Matthews, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Matthews of Toronto, Ont., took place here this afternoon in St. Bede's Chapel, Rosemary Hall.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered reopening of hearings into the reorganization proceedings of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company, and set Feb. 1, 1938, for the first hearing here before Commissioner Claude R. Porter and Oliver E. Sweet, Director of Finance.

A KIND of campaign has been shaping up recently to promote and encourage that literary form best known as the novelette. Although they use a different and fancier term, novella, the editors of Story and -Edward J. O'Brien have been sponsoring the movement with enthusiasm, and have unearthed a number of writers whose talents turn naturally in this direction.
The National Park Service offered its own explanation today for the painting of "Washington Crossing the Delaware," in which it said that "realism is completely lacking."

The National Horse Show Association, now preparing its annual horse show, which will be held from Nov. 3 through Nov. 10 at Madison Square Garden, is incorporating several important innovations into its plans for the show this year plans which,
Ray Phebus, one of Washington's rookie pitchers, chalked up his third victory today in four major league starts, when he hurled the Senators to a 5-to-8 victory over Philadelphia.

Walter J. Donnelly, former commercial attache at Havana for the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the United States Department of Commerce, will discuss present market conditions in Cuba at a meeting of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Tuesday.
Philip Collins keeps a record of the out-of-State cars that pass his door. This year, from June 1 to Labor Day,

Police took a 2 months' old baby girl from a junk man and his wife today while they investigated a story that the infant had been purchased for $1 from a couple to whom it had been given by an unwed mother.

LONDON. GOOD-BYE to Ortheris, Learoyd and the great Terence Mulvaney, who "was a corporal wanst!" A new Tommy Atkins seems to be trembling on the brink of reality. Just what he is going to be like nobody quite knows yet. The British Army is not getting him in the numbers it needs,

Dr. Arthur E. Brides, one of the great names of Yale's long football history, was found dead in bed today at the Norfolk Medical Center, of which he was superintendent. His age was 49. Death was due to a heart attack, superinduced by gall bladder ailments.

The Earl of Athlone, accompanied by Princess Alice, will preside at a dinner at Grosvenor House on Nov. 17 in connection with the Rudyard Kipling Memorial Fund to endow bursaries at the Imperial Service College, Windsor, and the Kipling Library.

Fair trade laws should be given a fair trial and may result not only in permanent advantage to the manufacturer but also to the retailer and the public, but the "individual manufacturer must base his policy of retail price maintenance on his own facts and figures,"

Miss Ruth Elizabeth Corbett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willeby T. Corbett of this place, was married to Dr. Dwight T. Bonham, also of Rockville Center, here tonight in St. Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church.

Miss Janet Richardson German, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Richardson German of this place, was married to E. Harris Harbison of Princeton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Warner Harbison of Sewickley, Pa., this afternoon in Prospect Presbyterian Church here.

OVER in Nutley, N. J., there are at least two men who still believe that one good picture is definitely better than two Class B offerings. Determined to do something about the matter, they have formed the Anti-Movie Double Feature League of America and plan to circulate petitions urging the boycott of twin feature programs.

David Van Alstyne Jr. of Van Alstyne, Noel Co. has been elected a director of the Emerson Electric Manufacturing Company, Inc., St. Louis. The Empire Trust Company has been appointed depositary for the 7 per cent general mortgage gold bonds of No. 1 West Thirty-ninth Street Corporation, due on April 1, 1945.

The new Corning Glass Works Building at 718 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of Fifty-sixth Street, is completed and the first tenants will move in tomorrow. The four upper floors will be occupied by the metropolitan offices of the glass concern, the Macbeth-Evans division,

EVEN in the cold lakes and rivers of the Michigan peninsula, Northern Wisconsin and Minnesota, muskellunge are no longer as big as they were in the days of Paul Bunyan when that legendary giant lumberjack used whole hams for bait, goose wings for feathers and sometimes battled with a fish for two days at a time.

Miss Beatrice Andrews, daughter of Mrs. M. M. Andrews of Denver, was married today to Victor Arthur Miler, Denver attorney and brother of Mrs. Alfred Victor du Pont, at the du Pont home, Westover Hills.

A platform aimed at establishing minimum prices for drinks sold over bars, cutting license fees and changing the form of penalties imposed on bar and grill owners for minor infractions of the law was made public here yesterday by John J. Daly, president of the State Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association, Inc.

A delegation of members of the American Legion attending the recent convention in this city who were interested in realty matters and building projects visited several of the home development centers in Queens and other parts of Long Island last week.
Ragnhild Hveger,17-year-old Danish Olympic swimmer, bettered by more than two seconds the accepted world record for the women's 150-yard back-stroke swim tonight.

IT is a pleasure to praise Mr. Gray again for another fine bit of popular scientific reporting. He is a reporter above all, but what a reporter! He seems never to find that alleged unfortunate conflict between truth and news value.

For the fifth successive week THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has declined, dropping to 104.9 for the week ended Sept. 18 from 106.6 (revised). The index was 102.2 for the week ended Sept. 19, 1936.

The performance of Verdi's "La Traviata" by the Hippodrome Opera Company at the Hippodrome last night attracted an audience of 5,000. Heading the cast were Norina Greco as Violetta, Gil Valeriano as Alfredo and Mario Cozzi as Germont.

The "open door" of the Teruel front is now shut tight and barred so strongly that the Rebels would have to launch an offensive far greater than any yet attempted in Spain to break through to the coast and Valencia.

Two important considerations have animated members of the Women's City Club in their current preparations for a series of exploratory discussions of New York State's care of its mental defectives, to be launched within the next few weeks.
TEACHER: At a convocation marking the beginning of its 173d year, Brown University last week conferred the honorary decree of Doctor of Laws

Americans here, particularly business firms, are becoming irritated and some are almost frantic over delays in the delivery in Shanghai of American mails. Until today nothing had been received for four weeks except occasional letters of clipper ships delivered up the coast from Hong Kong.

Topics tending to show the value of good neighborhoods and pleasant relations between the landlord and tenant will have an important place on the program being prepared for the forthcoming convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in Pittsburgh from Oct. 20 to 22 inclusive.

Robert Stuart Oliver Jr., former vice president of the First National Bank here and one-time member of the local Board of Education, died of a heart attack yesterday in Trenton, N. J., where he had gone to arrange details connected with his motor-vehicle agency in this township. His age was 46.

REGISTRATION at the Institute of Musical Art has been so heavy that enrollment has been limited to 900 students. New students will be registered from tomorrow until Oct. 4. The school opens Oct. 7. The degree of Bachelor of Science with major in music will be conferred upon candidates who have completed the four-year course in Public School Music. .

For the month of October no fewer than a score of field trial meetings have been scheduled that will claim the attention and participation of enthusiasts in the metropolitan district of New York. A majority of these are within easy motoring distance of the city.

MAXWELL ANDERSON during the past week presented "The Feast of Ortolans" as his first original effort in radio drama, which the broadcasters listed as "a poetic interpretation of an episode concerned with the French Revolution." As a novel and noble experiment Mr. Anderson did not resort to an individual protagonist of the action, but instead employed the entire group as a single group protagonist.

Word was received here yesterday of the death on Friday at his home in Settimo-Vittone, Italy, of Antonio Yon, father of Pietro and Constantino Yon of this city, respectively organist and musical director of St. Patrick's Cathedral and the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer. He was 86 years old.

AS we were saying, before we were interrupted by the Legion convention, there is nothing like a foreign film to wrest us from the insularity that constant attendance upon the Hollywood product is likely to breed. Hollywood still dominates the cinema world and no nation has successfully challenged that domination.

WASHINGTON - With international problems and disturbances holding the spotlight, up-to-date maps are in great demand by the State and other Federal departments. This means busy days for Samuel W. Boggs,

Trading in corn for September delivery came to an abrupt end today, the directors of the Board of Trade ordering operations in that future suspended and establishing a settlement price of $1.10 1/2 a bushel. It was the first time that such action had been taken since Sept. 20, 1918,

After a day of upsets and surprises, most of which came in the first round when favorites fell like ten-pins at the A. B. C. tourney, the annual Piping Rock mixed foursomes golf event is now down to the semi-final round with a perfect geographical distribution.

Establishment of an appeals board to review dismissals and other personnel questions affecting employes in the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department was announced yesterday by Paul Sifton, Deputy Industrial Commissioner.

UP to a few years ago the beauty of the Autumn landscape in the northern playgrounds had never been for sale. Not, at least, in up-State New York, in New England or in Canada. These northern playgrounds locked their doors and put up white shutters on Labor Day or thereabout.

INDIA for thousands of years has been a fountain-spring of spirituality. Perhaps it is the influence of the Himalaya upon its people, drawing their souls up to unbelievable heights. Maybe it is the onward sweeping grandeur of its deep-flowing rivers.

The marriage of Miss Margherita Childs, daughter of Mrs. Henry G. E. Kyburg of Cos Cob, and Eversley Childs of New York, to Maxime Charles Fidao, son of Maxime N. Fidao of Cos Cob, and the late Mrs. Fidao, will take place on Friday afternoon, Nov. 26.

A car containing fifty tons of scrap iron broke away from a Temiskaming Northern Ontario train in the Cobalt Railway yards yesterday and sped twelve miles through towns and villages at more than sixty miles an hour before it was stopped by Leslie Joy, a brakeman, who boarded it soon after it started its runaway trip.

Utility tax receipts for July reached $1,300,000, Mark Graves, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, reported today. The public utilities pay 97 per cent of the amount collected, the remainder coming from resellers of service.

A BOOK about glass-not a book about stained glass, or table glass, or scientific uses of glass, or glass manufacture, or modern novelties in glass, but a book about all these things. "Five Thousand Years of Glass" is an outline of the making and using and decorating and perfecting of glass through the ages.

All records were broken in the season just closed in the number of persons participating in Summer camping in the New York divisions of the Palisades Interstate Park of New York and New Jersey, the park commissioners announced yesterday.

Miss Muriel June York, daughter of Mrs. Edward Palmer York of New York and this place, and of the late Mr. York, well known architect, was married to Alfred Chappell Sheffield this afternoon in Calvary Church here, where her sister, the former Miss Clarinda York, was married to John W. Lincoln last November.

In a slow game, marred by many penalties, Springfield College opened its home football season today with a 7-0 victory over Stroudsburg State Teachers College of East Stroudsburg, Pa. The charges of Paul Stagg, new head coach at Springfield, scored their lone touchdown in the second quarter.

Mrs. Louisa Lane Van Rensselaer, widow of William Bayard Van Rensselaer, died last night after a week's illness. For many years, Mrs. Van Rensselaer had been a leader in Albany social circles. She entertained many noted personages who came to Albany and was a patroness for many of the charity balls which preceded the induction of a new Governor.

A large plot with a dwelling containing seven rooms and a two-car garage on Harding Road, Morristown, N. J., in the Washington Headquarters section, has been purchased by Horace E. Murphy of Brooklyn for occupancy.

HATS are on the rampage again. They are shooting into the air at a great rate. High and as slender as stove pipes they perch on one side of the head, their upturned brims sharply clipping across hair and forehead.

THE Cubs are still in the race, but Secretary Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick of the Giants says that it doesn't matter. The Giants are going to be in the series. Mr. Brannick has gone further than that. It was a fine day and he was in a happy mood. He had just figured out that, man for man, the Giants were stronger than the Yankees. He has his own way of computing those things.
WASHINGTON. THERE has been a perceptible shift within the last few days in traffic across the bridges over the Potomac River that join Virginia to Washington.

A crowd of 18,000, the largest opening attendance in years, today saw Holy Cross avenge the scoreless tie of last season with a 21-to-0 victory over the St. Anselm's football team. The Crusaders took a six-point lead in the opening period. On a well-executed forward pass,

The marriage of Miss Priscilla Hollister, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Buell Hollister of Salters Point, this place, and Corning, N. Y., to Territt H. Mowbray of Bermuda took place here this afternoon.

A campaign for passage of a proposed Westchester County charter, by referendum on Nov. 2 will be revived, after a two months' lapse, at a county-wide mass meeting in Larchmont Junior High School Wednesday night to be sponsored by the Larchmont League of Women Voters.

King Christian will celebrate his sixty-seventh birthday tomorrow by opening Europe's longest bridge, built for the Danish State Railways by a British engineering concern, Dorman, Long Co., across the "Great Stream" between the islands of Zealand and Falster.

AS they grow older theatrical managers are inclined to lose their hair and teeth, to say nothing of their money; but they have compensations in the form of delusions. One of these is the notion that certain actors more or less belong to them-at any rate, they generally refer to them as "my actors." ctors."
LONDON.--One of the world's most unusual museums, where the custodians invite visitors to operate all manner of machines and be as clumsy as they can about it, has just celebrated its tenth birthday.
Sixty-six of the leading book publishers of the country have already made reservations of space for exhibits at the National Book Fair to be held Nov. 5 to 21 at Rockefeller Center.

Mrs. Owen J. Toland's bay gelding, Justa Boy, won the highest honors at the close of the forty-first annual Bryn Mawr Horse Show when Morris H. Dixon rode the gelding around the tanbark oval to be judged the champion hunter. With the triumph went a challenge cup presented by R. Penn Smith Jr. for the R. Penn Smith Memorial. A crowd of 15,000 attended.
With its star fullback, John Chimento scoring both touchdowns, Xavier High School began its football campaign by beating the St. Catherine's Parish Club, 12-0, at Innisfail Park yesterday.
American Pen Women (New York League)-Annual fellowship luncheon. Mrs. Ida Benfy Judd, speaker o "Literature Across the Footlights," 1 P. M., George Washington Hotel.

With methodic precision the Yankees hammered three Red Sox hurlers for thirteen hits at Fenway Park today and slapped a second straight defeat on Uncle Tom Yawkey's team, 5 to 2, as Lefty Gomez scored his twenty-first pitching victory of the campaign.
Shipping circles express great anxiety concerning fate of the Chilean passenger vessel Pudeto, on which fire broke out early this morning when she was northward bound opposite Atico. Peru.
William Henry Crocker, 76 years old, nationally known financier, banker, political and civic leader of San Francisco, died tonight at his home in Hillsborough, Calif.

Attacking the proposed formation of a central reserve bank at a time when the present Administration soon will be going out of office, Antonio Carlos de Andrada, former Speaker of the House, today continued his speech of opposition which he started at the session yesterday.
Japan's North China army marshaled its forces at captured Paoting today and planned to extend its conquests.

The new minimum structural requirements for residential building in Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Staten Island under the Federal Housing Administration's mortgage insurance plan were made public yesterday.

Miss Margaret Wessels, secretary to the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, died yesterday in her home at 15 Rugby Road, here, after a long illness. She was 49 years old.

Frank A. Brennan, 70 years old, life-long resident of Flushing, died Friday night at his home, 36-47 Union Street, Flushing. For thirty-two years he was employed in the Queens Water Department as a foreman and had planned to retire next Friday.

The attack of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, on the La Guardia Administration's accomplishments was termed last night "Very close to being impudent insolence," by City Chamberlain A. A. Berle. Mr. Mahoney had attacked the La Guardia Administration in a speech at his club house on Friday evening;
BUSY days lie ahead for camera hobbyists. During the Summer, such fans function for the most part as individuals; Fall brings a rush of group activities.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts. 2,000, including 1.500 direct; largely nominal; few sales good to choice 140-170-pound weights, $11.60-$12, steady; estimated holdover 1,000; compared week ago generally 10-25 cents lower.

Anthony Bisagno, 3 years old, killed under the wheels of a backing coal truck driven by his uncle in the driveway of his grandparents' home here late this morning. The child, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Bisagno of 146 Delevan Street, New Brunswick, apparently was trying to climb on the rear of the machine and fell under the wheels when it started to move.

Former State Senator Caleb H. Baumes, father of the "Baumes laws" enacted in 1926, making a life term mandatory for fourth-time criminal offenders, died of a heart attack today on board a New York Central train near Hudson. He was 74 years old. The former Senator was on his way home from the national convention of Odd Fellows at Milwaukee.

New business booked by the furniture industry in August was 11 per cent below that of July and 7 per cent under August, 1936, according to a report issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants, which noted that the furniture industry is continuing "to feel the effects of a predominantly gloomy business sentiment."
The first concerns to occupy space in the office section of the new Corning Glass Works building at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street will move in tomorrow.

Unless the French harbor police can manage to save two engineers belonging to the Spanish Government freighter Cabo Tresforcas, now docked here, they will be taken to Earcelona to answer charges of trying to desert to General Franco, leader of the Spanish Insurgents.

An expansion of the New York City school system to place greater emphasis upon the needs of the adult and to tackle the recreational problems of the child after school hours is planned for this Fall, educational leaders disclosed yesterday.

Bulgaria's first large-scale army manoeuvres will begin Monday and will be attended by a special German delegation. The army will display armored cars, airplanes and other engines of war prohibited by treaties, which has provoked bitter comment in the Greek press.

Distribution of consumer protection labels by the National Coat and Suit Industry last week recorded an increase over the corresponding 1936 week for the first time in five weeks, F. Nathan Wolf, executive secretary of the industry's recovery board announced yesterday.

The American Federation of Labor may ask Congress to withdraw the United States from affiliation with the International Labor Organization in Geneva if a dispute over American labor membership on the I. L.O. governing body is not straightened out within a reasonable time, it was learned today.

BOSTON. TWO openings on the same evening, both marked by names of negotiable value in the theatre and both approved by the social mentors of the town, have stirred a pleasurable dither of excitement during the week that is just past. One of them, the Theatre Guild's production of Ben Hecht's new play,
The Treasury warned today that any attempt to board the ship bringing Justice Hugo L. Black

The Rev. C. A. Burch, American missionary, in a letter received today from Hofei, Anhwei Province, where he is superintendent of the Luchow Christian Hospital, gives an account of conditions in "an average Yangtze Valley interior town."

Popular dances of the early nineteenth century, including the polka, mazurka and polonaise, will feature the benefit dinner dance entitled "A Night in Krakow," which will mark the formal opening of La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis on Tuesday night.
FOR hardy travelers the latest thing in "cruises" is a boat tour of underground Paris, where motor vessels carry passengers over subterranean waters-namely, through the sewers of the French capital.
William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to France, sailed for the United States today on the liner Normandie.

Edward A. Custer, who a month ago fought off death in order to read the reviews of his first book, died today knowing that the work, his autobiography, "No Royal Road," had been received favorably by critics. He was 76 years old.

Attorneys for Major Frederic McLaughlin said today that he would accept legal notice Monday of the divorce suit' filed last week by his wife. Mrs. Irene Castle McLaughlin, and would file an answer denying her charges of cruelty but offering her a temporary allowance while the suit is pending.

Play in the international chess masters tournament at Semmering, Austria, has been largely of the ultra- cautious, watchful - waiting type, especially in the early stages. Drawn games consequently were in the majority. This was to be expected with so many outstanding experts engaged.

Indians claiming direct descent from powerful tribes that controlled this continent 300 years ago met yesterday afternoon in two groups within a mile of each other in Brooklyn. Representing twenty-four tribal families, they gathered in the full, feathered regalia of tradition to observe American Indian Day. observe American Indian Day.

Life insurance companies have increased their holdings of United States Government obligations by more than $1,400,000,000 since January, 1936, to an estimated total of slightly more than $5,300,000,000 now.
Harry W. Colmery, former national commander of the American Legion, sailed yesterday on the Italian liner Rex to visit Italy and attend the Legion pilgrimage to the battlefields of France.

The marriage of Miss Paisley R. Ruediger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wadsworth Ruediger of Montclair, N. J., to Henry Breuer 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Layton Breuer, also of Montclair, took place here yesterday at noon in the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. Orin A. Griesmyer performed the ceremony.

Estate owners of the Purchase section of Harrison won a second point tonight in their fight to halt construction of a ninety-foot Water tower on Kennel worth Road when the Harrison Zoning Board of Appeals reversed the action of its building inspector, Edward French, who issued a permit in August for construction of the tower.

Miss Matilda Thayer Basinger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Waiter Garnett Basinger of this city, was married tonight in St. Paul's Episcopal Church to Lieutenant W. H. Sterling Wright, U. S. A., of Fort Riley, Kan., a member of the United States Army horse show team and a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Wright of Mountain Lakes, N. J.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in relatively small volume and almost all were for payment in future months. The September total of prepayments, therefore, continues unchanged from a week ago.

A 12-year-old girl, whose ankles were tied with a chain fastened to the wall of a dark coal bin in the basement of a west side home was found tonight by police after neighbors reported hearing the child's almost continuous crying.
The Spanish Government tonight announced an important victory on the North Aragon front, near the French border.

The Public Service Commission ordered today an investigation into what it termed the "failure" of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation to "progress" the construction of rural electric lines in various areas of the State.

ON LOCATION--Tomorrow evening at the Ritz Theatre. This is one of last week's children, put over to now. But still being a play about the films, one written by Kent Wiley (said to be the pseudonym of Samuel Ruskin Golding) and with a cast including Jack Norworth, Leslie Denison, Kathleen Hart, Leonard Doyle and Scott Moore.

DURING the first week of December. 1931. The Baltimore Sun denounced in forthright terms a lynching which had just taken place at Salisbury, on the Eastern Shore of Maryland. A helpless Negro, who had had a back-wage dispute with a white employer in which both of them were badly wounded, was dragged from a hospital bed and strung up in the Court House Square;

Final authority to call a strike was placed in the hands of the general executive board today by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America at its third annual convention here.

ONE of the annual events important to collectors is the appearance of another edition of the American standard postage stamp catalogue. The book for 1938 was published last week, and an analysis of the contents of this "bible of philately," the ninety-fourth of its Kind, discloses facts and figures which reflect the hobby's expansion during the previous twelve months.

The need for reducing maximum terms on major electrical appliances and for finding a better method of quoting carrying charges to consumers are two phases of installment selling giving serious concern to credit managers, according to the Year Book of the Credit Management Division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, prepared by J. Anton Hagios, director of the bureau, and released yesterday.

Nineteen fraternities at Rutgers University pledged 137 freshmen in the pre-season period, Dr. Fraser Metzger, dean of men, announced today. Delta Kappa Epsilon led in pledging nineteen, and Kappa Sigma, Raritan Club and Theta Chi tied for seconnd place with thirteen men each.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman, titutar leader of the Republican party in this State, came as close as he could to a personal defeat, without actually encountering that misfortune, in Tuesday's primary election.

VISITORS who would savor Louisiana's history need to become acquainted with the members of one of the strangest organizations in the world, the Live Oak Society of Louisiana. Composed of venerable trees that have looked down upon the enactment of many dramatic events in the development of this region, scene of early French and Spanish colonization of the New World, the society has been supplied with a bona fide constitution,
Count de los Andes, who has been former King Alfonso's aide since the death of the Duke of Miranda, has been requested by the French police to leave Biarritz and take up his residence in Paris.

Attempts to interfere with the law of supply and demand have always failed, and for this reason, both cotton and cotton cloths should be permitted to seek their natural levels, Howard Veit, vice president of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., declared in a letter sent to the trade yesterday.

Postmaster Albert Goldman issued a request yesterday asking that all persons who change their address on or about Oct. 1 to file the proper notice with the Postoffice. Form cards for this purpose may be obtained at any postoffice station.

The Wilmot Woods home development in Westchester County, near Scarsdale, is being modeled on the plan of the old New England villages, state the builders, Haring Blumenthal. In the center of the tract a village green, covering four acres, has been laid out and the houses facing it will all be in the Colonial architectural style.
Members of the alumnae of the Academy of Mount St. Vincent-on-Hudson will hold a card party and tea next Saturday at the Pierre in behalf of their charitable enterprises.

The University of Southern California trundled its 1937 Trojan war horse out of the barn today and watched it gallop over a College of Pacific squad, 40 to 0. Thirty thousand spectators wondered if Coach Howard Jones's Trojans were really as powerful as they looked.

Dr. Jean Wells, daughter of Mrs. Ernest Alden Wells of Ithaca, N. Y., was married to Dr. Joseph Bentley Hollinshead, son of Augustus Livingston Hollinshead of West Englewood, N. J., this afternoon at the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Dr. and Mrs. Donald B. Wells of West Hartford. Rev. Dr.

A SUMMER hotel where the sun shines eighteen hours a day will be available to vacationists when Mount McKinley National Park's new hotel is completed. The Federal Government, with a PWA allotment of $350,000, is adding to the scant lists of Alaskan hotels this construction,

THE entire Southwest is cleaning house, looking forward to a greater influx of Winter visitors than ever before. From San Antonio and Laredo-the two towns that have profited most from the opening of the new highway from the Rio Grande to Mexico City-west to the Pacific Coast the Autumn housecleaning, burnishing and furbelowing and painting goes on apace.

Lieut. Gen. Jinzaburo Mazaki, formerly one of the Japanese Army's ruling triumvirate, has been acquitted of participation in the military revolt of February, 1936, and with this action the investigation that has been going on for seventeen months into that uprising has terminated.
Miss June Mapes, 5??, Arlington School principal, said today she would not prefer charges against Robert Snyder, 12-year-old pupil who shot her and then turned the gun on himself.

ONLY a few miles from Chaumont, General Pershing's head quarters, during the World War, where an A. E. F. memorial monument was recently dedicated, is to be found Morteaux, the smallest village in France.

Miss Willa Charlotte McNamara, daughter of Charles J. McNamara of Methuen, Mass., and the late Mrs. McNamara, was married here this afternoon to Robert Paul Baechlin, son of Mrs. Henry Baechlin of East Orange and the late Mr. Baechlin, in Christ Church of Bloomfield and Glen Ridge.

The engagement of Miss Lillian Ruth Simon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myer Simon of this place, to Dr. Carl Lynnwood Shapiro of Syracuse, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Shapiro of Chelsea, has been announced by her parents.

Richard K. Mellon's Escape 3d, making his first important start of the year, captured the thirty-ninth running of the famed Meadow Brook Cup today before a crowd of 5,000 on the estate of F. Ambrose Clark.

OPENING with the words: "You, Americans, must try to know the new Spain, the Spain of Franco," a new series of English programs from Rebel headquarters at Salamanca, Spain, was inaugurated a few days ago on shortwaves.

The Pan-American conference of traveling salesmen, commission agents and factory representatives opened here this afternoon with delegations present from Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Uruguay, Cuba and Mexico.

An investigation by the Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Japan into the alleged sales of Japanesemade goods in Latin America under "Made in U. S. A." labels will be asked by Choykuro Kadono, president of the chamber, on his return to Japan, Mr. Kadono said here yesterday.

A bronze plaque of General Hunter Liggett, presented by the San Francisco Army and Navy Club, was unveiled today in the Berks County court house by Judge Paul N. Schaeffer, who assailed the Socialist city administration for previously refusing the gift because its members did not believe in war.

C. T. Richard, Provincial Secretary-Treasurer, announced today that the Province of New Brunswick had sold privately in the United States $3,250,000 of 3 1/4 per cent debentures through Whiting, Weeks Knowles, Inc., Boston.

Members of society on Long Island are planning a new departure in Eastern polo with the aid of some of the game's best players. On Wednesday, the first high-goal night polo game in this section of the country will be played on Bostwick Field, Old Westbury, as a benefit for the Boys Club of New York.

The Treasury's plan, announced this week, to have Harold N. Graves, administrative expert, overhaul the machinery of the Internal Revenue Bureau to cut red tape, end overlapping activities and expedite the audit and settlement of tax cases in dispute is the latest of a series of efforts in that direction made in recent years as the tasks of the bureau have increased.

A twilight attack by several hundred heavy tanks was one of the outstanding events today in the German Army manoeuvres in North Prussia. Blue tanks made a surprise move on Red positions over a two-mile front,

The tip of Manhattan Island, preserve of the Wall Street broker and the Maiden Lane jeweler, was also the happy hunting-ground for the pickpockets, sneak thieves, forgers and confidence men of an older New York.

By ARTHUR J. DALEY Mannhattan opened its season at Ebbets Field yesterday, but not with the expected flourish of a touchdown parade. The mighty men of muscle in the Jasper lineup heralded as the best in Green football history, looked muscular but not very mighty as they were hard pressed to defeat Little St. Bonaventure, 21 to 12.

Raymond B. Fosdick, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, returned yesterday on the French liner Paris from a six weeks' trip, during which he visited London, Paris and Geneva for the foundation. He said that so far as he could observe there was not likely to be any general war in Europe, at least not for a year or more, because the nations were not prepared for it.

Colonel and Mrs. Harvey Llewellyn Jones of Washington, formerly of Westfield, N. J., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Harvey Jones, to Richard Marsden Tuthill of Rochester, N. Y.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Brosnan, daughter of Mrs. Humphrey Brosnan of West New Brighton, S. I., and the late Mr. Brosnan, to Joseph Chambers, son of Mrs. Robert Chambers of Brooklyn, took place yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier in Brooklyn.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Marjorie Finlay Hewitt, daughter of Mrs. Kenneth Leslie of Woodville, N. S., and of George Frederick Hewitt Jr. of Montclair, N. J., to Frederick Plympton Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Levi Pease Smith of Burlington.

WASHINGTON.--A decided upturn in the worm business is revealed in statistics gathered annually by the United States Bureau of Fisheries. The rise came in 1933, when the worm production increased nearly 1,000 per cent as compared with preceding years; production currently is about 17,000,000 worms a year.
ABERMAN-Morris J., beloved husband of Rose, devoted father of Evelyn and Ben. Services at Park West Memorial Chapel, 79th St. and Columbus Ave., Sunday, Sept. 26. at 2 P. M.

Vittorio Mussolini came to the film capital today to learn the mechanics of motion-picture making. A police guard took the son of H Duce in hand after he stepped from the plane that brought him from New York, but there was no sign of any anti-Fascist demonstration.
Brooklyn at New York--Hoyt vs. Hubbell or Schumacher. Boston at Philadelphia--Shoffner vs. Smith or Passeau. Pittsburgh at Cincinnati (2)--Tobin and Brandt vs. Derringer and Cascarella.

LESS than twenty-four hours after the Staatsoper people had disposed of a last "Magic Flute" under Toscanini at Salzburg they were at it again hammer and tongs in Vienna, dispensing "Rosenkavalier" under the furious exhortations of Herr Knappertsbusch.

Miss Louise Haxall Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Morrison Harris of Roland Park, was married here today in the First Presbyterian Church to Richard Alvey Jamieson, son of Mrs. Clifton J. Haden of Evanston, Ill., and John Vincent Jamieson Jr. of Maryland.

FROM France Raoul Dufy and from Italy Ferruccio Ferrazzi have come to help transact that annual business of prizes at the Carnegie International, which opens in Pittsburgh Oct. 14. The two European artists crossed on the Queen Mary and were met here Monday morning by Homer Saint-Gaudens, director of the Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute. ute. Tuesday.

Reports by the first fifteen railroads to issue figures for August showed a slackening in the rate of gain in gross revenues and a substantial decline in net operating income. The fall in net operating profit, shown despite a slight increase in gross, may be attributed to higher wages and costs.

Pope Pius today urged Catholicism as the only real anti-Bolshevist campaign, while Premier Mussolini and Chancellor Hitler were engaged in what the Pontiff called "a very solemn and very festive" occasion.

Four Italian workmen were executed early yesterday by Italian authorities at the scene of their robbery and assassination of five native Ethiopians, according to dispatches published today in the Corriere Della Serra of Milan.
The Chicago Cubs found their favorite stooges, the Cardinals, about as usual today, and whipped them, 5 to 2, to remain three and one-half games behind the Giants in the National League pennant race.

Charles Lyon Krum, 85 years old, co-inventor of the teletype, a machine used for printed communication by wire, died today at his home of heart disease. He formerly was vice president of the Western Cold Storage Company.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter T. Scudder of this city and Shelter Island Heights, formerly of South India, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances E. Scudder, to Dr. Charles Stedman Glisson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Glisson of Hawkinsville, Ga.

Mussolini and Hitler began their momentous reunion with a day of ceremonies at Munich. It was marked by enthusiasm of great throngs, by a review of marchers representing Nazi picked forces, and by visits to historic places. .

Provincial newspapers received in Moscow the past two days report nineteen death sentences at Vladivostok. Most of the victims were railroad workers convicted on charges of willful damage to railroads at the behest of Japanese secret agents.

The marriage of Miss Katharine Moir Thomas, daughter of Mrs. George Lloyd Thomas of Montclair. to Edmond Lafayette Prince, son of Mrs. Horace C. Prince of Wilmington, N. C., and the late Mr. Prince, took place this afternoon in the home of the bride's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. H. Russ Van Vleck of Montclair.

Brown won its first opening game since 1934 in defeating Connecticut State, 20 to 0, on Brown Field today. After battling through a scoreless first half, Brown got its attack functioning properly in the third and fourth periods and Scored three touchdowns in a space of twenty minutes.

Bayside (71)--First round, club championship: M. Bartlett defeated H. Lenlein, 4 and 3. Brookville (72)--Semi-final round, club championship, first flight: David P. Seaman defeated George Meredith, 4 and 2; J. Nelson defeated Dr. T. J. Evers, 4 and 3. Second flight: L. Gavin defeated E. Rolins, 6 and 5; c. Smith defeated A. Snouder, 3 and 1.

Thirteen clubs affiliated with the New York League of Girls Clubs, 31 East Thirty-seventh Street, will open the Fall activities this week, starting Wednesday at 8:30 P. M. with an "invitation nights" program.

Miss Virginia Louise Bannon, daughter of Joseph Vincent Bannon of Kew Gardens and the late Mrs. Bannon, has completed plans for her marriage to Frederick Anthony Meyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael George Meyer of Richmond Hill and Monmouth Beach, N. J.

Pensioned On their own applications: LIEUTENANT To take effect 12 Midnight, Sept. 30. Joseph Rosenstock, 42d Precinct, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed March 2, 1907. PATROLMEN To take effect 12 Midnight, Sept. 25. Alvin L. Scheffler, Traffic Precinct K, at 51,500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 25, 1912. To take effect 12 Midnight, Sept. 26.
After a brief respite from the downward trend at the opening, bond values yesterday resumed their plunge to the lowest levels in

Miss Edna V. Boyce, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Boyce of Almonte, Ont., was married to John S. Karl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Karl of Rochester, N. Y., yesterday afternoon in the Jansen Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria by the Rev. R. T. Blumquist of Forest Hills, Queens.

WHILE it may be set down to coincidence, to just a natural order of events, the fact nevertheless, is noteworthy that the present florescence of books by and about Paul Gauguin follows close on the heels of a phenomenal public interest in Vincent Van Gogh that was stimulated by means of books and by the splendid exhibition put on a couple of seasons ago at the Museum of Modern Art.

ADMITTEDLY one of the greatest directors in Hollywood, John Cromwell will lend the weight of his name to two important Broadway plays this season--thus constituting practically a one-man back-to-the-stage movement.

Industrial employment at the end of August was about 43,000 persons greater than on July 31, with a payroll increase of almost $8,400,000, Secretary of Labor Perkins announced today, on the basis of a monthly survey of eighty-nine manufacturing and sixteen non-manufacturing industries.

Pointing out that President Roosevelt had proclaimed the week of Oct. 3 to 9 Fire Prevention Week, The National Board of Fire Underwriters said yesterday that hundreds of chambers of commerce would sponsor fire safety campaigns that week.
The widespread popular interest in psychology has infected the pre-college student, according to a survey here at Wheaton College concerning the principal academic ambitions of the entering class.

With the introduction of curriculum changes this year, Columbia College will carry forward a policy aimed at enabling the student to take full advantage of his educational opportunities, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes declared in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, made public yesterday.

Alabama defeated Howard College, 41 to 0, today in its opening football contest. The Crimson Tide rolled up 28 points in the first half, using the second and th?? string teams more than half the time. Herky Mosely, sophomore, returned a punt 92 yards and a touchdown in the second quarter.

THE very welcome success of Mr. Housman's "Victoria Regina," both here and at long last in London, is a sufficient reason for his new book. It continues and expands his dramatic biographies of the Victorian era as wittily and more variously, and with the same command of credible dialogue as he has always shown.

Miss Josephine Pineros de Leon of New York, daughter of General Jose del C. Pinieros of Bogota, Colombia, and the late Mrs. Mercedes de Leon de Pineros, was married here tonight to D. Eugene Delgada-Arias of this place in St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Robert Barnett, the pastor, officiated.

Century-old Mount Holyoke College welcomed a new president and a new dean of residence to the campus this week and with a capacity enrollment of about 1,030 students began classes for its 101st academic year.

Japan was accused of frightfulness and the Japanese Army in China with having "put itself beyond the pale of humanity" through indiscriminate bombings of open towns and villages and other "illegal" acts by Dr. C. T. Wang, the Chinese Ambassador, in a telegram delivered to the State Department today.

Mrs. H. Laurence Dowd heads a volunteer secretarial committee now making an appeal in behalf of the Opportunity Shop for donations of clothing, furniture, household articles, books and pictures suitable for 'resale at the shop.

AVIROM-GRILL--Mr. and Mrs. L. Grill, 362 Eastern Parkway, announce engagement of their daughter, Goldie, to Mr. Jack R. Avirom of New York. BURGER--SALOMON--Mr. and Mrs. Albert Salomon, 246 Bedford Ave., Mount Vernon, N. Y., announce the engagement of their daughter, Lillian, to Dr. Mortimer D. Burger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Burger, 151 Park Ave., Mount Vernon, N. Y.

Bombs bursting over Madrid and Shanghai are increasing Europe's fear of war from the air. In the following article, the first of two, the aerial armadas of the great powers of Europe are described. In the forthcoming article the machinery of defense against these fleets will be depicted.
Twenty-two persons, including eighteen children, were curshed to death and 140 were injured here today durng a huge demonstration before Ras et-Tin Palace.

ALTHOUGH the title is "Concord River" the chief subject is bird life. For William Brewster, who died in 1919, was a distinguished ornithologist whose great mass of field notes clarified and amplified the exact knowledge of birds during the years when they were first coming under systematic observation by several men with scientific minds.

Miss Eleanor Stuyvesant Pendreigh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Mackenzie Pendreigh of Bloomfield, was married this evening in Grace Episcopal Church here to Edwin Laws Anderson, son of Mrs. Joseph Anderson of South Orange and the late Mr. Anderson.

Miss Mary Helen Warren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred E. Warren, granddaughter of the late United States Senator Francis E. Warren and niece of General John J. Pershing, was married here this afternoon to John B. Welborn, assistant vice president of the First National Bank of Denver.

World War veterans of the 316th Infantry Association will send an expedition to France to learn whether the Unknown Soldier who rests in Arlington National Cemetery is one of their buddies who dropped in the Argonne sector.

Japan is determined to crush Chinese "anti-Japanese armies" and anti-Japanese influence in China, and if this necessitates military operations south of the Yellow River (or in other directions) she may push beyond that line, Lieut. Col. Tan Takahashi, chief of the China section of the Japanese Army General Staff said yesterday in an interview arranged by the Japanese Consulate General here.

Charles Johnson Post, Commissioner of Conciliation in the United States Department of Labor, speaking at the convention of the Book Manufacturers Institute in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, was quoted in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Friday as saying that the problem of economic conditions is "a business man's problem and does not rest in the hands of labor."

The three hold-up men who shot and killed Patrolman John H. A. Wilson Thursday afternoon when he interrupted a robbery at 65 Fulton Street continued to elude arrest yesterday, but the police remained confident of an early "break" in the case.

Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, wife of the Irish Free State Minister at the Vatican, will be guest of honor at a tea opening the season's activities of the Carroll Club, 120 Madison Avenue, to be given tomorrow by the board of directors and the executive council of members.

A hearing has been called by the Securities and Exchange Commission for Oct. 14 on an application by the Southwestern Development Company for its acquisition from the Consolidated Oil Corporation and the Amarillo Oil Corporation of $3,292,000 first mortgage 6 per cent sinking fund gold bonds of the South Plains Pipe Line Company, a subsidiary of the applicant.

Cash estimated by bank officials at $7,000 was obtained here today by two armed robbers who held up the Royal Bank. The two escaped and sped toward Toronto by coupe. They entered the bank shortly before noon and lined up the staff, scooping up all available cash.

The marriage of Miss Mary Elizabeth Alexander, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Long Alexander, to Albert Mason Rockwell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lea Waite Rockwell of Wethersfield, Conn., took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.

The chancelleries of other European powers have no illusions about the quantity of the expressions of comradeship which attend the visit of Mussolini to Hitler. They are much more interested in the quality of the agreements which may follow the visit of the Italian dictator to Nazi Germany.

Walter Kau, 33 years old, assistant secretary to the treasurer of the Allied Chemical and Dye Company of New York, committed suicide this morning by shooting himself through the head with a .32 caliber rifle.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Adlai Stevenson Hardin of Rowafton on Monday at the Norwalk Hospital. Mrs. Hardin is the former Miss Carol Moore of New York, daughter of the late Dr. Franklin T. Moore.
THE featured Victor set of the month contains ten songs of Stephen Foster and is released to coincide with the composer at the University of Pittsburgh.

Miss Catherine Heald, 31 years old, of New York City, who was found unconscious in a wooded section here, apparently a poison victim, was in a critical condition today in Norwalk Hospital. Dr. David Ellrich said that she had failed to regain consciousness since she was found by two youths at midnight and that she was suffering from an overdose of a sedative.
Miss Anita Harding, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Matthews Harding of Boxwood, Wynnewood, was introduced to society this afternoon at tea which her parents gave at their home.

An intercepted pass late in the third period today turned the tide that sent the Case School of Applied Science back to Cleveland with a 14-to-7 verdict over Lehigh. The game, marking the opening of the season for both elevens, was played before a crowd of 8,000, the biggest gathering to witness an inaugural contest in Taylor Stadium.
In its endeavors to treat undergraduates as individuals with complex personalities as well as intellects, Wellesley College officials this week enlisted the cooperation of the students themselves.
Admiral Kiyoshi Hasegawa's suggestion that foreign diplomats should leave Nanking Is explainable by that seaman's unfamiliarity with international law.

To strengthen Mayor S. Davis Wilson's drive to have District Attorney Charles F. Kelley ousted from the leadership of the present grand jury investigation of vice and crime in Philadelphia, a corps of police clerks worked steadily today checking on all vice and gambling arrests made here in recent years.

The University of Idaho's Vandals celebrated their return to the Pacific Coast Conference today with an upset 7-to-6 victory over the Oregon State College eleven. In the last three minutes of play, the Vandals scored from the center of the field on a pair of passes and a line buck.

Members of society arrived at the F. Ambrose Clark estate today on horseback, in coaches drawn by four horses, in buckboards, phaetons, English dog carts and farm wagons, using them later as places of vantage on the ride from which to view the Meadow Brook Cup Steeplechase.

ONE of the delights of the tropical fish hobby is that new and exciting specimens are continually being introduced. Some are weird-looking creatures. some are beautiful, others are unknown quantities.

Traveling on a thirteen-car special train and guarded and pampered by a retinue of forty cowboys, grooms and property men, more than 400 head of assorted livestock have arrived in Kansas City from San Antonio for a week's stop before proceeding to Madison Square Garden in New York and the eighteen-day rodeo starting Oct. 6.
