Miss Kathryn Ellen Hotchkiss was married here this afternoon to Robert Clark Fenn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Fenn of Middlebury, at the First Congregational Church by the Rev. Thomas Cochard, pastor of the Prospect Congregational Church.

TEN business and professional men in big checked aprons step dexterously about a kitchen preparing a dinner which they will later eat Six Junior Leaguers work up a becomingly heightened color over mixing bowl and kettle.

WHEN the classic biographer, Plutarch, set out to sound the glories of the great, he did it in longhand scrawl upon rolls of crinkled papyrus (the same being all he could get in the stationery stores of his day).

With its emphasis on limits of the acreages of the crops it covers, the 1938 farm program looks to the Corn Belt a good deal like the old outlawed AAA with the nomenclature revised and a somewhat different technique of application and administration.

The recent "crisis of labor" in this country provoked many heated and extreme statements on both sides, some of which continue, but meanwhile there has been also a growing crystallization of thoughtful opinion; and it is this that seems likely in the long run to be most influential.

A determination not to undertake the circulation of Nazi and Fascist propaganda in other Countries, at the same time asking those other nations to desist in their defamation of the two regimes, was one of the topics Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy discussed at Munich today, according to officially informed Italian correspondents, accompanying Premier Mussolini.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore, to select those of the greatest general interest.

What is said to be the first national forum on real estate appraisal and mortgage analysis ever held in this country will be held in Washington, Nov. 19 and 20, under the joint auspices of private organizations and governmental agencies, according to H. O. Walther of Chicago, president of the Society of Residential Appraisers, one of the three private organizations participating in the forum's sponsorship.

Samuel J. Tilden High of Brooklyn came from behind in the final minute of play today to tie the Great Neck High eleven, 7 to 7, before a large crowd. Great Neck had tallied in the second period and seemed headed for victory with a strong running attack.

Hobart College opened its football season today by defeating Upsala College, 7-0, in a game featured by hard running attacks by both teams. Hobart was put in scoring position by a 30-yard pass, Bowling to Ferris. Miller smashed to a score from the 3-yard line. Stanziale starred for Upsala on both offense and defense.

Pittsburgh's Golden Panthers crushed the struggling Ohio Wesleyan Bishops, 59 to 0, today as 19,700 sweltering fans marveled at the sharp powerful thrusts that marked every period with at least two touchdowns.

Brown University looks ahead today to the academic year as a period of innovation, expansion and progress. It will be the first full year of administration under President Wriston, who was installed in February.

Miss Vulvia Marjorie Washburne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Washburne of West Hartford, and Donald Wendt Strevell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew S. Strevell of Albany, N. Y., were married this afternoon in the chapel of Immanuel Congregational Church by the Rev. Fletcher D. Parker, minister of the church.
In a telegram to the League of Nations today Japan rejected an invitation to sit with the League's advisory committee on the Far East.

Faced with the necessity of slashing departmental requests by almost $50,000,000, Mayor La Guardia sat down yesterday with Kenneth Dayton, Acting Budget Director, to whip together the city budget for 1938, the first version of which must be presented to the Board of Estimate next Saturday.
Mrs. Bernard S. Deutsch, widow of the late President of the Board of Aldermen, announced yesterday that she was a candidate for election to the City Council.

TEACHING on the radio and teaching at Yale are radically different. The former is coercive education, the other persuasive. So declared Dr. James Rowland Angell, former president of Yale University and now educational counselor of the National Broadcasting Company, as he sat in his new office at Radio City and in a reflective mood linked his forty-five years as a teacher with the possibilities in educational broadcasting. .
The engagement has been announced of Miss Ruth Frances Peck, daughter of Clifford De Witt Peck of this place, to Russell Everett Adamson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Adamson of Madison, N. J.

Youth will be served by the department of problems in industry of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs through the furtherance of plans for apprentice training to remedy the shortage of skilled workers in certain trades as well as to shorten the actual preparation for journey work.

After making yesterday the lowest records since May, 1933, with December touching 8.17 cents a pound in early trading, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered $1 a bale and ended unchanged to 5 points higher than on Friday.

After almost a year of silent wound-nursing the Republican party is rousing itself and preparing to return to the political wars. The wounds are not all healed, but the spirit is reviving, as was shown at the meeting of the executive committee here this week to consider means of restoring the party to power and prestige.

OCTOBER'S approach gives a number of veteran radio performer the cue to resume broadcasting, and so this week finds Eddie Cantor, Kate Smith and Tony Wons joining the cavalcade for the 1937-38 season.

Henry E. Stern, former City Court judge, died today after a year's illness. He was 80 years old. He was widely known in fraternal circles, the oldest Past Master of Washington Lodge of Masons and former head of the Past Masters Association. For several years he represented his Odd Fellows lodge in Grand Lodge sessions.

When the University of Pennsylvania's freshman class, comprising the advance guard of nearly 4,500 undergraduates, arrives on the campus Monday morning its members will find little to remind them that the path of a first-year student once was a rocky one.

The controversial sugar legislation enacted in the closing. days of the last session of Congress and reluctantly signed by President Roosevelt is considered by some persons in the industry to be so unfair to growers and consumers in the continental United States that a determined effort probably will be made at the next session of the Congress to alter the act.

Dr. James Phinney Baxter 3d, the new president of Williams College, paid a tribute to Dr. Tyler Dennett, his predecessor, today at the opening of the academic year. Addressing a meeting of 800 students and faculty members, he said that it was "sad to think of Dr. Dennett's departure."
The condition of U. S. Naval Cadet Robert Quinn, 17 years old, of Carnegie, Pa., who underwent an operation for peritonitis at the Royal Navy Hospital Thursday, was reported satisfactory today.
SOME further gain was reported for retail trade last week against such retarding influences as the continued reaction in security and commodity markets and hot weather.
Stocks fluctuated erraticaally and closed fractionally lower in heaviest trading on a Saturday since March; turnover, 1,469,520 shares.

As he himself felt zest and awareness in living, so much the more he wished a vigorous. many-flavored, untrammeled living for men and women everywhere.

WHEN Agnes de Mille returns to the local concert field, after an absence of several seasons spent partly in Hollywood and partly in London, it will be with a company of her own-or at least in part her own. In conjunction with the English dancer and choreographer Antony Tudor,

A change in curriculum to include a course in laboratory technology was announced this week by Dr. J. Laurence Meader, president of Russell Sage College for Women, at the opening of the new college year. The course is four years and leads to a Bachelor's degree.

Political strategy comes less naturally to women than to those masculine leaders who have absorbed its fine points through boyhood and adolescence, but the earnestness with which the feminine divisions are concentrating on mastering the topic indicates how much more keenly the economic situation stirs their interest than in former years.

A big, belligerent Ohio State football team made two touchdown thrusts through the rain today to defeat Texas Christian, 14 to 0, and end the Horned Frogs' record of never having lost an opening or intersectional gridiron contest.

Tree surgeons have been searching for many years for a practicable, durable, tree wound dressing. Many substances have been tried. Few have been found satisfactory. The simplest dressing is orange shellac.

A report containing fifteen specific criticisms of the Federal Undistributed profits tax and asking that Congress, in the next session, pass legislation to remove inequities hampering business expansion and retarding employment, has been sent to the Treasury Department by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George K. Hooper of this city and Pasadena, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary De Forest Hooper, to Henry B. Belden of Scranton, Pa., and Santa Barbara.

The sharpest battle in the history of the reciprocal trade agreements program will occur in Washington next month when foreign traders and protectionists clash over concessions to be granted by the Government in negotiating a trade treaty with Czechslovakia, business men predicted here yesterday.
If budget balancing and increased foreign trade be taken as the criteria, Canada presents- probably the most striking picture of reviving prosperity in the world today.
Doubt as to the efficacy of compulsory homework for New York City's elementary school children is cast by a survey made by Peter J. Di Napoli, just published by Teachers College, Columbia University.
While Reichsfuehrer Hitler welcomed Premier Mussolini in Munich, the League of Nations warmed its magnificent new Assembly Palace tonight with a brilliant if not gay reception.

The Bloomfield High Bengals, State champions of 1936, still reigned supreme on New Jersey gridirons, following their 9-to-0 victory scored today over Phillipsburg. The Bengals put over a touchdown in the second period on a pass and on the first play of the final session Stan Krivik kicked a field goal from Phillipsburg's 29-yard line.

Dr. James Phinney Baxter 3d, the new president of Williams College, paid a tribute to Dr. Tyler Dennett, his predecessor, today at the opening of the academic year. Addressing a meeting of 800 students and faculty members, he said that it was "sad to think of Dr. Dennett's departure."
The condition of U. S. Naval Cadet Robert Quinn, 17 years old, of Carnegie, Pa., who underwent an operation for peritonitis at the Royal Navy Hospital Thursday, was reported satisfactory today.
SOME further gain was reported for retail trade last week against such retarding influences as the continued reaction in security and commodity markets and hot weather.
Stocks fluctuated erraticaally and closed fractionally lower in heaviest trading on a Saturday since March; turnover, 1,469,520 shares.

He was widely known in fraternal circles, the oldest Past Master of Washington Lodge of Masons and former head of the Past Masters Association. For several years he represented his Odd Fellows lodge in Grand Lodge sessions.

TO THE triumph of the Spring Maurice Evans is likely to add a triumph of the Autumn. "King Richard II," which has resumed operations at the St. James, is still the liveliest Shakespeare of a Gotham decade. Although the current Bolingbroke lacks somewhat the inner authority of Ian Keith and the Gaunt is all surface declamation,

It is a curious paradox that the Soviet regime, whose central position from the outset has been equality and abolition of distinctions of wealth, birth or class, now shows sharper and more widespread inequalities than any country in the world.

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Burgess Watson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Watson of this place, to John Bradford Millet, son of Dr. and Mrs. John A. P. Millet of Stockbridge and New York, has been announced by her parents.
F. M. Rhed of the Hoover Company will demonstrate "New Methods of Training Salesmen" at the luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt on Tuesday.

HE was, said John Randolph. "the Cock of Kentucky," and it is of the Cock of Kentucky that Mr. Mayo writes in this first volume of his monumental biography of Henry Clay. The designation was wonderfully apt, and if it implied a sneer, that was easy to bear.

After yesterday's victory over the Dodgers, the Giants need only eight of their twelve remaining games to win the National League pennant, for then, even if the Cubs should capture all nine of the contests they have left, the final standing would be:

Transition changes at Yale from the administration of President James Rowland Angell to that of Dr. Charles Seymour, historian, scholar and for ten years provost of the university, will be marked by a quiet, almost unobtrusive program.
Senator Hattie W. Caraway said today that it "now appears that the President may call a special session of Congress."

Clearings of the Westchester County Clearing House Association for the week ended on Friday totaled $3,693,226, compared with $3,153,036 in the preceding week and $2,298,077 in the corresponding week of 1936.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 24 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Maude Adams, idolized by thousands who saw her in "Peter ??" a generation ago and who left the stage nineteen years ago, arrived here yesterday to take up her duties as counselor in dramatics at Stephens College, a high school and junior college for girls.
Wholesale prices in The Netherlands continue to rise slightly, the index for August being 77.6, compared with 17.5 for July and with 62.6 for September, 1936.

Irving A. O'Hara, retired detective sergeant of the New York Police Department, brother-in-law of the late Mayor John F. Hylan, whom he served as bodyguard during most of the Hylan Administration, 1918-25, died suddenly at 8 o'clock last night of a heart attack at his home, 70-19 Harrow Street, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 63 years old.

Grenville Taylor Emmet, recently appointed United States Minister to Austria, who presented his credentials to President Wilhelm Miklas ten days ago, died suddenly in the Hotel Bristol at 9:30 o'clock tonight. At his bedside was his wife, who had taken a special plane from Paris today.

Show folk on Beale Street mourned today the death of Bessie Smith, 50, "queen" of blues singers, who was killed in an automobile accident. In 1917 Bessie sang the blues in a Beale Street show house, attracted attention of Eastern theatrical agents and was soon famous. Broadway welcomed her.

Five thousand persons using the Garden State Bus Lines daily between Ho-Ho-Kus and New York and Jersey City and Passaic were warned today by Joseph Krueger, president of the company, that he could not guarantee service beginning tomorrow. A strike of his sixty drivers was scheduled to start at 5 A. M. tomorrow.
The first Inter-American Aviation Conference ended last night after voting in favor of an inter-American policy instead of a world policy on aviation matters.
The fortnightly settlement was negotiated without difficulty, the only failure being of a small brokerage firm and the amount involved was insignificant.
Niagara University today beat the Notre Dame B eleven in its opening game, 1 to 0. A fifty-fiveyard dash by Rybak of Niagara was the feature. The line-up:

Miss Katherine Schoonmaker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus Schoonmaker of this city, has chosen Oct. 29 as the date of her marriage to Frederic Burdett Town, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Edward Town of South Orange.
Yale will hold the first exercises of the 237th year of the university tomorrow morning, when a freshman class limited in membership to 850 meets for organization in Woolsey Hall.

The atrocities being committed in the world today by "supposedly civilized" people surpass those of the Assyrian conquerors centuries before Christ, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared yesterday in his sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

Great Britain, with her present armament program, is not preparing for another war but is merely protecting herself against attack, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks declared yesterday morning at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fiftythird Street.
Frank Isaac Schechter, an authority on trade-mark laws, died early yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. In ill health for a year, he was stricken with pneumonia a week ago. He was 47 years old.

The government today instructed the Finnish envoy at Moscow to present a serious protest to Maxim M. Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, on account of recent violations of Finnish territory by Soviet military airplanes.

The wedding of Miss Anne Bulkeley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Bulkeley of this city, and Philip Henry Yost, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Henry Yost of West Hartford, took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents.

The Port of New York Authority has purchased from the Edward Altorfer estate the three-story flats at 201-207 Thirty-third Street, southwest corner of Hudson Avenue, and the one-story store building at 210 Thirty-second Street and from the Palisade Building and Loan Association the dwelling at 821 Thirtyfirst Street, all in Union City.

A demand that Justice Hugo L. Black resign or be removed from the Supreme Court without delay, unless charges of his membership in the Ku Klux Klan are completely disproved, was made in a resolution adopted yesterday by the New York County Board of the Ancient Order of Hibernians.
Two girls who went along to a holdup "for the thrih," and three youths arrested with them yesterday, faced possible murder charges as one of the victims lay seriously wounded in Bellevue Hospital.

Society turned away from the extensive program of races, polo and steeplechase events today, long enough to attend the fifteenth annual dog show of the Westbury Kennel Association that was held on the polo field of the estate of Mrs. John S. Phipps.
Mrs. Rosie May Billings Orsborn, 34 years old, of New Carlisle, has become her own stepmother by her marriage to Oscar H. Orsborn, 77, the second husband of her mother, who died in 1936.

Reports of a "miracle foretelling a Chinese victory" ran through the Chinese Nantao quarter of Shanghai tonight. The report was that the Nantao city god, a huge wooden image, appeared in the street, went to the Chapei area to comfort Chinese troops, then returned to his place at Nantao Temple.
With the fifty-second triennial General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church opening in Cincinnati Wednesday, Oct. 6, unusual interest will center in the election of a Presiding Bishop.
Jeers, catcalls and stench bombs greeted Clement R. Attlee, Labor Parliamentary leader, tonight as he addressed a Labor meeting in the East Ham Town Hall.

The ultimate truth of human nature is governed by three lawsthose of pleasure, power and pride, declared the Rev. John E. Kuizenga, professor of Princeton Theological Seminary, Princeton, N. J., in his sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.
Dr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Reynolds have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Niblock, to the Rev. William A. Parsons.
The sun never sets on the British flag, and the all-seeing eye of 10 Downing Street keeps constant watch over great

The American Indian returned to New York yesterday and temporarily took and held a small outpost near the northern tip of Manhattan Island, sold by his ancestors many years ago for an estimated $23 worth of trinkets.
Rumanian anti-Semitic leaders expressed great satisfaction at the decree Premier George Tatarescu issued yesterday forbidding the collection of money for the Zionist movement.
America is more "jittery" about war than Europe, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday at Christ Church, Methodist Episcopal, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

W. B. Rhode of South River emerged from a triangular tie to gain high gun in the distance handicap, feature event of the third and final day of the first Atlantic States trapshooting championships at the North Jersey Gun Club today.

The Farm Credit Administration wrote "paid in full" on 25,113 farmers' mortgages during the twelve months ending Sept. 1, an increase of more than 60 per cent over the preceding twelve months, W. I. Myers, governor of the FCA, announced today.
J. Howard Sturge, superintendent of the Bergen County division of Public Service, Electric and Gas Company, died yesterday of a heart attack at his Summer home in Indian Lake, N. Y. His age was 51.

Seneca Ave (10-2762a), a e cor of Hunts Point Ave, 123x35; Hyman Finkelstein to Wycliff Corp, 939 Intervale Ave; mtg $46,000. Townsend Ave (11-2847), w s, 100 ft s of 174th St, 50x100, also Townsend Ave, w s, 150 ft s of 174th St, 25x100; Wildoh Realty Corp to 270 Seaman Ave, Inc, 1 441 St Nicholas Ave; mtg $109.200.

The funeral of Miss Margaret Wessels, secretary to the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, was held yesterday in the Fairchild Chapel, 86 Lefferts Place, Brooklyn.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis C. Marburg of Montclair have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hildegarde Marburg, to Howard H. Hennington, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Hennington of Rochester, N.Y.
Money for lending continues to be overabundant and the rate extremely easy despite the failure of the Dutch-Indian 3 per cent 912,000,000guilder conversion loan.

The Dutch are less inclined to attribute Wall Street's weakness to political fears than to the influence of major economic factors, especially the recession in the building outlook, the decrease in steel activity, railroad wage and freight-rate difficulties and the crumbling of commodity prices.
William Henry Rouse, member of the Virginia Unemployment Commission, former Mayor and City Attorney of Bristol, Va., died at a hospital here early today. He was 62 years old.

Leaving behind eighty-five of her officers and seamen the Spanish Government destroyer Jose Luis Diez sailed from Falmouth tonight after the damage inflicted by Insurgent planes off Gijon had been repaired.

The South Shore Polo Club triumphed over a 101st Cavalry quartet in a Long Island League game today, 8--5. A two-goal offensive in the third session put the home squad ahead and it remained in front thereafter. The line-up:

Mayor La Guardia's mediation board, recently appointed in an effort to avert a strike of at least 8,000 of the B. M. T.'s employes on rapid transit, street car and bus lines, will resume today its peace conferences with spokesmen for the company and the C. I. O.-chartered Transport Workers Union.

Miss Jean O. Pratt, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David D. Pratt of Rochester, N. Y., and New Bedford, Mass., has selected Oct. 9 as the date for her marriage to Kenneth C. Ogden Jr., son of Kenneth C. Ogden of 50 East Seventy-second Street, and the late Mrs. Ogden.

Demand for apparel and accessories was unabated in the wholesale market last week, and deliveries on most items slowed to the point where it presents a definite problem to retailers faced with active consumer purchasing.

An airplane carrying a young pilot and a woman plummeted into the ocean from about 500 feet near here this afternoon, injuring both occupants, the woman seriously. The victims are Henry S. Smith, 25 years old, of New Roselle, N. J., and Miss Janet Hunt, 24, a registered nurse of New Brunswick.

Swiftly swinging back into command through a 21-yard field goal by Dick Crayne in the last three minutes, the Brooklyn Dodgers shaded the Cleveland Rams, 9 to 7, before 12,000 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday and gained a first-place tie with the Pittsburgh Pirates in the Eastern division of the National Football League.
Tiny power boat models skimmed along the surface of the Lincoln Memorial Reflecting Pool here today in the annual championship regatta sponsored by the Miniature Regatta Association.

Representative Celler of New York, ranking member of the House Judiciary committee, today urged W. A. Ayres, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, to prosecute business organizations which indulge- in "horizontal" price-fixing combinations in violation of the Miller-Tydings Act.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 76 per cent of capacity, down 5 points from the week before. The decline was not altogether in accordance with expectations, for buyers had been taking deliveries freely on old orders, and it was thought that as those orders ran out they would be replaced fully by fresh orders.
President Roosevelt ended his relaxation in the Yellowstone National Park today, and tonight his train was rolling westward, for inspection and speeches.

Miss Jean Fern Allen, daughter of Devere Allen, author, lecturer and member of the Socialist National Executive Committee, and Mrs. Allen of Little Forest, Wilton, became the bride of Hugh N. Young, son of Captain and Mrs. Henry A. F. Young of South Wilton, yesterday in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church here.

Mayor La Guardia, who so far has avoided the appearance of much personal activity in his campaign for re-election, will visit both groups of his labor supporters today. At 10 A. M. he will call at the headquarters of the American Labor party in the Hotel Claridge.

Men should not speak of laborers and producers disparagingly, but as "friends and benefactors," the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman said yesterday in his sermon at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

It is the task of the Christian church to bring the entire human race together into one unified group, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the James Memorial Chapel, Broadway at 120th Street.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 92.2, which compares with 92.4 two weeks ago, 91 three weeks ago and 91.7 four weeks ago.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 82.2 on Sept. 22, compared with 83 a fortnight before, 83.3 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 13, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.
An organized air hunt was in full swing tonight in the Northern Territory of Australia for Dr. Clyde Fenton, the "flying physician."
The Paterson Panthers continued their undefeated march today when they set back the Washington Presidents, 14-0. It was Paterson's fourth straight victory without a score being made against it.

With the closing last night of New York's first all-trailer show, A. B. Hopkins, director of the exhibition, warned that New York City probably would have a serious trailer problem on its hands in 1939 because of the failure of the World's Fair planning commission to set aside adequate facilities for the parking of mobile homes of visitors to the fair.
Committee for Industrial Organization butchers tonight called for a mass walkout at thirteen Hygrade-Meat Packing Corporation plants in eight cities.

The women's singles championship of the eleventh annual Pacific Southwest tennis tournament went to Miss Alice Marble today when America's 1936 national titleholder routed Miss Gracyn Wheeler of Santa Monica, 6--1, 6--0.
Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Hartzog have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jene Hartzog, to Richard Edward Wengren of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. L. Wengen of Portland, Me.

Production plans for Ginger Rogers go on unabated at RKO. Pandro Berman has announced the purchase for her of the Ursula Parrott story, "She Married for Money." It is thought that both "Vivacious Lady" and "Castles in the Air" will occupy her talents before "She Married for Money" is put before the cameras.

The possibility that the cotton crop now forecast at more than 16,000,000 bales will provide a considerable quantity of low-grade cotton at prices tending to narrow the spread between cotton and various substitutes has stimulated appraisal by cotton mills of the possible stimulus to recapture of old markets and opening of important new outlets, according to a statement relets, according to a statement released for publication today by the Cotton Textile Institute.

In planning a program of activities for the year each congregation should first try to answer the question: "What do we believe about God?" the Rev. Dr. S. Tagart Steele Jr., vicar of the Protestant Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession, Broadway and 155th Street, said yesterday.

The fiftieth season of the, Abbott E. Kittredge Club for Girls, which is composed mostly of young business women of Greater New York, will begin on Friday. Several additions have been made to the regular calendar of social, cultural and business activities.

With addresses, music and prayer, the cornerstone of the administration building of the new home of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind on Stratton Street, Yonkers, was laid this afternoon in the presence of officials and invited guests.

Five powerful Fire Department pumpers worked at full speed last night to hold down a flood rising from a broken water main in the excavation for the Sixth Avenue subway at Sixth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

The effect of the Far Eastern complications has not been serious on British commerce. Because of the long depression, British exporters neglected China, and the Empire's commercial counselor in Shanghai, in a report just issued,

Ticket prices for Manhattan's football game with Texas A. and M. at the Polo Grounds Saturday, as announced yesterday by James J. Tierney, business manager, will be $2.75 for box seats; $2.20 for reserved seats, and $1.10 for general admission.

Mayor La Guardia put in a full day yesterday working with Acting Budget Director Kenneth Dayton in the latter's Municipal Building office on the task of slashing from $40,000,000 to $50,000,000 from the $642,419,676 which city departments have submitted as estimates of their operating costs for 1938.

The fifth and final concert of the gratifyingly successful Tchaikovsky series presented by the Federal Symphony Orchestra under the auspices of the Federal Music Project, occasioned another sold-out house at the WPA Theatre of Music last night.
Greenbrier Tennis Club officials looked over the list of entries today for the first open tennis tournament in sports history and found the names of ranking amateurs conspicuous by their absence.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Rindfusz of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Faire Jane Rindfusz, to Magnus W. Edwards of Hartford, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Otto E. Edwards of East Norwalk.

A sensational catch by Joe Carter, an end, of a 50-yard forward pass in the last seventy seconds of play today gave the Eagles a 6-to-6 tie with the Chicago Cardinals in a National League professional football game.

Beckwith Havens of Syosset, L. I., and John R. Dibert of East Orange, N. J., who were the first men to fly Long Island Sound twenty-five years ago, re-enacted the event today. A small party of friends saw them off from the Pan American Airways here.
The week's market on the Boerse witnessed some temporary activity and substantial, although irregular, recoveries developed on Wednesday and Thursday.

Miss Beatrice Alvira Austin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest B. Austin of 666 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, to Eugene Franklin Baynon, son of Mrs. George P. Kaiser of 1,082 Hancock Street and the late Elihu Kendal Baynon.

Coordination of the expert services of the city's private and public agencies dealing with the problem of school maladjustment and delinquency to reduce the delinquency rate is recommended in the second interim report of the Board of Education's joint committee, headed by James Marshall, vice president of the board, and Miss Margaret J. McCooey, Associate Superintendent of Schools.

The appalling world situation, instead of making pessimists and cynics of us, should make us better Christians, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, said in his sermon there yesterday.

Three candidates for the congressional seat of the late William P. Connery Jr. tonight began their final swing around the Seventh Massachusetts District, making President Roosevelt and the New Deal principal issues in Tuesday's special election.

Despite a vigorous attempt last evening by W. Kingsland Macy, Suffolk County Republican chairman, to bring the county committee members of the Town of Huntington into line with his ideas on nominations for town officers,

Two men narrowly escaped death carly today when an au. tomobile in which they were riding fell seventy-five feet from the top of the cliff overlooking the midtown tunnel and crashed against a rock ledge. The ledge prevented the car from dropping another seventy-five feet to the bottom.

The Pirates took both ends of a doubleheader with the Reds today, nosing out a victory in the final two innings of the opener, 5 to 4, and capturing the nightcap, 2 to 1, by scoring twice in the first inning.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rockhill of New York entertained a number of young friends of their daughter, Miss Katharine L. Rockhill, at dinner tonight at Cranehill, Great Barrington.
Members of the Westchester County Historical Society see little chance of Kykuit, country mansion of the late John D. Rockefeller at Pocantico Hills, ever becoming a county historic shrine,

The Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor received $153,037 in the last year for articles made in its workshops by blind and otherwise handicapped persons, according to the ninetyfourth annual report, issued yesterday by Dr. Marcus C. Hankinson, president. This income exceeded the previous year's total by 20 per cent.

The Right Rev. W. Bertrand Stevens, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Los Angeles, pleaded for unity among the Christian sects through support of the Oxford and Edinburgh conferences in a talk at St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church, St. Ann's Avenue and 140th Street, yesterday.

With more than 65,000 persons attending, Golden Jubilee Week of the New Jersey State Fair opened here this afternoon, to continue day and night through next Saturday. A troupe of "hell drivers" provided the main attraction at the matinee, with Edwin Franko Goldman and his band giving a concert tonight.

Mrs. May F. McCann, the divorced wife of George O. Frank, Stock Exchange teller who was killed in Brooklyn early Tuesday morning, was questioned for several hours yesterday by the police ana representatives of the Brooklyn District Attorney's office but apparently was able to throw no light on the murder.
Until the very end of a long life, Edward A. Filene indefatigably devoted all his resources to the betterment of the world, which he frequently said had done so much more for him than he deserved.

Officials of Knickerbocker Hospital, 70 Convent Avenue, issued an appeal yesterday for contributions to a seventy-fifth anniversary fund of $75,000 for a new clinic building and other improvements and expenses. The hospital is in special need of money for its work among children, it was said.

Bareheaded and looking much less nervous than on the day of his wedding nearly four months ago, the Duke of Windsor arrived in Paris this morning with a yellow leather portfolio under his arm and with his Duchess, who has come to buy clothes.
YOUNG HENRY OF NAVARRE, by Heinrich Mann (Knopf, $3.) A historical novel. REMEMBERING LAUGHTER, by Wallace Stegner (Little, Brown, $1.25.) A prize-winning novelette.

As another step in its broad policy of maintaining an easy money market and encouraging commercial banks to make loans to accelerate business expansion, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System today issued a general revision, effective Oct. 1, of its regulations covering discounts and advances by the Federal Reserve for member banks.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph Hoyle Hudson, rector of St. Augustine's Protestant Episcopal Church, 2026 West Columbia Avenue, for the last sixteen years, died today in the Episcopal Hospital after an illness of several weeks. He was 55 years old.

The spiritual results of the work of martyrs are not to be measured by human yardsticks, the Rev. Henry F. Hammer declared yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. "As the church looks abroad today and sees persecution and the death of martyrs," he said, "the church is optimistic, because where martyrs die the church lives, as the blood of the martyrs makes up the seeds of Christianity.

Lightning, 7-year-old bay gelding belonging to Mrs. Milton Reiner of the Saxon Woods Hunt Club, captured the hunter championship and then went on to win the reserve rosette in the title jumping event in the annual Sleepy Hollow Farm horse show today.

With the commendation and blessing of Pope Pius XI, the National Council of Catholic Women opened today its seventeenth annual convention for the special consideration of the personal responsibilities of Catholic laywomen to further the civic and social as well as the spiritual objectives indorsed and enjoined by the church.
The Athletics scored three runs off relief pitcher Wes Ferrell in the ninth inning and gained a 7-7 tie with the Senators today when the game was called after eleven innings because of darkness.
The Autumn outlook for light industries is considered favorable. Western coal and steel activity, however, is hampered by the shortage of railroad cars.

Fifteen hundred union employee of Fisher Body Corporation abandoned their announced intention of taking a strike vote today subsequent to a warning from Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers.

As a result of their victory over the Dodgers yesterday, the Giants need only six of their eleven remaining games to capture the National League pennant, for then, even if the Cubs should win all seven of the contests they have left, the final standing would be:

Seventeen Federal agencies reported awards of 130 contracts valued at about $6,086,481 under terms of the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Thursday, the Department of Labor announced yesterday.

If any team the country over is deserving of the favor of fortune's smile it would be difficult to name a more eligible candidate than Harvard. If there is any recompense in this mundane world for conscientious, unremitting striving for improvement, Crimson football should go over the top this year.

Eligibility for membership in New York's three-cents-a-day hospitalization plan will be extended on Friday to permit enrollment for the first time of families in which the income earners work in small organizations or are self-employed, Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the Associated Hospital Service, 370 Lexington Avenue, announced yesterday.

An exhibition of paintings by D. Owen Stephens of the Hayden Planetarium-Grace Eclipse Expedition, who died in Panama while homeward bound from the June 8 eclipse of the sun, will be held beginning today and continuing throughout October at the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History.

Winding up their season's racing on Long Island Sound, the yachts of the Handicap Class engaged in their thirty-first annual regatta today. The winners were Walter N. Rothschild's gray-hulled yawl Avanti, which may go in the Miami-Nassau race across the Gulf stream the coming Winter; Granbery and Cross's Anita, sailed by George P. Granbery, and Mrs. P. S.

On the eve of the twenty-ninth annual convention of the Metal Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor there were indications tonight that an attempt would be made to put through a resolution calling upon the federation's forthcoming convention to expel the suspended C. I. O. unions.

Premier Mussolini is keeping a watchful eye on the movements of his son, Vittorio, who is in Hollywood to learn something about motion-picture production. It Is understood that Il Duce was not particularly eager for his son to go to America, because of possible Communist or anti-Fasicst demonstrations.

There was much talk of last week's great run of tuna at the Atlantic City Tuna Club today, but little action. The club dock, where some 7,000 pounds of tuna were tossed from five boats a week ago was practically barren as, one by one, the fleet came in tonight.

Trust company officials in New York State are making preparation for the opening soon of a relatively new type of trust service--the common trust--which they hope will greatly facilitate their work in handling certain types of existing trust funds and may enlarge

THE scene of "Remembering Laughter"* is Iowa in the days when a horse-and-buggy was a vehicle, not a figure of constitutional speech. The story is a skillfully drawn triangle in a capsule. A breezy Scots farmer falls in love with his charming young sister-in-law. His rather dour wife discovers that they are lovers.

Denouncing Japan's invasion of China as an act "without parallel in wanton cruelty," Bishop William Newman Ainsworth of the Methodist Episcopal Church South asserted in a letter made public yesterday by the American League Against War and Fascism that "millions of noble Japanese" opposed the invasion.

Five hundred uniformed members of the Police Square Club, a Masonic organization, attended a memorial service yesterday afternoon at the Riverside Church for twenty-nine members who died in the last year.

Alexander H. Kaminsky, Assistant District Attorney for New York County and prosecutor in many important murder trials, died early yesterday in his apartment in the Beacon Hotel, Seventy-fifth Street and Broadway. He was 54 years old.

King Christian cordially greeted thousands of spectators today as he dedicated Europe's longest bridge -- 10,432 feet - across the sound between the islands of Zealand and Falster in bright mild sunshine.
Charles Godfrey Strater, retired Louisville tobacco manufacturer, died here yesterday at his home, 35 Onondaga Street, at the age of 81. Three sons, Charles H., Leonard G. and Henry Strater, survive.
The value of farmers' sales of produce in the business year ended on July 31 was 8,900,000,000 marks, against 8,700,000,000 in the preceding year and 6,400,000,000 three years ago.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Rausch of this place have announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of their daughter, Miss Helen Dorothy Rausch, to Walter Persson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Persson of Roslyn.
More than 6,000 Harvard students will arrive here tomorrow and before nightfall will have entered for the year's courses in the college and graduate schools.
The National Bank of Nicaragua has shipped $50,000 of newly-mined gold to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to be used for currency reserve.

A joint message on the Far Eastern situation has been addressed to the American churches by the Ccmmittee of Reference and Council of the Foreign Missions Conference and the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

Ten of the nineteen starters capsized as the fourth and final series for the canoe-sailing championship was staged by the Associated Canoe Clubs of Sheepshead Bay in Rockaway Inlet yesterday. A brisk northwest breeze gave the contestants considerable trouble, but the skippers of the craft that tipped over experienced nothing more than a ducking.

An award of $717 has just been made by Referee Ferdinand Hoyt in the State Workmen's Compensation Court to Walter Lang of Otisville because of a 15 per cent loss of the occupational usefulness of his right hand.
British industries, already bearing huge losses, which may increase indefinitely, as a result of the Sino-Japanese conflict, will convene this week to plan action to protect their interests.

China's recent request to the standing committee of the Council of the League of Nations for technical aid to China and immediate consideration of such problems as fighting cholera has awakened much sympathy in the British delegation.

Dr. Hans H. Dieckhoff, German Ambassador to the United States, Mrs. Dieckhoff and their daughter Charlotte; Sumner Welles, UnderSecretary of State, and Mrs. Welles; Viscount Knollys, Sir Hugo Cunliffe-Owen and Lady Cunliffe-Owen and Rajkumar Pratrap Singh, ruler of the feudatory State of Dhenkanal, India, with his family, are among the passengers due today on the North German Lloyd liner Europa from the Channel ports.
Canadian demand for United States cash oats to date has failed to assume the volume recently expected by the trade.

A total of $52,410,007 was spent by the Works Progress Administration on Queens parks, highways, public buildings and other physical improvements in the two years from Aug. 1, 1935, when the WPA was established, to July 31, 1937, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, reported yesterday.

Forty-seven men, representing communities from Riverhead to Brooklyn, competed today in the annual Long Island horseshoe pitching championship in Hempstead Lake State Park. Vito Fleccia of Brooklyn, State champion, won seven and lost no games, winning first place.
Appointment of Thomas Holland of Michigan to be chairman of the Public Contract Board, and Oscar R. Strackbein and Major Robert Nelson Campbell as members, was announced today by Secretary Perkins.

Patricia Maguire, 32, the Oak Park sleeping sickness victim who has lain in a coma for five years, was moved today from her home to the Presbyterian Hospital to undergo an oper- I ation for an abdominal tumor. Her condition was described as critical.

Resolutions urging that an Italian-American be named to succeed Newbold Morris of New York City as Republican candidate for delegate at large to the Constitutional Convention were passed today by the Columbian Republican League's State convention.

Nanking today concentrated its energies on effacing and alleviating the effects of yesterday's terrific Japanese air bombardments. The labor corps worked at a forced pace removing the debris, clearing streets, repairing telephone lines and broken water mains. Special efforts were made to restore the central power station to normal service.

BAUMES--Senator Caleb H., of Newburgh, Sept. 25, passed away on train returning from Sovereign Grand Lodge, l. O. O. F., convention, held at Milwaukee, Wis. Funeral service will be held at Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church at Newburgh, Tuesday, Sept. 28, at 2:30 P. M., Eastern standard time. Interment Cedar Hill Cemetery, Newburgh, N. Y.

Catholic University's eleven sent Canisius College down to 14-6 defeat before 6,500 spectators today, scoring on an aerial bombardment in the first quarter and capitalizing on a blocked kick in the fourth.

Led by the British internationalist, Gerald Balding, and Robert Eisner, Princeton captain, Cowdray Park downed the Shrewsbury Polo Club, 6 to 4, today. A crowd of 2,000 watched the final game of the season for Shrewsbury.

The Nazi swastika imprinted upon the American flag on posters announcing the annual reunion of German societies in New York on "German Day," Oct. 3, will bring indictments unless the placards are withdrawn, Samuel Untermyer dedared here today at the annual convention of the Jewish War Veterans.

Charles V. Drew, mining engineer, vice president and a director of the Cerro de Pasco Copper Corporation, with which he had been associated since 1904, died Friday morning in the New England Deaconess Hospital, Boston, following an operation performed on Thursday. He would have been 65 years old on Oct. 1.
A fourteen-acre estate with a large house and several outbuildIngs on Newfield Road, in Stamford, Conn., has been purchased by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Fried of 1,200 Fifth Avenue, New York.

Though Broadway is as hospitable a street as the next one, its theatre box offices were smiling as the Legionnaires left town. True to the maxim that certain kinds of conventions actually reduce theatre patronage, business improved as the exodus started.
The index for wholesale prices in France stood at 614 on Sept. 18, against 605 on Sept. 11 and 580 on Sept. 4. The world gold price index was 22.

Conducting a special All Angel service that he wrote ten years ago, the Rev. Dr. William Norman Guthrie returned yesterday morning to the Episcopal Church of St. Mark's - in - the - Bouwerie, Tenth Street and Second Avenue. He said after the sermon that the vestry's search, announced last Spring, for a successor to him, was continuing. Dr. Guthrie will remain until a new rector is found.
The Brooklyn Eagles, defending titleholders, gained their first victory in three American Football Association starts today at City Stadium, downing the New Rochelle Bulldogs. 9--0.

After five hours of jockeying small boats through a boiling sea, police and Coast Guardsmen rescued ten men yesterday from the jetty at Rockaway Point, Queens. Two others, part of a group of eighteen that had gone on the jetty to fish, were swept into the water before the arrival of the rescuers,

Education and religion without the "plus sign" are not enough to meet the issues of the world today, Dr. Henry Hallam Tweedy of the Yale Divinity School said in addressing the Northfield Seminary students and faculty in chapel here today.

Asserting that it was of the utmost importance not only to reelect Mayor La Guardia but to give him a supporting majority in the new City Council, the Citizens NonPartisan Committee, of which Samuel Seabury is chairman, made public yesterday a list of thirty-three Council candidates, whom it recommended for election.

Whatever else may have happened in Hungary, the drama remains unaltered. As represented by "The Lady Has a Heart," which was put on at the Longacre Saturday evening, it is an abstract of the polite conventions. Ladislaus Bus-Fekete has written the current exhibition in quaintness.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Sarah Norwood Ross, daughter of Mrs. John Henley Ross of Termon Rock, this place, and the late Mr. Ross, to Herbert St. John Webb Jr., son of Mrs. Webb of Montclair and the late Mr. Webb.
The Negro National League AllStars and the champion baseball team of the Dominican Republic divided a double-header at the Yankee Stadium yesterday before 20,000 spectators.

For the first time in the history of the Health Department, out-of-State milk supplies are being supervised at their source. Since July 1 a corps of fourteen milk sanitarians, who will inspect about 18,000 farms and about 169 dairy plants, have been added to the Bureau of Milk Sanitation.

John Haynes Holmes reported on the Oxford conference on Christian life and work to his congregation at the Community Church in the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street. Mr. Holmes declared that the conference was one of the most important in modern religious history and that its declarations

Bowery, 139, 25x108.1; J. J. Cohen, as receiver, to Hoohberg Bros Schwartz Realty Corp, 328 Broome St; mtge. $25 200 ($13). Madison St, 68-70, runs to Oliver St (4648); Compco Realty Corp, Samuel R. Rosoff, press, to Comprehensive Omnibus Corp, 433 E 92d St. (50c).

Well sustained production over the many weeks in which buying has been at a relatively low rate has carried steelmakers sufficiently close to the end of backlogs to indicate a shortening of activity to match incoming business, the magazine Steel says this week.
St. Joseph's Hawks opened their 1937 gridiron campaign today at the Overbrook Stadium before a crowd of 6.000 by crushing the Panzer College eleven of East Orange, N. J., 40-0.

The Indians took advantage today of dark, cloudy weather and sent two fireball pitchers, Johnny Allen and Bob Feller, against the Tigers in a double-header. Allen won his fourteenth victory without a defeat in the opener, 9 to 3, and Feller fanned ten batters in a 4-to-3 triumph.

The Blind Brook Esquires conquered the Fort Hamilton four, 9-4, yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in an Eastern Polo League contest. The home team received three goals by handicap and gained its other point in the last two minutes of the final session.

Considering the relative magnitude of Holland's commercial interests in the Far East, reports reaching here to date indicate that the Sino-Japanese conflict has exerted an almost negligible influence in so far as home repercussions are concerned.

Broadway theatrical producers and stagehands, at odds over a new contract since the old one expired on Sept. 5, will sign a twoyear agreement this week rescinding the wage cut made in 1932, it was announced yesterday by James J. Brennan, president of Theatrical Protective Union No. 1.

The German wholesale price index on Sept. 15 stood at 106.3, unchanged from Sept. 8. In the first eight months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index, based on the average of 1913 as 100, ranged between 106.9 on Aug. 11 and 105.2 in the first week of Januarv.

Sir Hubert Wilkins, who returned to this country recently from the Arctic, where he searched for Sigmund Levanevsky, missing Russian flying ace, said tonight at Pawling that he believed the fliers were still alive.

A ransom demand from men who kidnapped Charles S. Ross, 72, a retired greeting card manufacturer, late last evening when he was in the company of a former stenographer, was anxiously awaited today by Mrs. Ross and investigators.
Rumania's exports of petroleum have decreased sharply. In the first eight months of this year the export total was only 3,895,000 tons, compared with 4,398,000 in the same period last vear.

An active campaign to publicize the suitability of floor coverings for Christmas gifts will be launched here by rug manufacturers, jobbers and cooperating retailers early in November and carried through until the close of the holiday shopping season.
Del Baker, acting Detroit manager who has been ill at the Hotel New Yorker for nearly two weeks, will leave New York tomorrow to join the Tigers in St. Louis, The Associated Press reports.

The Bees made a clean sweep of the two-game series when they reached five Philadelphia pitchers for twenty-three hits and won by 17 to S today. Getting five runs in the first inning off Wayne LaMaster

A sad fact about mechanical progress is the way in which inventions cancel each other. The elevator makes the skyscraper possible. The street car, the elevated lines, the subway and the motor car enable us to get in large numbers to and from where the skyscrapers are. Everything ought now to be lovely.
A team made up of members of the Argentine polo squad lost, 7 to 6, to a Long Island four, Louis Stoddard Jr., Pete Bostwick, Earle Hopping and Gerald Dempsey, at Bostwick Field today.
Murray G. Jenkins, a lawyer who had been practicing in New York since 1907, died suddenly here today of a heart attack at his home, 42 Maher Avenue. He was 53 years old.
Capitalizing two breaks, the Boston Shamrocks opened the defense of their American Football League crown with a 16-0 victory over the Rochester Tigers today before a crowd of 5,000.

Walter Scanlon's 60-yard center shot in the final period enabled the Bethpage Polo Club, defending champion, to beat West Hills, 8-7, today in the first game of the annual tournament for the Herbert Bayard Swope Trophy.
Harry Isaacs of Dorchester, Mass., last surviving Jewish Grand Army veteran, died last night at the age of 92.

Mrs. John F. Montgomery is expected this week at the Pierre, where she will be joined later by Mr. Montgomery, the United States Minister to Hungary. Mr. and Mrs. Montgomery, who returned from Budapest in June, spent the Summer at The Cascades, their home in Manchester, Vt.
Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,347,877,500.

County Judge Gerald Nolan of Yonkers, because of his nomination for Supreme Court Justice by the Republicans of the five counties in the Ninth Judicial District, is expected to resign" as County Judge late this week.

The Garden Club of Teaneck won the sweepstakes prize for clubs in the sixteenth annual flower show of the Federation of Garden Clubs of Bergen County, held today in the Hackensack Woman's Club. More than 2,000 persons attended the show, which established a record for size. Thirty-three clubs participated. There were 750 entries.

The Blind Brook Knights topped the First Division team of Brooklyn, 8--7, in a thrilling Eastern Polo League contest today at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club. Jack Fink's goal in the closings minute of play decided the honors.

Miss Helen Hinsdale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Heath Hinsdale of this place, will become the bride of John Paul Faude, son of Mrs. Paul Faude of West Hartford, formerly of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Rev. Paul Faude, on the afternoon of Oct. 16 in St. John's Church.

Behind the superb twirling of Jimmy Dempsey, who struck out ten, yielded six hits and gave three walks, the New York Athletic Club nine ended its season yesterday by conquering the Long Island City Baseball Club, 5-1, at Travers Island.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry F. Sweet gave a tea at their home here today at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Ross Sweet, to Robert Stryker Everett, son of Mrs. Clifford B. Everett of Elizabeth, N. J., and the late Mr. Everett.
After two postponements, they are going to try to raise the Ritz Theatre's curtain tonight on "On Location," first scheduled for last Monday and then for last Friday.

The Labor movement in America, to attain its- objectives, "must organize and exert itself not only in the economic field but also in the political arena," John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, writes in the current issue of Princeton University's Public Opinion Quarterly, published here today.

The comparative inactivity of trading on the Stock Exchanges in August was illustrated in a summary published today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, showing that the dollar value of sales last month amounted to $1,277,536,486, a decrease of 9.8 per cent from the value of sales in July and 22.9 per cent from August, 1936.

There is no record of London stock selling in New York, as British rules prohibit brokers from revealing business deals. In any case, the broker must sell to the jobber, so that he either retains the stock for resale or sells through an arbitrage house.
It took the right-handed Johnny Wilson from Portland, Ore., a long time, but he finally beat the Yankees for the first time today in his fifteenth victory of the year.
Finishing strongly, the Rumson Country Club four halted the Governors Island team, 7-4, yesterday at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island.

Glenn Cunningham ran a 4:19.7 mile on a five-lap track yesterday as he romped off with the featured event on the second annual track and field program sponsored by the Claremen's P. B. and S. Association at the Castle Hill Athletic Field in the Bronx.

Old Westbury, new open champion qualified for the final of the Water bury Cup polo tournament today by defeating Aknusti, 18 to 10, on International Field. On Wednesday Old Westbury and Greentree will bring the high-goal season to an end in the final of the Waterbury, starting at 3 o'clock.

For decades many business men have regarded the stock market as a significant business barometer. The market's reputation in this respect was enhanced in the minds of some persons by the episode of 1929.
The Rev. Felix J. O'Neil, poet-priest and pastor of St. Edward's Church here, died last night at the church rectory at the age of 77 after a two months' illness.

Mr. and Mrs. Orville Browning Carrott of Belle Haven, Greenwich, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Carrott, to William Hall Boardman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Boardman of Quarry Top, Riverdale, N. Y.

Christians today possess few of the worth-while things within their reach, because their lives are hampered by negligence and disobedience to God's commands, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared yesterday.

The United States Lines have signed a contract with the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company for the installation and operation of radiotelephone service on the transatlantic liners Manhattan and Washington, it was announced yesterday.

Several hundred Staten Island friends of Patrolman John H. A. Wilson, shot down Thursday as he sought to frustrate a hold-up in Fulton Street, Manhattan, passed by his bier yesterday in the home of his sister, Mrs. Charles Shay, at 33 Prospect Place, New Dorp, S. I., while fellow police continued an unsuccessful search for his killer.

Two detectives of the pickpocket squad and two civilians were arrested on charges of assault and robbery at 4 o'clock yesterday morning, accused of taking $100 in cash from Christos Christofis, owner of the Seamen's Restaurant at 564 Ninth Avenue.

A report by the Department of Parks on its revenue-producing facilities, which include 368 tennis courts, ten golf courses, twelve swimming pools, two beaches and Randalls Island Stadium, indicates a steady and consistent gain in public use and financial returns.

Internal revenue collections in the fiscal year ended June 30, 1937, were $4,653,195,315.28, as compared with $3,520,208,381.09 in 1936, an increase of $1,132,986,934.19, or 32.2 per cent, according to a report by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, issued today.

The tendency on the Stock Exchange was somewhat irregular this week under the influence of numerous factors. From the external point of view, the Bourse was favorably impressed by the slight improvement in international affairs following better prospects in the Mediterranean sphere, but weakness in foreign markets was a bear point.

Admiral Vladimiro Pini, Vice Admiral Count Giuseppe Raineri-Biscia and Admiral Bixier, four naval commanders and one air major arrived here from Italy today to take part in the technical conference with French and British colleagues on the question of Italy's participation in the Mediterranean patrol. The conference begins tomorrow.

The picked eleven representing the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association defeated the champion team of the Brooklyn Cricket Club by one wicket and 70 runs in the final match of the season at Livingston, S. I., yesterday.

Miss Barbara Scripture, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert N. Scripture of this city, will be married to Philip Judd, son of Mrs. Florence Gates Judd of New Britain and Harold Lee Judd of Berlin, Conn., on Oct. 16 in the First Baptist Church here.
Behind and beneath the sound and the fury of the sensational events that occurred inside the U.S.S.R. in the last year there are certain facts and "facts are stubborn things," as Lenin said.

Herbert Mendelson's glossy white Notre Dame added the President's Cup to a trophy collection that this year includes the Gold Cup, won on Labor Day at Detroit, by beating off American and European speedboat opposition this dark, murky afternoon on the Potomac.

A monument to Muncie's Ball brothers, gift of grateful townspeople, was dedicated today in this factory city--so typical of the Midwest that sociologists labeled it "Middletown" and wrote hooks about it.

An S O S was flashed at 12:25 o'clock this morning from the 5,112ton British freighter Lackenby, reporting that she was aground on the south end of "Bell Island," and in need of "immediate assistance."
The National Bituminous Coal Commission will open hearings in Washington tomorrow in preparation for the setting of minimum prices for bituminous coal as required under the Guffey-Vinson Act.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy officiated at the dedication of the Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church, Kessel Street and Herrick Avenue, Forest Hills, yesterday morning at 11 o'clock. The church was completed recently at a cost of about $170,000 and is considered one of the most beautiful churches in Queens.

H. Boker Co., renewal on greater portion of space in 101-3 Duane St., and 10-12 Thomas St.; Charles F. Noyes Co., brokers. John Annunziata, mfr. of dresses, in 463 7th Ave., and additional space in same building through Martin Urband Co., to Max Isaac and Irving Spielberger, mfrs. of dresses; Harry Rothman, textiles, in 270 W. 39th St.;
Two Closter children are dead and three others are ill, one of them seriously, as a result of ulcerated colitis, believed to have been caused by food poisoning.
Philip Axt of Forest Hill Field Club and George Nye of Glen Ridge today won the second annual Glen Ridge Country Club invitation bestball golf tournament with a score of 69, 71--140.
Ellsworth Milton Statler, heir to a hotel fortune, and Barbara Marguerite Miller, a dentist's assistant, applied for a marriage license today. He is 25 years old and she is 21.

Miss Edith Grace Smyth, daughter of Judge and Mrs. George W. Smyth of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Carl Joseph Weisenbach of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. A. Weisenbach of Wayne, Pa., on Oct. 16 in St. John's Episcopal Church, Yonkers.

Solid Left-Wing support for Mayor La Guardia was assured as the Communist party joined the Socialists in withdrawing from the Mayoralty race to free its members to vote under the American Labor party emblem.

A Chesapeake Ohio passenger train killed seven persons tonight in a collision with a truck at a crossing in Hansford, near here. A mother, father and four children were among the victims. A fifth child of the family, 2 years old, is in a Montgomery hospital with a broken arm. Attaches said she would recover.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Mildred Ruth Jones, daughter of Lieut. Col. Nathaniel A. Jones, U. S. A., and Mrs. Jones of Mitchel Field, L. I to Lieutenant Audrin R. Walker, U. S. Air Reserve, stationed at Kelly Field, Texas, which will take place on Oct. 14 at the Officers Club at Mitchel Field.

The responsibility for an active church rests with the laymen and not with the preacher, the Rev. Dr. W. M. Howlett, educational secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, told the congregation of the North New York Congregational Church, East 143d Street near Willis Avenue, yesterday morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governor Poindexter of Hawaii in his radio broadcast last night from the Sacramento aeronautical convention expressed his belief that the Hawaiians form the spearhead of our defense of the West Coast; that the islands are the keystone of an arch extending from the Aleutians, up in Alaska, to Hawaii and on to the southward toward the fortifications at the Panama Canal.

Reports of trade from industrial centers of Britain continue encouraging. Orders placed by Russia in August amounted to [Pound]1,781,524, against [Pound]795,110 a year ago, making [Pound]13,673,386 in the eight months through August, compared with [Pound]6,848,159 in the corresponding period of 1936.

Miss Alice Bradford Beves, daughter of George Edward Beves of this city and London and of Mrs. George Edward Beves of Haverford, has completed plans for her marriage on Oct. 16 to Thomas Harlan Libby of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Libby of Wynnewood, which is to take place in Old Saint David's Church, Radnor.
Japanese reported tonight that their troops in Western Hopeh Province had broken through the inner Great Wall in a drive toward a Chinese troop concentration at Yenmen Pass, in Shansi Province.

With Italy's entry into the Nyon anti-piracy arrangement and her general relations with France and Britain turning on the problem of Italian combatants in Spain, the question has arisen here of whether the transport of more of these combatants to Spain may not be facilitated by the Nyon arrangement through a drafting fault in it.
Enrollment of students at the Institute of Musical Art will begin on Thursday and continue until Oct. 4. The school opens Thursday, Oct. 7. Advance registration,
All types of building construction increased in number and value in August over July, but there was a decline in estimated cost from August, 1936, the Department of Labor has announced.

A large collection of artifacts from North America's oldest known inhabited spot-the Lindenmeier site in Colorado-was obtained this Summer by Dr. Frank H. H. Roberts Jr., Smithsonian Institution archaeolabout the close of the last Ice Age.

The engagement of Miss Dorothy Helene Pagenstecher, daughter of Mr. ard Mrs. Albrecht Pagenstecher of this place, to Charles A. Frank Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank of 1,148 Fifth Avenue, New York, has been announced by her parents.

Frederick H. Stinchfield, president of the American Bar Association, said today that the Roosevelt Administration apparently was determined "to destroy the Supreme Court of the United States as we have heretofore known that court."
The Federal Trade Commission has announced the following hearings on complaints, all at 45 Broadway, New York:

Striking employes of the Heppenstall Steel Company ratified a businesss agreement" today ending a two-and-a-half month strike. C. W. Heppenstall Sr., president, said maintenance men and office workers would return to work Monday and others of the 900 workers involved would go back as rapidly as other departments could be reopened.

The chief driving forces behind liberal Christianity are "a longing for freedom and serving one another through love," said the Rev. Dr. Heye Faber of the faculty of the University of Leyden, Holland, in a sermon yesterday morning at the Unitarian Church of the Saviour, Pierrepont Street and Monroe Place, Brooklyn.

The six major local governments in Cook County, Ill., paid off, in cash, $30,085,500 of bonds in the first nine months of this year. The operations were through their sinking funds and tax collections.
The Scots Americans, champions of the American Soccer League, were defeated, 3 to 2, by Brookhattan in the opening game of the season before 5,000 at Starlight Park yesterday.

Members of the Department of Taxes and Assessments have formed a New York chapter of the National Association of Assessing Officers. The following deputy tax commissioners have been chosen as officers of the chapter: John F. St. George, president; Edward A. Goetting, vice president; Louis R. Saxon, executive secretary, and Charles P. Champi, financial secretary.

Soviet Russia's list of executions was swelled today when twenty-one more men were shot as disloyal "wreckers" in the agricultural industry. Twelve of them were accused of plotting rebellion at two tractor stations in the Caucasus Mountains.

(Figures in parentheses indicate par) Arrowbrook (70)--First round for club championship: Dave Hammer defeated Jack Goodman, 5 and 4; Herman Yorks defeated Nat Lurie, 4 and 3; Harry Parker defeated M. R. Thompson, 2 and 1; Ralph Stevenson defeated M. Bachenheimer, 5 and 4; Sam Shapiro defeated Thomas Mitchell, 2 and 1.

The body of Mother Ann Marita Maley, secretary-general of the Catholic teaching order of Loretto, who died of a stroke here Friday, will be sent to Loretto, Ky., home of the order, next Monday for burial. Her age was 53.
The Japanese Army began this morning bombardment of the Chinese forces near Shanghai, bombs from planes and exploding shells from warships drowning out the cathedral chimes during the early morning.

Four pedestrians were injured seriously when an automobile, allegedly struck in the rear by a Fifth Avenue bus, crashed into a safety island and overturned at Broadway and Sixty-eighth Street about 10 o'clock last night.
Greta Nissen will make her London stage debut in "People in Love," a comedy by Arthur Reid, Canadian author, opening at the Ambassadors' Tuesday.
Mr. and Mrs. Selig Fishman have announced the engagement of their twin daughters-Evelyn to Oscar Shanken, and Lillian to Dr. Jack Chasnoff of this city.
Plans for one-family brick houses have been announced in connection with the sale by the Pentaboro Realty Corporation of four parcels of vacant land in the East Elmhurst section of Queens.

The semi-annual report of the American. Smelting and Refining Company and subsidiaries issued today by Simon Guggenheim, president, for the first six months of this year, shows a net income of $9,624,997, compared with $7,807,528 in the first six months of 1936.

After a day of brilliant competition the chief award in the fifteenth annual show of the Westbury Kennel Association this afternoon was given to the Scottish terrier Cedar Pond Castaway, bred, owned and handled in the ring by John Goudie of Great Neck.

Premier Mussolini's visit to Germany, although the focus of political interest and officially represented as an asset in the Reich's diplomatic account, exerted little influence on Germany's financial markets.

Business girls are rapidly losing interest in reducing diets, although three out of four prefer marriage to a business career, according to a study made among about 2,600 "white-collar" workers selected in twenty-two cities by the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company.

Cotton prices continued their downward trend last week and at the close of the week they were at the lowest level since May,1933. At the law of the week they were not much above one-half of those which prevailed at the end of March this year.

Of horrors in the Sino-Japanese war there is no end. The latest to be disclosed is that neither the Japanese nor the Chinese make a practice of taking prisoners. Almost invariably each side, after a victory, announces that the defeated forces were annihilated.

Brother-and-sister combinations seem to have something on other pairings in the Piping Rock mixed foursomes tourney, for last year Frank Wattles and his sister, Miss Peggy, one-time New York State titleholder, carried off the honors and this year the trophy went to Hugo Rutherfurd and his sister, Miss Alice, members of the Baltusrol club in New Jersey.
The New York Americans, champions of the American Soccer League, opened their regular season yesterday by defeating the Hispanos, 4-0, at Commercial Field in Brooklyn.

Lieut. Col. J. Ralston Flemming, an attorney here for seventeen years, died yesterday at the age of 63. Colonel Flemming, a member of the United States Army Reserve Corps, was born in Charlotte, N. C.;

Robert Lathan, editor of The Asheville Citizen, died at his home in Albermarle Park here tonight after a brief illness. His age was 56. Mr. Lathan, who had served as editor of The Citizen since 1927, won the Pulitzer Prize for the best editorial in the United States in 1924.

Dr. Charles Hatch Ehrenfeld, for forty-two years an educator and chemist, died here last night of heart disease. His age was 73. Born in Shippensburg, Pa., March 12, 1864, he was the son of the late Professor C. L. and Helen M. Hatch Ehrenfeld.
One hundred changes in pistorates were announced at the close of the 101st annual conference of Li the New Jersey Methodist Episcopal Church here tonight.
The American Bank Note Company, New York, is to print 11,500 notes for 50 colones each against a municipal loan of 575,000 colones approved by the National Congress.

With the rush for apartments entering its final week before the traditional Fall moving day, agents reported over the week-end a continuance of the demand for suites in scattered sections of the city. Miss Faith Fahnestock leased a penthouse apartment of seven rooms in 975 Park Avenue through the Van Rensselaer Realty, Inc.

The American Institute of Architects announced yesterday that Miss Elizabeth Coit of 333 East Fifty-eighth Street had won an Edward Langley scholarship of the institute for research into methods of economical design and construction of single-family and apartment houses.

Despitewarnings from Rome to correspondents against too much sentimentalism, the German press is all taken up with dithyrambic accounts of the meeting between Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Premier Benito Mussolini, and glowing reviews of Premier Mussolini's career and achievements are being printed.
Virtually every front in Spain burst into activity today.

Determined to make a fight of it, come what may, those dear old Dodgers of Flatbush, making their last appearance of the year at the Polo Grounds, enthralled a gathering of 26,044 yesterday by giving the Giants as good as they received for about two hours.
The three most successful money seekers of the golfing season led the way into the semi-finals of the $12,000 Belmont open match play tournament today before a gallery of 8,000.

Lewis Yelland Andrews, District Commissioner of Galilee, whose life had been threatened frequently during the last two years because of the strictness of his rule, and his bodyguard, Peter R. McEwan, a British police constable, were shot and killed at Nazareth as they were leaving the Anglican Church today.

At least 100,000 visitors will be in New York next month to attend seventy-nine scheduled conventions and shows, John R. Young, manager of the convention bureau of the Merchants Association of New York, declares in a statement released for publication today.

It would be interesting to know the thoughts that scurry through the active, sometimes antic, mind of Benito Mussolini as he wakes up in the state chamber of-the pleasant old presidential palace in the Wilhelmstrasse.
Representative McReynolds of Tennessee said in an interview here today that he thinks the WagnerVan Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill will be enacted at the next session of Congress.

With its dependable regularity, the upset made itself felt on the first major day of football as hundreds of teams started the long procession of a new season from coast to coast on Saturday. Among those elevens nearest this part of the country form held fairly well, with here and there some unexpected resistance on the part of those labelled the victim before the start.
The body of Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, who died of pneumonia early today in the American Hospital here, was taken to a crematory chapel today.

Mrs. Richard Percy Limburg will direct the activities of the women's division in the joint campaign for $6,250,000 of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities, it was announced yesterday.

Farm buying power this year will be within 1 per cent of the figure for 1929 and 3 per cent above the average for the few years immediately preceding the depression, according to a study of the subject published by the Guaranty Trust Company in its monthly publication, The Guaranty Survey, out to day.

The White Sox took both ends of a double-header from St. Louis today, 4 to 3 and 4 to 1, to give them a two-to-one edge in the series which marked the Browns' final appearance of the season in Chicago.
