Kerry and Cavan drew at 11-11 in the final game of the all-Ireland Gaelic football championship today although 55,000 spectators left thinking Cavan had won.

The Chicago Cubs, battling to overhaul the fleeting New York Giants, broke even in a double-header with the Cardinals today. The Redbirds won the first game, 6 to 5, and the Bruins came back to capture the final, shortened to eight innings, 8 to 5.

Former Representative John W. Summers died at his home here last night at the age of 67. He had been ill several months. Mr. Summers had two distinctions. He was at one time the physician with the longest term of service in Congress and he was author of a bill prohibiting payment of salaries to District of Columbia teachers who taught "disrespect for the Holy Bible."
Five hundred and forty-one CCC workers arrived here early this morning on three special trains from camps in California and the Northwest. Five hundred and twenty of them will be discharged tomorrow.
Pope Pius received Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, today for an hour-long conversation prior to the latter's departure this evening on what has been termed a vacation trip.
A double bill composed of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" was presented by the Hippodrome Opera Company last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music before 2,100 persons.

There is a new tavern in Salisbury Court, near Fleet Street. London has too much geography; but if memory holds her seat, Salisbury Court must be in that Alsatia of the disreputable and the lawless described in "The Fortunes of Nigel."

Prices of lard declined sharply here last week due principally to scattered liquidation induced by the weakness in cottonseed oil, the stock market and consumer resistance to paying what was regarded as an unwarrantedly high level in comparison with lard substitutes.
Mrs. J. Lester Parsons of Llewellyn Park, mother of Mrs. George Vanderbilt of Sands Point, L. I., died today in the Parsons Summer home at Eastern Point, Conn., after an eighteen months' illness.

Mr. and Mrs. John I. Robinson of Springfield, Mass., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Sophie Beatrice Robinson, to Norman S. Altman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Altman of this city, which took place Saturday evening in Washington, D. C. The couple will make their home in Washington.

The redoubtable Cornelius Shields, who spent a good part of the Summer in the afterguard of the America's Cup contender Yankee, found time, nevertheless, to sweep the season's honors in the hard-bitten International Class of boats.

Steamship interests in New York and Philadelphia are receptive to the idea of a passenger line to Atlantic City, it was revealed here tonight, and accordingly, the Atlantic City Chamber of Commerce will campaign for establishment of such a' line next Spring.
President Mustafa Kemal Ataturk today appointed M. C. Bayar, Minister of National Economy, Premier of Turkey and entrusted him with the formation of a new Ministry.

Russia, whose intervention in the Chinese warfare is feared in Tokyo, has taken a strong position on bombings. She announced last night she had delivered a note to Japan saying she would hold that country responsible if the embassy

Sir George Holden, prominent Lancashire cotton spinning industrialist, died today at the age of 47. Sir George was managing director of the combined Egyptian Mills, Ltd. He succeeded his father to the baronetcy in 1926.

With the passing of the September delivery of corn due to the suspension of trading in that future by directors of the Board of Trade in their fixing of a settlement price at $1.10 1/2 a bushel because of evidence of an attempted corner, the new crop situation has come to the fore as a major influence in the market.
Bass, Ratc??ff Gretton, Ltd., English brewers, have appointed W. A. Taylor ' Co., 15 Laight Street, New York, sole distributors in this country of Bass ale, effective Oct. 1.

The cotton market here was more active last week than it had been in some time, but prices continued to decline, making new lows for the season, with the near months virtually at the 8 1/2-cent level.

Two spectators were killed and ten others injured today during Czechoslovakia's automobile Grand Prix, when the German entry, Hermann Lang, lost control of his racer and crashed into the crowd. Lang emerged from the accident unhurt.

A million persons thronged Unter den Linden today inspecting the unprecedently costly decorations prepared there for Premier Mussolini's entry into the capital tomorrow. Munich had set a record of adornment in the Premier's honor, but Berlin has far surpassed Munich.

An invitation to Samuel Untermyer and Representative Samuel Dickstein to "come up here and see our camp and talk to us," was extended today by Fritz Kuhn, National Bundesfuehrer of the GermanAmerican Volksbund, at a festival closing the 1937 activities at Camp Nordland, the camp of the New Jersey Bund here.

The future of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, a national organization representing the leading exchanges of the country, is likely to be determined at a meeting today of representative members at its headquarters, 42 Broadway.
A well-dressed middle-aged woman was found dead today, lying in the rear of her automobile in a garage, with $1,690 in bills serving as a pillow.

Although findings in the inquiry covering production are not yet known, it is generally felt that the forty-hour labor week may be modified somewhat, especially along the line of enabling certain industries, and especially the railways, to extend working hours slightly, while maintaining the principle of the law.

Aerial bombardment of civilian populations may be a tactical blunder, in the opinion of American military experts. The Infantry Journal, edited by Lieut. Col. E. F. Harding of the United States Infantry Association, says in a current article,

THEY have to shave once in a while and comb their hair now. The Yale football players are back in New Haven. They hated to leave Gales Ferry. What weather! What comfort! And what food! This tourist dropped in just as the squad was getting ready to pack up and get out. Clint Frank was encountered on the lawn.

An invitation to Samuel Untermyer and Representative Samuel Dickstein to "come up here and see our camp and talk to us," was extended today by Fritz Kuhn, National Bundesfuehrer of the GermanAmerican Volksbund, at a festival closing the 1937 activities at Camp Nordland, the camp of the New Jersey Bund here.

The future of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, a national organization representing the leading exchanges of the country, is likely to be determined at a meeting today of representative members at its headquarters, 42 Broadway.
A well-dressed middle-aged woman was found dead today, lying in the rear of her automobile in a garage, with $1,690 in bills serving as a pillow.

Although findings in the inquiry covering production are not yet known, it is generally felt that the forty-hour labor week may be modified somewhat, especially along the line of enabling certain industries, and especially the railways, to extend working hours slightly, while maintaining the principle of the law.

A new Fascist party, the Netherlands Nationalist Movement, has been formed by a number of former members of the National Socialist movement. Anton Adrian Mussert, Nazi leader, lost ten prominent members last week after a disclosure of the leader's espionage methods.
The outlook for the stock market is regarded as uncertain, although, in view of the recent international "shake-outs," the technical position is believed to be improved.

Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, announced tonight that Judge John J. Burns of New York and Boston, who has been serving as special counsel to the commission, has resigned to return to his private law practice.

The best of G. K Chesterton's essays, poetry, detective stories and miscellaneous writings are to be included in an omnibus volume, edited by R. T. Bond, and scheduled for publication by Dodd, Mead late in October under the title "The Man Who Was Chesterton."

For the third year in succession, the New Jersey Women's Golf Association team of fifteen picked players defeated a similar team representing the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association by 9 1/2 to 5 1/2 at Wykagyl today.

To some readers of the recent daily grain quotations, the action of the corn market may have seemed incomprehensible. Last Friday, corn for delivery in September closed on the Chicago Board of Trade at $1.10 per bushel; its price had gone as high as $1.16 3/4.

Steel operations in the United States this week are estimated at 74.4 per cent of ingot capacity by the American Iron and Steel Institute, representing a decrease of .1.7 points, or 2.2 per cent, from last week. A month ago the

The possibility that the yearly appropriation from the Rockefeller Foundation to Nanking government institutions may be withdrawn was envisaged here today as Dr. J. B. Grant, foundation representative, is expected to arrive from Shanghai Monday.

E. C. Mauchley, an official of the F. W. Woolworth Company, has purchased the T. C. Taylor residence on two acres of land on the south side of Wilmot Road in the north end of New Rochelle, Westchester County. Mr. Mauchley and his family will occupy the property immediately. The house is of the

The second annual military ball in aid of the Catholic Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity at the United States Military Academy, West Point, will be given under the auspices of the Holy Trinity Guild on the night of Nov. 13 in the grand ballroom of the Astor.
Miss Virginia Anna Stevens, daughter of Mrs. Frank Harvey Stevens of Maplewood, will be married on Oct. 13 to William Robert Bishop, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elbert Emery Bishop of Bloomfield.

A report that $2,000 had been stolen from a safe aboard the destroyer J. Fred Talbott in the navy yard in Brooklyn had navy yard officials, the navy publicity office, the department in Washington and several non-combatants considerably agitated yesterday before it was finally decided the amount of the theft had been somewhat exaggrated.

The National Committee to Uphold Constitutional Government announced today receipt of $213,000 in contributions for its campaign. The money, said Frank E. Gannett, committee chairman, came from 12,490 persons.
The Federal grand jury investigating the labor situation in Harlan County today returned indictments against about forty individuals and twenty-two coal companies, all of Harlan County.

The action of the Federal Reserve Board in making the negotiable paper of finance companies eligible for rediscount at Reserve banks was hailed yesterday as "a gratifying recognition that installment credit occupies a sound and necessary place in the nation's credit structure" by Edwin C. Vogel, chairman of the executive committee of Commercial Investment Trust Corporation.

Augustus K. Thomas, connected with the appraiser's stores of the Port of New York more than fortytwo years, died yesterday at his home here after an illness of several months. He was in his sixty-fifth year.

Establishment of a World's Fair district with boundaries about 1,000 feet outside the present boundaries of the World's Fair site, in Flushing Meadows Park, Queens, was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate, with provisions for regulating advertisements, amusements, parking and other activities within the district.

The first concert in a series of six will be presented by Macklin Marrow and the New Court Symphony, an orchestra of thirty-five players, at the Concourse Plaza Hotel in the Bronx tonight. The concerts are sponsored by the Bronx TheatreMusic League, Margaret V. Wall, managing director.

Miss Alice McComb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Wadsworth McComb of this city, has chosen Nov. 12 as the date for her wedding to Stanley Anderson Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Curry Harris of New York. The ceremony, which will be performed at the McComb home, will be followed by a reception.

Oscar Igstaedter, an expert on customs law who had been associated with the New York law firm of Olvany, Eisner Donnelly since 1929, died in his sleep at his home here early this morning of heart disease. An intermittent sufferer from a cardiac ailment for the last three years, he had been well recently until yesterday. He was 60 years old.
Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's first ranking officer, General Chu Shao-liang, relieved General Chang Chih-tsung of the command of the Chinese forces in Shanghai today.

Following the lead of the House of Representatives which recessed last Saturday, the Senate tonight suspended regular sessions until Nov. 1. It is planned to hold special sessions, however, with five days' advance notice in an attempt to push through the amnesty bill and several laws backed by Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff, in his three-year plan.

Business and residential properties in several localities of Manhattan Island, including the Midtown, Chelsea, Stuyvesant Square, Harlem and upper East Side areas, attracted the attention of investment buyers yesterday. The old five-story brownstone dwelling at 61 West Forty-sixth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues and adjoining the Hotel Wentworth, was sold by William H. Brown through Samuel Hurwitz, broker. The house,

Hearings before a legislative committee on insurance law revision began yesterday morning in the State Office Building, 80 Center Street, with most of the day's proceedings devoted to a discussion of whether a broader base of underwriting should be included in the proposed new insurance code.

A minor decline was registered in automobile production last week when a sharp drop was seasonal, and the adjusted index has spurted to 133.6 from 108.7. It was 88.6 for the week ended Sept. 26, 1936.

Insurgent Generalissimo Francisco Franco's headquarters announced tonight the capture of Ribadesella, important Biscayan coast town thirty miles east of Gijon. The Insurgents reported advancing up the east bank of the Sella River, where they have been encountering strong resistance, and taking the town.

Mrs. Jessie Smith Koewing, who once had the distinction of being Hunter College's youngest graduate, died today at her home here after a month's illness. Her age was 76. She was the widow of Frank Koewing, founder of the Standard Fashion Company.
Mr. and Mrs. James M. Scott of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Clarice M. Scott, to Edward M. Sheppard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Sheppard.

The domestic price of copper was lowered yesterday 1 cent a pound to 13 cents. The move was initiated by the custom smelters and later was followed by the leading producers. The change in quotation is the first since April 29, when the level was established at 14 cents, following a decline from a high of 17 cents on March 30.

Mrs. Anna Wentworth Caldwell Sears, wife of Joseph Hamblen Sears, formerly an editor for the publishing firm of Harper Brothers and later, 1904-18, president of D. Appleton Co., died here today in the family's country home, the Other House, on Cove Neck Road.

United National Corporation-Year to June 30: Consolidated net earnings after provisions for taxes and elimination of earnings applicable to minority interests in subsidiaries, $332,583, equivalent to $1.45 a share on the outstanding participating preference stock, against $370,535, or $1.61 a share for the preceding year.

The odds against Dan Bulger, Sir Abe Bailey's favorite for the Cambridgeshire on Oct. 13, were shortened to 100 to 12 when the cards were called over at the Victoria Club today. At the previous callover the 4-year-old, winner last year, had been backed at 9 to 1.

Secretary Hull issued a statement today deploring the death of Grenville T. Emmet, United States Minister to Austria. "I have learned with deep distress of the sudden death of Mr. Grenville T. Emmet," he said.

The Treasury sold today an offering of $50,000,000 of Treasury discount bills with a maturity of 273 days, at the rate of 0.384 per cent on a bank discount basis, the lowest rate since an issue of similar size and maturity was sold on Feb. 17 at a rate of 0.373 per cent.

Irving C. Fox, counsel of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared here today that retail merchants should no longer "hush" the labor situation, which he characterized as "the greatest problem confronting the retailer."
Motorists who do not get their new driving licenses before Thursday night cannot legally drive cars on Friday or thereafter, Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, said today.

R. S. Richards of Kay Richards Co., Pittsburgh, was elected yesterday president of the Associated Stock Exchanges. J. Gates Williams of Francis, Brother Co., St. Louis, was elected vice president, and Marshall A. Barbour of J. B. Barbour Co., Pittsburgh, was named vice president.

Russia and Japan were reported today concenrating large bodies of troops along the already heavily guarded frontier of Siberia and Manchukuo. Reliable sources declared the sitnation between Russia and Japan was more serious than it had been at any time since 1931, when the Japanese Army started creating the Manchukuoan Empire out of Chinese Manchuria.

Bitter criticism of President Roosevelt's view of the Constitution, coupled with an effort to bring about a lawyers' inquiry into the manner in which Justice Black was recently appointed to the Supreme Court despite reported Ku Klux Klan affiliations, marked the opening today of the annual convention of the American Bar Association.

Some of us who are not very mathematical get lost when efforts are made to make us understand how the votes are counted under a system of proportional representation. It is not so hard, however, to grasp the idea that this ingenious device gives minority groups a chance to be heard, even though it does not, and of course should not, give them a chance to override the majority.

The marriage of Miss Helen Hotchkiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Carlton Hotchkiss of Old Greenwhich, to Daniel Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Miller of Stamford, will take place on Oct. 9, at the home of the bride-elect's parents.
Neither the Japanese Army nor the Japanese naval landing force in the Shanghai area claimed any advances or admitted any retreats in the twenty-four hours ending at 5 P. M. yesterday. However, more

Miss Virginia Hoyt of New York, sister of Mrs. A. Felix du Pont Jr. of Wilmington, Del., and Marion, today became the bride of Charles Lawrence Peirson of Boston at the du Pont Summer home The Anchorage.

Death Announced Fireman First Grade Peter J. Harmon. Engine 61, died Sept. 24 in the discharge of duty from injuries when responding to apparatus quarters. Funeral will take place from 351 E. 180th St.. Bronx, at 9:30 A. M. Tuesday, Sept. 28. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

Meeting at their first Fall session at the Springfield Gardens Presbyterian Church, 137th Avenue and Springfield Boulevard, Queens, members of the Brooklyn-Nassau Presbytery, by a unanimous vote, condemned gambling as a means of raising church finances.

Lieutenant Hardwick, Navy football coach, broke another precedent today when he allowed his regulars to scrimmage on the Monday after a game. The session was the first after the opening of the academic year.

For the first time since rayon entered the shops of the country, the Federal Government has defined this product and, in cooperation with the rayon trade, has prescribed rules of fair trade practice which should go far to end the confusion resulting from the multiplicity of names by which rayon is described.

The Spanish revolution was denounced today as a move in the Communist campaign for world supremacy, the Loyalist Administration was characterized as a "phantom government" created and controlled by Soviet Russia,
The engagement of Prince Paul of Greece, heir presumptive to the Greek throne, to Princess Frederika Luise, 20-year-old daughter of the Duke of Brunswick, was officially announced tonight.

The government, in its warfare against locusts, which destroyed the greater part of the country's cotton, corn and bean crop, today began paying a bonus of 30 cents for a five-gallon tin filled with the insects. The tins must be brought into government buying stations.

THE best news of the day was that Endeavour was sighted off the Irish Coast. There was a real sporting venture, bringing that slim yacht to home waters through the great September gales that sweep the North Atlantic. The towline parted

Twenty-two alleged members of an international band trafficking in faked passports have been arrested here. The gang manufactured to order passports of all countries, including the United States, and also supplied counterfeit visas and entry permits.

With varying points of view expressed as to the future course of business, the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System reported today that in August industrial activity advanced from the level of the two preceding months and, on a seasonally adjusted basis, was close to the volume of last Spring.
The legislative committees to attend the funeral of former Senator Caleb H. Baumes at Newburgh tomorrow afternoon were announced today by Senator John J. Dunnigan and Speaker Oswald D. Heck.

ALTMAN--George J., beloved husband of Jane, devoted father of Jerome, Jack and Beatrice Simon; dear brother of David. Services Wednesday, Sept. 29, at 2 P. M., at his late residence, 189 Penn St., Brooklyn. ALTMAN--George J. Pilgrim Lodge, No. 890, F. and A. M., sorrowfully announces the passing of Brother George J. Altman.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine came back to his office yesterday from the funeral of a patrolman who had died fighting hold-up men to be faced with a report of an assault and robbery in which two of his detectives are accaused. The effect on him was visible.

Automobile accidents, deaths and injuries increased in the city last week, as compared to a year ago, it was announced yesterday by Harold Fowler, First Deputy Police Commissioner. He attributed the increase to the convention of the American Legion.

Members of the MacGregor Arctic Expedition spoke their own messages of greeting to friends and relatives here yesterday in a shortwave broadcast from their Winter camp at Reindeer Point, near Etah, in the northernmost part of Greenland. The message was heard over networks of the National Broadcasting Company throughout the United States.

A demand that union labor be employed on all equipment contracts let in connection with WPA projects developed yesterday out of the strike called by eight American Federation of Labor unions against twenty-five private contractors doing work for the Federal relief agency.

The marriage of Miss Katharine Emory Burnet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Heyward Burnet of Waco, Ga., and Charleston, S. C., to Dr. Frederick A. Steele of Summit, N. J., took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

Responding to the usual seasonal influence, the number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States showed an increase in the week ended Sept. 23, the total being 159, compared with 139 a week earlier and 134 a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The Indians said their good-bye to Cleveland today with a 2-1 loss to the Tigers. Elden Auker, submarine righthander, torpedoed the Indians when trouble threatened and won his sixteenth game, against nine defeats, even though Cleveland outbatted his teammates, seven hits to four.

Supporters of Dr. Lovelace B. Capehart on the newly elected Democratic county committee in the Nineteenth Assembly District met last night at the Citizens Democratic Club, 139 West 125th Street, and declared Dr. Capehart elected as Democratic leader of the district. Dr. Capehart was the

While the attention of the world has been centered on Japanese bombing raids upon Chinese cities, another phase of Japan's war against the Chinese has been overlooked. For the past few weeks Japanese warships have been systematically destroying Chinese trading and fishing junks and often displaying callous disregard of human life.

In the thirty-six weeks ended on Sept. 5 the North American Rayon Corporation earned $2,509,318 after providing for depreciation and all taxes, except Federal surtax on undistributed profits, according to the report issued for today. After allowing for dividend requirements on the prior preferred stock, net earnings were equal to $4.65 each on the 512,374 outstanding shares of combined Class A and B stock.

At the request of President Roosevelt, the Treasury is scanning estimates of expenditures in an economy drive, Secretary Morgenthau said today. "In line with talks I had with the President before he left Hyde Park," Mr. Morgenthau stated, "we are looking in every direction to see where we can save any money for this fiscal year."

Trading was only fair to slow on most classes of fresh meats yesterday. Lamb, veal and calf sold lower, fresh pork cuts uneven, beef mostly unchanged. Yesterday and today being Jewish holidays, there will be no kosher markets until Wednesday. Price quotations on kosher meats are largely nominal, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

General Evangeline Booth, head of the Salvation Army; Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State, and Mrs. Stimson; Mrs. Roswell Miller, daughter of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, are among the passengers arriving today on the Berengaria of the Cunard White Star Line.

Tom O'Connor of Bloomfield and Alec Ternyei of Elmwood recorded a brilliant six-under-par 66 to capture the honors in the oneday pro-pro tournament of the New Jersey P. G. A. today at the Preakness Hills Country Club.

Twenty thousand sealskins and 510 fox pelts brought a total of $450,000 today at the Federal Government's semi-annual auction here. The seal skins, the Government's share in the Pribilof Islands hunt, brought an average price of $22, a decrease of $7 compared with the April price.

International peace can be best maintained "by the exchange of intellectual ideas between nations," former President Herbert C. Hoover said yesterday in welcoming Belgian exchange students here on a grant of the Commission for Relief in Belgium Educational Foundation, Inc.

An article by Pearl S. Buck that appears in the October issue of the magazine Asia and about which THE NEW YORK TIMES made editorial comment yesterday caused the Chinese Consulate General at New York to issue a statement last night which said:

Moscow is decidedly more satisfied with the international situation than a month ago. Although it is understood that Foreign Commissar Maxim M. Litvinoff did not attain all his objectives at Geneva and suffered a minor check when Spain was not re-elected to the League Council it is felt he has done much to restore Soviet prestige and has succeeded in clearing the international atmosphere by his frank and vigorous speeches.

New York Curb Exchange has ruled that certificates and certificates of deposit for Standard Gas and Electric Company twenty-year 6 per cent gold notes and 6 per cent convertible gold notes shall be quoted "flat" on Oct. 1, when 3 per cent interest payments will be made on each.

Plans for the census of unemployed and partially employed persons in the United States got definitely under way today when representatives of industry, labor, agriculture and the government gave their full approval to the program submitted to them by John D. Biggers, the Administrator of the Census. Mr.

Paul Pirrone, Cleveland middleweight with a powerful punch, will tackle Herbie Katz of Brownsville in the star bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, tonight. Katz is a good drawing card
Fifty late-staying members of the Summer colony gathered at the Newport Beach skating rink tonight for the second in the series of roller-skating parties arranged by Mrs. Dan W. Jones.

Edward Blodgett Fitts, Professor of Dairy Husbandry at Pennsylvania State College, died of a heart attack today in his sixty-seventh year. He had served on the faculty here for fifteen years. Born at East Windsor, Conn., he was graduated from Connecticut Agricultural College in 1893 with the degree of Bachelor of Scienoe.

Two fine old Fifth Avenue mansions will be demolished immediately to provide a site for a seventeen-story apartment house to be erected by the Campagna interests. They are the residence of the late Dr. Ernest Fahnestock at 954 Fifth Avenue and the adjoining private home of the late J. Horace Harding at 955, between Seventy-sixth and Seventy-seventh Streets.
The redcloaked official at Lloyd's of London again gave resounding taps on the Lutine bell at 1:35 this afternoon to report the finding of Endeavour I, and this time there was no mistake.

Two years of painstaking work have brought to completion the large stained-glass window depicting events in the life of George Washington, designed and executed under the direction of the WPA Federal Art Project for placement in Washington Hall at the United States Military Academy at West Point.

The State Department announced today that George Fort Milton, Chattanooga, Tenn., newspaper editor, has been appointed a special assistant in the trade agreements division to advise Secretary Hull on reciprocal trade policies.
A total of 3,694 students had enrolled in the four classes of Harvard College at the close of registration today. This is two less than the total a year ago.

Pensioned On his own application: PATROLMAN-Leo A. Walsh, 75th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 25, 1912. Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANT-Emil C. Blumler, from 7th Division to 42d Precinct, assignment to desk duty continued.

The five-and-one-half-story apartment house at 1,375 Grand Concourse, at the southwest corner of Elliot Place, the Bronx, on a plot 100 by 126 feet, has been sold by Heiman Seisner to a client of J. Murray Gillman, attorney. Rubin Nason were the brokers in the deal and the seller was represented by Abraham Sidney Lichter as attorneys.

Mrs. Nina Bevan Jenney, wife of William Sherman Jenney, vice president and general counsel of the Lackawanna Railroad, died today at Little Close, the family's Summer home here, after having been in failing health for several months. Her New York home was

Miss Adelaide Mary Nagro, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Nagro of this place, was married to Francis Joseph O'Connell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. O'Connell of Fort Edward, N. Y., here today in St. Joseph's Church by the Rev. Edward McManus.

A decline in the use of coal as fuel for merchant ships is indicated in the report of the statistical bureau showing only 977 coal burners among the total of 5,387 ships transiting the Panama Canal in the fiscal year 1937.

Secretary Morgenthau reported today that Eldon P. King, Deputy Internal Revenue Commissioner, would sail soon for Geneva to attend a meeting of the League of Nations tax committee. Mr. Morgenthau told his press conference that Mr. King might "broach the subject of exchanging tax information between the United States and other countries."
President Roosevelt has lost some strength, but not much, in this once rock-ribbed Republican State, according to the private opinion of Democratic and Republican leaders.

Julio Alvarez del Vayo, in a speech before the Assembly's political committee, pleaded for the abandonment of non-intervention so that Valencia also could get arms. "If the League," he said, "is no longer able to give the victim of aggression active help it ought to give under the covenant. at least let it not be degraded by the iniquity of denying the victim what he needs to defend himself."

43d St, 308 W. 25x100.4; Patrick J. Walsh, ref, to Patrick J. Hayes, exr; Katherine Brophy, 452 Madison Ave; foreclosure ($30). 77th St, 163 W. 17.6x102.2; Geo. Sinram ano to Geo. F. Sinram, 15-901 35th Ave, Flushing, L. I.; correction deed; (50c). 118th St. 278 W. 25x100.11; Helen Schmitt, to Tanpardo Realty Corp, 9 E 40th St; ($10).

United States PRINCIPAL ANIMAL HUSBANDMAN. $5,600 a year; Bureau of Animal Industry, Department of Agriculture. Applications must be on file not later than Oct. 25, if received from States other than those named below. Oct. 28, if received from the following States: Arizona, California,

Billy Beauhuld, Jersey City's undefeated lightweight boxer, kept his victory string intact last night by defeating Frankie Klick of San Francisco in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Royal Windsor Arena.

Women sat on juries yesterday for the first time in New York City and seemed to like it. Judges and court attendants went out of their way to be courteous and even lawyers modified the thumping tone of an appeal to masculinity.

The City Fusion party launched its Brooklyn campaign for the reelection of Mayor La Guardia last night with a rally of about 200 persons at Fusion headquarters at 304 Fulton Street. The triumphant election of Mayor La Guardia by a landslide vote was predicted by leaders of the Fusion cause.

Although he ran out badly in the stretch and lost a length or more, William H. Gallagher's Rudie still was good enough to score an easy victory in the mile of the featured Friar Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

Charles A. Baehler, whose fame as one of the world's greatest hotel men is bound up with that of Shepheard's Hotel here, died suddenly today at the age of 66. The fact that he was Swiss gave him a good start in his career and his knowledge of languages, head for figures and marked urbanity did the rest. His only setback came

Gilbert Miller starts his local season and Henry Miller's Theatre turns on its lights this evening with "French Without Tears," this being the Terence Rattigan comedy that has been fetched from London.
The engagement is announced of Miss Charlotte Ludlow Whiteley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stockett M. Whiteley of Roland Park. to Norval H. King Jr., son of Mrs. N. H. King and the late Mr. King.

A 10 per cent increase in sales of premiums and the entrance into premium merchandising of numerous companies never before in the field can be traced directly to the Robinson-Patman act and its restrictions on advertisingg allowances, Howard W. Dunk, secretary of the Premium Advertisers Association of America, Inc., said
The second book of Compton Mackenzie's "Four Winds of Love" will be published on Oct. 7. The title is "The South-Wind of Love" (Dodd, Mead).

Mrs. Mabel Davis Bailey, daughter of Mrs. Byron E. Davis of this city, was married at her mother's home at noon today to Oliver B. James of Oyster Bay and New York by the Rev. George A. Brock, pastor of the New England Congregational Church.

Lovill (Chubby) Dean, first baseman-pitcher of the Athletics, is out of -action as the result of a head injury suffered yesterday in a game at Washington. Dr. John Baird, Athletics' physician, said an examination showed no fracture but there might be a slight concussion. He ordered Dean to rest.

A niece of Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman was announced today as winner of second place in a civil service examination for district superising public health nurse. She is Miss Margaret G. Arnstein of Dobbs Ferry and New York City. The State Health Department reported that her mark was 92.56.

The Consolidated Edison Company declared yesterday the plan of exchange of New York Steam Corportion preferred shares for Consolidated Edison preferred shares effective as of Sept. 25, since twothirds of the outstanding Steam preferred shares had been deposited for exchange under the plan by the close of last week.

Eleven promotions and appointments to the editorial, managerial and circulation boards of The Campus, undergraduate publication at City College, were announced yesterday by Bernard Rothenberg, editor-in-chief.

Fifteen leaders of Young Republican organizations met today with John D. M. Hamilton, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, to discuss plans for revival of the party in time to participate effectively in the 1938 Congressional elections.

With forty-two years of coaching behind him, a record of service excelled only by that of Amos Alonzo Stagg, Glenn Scobey (Pop) Warner is still going strong at Temple University, though an ailing hip causes him to lean heavily upon his cane and upon his smart, hard-working "top sergeant," Fred Swan, and Chuck Winterburn. his backfield assistant.

Since the New Deal has virtually been eliminated as an issue in the municipal campaign through the nomination by the Republicans of Mayor La Guardia and by the Democrats of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, both Mayoralty candidates being committed to the Roosevelt policies in the nation, the supporters of Mr. Mahoney have reached the conclusion that the "united red front" for La Guardia will afford them a new and profitable angle of attack on the Mayor.

Four drawn games in the fourteenth and final round today brought to a conclusion the international chess masters' tournament, which has been in progress since Sept. 8, and the extra half-point gained by Paul Keres, 21-year-old representative of Estonia, enabled that brilliant expert to carry off the first prize on a total of 9-5, a full point ahead of Reuben Fine of New York, one of the two Americans entered in the competition.

Local sportsmen who were aboard the last "Fisherman's Special" to Montauk on Sunday came back with one of the banner catches of the season. Porgies and sea bass were counted by the bushel when the boats brought in the fish on the last big run of the Summer-Fall season.

Mrs. Opal S. Hill, the Kansas City (Mo.) veteran of the fairways, toured the Belle Meade Country Club course in 74 strokes, two under par, today to win the medal in the second annual Southeastern women's invitation golf tournament. Seven strokes back in second place were Mrs. Jane Cothran Jameson and Miss Kathryn Hemphill, both of Columbia, S. C.

Saturday's scrimmage in which Bobby Stuart was lost for several weeks at least, proved more serioUs than at first thought. Harvard lost the services indefinitely of Jim Russell, leading candidate at center. Russell received a stomach injury.

The chief optimists of business today appear to be the automobile manufacturers, who, in preparation for the coming new model year, are setting new high production schedules and announcing all-time record advertising campaigns.

In celebration of his fifty years as organist and choirmaster of the East Sixty-eighth Street German Evangelical Reformed Church, a dinner to Philip Hauser, musician and composer, will be held tonight at the New York Turn Hall, Eighty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, by the congregation.

David Lazarus, for twenty-seven years Democratic leader of the Sixth 'Assembly District, retained his position, having gained last night at a meeting a majority vote of the county committeemen elected at the polls on primary day, according to Herbert Hirtenstein, secretary of the Jefferson Democratic Club, 247 East Seventh Street, where the meeting was held.
The boards of directors of the Rainier Pulp and Paper Company,

A bill for the establishment of a federal travel commission is being drafted so that it can be introduced into Congress at its next session, it was announced yesterday afternoon by Hillory A. Tolson, an assistant director of the National Park Service of the Department of the Interior.
Mrs. Arthur A. Houghton is expected to arrive at the Carlyle today from Corning, N. Y. Lord Mottistone of Mottistone Manor, Isle of Wight, is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works, recently reorganized under the Federal Bankruptcy Act, received permission from Federal Judge Oliver B. Dickinson today to increase its borrowing capacity from $3,000,000 to $5,000,000 to meet overhead costs of increased production.

Drake's Restaurant at 119 West Forty-second Street, whose menu cards for more than a quarter of a century bore the boast "Drake's Never Closes," passed out of existence yesterday when its entire equipment was sold under the auctioneer's hammer.

Declaring that the one issue of the campaign was good government, Mayor La Guardia promised 2,000 members of the New York County Republican Committee last night to continue to give the city an honest and efficient administration.

Shipments of fabricated structural steel in the United States in August reached the highest point of the year, amounting to 158,228 tons, and were 67.6 per cent of the so-called normal, which is the monthly average for 1928 to 1931, inclusive, the American Institute of Steel Construction reported yesterday.

Investigation of the kidnapping of Charles S. Ross, wealthy retired greeting card manufacturer, centered today on efforts to piece out a history of his conversations and movements on Saturday. The theory was that the men who seized him on a road near Forest Park late Saturday evening approached him earlier in the day.

Only three of the forty-two teams which teed off in the bi-monthly Long Island P. G. A. amateur-pro best-ball tournament at the Oakland Golf Club at Bayside yesterday succeeded in bettering the course's par figures of 70 and wound up in a three-cornered tie for first place.

Ralph Greenleaf, world titleholder, gained a substantial advantage over George Kelly in their 1,500-point pocket billiard match by capturing the first two blocks yesterday at the Strand Billiard Academy. The former won by 125-88 in eight innings in the afternoon and then took the night block, 125-38, in twelve frames.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets and Mayor La Guardia's running mate for district attorney of New York County, invaded the Democratic stronghold of James J. Hines, the Eleventh Assembly District, last night to speak before a district rally of the American Labor party at 2,744 Broadway, near 106th Street.

Princeton University's class of 1941, 645 strong, entering upon its collegiate career today, demonstrated to the satisfaction of returning upper classmen that, though it is one of the largest classes in Nassau history, it also is as "green" as many of its predecessors.

Fifty-eight pickets were arrested in Times Square last night as 200 cafeteria workers staged a mass demonstration in the block in front of the Horn Hardart Automat at 1,557 Broadway, between Fortysixth and Forty-seventh Streets. Pedestrian and automobile traffic was seriously disrupted in the block for about half an hour as twentyfive policemen, including two mounted men, broke up the crowd

Continued reports of Japanese frightfulnesss" in China aroused the British Government and public opinion to new protests today and gave further impetus to the movement for an unofficial consumers' boycott of Japanese goods.
Mrs. William Smith Morton today announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Smith Morton, to William Dodson McClelland of Richmond, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. L. McClelland of Baltimore.

A million or more Germans packed in masses ten to fifteen deep along five miles of marvelously decorated streets gave Premier Mussolini and his suite today a welcome to Berlin exceeding anything the capital had ever seen before. It came as a climax to a train ride from Essen that also had been somewhat a triumphal progress through the western half of the Reich.

Half a boatload of exotic birds, beasts and reptiles from the Far East arrived in this port yesterday afternoon. The collection, numbering about 300 specimens, filled the entire afterhold of the Silverash, a British freighter, which docked at Pier 9, Stapleton, S. I.

Morris Rosenbluth, for the last ten years credit manager of StrausMiller Co., dealers in women's garments, committed suicide about noon yesterday by jumping from a window of the office where he was employed on the seventeenth floor of the Garment Center Building, 498 Seventh Avenue.
Boston at New York (2)--MacFayden and Bush vs. Smith or Melton and Vandenberg. Brooklyn at Philadelphia-Fitzsimmons vs. Johnson or Mulcahy.

Miss Eleanor Montague, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Everett Montague of Riverside, Greenwich, will be married on Nov. 6 to Robert Vincent Harry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Guy Harry of Brooklyn, N. Y.

The situation in North China concerning the collection of customs duties is being watched closely by the United States Government. While no intimation has been received in official circles of any change in the customs collection system,

Acceptance by the Interstate Commerce Commission of the standards of capitalization proposed by the commission's Bureau of Finance in its plan for the reorganization of the Western Pacific Railroad Company would "constitute such a shock to railroad credit as to render doubtful the ability of any railroad hereafter to sell any securities on a favorable basis, particularly if issued for more than 50 per cent of future additions and betterments,"

The Tennessee Valley Authority won a victory today on points of preliminary procedure in the Federal court suit of seventeen private utilities which are attacking the agency on constitutional grounds.

Having witnessed yesterday the might of the German Army, even if only in manoeuvres, Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy saw today an equally impressive demonstration of Germany's industrial armament, when Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler showed his guest the Krupp Works here, the Reich's traditional, although by no means only, armament smithy.

Parking tickets placed on automobiles here by the police can be ignored by car owners without violating the law or being in contempt of court, City Judge Jacob A. Bernstein ruled today in sustaining objections filed by Manlio S. Severino, an attorney, who found a ticket on his automobile last week.

The Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service will begin a drive for $250,000 next Monday. John M. Schiff of Kuhn, Loeb Co. will head the campaign. He is vice president of the service's board of directors and a grandson of the late Jacob M. Schiff, one of the principal supporters of the organization, which was founded in 1893 by Miss Lillian D. Wald.

Ray Perrault, regular right end, and Ray Worth, the first-string center, probably will be unavailable Saturday when Boston College launches its intersectional football competition here against Kansas State. Perrault suffered a knee injury against Northeastern Saturday and Worth came out of that opening game with a pulled tendon.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against CAPE COD FISH CO., INC., 2 Fulton St., by Ackerly Sandelford, Inc., for $396; Berman Fish Co., $234; Wallace, Keeney Lynch Corp., $277. KING LAMPS, INC., manufacturers, 457 West Broadway, by Onyx Novelty Co., Inc., for $178; Allegheny Steel and Brass Corp., $58: Frank Dank, $270.

Succoth, the Jewish Festival of Tabernacles, or harvest observance, ended yesterday. In the conservative and orthodox places of worship, Simhat Torah, the Rejoicing of the Law, will be observed today.

With the trading in September corn ended except for the actual work of closing out the open interest either by settlement at $1.10 1/2 a bushel or a delivery of the cash grain, the trade today fell back to considering the supply and demand situation.
Controller Frank J. Taylor will hold a conference in his office at 11 o'clock this morning to discuss ways in which taxing agencies may benefit industry.

Naming names, the League of Nations Advisory Committee on the Far East declared inexcusable tonight "the bombardment by Japanese aircraft of open towns in China." The United States representativeLeland Harrison, Minister to Switzerland-did not vote and made no comment, but the delegates of the twenty-two other nations on the committee adopted a resolution that "solemnly condemns" what the United States in its recent note to Japan "disapproved."

Charles Ambruster, inventor of the automatic die for making lock parts and other inventions, died at his home here yesterday. He was 81 years old and was the oldest employe of the Eagle Lock Company, whose employ he entered when he was 13 years old.

With Associate Justice Hugo L. Black nearing American shores after a vacation abroad, the national capital tonight apparently had no inkling of what the new associate justice plans to do regarding the allegations of past or present membership in the Ku Klux Klan.

The bitter jurisdictional fight between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization over control of the more than 1,200 employes of the National Electric Products Company at Ambridge, Pa., ended

Just as Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, had concluded a tribute to the Rev. Ambrose M. Dwyer, pastor of St. Patrick's Church, Binghamton, at a dinner here tonight, Father Dwyer was stricken with a heart attack. He died on the way

Dr. Hans H. Dieckhoff, German Ambassador to the United States, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa from his vacation in Europe. He appeared optimistic over the political situation in Europe and said the tension there was less than a year ago. "I think it is an exaggeration to expect a serious conflict." he added.

Thomas D. Kernan, president of the Catholic Book Club of New York, was the guest of the other officers and editors of the club at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night prior to his departure for Paris where he will become director of the Paris branch of the Conde Nast Publishing Company.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the following additional applications for registration as broker or dealer in the over-the-counter market received from. New York City (Symbols: S, sole proprietor; P, partnership; C, corporation):
Found "riding the blinds" on President Roosevelt's special train, Clayton Treat said from a jail cell today: "They told me I was lucky I didn't get shot."
Big Buck Newsom and the Red Sox split with the Athletics today when the Boston right-hander, after winning the opener, started the second game and was shelled from the mound in three innings.

Colonel Warren Ray Thompson, a construction engineer since 1923 associated with the Cities Service Company, died Sunday afternoon of a heart attack at his residence, 1 Fifth Avenue. Born at Lykens, Pa., he would have been 60 years old on Oct. 19.

Bob Feller, the Iowa farm boy who came up from the Corn Belt to the Indians and equaled the major league strikeout record, will pitch on a Western barnstorming tour at the close of the American League season.

Louis Wiley, business manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who died Feb. 20, 1935, left a gross estate of $350,119 and a net estate of $322,495, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The principal asset of the estate was a group of life insurance policies valued at a total of $291,484.

The first group of visiting members of the American Legion, numbering 244, arrived here this afternoon. They were welcomed by the commander of Paris Post 1, Bernard A. Ragner; the Department Commander of France, Elbert Lee Dodds, and Past Commander James L. McCann, together with a post color guard and many other members of the local post.

The volume of orders coming into the local merchandise markets yesterday continued quite good, according to both manufacturers and resident offices. Mails were heavy, covered a wide selection of merchandise and came from most sections of the country.

The text of President Roosevelt's speech here today was as follows: Governor Clark: And I am going to say what Senator Borah said: "Friends and Neighbors." I shall never forget this morning. And when I look back on
Earl's Mr. Will and Guy Scotiana divided honors in today's six-race Grand Circuit program, enlarged by the postponement of Saturday's card because of rain.

Two Pennsylvania golfing neighbors and Ryder Cup team-mates, Henry Picard of Hershey and Byron Nelson of Reading, today qualified for the final of the $12,000 Belmont open match-play tourney with lopsided victories over more eminent rivals.

Efforts were made to effect a compromise on the demands of longshoremen in Atlantic and Gulf ports for a new wage contract, at a conference yesterday of representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association.

An annual series of four speed boat regattas of international importance, two to be held each Summer on American waterways and two on. European lakes, is the ambitious plan of Count Theo Rossi, the Italian nobleman who invaded the United States this month and became the runner-up for both the Gold Cup and President's Cup.

William C. Walker's Sons were co-brokers with the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., in the recent leasing of an additional floor in 114 Fifth Avenue to S. H. Kress Co., who now occupy fourteen floors. The contract to demolish the former home of Jacob H. Schiff at 965 Fifth Avenue has been awarded to the Edward R. Walsh Company. The site will be improved with an eighteen-story apartment house.

Whether the action of the Federal Reserve Board in decreeing a further lessening of credit regulations for member banks by making installment finance paper acceptable for rediscount acted as a stimulant to the stock market yesterday was a debatable issue.

Ray Steele, 214, Califfornia, threw Abe Coleman, 204, Poland, in the main wrestling exhibition at the Hippodrome last night. The victor employed a leglock to end the match in 25:03. The thirty-minute semi-final was won by Joe Cox, 226, Kansas City, who tossed Bill Sledge, 214, Texas, in 20:07, with a body tackle.
Clark School opened today with the largest enrollment in its history. The students come from fourteen States, as well as Canada and England. Twenty are from New York.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange continued yesterday the rally that developed on Saturday and despite irregular fluctuations over a range of $1 a bale gained 4 to 9 points. Liverpool recovered sharply and the improvement in the share market attracted heavy commission house buying.

The three members of the Transit Commission conferred informally yesterday on their appointment of former Mayor James J. Walker as an assistant counsel at $12,000 a year. No decision was reached. The meeting followed the refusal of Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the State Department of Public Service, to approve or disapprove the appointment.

The Texas Pacific Railway Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to assume obligation and liaability in respect to $1,275,000 of its equipment trust certificates, Series D, and to dispose of said certificates.

Despite the fact that Coach Earl Blaik was dissatisfied with the performance of his Dartmouth eleven in the victory over Bates last Saturday, he retained the same first line-up when the team worked out this afternoon.

MANHATTAN BAMBERGER, AMY V. (Sept. 2). Estate, less than $2,500. To Martin Bamberger, husband, executor, 200 W. 70th St., residue: five specific bequests. Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co., 70 Broadway, executor.

Georgie Daly, crack English lightweight, scored his second American ring victory by knocking out Al Dunbar of Brooklyn tonight at Laurel Garden in 2:20 of the second round of a scheduled ten-round bout. Daly weighed 139 1/2 and Dunbar 138 1/2.

Warner Brothers will choose one of three band leaders now under contract to them for the important role in "Garden of the. Moon," the John Barton Browne and H. BedfordJones magazine story which they have just purchased. The three under consideration are Rudy Vallee, Fred Waring and Johnny Goodman.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 22: An increase of $20,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans; decreases of $50,-

The destroyers Manley and Claxton, which sailed from Norfolk last Wednesday to relieve the destroyers Kane and Hatfield of the European squadron, were damaged in a hurricane on Saturday 300 miles east of Sable Island, and were ordered today to return to the Boston Navy Yard for repairs.

Mrs. Ellen Elizabeth Bryan, widow of Captain Lawrence J. Bryan, U. S. A., died yesterday at her residence, 200 West Seventy-ninth Street, after a long illness, at the age of 72. During her residence in Washington, D. C., Mrs. Bryan was associated with the Congressional Library and was an active supporter of several philanthropies.

The second of the American track and field teams that toured Europe this year returned to New York on the Cunard White Star liner Samaria yesterday, but the newest arrivals proved to be merely a rear guard left behind by the rest of the squad. The majority of the

OUT of the Boston Athenaeum, where, as all will remember, the name of the late George Apley was not unfamiliar, comes a biography of the late John Jay Chapman. Chapman died in 1933 at the age of 71, and his family handed over his papers to M. A. DeWolfe Howe. An absorbing book,* consisting in large part of letters, is the consequence.

The Huntington Republican County Committee scored a complete victory over W. Kingsland Macy, Suffolk County Republican leader, when its candidates were nominated to every office at the Republican Township Convention tonight in the Greenlawn firehouse.

Mrs. William Ellery Sedgwick of Stockbridge gave a tea this afternoon in compliment to the Stockbridge library directors, of whom Mr. Sedgwick is president, and Miss Harriet McFadden of Hollidaysburg, Pa., recently appointed librarian.

The Cardinals are out of the 1937 National league pennant fight, but this disappointment is somewhat offset by the success of the organization's twenty-eight farm clubs, nine of which were pennant winners.

John P. Morrissey, insurgent Tammy candidate who defeated Charles Sheridan as district leader of the Sixteenth Assembly District South in the recent primaries, was guest of honor last night at the Cherokee Club, 334 East Seventyninth Street, at which the district committee formally elected him to the leadership.

Bond prices turned highly irregular yesterday in fairly active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Despite the establishment of numerous new low quotations among the secondary and the more speculative issues, there were several impressive rallies in pivotal issues in consonance with the stockmarket trend.

The New York Giants have replaced the Pittsburgh Pirates as the leaders in the race for offensive honors in the National Football League. According to the official figures announced yesterday, the local eleven has gained a total of 531 yards in two contests for a 265 average.

Miss Louise M. Newman, former owner of Newman's department store in Brooklyn, where she resided at 12 Monroe Place, died here today in her Summer home at the age of 88. The nearest surviving relative is a niece, Mrs. Henry Irwin Jr. of Garden City, L. I.

As a result of their double triumph over the Bees yesterday the Giants need only four victories in their remaining nine games to clinch the National League pennant, for then, even if the Cubs won all of their six contests the standing would be:

Morton Cooper hurled Columbus into the little world series with Newark, which will open Wednesday in Newark, by defeating Milwaukee, 10 to 4, on four hits today. The visitors' margin in the secondround American Association playoff was four games to two.

Joe Mazziotti, Elmsford professional, teamed with Paul Runyan, Metropolitan professional, to take first honors in the Westchester P. G. A. pro-pro best-ball golf championship held today at the Gedney Farm golf course. The winning pair carded a 67 in the morning and needed two strokes more in the afternoon for a thirty-sixhole total of 136.

Police investigating the assassination of James Yelland Andrews, Commissioner of Galilee, and a British constable yesterday, today arrested 106 Arabs while the two victims were buried here with full military. honors.

Movements of vessels follow: At San Diego: Bridge, Sept. 26; Clark. At Manila, Sept. 26: Canopus, Pigeon. At Boston Yard, Sept. 25: Case, Conyngham. At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Cumings, Sept. 26. Roper, Sept. 25.

Pressing resolutely on, the Giants advanced toward the National League pennant in double-quick time yesterday as they played the first of four scheduled doubleheaders. They bagged both ends of their twin bill with the Bees while a crowd of 15,821 bellowed its unanimous approval.

Confident that the Supreme Court will grant a review of a lower court decision in the anti-trust suit of the Government against the Aluminum Company of America, the company today asked the justices to set an early date for argument of the issue.

State or Federal control of Pennsylvania's anthracite coal fields, aimed at eliminating bootlegging and rehabilitating the hard coal industry, was recommended by Governor George H. Earle here today at a conference of operators, union representatives and independent miners.

198th St (12-3278), s w cor of Webster Ave, 91x53; Conn Cohalan. referee, to The Ebling Co, 598 Madison Ave. Edson Ave (17-5056), e s. 340 ft s of Nereid Ave. 26x87; Division Realty Holding Co to Beatrice D. Lyons, 172 Bennett Ave. 168th St (10,2681), s w cor of Prospect Ave, 105x30; Sam Polansky to Polansky Realty Corp.
JOHN JAY CHAPMAN AND HIS LETTERS, by M. A. DeWolfe Howe, (Houghton Mifflin, $4.) A biography. THE CANNING CLAN, by Earl Chapin May. (Macmillan, $3.) History of the canning industry in America.

A substantial tonnage of steel orders has been placed with United States exporting companies by European corporations, principally British, in the last few days, it was learned in steel circles yesterday. In the main, such orders are for ingots, but some semi-finished products also are being bought here.

Lafayette College began its 106th year today with a large attendance. At the opening convocation in the Colton Memorial Chapel, 900 students heard President William Mather Lewis urge a new standard of undergraduate efficiency.

Peter Forrest, attorney, in 342 Madison Ave; Ault Wiborg Carbon Co, in 240 Madison Ave; William C. Euler, in 299 Madison Ave: Schwartz-Gilbert Co, Inc, in 3-5-7 W 22d St; renewals by the Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corp, broker. Robert Giraud, Inc, beauticians, in La Maison Francaise, Rockefeller Center. Abe Haimowitz, restaurant, in 260 W 38th St; George Gottlelb, restaurant, in 159 W 49th St.

Maria Huebner, 17-year-old daughter of an Austrian hotel proprietor, who came to Egypt to marry the 64year old former Premier, Tewfik Nessim Pasha, will go home without a husband. The financial arrangements collapsed today.

Philip W. Russell, since 1934 a partner in Fenner Beane, has succeeded the late Alpheus C. Beane as the firm's senior partner in New York. Charles E. Fenner continues as senior partner with headquarters in New Orleans.

Lace shipments from Calais to the United States in the first eight months of the current year amounted to 493,535 pounds, valued at $1,398,297, which was 82 per cent greater in quantity and 155 per cent greater in value than for the corresponding period of 1936, Richard W. Byrd, American Vice Consul at Calais, has reported to the Department of Commerce, it was announced today.
Mike Jacobs revealed yesterday that he is trying to sign Tommy Farr, the Welsh heavyweight, to meet Max Baer in one of his boxing shows at Madison Square Garden in the coming season.

MANHATTAN FEIR, ANNIE (March 29, 1934). Gross assets, $72,562; net, $27 761. To Henry Feir, husband, residue; Mollie Leopoldstadt, mother, and Henry Stern, cousin, $5,000 in trust each. Chief assets, real estate, $70,000. Abraham I. Kirschenbaum, attorney, 258 Broadway.

Urging that a bipartisan judiciary be maintained in the Ninth Judicial District, delegates attending a Democratic judicial convention here this afternoon nominated Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme of Bronxville as their candidate in the November election.

Wholesale grocers of the country averaged gains of 10 per cent in volume compared with a year ago, the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly summary of conditions in the grocery industry. The gains are due chiefly

A $600,000 building and permanent loan on the seventeen-story and penthouse building to be erected at 226-30 Central Park South has been arranged by William A. White Sons for the Park Slope Construction Corporation, Siegfried Moisseiff, president.

The women's United States golf crown will pass to one of the 136 contestants who will start play for it on Monday at the Memphis Country Club, Memphis, Tenn., in the forty-first annual championship. It was won a year ago by Miss Pam Barton, the English girl, who carried the title back across the seas and added it to the British championship she had previously captured.

A plea by Alfred Kohlberg of Bronxville, an oriental rug importer, for permission to place his four children on the witness stand here before Official Referee J. Addison Young so they might express a preference for their mother or him was rejected today by Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief.

With Russian legislative elections in the offing, the drive against "antiSoviet wreckers" turned today to old provincial politicians in Soviet Union border republics to stamp out any separatist sentiment.

Don C. Wheaton, a partner of Starkweather Co., will retire from the firm on Thursday to head a new company now being organized to act as national distributors for the stock of the National Investors Corporation.

New York, which had come to know in person or by his familiar photograph the jaunty figure of Rear Admiral Harris Laning, will regret Admiral Laning's forthcoming retirement from active service, and his departure next Friday (Oct. 1) from the post he has so ably filled-Commandant of the Third Naval District, and of the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Ernest G. Draper, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, in a letter in today's TIMES, argues that an injustice was done him by the following criticism which appeared in a recent TIMES editorial:

Plans were filed yesterday for a 102-family apartment house to be constructed at 1-17 Seventy-fourth Street, Brooklyn, at an estimated cost of $385,000, and for a six-story house on Forty-second Street, Long Island City, Queens, costing about $150,000.

The governing committee of the Investment Bankers' Conference, Inc., held its quarterly meeting here today to discuss its program for making more effective the nation-wide organization it has set up to promote self-regulation in the over-thecounter markets and to cooperate with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A strike call to more than 4,000 shipping clerks in the garment district, effective this morning, was issued yesterday by the Shipping Clerks Union, independent organization, with offices at 567 Seventh Avenue. According to

Department store stocks of merchandise on hand at the end of August still showed sizable increases over a year ago, ranging up to 136.9 per cent in one instance, according to figures for large stores in the Second Federal Reserve District issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
A decline of 4,297 from the previous week was shown when Administrator Hopkins today announced employment on WPA projects at 1,456,915 during the week ended Sept. 18.

No real alarm is felt in Europe over the possibility of war, in the opinion of Lord Mottistone, British soldier and statesman, who arrived here yesterday from England, via Montreal. He crossed on the Empress of Britain.

Max Silverman, who has been held in $250,000 bail in Los Angeles since his arrest there last week by an aide of Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets, was accused of extortion yesterday in an eleven-count indictment handed up to Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora by an extraordinary grand jury.

With lar the assertion that "court packing" was the chief issue to be decided by the municipal election five weeks hence, Jay Cooke, chairman of the Republican City Committee, opened the Republican campaign tonight with a radio address, in which he also introduced as an issue the "high cost of living."

Army's football squad turned out in good shape today for the las week of practice before Saturday' opener with Clemson College and was set to work tuning up its de fense against the vaunted attack of the Southerners. Clemson made ten first downs against Tulane Satur day, losing by a touchdown.

Sheriff St, 56, 25x100; Manuel Greenbaum and ano. to Helen Gersh, 2,077 Wallace Ave, 10 yrs, 4%, $5,000. 5th Ave, 954, 30x120; 955 Fifth Ave, Inc, (Anthony Campagna, pres) to Central Hanover Bank Trust Co, et al,. trus, Ernest Fahenstock, p m mtg, due Oct. 1, 1938, 3 and 4%; $82,500.
Mayor La Guardia worked from 8:30 to 6 on Sunday trying to slash forty or fifty million dollars from the city budget. He was
Michael L. Igoe, United States District Attorney, tomorrow will file suit in District Court to collect $345,011.96 in income taxes, penalties and interest from Al Capone.

The toasts exchanged by Chancellor Hitler and Premier Mussolini at tonight's banquet here follow: CHANCELLOR HITLER Your Excellency, as Fuehrer and Chancellor of the German people I have the great honor and pleasure of being able to welcome you heartily in the Reich's capital.

James A. Farley, National Democratic party chairman and Postmaster General, said in an interview here today that there was little possibility of a third party showing any great strength in the 1940 elections.

President Roosevelt was headed for the giant Bonneville Dam tonight for a formal speech tomorrow after a talk at Boise, Idaho, this,morning in which he outlined his efforts to go beyond the "petty problems of the day, the trials and disputes of the moment" and attend to his "obligation" as President to look to the future of the nation.
Columbia's football team yesterday moved into the final week of preparation for its opening game against Williams on Saturday at Baker Field.

Hardhitting Barbados batsmen had 246 runs for the loss of six first-innings wickets at the close of play today in their three-day intercolonial cricket match with British Guiana. Carew swung the best bat during the day, scoring 67 runs, while Innis hit a sparkling. 55 and Sealy 44. Gaskin was British Guiana's most effective bowler, taking two wickets for 36 runs.

Japan's terrorism has been extended to the sea. Survivors of a Chinese fishing fleet arriving at Hong Kong yesterday told of the sinking of eleven junks by a submarine with the loss of 300 lives. Other attacks of the same

The Potter Estate has sold to a client of Oscar Rosenbaum the four five-story dwellings and the twostory garage known as 1,562-8 First Avenue and 403 East Eighty-first Street, forming the northeast corner, and occupying a plot 102.2 by 131.6 feet. Assessed at $159,000,

Sixteen players were dropped from the Pennsylvania varsity squad today as the Red and Blue held its first practice on Franklin Field after ten days' conditioning at Camp Hershey. The varsity group now numbers thirty-six.
A maid who had just finished her first day of employment was drowned accidentally last night in a bathtub at the residence of her new employer, Edward W. Stern, 21 East Eighty-seventh Street.
Miss Kay Stammers, English woman tennis star, signalized her entry in the Pacific Coast championships today with an 8-6, 6-3 victory over Miss Anne Morgan, youthful left-hander from Berkeley.

Thomas P. Montgomery died this morning at his home, 14 Hubbard Court, after a heart attack, at the age of 71. He was president of the Welsbach Gas and Electric Company of New York and had lived here two years. He was a native of Syracuse, N. Y., having been born there Sept. 16, 1866.

Metropolitan Museum of Art, "Decorative Arts: Elements of Design," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Color Facts," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.; "Egypt: The Beginnings," Edwin L. M. Taggart, 4 P. M.; "Paintings," Edith R. Abbot, 4 P. M.

Any lingering hope Japan may have had that its campaign of frightfulness is not universally condemned among civilized peoples must have been dispelled by the action of the League of Nations Far Eastern Advisory Committee yesterday.

Dr. Frank L. Babbott, president of the Long Island College of Medicine, welcomed 369 students back to classes yesterday in opening exercises which marked the beginning of the seventy-eighth year of medical training at the institution.

Of Robert Lathan, the eminent Carolinian editor, it will be remembered by the nation's press and the constituency he enlightened that he was independent, honorable, fearless and learned in the American tradition he daily served. As editor of the venerable Charleston News and Courier, the economic-political article which won him a Pulitzer

Strength in the transatlantic issues was the focus of attention in the stock market today. While securities, otherwise, were quiet the resurgence among the internationals imparted an undertone of general confidence which was discernible over a broad front.

Charley (Red) Ruffing's chances to repeat his 1936 record of twenty victories were set back today by the elements. The Yankee right-hander was scheduled to oppose Jimmy DeShong of the Senators, but an early morning rain washed out the game, precipitating a double-header for tomorrow, when the Yankees bid adieu to Griffith Stadium.

The realty man's complaint that assessed valuations have been maintained at too high a level during the recent lean years finds powerful support in an analysis of Manhattan foreclosures and resales by lending institutions since the beginning of 1935.

The ginkgo tree planted in the northwest corner of City Hall Park by James J. Walker when he was Mayor in 1929, was chopped down yesterday; it had died. Legend says that the bark of the tree is good luck, and many persons have taken bits of it away with them in the last eight years.

Indicating that he was dissatisfied with the lack of progress in reorganization of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacifio Railroad, Federal Judge James F. Wilkerson urged today that attorneys for the trustees speed up action which would take the road out of the courts.

Grocery manufacturers will not attempt to fix resale prices if and when they move to place their products under State Fair Trade Laws, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc.,

Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad System were authorized today by Federal Judge Carrol C. Hincks to pay three items of interest amounting to $309,340. The largest, $259,340, is for

The Rajah Sankara Pratap Singh Dev Mahindra Bahadur, ruler of the State of Dhenkanal, Bengal, India, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa to spend a month in this country. He was accompanied by the Rani Srimoti, two other Indian princes and two officers of the household.

Premier Mussolini's and Chancellor Hitler's plan for a rapprochement between the Rome-Berlin axis and Britain as a first step before calling back to life the 1933 Four Power Pactwhich possibly may be transformed into a five power pact in the process of resuscitation-is understood by authoritative Italian sources to have taken definite shape in the days the dictators have spent almost constantly together.
Out of the wreckage of Shanghai came news today of the safety of a Boston man and a bank vault, half as long as a city block, ordered from here more than two months ago for the Bank of China.

Colonel and Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice have sent out invitations to the marriage of their daughter, Miss Mary Adeline Prentice, and Benjamin Davis Gilbert of Clayville, N. Y. It is to take place at Mount Hope Farm, Williamstown, the afternoon of Oct. 16.

Absolute severance of all ties between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization will be one of the central demands to be served on the federation when it meets here next week, according to the sentiment of delegates to the convention of the metal trades department which opened here today.

Three steamships which are scheduled to make trips around the world next Winter will cancel their stops in China and Japan and go down to Australia if conditions in the Orient are not improved during the next few months.
Miss Gwendolyn R. Sharwell, daughter of Walter G. Sharwell of this place, was married to A. Gold Harrison Jr., also of Caldwell, today in the Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. Edwin I. Stearns.

Representatives of the National Foreign Trade Councils committee on Spain, and Miles M. Sherover, president of the Hanover Sales Corporation, representing the Spanish Loyalist Government, met yesterday for an informal discussion of the settlement of American claims of $30,000,000 to $50,000,000 in commercial balances which have been tied up in Spain since before the revolution. The meeting was confined

Manager Burleigh Grimes tried his most desperate measure of a sad season today, but the Dodgers lost anyway to the Phillies, dropping their twelfth straight game. Their hold on sixth place thus was cut to a game and a half.

Ambassador Daniels, at a recent celebration in honor of the late President Masaryk, spoke also in praise of his wife, an American,- born in Brooklyn, who "exerted great influence upon him and his career." They worked ever in
The Duchess of Windsor began today a tour of Paris shops to buy a Winter wardrobe. The Duke escorted her to the atelier of Mainbocher and then went to their hotel.

Secretary Ickes said today that at President Roosevelt's request an order closing Yellowstone National Park to travel Sept. 26 had been revoked. The park will be open to tourists another fortnight unless snow blocks highways, he said.

The Pure Oil Company announced here yesterday that stockholders had subscribed to 8,040 of its cumulative 5 per cent convertible preferred stock and forty-one of its common shares in accordance with a recent offer made to its common stockholders.

The Cubs, still trying to catch up with the first-place Giants, won the opening game of a series with the Reds today, 7 to 4, but saw their deficit increased to four and a half games as the Giants won two from H Boston.

The Weather Bureau tonight issued the following storm warning: Advisory 9:30 P. M.-Northeast storm warnings ordered 9:30 P. M. Cape Hatteras to Nantucket, Mass. Disturbance off South Atlantic coast will cause strong northeastward winds probably reaching gale force along the Middle Atlantic and Southern New England coasts.

A request to the district attorneys of New York and Kings Counties for the cooperation of their commercial frauds departments in petty prosecutions for violations of the Feld-Crawford Act, was made yesterday by Crichton Clarke, counsel for the American Booksellers Association. The request was made in

The report of the American Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended Aug. 31, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income, after all expenses and charges, of $11,559,193, as compared with a net of $9,833,104 in the twelve months to Aug. 31, 1936.
In view of the pressure on space this morning and the high cost of newsprint, this department will endeavor to be brief about "On Location," which was put on at the Ritz last evening.

The judicial conventions of the major parties for the Second Judicial District were held yesterday in Brooklyn.
