While the Democratic delegates took little time to name their three candidates, the Republicans almost had a floor fight because some of the La Guardia adherents in Brooklyn wanted to name a member of the American Labor party in return for endorsements for the two Republicans.
The Bureau of Navigation today released the following orders, dated Sept. 24.: LIEUTENANT Bentel, C. E., Med. Corps, the Salinas, to instruction in the Naval Hospital, San Diego, Calif.

Mrs. Rosalind Coghlan Pitman, wife of Richard Pitman, casting agent and artists' representative, and a daughter of the late Rose Coghlan, died suddenly yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage at her home, 117 Livingston Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

Earl Arthur Cox, president of the on New York State Bakers Association from 1929 to 1933, died suddenly here this morning of a heart attack while motoring from his home, 45-28 256th Street. He was 56 years old. Mr. Cox formerly was
One man was killed and two other men and a child were seriously injured in an automobile accident at Jamaica Avenue, near Ninety-fourth Street, Woodhaven, at 7 o'clock last night.

Before a Wyoming audience a few days ago President Roosevelt said that present circumstances are-making it easier for the Government to balance its budget, "and we are doing it." By this he could not have meant to suggest that the budget is in balance now, for this is plainly not the case.

Premier Felicien Slawoj-Skladkowski on Saturday told a delegation of Jewish leaders, complaining of street attacks and damage to their property, that the Government would do everything possible to prevent a repetition of such anarchy and lawlessness, which, he said, was unworthy of the Polish nation.

Judge Otto R. Heiligman today directed the acquittal of former Magistrate Francis X. O'Connor and James McCann on charges of attempted "jury-fixing." He refused to dismiss similar charges against two other defendants, John Campbell and Andrew Ratto.

Tammany leaders who supported Jeremiah T. Mahoney in the primaries and others who gave their support to United States Senator Royal S. Copeland, who went down to defeat as an. aspirant for the Mayoralty nomination, will meet under a flag of truce at the meeting of the Tammany Executive Committee and the Democratic County Committee which will be held at in Tammany Hall, Seventeenth

Threaineedle, a campaigner from the Middle West, scored her second straight success of the meeting in the Southfield Purse, mile and seventy-yard feature, today. The daughter of Reigh Count, owned by M. Vehon, led four others of her sex to the wire, with Coronium second, two lengths away. Third money went to Careful Miss.

H.M.S., a chestnut gelding owned and driven by Robert Elderkin of St. James, L. I., captured the 2:25 trot that featured the racing program of the annual Queens-Nassau County Fair at the Fair Grounds today. H.M.S. took two straight

Gregory H. Melanson, former Swampscott aviator and explorer, scion of a Lynn shoe manufacturing family and part heir to his- father's $800,000 estate, died here early today of a heart attack. He had been ill since Saturday. His age was 27.
The Omaha Bee-News, a William Randolph Hearst newspaper, will announce suspension of publication in its morning and evening editions tomorrow.

As the date approaches when the migratory urge among apartment dwellers begins to wane there still remain enough families who feel a need for a change of quarters to sustain an activity which promises to carry over the traditional Oct. 1 moving day by sheer momentum.

Movements of livestock with Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 14,000, including 4,500 directs. The market was steady to 10 cents lower than Friday's average; top, $12.45, bulk good and choice 190-230 pounds, $12.25$12.45; 240-300 pounds, $11.85-$12.35; 150180 pounds, $11.75-$12.35; bulk good sows, $10-65-$11.00; lightweights to $11.10 and better. Shippers, 2,000; estimated holdover, 1,500.

The Committee of Utility Executives, official representatives of the private utility industry of the United States, issued today a booklet containing quotations from the voluminous report of the President's National Resources Committee to prove that steam was a cheaper and more desirable source of electrical energy than water power.

As the members of the American Bar Association gather at Kansas City, the President is foremost among their anxieties. Their chief officer, Mr. Stinchfield, sounded the topical keynote at once when he spoke of the "unequal struggle impending between the President and the lawyers of the United States." Doubtless the resolutions to

Cornell's varsity, which faces Colgate Saturday, worked lightly today, taking it easy after Saturday's victory over Penn State. With Stahl absent because of sinus trouble, Captain Hughes resumed his old place at center virtually recovered from a twisted knee.

Lewis B. H. Adams, 67 years old, of 562 West 148th Street, died last night at St. Luke's Hospital. He was a native of Saugerties, N. Y., and for many years had been connected with the Willcox Gibbs Company in this city. He is survived by his son, Lewis R. Adams, and a sister, Mrs. Albert Stencken.

Declaring that he would not have campaign manager or a campaign headquarters during the Mayoralty contest, Mayor La Guardia yesterday asked organized labor throughout the city to support his "nonpartisan, non-political" candidacy for re-election solely "on my record."

The Andrew Jackson High School, Cross Island Boulevard and 116th Avenue, St. Albans, Queens, which has been in use since last May, was formally dedicated yesterday afternoon. Mayor La Guardia presented the keys to the building to Acting Principal J. Allison S'evenson before an audience of 1,500 pupils and parents in the auditorium of the school.
Mr. and, Mrs. Robert A. Porterfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Porterfield, to Wilmon W. Hartman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred H. Hartman.

Statistics given out this week by our always active Park Department show that our citizens are increasingly interested in healthful recreation, even when they have to pay a little for it. In 1934 343,107 golf players tried to beat the jinx on the department's courses; this year the figure is 585,000.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe granted authority yesterday to Frederick V. Goess, as receiver of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, to accept $125,000 from the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company in settlement of a claim for $200,000 to cover alleged dishonest deals made by Joseph W. Harriman, convicted former president of the bank.

If manufacturing processes remained unchanged for twenty years, it would take that length of time for sales engineering to catch ip with them, F. M. Rhed, formerly of the educational department of the Hoover Company, yesterday told the weekly luncheon of the Sales Executives Club of New York, in advocating scientific training for salesmen.

An election among the "shore gangs" of the International Mercantile Marine Company and United States Lines, the Huron Stevedoring Corporation and the Acme Scaling Company, Inc., was ordered today by the National Labor Relations Board.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 25: Hundt, Lt. Comdr. L. T., the Enterprise, to duty as Commanding Officer, Patrol Squadron 15, the Owl.

Premier Benito Mussolini's visit to Berlin has caused Argentine newspapers to recall President Roosevelt's, visit to Buenos Aires. They compare the military precautions for Mussolini's safety with President Roosevelt's democratic manner and his close contact with the people who crowded about him wherever he went.

Twilight Song, 3- year - old filly owned by Will Strang Jr. of Brooklyn, won the forty-fifth trotting of the $9,295 Kentucky Futurity on the Grand Cirouit today, clipping off her two miles in 2:01% and 2:01%4.

A driving rain and slippery going failed to halt Coach Fritz Crisler's Princeton squad today and the Tigers rang down the curtain on their fortnight of pre-college training with two arduous sessions aggregating more than five hours.

Discovery of land about 400 miles north and east of here in the Arctic Ocean was reported today by Alexsei Gratciansky, Soviet pilot, on his return from a third northern flight in search of the missing Russian transpolar fliers.

Phelps, Fenn Co. headed the successful syndicate yesterday in the purchase of a new issue of $1,810,000 of relief and water bonds of the city of Buffalo on a bid of 100.031 for 3.20s. The bonds, dated Oct. 15, 1937, and maturing Oct. 15, 1938 to 1957, will be reoffered at prices to yield from 1.25 to 3.25 per cent, according to maturity.

Governor Earle today painted a dismal picture for the future of Pennsylvania's once-prosperous hard coal fields unless State regulation of industry was established. He advocated State regulation of the industry at a meeting of operators, miners and "bootleggers" at the Capitol yesterday.

The following Engineer Corps reserve officers are relieved from their present assignments, as indicated after their respective names, and are assigned To 78th Engineer Co. (D T) RAI (Camden District), Capt. Ralph Schultz, (515th Engr. Bn). 40 East Washington Ave., Pleasantville, N. J.

Marvlo Mills, Inc., textile converters, have leased larger quarters in 62-64 Worth Street, through to 31-33 Thomas Street, and will move from their old offices at 54-56 White Street upon completion of renovations to the Worth and Thomas Streets structure.
European passengers aboard the steamer Kaying, which has arrived at Hong Kong, report having seen a Japanese destroyer firing on two Chinese junks on Monday evening.

The civil suit by which the Federal Government hopes to collect $345,011.96 in income taxes, penalties and interest on assessments from Al Capone was filed in United States District Court today by Assistant District Attorney David Bazelon.

The Government at Nassau has embarked on an expansion program involving the expenditure of $500,000, largely allocated to public works such as telephone facilities, sewerage and water, according to James Henry Jarrett, Acting Governor of the Bahamas,

After three hours of continuous aerial bombing of Chapel in the vicinity of the North Station with five-plane squadrons working in relays, an official Japanese spokesman announced this morning that the long-heralded advance into Chapel was being begun by naval landing forces.

The quality of the work that has been done by artists in connection with the Index of American Design, a WPA Art Project, is put to the severest possible test at the Downtown Gallery, 115 West Thirteenth Street, where an exhibition composed of actual folk art objects and drawings of these objects is now current. It opened to the public yesterday and will continue for a fortnight.
Movements of vessels follow: Chefoo to Fairway Buoy, Sept. 28, Bittern, Heron. At Almirante, Sept. 28, Gannet, Teal. Balboa to San Diego, Hull, Worden, Sept. 27.

About one-third of the 7,601 cases which the National Labor Relations Board has handled in the twenty-three months of its existence concerned allegations of unfair labor practice and almost another third consisted of petitions for elections, the board stated today. Most of the unfair

President Roosevelt's denunciations of "economic royalists" and a "privileged minority" were attacked today by Harper Sibley, former president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, in an address to more than 1,500 New Jersey club women in the Shubert Theatre here. He was one of a group of speakers at the annual New Jersey Review of the News Conference, given by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The Colon Development Company, Ltd., which is affiliated with the Royal Dutch-Shell group, announced yesterday that it would redeem on Oct. 30, at $5 for each ??l sterling principal amount plus 5 per cent interest accrued and unpaid from Oct. 1 to Oct. 30, all its redeemable income stock, Series A, then outstanding or required to be issued under the reorganization plan dated Feb. 26, 1936.

Franz Fuchs, formerly employed by Vienna's Socialist municipality, was sentenced to five years' imprisonment today for offenses connected with the civil war against the Socialists in February, 1934. After he had allegedly
Army's football squad had an afternoon of rainy weather football today as the cadets continued the hard schedule arranged in preparation for Saturday's opener with Clemson.

For the nature-faking that has made Senator Borah familiar to millions as "the Old Lion of Liberalism" blame the same pictorial typewriters which have hammered out, and into the American consciousness, such names as "The Wild Bull of the Pampas," etc. Mr. Borah is nothing like the lion in his legendary (and inaccurate) role as monarch of the jungle.

A forty-five-minute scrimmage between the varsity and freshmen concluded a two-and-a-half-hour workout for Coach Jimmy Crowley's Fordham football squad at Fordham Field yesterday. Working entirely on offense, the Maroon scored four times on the greenshirted cubs. Pete Holovak,
Bert B. Meek, vice president of the Hearst Corporation and State Director of Public Works under former Governor C. C. Young, died today at his home on San Francisco peninsula. He was 53 years old.

Robert Irwin, 29 years old, the sculptor who is awaiting trial in the Gedeon slaying last Easter, refused yesterday to submit to an examination by the lunacy commission appointed by General Sessions Judge Freschi. This was learned after the commissioners,

Indictment of three large automobile financing concerns and their leading officials, instead of the minor executives who have testified thus far, was revealed today as the objective of a Federal grand jury investigation which is now in progress here.

Renewals of automobile operators' licenses were coming in at a better rate than during a comparable period last year, I. J. Brody, deputy commissioner of Motor Vehicles, said yesterday. Up to the close of business on Monday night, he explained, 562,934 renewals had been issued, 35,822 more than on the

Rumors alleging the possibility of a military dictatorship in Brazil caused General Pedro Aurelio Goes Monteiro, inspector general of the army, to issue a statement today branding such reports as malicious intrigue.

The Lufthansa plane Ju-52, missing more than a month since it took off from Amshi, Afghanistan, for Kabul, Afghanistan, landed at the latter city yesterday afternoon after having crossed the Pamir Mountains.
Ruby Keeler's first starring picture for RKO under her two-year contract recently signed will be "Love Below Freezing,' which has had a major script operation since it was announced for Mitzi Green.

Receipts 12,000 including 2,500 directs. The market was fully 25c lower than monday's average: weights from 180 pounds down 25c-40c off; top $12.30; bulk good and choice 190-230 pounds, $ll.90-$12.25; 150180 pounds, $11.40-$12; bulk good and choice 240-300 pounds, $11.60-$12.15: most good sows S10.40-75; few best light weights to $10.90. Shippers 1,500; estimated holdover 3,000.

W. H. Albers, president of the Albers Super Markets, Cincinnati, and active champion of nationally advertised grocery brands, yesterday was elected president of the Super Market Institute, Inc., organized at the close of a two-day convention of super market operators from all parts of the country at the Hotel Astor.

Another highly dangerous candidate for the rich Futurity loomed up at Belmont Park yesterday when C. V. Whitney's Dauber scored a sensational victory in the Nursery Handicap in a field cf candidates for Xturday's classic.
87th St, 56-60 E. 76.8x100.8; 60 E 87th St Corp, Barnet Levine, president. to Fannie Mandel, 56 E 87th St; bldg loan; prior mtg. $230.000; due May 1, 1941, 4 2-3 per cent: $3,500.

Two detectives of the pickpocket squad, accused of assault and robbery and out on $1,000 bail each, who were suspended from the department pending Investigation, were demoted to uniform rank yesterday, it was announced by Commissioner Valentine.

Dr. J. Eastman Sheehan, New York plastic surgeon, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria from Spain, where he went ten weeks ago at the invitation of General Franco to instruct surgeons of the "White" Army in plastic surgery.

Theodore Flatt Jr., strapping 27year-old Ledgewood laborer, received a State prison sentence of seven to ten years and was fined $1,000 by Judge Harry Runyon in Special Sessions Court here today after admitting he had bigamously married Helen Black, 12-year-old Ledgewood schoolgirl.

Charging that an interlocking directorate of the North American Company, headed by Harrison Williams, had compelled the North American Light and Power Company to accept $4,000,000 in loans in lieu of stock issues to retire notes, John H. Murphy, a holder of Preferred stock of North American Light, sued yesterday in Federal Court to invalidate the deal.

The monetary policies and the borrowing of the New Deal offer little if any threat of inflation, but on the other hand are equally unlikely to bring about the -full employment of either labor or capital, Professor 0. M. W. Sprague of Harvard University declared last night at a dinner at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

American League Philadelphia at New York (2)Ross and Smith vs. Wicker and Vance. Detroit at St. Louis-McLaughlin vs. Mills. Cleveland at Chicago (2)-Wyatt and Whitehill vs. Cox and Dietrich. Boston at Washington (2)-McKain and Henry vs. Chase or Appleton and De Shong.

The North Boston Lighting Properties, Boston, a subsidiary of the New England Power Association, has filed a declaration under the Public Utility Holding Company Act and a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering the issuance of $13,000,000 of secured notes, 3 1/4 per cent series due in 1947.

Marked superiority in the pitching department-as. shown in the season records-gave the Newark Bears the edge tonight as they prepared to stack up against the Columbus Red Birds in the Little World Series for the championship of minor league baseball.

Following are the texts of the two addresses made by President Roosevelt yesterday: Today I have a feeling of real satisfaction in witnessing the completion of another great national project, and of pleasure in the fact that in its inception, four years ago, I had some part.

Less than a month after their marriage, Anthony Niosi, 25 years old, and his wife Mary, 21, were found dead yesterday afternoon on the bedroom floor of their newly furnished three-room apartment at 4,436 Matilda Avenue, the Bronx.
The buildings at 177 East Seventy-fourth Street and 1,290-4 Third Avenue are 100 per cent rented, according to Byrne Bowman, Inc., rental agents.

James A. McGinniss, counsel for inheritance tax matters in the Surrogate's office of New York County, died Sunday night at his home, 100-46 204th Street, Hollis, Queens, of heart disease. He was 57 years old. He is survived by his widow and seven children, James, Robert, Mildred, Christene, Edward, Grace and Warren.
These awards of honors to members of the sophomore and freshman classes at Vassar College are announced:

Funeral services for former State Senator Caleb H. Baumes, author of the "Baumes Law," which provided mandatory life sentences for fourth felony offenders, were held today in Trinity Methodist Epniscopal Church.

The Sweets Company of America, one of the largest candy manufacturers in the country, has purchased the former Elevator Supplies Company plant occupying the entire block fronting on Park and Willow Avenues, between Fifteenth and Sixtenth Streets, Hoboken, N. J.

A fight for recognition of the C. I. O. as entitled to represent technical employes in Columbia, owned and operated radio stations in New York and Washington was begun yesterday by the American Radio Telegraphists Association, C. I. O. affiliate. at a hearing held by the National Labor Relations Board at City Hall before H. R. Korey, trial examiner.
Miss Helen Dettweiler of Washington lost to Mrs. Alberta Haycraft of Minneapolis in the first round of the Southeastern women's invitation tournament today.

Two years and nearly eight months after leaving Buenos Aires, Miguel Divo, who earns his living as a magician in Argentina, drove a battered model T Ford through the Holland Tunnel yesterday morning and completed a motor journey of 22,000 miles that had been started on a dare.

More than 2,000 retail kosher butchers in Brooklyn held a meeting at 450 Eastern Parkway last night and voted to close their shops Friday afternoon and to keep them closed until wholesalers reduce the price of poultry and meat.

Miss Carolyn Flagler Morgan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Heber Morgan of this city, has completed plans for her marriage Oct. 15 to Norman Brassler, son of Mrs. Otto Brassler of Englewood and the late Mr. Brassler.

As a cooperative move in administration of over-the-counter regulations promulgated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which will become effective on Friday, the Investment Bankers' Conference, Inc., Has sent to its members throughout the country an interpretation of their provisions as they affect various situations.

At the celebration of the publication of the first volume of the Dictionary of American Biography (in 1928) the hope was expressed that Dr. Jameson, who drew up the original plan for the work and found the means to make possible the gathering of the material for its publication, would live to see the twenty volumes from "Abbe to Zunzer." Happily that hope was fulfilled.

William Boyd, former advertising director and vice president of the Curtis Publishing Company, died at his home in Germantown today in his seventy-fourth year. Before entering upon an advertising career, Mr. Boyd had served as a secretary of the Young Men's Christian Association in Kansas City and Evanston, Ill.

Paced by Clarence Ehresman, Ashbourne pro who turned in a subpar 67, eight golfers survived two rounds of match play over the rainsoaked Llanerch course today to advance to the quarter-finals of the Philadelphia P.G.A. championship.

The new two-year contract between Theatrical Protective Union Local 1, the Broadway stagehands' union, and the League of New York Theatres, the producers' organization, will be signed as soon as it can be drawn up, it was said yesterday after a meeting of representatives of the two groups.
The good news that the bread ration is being increased and the bad news that no citizen can keep more than one or two blankets per bed were contained in two decrees today.

The cooperative movement in Sweden has encouraged the development of voluntary chains and has no intention of attempting to force capitalistic enterprise out of existence, Anders Hedberg, secretary for international questions of the Cooperative Union of Sweden, declared at a press conference here yesterday. Mr. Hedberg,

Newbold Morris, Republican-Fusion candidate for President of the Council, charged last night that Tammany was awaiting opportunity to raid the city's relief funds and declared that the attempt of Abraham Kaplan, campaign manager for Jeremiah T. Mahoney, to pin a "red tag" on Mayor La Guardia would be completely unsuccessful.
Despite the United States' Neutrality Act, China may soon find it possible to obtain a great number of American bombers and pursuit planes by way of France.

In the account of the appraisal of the estate of Louis Wiley, business manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, as published in THE TIMES yesterday, there was omitted the fact that the estate placed a value of $80 a share on thirty-five shares of the common stock of the New York Times Company, which valuation was changed in the official appraisal to $450 a share.
By HENRY G. WALTEMADE Tremont Ave. 4SS-490 E. two 4-story tenements, 46.6x76.11 irregular; Felix A. Muldoon, trustee, against S P L Building Co; due, $112,532; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Charges that the attacks on Justice Black of the Supreme Court were inspired by "malice and politics" in the hope of hurting the President and embarrassing his Administration were made by Senator Smathers of New Jersey today.

The little farmhouse where John D. Rockefeller was born in 1839 became Tioga County property Saturday. E. Burt Cornell, County Treasurer, said the property automatically went to the county when the owner, Henry D. Shea of Brooklyn, failed to pay taxes of $90.37.

At an executive meeting here today the Westchester County Board of Health appointed Dr. George H. Ramsey of Albany as the new Westchester County Health Commissioner, and voted to capitulate to town and village officials who want the county health organization decentralized.
The Hygrade Meat Packing Corporation reached a "collective agreement" with C. I. O. butchers tonight and ended the threat of a general strike in eight other cities.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Piers Summey, daughter of Mrs. David Long Summey of 155 East Forty-seventh Street and Greensboro, Vt., to Dr. Edward Herbert Jr., a physician, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Herbert of Fall River, Mass., took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square.

The Transit Commission, beset by the refusal of Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the State Department of Public Service, to approve or disapprove its appointment of former Mayor James J. Walker as assistant counsel in charge of gradecrossing elimination, rescinded that appointment yesterday and immediately reappointed him.

Twentytwo hundred woolgrowers are curtailing their offerings at the auction sales here owing to their disinclination to accept current prices. Nineteen thousand three hundred bales will be catalogued next week instead of 25,000. Since the first sales

The Banking Act of 1935 opened the door to the discounting by Federal Reserve Banks of the notes of member banks secured by any assets, the test of eligibility being merely that such assets should be "satisfactory" to the Reserve Bank making the advance.

As part of the national celebrations of the 150th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution, Pennsylvania and New York will honor today the memory of Gouverneur Morris, Constitution signer and statesman.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Patteson of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Sheppard Patteson, to James K. Irvin of Irvington-on-Hudson.

Like Kipling's liner, Endeavour I was a lady. Like other cup defenders and challengers, she was built to win races in coastal waters, under moderate winds, and not to take it on the nose, all alone, in the wilderness of the western ocean. When she made transatlantic voyages it was intended that she should be towed by a polite and gentlemanly escort with the aid of steam or gasoline. One would as soon have set
Included among the plans filed by architects yesterday was one for a sixty-five family apartment house in Brooklyn which it is calculated will cost $245,000. In the Bronx, a

Captain Daniel Gilbert of the State's Attorney's police and several other officials directing the investigation into the kidnapping of Charles S. Ross arrived at the retired manufacturer's apartment late tonight in what appeared to be an important development in the case.

A special entertainment entitled "A Night in Krakow" marked the formal opening for the season last night of La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis. The celebration was in aid of the American branch of the Russian Invalids of the Great War.

There is obviously less uneasiness in France over the reception Premier Benito Mussolini has been having in Germany than would have been the case before the Nyon conference that organized the "piracy" patrol in the Mediterranean.

Business failures increased in four groups in the week ended Sept. 23, compared with the corresponding period last year, the commercial service division being the only one to show a decline, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Dr. Charles E. Davis, oldest living alumnus of the University of Michigan, died today at his home in Cassopolis at the age of 93. He was graduated in 1874, then served as alienist on the Chicago Medical Board.
Thirty-one persons were reported condemned to death as agricultural "wreckers" today in Soviet Russia's drive against sabotage.

The Italian public heard Premier Benito Mussolini speak in a foreign tongue for the first time when his and Chancellor Adolf Hitler's addresses in the Berlin Stadium today were broadcast throughout Italy.
American military authorities believe that Japan may be on the verge of bringing out a "mystery" gun for use in the Chinese aerial combats.

A total of twenty-two departments registered advertising losses while only fifteen experienced gains during August, as compared with the same month last year, according to a breakdown of department store linage in New York and Brooklyn by Media Records yesterday.

After hearing United States Senator A. Harry Moore, their party's nominee for Governor, allude to President Roosevelt as "our present great leader and statesman," delegates to the Democratic State Convention adopted unanimously here today

When one of the more than 300 fields in Texas can produce enough oil products in one hour to supply the whole United States for three days it is time that oil producers used some conservation sense, members of the National Association of Petroleum Retailers believe.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,666,300 barrels, compared with 3,671,200 in the previous week, a decline of 4,900, according to the American Patroleum Institute. Declines of 8,700 and 6,400

The Council of Actors Equity Association ratified yesterday an agreement which will enable Equity and chorus Equity members to perform in other unionized branches of the entertainment field without paying a second set of full dues.

17th St, 9 E, 25x85.1 irreg: Wm. F. Wilkie to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp, trustee, 346 Bway; mtg $25,000. 118th St. 3 W, 27.9x100.11; Dorene Leslie to Ralph Edwards Co, 152 W 42d St; mtg $16,000.
The American Labor party filed yesterday with the Board of Elections certificates of nomination of Mayor La Guardia and several of his running-mates.

Conflicts, jealousies and lack of cooperation were charged to Federal in agencies engaged in crime investigation in the report of a study on crime control made public today by the Brookings Institute. The agencies were also accused of indulging in "feverish bursts of

The heavily industrial Seventh Congressional District tonight elected a Democrat to the House for the ninth consecutive time, choosing Lawrence J. Connery of Lynn in a special election to fill the seat of his brother, the late William P. Connery, who was chairman of the House Labor Committee.

The Duke of Windsor talked with a British Cabinet Minister today for the first time since his abdication. Leslie Hore-Belisha, Minister of War, who has been attending the French Army manoeuvres, called at the Duke's hotel and conversed with the former sovereign for more than an hour.
Good weather today permitted the Loyalists to drive ahead on the northern Aragon front, where they took the villages of Latre and Serue as well as other minor positions.

The infant mortality rate for the first thirty-eight weeks of this year was 46.1 per 1,000 live births, the lowest in the city's history, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday. The previous low for a comparable period was set last year, when the rate was 46.4.

The imposition of penalties ranging from $100 to $1.700, assessed in the last ten days against fifteen manufacturers of blouses in the $15.75 field for granting excessive discounts and for other unfair practices will be reported tonight by B. H. Lerner, executive director of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers, to the board of governors of the association.
Herbie Katz of Brownsville scored a knockout victory over Paul Pirrone of Cleveland in the feature bout scheduled for eight rounds before a crowd of 4,000 at the Broadway Arena last night.

Service on the Forest Hills-Greenpoint line of the city's Independent Subway System between Court Square and Twenty-first Street, Long Island City, was delayed for forty minutes early yesterday as a result of a break in a ten-inch water main at Eleventh Street and Jackson Avenue. At 5 A. M. the water had flooded the tracks.

The four-story apartment house at 2,069 Union Street, corner of Sutter Avenue, Brooklyn, has been purchased by investing clients of M. Berman, attorney. The house is on a plot 100 by 100 feet and has five stores on the ground floor.

Conditions in the local commodity futures markets yesterday were mixed. Although most of the changes were on the down side, secondary metals and cottonseed oil advanced moderately. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, -ye, oats, butter, lard, tin and spot cotton advanced, while coffee, cocoa, raw sugar, silk, rubber, eggs and wool tops declined.

Dr. John Franklin Jameson, distinguished historian, scholar and writer, died at his home here today of pneumonia and heart complications. He was 78 years old. Before taking the post of chief of the Manuscript Division of the Library of Congress in 1928, Dr.

My dear Friends and Neighbors: As the candidate for Mayor of the united democracy of the City of New York. I want to thank you for the privilege of being permitted tonight to discuss with you in this hospitable clubhouse some of the issues of the campaign.

MANHATTAN HALEY, FREDERICK JOSEPH (March 25, 1936). Gross assets, $5,985; net, $3,510. To Sarah Augusta Haley mother, residue; Harriet E. Dow and Annie Washburn Parker, aunts, share remainder interest. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $4,741. Olcott, Paul, Havens Wandless, attorneys, 70 Pine St.

Mrs. Huntington Hartford arrived from New York this morning to take up her residence at Boxwood Farm. She was accompanied by Mrs. John Jacob Astor. The Hartfords acquired Boxwood Farm this Spring and during the Summer restoration and remodeling has been going on.

Recent innovations in air travel, designed to promote comfort, furnish the best "selling points" for advertising designed to attract a feminine audience, according to Helen Stansbury, director of the women's traffic division of United Air Lines.

Ivan (Ching) Johnson, battlescarred veteran of eleven campaigns in the National Hockey League, has been granted his outright release at his own request, Lester Patrick, manager of the New York Rangers, announced yesterday. The 40-year-old player, who

Standing near the giant Bonneville Dam, a keystone in the New Deal's reclamation and power program for the Pacific Northwest, President Roosevelt struck back today at those who accuse him of seeking to destroy individual liberties by protecting national resources. At the same time he promised a balanced budget for the next fiscal year in answer to the critics of Federal spending policies.

The annual flower show of the Westchester and Fairfield Horticultural Society, with the garden clubs of Greenwich and Rye cooperating, which opened in the state armory this afternoon is the largest ever held in the Society's history. It will be continued tomorrow

Controller Frank J. Taylor presided yesterday at a conference in his office held to determine how official taxing agencies could best aid industry in the city. The session was closed to the public. In a statement issued later the Controller said that the subject was full of complexities.

Thomas J. Fergus sold to the Arving Management Inc., of 16 Court Street, Brooklyn, the three three-story flats at 615-19 Ocean Avenue, Jersey City, N. J. and the two three-story flats with stores at 680-82 Broadway, Bayonne.
Edmund Deschenes, vice president and general manager of the Central Vermont Railway, died here tonight after a long illness. His age was 59.

The New York Coffee and Sugar Clearing Association rules yesterday that members of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange must put up an additional original margin of $250 on their open positions in December Santos coffee contracts, beginning tomorrow.

Facing frankly the situation in which France is producing less than enough to carry the burden of her charges for defense, debt service and social improvement, Premier Camille Chautemps today told the inquiry commission set up to increase production that while he would not change the forty-hour-week law he would try to get it applied to meet production demands.

A tentative agreement has been reached for a merger of the American Bridge League and the United States Bridge Association, thus bringing to a close a feud between the two organizations that has lasted for several years. It was disclosed yesterday that a contract is being prepared for signature by officials of the two groups, providing for the merger.

In the Republican judicial convention three candidates for judges of the Supreme Court, Second Judicial District, were nominated with the old-fashioned partisan fervor. They were described by their nominators as "real Republicans" and "100 per cent Republicans." Mr. Jacob Livingston, a perfect specimen of that ancient breed, had the call for the convention read twice in order to stress the fact that its proper and sole business was "to nominate three Republicans." there had been

Miss Madeleine Curtis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Eliot Curtis of 400 East Fifty-eighth Street, has chosen Oct. 14 as the date for her marriage to James W. Walsh Jr. of this city and Lawrence, L. I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Walsh. The wedding will take place
Dimitly V. Bogomoloff, Soviet Ambassador to China, left yesterday morning by airplane for Moscow on a special important mission, the nature of which was not disclosed.

With the return of Harold Hansen and Bill Worden, both backs, to the playing field the Navy varsity squad was 100 per cent present today. Irwin Fike, the big end of last year's first team, who did not start last
Despite a driving rain, there was no let-up in the Dartmouth eleven's program today and Coach Earl Blaik drove three teams through an hour and a half scrimmage on a muddy field.

In the comparative solitude of Griffith Stadium and in a bleak atmosphere of overcast skies, Charles (Red) Ruffing hurled his best game of the season today as he set down the Senators in the first half of a twin bill that marked the farewell appearance of the world champion Yankees in the capital this season.

The ninety-sixth season of the Philharmonic - Symphony Society, opening Thursday evening, Oct. 21, at Carnegie Hall, will introduce several works of American and European composers, it was announced yesterday. John Barbirolli will be conductor and Georges Enesco guest conductor.

Tony Galento, Orange, N. J., heavyweight, knocked out Lorenzo Pack of New York in the sixth round of a scheduled ten-round bout at Convention Hall tonight. Galento weighed 2221/2 and Pack 210 1/2. The end came one minute 29 seconds after the round started.

F. L. Flanders's Tugboat Frank, a non-winner in eight starts before being shipped to this track, made it two victories In a row in the Essex Claiming Handicap, today's feature event. Picking up two pounds after defeating the same caliber of horses last week.
The Public Service Commission today ordered all municipal electric plants in New York State to pay a 6 per cent interest rate on deposits to secure payment for electric service.
A decline of almost 20,000,000 pesos (about $5,000,000) since Aug. 30 in the monetary metal reserves of the Bank of Mexico was shown today in its weekly statement.
Steel ingot output declined last week when an increase was seasonal, and the adjusted index dropped 10 points to 111.3. It was 121.9 for the previous week and 108.1 for the week ended Sept. 26, 1936.

SECOND GRADE DETECTIVE--Edward J. Kelly, from 18th Division, M. O.; D. D.. to 28th Precinct, designation as second grade detective revoked. THIRD GRADE DETECTIVE-Edward P. Fehling, from 18th Division. M. O. D. D., to 79th Precinct, designation as third grade detective revoked.
Harlow H. Curtice, president of the Buick Division of General Motors, announced today that increases in prices of Buick closed cars had been kept to a maximum of 4.1 per cent.
Estate more than $20,000. To Victor Bonsall nephew, executor, 145 W. 96th St., and Norman W. Bonsall, nephew, executor 2,132 Kimball St., Brooklyn, one-half residue each.

More than 3,000 shipping clerks employed in hundreds of establishments in the. garment area went on strike yesterday in response to a call from the Shipping Clerks Union, independent organization, for a minimum wage of $18, a forty-hour week and the closed shop.

The report of the Wayne Pump Company and subsidiaries for the nine months ended on Aug. 31, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $1,385,346 after expenses, estimated normal Federal income tax and special provision for Indiana taxes. The net profit is equivalent

In writing his sermon the average pastor is inclined to aim over the head of his congregation, be complex where he should be simple, use hackneyed illustrations and employ "twenty adjectives where one would suffice," the Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick, pastor of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, told 115 Brooklyn pastors and active laymen at a "retreat" yesterday.

Julius Solters's nineteenth home run of the season in the tenth inning of the first game of what was to have been a double-header today gave Cleveland a 7-to-6 victory over the White Sox. With Chicago leading, 10-5, the

Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Socity of the United States, announced yesterday the return of the organization to the State of Texas and the appointment of W. W. Klingman, who has been agency vice president, as general manager for the State.

Luncheon, New York Building Congress and Committee for Economic and Social Progress, Hotel Astor, 12:15 P. M. Address by John W. Laing. Loyalty Day luncheon, Kiwanis Club, Hotel McAlpin, 12:15 P. M. Address by Dr. Robert W. Searle.

The Army postponed the battle of Indiantown Gap today bemause of rain. "Soldiers aren't sissies," insisted Major Gen. A. J. Bowley, commander of the Third Corps, "but there's no sense risking pneumonia if they don't have to."

At Bonneville yesterday President Roosevelt spoke on a favorite theme. This is his belief that the conditions of modern life, and the responsibilities of the democratic state, require the Government to enter the field of national "planning." In the sense in which he used the word at Bonneville the argument is irrefutable.
Miss Patricia of Maguire, ill of sleeping sickness for ti five years and seven months, died th tonight in Presbyterian Hospital. Pneumonia was the immediate cause Df death. She was 32 years old.

John L. Lewis, his Committee for Industrial Organization and the labor situation created by its activities in the various parts of the country were denounced and defended during today's industrial discussions of the National Council of Catholic Women.
Ernest Mayo Long, general counsel for the Virginia Trust Company and well known in educational affails of the city and State, died at his home here yesterday.

The Church Street Annex of the New York Postoffice. which will occupy five stories of the new Federal Office Building and replace two important old postal centers in the vicinity, will be opened to the public on Monday to provide modern, fast handling of mail on a large scale, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday.

Returning to the racing wars after ten weeks' rest, the Araho Stable's Much Gusto today toyed with five rivals as he drove to a half-length victory in the six-furlong Laconia Handicap through a driving rain at Rockingham Park.

Merger of three of Wisconsin's largest shoe manufacturing companies, with a total daily capacity of 20,000 pairs of shoes, was announced today. The Ideal Shoe Manufacturing Company, with plants in Milwaukee and Waupun:

Braving a stiff wind and a cold rain, Mrs. Sylva Annenberg of Fresh Meadow turned in a card of 41, 43--84 to take first honors in the one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association over the Sands Point Club course today.
Cross-country practice began yesterday at New York University's Ohio Field when approximately thirty candidates reported to Coach Emil Von Elling for their first workout.

st.Louis' discouraged Browns-sunk in the cellar of the American League - bowed before Detroit's Tigers today, 6 to 1. Detroit took an early lead and never was in danger. The Browns' run, in the fourth, resulted from

Wilson Ave (16-4588), w s 286 a of Burke Ave, 50x100; Mount St Vincent Co-Operative Bldg Loan Assn to Cecilia M. Schwalbenberg, 3,738 Wickham Ave. Height Ave (15-4331), e s 450 n of Lydig Ave, 50x100: Zyra Brody to Ralph Loffredo, 2,303 Belmont Ave.
The President was headed toward Seattle tonight after a long day of driving through some of the most beautiful scenery he has ever seen, and a tumultuous welcome from 200,000 people.
Ameri can fishermen spent $8,002,887.31 for anglers' licenses in the 1935-36 season, an increase of $993,878.21 over the amount spent during the previous year, the Commerce Department reported today.

Joseph Miller, 43 years old, of 308 West Eightieth Street, who said he was an engineer, was convicted yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions of preying on persons using the want-ad columns of New York papers. He was remanded to jail for sentence Oct. 7.

Invitations to enter teams in the fifteenth annual interscholastic cross-country run sponsored by Manhattan College, to be held Saturday. Oct. 16, were mailed to more than a hundred high and prep schools yesterday.
The Stephen Daye Press of Brattleboro will publish tomorrow Charles Morrow Wilson's "Aroostook: Our Last Frontier," called the first complete story of this famous Maine county.

Danno O'Mahoney and Ed Don George, both former claimants of the world's heavyweight wrestling title, will meet tonight in the feature finish match at Madison Square Garden. Steve (Crusher) Casey will meet Tom Hartley in the

Nurses must be "artists in the blending of discipline and humor," the 1,000 delegates attending the New York State Nurses Association convention in the Arena here were told today by Dr. Laurens H. Seelye, president of St. Lawrence University.

Mr. and Mrs. Linton Brown Crandall of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Blanchard Crandall, to Frank Huthwaite Riley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Riley of Long Hill, Shelton.

American newspaper reports of Japanese atrocities - are severely condemned here and described as "horror propaganda." The expression "Jap-Nazi" is especially attacked, and also the report that Japanese are using new Krupp guns in their Shanghai bombardment.

FRENCH WITHOUT TEARS, a "light comedy" in three acts, by Terence Rattigan. Staged by Harold French; setting y Raymond Sovey (after original sketch by G. K. Benda); produced by Gilbert Miller, in association with Howard Wyndham and Bronson Albery. At Henry Miller's Theatre.

Mr. and Mrs. Pierre S. duPont 3d will give a large dance tonight at the Waterbury (Conn.) Country Club for Mrs. du Pont's sister, Miss Martha Holcomb, and her fiance, Frank Ronald Stemp of Paget, Bermuda, who will be married tomorrow afternoon in St. John's Church, Waterbury. Miss Holcomb is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Wainwright Holcomb of Waterbury and Fishers Island, N. Y.
The University of Pennsylvania and Army will meet on the gridiron in 1940 and 1941, according to an announcement by H. Jamison Swarts, Director of Athletics at Penn, today. Elevens of the two schools

Miss Mary H. Parsons of Salisbury, Md., outbid investment bankers of Philadelphia and Baltimore today and won the award of her home city's entire block of $30,000 of bonds issued to finance building of highway by-pass.

Mrs. Ellen Ann Hughes, widow of William R. Hughes, New York industrialist and Welsh leader, died today at her home here after a long illness. She was 68 years old. Mrs. Hughes was born at Delta, Pa., a daughter of the late Owen J. and Mary Edwards Jones. She resided in New York most of her life.

We have just witnessed a historic event, the significance of which has no parallel. More than a million people have gathered here participating in a demonstration which is being closely followed by the national communities of two countries, numbering one hundred and fifteen millions, besides hundreds of millions more in other parts of the world who were following the proceedings over the radio as more or less interested listeners..

The Atlanta Crackers squared the Southern Association-Shaughnessy playoff at 3-all today by defeating the champion Little Rock Travelers, 8 to 7. Pitcher Emil Leonard batted in the winning run in the last of the ninth. after the Crackers had come

A public hearing was called today by the Securities and Exchange Commission for Oct. 15 on the application of the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the $6 cumulative preferred stock, $25 par value, of the American Zinc Lead and Smelting Company, St. Louis.

The convention of the Metal Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor today unsparingly condemned the Committee for Industrial Organization and accused it of writing agreements that bound its members to substandard wage-andhour conditions. The way was left open for action to expel the suspended C. I. O. unions at next week's convention of the federation.

The first jury with women members to hear a divorce suit in New York City returned a verdict last night declaring that Mrs. Mae Jackson had been unfaithful to her husband, Frank W. Jackson, an insurance man of 83 Washington Avenue, Westwood, N. J. The defendant wept bitterly at the verdict.

Six stuffed specimens of an African bird previously unknown to ornithologists and closely related to the peacock family of India were brought to the American Museum of Natural History yesterday by Dr. James P. Chapin, associate curator of birds. After a search of nearly

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Otto J. A. Grassi of 1 Beekman Place, formerly of Scarsdale, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Brunhilde A. C. Grassi, to Kenneth Edmund Ryan of 507 East Fifty-fifth Street, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund F. Ryan of Binghamton, N. Y.

Senator Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, urged today that President Roosevelt act, rather than talk, to bring economy in government. "The only way to stop spending money is to stop writing checks," he said.

The Chinese reverses in ing North China are attributed here to and lack of coordination, and unification has been commended to the armies operating along the TientsinPukow and Peiping-Hankow Railways.

Two barklesss" dogs, called the "Barkless Besenji" in the Congo where they originated, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star, liner Berengaria in the custody of B. Hamilton Rogers. They are the first of the breed brought here.

The rain, wind and cold put the golfers to rout yesterday and only thirteen of the more intrepid turned out for the regular one-day amateur event of the Long Island Golf Association, played over the Queens Valley golf course at Forest Hills, L. I.

There are reports that the Treasury Department, yielding to some of the criticisms that have been made of the undistributed profits tax on corporations, will shortly recommend at least some modifications of that tax designed to relieve corporations in debt and small business concerns. Such modifications should be warmly welcomed, though they would have to be more extensive than seems likely if they are to remove the fundamental objections to the tax.

After a clash this morning, when 400 A. F. of L. workers formed a flying wedge and forced their way through C. I. O. picket lines, twenty-five State Troopers equipped with riot guns and tear gas went on guard at the entrances of the Mueller Brass Company plant here.

Miss Laura Caroline Dahlen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Dahlen of South Orange, was married to the Rev. Albert Louis Neibacher of this city last evening in St. Luke's Lutheran Church, West Forty-sixth Street, of which the bridegroom is pastor.

Trading was mostly only fair to slow. Lamb sold lower, strictly choice veal held steady, but other grades were weak to lower and all grades calf were sharply lower. Fresh pork euts were steady to lower and beef steady to slightly lower, Due to the Jewish holidays there were no kosher markets, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Unusually heavy buying of tin by Japan today gave rise to reports in financial circles that Tokyo is keenly disturbed over the possibility that Britain will cut off trade relations as a protest against recent civilian bombings.

Senator Rodolphe Lemieux, Cabinet colleague of the late Sir Wilfrid Laurier and former Speaker in the Canadian House of Commons, of which he was a member for nearly thirty-five years, died at his home today. He was 70 years old.
As the climax of their demonstration of the new friendship of their countries, Premier Mussolini of Italy and Chancellor Hitler of Germany tonight addressed directly and indirectly 3,000,000 Germans.

Mr. Maxwell Anderson and his contributing genii, who so far have won all two of the Critics Circle prizes, will be trying tonight at Empire to make it three in a row. Mr. Anderson is the author of "The Star-Wagon," Guthrie McClintic is
While avoiding scrimmage and possible injury with the Clarkson game scheduled for Friday night, Coach Ossie Solem put his Syracuse football squad through an extensive workout today.

President Roosevelt's Bonneville speech was one that will make votes in the Pacific Northwest, according to political opinion here. The effect, it was said, would not be limited to Oregon, but would be felt in Washington, Idaho and parts of Montana within the Columbia River basin.

The Japanese Army's inability to advance as scheduled at Shanghai is said to be the result of the defenders' lack of knowledge of military tactics. They do not know when they are outmanoeuvered or whipped.

An exchange of messages between President Wilhelm Miklas of Austria and President Roosevelt on the death of Grenville T. Emmet, United States Minister to Austria, was made public today by the State Department. The message from President Miklas read:

The Very Rev. William Foxley Norris, dean of Westminster, died at his home here today at the age of 78 of a heart attack after a long illness. Known as one of the most popuular church personalities in England, Dr. Norris combined the talents of artist, business man, art

With Fall moving day only fortyeight hours away, many apartment dwellers are hastening to sign leases for new quarters, reports received yesterday from brokers in scattered parts of the city revealed.

Bryn Mawr College opened its fifty-third academic year today with 143 new students, the largest freshman class in its history. In an address before the student body Dr. Marion Edwards Park, the president, stated that the new

The Rev. Dr. William I. Chamberlain of 36 Gramercy Park, educator, and a leader in the work of foreign missions, who was corresponding secretary of the board of foreign missions of the Reformed Church in America from 1909 until his retirement in 1935, died yesterday of heart disease in the Presbyterian Hospital, where he had

Rudolph C. Koch, for almost forty years a manufacturer of piano strings used in the production of thousands of instruments by a number of leading makers, died Monday morning of heart disease in his home, 53 Trossach Road, Stapleton, S. I. His age was 71.

Addressing the 39th annual convention of the National Association of Retail Druggists, which opened sessions yesterday at Hotel Jefferson, Congressman Wright Patman, Democrat, of Texas, declared today the 'conduct of retail business should be restricted to the distribution by corporations to a single state.
A real life "Beggars' Opera" wedding was interrupted here today when the police arrested the bride and bridegroom and their twenty-six guests as pickpocket suspects.

Spokesmen for fire and casualty insurance companies told the Joint Legislative Committee on Insurance Law Revision at a hearing yesterday that the danger of inflation and the need for keeping the assets of their companies in a liquid state made it "unsafe" to restrict the

Miss Evangeline Booth, general of the Salvation Army, with headquarters in London, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria after an absence of two years, accompanied by her private secretary, Commissioner Richard Griffith. She was met at the pier at the foot of West Fiftieth Street by senior officers of the Army in New York.

Marlene Dietrich, visiting Paris, has ordered from Schiaparelli a simple black crepe dinner gown with separate embroidered velvet half-sleeves of Peruvian origin. Also she has ordered one long-sleeved evening gown whose lines accent the bust, in brilliant green, gold and black jeweled lame. A fine black wool dinner gown, very decollete, with a black velvet jacket embroidered in black silk, also won-her fancy.
The MacGregor Arctic expedition is digging itself out of seven-foot snowdrifts. Heavy snow has fallen for the last fortyeight hours and there is an average of two feet of snow on the level stretches.

The French franc gave renewed evidences of weakness yesterday, when the discount on forward contracts in the exchange increased sharply and reports were received from Paris that the Government there was considering placing restrictions on dealings in future francs.

A direct challenge to the Roosevelt Administration's assertion that justice is delayed in the lower Federal courts was apparent in a report tonight by Chief Justice Hughes of the conclusions of the recent conference of senior Circuit Court judges. He declared that such a general indictment against the District Courts was unjustified.

Roger W. Babson, American economist, and Mrs. Babson, Victor McLaglen and Brian Donlevy, screen actors, and John Martin, English banker, and Mrs. Martin are among the passengers sailing today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Others will be P. W. Donner, M. P., Miss G. M. Moore, Mr. and Mrs. David C. Beebe, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Sutro, Lieut. Col. T. Tokahashi, Captain L. M. Paterson, Grant Massie and Lawrence Read.
Dr. Joseph Earl Malin, head of the Department of Education at Beaver College since 1931, died today in Jenkintown, where he had undergone an appendicitis operation two weeks ago. His age was 48.

The Alteration Plumbers, Helpers and Steamfitters Union announced last night that it had reached an agreement with the Association of Heating Contractors for the termination of a strike which has been in progress for about a month and the return of about 700 men to work. The agreement provides a

As far as the Giants are concerned, that was a very nice rain yesterday. The chances are that they didn't need it, but they could take it. A little more of that weather and the Cubs will be all washed up for the season. It is practically assured now that the Giants and Yankees will get together for the post-season festivities.

Without so much as turning a wheel in their own behalf, the Giants were swept two more important strides toward their second successive National League pennant yesterday when rain wiped out their final double-header with the Boston Bees at the Polo Grounds.
Foreign and American seeded players were easy victors in all events save one today as play in the fortyeighth annual Pacific Coast tennis championships went into the second round.

A banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and Bonbright Co., Inc., will offer today a new issue of $8,500,000 of Ohio Edison Company first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds due on Sept. 1, 1967. The bonds will be priced at 100 1/2 to yield 3.97 per cent.

The Tammany executive and county committees met last night in Tammany Hall, re-elected David H. Knott and William P. Kenneally as their respective chairmen, and pledged loyalty to Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidate for Mayor, and his running mates, Controller Frank J. Taylor and Max J. Schneider, candidate for President of the Council, who defeated the Tammany ticket headed by Senator Royal S. Copeland in the primary election.

With one major change in the line, Cornell's varsity went through a stiff scrimmage tonight against the second team. Sid Roth, handicapped in early practices by a heavy cold, went to left guard for Jack Hemingway, who played with the reserves.

While the dictators of Germany and Italy proclaimed their solidarity in Berlin tonight, the British and French Foreign Offices quietly began the preparation of a joint note to Italy intended as the first move of a new effort to end foreign intervention in Spain.

John M. Mickle, 77, looked back today over more than half a century of newspaper work and could find nothing exciting about it. Assistant editor of a weekly paper at Holly Springs, Miss., Mickle said he started his career as a printer's devil. "But there hasn't been

Although a good percentage of manufacturing companies have indicated that they are spending substantial sums of money this year for advertising to escape the tax on undistributed profits, the amount of such funds diverted to advertising in the final quarter will not equal that of 1936, accountants and advertising men remarked here yesterday. Under such circumstances,

The first of a series of dramatizations of police heroism, based on authentic police records, will be broadcast at 5:45 P. M. Saturday by WNYC, according to an announcement of the radio production division of the WPA released at Police Headquarters yesterday.

The offices of the Paul Block Newspapers made public yesterday a letter addressed to the editors of The Nation by Max D. Steuer, counsel for Mr. Block, alleging that certain statements in a current Nation article, "Who 'Exposed' Black?" are "absolutely false."

The voice of young America was lifted yesterday in a mixed chorus of praise and condemnation of the type of premiums which manufacturers of cereals, foods and other products aimed at the juvenile market send out, when seven youngsters, ranging from 7 to 12 years of age expressed their opinions at a symposium held in conjunction with the convention of the Premium Advertising Association of America, Inc., at the Hotel Astor.

Truman H. Newberry, former Secretary of the Navy, and Mrs. Newberry, who have been at the Plaza since returning from their Summer home in Watch Hill, R. I., are leaving today for Detroit. General and Mrs. J. William Kilbreth have returned from Bar Harbor and are at Mayfair House before going to 907 Fifth Avenue.

The entire stock and fixtures of the James C. Lindsay Hardware Co., wholesalers of Pittsburgh, will be sold at auction there at a threeday sale starting on Tuesday, Edward Jacobs, local auctioneer, announced yesterday.

Football fans are getting something in return these days for the Federal tax they pay on tickets-some shiny new stadia. The Government, which has been pocketing around $1,000,000 a season for several years from its 10 per cent levy on amusements, is indirectly turning it back to the gridiron enthusiasts.

Lou Uamps, .1z/, z2, url, Z;Un-, a well-earned victory over Johnny Rohrig, 1331/212, of Clifton, N. J., when he gained the decision in the eight-round feature bout in the New York Coliseum before 6,000 spectators last. night. Rohrig landed a hard left to CamDs's chin in the first round
William C. Carter, in charge of production, and Edward J. Burnell, general manager of the main plant at Chicago, have been elected vice presidents of the Link Belt Company.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 27: COLONELS Heysinger, J. D., Med. Corps, Ft. Sam Houston, Texas, to Ft. Lewis, Wash., about Dec. 15. Osborne, T. D., F. A., General Staff Corps to duty as Chief of Staff of the Hawiian Dept Nov 27.

Stockholders of the Tubize Chatillon Corporation approved yesterday the issuance of not more than $5,000,000 of convertible debentures, at the discretion of the directors, at any time prior to Jan. 2, 1939.
Freddie Bartholomew, who has been on "strike" from the MetroGoldwyn-Mayer movie studio since July, was prohibited by court order today from working for any other studio.

Plans for a month-long campaign to raise $250,000 for the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service were mapped yesterday at an organizing meeting of the women's division at headquarters, 99 Park Avenue. Mrs. George B. St. George, chairman, announced that three report lunches would be held on Oct. 14, Oct. 28 and Nov. 4, and a dinner on Oct. 20 at the Ritz Hotel.
George Kelly defeated Ralph Greenleaf in the third and fourth blocks of their twelve-block pocket billiard engagement yesterday at the Strand Academy.

The sponsors of a remodeling operation which transformed a typical outmoded Brooklyn brownstone dwelling into a profitable sixfamily apartment building in modern style are pointing to this project as a model which might well be followed in turning hundreds of similar houses into attractive modern buildings.

Mrs. Bertha Viola Bertschy, one of the early graduates of Hunter College, died yesterday at her home after a five-month illness. Her age was 81. She was the widow of Samuel Bertschy, one of Paterson's pioneer silk manufacturers.

A second group of American Legionnaires, numbering 316, arrived from Bremen at the Gare St. Lazare this afternoon. They were welcomed by General Pierre Vincensini, French liaison officer; French veterans and a reception committee from the American Legion Paris Post.

The greatest need of college students today is for a refuge from their many academic and social activities, President Ada L. Comstock told more than 1,000 young women today at the opening exercises of Radcliffe's fifty-eighth year.
The Rutgers varsity went on the offensive against the freshmen today in an hour's regular scrimmage and marched the length of the field four times.

Launching a determined reply to Barbados first innings score of 301, British Guiana had scored 165 runs for the loss of three wickets as stumps were drawn tonight to close the second day's play in their intercolonial cricket match.
Secretary of State Cordell Hull gave support today to the action of the League of Nations in condemnation of Japanese aerial bombardment of Chinese open cities and civilians.

Chinese speakers in America now are busy terming the conflict in the Far East a war between "fascism and democracy," the implication being that the Chinese represent democracy. I shall be grateful if these speakers will answer one question: What important leader in the history of China has ever gained his position by popular vote?

Gaynell Tinsley of the Chicago Cardinals, newcomer in the ranks of professional football, was the outstanding performer in the National Football League last week, according to figures released yesterday He went into a tie for point-scoring honors with eighteen tallies and for the lead in passreceiving with eight catches for 203 yards gained.

Paul Dean, Cardinal pitcher and younger brother of Dizzy Dean who went on the voluntary retired list last month, was voted a half share in the division of the world series money the Red Birds will receive for finishing third or fourth at a meeting before the game with the Pirates today.

The American Constitutional Federation of New Jersey, incorporated here yesterday, was established because its five incorporators believed certain policies of the Roosevelt Administration were leading toward dictatorship in the United States, Frederick S. Kellogg, president of the federation, said today.

The Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, through its executive committee, has issued a statement condemning Japan's action in China as a violation of "every principle of international justice and of regard for human rights as well as those Christian principles by which we must all be judged." The statement,
The Morning Post, London's oldest newspaper, which has a 165-year history of continuous publication, will die with the issue of Thursday morning, Sept. 30, it was reported in Fleet Street today.

Miss Fannie Elizabeth Henry, supervisor for the last five years of the Barricini Candy Company, with offices at 31-02 Northern Boulevard, Long Island City, died yesterday at Knickerbocker Hospital after an illness of three months. Miss Henry was 30 years old and lived at 601 West 160th Street. Surviving are her mother, Mrs. Helena B. Haase;

A compromise offer on the part of the New York Shipping Association closed negotiations between the association and the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday and gave promise of a new agreement to replace the current contract which expires tomorrow night. Joseph P. Ryan,

Haiti will be added to America's telephone directory this afternoon with an exchange of greetings between Secretary of State Cordell Hull in Washington and August Turnier, acting secretary of foreign relations for Haiti, in Port au Prince. The service will be handled

The six-story business building at 244-8 West Twenty-seventh Street, containing about 30,000 square feet of floor space, has been leased for a long term by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company o Philip Gloussman, who plans to use the structure for the storage of automobiles.
Norman Ebbutt, former Berlin correspondent of The Times who was expelled recently as a "reprisal" for Britain's expulsion of three German journalists, is seriously ill in Ramsgate Hospital.

Dr. David R. Craig, who has been director of research for the American Retail Federation, was elected president of that organization at a meeting of the executive committee of the board of trustees here yesterday. He succeeds Col. C. O.

An amended plan for the reorganization of the Old Colony Railroad through its sale to the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company, was filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission by order of the board of directors of the Old Colony.

Announcement was made yesterday by Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Kimball of Manhasset, L. I., of the remarriage on Monday of Mrs. Kimball's sister, Mrs. Priscilla Dodge Bushnell, and H. Thompson Bushnell, son of Mrs. Ericsson F. Bushnell of 25 East End Avenue and the late Mr. Bushnell.

The marriage of Miss Bettina Martinelli, daughter of Giovanni Martinelli of the Metropolitan Opera Company and Mrs. Martinelli, to Mario Libotte, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ottavio Libotte, will take place on Saturday in the Church of St. Ignazio, Rome.

Loose play by the Cardinals allowed Pittsburgh to tally four runs in the fifth frame today and move into third place in the National League with a 6-to-2 victory. Ed Brandt, the Pirates' big southpaw, gave seven hits, three of them

Children will censor new toys designed by manufacturers, according to a plan announced yesterday by Miss Lillian Rifkin, director of the Tested Toy Laboratory, 103 Park Avenue, which has been organized for the purpose. Before the toys are

By ron Nelson of Reading today proved to be a better mudder than Henry Picard of Hershey, his Pennsylvania professional golfing neighbor and Ryder Cup team-mate, as he gained a 5-and-4 victory in the thirty-six-hole final round of the $12,000 Belmont open match play tournament.

The streets of Tokyo resounded tonight to the tread of marching men as Military Ordinance No. 41 went into effect. Affecting virtually every able-bodied man in the empire, it prolonged indefinitely military service for active and reserve officers and men.

Miss Lillian Phelan entertained with a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for Miss Eunice Howley, daughter of Mrs. William E. Howley of this city and the late Dr. Howley, whose marriage to Lieutenant John J. Phelan of Fort Jay, Governors Island, will take place Saturday in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, charged last night that Mayor La Guardia had made New York City "a city of strife, a haven for Red agitators, destroying property and violating the laws of our great city and State."

No gentle air of lavender and old lace about either of today's books. Quite the opposite. John Steinbeck's "Red Pony"* is sentimental tragedy on the order of "Of Mice and Men." Liam O'Flaherty's "Famine" is as stark and serious as his now-famous "The Informer." Of the two, "Famine" should reach the wider audience, if only because it is a story with which many Americans have an ancestral tie.
With September corn and other grains out of the way, trading today resumed its usual poise and strict attention was paid to supply and demand conditions. There were no new

Mayor Harold H. Burton, a Republican, won a smashing victory tonight over John O. McWilliams, Democrat, for first position in Cleveland's Mayoralty primary, unofficial returns from over 75 per cent of the city's 864 precincts indicated.

Mrs. Diana Lanzetta was robbed of $12 and two diamond rings yesterday afternoon by two men who forced their way into her apartment on the ninth floor of the Hotel Ansonia, Broadway and Seventy-third Street, and tied her to the bed with a bathrobe cord while they searched the place.

Lester, Carter Co. will be dissolved by mutual consent effective on Oct. 8, it was announced today. The firm is a member of the Chicago Stock Exchange, an associate member of the New York Curb Exchange, and does a general over-the-counter business.

Federal Art Project No. 1, two floors in 95 Madison Ave; Dr. Hilda Monkemeyer. publisher, in 225 5th Ave; Alwill Projecto Corp games, in 27-37 W 60th St; Ellis Manufacturing Co, hassocks, in 225 5th Ave; Cross Brown Co, broker.
Clay Bryant, towering right-hander, today pitched and batted the Cubs to a 2-to-0 victory over the Reds and thus kept alive the flickering flame that is the Chicagoans' pennant hope.

Jacobus Von Belsen, artist and refugee both from Russia and Germany, died early yesterday morning from a stroke in his home in the Arcade Theatre Apartments, Broadway and Sixty-fifth Street. He was 67 years old and had been in this country less than a year.

Willialms College scrimmaged for two hours on Cole Field this afternoon in preparation for the meeting with Columbia on Saturday despite a steady rain that made passing plays too difficult to attempt.

A plea for the elevation of reason over instinctive emotional impulses in the conduct of human affairs was made today by Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of Princeton University, in delivering the traditional president's address as the university formally opened its 191st academic year.

The Export Line freight and passenger ship Excambion was held at her pier in Jersey City yesterday afternoon when the crew went on strike, protesting the line's refusal to pay each man a $50 bonus for taking the ship into allegedly "dangerous" waters in the Mediterranean.

Dean Ignatius M. Wilkinson of Fordham University Law School urged the Catholic Guild of Lawyers last night to "fight to the finish" President Roosevelt's Supreme Court program, which he asserted violated the principles of constitutional democracy.

Dean Ignatius M. Wilkinson of Fordham University Law School urged the Catholic Guild of Lawyers last night to "fight to the finish" President Roosevelt's Supreme Court program, which he asserted violated the principles of constitutional democracy.

A year ago maurice J. (Clipper) Smith, one of the original Rockne watch-charm guards, left one of the strongest squads on the Pacific Coast behind him at Santa Clara to succeed Harry Stuhldreher as head football coach at Villanova.

Average profit in 1936 of 3.8 per cent was earned by shoe stores that submitted their operating figures in an analysis of operating and merchandising experience conducted by the research and statistical division of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.,

JOURNAL AND LETTERS OF STEPHEN MACKENNA, edited, with a memoir, by E. R. Dodds. (Morrow, $4.) New light on the Irish poet. DOWN THE PROUD STREAM, by Carl Fallas. (Longmans, Green, $2.50.) A novel of the English countryside.

Prices continued their recovery yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and the list ended 4 points higher to 3 points lower. About 50,000 of the 60,000 bales certificated stock was delivered to holders of the October position here.
The May Tyler estate consisting of the thirteen-room house on five acres of land at Smithtown, L. I., has been sold to Mrs. John Reynolds. According to the Clark-Ryle

Anxious to avoid exciting school children over the undeclared Sino - Japanese war, the British Broadcasting Corporation last night cancelled a program in which a Chinese and Japanese were to give their resnective views of the conflict.
Before a crowd which overflowed the courtroom, Mrs. Irene Castle McLaughlin, former dancer, and her husband, Major Frederic McLaughlin, fought the first skirmish in their divorce contest today.
Stocks steadier, closed generally higher in less active trading; turnover, 1,307,540 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds advanced; others mixed; transactions, $7,547,575.

Governor Lehman was asked today to close Belmont Park, one of the outstanding race tracks of the East, as a "public nuisance." Samuel Marcus, a New York City attorney, asked the Governor by letter to direct Attorney General Bennett to apply for a preliminary injunction restraining the Westchester Racing Association from conducting races there.

Francis C. Martin, a Johnstown banker, testified before the National Labor Relations Board today that, during the early days of the Bethlehem steel strike, he received $10,000 as chairman of the Citizens Committee from Sidney D. Evans, "an employee of the Bethlehem Steel Company."

Yesterday's rain and unsettled prospects resulted in the postponement of today's polo game at Meadow Brook in which Old Westbury and Greentree were to have met in the final of the Monty Waterbury Cup tournament.

A new committee for holders of 5 per cent first mortgage bonds of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., has been formed, it was announced yesterday. The group is headed by Sir Henry L. Drayton, former Minister of Finance for Canada.

John L. Haley, president of the Central New York Power Corporation, announced yesterday that "the bearer scrip certificates for fractions of shares of the preferred stock. 5 per cent series, of the Central New York Power Corporation (formerly named Niagara Hudson Public Service Corporation),

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition Filed-By JOHN PAUL CHESTER, bookkeeper, 143 W. 73d St.-Liabilities, $2,724; no assets. WILLIAM FRIEDLIN, bartender, 638 Kelly St.-Liabilities, $6,410; no assets except insurance.

Determined not to permit any mass picketing that would obstruct pedestrian traffic, the police last night arrested ten pickets in a demonstration in front of the Horn Hardart Automat at 1,557 Broadway, between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets.

The body of Brig. Gen. De Witt Clinton Falls, retired, formerly commanding officer of the Seventh Regiment (107th Infantry), New York National Guard, arrived yesterday from England on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. General Falls died on Sept. 7 in London. The body will lie in state in

Robert Wardrop, one of Pittsburgh's outstanding bankers, died at his home in suburban Sewickley early today of pneumonia at the age of 87. He had continued to be active as chairman of the board of the First National Bank until his last illness.
