There will be no increase in the price of milk to consumers in New York City next month, although a seasonal price rise is usual in October. The announcement was made yesterday after a meeting of representatives of the Metropolitan Cooperative Milk Producers Bargaining Agency and the Metropolitan Milk Distributors Bargaining Agency in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
The F. E. Myers Brother Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents a common share. The company paid $1.25 on Sept. 27, $1 on June 26 and $1 on March 26.
There is a unanimously anxious deadlock here tonight over what to do about Spain. It developed in a public debate in the Assembly's political commission.

Three years ago Mr. Wickham Steed wrote an alarming article for The Nineteenth Century and After in which he presented seemingly official documents to prove that the Air Gas Attack Department of the German War Office had been conducting experiments in Paris and London since 1931 for the purpose of ascertaining how underground railway systems could best be infected with deadly germs in an attack. Now comes the Deutsche Wehr,

The Foreign Ministry denied today that any one connected with the Argentine Embassy in Madrid was involved in a Rebel plot. The Spanish Government charged several South American embassies and legations were involved.

The golden wedding anniversary of Mr. and Mrs. James Reilly of 168 Glenwood Avenue, Yonkers, will be observed this morning at 9 o'clock with a nuptial mass at the Monastery of the Sacred Heart, Yonkers.

The marriage of Miss Anne Marie Semler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans J. Semler of Huntington Bay Hills, to John Edward Mahoney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Denis A. Mahoney of New York and Freeport, took place this morning at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church here. The Rev. Harry Hammer of

Labeling the opposition "Red" and calling for a "free police" is the "Hitler way," Israel Amter, State chairman of the Communist party, declared yesterday in reply to attacks by Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic nominee for Mayor, and Abraham Kaplan, Mr. Mahoney's campaign manager, charging "Red" influences in the support of Mayor La Guardia.

A newsreel photographer, here to take pictures in the air, was shot down to safety today by a marksman priest after a cluster of thirty balloons had carried the cameraman on an unscheduled and unwanted flight of thirteen miles, at altitudes ranging to 2,000 feet, over an alarmed countryside.
Sales of small lots of print cloths in second hands at concessions of 1/16 cent under mill quotations developed yesterday, but gray goods otherwise were quiet and steady.
Despite a determined fight in the executive committee of the New York County Republican Committee to make him the nominee of the Republican party as well as of Tammany Hall, Justice Aaron J.

On the show grounds of the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, L. I., the first session of the thirtyfifth annual Piping Rock horse show will be held this afternoon. The exhibition will continue through Saturday to complete a four-day program of seventy competitions.

Although attacks upon recent Federal legislation continued to mark its proceedings, the American Bar Association, through its leaders, took steps today to temper the bitterness of the criticisms of the New Deal voiced at its opening session yesterday.

Commenting on a report from Nanking in yesterday's NEW YOR TlLES to the effect that the Rockefeller Foundation might withdraw its yearly appropriation for Chinese Government institutions, Raymond B. Fosdick, president of the foundation, said yesterday that "no decision has been made by the Rockefeller Foundation in relation to its work in China."

Dr. Leopold Sachse, stage director of the Metropolitan Opera Association, has been appointed to the faculty of the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music. He will lecture on the history and esthetics of opera.

The Foreign Ministry denied today that any one connected with the Argentine Embassy in Madrid was involved in a Rebel plot. The Spanish Government charged several South American embassies and legations were involved.

The golden wedding anniversary of Mr. and Mrs. James Reilly of 168 Glenwood Avenue, Yonkers, will be observed this morning at 9 o'clock with a nuptial mass at the Monastery of the Sacred Heart, Yonkers.

The marriage of Miss Anne Marie Semler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans J. Semler of Huntington Bay Hills, to John Edward Mahoney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Denis A. Mahoney of New York and Freeport, took place this morning at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church here. The Rev. Harry Hammer of

Labeling the opposition "Red" and calling for a "free police" is the "Hitler way," Israel Amter, State chairman of the Communist party, declared yesterday in reply to attacks by Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic nominee for Mayor, and Abraham Kaplan, Mr. Mahoney's campaign manager, charging "Red" influences in the support of Mayor La Guardia.

Holders of Irish Free State external 5 per cent bonds, due on Nov. 1,1960, will be notified today that $12,000 of the issue was drawn by lot for redemption at par on Nov. 1. Payment will be made at the National City Bank.

The total for electric power production was slightly lower last week. However, the daily average increased against an unchanged seasonal trend and, after adjustment for an upward long-term trend, the index rose to 104.7 from 104.2. The index was 105.3 for the week ended Sept. 26, 1936.

Officials of the Polo Association announced yesterday that the final round of the Waterbury Cup tournament, in which the Greentree and Old Westbury teams are to meet in the last high-goal contest of the season, has been scheduled now for Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock.

Secession of fifteen members from the League of Women Voters after a secret meeting on Monday was revealed last night. The participants. who had pledged silence on the subject, disapproved of the unification of all the borough units under one head.

Playing under perfect weather conditions, Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of Queens Valley led a field of twenty-five to capture the low gross honors with a score of 43, 41-84 in the Long Island Women's Golf Association one-day tournament at the North Hempstead Country Club today.
Lady Castlerosse, wife of Viscount Castlerosse, who will arrive on the Normandie, will be at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mr. and Mrs. Edward Nay Morris will pass the Winter at the Madison.

Total sales in August of reporting wholesale firms averaged about 1 per cent higher, than last year, following the decline reported for July, according to the monthly re-port of the Federal Reserve Bank. Cotton goods concerns showed the largest increase in sales since last February,

A warning against inflation was delivered by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, still Economic Minister and Reichsbank president, today, in addressing 4,000 leading savings bank directors assembled at Essen for the first conference in four years.

" Health Day," to impress upon pupils the importance of freedom from physical defects, will be observed today in the public schools of this city, according to an announcement by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

The short afternoon program that opened the four-day Piping Rock horse show today attracted members of society to the ringside and provided an occasion for afternoon tea at the Piping Rock Club and at near-by homes.

Stocks recovered losses of 1 to 4 points and closed with irregular gains; turnover, 1,353,530 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds generally higher, foreign issues lower; transactions, $7,428,000.

The Transit Commission struck back at the Citizens Union yesterday in a letter charging that organization with misstatement of facts in its drive to get the 1938 Legislature to abolish the commission.

As a result of investigations conducted by Dr. Alexander Gettler, city toxicologist, and experts from the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, it was determined yesterday that deaths of Anthony Niosi, 25 years old, and his wife, Mary, were due to carbon monoxide poisoning which escaped from a defective refrigerator.

Amid cheers from C. I O. longshoremen, A. F. of L. teamsters abandoned their blockade of the waterfront today and went back to work on the docks while their leaders vowed that they would continue along other lines their "finish fight" against the stevedores for control of warehousemen.

The Indians scored their second ten-inning victory in two days over the White Sox, 5 to 4, today in the first game of a double-header, but Chicago gained an even break by winning the nightcap, which was called because of darkness after four and one-half innings, 1 to 0.
Approval of the appointment of six men to form the National Advisory Cancer Council was announced today by Secretary Morgenthau.
The New York Football Yankees outplayed the Cedarhurst F. C. tonight at the Municipal Stadium before a crowd of 3,000 to win, 29 to 7.

AREASONABLY precocious child could almost read Mr. van Loon's new book* before he could lift it. "The Arts"-Clive Bell once wrote a considerably slimmer book and just called it "Art" is a very large book on a fairly wide subject.

Justice Black reached the home of his brother-in-law, Clifford J. Durr, soon after 6 o'clock tonight and there in quiet Alexandria began immediately to draft a speech he proposes to deliver to the nation, probably Saturday or Sunday, to "explain" his alleged connection with the Ku Klux Klan.
The heroism of twenty Chinese soldiers cost their lives early today but failed in a dramatic attempt to sink the cruiser Izumo, Japanese flagship at Shanghai.

Williams devoted today's session to running through plays on Cole Field in preparation for Saturday's game with Columbia. Coach Charlie Caldwell followed yesterday's long scrimmage in the rain by polishing up on fundamentals and again emphasized kicking.

Bundles of records, books and contribution lists of the Citizens' Committee were submitted this afternoon at the National Labor Relations Board's investigation into the Bethlehem steel strike by George C. Rutledge, secretary-treasurer of the Johnstown Bank and Trust Company, who was treasurer of the committee.

The experience gained in England through the construction of 3,250,000 houses since the World War has shown that an effective low-cost housing program can be devised which would provide homes for 85 per cent of the potential small-house market without governmental subsidy, according to John W. Laing, British builder.
Cornell's first and second elevens were given a long defensive drill against Colgate formations in a dummy scrimmage with the scrubs today.

Three years of increasing sales gaines have proved the value of the woman's viewpoint in retailing, Mrs. Hortense M. Odlum, president of Bonwit, Teller Co., said yesterday in an interview marking her third anniversary as head of the Fifth Avenue specialty shop. Mrs. Odlum, the only woman chief executive of a large retail enterprise in this country, will be tendered a reception this afternoon by the employes of the store.

The optimism which greeted the announcement last week of the Anglo-French invitation to Italy for a three-power discussion of non-intervention in Spain has given place to a feeling of nervousness and pessimism following publication in the Italian press of the Geneva speech by Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos of France yesterday.

It was learned here today that a final agreement between, the Opposition parties in Yugoslavia will be signed tomorrow at Zagreb. The agreement includes a demand for immediate abolition of the present Constitution, forced on the nation during the late King Alexander's personal rule, and the forming of a concentration government, composed of the leaders of all parties and thus having the support of the whole nation.

Ray C. Ewry, maker of world's records a generation ago in the standing high and standing broad jumps, who won more Olympic championships than any other athlete in the world, American or foreign, died last night at his home, 343 Ridge Road, Douglas Manor, Queens, after a three-month illness. On Oct. 14 he would have been 63 years old.

Ending five years of rivalry as the governing organizations of the contract bridge world, the American Bridge League and the United States Bridge Association announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge into the American Bridge Association, which will take over the activities of its two predecessors beginning with the national championship tournament in Washington Nov. 29.
A group of high-ranking Japanese agreed today to practice "honorable shabbiness" to reduce Japan's textile imports.
MAINHATTAN BAAB, MARY M. (March 13, 1936). Gross assets, $411,540; net, $392,125. To the estate of Mary C. Baab Bayer, daughter. Chief assets, transfers, $301,329. Beam Cullen, attorneys, 67 Wall St.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 12,000, including 4,000 directs. The market was steady to 10 cents lower than Tuesday's average: bulk good and choice 180-230 pounds. $11.90-$12.15;

Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, candidate for District Attorney of New York County, charged last night that the "flabby operation of justice," in which "lazy and incompetent" enforcement officials failed to make a determined effort to overcome the fears of witnesses, was responsible for the success of racketeering in New York.
A piano was loaded on an airplane here today as part of the first consignment carried by a new air service devoted exclusively to freight haulage between Great Britain and continental cities.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society has received $18,000 in new subscriptions through the efforts of various committees, it was reported yesterday at the first Fall meeting of the committee on subscription activities at Steinway Hall.
The Rev. J. Roger Smith, Professor of Ethics at St. Joseph's College here, died this afternoon in his rooms at the college after a lingering illness.

Highland Worthy, a bay gelding by Highland Scott from Daisy Brooks, owned by Robert Hoeffner of New Hyde Park and driven by the veteran, Jerry George, came within one-quarter of a second of the track record in the second heat of the 2:12 pacing race at the Fair Grounds today, finishing in 2:06 3/4.
Night polo made its first appearance on Long Island tonight when the promoters of Bostwick Field put on a game under are lights. The Boys Club of New York shared in the receipts.

The first of a series of mass meetings to acquaint residents of Westchester County with the provisions of the new charter, to be submitted to a referendum on Nov. 2, was held tonight in the Mamaroneck Junior High School.

On Sept. 21 The Associated Press carried a story erroneously quoting Sheriff Michael J. Boyle as having testified in the National Labor Relations Board case against Bethlehem Steel that C. R. Ellicott, general manager of the Cambria works, was "very enthusiastic" about asking the Governor for martial law during the Summer's steel strike.

Joseph P. Ripley, chairman of the bondholders' representative committee of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, replying to the contentions of the new bondholders' defensive committee that his committee's plan would deprive present bondholders of their first-mortgage position,

Sharp declines in prices for rayon fabrics since early Summer have made possible use of better quality goods in low-priced dresses, it was learned yesterday, and a number of manufacturers now are using cloths in $2.25 dresses which were put into the $2.87 1/2 range when Fall lines were being prepared.

The large one-family dwelling on a half-acre plot at 678 Cornaga Avenue, Lawrence, L. I., has been sold by Elizabeth -Schirling to a client of Charles Buermann Co., Inc., brokers in the deal. The property adjoins one of the town's two golf courses and is within a short distance of Atlantic Beach.

General financing policies of the Treasury, including the advisability of substituting another type of security for the 273-day Treasury discount bills now sold weekly, were discussed today at a meeting of the executive committee of the Federal Reserve's open market committee with Secretary Morgenthau.

By the light of a silvery moon, which did not seem to fit in very well with the less romantic business at hand, the Giants missed their way toward clinching the National League pennant today when darkness closed down on their efforts to bag both ends of a double-header from the Phillies.

His holiness directs an encyclical letter on the rosary of the Blessed Virgin Mary to the Catholic Episcopate in order to exhort all the faithful to practice of this devotion, especially during the coming month of October.

The British Cabinet, determined to bring about withdrawal of foreign fighters in Spain, yesterday pushed its effort to get Rome to discuss the question. It approved the draft of an AngloFrench note inviting Italy to a three-power conference. [Page 1.]

1st Lt. Harry G. Drapeau, QM-Res., 27 Henry St., Jersey City, N. J., 521st Quartermaster Regiment, is ordered to active duty for a period of six months, effective Oct. 1. He will proceed to Headquarters, Schenectady District, CCC, Schenectady, N. Y., for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities.

Mr. Justice Black is of course entitled to choose his own time and place for any statement he may make, but in fairness to himself, to the President who appointed him, to the Senate which confirmed him, to the court of which he is a member and to the nation which holds that court in high respect, this statement should deal specifically with the questions which have been asked.

Passengers arriving today on the French liner Normandie include William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to France; Dr. Alexis Carrel, Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler, Pierre Cartier, Mrs. Vincent Astor, Mrs. Isaac Gimbel, Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Claudel, Countess de Zoppola, Countess de Camargo, Lady Castelrosse.

Hundreds of telegrams and telephone calls praising Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, for his attack on Mayor La Guardia's radical supporters and the Mayor's "radical tendencies" were received yesterday at Mahoney campaign headquarters.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, pleaded with shipowners yesterday to remain neutral in the fight between conflicting maritime labor interests to the end that the Government, acting through the board, may settle disputes with a minimum of trouble.

Louis J. Taber of Columbus, Ohio, master of the National Grange, in an address today at the New Jersey State Fair here, advocated amending of the Constitution to make all public employes, including judiciary, subject to income taxes.
Frank Phelps, born in New York City ninety-two years ago and a resident of Stamford for fifty-eight years, died at his home here yesterday, 92 Lindale Street.
At the request of prospective bidders, an auction sale of the interests of Florenz Ziegfeld in seventy-two of his best-known theatrical productions was postponed today to Oct. 15.

A design for a new type of railroad locomotive-steam-turbine powered and capable of traveling 120 miles an hour-was was described today by L. P. Michael, chairman of the steam turbine and condensing locomotive committee, at the annual meeting of the Railway Fuel and Traveling Engineers Association,

Mrs. Edward A. Emerson of the Hortulus Garden Club received not only the highest rating but seven A's or 100 per cent in one of the special classes today at the annual flower show of the Westchester and Fairfield Horticultural Society and Greenwich and Rye garden clubs.

Dr. Ralph C. Jenkins was installed today as president of Danbury Teachers College at exercises in Fairfield Hall. Dr. W. E. Butterfield, Commissioner of Education, formally installed the president, following the ceremony of establishling the college, and opening the four-year course, which succeeds the three-year course in the Danbury Normal School.

Attorney General Cummings today classed the report made by Chief Justice Hughes and the senior Circuit Court judges as a "complete capitulation" to the argument raised by President Roosevelt and his Administration that the Federal Judicial system was behind in its work and needed more judges.
Persistent rumors from abroad of the death of ex-Kaiser Wilhelm of Germany is beginning to annoy both official circles here and the ex-monarch's entourage at Doorn.

Barnard College has added twenty new members to the faculty, it was announced yesterday. Dr. Henry A. Boorse was named Assistant Professor of Physics and executive head of the Barnard section of that department.

Things happened all in a rush yesterday for Nicholas Prathastakis and his eight small, motherless children. He took seven of the youngsters, who range in age from 7 months to 10 years, to Children's Court. He had been accused of neglecting them, and he knew there was a chance he might lose them.
Governor Charles F. Hurley today invited Governor E. D. Rivers of Georgia to partake of the hospitality of New England over the chalk lines of the football gridiron.

Forms sent to its members last night by the New York Security Dealers Association answer one vexed question in connection with the new rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission for over-thecounter dealings, which will become effective tomorrow.

Contracts for all types of construction awarded during the first eight months of this year in the New York area were valued at more than $315,000,000, according to a summary by the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

The marriage of Miss Verna Green; daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Green of Redlands, Calif., to William Weston Bray, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Bray of Syracuse, N. Y., took place here yesterday morning in the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church.

A total of 110 new members has been added to the roster of the United Hunts Racing Association, according to an announcement yesterday by Lewis E. Waring, secretary-treasurer of the organization. Mr. Waring also announced that the purses would be increased for the coming Fall meeting, which will be held at Belmont Park on election day. Nov. 2.

Transfer and Assignments PATROLMAN-Alfred Whitenack, from 103d Precinct to 18th Division, assigned to duty as chauffeur. Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANT-Ivo F. Vogel, from 108th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. Office, Queens County. for 1 day.
The fast-stepping Cubs made it three straight over the Reds today, cashing in on six hits allowed by Gene Schott to win, 3 to 0.
Mrs. Paul Redfern, whose husband disappeared ten years ago on an airplane flight to South America, disclosed today that she was preparing to ask that he be declared legally dead. Several expeditions,
Hearings on the Old Colony Railroad's $18,000,000 claim against the New Haven Railroad, arising out of the disaffirmance of the latter's lease of the former, was adjourned today to Oct. 14.
The Greater City Master Plumbers Association, through its attorney, pointed out yesterday that it had reached no agreement with the Alteration Plumbers,

With the contest rules altered in the hope of eliminating the cause of last season's controversy, the second play competition for awards, fellowships and scholarships sponsored by the Bureau of New Plays, will open officially tomorrow, Theresa Helburn, head of the bureau, announced yesterday.

In these changing modern times, when the average apartment tenant family moves every two years or so, those of the old school who look back sentimentally to the days when a man was likely to live out his life in the house where he was born will find some consolation in the news that a tenant in the house at 101 West Eightieth Street has been there for thirty-seven years.

President Roosevelt relaxed for the first time today since he started his Western tour a week ago. Secluded from visitors at the home of his son-inlaw and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. John Boettiger, much of his time was spent with Mrs. Boettiger's two children, Eleanor and Curtis Dall.

The agrarian policy of the government reached today into San Luis Potosi, home state of General Saturnino Cedillo, one of its leading opponents. Gabino Vazquez, head of the Agrarian Department, who arrived there yesterday, promised 500 groups of peasants who had filed petitions for land that steps would be taken forthwith to break up big haciendas and meet their demands.
The British Air Ministry has approved the sale Of airplanes of British manufacture to China, it was reported today in unofficial but well-informed quarters.

Stocked with a fair proportion of letter winners from last year, Peddie School's football squad participated in a two-hour drill today in preparation for Saturday's scheduled opener with Adelphi Academy that will serve as the first test in the role of head coach for Larry Kelley, of Yale fame.
John W. Davis has accepted the i chairmanship of the 1937 United Hospital Campaign, David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund, announced yesterday.
The directors of the Hackensack Water Company decided yesterday to withdraw the petition that had been filed with the Public Utility Commission of New Jersey covering a refinancing program.

The New York City Omnibus Corporation, a consolidation of the Madison Avenue Coach Company, Inc., and the Eight Avenue Coach Corporation, reported yesterday for August a net income of $100,142 before Federal surtax on undistributed profits and tax on excess profits and before a deduction of $19,353 charged to income in respect to the provision for amortization of "the amount to be amortized on the basis of the recapture contract in monthly instaiments."

In the last three weeks twelve contracts for factory construction in ten different industries have been signed by the Austin Company, industrial engineers and builders, George A. Bryant Jr., executive vice president, announced yesterday.

The National Council of Catholic Women voted at its closing session today its "sincere sympathy, its prayers and its charity" to the women and children suffering from the "cruel internecine war" in Spain, resolved by "study and by action"

The Board of Education voted unanimously today to issue $6,650,000 of 20-year bonds to meet obligations now in default because of delinquent taxes. Advertising of the prospective issue, to be dated Nov. 1, will begin within a week and bids probably will be opened late in October.

J. W. Seligman Co., fiscal agents for the State Mortgage Bank of Yugoslavia, announced yesterday that the bank had deposited funds sufficient to pay 15 per cent of the face amount of all Oct. 1 coupons on $3,545,500 of secured 7 per cent bonds of the bank due in 1957 which were reported to be in circulation outside of Yugoslavia.

William Fellowes Morgan, Commissioner of Markets, intervened yesterday in the threatened closing of shops by the Federation of Kosher Butchers, scheduled to begin tomorrow afternoon, by inviting officials of the federation, who say they represent some 5,000 retail distributors, to confer with him at his office at 1 P. M. today.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens told more than 1,000 persons attending a testimonial dinner in his honor last night that the only persons opposing him for re-election "are the radicals from across the river." Mr. Harvey said that there were only two issues in his election campaign, one being his record of nine years in office and the other his fight for Americanism.
A jury of ten women and two men today convicted Robert Burke, ousted Columbia University student, of rioting here on June 10 at the time of the steel strike.

Upholding the defense plea of justifiable provocation, a Montreal jury acquitted today Joseph Fuentes, Almeria-born Spaniard, who was charged with willfully causing $20 damage to the picture of Adolf Hitler in the office of the German Consulate here.

Maxwell Anderson and his crew of playmakers are back. They put on "The Star-Wagon" at the Empire last evening and restored theatre-going to the status of a ileged profession. Although Mr. Anderson is not the most original playwright in the world nor the

Jacob Emil Leitner. Inc, has placed a permanent mortgage of $155.000 on the recently completed six-story apartment at 111-19 Mount Hope Place, the Bronx, for Framan Holding Corporation, Louis Gordon, president, with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

MANHATTAN TRANSFERS 5th St. 34-40 E, 92x98.9; Commurch Holding Corp. Alva F. Hughes, president, to Community Church (Second Congregational Unitarian Church), 550 W 110th St. (50c). 10th St., 319 W. 20x100.11: I. Maurice Wormser, referee, to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp, trustee, 346 Bway;
Evidence that Japan is in China for no selfish reasons may be found in Carl Crow's book "400,000,000 Customers." Mr. Crow says that in the

The Mexican Supreme Court enjoined today the seizure by the Finance Department of the home of Sefiora Genoveva Vera, sister of Puebla's Archbishop, which had been ordered because the Archbishop resided there. The Archbishop's sister claimed the house was her property, which was accepted by the court.
Plans for placing this city's oldest schoolhouse in the rear yard of the Newark Museum to be preserved for posterity were announced today by Samuel Roessler, president of the Board of Education.

The idea of transferring the problem of Japanese hostilities in China to a committee of nations with interests in the Pacific had hard sledding in the Far Eastern Advisory Committee of the League of Nations, sitting publicly today.

Conferences on the possible necessity for appropriations in the 1938 budget for resumption of service on foreign bonds are to be held by the House Budget Committee, a few Senators and the Finance Minister in case the recent negotiations with the Minister by Dana Munro, representing the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., result in a definite arrangement.

In view of the interest in the course of trade and industry excited by the break of stocks, the statistical summaries of August's business, just given out, are interesting. The last half of August witnessed a 9-point decline in Stock Exchange "averages," but all the summaries of that month's business activities are favorable.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said tonight that treatment given to various classes of creditors under a modified plan for reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad "is probably as equitable as can be arrived at."

Only one common school district out of three in the vicinity of Northport has voted funds for bus hire to transport pupils to St. Philip Neri parochial school in Northport, it was announced today by A. M. Jones, district superintendent of schools.

Announcement was made here today of the marriage in Toronto on Monday of Miss Phyllis Barber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Henry Barber of Guelph, Ont., to James Frederick Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Miller of Roland Park, Baltimore.
Finance Minister Georges Bonnet, in an optimistic mood, tonight announced the success of the conversion of the 41/2 per cent 1934 bonds falling due in October.
John B. Reardon, a policeman who died a bachelor on Aug. 25, at the age of 63, left $50,000 in savings bank deposits. Th books were discovered today hidden in his home.

Professor Charles Vaillant, called the X-ray martyr, today underwent his fourteenth operation, a stomach incision, made necessary by his voluntary exposure to X-rays during his lifelong radium research work.

A BIG fellow with a wide-open, wind-burned countenance breezed in, said "Howdy" in a hearty voice and launched immediately into an inspiring oration on the Texas A. and M. football squad, the outfit that will tackle Manhattan at the Polo Grounds this Saturday.

A hard hitting British Guiana batting partnership of Peter Bayley and C. S. Persaud sent records tumbling today to send the home team far in front of Barbados in their threeday match for the right to meet Trinidad in intercolonial championship games.

There is no evidence after the Italian departure today that, despite the smiles they exchanged and the show of cordiality they somewhat ostentatiously put on whenever they were together in public, Premier Mussolini and Chancellor Hitler like each other any better after II Duce's visit than they did at their first meeting, in Venice three years ago.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Under the Soil Conservation Act and pending ever-normal-granary proposal, when one considers the mild control to which agriculture was subjected by the government and the large amount of benefits, direct and indirect, which it received, one cannot fail to detect a considerable disparity between the two.

A new name was added today tc the winners of the Frank Melville Jr. Memorial Challenge Cup fox this year, when the big chestnut gelding Sun Faun was placed at the top of a field of twenty-five at the opening session of the thirty-fifth annual Piping Rock Horse Show.
There was published yesterday an authoritative report which throws fresh light on one of the important points involved in the controversy over the President's court reorganization plan.

President Mustafa Kemal Ataturk denies there will be a constitutional change following the resignation of Prime Minister General Ismet Inonu. The President has named Jelal Bayar, Minister of National Economy, to act as Prime Minister until the Grand National Assembly convenes Nov. 1.

Genie Palatine, one of the most consistent and most heavily campaigned fillies in training, triumphed yesterday in the sixty-seventh Ladies' Handicap, featured event at Belmont Park, for which only three faced the starter.
The Yankees rounded the century mark yesterday amid a shower of base hits, a monotonous procession of runs and a spirit of good, clean fun that may cost somebody some money or bring a reprimand.

Dr. Mary H. S. Hayes, director of the Junior Placement Service of the National Youth Administration, said today that 5,716 young men and women were placed in jobs in private industry during July, and that 5,777 others were placed in August.

The entire output of the Great Lakes Paper Company, Ltd., has been sold for eight years, C. H. Carlisle, president, announced today. Notice was given to the bondholders of the company that the interest due on Oct. 1 will be paid on that date.

The possibility that Matthew Woll will ask the American Federation of Labor at its Denver convention to petition Congress for withdrawal from the International Labor Office, as reported in the European press, perturbs- I. L. O. officials here although they decline to comment.

The firm of Albert Graef, Inc. has been formed at 70 Pine Street, to conduct a general investment business. It includes Albert Graef, president; Eduard Wallach, vice president; Norbert Roesler, vice president, and Theodore Thiesing, secretary.

Midnight tonight will mark the deadline for making application for renewal of automobile operators' licenses. To handle the thousands of late comers expected today additional cashiers, clerks, examiners and inspectors have taken extra space in the basement of the State Building at 80 Centre Street.

Quotations of French franc futures again broke sharply yesterday although the price of the spot franc continued to be held up by official support. At one time during the day the discount on French exchange for delivery three months hence widened to 261/4 points, which was equal on an annual basis to 303/4 per cent. Subsequently this discount was reduced to 22 1/2 points, compared with 19 1/2 points on Tuesday.

Bruce Coltart, long-hitting pro from the Woodcrest County Club, Haddonfield, N. J., and Matt Kowal of Philmont marched into the final of the Philadelphia Professional Golfers Association tournament by scoring two victories each day. They will meet for the title Sunday.

The tightness of the army's purse strings kept down the noise in the battle of Indiantown Gap today. The spat-spat of machine guns and rifles and the roar of the motors of the new fifty-mile-anhour tanks and observation planes reverberated down the narrow mountain valley, but the army hasn't enough money to let the big guns go.

Nicaragua's commission for control of foreign exchange operations, composed of J. B. Ramirez, Minister of Finance; James H. Edwards, manager of the National Bank of Nicaragua, and Irving A. Lindberg, Collector General of Customs and High Commissioner, announced today that the present rate of exchange, two cordobas to the dollar, would be maintained until June 30, 1938.

The Mussolini visit to Germany was a demonstration, not a conference. The one thing clear in the accounts of the four-day performance is that the two dictators had little time for serious private discussions. They traveled on separate trains, and each day's program was filled from morning until night with public appearances.
New York City gained 6,703 factories from 1933 to 1935, an increase of 34.9 per cent, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday.

Lieut. Col. T. Takahashi, an officer of the general staff in Tokyo, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria bound for Europe on a special military mission that will take him round the world. He will return to Tokyo from Moscow over the Transsiberian Railway.

Henry D. Riley, 20 years old, a Princeton University freshman from Southern Pines, N. C., accidentally wounded himself in the right leg tonight with a revolver while unpacking his luggage in a university rooming house.

Debta of 62,099 farmers were reduced by $51,423,010, or 25.2 per cent, in the two years ended on Aug. -31, the Farm Security Administration announced today, as a result of the voluntary farm-debt adjustment program of the administration.

J. Laurence Meader, president of Russell Sage College, called upon members of the State Nurses Association today to fulfill their responsibilities as "professional men and women of high ideals" by assuming leadership in community affairs.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 28: COLONELS Baldwin. T. A., Jr., Air Corps, two months and one day leave, Sept. 29. Schley, J. L., Eng'rs, Ft. Belvoir, Va., to office of Chief of Engineers, Washington, D. C.

The twenty-sixth annual Fall vegetable and flower show of the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society opened this afternoon in the parish house of Christ Episcopal Church with more than 100 classes in what was described by judges and gardeners as the best show in several years.
Japanese sources reported tonight that their infantry in Northern Shansi Province was engaged in a daring offensive in the high mountains surrounding the city of Taichow.

The golfing prowess of the mysterious John Montague of California, the former LaVerne Moore of upper New York State, which is believed by many people to be something of a myth, was proved once again at the North Hempstead Country Club today, where, playing in a friendly game with four other players, Montague carded a sensational 65, five strokes under par for the 6,265-yard layout.

Walter Huston, who played the role of Abraham Lincoln for First National in the picture of that name in 1931, will do for Metro-GoldwynMayer the role of Lincoln, this time in "Benefits Forgot," in which he has the leading role as well. Mr.

Roger W. Babson, economist, and Mrs. Babson sailed yesterday on the Berengaria of the Cunard White Star Line for a two-month trip in Europe. Mr. Babson said he was going to get the "real story of conditions in Europe."
Joint annual Fall meeting. American section of the Universal Christian Council and the World Conference on Faith and Order, George Washington Hotel. 10 A. M.

One hundred and twenty-four scholarships and eight fellowships, with a total value of $55,289, have been awarded by the Columbia University Law School, it was announced yesterday by Dean Young B. Smith, who also named eleven students to the staff of The Columbia Law Review.

The Duke of Kent today "played himself in" as captain of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club by a 60-yard drive off the first tee. Accompanied by Sir John Simon, the retiring captain, the Duke appeared somewhat nervous as he looked down the fairway where groups of caddies were gathered at various distances to retrieve the ball.
Stockholders of the Railroad Employes Corporation approved yesterday an increase in its authorized Class A common stock from 60,000 to 250,000 no-par shares. There are 48,981 shares outstanding.

The Arctic storm of the last sixty hours appears to be abating after forcing heavy icebergs against the supply ship of the MacGregor Arctic Expedition this morning, breaking two ten-inch hawsers. The ship's third anchor continued to drag and hold.

A consumers' boycott against Japanese goods, particularly silk, is suggested as a means to help end the Japanese invasion of China in an editorial appearing in the current issue of The Nation. Offering the slogan "Don't Buy Silk," the editorial points out that,

The John Irving Shoe Corporation reported yesterday for the six months ended on July 31 a net profit of $156,239 after expenses and charges, but before provision for surtax on undistributed earnings. After dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock, the profit was equivalent to $1.12 a share on the 122,918 shares of $1 par common stock.

Druggists attending this afternoon's sessions of the National Association of Retail Druggists at the Hotel Jefferson here were warned by United States Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland to observe carefully the provisions of the Tydings-Miller Act.

The longrange destructive power of modern aircraft caused British insurance companies today to cease issuing war risk insurance. Citing the havoc wrought by bombing planes in Spain and China, nearly 300 British companies issued a statement declaring the developments of aerial warfare have introduced an incalculable hazard in such insurance.

Edward F. Roosevelt, New York World's Fair commissioner for Central and South America, after a conference with President Anastasio Somoza and members of the Cabinet, announced today that Nicaragua would participate in the 1939 exposition.
The Pirates overcame a two-run deficit in the seventh inning today to beat the Cardinals, 7 to 5, after both starting pitchers had been shelled out.

The defensive performances of five sophomore linemen and the absence of two outstanding regulars, out with minor injuries, marked another long scrimmage between the first and second Dartmouth elevens today.
F. Adair Monroe, president of the Cuba Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that it was doubtful that the company would have as good a year as in the immediate past.

Influenced by a sharp decline in prices of cotton abroad and by continued favorable weather for maturing and picking the crop in this country, prices on the Cotton Exchange here moved lower yesterday to end with losses of 8 to 16 points, or 40 to 80 cents a bale.
The racing yacht Endeavour I, which broke away from its tow Sept. 13 while returning from America, was sighted again today.

The next to the last step in winding up the receivership of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company, which brought six years of litigation, was taken today when Chancellor Josiah O. Wolcott signed an order authorizing the newly elected directors to borrow about $1,100,000 to pay off costs of the litigation and all obligations.

The names of the eight winners of Edward Langley scholarships for this year, aggregating $4,900 and designed to "promote higher education in architecture," were announced here yesterday by the the American Institute of Architects, sponsors of the awards, on behalf of Edwin Bergstrom of Los Angeles treasurer of the institute and chairman of the committee making the awards.

Upholding Mayor La Guardia's attitude toward labor disputes, Police Commissicner Valentine asserted yesterday that the policy of "absolute neutrality" in strikes had been observed by the police throughout the administration. He spoke at a luncheon of the Citizens Budget Commission in the Hotel Astor.
Premier Mussolini left Berlin this afternoon carrying with him as the final event of his visit tbe impression of an imposing display of Germany's military strength.
All-day negotiations left the League of Nations still deadlocked over what resolution to adopt on the Spanish war. The deadlock seemed less complete than it was yesterday.

The charge of homicide against Miss Gertrude O'Keefe, 37-year-old typist, in the slaying of her former fiance, George 0. Frank, 47 years old, a teller employed by the New York Stock Exchange, was dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Charles Solomon in Brooklyn Felony Court on the ground it was supported by insufficient evidence.

Former Senator J. Thomas Heflin of Alabama was a special attorney for the Department of Justice, at a salary of $6,000, for about a year until ten days ago, it was revealed through questions put to Attorney General Cummings today.

A bright, warm sun beat down on Ruppert Stadium as the Little World Series, pitting the International League's wonder team, the Newark Bears, against the Columbus Red Birds of the American Association, got under way today.

Henry T. (Dick) Merrill, Eastern Airlines pilot, who was fined $500 by the Bureau of Air Commerce recently for alleged failure to observe regulations in a take-off with passengers from the Washington Airport, filed an affidavit today defending his position.

Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman, conductor of the band bearing his name, yesterday disclosed that a new march composed by him would inaugurate his series of concerts at Kismet Temple, 92 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, Sunday afternoon, Oct. 17.

Litte Rock's Travelers, 1937 champions of the Southern Association, defeated the third place Atlanta Crackers in the deciding game of their play-off, 5-2, today for the right to meet the Fort Worth Texas Leaguers in the Dixie series.
As a title to be taken literally, not colloquially, "Sophie Lang Goes West"--the newcomer at the Criterion--is at once specific and vaguely foreboding.

The marriage of Miss Adele Matison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dave A. Matison of this city, to Abner Freeman, son of Mr. and, Mrs. David Freeman of Minneapolis, took place here yesterday in Temple Knesseth Israel.

The number of undergraduates playing intercollegiate football at Princeton University this Fall was raised above the 250 mark today as ninety-five and ninety-three candidates, respectively, reported for the varsity 150-pound and freshman squads.

Rather than take any chances of injuries before the opening game with Maryland, the Pennsylvania coaches eliminated all contact work today and had the varsity eleven polish up its running and passing plays.

Sharp differences of opinion as to the method of severing connections with the Committee for Industrial Organization unions, which were suspended a year ago, were disclosed among American Federation of Labor leaders today upon the arrival of William D. Hutcheson, burly president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters.

Rumors were current in some political circles today that Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, would be the choice of President Roosevelt to succeed James A. Farley as Postmaster General when the latter retires to join the reorganized Pierce-Arrow Company.

New York newspaper executives were hosts at luncheon and golf today at the Westchester Country Club to members of the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York. It was a return engagement, the retailers having been hosts at a tournament in June.
Fewer students are needing financial aid to carry on their college courses this year, according to Emory E. Grayson, director of placement at Massachusetts State College.

Dr. F. L. Hardy, a dentist here, who had kept his. deer gun handy for months during a wave of attempted bank robberies in Michigan, fired twice through his office window today and brought down two fleeing bandits, killing one.

Major and Mrs. Schoolfield Grace of Locust Valley, L. I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Grace's daughter, Miss Frances Sloan Worrall, to George Edgar Ward, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Mortimer Ward, also of Locust Valley.
Four hundred and forty-eight CCC youths, all residing in New York or New Jersey, arrived here today on two special trains from camps in California and the Northwest.

No comet of any note now illuminates our skies, yet there are signs and portents. A photographer, going up with a cluster of balloons to take pictures of a country club, has had to be shot down. A consignment of barkless dogs has arrived. First jury with women members to hear a divorce suit in New York City has just voted in favor of the complaining husband.

Terming "unworkable" the revised plan for reorganization of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company, Federal Judge George A. Welsh today virtually blocked the $133,000,000 program and stunned most of the interests that have been seeking to solve the city's transit problems.

The Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today that a resident foreign corporation derives income subject to Federal income tax by reason of the purchase in the United States of its bonds for less than the face value or issuing price.
Ross and Kelley vs. Gomez and Vance. Boston at Washington (2)-McKain and Wilson vs. Phebus and Chase. Detroit at St. Louis-Bridges vs. Muncrief.
A long scrimmage today between the Navy varsity and plebes was featured by the stalwart defense of the latter. The big backfield, with Bill Ingram absent, appeared punchless. Captain Ray DuBois,

Baron Gottfried von Cramm, Germany's tennis ace, found the going difficult today as he defeated Howard Blethen, San Francisco, in the Pacific Coast championships. The lanky German finally won, 6-2, 7-9, 6-4, in a heated third-round match.
The 15-year-old mile world record for trotters was broken today by Greyhound.

At a meeting of the board of managers of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, Frank J. Knell was elected a vice president and J. Lawrence Watkins Jr. was elected to the board of managers to fill the vacancies caused by the recent death of Alpheus C. Beane.

The judiciary slates of the Republican and the American Labor parties for the First Judicial District were criticized yesterday by Samuel Seabury, who declared that leaders of both parties had "made a mess" of their nominations by failing to endorse Supreme Court Justice Thomas F. Noonan.
THE ARTS, by Hendrik Willem Van Loon. (Simon Schuster, $3.95.) A broad survey, with illustrations by the author. THE COLONIAL PERIOD OF AMERICAN HISTORY: Vol. 3,

Basil B. Aylesworth was elected yesterday a director of L. C. Smith Corona Typewriters, Inc., at the annual meeting of stockholders in Syracuse, filling the vacancy caused by the death of Wilbert L. Smith.
Captain Raymond Spear, retired, of Norristown, Pa., an outstanding surgeon in the Navy Medical Corps, died in Coronado, Calif., yesterday at the age of 64, the Navy Department was informed today.
Former State Senator Cosmo A. Cilano of Rochester died' at the Raybrook Sanitarium today at the age of 44. He served as a Republican from Monroe County from 1929 to 1934.

Tomorrow-Town, modern architects' dream of a neo-democratic community of the future, is to rise on the Flushing Meadows dumps of yesterday. It will be a dramatic display costing in excess of $1,500,000.
Retail package deliveries for the week ended Sept. 25 scored an increase of 1 per cent over the corresponding period last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service.
Alvin Pike Howard, New Orleans banker and vice president of The Times-Picayune Publishing Company, died suddenly tonight at Plainview, Texas, on the way to his ranch. His age was 48.

Any further attempts to change the make-up of the Supreme Court will be fought by a special committee of the American Bar Association, under a unanimous decision reached at the convention here today. A special commission of seven members was created by the association's Assembly, with the approval of the House of Delegates.

Final standings of the sloops in the International and Victory classes for the season's racing on Long Island Soundwere announced yesterday by the chairmen of the groups, Cornelius Shields for the Internationals and Robert W. Fraser for the Victorys. The season's winners were Shields's Aileen and W. and R. Benson's Blue Jacket.

After three weeks' investigation of white slave traffic on evidence gathered by Federal agents, who conducted raids in Atlantic City, Philadelphia and Wilmington, Del., the Federal grand jury made its first report today, handing up indictments against four persons, charging violations of the Mann Act.

After having subjecTed ?? the most intensive aerial bombing that any section of Shanghai has suffered during the hostilities here, Japanese naval units early yesterday pushed swiftly westward in an effort to take over Chapei by driving out the Chinese forces who had long been barricaded there. The effort failed.

In a quiet stock market here today the level of prices was lower in general, most sections losing ground. Gilt-edge issues were firm; among the foreign loans, Japanese bonds weakened. Transatlantic stocks sagged,

Word has come to the ears and eyes of Andy Kerr in his sylvan retreat in the Valley of the Chenango that Colgate has quite a football team this year. The reports have been reaching the thin little Scotsman annually since he transferred his lares and penates and

Virginia Ave (14-3733); W S. 227 ft n of Eastern Blvd, 50x101: Frederick Schottky to Luysi Pravetz, 987 Trinity Ave. Hull Ave (12-3352); e s. 326 ft S of Gun Hill Rd, 50x100; William P. Schwarz to Minnie Goldberg, 935 St. Nicholas Ave.

With the opening of the season on woodcock in certain sections of this State set for tomorrow, the Conservation Department forwards a summary of regulations to serve as a reminder for hunters in New York.

A contribution of 2,000 cubic centimeters of blood serum, to be used in the treatment of persons wounded while fighting for the Loyalist forces in Spain, was presented last night to Dr. Edward K. Barsky, an American physician who has served in medical work in Loyalist Spain.

A complete revision and overhauling of the curriculum in the New York City evening elementary schools, to make it more practical and less academic, is being attempted this Fall, Ignus 0. Hornstein, assistant director of evening schools, disclosed yesterday.
A deadly epidemic, which has killed 283 persons and caused serious illness of 5,200 since Monday, gave health authorities of Fukuoka Province grave concern today.
Mayor La Guardia said he thought the motion picture was "all right" as a campaign medium yesterday after he witnessed a preview of next month's March of Time featuring his administration of the city.
The Lenox Library Ass Seciation, of which Grenville Lindall Winthrop is president, opened at Sedgwick Hall today the eighteenth annual exhibition. of arts and crafts.

Miss Elaine Rawlinson, a young artist of 390 Riverside Drive, won first prize of $500 yesterday in the National Stamp Competition for a design for the one-cent stamp in the new Presidential series, it was announced by the Procurement Division of the Treasury Department in Washington, Section of Painting and Sculpture.
Frank Purnell, president of Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, predicted today better business for the country and improved tonnage for the steel industry in the next six months.
The execution at Leningrad of ten alleged terrorists, accused of disrupting electric power service at Leningrad, was announced today in the official Communist publication, Pravda.

Joseph Andrews, vice president and trustee of the Bank of New York and Trust Company and a director in several insurance companies, died at his home at 254 Chestnut Street here this morning at the age of 75.
The Republican State Central Committee elected Benjamin E. Harwood of Chester by acclamation today as State chairman to succeed the late J. Henry Roraback.
J. Stewart Barney gave a farewell dinner last night in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis for Mr. and Mrs. Eric S. Hatch, who are leaving for California.

Genaro Estrada, former Foreign Secretary of Mexico and author of the doctrine by which Mexico automatically recognizes new governments after changes in a regime, even though the change may be due to internal trouble or armed revolution, died today of a heart attack at the age of 50. The doctrine,

A mere implication by Justice Black when he landed at Norfolk yesterday that he will have something to say about the alleged records of his Ku Klux Klan affiliation was worth streamer headlines in the afternoon newspapers, and got them. Smiling and cool, all he, would say was "maybe." To this degree,

The crew of the Export liner Excambion ended a one-day strike yesterday afternoon when a compromise was effected on their demand for a "war bonus" of $50 a man for taking the ship into waters allegedly made dangerous by the Spanish war.

Langdon W. Post, speaking yesterday as chairman of the New York City Housing Authority at exercises marking the arrival of tenants for Williamsburg Houses, largest low-rent housing project in the country, declared that this $14,000,000 project was only the beginning for Brooklyn and that plans were well advanced for a $16,000,000 development.

Miss Laura Howell Smith of New York, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Smith, was introduced to society this afternoon at a tea given by her uncles and aunts, Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Smith of Goughacres;

Miss Charlotte L. Quimby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace H. Quimby of Maplewood, was married this evening to Charles William Smith, son of, Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Smith, in the Methodist Episcopal Church of Orange.

A new edition of Boswell's "Johnson," incorporating some 900 marginal notations written by Hester Lynch Thrale upon two copies of the work that she owned, will be brought out by the Limited Editions Club this Fall.
Clyde Derrick, who once blamed gambling as the cause of all his troubles, flipped a coin today, lost and pleaded guilty to the kidnapping of two Johnson City policemen.

Mrs. Grace Coolidge, widow of the former President, let a contract today for the construction of a seven-room, air-conditioned home to cost $25,000. The award went to the William J. Quinn Company of Longmeadow. Work will start immediately.

Justice Black of the Supreme Court, returning from a vacation today, refused to answer a specific question whether he is or was a member of the Invisible Empire, Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, but made it plain that he does not intend to resign from the court.

A brief ceremony in the surveyor's office of the Custom House yesterday afternoon marked the end of the forty-six years' career of Miss Eva F. Smith as customs inspector. She will meet the Normandie tomorrow as her last assignment.

State officials of New York and Pennsylvania joined yesterday in honoring the memory of Gouverneur Morris as a signer of the Constitution in ceremonies at his grave in the churchyard of St. Ann's Episcopal Church, St. Ann's Avenue and 140th Street, the Bronx.

Radio telephone service between the United States and Haiti was opened this afternoon with an exchange of felicitations between Secretary Hull, speaking from his office in the State Department, and Auguste Turnier, acting Minister of Foreign Affairs of Haiti, speaking from Port Au Prince.

The Paragon Stable's Bold Turk had little trouble conquering four juvenile rivals today despite a 120-pound impost, taking the six-furlong Maplewood Handicap by a length and a half at Rockingham Park. His stablemate Family Friend, similarly weighted down, finished third.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Helen Price, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Price of this city, to Horace Kirby Dowell 3d, son of Mrs. Horace K. Dowell of Forest Hills, L. I., and the late Mr. Dowell.

Parity income for the country's farmers remains the unchanged agricultural goal of the Administration, Secretary Wallace stated today, adding that he would go into the subject in detail at the meeting of cotton farmers in Memphis on Friday.
Italian forces for pacification and colonization are keeping Ethiopia under control despite native agitation, French advices from Jibuti indicated today.
A West Side property that has been in one ownership for more than a century figured in a deal yesterday when Nathan Wilson, operator, through his West Side Equities, Inc.,
North China is alarmed by the outbreak of cholera at Tangku and Taku, the ports for Tientsin, where there are seventeen cases. Five cases were brought from Shanghai.

A modified plan that cuts more than $100,000,000 from the estimated $187,000,000 cost of the proposed rapid transit project for Northern New Jersey was offered today at the first of five meetings of the North Jersey Inter-Chamber of Commerce Conference in the Jersey City Chamber of Commerce.

Pope Pius delivered a strong condemnation of Communist, neo-pagan and atheist theories today in an encyclical issued at Castel Gandolfo, his Summer home. He said these theories were attempting to destroy Christian civilization.

Again the Henry Street visiting nurse "enters the picture," as she has actually entered the homes of thousands, to bring nursing aid and cheer to the ill and especially to expectant mothers and to children who are motherless for a time.
Local market prices for farm commodities have declined to a point where the farm price index for September is at the lowest in fourteen months, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics announced today.

Far from giving any sign of modifying her policy in China as a result of widespread protests, Japan revealed in a note to the United States that she intended to pursue her present course. The note, which was a reply to a Washington protest of a week ago, was received at the State Department yesterday, but not made public. There was no indication of further action by this country. [Page 1.]

Dan O'Mahoney, the youthful Irishman who once held the world wrestling championship, defeated Ed (Don) George of North Java, N. Y., in the feature grappling exhibition at Madison Square Garden last night.

Continuing the preparations for Columbia's opening game against Williams on Saturday, Lou Little yesterday put the Lion squad through a three-hour session in which all phases of kicking and protection of the kicker were reviewed.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum in the United States on Sept. 18 amounted to 309,405,000 barrels, the Bureau of Mines reported today.

The bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated Sept. 27: REAR ADMIRALS King, E. J., to additional duty as Commander of Patrol Wing 1, Aircraft Base Force. Sexton, W. R., to additional duty as Commander of Destroyer Flotilla 2, Battle Force, Oct. 1.

Mortgage foreclosures on residential property throughout the country dropped in August to the annual average level that prevailed in 1928, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today. The August index figure was 176, while the average for all of 1928 was 180.

The Transit Commission's application for approval of its new appointment of former Mayor James J. Walker as an assistant counsel, with an annual salary of $12,000, was delivered yesterday to Chairman Milo R. Maltbie of the State Department of Public Service. Mr. Maltbie gave no indication of his decision.

Mrs. Edgar C. Leaycraft and Miss Carol Donohugh gave a tea yesterday at Mrs. Leaycraft's home, 315 East Sixty-eighth Street, for Miss Edna Dudley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Leonard Dudley of, Hearthstone, Pleasantville, and Burr Brower, whose marriage will take place Oct. 9 in Pleasantville.

Princeton's freshmen will have to study hard during the next four years if they are to find a good answer to the question President Dodds put to them the other day. He asked: "How can we construct a scheme of life in which social change can be accomplished peacefully, without recourse to the violence of war and revolution into which our instincts repeatedly lead us?"
Morris Zachariash, 10-year-old student at the Hebrew Theological College of Chicago, was pronounced a "genius" today by Rabbi Saul Silber, president of the institution.

State Treasurer John Stanley ddis died here tonight in the ofce of the town clerk, which posion he also held. Medical Examiner Toward Stevens said death was due a heart attack. He had suffered veral attacks recently. His age as 48.

The four-story apartment house containing eight suites at 767 Park Place, Brooklyn, was sold by the New York State Teachers' Retirement System to Peter A. Farrar. The deal was negotiated by Pease Elliman, Inc., in conjunction with Grattan MacMahon.

Mr. and Mrs. Everett Antrim of Worthington, this city, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Denny Antrim, to William Edward Cole Jr., son of Major General William E. Cole, U. S. A., and Mrs. Cole of Fort Hayes, here.

In a policy speech, broadcast throughout Australia from Deloraine, a small town in Northern Tasmania, Joseph A. Lyons, Prime Minister of Australia, pointed out that since he assumed office in 1931 500,000 unemployed have found work.
Binghamton, N. Y., will enter the market on Oct. 14 with a new issue of $175,000 of bonds for high school equipment. Details will be announced later.

More than 500 pupils of the Cooper B. Hatch Junior High School stormed City Hall during the noon recess today after going on strike earlier in protest against the transfer of six of their teachers to other schools.
The contract for installation of the new additional offices of Alliance Distributors, Inc., on the third and fourth floors of 153-7 Fifth Avenue, has been awarded to the A. J. Courtmel Company, Inc.,

Harry M. Riddle, banker and president of the Asbury Graphite Mills, largest manufacturers of graphite in America, died suddenly this morning on his estate at Asbury, near here. The cause of his death was given as a heart attack. He was 72 years of age.

The competition between oilburning and anthracite-burning equipment may develop ino a real battle next year if anthracite continues to register the gains that Anthracite Industries, Inc., claims it has.

Without a dissenting vote Sir Harry Edward Augustus Twyford, textile manufacturer, was chosen today to be Lord Mayor of London for the ensuing year. On Nov. 9 he will take office and ride through the streets of London in a gilded coach.

A sponsor has been found in the person of Dwight Deere Wiman for a New York season to be given by the group who presented plays this Summer at Surry, Me. They will be known as the Surry Players, and their first show will be "As You Like It," which they revived last Summer down East. Three others will follow.

Miss Stella Rae Carter, daughter of Mrs. Oliver Goldsmith Carter of 1,440 Albemarle Road, Brooklyn, has completed plans for her marriage to Alvah Weeks Haff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvah Cornell Haff, also of Brooklyn, which will take place on the afternoon of Oct. 15
Joseph A. Broderick, it is understood, will resign tomorrow as a member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. It is said he will join a savings bank in New York.

Miss Marion Wharton of this city and Islip, L. I., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard Wharton, will be married to Gerard Hallock 3d of Brooklyn on the afternoon of Oct. 12 in St. Mark's Church, Islip.
Defending champion, Miss Kathryn Hemphill was eliminated today as Miss Jane Cochran Jameson and Miss Marion Miley advanced to the final of the Southeastern invitation golf tournament.

Valdina Farm's Eagle Pass, the longest shot, at nearly 19 to 1, raced a courageous mile and a furlong today to outclass thirteen other thoroughbreds in the twentysixth running of the $10,000 added Havre de Grace Handicap.
Mrs. William Whittingham Battle of New York entertained at a cocktail party in the Homestead Club this evening for Miss Mary D. Brooks, Mrs. James B. Weir and Mrs. Joseph Reynolds Guernsey.

The Earl Peel, chief author of the Palestine partition plan, died at his home in Petersfield today at the age of 70. He had been Secretary of State for India twice, and held many other important offices before assuming the chairmanship of the Royal Palestine Commission. His greatest personal interest was Indian affairs.

A continued active foreign demand for domestic cash wheat and independent strength in Winnipeg where the October delivery acted congested brought about a sharp rally on the Board of Trade here today after an early decline of around 1 cent a bushel in sympathy with Liverpool and with securities and other commodities.

Mrs. Jane White, wife of former Governor Horace White and socially prominent resident of this city for many years, died of heart disease this morning in her home. She was stricken with acute indigestion on Sept. 15.

Grenville T. Emmet's body lay in state at the American Legation today from 10 A. M. to 4 P. M. The large reception room was converted into a funeral chapel draped in black. On a catafalque beneath a black canopy and covered with the Stars and Stripes rested the coffin containing the body of the Minister, who died after a month here.

The appointment of Fred Spuhn, a member of the Yale rowing staff for the past nine years and former mentor at Pennsylvania, as head crew coach at Princeton was announced tonight by Professor Burnham N. Dell, chairman of the University Council on Athletics.

Miss Lillian Sorrentino, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Sorrentino of Brooklyn, was married here yesterday afternoon to Angelo Sellaro, son of Mrs. Vincent Sellaro of Lawrence, L. I., and the late Dr. Sellaro, in the Church of St. Gregory by the Rev. Joseph A. Daly.

Supreme Court Justice Hugo Black's activities as chairman of the Black Committee in the Senate disqualify him for his new post as much as his reputed membership in the Ku Klux Klan, Messmore Kendall, New York attorney and president-general of the National Society, Sons of the American Revolution, declared here today before the annual meeting of the New Jersey Daughters of the American Revolution.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for numerous alterations in Manhattan, a Brooklyn apartment to cost $507,000 and several small dwellings in Queens. The plans follow:

The Port of New York Authority purchased from Dario Maffei the three-story flat and the one-story concrete garage at 706-708 Paterson Plank Road; from Mrs. Henrietta Hoyer the two-story dwelling, on a plot 78 by 108 feet,
Madison Square Garden was being transformed yesterday into a huge bar in preparation for the twelfth annual World's Championship Rodeo, opening next Wednesday and continuing through Oct. 24.

When Joseph Schreier, 24 years old, pleaded not guilty in the Felony Court yesterday to possessing three pistols and two boxes of cartridges in the Palace Hotel, in West Fortyfifth Street, it developed he had been questioned for several hours about the murder of Mrs. Esther Gordon.
A large scale battle throughout Northeast Spain raged tonight as Government and Insurgent forces struggled for control of the main avenues to the French border.

A solemn high mass celebrated by the Rev. Locksley A. Appo, pastor 'of St. Brigid's Church, Westbury, L. I., opened the fifth annual Eucharist Congress of the Diocese of Brooklyn yesterday morning at the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church, 9,719 Flatlands Avenue. Six hundred persons attended the mass.

The efforts of the State Mediation Board to settle the strike of editorial and commercial employes of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle have failed, it was disclosed last night by William H. Davis, chairman of the board, at the close of a twohour conference late yesterday afternoon.

Less than half the funds collected by Spanish relief organizations in this country have been sent to Spain, according to a report issued by the State Department covering their financial activities from May to August, both inclusive.

The filing of ten additional registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission in time to meet the deadline for using June 30 in financial statements.

The inference, conveyed by supporters of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, that one must be a Communist to get on relief in this city is likely to prove harmful to the unemployed and the taxpayers, even though the charge itself is "ridiculous," Miss Charlotte E. Carr, former executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, said yesterday.

Mrs. Josephine Houghteling Griswold of 783 Park Avenue, widow of Frank Gray Griswold and mother of Cass Canfield, president of Harper Brothers, publishers, died yesterday after an illness of several weeks in the El Mirasol Hotel, Santa Barbara, Calif., where she had passed the Summer. She was 73 years old.
The Browns handed the Tigers their first three runs on a platter today, but scored four in the sixth on Joe Vosmik's double and Harland Clift's homer to win, 7 to 6.

Agents of the Department of Justice and policemen of the State Attorney's s office continued their search today for Charles S. Ross. Four days of investigation had given them no clew to the identity of the kidnappers of the 72-year-old retired business man, nor none as to where he may be held captive.
Mrs. Grace Morrison Poole of Brockton, Mass., was married here this morning to Dr. Henry Gilbert Reynolds of Paducah, Ky., at the home of her brother, William H. Morrison Jr.

With today's issue The Morning Post went out of existence after 165 years of continuous publication. "The empire's senior daily" has been absorbed by its more successful rival, The Daily Telegraph, after living through eight reigns, the Napoleonic wars and the World War.
The Red Sox picked up a full game on the Indians in their fight for fourth place in the American League today by taking both ends of a double-header from the Senators,

The adjustment of the steel industry and allied units to a reduced volume of new business continues this week, according to Iron Age but a point of equilibrium between production and incoming business may be reached within the next two or three weeks, during which time orders from the automobile industry are expected to increase materially as the motor plants swing into volume output of 1938 models.

A. W. Sherer, the Lee W. Maxwell home on Round Hill Rd, Greenwich, Conn.: Douglas L. Elliman Co. Inc, and Ladd Nichols, Inc, co-brokers. Clyde D. Yeomans, in 1,424 Stout Ave, Scotch Plains, N. J.; Wilton L Ressler. in 506 Wildwood Rd. Allenhurst Park Estate; Miss Rosalind M. Ross, in 604 Palmer Ave, West Allenhurst; the New Jersey Realty Company, broker.
Phil Perkins of Cleveland, former British amateur champion, won the annual Ohio open golf championship at the Acacia Club today with a seventy-two-hole total of 290,
Fyr Fyter An initial dividend of 40 cents a common share was declared yesterday by the Fyr Fyter Company.

Dr. Harold E. Anthony, curator of mammals at the American Museum of Natural History, returned by airplane yesterday from the "Lost World" on Shiva Temple, otherwise known as "the Island in the Sky" in the Grand Canyon, whither he had gone to investigate the effects of thousands of years of isolation on the evolution of animals.

Scrimmaging in a secret practice, details of which were withheld, the Yale eleven today held its longest and probably its only intensive drill of the week in direct preparation for the opening game of the season on Saturday with Maine University.

Apartment leases reported yesterday by renting agents included contracts for duplex suites in houses on Park Avenue. A large furnished duplex in 925 Park Avenue was leased by the Payson McL. Merrill Company for Herbert L. Mills to Voldemar Vetluguin, editor of The Red Book Magazine.

Under the leadership of the railroad issues, the bond market rallied in the late trading yesterday and prices moved irregularly higher. The rise in the bond list followed closely the rally-in the stock market. While United States Government obligations were steady, their action was not so impressive as the remainder of the bond list.

An additional reduction of 1 cent a pound to 12 cents was made in the price of copper in the domestic market yesterday by one of the leading custom smelters. The other leading smelter and the principal producing companies maintained their price at 13 cents, although it was reported that a small producer was offering the metal at 12 cents.

Between the speeches delivered yesterday in Berlin by Premier Mussolini of Italy and Chancellor Hitler of Gerthere was such difference of tone that what was said seems, in French opinion, to be less important than the manner of its saying.

C. P. Randolph has been elected vice president of Edison General Electric Appliance Company. David J. Martin has been appointed managing director of the Bossert Hotel by the Brooklyn Trust Company and Paul Fulton has been named manager of the Half Moon Hotel, of which Mr. Martin has been managing director.

Turpentine firm; 27 3/4c: sales, 115 barrels: receipts, 200 barrels; shipments, 25 barrels; stock, 36.758 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 809; receipts, 1,148; no shipments: stock, 69,503. Quote: B, D. E, $7.40; F. to K, $7.65: N, $7.67 1/2; WG, $8; ww, X, $8.35.
Federal Trade Commission heard final argument today in the case of the Hoffman Beverage Company, Newark, N. J., on a complaint alleging disparagement of the products of competitors in beer sales.

Hundreds of industry-taxing laws enacted by States since 1929 have hampered business enterprise, increased costs and interefered with the flow of goods to consumers, members of the American Petroleum Industries Committee said today.

Defending a program prepared for the Episcopal Church's general convention here on Oct. 6-20, the Cincinnati Church League of Industrial Democracy replied today to criticism from Bishop William T. Manning of New York with the assertion that "any statement which attempts to identify the C. L. I. D. philosophy with that of organized communism simply displays either an obvious ignorance of what a Communist is or a deliberate attempt to mislead the public."

Mrs. Dorothy Wiley Lawson-Johnston of Greenwich, Conn., and London, England, today filed in Superior Court here a suit for divorce from John Robert Lawson-Johnston of London, a former member of the British Embassy staff in Washington.
Miss Virginia Woodruff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Burnett Woodruff of Flushing, has completed plans for her marriage to Richard Jones Mead, son of Mrs. E. Jones Mead of Binghamton, N. Y.

Charles D. Millard of Tarrytown resigned today as Representative in the Twenty-fifth Congressional District. He is the Republican candidate for Surrogate of Westchester County in the November election.
With no change in the line-up, Army's varsity had a forty-five minute scrimmage today and displayed much improvement in blocking and tackling as it scored several times against the juniors.

Mrs. Charlotte Fisher McGhie of 101 South Mountain Avenue, wife of John McGhie, retired Eastern manager of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company of New York, died here this afternoon in the Mountainside Hospital after an operation.
