Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, shook up the organization of the U. A. W. A. today with the announcement of dismissal of ten organizers and assignment of regional directors.

An exhibition illustrating town construction and architecture in Soviet Russia, by means of photographs, maps and plans, is current until Oct. 15 at Russell Hall, Teachers College, Columbia University.

Copper markets both here and abroad were firmer yesterday. In the domestic market the leading smelter, which cut the price 1 cent a pound to 12 cents on Wednesday, advanced the price to 12.25 cents and then to 12.50 cents in the late trading.

An important development in. the North China warfare is expected soon following the Japanese announcement that Japanese troops captured Tungkwang, only a few miles north of the Shantung border, coupled with advices from Tsingtao reporting that General Han Fu-chu declared that he is acting under the orders of the Nanking Government for resistance against the "foreign foes."

The proportion of the bank's reserve to public and private deposits is 25.6 per cent. Last week the ratio was 26.7 per cent; two weeks ago, 25.4. Highest ratio of the year to date was 42 per cent, on Jan. 21; the ratio of Aug. 5, 16.6, was lowest.

Mayor La Guardia delivered a sharp attack yesterday on the Citizens Budget Commission, charging it with having made up a "fictitious balance" for the 1938 budget to justify its demand for a $12,000,000 cut in water rates.

The Pittsburgh Steel Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on June 30, 1937, a net profit of $1,391,664 after depreciation, depletion, amortization, interest, Pennsylvania and normal Federal income taxes and other charges. With allowance for annual dividend requirements on the 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock
Forty-five families left their dark tenement flats yesterday to find "the more abundant life" in the sunlit, airy rooms of Williamsburg houses.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Sept. 29 were announced today; COMMANDER Donohue. R.. Headquarters, to New York Division, for duty in connection with commissioning air station at Floyd Bennett Field, New York. N. Y., and in command when commissioned.
Some resentment is being expressed in official quarters over the fact that, although f10,000 reward has been offered by the Palestine Government for the arrest of the assassins of James Y. Andrews,

The end of this year's Argentine polo visit came tonight with the dispersal at auction of the thirty-six horses brought up with the San Jose team, the sale being conducted at Post's Polo Field under a tent. At no time was the bidding as spirited as it has been in past Argentine auctions.

A campaign for a "fitter Britain" was launched tonight by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain with an appeal for a "concentrated and determined crusade against ignorance, carelessness and indifference about health services."

Clyde Armstrong, a stage and screen actor, died yesterday morning in his sleep at his home, 159 West Eighty-fifth Street. He was 58 years old. His last Broadway appearance was in "It Pays to Sin," in 1933. Since then he had been coaching students at a New York theatrical school.

IN 1925 the Pittsburgh Pirates and Washington I Senators engaged in a world series and the Pirates eventually won out on a very rainy day in Pittsburgh. But it wasn't the Pirate victory that caused the brisk debate in the office of President Ford C. Frick of the National League yesterday. It was another little matter that came up in the series-and might come up again next week.

The New York State committee of the Communist party withdrew yesterday fifty-five of its slate of eighty candidates in favor of candidates nominated by the American Labor party as "a matter of united front discipline." This withdrawal,

Dr. William H. Allen, former secretary of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, commenting yesterday upon ownership of the Rockefeller birthplace in Tioga County, said that several years ago when he was collecting data for a book on John D. Rockefeller he got an idea that the farm should be preserved, since he felt that in time it would be wanted for museum purposes.

The mysterious "creeping death," an epidemic which already has snuffed out nearly 300 lives in Fukuoka Province, seeped through the hygienic barriers around the city of Omuta today into four neighboring communities, bringing fiftytwo new cases.

Willis Elsh, William Snyder and Delmar Simmons, high school boys. presented novel excuses today to explain yesterday's absence from school: "Teacher, we've been catching trout for President Roosevelt's dinner."
Several thousand members of society, their guests and their children visited the show ring on the second day of the Piping Rock horse show being held at the show grounds.
Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Henry Ferris of this place and Riverside, Conn., have -announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Derby Ferris, to Nils Anderson Jr. of Plainfield.
HOW COME, LAWD? a "Negro folkdrama" in three acts. by Donald Heywood, Staged by Charles J. Adler; scenery by Stagecraft Studios; produced by Negro Theatre Guild. At the Fortyninth Street Theatre.

An $18,0000,000 accounting suit against the Cities Service Company and its president, Henry L. Doherty, was ordered yesterday marked off the calendar when it came up before Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin. Attorneys for the plaintiff. Morton Marks.

While his faithful "seeing eye" police dog stood beside him, proudly wagging its tail, Michael Supa, a blind sophomore from Binghamton, was cheered by 1,000 Colgate University students today when he received the award of the first Ebenezer Dodge Prize, given for excellence in studies, including Latin or Greek, or both.

Desperate efforts were being made tonight to save the Building Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor from splitting into two factions and thus endangering the machinery for peaceably adjusting jurisdictional disputes without strikes.
Governor Lehman issued his Fire Prevention Week proclamation today. It read as follows: "Whereas, fire continues a major cause of accidental death and property destruction in this State,
Almost complete figures today of Pennsylvania's registration for the municipal elections showed an enrollment of 3,868,514 voters, a decrease of more than 1,000,000 from last year.

Joseph A. Broderick, whose resignation from the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System was forecast in Washington on Wednesday, was elected yesterday president and a trustee of the East River Savings Bank. He will succeed the late Darwin R. James.

Getting through along the fence in a hard drive under Jockey A. Cooper's urging, Salvatore Pisacano's Pastry yesterday captured the featured Lothario Handicap at Belmont Park to enhance his record as the best thoroughbred in Class D.
Lumber production declined more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index has eased to 85.0 from 86.1. The figure for the week ended Sept. 26, 1936, was 85.5.

1st Lt. Henry Peck, Inf.-Res., is relieved from further assignment and duty with CCC Co. 1,225, Camp SP-4 (NJ), Norma, N. J.; and will proceed to Camp P-121 (NY), Fort Ann, N. Y., to take command of CCC Co. 205 and accompany it to the Ninth Corps Area.

The prolonged strike of members of the Commercial Artists and Designers Union, Local 20,329, affiliated with the A. F. of L., was ended yesterday by an oral agreement between the Fleischer Studios, Inc., 1,600 Broadway, and the union.

Out of a field of forty of the crack timber-toppers of the East competing in the $1,000 jumper sweepstakes, two from the stable of Mrs. Julius Bliss of Bronxville, N. Y., came through today to place one-two in the richest and most interesting event of the program of the second day of the thirty-fifth annual Piping Rock Horse Show.

The Nassau Trot, initial offering of the daily matinee at the ninety-fifth annual Queens-Nassau Fair, today went to the 3-year-old bay Freckles. The colt, by Guy Day-Lookaway Express, took the $1,000 purse in three straight heats. It was the first time that the post horse has won a heat during the current meet.
The Private Library Department of Houghton Mifflin will publish this month the first collected autograph edition of the works of Willa Cather.
There was a pronounced drop in the level of business activity in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the bureau of business research, University of Pittsburgh.

The 10,000-ton cruiser Brooklyn, armed with fifteen six-inch guns in five triple turrets and incorporating in her design many radical innovations in American naval construction, was commissioned at the navy yard in Brooklyn yesterday.

A strike of 2,500 window washers in this city was called last night by a unanimous vote of 1,500 members of the Window Washers Protective Association, Local 2, of the Building Service International Union, at a meeting in Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street. The strike was voted after the failure of negotiations for a new contract with the Window Washers Contractors Association.

Robert Behr, deputy surveyor of customs, will terminate his fortyfive-year career in the service today when he reaches the automatic retirement age of 70. He has been named a director of the Travel-On Bureau in the Ambassador Hotel.

The psychology of the criminal sexual- pervert is still so little understood that an effective preventive program must depend on the future findings of research workers, according to testimony given yesterday before the joint legislative committee investigating such crimes.

The French franc yesterday threw off some of the pressure which has been weighing upon it in the foreign exchange market. Spot quotations gained 5/8 point to 3.42 3/4 cents, and the discount on ninetyday futures, while still large, was reduced 1 point to 21 1/2 points.

Senator Royal S. Copeland said today that "with two New Dealers to choose from" he preferred to support Jeremiah T. Mahoney for Mayor of New York. "I'll campaign for him if he wants me to," Dr. Copeland said. He is in Washington to address the convention of the International Association for Identification tomorrow.
Hank Soar will be in the starting backfield for the New York Football Giants when they face the Eagles in Philadelphia on Sunday, it was announced yesterday by Coach Steve Owen.

Secretary and Mrs. Hull will pay an official visit to Canada next month on the invitation of the Governor General and Lady Tweedsmuir and thus return the visit to Washington of Prime Minister Mackenzie King in March.

Most of the 3,000 shipping clerks in the garment area, employes of dress manufacturing establishments who went on strike on Tuesday, were back at work yesterday as a result of agreements signed by nearly 500 individual employers with the Shipping Clerks Union, the strike organization, Louis Dworkin, manager of the union, announced yesterday.

The sad news tonight is that the Dodgers now possess but do not boast a losing streak of fourteen games and are coming home practically on their backs to meet the pennantwinning Giants in a three-game series.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 10,000, including 3,000 directs. The market was mostly 10 to 15c higher than Wednesday's average, but closing with the advance largely lost. Top, $12.35; bulk good and choice, 190-230 pounds. $12$30; 240-300 pounds, $11.70-$12.25; 150-180 bounds. $11.65-$12.15:

Coach ,Earl Blaik today continued his policy of shifting his players around, three more changes being made in the Dartmouth squad as the team looked over Amherst plays. For the third time this week Gus Zitrides and Henry Ingersoll swapped places at right guard, this time the former getting the varsity call.

Pennsylvania's "evolution school case" ended unexpectedly today in a compromise providing for Mrs. Laura Elms Morris's resignation as a teacher and withdrawal by the Whiteley Township School Board of charges of incompetency and crueltv against her.
The Political Commission of the League of Nations Assembly adopted tonight the strongest resolution the League has yet produced on the Spanish war.

ON HIS OWN APPLICATION: Patrolman Michael A. Cardlin, 88th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed July 2, 1908. Transfers and Assignments Lieutenant George A. Reynolds, from Mounted Squadron 1 to Mounted District, assignment changed from desk duty to clerical duty.

Senator Henry F. Ashurst, who as chairman of the Judiciary Committee led President Roosevelt's fight for reorganization of the Federal courts, said in an interview today that he believed the issue dead.

In his Bonneville address on Tuesday the President pictured the social future of the great hydroelectric plants which have been built along the Columbia River. Smaller agricultural and industrial communities flourishing because they have electric energy-the vision has its justification in the light of technological history.

A Federal Court hearing at which five railroads planned to rest their protest of a $30,000,000 State tax levy was halted today as the State opposed exhibits comparing railroad assessments with other valuations. It will be resumed on Monday.

Recipient of what was probably the most enthusiastic demonstration for a candidate for New York City office in recent years, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia formally accepted nomination by the American Labor party at a crowded meeting in Carnegie Hall last night.

About 1,500 exhibits of devices, appliances and methods for increasing administrative and operational speed, economy and efficiency will be shown at the National Business Show in the week of Oct. 18 in Commerce Hall at the Port Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteen Street, it was announced yesterday by Frank E. Tupper, president of the show.
Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director and treasurer of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, is confined to his home by illness.

The resolutions committee of the Republican State Convention made public today its tentative draft of a platform on which Senator Lester H. Clee of Essex County, the party's nominee for Governor, would seek election in November and Senator Clifford R. Powell of Burlington County, who was defeated for the nomination in the New Jersey primaries, attacked it immediately as one of "old-fashioned platitudes."

Inability of the nonpartisan committee of the American Federation of Labor to obtain permission to swing a La Guardia banner %between two bank buildings in West Fourteenth Street did not bother the Mayor at all when he visited the committee's headquarters in the County Trust Building yesterday morning.

The United States liner Manhattan will arrive today, bringing among her 1,044 passengers a number of prominent public officials, including Justice James Clark McReynolds of the United States Supreme Court, Senator Sherman Minton of Indiana, Senator Elbert D. Thomas of Utah, Senator James F. Byrnes of South Carolina, RepFesentative Fred Bierman of Iowa and Representative Virginia Jenckes of Indiana.

Reception, British Empire Chamber of Commerce, British Empire Building, Rockefeller Center, 4:30 P. M. Presentation to Robert R. Appleby of the Order of Commander of the British Empire by Sir Gerald Campbell, guest of honor.

While Republican leaders yesterday continued unbending in their reaction to the demand by Samuel Seabury for the nomination of Supreme Court Justice Thomas F. Noonan, Mayor La Guardia took a hand in the tangle over the judiciary slates.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer today a new issue of $1,480,000 city of Jersey City hospital and general improvement 4 per cent bonds, at prices to yield from 1.50 to 4 per cent, according to maturity.

The marriage of Miss Minna Rose Heyman, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Heyman of Jersey City, N. J., to Horace G. Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Davis. also of Jersey City, took place last night at the home of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Benjamin Heyman, 44 Gifford Avenue, Jersey City.

Open-market money rates continued unchanged in September, but there was an important relaxation of basic credit conditions which was reflected in a progressive decline in the rates paid by the United States Treasury on its weekly bill issues.
Dr. Alexis Carrel, medical scientist and member of the Rockefeller Institute, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie to continue researches in which he has been engaged for several years.
Women jurors, who served In New York County Supreme Court this week for the first time, may look forward to having a place soon where they can powder their noses.

An appeal from Supreme Court justice Francis Bergan's decision that he was not the winner of the Vestchester Surrogate election last November was filed by Surrogate William J. Sheils with the Appel??te Division in Albany today.

Alarmed at his inability to secure the services of a single foreign-educated Chinese doctor to staff eighty base hospitals, Dr. Peng Chin-chou, Secretary-General of the Red Cross Society, has gone to Nanking to make an appeal for aid from high government authorities.

Dick Midkiff, former University of Texas star, held Fort Worth of the Texas League to five scattered singles tonight while his Little Rock team-mates pounded the offerings of three pitchers for fourteen hits and a 10-to-O victory in the Dixie series opener.
A new Mediterranean warship patrol plan, giving Italy a sector cutting across the main sea routes, was sent today to French, British and Italian governments for approval.

Joaquin J. Elizalde, foremost Spanish business man in the Philippines, died today of coronary thrombosis at the age of 65. He was chairman of Elizalde Co., which employs 10,000 persons. Its business includes import and export of sugar and inter-island shipping of hemp and other products.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Right from the center of hostilities in Shanghai, with shells flying over, our heads, I venture to address you regarding the spectacle of six peace organizations in America badgering President Roosevelt to the point of forcing him to threaten to "shanghai" some 8,000 Americans in Shanghai and China.

The Rev. Dr. Bartholomew J. Eustace was yesterday appointed by Cardinal Hayes as pastor of the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, New Rochelle. Dr. Eustace has been for the last twenty-one years Professor of Philosophy at St. Joseph's Theological Seminary,

Deputies Gavrilovitch and Markovitch, delegates of the Serbian extraparliamentary opposition, who left Belgrade yesterday on a sperial mission to confer with Vladimir Matchek, Croat leader, arrived here today, and the three men had a two-hour conference. Afterward Mr. Matchek told your correspondent:

Increased exenditure on Britain's defense proram is reflected in revenue returns for the first half of the budget year, which ended tonight, showing a deficit of [Pound]98,536,050. At the same date last year the deficit was just over [pound]80,000,000.

While buyers have bought sample quantities of Spring wash goods and of some other Spring dry goods, they have shown no inclination to place contracts as yet, and it was estimated in wholesale buying offices yesterday that little more than sample operations would develop for another thirty days.

Trade in wool goods this week has been slow, the New York Wool Top Exchange reported yesterday, and noted that buyers sampled the new lines of men's wear but deferred placing of contracts until they have time to compare selections.

A nation-wide boycott of Japanese goods will be launched at a mass meeting at 8 o'clock tonight in Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday by the American League Against War and Fascism and the American Friends of the Chinese People.

Mayor La Guardia does not intend to pay one cent of the $5,000,000 which former Mayor James J. Walker promised to pay the Federal Government to get back the Old Postoffice property, it was learned yesterday.

The Federal Power Commission today publicly reprimanded C. Edward Paxson, counsel for subsidiaries of the Associated Gas and Electric System, for a statement which he issued on Sept. 18 to the press and which, the commission contended, impugned its motives.

A registration statement covering $80,000,000 of debentures, the proceeds from which will be used for refunding and capital expenditures, has been filed by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933.

Ralph Greenleaf defeated George Kelly twice yesterday in their 1,500point pocket billiard match at the Strand Academy to lead by 848-671. Greenleaf scored, 125-27, in seven innings, and 125-20 in thirteen. Greenleaf has won five of the eight blocks so far.

Football at Syracuse is in a stage of transition. At the end of the 1936 campaign Via Hanson, one of the greatest all-around athletes to wear the Orange, handed in his resignation, and Ossie Solem, who put Iowa athletics back on its feet, was brought in from the Big Ten as the new head coach.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court has unanimously upheld compensation awards to two employes of the New York Stock Exchange who were injured in athletic contests.
Japan's great push at Shanghai entered its fourth day this morning and included fierce hand-to-hand fighting in Chapei, on the border of the International Settlement.

Baron Gottfried von Cramm, Germany's amateur tennis champion, met his first stiff competition of the Pacific Coast tennis tournament today and was forced to three sets to defeat Dick Bennet of Oakland, State singles champion. The score was 4-6, 6--2, 6--2.

Florida clamped the lid on slot machines tonight, two years after they were legalized and taxed by the Legislature. A new law prohibiting operation became effective at midnight, but the State Supreme Court overruled, for a time at least, a section authorizing seizure of machines in storage or in transit.
Buenos Aires was isolated from radio communication with the rest of the world during the hour today between noon and 1 o'clock.

It is premature to discuss the outcome, but the signs point to the approach of a showdown on the question of intervention in Spain. The Geneva proposal to end the non-intervention agreement unless foreign troops are withdrawn would not of itself promise results if it were not clear that Paris and London are taking the same line.

Mrs. Margaret Scott Kelly, widow of Solon C. Kelly Sr. of Stamford, Conn., was married to Paul Burress of Palm Beach, Fla., and New York, yesterday in Rutgers Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. Dr. Danniel D. Russell.

Mrs. Patricia Mudgett, 26 years old, who is being held here on a worthless check charge, has been identified through fingerprints as a fugitive from a Framingham (Mass.) reformatory, where she was serving a term for bigamy, according to Police Chief Paul Yerick.
President Roosevelt paid a "good neighbor" visit to British Columbia today and received a lusty welcome from cheering crowds on the docks and lining the streets through which he passed.
The Standard Oil Company, a holding corporation for the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, has b moved its registered office again in an effort to avoid assessment "discrimination."
Princeton's gridiron battalions began tapering off for Saturday's opening contest with the University of Virginia today, and Coach Fritz Crisler eliminated scrimmage for the first time this season.

30.-The defending team of Victor Ghezzi, Deal, and Clarence Clark, Forest Hill, won the qualifying medal in the third annual New Jersey pro-pro best-ball golf championship today with a par-shattering 36hole total of 134 at the Preakness Hills Country Club.

The necessity for not only watching but. detecting in advance any trend unfavorable to advertising was stressed yesterday by Dr. Howard T. Hovde, Assistant Professor of Marketing, Wharton School of Finance and Commerce, University of Pennsylvania, at a round-table discussion of the Premium Advertising Association at the Hotel Astor.

Preparing for its attempt at revenge over the Old Westbury team when the rivals meet again in the final of the Monty Waterbury Cup tournament on Sunday, Greentree galloped through a six-period warmup game against Delray on Whitney Field today at the Meadow Brook Club.

The wedding of Miss Florence Janet Biggar, Greenwich, daughter of the late J. Leslie Biggar and Mrs. Biggar, to F. Gilbert Wheeler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Wheeler, will take place on Oct. 16 in the First Presbyterian Church, Greenwich. The Rev. Dr. Minot C.

Representative Christopher D. Sullivan, leader of Tammany, announced yesterday the names of seven Tammany candidates for the City Council to be elected in Manhattan. Taken in conjunction with the naming of only four Council candidates by the Democratic

Business activity is being maintrained at a general satisfactory level as the year enters its last quarter, although questions of national monetary policy have caused confusion and uncertainty, according to Banking, the official journal of the American Bankers Association, in its review of business in the October issue.

Cuba's contribution to the 1939 World's Fair will consist of a complete Cuban village and copies of the first cathedral at Havana, of Morro Castle, a tobacco factory and sugar mill, Paulino Soles y Estrada. commissioner general from Cuba to the fair; revealed yesterday in an interview at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.
The War Department issued the following orders today dated Sept. 29: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Browne, F. W., Finance Dep't, one month leave, Sept. 29, with permission to visit foreign countries.

British Guiana batsmen scored 629 runs in their first innings against Barbados in their game for the right to play Trinidad in the intercolonial test cricket matches, and records fell freely. Barbados replied with 66 for the loss of one wicket when stumps were drawn today.
Some careless hand, a stranger, From the wall along my field Toppled a rock that would not To my single efforts yield. But the shoulder of my neighbor, His heartland will, with mine,

Elbert Lee Dodds, American Legion commander of the Department of France, today issued a formal statement on behalf of the Legion, branding as grossly exaggerated cabled reports from Legionnaires questioning the hospitality shown the Legion members and their wives in Paris which have been appearing in the American press since the arrival of the first contingent early this week.

Gladstone's personal character and place in history as a statesman have suffered much recently and in "Mr. Gladstone," tried out at the Gate Theatre tonight, Hugh Ross Williamson attempts to redress the balance.

Wholesale prices advanced again in the week ended on Sept. 25, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The advance lifted the bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, to 87.5, compared with 87.4 the preceding. week and 81.0 a year before.

The three-platoon ten-group system is Installed in the 6th, 35th and 44th Battalions, effective 12:01 A. M., Oct. 1. Promoted The following captains are promoted to the rank of battalion chief, with compensation each at the rate of $5,300 per annum, to take effect at 12:01 A. M., Oct. 1. They will report to the Assistant Chief of Department for assignment to duty:

Joseph A. Conry, attorney for the Federal Maritime Commission, defended Government subsidy of the merchant marine in an address yesterday before the graduating class of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy on the floor of the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street.
Sale of the New York Stock Exchange membership of Michael J. Meehan, "boy wonder of Wall Street" in the 1929 boom days, was announced yesterday. The consideration was nominal.
Secretary Wallace has replied to a request from Mayor La Guardia for Information and advice concerning meat prices in New York.

Columbia University receives $212,538, virtually the entire estate of the late Professor William Campbell, the transfer tax appraisal of the estate showed yesterday. Dr. Campbell, who was Professor of Metallurgy at the university, died on Dec. 16, 1936.

Expansion of Fall business was reflected in the weekly statement of the Bank of Canada for Sept. 29 issued today. Note circulation increased almost $2,000,000 to $161,333,31, from $159,347,922 on Sept. 22.
A bill which delegates said b would raise the standards of nursing in New York State and insure safe care to the public was drafted today by the State Nurses Association in convention here.

In accepting the resignation of Dr. Frederick W. Parsons as head of the Mental Hygiene Department and announcing the selection of Dr. William J. Tiffany as Commissioner of the department, Governor Lehman today expressed his satisfaction that he was able to promote to the office of commissioner one who had risen from the ranks.

At the close of a lengthy practice today, Coach Harvey Harman announced that Bob Dougherty will call the signals and occupy the quarterback position in Pennsylvania's opening game against Maryland on Saturday. Dougherty, substitute last year, also will do most of the punting and play the safety position for the Red and Blue.

Mrs. Julian S. L. Humphrys entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius, Mrs. William Adams Kissam, Mrs. Franklin Remington and Mrs. George R. D. Schieffelin.

General Sessions Judge Koenig granted yesterday another postponement of the start of the firstdegree murder trial of Robert Irwin, 29 years old, a sculptor, in the triple Gedeon slaying last Easter Sunday in an East Fiftieth Street aparment.

Dr. Charles Seymour, who will be formally inducted as president of Yale a week from today, had a welcome from the undergraduates Wednesday night that may be more interesting to some of us than the dignified ceremonial that awaits him.
Dividends amounting to $363,170,461 were declared in September by 1,311 companies compared with

Apartment leasing activity which, according to custom, comes to an end with Sept. 30th, is not showing appreciable diminution, judging from the lists of new tenacies which continue to be submitted by brokers and renting agents.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Arthur DelaI Hay of this place of the engagement of their eldest daughter, Miss Beatrice DelaHay, to Donald Lawrence Burton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Burton of Gedney Farms, White Plains.

John Deegan, a striking district circulation manager for The Brooklyn Eagle, appeared in the Coney Island Court yesterday morning in answer to a summons that had been obtained by Theodore Goldberg, a non-striking district circulation manager, but Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto held that the summons was invalid because it did not contain a brief description of the alleged offenses.

Led by Frank Demaree, the Cubs broke a 1-all tie in the ninth inning today to win, 4 to 1, and make it four straight victories over the Reds before a crowd which, when play was called, included an even dozen bleacher occupants.

Baseball history made by the Giants scarcely a year ago virtually repeated itself today as the Terrymen climaxed another remarkable pennant drive by clinching their second successive National League championship and thereby assuring for New York its fifth world series on a five-cent fare and the second of this kind in a row.

Probate Judge Henry P. Field, in whose office Calvin Coolidge began the study of law, died in a hospital here today after a long illness. His age was 78. Judge Field was in partnership with the late John C. Hammond when young Coolidge started reading law upon his graduation from Amherst. Judge Field also sponsored Coolidge when the latter applied for admission to the Hampshire County bar.

A fund for the "impartial relief" of Spanish children is being raised by The Parents Magazine, 9 East Fortieth Street, it was announced yesterday. The magazine, which has initiated the fund with a $1,000 contribution, will send all gifts through the American Red Cross to the International Red Cross Committee for the relief of children of Loyalist and Insurgent families alike.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City rose $1,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday $8,166,000,000, according to the conedition statement of the banks, issued yesterday. This advance, although small,

Nearly forty United Automobile Workers played a lively game of hide-and-seek with their international president in his hotel todya, undeteerred by a revolver he pointed at them from the door of his suite.
Edward Monaghan, 49 years old, died here today in St. James's Hospital of injuries suffered last night when he was struck by an automobile which was being pushed by another car.

The United States Lines announced last night that bids would be asked today in the United States and foreign countries for the scrapping of the liner Leviathan, which has been tied up since September, 1934, at a pier in Hoboken.

In a press statement today Leon Trotsky said that Joseph Stalin's agents were now seeking to murder the widow of Ignace Reiss, a militant Communist who was murdered at Lausanne following his renunciation of Stalinism.

Federal credit union loans outstanding on June 30 amounted to $11,152,100 compared to $4,328,905 at the midpoint of last year, C. R. Orchard, director of the Federal Credit Union Section of the Farm Credit Administration, announced today.

General advances were the rule in most of the commodity futures markets yesterday, after a period of -weaker prices. Coffee futures, however, were lower on weakness in Brazilian exchange and rubber and hides registered moderate declines. On .the cash markets,

The WPA Federal Music Project, which opens its new season Sunday night at the Theatre of Music with a concert by the New York Civic Orchestra, will inaugurate four special series of concerts during the month of October.

In the first transfer of the property since 1886, the six-story basement and sub-basement building on a lot 26 by 100 feet at 29 Great Jones Street was sold by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company as trustees for the Samuel D. Babcock estate.

Joseph A. Belz, superintendent of the composing room for The Evening Bulletin, died today of a heart at tack while at work. His age was 52. He entered the employ of The Evening Bulletin thirty-seven years ago and was named superintendent ter years ago.
Drake St (10-2775D), n e s; 200 ft n w of Viele Ave, 50x100; Florence E. Wieland, trustee, to Lucrezia Marchese, 341 Halleck St.

W. J. Roche, former chairman of the Canadian Civil Service Commission, died here late this afternoon after a long illness. His age was 77. William James Roche, M. D., C. M., LL. D., ex-M. P., chairman of the Civil Service Commission, former chancellor of the University of Western Ontario, situated at London, Ont., had an active career.

Purcell L. Smith, vice president of the Commonwealth Edison Company for four years, is expected to be elected to the new berth of chairman of the board of the Middle West Corporation at a meeting of Middle West's directors on Monday, it was reported today.

Salomon Brothers Hutzler, Dick Merle-Smith and Stroud Co., Inc., submitted yesterday the highest bid for an issue of $1,300,000 of 2 3/4 per cent equipment trust certificates of the Cambria Indiana Railroad Company. They bid 101.033 for the certificates, which will mature in one to ten years.

Robert Stegman, 27 years old, a broker's teller, of 265 Hancock Street, Jersey City, was killed yesterday- morning when an automobile in which he was riding crashed into a pole at Southern Boulevard and 133d Street, the Bronx.

The first session of the Cortes [Parliament] under the government of Premier Juan Negrin opens in Valencia tomorrow. While Government pursuit planes patrol overhead to prevent any Rebel bombardment of the City Hall, where the Deputies are to meet, an important debate is expected to take place on Government policy.
Moderate advances over a broad front characterized the course of the stock market today. Dealings, however, were inclined to quietness, without outstanding untoward event.

The British sloop Scarborough, attached to the British America and West Indies Station, will arrive in New York this morning at about 8 o'clock and moor to Pier 90, North River, foot of West Fiftieth Street.

Chancellor Hitler was host today to 1,000 German workmen who had constructed the German Pavilion at the Paris Exposition. He complimented them for their industry and workmanship at a luncheon in the Kroll open-air restaurant in the Tiergarten.

A luncheon. meeting of the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate Automobile Insurance and an honorary advisory committee of twenty-six State officials, members of the judiciary, educators and business, civic and welfare workers will be held- on Monday in the Hotel Victoria, it was announced last night by State Senator Julius S. Berg, chairman of the investigating committee.
The Red Sox and Senators divided a double-header today to close the major league baseball season in the Capital. Washington won the first game, 4 to 3, but dropped the second, 9 to 3.

Funeral services for Grenville T. Emmet, American Ambassador, were held in the little Anglican church attached to the British Legation this morning. The legation's chaplain, C. H. D. Grimes, officiated.

The engagement of Miss Mell Ford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Latimer Ford, to Harry Brimhall Goodwin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold C. Goodwin of Springfield, Mass., has been announced. The wedding will take place in November.

A proposed ordinance asking for outright condemnation of all lines of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company, including surface routes, subways and buses, so that the city might assume control over the system, was sent today to the City Council by Mayor Wilson.

Twenty-five families who had been investigated, interviewed by social workers and selected from thousands of applicants received the word today to move into Greenbelt, the government's $14,000,000 community.

Despite the dry and non-committal tone of the Japanese reply to Joseph C. Grew, the United States Ambassador, it can still be said with confidence that Japanese air operations over Chinese cities will not again be on the unrestricted scale of Sept. 22 [when the dead and wounded in Nanking raids were put at 2001.
26th St, 249 W. 6-story stone tenement, 25x98.9; The Franklin Savings Bank in the City of N. Y. against Edna H. Parker (Edna Holtorf), due, $17,099, taxes, etc, $85; to plaintiff for $14,000.
Retailers are watching closely the development of a consumer reaction against Japanese goods as a result of the public sympathy with China in the undeclared war.

Philadelphia's two morning newspapers, The Record and Inquirer, announced today an increase from 2 to 3 cents a copy in territory outside the greater Philadelphia district. The increase is effective immediately.

Rosalind bettered one record and equaled two trotting standards in capturing the forty-eighth running of the $2,000 Transylvania at today's Grand Circuit session. Her three heats in 2:02, 2:00 and 1:59 1/4 tied Greyhound's time for a three-heat race made last year at Goshen. The second clocking equaled the world record for a 4-year-old filly, held jointly by Miss Bertha Hanover, Tara and Calumet Evelvn.
Secretary Morgenthau at his press conference today declined to state whether he had any hope of balancing the Federal budget in the present fiscal year.

For three hours tonight Newark and Columbus battled all over Ruppert Stadium. The big. break came in the eleventh. inning and it: favored the Red Birds, who repeated their 5-4 victory of yesterday to send their little world series stock soaring on the wings of a two-game advantage over the International League's standard-bearers.

Sir William Ray, who resigned as Conservative Member of Parliament for Richmond early this year because of ill health, died here today at the age of 61. Knighted in 1929 after many years of service in London municipal affairs, he was elected to Parliament by acclamation in a by-election in 1932. The vacancy had been caused by the resignation of the late Sir Newton Moore.

Former Mayor James J. Walker, who was reappointed on Tuesday as assistant counsel for the Transit Commission, made it clear yesterday that he did not intend to begin work under the new designation until it had been approved by the State Civil Service Commission and Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the State Department of Public Service.

Incessant fog and snowstorms at Rudolf Island, north of the Franz Josef Archipelago, where the four planes of the Sheveleff expedition seeking to rescue Sigismund Levanevsky and the five other Russian Polar fliers, missing since Aug. 13, are waiting, has brought about a change in plans.

More than 200 members of the Connecticut Society of Civil Engineers, with members of the Hartford Engineering Club as their guests, inspected the portion of the $21,000,000 Merritt Parkway from Norwalk to the New York State line, in the first formal examination of the work on any part of this project.

In virtually a repetition of Wednesday's market action, prices on the Cotton Exchange here lost yesterday 4 to 9 points, or 20 to 45 cents a bale, and all months but October sold in new low territory for the season.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates Sept. 29 unless specified: San Diego to San Pedro: Altair, Sept. 30; Arctic. At Seattle: Phelps, Porter. At Chefoo: Pillsbury, Pope. Acushnet, at Washington Yard, Sept. 30. Blue, at New York, Sept. 30.

Mrs. Alice Hoyt Haight, wife of Charles Sherman Haight of 960 Park Avenue, New York, died early today at her country residence here after an illness of less than a week. Her husband is an admiralty lawyer of the firm of Haight, Griffin, Deming Gardner of 80 Broad Street, New York, and a director of the United States Leather Company and the Maritime Association of the Port of New York.

Herbert Patterson, formerly with L. J. Phillips Co., is with Hattie M. Melhuish. Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., announces that Miss Helen A. Mayne and her associates of the H. A. Mayne Company have become associated with the Ashforth organization in the residential department.
It doesn't make much difference as consequences are measured, but the Yanks yesterday touched a new low for the season at the Stadium. They dropped both ends of a doubleheader to the Athletics.
All the 55,000 Spanish refugees in France, with the exception of those who are sick, are to be sent home before Winter comes, it was learned today.

By a margin of a single stroke Mrs. Emmett Whalen of the Westchester Hills Golf Club won the weekly tournament of the Women's WestchesterFairfield Golf Association today at the Apawamis Club. She was out in 43 and needed one stroke less on the incoming holes.

Irving C. Krewson, president of Irving C. Krewson Corporation, resident buyers, was tendered a dinner by the staff of that organization at the Hotel Martinique last night on the occasion of the twenty-fifth anniversary of his service with the concern.

Hitting back at those who charge the reciprocal trade agreements program with being primarily responsible for increased imports of farm products, with consequent injury to farmers, the National Foreign Trade Council in a statement yesterday asserted that careful analysis of the figures disproves the argument.

Premier Benito Mussolini, on his arrival here this evening, was greeted with a frenzied welcome that was clearly meant to express the nation's approval of his meeting in Germany with Chancellor Adolf Hitler and to show the extent of his enormous popularity at home.
Wooster St, 241, n w cor 3d St (43-45). 110.9x42xirr-g.: Rogan Realty Corp (Harry A. Gordon, pres.) to Mayfair Management Corp, 1,450 Bway; mtg $140,800 ($1).

With an estimated attendance of about 5,000 visitors, the annual three-day flower show closed tonight. The proceeds will be devoted to the Greenwich Hospital and United Hospital of Port Chester, N. Y.

Michael King died in his sleep at his home, 147 Washington Place, early this morning. He had passed his ninetieth birthday on Monday. He was born in Ireland, near Dublin, and came to this country when he was sixteen. He lived in Paterson for several years, and moved to Passaic sixty-nine years ago. At the age of 34,

Nearly every traditional textbook on logic has a chapter on Fallacies, and from time immemorial they have prominently listed there the argumentum ad hominem. A recent text, "An Introduction to Logic and Scientific Method: by Morris R. Cohen and Ernest Nagel, discusses it thus:
Dr. Clarence Garrabrant, great-nephew of a pioneer settler of Absecon Island and for fifty years a practicing physician here, died tonight in the Atlantic City Hospital. His age was 80.

ABBEY -The Rev. Edward W., D. D., Pastor Emeritus of the First Presbyterian Church of Smithtown, L. I., passed away Thursday evening, Sept. 30, in the ninetieth year of his age. Funeral service at the church, Sunday, Oct. 3, at 3 P. M. Burial at Watkins Glen, N. Y. ADDIS-Suddenly, at New Milford, Conn., Sept. 29, John Stanley Addis. Service at Congregational 'Church. New Milford, 2 P. M., Saturday, Oct. 2.

Meeting together for the first time, the American sections of the World Conference on Faith and Order and the Universal Christian Council for Life and Work, interdenominational bodies representing the Protestant churches of the world, voted yesterday to form a "united front" in their efforts to build a "World Council of Churches."

Jascha Heifetz, violinist, who for thirteen years has refused to lend either himself or his violin to-a motion picture, and who has allowed only one radio broadcast of his music, today was signed by Sam Goldwyn to appear as the star of a projected color epic, "The Great Music Festival," which Goldwyn hopes to put before the cameras in May.

O. Sam Cummings, president of the National Association of Life Underwriters, announced yesterday the appointment of chairmen and personnel of the twenty-ninestanding and special committees of the association for the year 1937-38.

Secretary Ickes said today that the Public Works Administration's fifty-one housing projects probably would be transferred by Executive order to the United States Housing Authority, which will administer the Wagner-Steagall act.

Mrs. Mary Knox Buchwalter, widow of Judge Morris L. Buchwalter, died today at Ivy Hall Sanitarium. She was in her seventy-fifth year. Mrs. Buchwalter formerly was registrar at Smith College from which she was graduated in 1885, and at Barnard College.

Vic Fusia, Manhattan's star running and passing left halfback, will start against Texas A. and M. tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by Coach Chick Meehan as he put the Jaspers through their last hard practice session in Innisfail Park. Fusia, a veteran back, was kept out of the contest with St. Bonaventure.
Mrs. Mary D. V. Helme, in 21 Greenleaf St, Beaumont Park, Rye, Westchester; Edward V. Siedle, broker. Spencer Armstrong, in Oakhurst Road, Shore Acres, Mamaroneck; Houghton Company, broker.
Army had nearly two hours of gridiron practice today in preparation for the opening game with Clemson College here on Saturday, but the workout was not a full-speed session.

Mrs. Mary Metcalf Perin Barker, wife of Joseph Warren Barker of 417 West 117th Street, dean of the faculty of engineering at Columbia University, died yesterday at Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Mrs. Barker was active on the board of Knickerbocker Hospital and on the United Hospitals Campaign Committee and was an officer of the Women's Engineering Club.

Louis Warmers, a real estate broker and for thirty years Democratic captain of the Twentieth Assembly District in Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home, 1,393 Madison Street, of pneumonia. He was born in Manhattan seventy-nine years ago and had lived in Brooklyn for sixty years.

The French liner Normandie brought among her passengers yesterday an unusually large complement of actors, actresses, singers and others of the, entertainment world. Miss Hedy Kiesler, Viennese actress and star of the Czechoslovak film "Ecstacy" which was temporarily banned in the United States several years ago on indecency charges, was one.

Resolutions calling for the early placing of Spring orders for boys' and students' clothing, fibre identifiction, the holding of semi-annual conferences between retailers and manufacturers, and for steps to promote this merchandise were adopted at a meeting yesterday of merchandise managers and buyers under the auspices of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, and members of the Association of Boys' and Students' Clothing Manufacturers.

When the Giants yesterday clinched their third National League pennant in the five-year tenure of Bill Terry as manager, they officially opened the floodgates at their headquarters for world series ticket applications.

The Rev. Dr. Augustus Steimle, pastor of the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninetythird Street and recently one of the delegates from the United Lutheran Church of America to the Edinburgh Conference, died last night at his home, 174 West Ninety-third Street. Uremic poisoning with a heart complication was the cause of death. He was 67 years old.

The Consolidated Tenants League, Inc., of 209 West 125th Street annouilced yesterday plans for its second annual "tenant parade" to be held on Oct. 9, starting at Dorrance Brooks Park, 136th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. Harlem.

The City of New York has leased space on the second floor of the Bernheimer Building, at the northwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 116th Street, for a courtroom to be occupied by the Tenth District Municipal Court.

Lawrence, Blake Jewell, Inc., has arranged a building and permanent first mortgage of $675,000 for the 19 East Eighteenth Street Corporation on the fifteen-story apartment to be built on the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Eighteenth Street.

Lawrence Hanfgarn of Floral Park, L. I., appealed to the Supreme Court today in an attack on the constitutionality of a 1935 New York State law which abolished civil actions for alienation of affections, seduction and breach of promise.

Father Divine escaped a receivership for part of the property of his Peace Mission yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook denied the motion by Mrs. Verinda Brown, a former "angel," for a receiver and for posting of a bond.

Because of the absorption of 20,000 dismissed WPA workers on home relief rolls, the city's relief bill for the last quarter of this year showed a $2,562,400 increase over the preceding quarter when the Board of Estimate voted the appropriation yesterday.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

The annual Fall one-day tournament of the Artists and Writers Golf Association was held today at the North Hempstead Country Club with two competitions, an eighteen-hole medal-play handicap and a partners' best-ball match-play handicap against par. Nearly seventy-five members participated.

The $20,000,000 aircraft carrier, Yorktown steamed across Hampton Roads at dawn today and three hours later was commissioned as a unit of the navy and turned over to her commanding- officer, Captain E. D. McWhorter.

The wheat market on the Board of Trade here showed a strong undertone in the early trading today. Fairly aggressive buying, attributed to cash and export interests, lifted futures more than 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish both here and in Winnipeg.
" La Boheme" will be presented iSunday evening by the New York Hippodrome Opera Company instead of the originally announced "Othello."

A syndicate of investors headed by Lewis Suslow has purchased from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank the four-story apartment house for eight families at 2,089 Webster Avenue, north of East 180th Street, the Bronx.

The last day of validity for the automobile operators' licenses issued in May, 1936, brought a rush of business yesterday to the Motor Vehicle Bureau at 155 Worth Street and to other branch offices in the city.

Though all of the regulars were on hand and ready to get into action, Coach Hardwick and his helper devoted most of their attention to the second stringers during the Navy's practice today. The first eleven got some work, however, along the line of forward-pass defense.

Mixwell, 4-year-old Misstep gelding, making his- thirtieth start of the season today at Rockingham Park in the silks of Miss Anita Doris, survived a six-furlong duel with the Burnell Stable's Patrolite to capture the Reading Claiming Purse by a head. The race was timed in 1:123-5.

The campaign against unfair returns which has been conducted by the bathing suit group of the National Knitted Outerwear Association will be continued for the coming season, it was decided at a meeting at the Hotel Astor last night.

Captain John Walker Ross, editor of The New Orleans States, for which he worked fifty-two years, died today at the age of 69. He was nationally known as an editorial writer and as a political reporter in the hectic days of the Louisiana Lottery fight.

Seth Wilson, 17 years old, son of Edwin C. Wilson, counselor of the American Embassy in Paris, was sought as missing here yesterday at the request of his aunt, Mrs. Myra Connell, with whom he made his home at 15 Park Avenue.

Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott, promoting six captains yesterday to the rank of battalion chief, urged the commanders to give full service to the people of New York, who made their promotions possible by approving the three-platoon system in the Fire Department.

The National Restaurant Association's public good-will and friendship campaign, launched a year ago with the slogan "Good food is good health," has achieved "remarkable results," Frank J. Wiffler' secretary, told members today in his annual report.

Although consistent reports have been circulated that the cost of foodstuffs in Japar will show a marked upward trend, prices have shown no signs of skyrocketing, the Commerce Department has been advised by the American commercial attache at Tokyo, it was announced today.
A state of war will be decreed in Brazil within seventy hours, it was stated tonight by Dr. Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares, the Minister of Justice.

The Rev. Walter A. Kerwin, pastor for the last twenty-three years of Our Lady of Solace Roman Catholia Shrine Church, West Seventeenth Street and Mermaid Avenue, Coney Island, died yesterday at the rectory, after a stroke of apoplexy earlier in the. day. It was the second in two years. He was 62 years old.
Miss Marian C. Kingsland, who has been traveling in Europe with her aunt, Mrs. Newbold Morris, returned on the Normandie. She has joined her father, George Lovett Kingsland, at the Pierre.
Spanish Government officers said tonight that the Insurgents were rushing heavy reinforcements into Jaca, near the French border, to meet an unchecked Government drive less than twenty miles away.

THE President's prestige, people said, was declining at a terrific rate. Many who had been his friends had become his enemies. Lawyers were against him almost as a body, and merchants and bankers were frightened of what he would do.

The education of the public mind in the United States to accept the possibility of a reduction in the price of gold is recommended in an article by R. H. Brand, managing director of Lazard Brothers Co. of London, published in the current issue of International Conciliation by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, with a foreword by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president.

William Fellowes Morgan, Commisisoner of Markets, was unsuccessful yesterday afternoon in his attempt to avert a stoppage "strike" in the 5,000-odd butcher shops of the Federation of Kosher Butchers in a protest against what they contend is an excessive wholesale price of meat.

A vigorous fight for the lion's share of the medium price, blended whisky market in New York will be launched shortly by distillers and promises to boom advertising linage in newspapers here, according to comment here yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin F. McGuckin gave a dinner tonight at Kate's Mountain Lodge. Mrs. H. W. Adams entertained there in honor of Mrs. Beale E. Poste. Mrs. Edward W. Lloyd and Mrs. R. G. Raymond were there with luncheon guests.

Miss Betty S. Trippe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Juan T. Trippe of New York and East Hampton, L. L., was designated by Secretary Swanson today as sponsor of the destroyer Trippe, which will be launched at the Boston Navy Yard on Feb. 1.
The opening this evening is up at the Adelphi, where the Federal Theatre Project will set forth "A Hero Is Born," or Theresa Helburn's fantasy derivative from a story by Andrew Lang.

A PolishGerman minorities agreement is ready to be signed on Foreign Minister Josef Beck's return from Geneva. It will be another "nonaggression pact" in which each Government will solemnly proclaim the rights of its minority in the other country and will undertake to respect the rights of the other's minority.

Frank A. Mannen, senior vice president and member of the insurance brokerage firm of Marsh McLennan, at 70 Pine Street, New York, died this morning in the Harkness Pavilion of the Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. He was 70 years old and resided here at 16 Pryer Lane.
The lag recently noted in awards for engineering construction, as compared with 1936, continued last week.

The engagement of Miss Constance White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward N. White of this place, to Richard Glover, son of Dr. and Mrs. T. R. Glover of Cambridge, England, has been announced by her parents.
The Connecticut Board of Fisheries and Game will meet next Thursday to pass on the question of an open season for grouse, a topic in which sportsmen of that State are vitally concerned.

William Robertson Coe, with a total of 109 points, won the sweepstakes award tonight at the thirty-sixth Fall vegetable and flower show of the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society in Parish Hall of Christ Church here.

John Haynes Holmes, pastor of the Community Church, announced yesterday his withdrawal as a candidate for the City Council. It would be impossible, Dr. Holmes declared, "to undertake a task of this kind and still fulfil my primary duties as minister and pastor."

The net income of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore and its wholly owned subsidiaries amounted to $6,570,030 in the year ended on Aug. 31, after deductions for Federal income taxes, depreciation and fixed charges, according to a report issued yesterday.

Oddlot trading on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Sept. 25 showed a continuance of the buying trend with 300,455 shares bought on balance by customers, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The net operating income for August of 137 Class I railroads amounted to $50,307,881, a drop of 22.2 per cent from the same month of 1936, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday. The decrease "was due to rising costs of operation, which include increased costs of materials, supplies and fuel and also a higher wage rate," the association said.

Max Silverman, long a fugitive from the rackets and Drukman inquiries here, formally signed a waiver of extradition in Los Angeles yesterday and started for New York by plane in the company of two New York detectives.

The Federal Trade Commission concluded examination yesterday of witnesses for the Richard Hudnut Company, one of the corporations in the cosmetics field that have been charged by the Government with violation of fair trade practices.

Hugo L. Black, the newly appointed associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, will speak tomorrow night over three broadcasting chains, embracing 300 radio stations, to answer, it is assumed, the charges that he is, or has been, a member of the Ku Klux Klan.

Another chapter in the long history of Virginia Military Institute will be closed tomorrow when Major Gen. John Archer Lejeune relinquishes his command as superintendent to Major Gen. Charles Evans Kilbourne, after heading the institute since 1929.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended Sept. 30 were announced today: Kaluf, Major J., Quantico, Va., relieved from duty on Staff of Marine Corps Schools and assigned to duty as Secretary Marine Corps equipment board there.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in September was the largest for any month since April. The most active day of the month was the thirteenth, when 2,561,820 shares were sold, and the slowest day's trading was 690,900, on Sept. 3.

The Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that corporations had a right to seek court aid to prevent disclosure by the Securities and Exchange Commission of information regarding their organization. The ruling was given in an opinion by Associate Justice D. Lawrence Groner in three cases involving
Solvay American Investment Corportion 5 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $100 par, has been stricken from the Stock Exchange list.
8th St. 393-5 E; to 3-story nursery: Ninth Street Day Nursery Orphan Home, Inc, 733 E. 9th St, owner; C. B. Meyers, architect; cost, $10,000.

Competition to insure protection to the consumer must remain free and must have definite, legislative safeguards, Congressman John E. Miller, Democrat, of Arkansas, told delegates to the National Association of Retail Druggists at the afternoon session of their annual convention today at Hotel Jefferson.
Sir Gerald Campbell, British consul general, will be guest of honor at a reception this afternoon in celebration of the opening of new offices of Yardley Company at 620 Fifth Avenue.
Official New York rejected today the application of a third national labor union to incorporate within the State.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company today applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to assume authority and obligation for the issuance of $1,660,000 equipmenttrust certificates, Series 1937,

KELLEY, BERNARD W. (Sept. 5). Estate, less than $10,000. To Madeline Kelley, 138 73d St., Brooklyn; Gerard W. Kelley, 3,450 Corsa Ave., Bronx, and Eugene F. Kelley, executor, ??3 Radford St., Yonkers, N. Y., children, equally. MABURY, AUGUSTUS (May 3). Estate, $2,000. To Annie Jackson, 84 Wallingford Rd., Brighton, Mass., residue. William Geng, friend, executor, 115 Manhattan Ave., New Rochelle, N. Y.

The expansion of excess reserves was carried further in the week ended on Wednesday, thanks largely to continued Treasury disbursements out of deposits previously accumulated in the Reserve Banks. Total reserves rose $56,000,000 to $7,033,000,000, while the excess over requirements amounted to $1,060,000,000, a rise of $40,000,000.

Numerous firm changes, reorganizations and additions to the staffs of brokerage houses were announced yesterday to become effective today. Howard S. Hoit. founder of the firm of Hoit, Rose Troster and for many years a partner in it, has rejoined the organization as a general partner.

The marriage of Miss Martha Holcomb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Holcomb of this city and Fishers Island, N. Y., to Frank Ronald Stemp of Paget, Bermuda, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hubert Stemp of Canford Cliffs, Dorset, England, took place here this afternoon in St. John's Church. The Rev. Dr. John N. Lewis performed the ceremony.

A plan of pensions and group life insurance for 2,700 members of Harvard University's non-teaching staff will be put into operation on Nov. 1. As members of the faculty and teaching staff have been eligible to participate in retirement plans, the system for non-teaching workers will complete the establishment of retirement provisions for all employes of the university.

Arthur P. McNulty, who was assistant campaign manager for the American Labor party last year, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as a Municipal Court justice to serve until the end of the year.

Start of classes today forced Cornell's football squad to practice under floodlights for the first time this season. The drill was stiff, the first and second teams rehearsing defense manoeuvres against Colgate plays and then clashing in a touch-tackle scrimmage in which blocking was stressed.

Bank clearings declined 5.9 per cent in the week ended on Wednesday from the corresponding period of 1936. In the preceding week there was an increase of 22.5 per cent in a similar comparison, as a result of the heavy midmonth settlements which were included in that period.

The disposition of the State Department today was to refrain from prolonging the diplomatic controversy with Japan over her bombing of open cities and towns in China or at least to defer a decision on policy until after the Assembly of the League of Nations has concluded its sessions in Geneva.

Following is the text of Mayor La Guardia's address at Carnegie Hall: Mr. Chairman, ladies and gentlemen: It is nearly midnight now. I know most of you have to work tomorrow, and I must work tomorrow.
Reflecting the general unsettlement in security markets and the sharp decline in values, the new investment market was virtually at a standstill during September.

The program for the annual convention of the American Bankers Association, to be held in Boston from Oct. 11 to 14, has been planned to give a comprehensive survey of the prospects of institutions in the United States and of various phases of business, banking and finance, according to an announcement made here yesterday by Tom K. Smith, president of the Boatmen's National Bank, St. Louis, who is president of the association.

The Bureau of Mines said today that an "abnormal export situation" in the crude oil industry, with considerable oil going to the East, probably would counteract the usual Autumnal decline in demand for oil.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor are expected here next week. It is believed they will remain here and at Enzesfeld Castle for a few days, after which they will go to Graz.
The battle between the Pirates and Cardinals for third place in the National League apparently was settled in Pittsburgh's favor in one in-Ding today.

The first definite breach in a long-standing agreement by seven major motion-picture companies not to back production of any plays by members of the Dramatists Guild was revealed yesterday in an announcement from Columbia Pictures that it is prepared to sign the Guild's minimum basic agreement.
The third largest fire in the history of Baltimore destroyed Carlin's, the city's largest amusement park, early today, injuring two firemen , and causing more than $250,000 damage.
Miss Sara Heller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar W. Heller of this city and Rumson, has chosen Nov. 11 for her wedding to Joseph Fewsmith Lord, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howell Gurney Lord, also of Newark.

The Indians climbed to within a game and a half of the third-place.White Sox today as Johnny Allen pitched them a 6-to-4 victory in the opener of a double bill for his fifteenth straight of the season, and Bob Feller fanned eleven to down the Chicagoans, 4 to 1, in an eight-inning nightcap.

Prompt action by the State to end the emergency mortgage foreclosure moratorium was urged by realty interests and representatives of lending institutions at a public hearing held here today by the joint legislative committee studying the moratorium and deficiency judgment problems.

The Tigers clinched second place in the American League today even though they were overwhelmed by the Browns, 10 to 3. Assurance of the position of runner-up to the Yankees came when the third-place White Sox lost a double-header to the Indians.

Playing at home, Queen of South held Dundee to a 2-2 draw in a First Division, Scottish Football League, match today. By sharing the points Dundee moved into a tie with the Glasgow Rangers for leadership of the league, each having 15 points. In a county Rugby match at Norwich, Eastern Counties defeated Leicestershire, 17-8.
Postmaster General Farley ridiculed here tonight Senator Vandenberg's suggestion of coalition between anti-New Deal Democrats and Republicans.

Miss Judith Allen, screen actress, sued Mrs. Delphine Dodge for $2,000,0001 today, charging that the heiress had alienated the affections of her husband, Jack Doyle, boxer and actor. The plea gave the de.
With Mary Pickford looking on, Mayor La Guardia signed a proclamation at City Hall yesterday calling on the public to participate in observance of Loyalty Days tomorrow and Sunday.

Any idea that there is no "open door" for young men seeking jobs in modern industry and finance was characterized today by Jason Westerfield, secretary of the New York Stock Exchange, as "mischievous humbug."

Loaded with 600 head of wild steers, bucking horses, range cows land other stock for the twelfth annual world's championship rodeo, a special train will arrive about noon today at the stockyards at Forty-first Street and Eleventh Avenue.

Admiral Vladimir Orloff, who with Foreign Commissar Maxim M. Litvinoff, represented Soviet Russia at the coronation of George VI, has been removed as Commander-in-Chief of the Soviet Navy, it became known in a roundabout way today.

ADLER, KAROLINE (June 11, 1936). Gross assets, $2,966; net, $1,313. To Carol Adler, granddaughter, $1,000; Elsie Adler, daughter, and Oscar Adler, son, one-half residue each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $1,520. Samuel B. and Bernard Pollak, attorneys, 570 7th Ave.

MORNING EVENTS Class 33, Model Hunters, ThoroughbredsFirst, Mrs. E. H. Augustus's ch. g. Chatter Chat; second, Mrs. Harvey Gibson's gr. g. Coq d'Argent; third, Crispin Oglebay's b. g. Wilderkit; fourth, Miss Dolly Von Stade's b. g. Crazy Creek.

The formal beginning on the new.$400,000 men's gymnasium at Bucknell University was marked this morning by cornerstone-laying ceremonies featured by a radio address by Kenesaw M. Landis, commissioner of organized baseball.
Nebraska's vaunted line will get its first football trial of 1937 on Saturday against just about the strongest testers in the businessthe Minnesota backfield.

Miss Anne Whitifey Rose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ambrose Whitney Rose of Huntington and Block Island, have announced the plans of her wedding to Donald Frederick Hackstaff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William Hackstaff, also of Huntington.

An order halting reorganization of the Baldwin Locomotive Works was withdrawn today by Judge J. Whitaker Thompson of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals after counsel for the company had questioned his right to grant the order.
It cost the Columbus Red Birds $1,000 in cash and jewelry tonight as they won their. second game of the little world series with the Newark Bears.

Ten producers of the Pocahontas Field of Southeastern West Virginia and Virginia today made such serious objections before the Bituminous Coal Commission to the methods of classifying coals by the producers' board of the region that the commission set an investigation of the whole matter for next Monday and ordered all members of the district board and its classification experts to be present.

A nation-wide campaign to encourage the industrial expansion of the South will be started at once by the Governors of nine Southeastern States, it was announced here today. The project calls for the expenditure of $100,000 in the first year, which sum has already been raised, and $250,000 a year in advertising alone after that, the announcement said.

Because of an adverse vote by the State Banking Board yesterday, the State Banking Department will not grant an organization certificate for the Real Estate Trust Company of New York, whose sponsors included Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, and who wanted it to act as a trustee for guaranteed mortgage certificates.

Miss Marion Miley shot consistent sub-par golf at Mrs. Jane Cothran Jameson and won the Southeastern women's invitation tournament today, 2 up. The smiling Cincinnati golfer came from behind in the eighteen-hole final after the Columbia (S. C.) star led her by one hole at the turn.

Five million persons, comprising two-fifths of the total population of the State, received public aid under the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, but 70 per cent of that number had left the relief rolls by the time the functions of the TERA were turned over to the State Department of Social Welfare on July 1 of this year, the TERA informed Governor Lehman yesterday in its final report.

The Rev. Dr. Edward W. Abbey, pastor emeritus of the First Presbyterian Church of Smithtown and one of the oldest ministers in the country, died last night at his home in Smithtown Branch. He was in his ninetieth year. Dr. Abbey had served in the ministry for sixty-three years and during the last thirty-four years was pastor of the Smithtown church.

Miss Sylvia Szechenyi entertained a group of friends with a picnic luncheon at Bailey's Beach today. Miss Nancy Wilson is a guest of Miss Szechenyi's mother, Countess Laszlo Szechenyi, at the Breakers.

Miss Mary W. Dewson's resignation as vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee was announced today. In resigning she told Chairman Farley that she could not continue in such a position in view of her recent appointment to the Social Security Board.
Gold received at the Port of New York in September aggregated $67,237,300, compared to $47,551,500 in August and $137,121,600 in September, 1936. Almost one-half of the gold came from Great Britain.

Throughout this country there has seemed to be of late a growing thirst for information. The wide spread of forums attests it; so do the increased numbers of newspaper and radio commentators, and the greater concentration on Washington of the spotlight of inquiry.
Daylight saving was observed this year by 30,000,000 people, according to the newspapers.
In every prison that the Government lodged him Noble John Moore has been treated as a pariah by his fellow felons.

A resolution proposing three steps to bring tax relief to automobile owners in thirteen States was adopted today by members of the Interstate Conference on Automotive Taxation meeting at the Stevens Hotel.

Dr. Blase Cole, a lay judge of the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals and former State Senator, was killed and three companions injured this evening in a collision between Dr. Cole's automobile and a truck on Roles 23 west of here.

A complaint charging misuse of the United States flag in an advertisement for celebration of German Day was filed yesterday in Yorkville Court by the German-American League for Culture, an antiNazi organization.

That phase of football that comes under the general head of eating and oratory stepped off to a fast start yesterday with the holding of the first luncheon of the Touchdown Club at the Princeton Club at high noon and the staging of a Columbia-Army beefsteak dinner at Jack Dempsey's in the evening.

While Gosport prepared a resplendent welcome for the Endeavour I and the intrepid nineteen men who sailed her through one of the Atlantic's worst storms, an enterprising reporter tonight got a story of how narrowly they escaped death a few seconds after the yacht broke away from the Viva's towline.

Only one of the six bouts on the weekly boxing program at the Fort Hamilton Arena in Brooklyn last night went the limit. Vincenzo Dell'Orto, 123, Italy, defeated Sammy Garcia, 119, Boston, in eight rounds. In another star eight-rounder Pete Scalzo, 126, West Side, knocked out Harry Gentile, 125, Matawan, N. J., in 2:15 of the third.
Mrs. Hortense M. Odlum, president of Bonwit, Teller Co., was the guest of honor last evening at a reception celebrating her third anniversary as head of the Fifth Avenue specialty shop.

THE LONG VIEW, by Hilda Morris (Putnam, $2.50). A novel of American life. LUIGI PIRANDELLO, 1867-1936, by Walter Starkie (Dutton, $2). A revised edition. THE CHECKERED YEARS, by Mary Dodge Woodward (Caxton, $3). Excerpts from a frontier diary, edited by Mary Boynton Cowdrey.

J. A. Schallenberg has been appointed assistant controller of Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation. Cary M. Bok was elected yesterday treasurer and acting secretary of the Curtis Publishing Company. As treasurer he succeeds Philip S. Collins, resigned.
Harris Hammond, son of the late John Hays Hammond, mining engineer and inventor, filed a petition in bankruptcy in Federal Court yesterday, reporting liabilities of $2,644,904 and $3,926 in assets.

In presenting his first budget to the finance commission of the Chamber of Deputies-with an estimated surplus of 1,602,000,000 francs-Finance Minister Georges Bonnet warned the country that his figures and the franc could not be maintained unless French capital and labor would make the necessary effort to increase production.

Voicing a warning today that the country was in danger of a business recession at any time under the present Federal tax structure, Morris S. Tremaine, Controller of the State of New York for ten years, blamedthe stock market collapse of recent weeks on the New Deal's tax system.
Redemptions of bonds prior to their maturity dates during September were in somewhat larger volume than in the preceding month, but were the smallest amount for a September in three years.

General Felipe Alfau, who received the highest military decorations of Spain under the monarchist regime for his services in colonial campaigns, died on Sunday in Tangier, Morocco, at the age of 85, according to word received here yesterday.
Miss Anastasia Van Burkalow of the Hunter College class of '31 has been appointed to the James Furman Kemp Fellowship in Geology and Mineralogy at Columbia University. Professor Edward M.

Today the New York State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration publishes its final report, which covers the period from Nov. 1, 1931, to June 30 of this year. It is in many ways a remarkable document, but further light must be thrown on some of its statements before a clear picture of the State relief program can be formed. The report asserts, for example:
A group of Episcopal clerics said by leaders to number more than 1,300 took a stand today against any modification of church law concerning remarriage after divorce.
Stocks sagged and closed irregular after slight early gains; turnover, 1,045,498 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds higher, foreign issues irregular; transactions, $7,495,750.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 28: Hobbs, Lt. I. E., the Gannet, to Naval Aircraft Factory, Philadelphia. Spahr, Jr. Lt. O. W. Jr., the Preble, to the Antares. Martin, Jr. Lt. J. C., the R-4, to the Snapper and on board when commissioned.

The controversy over the Nazi rally to be held here tomorrow night reached a high pitch today with the arrival of Ernst Bohle, Nazi party leader for foreign countries, who will be-the chief speaker at the rally.

Bonds continued to move forward yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, but the volume of trading showed only a slight increase. Secondary railroad issues supplied the leadership in the up movement, again responding to a lively demand, with gains of major fractions to 3 points.
