The American Bar Association today refused, through its General Assembly, to make a direct investigation of the "latest appointee" to the Supreme Court by a vote of 193 to 161, but the fight will be resumed on the floor tomorrow.

Appointments for 1937-38 to The Fordham Ram, student weekly newspaper of Fordham College, are announced this morning in the columns of its first issue for the current scholastic year, the nineteenth of its publication. The appointments were approved by the dean of the college and the new faculty adviser to The Ram, the Rev. Lawrence S. Atherton.

An appeal for relief funds for Chinese war sufferers will be issued tomorrow by a committee of leading citizens cooperating with the British Red Cross and the China Association. The announcement tonight followed a published offer by Sir Abe Bailey to start such a fund with a [Pound]1,000 contribution.

Frank Coyne of Yonkers, former District Attorney of Westchester County, was endorsed today for county judge by the executive committee of the Westchester County Republican Committee, it was announced at committee headquarters.

Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General in New York, presented the badge of the civil rank of Commander of the Order of the British Empire yesterday to Robert K. Appleby, chairman of the executive board of the British Chamber of Commerce.

Sam Sorkin, general manager of the Association of Workers in Public Relief Agencies, Local 9, of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, denied yesterday the charge of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic nominee for Mayor, that the relief set-up in New York City was under Communist control and that only Communists received adequate service from the ERB administration.

By ROSCOE McGOWEN Catching the pennant-winning iants in a state of relaxation at bbets Field yesterday, the longiffering Dodgers sneaked over a 4 victory to end their record losg streak at fourteen games.

Miss Margaret M. Maloney and George R. McCormick, who are to be married tomorrow morning at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, were the honored guests at a buffet supper which Mr. and Mrs. John B. Hull Jr. gave tonight. Members of the wedding party were among the guests.

The Tennessee, Alabama Georgia Railway Company presented todayto the Interstate Commerce Commission a reorganization plan to transfer its assets from a syndicate managed by Coverdale Colpitts, consulting engineers of New York, to a company to be known as the Delaware Corporation.

Julius J. Umansky, Socialist designee for Borough President of the Bronx, made public last night his declination of the nomination. He remained as designee for the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District.

40th St, 237 West, 5-story tenement, 25x98.9: the Greenwich Savings Bank against Ludin Realty Co; due, 46,286; to plaintiff for S30,000. By ROBERT FISHEL 115th St, 6 E., 6-story tenement, 25x100.11: Greenwich Savings Bank against Granthan Estates, Inc; due, $25,333; taxes, etc, $85; to plaintiff for $15,000.

Two volumes of artists' memoirs are scheduled for publication this month. One is Thomas Hart Benton's "An Artist in America" (McBride). The other is "The Journals of Delacroix," in Walter Pach's translation, which will be issued by Covici, Friede.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced last night that a comprehensive settlement had been reached involving the claims made through him as representative of creditors of the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company in Rehabilitation against the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

John J. Kalb, pioneer Rochester resident who traveled West by stagecoach in 1878 and returned to the city to run a tannery with his father and later direct a leather store, was dead today at the age of 83. Mr. Kalb, descendant of

Richard J. Daly of New Rochelle, head of an "investment advisory service" here until his arrest in June, was sentenced today by County Judge Gerald Nolan to two and a half to ten years in Sing Sing Prison for first degree grand larceny. He pleaded guilty two weeks ago to misappropriating $2,400 deposited with him for investment by John K. Bastian, former White Plains Commissioner of Public Welfare.

Earnings of the Royal Typewriter Company, Inc., for the seven months ended on July 31, last, were the best on record. The net profit amounted to $1,788,922 after Federal income taxes and other charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

Solvlng Bill Lee for three runs in the first inning, the Cardinals defeated the Cubs, 4 to 1, today and assured Themselves of winding up the season in the first division. Si Johnson scattered eight hits for his twelfth victory. The lone Chicago

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today: CUSTOMS 4043-United States v. Arnold Bernstein Steamship Co. Judgment ordered corrected. 4056-C. W. Hunter v. United States. Time to deposit printing costs extended to Oct. 31, 1937, upon motion of appellant.

John F. Ryan, a former cafe proprietor of Brooklyn and husband of the late Maggie Cline, wellknown musical comedy singer of the Eighteen Nineties, died on Thursday at his home, 136 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, at the age of 84.

Charles Baron, 70, assistant foreman at a vest company, returning v From a bank today with the firm's $1,392 payroll, was beaten by two thugs who snatched a package from under his arm. Company officials told police he had been robbed of the payroll. At a hospital,
President Roosevelt had no comment to make tonight on the radio speech in which Associate Justice Black discussed his connection with the Ku Klux Klan.

Miss Kathleen Hickok Parsons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Parsons of this place, was married to David Waters of New Rochelle, son of Mrs. Charles T. Waters and the late Mr. Waters, this evening in the Larchmont Avenue Church here.

A new process of smelting low-grade iron ores, invented by two Germans but first successfully applied by an American in England, is now being developed here on a large scale to provide the German Army with its iron and steel in case of a future war and a new blockade.

Wil1am P. (Mickey) Devine, former major league baseball player, died at his home tonight after a heart attack. His age was 45. Devine, who spent nineteen years in organized baseball, broke into the major leagues as a catcher with the Boston Red Sox.

A sensational iron shot by Tommy Harmon, played by lantern light to a green hidden in the dark, enabled the Montclair pro and Steve Ternyei of Aldecress to gain the semi-finals of the third annual New Jersey professional best-ball golf championship today at the Preakness Hills Country Club.

A revamped Cornell eleven will face Jack Colgate in the renewal of their gridiron rivalry on Schoellkopf field tomorrow. Captain Ted Hughes, held out of the Penn State game because of injuries, will be at center. Sid Roth,

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 30: BRIGADIER GENERAL Peyton, P. B., one day leave, Sept. 30. COLONEL Hunt, C. A., (Inf.), General Staff Corps, one day leave, Oct. 4.
Syracuse's inexperienced football forces made their debut tonight under Ossie Solem's coaching by staging a second-half rally to overcome Clarkson, 26 to 6, before a crowd of 118,000.

Yesterday's news contained two illuminating notes on the highly contro'versial subject of government. Nobody questions that today's crisis is in large part governmental. The central question of our time is how to regulate the complex machinery and interlocking networks of twentieth-century life in the interests of the whole people.

The University of Mississippi and Temple battled to a scoreless draw at the Owls' Stadium tonight before 22,000 fans, but Coach Pop Warner's team had at least four opportunities to put over touchdowns.

Plans for alterations were announced yesterday in connection with sales of buildings in Manhattan. The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company sold to Edward and Ethel Romaine the front and rear house on a lot 21 by 97.6 feet at 21 Cornelia Street, containing seven apartments.

As a means of preventing controversies such as have followed the naming of Justice Hugo L. Black to the Supreme Court, the American Bar Association today adopted a resolution petitioning the United States Senate to hold public hearings on all future judicial appointments.
H. W. A. F. pr Crichton-Browne, explorer, died at his home in Shropshire today at the age of 71. Surviving is his father, Sir James, who is 96 and who published his most recent book in 1932.

The Wild West came to town at 10:55 o'clock yesterday morning. A long train loaded with 600 bucking horses, wild cows, enormous Brahma steers and other livestock backed into a siding at Forty-first Street and Eleventh Avenue and unofficially the twelfth annual World's Championship Rodeo was under way. Officially it will begin

Greenwich's grand list of taxable property reached an all-time record of $180,100,720, representing an increase in the total gross of $4,047,300 over last year's figure of $176,047,300, the Greenwich Board of Assessors revealed today. It is the biggest annual increase in many years.

Manhattan Broadway, 4,275-95, 29.9x100.11; for ??-story auto showroom and service building; Estate of Patrick J. McNulty, 551 W 52d St. owner; William Shary, architect; cost Alterations Madison Ave, 519; to 5-story tenement and stores; Five Hundred and Nineteen Madison Ave Corp, 527 7th Ave, owner; D. P. Hall, architect; cost, $20,000.

George Washington University successfully launched its 1937 football campaign tonight at Griffith Stadium with a 34-6 victory over Wake Forest. A throng of 12,000 fans saw the Deacons hold their heavier opponents in check in the first half, only to weaken in the final.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Macdonald of this city have announced the engagement of Mrs. Macdonald's sister, Mrs. Mary Katherine Conway Bogart, widow of Arthur Lawrence Bogart, to Wallace John Law of Cranford.

Miss Irma Patricia Butler, daughter of Mrs. Clifton Downing Butler of Flushing, Queens, was married to Delmont Locke Bogart, son of Mrs. E. Locke Bogart of Scarsdale, N. Y., yesterday morning in the chantry of St. Thomas Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, the rector.

John Raymond (Ray) Henderson of Omaha, Neb., and three other passengers were killed and five were seriously injured today when the British Imperial Airways flying boat Courtier, connecting Alexandria and London, sank after crashing in Phaleron Bay.

The band played two ruffles and flourishes yesterday afternoon; the saluting guns of the station ship Seattle were fired thirteen times and the flag of Rear Admiral Harris Laning fluttered down from the main truck for the last time.

Trading by members of the New York Stock Exchange in round lots for their own account in the week ended on Sept. 4 aggregated 1,731,350 shares bought and sold and was. approximately the same proportion of total volume, 20.59 per cent to 20.99 per cent, as in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

The firm of Guggenheimer, Strasser Meyer having been dissolved, Charles H. Meyer will continue the general practice of law at 63 Wall Street and will act as counsel in matters involving stock brokerage and stock exchange law. Ira D. Wallach will be associated with him.

Sixteen pickets engaged in a minor scuffle with police yesterday afternoon at 1:30 o'clock in front of 1,600 Broadway, offices of Max Fleischer Co., makers of animated cartoons. One picket was slightly

Spanking, the misery caused by wearing the wrong kind of clothes, being made to "feel wicked," and the unfairness of teachers are the childhood punishments that make the deepest impression and remain poignant well into adult life, a study presented at yesterday's opening session of the Progressive Education Association's conference disclosed.

With Mayor La Guardia scheduled to present his 1938 executive budget to the Board of Estimate in City Hall at noon today, the Citizens Budget Commission taxed him yesterday with lacking a foundation for his charges that the commission's budget estimates were inaccurate.

Jim Tobin held the Reds to six hits and collected four himself to lead the Pirates to a 6 to 3 victory today. The triumph was the seventh straight for Pittsburgh and the eighteenth out of nineteen games with the Reds this season. The box score:
For the first time in the history of world series competition a woman was "cut in" yesterday on the division of the players' share of the receipts for the post-season baseball clashes.
The Norfold, a Norwegian oil tanker, was badly damaged today in a collision with the Nevadin of the American-Hawaiin line during a fog.

Senator Copeland, who has been one of the severest critics of administration policies, said today that President Roosevelt's New Deal program would win in the 1940 election unless a strong third party with something like the strength of the Progressive party in 1912, was formed.

More than 603,000 employes were on the payrolls of the steel industry in the United States in August, compared with 594,000 in July and 522,000 in August, 1936, the American Iron and Steel Institute has reported. The increase reflected

With reference to your editorial of today wherein you question the meaning of the statement in the final TERA report that 5,000,000 different people in New York State have been on relief at some time or other since 1931, please know that this figure is based on different individuals, excluding all duplication of names.

Another of the sporadic strikes being called by the Building Service Employes International Union, Local 32B, affected yesterday the 18-story Beaux Arts Apartments, 307 and 310 East Forty-fourth Street, tying up sixty tenants who were attempting to move in or out of the buildings.

Numerout transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations in August and some in earlier months were shown by a summary of reports made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Natalie Nadelle, Inc., Nettie Cohen, president, store for dress shop at 9 E. 49th St. through Culver, Hollyday Co. and William A. White Sons, brokers. Buthman Ramelmeier, store for butcher shop at 642 Columbus Ave.; HaggstromCallen-Davis Co., brokers.

The stock-transfer books of the Northern Securities Company, formed in an unsuccessful effort to consolidate control of the Great Northern and Northern Pacific Railways, will finally be closed on Oct. 30, it was announced yesterday.

Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, commander of the United States Yangtze River patrol, ordered the patrol ship Guam to Wuhu, thirty miles up the river, to give officers and sailors shore leave after their weeks of continuous confinement aboard ship off Nanking.

A nominal increase took place in cotton-mill activity last week when a marked gain was seasonal, and the adjusted index has eased to 129.1 from 133.0. For the week ended Sept. 26, 1936, the figure was 136.9.

The report of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries for the first eight months of this year, made public yesterday, showed a consolidated net profit of $12,948,496 after Federal income taxes, depreciation, interest, amortization and 'other charges. After dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock, the profit was equivalent to $5.36 each on 1,805,000 common shares.

Additional details on 1938 automotive advertising campaigns were released yesterday by leading companies. Increasing its budget approximately 20 to 25 per cent, the Cadillac Motor Car Company will launch its new campaign on Oct. 22.
The resignation of Donald Kirkpatrick as president of the National Bank of New Jersey and the election of Raymond E. Grymes as acting president was announced here today.

Mrs. Lois Frances Clark Harding, a retired actress, known on the stage as Lois Frances Clark, died yesterday in a hospital in Brentwood, L. I. Her age was 74. Born in Dubuque, Iowa, Mrs. Harding appeared first on the stage in the early Eighties.

The Department of Markets In conjunction with the United States Department of Agriculture will start an immediate "comprehensive survey" of the cost and methods of selling meats throughout the city, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, announced yesterday afternoon.

The Newfoundland Commission Government published today terms of an agreement with, Frederick S. Lawrence of the Explorers' Club, New York, whereby he would stock reindeer in Labrador, apparently for commercial purposes.

Representatives of Los Angeles are here to arrange for the sale of a contemplated issue of $10,200,000 of electric-plant revenue bonds of the Department of Water and Power of the city of Los Angeles, it was announced yesterday.

Franklin D. Roosevelt and Burton K. Wheeler are bitter opponents on the subject of reorganizing the United States Supreme Court, but they have been allies for so long in pouring Federal funds into this Northeastern Montana area that the court issue is ignored in the section and neither has lost perceptibly in strength with the people.

Federal Government officials were charged yesterday by Abraham Epstein, authority on social security, with Fascist and dictatorial tactics, involving "a serious encroachment on academic freedom," in what Mr. Epstein characterized as an attempt to curtail lectures he is giving at New York University.

Although the opulent saturnalia called "Bravo!" had been going on for almost two weeks at the new International Casino, the management summoned one and all to a second unveiling last Wednesday night, as if to say:

Their vaunted batting attack stopped cold, the Newark Bears, prohibitive favorites to win the Little World Series when it started, went down to their third straight defeat at the hands of the Columbus Red Birds in the third game tonight at Ruppert Stadium.
The American Newspaper Guild filed a complaint with the National Labor Renations Board today against The Chicago Tribune. It charged that
A banking group composed of Blyth Co., Inc., and including Kaiser Co., Schwabacker Co.

S. Laurence Bodine, a retired business man and sportsman, died at his home, Greenbank Farm, Newtown Square, today after a short illness. He was 73. Born in this city he was the son of Francis Lee and Mary Milliken Bodine. After his graduation from

The Milwaukee Journal announced today that 558 of its employes owned 30,000 shares, or 25 per cent, of its outstanding capital stock. Thus, the paper said, pledges made when The Journal was acquired from heirs of the founder, L. W. Nieman, had been fulfilled.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared today in one of the most belligerent speeches of his career that the federation would invade the territories of the unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization. He also ordered all unions
Duquesne their University swamped West Virginia Wesleyan tonight before 14,000 spectators by 39 to 0, and thus avenged the 2 to 0 setback received last year.

Miss Kay Stammers, Englahd's Wightman Cup team member, was the victim of the biggest upset in the Pacific Coast tennis tournament today while Don Budge and Baron Gottfried von Cramm advanced toward their fifth meeting of the year.
The United States Lines, which announced Thursday its intention to dispose of the liner Leviathan and build a new modern ship to operate in the transatlantic trade with the Manhattan and

Movements or vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 30, unless specified: San Pedro to Mare Island Yard: Altair, Arctic. At Mare Island Yard: Antares, Partridge. At Cristobal. Oct. 1: Decatur, Dickerson, Fairfax, Herbert, Leary, Tattnall, Tillman.

Miss Alice Lucile Reilly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fairfax A. Reilly, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to Frederick Fairfax Hufnagel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Hufnagel, also of Mount Vernon. The Rev. Carl S. Weist performed the ceremony in the presence of the two families.
Queen Wilhelmina is indisposed, without any official indication of the nature of the complaint. As a result The Netherlands is without a Foreign Minister.

Artur Rodzinski, conductor of the Cleveland Symphony Orchestra, returned from Europe yesterday on the Manhattan of the United States lines, having attended the Salzburg Festival, where he became the first American conductor to present an American composition.

Returning from Seattle to New York for a speaking engagement Monday, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt arrived on a commercial plane at Newark Airport at 7:35 this evening. She was accompanied by her protegee, Miss Mayris Chaney, who has been dancing in Chicago.

Newbold Morris, Fusion candidate for President of the City Council, and Joseph D. McGoldrick, his running mate for Controller, made campaign appearances at Republican, Labor and Fusion dinners and meetings last night in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens.

The Rev. Dr. William Hubert Rogers, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventyninth Street, will deliver the opening sermon at the annual convention of the New York State Baptist Association. This will be held in the First Baptist Church, Binghamton, N. Y., beginning Monday evening, Oct. 25.

John C. F. Davis, publisher of The Glen Cove Echo for forty-five years, and son of the late Buell G. Davis, who founded the weekly in 1875, died early this morning at his home after an illness of several months. He was 67 years old.

When nearly 700 pupils of the Cooper B. Hatch Junior High School continued their strike today to protest the transfer of six teachers, C. Paul Nay, truant officer, announced that if the students did not return to their classes on Monday parents Of the leaders would he arrested.

Charging that farmer members of the Milk Producers Bargaining Agency were selling milk for New York consumption at prices lower than the $2.35 per hundred pounds agreed on, the Metropolitan Distributors Bargaining Agency warne yesterday that a breakdown in the price arrangement was impending.

" Wallis blue" went by the board today. New clothes chosen by the Duchess of Windsor were black, brown and red. Only one costume, probably for old times' sake, struck the familiar blue note. It was a traveling ensemble in navy blue woolen.

About 500 employes of the Apex Hosiery Company, mostly women, marched on City Hall today to ask Mayor Wilson for protection against 'intimidation by the C. I. O." While the main body of paraders was shouting in the courtyard of the building, the Mayor conferred with a delegation' and-ordered the police to provide "adequate protection."

Statistical workers of the New York Stock Exchange, plus twenty extra clerks transferred from other departments, started yesterday tabulation of the returns to the Exchange's questionnaire on the trading in United States Steel common in September.

Miss Barbara Marguerite Miller was married today to Ellsworth M. Statler, adopted son of the late E. Statler, hotel builder and operator. The ceremony was performed by the the Rev. E. W. Haney in the Pueblo Oratorio Chapel.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today the resignation of Dr. H. E. Hoagland as a member of the board, and the appointment by President Roosevelt of Dr. William H. Husband as his successor. Dr. Hoagland, appointed in 1934 as one of the two Republican members, already has returned to Ohio State University from which he obtained a leave of absence to serve here.

THERE seem to be no books published today, and instead of reading one published earlier in the week, I have leafed through one that was never published at all. It is the privately printed Decennial Report of the Harvard College Class of 1927, a bound volume of some 375 pages revealing the effects, or something like the effects, of ten long years upon the boys.

Underworld bullets seriously wounded one labor union leader in the Bronx yesterday afternoon and killed another early this morning in downtown Manhattan. The wounded man, Max Rubin, 48 years old, business agent for the Clothing Drivers and Helpers Union, Local 240, A. F. of L., was reported to have visited recently the offices of Special Prosecutor Thomas E.

In an unbecomingly impish mood the Federal Theatre is marching in mass formation through an Andrew Lang fairy tale. In Theresa Helburn's dramatic adaptation it is known as "A Hero Is Born," and it was performed in circus dimensions at the Adelphi last evening.
Capitalizing upon its opponent's weakness in the air, Bayonne High School's football team opened its 1937 campaign tonight with a 20-0 victory over the local East Side High eleven.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Manly Whedbee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Whedbee, to George Webb Constable, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Pepper Constable, took place here today at the Shrine of the Sacred Heart at Mount Washington.

74th St, 225-39 E, 200x102.2: Dass 74th St Corp (Harold L. Herrick, vice president), Medpick Corp (Harold R. Medina, vice president), Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in City and Diocese of N. Y. and 225 E 74th St Corp (Robert Bricken, president) to General Realty and Utilities Corp. 285 Madison Ave; bldg loan, due Dec 1. 1942. ad 4 1/2%; $50,000.

Taxable real estate in New York City, including real estate of corporations, is valued on the tentative assessment rolls for 1938 at $16,087,629,017 and shows an increase of $195,414,285 over the final real estate assessed valuation for 1937.

The marriage of Miss Janet Wilcox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank N. Wilcox of this city, to Edward Parkinson Amory of Bristol, Conn., son of Mrs. Edward P. Amory of Chicago, took place in the First Congregational Church tonight. The pastor, the Rev. Albert Jones Lord, performed the ceremony.

Arthur Kitson, 78-year-old inventor who worked with Thomas A. Edison on the original electric light, died here today. Mr. Kitson also was a collaboratory with Alexander Graham Bell on the invention of the telephone.

Lovers of rural sports have been looking forward to October and the potato-picking contest which Governor Barrows of Maine proposed between a representative of his State and a delegate from Idaho, another mighty mother of "subterranean tubers."

Stocks closed irregular after pivotal issues declined; turnover, 673,845 shares, smallest since Aug. 31. United States Government bonds quiet and lower; other issues steady and mixed; transactions, $6,438,600.

A North-South rivalry begun in 1890 will be renewed in Palmer Stadium tomorrow afternoon when Princeton launches its sixty-sixth football campaign against the University of Virginia. About 10,000 persons are expected to witness the game.

Mrs. Samuel A. Welldon of 28 East Thirty-sixth Street, whose baggage was held by customs authorities after her arrival on the Normandie on Thursday, settled with the government by paying duties and penalties of $3,500 for failure to declare and undervaluation. The twenty trunks seized by the customs and examined at the Appraisers' Stores were returned to Mrs Welldon on payment.

Mrs. Mary Low Danaher. widow of Judge Franklin M. Danaher of Albany, a member for many years of the New York State Board of Law Examiners, died today at her home here at the age of 81. Mrs. Danaher was born in Albany and made her home there until moving to Bronxville eight years ago.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, assailed Mayor La Guardia as a pledge breaker last night in an address at the New Era Club, an organization of business men, at 274 East Broadway. He charged the Mayor with having broken and disregarded vital campaign pledges made four years ago. He urged the voters to throw

A few hours after he had made his statement denouncing proposals for mediation and announcing Japan's determination to fight China to the bitter end, the Japanese spokesman added today a postscript of a more constructive character.
The marriage of Miss Louise Wilson, daughter of Mrs. Richard Edward Wilson of Yonkers and the late Rev. Dr. Wilson, to Waiter Evans Jr., son of Walter Evans of Newburgh and the late Mrs. Evans,

Lester W. Herzog, up-State Works Progress Administrator, issued an order today to requisition all employable family men on relief rolls in communities where there are WPA projects on which they can work.
National production of shoes other than rubber amounted to 38,484,000 pairs in August, the Department of Commerce reported today, compared with 34,755,000 in July.

The Ku Klux Klan is being revived in Ohio, Michigan and Indiana, with Toledo as regional headquarters, according to a letter from William E. Cahill, former Kleagle, sent to a Toledoan who apparently has the same name as a former Klansman.

Miss Laddie Irwin, Glen Ridge star who reached the semi-finals of the recent New Jersey championship, shot a fine 82 today to capture low gross honors in the one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Essex Fells Country Club.
Officials of the Great Lakes Transit Corporation announced today that the C. I. O. "sit-down" strike was settled at 2:33 A. M. Details of the settlement were not revealed in the first announcement.

The Japanese military invasion of China was denounced last night at a mass meeting in Madison Square Garden. Support in this country of the Chinese cause was urged and a nation-wide boycott of Japanese goods was advocated.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to listing the Park Lexington Company, Inc., first mortgage, leasehold sinking fund, 3 per cent bonds due in 1964. Attention is directed to the fact that coupon No. 1 for $20 for each $1,000 bond represents interest accrued from May 1, 1937, to Jan. 1, 1938.

If Mr. Justice Black had been able to deny his earlier association with the Ku Klux Klan, a simple statement of a few words would have been sufficient for the purpose. That statement could have been made in Paris weeks ago. It could have been made

Eddie Collins Jr. today was award-ed the gold medal presented by Malcolm Farmer, chairman and director of Yale Athletics, for being the most valuable member of the baseball nine last Spring. Collins played second base and his batting, base running and fielding were outstanding.

In accordance with recognized democratic practice, the civil war notwithstanding, the Negrin Government appeared before the Cortes here today and asked for a vote of confidence on its acts since taking office and on its program for the future.
A 23year-old deaf-mute was sentenced to six months in county prison by Police Judge Eugene Mariano today on a charge of shooting nails and tacks at wrestlers during a bout at the Camden Armory.

Eighteen directors of General Mills, Inc., received remuneration of $529,667 for-the last fiscal year, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday. The three highest-salaried executives, who were not named, received $75,000, $50,000 and $50,000, the report showed.

President Roosevelt surprised the Senate and the country on Aug. 12 when, by forwarding the nomination of Senator Hugo L. Black, he revealed as his choice for the Supreme Court vacancy a man who had in no way figured in any discussion of possible nominees.

Turned out in true sporting fashion, even to the wire-haired foxterrier, the sporting tandem from the Windholme Farm of Harry T. Peters of Islip, L. I., this afternoon was the winner of the C. K. G. Billings Memorial Trophy, one of

A specially appointed committee of the Department of Commerce heard charges of insurbordination and intoxication involving members of the crew of the Panama Pacific liner California yesterday afternoon at the Federal Building, 45 Broadway.
New discoveries in Baffin Land were reported today by the British University polar expedition, which arrived here in the Norwegian sealing vessel Isbjorn.
Dr. and Mrs. Ben Witt Key of 1,170 Fifth Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Webb Key, to James Owen Watts Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Owen Watts of Lynchburg, Va.

George Grubee, 27-year-old truck driver, was convicted yesterday of murder in the second degree for the slaying of Mrs. Jessie Harris, 27, mother of two children. Grubee thereby faces a mandatory sentence of twenty years to life imprisonment.

Spanish Insurgent troops today poised for another smash at Covadonga, where national shrines are defended by Asturians in one of the wildest regions of all Spain. Driving a tortuous path toward Gijon, focal point of the Government's last stronghold on the northwest coast, two Insurgent brigades moved toward the neighbor towns of Covadonga and Cangas de Onis.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $5,681,911, to be represented by fifty-five municipalities, promising one of the quietest periods in several months for this market. It compares with the revised total of $8,750,389 for this week.

China submitted a resolution to the Far Eastern Advisory Committee today containing the condemnation of Japanese aggression she desires. The committee referred this to a sub-committee of thirteen including the United States which it established today.

Justice Hugo L. Black told the American people tonight that he had once belonged to the Ku Klux Klan, that he had resigned before he became a Senator, that he had never rejoined, and that his public record spoke for itself.

It has been announced that copper producing companies operating under the restriction scheme have agreed upon a program of production which will result in their output being reduced to the rate of 105 per cent of basic quotas by the end of November.

Mrs. Harriet B. Newell Tobey, widow of Colonel Bennett H. Tobey, a veteran of the Spanish-American War, died last night at her home here after a long illness. Mrs.. Tobey, who was born in New Haven, had lived in Glen Cove for about forty years.

Gottlob Kautzmann, former banker and jewelry manufacturer in Newark, died yesterday in Miami after a long illness. He was 69 years old. For several years he had been president of the Vernet Lumber Company of Miami.

Murdock Ave (17-5097), s e eor of 241st St. 100x40; Frederick E. Elsmeier to Hugh Dolan, 1.609 Taylor Ave. Tiffany St, 1,144 (10-2718); Esther Israel to Geza Schmacher, 1,069 Tiffany St. Intervale Ave, 1.163 (10-2692): Central Savings Bank to 1,163 Intervale Ave, Inc. 1,163 Intervale Ave.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In the interests of a collegiate atmosphere and good, clean fun, I wonder if you would take up something for us with the management of THE TIMES. Last year I' wrote to Mayor La Guardia asking if the University of North Carolina students could build a bonfire in Times Square after the N. Y. U.-North Carolina football game.
Fort Worth evened the Dixie series tonight by blanking the Littie Rock Travelers, 3 to 0. Little Rock won the first game last night, 10 to O.

Plans for the establishment of a realty mortgage institution designed to permit a freer flow of investment funds in this field were outlined here today by Wendell P. Barker, former chairman of the State Mortgage Commission, who is sponsoring the enterprise.
The reaction to Justice Black's radio speech, admitting past membership in the Ku Klux Klan and subsequent withdrawal from it but disavowing religious or racial bigotry, was divided last night.

Fifty Japanese tailors rushed into the offices of the Finance Ministry today to denounce the Government's recent policy of "honorable shabbiness" as a "patched pants" campaign. Hammering on the desk of Vice Minister Sotaro Ishiwatari, they shouted, "We have to live, too." Mr. Ishiwatari sighed in sympathy, but gave no assurance.

The Southern New York Fish and Game Association, with headquarters at White Plains, has made public a copy of the proposed resolution calling for a change in set-up of the Conservation Department of this State. A vote on the resolution

Treasury Procurement Division today awarded the following textile contracts: 543-T, Broadcloth--M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., 783,150 yards; S. C. Marks Co., 22,500; Riverside Dan River Cotton Mills, 17,500.

Paul V. Baivier, who for more than forty years was engaged in the manufacture of wooden shoes at Kiel, this county, died at the hospital here today at the age of 62. During the last twenty years his factory was the largest of its kind in the United States.

After three hours of argument in the United States District Court here this afternoon,.Federal Judge Edwin S. Thomas reserved decision on the motion of the Lektro Shave Corporation that James Rand, Remington-Rand, Inc., and its subsidiary, the General Shaver Corporation, be adjudged in contempt for making and selling a razor de Thomas in June.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Brown, daughter of Mrs. E. Lewis Brown of Maplewood, to Arthur Perin Britten, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence M. Britten, also of this town, took place this evening in Prospect Presbyterian Church here. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Arthur Nelson Butz.

A military tribunal on Wednesday condemned to death sixteen former officials of the Okhtensk chemical works and "the sentence has been carried out," the Leningrad Pravda dedared laconically yesterday.

Unionization of State employes, which has been progressing rapidly of late, had a setback today when Governor Murphy and Leon D. Case, Secretary of State, reprimanded American Federation of Labor pickets who have been protesting lay-offs of State Department employes. Pickets have appeared

A police threat to escort non-striking workmen into the. plant ended' a sitdown strike at the Detroit Gasket and Manufacturing Company this afternoon after disorders in which several persons were injured.
Edward P. Mulrooney, former New York City Police Commissioner, said today that the exploits of the nation's famed "G-men" had made the policeman instead of the gangster "the idol of American youth."

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Rosenman denied yesterday a separation sought by Mrs. Nola Locke Mandel of 65 Central Park West from Henry Masdel, builder. Justwice Rosenman held that the "present marital difficulties of these parties arise from an unwillingness on the part of the plaintiff to adjust her standard of living to the reduced earnings of the defendant."

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today. dated Sept. 29: VanHook, Comdr. C. E., the Relief. to Naval Reserve Officers' Training Corps Unit. University of California, Berkeley, Calif.

Justice James Clark 'McReynolds of the Supreme Court returned from a European vacation yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan. He was interested in the controversy over the alleged members of Justice Black in the Ku Klux Klan and asked several questions as to how the matter had been handled by the American press.

High retail meat prices throughout the country are directly attributable to small supplies on hand during July and August, experts of the Department of Agriculture suggested today as figures of production were studied. It was found that

Miss Edwina de Bour Davison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Davison of this place, was married here tonight in the West Side Presbyterian Church to Ernest H. Gill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gill of Dover. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Arthur M. Hughes.

Hollywood has come shyly to realize that there's story gold in the Los Angeles foothills and, with "A Star Is Born" successfully mined, it has produced a less spectacular nugget in "It Happened in Hollywood," which came yesterday to the Rialto.

Lieut. Col. Leroy T. Howard of the Army Medical Corps died at his home in Hyattsville, Md., last night at the age of 48. Born in this city on Oct. 27, 1888, he was graduated from the Georgetown University Medical School in 1913 and was commissioned a first lieutenant in the Regular Army Medical Corps in 1917.

Mrs. Eleanor Thurman Smith, a member of an old New York family, died on Thursday at her home, 285 Central Park West, after a long illness at the age of 68. Mrs. Smith was the widow of Francis Elisha Smith, flour-mill owner.

Mayor La Guardia fined yesterday two of the four vacancies on the Board of Higher Education, governing body for the four city colleges, by the appointment of Dr. Carmyn J. Lombardo of 7,410 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn, and Ernest MacDonald of Kew Gardens, Queens, to posts as trustees.
William S. Hart, cowbody actor or the silent films, has renewed his Supreme Court fight to obtain some of the profits of his last silent picture. "Tumbleweeds."

The Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation announced today that it had barred the Chesapeake Lines from carrying passengers on its larger ships due to non-observance of safety-at-sea regulations. The bureau said not more than three vessels were affected.

A reduction of excess member bank reserves, a slackening of industrial activity and a check in the expansion of credit are described in the current monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, issued yesterday, as the events that led up to the action of the Federal Reserve and Treasuny authorities last month in pumping fresh excess reserves into the banking system through the use of $300,000,000 of gold previously sterilized.
Katonah High's eleven, unbeaten during the last two campaigns, bowed to Hastings High, 7-0, today. Lincoln Grady, right halfback, tallied for Hastings in the third quarter. He intercepted a pass

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 25 amounted to 840,446 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 13,881 cars, or 1.7 per cent more than for the preceding week, 33,203 cars, or 4.1 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 210,511 cars, or 33.4 per cent more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Notre Dame's fiftieth gridiron array, regarded by some as being the most powerful since Elmer Layden took charge of football coaching here four years ago, will open its nine-game schedule tomorrow against Drake.

The funeral of the Rev. Dr. Augustus Steimle, pastor of the Lutheran Church of the Advent since 1918, will take place tomorrow at 2:30 P. M. in his church at Broadway and Ninety-third Street. Dr. Steimle died suddenly Thursday night at his home, 174 West Ninetythird Street.

Reports from Southern spot circles that growers were offering less cotton and were more inclined to accept the government loan caused an active covering movement in the late trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday.

Kentucky's Court of Appeals held today that the proposed Child Labor Amendment to the Federal Constitution was no longer before the people. The ruling was made in an opinion invalidating the State's ratification of the proposal early this year.

Although United States Senator A. Harry Moore has not supported all of President Roosevelt's bills in Congress, he will seek election as Governor of New Jersey on a platform that "enthusiastically endorses" the present national administration.
The trim, gray-blue British escort vessel Scarborough stood into New York yesterday morning for a twelve-day visit, and moored to Pier 90, at Fiftieth Street in the Hudson River. The vessel is

The Palestine Government today took drastic action against the instigators of the terrorism that has been reigning here for more than a year. All members of the Arab High Committee who could be found were arrested and deported.

Miss Elizabeth Lord, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. S. Lord of this place, was married tonight to Russell Hall of Boston and South Windham, Me., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Russell Hall of Melrose Highlands, Mass.

Miss Marjorie Matthew, daughter of Mrs. William Ralph Condit of this city, was married this evening to Fred Howard Porter Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred H. Porter of Beverly, Mass.; and her sister, Miss Dorothy Matthew, was married to Lawrence Edmands, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Albert Edmands of Wellesley Hills, Mass., in the Church of St. James the Less, Scarsdale. The Rev. Alan R.

Gosport greeted the Endeavour I this morning with a reception rivaling those nautical carnivals for which New York harbor is famous. Accompanied by a flotilla of yachts, tugs and harbor craft of every description, with whistles shrieking, airplanes circling overhead and FOR SCH flag-decorated quays lined with well wishers, the Endeavour I brought her battle with the sea to an end.

Authorities today termed the deaths of a mother and two of her children by shooting as a double murder and suicide. They said that a daughter, who had been under the observation of a psychologist, apparently had killed her mother and her young brother before taking her own life.
Mikhail Mikhailovitch Slavutsky, Soviet Am- A bassador to Japan, was invited today to have luncheon with Emperor Hirohito at the Imperial Palace Oct. 4.

Before a cheering audience of 3,000 farmers, business men and average citizens who depend for a living on the domestic cotton crop, Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, served notice on the world today that "the United States intends to keep its place in the world cotton market," and that the Roosevelt Administration would subsidize cotton farmers to stay in business and successfully compete with foreign producers.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jacob H. Gerhardt of Brooklyn of the engagement of Me their daughter, Miss Marie Adeline and Gerhardt, to Dr. William Robert Griffin, son-of Mrs. John Joseph Griffin of Sayville, L. I., and thw late Mr. Griffin.

The secret visit of Josef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, here, following closely after the visit of Dr. Milan Hodza, Premier of Czechoslovakia,--which was discovered only because an obscure inn in Baden, where Dr. Hodza had engaged a small room in which he met Kurt von Schuschnigg,

Allen St, 37, 25x100; Esther Wertheim to 37 Allen Corp, 305 Bway; mtg $10,200 ($6). Baxter St, 87, 25x100: Antonia Raffaele and another to Savina Armanniaco, 451 Pearl St; mtg $16,000 ($1). Great Jones St, 29, 26.9x89.9x26.8x99.6; Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co, executor: Samuel D. Babcock to Joseph Perlov. 3,975 Sedgwick Ave ($10.50).

At the closing matinee of the ninety-fifth annual Queens-Nassau County Fair light-harness meeting today the 3year-old bay mare Miss Vermont took the first two heats and placed second in the third to win the $600 purse in the Bay Shore 2:18 class trot.

The Dun-Bradstreet index number of average commodity prices as of Oct. 1, published yesterday, reported an average advance during September of only one-half of 1 per cent. Since Jan. 1, when the highest Dun average of the year was reached, there has been a decline of 6 1/4 per cent. Compared with Oct. 1, 1936,

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange settled back into almost routine channels, with prices fluctuating within relatively narrow limits. The buoyancy that had characterized operations in the corporate section most of the week lost much of its force, and, while prices generally held firm, the appearance of numerous weak spots gave the market an irregular undertone.

If all the members of the churches in the United States were to show their loyalty to the church of their faith by attending services today or tomorrow, the church edifices could not hold them but would perhaps give them standing room, for there are almost 60,000,000 church members (nearly half the population of the United States) and only 210,000 church edifices.
Bucknell downed Lebanon Valley tonight, 13-0, with a 69-yard touchtown march in the second period and a 51-yard drive for the second tally in the fourth chapter.
Bernardine Clark, 20, of New York, began a court fight today against her father, Bert Clark, vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, for possession of an airplane.

New bond financing this week showed greater diversification and was the largest volume in more than a month, totaling $17,287,000, as compared with only $3,278.000 new issues placed last week. During this period last year a total of $19,561,500 in new bonds was marketed.

The export demand for domestic hard Winter wheat was much less active today and led to a more bearish feeling on the part of the professional element. While there was some buying of futures early on the Board of Trade here, attributed to cash and seaboard interests, it was not sustained, and prices receded 1 1/2 to 2 cents a bushel from the top, with the close around the low.

Mrs. Josephine Flynn, Democratic National Committee woman from Connecticut since May, 1936, died today at her home here. She had been ill for six months. She was 52 years old. Mrs. Flynn, who was the wife of Dr. John F. Flynn of this city, had been active in the Connecticut Federation of Democratic Women for years.

Because today is Loyalty Sabbath in the synagogues and tomorrow is annual Loyalty Sunday in the churches clergymen will preach sermons on the duty of weekly attendance at one's house of worship. Tomorrow will see the last of the pastors back from their Summer vacations. It will be the annual

At last Great Britain is meeting terrorism in Palestine as it should. Answering the demand of Arab leaders for release of the 200 prisoners seized after the slaying at Nazareth last Sunday of a British Commissioner and his bodyguard, the authorities in Jerusalem yesterday outlawed the Arab Higher Committee, arrested some and deposed others of the Arab officials directing its subversive activities.

The marriage of Miss Katherine Emily Mussen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur G. Mussen of this city and Saranac Lake, to Davis W. Snow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Silas Snow of Williamsburg, Mass., took place yesterday morning in the rectory of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Rev. Henry F. Hammer performed the ceremony.

KINGS MOON. LEON E. (Aug. 3. 1936). Gross assets, $30,502: net. $29,117. To grandchildren, Alan J., Kenneth R., Geraldine F. and Edith J. Moon, daughter-in-law, Edith G. Moon, $200 each; brother, Erwin B. Moon. wearing apparel valued at $50: wife, Laura R. Moon. life income

The Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today that the American Airlines, Inc., air-mail contractor. was flying mail over five routes at rates which were not fair to the company and ordered that "fair and reasonable" rates not only be put into effect at once, but made them retroactive to March 9, 1936, when the contractors filed a plea for higher recompense.

The Bargaini East Lampeter Township School Board announced today that it would enforce school attendance laws against the Amish and Mennonite opponents of a new consolidated school which opens Monday if they refuse to send their children to the school. Seven buses will tour

Senator William E. Borah, Progressive Republican, who voted against Justice Black's confirmation, said tonight: "Justice Black stated the matter of his relationship with the Klan as I understood it to be when I spoke on the subject in the Senate.

Major C. L. Hanington, managing editor of The Trinidad Guardian, died today. He was 60 years old. Born in Dorcester, N. B., son of the late Justice Daniel Lionel Hanington of the Supreme Court of New Brunswick, he was called to the New Brunswick Bar in 1900 and practiced for fourteen years.

British Guiana defeated Barbados by an innings and 220 runs today and won the right to meet Trinidad in the final round for the triangular intercolonial cricket championship. Scores for the five-day match were:

A fiery cross the Attorney about eighteen feet high was touched off just after midnigt tonight near historical Bancroft Tower on a hill in the exclusive residential district of Worcester. Some near-by residents believed it might be a student prank.

Carrying on of the suggested consumer boycott here against Japanese silk as a protest against that country's policy in China was described in the silk and hosiery industry here yesterday as a "double blow striking at American labor and capital" as well as at Japan. No specific plans to offset the boycott were under way, it was said, with the belief expressed that "it would not last long if it does develop."

Asserting that the Neutrality Act of 1937 "virtually makes the United States an ally of Japan," Raymond Leslie Buell, president of the Foreign Policy Association, urged Congress tonight to amend the law in "one of two directions."

Newark Academy defeated the Montclair Academy eleven today by 26 to 6. Newark displayed close teamwork, scoring three touchdowns in the first half on line plays, led by Ernie Fellows, formerly of East Orange High School, and Russ Fredericks, who played with Bloomfield High School's State championship team last year.

Miss Shirley Kopp, 17-year-old business school graduate, was killed instantly yesterday afternoon when a stray .22 caliber bullet struck her in the forehead as she was riding on a B. M. T. trolley through a wooded section of Forest Park, in Richmond Hill, Queens.

The Piping Rock Horse Show Ball tonight at the Piping Rock Club attracted more members of society than ever before have taken part in this feature of .the annual society and sporting fixture. The capacity of the club and the specially erected marquee was taxed.

The presence of women jurors has had a beneficial influence on men jurors, it was revealed yesterday by John Ahern, chief jury clerk of the New York County Supreme Court. No longer do the men jurors, awaiting in the jury room their call for service, harass hard-working clerks with innumerable questions about the details of their work.

The death of three deer in falls down a 100-foot precipice of the Palisades, here this morning in fright at being chased by dogs resulted today in a police order to kill all dogs on sight in the New Jersey section of Palisades Interstate Park.

Chinese armies along the TientsinPukow Railway front, in North China, after reinforcement and reorganization launched a counteroffensive yesterday and recaptured the towns of Potowchen and Sengchiakou, Nanking's official spokesman announced this morning. [Potowchen is about thirty miles south of Tsangchow, strategic point on the railway, and about eighty miles south of Tientsin.]

The Appalachian Electric Power Company of Huntington, W. Va., a subsidiary of the American Gas and Electric Company, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $57,000,000 of first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds due in 1967 and $10,000,000 of sinking fund debentures, 4 per cent series, due in 1952, the commission announced today.

All Americans had not left the middle and upper Yangtze Valley by noon of Sept. 26, in fact there were still about 1,000 there and when the Japanese planes began bombing the Canton-Hankow Railway on Sept. 27 they misunderstood the plain tenor of the American Ambassador's negotiations and requests.

Darkness and the Red Sox caught up with the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium, and as a consequence, the American League champions equaled their longest losing mark of the year-four straight defeats. Marse Joe McCarthy's boys didn't look like a team to beat the conquering Giants in the world series.

In an attempt to check the trend of organized labor to Mayor La Guardia, thirty executives of labor unions met yesterday at the Paramount Hotel and formed a labor committee to support Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic nominee for Mayor, and his running mates, Controller Frank J. Taylor and Max J. Schneider, candidate for President of the Council.

After threatening for some time to do so, R.-K.-O. has signed the Marx brothers and will put them into the play "Room Service," which the studio purchased from its Broadway producers last July at cost of $255.000. The picture has
Adams Co., Real Estate, Inc., were the brokers in the recent leasing for the Gerry Estates, Inc., to the Mercury Theatre, Inc., of the theatre at 108-112 West Forty-first Street, formerly the Comedy.
Jacob W. Endel, honorary president of the Temple of the Covenant of Washington Heights, died on Thursday in his home at 215 West Seventy-fifth Street after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

Brig. Gen. Robert Alexander Brown, U. S. A., retired, who captured Geronimo, America's Indian public enemy No. 1 of years ago, died last night at Letterman Army Hospital here. His age was 77. Born in Delaware County, Pa., General Brown was graduated from West Point in 1885. As one of the

From The Herald Tribune (Ind. Rep.) Mr. Justice Black's whole conduct 'since the charges of Klan membership were brought against him has been that of a coward. Faced by repeated opportunities to tell the truth as he saw it, he has skulked and dodged and run away.
Carnegie institute of Technology will open its gridiron season tomorrow afternoon by entertaining the New York University Violets in the stadium at 2 o'clock. In eleven. meetings

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, said last night that he did not hear and had not read Justice Black's speech, but had heard it stated that Mr. Black admitted his membership in the Klan and subsequent withdrawal from it.

The wedding of Miss Kathryn Lawler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lawyer of this place, to Richard Nye Gulick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Gulick of East Orange, took place this evening in Christ Episcopal Church here. The rector, the Rev. Charles E. Hutchison, officiated.
The plant, raw materials, equipment and real estate of DraperMaynard Company, Plymouth, N. H., manufacturers of sporting goods, will be sold at public auction on Oct. 12 and 13.

Unable to obtain anything but identical prices through competitive bidding, the Treasury Department has awarded the Federal Government's $1,000,000 tire contract for the next six months to Sears Roebuck Co. of Chicago, the Treasury announced this afternoon. The contract is effective today.

Charles H. Smith, prominent fire insurance man, died here today in his sixty-second year. He was a native of Charlestown, Mass.; a graduate of the Massachusetts Insti- H' tute of Technology and a member of the University Club of Boston.

Walter Brower, special assistant to Attorney General Cummings and a close friend of Associate Justice Hugo L. Black of the Supreme Court, issued a statement through an associate yesterday categorically Denying that he was a member of I the Ku Klux Klan. He left open,

Platte Wilson, Lincoln County chairman, said today that he had refused to distribute copies of a speech by Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania which threatened Senator O'Mahoney of Wyoming and other Democrats who opposed President Roosevelt's court-reorganization plan with "election trouble."

Another rolling half dozen approved families moved in to Greenbelt and settled down today in the recently completed section of the Farm Security Administration's model community project, which eventually will consist of 885 new homes renting at from $18 to $41 per month.

Walter H. Lake, formerly senior partner of Graham Hinckley Co., New York importers and exporters, died today at his home here. His age was 71. Born and educated in London, England, Mr. Lake resided here about thirty-five years.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
Offhand, one would say that the task of analyzing the Yankees and Giants as they prepare for their seeond successive world series clash was a comparatively simple one.
Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, arrived at Newark Airport from Detroit at 4:50 yesterday afternoon and a few minutes later left for New York City.

MORNING EVENTS Class 2, Registered Thoroughbred Mares, Suitable to Produce Hunters--First, Miss Wilhelmine S. Kirby's ch. m. Precaution; second, Crispin Oglebay's ch. m. Hi-Boy; third, Mrs. Geo. Murnane's b. m. First Arrival; fourth, Mr. and Mrs. Gerard S. Smith's ch. m. Bruberry.
Miss Muriel Cleland of Bedminster, N. J., seemed pointed for top honors in the jumper classes of the Montclair Horse Show today when her Johnnie W. captured two blues.
Elden Auker had an easy time winning his seventeenth game of the season today as his Tiger team-mates collected eighteen hits, including four home runs, to conquer the Browns, 14 to 4.

Dramatized plays illustrating the possibilities of graphic presentation of commercial subjects will be shown to the public beginning next Tuesday by the New York World's Fair Corporation, it was announced yesterday. The show includes exhibits of four familiar but unrelated industries, including fashions and fabrics combined as one industry, the use of color, clock manufacture and chemistry.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 684,000 bales, against 684,000 a week ago, 691,000 two weeks ago, 699,000 three weeks ago and 763,000 a year ago; of which American 216,000 bales, against 220,000 a week ago, 209,000 two weeks ago, 220,000 three weeks ago and 235,000 a year ago.

The French stabilization fund appeared here yesterday to have been caught napping for a short time and the franc fell swiftly to the lowest price in eleven years, 3.35 cents, before the authorities could regain control and restore it to the levels, around 3.43 cents, where it recently had been supported.

The agreement of merger of the Enterprise Savings and Loan Association into the American Cooperative Savings and Loan Association was filed with the State-Banking Department today, according to the department's weekly bulletin.

Aloha, their stately, square-rigged yacht, will be broken up, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Curtiss James announced today. While it was definite that gear and equipment of the black-hulled bark, one of the most famous yachts afloat, would be sold on bids, reports were that the owners had not decided what disposition to make of the hull.

The American premiere of Teresa Deevy's new play "Katie Roche" will be presented to Broadway tonight by the Abbey Theatre Players of Dublin, opening a season of Irish repertory at the Ambassador Theatre. Curtain is at 8:40.
An eight-yard forward pass from Mike Kosteva to John Pilconis, substitute end, in the last quarter tonight gave LaSalle College a 6-to-0 victory over the West Chester State Teachers football team.

Sir John Simon, formerly Great Britain's Foreign Secretary and now Home Secretary, today warned Britons against dictators. "These new-fangled methods of totalitarian States may give the appearance of great solidarity, and no doubt it is very impressive to see millions of people marshaled like one man," Sir John declared, addressing the Scottish Liberal National Conference at Peebles.

Moderate declines in total deposits and assets were shown in the statements of condition on Sept. 30 which local banks and trust companies began yesterday to issue. Of the banks to report, most showed a reduction in holdings of United States Government securities, an increase in cash and an improvement in loans and discounts, compared with the figures reported for June 30.

Turpentine, firm, 281/2C; sales 96 barrels; receipts 333 barrels; shipments 4 barrels; stock 36,348 barrels. Resin firm; sales 739; receipts 983; no shipments; stock 70,692. Quote: B, D, E, $7.40; F to K, $7.75; M, N, $7.77 1/2; WG, $8.10; WW, X, $8.60.

Robert Dicks Shore, treasurer of R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, died this morning at a Winston Salem hospital. His age was 48. He underwent an operation Sept. 20 and his condition was thought improved until three days ago when it became critical.

Horses from the West are considered to have pretty much at their mercy the main portion of the world's richest juvenile purse, the Futurity, which will be run over the East's most famous course, Belmont Park, this afternoon.
William Kelly died this afternoon at the General Hospital here as the result of an accident Sept. 22, when he fell while descending the steps of the Ford Hospital. He was 83 years old.
The two four-story brick apartments at 834-38 Grand Street, Jersey City, N. J., have been sold by the Trust Company of New Jersey to Herman Hotkiss, through J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker.

Harry J. Rubinstein, impartial chairman of the price settlement board of the New York City dress industry, has been chosen as impartial chairman for a section of the silk industry represented here by the Silk Commission Manufacturers Association.
Lawrence High School's eleven, unbeaten in two years, crushed the Hicksville High team, 38 to 0, before 3,500 spectators at Lawrence Stadium tonight.

MANHATTAN BRESLER, PAUL (Aug. 12). Estate, less than $15,000. To Alma Bresler, widow, executrix, 12 Old Broadway. DEXTER, MARY GEORGETTE (Sept. 22). Estate, more than $10,000. To Edna Gregory Crawford, niece, Ridge St., Port Chester, N. Y., household, personal effects and one-fourth residue; Chester Urban Palmer.
Van A. Bittner of Chicago, Mid. west director of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, warned Tom Girdler, chairman of the board of directors of the Republic Steel Corporation, today to "sign

Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANTS-Christian R. Salseider, from 40th Precinct to 18th Division. Assignment to desk duty discontinued. Joseph Meade, from 7th Division to 40th Precinct. Assignment to desk duty continued. PATROLMEN-William P. Meehan, from borough headquarters squad, Manhattan, to 109th Precinct.

Reorganization of PWA field activities into eight or ten regional jurisdictions, each comprising several States, was announced today by Secretary Ickes. To these regional units will be transferred the work and remaining personnel of the present State offices in a drive for greater economy.
Ending preparations for the opening game with Clemson College of South Carolina tomorrow, Army's football team went through a brief practice session on The Plains today.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Iva Braham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester M. Braham of Brooklyn, to Julius von Sternberg Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. von Sternberg, also of Brooklyn, took place last night in St. Mary's Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn.

Mrs. Casimir Hofmann, 84-yearold mother of Josef Hofmann, noted pianist, will come to America to attend her son's Golden Jubilee concert at the Metropolitan Opera House on Nov. 28, it was announced yesterday. Despite frequent

Another record-shattering performance featured the closing day of the Grand Circuit meeting here today. Dean Hanover, champion 3-yearold trotter, lowered his own world mark for three heats by a stallion when he won the fifty-ninth renewal of the $2,000 Kentucky Stake in 2:00 1/4, 2:00 3/4 and 2:00 3/4.

A recount today gave Fred W. Nelson the Republican nomination for member of the Assembly in the First District instead of Paul B. Mercier, the present Democratic Assemblyman, who ran as an Independent after the Democratic organization had turned him down. In the original

The decision of the large copper producers outside the United States to reimpose restrictions on operations should have a stabilizing influence on copper prices both here and abroad. Because the statistical

Colonel Creighton Webb has returned from Newport to 125 East Seventy-fifth Street. Mrs. James Barlow Cullum and Miss Mollie Cullum are at the Plaza. Mrs. Philip G. Cammann has returned from Southampton, where she passed the Summer, and is at 1,172 Park Avenue for the remainder of the Autumn and Winter.

Discovery of the oldest human portrait in the world-older by at least 15,000 years than any in existence-was announced today by Dr. Karel Absolon, who has been a pioneer in digging up remains of the prehistoric mammoth hunters of Central Europe.

Several residential properties figured in deals involving Brooklyn properties reported by brokers. The three-story brownstone dwelling at 280 Garfield Place, between Eighth and Prospect Place, was sold by Mrs. Ethel Stokes Quell to a client of Charles E. Rickerson for occupancy.
The president of the Paris Municipal Council in a proclamation today requested Parisians to fly American and French flags tomorrow in honor of the American Legion parade.

MATRON (Immigration Service), $1,320 a year-Applications must be on file with the manager, Second United States Civil Service District, Federal Building. Christopher Street, New York, N. Y., not later than Oct. 11. Vacancies in this position in the Immigration Service, Ellis Island, N. Y., and future vacancies in positions requiring similar qualifications in the same locality, will be filled from this examination.
Retail trade here improved somewhat during the week in comparison with last week, but reports continued to refer to the fact that sales increases are harder to obtain.

The effect of the Fall rush for apartments is beginning to show in the form of fully occupied buildings. Agents are dusting off their "No Vacancies" signs as they report houses 100 per cent rented after one -of the busiest seasons in years.

An offer of the Trades and Labor Congress of Canada to mediate in the dispute between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization in the United States will be considered by those two bodies, it was disclosed here today.

Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, in a speech last night in his campaign for the office of District Attorney, warned members of the American Labor Party of the Third and Fifth Assembly Districts against an attempt to "steal" the election by fraudulent registration next week.

The Florence Fleming estate has sold through Joseph P. Day, Inc., the eleven-acre property, with an eighteen-room residence, at Wading River, L. I., to Matilda Jacobs. The tract is situated on the main road near Wading River Village.

King Football will widely extend his domain in the schoolboy ranks today, for dozens of high school teams in the metropolitan area are slated to open their seasons and many of the East's leading prep school squads are also booked to lift the curtain on their 1937 schedules.

Mrs. Francois de Saint Phalle of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Catherine de Saint Phalle, to E. Eldridge Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Erskine M. Smith of Old Orchard, Haverford.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 7,000, including 2,000 directs. The market on good and choice hogs 225 pounds down was mostly 10-15 cents lower than Thursday's average; late market, 1525 cents lower with packing sows mostly 25 cents lower: top. $12.25: bulk good and

The St. Vincent College eleven scored two quick touchdowns in the second period tonight to defeat a plucky St. Bonaventure team, 13-0. Bruner, St. Vincent quarterback, intercepted a Bonaventure pass on his own 35 and ran to the Bonaventure 39.

After President Getulio Vargas at 3 o'clock this afternoon had asked Congress to approve the state of war for a ninety-day period urged by Brazil's military heads, the Chamber of Deputies, meeting in extraordinary session, adopted the measure by a vote of 138 to 90 and sent it to the Senate tonight.

Thomas L. Holling, candidate of the Non-Partisan Committee for Mayor of Buffalo, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner given by the committee at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Fifty-five guests from New York City and Buffalo attended. Mr. Holling returned
There will be no $100,000 income from radio broadcasts of world series games this year for the first time since 1933.

Mrs. Jeannie Robison, widow of William Robison, who was a member of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday at her home on Old Country Road at the age of 84. She was a member of the National Society of Colonial Dames and was of the Floyd-Jones family, one-time owners of most of Massapequa and the land now occupied by Jones Beach.

The body of Senator Rodolphe Lemieux, once the "strong man" in the Cabinet of the late Sir Wilfred Laurier, was carried through a drizzling. rain today to Cote Des Neiges Cemetery, followed by high representatives of government, clergy, bench and bar.

Justwice Black sat in an antique chair before a battery of six microphones while he delivered his historic speech to the nation tonight. He was alone in the living room a of a friend, save for radio an- were nouncers and technicians.

Three United States Senators returned from Europe yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan after attending meetings of the Inter-Parliamentary Union in Paris. None would say what he might have done in the voting in the Senate on confirmation of Senator Hugo L. Black had Mr. Black's reported membership in the Klan been known.

The Nazi harvest festival rally here tonight, which had been preceded by many rumors and threats, turned out to be no more exciting than any other community meeting and ended the same way with the audience singing "God Save the King."

Football's laggards will move into the front-line trenches today and for every big college team from coast to coast the season will be officially under way. Yet such are the caprices of the schedule-makers that the sectional title hopes of some potential leaders are likely to be blasted before they even get out of their starting holes.
Texas A. and M.'s powerful football team will make its first appearance in New York today when it faces the Manhattan eleven in an intersectional battle at the Polo Grounds. The return meeting of

Miss Harriet Dorothea Escher, daughter of Gustava Edward Escher of this place, was married today in Central Presbyterian Church here to Harrison Ball, son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Arthur Ball of New York. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Rockwells Brank.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Topping Green, daughter of Mrs. Howard Green of this place and the late Mr. Green, to William George Daub Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Daub of Red Bank, took place here this evening at the home of the bride's mother. The Rev. Morton A.

The monthly dinner meetings of the New York Employment Managers Association will begin Thursday evening, Oct. 7, at Schrafft's, 13 East Forty-second Street. The Merchants Association of New York has notified members that air express shipments valued at 10 pesos or more, c.i.f., arriving in Colombia since Sept. 18 had to be covered by certificates of origin for both United States and foreign goods.

Two nominees of the American Labor party for Supreme Court Justice in the First Judicial District, Paul J. Kern, Civil Service Commissioner, and Nathan Frankel, executive secretary of Mayor La Guardia's City Industrial Relations Board, withdrew last night as candidates, leaving two vacancies on the judicial slate of the Labor party.
Buying of household washing machines is sharply increasing in the upperprice levels, statistics compiled for the American Washing Machine Manufacturers Association reveal.
Harold B. Smith of Hiltz Co. has been elected president of the Security Traders Association of New York to serve for the coming year. William A. Titus Jr. of John Melady Co. is the new first vice

Judge Blase Cole, who was killed last night in an automobile accident in which William A. Dolan, his successor as Sussex County's State Senator, and two others were injured, will be buried Sunday afternoon.

William Gibbons, a banker and jeweler, died at his home in Wynnewood yesterday at the age of 81. He had been president of the Haddington Title and Trust Company and chairman of the board of the Hamilton Trust Company.

The Tipton County grand jury reported today "with sincere regret" its inability to establish the identities of six masked men who seized a Negro from Sheriff W. J. Vaughan Aug. 16 and left his body suspended from a highway bridge.

An apartment house project on the new Henry Hudson Parkway was financed when the Cajorco Realty Company (Harry Colen and Anparkway and extends through to thony S. Cantoni) obtained abuilding loan of $500,000 for the erection of a garden-type house adjoining the Baptist Home to the south at 236th Street and the parkway.

The high cost of living and lavish spending at Washington, which he holds largely responsible for it, will be the chief issues in the campaign of Bruce Barton, Republican nominee for the Aouse of Representatives in the Seventeenth Congressional District.

Thirty-ninth annual convention of the New York State Osteopathic Society, Hotel Pennsylvania, 9 A. M. Continues tomorrow. Fifteenth annual conference of the New York Women's Trade Union League, Russell Sage Foundation Building, 130 East Twenty-second Street, 10 A. M. Speakers:

Employe stock dividends amounting to $8,700 were distributed today among 250 workers for the Rich Manufacturing Company, automobile valve maker, as the third-quarter profit-sharing award of this year.

The Rev. Daniel Edgar Weeks of Renovo, Pa., has been chosen assistant pastor of the Fifth. Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, of which the Rev. Dr. John S. Bonnell is the pastor. Mr. Weeks succeeds the Rev. Lockhart Amerman, who resigned to take a postgraduate course in the University of Edinburgh, Scotland, having Won a year's fellowship.

Revocations Paragraph TV of Special Order 178. Sept. 30, 1937, in so far as it pertains to the appointment of Alexander Hoffman as an ununiformed fireman, with assignment to H. L. 29, is revoked, he having failed to report for duty. Paragraph II, Special Order 177, Sept. 29. in so far as it relates to the members of the Department Band reporting at Station

The City Affairs Committee made public yesterday the text of letters sent to Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the State Department of Public Service, and Miss Grace Reavy, president of the State Civil Service Commission, urging the disapproval of the Transit Commission's new appointment of former Mayor James J. Walker as assistant counsel at a salary of $12,000 a year.

The newspaper Asahi displayed prominently today a dispatch from Harbin, Manchukuo, reporting that the headquarters of Soviet Russia's Far Eastern Army had been transferred from Khabarovsk 1,400 miles westward to Irkutsk.

The Empire City Savings Bank sold to the Garant Building Company, Inc., Samuel R. Soffin president, the one-story taxpayer at the northwest corner of Walton Avenue and 165th Street, the Bronx. The building occupies a plot 87 by 100 feet and contains twelve stores. Nathan Strunsky was the broker in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $45,000.

Joseph P. Kennedy's speech before the Coast Guard Academy last week was a timely reiteration of the absolute necessity of discipline aboard our merchant ships. "Full recognition of the master's right to obedience at sea" is, as the chairman of the Maritime Commission pointed out, fundamental to the existence of any merchant marine.
The twelfth annual Montclair horse show was opened today in the outdoor ring of the Montclair Riding Club. Several hundred persons attended. The show will end tomorrow.
Governor Lehman today formally accepted "with sincere regrets" the resignation of Louis D. Posner as a member of the Mortgage Commission, on which he had served since February, 1935.

Marshall College uncovered a powerful attack tonight to defeat the Western Maryland eleven, 21 to 0, before a crowd of 10,000. Marshall scored eleven plays after the kick-off, Left Halfback Herb Royer climaxing a 71-yard drive with a 10-yard plunge through the line.
Folk songs and dances of Norway will be presented tomorrow night at the New School for Social Research as the opening program of the series entitled "Folk Songs and Dances of Many Peoples."

BOSTON COLLEGE vs. Kansas State-Alfred G.
