Vanderbilt was looking over the exhibition of photographs of horses by Bert Clark Thayer at the Sporting Gallery and Bookshop when somebody asked him how his horses were coming along. "Slowly!" said A. G. V. "And the word is used advisedly." He added gloomily that

The weekly sessions of the Associated Clinic, conducted under the auspices of the Brooklyn Church and Mission Federation for six years at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, than those were resumed yesterday noon.
One Mass. of the nation's big football games N. H. tomorrow will decide if Nebraska's sched veteran line can halt Minnesota's Potts rampaging backs.

With today the last day of the account, the stock market generally was quiet, but an underlying firmness was apparent. Steadiness ruled among the gilt-edge issues. Chinese bonds were off in the foreign section, and Japanese issues fared only a little better.

Well-informed Italian circles indicated today that Italy will make her acceptance of the Anglo-French invitation to discuss non-intervention conditional on Germany's joint participation. It is not clear, however, whether Italy will insist on an outright invitation to Germany to join the conference or whether she will reserve the right of consulting Germany during the negotiations.

Authoritative sources disclosed today that a falling world market and late-planted crops in communal farming areas had shattered the Mexican Treasury chances of any considerable return this year on its 40,000,000 peso investment in the cotton business.

The Journal of the American Bankers Association has contributed its views on the puzzle of the recent falling market. It believes that, despite some present signs of reduced Autumn business activity and despite also rising costs of doing business, recovery "nevertheless has a strong hold on the country, and no change seems to have occurred that indicates the arrival of an important turning-point."

Japan's trading accounts for the nine months ended yesterday are heavily in the red owing to the large purchases of military goods and industrial raw materials. On the other hand, exports continue to expand steadily and the period just completed gives Japan another record for sales abroad.

Elimination of "high pressure" sales events and the development of the policy of having the "right merchandise at the right price at the right time" have proved sound for Franklin Simon Co. during the year in which it has been operated by the new management headed by Leroy C. Palmer, president, and Russell E. Dill, executive vice president and treasurer.

More unevenness was indicated this week in retail trade in comparison with the corresponding period last year, sales for the country as a whole being estimated at 7 to 20 per cent over the 1936 totals, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Ladies and Gentlemen: The Constitution is the supreme law of our country. The Bill of Rights is the heart of the Constitution. The constitutional safeguard to complete liberty of religious belief is a declaration of the greatest importance to the future of America as a nation of free people.

Arrests in the Federal Governrment's drive against organized vice which started with raids on houses in Atlantic City, Philadelphia and Wilmington; on Aug. 29, total 212 to date, it was disclosed here today.

The total value of American exports in August was $9,500,000 greater than in July, while the value of imports declined $20,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today in its monthly survey of foreign trade.

A few minutes before Supreme Court Justice Hugo Black began his radio speech tonight a fiery cross loomed in the darkness from the Meuntain Lakes Dam, visible from nearly every part of this borough. The cross, built of two-by-fours well soaked with kerosene, blazed long after the speech was finished.

The marriage of Miss Jessie Blanche Mapes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leland Russell Mapes of Evanston, III., to Herman Hamel of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Herman Hamel, took place here last night in the Church of the Transfiguration.
One hundred and fifty members of the Municipal Bond Club of New York and fifteen guests assembled here today for the club's sixth annual field day at the Oakland Golf Club.

Magistrate Leonard McGee dismissed a complaint charging misuse of the United States flag in an advertisement announcing the celebration of German Day, at a hearing on this issue yesterday in Yorkville Court.

Chester Nichols, 27, who has studied singing seven years, won third place in a radio contest for new vocalists and once played in a motion picture, has been appointed dog catcher. "I love dogs," he said, "and this job will help me pay for more singing lessons."

Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto, sitting in Coney Island Court, issued summonses yesterday afternoon against Isidore Kaufman and John Deegan, striking employes of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, charging them with conspiracy in connection with the eighteen-day-old strike called by The Eagle unit of the American Newspaper Guild.

Major Gen. John A. Lejeune formally transferred command as superintendent of Virginia Military Institute to General Charles E. Kilbourne today at the end of a colorful garrison review in full dress uniform by the infantry, cavalry and artillery units of the cadet corps.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petition ANSONIA FIRE PREVENTION ENGINEERING CO., INC., 209 E. 27th St.Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $56,030 and assets of $50,219.

The Brazilian-American debt-payment scheme which will follow along the line of suggestions advanced by the Souza-Costa mission to the United States is within scope of realization, according to information divulged yesterday by Treasury officials here.

Samuel Tandler, builder of apartment houses in Rochester, died today. He was 51 years old. Alone and almost without funds, Mr. Tandler came from his home in Austria to New York at the age of 16 in 1902. Two years later he came to Rochester to pursue his trade of decorator and painter.

Reports by 141 Class I railways to the Interstate Commerce Commission showed that their net income in the first seven months of the year was $55,262,128, against a net income of $3,506,435 in the same period last year.

Miss Doris Martin, daughter of Mrs. Rigby Martin of New York and Frederick John Martin of Westport, Conn., was married here this afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration to Bethuel Moore of 16 East Eighth Street, New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Moore of Louisville, Ky. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Reginald H. Scott.
As millions cheer to see the stout ship Endeavour I coming safe into Gosport out of the Atlantic storms, there may-be a tendency to forget what a good
What is regarded as one of the most important meetings of the French Cabinet in many years will be held tomorrow at the Chateau Rambouillet under the presidency of President Albert Lebrun.

Pennsylvania will open its sixty-first intercollegiate football season on Franklin Field tomorrow against the Maryland eleven. A veteran Penn line will go into action, but the backfield will be comparatively new.

Mr. and Mrs. Wilton Lloyd-Smith gave a dinner dance tonight at Kenjockety, their country home at Lloyd Neck here, for Miss Joan Belmont and Ellsworth N. Bailey, whose marriage takes place tomorrow in the Church of St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley.

A large percentage of the kosher butcher shops expect to close for an indefinite a consequence there were practically no kosher markets yesterday. There was no steer slaughter and the calf and lamb kills were confined to a small percentage of the regular Friday slaughter and intended for the non-kosher trade.
When the curtain rang down on Cornell's first season of football under Carl Snavely last Autumn, the Ithacans were judged to be as handsomely fixed for 1937 as any team east of Pittsburgh.

William E. Blood, president of A. O. Schoonmaker Co., has leased an apartment consisting of fourteen rooms and five baths, comprising an entire floor, in 944 Fifth Avenue, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers, who also announce the rental of suites to Robert Lea in 400 East Fiftyninth Street, Frank Gramkow, in 455 East Fifty-seventh Street, and Miss Elva L. McKee, in 350 East Fifty-second Street.

Prince Taka Kuni, uncle of Empress Nagako of Japan, died today. His age was 61. Emperor Hirohito ordered a threeday court mourning, beginning tomorrow. The Empress will observe mourning for ninety days.
There were nearly 2,000 known cases of cholera today among Chinese living in the International Settlement and the epidemic was increasing at the rate of 100 cases daily. The peak was not in sight.

Another painting by an old master has come to this country and entered the collection of the Worcester Art Museum, Worcester, Mass. It is "The Discovery of Honey," a panel painted by Piero di Cosimo, Italian, 1461-1521, and has just been acquired from Dr.

Another step toward the Vatican's official recognition of General Francisco Franco's government in Spain was forecast today when it was learned that Monsignor Ildebrando Antoniutti, Apostolic Delegate to Spain, would soon be appointed unofficial Vatican Charge d'Affaires to the Insurgent Government.

Yehudi Menuhin, whose concert at the Opera House here last night was the beginning of a tour that will end next Spring in Europe, said he had received from the German Government final approval for inclusion of the long-lost Schumann concerto in a program he will play in St. Louis, Mo., Sunday, Nov. 14, a day after its world premiere in Germany.
Old Westbury had its final warm-up for Sunday's climax to the high-goal polo season, when it plays Greentree for the Waterbury Cup, by romping through a White side, 15 to 3, today. Elbridge and Bobby

A sharp increase in automobile production was noted today by Ward's Automotive Reports, which placed the current week's output at 45,830 units, compared with 28,030 last week and 23,175 for this week a year ago.
Walter Woods, popular East Side year middleweight, evened his score with Solly Krieger of Williamsburg last i night, decisively outpointing his rival in the main bout of ten rounds at the Hippodrome.

Another step toward the Vatican's official recognition of General Francisco Franco's government in Spain was forecast today when it was learned that Monsignor Ildebrando Antoniutti, Apostolic Delegate to Spain, would soon be appointed unofficial Vatican Charge d'Affaires to the Insurgent Government.

Yehudi Menuhin, whose concert at the Opera House here last night was the beginning of a tour that will end next Spring in Europe, said he had received from the German Government final approval for inclusion of the long-lost Schumann concerto in a program he will play in St. Louis, Mo., Sunday, Nov. 14, a day after its world premiere in Germany.
Old Westbury had its final warm-up for Sunday's climax to the high-goal polo season, when it plays Greentree for the Waterbury Cup, by romping through a White side, 15 to 3, today. Elbridge and Bobby
Some Vermont rural families have taken advantage of unusual opportunities in their efforts to can food for Winter use.

John Duncan, who was the oldest living alumnus of the University of North Carolina, died recently at his home in Columbia, Texas, at the age of 99, according to word just received here by Alumni Secretary J. Maryan Saunders.

The need of State regulation in the mortgage field is as pressing today as it was two years ago, according to Professor Maurice Finkelstein, general attorney for the State Mortgage Commission, who has just reported the results of a study he and his staff have made with a view to suggesting means of creating constructive legislation on the subject.

Miss Cornelia Waldo Blagden, a descendant of the Waldo and Mason Jones families of New York and a daughter of Mrs. Francis Meredith Blagden of 176 East Seventieth Street, New York, and Sterlington, and of the late Arthur Campbell Blagden, was married here today to Henry Lowrey Pierson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Haines Pierson, also of Sterlington.

Big John, well-named chestnut gelding owned and ridden by Mrs. Howard Hanna Jr. of Mentor, Ohio, this afternoon won the grand hunter championship of the thirty-fifth annual Piping Rock Horse Show, which came to a brilliant conclusion on the grounds of the Piping Rock Club.

RADIO NATIONS, the short wave broadcasting station at Geneva, was opened five years ago for the transmission of weekly talks dealing with the work of the League of Nations in the hope that such broadcasts would help the peoples of the world realize more fully the possibilities of international cooperation.

Colonel Edward Havemeyer Snyder, commandant of the historic military unit, the Old Guard, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner at the George Washington Hotel in recognition of his twentieth year as head of the guard and his fifty-fifth year of consecutive military service.
ANCHIN--STELNBERG--Mr. and Mrs. Isidor Steinberg announce the engagement of their daughter, Frances Elinor Steinberg, to Mr. Howard Anchin, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Israel Anchin.

JUST view those Yankees now, "the glass of fashion and the mold of form, the observed of all observers." The prestige of the club is tremendous. Nine pennants and five world championships--with possibly another on the fire--in seventeen years. The club that went through three world series without losing a game. The club that had Babe Ruth.

At the conclusion of virtually a full month of searching self-examination and analysis of business trends, industry in the United States has revised downward its calculations of near-by prospects, and in a number of cases has curtailed programs for plant expansion.

Except for tropical worsteds and gabardines, most textile lines which have been offered for Spring have been bought only in sample lots, and buyers have shown a distinct reluctance to make forward commitments.

A large stained - glass window depicting events in the life of Washington was dedicated today in Washington Hall, the cadet mess hall, where it was installed by the WPA. The formal presentation to the academy was by Miss Audrey McMahon, assistant director, Federal Art Projects, Works Progress Administration.

Miss Mary Catherine Zwelzig, daughter of Mrs. M. Luther Zweizig of Reading, Pa., and the late Rev. Dr. Zweizig, to Gerrish Thurber. son of Mrs. Samuel Wood Thurber/ of 157 East Seventy-second Street and the late Dr. Thurber, took place here yesterday noon in the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

Fishermen in the vicinity of Ambrose Lightship during the past few days report sighting plenty of good-sized tuna. Ed Buckley of Freeport caught one of 171 pounds on Thursday and Jim Combs, dockmaster at Freeport, took a day off and landed one of 102 pounds.
Dr. and Mrs. James Phinney Baxter 3d will give a large reception at President's House, Williamstown, next Friday afternoon after Dr. Baxter's induction as tenth president of the college.

Three German fliers, Baron Karl August von Gablenz, Robert Untucht and Herr Kirschoff, who were lost for weeks after landing in an oasis on the Pamir Plateau, have sent from Teheran, Iran, an account of what happened before their reappearance at Kabul, Afghanistan.

Samuel S. Bloch, president of the Bloch Brothers Tobacco Company, died suddenly tonight of heart disease at his home here. He was 87 years old. He had been ill for several months but his condition had not been serious.

With reports indicating sales increases are much harder to get and with the possibility that the margin of gain over 1936 will be materially reduced in the last quarter of this year, store executives are giving serious consideration to the conclusion that a large portion of the "depression void" in purchases of consumer goods has now been filled.

Mr. and Mrs. Marshal Stearns of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Russell Stearns, to Dr. Chauncey Johnson Pattee, son of Mrs. Frank Johnson Pattee of Montreal and the late Dr. Pattee of Hawksbury, Ont.

An "important engagement" in California will prevent Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana from joining citizens in welcoming President Roosevelt to the State tomorrow. Senator Wheeler telegraphed to the Helena bureau of The Associated Press today from Gerber, Calif., saying that he was wiring his regrets to the President as follows:...
Argentina and Illinois shared honors in the two closing feature events at Hawthorne today.
Many women of prominence are actively interested in a luncheon to be given by the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York on Oct. 14 at the Biltmore.

ANNALS OF THE NEW YORK STAGE. By George C. L. Odell. Volume VIII. 779 pp. 296 photographs (1865-1870). Volume IX, 742 pp. 361 photographs (1870-1875). New York: Columbia University Press. $8.75 per volume. BY common agreement, this is a work of scholarship which is veritably definitive. George C. Odell, Brander Matthews Professor of Dramatic Literature at Columbia University, has left no stone unpolished in his search for theatre history in Manhattan and near-by villages.

With nearly 50,000 stamps and covers assembled, including a small display from the collection of President Roosevelt, the National Stamp Exhibition of the New York Museum of Science and Industry was opened in the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center at 10 A. M.

THIS has been a week of musical plays-in one theatre "Crazy Days," by Stanley Lupino, written presumably for Stanley Lupino and Laddie Cliff, though Laddie Cliff was prevented by illness from appearing on the first night; and, in another theatre, "Going Greek," written by a multitude of authors and composers as a "vehicle" for Leslie Henson.

A model of New York City, twentytwo feet wide and thirty-seven feet long, will be placed on public exhibit in Education Hall of the American Museum of Natural History tomorrow afternoon for two weeks. Built on a scale of 300 feet to the inch, the model, which consists of more than 20,000 pieces, shows the boroughs of this city as they would look from an altitude of three miles.
NO SURRENDER: A veteran of the political and economic wars was in New York last week to address the Lions Club. General Jacob S. Coxey,

Two stylishly dressed hold-up men with a lot of pride but no cash put on the proverbial high hat yesterday afternoon and snubbed loot of at least $24 as mere chicken feed. About 1 P. M. they entered the office of the Artist Fast Freight, a trucking concern, on the third floor of 30 East Twentieth Street, just east of Broadway.

The Hun School of Princeton will open its Fall term on Monday with an enrollment of 120 students, the largest in recent years. Dr. John Gale Hun, headmaster, announced today the addition of three instructors to the faculty.

THE present Sino-Japanese war has brought the world a step nearer to that stage of human progress when the bombing from the air of crowded cities with their noncombatants will be an essential feature of human warfare.

HERALDING the more substantial releases to be expected from now on through the Winter months comes another of the recordings made by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra before Arturo Toscanini's farewell.

Miss Nathalie Tucker Powers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Powers of Bridgeton, was married here this afternoon to Richard Franklin Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin T. Miller of Auburndale, Mass. The ceremony was performed in the Old Broad Street Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Austin Brady of Woodbury, N. J., formerly of Bridgeton.

SINCE its announcement last Spring the New Friends of Music has engaged a number of artists for its Mozart-SchubertSchumann cycle of chamber music and Lieder to be given this season at Town Hall on Sunday afternoons.

A hobo caught a train at Idaho Falls, Idaho, one night last week, wedged himself between two cars and "rode the blinds" until the train halted at Pocatello. There he was arrested, for he was riding the special in which President Roosevelt was making his pulse-taking tour of the Northwest. "I didn't know I was riding on the Presidential special," the hobo explained.

THUS far shown only to automobile editors and technical writers, the first automobiles to use conditioned-air systems for Winter driving will be viewed at Chicago tomorrow by the distributors who will present them to America.

The following Foreign Service changes since Sept. 24 were announced today by the State Department: Lucien Memminger of Charleston, S. C. consul general at Belfast, assigned Copenhagen as consul general. Hallett Johnson of South Orange, N. J. counselor of embassy at Warsaw, to Stockholm as consul general.

The thirteen-acre estate with an English-type residence of twentyfive rooms known as Audley House at Mendham, N. J., has been leased for a year with an option to purchase by Miss Gill of Westfield, N. J., who will use the property for a private school.

" Today our airmen dropped bombs on the Fort of London."--German official report, June 13, 1917. IT was high noon on that June day in London and a bright sun shone from a cloudless sky. Miles up some one saw what looked like "white butterflies"--German Gothas in their first raid over the metropolis of England. Death came without warning.

Miss Elise Holderness, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Holderness of this place, was married to Dr. Henry L. Shepherd of Farmington, this afternoon at the home of her parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Quincy Blakely of Farmington.

Miss Elizabeth Campbell Young, daughter of Dr. Hugh Hampton Young, was married here to Warren Russell Starr of Honolulu, son of Mr. and Mrs. Middleton Starr of San Francisco, this afternoon in St. David's Protestant Episcopal Church, Roland Park. A large reception at Dr. Young's Roland Park home followed the ceremony.

Miss Ann Boardman Reynolds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Reynolds of West Hartford, was married here today to Rockwell Braddock Ward, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Burwell Ward, by the Rev. William T. Hooper.

Two bottles of champagne instead of the customary one crashed against the prow of the 10,000-ton light cruiser Nashville at noon today, and amid the cheers of 3,000 spectators and the whistling of river craft she slid down the ways at the New York Shipbuilding Company's plant into the Delaware River.

Mr. and Mrs. Hervey B. Phillips of South Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Rickert Phillips, to John Fowler Ackerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Irving Ackerman of Paterson.

Miss Catherine Thurber Arrighl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Arrighi, was married yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents, 12 Fifth Avenue, to Charles Horton Watson, son of Mrs. Charles H. Watson of 36 Gramercy Park and the late Mr. Watson. The Rev.

The marriage of Miss Joan M. Belmont, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan Belmont of 434 East Fifty-seventh Street, New York, and Cove Neck, to Ellsworth N. Bailey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore L. Bailey of New York and Harriman, N. Y., took place this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of. St. John's of Lattingtown at Locust Valley.

The University of Oregon Webfoots christened their new turf gridiron today by defeating the Stanford Indians for the first time in thirteen meetings. The score was 7 to 6. Two sophomore halfbacks collaborated in producing Oregon's touchdown in the second period, Jay Graybeal catching Bob Smith's pass on the Stanford 23 and sprinting the rest of the distance to the goal line.

Mr. and Mrs. John M. Duffy of 493 First Street, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Duffy, to Lieut. Comdr. Alfred Edward Flannery, surgeon in the Medical Corps of the British Royal Navy, now stationed at Malta.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Rose L. Pascal of Woodhaven, Queens, of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alma Berenice Pascal, to Myron Read, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas T. Read of Scarsdale, N. Y.

Bettina Martinelli, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Giovanni Martinelli, was married today to Mario Libotte, Roman lawyer, in the Church of St. Ignazio. Her father is a leading tenor of the Metropolitan Opera in New York.

EVEN without the theatrical productions of past seasons--these are now reserved for the Florentine Musical May--Venice's "Fifth International Modern Music Festival," just finished, has been one of the most brilliant of the series.

For the first nine months of this year the Serial Federal Savings and Loan Association of New York had an 86 per cent increase in savings accounts compared with the same period of last year, George E. Palmer, secretary-manager, reported yesterday.

Premier Paul van Zeeland, in poor health as a result of his long years of captivity in German prison camps during the World War, and sick and tired of politics, handed his resignation, together with that of his Cabinet, to the King last Friday.

Demands for wage increases In the building industry are "ill-advised" and constitute a check on recovery in construction, in the opinion of H. I. Feldman, architect, who cites as a second hindrance to building recovery the practice of restricted bidding for contracts.

Mrs. Edward Hutchins of Boston ras married to Leroy Brinckerhoff litkin, son of' Mr. and Mrs. H. leroy Pitkin of this place, today. The wedding took place at the firstt Presbyterian Church here, the rev. Carl H. Elmore officiating. ohn P. Pitkin, brother of the ridegroom, was best man.

The capital, appraising Justice Black's "fireside chat" to the nation, mingled its approval or disapproval today with disappointment that he failed to clear up the principal point in the mystery, as it appears here.

Thousands of Fifth Avenue pedestrians and shoppers yesterday morning lined the curbs from Sixtyseventh Street to Fifty-fourth Street to watch the ten-block long, military funeral procession accorded to Brig.
Miss Charlotte Carr, new head resident of Hull House, who started her career as an $18-a-week matron in an orphan asylum, has taken over her duties here as the successor of Jane Addams.

IT sounds strange to automotive ears to hear talk about selling more motor cars by reducing the number of dealers. The industry has been brought up on the idea that retail car sales multiply as the number of retail outlets expands.

The marriage of Miss Grace Dietrich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Dietrich of South Orange, to Dr. Thomas S. Breese, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Breese of Morristown, took place this evening in Vailsburgh Methodist Episcopal Church. The pastor, the Rev. Ralph Roby, officiated.

In a special statement to be distribute tomorrow to 25,000 New Yorkers, John W. Davis, chairman of the 1937 United Hospital Campaign, declares that the 5,908,421 days of care given last year to the sick and injured in the city's voluntary hospitals are the equivalent of 162 centuries of time.

Today Maplewood (N. J.) Woman's Club--First concert of season. Theodore Uullman, concert pianist, 3:30 P. M., clubhouse. Monday A. W. A.-Admissions tea, 5 P. M., clubhouse. Bronxville Woman's Club-Garden department meeting. Dorothy Biddle, speaker, 2:30 P. M.

Convinced that first impression means everything, Fordham touched off its forty-ninth football campaign yesterday in a manner which easily bespoke its preparedness for the heavy guns which are waiting in the offing.

Miss Anna Gardner Cole, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Parliman Cole of this place, was marrieto Philips Stockton Trenbath, son of the Rev. Robert Wight Trenbath and Mrs. Trenbath of Montclair, N. J., this evening in the Church of St. James the Less here.

Threats of a city-wide strike of hosiery workers, which followed charges that the Committee for Industrial Organization was intimidating employes of the Apex Hosiery Company, were dissipated today as the C. I. O. made gestures of peace which won sympathy from company officials.

With the war costing the Chinese Government roughly $1,000,000 daily the Government has funds already available to carry on the struggle another six months, a high financial authority revealed to the writer today in discussing the nation's resources in relation to its ability to wage a long conflict with Japan.

Whatever chances the suggestion made in June, 1933, for the creation of a four-power pact in Europe may have had, they seem now in French opinion to have been definitely eliminated by speeches made during the past week in Berlin by Der Fuehrer and II Duce.

MR. PINKERTON again with all his engaging ineptitude, his innocent faith in human nature, his astonishing flashes of sagacity; above all, with his sheer genius for stumbling into the very midst of mysterious crime.

Representative George N. Seger, Republican, of Passaic, N. J., today called Justice Black's radio address "a sorry and weak performance." "When Justice Black was the grand inquisitor of the Senate and when he was opposing anti-lynching legislation in that body he was not bill-of-rights minded," Mr. Seger said.

Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, expressed disappointment yesterday that the Board of Taxes and Assessments had failed to give more adequate relief to realty owners than appears in the figures just announced for 1938 tax valuations.

MAN inhabits today a world very different from that which encompassed even his parents and grandparents. It is a world geared to modern machinery-automobiles, airplanes, power plants; it is linked together and served by electricity. New conditions create new needs. New needs, in turn, impose a new design
Automobile Finance Company -- Eight months ended on Aug. 31: Net profit, $192,410, equal to 61 ?? each on 240,310 common share outstanding, compared with profit of $90,242 in same period last year.

The Senate tonight in special session approved a bill granting sugar producers a mortgage moratorium up to 1945. The legislation, which was passed by the House of Representatives last month, extends and amplifies the moratorium enacted by the Presidential decree in 1934.

AT the same time that Maurice Maeterlinck celebrates the seventy-fifth anniversary of his birth several of his compatriots--Flemings or Walloons-belonging to the generations which follow his, are publishing quite a series of novels and short stories which bear witness to the renaissance of Belgian letters as expressed in French.

BRIN--SLMONSON--Mr. and Mrs. Max Simonson announce marriage of their daughter, Tessie Edna, to Mr. L. Milwood Brin. Friday. Oct. 1, Hotel Croydon. DAVIS--HEYMAN--Mrs. Samuel Heyman announces the marriage of her daughter, Minna Rose, to Horace G. Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Davis of Jersey City.

Army engineers said today that the first major project in a $27,000,000 floodcontrol program in Southern New York might be undertaken before Spring. Plans for two dams at Arkport and Whitney Point are ready.

Albert Lemoine, a 30-year-old policeman, was pitched to death from his motor cycle early today while pursuing an automobile whose occupants he sought to question in connection with the mysterious firing of shotgun charges into the windows of city officials and judges.

Stevens Institute of Technology, here opened this week a three-story, redbrick dormitory, Palmer Hall, with accommodations for seventy-six students, more than doubling the dormitory accommodations, exclusive of fraternity houses.

A thousand United States war veterans, with their wives and children marched up the Champs Elysees at sunset today to honor the unknown soldier. It was a collection of quiet men, some well-past middle age, who made up this gathering of American Legionnaires which has been calledd the "Third A. E. F."

November election candidates in the eighteen towns of Westchester County were nominated this week at party caucuses and the ballots will take further shape on Monday when the county Republican and Democratic committees hold their annual reorganization meetings here. Most of the city and county candidates were nominated in the primary two weeks ago.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Townsend of Bryn Mawr have announced the engagement of Mrs. Townsend's daughter, Miss Nancy Montgomery Dallam, to Charles Sinkler 2d, son of Mrs. S. Deas Sinkler of Ithan.
Miss Margaretta Catherine Niebergall, daughter of Mr. and-Mrs. Henry Hoffman Niebergall of Bloomfield, and Joseph Frederick Dox, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Dox of Verona, were married today.
Mr. and Mrs. Hollings C. Renton of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Evelyn Renton to George Frederick Beckley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Beckley of Larchmont.

A MEANS of knitting the innumerable elements of America's vast travel business into a unified industry acting in concert to develop the domestic travel field was suggested last week in a proposal of the National Park Service to present a bill before Congress in January for the creation of a National Travel Commission.

Getting off to an early lead, Arnold College today defeated Lowell Textile, 12 to 6. By a powerful attack in the first and second periods, Arnold marched down the field to score in each session, with Puduah and Benvenuti carrying the ball over.

At the close of this week, on Thursday, Friday and Saturday, we shall observe the 150th anniversary of the founding of Erasmus Hall High School, the first secondary school to be chartered by the Regents of the University of the State of New York.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Gail Crane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Noble Crane of Bellaire, Queens, to Eyre Massey Bunn, son of Mrs. Walter C. Bunn of Bergenfield, N. J., and the late Mr. Bunn, took place yesterday afternoon in the First Methodist Episcopal Church of Hollis. The Rev. William Berguin performed the ceremony.

Miss Grace Shiel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Shiel of this place, was married to Frederick D. Roe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Roe of Newark, this morning at the Sacred Heart Church. Mgr. T. M. Donovan officiated.
A cake five feet tall and weighing 140 pounds turned an otherwise dull day into a happy one yesterday for the child patients in the New York Orthopaedic Hospital, 420 East Fifty-ninth Street.

Vassar College has embarked upon what-is believed to be a new project in undergraduate education, the creation of a social museum for the preparation and exhibition of material relating to every phase of life in the region in which the college is located.

WASHINGTON. -- Reports from State WPA directors reveal that work done under WPA auspices has often brought good positions to women with initiative and the ability to fit themselves for new types of work.

Annual Fall assembly of the Council of Fraternal and Benevolent Organizations, Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth treet, 2 P. M. Speakers : George Z. Medalie, B. Charney Vladeck, Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May.

China's "forgotten children"--hundreds of famished, dirty, half-naked war orphans--are roaming the streets and alleys of Shanghai. Animal-like, they dart about, spending their days in an endless hunt for food.

Japan's tremendous offensive by land, sea and air buckled for the sixth consecutive day today against the stone-wall defense of the Chinese troops entrenched in Chapei on the outskirts of the International Settlement.

Good real estate does not lose its value, Peter M. Fraser, vice-president of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company of Hartford, told the delegates to the recent New England regional convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards held in that city.

Scores of Chinese students in American universities are without support as a result of Japan's invasion of their native land, according to Y. E. Hsiao, general secretary of the Chinese Students Christian Association, which is investigating the plight of the students in an attempt to render aid.
Justice Black's "pious words may serve as atonement for him and some explanation to those who have been questioning his fitness to sit on the Supreme bench of the land," Rabbi William F. Rosenblum of

SHUFFLING all the cards in his retrospective pack, Abraham Walkowitz plays a game of patience at the Park Art Galleries, 48 East Fiftieth Street; a game so intricate, so full of surprise moves that it will probably be watched by the local art world with the attentiveness that surrounds,

The American Public Health Association will hold its sixty-sixth annual meeting here from Tuesday through Friday. It is expected that more than 5,000 health officers, physicians, nurses and educators will attend the sessions, which will be devoted to many topics, including "design and sanitation of bathing places," "meeting flood conditions more effectively," "the homicide situation in the United States" and "rat control."

Frost need not bring an end to garden flowers for those who are loath to see them go. An hour or two spent in the garden on a mid-September day will unarth many candidates for Winter window boxes, and for flower pots placed in sunny east and south windows.
IN a recent essay Albert Jay Nock called attention to Thiers's profound remark to Count Walewski, who, not content with a career in diplomacy, vainly imagined he could write a good play.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Jenness Ehleider, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas John Ehleider of this city, to Robert Galbraith Ewart, son of Mr. and Mrs. FranK A. Ewart of Braintree, Mass., took place here tonight in Christ Episcopal Church.

The marriage of Miss Ethel M. Lawrence, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Lawrence of 829 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, to John S. Maun, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Maun, also of Brooklyn, took place there yesterday morning in the Church of St. John the Baptist. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas Hill, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

Governor Cone has poked old embers into flames by announcing that he will not enforce the law against gambling if Miami wants such a diversion. for Winter visitors, and that he will not establish a border patrol to keep out jobless persons.

As sweepingly as though a "clear the decks" order had been issued, everything not pertaining to the absorbing topic of registration has been shunted aside on the executive desks in headquarters of women's groups and a monopoly. given to this civio theme.

Minnesota's dream of marching to its fourth successive national football championship exploded in an upset today that rocked the gridiron world. In sun-baked Memorial Stadium, before a capacity crowd of 36,000 frenzied spectators, Nebraska conquered the mighty Gophers, heretofore defeated only once since late in 1932. The score was 14 to 9.

Carrying all the Socialist Ministers in the Cabinet with them, Premier Camille Chautemps and Finance Minister Georges Bonnet today at a Cabinet meeting held at the Chateau Rambouillet altered the whole course along which France has been traveling since the Popular Front Government came into power fifteen months ago.

With all their similarities, the New York Stock Exchange and the London Stock Exchange are vastly different. The dissimilarity has been growing more pronounced in recent years, for, while the brokerage business in New York has been comparatively unprofitable, London brokers have enjoyed a high degree of prosperity.

The tanker Wallace E. Pratt of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey's fleet was launched at the shipyard of the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company today. The sponsor was Miss Nancy Pratt, 18, daughter of the company's director, for whom the. craft was named.

Merchant mariners familiar with the sea lanes of the world sailed from this port yesterday on the battleship Wyoming as the United States Navy began its first training cruise for officers and men of commercial vessels.
The Central Harlem Health Center, costing $270,868, will be opened at 12:30 P. M. tomorrow at formal ceremonies in the building. Mayor La Guardia will head the list of speakers.

Seizing upon popular resentment against Japan in her undeclared war with China, American manufacturers who have suffered from Japanese competition have organized to establish a permanent boycott against both raw and manufactured goods from that country, it was learned here yesterday.

Japan's conflict with China came at the end months of remarkable prosperity, reflected in the accounts of 1.437 leading companies just investigated by the Industrial Bank of Japan. Profits were reported by 1,379. Fifty-eight showed small losses, aggregating 2,660,000 yen.

Getting off to a whirlwind start, Wesleyan easily defeated the Connecticut State College eleven today, 17 to 6. Holzer of Wesleyan took the opening kick-off and threaded through the opposition for a touchdown.
AN end to the confusion which has resulted from having too many tournaments each year advertised as "national championships" is promised in an announcement made last week.
Immediate organization of American exporters and others who have suffered property damage in China was urged here yesterday by Oren O. Gallup, secretary of the Export Managers' Club of New York, Ihc.

In a very sober article in The Public Opinion Quarterly, Mr. John L. Lewis, president of the C. I. O., undertakes to tell us "What Labor Is Thinking." Whether or not the article reflects accurately the views of "labor," it is in any case significant for the light it throws on the economic and political program of Mr. Lewis himself.

Reorganizing almost completely the financial committee of the League of Nations, which is among its most important standing committees, the League's Council today named to the committee Thomas Jefferson Coolidge, formerly Under-Secretary of the United States Treasury, and Sir Frederick Phillips, Under-Secretary of the British Treasury.

THEY are brought together-a group of folk art objects and a group of drawings graphically reproducing those same objectsand the WPA Index of American Design thereby demonstrates the caliber of artists to whom an exacting task has been entrusted. The worth of the Index idea itself, which looks to the building up of a comprehensive reference file of

After the "three very active and fruitful years" of the Tyler Dennett administration, Dr. James Phinney Baxter 3d, former Harvard history professor who will be inducted as tenth president of Williams next Friday, is going to "try to take the first year easy."
New Orleans residents waded today in a flood from rain caused by two tropical disturbances which merged in the Gulf of Mexico. Every section of the city was affected. Water stood from a few

Louisiana State University triumphed in the mud tonight, defeating the University of Texas, 9 to 0. The touchdown came near the end of the first period. Charlie Haas punted from behind his own goal line to the L. S. U. 41 and Pinky Rohm dashed through the entire Longhorn team for the score. Milner kicked the extra point.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mrs. Arthur Lawrence Bogart of this city to Wallace J. Law of Cranford.
I REMEMBER in the Moissi production, the German text of which I could not follow, that Was surprised by "To be, or not to be" coming so quickly on top of "O! what a rogue and-peasant slaves am I."

John R. Seckler, head of the Seckler Shepperd syndicate, developer of the Highland Lakes community near Stockholm, Sussex, reports that during the past season 250 cabin plots were sold and many of them were improved with Summer cottages.

Thomas J. Donnelly, former Demc cratic Assemblyman and for many years national secretary of the Foresters of America, fraternal organization, died of a heart attack today in his apartment at the Fairmount Hotel here. He was 75 years old.
Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, outlined today an "allweather" program to thousands of farmers from Kentucky, Tennessee and Southern Indiana assembled here.

Consecutive monthly heavy imports following the eight-year July record of 47,533 metric tons is responsible for a generally heavy stock situation and market saturation in Peru at the end of September, according to the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce in a report today.
Newark's Bears, champions of the International League, combined eleven hits with five Columbus errors tonight to defeat the Red Birds, 8 to 1, in the fourth game of the little world series.

Reports that the Distilled Spirits Institute has abandoned its earlier intention of getting a nationally known figure as successor to the late W. Forbes Morgan, president of the organization, circulated through the liquor industry here last week. Although no confirmation was obtainable from institute members or officials, the rumors were given credence by other branches of the industry.
Miss Matilda Fassitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Fassitt of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to William Reese Scott 3d of Swarthmore, son of Mrs. William R. Scott.

Miss Marjorie Etta Robidoux, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Robidoux of this city, was Married to Robert William Leeming, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Leeming of East Orange, this evening in Munn Avenue Presbyterian Church here.- The Rev. Dr. Robert Brewster Beattie, pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

Jack and Jerry are pulling hard for education, but the education isn't their own. Jack and Jerry are a pair of mules, anti they play an important role in the otherwise mechanized transportation system that costs the Franklin Center School $20,000 yearly to pick up and to deliver its students.

Magistrate Michael A. Ford, dismissing in Jefferson Market Court yesterday charges against five alleged bookmakers, assailed the police as incompetent in gathering evidence in such cases and declared he was "amazed at the bad detective work" involved.
The Community of St. Johnland will be the beneficiary of the performance of Mozart's comic opera, "Cosi Fan Tutte," by the Salzburg Opera Guild the night of Nov. 6 at the Majestic Theatre.

Colgate returned to Schoellkopf Field after an absence of fourteen years today and a steam roller reminiscent of the Git Dobian juggernaut that rolled over the Maroon by 34-7 in 1923 exploded one of the bombshells of Eastern football by burying the invaders from the Chenango under a 40-7 score.
Outstanding experts will address the sixth annual meeting of the Controllers Institute of America, which will commence a three-day convention tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria.

A document throwing new light on the invention of the tugboat has just been discovered here. It tells of a battle 125 years ago between an inventor with the famous name of John L. Sullivan of Boston and Robert Fulton, inventor of the steamboat.
WITH three electric cameras trained on the field, the British Broadcasting Corporation recently attempted to televise twenty-two football players in action at Arsenal Stadium during rehearsal.

MANHATTAN PERKINS. JAMES RIPLEY OSGOOD (Sept. 21). Estate, $10,000. To Janet Rane Perkins, widow, executrix, 21 E. 66th St.. residue. NACHETINOVICH, LEONARDO (Sept. 26). Estate, $10,000. To Annais Nachetinovich, widow, executrix, 235 E. 22d St., residue.

Draper, president of the Trades and Labor Congress of Canada, will appear before the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor here next week to explain his organization's recent mediation proposal to the A. F. of L. and the C. I. O.

The whole country has been quiet and calm for the last forty-eight hours. Arabs in towns and villages are going about their daily business as usual and so far there is not the slightest sign of trouble.

Leading figures among the nation's industrial, financial and railroad labor and management executives united here today with representatives of the national Government and of several States to honor William M. Jeffers, the former call boy who has just become president of the Union Pacific Railroad, succeeding Carl R. Gray.

Miss Elizabeth Andrews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Andrews of this place, and Charles A. Flynn Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Flynn of Plainfield, were married this afternoon at the bride's home by the Rev. C. A. Heavey of Plainfield.

Registration statements covering the issuance of 231,500 shares of $1-par common stock by L. E. Carpenter Co. of Newark, N. J., manufacturer of imitation leather goods products, and 24,000 shares of nopar stock by the Hellenic Hydro Electric and Metallurgic Corporation of New York have been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to an official announcement today.

The American Red Cross is shipping to China enough medical and surgical supplies to equip three hospital units of 500 beds each, it was announced at headquarters here today. The supplies will be used for the relief of all nationalities.

The Westchester County Clearing House Association reports clearings of $3,436,070 for the week ended on Friday, compared with $3,694,227 for the preceding week, and $3,376,336 for the corresponding week last year.

" Unfriendly" grocery retailers who use nationally known products as the butt of advertising campaigns in behalf of private brands, or "football" national brands as loss-leaders, will be disciplined by being cut off from the national products they attack, according to expressions by individual manufacturers here last week.
Holy Cross took a hard-played game from Providence College today, 7 to 0, before a crowd of 10,000. Providence put up a stiff fight, but lacked a real punch.

THIS book is illustrated with forty-eight reproductions of paintings of the old English scene, and in a sense it may be said to be written around the work of the landscape painters of the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries. Certainly R. H.
Representatives of the meat-packing industry are loath as individuals to comment on the rising cost of meat to the consumer and the prospect of further increases.

Miss Bettina Thurber Barrett, daughter of Thomas A. Barrett of this city and the late Mrs. Barrett, was married this afternoon to John William Chapman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard G. Chapman of Syracuse.

Work is progressing rapidly on the first group of twenty low-cost dwellings under construction in the Alden Estates development on King Street, Port Chester, Westchester County. Ultimately 250 homes will be built on the site.

Members of the University of North Carolina New York Alumni Club will give a dinner dance on Saturday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador, after the North Carolina-New York University football game.

The astonishing success of Paul Keres of Estonia in winning the recent international chess masters tournament at Semmering, Austria, against such famous experts as Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, Reuben Fine and Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Salo Flohr of Prague, has aroused the curiosity of the chess-playing world in the methods adopted by this 21-yearold youth.

THIRTY days hath September and twenty-five new pictures from Hollywood. Not yet one a day, which is a consummation devoutly to be unwanted, particularly when we discover such clouds on the immediate October horizon as Joe Penner and Gene Raymond.
Spanish Insurgents swept through historic Covadonga tonight along the Biscayan coast to new battlefields on the way to Gijon, last government port in the north.

THE Rolling Rock and the Meadow Brook are good-sized hunts in their effete Eastern way, but the most imposing in the West is Hunt Stromberg, who hardly ever touches an idea unless it is large-scale and impracticable for lesser men.

IN the showrooms of 3,000 dealers the 1938 Willys line of motor ve hicles goes on display today. It includes three new passenger-car units and a line of light commercial units, offered for the first time.

The State Association of Magistrates endorsed today a proposal calling for establishment of State camps for habitual inebriates. City Judge Jacob Gitelman of Rochester presented the proposal, asserting that the jailing of chronic alcoholics was "an unjustifiable expense to the taxpayers and does the inebriate no good."

Methods of modern war are arousing protests throughout the world. By acclamation, the League of Nations has expressed "horror and indignation" at the bombing of Chinese cities by Japanese airmen, which attacks are declared by Secretary Hull to be contrary to principles of law and humanity." Britain,
FROM the crazy-quilt pattern of New York school lunches as they are again being eaten by hundreds of thousands of children, there may some day emerge a typical New York school lunch.
The engagement has been announced of Miss Marion Sohn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Sohn of 420 West End Avenue, to Richard H. Stern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton H. Stern, also of this city.

Naturally the murder case Yes of the People of the State of and New York vs. the Six-Notch No Kid in December, 1937, at tracted wide attention. By this time criminal procedure in the United States had been pretty well reorganized on the new principle enunciated in the leading Die-Hard Liberal press.

Jose Ramon Rivero, 27 years old, brother-in-law of Juan Ignacio Pombo, Spanish Atlantic flier, was shot dead in his office here last night. The police arrested Manuel Sainz, a salesman, after two witnesses had identified him as the man who had broken into the office and fired four shots at Rivero.

TRADE lost little of its jerkiness last week and yet the average for the country probably continued to improve. By various sections the spread in results was quite wide. The Coast may have dipped a little under last year, the New England gain was only slight.

SCREEN rights to the operettas of Gilbert and Sullivan have finally been relinquished by the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, but not to a Hollywood studio. The producers will be the General Cinema Finance Corporation, Ltd., a new outfit which apparently was organized especially for the purpose.

Two large Bronx parcels will be offered at auction on Tuesday in the Vesey Street salesroom by Edwin J. McDonald. They include the plot at 2,267 White Plains Road on which are several frame sheds; and the adjoining vacant plot fronting on Olinville and Astor Avenues and White Plains Road.

A. E. HOUSMAN is to be commemorated with a scholarship fund at Bromsgrove School. Housman was there from 1870 to 1877. The fund's income will go to send boys from the school to Cambridge or Oxford. Any one who would like to subscribe to the fund should send a check to the A. E. Housman Memorial Scholarship Fund, Bromsgrove School, Bromsgrove, Worcestershire, England. And not to Shropshire.

The Ursinus Bears, coming back on the rebound after a defeat at the hands of Bucknell, downed the eleven from Delaware University, 11-6, before a crowd of 2,500 today. The Bears took a 3-point lead on Roy Sawson's dropkick from the 27-yard line. Ware and Sheats collaborated to block and recover a punt on the 5 to pave the way for Delaware's touchdown.
High officials of one Asiatic republic and political bosses in another were disclosed today to have been removed from their posts in a drive against alleged widespread separatist movements.

Miss Kathryn Ruth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Milton Ruth of Maplewood, and Charles Gunnar Holmberg 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Holmberg Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Westfield, were married this evening in the Women's Club of Maplewood by the Rev. Dr. John E. Charlton, pastor of Morrow Memoral Church here.
Mrs. Stella Starr, 32-year-old mother of ten children, of whom only four are living, was in a critical condition in Flushing Hospital last night with a bullet wound in the right side of the back.
Clifton's Beau, 6-year-old brown gelding owned by Mrs. Harry Frank Jr. of Warrenton, N. J., captured the hunter laurels at the Montclair horse show today.

As a contribution to the profitable use of the leisure time imposed upon many by the changed economic situation, Temple University today announced a comprehensive series of avocational courses, designed for those who wish to "ride" hobbies.
Against a background of cheering, uproarious throngs, President Roosevelt toured the mountainous Columbia River Basin this week. "I never saw so much enthusiasm in my life," said Governor Charles H.

From some of the upper windows of the houses surrounding Villa Torlonia, the residence of Premier Mussolini and his family, a partial view may be obtained of the dictator's back yard, and from them many pairs of indiscreet eyes are always ready to spy the movements of a plump, middle-aged, fair-haired woman who derives obvious and unaffected pleasure from feeding a couple of dozen chickens.

The Rev. C. C. Chapman, Professor of Constitutional History at Loyola University of the South, today cited a Federal statute as indicating that former membership in the Ku Klux Klan barred Justice Black from Federal office.
Turpentine firm, 28c; sales 51 barrels; receipts 48 barrels; shipments 70 barrels; stock 36,736 barrels. Resin firm; sales 534; receipts 1,967; shipments 10; stock 72,649.
Pleasure boating is by no means over for the year. Labor Day and the reopening of school may be the signal for most yachtsmen to end their seasons afloat but there are some stay-ons.
Plans are being discussed for one of the familiar events of the Winter season here--the December Back in aid of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House.

Current business uncertainty, created by slow retail trade, the stock market slump, heavy invenstories, the Sino - Japanese conflict and continued Washington pronouncements on taxation and regulation, is beginning to force a curtailment of advertising expenditures by leading companies for the balance of the year and is holding up 1938 schedules, according to reports here last week.
ISLAND cruises continue to at tract Autumn travelers. Steamship lines circling the Caribbean are particularly popular at present with tourists enjoying out-ofseason vacations.

THE Spanish Rebels have released 25 and 50 centimo and 1 and 2 peseta bicolored stamps with three trees as the design and inscribed "Aduntament de Pins del Valles," but bearing the overprint "Correus--Jornades de Jiliol del 1936--5 cts." General Franco has issued also a miniature sheet of 5-centimo blue stamps illustrating a Government building, inscribed "Cocinas Economicas" and overprinted "Viva Franco."
Ten honorary degrees will be conferred by Franklin and Marshall College in connection with the sesquicentennial anniversary, from Oct. 14 to 17. The degrees will be conferred
Northwestern, champion of the Western Conference, found the Iowa State Cyclones only a mild breeze today, rolling up a 33-to-0 score before 30,000 spectators in Dyche Stadium.
Princeton soccer players today bowed before the prowess of the champion Crescent Athletic Club team of the Field Club Soccer League of New York and New Jersey.
Three 15-year-old high school boys of Neptune and Ocean Grove were arrested at their homes today in connection with five burglaries and two hold-ups in Asbury Park the last three months.

The marriage of Miss Theodora Winslow Myers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Fleming Myers, to Aaron Moore Bagg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Clark Bagg of Holyoke, Mass., took place here this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church.

Miss Dorothy Adele Barry, daughter of Mrs. Ralph Frederick Barry of this city and the late Mr. Barry, was married to Frederick Gordon Ketcham, son of Frederick Arthur Ketcham of River Edge, N. J., and the late Mrs. Ketcham, here this morning in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edgar Cook.

A century of increasing success in bringing speech and understanding to children who are both deaf and blind and consequently mute is to be celebrated tomorrow. For it was on Oct. 4, 1837, that Laura Bridgman, the first deaf-blind mute ever to be educated, entered Perkins Institution for the Blind in Boston.

Consolidation into one department of the various State agencies now handling real estate and mortgage affairs was urged today by Benjamin J. Rabin, chairman of the State Mortgage Commission, in an address before the annual convention of the Real Estate Association of the State.

EIlen Wilson McAdoo, 22-year-old daughter of United States, Senator William Gibbs McAdoo, will make her debut as a professional singer Oct. 18 at a Federal music project concert in suburban Glendale, project officials here said today.
The effectiveness of a new political influence in Kansas-the men and women who are eligible to allowances under the State Social Security Law-will be demonstrated this Autumn.
The repatriation of Nicaraguans from Honduras continues as the motor ship Spitfire, chartered by the government, arrived at Bluefields with 200 Nicaraguans.

Announcement of the annual prize essay contest conducted by the New York State Chamber of Commerce in the public schools of this city was made last week by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools. Pupils are urged to compete in the writing of essays on the topic, "What are my responsiabilities as a citizens in the occupation which I may choose?"

About one-half of the 500 inhabitants of this community in 1837 favored retention of the name Saw Pit for their settlement, believing that it was properly descriptive and that the name Port Chester would sound pretentious.

With a plucky comeback after the invaders rushed across two touchdowns in the first four minutes of the game, Fordham Prep's football team gained a 12-12 tie with All Hallows Institute at Fordham Field yesterday. The contest was the initial one of the season for the Bronx rivals.

Gunmen who killed one labor union leader and critically wounded another delivered a setback, yesterday to Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's efforts to dissolve the underworld dominions of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro.

Joseph P. Day, Inc., and William L. Austin Jr. have been appointed joint sales agents for all the holdings of the Atlantic Beach Sales Corporation at Atlantic Beach, L. I., it was announced yesterday.

The fourth annual conference of the National Association of Assessing Officers- will be held in this city from Oct. 20 to 22 inclusive. The organization includes in its membership State tax commissioners and county and city officials whose duties are the assessment of property for taxation. John A.

The London Labor party, through its secretary, informed Shigeru Yoshida, the Japanese Ambassador, today of "our deep feeling of horror at the attack which your Government is making on China." The protest added:
DURING the past few seasons the orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera Association has undergone several revisions, a few drastic. In each case the change for the better was almost immediately noted.
The University of California coupled stout downfield blocking with costly errors on the part of the opposition today to defeat Oregon State, 24 to 6.

A closed-shop agreement embracing 967 employes of the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn was signed at 3 o'clock yesterday morning by representatives of Bing Bing, Inc., operators of the hotel, and the Hotel Service Employes Union, Local 32A, of the Building Service Employes International Union, an A. F. of L. affiliate.

Vanderbilt University, using a straight running attack and scarcely any passes, breezed through the University of Chicago, 18 to 0, today on rain-drenched Dudley Field before 5,000 spectators. Jimmy Huggins gave the Commodores their first score midway in the opening period after Fitzgerald, Maroon end, had punted out of bounds on his own 38-yard line.

Taking a lesson from the book of "boom-year" excesses, cities in all parts of the country are proceeding more cautiously today than in the past in annexing new territory. In the days when every neighboring farm was visioned as a potential suburban business or residential community with hundreds of new taxpayers, municipal authorities overstepped the bounds of reason many times in extending their corporate limits.

A Michigan State football team that was superior in everything but fighting spirit conquered the University of Michigan for the fourth successive year today, 19 to 14, deferring Wolverines' hopes of a revival of past gridiron glories.

Miss Margaret Marie Cotter, daughter of Mrs. Jeremiah Cotter and the late Mr. Cotter, was married this morning to John Charles Gilhooley in the Church of the Holy Souls. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph Quinn of St. Rose's Roman Catholic Church, Carbondale, Pa.

The Federal Trade Commisison today charged the Bausch Lomb Optical Co. of Rochester, N. Y., and the American Optical Co. of Southbridge, Mass., with violation of the Robinson-Patman Act. Six wholesale outlets which Bausch Lomb controls also were cited, as well as the officers of the American Optical Co.

The belief that this year's incoming male freshmen are more Optimistic and that this year's new class of girls is "better looking" than ordinarily was observed yesterday in a series of interviews with five of New York University's oldest campus figures.

When Postmaster General James A. Farley .dedicates the new Federal Office Building at Church and Vesey Streets tomorrow morning he will still a clamor heard around lower New York for the last forty yeas and various groups concerned with civic improvement may rest happy, their long struggle virtually ended.
Wheat futures held within a range of a cent a bushel today, limited interest being shown in the market here or in Winnipeg. No material pressure was in evidence, however, and while

Welding in building construction, a field which is expected to widen considerably after Jan. 1, when welding will, be permitted as a substitute for riveting under the New York City Building Code, will be featured at the eighteenth annual meeting of the American Welding Society in Atlantic City, Oct. 18-22.

The objective sought by President Roosevelt when he promised this week while on his Western trip that there would be an actual balance of the Federal budget during the fiscal Sear 1939, which begins on July 1 next, is understood here to be not merely bringing expenditures within revenues but a reduction of the J public debt by at least $600,000,000.
The University of Wisconsin reasserted its claim to State football supreme acy today with a 12-to-0 victory over Marquette University, winner of the mythical title the last two years.

The marriage of Miss Dorothea Charlotte Shaller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Charles Shaller of this town, to Edson Beam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Beam of Maplewood, took place this afternoon in the Methodist Episcopal Church of Orange. The Rev.

Miss Alice Elizabeth Werner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Werner of this place, was married here at noon today in the Presbyterian Church to Clarence Milton Chase Jr. of Bound Brook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence M. Chase of Hyannis, Mass., by the Rev. Fred M. Holloway.

Wreckage believed to be from the Purse liner Limit of Tacoma, missing in Alaskan waters several days with a crew of eight aboard, was found yesterday by Coast Guard patrol boats, the Coast Guard said today. Three sections of a hatch cover and one davit block were found.

Berlin last week held high holiday and staged mighty pageantry. Before millions of eyes and to roaring "heils," two men in uniform rode side by side in a luxurious automobile, behind one the crested flag of Italy, behind the other the swastika banner of Germany.

Miss Jean Newhall Willetts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Willetts of this community, was married this afternoon to Lieutenant Walter D. Coleman, U. S. N., in Trinity Episcopal Church. The Rev. Harry Lee Rice performed the ceremony in the presence of many friends and relatives.
Although seriously ill, Mohammed Tewfik Nessim Pasha, thrice Egypt's Premier, again today directed plans for his marriage to the 17-year-old daughter of an Austrian innkeeper and made a new will.

Coach Bob Zuppke's silver anniversary season at Illinois acquired a spot of tarnish today when a heavy, scrapping DePaul team from Chicago emerged with a scoreless tie. The Illini saved their biggest threat for the last three minutes. Captain Lowell Spurgeon was the spark plug of this rush, which started on Illinois's 29-yard line and ended when Harry Postaer intercepted a pass on the DePaul goal line and fought his way out 8 yards.

The present housing program of the United States, declares the National Association of Housing officials, brings the slum clearance problem into sharp focus by the provision that local governments must eliminate sub-standard housing if they are to participate in Federal grants.

The story of a fight by a wounded 16-year-old schoolgirl, Sylvia Paulding, the "Miss Brockton" of 1936, to beat off an assailant with a slipper after he had shot her young companion was contained tonight, the police said, in the confession of Leo F. Mockus, 27 years old, a carpenter and the father of three children.

Leaders of the Protestant Episcopal Church from far sections of the globe headed toward Cincinnati today, the vanguard of an estimated 25,000 expected to attend the church's fifty-second triennial General Convention beginning Wednesday.

In a thrilling battle, in which the Mountaineers held the vaunted Pitt Panthers to one touchdown for more than three-quarters of the game, Pitt finally rushed waves of replacements to roll up two more scores in the fourth period today, to win, 20 to 0, over West Virginia.

The threat of some form of State control over the anthracite industry, with its estimated $500,000,000 of investments, faced the hard-coal operators anew as Governor Earle moved this week to hasten a solution for the knottiest problem confronting his Administration.

Smashing on to a new world record of 1:15 1-5 for six and one-half furlongs, Hal Price Headley's Menow yesterday stamped himself a colt of the highest class when he made a runaway of the world's richest juvenile race, the $76,000 Futurity, run for the forty-seventh time before 30,000 persons at Belmont Park.

NOW that bicycling has become an accepted pastime, the men who direct public safety and recreation are puzzling over ways to accommodate the crowds on wheels. The first step toward uniform regulation in New York was taken last Friday,

Samuel Bell Jr., president of the Bellson Company and the Quaker City Flour Mills and a member of a .family which has been identified with the flour industry for more than a century, died at his home here today in his eighty-fifth year.

Mrs. Isabelle T. Landroth Peirce, widow of Benjamin Osgood Peirce, former Hollis Professor of Mathematics and Natural Philosophy at Harvard University, died today at her home. Mrs. Peirce was a native of Cupar-Fife, Scotland, descendant of a long line of prominent Scotch clergymen.

THE President visited the Pacific Northwest last week, saw mountains almost three miles high and canyons more than a mile deep, looked out over the greatest timber preserves in the world, penetrated into the heart of the wilderness and inspected the largest structure ever undertaken by man-the Grand Coulee Dam.

HIS Majesty Victor Emmanuel, King of Italy, a taxpayer of the French Republic. He pays taxes on the historic estate at Hautecombe, the Lake of Bourget, which is partly a royal residence (seldom used) and partly a Cistercian monastery, still inhabited by a group of monks following the rule of St. Bernard of Clairvaux.

IMMEDIATELY after delivery of the new television "wagon" to Radio City on or about Oct. 18, the engineers of the National Broadcasting Company plan to begin their intensive schedule of outdoor tests in the New York area.

The collier Ida Hay Atwater, tied up since last Monday by labor troubles with a C. I. O. organization crew of thirty-one, sailed for Norfolk, Va., today manned by a force of American Federation of Labor seamen.
ROME.--Slowly the Italian press has been revealing the extent of Italy's participation in the Spanish civil war, which has so far cost the Italian taxpayer billions of lire.

The marriage of Miss Olive Mildred Cummings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Westover Cummings of this city, to James Kenneth Campbell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Campbell of East Orange, took place this afternoon in Incarnation Episcopal Church here. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Carolus Webb.

Unless the schools assume responsibility for mobilizing existing unrest and insecurity of youth along constructive channels, the way will be left open for a potential Hitler or Mussolini to set up a political dictatorship here, speakers at the Progressive Education Association's conference warned yesterday.

Despite the sharp slump in sales during the Summer paper production will probably come close to the 1937 record-breaking total, manufacturers said here yesterday. The let-down in the last few months developed after frantic efforts by buyers had cleaned up all available spot stocks and created shortages on rumerous items.

Miss Elizabeth Davie, daughter of Mrs. James W. Davie of Wynnewood and of the late Mr. Davie, was married this evening to Clement S. Walter Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clement S. Walter of Bethlehem.

Texas A. and M. awakened in the final eight to unleash the full fury of its passing and running game against Manhattan at the Polo Grounds yesterday and to the deep disappointment of a gathering of 18,000, that already was mentally tearing down the goal posts, defeated the Jaspers, 14 to 7.

Lawrence University's community service plan, stimulated under the leadership of President Laurens H. Seelye, will assume practical shape this week with the scheduling of student addresses in various north country villages.

The St. Andrew Hotel, which has stood for nearly forty-five years on the northwest corner of Broadway and Seventy-second Street, will be torn down before the close of the present year and on its site will be erected a two-story commercial building.

The Washington Huskies inaugurated a drive for their second successive Pacific Coast Conference football championship today with a hardwon 7-to-O victory over the University of Southern California Trojans.

Because news is usually bad news, the record of trouble and the tireless trouble-makers of the world, the Scandinavian countries are seldom in the headlines. These detached States of Europe's northernmost peninsulas do not covet their neighbors' lands or their neighbors' goods or their neighbors' power.

Harvard romped and passed its way to a 54-to-0 victory over Springfield today in its opening game of the season. Two touchdowns were made in each period, while the Gymnasts had little to offer in the way of attack.

Chanin urges home-building organizations, lending institutions and public housing authorities to concentrate on devising such a method.

Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff gave a farewell card party and tea yesterday at the Corners, her home here, for Mrs. A. Ely Terry, who left today for New York after passing the season at Bon Acre, her Summer place.

EYES trained skyward, a tense and eager cluster of men at the Buffalo Airport gaze in tently at the graceful loops of a new plane high in the air. Horror sets lines in their faces as the gleaming new craft in test flight loses a wing and the crazily gyrating plane speeds earthward.

Georgetown's football eleven scored a 38-0 victory over the Shenandoah College eleven today in the season's opening game. The Hoyas held a 6-0 lead at the end of the half but, returned after the intermission to smash over three touchdowns in the third quarter and another pair in the fourth period.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis R. Whittemore of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adelaide Duff Whittemore, to Charles Sanford King 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. King, also of Scarsdale.

Although wide gains in retail sales continued to be reported in many districts last week, there was evidence of appreciable slackening of industrial activity, and in some districts there were declines in department store volume.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the ladies auxiliary of the Lutheran Hospital of Brooklyn will be celebrated tomorrow at a luncheon to be held at the Hotel Edison. Guests of honor will inelude eleven of the twenty-seven members who were present at the first meeting.

Mr. and Mrs. William T. Edwards of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Elizabeth Edwards, to Arthur Chamberlain Jr. of London, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Chamberlain of Rackenford Manor, England.

Captain William Sallsten is building in this little village near Saugerties a sort of catamaran in which, about the middle of the month, he expects to set sail for a two-and-a-half-year trip by himself around the world.
Sheriff Thomas J. Gibbons of Ramsey County refused today to attempt. to serve a subpoena on President Roosevelt when the President is in St. Paul Monday night.

Committees of women prominent in society are assisting with various activities attendant to the "Little Old New York Celebration" of SaksThiry-fourth Street, marking the thirty-fifth anniversary of the store, which began yesterday and will be continued through this week.

Mrs. H. Murray La Mont of 104 East Eighty-first Street has announced the marriage of her daughter, Mrs. Florence Appleton Milholland, to John M. Dodd, son of Mrs. E. Rodney Burnett of 540 Park Avenue and East Hampton, L. I., which took place on Tuesday.

ALDRICH--Dr. and Mrs. Harold B., Jr., announce birth of a son, Sept. 25, 1937, at Polyclinic Hospital. BANENDALE--A daughter to Mr. and Mrs. Francis W. Baxendale, on Sept. 27, 1937, at Park East Hospital.

When 136 players with low handicaps of 6 or less tee off in the ferty-first women's national amateur championship at the Memphis Country Club tomorrow the cream of the women's golfing talent in the United States will be seen in action. Every player of note in the country is entered for this tournament.
