LAST of the Southern States to get its highway work under way, Mississippi will shortly have one of the fastest and most modern State systems in the world. An extended trip through Dixie, just completed, has revealed amazing changes in highway service everywhere.
Fascism is considered twice as great an evil as communism by the William Smith students, ??ile the Hobart men, by a margin of one vote, find communism to be the worse evil,

Mayor La Guardia submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday, with a plea for "delicate" handling, an executive tax levy budget of $589,222,376 for 1938. It represented, on its face, an increase of $26,223,459 over the tax levy budget for 1937,

Bucks County, Pa., is proving popular to New Yorkers seeking farms, according to J. Carroll Molloy, Doylestown broker. More than forty farms in the county have been sold to residents of the New York metropolitan area since the first of the year. he reports.
The price of meat seldom has been subject to such widespread interest as now. It is being talked about as much as the war in China and other front-page news.
Losses under the Federal Housing Administration plan of insuring mortgages are negligible, Stewart McDonald, FHA Administrator, declares in a report on the activities of that agency.

POSTPONEMENT: Army manoeuvres were scheduled one day last week at Indiantown Gap, Pa. It rained. The manoeuvres were postponed. Major Gen. A. J. Bowley, commander of the Third Corps, explained: "Soldiers aren't sissies, but there's no sense risking pneumonia if they don't have to."

SO important is the American automobile tourist to the nation and to the States which he favors that the Bureau of Public Roads of the United States Department of Agriculture has made a study of his vacation wanderings to learn where he goes, how long he stays and how he distributes his share of the five-billiondollar annual trade.

A 24-1 shot, Mansco, 4-year-old Polymelian gelding picked by Miss D. I. Letendre in a claiming race two months ago, today rushed home to a nose victory in the six-furlong Colonel A. J. Pierce Handicap before 20,000 at Rockingham Park.

Two free-passing football teams, Texas Christian and Arkansas, pitched through four periods to a 7-7 draw before a sell-out throng today. Sixty-one passes sailed through the air. One was good for 75 yards and the Arkansas touchdown. The aerial magic also played a big part in the Texas Christian score, but it was Davey O'Brien, 147-pound sniper, who finally plunged over.
Miss Mary Lee Barrows, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lee Barrows of Haverford, was married this afternoon to John Morton Fultz Jr., son of Mrs. John Morton Fultz of Ardmore.

The swimming team of James Monroe, champion last year of the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high division of the Public Schools Athletic League, successfully weathered its first test of the season yesterday, defeating Haaren, 48 to 23, in the 25-yard pool of De Witt Clinton.
The number of Federal savings and loan associations in active operation in the United States passed the 1,300 mark this week, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today.

Camden, attractive Maine Summer resort, is to be the meeting place next Thursday, Friday and Saturday of both the Fall Conference of the National Council of Garden Clubs and of the North Atlantic Region of Garden Clubs.

The current Chinese quotation on a live Japanese General is $14.50, Japanese military authorities report. They said their information came from a Chinese Government "price-list" found on a prisoner taken in the Shanghai fighting.

Columbia opened its football season at Baker Field yesterday with a victory over Williams, 40 to 6. Before a crowd of about 14,000, mostly Columbia men and their friends, watching under gray skies, this year's Lion squad moved as it might have been expected to do in the initial game of the campaign, stalling now and then but quite frequently showing bursts of flashing power.

The strike goes on in "little steel," and union leaders say it will continue until they obtain their objectives. But the employers say that its effects are negligible, four months after the first cry of "shut 'em up tight."

Wallace Wade turned loose a powerful set of backs in the second half of today's football game and Duke University defeated Davidson, 34 to 6, before a crowd of 8,500. Bob O'Mara, 185-pound fullback, and Eric (the Red) Tipton, filling the shoes of Ace Parker, Duke's 1936 All-American halfback, accounted for two touchdowns each rune in puke's convincing second half his demonstration.

Using the skyway as a highway, the Catholic University Cardinals winged their way to their second straight victory of the 1937 season today, defeating Loyola University of New Orleans before 5,000 at the Catholic University Stadium, 14-0.

Mrs. Arthur Brin of Minneapolis, president of the National Council of Jewish Women, will attend a series of meetings this week at council headquarters, 1,819 Broadway, preliminary to the organization's fifteenth convention to be held in Pittsburgh, Jan. 23 to 28.

Miss Edna Marie Rau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Rau of Irvington, was married this afternoon to Andrew John Bachmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Bachmann, also of Irvington. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Lutheran Church, Newark, by the pastor, the Rev. Oscar Braune.

From Gibraltar to Port Said-along ship lanes extending more than 2,000 miles from east to west-cocky little destroyers stripped for action as in wartime maintain a day-and-night patrol against a "pirate submarine" which has not yet materialized. That submarine torpedoings occurred prior to the institution of the patrol seemed fairly certain,

Under the influence of large-scale Saturday hedging operations, usual at this season, several months made new low records on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list ended with a loss of 8 to 18 points.

Declaring that the reciprocal trade agreement with Czechoslovakia proposed by Secretary Hull was a menace to America's billion-dollar shoe industry in general and the twenty thousand shoe workers of this community in particular, civic groups of Binghamton, Johnson City and Endicott moved today to impress Washington with the need for a higher instead of a lower duty on shoes.

If one wants to start a wall-garden in the Fall the operation should be begun in September or early October, according to the experience of the builder of a beautiful ever-blooming wall-garden in Great Neck, L. I. But even if one waits until Spring, when the main job must be proceeded with in the first part of April, unless early frosts prevent, much preliminary Work can be done now.
Mrs. Frederic F. de Rham and her ball committee held meetings throughout the week at the Tuxedo Club to complete the final plans for the annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball, to be held there on Oct. 23.
Forty-two sales of modernized homes in various sections of Brooklyn and Long Island were sold in September by Realty Associates, Inc., reports Harry D. Burchell, vice president.
The New York State Automobile Association endorsed today a proposal for a flat $3 State registration fee for all privately-owned passenger automobiles.
The Cortes ended its session today with a unanimous vote of confidence in the Negrin Government, although not before the Syndicalist Deputy Angel Pestana had voiced some sharp criticism.

The Give-and-Take Shop, Inc., a recently organized thrift shop, will be opened to the public Wednesday at 1,272 Third Avenue under the joint auspices of the social service committee of the Neurological Institute and the Associate Alumnae of Barnard College.

China, believing the force of world opinion to be behind her, will press immediately for economic sanctions against Japan, a Foreign Office spokesman declared today. "Until now our efforts for the invocation of sanctions have been quietly behind the scenes,"

An increase of 8.6 per cent in auto accidents in New York State during the first seven months of 1987 as compared to the similar period last year and an increase of 18.6 per cent in fatalities for the same period over 1936 were reported yesterday by the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles.

Another Princeton gridiron campaign, the sixty-sixth in the colorful history of Old Nassau, was launched today at Palmer Stadium in an Indian Summer setting and the Tigers, somewhat of a question mark, took their first step in the right direction with a well-merited 26-0 triumph over the University of Virginia.

Victor Ghezzi of Deal, the New Jersey open champion, and Clarence Clark of Forest Hill successfully defended their New Jersey pro-pro best-ball championship today by deeating the Rumson pro-assistant team of Craig Wood and Ben Loving, 4 and 3, in an eighteen-hole final at Preakness Hills Country Club.
RAPIDLY America is building up an army of young Ameraican designers, men and women, who are finding an outlet for their talents in the custom made departments of specialty and department stores.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that negotiations would be started this week with three shipping lines to which it had been certified as a result of National Labor Board elections. The three companies, the International Mercantile Marine Company, operators of several separate lines;

Although outhit ,the White Sox bunched their blows in four innings today to defeat the Browns easily in the opener of a three-game series, 8 to 2. Bill Miller, a right-handed recruit from San Antonio, started on the mound for St. Louis and allowed seven hits in four innings.

CANADA'S federally controlled Broadcasting Corporation has announced new regulations, ineluding a number of restrictions on broadcasters, effective Nov. 1. Among the broadcasts to be barred are court trials, talks on birth control or venereal diseases, dramatized political programs and fortune telling or crystal gazing.

The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, which for more than a year has been investigating the financial structure of several American railroads, principally those within the so-called Van Sweringen system, is expected to enter an entirely new field of inquiry when it reconvenes the latter part of this month.

Miss Millicent B. Parkhurst, daughter of Mrs. Frederick J. Parkhurst of Princes Bay, S. I., and the late Mr. Parkhurst, was married in Manhattan yesterday afternoon at the Church of the Transfiguration to William McRea Ford of Garden City. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray.

The marriage of Miss Mary Therese Conneen, daughter of Andrew M. Conneen of South Orange, to Charles Meirs Denise Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Denise of Bethlehem, Pa., took place this morning in the Church of Our Lady of Sorrows, South Orange.

Delegates and visitors to the conference of the Eastern division of Zonta International at New Brunswick, N. J., yesterday and today were expected to total more than 100. New York, Pennsylvania, Maryland, the District of Columbia and New Jersey are represented at the meetings, most of which are being held on the campus of the New Jersey College for Women.

President Roosevelt has served notice that "he will not stand for another big subsidy for the cotton South to be raised by direct appropriation from the Federal Treasury for financing AAA cotton programs," Edward A. O'Neal,
A desire to see more Americans fighting in the Loyalist ranks was expressed by General Jose Miaja, Madrid defense commander, today in a note to Louis Fischer.

Nearly a year and a half has gone by since Premier Mussolini announced that Ethiopia, whose Negus had fled on a British destroyer, was annexed by Italy and the Italian King took over the title of Emperor. The world, with its attention absorbed by other wars, has more or less assumed that Ethiopia has become a well-ordered section of "Italian East Africa."
IT is chiefly as the projection of an incandescent and meteoric personality that this biography of John Jay Chapman, with its host of illuminating letters, is interesting.
With 5,000 ?? present, the annual Huntington Valley hunts meet on Juste, Faron, the estate of George W. Eikins, was greeted with four fine races and ideal weather today.

Gross earnings of Teck-Hughes Gold Mines for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31 were $4,674,914, or $11.48 a ton treated, an interim report reveals. Income from investments was $104,878, compared with last year's $127,721, when gross earnings were $4,905,387, or $12.10 a ton.

The marriage of Miss Olley Virginia Jones, daughter of Mrs. Theodore I. Jones of White Plains, N. Y., and the late Mr. Jones, to James Robbins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Robbins of Milton, Mass., took place yesterday morning in the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale, N. Y.

The Government completed the first quarter of the fiscal year Thursday with a deficit of $273,823.482 as compared with $524,884,087 for the corresponding period last year, the Treasury's month-end statement showed today.

The 6.7 miles of parkway, under construction in Riverside and Fort Washington Parks in connection with the West Side Improvement, will be opened to the public on Oct. 12, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Parks.

President Roosevelt, sitting at the edge of what he himself described as "the largest thing ever constructed by man at a single spot," today forecast a wholesale transference of thousands of people from the Middle West and the Dust Bowl to this area.

The best news for San Francisco's strike-torn waterfront came late this week when warring dock workers, teamsters and other unions agreed to bury the hatchet and go back to work and clear the docks of accumulated shipments and keep things moving.

A children's operetta company being organized at the Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A. for boys and girls between the ages of 9 and 15, :under the direction of Leah Jaffa. Auditions will be held tomorrow from 3:30 P. M. to 5:30 P. M.

The housing project known as Chatham Village, created by the Buhl Foundation on a forty-fiveacre tract on Mount Washington, about two miles from Pittsburgh, shows a record of 99 per cent productive occupancy since the opening in 1932.

Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Economics Minister and President of the Reichsbank, is expected here the latter part of this month. The official pretext for his visit is that he is returning the call paid upon him in Berlin by the president of the Rumanian National Bank.

Stocks drifted narrowly and closed firm and mixed in the slowest Saturday trading since Sept. 4; turnover, 285,220 shares. United States Government and other bonds steady in quiet trading; transactions, $3,289,000.

Snapping their four-game losing streak, the Yankees yesterday held a noisy World Series rehearsal at the Stadium that was voted a success by a loyal band of 2,449 paying spectators and Manager Joe McCarthy.

The stenographic report of the arraignment of Max Silverman before Supreme Court Justice Pecora yesterday follows: The Clerk--Max Silverman to the bar. (Addressing the defendant.) Have you an attorney?

C. C. N. Y., showed a smooth, low-charging line and a set of hardrunning backs as it opened its 1937 football season, its fourth under the tutelage of Benny Friedman, with a 24-0 victory over Brooklyn College yesterday afternoon at Lewisohn Stadium.

The relation of the new Federal Housing Act to this city will be the main topic of discussion at the meeting of the Women's Committee of the National Public Housing Conference on Wednesday at 10:30 A. M. in the Hotel Madison. Mrs. Mary A. Simkhovitch, Miss Fannie Hurst and Miss Helen Alfred will make addresses.

Formal opening last week of the new $1,500,000 addition to the stainless steel plant of the Rustless Iron and Steel Corporation in Baltimore doubled the plant's former capacity, bringing its present productive facilities to 40,000 tons of stainless steel ingots and 12,000 tons of billets, bars and wire annually.

THE COLONIAL PERIOD OF AMERICAN HISTORY. The Settlements, Vol. III. By Charles M. Andrews. Svo. New Heven, Conn.: Yale University Press. $4. The settlements of Jamaica, New Netherland, the Jerseys, the Carolinas and Pennsylvania.
Donald Budge moved today toward a likely fifth meeting this year with Baron Gottfried von Cramm of Germany by downing Frank Kovacs in a semi-final match of the Pacific Coast tennis championshins.

The marriage of Miss Nell Ford Russell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Russell of this city, to Lyman Lord Tremaine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Tremaine of Westfield, N. J., took place here yesterday afternoon in the chantry of Grace Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie.

The engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Ethel Grimmer, daughter of Otto Grimmer of this city and Ocean Grove, N. J., and the late Mrs. Grimmer, to Robert Freeman Spindell of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Foster Spindell of Chester, Mass., was announced yesterday at a luncheon given by Mr. Grimmer in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. The wedding will take place Dec. 1.

Miss Margaret Tuttle Spencer became the bride this afternoon of Robert Livingston McMillan. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Boynton Merrill in the Second Church- of Newton. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Spencer Jr. of West Newton.

FRANCE'S promised stamp commemorating the United States Constitution is a 1.75-franc light blue with design showing La Belle France and Columbia clasping hands against a background of the Stars and Stripes and the French Tricolor.

Deliberations of the State unit of the Daughters of the American Revolution at Lake Placid on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, in its annual conference, will borrow unwonted significance from the attendance of the President General and a possible successor to her post.

The new wing of the Smith College library was opened to the faculty and students of Smith College for the first time this last week. The books were moved into the addition before July 1, and the building was used by the School for Social Work during the Summer session.
Overcome by the accurate forward passing of Bob O'Malley and the running of Steve Truex, Hamilton lost its opening game today to Trinity College, 25 to 0.

The National Democratic Club will hold a reunion party Tuesday night at its clubhouse, 233 Madison Avenue, in honor of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratio candidate for Mayor, Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins, president of the club, announced yesterday.

Mrs. Frances Sutherland has been appointed budget adviser for members of the West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association. Dr. Herman L. Reis, president, in announcing the appointment, said it had long been acknowledged by building organizations that the first barrier against home ownership was the "down payment."

Retail distribution is moving into a "revolutionary era which is likely eventually to work a tremendous change in present-day merchandising and advertising methods and contribute to the development of a nation of alert, better-informed and more intelligent shoppers," according to a symposium of leading authorities in the consumer, retail and industrial fields, commenting upon the present trend toward supplying the customer with adequate merchandise information.

An application by the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the "American shares" of the General Italian Edison Electric Corporation, representing ordinary shares of common stock and the underlying shares of capital stock of 200-lire par value, was granted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

H. Danforth Starr, New York stock broker has purchased the farm of Adolph Anderson in the Ten Mile Hill district of Sherman, Conn. The property consists of 120 acres of land on which are an old tenroom Colonial home with improvements, a large dairy barn and several outbuildings.

More than $130,000,000 worth of home financing business has been insured under the FHA's mutual mortgage system by savings, building and loan associations since the administration's inception, Federal Administrator Stewart MoDonald announced yesterday.

Robert H. Bloodgood, 64-year-old salesman and native of New Brunswick, N. J., died today of a heart attack at his home here. Mr. Bloodgood came to Washington in 1930 as district supervisor of the decennial census.
ONE of Italy's new instrumental ensembles, which fills a distinct gap in the music life of the peninsula, is the "Gruppo Strumentale Italiano," heard in various works at the Venice festival.

THREE years ago William Ralph Inge ceased to be dean of St. Paul's. Escaping from the gloom of a dome that threatened to descend on his head, he gayly unbuttoned his clerical gaiters, retired to a manor house in the country and left an embarrassed civilization to its destined fate.
After the benefit performance of "French Without Tears" at Henry Miller's Theatre on Thursday night a special supper party will be given at the Restaurant Larue, 45 East Fifty-eighth Street.

ONE of the mysteries which many observers find in President Roosevelt is the confidence which he shows, in the face of an apparently crushing defeat which wrecked his Supreme Court plan and threatened to hamstring his whole program.
A new home development in St. Albans, at the eastern extremity of Queens Borough, has just been started by a syndicate known as Jefferson Homes, headed by Victor Ruggerio.

The Repertory Players, who have a reputation for encouraging new plays and actors into the public notice, will resume activities on Sunday at the Strand Theatre with "Trouble for Two," a comedy by Hugh Burden. The cast includes Anthony Quayle,.

A new group of twenty-five houses has been completed by Nathan Halperin, builder, in his development on East Forty-eighth and Forty-ninth Streets and Lenox Road, Brooklyn. Ultimately there will be fifty-one houses in the development. Six of the homes have been sold from plans.

SWEDEN was never quite the same after the Vikings. That rugged era gone, European culture. seeped in more and more. It did not mean that thenceforth the loom-of Swedish-life was to find itself bereft of a native warp and woof. It meant only that the culture of a great Northern race was to grow increasingly cosmopolitan.

A survey of the nation's commerce and finance will be presented by women bank executives when the Association of Bank Women opens its fifteenth annual convention at the Hotel Somerset in Boston on Friday.

CHEROKEE, N. C.--Once again the corn is garnered, the snakes have gone to bed for the Winter, and the Cherokees are ready for their twentyfourth annual harvest festival, to be held here on Tuesday through Friday. They have brought in their corn from Soco, their pumpkins from Painttown, and their potatoes,
A 30yard drive for a touchdown in the third period enabled Tilton School to defeat Exeter for the first time in its history today.
Indications that classical subjects have not been entirely forgotten by new college students are found in the elections made by the incoming class of 245 which registered at Bates College.

David Kliegman, partner in the firm of Kliegman Brothers, manufacturers of laundry supplies, soaps and chemicals, and who was active for many years in philanthropic and social work in Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home, 1,820 Avenue N, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 54 years old.

ANDRUSS-Jennie, on Oct. 1, beloved mother of Abraham A. and Frank E. Andruss. Funeral private. BURNS--Thomas E., on Oct. 1, brother of the late Ella B. Rlelly. Funeral from Moadinger Funeral Parlor, 1,120 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, N. Y., Monday, 9:30 A. M.: thence to St. Jerome's Roman Catholic Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

The present cessation in building operations will be only temporary, declares Edward F. Hosinger, president of the Long Island Real Estate Board.' Increased labor and material costs, he explains, have made building so 'expensive that, based on the income or earning possibilities of a building, operating builders do not feel justified in adding more new construction.

BLUEGRASS Virginia this month offers a double bill of equestrian activity which continues into November. A season-long series of open-air horse shows culminates at Warrenton, Va., Friday and Saturday in the thirty-eighth annual edition of the Hunter Show of America.

Stocks drifted aimlessly during the brief trading period yesterday and closed generally firm. Transactions on the Stock Exchange aggregated 285,000 shares, the smallest total since Sept. 4. The bond market was steady, with the turnover there also the smallest in four weeks.
Now that suits are as important a part of one's wardrobe as dresses and coats, blouses to wear with suits become of interest.

The Junior Service League of Scarsdale will sponsor circus performances for a week starting Oct. 11, at the County Center, White Plains, to aid the social service unit of the new White Plains Hospital. Mrs. Henry Eckhardt is chairman of the benefit.

MORNING EVENTS Class 12, Children's Ponies and Hacks Under Saddle, Not Exceeding 14.2, Ridden by Children Under 16 Years-First, Miss Cynthia Cary's ch. m. Shirley; second, Miss Alice -Woodward. Babcock's bilk. m. Shamrock; third, Miss Nuala O'Donnell's roan Cream Puff; fourth. Miss Jane Renwick St. John's blk. m. Baby Luck.

The capital, appraising Justice Black's "fireside chat" to the nation, mingled its approval or disapproval today with disappointment that he failed to clear up the principal point in the mystery, as it appears here.

Featuring three brilliant long-disLance runs, two by Thomas (Red) Harp and the other by Sophomore George Cafego, Tennessee's powerful football machine trampled Virginia Polytechnic Institute, 27 to 0, today before 10,000 spectators.
Like little bears, the Dionne quintuplets need more sleep in Winter. So, starting Oct. 10, they go on a new schedule under which they can be seen by visitors only a half-hour each morning.

THE Swedish Tercentenary Art Exhibition now in the Mezzanine 'Galleries of International Building, Rockefeller Center, is the prelude of ceremonies which will mark the issuance of Swedish postage stamps recalling the founding of America's New Sweden three centuries ago. The event probably will also be commemorated by a United States stamp.
Miss Katharine Munson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Sharp Munson of Merion, was married this afternoon to John F. Ducey Jr. of New York, son of Mrs. John F. Ducey of Boston.

Too few amateur gardeners seem aware that there is more than one kind of snowdrop. Too many have never heard of the snowflakes or leucojums. These plants, because of their many virtues, deserve wide attention.
Miss Priscilla Goodman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edmund Goodman of Bryn Mawr, was married this afternoon to Nathan Myers Fitler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Myers Fitler also of Bryn Mawr.

The marriage of Miss Evelyn Marie Stumpf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Stumpf of this place to Peter A. Finch, also of Scarsdale, son of Mr. and Mrs. August Finch of Cuxhaven, Germany, took place this afternoon in the Church of St. James the Less. The Rev. James Harry Price, the rector, performed the ceremony.

Lillian Gish, American. actress, requested through the United States Department of State today that the body of John Raymond Henderson, buried in the Protestant Cemetery, be disinterred and sent to the United States.
India marked the sixty-eighth birthday of Mohandas K. Gandhi today with nation-wide mass meetings and the launching of a prohibition campaign in Madras.

One of the chief obstacles to be surmounted in the sale of homes is the lack of knowledge by the general public of present-day financing -methods, states George Reich, sales director of the Kew GardensForest Hills development at the junction of Grand Central Parkway, Queens Boulevard, Interboro Parkway and Union Turnpike, Queens.

THE open season for big game in Canada gets into full swing this month. If one can judge by the influx of motor tourists and anglers in the Summer months, the Dominion should this Autumn play host to an unusual number of Americans who will come to stalk moose, deer, caribou and the other wild animals found in abundance north of the international boundary.

With Governor Cross as a special guest the Cass Gilbert Memorial Building here was dedicated this afternoon. No formal exercises were held. The Governor, in a brief speech, paid tribute to the architect.

An exhaustive examination into the state of this country, with the aid of twoscore authorities- from divergent fields, will constitute the program of the seventh annual Forum on Current Problems, to be conducted tomorrow and Tuesday at the Waldorf-Astoria under auspices of The New York Herald-Tribune.

SUMMER vacationists returning from the Paris Exposition bring a different kind of report on the decorative arts than that which came to us from the great French exposition of a dozen years ago. At that time we on this side of the water knew little of the modern style.

A new entertainment project of interest to members of society and the artistic world will be inaugurated by Miss Jessie Fanshawe on the evening of Nov. 14, when the first reception and dinner dance of the recently organized Sunday Evening Informal Club will take place in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Mrs. Anna Hirsch of 2 East 111th Street, co-leader of the Seventeenth Assembly District, Democratic, died yesterday at her mother's residence, 2,719 Morris Avenue, Bronx, after a brief illness at the age of 46.

The marriage of Miss Alice Louise Morton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot H. Morton of this village, and Leroy S. Wells, son of Mrs. Wilhelmina Wells of Smithtown, took place this evening in the Huntington Baptist Church. The Rev. William P. Haugh, pastor of ficiated.

Leaders of the shipping industry have decided that stern measures are needed to curb indiscriminate strikes and acts of insubordination on American ships and will ask that the government take such steps as are considered necessary to curb them, it was learned yesterday.

In terms of gold the French franc fell yesterday to its lowest level in modern financial history. In July, 1926, when post-war inflation was at its worst, the French franc sold as low as 1.9375 cents. At that time, of course, the dollar had a higher gold content than it now has.
The University of North Carolina rode to a 20-to-0 victory today to spoil football homecoming day for North Carolina State College.

President Manuel--Quezon tonight claimed the "right and duty" to arraign the Philippine judiciary "at the bar of public opinion," and credited President Roosevelt with creating in a similar manner a "wholesome effect" on United States courts.

Thirty-one upperclassmen at Princeton University. have been named managers or co-managers of twentyeight student employment agencies for the academic year 1937-38. It was announced today by Richard W. Warfield, '30, director of the university's bureau of appointments and student employment.
In its first game under Larry Kelley, the Peddie School eleven today conquered Adelphi Academy of Brooklyn by 13 to 0.
E. H. L. wants the entire poem about trees in which the following lines occur: "Man spends his noisy days in search of gain, while trees find God in sunlight, soil and rain."
Scoring a touchdown in the second period, Morristown High School defeated East Orange High today, 7 to 0.

Japanese forces have crossed the border into Shantung Province and are advancing on the important city of Tehchow, on the Tientsin-Pukow Railway, about twenty miles from the Hopeh Province border, according to Japanese advices.

Declaring that he had received free hand from President Roosevelt, that "my judgment and conscience will be my guide," and "I will have no boss except the public," Frank RMcNinch, "borrowed" by Mr. Roosevelt from the Federal Power Commission to take charge of the Federal Communications Commission and iron out difficulties in that agency, today intimated that he would ask Federal regulation of radio broadcasting rates.

To the Music Editor: I am among those who agree with the manager of the St. Louis Symphony that Saturday night is the worst possible time for the broadcast of the so-called Toscanini concerts. Not only does the Cincinnati Symphony hold its concerts then, but surely every other city (Most cities.-Ed.) that has an orchestra also gives its concerts on Saturday nights.
Mrs. Gibson Fahnestock, who will conclude her season on Monday, gave a farewell luncheon today. Mrs. George Henry Warren Jr. was also a luncheon hostess.
Unusually brisk and even heavy betting on the outcome of the World Series between the Giants and Yankees is being forecast for the all-New York classic which opens at the Stadium on Wednesday.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 1: COLONEL Mauborgne, J. O., Signal Corps, Wright Field, Ohio, appointed as Chief Signal Officer, with rank of Major General, and ordered to Washington, D. C.

Miss Edith Gilbert Haines, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Haines of this place, was married to Dudley Chase Bostwick, son of Mrs. Arthur C. Bostwick of New York and the late Mr. Bostwick, this afternoon at the Haines home here. The Rev. Alan R. Chalmers performed the ceremony.

Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons announced a new trade treaty with Canada, operative yesterday, reducing duties on commodities that Canada imports to an annual value of [Pound]700,000 and of which Australia's share is [Pound]117,000.

Phillips Andover Academy defeated New Hampshire freshmen, 32-6, to open the season today. Harrison, Seymour, Kansel, Gould and Tine all made long runs, Gould's 69-yard dash for a touchdown in the last period topping them all.

A dinner was given last night on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis by Gerard H. Pagenstecher for Miss Marie Brooke Heck and James Tileston Baldwin who will be married on Oct. 16 in the Church of St. John of Lattingtown at Locust Valley, L. I.
Jim Turner, the Bees' 31-year-old freshman pitcher, today became the first National League right-hander to win twenty games this season when he set down the Phillies, 7 to 1.

Repeating with increased vigor his Klan membership charges against Walter S. Brower, special assistant to Attorney General Cummings and close friend of Associate Justice Hugo L. Black of the Supreme Court, former General Sessions Judge Alfred J. Talley issued a statement yesterday asserting that Mr. Brower was present when Justice Black was made a life member of the order.
Nelson Curtis, trustee and director of the National Rockland Bank and brother of former Mayor Edwin U. Curtis of Boston, died yesterday at the Faulkner Hospital. He was 73 years old.
The Georgia Tech eleven crushed Mercer University's Bears today by 28 to 0. Tech got all of its points in the first half. The Engineers rolled up

An attempt to capitalize on consummer complaints against the price advances in meats will be made this week by fish interests in a determined drive for new business. The campaign will take the form of intensive selling effort to persuade retailers handling meats and fish to stock larger quantities of sea foods and will include the distribution of posters and other dealer sales helps to the retail stores.

FUNNEL-SHAPED as it is, a telephone mouthpiece looks like an ideal germ-trap. It follows that we run the risk of catching a disease whenever we call up the home to say we are detained by mysterious business at the office.

ALTMANN--Mr. and Mrs. Moses Altmann, 215 West 91st St., announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Murray, at Temple Israel, 210 West 91st St., Saturday. Oct. 9, at 10 A. M.; at home Saturday evening; no cards.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Tanner, who are occupying Oak Lawn, the home of Dr. and Mrs. Peter J. Hoguet in the Piping Rock Club grounds this season, were hosts at a tea dance and buffet supper today after the closing session of the Piping Rock Horse Show program near by.

The capital, appraising Justice Black's "fireside chat" to the nation, mingled its approval or disapproval today with disappointment that he failed to clear up the principal point in the mystery, as it appears here.

Dr. Levering Tyson, inducted today as president of Muhlenberg College, pledged his administration to an educational program which will equip graduates to meet the "onslaught of the propaganda machines" and "adhere to the principle that religious training is a part of the equipment of the welleducated man."

Holders of common shares of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation exercised rights to buy approximately $2,000,000 of the fifteen-year sinking-fund convertible 31/2 per cent debentures, the company announced yesterday. The rights expired on Oct. 1.

A messenger arrived at the White House on the morning of May 18 with a communication for the President. Mr. Roosevelt, according to custom, was reading the morning papers in bed. He put them aside, opened the message and learned that he was to have an opportunity to fill the first Supreme Court vacancy in over five years. Justice Willis Van Devanter had resigned.

The United Automobile Workers of America will not accept responsibility for uninterrupted production in auto factories until the union has won closed-shop contracts throughout the industry, Homer Martin, president of the C. I. O. affiliate, told members of the New York Women's Trade Union League yesterday at their fifteenth annual conference in the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

Fred G. Richardson thinks he has the oddest collection of postmarks in the country. From Alaska to the corners of the nation he has combed postoffices for odd names and displays hundreds of postcards mailed to him from these places.

Mrs. Mabel G. Moore, wife of Dr. Joseph W. Moore, chairman of the Parole Board, died at her home here today after a two-years' illness. She was 60 years old. Mrs. Moore, the former Mabel G. Trafton, was married to Dr. Moore in 1906 and aided him during the seventeen years he was superintendent of Mattewan State Hospital for the Criminally Insane.
Christmas's Rough Time led a speedy field home today in the $7,500 added Capital Handicap, inaugural feature of the Laurel 25day meeting.

A HISTORY of the arts has this advantage over most other kinds of history, that it can concern itself mostly with things that are a credit to the human race and leave out most of those that are not. Mr. Van Loon has already written "The Story of Mankind," but here he has written it again, in a different and just as entertaining way.

The first Sunday tea of the Episcopal Actors' Guild will be held today in the Guild Hall of the Church of the Transfiguration, 1 East Twenty-ninth Street. Miss Josephine Hull of the "You Can't Take It With You" company will be guest of honor.

THE Madrigal Singers, under Lehman Engel, will give twelve concerts on alternate Wednesday, beginning Oct. 13, at the Theatre of Music. Works to be performed include Cavalieri's "Sacred Representation of the Body and Soul," masses by Schubert and Haydn, Lassus and Palestrina, folk songs, madrigals and chansons.
Mr. and Mrs. Abram Warschauer of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rita Warschauer, to Seymour Kempner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Kempner of Westerleigh, S.I.

The whole unsavory mess, every one in Washington hopes, is at an end. Mr. Justice Black has admitted to the United States, and by short wave to the entire world, that he once was a member of the Ku Klux Klan. He has emphatically denied present membership in or sympathy with the Klan. On Monday undoubtedly he will sit on the Supreme Court bench.

The total number of placements and the established earnings of Barnard College students in the last academic year were larger than ever before, according to a report presented to Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve by Miss Katharine S. Doty, assistant to the dean and head of the Occupational Bureau.
Five workmen were killed and at least a score of others injured here today when a bulkhead collapsed under pressure in an interceptor sewer being constructed under West Jefferson Avenue.

Contending Teams-New York Yankees, champions of the American League; New York Giants, champions of the National League. Managers-Joseph V. McCarthy, Yankees, and William H. Terry, Giants. How Series Is Decided-Best four out of seven games.

The "too tolerant" policy of retailers in accepting returns will be brought up at the next conference between representatives of the retailers' and manufacturers' associations on trade practice matters, it was announced yesterday by Morris Kolchin, executive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc. "We shall recommend,"

Modernization of the lobby of the American Woman's Association at 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, a surprise feature to most of the members returning to the club after the Summer vacation season, represents a generous gesture on the part of Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt.

Dr. James R. Angell, retiring president of Yale University, said at the dedication today of the Martin Biological Building at Swarthmore College that students entering colleges now were trained to an equivalent roughly one year beyond the level that they had been in the past.

Colgate University is in the throes of a readjustment made necessary by adoption of a new plan of deferred rushing by the fraternities. All members of the freshman class of 300 are living under conditions different from those in past years.

Mrs. Isabella Gessoni, 44-year-old mother of two children, was shot and killed today in the butcher shop operated by her husband, Jean, at 166 Warwick Street, here. Roche Rossi, 51 Avon Avenue, a relative who had been dismissed from the shop some months ago, was severely injured when two butchers in the place disarmed him after, it is alleged, he had shot Mrs. Gessoni.

ROMANCE and politics can both make strange bedfellows, but here we see Sophie Kerr compelling them to lie down together and like it. If the political mystery is more engrossing than the love story, that is not the fault of Miss Kerr's
Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor; ridiculed and satirized yesterday a newsreel summary of Mayor La Guardia's administration scheduled to be shown in theatres in the city this week.

Lawrenceville defeated the Newman football team, 25-0, in a onesided game today. The Red and Black broke through in the second quarter when Rose went 40 yards off tackle. Jordan scored twice and Rasmussen once in the last period. Only the first extra point was kicked.

James Smith, inspector of boilers for the Port of Nwe York since 1931, who took a part in the investigation of the Morro Castle and Mohawk disasters, died early yesterday at his home, 337 Bement Avenue, Port Richmond; S. I. He was 66 years old.

The teams of Curtis, Newtown and Textile yesterday captured top honors in the opening meet of the P. S. A. L. cross-country season at Van Cortlandt Park. Each led its group, Curtis having 25 points, Newtown 39 and Textile 53. About 300 schoolboys participated.

After spotting its rival two touchdowns in the second period, the New York University football team crashed through with a rousing closing rally that brought a dramatic triumph over the game Carnegie Tech eleven at Pitt Stadium today.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Oct. 1 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:
Winsunvale, the 130-acre farm with a fourteen-room house, formerely owned by ex-Governor Winant of New Hampshire at Pittsfield, N. H., has been sold for occupancy to John Keenan of Jamshedpur, India.

The cost of living, which has been steadily and relentlessly rising for the past five years in this country and generally throughout the world, has reached the point where it is a topic of conversation and a source of worry for politicians. The pocketbook nerve seems to be the most sensitive part of the body politic.

The joint trial of eighteen major oil companies, six subsidiary oil companies, three trade publications and forty-six individuals charged with conspiracy to fix gasoline prices in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act will be opened tomorrow in Federal court in Madison, Wis.

Representatives of the Alteration Plumbers, Steamfitters and Helpers Union signed an agreement yesterday with officials of the Greater City Master Plumbers Association for increased pay for mechanics and helpers in that industry.

As the American Federation of Labor prepares for the opening of its annual convention next Monday the prospects for peace between the federation and the Committee for Industrial Organization appear dim and distant.

Despite a decrease in the number and volume of direct reduction loans during August, the twelve Federal Savings and Loan Associations of. the Philadelphia District showed an increase in assets and number of new savings accounts for investors according to a recent report for the associations of the Philadelphia area.
Muhlenberg put pressure on St. Lawrence in the second half today and emerged with an 18-6 victory. St. Lawrence scored in the second period on passes from Ferris to Versocki and Ohmann.

Belleville held Bloomfield's Bengals, perennial State high school football champions, to a scoreless tie today. Bloomfield time and again threatened but Belleville's line held. In the first period Bloomfield carried the ball from the Belleville 40 to the 8-yard marker and was repulsed. Stan Krivik attempted a field goal from the 18 but missed.
Using a smart running attack, Union College's eleven defeated Hobart College for the first time in four years today, winning, 9 to 0, before a near-capacity crowd.

By his own admission Mr. Justice Black joined the Ku Klux Klan "about fifteen years ago," which would be in 1922. In that year and the following year there were indictments of Klansmen in a large number of Southern States on charges of whippings and kidnapping.

The Board of Realtors of the Oranges and Maplewood has gone on record as favoring an early decision on the location and prompt completion of the proposed extension to New Jersey's State Highway No. 10. The present uncertainty as to the extension's location is retarding county planning and development, the board points out.

In real estate circles throughout the country there is a general opinion, declares Robert H. Armstrong, of Armstrong Armstrong, that the real estate business, in spite of the increase in rents and values, is falling behind the year 1936.

The memory of two former administrative officers of Lehigh University will be honored at the Founder's Day exercises Wednesday. They are the late Dr. Henry S. Drinker, '71, president of the university from 1905 until 1921, and the late Dr. Natt M. Emery, former instructor, registrar, acting president, vice president and controller during his forty years' service for the university.

Patrons and patronesses for the benefit performance of "The StarWagon" on Wednesday night at the Empire Theatre are planning dinner parties to precede the performance, which has been arranged as the annual theatre benefit for the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.

A comprehensive program of courses in preparation for public service and social work will be given by the Hunter College Evening and Extension Division in the Autumn semester, according to an announcement by Professor A. Broderick Cohen, director.

Announcement has just been made that two performances of "Angel Island"-on Oct. 26 and 27-will be given for the benefit of the work conducted by the auxiliary to the Tuberculosis Division of the Bellevue Hospital Social Service and for the Convalescent Relief Committee of the hospital.

GOVERNORS ISLAND So much of paragraph 13, Special Orders 138, dated June 15, 1937, relating to 2d Lt. Emanuel Targum, Inf.-Res., as reads: "If not sooner relieved for the convenience of the Government, or otherwise, each officer will be returned to his home so as to enable him to arrive threat not later than midnight Dec. 17, 1937, at which time he will revert to inactive status," is amended so as to read:

A LONG the River Vltava, which flows through Prague, there is a settlement called Stechovice, to which hundreds of young men and women retreat every week-end in Summer and early Autumn. Abandoning city life, they head for this refuge as soon as work has ended.

This week one of Palestine's ablest British officials, Lewis Yelland Andrews, District Commissioner of Galilee, became the latest victim of the series of killings which have occurred in the last year. Mr. Andrews was outstanding among British officials in Palestine for his thorough knowledge of the country and its peoples and his excellent organizing ability.

Cario Marchetti, founder of the city of Venice, Calif., and long prominent in civic and political affairs of his adopted city and State, died today in Cedars of Lebanon Hospital with his family at the bedside. He was 76 years old.

NEXT Thursday night the members of fifteen different societies as well as hundreds of private in dividuals will gather in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to celebrate the fiftieth wedding anniversary of a man who for well over a generation has played host to more people than any one else in America.

Lafayette's football team scored its first opening game victory in three years today by defeating Upsala College, 33 to 0, before 4,000. It was the first Lafayette team coached by Hooks Mylin former Bucknell mentor.

Active savings, building and loan associations in the United States made new home mortgage loans in August amounting to $68,539,000, an increase of 22 per cent compared with .the $56,134,000 in August, 1936, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.
IN the Forties of the last century the worst peacetime famine in recorded European history struck the Irish peasantry to its knees. In the two successive years, 1846 and 1847,

Nathan D. Shapiro, Brooklyn attorney and counsel to the City Taxpayers League, makes the suggestion that in the studies now being made by the legislative committee on mortgage moratorium and deficiency judgments and by various realty bodies in this State some help in solving the problem might be obtained by studying the New Jersey statute regarding deficiency judgments.

Miss Adele Teitelbaum, daughter of Louis Teitelbaum and the late Mrs. Teitelbaum, was married to David Bernstein, son of Mrs. Herman Bernstein of New York and Sheffield, Mass., and the late Mr. Bernstein, yesterday at the home of her uncle and aunt, Mr. And Mrs. Hyman Dickman of 4,802 Twelfth Avenue, Brooklyn, with whom she has made her home for several years. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Joseph Peimer.

Long after the indignation aroused by an eyewitness story from tortured Spain and the conflicting opinions on the C. I. O. voiced at last week's Washington convention have become hollow murmurs, the National Council of Catholic Women will be devoting its unified energies this Winter to defeat of the proposed Equal Rights Amendment.

Rheumatic fever remains the "great enigma of medicine," Dr. Howard W. Haggard, Professor of Applied Physiology at Yale University, declares in a foreword to a pictorial pamphlet, made public yesterday, which describes the work of Irvington House at Irvington-on-Hudson, N. Y.
The Pirates clinched third place in the National League today by beating the Reds, 4 to 3, in an eleven-inning battle. The victory was the Pirates' fifteenth in a row over the Cincinnati club.

WASHINGTON--Though the average American city has a population of 21,800, approximately one American out of eight, or 12.3 per cent, lives in a city of more than 1,000,000, the National Resources Committee revealed in a recent report.

H. D. McIntosh, proprietor of a large British soda fountain chain, was about to order 100,000,000 Japanese straws last week. But when he read of the aerial attack on Canton, where thousands of non-combatant Chinese were killed or wounded by Japanese bombs, he tore up the order.

A desperate but nonetheless futile attempt to break the monopoly having failed on all fronts, New York will move into another state of civil war this week as it rides to another exclusive world series on a 5-cent fare.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Silsby Maryott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Maryott of Pawtucket, R. I., to Dr. Henry Alfred Barrett of New York, formerly of Vancover, B. C., took place here yesterday morning in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick.

The Lehigh Valley Railway Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to abandon its Cortland Branch, comprising 20.26 miles of single track main line and 1.65 miles of sidings in the counties of Madison and

More than 20,000,000 visitors have passed through turnstiles of the Paris Exhibition of 1937, and although that number is behind the grand total of 33,000,000 who visited the Colonial Exhibition some years ago, still there is no doubt that it justifies the claim that the exhibition has been a success.

Speaking before the recent annual meeting of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, Charles G. Edwards, president of the Central Savings Bank of New York City, declared that real estate is one of the most stable forms of wealth.

The auction on Oct. 16 of 450 lots in the Flushing Manor development bounded by 154th Street, Willets Point and Cross Island Boulevards and Bayside Avenue, Flushing, L. I., is arousing considerable interest, according to Edward Breuer, auctioneer.

With its membership changed for the first time since Franklin D. Roosevelt became President, the Supreme Court will meet on Monday for a term at which important objectives of the New Deal will be passed upon.

The franc closed here today 151 5/8 to the pound, a depreciation of virtually 7 francs in the day's trading. After opening at 147 francs, the rate went down to 152 1/2 on fear of a collapse following the meeting of the French Cabinet.
To the Board of Estimate and Apportionment: Gentlemen: I submit for your consideration the executive budget for the year 1938 in the amount of $589,222,376.15. This compares with $562,

OCTOBER exhilarates broadcasting. With the opening of the tenth month all traces of Summer's "programs of a lighter vein" are brushed away as songsters, comedians, musicians and actors, refreshed by three or four months away from the microphone, return to offer brighter to songs, new twists to jokes,

Warren Hadley of Cedar Ridge and John Dolan of the home club led a field of fifty-one teams at the half-way mark in the first annual invitation best-ball tournament at Crestmont Golf Club today with a sub-par round of 35-35-70.

Senator Borah is quoted as saying, of the facts in the case of Mr. Black: Justice Black stated the matter of his relationship with the Klan as I understood it to be when I spoke on the subject in the Senate. I understood he had been a member of the Klan, but had not been a member since about eleven years.
ANNOUNCING its product for 1938, the Packard Motor Car Company disclosed last week that it had completely redesigned the two principal sellers of the line, the Six and the One Twenty.

A group of Harvard students has adopted President Conant's suggestion that "study would make an interesting and valuable extra-curricular activity," and the result is a non-credit evening course called "outlines of Christianity."
Three men were injured, one seriously, today in an automobile accident on the William Penn Highway near this Central Pennsylvania town. The injured were M. Ostrou,

As Japanese troops pushed southward toward the Yellow River last week and westward along the route of empire-the ancient KalganUlan Bator caravan trail-tension increased between Russia and Japan, now traditional rivals in the Far East.

Chauncy Butler, son of the founder of Butler University, died last night at his home at Interlachen at the age of 89. Born in Indianapolis, he served with the 132d Regiment of Indiana volunteers at the age of 15 in the Civil War.

Miss Elizabeth Mahn Terry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Terry of Sewickley, Pa., was married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church to David P. Blankenhorn, son of Mrs. Maurice Wells of this city and David F. Blankenhorn of Pasadena, Calif.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Augustus T. Rush of Orange of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia M. Rush, to Ensign A. Warren Aylesworth, U.S.N., son of Mrs. Marie Therese Aylesworth of New Orleans.

Builders, realty owners and brokers not only in Queens Borough but throughout the entire metropolitan area expressed enthusiastic approval yesterday of the plan to construct a model community town on a tract of approximately ten acres within the grounds of the 1939 World's Fair on the Flushing Meadows.
CHARLIE M'CARTHY, Edgar Bergen's ventriloquist dummy, is reported to be far ahead in a recent survey among listeners in forty key cities to determine the most popular broadcasts.

A brightness gauge which tells exactly just how bright a surface is or how much light it reflects, is the invention for which a patent has just been awarded here to Dr. Matthew Luckiesh, director of the Lighting Research Laboratory of the General Electric Company.

The stability given to residential mortgages under the insured mortgage system is clearly indicated, points out Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator, by the fact that on June 30 this year insured mortgages totaling $101,826,925 had been purchased by institutions in every part of the country from the originating mortgagees.

Miss Rosalind E. Bigelow, a descendant of John Bigelow, who settled in Boston in 1636, and of Colonel Timothy Bigelow of Worcester, Mass., an aide-de-camp to General Washington, was married here this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church to John Richard Burkett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Richard

Hundreds of children who have taken part in the garden project sponsored by the New York Plant and Flower Guild at the Avenue A Children's Gardens will celebrate Harvest Day on Friday at their gardens.
WITH five concerts scheduled for Town Hall this week, among them a benefit song recital by Roland Hayes, the new music season gets under way.

GIANT ocean liners, the largest detached and movable objects made by men, are magnified versions of small models that are tested for weeks or months in little imitation oceans. The models, made of wood or paraffin precisely to scale, operate under their own power.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declined today to comment on Supreme Court Justice Black's radio address. Mr. Green said that he would have nothing to say and all efforts to elicit some hint of his feeling were unavailable.

A misunderstanding of the Wagner Housing Act has arisen, which if not promptly corrected, threatens to retard the construction of low-cost houses and deprive many families of needed homes, points out Peter J. McKenna, identified for many years with the Long Island home-building industry.

New York State employes in the metropolitan area will be hosts at a dinner next Saturday night at the Hotel Astor in honor of Governor Lehman, State Senator A. Spencer Feld of New York and Assemblyman Laurens M. Hamilton of Rockland County.

Mildred Holmes King today received a divorce from Harry Orland King of Bridgeport, Conn. An agreement provides $100 a month for the support and education of three children until certain debts are paid and thereafter a minimum of $400 and a maximum of $1,000 month.

The text of President Roosevelt's speech today here was as follows: Coming back to Grand Coulee after three years I am made very happy by the wonderful progress I have seen. I cannot help feeling that everybody who has had anything to do with the building of this great dam is going to be made happy all the rest of their lives.

Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, warned the American Labor party yesterday not to be swayed from its fundamental aims by the desire to win more offices in the present campaign.

Five dark-eyed Hindu girls who journeyed together half way around the world before their arrival here on the Bremen last week are already embarked on the search for a higher education in various universities in this country.

Miss Margaret Trefy Stafford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Stafford of this city, was married to Oliver G. Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Lewis of Indianapolis, at the Stafford home here today.
Three men were injured, one seriously, today in an automobile accident on the William Penn Highway near this Central Pennsylvania town. The injured were M. Ostrou,

As Japanese troops pushed southward toward the Yellow River last week and westward along the route of empire-the ancient KalganUlan Bator caravan trail-tension increased between Russia and Japan, now traditional rivals in the Far East.

Chauncy Butler, son of the founder of Butler University, died last night at his home at Interlachen at the age of 89. Born in Indianapolis, he served with the 132d Regiment of Indiana volunteers at the age of 15 in the Civil War.

Mississippi State marched to a 38-0 triumph over Howard's Bulldogs from Birmingham today. The Maroons scored once in the opening period, three times in the second, once in the third and again in the final.

Wearing her grandmother's bridal costume, Miss Nancy Hunter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tracy Gould Hunter of 124 East Eighty-first Street, this city, and Savannah, Ga., was married yesterday afternoon in the chantry of St. Thomas Church

In another severe fall to lower levels than it had touched for eleven years, the French franc broke away yesterday from its official controls. It fell in this market to 3.28 cents and closed at 3.29 cents, off 147-16 points from the previous close, but abroad it was reported to have reached even lower figures, with quotations in The Netherlands equal to 3.23 cents and closing rates in London equal to 3.26 1/2 cents.

Evidence has been obtained indicating that an organized attempt would be made by Tammany Hall to roll up a substantial number of fraudulent votes against Thomas E. Dewey, Republican- American Labor-Fusion candidate for District Attorney of New York County, Aaron Benenson, chairman of the law committee of Mr. Dewey's Citizens Committee, declared last night.

Funds for an increase of slightly less than 10 per cent in the wages of 10,404 employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau were provided by the Board of Estimate in voting the quarterly home relief budget last Thursday, It became known yesterday.

Several large properties have recently been sold in Dutchess County, N. Y., by Homer Guernsey, Poughkeepsie broker. Among them was the Mrs. Nona Gould farm of 121 acres near Millbrook, which was purchased by Mrs. Helena Woodall of New York City. E. C. Dayton acted as co-broker in the deal.

Port Chester High, defending W. I. A. A. titleholder, opened the season by extending its victory string to ten games with a 6-to-0 victory over the Amesbury team of Massachusetts, before 2,000 fans at the John W. Ryan Memorial Stadium today.
Centenary's Gentlemen shoved the Southern Methodist Mustangs about the Cotton Bowl today, winning, 7 to 6, over a team which dozed through several opportunities.
The Indians, led by Hal Trosky, who hit two home runs, pounded three Tiger pitchers today for a 12-to-5 victory in the first game of the season's final series.

At a convoction to be held next Wednesday at 11 A. M. the college of William and Mary will award an honorary degree to Sir Campbell Stuart, K. B. E., chairman of the Imperial Communications Advisory Committee and a director of The Times of London.
The Atlantis, scientific ship of the Oceanographic Institution here, went fishing for rocks from submarine canyons last Summer and is back with evidence of new worldbuilding forces.

Mrs. Georgia Vail Plummer, widow of Dr. Paul Plummer of Southington, Conn., died at her home here this afternoon after a long illness at the age of 69. She was a daughter of the late Charles Vail of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., a descendant of early settlers of Dutchess County, N. Y.

ON an Ohio campus this week college presidents and laymen will celebrate the centennial of an American revolution in education. They will dedicate a memorial gateway and amphitheatre where a hundred years ago in the midst of a swampy, stump-dotted clearing four young women, defying ageold custom, took their places in a college classroom as regular students beside the men.

State Senator Jacob J. Schwartzwald, Democrat, of the Seventh Senatorial District, Brooklyn, made public a copy of a telegram which he had sent to President Roosevelt requesting him to "demand the resignation" of Justice Hugo L. Black. The telegram read as fo lows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I express my whole-hearted approval of your editorial "Bombs Over China," published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 22? You have, in my opinion, correctly evaluated the character of the undeclared war which Japan is carrying on against China.

Efforts by Mayor La Guardia and his supporters to get the Republican nomination for Borough President of the Bronx for Isidore Nagler and the City Fusion party nomination for Borough President of Queens for George U. Harvey made no progress yesterday.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity continues to decline but less sharply. For the week ended Sept. 25 it stands at 104.7. This is the lowest level since the week ended Feb. 18. The figure was 104.9 for the previous week, and 102.7 for the corresponding week a year ago.

Curt Davis's six-hit pitching and a concentrated thirteen-hit attack against Bob Weiland gave the Cubs a 5-to-1 victory over the Cardinals today. The defeat, their sixteenth in twenty-one meetings with the Chicagoans this year, removed the Redbirds' last chance of finishing in third place.
Using three complete teams, Penn State successfully opened its home football season with a 32-to-6 victory over Gettysburg before 11,000 today.

Army opened its football season today with a hard-earned victory over Clemson College. The score was 21 to 6, and 10,000 spectators were assembled in Michie Stadium to witness the contest. Ideal football weather prevailed.

" ANIMAL TREASURE" is a well-rounded and charmlingly told story about the adventures and observations of three young naturalists in British Camaroons. It proves that there is something new under the sun-even in highly exploited and much-explored Africa.

Virtually going over the gunwale from an America's Cup yacht to a much smaller sloop of the styled International Class,Gerard B. Lambert, owner-skipper of the internationally famed Yankee, today sailed on Cornelius Shields's Aileen in the first of two final races of the season for the division.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Sept. 24 a dispatch from Washington stated that "one of the central themes at the conference with the British officials which began on Monday is the devising of some program which would serve to check the flow of gold to the United States.

Plans have been completed by Miss Mary Elizabeth Bates, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Bates of Scarsdale, N. Y., for her marriage to Russell Whiting Nichols, son of Mrs. Walter W. Nichols of Washington, formerly of Melrose, Mass., and the late Mr. Nichols, which will take place next Saturday afternoon in the Unitarian Church in Winchester, Mass.

More important than the fact that the unemployed of the country are about to be counted was the announcement last week that big business had pledged itself to cooperate in an effort to make the census trustworthy.

Paddling to college in a seventeen-foot canoe is a new mode for undergraduate transportation set by Roger Hubert of Yonkers, who enters as a freshman at Middlebury College this year. Wanting to get in trim for the football season,

Columbia College freshmen, like those under the much-discussed new regime at St. John's College, Maryland, are being required this Fall to read some of the "great books" of ancient and modern thought.
New York State officials prepared today to leave for special hearings in Dallas, Texas, as the court fight to determine the legal domicile of the late Colonel Edward H. R. Green

Tallying all its touchdowns in quick time, with Al Wilson's 95-yard runback of the second half's opening kick-off as the big feature, Yale launched its 1937 football campaign in victorious fashion today, blanking the University of Maine, 26 to 0, in the Yale Bowl.

Henry M. Anderson merchant, banker, former postmaster and former tax collector here, died Wednesday, and Miss Albertine Anderson, former school teacher, died yesterday in Kerhonkson. He was 76 years old and she 71.
THE newness and goodness of the new writing and letters in England and America is very much an editor's choice. Mr. Gregory, a well-known poet and critic, is responsible for the American selection.

A course known as "The Problem of War" will be given in the second semester this year at Wesleyan University with the aim of providing a dispassionate, objective study of the factors making for war and peace.

TWISTED fingers and straight, black ones and white, old and young, fingers of men and women-millions of them now from Carolina to Texas and beyond are thrusting into browngreen bolls for the white treasure of the South. Interrupted by heavy rains in early September. cotton-picking goes on at a maximum pace, with the end almost in sight.

Scoring twice in the opening period and once in the third the James Madison High football team easily turned back New Utrecht, 19-0, yesterday at Lincoln Field before a crowd of 5,000. Ally Goldberg, left halfback, was the star for the winners.

Washington and Lee defeated Richmond University, 6 to 0, on Wilson Field today. Chubby Howard, 210pound fullback, went over for the touchdown in the first quarter after a ruling of interference by a Richmond back on a pass to Spessard had placed the ball on the 3-yard line.

" THERE'S more than just luck in the rodeo arena There's more than a Wild West show seen from a big grandstand. There's a good deal that has to do with life and death; plain life and ordinary death," says the author on page 192, and he convinces the reader that it must be so in this realistic and snappy tale.

THE summit of Mount Whitney, Calif., highest peak in continental United States, is now to be fitted out with an overnight rest house, a museum and a system of maps, guide books and a "gun-sighting" telescope for the use of hardy mountain climbers. The development, unique in high mountain areas, was suggested by the writer and recently approved by the Director of the National Park Service.

Operative builders of homes under the FHA insured mortgage systern in and near New York City have completed more than 12,500 single-family houses, nearly 70 per cent of which have been sold, Thomas G. Grace, State director of the administration, announced yesterday.

Cardinal Hayes returned yesterday to his home, 452 Madison Avenue, from the College of Mount St. Vincent-on-Hudson. He went there on Aug. 26 from St. Vincent's Hospital where he had been a patient since Aug. 12.

THE winning design by Elaine Rawlinson of New York in the national competition sponsored by the Treasury Department is something wholly "new" in this country's stamp history, according to government philatelists.

Police of two nations tonight disclosed the arrest of a blond Swiss woman and two men accused of complicity in international espionage and counterespionage. Uncovering of the mysterious spy ring, French and Swiss police said, solved the "one-way ride" of a secret agent for an unnamed European power.

Miss Eunice Howley, daughter of Mrs. William Edward Howley of 136 East Seventy-thiry Street and the lte Dr. Howley, wasmarried yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral to Lieutenant John J. Phelan Jr., U. S. A., son of Major Gen. John J. Phelan, also of this city, and the late Mrs. Phelan. The ceremony was perfomed by the Rev. Henry F. Hammer.

Miss Margaret Mary Maloney, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Henry Maloney, was married to George Raymond McCormick, son of Mrs. Michael McCormick, both of this town, at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church this morning by the Rev. James Donoghue. The bride wore heavy white satin with Alengon lace bodice, a long full train, tulle veil, lace cap and carried white roses and lilies of the valley.

IT was Dr. Johnson who complained 150 years ago that the Whigs had it their own way wit history. Had he lived in the era of Macaulay or, still later, in that of Froude, he would have had even more reason to complain.

Many prominent persons will attend the dinner Thursday night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria in honor of the golden wedding anniversary of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Tschirky. Mr. Tschirky, the hotel's host, is widely known as "Oscar of the Waldorf."

What can be done to keep flowers fresh for a long time? Very little, is the answer. Flowers can be cut in the early morning to insure freshness. In the daytime, especially when the sun is shining, plants lose water at a great rate and will not adjust themselves to room conditions easily.

Scoring the only touchdown of the game in the final quarter on a 27-yard pass after repeated futile attempts, the University of Kentucky Wildcats defeated the Xavier University Musketeers, 6 to 0, today.
Japanese Secret Service men and Tokyo criminologists began an investigation today of the theory that the mysterious creeping-death plague in Fukuoka Prefecture was the work of a human germ-spreader.

Honus Wagner, commissioner of semi-pro baseball, yesterday announced that 1938 national semi-pro baseball championships would be decided in the United States, Canada, Cuba and Mexico, The Associated Press reported.

The Rev. Obadiah Cyrus Auringer, retired Presbyterian minister, author and historian, died at his home here today. His age was 88. Prior to his retirement twenty years ago, he had served pastorates at North Troy, 1892-1904, and Forestport, 1904-16.

Miss Helen Virginia Sheaffer, daughter of Mrs. Henry Richard Harris of Wayne and of the late William Paul Sheaffer, was married this afternoon to Allan Clyde Hale Jr., son of Mrs. Allan Clyde Hale of St. Davids.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Black, daughter of Mrs. Marion C. Black of this place and of Witherbee Black of New York, to John Davidson Ware, son of Mrs. Sidney A. Lawton of Pound Ridge, N. Y., and of the late Leonard Everitt Ware, took place here this afternoon in the Long Ridge Universalist Church.

The New York Hippodrome Opera Company last night rejoiced in an audience of some 5,500, the largest of its current season, who came to hear Puccini's "Madams Butterfly." With one exception, the cast was one of old friends.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Tomorrow Melville Shoe Corporation (pf. and com.). National Tea Company (pf.).

With the sale of electric shavers this year expected to double that of last year, manufacturers of safety razors, shaving soaps and brushes are launching intensive advertising campaigns, featuring special offers, to hold their share of the market.

Heads of committees which will consider food, curriculum, recreation and other phases of college life were named today at New Jersey College for Women by Miss Betty Van Duyne, president of the Cooperative Government Association.
The old five-story tenement at 423 East Seventeenth Street, between Avenue A and First Avenue, has been remodeled, into a modern apartment house containing twenty tworoom suites.

-Miss Erna Bivins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Bivins of Caldwell, was married tonight to Carl Eugene Youngman, son of Mrs. Ernest R. Youngman, also of this place, at the Caldwell Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Edwin I. Stearns.

THE most important dance event of the moment, interestingly enough, is not strictly a dance event at all, but an art exhibition. In memory of the tenth anniversary of Isadora Duncan's death, Abraham Walkowitz is showing a hundred out of the 5,000 drawings he made of the dancer during the twenty years of his close study of her art at the Park Art Galleries, 48 East Fiftieth Street.

The engagement of Miss Katharine H. Bennett, daughter of John C. Bennett of this place and the late Mrs. Bennett, to Henry C. Tappen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry N. Tappen, also of Montclair, has been announced by her father.
Movements of livestock on the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner and chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, will talk on the social aspects of housing in America next Wednesday evening at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

Scoring as many points in the last quarter as it tallied throughout the season last year, the Rutgers football team defeated a gallant Hampden-Sydney eleven, 20 to 0, before 4,000 spectators on Neilson field today.

WELLS'S latest writing hero has discovered that a writer is never "what he is * * * he is what he seems to be. He is an effect--an impression" But effects are momentary and impressions mutable, since they depend on the nature and mood of the beholder.
The old five-story tenement at 423 East Seventeenth Street, between Avenue A and First Avenue, has been remodeled, into a modern apartment house containing twenty tworoom suites.

-Miss Erna Bivins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Bivins of Caldwell, was married tonight to Carl Eugene Youngman, son of Mrs. Ernest R. Youngman, also of this place, at the Caldwell Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Edwin I. Stearns.

In memory of the tenth anniversary of Isadora Duncan's death, Abraham Walkowitz is showing a hundred out of the 5,000 drawings he made of the dancer during the twenty years of his close study of her art at the Park Art Galleries, 48 East Fiftieth Street.

The engagement of Miss Katharine H. Bennett, daughter of John C. Bennett of this place and the late Mrs. Bennett, to Henry C. Tappen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry N. Tappen, also of Montclair, has been announced by her father.
