Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner and chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, will talk on the social aspects of housing in America next Wednesday evening at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

Scoring as many points in the last quarter as it tallied throughout the season last year, the Rutgers football team defeated a gallant Hampden-Sydney eleven, 20 to 0, before 4,000 spectators on Neilson field today.
Arrangements for the fourteenth annual field trial meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association are announced by Henry L. Ferguson, secretary.
Six of the largest national organizations of women will be represented by their presidents at the semi-annual meeting on Thursday of the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War.

Miss Christine Robinson, daughter of Dr. Louis N. Robinson, head of the Prison Industries Reorganization Administration of Washington and formerly of the Russell Sage Foundation, and of Mrs. Robinson of Swarthmore, was married tonight to William Downham Taylor, son of Mrs. John B. Taylor of Swarthmore and West Virginia and of the late Mr. Taylor.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson's series of bitter attacks upon Republican leaders drew from Jay Cooke, chairman of the party's city committee, a description of the Mayor as a "renegade" who has "pressed the kiss of Judas" on the brow of the Republican party.

After Bill Kalfass, rookie southpaw, had turned back the Senators, 10-3, in the first game of a double-header at Shibe Park today, the second game was called because of darkness at the end of the fifth inning with the score tied at 6-all.

Senator Johnson issued a statement today declaring it "a sorry thing" that Hugo L. Black should go upon the Supreme Court of the United States. "Despite his rhetoric and his touching allusions to his Negro, Jewish and Catholic friends, one damning fact stands out in bold relief," Senator Johnson said.

The recently completed apartment house in the group of four now under construction in the block bounded by 186th and 187th Streets, Laurel Hill Terrace and Amsterdam Avenue in the upper Manhattan section is now 75 per cent rented, according to the Shakbro Realty Corporation, builders.

At 4:50 this afternoon Speaker Pedro Alexlo of the Chamber of Deputies gave his sanction to the state of war voted last night by the Chamber by a large majority and by the Senate earlier in the afternoon under an emergency resolution, 22 to 3, thus putting it into effect throughout Brazil.

OUR exploitation of the American Indian is something of a blot upon our national escutcheon, but, as Major Laban J. Miles said, "there are always two sides to a question--the mule's side and the driver's side."

A DOZEN American painters are well represented by water colors in the opening show of the season at the Milch Galleries (till Oct. 16). The surprise of the show lies in the appearance of papers by Francis Speight and Edward Bruce, both having but recently taken up the lighter medium.
Arrangements for the fourteenth annual field trial meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association are announced by Henry L. Ferguson, secretary.
Six of the largest national organizations of women will be represented by their presidents at the semi-annual meeting on Thursday of the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War.

Robinson, head of the Prison Industries Reorganization Administration of Washington and formerly of the Russell Sage Foundation, and of Mrs. Robinson of Swarthmore, was married tonight to William Downham Taylor, son of Mrs. John B. Taylor of Swarthmore and West Virginia and of the late Mr. Taylor.

"Despite his rhetoric and his touching allusions to his Negro, Jewish and Catholic friends, one damning fact stands out in bold relief," Senator Johnson said.

OUR exploitation of the American Indian is something of a blot upon our national escutcheon, but, as Major Laban J. Miles said, "there are always two sides to a question--the mule's side and the driver's side."

The new main offices of the Morris Plan Bank now being constructed in the Lincoln Building, 56 East Forty-second Street, are nearing completion and the bank will move into its new rooms from its present quarters at 33 West Fortysecond Street on Monday, Oct. 11.

President American Rose Society American rose gardens and florist greenhouses owe much to the labors of Jean Henri Nicolas, of Newark, N. Y., whose ashes have just been laid beneath the rose bushes he there experimented with.

THE law to end all aviation laws-or unify them in oneis soon to come into being. A committee was appointed last week by Secretary Roper of the Department of Commerce to write it, and when the next session of Congress moves around there will be proposed aeronautical legislation affecting all airlines, both domestic and foreign, and either strengthening present legislation or superseding it.

FOR little girls (and there are many), whose fondest dream it is to borrow a real live baby to play with and take care of, Mrs. Brink's latest book is the perfect fantasy. When, on the night of Sept. 20, the S. S. Orminta on its way

FOR the inauguration of the new art gallery in the State University of Missoula, Mont., Robert W. Macbeth, president of the Macbeth Galleries, was asked to assemble a representative group of American paintings. In all, thirtyfive pictures were selected, and these went off to Montana last week--blazing a trail into a section of our great Northwest that,

Miss Frances Harriet Bagg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James G. Bagg of this city, was married to Robert Keen Moses, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace C. Moses of Montclair, N. J., this evening in the Chester Hill Methodist Episcopal Church here.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Stanton Doughtie, daughter of Mrs. Richard Thaddeus Doughtie of this place and the late Mr. Doughtie, to Dr. James McRae Bethea of New York took place here tonight in St. John's Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frank E. Walters.

The American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators, ending its annual conference here this afternoon, agreed on an accident-reduction program, but failed to agree upon a program to free highway commerce from tax and regulatory barriers at State boundaries.

The Bethpage Knaves captured the Long Island Polo League championship with an 8-7 verdict over the South Shore quartet today at Hazard Field. A three-goal outburst in the fourth session broke a 5-all tie and gave the game and title to Bethpage. In this session,

Warners will put the Dostoievsky novel, "The Gamblers," into work just as soon as a cast can be settled upon. At present Bette Davis and either Charles Boyer or Brian Aherne appear likeliest to play the leading roles. Max Reinhardt will direct, and the burden of the scripting has been upon Milton Krims.
George William Irmisch, the last village president and first mayor of Lindenhurst, died last night in the South Side Hospital, Bay Shore, following an operation. His age was 75.

Chinese military authorities today asked the United States Destroyer Squadron No. 5 to vacate Chefoo harbor, on the north coast of Shantung Province, within forty-eight hours. The squadron includes the mother-ship Black Hawk and four other units.

The work of Christianizing the outcasts of India was described yesterday morning by the Right Rev. V. S. Azariah, Bishop of Dornakal, in Central India, at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Bishop Azariah made an appeal for assistance in the missionary field.

Families on relief in New Jersey are receiving allotments 40 per cent below minimum subsistence standards and relief administration in the State has deteriorated since the ERA relinquished control to municipalities.

Premier Benito Mussolini's visit to Germany has been entirely without influence on the markets. In the judgment of financial circles, the visit has emphasized and advertised existing Italo-German associations but has added no new element to them.

With only one dissenting vote, more than 3,000 members of the Federation of Kosher Butchers decided yesterday afternoon to continue their stoppage "strike" against what they claim is an excessive wholesale price of meat.
The New York-Brooklyn Federation campaign for $6,250,000 received pledges of support yesterday from delegates of 800 Jewish fraternal and benevolent organizations, representing 200,000 persons,

Establishment of ocean and rail rates, which would preclude New York shippers from obtaining storedoor collection and delivery at the New York rates, a service given by the all-rail lines, is being strongly opposed by the Merchants Association. Tariffs which have this effect were recently published by the Southwestern railroads, but were suspended pending a hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The largest undergraduate enrollment in the history of Princeton University was reported today by Wilbur F. Kerr, Registrar. Undergraduate registrations to date total 2,365. About a dozen more students who have been detained by illness or other causes are expected in the next week.

The railroads of the country and representatives of the five operating brotherhoods agreed tonight on a new wage schedule, retroactive to Oct.1, that will give all engine, train and yard service employes a pay increase of 44 cents a day.
Ed (Beartracks) Greer permitted only one Little Rock Traveler to wander past second base today in a 3-to-0 victory that put the Fort Worth Panthers in the Dixie Series lead, two games to one.

Merwin K. Hart, president of the New York State Economic Council and chairman of the Committee of American Private Enterprise, made public yesterday a letter he has sent followers of both organizations urging them to "rise in revolt" against the "forces of destruction of the Roosevelt Administration."

The Green Bay Packers scored their first victory of the season today at the expense of the fast-stepping Detroit Lions, 26-6. The first Packer tally came two minutes after the start when George Svendsen, Green Bay center, blocked Dutch Clark's punt, Green Bay recovered on the Lions's 29.

Several reassuring factors are noted in the steel industry as producers enter October with a fair volume of incoming business and confidence for improved demand, according to the weekly review by the magazine Steel. Foremost among the brighter developments is the certainty that the automotive industry soon must start buyin in large volume as 1938 model assemblies increase.

In a game marked by terrific tackling, a scarcity of passes and a steady stream of fumbles, Gonzaga University and St. Mary's College fought to a scoreless football tie today. Gonzaga dipped to within three yards of the Gaels' goal line in the third period after St. Mary's had missed an easy field goal in the preceding quarter, but aside from these two scoring bids, the battle was held mainly between the 20yard markers.

Dr. Henry Cortlandt Johnston, physician at Staten Island for thirty-seven years, died last night after a long illness at his home here. He was a son of the late Francis Upton Johnston, M. D., and the late Margaret Antoinette Babcock Johnston of New York.
Having invited Italy in the friendliest fashion to discuss the diplomatic problem of Spain in all its aspects, the British Government sat back today with some confidence to await a reply from-Rome.

Freight carloadings in the last three months of this year should run 6.2 per cent ahead of the levels for the same period last year, according to estimates made by the thirteen shippers' advisory boards. All but two of the boards forecast Increases for their areas.

The view that the United States would be wise to "walk warily and keep our powder dry" in case of another European war was expressed yesterday afternoon over National Broadcasting Company networks by Frederick T. Birchall, chief European correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, speaking from Geneva in an'interview with Linton Wells, author, journalist and world traveler.

With proper recognition and financial support, the position of school physician "might well develop into the dignity of a specialty of medical practice," Dr. J. H. J. Upham, president of the American Medical Association and dean of the faculty of medicine at Ohio State University, declared last night in a paper read before the American Association of School Physicians at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Sailings of the steamships St. John and Boston of the Eastern Steamship Company for St. John, N. B., and New York, respectively, were indefinitely postponed tonight as a result of what the company described as a jurisdictional dispute between rival labor unions.

Gaynell Tinsley, freshman end sensation of the early National Professional Football League season, scooped up a ball fumbled by Harry Mattos of the Rams, and ran, stumbled and battered his way twenty yards for the only touchdown of the game as the Chicago Cardinals topped the Cleveland Rams, 6 to 0, today before a crowd of 10,000.

Production in the lumber industry in the week ended on Sept. 25 stood at 75 per cent of the 1929 weekly average, and at 70 per cent of the average of 1929 shipments, the National Lumber Manufacturers Association reported today.

Going down before the champion Giants, 4-1, in the season's finale at Ebbets Field yesterday, the Dodgers barely staggered over the finish line in sixth place, but still contrived to break a National League record and tie a major league mark.
Edward J. Rapson, Professor of Sanskrit at Cambridge University, 1906-36, collapsed and died tonight while dining at St. John's College. His age was 76.

Katherine De Mille and Anthony Quinn worked in separate motion pictures last night until 6 o'clock, made hurried final preparations and were married a few hours later. Cecil B. De Mille, foster father of the bride, left the studio set at 8 P. M. and hurried over to All Saints Church to give her in marriage.

Patrolman Wilhelm Pearson, 37 years old, a member of the Kearny force for the last fourteen years, was wounded fatally by a bullet fired by his wife early this morning in front of their home at 315 Hickory Street, in the Arlington district of Kearny.

An increase of more than 39 per cent was registered by Canadian imports in August, the total value being $69,965,939, compared with $50,257,754 in August, 1936, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

The Daily Mail said today that Alexander Korda would take a six months' trip abroad and that he expected a deal between himself and Samuel Goldwyn for joint ownership of the the United Artists Corporation would be consummated before his return.

Miss Carol Wilmot Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilmot M. Smith of this place, has announced the plans for her wedding on Oct. 23 to Raymond Stanton Patton Jr., son of Rear Admiral and Mrs. Patton of Washington, D. C.
Seymour Blauner, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, has become a partner in Blauner, Simons Co., following the dissolution of Harris, Blauner Perry.

Niagara University scored its first football victory over Canisius since 1932 before a crowd of 11,000 today, 13 to 0. The Purple swept across the Canisius goal line twice in the second period. Joe Regan threw a 20-yard pass to Sam Ingrasci for the first touchdown and shortly afterward Morgan Davies raced 26 yards off tackle to the 6-yard line and scored on the next play.
Edgar W (Ed) Howe, noted author, editor and philosopher, died in his sleep today at 2:20 A. M. at his home here. Death was due to gradual paralysis and infirmities of age. His age was 84.
The San Diego Padres won the Pacific Coast League play-off final today by defeating Portland, 6 to 4, for the fourth straight time.

Selfishness is a "natural tendency," the Rev. Robert H. Dolliver declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the John Street Methodist Episcopal Church, 44 John Street. Theology, he explained, is the force that can check the tendency.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Garvan of 740 Park Avenue, this city, and Roslyn, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Flora Brady Garvan, to Francis Dana Winslow 2d, son of Mrs. Herbert Reed Lawrence of Tuxedo Park, N. Y., and the late Kenelm Winslow.

Marcel Boussac's Corrida romped home a length and one-half ahead of his field to win the million francs prize money in the Prix del'Arch de Triomphe, outstanding event of the French Fall racing season today. The purse was about $34,000 at current exchange rates.
The commercial treaty signed between Cuba and Chile last March 13 was ratified by the Senate "in totality" at a special session lasting until the early hours of this morning.

With the September delivery of corn out of the way and most of the stock of old corn now concentrated in the hands of one of the leading elevator interests, the market fluctuated in a natural manner during the week, with supply and demand considerations receiving more attention than of late.

Vainly Japan is trying to undo the effects of its military policy on Chinese and world opinion. The latest explanations by the spokesmen of the Foreign Office, the Army and the Navy are just as unconvincing as the many earlier statements of high diplomatic and military officials.
The following WPA Federal Art Project exhibitions will be on view this week: Post Graduate Hospital, Twentieth Street and Second Avenue-36 children's paintings.

At noon tomorrow the nine Justices of the Supreme Court will take their places on the bench for the opening of a new term, which will bring up for their consideration a number of important cases bearing on vital policies of the New Deal.

Wreckage of a trimotored commercial plane, missing with its American pilot since Wednesday, was sighted yesterday in the jungle twenty-five miles southwest of Puerto Cabezas. Aerial searchers said there was no sign of the plane's occupants, Pilot Lynn Shepherd, a Missourian, and his Nicaraguan co-pilot, but there were indications the two had been killed.

Fraidy Cat, 5-year-old gelding owned by H. P. Headley, has been assigned top weight of 126 pounds for the Keene Handicap, $2,500 added feature, the highlight of opening day at Keeneland race course next Thursday. The Lexington track will conduct a nine-day meeting.

Although the Abbey Theatre Players are beginning their engagement here with a half-hearted comedy, it is pleasant to have them in our neighborhood again. Presently they will be reviving Synge and O'Casey, and possibly some of their new plays will be more ebullient than "Katie Roche," in which they appeared at the Ambassador on Saturday evening.

The funeral of the Rev. Dr. Augustus Steimle was held yesterday afternoon in the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninety-third Street, of which he had been the pastor for the last nineteen of the forty-six years he had served in the ministry.

Drizzling rain dampened final preparation today for the fortyfirst annual women's national golf tournament, but the showers failed to lessen the enthusiastic support favoring Miss Marion Miley of Cincinnati to win the 1937 crown.
Frank O. Lowden, former Governor of Illinois and "elder statesman" of the Republican party, conferred at his Sinissippi Farm today with former President Hoover and Alf M. Landon.

Defeat by Nebraska may be the spur needed to arouse sluggish Minnesota. "Sluggish" is the word Bernie Bierman, head coach of the Gophers, used in summing up the defeat of his players, who before the setback by the Cornhuskers seemed certain to win the Big Ten championship hands down and go through the 1937 season undefeated, with another claim to the national title.

Prince St, 137-141, 60x71.3; excr. will of Florence Rudden to Marnick Realty Corp, 129 Greene St; $20,000 over mtg, $22,500. Park Ave. 1,314, 25x73.3; Samuel Poretz and Yetta Beineson to Ida Rifkin, 85 E 99th St (50 cents).
Belgium today issued warning that she would resist any future violation of her territory even though she has withdrawn from the Locarno Treaty providing a four-power guarantee of Belgian neutrality.

Registration for the general election on Nov. 2-will begin today in New York City and continue throughout the week. Special precautions will be taken by the Police Department and by law committees of candidates to prevent illegalities.

Robert W. Barrows,. Williams College freshman and son of Governor Lewis 0. Barrows of Maine, was killed and three' other Williams students were injured, one seriously, when the driver of their car lost control and it crashed into a stone culvert and tree.

Cocker spaniel fanciers from Long Island, Pennsylvania and Connecticut gathered on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Kettles Jr. today and participated in a highly interesting interclub challenge match. The top honors went to the Cocker Spaniel Club of Philadelphia on a total of 20 points. The Connecticut contingent placed second with 17, while Long Island was third with 13.

Taking up the offensive merits of the Yankees and Giants, we move directly into the domain of the American League champions, their modus operandi, so to speak, by which they hammered their circuit into submission two years hand running and which, if not checked, is apt to see them tear off with their second straight world championship.

Mayor La Guardia and Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott will open the two-way radio telephone communication system on the city's nine fireboats at exercises tomorrow aboard the fireboat John J. Harvey at the Battery.
A week ago this column cited Betsy Flanagan Hustler, the Revolutionary barmaid who invented cocktails,

After members of his congregation had responded yesterday morning to a roll-call of nationalities, disclosing the presence of representatives of seventeen nations of Europe and Asia, the Rev. Dr. David M. Cory of the Cuyler Presbyterian Church, 360 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, said:

Two convicts were killed and two were wounded when twenty-seven of the most vicious criminals in the Texas penitentiary system attempted to escape the Eastham Farm today. A guard atop the inmates' quarters picked off three of the group as they dashed from the building and another guard slipped around the building and felled another.

The annual celebration of German Day, which the disciples of Adolf Hitler in this country have struggled to control for the last few years, brought together sixteen GermanAmerican organizations last night in Madison Square Garden-including the Steuben Society, which last year was still resisting the GermanAmerican Bund and the leadership of Fritz Kuhn.
Major General Sir Granville Ryrie died today, aged 72. Parliamentarian and soldier, Sir Granville was Australia's High Commissioner in Great Britain from 1927 to 1932.

Foreign capital in the amount of $3,551,147,000 flowed into the United States between Jan. 2, 1935, and June 30, 1937, according to an analysis of capital movements made public by the Treasury Department today.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 90.7, which compares with .92.2 a week ago, 92.4 two weeks ago, 91.2 three weeks ago and 91 four weeks ago.

A much stronger undertone has developed in the world wheat markets of late, importing countries becoming aggressive buyers of North American grain as the result of inability to obtain liberal supplies of good quality wheat from the Black Sea and the Southern Hemisphere.

Senator H. Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, speaking today at the Constitution Day celebration of the town of Brookline, declared that the appointment of Justice Black was "a stain on the Supreme Court."

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Annette Ross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Stevenson Ross of Lincoln, to Alan Foster Whitman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Whitman of New Brunswick, N. J.

A heavy rain which fell until just before game time forced postponement today of the fifth game of the little world series between Columbus, winner of the American Association pennant, and Newark, International League champion.
Two persons were seriously injured and many slightly hurt in clashes late this evening when Mahmoud Nokrashi Pasha, former Wafdist leader, opened a new political club here.

Lewis Weiss, 20-year-old honor graduate of Brooklyn Technical High School, class of '35, and Miss Frances Hajek, 19, daughter of a Queens bakery owner, were found shot and stabbed to death yesterday afternoon in Hollis Woods, off Central Parkway, in Hollis, Queens.

The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor, concluding one of the bitterest attacks yet made against the Committee for Industrial Organization, announced today that it would ask the annual convention tomorrow to empower it to revoke the charters of the suspended C. I. O. unions.

An attempt by Sir Oswald Mosley at the head of a column of more than 2,000 Fascists to march through Bermondsey on the south side of the Thames late this afternoon provoked some of the worst street fighting seen in London since the general strike of 1926.

Like the champions that they are, the Yankees yesterday rang down the curtain on the 1937 season at the Stadium before some 4,206 of the hardy faithful, eager to be in on this final dress rehearsal for the world series, by conquering the Red Sox, 6 to 1.
High excitement ruled the Bourse this week. Even on Monday, rentes and French securities already had begun to weaken, and the decline was aggravated later on.

Two Federal housing enterprises which have just been opened prove what was already known-that the housing problem can be solved if enough money is spent on it. The Williamsburg Houses in Brooklyn will take care of 1,622 families at monthly rentals which will come to an average of somewhere between five and seven dollars a room. Greenbelt,

A dozen Malay sailors of the Manz Line freighter City of Delhi were in jail tonight after an alleged refusal to obey officers' orders aboard the ship in port here. One of them, Amat Jamal, 27, was charged with "continued disobedience." Ship's officers alleged the men failed to work under a boatswain and demanded Jamal replace him.
A. F. Knotts, who bought 25,000 acres and laid out the city of Gary, Ind., while acting as attorney for the United States Steel Corporation, died today at the age of 81.

The St. Mary's Celtics bowed in their American Soccer League fixture with the Irish-Americans of Newark at Celtic Park, Brooklyn, yesterday. The Jerseymen came through with a notable victory by 4 to 0, after taking a 1-0 lead in the first half. In the preliminary game between the reserves, the St. Mary's combination gained a 4-to-1 verdict.

The Right Rev. Samuel Heaslett, Anglican Bishop of South Tokyo, has cabled to the Archbishop of Canterbury requesting him to reconsider his decision to preside at the public meeting in London on Tuesday to protest against the Japanese bombings of noncombatants in Chinese cities.

Charging that the recent pastoral letter of the Catholic hierarchy in Spain showed its "open hostility" toward the principles of popular government, freedom of worship, and the separation of church and State, 150 Protestant clergymen and educators and laymen made public here yesterday an open letter in reply.

The Cubs got in a final jab at their season's favorite opponents today. Tagging rookie Norbert Kleinke for two runs in the sixth and three in the seventh, they defeated the Cardinals, 6 to 4, despite a ninth-inning rally that included Johnny Mize's twenty-fifth homer with one on. It was Chicago's seventeenth victory in twenty-two meetings with St. Louis.

Back to the western front 1,000 American veterans came today in sightseeing buses. Nearly 1,000 others of the American Legion pilgrimage to France remained in Paris. They found many signs reading, "Welcome Legion," and many crossed French and United States flags on public buildings.

Frank Lay, 42 years old, of 54-02 Sixty-eighth Street, Maspeth, Queens, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of felonious assault and Sullivan law violation in connection with the shooting Saturday morning of Mrs. Stella Starr, 32year-old mother of ten children, of whom only four are living.

Although cotton prices were steadier last week than in any like period in about two months, they finished the week with further declines, touching new low levels since May, 1933. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange for the week showed net losses ranging from 7 points on the current Octoer to 31 points on the distant July contract.

With bombs dropping on helpless Chinese cities, guns booming in Spain, the civilized world in a state of nervous tension because of the danger of war, it is a relief to turn to the pages of a report which has just been issued by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and which takes stock of the nation's health in the last twenty-five years (1911-1935).
Leon (Goose) Goslin, for eighteen years in the major leagues, reached the end of that trail tonight.

The Presbyterian Church here was filled completely this afternoon during the funeral services for Dr. Blase Cole, lay member of the Court of Errors and Appeals, who was killed on Thursday in an automobile accident. The Rev. Dr.

Rumors that Soviet planes had joined the Chinese air force were revived here today by the presence over Nanking of numbers of planes that, experts say, were of a type not seen here before. The planes apparently were making test flights.

Large profits from the shipment of cotton to ?? an and a resultant furore for imported Japanese finery among Nicaraguan working girls today moved the Nicaraguan National Bank to take steps to enforce the cultivation of foodstuffs as well as the profitable cotton staple.

Dr. Wilhelm Filchner, one of Germany's leading scientists, came out of the Himalayan wilds in rags today to learn of riches. All the way from Calcutta, and to a narrow wooden bridge twenty-five miles north of here, had hastened Count von Podewils-Durniz, German Consul General, to tell Dr. Filchner he had won a $40,000 prize.

Boatswain's Mate Lewis Cihlar of the Ditch Plains Coast Guard Station, Montauk, L. I., is looking for big striped bass these days. Actually, that is not a new undertaking, for he has trod the beach near the station for many years, pulling stripers out of the surf until he is one of the best known fishermen added. in the vicinity.

John Cunniff, Branch Brook star, and Dr. John Connelly of the home club scored a 67 today for a thirtysix-hole best-ball total of 139 to capture the Joseph M. Byrne Memorial Trophy in the first annual memberguest invitation tournament of the Crestmont Golf Club.

New York Herald Tribune seventh annual forum on current problems begins this morning at 9:15 at the Waldorf-Astoria and continues tomorrow. Sixth annual meeting of the Controllers Institute of America begins at the Waldorf-Astoria this morning at 9:30 and continues Tuesday and Wednesday.
The New York Americans continued to lead the American Soccer League when they defeated the Philadelphia Germans by 1-0 before a crowd of 3,500 at Starlight Park yesterday.

The New York Civic Orchestra, with Fritz Mahler conducting and with Miss Lois Bannerman, harpist, as guest artist, presented a program of music by Bach-Abert, Ravel, Wagner and Dvorak at the WPA Theatre of Music last night. A large audience received the orchestra, conductor and soloist cordially.

The Evergreen Farms four defeated the Burnt Mills Polo Club, 8 to 4, at Schley Field today. The winners took the lead in the first period and were never threatened despite a late spurt by the home club.

The best assurance against a major recession in business at this time is that the conditions which usually precede a depression have not developed yet, the National City Bank of New York says in its current monthly letter, published today.

The crumbling of Asturian defenses on both flanks of Cangas de Onis left the hard-pressed garrison town the only major barrier today to Spanish Insurgent conquest of the Biscayan coast. Adverse weather was retarding Insurgent operations somewhat.
Sixteen youngsters of the "plain people" in East Lampeter Township tonight seemed assured of a holiday when classes "take up" tomorrow at the new Smoketown consolidated school.

Lee Coyne and Glen Kreider, commercial photographers, in 333-35 4th Ave.; Kraus Sons, Inc, badges and banners, in 11 E 22d St; Amasia Importing Corp, through Stanley Sogg Co, in 10 E 39th St; Daggett Textile Co, in 395 Broadway; Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, Inc, broker.

With most of the food super-markets indicating their preference for national brands, a definite realignment of advertising allowances and to some extent consumer-advertising appeals during the next year or two will be developed by national manufacturers, according to views expressed by executives in the field.

Drenched and chilled, James Mason, a convict, ended his "strike for freedom" tonight after more than twelve hours on a narrow catwalk atop a 150-foot water tower inside the Ohio penitentiary walls. He told officials meekly that the cold forced him to give up his "strike."

Whistling Jake Wade let the Indians have only one hit today while the Tigers gained a 1-to-0 victory over Johnny Allen, who was trying to equal the American League record of sixteen straight victories. Allen allowed five hits.
A three-way battle for 1937 Pacifio Coast Conference football honors appeared in the making today, with the race under way at seven of the eight camps of the circuit.

Jean Prevost, young French journalist, has received the first Jesse Isidor Straus Traveling tureship, founded by Mrs. in memory of her husband, the former Ambassador to France, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Stephen Duggan, director of the Institute of International Education.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schey of this city and East Hampton, L. I., will give a supper dance on Dec. 4 at the Pierre to introduce their daughter, Miss Teresa T. Schey.

" The status of the Jew throughout the world was never more tragic," Rabbi Stephen S. Wise told 600 persons who met at Essex House here today to organize the New Jersey division of the American Jewish Congress. Twenty-five municipalities were represented at the all-day conference.

Protesting against the efforts of "communistically inclined labor leaders to force the labor movement of New York City into Communist - Republican coalition," spokesmen for forty labor unions, representing 100,000 unionists, met yesterday and pledged their support to Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor.
Miss Constance Willard Huntington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Huntington of this city, will be married on Oct. 30 to Charles Farrand Taplin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. C. F. Taplin of Cleveland.
Tension is running high among Palestine Arabs, but no untoward incident was reported anywhere in the country today. However,

Corportion reports indicated today that salaries of top executives increased twice as fast last year as those of other workers. The pay checks of 179 leading industrialists and merchants rose, on the average, 15.66 per cent, according to an analysis of reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

George Savarese, senior fullback, whose dashing play aided New York University in gaining a dramatic triumph over Carnegie Tech at Pittsburgh on Saturday, will be lost to the Violet squad for at least one month, it was revealed last night by Dr. Mal Stevens, coach of the University Heights team.

Agriculture earned 9.4 per cent of the $63,799,000,000 national income of 1936, compared with 23 per cent for manufacturing. The 14.5 per cent of the nation's income that went to government (including work-relief wages) was the second highest percentage received by any division, the Department of Commerce reported today.

All eyes will be on Mr. Justice Black when the Supreme Court meets today. This is inevitable in the circumstances. Because of the ro1e which the Ku Klux Klan has played in the life of the American people, it is not to be expected that Mr. Black's membership will be regarded as an episode easily ignored and soon to be forgotten.
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur MacPherson of New York entertained at luncheon in the Colonial Room of the Homestead today in honor of Mrs. Frank Vance Storrs and Mrs. Dorothy Adair.
Calculation of the principal basic factor going into the complicated formula upon which it must base its minimum prices was completed by the National Bituminous Coal Commission today.
Miss Mabel Choate was a dinner hostess last night for her week-end guests, Mr. and Mrs. S. Prescott Fay and Mr. and Mrs. George B. Dabney of Boston.

Thomas Long, 26 years old, of 540 East Seventeenth Street, was killed' at 4:30 A. M. yesterday when the car in which he was riding was in collision with a newspaper truck at Madison Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street. The driver of the truck and the operator of the car in which Long was a passenger were injured.

Absent five years from Broadway, Arthur Hammerstein announces his return to theatrical production along this thoroughfare in whose annals the name of Hammerstein has long been famous. His offices have been established in the Palace Theatre Building.

Miss Betsy Ann Avery of this city, daughter of Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Christopher L. Avery of Eastern Point, will be married to George D. Freeman 3d, son of Colonel and Mrs. George D. Freeman Jr. of West Hartford,

Another brilliant passing performance by the famed Slingin' Sammy Baugh and some highly effective defensive play by his team-mates were among the predominant features as the Washington Redskins topped the Brooklyn Dodgers, 11 to 7, in their National Football League clash at Griffith Stadium today.

John W. Davis, general chairman of the 1937 United Hospital Campaign, announced yesterday that Clarence Francis, president of the General Foods Corporation, has accepted the chairmanship of the commerce and industry committee.

Miss Catherine Byrnes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Byrnes of this place, has chosen Oct. 16 as the date for her marriage to Robert Francis Flood of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice S. Flood of New Rochelle.

Absolute calm throughout the republic was reported today following the declaration yesterday of a state of war. Communist suspects are in hiding from the police, who have received full power to clean them out.

The famous Eton blue silks with brown top, which have dominated the American turf for more than forty years, will disappear at the end of the 1937 racing season, according to an announcement yesterday from Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney.
France's general wholesale price index on Sept. 25 stood at 617, against 614 on Sept. 18 and 605 on Sept. 11. Native products were 630, against 625; imported products 595, unchanged;

The Rev. Dr. Raymond Lalor Forman preached his final sermon yesterday morning as pastor of St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, and took as his theme the phrase "Finally Brethren," which was used frequently by St. Paul in his advice to his far-flung congregations.

George Meany, president of the State Federation of Labor and chairman of the American Federation of Labor's Non-Partisan Committee for the Re-election of Mayor La Guardia, announced yesterday the completion of the committee, which has 175 members.

The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston, represented by Coleman Perlstein, attorneys, of Jamaica, placed a $275,000 first mortgage on the sixstory elevator apartment house at 110-20 Seventy-third Road, Forest Hills.

While the country at large in Saturday's football had frequent spots of unexpected results and contests in which, though the expected teams won, the scores were not what had been looked for, the East had one of the most highly interesting games it has had in a good many years, the Cornell-Colgate clash at Ithaca.

Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Dammann of 1,112 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia R. Dammann, to Robert M. Granat Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Granat of Philadelphia, formerly of this city.

Old Westbury and Greentree brought high goal polo to the end of its season today and sent home the biggest crowd that has ever seen a Monty Waterbury Cup final with the memory of the year's best game. Other encounters may have been more technically perfect in spots, but none of them could match today's contest for sustained drama.

Miss Constance Vernette Bill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence A. Bill of Hempstead, L. I., will be married to Alton Austin Cheney, Yale, 1929, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Austin Cheney of this city, on Oct. 23.

The Newark Tornadoes, undefeated in three previous American Professional Football Association starts, were upset by the Mount Vernon Cardinals, 7 to 0, at Memorial Field today. When Pop Williams passed six yards to Bill Harris over the goal line midway in the first quarter it was the first time Newark had been scored upon this season.

Study of an Indiana court decision outlawing an anti-picketing ordinance passed by a Town Council has led C. I. O. officials to decide upon a legal offensive in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and elsewhere against municipalities seeking to "throttle" union organization and prevent picketing through adoption of similar ordinances.

The general election in Victoria yesterday resulted in a stalemate with slight gains for Labor party supporters of Premier A. A. Dunstan's Country party Ministry. In the last Parliament the Country party, with twenty seats in the Legislative Assembly of sixty-five, was supported by the Labor party with eighteen seats and three Independents.

Frankie Bailey of New Brunswick, A. A. A. Eastern States champion in 1936, defeated Bob Sall, holder of the title in 1933, in the final auto race meeting of the 1937 season at the Ho-Ho-Kus half-mile dirt track today.

The text of the open letter issued by 150 Protestant clergymen and educators and laymen on the recent pastoral letter of the Spanish hierarchy follows: The pastoral letter issued by the prelates of the Catholic Church in Spain stirs our anxieties.

A widespread and dangerous spirit of levity exists toward marriage, according to the Rev. Dr. W. Coleman Nevils, rector of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eightyfourth Street.

A preliminary examination of Mayor La Guardia's executive budget of $589,222,376 for 1938 shows the entire feasibility of reducing city water rates to the level prevailing before Jan. 1, 1934, Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, declared yesterday.

The Giants battered the Eagles from pillar to post before 13,000 spectators at Municipal Stadium today, but the Philadelphians, showing the durability of gridiron Battling Nelsons, made the game closer than it had any right to be.

The trouble with the world today, said the Rev. Carlos G. Fuller, the pastor, in his morning sermon yesterday at the Featherbed Lane Presbyterian Church, University Avenue and 174th Street, the Bronx, is that too many Christians fail to "take hold" of the power of God.

Ten archbishops and bishops of the Russian Orthodox Greek Catholie Church in America, dressed in their ceremonial robes, attended a four-hour service yesterday in the Cathedral of the Protection of the Holy Virgin, 5 East Houston Street.

Max Marston of Philadelphia, former national amateur golf champion, won the George Arthur Crump Memorial Cup today by defeating L. M. Lloyd of New York, 4 and 3, in the final round on the Pine Valley course.

Although outgaining their rivals throughout, the Brooklyn Eagles of the American Football Association played to a 7-all tie in an exhibition game with the Brown Bombers yesterday at Dyckman Oval. The Bombers scored in the first period on Matthew's 25-yard run after a 35-yard forward from Lillard.

Norman Thomas, in a speech before 700 persons in the Community Church, 550 West 110th Street, issued a warning last night that true supporters of democracy could not afford to show "any tolerance for the Ku Klux Klan, or for the despicable forces which aim to deprive people of their civil liberties."

The troubles afflicting the world are far less political and social than they are moral and religious, declared the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin in his sermon yesterday morning at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

Dr. Francis W. O'Connor of 50 Haven Avenue, director of the Department of Tropical Diseases at Columbia University, where he had been an Associate Professor of Medicine since 1928, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center following an operation to re lieve an intestinal obstruction. He was 53 years old.

Henry G. Arnsdorf, registrar of New York University, announced in his annual report, made public yesterday, that the net cumulative enrollment during the academic year 193637 reached 43,510 students, the largest in the history of the institution.

A large group of Chicago Negroes today adopted a protest against the seating tomorrow of Associate Justice Hugo L. Black. They declared that Mr. Black had not changed his views regarding rigths of racial and religious minorities during the years since he ceased to be a member of the Ku Klux Klan.
The text of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's radio speech follows: Tonight I am going to talk about murder-murder in the bakery racket. I am also going to talk about an attempted murder.

Trading in oats was light here last week, the feature being the development of a fair shipping demand from Canada. The effect of the latter, however, was short-lived on the futures market with the close yesterday showing prices 1/4 cent lower to 1/4 cent higher than the preceding week, with December 30 3/4 cents, and May at 313/4 cents a bushel.

If you are a voter in this town and mean to have your say in the municipal election, what day of this week are you going to register ? Today you'll get your first chance to register and to be enrolled, if you wish, as a Democrat, Republican, American Laborite or Socialist. Today and Tuesday, Wednesday,

The two-story garage and service building on the southeast corner of Jerome Avenue and 182d Street, occupied for several years by the Studebaker Corporation, has been leased for a term of ten years to the Ascot Garage Corporation by Joseph G. Platzner as broker in cooperation with the Garage Trading Corporation.

The other day, while Premier Mussolini was still in Berlin, Dr. Ernst Woermann, German Charge d'Affaires here called at the Foreign Office to make cautious inquiries with regard to the Anglo-French note of invitation to Italy to enter tri-partite conversations with the object of discussing the removal of foreign volunteers from Spain.

More than 3,000 delegates are expected to attend the two-day New York Herald Tribune Forum on Current Problems which will be convened at the Walderf-Astoria this morning. They will represent the country's organized women, organized youth and graduate and un.dergraduate groups from more than 150 leading educational institutions.

The Scots-Americans conquered Baltimore by 2-1 in the opener at their new soccer field today. Patschke scored for Baltimore after twenty minutes of play in the first period. Fisher, on Conn's pass, equalized at thirty-seven minutes. Three minutes from full time, Fisher tallied again.

Miss Marjorie Lewis MacDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Walker MacDonald of 858 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, will be married on Oct. 22 to Philip Faxon Mygatt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic E. Mygatt of Washington, Conn.

Cowboys and cowgirls from the Western plains began arriving in New York yesterday to prepare for the twelfth annual World's Championship Rodeo that will open at Madison Square Garden Wednesday. The arrivals were a vanguard of 80 of the 200 to come.

About 8,000 students of high schools, academies and colleges of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn attended the third annual diocesan rally in the interest of home and foreign missions under the auspices of the Catholic Students Mission Crusade, yesterday morning at a solemn high mass in the open air at St. John's Home Field, Albany Avenue and Prospect Place, Brooklyn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It has been the cry for many years that capitalism is failing. The truth is that capitalism is not being permitted to function properly. For what is the essence of capitalism? Simply this: a system of social production under which the greatest social values can be created.

Egbert Moxham Jr., with his bluehulled sloop Maid of Honor, today won the final race in the new International Class off the Larchmont Yacht Club. Over eight miles of windward and leeward sailing across Long Island Sound to Matinicock Point, east of Glen Cove, and back,

In the presence of a congregation that crowded the Church of the Ascension here this morning, a shrine of peace was unveiled and consecrated by the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Suffran Bishop of New York Protestant Episcopal Diocese.

A firmer undertone prevailed in the lard market here last week. Continued heavy withdrawals of supplies held in cold storage at leading points of accumulation. for domestic distribution and the consequent removal of hedges lifted prices more than 1/2 cent a pound at the extreme, compared with the close of the previous week.

Pittsburgh took a double-header from Cincinnati today and tied a major league record of winning twentyone of twenty-two games from one club. The scores were 4--3 and 4-0. the second contest being called in the seventh because of rain.

The Autumn luncheon and card party of the Junior Catholic Big Sisters will take place on Saturday in the Roof Garden of the Astor. During the afternoon there will be a fashion showing of Autumn and Winter costumes.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor will soon visit the United States. The following formal announcement on behalf of the Duke was made here tonight: In accordance with the Duke of Windsor's message to the press of the world last June that he would release any information of interest regarding his movements, ...

Political talks in the city campaign scheduled for broadcast today are: Frank J. Taylor, Controller, and Max J. Schneider, candidate for the Presidency of the City Council, over WHN from 9 to 9:15 P. M., interviewed by Bryce Oliver, commentator.

Foreign military experts who have watched the Shanghai warfare expressed the opinion today that no major power, least of all the United States, need fear Japan's armed forces. "The old bugaboo about Japan being a menace to the Western world, especially the United States, definitely has been exploded," one declared.

The Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray yesterday morning commemorated the eighty-ninth anniversary of the founding of the parish of 'he Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (the Little Church Around the Corner), Twenty-ninth Street, east of Fifth Avenue.
Paris views as incredible the rumor of an increase in the gold price-in other words, devaluation of the dollar and the pound-which has induced the rise in gold mining shares this week.

Stenographers and clerks read the most, while business executives are at the bottom of the list, Dr. Ralph Tyler of Ohio State University declared yesterday at the final session of the Progressive Education Association's school curriculum conference held at the Lincoln School Auditorium, Teachers College.

Ensign Fred (Buzz) Borries, who scampered to All-America fame as a halfback for Navy in 1934, is going to get a chance to cavort as an "Army" man. LieutenantHarry J. (Hank) Hardwick, Navy's head football coach, said Borries, assistant plebe coach, would personally test the Middies' defense before the Army game.

" To Have and Have Not," Ernest Hemingway's new novel that Scribner will publish on Oct. 15, has gone into a third large printing. A second printing has been ordered for Dan Wickenden's novel "The Running of the Deer," to be issued by Morrow on Oct. 13.

Criticism of Japan for violating the nine-power treaty was voiced by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, in an address yesterday over radio station WABC.
Maritime Commission officials disclosed today that Government merchant ships were being routed to keep them out of the danger zones of the Chinese and Spanish conflicts.
Wall Street continues to be the dominating influence in the London stock market although it is sometimes difficult to discern where this influence begins or ends.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,347,953,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

Madame Bertha Gounod, who before the World War made clothes for royalty in her shops at Monte Carlo and St. Moritz, and during the last two years made them for the poor as a seamstress on a WPA sewing project here, died at Englewood Hospital this morning of heart disease. She was 77 years old.

A survey of world opinion toward Japan in this morning's newspaper Nichi Nichi gives disconcerting results from the Japanese viewpoint. The only countries supporting Japan's "holy war" in China are found to be Germany and Italy, whose interests and influence in the Far East are almost negligible, while the United States and Britain, whose friendship and trade are valuable to Japan and who have real power to influence events, are found deeply unfriendly.

In this State, which boasts the largest percentage of rural population of any in the Union, President Roosevelt is just about as strong with the far?? as he has ever been, in the judgment of the political observers. The depression converted this traditionally Republican territory in 1932, and the President's efforts to restore the purchasing power of the farmer kept it there, by about the same margin, in 1936.

Organization of the Anti-Communist party to oppose the re-elec; tion of Mayor La Guardia was announced yesterday by Edward E. Spafford, formerly national commander of the American Legion. Headquarters have been established in the Hotel Commodore. The emblem of the party is the Liberty Bell.

The attempted murder of Max Rubin, important witness in the bakery rackets prosecution, was described as a challenge from an underworld about to "carck up" by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey yesterday. He added "I accept that challenge."

Challenger's Stylish Bill, handled by H. B. Rowley of Horseheads, N. Y., won the open, all-age stake that replaced the championship event at the Empire State field trials today. The stake was substituted because of a lack of dogs in the title event.

The Rev. Dr. Henry M. Tyndall, pastor and founder of the People's Tabernacle, 56 East 102d Street, heard himself described yesterday morning, at the forty-fifth anniversary celebration of the founding of the tabernacle, as one who was like Jesus.

Additional local banks and trust companies yesterday made public statements of their condition as of Sept. 30 in advance of the expected calls for reports by the State and Federal supervisory authorities.

Governor Ayers, I almost said my old friends of Fort Peck, because some of you were here three years ago. Three years have come and gone and I see a great change. When I was here before, there was just the beginning of a dam and now it is about threequarters finished.

Mrs. Susan Tennessee Cantrell, about 60, Clifton, N. J., was killed today and her son, Dr. William Clyde Cantrell, was critically injured when their car skidded on wet pavement and overturned twenty miles west of here.

Youthful Bobby Riggs, national clay courts champion, furnished the major upset of the forty-eighth Pacific Coast tennis championships today by defeating Germany's Baron Gottfried von Cramm in three straight sets in a semi-final match.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy, whose candidacy for re-election has been disapproved by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, is being put forward by a group of supporters as an independent candidate, it became known yesterday.

In a charity polo game at Bostwick Field today, the Bostwick Field team of Eddie Gerry, Earle Hopping, Dunbar Bostwick and Billy Post defeated a Westbury side on which Jimmy Mills, Bobby Gerry, Peter Grace and John Fell played, 10 to 8.

White Plains Rd (15-4050), e s, 270 ft n of Morris Park Ave, 125x100; Isidore Cuba to 1,826 Plains Realty Corp, 2,100 Anthony Ave. Westchester Ave:(14-3775), n e cor of Ward Ave, 50x106; Capitol Holding Co, Inc, to Betlygel Realty Corp, 292 Madison Ave.

Germany's wholesale price index number for Sept. 22 was 106.2, against 106.3 on Sept. 15. The cost-of-living index for September was 125.1, against 126 in August. The decline is ascribed to a seasonal cheapening in the prices of vegetable foods.

Praising the work missionaries have accomplished in the Orient, Dr. Robert W. Searle, secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, contrasted their "unselfish idealism" with what he termed "selfish interests" of industry and "international politics" in an address today in Kirkpatrick Chapel, Rutgers University.

Invitations have been issued for the wedding of Miss Emily G. Sessions, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Kenneth Sessions of Bristol, and W. Penfield Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Blake Gordon of Danbury, which will take place Saturday evening, Oct. 23. at Beleden,

Ed Stark, 165-pound halfback, led the Los Angeles Bulldogs to a 20to-9 victory over the Rochesterg Tigers in an American Football League game today before 8,000 spectators. Stark scored in the first period when he took an attempted field goal and raced 95 yards.

Groups of French and Italian sailors engaged in a mass fist fight in the Shanghai French Concession dance hall area tonight. An estimated 200 sailors of each nationality rushed from dance halls along "Bloody Alley" and battled in the streets.
As expected for the past two weeks, Ducky Medwick of the St. Louis Cardinals and Charley Gehringer of the Detroit Tigers are the 1937 big league batting champions.

Everything is in readiness for the opening tomorrow in Federal court here of the trial of forty-six individuals, twenty-three oil companies and three trade publications charged with conspiracy to fix and maintain artificially high gasoline prices in ten Midwestern States in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

Establishment of a new system of Public Administrators whereby a central administrator and one assistant would have charge of the five public offices now extant was recommended to Mayor La Guardia yesterday by Paul Blanshard, commissioner of accounts.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Renations Board, said yesterday that of the eighty-four steamship lines on which voting is to be conducted to determine labor affiliation eighteen have been charged with discrimination against one union or the other.
Mrs. John Dows Mairs gave a tea yesterday at her home, 148 East Forty-eighth Street, for Miss Mary Vail Hewitt, whose marriage to Mrs. Mairs's son, Edwin H. Mairs 2d, will take place Oct. 22.

Negotiations virtually have been completed whereby the ships of the Panama Pacific Line will be transferred from the intercoastal service to operate between New York and the east coast of South America, while ships of the Munson Line will be operated between New York and London, and some of the fleet of the United States Lines now operating in the Atlantic will go into the transatlantic service.

Discussing the prospect of a setback in world business, the Institute for Trade Research has come forth with an opinion that the recent weakness in the stock markets is being overvalued as a sign of impending reaction.

Lou Fette, the Bees' 30-year-old rookie, shut out the Phillies, 6 to 0, today and joined his room-mate, Jim Turner, and Cliff Melton, Giants' southpaw, as the first National League freshmen to win twenty games since Grover Cleveland Alexander did it for the Phillies nearly a quarter century ago.

A spirit of consecration, appreciation and faith in human ability are all necessary for life and sustenance, the Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland declared yesterday before the congregation of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street.

In the course of two vigorous speeches today, President Roosevelt pledged a balanced budget and struck back at critics of his spending policy. And he pointedly bracketed the names of three of the Montana members of Congress with himself, but omitted that of the fourth-Senator Wheeler, who broke openly with Mr. Roosevelt over the court-reorganization program.
Sponsors of a national lottery to raise Government revenue moved today to insure a hearing for this legislation at the next Congress session.

The Jamaica Fall race meeting of the Metropolitan Jockey Club will get under way today to run for a fortnight, which will mark the last of the sport on Long Island this season. With Stubbs as the probable favorite in the Belgrade Stakes, six races will be contested starting at 2:30 P. M.

Jack, a rotund army mule at Fort Totten, Queens, will receive full military honors on the occasion of his retirement from active service Friday afternoon at 4:30 o'clock, after twenty-seven years on duty, Lieut. Col. E. E. Bennett, commanding officer, announced in formal orders yesterday.
William S. Fitzgerald, former Cleveland Mayor and law director, died at his home here today. His age was 57.

The engagement of Miss Muriel Gerli, daughter of Mrs. Emanuel Gerli of 907 Fifth Avenue and Eastwood, Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Gerli, to Nelson Macy Jr. of Greenwich, has been announced by her mother.

Word on the measurement rule changes for the various "meter" yachts, effected at the recent meeting of the International Yacht Racing Union in England, was received here yesterday in a letter to the North American Yacht Racing Union from Philip J. Roosevelt and Clinton H. Crane, who attended as American representatives.
By a nearly unanimous show of hands, an audience of several hundred attending the opening of the annual national business
The White Sox assured themselves of third place in the final American League standings with a double victory over the Browns today.
The New York University-Carnegie Institute of Technology football score was smeared in six-foot-high black letters on the $8,000,000 sandstone home of the Mellon Research Institute today.

GOSSIP is the art of making yourself entertraining to one person by telling him things about another. In life it is often called reprehensible. In the novel it is usually called characterization. Yet one of the main objections to gossip-that it is not true-applies equally to characterization.

Predictions voiced last week by many brokers that the brisk activity in apartment leasing would continue well past the traditional moving day, Oct. 1, seem to be borne out by the large volume of contracts for residential space reported over the week-end.

The First Division quartet of Brooklyn topped the Governors Island Yellows, 5-4, yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation. A crowd of 3,000, including several hundred youngsters from the Bay Ridge Boys Club, witnessed the game. Attorney General John J.

More than 5,000 marchers from thirty parishes took part in a religious procession in Canarsie yesterday afternoon, ending the fifth annual Eucharistic Congress of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn.

Investment buying of business properties in the midtown area was the outstanding feature of the realty activity during the week-end. In the Twenty-third Street block between Seventh and Eighth Avenues where several building improvements have recently been made,

Japanese who have been trying for almost a week to break the Chinese lines north of Shanghai had their first considerable success yesterday, when they made a gain of about a mile on a five-mile front, capturing thirty-six villages.

Mayor La Guardia's executive budget was offered yesterday by Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, as proof of his contention that the Mayor has completely ignored his campaign nledses of 1933.

Part of the responsibility for America's crime problem was assigned by Senator Borah today to the "confused humanitarians who sit on pardon boards." He spoke at the dedication of a monument on the site of Fort Wilson, built sixty years ago during an Indian uprising.
The British bond market, which has responded to factors entirely different to those current in the United States, is quietly strengthening after the relapse which developed in the second quarter.

J. S. COAT CO., 1,124 St. Nicholas Ave,253 W. 35th St.-By Eagle Silk Woolen Co., Inc., for $200; Mitchel Berger, Inc., $300; Samuel Benjamin, $40, The members of the firm are listed as Irving Funt and Tillie Sobel.

R. D. Triggs of Madison, N. J., won the rifle championship and J. E. Rhodes of Philadelphia captured the pistol title at the Delaware Tidewaters shoot which ended today. Triggs finished with 1,368 of a possible 1,400. Rhodes scored 817 out of 900.

Mr. and Mrs. John Ripley Buchanan of this place have announced the engagement of Mr. Buchanan's daughter, Miss Helen Warren Buchanan, to William Standley Stokes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. W. S. Stokes of Berwyn, Pa.
Buying interest in the New York wholesale market last week again centered on apparel and accessories, while calls for staple items in the cotton and house-furnishing markets were few.
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbels. Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College, in heir annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, expressed shock and surprise that figures compiled by the Seven Colleges Committee showed that women donors are far less likely to give to education than men.

Beginning next Sunday Fifth Avenue near Rockefeller Center will hear the old Christian hymns "broadcast" from the tall spire of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Chancellor Hitler attacked with new energy here today those nations that refused to return to Germany her former colonies. He was addressing 1,200,000 peasants on the occasion of the National Socialist annual thanksgiving festival celebrated throughout the Reich.

Claude Hugh Clark, retired Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor of mechanical engineering, died today at his Summer home after a brief illness. Professor Clark taught at M. I. T. for more than twenty years, retiring in 1933.
Professor Henry Pratt Fairchild of New York today announced the marriage on Friday in New York of his daughter, Miss Eleanor Rogers Fairchild, to Hugh Saunig of New York.

The Shenandoah (Pa.) Presidents downed the Paterson Panthers today on the Hinchliffe Stadium gridiron, 9-7. A Paterson fumble in the last quarter on the 15-yard line enabled Shenandoah to score the winning touchdown on a forward pass from Hino to Metrillo.

Government supply contracts under the terms of the Walsh-Healey Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $3,870,694, the Department of Labor announced today. This compared with $6,086,481 in the preceding week.

Miss Jane Goodlove, daughter of Mrs. A. Francis Goodlove of this city and Covert Le Fevre Goodlove of Ridgewood, N. J., will be married to Curtis D. Morgan of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Morgan of Tampa, Fla.,

Numerous school football squads encountered their first taste of combat during the past week-end and the dose was not a bitter one in so far as it concerned a vast majority of the principal favorites.

Except for yesterday, which witnessed an active bull market, the stock market passed the week undecided, closing steady to firm. The heaviest trading was in Hoesch and other heavy industrials in anticipation of annual reports, but in some of these sharp reactions followed early advances.

The Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, has been chosen as the collective bargaining agency for clerical employes of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, it was announced yesterday.

After three straight defeats, night a two of them in league games, the New Rochelle Bulldogs, with a revamped line-up, scored a 13-to-7 American Association victory over the Bushwicks of Brooklyn at City Park today, tallying both touchdowns on long end runs in the opening period.

Meta Schumann, teacher, accompanist and composer, died yesterday at her residence, 8 West Seventy-sixth Street, of heart disease after an illness of three months. She was born in Minneapolis fifty years ago.

The Tampa flogging case, in which eight men, five of them former officers, are accused of causing the death of a labor organizer in a tar-andfeather incident, comes to court for a second time this week with the Ku Klux Klan publicly disavowing any connection with it.

The marriage of Miss Florence Henley Kirk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Parker Kirk of this place, to Alfred Wheeler Roberts Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. A. W. Roberts of Allendale, N. J., took place here last evening in St. John's Episcopal Church.

THE FAITHFUL WIFE, by Sigrid Undset (Knopf, $2.50). A novel of marriage and divorce. NEW FRONTIERS OF THE MIND, by J. B. Rhine (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50). The story of the Duke experiments in clairvoyance.

THEY yell-yell-yell Cornell! That must be quite a team they have far above Cayuga's waters. The way the Cornell ball-toters ran over, through and around the Colgate outfit was the football sensation of the day in the East.

Seeking new evidence on the prehistoric beginnings of homo sapiens, the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia and the Peabody Museum of Harvard are cooperating in an extensive man hunt, which will get under way this week.

The Athletics and Senators split a double-header today before 5,000 shivering die-hards. Frank Hayes's home run with two on in the sixth provided a 5-4 Philadelphia victory in the first game and Washington grabbed the second, 4 to 3, in five innings.

A boycott of Japanese goods will be endorsed by the Labor party as one of the first actions of the party's annual conference which opens at Bournemouth tomorrow. The party executive tonight approved the terms of a resolution which not only calls for a boycott but also demands the speedy reconvening of Parliament "to consider action to be taken" to put a speedy end to "the shameful outrage against humanity."

The Bureau of Air Commerce, under the leadership of Fred D. Fagg Jr., is ready to dispense with a physical examination for a student pilot permit until the student is ready to begin solo flying. it was indicated by Dr. Louis H. Bauer of Hempetead, L. I., who spoke yesterday at the ninth annual meeting of the Aero Medical Association in the Hotel Waldorf Astoria.

Major Charles S. Moyer, retired United States Army officer, died today in a Clifton Springs sanitarium at the age of 55. A graduate of St. Lawrence and Yale Universities, Major Moyer was a civil engineer for several years before joining the National Guard in Buffalo in 1914.
It cannot be said that London has modified the currently much less hopeful view of the stock market and trade outlook in the United States which it has been forced to take in the last few weeks.

The decisions and instructions of the Tampa convention relating to the Committee for Industrial Organization and its activities have been carried out. The council has diligently sought to heal the breach.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 74 per cent of capacity, off 2 points from the week before and down 10 points in four weeks.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lincoln Taylor of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Pemberton Taylor, to Dr. Edgar Buell Butler, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Nelson Butler of West Hartford.

The annual entertainment given in aid of the Hebrew National Orphan Home, described as the largest institution of its type in the United States, will take place Sunday evening, Oct. 31, at Madison Square Garden. Performers from every branch of the amusement field will participate.

Back in town after his excursion to the West Coast, Charles B. Cochran was ready yesterday to specify the first show of his impending Broadway campaign. It will be "Nymph Errant," which he presented in London in 1933 and which he expects will be on the boards here by Christmas.

Cyrus Cates Babb, former president of the Maine Society of Civil Engineers, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 70. Since 1917 Mr. Babb had served as consulting engineer for several large power Companies, the Rhodhiss Manufacturing Company here and the E. A. Smith Manufacturing Company.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had entered an order to "cease and desist" from use of "unfair" methods, price discrimination and exclusive dealing contracts against the Christmas Club, 341 Madison Avenue, New York.

What other country would present a new decree extending punishment in certain crimes from ten to twenty-five years' imprisonment as mitigation of the existing law? Yet that has just happened here and strangely enough it is true.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the C. I. O., and principal speaker at a victory rally and public opening of the first annual convention of the Transport Workers Union of America in Madison Square Garden tonight, will endorse Mayor La Guardia and all other candidates of the American Labor Party, leaders of the union intimated yesterday.

United States Senator Alva B. Adams and Mrs. Adams, General John Palenyi, Hungarian Minister to the United States; M. PaskeSmith, British Minister to Colombia, and Sir Campbell Stuart, director of The London Times,

Miss Elizabeth Wilder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Enos Wilder of this city, will be married to Gustav A. Rundin of Darien, son of Mrs. Gustav A. Rundin of Los Angeles, on Nov. 12 in the chapel of St. John's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Gerald A.

The Maritime Commission announced today that it had designated a new steel cargo vessel for ocean transportation, economical in cost and capable of fifteen and a half knots. Faster by almost 50 per cent than the majority of American ships now engaged in foreign commerce, the new vessel was described as meeting the "imperative need" of Amerlean shipping for new and faster cargo vessels.

The Japanese forces advancing southward in Shansi Province have severed contact between the armies of Governor Yen Hsi-shan and the Eighth Route Army, formerly the famous Communist forces. This was admitted today at the Nanking headquarters of the Red armies.

No doubt can exist that the New York art season is again in full swing; for, with the opening of the first week of October, some twenty-five exhibitions are on the calendar. Old Spain, modern Germany and any number of contemporary Americans are represented in the formidable list.

Mayor La Guardia in a brief, impromptu address from Station WOV called last night for the election of Thomas E. Dewey as District Attorney of New York County. The Mayor also urged citizens to register this week.

Completion of the first plant in this country for the exclusive production of rayon staple fiber is announced by the American Viscose Corporation. The plant is located at Nitro, W. Va., and is entirely separate from the company's rayon pulp plant located in the same community.
Mrs Ellen McBride Craib, wife of B. S. Craib of New York and St. Louis, and daughter of the late W. C. McBride, oil man, died here last night at a hospital.

Associate Justice Hugo L. Black's radio broadcast last Friday evening was condemned today by the Rev. Dr. Robert R. Wicks, dean of the Princeton University chapel, as "a rather cowardly explanation" of why the former Alabama Senator joined the Ku Klux Klan.
Premier and van Zeeland will be ready soon to issue his report on his economic mission to the United States and Europe which he undertook at the instance of the French and British governments.

The alternative to a great religious revival in America is a breakdown of civilization or a surrender to paganism, the Rev. Dr. C. Pitt Beers, executive secretary of the Home Mission Society of the Northern Baptist Convention, said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Central Park Baptist Church, 235 East Eighty-third Street.
Under the influence of a sustained consumptive demand and continued strength in freights, liberal shortcovering developed this week in wheat, and prices advanced steadily.
Several hundred colonists attended tonight a musicale held in the Greenbrier Auditorium and sponsored by Mrs. Charles Luckman of Chicago.
The reported bombing of noncombatants in China by Japan was condemned from several pulpits of New York City churches yesterday as a barbarous act which violated all Christian principles.

Manager Bill Terry yesterday ended all conjecture about the man who will take the mound against the Yankees in the World Series opener Wednesday by announcing that his great southpaw ace, Carl Hubbell, will pitch.

Henry H. Krunsberg, retired navy man, who in 1884 first sighted the lost Arctic expedition of Major Gen. Adolphus Washington Greely, died at the United States Marine Hospital here today. His age was 76.

Preceded by a parade of tiny pedal and gasoline driven cars, the first miniature automobile show will open tomorrow in the International Building at Rockefeller Center with more than 500 small trucks, trailers, buses, limousines, roadsters, racers and fire and police rolling equipment on display.

One hundred and nine Princeton undergraduates have been appointed to serve as commissioned and noncommissioned officers for the college year 1937-38 in the university's field artillery unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps, it was announced today by Lieut. Col. David E. Cain, commandant of the Princeton unit.

Walter Amory of Syosset, L. I., who fought in France in the World War as an officer of the Royal Air Force, died yesterday in the Rockefeller Institute Hospital of pneumonia after a year's illness, at the age of 37.
The new Feast of Christian Doctrine, Catechetical Sunday, was observed yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral with special prayers for the permanent success of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine.

Miss Alice Farley has been appointed buyer of perfumes and toilet articles for Lord Taylor. She was formerly assistant buyer in this department. Roy Rudolph has been appointed buyer of women's better dresses, including dresses for the maternity shop and the special size shop.
Justice and Mrs. Hugo L. Black were guests at tea at the home of Justice and Mrs. Harlan F. Stone today, a few hours after Mr. Black had taken his seat on the Supreme Court.

The opinion that the Japanese are giving China deserved punishment for "anti-Japanese activities," was expressed by Prince Fumitaka Konoye, 22-year-old son of the Japanese Premier, upon his arrival at Newark Airport from California tonight.

There is little doubt left in the British and French delegations here that they expect the League of Nations to pay with the crown of its protege Emperor Haile Selassie for the withdrawal of Italian combatants from Spain for which they are hoping soon to begin negotiating with Rome.
