Husky Joe Greenberg, younger brother of the illustrious Hank, cracked a tenth-inning single tonight with the bases packed to give Fort Worth's Panthers a 3-2 triumph over Little Rock and a threeto-one edge in the Dixie series.

The movement to boycott Japanese goods began to have repercussions today, and there were signs that its sponsors had allowed their anti-Japanese feelings to carry them too far. For the first time since the bombing of Nanking and Canton it was evident that the British Government disapproved of the direction the boycott campaign was taking, and that official influence was at work to discourage the movement.
Professor Emeritus Richard von Hertwig, nestor of German zoologists, died here today at the age of 87. Professor von Hertwig was an authority on modern biology.

Max R. Mayer, a member of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, died yesterday afternoon at his residence, 1 Fifth Avenue, from the effects of a stroke suffered early in the morning. His office was at 66 Beaver Street. He was 71 years old.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 3 unless specified: At Mare Island Yard: Altair, Arctic, Oct. 2; Phelps, Porter. At Shanghai, Oct. 2: Bittern, Edsall, Heron, Pecos. Guantanamo Bay to Cristobal, Oct. 4: Cummings, McDougal. Cristobal to sea: Decatur, Dickerson, Fairfax, Leary. Tattnall.
George Townsend Cole, a well-known artist, died suddenly today at his studio here in the arms of his friend and companion of the last ten years, Jimmie Wolfe, film actor. His age was 63.

The New Rochelle Trust Company has sold to a client of Schiff, Dorfman Stein the plot known as 480 North Avenue, New Rochelle, fronting sixty feet on the avenue, running 250 feet deep, with a width of 100 feet at the rear line.

Voters of 121 municipalities located in thirty-three States, during September approved municipal bond issues aggregating $7,576,089, as compared with $6,612,200 approved during August, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.
Japanese artillery hammered Chinese positions today in a sustained bombardment designed to crack the enemy line extending from the northern edge of Shanghai to the Yangtze River.

United States Ambassador Joseph E. Davies returned to Moscow today after a Summer spent in commuting between his post in Moscow and vartous key points of Europe. In recent months Mr. Davies visited fourteen European countries and conferred with political and economic leaders as well as other prominent officials.
W. St. Clair Symmers, Professor Emeritus of Pathology at Queens University, died today. His age was 74. He was born of Scottish parents at Columbia, S. C., Jan. 4, 1863. He was a British subject

Assemblage of a site for an additional unit in the chain of Automat restaurants was completed by the purchase of the property known as 104 West Fifty-seventh Street, 20 by 100 feet, by the Horn Hardart Company. Together with the parcels

Rayford W. Alley, Democratic candidate for County Executive of Nassau County, opened his campaign today with a demand for a "thorough investigation" of why dog racing was permitted at the Mineola Fair Grounds during the last Summer, after Governor Lehman had demanded the closing of dog tracks throughout

In spite of continued attempts to fetter it, "the press of America is determined that it will never submit to censorship by legislative enactment, executive fiat, the jingle of tainted money, nor bullets from the dark," James G. Stahlman, president of the American' Newspaper Publishers Association, declared here yesterday.

Hugo L. Black took his seat as an associate justice of the Supreme Court today, and two vigorous protests to his legal right to sit were laid before the other justices and himself. The new member broke with tradition in that he did not repeat the judicial oath of office.

Traffic through the Panama Canal during September decreased, 444 commercial vessels passing through. They paid tolls of $1,935,673.78, as compared with 505 vessels and tolls of $2,195,308.87 in August. In September a year ago 466 vessels used the waterway and paid tolls of $2,045,440.82.

The New Friends of Music and the RCA Victor Company announced yesterday that they plan to cooperate in recording a large proportion of the works to be played during the sixteen chamber music concerts of the New Friends at the Town Hall this season. The recordings will be made available to the public.

President Roosevelt chose for his first speech in which he mentioned the Supreme Court, a section of the country in which there is some actual interest in his battle to reorganize that body. The interest here is, as previously noted, based on support for the old AAA, and also on a "give the President what he wants" philosophy.

The end of the Major League trail beckoned tonight to Lefty George (Rube) Walberg, 38-year-old Red Sox hurler, whose unconditional release was announced by Eddie Collins, general manager of the Boston club.

Several railroads issued yesterday estimates of what the increase of 44 cents a day to train operating employes would cost them, but officials refrained from expressing satisfaction or dissatisfaction with the agreement. For the railroads as a whole, the cost of the rise was estimated at $35,000,000 annually.

Continued Southern hedge selling caused prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday to drop to further new low ground for the season, sending the January and March positions below 8 cents a pound for the first time since May, 1933. The steady downward trend

The keel of the first of three new ships to be built for the Government-owned Panama Railroad Steamship Company for operation between New York, Haiti and the Panama Canal will be laid next month at Quincy, Mass., it was announced yesterday by Thomas H. Rossbottom, vice president and general manager.

Two men were killed and another was seriously injured at 9:15 o'clock last night when a tire of their automobile blew out and the car smashed into a stone abutment of the Myrtle Avenue bridge on the Grand Central Parkway at Glendale and was demolished.

More newspaper reporting of the kind "that dug up Justice Black's connection with the Ku Klux Klan" was advocated before the sixteenth annual New Jersey Newspaper Institute here today by Arthur Robb, executive editor of Editor and Publisher, who said "we haven't had enough of the reporting that digs behind official statements and keeps government on its toes and conscious of its responsibility to the governed."

Dr. Albert W. Ferris, who was president of the New York State Lunacy Commission from 1907 to 1911, died at his home here today after an illness of eight years. On Dec. 3 ne would have been 81 years old.

Turpentine firm, 28c; sales. 125 barrels; receipts, 407 barrels; shipments, 237 barrels; stock, 36,906 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 784; receipts, 1,424; shipments, 320; stock. 73,753. Quote: B, D, E, $7.40; F to N, $7.60; WG. $7.85; WW. X. $8.40.
Another British destroyer has- narrowly escaped damage or destruction by a torpedo fired by a submarine of undetermined nationality off the east coast of Spain.

Joseph Tomich, 19 year old, of 50 Penn Boulevard, Scarsdale, was arraigned here this afternoon before Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich on a charge of attempting to extort jewels and $100,000 from Mrs. S. Charles Einfeld of 58 Penn Boulevard, wife of the director of advertising and publicity for Warner Brothers Pictures. The hearing was adjourned to Thursday and Tomich was committed to the Westchester County jail.

Pierre Lorillard Kent of New York, who had been living for the last year in Panama City, Fla., died there yesterday, according to word received here by his uncle, Edwin C. Kent, whom he often visited.

The freighter Nashaba hung high on the shoals of Morsalines Bay today, a half mile off the coast, where three tugs had dropped her last night at the captain's orders. The tugs had attempted to take the American freighter to SaintVaast, fishermen's port east of Cherbourg, but water entered the hold faster than pumps ejected it, so the captain decided to beach the ship. It was planned to have the
Republicans in the Bronx yesterday shut the door on the proposal looking to fusion with the American Labor party in backing Isidor Nagler, its candidate for President of the borough.
Witan, the Blue Ridge Farm's fleet 5-year-old, captured top honors in the featured Inaugural Purse, a seven-furlong test, as the Fall meeting opened at Sportsman's Park today.

Modifications of the 1937 cotton loan program "to afford uniform protection to all producers throughout the belt and to enable them to market their cotton in an orderly manner" were announced today by the Commodity Credit Corporation.

The Third Avenue Railway Company is confronted with the problem of rising costs, S. W. Huff, president, said in the annual report for the year ended on June 30, issued yesterday. He said the company was making "strenuous efforts" to economize and to obtain reductions in taxes.

American Equitable Assurance Company-As of June 30, 1937, total assets were $12,273,413, compared with $13,633,693 at the end of 1936; surplus amounted to $6,137,983, against $6,263.703: unearned premiums $4,499,896, against $4,167,427.

A tour through Japan as guests of the Japanese Government will be made by eight high school teachers from this country and one from Canada "to acquaint them with Japan's social, cultural and economic achievements," it was announced yesterday by Iwao Yokota, representative here of the Board of Japanese Tourist Industries.
Two of the nation's best known specialists in crime eradication discussed the problems facing them last night in talks at the New York Herald Tribune Forum at the aWldorf-Astoria.

Catholic spokesmen here, replying yesterday to the open letter signed by 150 Protestant clergymen and educators and laymen in answer to the recent pastoral letter of the Spanish hierarchy, declared that the 150 signers were "misinformed on the facts" and were voicing "opinions that have long been discredited."

Mayor La Guardia intervened yesterday in the situation that has threatened to develop into a general strike of 15,000 workers in 350 facstories in the undergarment industry. The strike was to have gone into effect tomorrow.

In the United States Court of Claims the following proceedings were had today: H-47--Cherokee Nation. Corrections made In Finding 14 and in court's opinion; plaintiff's motion for new trial overruled. Plaintiff's motion for new trial overruled. 4271--Middle States Petroleum Corp.

Auburn and Tularie both lost ground in the Southeastern Conference championship race today when they battled to a scoreless tie on heavy turf in a football game postponed from Saturday. A crowd of 16,000 saw the contest.

The Argentine-bred Sabueso today literally charged through four rivals in the final sixteenth to carry the silks of Bing Crosby and L. C. Howard to victory in the six-furlong Hanover Purse at Rockingham Park.
Indecision among traders ruled a relatively dull and featureless
Federal Trade Commission hearings in New York this week announced today will include cases involving Justin Haynes Co., Inc., tomorrow afternoon; Marvo Beauty Laboratories,
Frankie Frisch, the distinguished and capable tactician who directs the-for-the-moment-somewhat extinguished Cardinals, once remarked on the eve of one of these world series conflicts:

Two mortgages aggregating $60,000 on 19 E 80th St have been assigned by the Empire Trust Co to the Manufacturers Trust Co. Mary Mombach assigned to Mildred Brachfeld a mortgage for $3,000 on 166 E 4th St, and this house has been simultaneously conveyed by John Mombach to Max Kalman.
Thomas F. Hanley of Flushing, who has been Federal receiver for national banks in Queens since 1934, resigned yesterday. He will be succeeded by Edwin H. Hellawell of Hempstead. Mr. Hanley said he
The "unemployment problem" for several thousand slot machines outlawed in Florida since Sept. 30 apparently has been solved by a Presidential decree admitting them to Cuba, it was disclosed today.
Manhattan Borough takes a hasty glance at the assessment lists for 1938 and thinks her fate is not unlike that of Mr. Atkins,

Unfilled orders of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation on Sept. 30 amounted to $1,534,579 and were the largest in the company's history, James Work, president, announced yesterday. This figure compares with $575,639 on Sept. 30, last year.

Five hundred voices, drawn largely from church choirs and school faculties of this city and neighboring towns, tonight swelled in mighty chorus to open Worcester's weeklong, seventy-eighth annual music festival.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, joined with 12,000 members of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, in endorsing Mayor La at Guardia for re-election at a meeting of the T. W. U. in Madison Square Garden last night.

An eight-room Colonial-style house on a half acre of land on Stevenson Road, Hewlett, L. I., was purchased by Marjorie Picker from the estate of Charles J. McGinnis. A Sheldon Jaffe, broker, negotiated the deal.

With the menu a closely held secret, Les Amis d'Escoffier Society announced yesterday that it would hold its first dinner of the season at 7 o'clock tonight at the Hotel Astor. Formed to perpetuate the memory of Auguste Escoffier, famed French chef and epicure who died in 1935, the society is composed of members of the culinary craft and business and professional men, gourmets all.

Automobile production increased sharply last week. Even after changing the seasonal factor to 37.8 from 32.2, in order to allow for the earlier date set this year for the Automobile Show, the adjusted index moved up to 143.8 from 133.6. The figure was 82.7 for the week ended Oct. 3, 1936.

H. Gordon Selfridge of London and his daughter, the Vicomtesse de Sibour, who arrived on the Queen Mary, are at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Oliver B. Jennings is at the Gladstone. Mr. and Mrs. Wright Barclay have returned to 1,165 Park Avenue after passing the Summer in Roslyn, L. I.

The engagement of Miss Rosanne Lawrence Wigham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald E. Wigham of this city, to Nicholas Cooke Jenks, son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Jenks of Morristown, N. J., and Philadelphia, has been announced by her parents.

The Missing Persons Bureau of the Nassau County Police Department sent an alarm throughout the Eastern States today seeking information as to the whereabouts of Captain Walter C. Mayer, former member of the United States Marine Corps and nationally known firearms expert, who has been

Death Announced With regret the death of Fireman Second Grade Frank J. Trzcinski of H. L. 146, which occurred at 6:05 A. M., Oct. 2, 1937, is hereby announced to the department. Funeral will take place from 255 Grove St., New Britain, Conn., at 7 A. M., Oct. 5, 1937.

The president and directors of the Manhattan Company were permitted today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to intervene in the reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company. The Manhattan Company sought this recognition as an interested

Mr. and Mrs. James Dwight Francis of New York, who occupied Mrs. Nina L. Duryea's cottage, The Mill, this season, have bought historic Arrowhead in Pittsfield from Mrs. Russell A. Hibbs. They will occupy it next season. The house, which was built in 1784, was owned for several years, from 1852 on, by Herman Melville, author of South Sea stories, including the novel "Moby Dick."

Plans for moving its principal Brooklyn office from its present site at 32 Court Street to new and enlarged quarters at 205-09 Montague Street were announced yesterday by the Manufacturers Trust Company. The bank announced that it had leased the entire building in Montague Street and would take possession early next Spring, when extensive alterations would begin.

Sir Campbell Stewart, director of The London Times and chairman of the Imperial Communications Advisory Committee, arrived here yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary for a vacation and to visit friends.

If the President wants to make a perfect score in being away from Washington-and therefore from any physical contact with Mr. Justice Black-until all the tiresome details of protest are over, he need only absent himself for another week. Next Monday the Supreme

Five hooded men, halting Sheriff Joe Allen of Santa Rosa County on a midnight drive, seized a Negro prisoner and shot him to death. The Negro, 30-year-old J. C. Evans, was charged with a "crime against nature" involving an attack on a 12-year-old white boy, and with robbing a filling station. He was being brought here for trial today.

Secretary Hull predicted today that the American shoe industry would benefit from a proposed reciprocal trade treaty with Czechoslovakia. Challenging statements in an advertisement in a Binghamton (N. Y.) newspaper criticizing the proposed treaty, Mr. Hull said that

Eleven passengers were hurt yesterday afternoon when a southbound trolley of the Third Avenue Railway was struck in the rear by another car at Westchester Avenue and Glover Street, the Bronx. Three of the injured were taken to Fordham Hospital.

The average rate of interest on the Treasury's $50,000,000 273-day bill issue sold today was 0.436 per cent, compared with 0.384 per cent last week, 0.411 the previous week and 0.711 per cent in the week before that, according to an announcement tonight by Acting Secretary of the Treasury Magill.

John Slater of New York City, dean of retail shoe men, today told the 300 delegates at the nineteenth annual convention of the New York State Retailers Association in discussing "style and its dangers," that "the danger point of style is the misinterpretation of fashion."

Dr. Lewis Williams Douglas, former Director of the United States budget, has been appointed principal and vice chancellor of McGill University, Sir Edward Beatty, chancellor of the University, announced here today after a meeting of the McGill board of governors and senate. Dr.

William A. Sullivan, 55, of Yonkers, N. Y., district manager there for the Metropolitan Insurance Company, died of a heart ailment early today at the home of Mrs. Emma Moser, Silver Hills, in suburban New Albany, Ind four hours
Donald R. Richberg, former counsel for the NRA, arrived here today and predicted "Government intervention" to end labor's jurisdictional disputes.
Robert McVickar, formerly a member and one of the board of managers of the New York Produce Exchange, died early yesterday at his home, The Spruces, Rhinebeckon-Hudson, at the age of 76.
Ivan William Erickson, 35, of Chicago, was stabbed to death early this morning in Taxco, Guerrero. Political questions again caused bloodshed in Mexico in the last

Advertising linage in New York newspapers during September continued to be adversely affected by the demise of The New York American, an analysis of Media Records figures for that month shows. Total linage amounted to 9,860,276, as against 10.146,433. a decline of about 2.8 per cent, nearly all of which was traceable to the dropping of the weekday editions of The American.

J. B. Priestley, British author and playwright, who is reputed to have a poor opinion of the United States, arrived yesterday from London on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to produce two plays and make a month's lecture tour starting at Columbia University on Nov. 16. It will continue at various universities and end in Oklahoma.

A television preview of the thirtyfourth annual business show, to be held in this city the week of Oct. 18, will be broadcast for a group of business executives, represented at the show when they assemble as guests of Lenox R. Lohr, president of the National Broadcasting Company, on Friday.
A man picked up for questioning in connection with some worthless checks was killed when he jumped from a third-floor window in City Hall this afternoon. The suspect was

Two Brooklyn magistrates disagreed yesterday over jurisdiction in the case of two striking employes of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle charged by the newspaper with conspiracy in connection with the three weeks' strike called by The Eagle unit of the American Newspaper Guild. Magistrate Mark Rudich,

The marriage of Mrs. Jane Kraus Rosenbloom, daughter of Benjamin F. Kraus of Pittsburgh, to Richard A. Loeb took place at noon yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Julius Loeb, 31 East Seventy-second Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise of Central Synagogue.

141st St (9-2286), n s. 568 ft e of Willis Ave. 56x100; Bronx Eye Ear Infirmary to Samuel P. Watson, 420 E 140th St. Nelson Ave (11-2874), s w cor of 172d St. 99x96; Pearl Ulmer to Lenson Realty Corp. 608 W 178th St; mtg $131,000.

The terminus of Pan American Airways New York-to-Bermuda air transport route will be removed after Nov. 1 to Baltimore. In announcing its removal from the seaplane base at Port Washington, L. I., the company said "this

Slight Democratic gains in the Connecticut township elections and the capture of the city of Torrington by the Democrats, who also reelected their Norwalk city ticket, headed by Mayor George Stack, marked the annual polling today.

In the face of Mayor La Guardia's threat to fight them in the courts, the Board of Aldermen voted with only one exception yesterday to cut the city's water rates by $12,000,000 a year, a move that was vigorously applauded by a host of civic workers attending the meeting in City Hall.

The six-story elevator apartment house known as Northtown Court at 2,065 Grand Concourse, adjoining the northwest corner of Burnside Avenue, has been purchased by an investor from the North Town Realty Company.

James L. Whitcomb has become managing director and executive vice president of the New York Retail Dry Goods Association, succeeding H. Nelson Street, who has resigned to join the Farrington Manufacturing Company and handle special promotion work in connection with "Charge-Plate," a new charge system to reduce recording errors and speed customer service.

Many of the persons listed in brokers' reports of apartment rentals yesterday took quarters on the upper East Side, and particularly on Park Avenue. The number of contracts closed reflected a slight easing of the pressure which has been borne by rentals, agents and brokers for many weeks.

Karl Schafer, seven times world figure-skating champion and twotime winner of the Olympic crown, arrived in New York yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to take part in the coming international troupe tour in which he will be co-starred with Miss Maribel Y. Vinson, the leading woman figure skater In this country for a decade.
Spokane's three newspapers announced increases in their subscription rates today, saying they were forced by rising labor and material costs and rising taxes.

The State Department of Health today reported 173 cases of infantile paralysis upState during September. This was four times as many as a year ago, Dr. Herman F. Senftner, acting director of the Division of Communicable Diseases, stated, but 105 cases fewer than in September, 1935. It was believed that the peak
Political talks in the city campaign scheduled for broadcast today are: Thomas E. Dewey, candidate for District Attorney, over WBIL (1,100 Kc.) from 6:15 to 6:30 P. M.
The international stock market indices for Oct. 2, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

Following its first meeting since the appointment of W. O. Douglas as chairman, the Securities and Exchange Commission today announced several changes in personing director of the important utilities division of C. Roy Smith, who
An attractive woman attorney, who did not reveal her name, had to check her hat today before she could enter the Supreme Court room.

A clear indication that Italy will refuse the AngloFrench invitation to a three-power conversation on Spanish affairs and suggest instead a discussion by the International Non - Intervention Committee was given today by Virginio Gayda in an editorial in the Giornale d'Italia.

The handsome Federal office building housing the Church Street postal annex at Church and Vesey Streets was dedicated yesterday by Postmaster General James A. Farley with words of praise for President Roosevelt, for all postal employes and for the increasing efficiency of the Postoffice Department.

George J. Lyons, chairman of the board of the Young Men's Board of Trade of New York, has been appointed vice chairman of the United Hospital Campaign, it was announced yesterday by John W. Davis, chairman.

After he had been called from his home by a man who, a few moments later, fired a revolver at close range, Joseph La Faro, 42 years old, of 500 Catherine Street, Fort Lee. a delegate of Local 346 of the Hod Carriers Union, with

A sharp rise in automobile accidents in the city over the last weekend compared with the corresponding period of 1936 was reflected in the weekly report of the traffic bureau of the Police Department issued yesterday.
The following executive appointments were announced today by E. G. Biechler, general manager of Frigidaire Division, General Motors Corporation:
A fleet of trucks will cart 100 loads of earth into Madison Square Garden today as one of the principal steps in converting the huge arena into a Western ranch suitable for a rodeo.

A picture of Chancellor Adolf Hitler swinging a farm girl in a peasant round dance at yesterday's harvest festival at Bad Prymont, attended by 1,200,000 persons, was published today in a Westphalia newspaper.

Dr. John Sundwall, Professor of Hygiene and Public Health at the University of Michigan, was reelected president of the American Association of School Physicians yesterday at its annual business meeting. The organization

Reflecting improvement in economic conditions in all parts of the country. resignations of young men from Civilian Conservation Corps to enter private employment have been more numerous in recent months than at any time in the four-year history of the corps.

Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN-John T. O'Grady, from 47th Precinct to 7th Division, assigned to clerical duty. James W. Mullane, from 114th Precinct to Borough Headquarters Squad, Manhattan, for duty with Midtown Squad. William D. Olive, from 7th Division to 18th Precinct, assignment to clerical duty discontinued. William N. McDonald, from Telegraph Bureau to 112th Precinct.

Five ideologies have taken root in our social system and divided Americans into as many groups, said Edouard Lindeman, Professor of Social Philosophy at the New York School of Social Work, at an annual conference for Brooklyn and Queens Y. M. C. A, officers at the Half Moon Hotel, Coney Island, yesterday.

Fred Spuhn, recently appointed head coach of crew at Princeton, formally took over as Gordon Sikes's successor this afternoon along the shore of Lake Carnegie, with 204 aspiring Tiger oarsmen reporting for the initial practice of the year.

President Roosevelt told a Montana audience on Sunday of a New York publisher who urged him to cut the Government's expenditures, but who "hemmed and hawed," and then "hemmed and hawed some more," when the President asked him, "Just where would you cut expenses?" The publisher seems to have made a pretty sorry mess of his answer to this question, but he need not have done so.

Sixty-sixth annual meeting, American Public Health Association, begins at the Hotels Pennsylvania, New Yorker and McAlpin at 9:30 A. M. and continues to Friday. Meeting tonight at Manhattan Opera House at 8:15 P. M. Speakers: Dr. Thomas Parran, Commissioner John L. Rice, Mayor La Guardia, Governor Lehman, Dr. Livingston Farrand, Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr.

Patrick St. John Stirling, 33 year's old, editor and partner In a London stock brokerage firm, was found shot dead today in his home here. A rifle was by his side and letters found in the room included one to

Mahdi captured the $3,240 Belgrade Claiming Stakes as Jamaica opened its Fall meeting yesterday with an unusually large crowd of about 10,000. Most were surprised to see the Sage Stable color-bearer lead from end to end of the six furlongs to have an easy time of it and a four-length margin.

Onehundred members of the late Summer colony and naval colony tonight attended the third of a series of roller skating parties here. The parties, which are being conducted by a committee headed by Mrs. Dan W. Jones, will be carried into late Autumn.

Launching what the War Veterans of the Federal Theatre Project say will be a "test case," Wallace R. Stark, founder of the veterans' group, made public yesterday a letter of resignation in which he charged "disgusting conditions" that made it impossible for him to continue as a project worker.

In an attempt to offset the support of the American Labor party and a committee of the American Federation of Labor for Mayor La Guardia, announcement was made yesterday of the formation of the Trades Union party which will support Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic nominee for Mayor, and all Democratic candidates in the five boroughs of the city.

Yanks 2-5 Favorites, With Price Against Giants Winning 8-5 Jack Doyle's odds on the world series were unchanged from the prices quoted two days ago, the Yankees remaining favorites yesterday. His price on the series is 2

"In Clover," the Allan Scott play which was to have opened this evening at the Vanderbilt, has been put over until one day next week. There are to be some script changes and some cast changes, and the whole thing is further complicated by the fact that Bretaigne Windust, who has been directing, must start rehearsing with "Amphitryon 38." In fact, he did so yesterday.

Miss Ruth Gordon Harrington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wentworth Lewis Harrington of Maplewood, has completed plans for her marriage on Oct. 16 to Dr. William F. Thornley, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Thornley of Millburn, in Morrow Memorial Church here. The pastor, the Rev. Dr. John E. Charlton, will perform the ceremony.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 1: Blakeley, Rear Admiral C. A., to duty as Commander of Carrier Division 2. Barker, Capt. W. C. Jr., Berkeley, Calif., to command the Pennsylvania. Boster, Lt. Comdr. C. M., Pensacola, Fla., to the Ranger.

High police officials and close to a hundred detectives ran into nothing but dead ends yesterday in a search for clues in the murder of Lewis Weiss, 20-year-old student, and Miss Frances Hajek, 19, both of Queens Village, Queens.

Columbia University's increased income and savings in the last academic year resulted in a deficit of only $7,909, instead of the estimated $701,256, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, reported yesterday at a meeting of the trustees.
County Judge Gerald Nolan announced- his resignation here today, explaining it was because of his candidacy for the Supreme Court in the November election.

The trade unions' grip on the Labor party was seriously shaken today when the party's annual conference at Bournemouth voted to give the purely political branch of the Labor movement greater weight in deciding the party's policies.

The selection of a jury of twelve men and two alternates to try the fortyseven individuals, twenty-three oil companies and three trade publications for violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act began in Federal court here this morning and was completed at 6 o'clock in the evenine.

A committee from the Federation of Kosher Butchers, whose 5,000 affiliated butcher shops in the metropolitan area have been closed since Saturday night in a stoppage "strike" against what they contend is an excessive wholesale price of meat, will confer this morning with Mayor La Guardia at City Hall.

The Nassau County Board of Supervisors approved today the awarding of a contract for reconstruction of the Long Beach Bridge. The contract was awarded to the lowest bidder, Andrew Weston Company of Inwood, L. I., with a bid of $202,991.

Private and public welfare agencies should cooperate in the development of public welfare programs and work together against political interference and lowering of standards, Stanley P. Davies, general director of the Charity Organization Society, said yesterday at the annual convocation of the Graduate School for Jewish Social Work at the Federation Building, 71 West Forty-seventh Street.

Please with the improvement in blocking and tackling shown by Army in Saturday's game with Clemson College, Coach Gar Davidson required nothing today from his first two teams except dummy scrimmage and assignment drill. He had the third team play a regulation game against the B squad in an endeavor to strengthen his reserves.

Dr. Gordon Francis Cadisch of 200 West Fifty-eight Street, dean of the Hudson College of Commerce and Finance of St. Peter's College, Jersey City, died here yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital, following an operation. He was 43 years old.

The need for extending to impovished boys and girls in 200 mountain counties In seven Southern States the aid that the Save-the-Children Fund of America now extends to 25,000 children in twenty-two counties was emphasized yesterday at a meeting of the fund's officers and field staff at its national headquarters, 1 Madison Avenue.

Two radio sales corporations and four of their attaches were found guilty in Special Sessions yesterday of violating the State law in using counterfeit trade-marks on radio sets, and two other corporations and three of their officials entered guilty pleas.

Atley Donald handcuffed the Columbus Red Birds with a three-hit pitching performance tonight, defeating the American Association champions, 1 to 0, and giving Newark's Bears, International League pennant winners, their second straight little world series victory.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, who is national president of the Amateur Athletic Union, was beaten in a fourteen-man race for twelve positions as delegates to the national A. A. U. convention last night at the annual meeting of the Metropolitan Association at the Hotel Capitol.

Dr. Theodor Lewald, 77-year-old president of the German Olympic Committee, resigned his post today. He received a congratulatory message from Chancellor Hitler for his services preceding and during the last Olympics.

The property of the Jacksonville Havana Railroad was sold yesterday in Virginia, Ill., under a decree of the Federal court in Springfield, Ill., to Henry P. Andrews and Leonard A. Wales, it was announced by Ralph M. Arkush, counsel for the railroad's bondholders' committee. The announcement said the purchase was made under an
This is a month of significant dates in the history of the Supreme Court, marking not only today when Associate Justice Black took his seat, but four other notable occasions.

The October grand jury, which has been investigating vice and crime in Philadelphia, returned indictments today against five men on charges of operating gambling houses. They were the first presentments sinceJudge Curtis Bok ordered the inquiry ten days ago.

While a fair volume of orders continued to appear in the local merchandise markets yesterday., continued mild weather in certain sections is hurting the sales of seasonal apparel, manufacturers and resident buyers reported yesterday. In areas where the weather had turned colder, brisk activity was reported and some fairly substantial reorder business appeared,
A call for a "positive" and "courageous" draft of policies by a committee of "distinguished Republicans" prior to a proposed 1938 convention came from Herbert Hoover today.
Three New York detectives received $1,000 today for their part in the capture of Joseph J. Bruno, life termer who fled the Schuylkill County jail and was missing for eight months.

Major Baden Fletcher Smyth Baden - Powell, brother of Sir Robert Baden-Powell, founder of the Boy Scouts, who was actively associated with pioneer experiments in aeronautics, died today at Seven Oaks at the age of 77.

The current lull in recovery, partly due to seasonal factors, is regarded by Administration experts as a healthy condition and a necessary preliminary to a greater and sounder prosperity in the near future, it was learned today.
Clark Griffith announced tonight that Stanley (Bucky) Harris has signed a contract to manage the Washington Senators for the third straight year. He did not disclose the salary.
The two-story bank building formerly occupied on lease by the New York Title Company at 205-9 Montague Street, Brooklyn, has been leased to the Manufacturers Trust Company.

In the Supreme Court of the United States, Maurice Rose, Bernard H. Flitzpatrick, John E. McAniff and Francis J. Duffy of New York City were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:
Eight gibbons captured in Siam by an Asiatic primate expedition early in the Spring enjoyed today their first freedom from cages since April.

Benjamin Strump, a garage owner, filed suit yesterday in Supreme Court to compel the Police and Sanitation Departments to enforce city ordinances banning all-night parking of motor cars on public streets. He asserted that all-night parking was general throughout the city.

For the first time in the history of the Court of General Sessions, which goes back to the latter part of the seventeenth century, when it was the Colonial Court of the Kings Bench of England, women were accepted yesterday as jurors in criminal trials.

Kemper Simpson, economic adviser to the Securities and Exchange Commission since 1934, quit to day as the commission abolished his office. He had been at odds with some of the policies of the commission and in a statement today contended that its activities had been dominated by those primarily interested in technical detail who were oblivious to many important economic problems with which it might have been expected to grapple.

Charles C. Burlingham, independent Democrat and former president of the Bar Association of the City of New York, has accepted the chairmanship of the Thomas E. Dewey Citizens Committee, Millard H. Ellison, Mr. Dewey's campaign manager, announced last night.

A tumultuous meeting of the Queens County Democratic Committee, at which twenty-eight patrolmen found themselves unable to restore order, nominated Justice of Special Sessions Lawrence T. Gresser for City Court Justice last night.

A reorientation of the national tuberculosis attack would bring about the elimination of tuberculosis in the United States, Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, said last night at the silver jubilee dinner of the National Organization for Public Health, Nursing at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Mrs. W. Gustav Triest, chairman of the committee arranging a luncheon and Autumn fashion review to be held on Oct. 20 for the benefit of the Prosperity Shop, will give a reception for members of her committee today in the Caprice Room of the Weylin, which will be formally opened for the season with the charity event.

Britain moved to convoke the signatories of the nine-power Pacific treaty to deal with the warfare in China at a meeting Of the sub-committee of the Far Eastern advisory committee in Geneva yesterday. Germany and Russia would be invited to the conference. The plan, however,

106th St, 54 W, 25x101; 54 West 106 Street Corp to Beatrice G. Smith, 1,220 Park Ave. ($20). 73d St. 203 E, 24.4 1/2x109.4 1/2xirreg; also 208 E 73d St. 25x102.2; Besmith Realty Corp to Beatrice G. Smith, 1,220 Park Ave. ($2).

The lithographic medium is being signally honored this week. Tomorrow night, in Boston, the Museum of Fine Arts will open, with a private showing, an exhibition embracing the entire scope of the lithograph's development, from the days when the first experiments were made by Senefelder and John Andre, to the present. Meanwhile, at

Governments should advertise more, William E. Mosher, director of the School of Citizenship and Public Affairs of Syracuse University, told the Civil Sevice Assembly of the United States and Canada today.

Dr. E. J. Kempf, from St. George's, paired with Walter Scheiber, professional of Milburn, to top a strong field today in the Long Island Golf Association one-day bestball tourney over the links of the Oceanside Golf Club.

An undertone of uncertainty prevailed in the grain markets for the Board of Trade here today with prices holding within relatively narrow limits. Trading was unusually light, with local operators and customers of commission houses apparently waiting for leadership on either side.

Buck Langhorne, once a $1,200 selling plater, won his first race of the year in eleven starts in the fifth event, which served as the feature on today's program at this track. Running in the colors of Mrs. K.
Tammany Hall, for the first time in its history, had a picket line in front of its building at East Seventeenth Street and Union Square yesterday morning.

The Park Avenue Tunnel, from Thirty-third to Fortieth Street, through which New York Central steam trains once ran and later Madison Avenue street cars clattered, was opened to passenger car and taxicab traffic yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and Borough President Samuel Levy.

Negotiations which began in May of this year have just been terminated whereby a client of Harry P. Nelson, Inc., has leased for a long term the five-story apartment at 115 West Eighty-fourth Street. The house, which in on a plot 39.6 by 100 feet, and contains eighty rooms, has been held by the same owners, the George F. Wilcoxson Estate, since 1899. Medina Sherpick acted for the lessor.

The Bondholders' Representative Committee of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., in a report mailed yesterday to bondholders, and signed by J. P. Ripley, chairman, replies to criticisms of the reorganization plan as sponscored by the committee. In referring directly to the recently organized bondholders' defensive

Leading Democrats of Connecticut attended funeral services here today for Mrs. Josephine Flynn, the party's National Committeewoman for Connecticut, who died last Friday. The Rev. Richard Dunn officiated at the solemn high mass at St. Augustine's Church.

I regret that the necessities of the schedule brought me through the greater part of North Dakota by dark. Last night, however, I saw a portion of the drought area of Eastern Montana-a situation akin to yours in the western part of this State.

Ed Howe wrote a lot of books, one of which, if marred a little by excessive melodrama and a tiresome, feeble villain, seems likely to survive. It is no disparagement of his works to say that his character and his life were of ampler interest. A lover of "the herd," he was

Stanley D. McGraw had as his guests for cocktails this afternoon at the Hempstead Club Mr. and Mrs. A. Henry Mosle, Miss Barbara Nields and Benjamin Nields 3d. In a group entertained by Mrs. G. Howard Ingalls were Mrs. Ballard Moore, Mrs. Kenneth Ellis and John J. Hicks Kerr.
Mrs. Letitia Cornell, the oldest retired New York City school teacher, was cheered today by the receipt of a telegram from Mayor La Guardia. It washer 102d birthday, and friends who

The Palisade, seven-story apartment structure at 327 West Fiftysixth Street was solo at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. The Bank of New York and Trust Company, as first mortgagee, bought in the property for $105,225.
Frank W. Adams, former manager of the Mutual Life Insurance Company office at 165 Broadway, died Sunday at his home in Montclair, N. J. On his retirement in

Investigators seeking the assailant of Max Rubin turned yesterday to a story of the allotment to industrial concerns of city owned piers, controlled by a combination of a racketeering employes' organization and a truckmen's union.

Mr. and Mrs. James B. Lowell were among those who gave dinners last night at the opening for the season of the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. James Russell Lowell and J. Lorimer Worden. In the party of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Kelly were Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Balfe, Mr. and Mrs. John A. Maher and
Science spanned 200 miles of land and water today to mate a batch of barred rock hens with Rhode Island red roosters by remote control, and then.turned the experiment over to time and nature.

The fisherman whose family conspires to drag him off to Bermuda right in the midst of the best season for local fishing need no longer sigh and put away his tackle. He can take it to the Islands with him and find plenty of use for it while the others are taking in the scenic beauties of the place.

Production of steel this week is estimated at 66.1 per cent of capacity, compared with 74.4 per cent in the previous week, an 8.3-point decline or 11.2 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Irving B. Laughlin, former United States Ambassador to Spain; Dr. Henry A. Atkinson of the Church Peace Union, A. M. Cassandre, painter; Jean Le Seyeux, actor; James Strachey, composer, and Representative Jed Johnson of Oklahoma are among the passengers due tonight from Europe on the French liner Ile de France.

A Government does not issue a formal communique after a Cabinet meeting unless it has important decisions to announce. The statement made by the French Ministers after their extraordinary session last Saturday gives a plain indication of a change in internal policy. France is still governed by the
The "army" of the Protestant Episcopal Church moved in today, pitched camp and began manoeuvress" in a pre-convention session of the church's fifty-second triennial meeting.

Predicting that the Roosevelt Administration's present monetary policy, featuring easy money, would continue unchanged for at least another year, Dr. O. M. W. Sprague, Professor of Banking and Finance at Harvard University, told the National Business Conference at Babson Park today that business need have no immediate fear of a serious inflation in this country.

Columbia's football coaching staff spent all of yesterday morning in conference with their four aides who scouted Army. They emerged from the meeting with a rigid training schedule for the team before the game with the Cadets Saturday at West Point.

Objections to claims amounting to $41,393,726 on participating debentures issued by the Kreuger Toll Company, now bankrupt, were sustained yesterday by Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum, who, agreeing with a decision of the Supreme Court of Sweden, ruled that the allowance to American certificate holders would constitute preferential treatment.

More than 2,000 persons attended a solemn requiem mass yesterday at the Shrine Church of Our Lady of Solace, West Seventeenth Street and Mermaid Avenue, Brooklyn, for the Rev. Walter A. Kerwin, pastor, who died in the rectory on Thursday at the age of 62.

Schedules for the City College junior varsity football and varsity cross-country teams for the Fall season were announced yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics. The jayvee eleven will open its season next Saturday by opposing the James Monroe High School eleven on the schoolboy's gridiron. Games also have been listed with Grover Cleveland High and Evander Childs.

The Presbyterian Board of Christian Education announced today appointment of the Rev. Dr. William F. Wefer of New York as assistant director of men's work, effective Dec. 1. Dr. Wefer has been pastor of the Good Shepherd Presbyterian Church since 1927 and has been chairman of the Park West Community Council of Social Agencies in New York City.

Five men were arrested last night by detectives and agents of the License Bureau of the Department of Public Welfare on charges of soliciting funds for a charitable purpose without a license. The men represented themselves as agents of the "Police and Court Officers Benevolent Association of the State of New Jersey," the police said.
The importation of approximately 300 categories of foreign goods will be prohibited or restricted after next Sunday as a war time measure to maintain yen exchange at the present level.

Walter Koepsell, Pennsylvania sophomore quarterback, who played so brilliantly in the opening victory against Maryland, is lost for the Yale game at New Haven Saturday. A severe ankle sprain will keep the Hudson Falls (N. Y.) player out of this week's game and he may miss the Columbia contest.
The Brooklyn Dodgers of the National Football League crushed the Wilmington Clippers in an exhibition game tonight, 48 to 12.

Dress rehearsal No. 1 for the annual Autumn drama known as the world series was held yesterday at the Yankee Stadium, where the first scene of the production will be unveiled before more than 70,000 spectators tomorrow afternoon if every seat is occupied.
Freddie Fiducia of Newark gained a close decision over Abe Feldman, veteran New Yorker, in the feature eight-round boxing bout at Laurel Garden tonight. Fiducia weighed 186 and Feldman 184.

The government's lines are closing in steadily on powerful Rebel positions at Cerro Blanco, just on the edge of Usera, to the south of Madrid. Yesterday no fewer than sixty-five houses were taken at the base of the hill and behind it and today the writer, together with some colleagues, was able to get onto part of the hill itself.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions PARAMOUNT STATIONERY CORP., stationery supplies, 580 Broadway-Voluntary proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $64,092 and assets of $75,134. POST FISH CO., INC., wholesale fish, 258 Water St.-Voluntary proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $47,397 and assets of $51,138.

Court circles were reported tonight to be displeased and even annoyed by the Duke of Windsor's statement in Paris yesterday that he would visit Germany and the United States soon to study labor and housing conditions.

Leo F. Mockus, 27, a carpenter, remained in jail tonight, unable to obtain $150,000 bail, after pleading innocent of charges of assaulting Arthur Gay, 19, and Sylvia Paulding, 16. Gay and the girl were shot Saturday as they sat in a parked car.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today: CUSTOMS 4049--United States v. A. Hauptmann, Inc. Reargued. 4090-United States v. Freedman Sla ter, Inc., etc. Argued.

Development of better employee and dealer relations through house or institutional magazines is spreading, according to a house organ forecast for 1938 by Robert Newcomb and Associates, publications consultants, released yesterday.
The single-family residence at 677 Bement Avenue, West New. Brighton, S. I., has been purchased by Wesley S. Blanchard from Mary Warren Vail of Troy.

Deputy Sheriff Harry Wicker said today that he was informed by villagers in Hyde Park that two fiery crosses were burned near President Roosevelt's estate last Friday night at the time Justice Black made his radio address.

Arthur L. Wilshaw defeated F ??er P. Spinnelli for the leadership of the Richmond County Republican organization at a meeting of the county committee last night at Public School 14 in Stapleton, S. I. The vote was 141 to 74. More than 300 persons attended the meeting,

For the Second time in two years Dr. Max ?? of Amsterdam, chess champion of the world, and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, who preceded him as titleholder, are ready to contest for supremacy in a return match of thirty games, scheduled to begin here tomorrow.

Mr. and Mrs. Leo Laigan entertained 100 guests at dinner tonight in the Terrace Room of the Greenbrier honoring Colonel W. A. Ayers, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission. After dinner the party attended a ball in the Cameo Ballroom which attracted 800 persons.

KINGS CANAVAN, CHRISTINE (Aug. 21, 1937). Gross assets, $24,105; net, $22,837. Evergreen Cemetery, $1,000; friend, Laura R. Hill, household chattels; husband, Walter F. Canavan, residuary estate. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $1,338; mortgages. notes, cash and insurance, $2,806; jointly owned property, 19,859; miscellaneous property, $100. A. Lloyd Lott. attorney. 16 Court St.

United States Senator William H. Smathers, returning here today after a vacation in North Carolina, said he would ask Congress at its next session to modify the Roosevelt administration's surtax on undistributed profits.
The League of Nations Assembly unanimously lined up today behind Cordell Hull, United States Secretary of State, on his political and economic policy without naming it.

Paul Junior, rugged lightweight from Lewiston, Me., outpointed George Zengaras of the East Side in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Royal Windsor last night. Using a sharp left hook to the face with considerable skill, the Maine boxer had little trouble scoring over his foe in the first five rounds.

A baby American alligator and 600 American Legionnaires did not have a scheduled meeting with Premier Mussolini today because the Italian leader was in the country resting from his strenuous visit to Germany.

According to Publishers Weekly, book production for the month just ended was greater than that for September, 1936. The number of titles published was 942. The total for the first nine months of the year is 7,814, as compared to 7,326 for the corresponding period of 1936.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 29: An increase of $32,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, and a decrease of $49,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities; a decrease of $27,-
The market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $7,589,880,676 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange.

A resounding blast was delivered today in Izvestia, Government organ, against the perennially weakest spot in the Soviet economic system-urban retail trade, especially of fruit, vegetables and other perishable foodstuffs. The Izvestia article blasts at r waste and mismanagement with a r violence usually reserved for "hyphenate public enemies."

Light work marked resumption of practice by Cornell's football squad today. In touch-tackle scrimmage the first eleven rehearsed plays against the second team and a scrub outfit. Captain Ted Hughes, center, and Herb Hilmer, reserve end, were on the injury list and did not practice.

Miss Katherine Woodward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur D. Woodward of this place, will be married to Daniel B. Curtiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Curtiss, also of Thomaston, on Oct. 11. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Louis I. Belden of Hartford, who will be assisted by the Rev. Leonard Smith of Thomaston.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Instead of any embarrassment, the American people have good cause to feel a sense of pride and inner satisfaction over the Black affair, since it revealed a healthy, virile and vigilant state of public opinion.

While more rigid requirements for a realty brokerage or salesman's license, and for the development of vacant suburban lands, have provided added protection for the investor against many sharp practices, real estate organizations see the need-for further changes in the State laws to guard the brokers themselves against unfair methods followed by some of their competitors.

Ex-kings have interested themselves in making clocks, in gambling, in drinking, in social life and in trying to get their thrones back. The Duke of Windsor is perhaps the first ex-king to undertake the study of housing.

The State of South Carolina will enter the market on Oct. 19 with a new issue of $1,350,000 of certificates of indebtedness. They will be dated Oct. 15, 1937, and will mature serially from Oct. 15, 1939 to 1952. Bidders are to designate the rate of interest.

Henry Bishop, one of the most extensive goldfish breeders in the country died today at his home near Baltimore at the age of 63. Goldfish hatcheries and lily pools on his picturesque estate were visited by hundreds of people weekly.

Speaking at a luncheon to dedicate the new $270,868 Harlem Health Center Mayor La Guardia assailed yesterday the inefficiency of his predecessors who left him "confronted with the neglect and confusion of the past sixty years." The luncheon was held in the center, on Fifth Avenue between 136th and 137th Streets.

Don Budge provided an expected finish today to the forty-eighth Pacific Coast tennis championships by retaining his men's singles crown against the attack of Bobby Riggs, Los Angeles star who was an unexpected finalist.

Mrs. H. E. Kincaid, head of the Wicklon Nursery and Kindergarten, has rented from Maude Heaton Steese the latter's estate with a twelve-room residence on Cornell Street in the Quaker Ridge section at the Scarsdale-Mamaroneck line, Westchester County.

THE Detroit Tigers led the American League in club batting and club fielding and the Chicago Cubs led the National League in club batting and club fielding. The Yankees and Giants will meet in the world series. And so, farewell to-figures. They may divert the eye but they confuse the mind.

Chicago's undefeated Bears fashioned a touchdown after an 82-yard parade in the third period tonight for a 7-to-0 triumph over the Pittsburgh Pirates of the National Football League. A crowd of 22,511 saw the contest, which strengthened the Bears' position on top in the Western division of the league with two victories and no defeats.

As a means of establishing world peace, foreign missionary work is more necessary than ever, Dr. Charles T. Leber said yesterday at a bi-monthly meeting of the Presbytery of New York in the parish house of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street.

Howard Day Greer, a retired employee of the Chase National Bank in New York, died in Corinth Hospital early today after a week's illness. His age was 62. Mr. Greer was born in Albany July 9, 1875, and moved to New York with his parents at the age of 16.

The Culver City-Hollywood quarrel over the name "Hollywood" ends at high noon Wednesday, when Governor Frank S. Merriam of California journeys down from Sacramento to meet with officials of chambers of commerce of both communities in the forecourt of Grauman's Chinese Theatre, Hollywood, where the hatchet-burying will take place. It is understood that Culver City will relinquish all its claims and charges forever.

The Josephine Home near Peekskill, N. Y., will be the beneficiary of a luncheon, card party and fashion show on Oct. 28 in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador. Mrs. Edwin Vogel heads the organization, which provides convalescent care for undernourished children. Mrs. Irving Ernst heads the benefit committee.

A downward movement in manufacturing activity in August compared with the preceding month is indicated by the monthly survey of wages, hours and employment of the National Industrial Conference Board.
Soviet trade with the United States totaled 160,172,000 rubles, or about $33,034,400, during the first six months of the year, the Commerce Department reported today. Of this total

Stressing the value of newspaper advertising in an address today before the convention of the National Restaurant Association, Leo Nejelski, advertising manager of Swift Co., urged a better type and a greater volume of advertising "to attract patronage and keep business rolling in."
Two recitals are listed for tonight. Leonora Corona, former Metropolitan Opera soprano, will appear at the Town Hall and Ruth Culbertson will present a program of piano music at the Barbizon.

The general level of retail food prices advanced fractionally during the month ended Sept. 14, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. The bureau's index, based on the 1923-25 average, rose to 85.8, as compared with 85.5 on Aug. 17, 85.9 on July 13, 84.3 a year ago, and 108.0 on Sept. 15, 1929.

Recent action of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System of making installment finance paper eligible for rediscount will without doubt encourage installment purchases and sales, Carl H. Henrikson, director of education of the National Association of Credit Men declared at the luncheon meeting of the Yonkers Kiwanis Club yesterday.
May Herzog, members of the New York Curb Exchange, have changed their firm name to L. S. May Co. They will retain .their membership on the Curb Exchange.

The Southern Pacific Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to acquire the railroad properties of the South Pacific Coast Railway Company, consisting of thirty-three
August Wickman, the first detective assigned to the Missing Persons Bureau, dropped dead at 5 P. M. yesterday while at work in police headquarters.
The increase of 5 1/2 cents an hour granted the five train-operating unions would seem to have been granted with an eye to the situation in respect to rival union ambitions. Previously, thirteen

The repeal of all depression tax measures, inasmuch as the nation is now "on the road to recovery," was advocated as the greatest possible business stimulant by Godfrey N. Nelson, lawyer, tax expert and secretary of the New York Times Company, in an address yesterday at the sixth annual meeting of the Controllers Institute of America in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Directors of the J. I. Case Company declared yesterday a year-end dividend of $6 a common share, payable on Oct. 23 to holders of record of Oct. 13. On Dec. 24, 1936, the company resumed the payment of dividends on the common stock with the distribution of $4 a share.
THE GOLDEN KNIGHT, by George Challis. (Greystone, $2.50.) A story of Richard the Lion Heart. MARC ANTONY: HIS WORLD AND CONTEMPORARIES, by Jack Lindsay. (Dutton, $3.75.) A new study.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 15,000, including 4,000 directs. The market was generally 25c lower than Friday's average; top, $12: bulk good and choice 190-230 lbs., $11.70-90; 240-300 lbs.,

Union City Apartment House Sold by Trust Company The Hudson Trust Company sold to Diedrich Haslop the four-story building containing six apartments and one store at 580 Bergenline Avenue, Union City, N. J.
Chicago completed arrangements tonight to give to President Roosevelt a rousing welcome tomorrow when he arrives to dedicate this city's new $11,500,000 Outer Drive bridge project.

After a month of rewriting and restaging at the Center Theatre, the governors of "Virginia" have been inviting the critics to return to the scene of the crime. Several of us did so last evening in the hope of seeing our critical sagacity translated into an exhilarating wonder work of the show world.

Give a Michigander a punter, a passer and a center and he will add them up to get a big eleven. These are vital components of a natural in the Wolverine scheme of football, or at least they were when Harry Kipke was booting the ball and Jack Blott was snapping it back for Hurry-Up Yost, and they are a fair nucleus for a winning team in any league.

Committees of young women of society are actively interested in the miniature automobile show which opens this afternoon for a week's exhibit in the International Building at Rockefeller Center. The show will be conducted as a benefit for the maintenance fund of the Boys' Brotherhood Republic, a cultural and recreational project for underprivileged youths.

Turning in a brilliant individual 67, four under par, Mike Turnesa, Fairview professional, captured the chief honors in the weekly proamateur golf tournament of the Westchester P. G. A. at Siwanoy today. Turnesa paired with Charles

Trial of a suit brought by two Purchase residents to halt construction of a ninety-foot water tank near their estates because "it would look like a Turkish mosque and would be a sore thumb in the air" began here today before Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme.

Speaking today as the Supreme Court was resuming its sessions President Roosevelt raised the court issue in two speeches in which he demanded and predicted the passage of legislation for crop and wage and hour control and hinted at a special session this Fall to speed their enactment.

The National City Bank in its statement of condition for Sept. 30, issued yesterday, showed deposits of $1,812,046,913, which were the largest in the history of the institution and represented an increase of $4,224,865 in the last quarter. The bank also reported an increase in its surplus account of $500,000 to $44,250,000, against $43,750,000 on June 30.

Grammar school children throughout Poland were ordered home today when their teachers struck. The strike is a demonstration against authorities for suspending the left wing executive committee of the teachers' union and appointing in its place a Government commissioner who is a member of the newly formed "Union of Young Poland," which is affiliated with
Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Greensboro, N. C., today established a modern record in women's golf when she won the qualifying medal in the national championship for the second year in succession.

William Green, opening the fifty-seventh annual convention of the American Federation of Labor today in the hall in which he nominated John L. Lewis for its presidency against Samuel Gompers in 1921, declared that the federation would build "the greatest fighting machine that was ever created within the ranks of labor" to drive the Committee for Industrial Organization out of existence.

John L. Meyer, president of Meyer Steffens, negotiated a first mortgage for $500,000 from the Mutual Life Insurance Company, on 255 W 88th St. a fifteenstory apartment house on the northwest corner of Broadway, assessed at $1,370,000.

By declaring anew a "state of war" for a ninety-day period, Brazil has again taken a disquieting step. Urged by President Getulio Vargas, who alleges the country is endangered by Communist plots, the Congress has voted to suspend the usual constitutional guarantees and to give to the Executive virtually dictatorial power, including the right to impose a strict censorship. This action, taken in the

Queens College, the fourth city institution of higher education, opened its doors for the first time yesterday. There were 400 selected graduates of high schools in the auditorium of the administration building of the college at 65-30 Kissena Boulevard, Flushing, when Dr. Paul Klapper, the president, called the opening session to order at 2 P. M.
The four umpires who will officiate in the world series were named by Baseball Commissioner K. M. Landis yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

Herbert E. Ellsworth, retired builder, died today at his home in Portland at the age of 83. He was a descendant of Oliver Ellsworth, Chief Justice of the United States, and was graduated from Wilbraham, Academy. He had served as First Selectman of the town of Portland.

The three buildings on the north side of Newkirk Avenue between East Sixteenth and Seventeenth Streets, Brooklyn, which for the last thirty years have housed the Flatbush School, nave been sold to Jack Carner.

The State Liquor Authority announced yesterday that 10,250 liquor licenses were renewed for the year beginning Oct. 1. This is about 300 fewer licenses than the number outstanding Sept. 30, the date of expiration.

A total of 299,828 persons registered in the city yesterday, the opening day for the qualifying of voters for the November elections. This was a slightly lower figure than for the first day of registration in 1933, and 61,273 below the total for the same day last year. Last year was an all-time high.

J B. RHINE'S long-awaited treatise on mun dane magic is one of the most interesting I have ever read, and I take no stock in it whatsoever. Not that the author's integrity is in question; everything he says is said not only well but temperately. The trouble is that his whole

Harold E. Dahl, the American aviator, whistled cheerfully and scribbled additional items in his memoirs tonight even though a Spanish Insurgent court-martial is expected to decree a death sentence for him tomorrow.
Thirty-six persons will share the world series melon the pennantwinning Giants will slice after the world series, and two who do not wear the uniform will get full portions.

Albert C. Goodwin, a lithographer, died today. He was 77 years old, born in Albany and a graduate of the Albany Academy and Albany Business College. Mr. Goodwin was active in civic affairs and Masonic circles.

Belgium will be strongly represented in the international military jumping contests of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden from Nov. 3 to 10. According to official word received yesterday by the National Horse Show Association, four of Belgium's most famous horsemen and eight crack mounts will be sent over.

The old Hunter College Building between Park and Lexington Avenues, Sixty-eighth to Sixty-ninth Streets, which was damaged by fire in 1936 and which the Municipal Sinking Fund Commission in June of this year ordered demolished, is to be replaced by a fifteen-story and penthouse building costing $5,000,000, according to plans filed yesterday by Shreve, Lamb Harmon and Harrison Fouilhoux.

The latest published returns on yesterday's popular elections for municipal councilmen in 800 cities and towns of Colombia give the Liberals majorities in 461 councils, including all the State capitals.

Mine operators in Mexico are worried by agitation among the workers of the American Smelting and Refining Company for wage increases, although most of their labor contracts will not expire for several months.

A warning against the introduction of too much government into business was sounded yesterday by Grover Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, in emphasizing the point that the 1939 fair here would be "essentially an industrial and business exhibit." He spoke at a luncheon of the Apparel and Accessories Associates, Inc., composed of leaders in those fields and sponsoring group for an exhibit of these industries at the fair, at the Empire State Club.

Germany put another submarine flotilla of twelve units into commission today. The flotilla consists of the mother ship Weichsel, the tender Mosel, one torpedo boat, seven submarines of 250 tons each, and two submarines held in reserve.

Consolidated net income of the Plymouth Oil Company including its subsidiary, the Big Lake Oil Company, for the first nine months of this year is estimated at $2,101,110, after depreciation, depletion, taxes and other charges.

Mrs. Sarah B. Huling, chairman of the national defense committee of the Daughters of the American Revolution, was summoned yesterday to appear in Yorkville Court to answer charges that she has withheld illegally property of the Margaret Mask Chapter of the National Society of the Colonial Dames of the Seventeenth Century.

The Navy football team has lost the services of Al Wallace, first-string center, probably for the season. The kidney injury he suffered in The Citadel game Saturday, while not dangerous, will keep him from the playing field for several weeks at least.
C. Herbert Packard, banker and druggist, and' a leading citizen of East Boston, died last night at his home in East Boston after a week's illness. He was 74 years old.

The Yugoslav Cabinet was reconstructed tonight in a counter-move to the pending signature of an agreement between the Serb Opposition and the Croats, who seek the downfall of the government of Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch.

Miss Minnie Fox Hopkins of 55 East Seventy-second Street, daughter of the late Mrs. John F. Dantell and the late Russell Fox Hopkins, has chosen Oct. 23 for her marriage to Dr. Charles Louis Gilbert of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Pierce Gilbert of Richmond, Va. The wedding will take place in St. James Church and the rector, the Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, will perform the ceremony.
Confessional Synod Protestants have broken off all relations with the Methodist Church in Germany as a result of the stand taker by Bishop Melle, German Methodist, at Oxford in August.

Stephen Powys's London hit, "Wise Tomorrow," had its American premiere here tonight at Ford's Theatre before an audience that found it interesting and provocative. Told as a sophisticated comedy, it is the story of an aging actress who tries to recapture her former glory by sponsoring a young actress torn between a career and love.

Fundamental offensive formations were rehearsed on University Field today as Princeton, with a triumph over Virginia behind it, launched preparations for Saturday's contest with Cornell. Perturbed by what Coach Fritz Crisler termed "spotty running" and "poor blocking," the Nassau board of strategy devoted all except twenty minutes of the twohour practice to polishing basic aerial and ground plays. The closing minutes of the session found the varsity still running signals under flood lights.

The volume of wool exports during the 1936-37 Argentine wool season which ended Sept. 30, was approximately 7 per cent above that of the preceding season, with average prices considerably higher, according to a report from Buenos Aires made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Federal Judge George A. Welsh temporarily restrained today the Pennsylvania Securities Commission from suspending or revoking the license of Howard J. Levitt, a securities dealer operating as Howard J. Levitt Co., Philadelphia.
Light dummy scrimmage stressing the development of a passing attack was the order of the day for the Rutgers varsity today.

Monarchist propaganda on a big scale is going on here to attract unusual attention to Crown Prince Michael's fifteenth birthday on Oct. 26. On that date Prince Michael will be promoted to a lieutenant in the army, and the event will be marked by the "biggest military parade Rumania has ever seen."
Week-end political developments in France were reflected here today in a steadying of the franc, which improved slightly after Saturday's slump to close at 150 1/16 in terms of sterling.

Something of the twelfth century has come to life amid the apartment houses on Washington Heights, where ,George Grey Barnard, the sculptor, will open to the public today, his collection of French Romanesque sculpture.

Although China and Japan normally supply about 40 per cent of the imports of medicinal herbs, roots, leaves and other crude drug materials, in the opinion of Department of Commerce officials, domestic medicinal and pharmaceutical manufacturers will not be seriously handicapped by the expected restrictions of these products.

A banking group headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and including Edward B. Smith Co., the Mellon Securities Company, Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; the First Boston Corporation. J. W. Seligman Co. and G. M.-P. Murphy Co. and Associates will offer today $46,003,300 of 3 1/2 per cent convertible debentures,

A group of Catholics here opposed seating Hugo Black in the Supreme Court today, and called on President Roosevelt to "acknowledge your error of judgment and remove the stigma that error has placed upon the membership of the Supreme Court."
Triffino Correa, a former army captain, has been arrested at Porto Alegre, where, it is alleged, he was agitating among army sergeants and plotting a Leftist uprising.

Leases taken by three large aeronautical concerns in various buildings in Rockefeller Center featured the contracts for commercial space reported yesterday. Imperial Airways, Ltd., the British national airline, leased space in the British Empire Building; Air France,

Yale University has embarked upon a project which will require until 1950 to complete and will result in the publication of between forty and fifty volumes, the Yale edition of Horace Walpole's Correspondence. The first two volumes will be published tomorrow by the Yale University Press, with King George VI heading the list of subscribers.

Dr. Louis Napoleon Delore, Montreal physician and a wellknown anatomist, died in a hospital here yesterday at the age of 75. Professor of Anatomy at the University of Montreal for forty-nine years, he celebrated last year the fiftieth anniversary of his entry into the medical profession.
Camden voters will decide in a referendum at the November election whether liquor shall be sold in this city on Sunday. The City Commission

It is not enough for a Special Prosecutor to send a few racketeers to prison. His more important function is to make the public understand just what racketeering is and how it affects each individual in the community.

While two police courts were busily occupied today in disposing of the first batch of 106 cases arising out of the Fascist-Communist clash during Sir Oswald Mosley's Southeast London demonstration yesterday behind the scenes efforts were being made to extend the ban on political marches through the streets of London.
Only fifty students were registered when the University of Nanking, Americansupported mission institution, opened its Fall term today.

THERE probably are plenty of readers who know nothing about Zora Neale Hurston, even though those with an interest in Negro letters are already her admirers. Miss Hurston is a rarity among members of any race; she is at once a popularizer and something of a scholar.

KINDLY check all guns at the door. There's enough shooting going on now in all directions. This is just a neighborly get-together. They're all nice fellows and they will all be wearing New York uniforms. Owner Horace Stoneham of the Giants wouldn't think of throwing dead cats at Owner Jacob Ruppert of the Yankees, win, lose or draw.

Clarence Edwards, former justice of the Court of Special Sessions and one of the founders and the first president of the Queens County Bar Association, died at his home, 87-06 Fifty-first Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens, yesterday of a heart ailment. He was born seventy-eight years ago in Fauquier County, Va.

Sales of the S. S. Kresge Company for September amounted to $12,096,784, against $11,752,862 in the same month last year, a gain of 2.9 per cent. In the first nine months of 1937 the sales aggregated $104,135,418, an increase of 5.6 per cent over the $98,605,172 sales reported for the corresponding period in 1936.

Pledges of adherence to the program of operation proposed by the American Bar Association have been signed by fifty-five collection agencies in New York State and will go into effect on Oct. 25, Stanley K. Oldden, president of the New York State Association of Collection Agencies, Inc., declared yesterday following a meeting of that body at the offices of the Credit Exchange, Inc., 112 West Thirtyfourth Street.

William Luiz RIckard, head of Rickard Co., Inc., advertising agents, 330 West Forty-second Street, died yesterday in the White Plains (N. Y.) Hospital. He underwent an operation a week ago Monday. His home was at 63 Edgemont Road, Scarsdale.

In a vigorous statement defending the recent pastoral letter of the Spanish hierarchy, Mgr. Michael J. Ready, General Secretary of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, today replied to the open letter signed by 150 Protestant clergymen, educators and laymen which denounced as "alarming" the hierarchy's attempt to justify a military rebellion against a legally elected government.
