The death rate of between 40,000,000 and 50,000,000 Americans with incomes of less than $1,000 a year from the ten major diseases that cause three out of every four deaths in the United States, is twice that of the rest of the population, Josephine Roche, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, told the annual convention of the American Public Health Association here yesterday.
The Federal Trade Commission announced today it has issued an order to the Babiglo Company, Inc., of New York to cease advertising soap as made from olive oil when such was not the case.

The mystery over the refusal of British authorities to allow Captain Reginald Jaffray to return to England after. a Continental holiday was more or less solved by an announcement in tonight's Star that his application for naturalization as a British subject had been rejected by the Home Office.

Robert Worth Bingham, United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, who arrives today from Louisville, Ky., will be at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Winthrop Parker' and the Misses Jeannette and Lois Parker have returned from Spruce Camp, their Summer home in Christmas Cove, Me., and are at 309 West Eighty-ninth Street.

Federal Judge George A. Welsh gave informal approval today to an increase of 7 per cent in pay and additional pension benefits and retirement privileges for employes of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company.

The Iridium Room of the St. Regis was thronged with members of society last night at a dinner dance for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund. The party served also to open the room for the late Autumn and Winter season. The beneficiary provides employment and rehabilitation for musicians temporarily out of work and in need.

Joe Louis, world's heavyweight boxing champion, is going to become a motion picture actor. He was signed today to co-star in a full-length picture with an allNegro cast. The film, entitled "The Spirit of Youth," will be made by an independent concern.

Pinned in her carriage caught beneath the front axle of a wagon drawn by a runaway horse, Edna Galton, eight months old, of 119 West Seventy-first Street, was dragged almost a block before the horrified eyes of hundreds of strollers at Central Park West and Seventy-second Street yesterday afternoon.

Newark's Bears, champions of the International League, battled their way back to even terms at threeall in the Little World Series with Columbus tonight, defeating the Red Birds, 10 to 1, in an exhibition of batting power and pitching finesse.

A nation-wide narcotic ring operating from New York during the last two years, smuggling opium and heroin into this port on transatlantic liners and distributing as far south as Texas, was believed smashed yesterday when seventyfour of its members were named defendants in a conspiracy indictment unsealed before Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum.
The C. I. O.-endorsed Mayoralty candidate in Detroit's primary election pulled steadily ahead of his A. F. L.-supported opponent as nearly half of the returns were tabulated officially early today.

Harry Richman, the band leader who flew the Atlantic with Richard Merrill as pilot last year, announced today that he will leave London for New York soon to prepare for a distance record attempt in a flight from Canada to Brazil.

The American Foundation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street, announced yesterday the award of the new Charles B. Hayes Memorial Scholarship of $250 to John W. Lewis of New York City, a blind student at the Juilliard School of Music.

President Roosevelt's speech on world peace at Chicago today was interpreted here as having thrown the door wide open for collaboration by the United States in efforts by other peace-loving and law-abiding nations to check Japan's illegal course in China by any reasonable means short of war.

Miss Katherine Wallace, daughter of Mrs. Michael Wallace of Clearview, Falmouth, Va., has completed plans for her marriage to Sidney B. Silleck Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney B. Silleck of Scarsdale, N. Y., which will take place next Saturday afternoon in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Fredericksburg, Va.

Six charitable and educational institutions are among the legatees named in the will of Henry T. Sloane, merchant and philanthropist, which was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mr. Sloane was 91 years old when he died on Sept. 19, leaving an estate formally valued at "more than $20,000."
Captain Ted Hughes returned to practice with the Cornell football squad tonight but confined his work to limbering-up exercises under Trainer Frank Kavanaugh.

Throngs turned out in Chicago today to accord to President Roosevelt the greatest demonstration of welcome of his Western tour. They cheered him along crowded streets, showered his car with a storm of confetti and applauded his globe-girdling call. for "concerted" action to restore universal peace.

Charles Wesley Dickinson, for more Fo than fifty years engaged in the manufacture of banknote machinery here, died yesterday at his home in this community after an illness of more than two years. age was 72.

BY means of the meager clues afforded by a discarded hat and overcoat ana a jacket smeared with wax, detectives found yesterday two men sought in connection with the fatal shooting of Patrolman John Wilson in a Fulton Street hold-up Sept. 23.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 2: Kellerman, Lt. R. R., the Enterprise, to Patrol Wing 4. Gobbell, Lt. W. M., Med. Corps, Destroyer Div. 23. to the Rigel. Gilbert, Jr. Lt. R. O., Jr., the Permit, to the Texas.

The French franc moved in erratic fashion in the foreign exchange market yesterday and the trading here was light compared with the heavy business reported from Paris where the franc was under severe pressure at times.

Officials of the Grace Line confirmed yesterday reports that it had bought the ships and trade of the Red "D" Line, a 99-year-old service operating between New York and Caribbean ports which include San Juan, Puerto Rico; La Guayra, Puerto Cabello, Maracaibo and La Vela de Coro, Venezuela, and Curacao, Aruba and Bonaire in the Netherlands West Indies.
Strife among the Democrats In Queens increased yesterday as the executive committee nominated County Clerk Thomas J. Towers for the City Court.
" The Dangerous Age" by the American dramatist, Edith Ellis, presented at the Embassy Theatre tonight, had a poor reception from the critics.

The Republic of Poland today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to register an issue of 3 per cent dollar funding bonds maturing on Oct. 1, 1956, and fractional certificates and separate coupons, to be offered in settlement of interest coupons on bonds issued by Poland, some of its political subdivisions and two of its banks.

Annual conference of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness begins at the Hotel Pennsylvania at 9:30 A. M. Annual meeting of society at 2:30 P. M. "Saving Sight Through Public Action," Dr. William F. Snow. Conference continues Thursday and Friday.

A report to the nation on the progress- of the World's Fair construction was delivered yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, in opening four model exhibits in the Administration Building on the fair grounds in Flushing Meadow.

The latest news from North China substantiates the expectations of those observers who have long believed that the Japanese intend to remove Emperor Kangte of Manchukuo, former Emperor of China, from Hsinking to Peiping as ruler of a great conservative empire including Manchuria, Jehol and the five Northern Chinese Provinces-Hopeh, Chahar, Shantung, Shansi and Suiyuan.

Japan was unanimously condemned as an invader and treaty-breaker by the League of Nations' Far Eastern Advisory Committee tonight in a resolution in which that body "expresses its moral support for China."

Comment of the press of the country, as gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES, indicates general approval of the President's address in Chicago calling upon peace-loving peoples to make a concerted effort in opposition to aggressor nations which are creating lawlessness in the world. Following are excerpts from editorials:

The fact that metropolitan newspapers are now publishing little about executions and other penalties inflicted on "hyphenate criminals" throughout the country does not mean that the authorities are trying to hush up the process of weeding out undesirables.
The former Miss Anita Foulke, Philadelphia society girl, was near Saranac Lake, N. Y., today with her husband of three days, Hazen G. Blanchard, Mount Desert Island woodsman.

Leonora Corona, American soprano, who was with the Metropolitan Opera for some years, unveiled the new recital season at the Town Hall last night. There have been WPA concerts and opera at the Hippodrome through September, in other years the dog days of local public performance in music;

Business failures were greater in three groups the week ended Sept. 3', compared with the corresponding period last year, while defaults in the retail and construction fields were lower, according to an analysis issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Lou Camps of the Bronx sufferes his first major setback in the professional ranks. when he was knocked out last night by Johnny Bellus of New Haven in the main bout at the New York Coliseum.

Mrs. William McCune of this place has announced that the marriage of her daughter-in-law, Mrs. Rowe McCune of Greens Farms, to Thomas Coggeshall of New York will take place on Oct. 14 at the McCune home. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Malcolm James MacLeod, rector-emeritus of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas New York.

Miners employed on the eighth level of the Coaldale colliery went on a sit-down strike today 1,350 feet below the earth's surface. Rejecting a compromise offer made by officials of the Lehigh Navigation Coal Company in a controversy that has continued for several weeks over the method of payment for work on the new level, forty-four men threw aside their picks and shovels and quit work.
